He could have\r\nleaned over and dammed the river below with a finger. 

He sat on top of\r\nthe mountain, and his beard in the wind was a white flag.\r\n\r\nAcross the plains, as he watched, there were fires glowing, and the\r\nmountain under him trembled from explosions a thousand miles away. He\r\nbent his head, and a muffled cry reverberated down the hillside and\r\nthrough the valley.\r\n\r\nA smaller figure appeared beside him, looking sad.\r\n\r\n"Try again, father," the smaller one said.\r\n\r\nThe old one shook his head. "It would be the same.

"\r\n\r\n"Give them another chance."\r\n\r\n"They would do it again.

"\r\n\r\n"Just once more."\r\n\r\nThe old one shook his head again, and for a while they sat, and they\r\nwatched the destruction. The fires burned higher, and the explosions\r\nshook their mountain more roughly.\r\n\r\nAt last, at the end, the old one reached down and scooped up some clay\r\nfrom the bank of the river. He held it in a huge, gentle hand, and the\r\nyounger one smiled.\r\n\r\n"You are good to give them another chance, father.

"\r\n\r\n"Not them," said the old one.\r\n\r\n"What do you mean?" the son asked, wonderingly.\r\n\r\n"Something else," the majestic figure answered, starting to knead the\r\nclay. "What shall it be?"\r\n\r\n[Illustration: Illustrator: Ray Houlihan]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Amazing Stories_ Oct.-Nov. 1953.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and\r\n    typographical errors have been corrected without note.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n

]\r\n\r\n\r\nBy putting himself into reverse, the doom-intended man left the\r\ntwentieth century far ahead. Nineteen fifty-six was a good year to\r\nget out of. John Arthur Benn watched the roaring twenties go by, and\r\nthe gay nineties, backwards, and wondered how it would be to pilot a\r\nriverboat on the Mississippi, or to fight under John Paul Jones.\r\n\r\nBefore he was really aware of it, he was for a speeding second a\r\ncontemporary of another John--Smith--and thought about the life of the\r\nRedman before the colonists began changing things around. By that time\r\nthe scenery had begun to get monotonous--just shrinking trees--and John\r\nArthur Benn swung over into lateral. 

Ah, England.\r\n\r\nThere went another namesake--Ben Jonson--and in a very little while he\r\nconsidered slowing down to meet still another. But King Arthur flashed\r\npast and into a womb in West Wales just as John was convulsed by a\r\nsneeze (it was quite drafty and he should have dressed more warmly),\r\nand as he stuffed his handkerchief back in his pocket he caught just a\r\ntantalizing glimpse of an interesting Druid ceremony.\r\n\r\nJohn Arthur Benn blacked out somewhere in the limbo of the\r\npre-Christian era, as he'd been warned he might, and when he came to\r\nhe found himself lying in a rather uncomfortable heap with his head\r\nin a mushroom patch. The mushrooms and the trees around him weren't\r\nshrinking any more, so John knew he'd stopped--or at least was going\r\nvery slowly. 

After a while he decided he wasn't going at all, and got\r\nto his feet.\r\n\r\nIt seemed very pleasant here, in the woods, so he found a fallen tree\r\nto sit on and took a wrapped sandwich and a small vacuum bottle of\r\ncoffee out of his pocket. When he'd finished his meal he walked to a\r\nstream nearby, rinsed the bottle, tossed the waxed paper onto the water\r\nto be carried away and pocketed the vacuum bottle.\r\n\r\nNow, he thought, what? This was scarcely dinosaur country. 

At this\r\npoint a wild boar chased him up a tree. To be killed by a boar would\r\nbe ignominious, after all this, although the animal was well enough\r\ntusked to have done the job, and so John Arthur Benn climbed to a high\r\nbranch, where the boar's persistence forced him to spend the night.\r\nHe slept, somehow, and, with the closing of his conscious mind--the\r\none that wanted to meet a dinosaur in fatal combat--the conventional\r\nsubconscious, which also sought suicide, but in a more familiar way,\r\nshifted him out of reverse.\r\n\r\nWhen he awoke, he was back in 1956, in Philadelphia. Irrevocably, John\r\nArthur Benn knew.\r\n\r\nHe went home and hanged himself in a closet.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


It could well become a\r\n minor classic._\r\n\r\n\r\nThe Last Supper\r\n\r\nBy T. D. Hamm\r\n\r\n\r\nHampered as she was by the child in her arms, the woman was running less\r\nfleetly now. A wave of exultation swept over Guldran, drowning out the\r\nuneasy feeling of guilt at disobeying orders.\r\n\r\nThe instructions were mandatory and concise: "_No_ capture must be\r\nattempted individually. In the event of sighting any form of human life,\r\nthe ship MUST be notified immediately. 

All small craft must be back at\r\nthe landing space not later than one hour before take-off. 

Anyone not so\r\nreporting will be presumed lost."\r\n\r\nGuldran thought uneasily of the great seas of snow and ice sweeping\r\ninexorably toward each other since the Earth had reversed on its axis in\r\nthe great catastrophe a millennium ago. Now, summer and winter alike\r\nbrought paralyzing gales and blizzards, heralded by the sleety snow in\r\nwhich the woman\'s skin-clad feet had left the tracks which led to\r\ndiscovery.\r\n\r\nHis trained anthropologist\'s mind speculated avidly over the little they\r\nhad gotten from the younger of the two men found nearly a week before,\r\nnearly frozen and half-starved. The older man had succumbed almost at\r\nonce; the other, in the most primitive sign language, had indicated\r\nthat, of several humans living in caves to the west, only he and the\r\nother had survived to flee some mysterious terror. Guldran felt a throb\r\nof pity for the woman and her child, left behind by the men, no doubt,\r\nas a hindrance.\r\n\r\nBut what a stroke of fortune that there should be left a male and female\r\nof the race to carry the seed of Terra to another planet. And what a\r\ntriumph if he, Guldran, should be the one to return at the eleventh hour\r\nwith the prize. No need of calling for help. This was no armed\r\nwar-party, but the most defenseless being in the Universe--a mother\r\nburdened with a child.\r\n\r\nGuldran put on another burst of speed. His previous shouts had served\r\nonly to spur the woman to greater efforts. Surely there was _some_ magic\r\nword that had survived even the centuries of illiteracy. Something\r\nequivalent to the "bread and salt" of all illiterate peoples. Cupping\r\nhis hands to his mouth, he shouted, "Food! 

food!"\r\n\r\nAhead of him the woman turned her head, leaped lightly in mid-stride,\r\nand went on; slowing a little but still running doggedly.\r\n\r\nGuldran\'s pulse leaped. He yelled again, "Food!"\r\n\r\nThe instant that his foot touched the yielding surface of the trap, he\r\nknew that he had met defeat. As his body crashed down on the\r\nfire-sharpened stakes, he knew too the terror from which the last men of\r\nthe human race had fled.\r\n\r\nAbove him the woman looked down, her teeth gleaming wolfishly. She\r\npointed down into the pit; spoke exultantly to the child.\r\n\r\n"Food!" said the last woman on earth.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _If Worlds of Science Fiction_\r\n    September 1952. Perhaps the west continent still existed; perhaps, dare he\r\nhope, with civilization. 

The crew of the Semilunis thought him quite\r\nmad. After all, hadn't the east and south continents been completely\r\nannihilated from the great sky fires; and wasn't it said that they had\r\nsuffered but a fraction of what the west continent had endured?\r\n\r\nThe Semilunis anchored at the mouth of a great river. The months of fear\r\nand doubt were at end. 

Here, at last, was the west continent. A small\r\nparty of scouts was sent ashore with many cautions to be alert for\r\nluminescent areas which meant certain death for those who remained too\r\nlong in its vicinity. Armed with bow and arrow, the party made its way\r\nslowly up the great river. Nowhere was to be seen the color green, only\r\ndull browns and greys. And no sign of life, save for an occasional patch\r\nof lichen on a rock.\r\n\r\nAfter several days of rowing, the food and water supply was almost half\r\ndepleted and still no evidence of either past or present habitation. It\r\nwas time to turn back, to travel all the weary months across the West\r\nWater, the journey all in vain. What a small reward for such an arduous\r\ntrip ... just proof of the existence of a barren land mass, ugly and\r\nuseless.\r\n\r\nOn the second day of the return to the Semilunis, the scouting party\r\ndecided to stop and investigate a huge opening in the rocky mountainside.\r\nHow suspiciously regular and even it looked, particularly in comparison\r\nto the rest of the countryside which was jagged and chaotic.\r\n\r\nThey entered the cave apprehensively, torches aflare and weapons in\r\nhand. But all was darkness and quiet. 

Still, the regularity of the cave\r\nwalls led them on. Some creature, man or otherwise, must have planned\r\nand built this ... but to what end? Now the cave divided into three\r\nforks. The torches gave only a hint of the immensity of the chambers\r\nthat lay at the end of each. They selected the center chamber,\r\napproaching cautiously, breath caught in awe and excitement. The torches\r\nreflected on a dull black surface which was divided into many, many\r\nlittle squares. 

The sameness of them stretched for uncountable yards in\r\nall directions. What were these ungodly looking edifices? The black\r\nsurface was cold and smooth to the touch and quite regular except for a\r\nstrange little hole at the bottom of each square and a curious row of\r\npictures along the top.\r\n\r\nThey would copy these strange pictures. Perhaps back home there would be\r\na scholar who would understand the meaning behind these last remains of\r\nthe people of the west continent. Tell me your story again."\r\n\r\nThe man was short and stocky, with Asiatic features and a long, stringy\r\nmustache. "The whole story?" 

he asked. "It would take a lifetime to tell\r\nyou." He stared out the window at the yellow sun and the red sun. 

He\r\nstill hadn\'t gotten used to seeing two suns. But that was minor, really,\r\nwhen there were so many other things he had to get used to.\r\n\r\nA robot waiter, with long thin metal tubes for arms and legs, glided\r\nover. When he\'d first seen one of those, he\'d thought it was a demon.\r\nHe\'d tried to smash it. They\'d had trouble with him at first.\r\n\r\n"They had trouble with me at first," he said.\r\n\r\n"I can imagine," said the girl. "How did they explain it to you?

"\r\n\r\n"It was hard. They had to give me the whole history of medicine. It was\r\nyears before I got over the notion that I was up in the Everlasting Blue\r\nSky, or under the earth, or something." He grinned at the girl. She was\r\nthe first person he\'d met since they got him a job and gave him a home\r\nin a world uncountable light years from the one he\'d been born on.\r\n\r\n"When did you begin to understand?"\r\n\r\n"They simply taught all of history to me. Including the part about\r\nmyself. Then I began to get the picture. 

Funny. I wound up teaching them\r\na lot of history."\r\n\r\n"I bet you know a lot."\r\n\r\n"I do," the man with the Asiatic features said modestly. "Anyway, they\r\nfinally got across to me that in the 22nd century--they had explained\r\nthe calendar to me, too; I used a different one in my day--they had\r\nlearned how to grow new limbs on people who had lost arms and legs."\r\n\r\n"That was the first real step," said the girl.\r\n\r\n"It was a long time till they got to the second step," he said. "They\r\nlearned how to stimulate life and new growth in people who had already\r\ndied."\r\n\r\n"The next part is the thing I don\'t understand," the girl said.\r\n\r\n"Well," said the man, "as I get it, they found that any piece of matter\r\nthat has been part of an organism, retains a physical \'memory\' of the\r\nentire structure of the organism of which it was part. And that they\r\ncould reconstruct that structure from a part of a person, if that was\r\nall there was left of him. From there it was just a matter of pushing\r\nthe process back through time. They had to teach me a whole new language\r\nto explain that one."\r\n\r\n"Isn\'t it wonderful that intergalactic travel gives us room to expand?"\r\nsaid the girl. "I mean now that every human being that ever lived has\r\nbeen brought back to life and will live forever?"\r\n\r\n"Same problem I had, me and my people," said the man. "We were cramped\r\nfor space. This age has solved it a lot better than I did. 

But they had\r\nto give me a whole psychological overhauling before I understood that."\r\n\r\n"Tell me about your past life," said the girl, staring dreamily at him.\r\n\r\n"Well, six thousand years ago, I was born in the Gobi Desert, on Earth,"\r\nsaid Genghis Khan, sipping his drink.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Fantastic Universe_ December 1957.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and\r\n    typographical errors have been corrected without note.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n            He wanted above anything else to go into space.\r\n               He had been waiting for it--a long time!\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was hours after the last official ceremony before Clifton could\r\nescape the crowd of planetlubbers with their babblings, their eligible\r\ndaughters and their stupid self-admiration. They\'d paid through the\r\nnose to get him here, and they meant to get their money\'s worth.\r\n\r\nThe exit led only to a little balcony, but it seemed to be deserted. He\r\ntook a deep breath of the night air and his eyes moved unconsciously\r\ntoward the stars.\r\n\r\nComing back to Earth had been a mistake, but he\'d needed the\r\nmoney. Space Products Unlimited wanted a real deepspace hero to\r\nhelp celebrate its hundredth anniversary. He had just finished the\r\nRegulation of Rigel, so he\'d been picked. 

Damn them and their silly\r\nspeeches and awards--and damn Earth! What was one planet when there\r\nwere a billion up there among the stars?\r\n\r\nFrom the other side of a potted plant there was a soft sigh.\r\n\r\nClifton swung his head, then relaxed as he saw the other man was not\r\nlooking at him. The eyes behind the dark glasses were directed toward\r\nthe sky.\r\n\r\n"Aldebaran, Sirius, Deneb, Alpha Centauri," the voice whispered. It\r\nwas a high-pitched voice with an odd accent, but there was the poetry\r\nof ancient yearning in it.\r\n\r\nHe was a small, shriveled old man. His shoulders were bent. A long\r\nbeard and the dark glasses covered most of his face, but could not\r\nentirely conceal the deep wrinkles, even in the moonlight.\r\n\r\nClifton felt a sudden touch of pity and moved closer, without quite\r\nknowing why. "Didn\'t I see you on the platform?

"\r\n\r\n"Your memory is very good, Captain. I was awarded publicly--for fifty\r\nyears of faithful service making space boots. Well, I was always a\r\ngood cobbler, and perhaps my boots helped some men out there." The old\r\nman\'s hand swept toward the stars, then fell back to grip the railing\r\ntightly. "They gave me a gold watch, though time means nothing to me.\r\nAnd a cheap world cruise ticket. As if there were any spot on this\r\nworld I could still want to see." 

He laughed harshly. "Forgive me if I\r\nsound bitter. But, you see, I\'ve never been off Earth!"\r\n\r\nClifton stared at him incredulously. "But everyone--"\r\n\r\n"Everyone but me," the old man said. "Oh, I tried. I was utterly weary\r\nof Earth and I looked at the stars and dreamed. But I failed the early\r\nrigid physicals. Then, when things were easier, I tried again. A\r\nplague grounded the first ship. A strike delayed another. Then one\r\nexploded on the pad and only a few on board were saved. It was then I\r\nrealized I was meant to wait here--here on Earth, and nowhere else. So\r\nI stayed, making space boots."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nPity and impulse forced unexpected words to Clifton\'s lips. "I\'m taking\r\noff for Rigel again in four hours, and there\'s a spare cabin on the\r\n_Maryloo_. You\'re coming with me."\r\n\r\nThe old hand that gripped his arm was oddly gentle. "Bless you,\r\nCaptain. 

But it would never work. I\'m under orders to remain here."\r\n\r\n"Nobody can order a man grounded forever. You\'re coming with me if I\r\nhave to drag you, Mr.--"\r\n\r\n"Ahasuerus."\r\n\r\nThe old man hesitated, as if expecting the name to mean something. Then\r\nhe sighed and lifted his dark glasses.\r\n\r\nClifton met the other\'s gaze for less than a second. 

Then his own eyes\r\ndropped, though memory of what he had seen was already fading. He\r\nvaulted over the balcony railing and began running away from Ahasuerus,\r\ntoward his ship and the unconfined reaches of space.\r\n\r\nBehind him, the eternal wanderer tarried and waited.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n

]\r\n\r\n\r\nMaybe a guy shouldn\'t believe everything he hears, but the trouble with\r\nsome people is that they don\'t even believe a true story. Let me buy\r\nyou a beer and tell you about it.\r\n\r\nAfter working some years in the baggage room of the local depot, I\r\ndecided to transfer to the train service, and made application for it.\r\nThe application was approved. I was sent to the city offices for the\r\ncourse of study and training which all trainmen undergo, and after\r\na time I was sent out as brakeman on a freight. I stayed for a year\r\nand a half. Then I succeeded in being assigned as head brakeman on a\r\nfast food special called The Red Ball Special. It made no stop between\r\nChicago and New York except for water and fuel. The big Diesel in which\r\nI rode as head brakie was a high-speed locomotive, used exclusively for\r\nhauling the food special.\r\n\r\nOur first stop was Detroit, where we cut off all but three cars, and\r\ntook on five more scheduled in New York at 9 the next morning. In New\r\nYork, I strolled along Broadway, gawking at the sights exactly like any\r\nother yokel.\r\n\r\nAfter a twelve-hour rest, the return trip began. I stood in my place in\r\nthe big Diesel till we had cleared for the main line, and then settled\r\nback to enjoy the ride.\r\n\r\nIt was close to midnight. 

I sat at the cab window half asleep, my\r\nsenses somewhat dulled by the steady rhythm of train movement. I\'d\r\nfinished an extra good cigar and had started to doze off when the\r\nengineer gave a low moan and toppled from his seat to the floor of the\r\ncab.\r\n\r\nThe fireman, much against the rules, but feeling safe with the engineer\r\nand myself to watch in his place, had gone back to inspect a suspected\r\nleaking air hose without waiting for the train to stop.\r\n\r\nI got the engineer back on his seat. He was dead.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI tied him in place and then began pulling on the whistle cord like\r\nmad. It was not my work to operate a Diesel. 

I\'d not troubled to learn.\r\n\r\nI wondered why the fireman did not get back. I was going to jump,\r\nalthough I didn\'t like my chances at that speed, when I suddenly\r\ndiscovered a strange man in the cab with me. He was a pretty ordinary\r\nlittle guy, except for a wild, shaggy head of hair.\r\n\r\n"You chump!" he squeaked at me. "Maybe next time you\'ll obey the rules,\r\nand not sneak by without finding out things! See that short rod with\r\nthe spring-clip? Squeeze that clip and pull the rod back. 

Move, you\r\nfathead!"\r\n\r\nI did as the shaggy man told me, and felt the speed of the train\r\nslacken slightly as the power went off.\r\n\r\n"Now, that brass handle sticking out of that pipe--move it to the right\r\nslowly. _Slowly_, you dunce!"\r\n\r\nNine cars and the Diesel ground slowly to a stop. The wheels shuddered\r\nand skidded slightly because of my inexperienced hand, but the train\r\ndid stop.\r\n\r\nThe stranger nodded in satisfaction. "When you get back home, bone up\r\non things. But right now you go take a close look at the manifest card\r\non the sides of the second and third cars...."\r\n\r\nI jumped to the ground to go back and look at the second and third\r\ncars. As I passed the rear of the Diesel I saw why the fireman had not\r\ncome back to the engine cab. All that was left of him was the lower\r\npart of his body. He had slipped, caught one foot and gone under the\r\nwheels.\r\n\r\nI came to the second car and read the manifest label. My hair stood\r\nstraight up.\r\n\r\nThe cars were marked:\r\n\r\n                                Danger\r\n                               DYNAMITE\r\n                           _High Explosive_\r\n\r\nThe shaggy man was at my side. "You\'ve got questions. 

But let me ask\r\nyou one: Ever hear a story about how if you travel back to the time of\r\nan ancestor and you let him die you never get born?

"\r\n\r\n"What about it?" I said.\r\n\r\n"It\'s true," said the shaggy man.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n

He only laughed back at me and turned his back,\r\nwaving a hand for the bartender. Maybe in a big city in the North it\r\nwould be different and probably it would not: this toleration we hear\r\nabout is no more good than an open fight, and there must be\r\nunderstanding instead. But here near the border, just on the American\r\nside of the border, a Mexican is called fair game, and a\r\nseventeen-year-old like me is less than nothing to them, to the white\r\nones who go to the big bars.\r\n\r\nI thought carefully about what to do, and finally when I had made my\r\nmind up I went for him and tried to hit him. But other men held me back,\r\nand I was kicking and shouting with my legs off the ground. 

When I\r\nstopped they put me down, so I started for the big red-haired man again\r\nand they had to stop me again. 

The red-haired man was laughing all this\r\ntime. I wanted to run, back to my own family in their little house, and\r\nyet running would have been wrong; I was too angry to run, so I stayed.\r\n\r\n"My sister," I said. "My sister is a witch and I will get her to put a\r\ncurse on you." I was very angry, you must understand this.\r\n\r\nAnd of course they had no idea that my sister is a real witch, and her\r\ncurses are real, and only last year Manuel Valdez had died from the\r\neffects of her curse. Of all people, sometimes I wish I were my sister\r\nmost of all, to curse people and see them shrivel and sicken and choke\r\nand die.\r\n\r\n"Go ahead, half-pint," one of the other men yelled. "Get your sister to\r\nput a curse on me. I bet she knows who I am; I been with every Mex girl\r\nthis side of the border."\r\n\r\nThis made me see red; my sister is pure and must be pure, since she is a\r\nwitch. And she is not like some of the others even aside from that. 

I\r\nhave heard her talk about them and I know.\r\n\r\nI called him a name and ran up to him and hit him; my fist against his\r\nsolid side felt good, but some other men pulled me off again. Yet it was\r\nimpossible to leave. This was wrong for me, and I had to make it right.\r\n"I shall get my father to fight you, since he is a giant ten feet tall."\r\n\r\nThe men laughed at me, not knowing, of course, that my father is a giant\r\nten feet tall in truth, and my mother a sweet siren like those in the\r\nbooks, the old books, with spells in her eyes and a strange power. They\r\ndid not know I was not a daydreaming child but a man who told truth.\r\n\r\nAnd they laughed; I grew angry again and told them many things, calling\r\nthem names in Spanish, which they did not understand. That only made\r\nthem laugh the more.\r\n\r\nFinally I left; it was necessary for me to leave, since I was not\r\nwanted. But it was necessary, too, for me to make things right. 

Nights\r\nlater they were dead for what they had said and done.\r\n\r\nFor I tell the truth always, and I had told them about my sister and my\r\nfather and my mother. But one thing I had not told them.\r\n\r\nI am sorry they could never know I was the winged thing that frightened\r\nand killed them, one by one....\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Fantastic Universe_ January 1957.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and\r\n    typographical errors have been corrected without note.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


And the Enforced\r\nBirth Control Program couldn\'t be enforced. Overpopulation still remains\r\nthe thorn in our side. Gentlemen--" He paused to look each of the\r\nassembled reporters in the eye. "--there is but _one_ answer."\r\n\r\n"Mass annihilation?" quavered a cub reporter.\r\n\r\n"Posh, boy! Certainly not!" 

The professor bristled. "The answer\r\nis--TIME!"\r\n\r\n"Time?"\r\n\r\n"Exactly," nodded Ohms. With a dramatic flourish he swept aside a red\r\nvelvet drape--to reveal a tall structure of gleaming metal. "As\r\nwitness!

"\r\n\r\n"Golly, what\'s _that_ thing?" queried the cub.\r\n\r\n"This _thing_," replied the professor acidly, "--is the C. Cydwick Ohms\r\nTime Door."\r\n\r\n"Whillikers, a Time Machine!

"\r\n\r\n"Not so, not so. _Please_, boy! A Time Machine, in the popular sense,\r\nis impossible. Wild fancy! However--" The professor tapped the dottle\r\nfrom his pipe. "--by a mathematically precise series of infinite\r\ncalculations, I have developed the remarkable C. Cydwick Ohms Time Door.\r\nOpen it, take but a single step--and, presto! The Past!

"\r\n\r\n"But, _where_ in the past, Prof.?"\r\n\r\nOhms smiled easily down at the tense ring of faces. "Gentlemen, beyond\r\nthis door lies the sprawling giant of the Southwest--enough land to\r\nabsorb Earth\'s overflow like _that_!" He snapped his fingers. "I speak,\r\ngentlemen, of Texas, 1957!"\r\n\r\n"What if the Texans _object_?"\r\n\r\n"They have no choice. The Time Door is strictly a one-way passage. 

I saw\r\nto that. It will be utterly impossible for anyone in 1957 to re-enter\r\nour world of 2057. And now--the Past awaits!

"\r\n\r\nHe tossed aside his professorial robes. Under them Cydwick Ohms wore an\r\nancient and bizarre costume: black riding boots, highly polished and\r\ntrimmed in silver; wool chaps; a wide, jewel-studded belt with an\r\nimmense buckle; a brightly checked shirt topped by a blazing red\r\nbandana. Briskly, he snapped a tall ten-gallon hat on his head, and\r\nstepped to the Time Door.\r\n\r\nGripping an ebony handle, he tugged upward. The huge metal door oiled\r\nslowly back. "Time," said Cydwick Ohms simply, gesturing toward the gray\r\nnothingness beyond the door.\r\n\r\nThe reporters and photographers surged forward, notebooks and cameras at\r\nthe ready. "What if the door swings shut after you\'re gone?" one of them\r\nasked.\r\n\r\n"A groundless fear, boy," assured Ohms. "I have seen to it that the Time\r\nDoor can never be closed. And now--good-bye, gentlemen. Or, to use the\r\nproper colloquialism--_so long, hombres!_"\r\n\r\nOhms bowed from the waist, gave his ten-gallon hat a final tug, and took\r\na single step forward.\r\n\r\nAnd did _not_ disappear.\r\n\r\nHe stood, blinking. Then he swore, beat upon the unyielding wall of\r\ngrayness with clenched fists, and fell back, panting, to his desk.\r\n\r\n"I\'ve failed!" 

he moaned in a lost voice. "The C. Cydwick Ohms Time Door\r\nis a botch!" He buried his head in trembling hands.\r\n\r\nThe reporters and photographers began to file out.\r\n\r\nSuddenly the professor raised his head. "_Listen!_" he warned.\r\n\r\nA slow rumbling, muted with distance, emanated from the dense grayness\r\nof the Time Door. Faint yips and whoopings were distinct above the\r\nrumble. The sounds grew steadily--to a thousand beating drums--to a\r\nrolling sea of thunder!\r\n\r\nShrieking, the reporters and photographers scattered for the stairs.\r\n\r\nAh, another knotty problem to be solved, mused Professor Cydwick Ohms,\r\nswinging, with some difficulty, onto one of three thousand Texas steers\r\nstampeding into the laboratory.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Fantastic Universe_ November 1956.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and\r\n    typographical errors have been corrected without note.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


The roll call of celebrities\r\nread like the Who\'s Who of S.F. Prodom: Theodore Sturgeon, Isaac Asimov,\r\nFritz Leiber, Willy Ley, Nelson Bond, John W. Campbell Jr., L. Sprague\r\nde Camp, James Blish, Judith Merril, "Ted" Carnell (Editor of New\r\nWorlds), Kelly Freas, Edmond Hamilton, Leigh Brackett, Anthony Boucher,\r\nWilliam Tenn, James E. Gunn, Frank Belknap Long Jr., and numerous\r\nothers, including Guest of Honor Arthur C. Clarke.\r\n\r\nA standing ovation was given Arthur Clarke before and after his speech\r\nat the Banquet, a serious address that lasted forty-five minutes and\r\ncovered many philosophical facets of the s.f. field. Especially rousing\r\nhands were given two of the real old-timers present, artist Frank R.\r\nPaul (Guest of Honor of the first Convention), and--out of the Ark--the\r\nman who once was an assistant to Thomas Alva Edison, the pioneer\r\nnovelist of scientific romances and the man who discovered the Golden\r\nAtom--Ray Cummings. World famous cartoonist Al Capp gave a hilarious\r\nspeech at the Banquet Sunday night, other large laughs being garnered on\r\nthe occasion by Isaac Asimov and Anthony Boucher, Robert Bloch again\r\nproving that he has no peer as a Master of Ceremonies.\r\n\r\nThe Masquerade Ball was filmed for televising, and was a sight for\r\nbugging eyes. Extraterrestrial glamour girls came in spectrumatic\r\ncolors: one, Ruth Landis of Venus (formerly Nuyok), was a verdant\r\nbeauty, fresh as a breath of chlorophyll; while tall Tam Otteson, a\r\nrecent import from England, had the judges agreeing that just looking at\r\nher was an education. 

Olga Ley won for the Most Beautiful costume, and\r\nJos Christoff--a survivor from the first convention of them all--was\r\nanother prize winner. Monsters, mutants, scientists, spacemen, aliens,\r\nand assorted "Things" thronged the ballroom floor as the flashbulbs\r\npopped.\r\n\r\nJohn Campbell lectured on and demonstrated his controversial psionic\r\nHieronymus machine, and famous fans sprang from der vood-work out--Sam\r\nMoskowitz, James Taurasi, Bob Tucker, Julius Unger, Raymond Van Houten,\r\nAllen Glasser ...\r\n\r\nDavid Kyle, E. E. Evans, James Taurasi, myself and 2 others were elected\r\nDirectors of the World Science Fiction Society.\r\n\r\nNo account of the Newyorcon could be complete without a deep bow of\r\nappreciation to the altruistic trio of committeemen (including one\r\ncomely woman) who all but destroyed themselves engineering the\r\nConvention: David A. Kyle, Ruth Landis and Dick Ellington.\r\n\r\nBy a vote of 3 to 1, London was selected as the site of the 15th Con, to\r\nbe held in \'57. For an unforgettable experience in the fantastic\r\nuniverse of science fiction enthusiasts, plan _now_ to attend the\r\nLONCON!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Fantastic Universe_ January 1957.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed.

It\r\nwill operate only on objects weighing less than three pounds, five\r\nounces and for distances into the past and future of twelve minutes or\r\nless. But it works."\r\n\r\nThe small-scale model looked like a small scale--a postage scale--except\r\nfor two dials in the part under the platform.\r\n\r\nProfessor Johnson held up a small metal cube. "Our experimental object,"\r\nhe said, "is a brass cube weighing one pound, two point three ounces.\r\nFirst, I shall send it five minutes into the future."\r\n\r\nHe leaned forward and set one of the dials on the time machine. "Look at\r\nyour watches," he said.\r\n\r\nThey looked at their watches. Professor Johnson placed the cube gently\r\non the machine\'s platform. It vanished.\r\n\r\nFive minutes later, to the second, it reappeared.\r\n\r\nProfessor Johnson picked it up. "Now five minutes into the past." 

He set\r\nthe other dial. Holding the cube in his hand he looked at his watch. "It\r\nis six minutes before three o\'clock. I shall now activate the\r\nmechanism--by placing the cube on the platform--at exactly three\r\no\'clock. Therefore, the cube should, at five minutes before three,\r\nvanish from my hand and appear on the platform, five minutes before I\r\nplace it there."\r\n\r\n"How can you place it there, then?" asked one of his colleagues.\r\n\r\n"It will, as my hand approaches, vanish from the platform and appear in\r\nmy hand to be placed there. Three o\'clock. 

Notice, please."\r\n\r\nThe cube vanished from his hand.\r\n\r\nIt appeared on the platform of the time machine.\r\n\r\n"See? Five minutes before I shall place it there, it _is_ there!"\r\n\r\nHis other colleague frowned at the cube. "But," he said, "what if, now\r\nthat it has already appeared five minutes before you place it there, you\r\nshould change your mind about doing so and _not_ place it there at three\r\no\'clock? Wouldn\'t there be a paradox of some sort involved?

"\r\n\r\n"An interesting idea," Professor Johnson said. "I had not thought of it,\r\nand it will be interesting to try. 

Very well, I shall _not_ ..."\r\n\r\nThere was no paradox at all. The cube remained.\r\n\r\nBut the entire rest of the Universe, professors and all, vanished.\r\n\r\n\r\nSentry\r\n\r\nHe was wet and muddy and hungry and cold, and he was fifty thousand\r\nlight-years from home.\r\n\r\nA strange blue sun gave light and the gravity, twice what he was used\r\nto, made every movement difficult.\r\n\r\nBut in tens of thousands of years this part of war hadn\'t changed. The\r\nflyboys were fine with their sleek spaceships and their fancy weapons.\r\nWhen the chips are down, though, it was still the foot soldier, the\r\ninfantry, that had to take the ground and hold it, foot by bloody foot.\r\nLike this damned planet of a star he\'d never heard of until they\'d\r\nlanded him there. And now it was sacred ground because the aliens were\r\nthere too. _The_ aliens, the only other intelligent race in the\r\nGalaxy ... cruel, hideous and repulsive monsters.\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\nContact had been made with them near the center of the Galaxy, after the\r\nslow, difficult colonization of a dozen thousand planets; and it had\r\nbeen war at sight; they\'d shot without even trying to negotiate, or to\r\nmake peace.\r\n\r\nNow, planet by bitter planet, it was being fought out.\r\n\r\nHe was wet and muddy and hungry and cold, and the day was raw with a\r\nhigh wind that hurt his eyes. But the aliens were trying to infiltrate\r\nand every sentry post was vital.\r\n\r\nHe stayed alert, gun ready. Fifty thousand light-years from home,\r\nfighting on a strange world and wondering if he\'d ever live to see home\r\nagain.\r\n\r\nAnd then he saw one of them crawling toward him. He drew a bead and\r\nfired. The alien made that strange horrible sound they all make, then\r\nlay still.\r\n\r\nHe shuddered at the sound and sight of the alien lying there. 

One ought\r\nto be able to get used to them after a while, but he\'d never been able\r\nto. Such repulsive creatures they were, with only two arms and two legs,\r\nghastly white skins and no scales.\r\n\r\n                                                       --FREDRIC BROWN\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Galaxy Science Fiction_ February 1954.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. One of Da\'s\r\ncustomers had shopped him.  The ipolice paid in high-grade\r\npharmaceuticals -- performance enhancers, memory supplements, metabolic\r\nboosters.  The kind of things that cost a fortune over the counter; the\r\nkind of things you could print at home, if you didn\'t mind the risk of\r\nhaving your kitchen filled with a sudden crush of big, beefy bodies,\r\nhard truncheons whistling through the air, smashing anyone and anything\r\nthat got in the way.\r\n\r\nThey destroyed grandma\'s trunk, the one she\'d brought from the old\r\ncountry.  They smashed our little refrigerator and the purifier unit\r\nover the window.  My tweetybird escaped death by hiding in a corner of\r\nhis cage as a big, booted foot crushed most of it into a sad tangle of\r\nprinter-wire.\r\n\r\nDa.  What they did to him.  

When he was done, he looked like he\'d been\r\nbrawling with an entire rugby side.  They brought him out the door and\r\nlet the newsies get a good look at him as they tossed him in the car.\r\nAll the while a spokesman told the world that my Da\'s organized-crime\r\nbootlegging operation had been responsible for at least 20 million in\r\ncontraband, and that my Da, the desperate villain, had resisted arrest.\r\n\r\nI saw it all from my phone, in the remains of the sitting room, watching\r\nit on the screen and wondering how, just how anyone could look at our\r\nlittle flat and our terrible, manky estate and mistake it for the home\r\nof an organized crime kingpin.  They took the printer away, of course,\r\nand displayed it like a trophy for the newsies.  

Its little shrine in\r\nthe kitchenette seemed horribly empty.  When I roused myself and picked\r\nup the flat and rescued my poor peeping tweetybird, I put a blender\r\nthere.  It was made out of printed parts, so it would only last a month\r\nbefore I\'d need to print new bearings and other moving parts.  Back\r\nthen, I could take apart and reassemble anything that could be printed.\r\n\r\nBy the time I turned 18, they were ready to let Da out of prison.  I\'d\r\nvisited him three times -- on my tenth birthday, on his fiftieth, and\r\nwhen Ma died.  It had been two years since I\'d last seen him and he was\r\nin bad shape.  A prison fight had left him with a limp, and he looked\r\nover his shoulder so often it was like he had a tic.  I was embarrassed\r\nwhen the minicab dropped us off in front of the estate, and tried to\r\nkeep my distance from this ruined, limping skeleton as we went inside\r\nand up the stairs.\r\n\r\n"Lanie," he said, as he sat me down.  "You\'re a smart girl, I know that.\r\nYou wouldn\'t know where your old Da could get a printer and some goop?"\r\n\r\nI squeezed my hands into fists so tight my fingernails cut into my\r\npalms.  I closed my eyes.  "You\'ve been in prison for ten years, Da.\r\nTen.  Years.  You\'re going to risk another ten years to print out more\r\nblenders and pharma, more laptops and designer hats?"\r\n\r\nHe grinned.  "I\'m not stupid, Lanie.  I\'ve learned my lesson.  There\'s\r\nno hat or laptop that\'s worth going to jail for.  I\'m not going to print\r\nnone of that rubbish, never again." He had a cup of tea, and he drank it\r\nnow like it was whisky, a sip and then a long, satisfied exhalation.  He\r\nclosed his eyes and leaned back in his chair.\r\n\r\n"Come here, Lanie, let me whisper in your ear.  Let me tell you the\r\nthing that I decided while I spent ten years in lockup.  Come here and\r\nlisten to your stupid Da."\r\n\r\nI felt a guilty pang about ticking him off.  He was off his rocker, that\r\nmuch was clear.  God knew what he went through in prison.  

"What, Da?" I\r\nsaid, leaning in close.\r\n\r\n"Lanie, I\'m going to print more printers.  Lots more printers.  

One for\r\neveryone.  That\'s worth going to jail for.  

That\'s worth anything."\r\n\r\n--------\r\n\r\nCory Doctorow has spent the past four years at the Electronic Frontier\r\nFoundation (www.eff.org), fighting at the United Nations and in\r\ntech-standards bodies to balance the rights of copyright and patent\r\nholders with the public interest. copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\n"Oluf!"\r\n\r\n"Bowron!"\r\n\r\nThey recognized each other simultaneously, there in the thin fringe of\r\ntangled brush skirting a hidden lake.\r\n\r\n"Oluf, it\'s good to see you again--I thought there was nothing but\r\nmountains, wolves and Wild Ones between me and civilization!" They\r\npicked their way slowly toward the shore together.\r\n\r\nOluf dropped gratefully to the warm sand. The sunset highlighted his\r\nreddish hair. "You\'re not far wrong--there was wolf spoor back on that\r\nnorth ridge. But what in the name of the Moon are you doing so far from\r\nNew York?"\r\n\r\n"Heading south, to stay," Bowron said. He scanned the brush and trees\r\nbehind them cautiously, then stretched out beside his companion,\r\nsighing. "I\'m getting too old for the winters, and the canned foods in\r\nthe ruins are getting scarcer every year."\r\n\r\nOluf looked at him in disbelief. "You\'re traveling alone?"\r\n\r\n"Aren\'t you?" The retort was sharp, with the keen edge of elderly pride.\r\n\r\nSomething like a weary chuckle sounded deep in Oluf\'s throat. He spoke\r\nwith easy candor. "Yes, but--look, Bowron, I\'m a hunter by choice. And\r\nI\'m big and in my prime. 

I can run half a day at top speed, and I\'m not\r\ntoo bad in a free-for-all. You\'re a teacher--wise, but not in the ways\r\nof the wilds; your senses are dull and your reactions slow, like all\r\ncity folk."\r\n\r\nBowron\'s eyes looked suddenly tired, older. He gazed out over the\r\nplacid water. 

"I could persuade no one to accompany me," he said\r\nsimply. "You made a good choice, Oluf, to terminate your education and\r\nseek the freedom of the wilds--the natural life that I think all must\r\nsomeday embrace." He sighed deeply. 

"Of course, there is the dream of\r\nachievement that the city dwellers entertain. We\'ve grown soft in\r\nour dependence upon the buried food in the rubble--spending our time\r\nin study of the books and other god-things, always hoping that we can\r\nunderstand and duplicate the old civilization. But our best thinkers,\r\nsince they are the most eager searchers, stumble most often into the\r\nhidden pockets of radioactivity that endure even yet; and they die, and\r\ntheir knowledge dies with them, and our dreams and aspirations become\r\ndimmer with each generation."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nOluf grunted, and Bowron went on as though to himself. "I\'ve come\r\nto believe that it\'s useless to follow in the footsteps of the\r\ngods--that we must wait, and think, and work, each in his own way,\r\nuntil we learn what is possible for us through our own trials and\r\nthe further development of our simple tools. We\'ve learned much from\r\nthe god-things, slowly, over the years. But we also know that we\'re\r\nmutants, changed by the radiation of the great war areas, breeding true\r\nat last, and that we are different from the Wild Ones. True, we\'re\r\nsuperior, but--we\'re not gods. Whether we can ever--"\r\n\r\nOluf had sprung to his feet and was gone with incredible speed. 

Bowron\r\nsat up tensely, listened to the crashing of brush, and, finally, to\r\na shrill squeal of departing life. He relaxed and waited until Oluf,\r\ngrinning, returned with a rabbit.\r\n\r\n"Our dinner, old-timer. Sorry I wasn\'t listening too closely to what\r\nyou were saying."\r\n\r\nLater, after they had eaten and were stretched comfortably on the\r\nmoon-drenched shore, Oluf grew reminiscent. "I remember your teachings,\r\nBowron. And I recall well our endless attempts to operate the\r\ngod-things--the machines and mechanisms. 

But all that always seemed\r\nstrange. Best of all I liked the tales of the old days--the stories of\r\nour ancestors."\r\n\r\nBowron nodded thoughtfully. "It was that way with most of my pupils. It\r\nwas more comfortable to dream of the past than to cope with the current\r\nhardships. It seemed to arouse some dormant instinct in all of us--" He\r\nbroke off and sighed. "Would you like to hear another of the stories?

"\r\n\r\n"Very much!"\r\n\r\nBowron studied the bright moon. "Well--once in the far and long ago,\r\nthere was a man named Smith, who lived in a big city...."\r\n\r\nWhen the tale was done, Oluf seemed deeply moved. "I believe," he said\r\nslowly, "that I\'ll go with you to the Southland. You might easily\r\nperish on the way, and such words as yours must live to give others\r\ncomfort and hope--for we may yet find living gods in some remote corner\r\nof the world. It must have been wonderful," he mused sleepily, "to\r\nhave lived in companionship with the gods--with men." He curled up\r\ncomfortably, paws tucked in, and laid his nose across his bushy tail.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n

]\r\n\r\n\r\nAt dusk the sergeant leaned over the parapet, weary, looking south\r\ntoward the enemy lines. For him this was the worst part of the day. The\r\nfighting was done until tomorrow and the enemy casualties were being\r\nbrought in through the gate below. Their bodies were piled in awful\r\nabandon on the big flat-bed trucks.\r\n\r\nA phrase from another war came to his mind. Walking wounded. There were\r\nno walking wounded in this war. They came in on the trucks, still and\r\ntangled, or they didn\'t come in at all.\r\n\r\nHe couldn\'t have merely wounded one of the enemy, as soldiers used\r\nto. The thought of inflicting such an injury, in the old conventional\r\nway, was obscene. To strike through the breast into the heart....\r\nHe shuddered with a trembling that came up through the thighs and\r\ncontracted his stomach.\r\n\r\nThe lieutenant had come to stand beside him.\r\n\r\n"You shouldn\'t watch, if it bothers you," the lieutenant said.\r\n\r\n"It\'s all right, sir," the sergeant said. He looked down again.\r\n\r\n"We had a good day. Three hundred, the colonel said."\r\n\r\n"That\'s good." The sergeant laughed sardonically. "Are we winning?"\r\n\r\n"It\'s hard to say. We\'re not losing."\r\n\r\n"Aren\'t we, sir?" The sergeant spoke bitterly. "Aren\'t they? Aren\'t we\r\nall?"\r\n\r\n"Look, sergeant--" the lieutenant began. Then he shrugged. The sergeant\r\nwas older than he was by seven or eight years. There was no need to\r\ngive him an orientation lecture. He reached in his pocket and took out\r\na fresh pack of cigarettes. He opened it. 

"Have one. A shipment just\r\ngot in."\r\n\r\n"Thanks." The sergeant took a cigarette. He stared at it and the\r\nfingers holding it trembled. 

"Look at it," he said hollowly. "Look at\r\nthe freakin\' thing!"\r\n\r\nThe lieutenant looked at it, then at the front of the pack. _Ruby tips\r\nto match your lips_, it said under the brand name.\r\n\r\n"What are they doing to us?" the sergeant said. He crumpled the\r\ncigarette in his fist and threw it down and ground it under his boot.\r\n"Isn\'t it hard enough?"\r\n\r\n"It must be a mistake," the lieutenant said. He sounded shaken, too.\r\n"Because of the shortage, maybe. Unless it\'s a fifth column trick. Like\r\nthe rumor about them not going to wake up again."\r\n\r\n"It is just a rumor, isn\'t it?" the sergeant said. 

His voice was almost\r\npleading. "We just freeze them for--for the duration, don\'t we? Don\'t\r\nwe, lieutenant? Because I couldn\'t go on if they were really dead.\r\nNobody could."\r\n\r\nThe lieutenant spoke sharply. "Snap out of it, sergeant! It\'s just\r\npropaganda. I\'m surprised at an old hand like you falling for it.

"\r\n\r\n"I\'m not, sir. We couldn\'t really kill them, could we? It\'d be suicide,\r\nwouldn\'t it? It\'s not total war, is it?"\r\n\r\n"Not total, no. There\'ll be an end to it one day, and then a beginning\r\nagain. I know it\'s hard, but it\'s the only way."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe last of the big trucks had rumbled in from the battlefield. The\r\nsergeant watched the gate close in the fading light. Beloved enemy, he\r\nthought.\r\n\r\n"Three hundred today," he said aloud. "And one was my personal\r\ncontribution. My platoon was strung out behind me, and she came up over\r\nthe hill--"\r\n\r\n"Sergeant!"\r\n\r\n"She was mine. I got her personally. I aimed slow and held the sight on\r\nher. Then I let go. It was almost like--"\r\n\r\n"Sergeant!" The lieutenant was trembling. "The third person singular is\r\nprohibited! You know that, sergeant!"\r\n\r\nThe sergeant was calm. "Yes, sir." He looked at the young officer. "But\r\nI feel better for having told about it. I\'m all right now, sir. I hope\r\nI didn\'t upset you."\r\n\r\n"No," the lieutenant said. "No. 

We\'ll forget about it."\r\n\r\n"I\'ll have one of those cigarettes now, sir, if you don\'t mind. It\r\ndoesn\'t matter about the tip, now that it\'s dark."\r\n\r\n"Well...." The lieutenant hesitated. "I was going to send them back to\r\nQuartermaster, with a report. But all right. 

Here. 

I\'ll have one, too."\r\n\r\nAs the sergeant lit them he could see a bit of the red tip in the\r\nlieutenant\'s mouth. He dragged deep on his own, pretending he could\r\ntaste lipstick.\r\n\r\n"Lieutenant," he said. "It doesn\'t matter where you hit them, does it?\r\nI mean it doesn\'t hurt them at all?"\r\n\r\n"No," the lieutenant said. "No, it doesn\'t matter. They just go to\r\nsleep.

"\r\n\r\n"I\'m glad." After a while the sergeant said, "I guess I\'ll hit the\r\nsack."\r\n\r\n"It\'s still early."\r\n\r\n"Yes. But I like to get up early. There\'s always a line in the\r\nlatrine--at the shaving bowls."\r\n\r\n"Combat troops don\'t have to shave," the lieutenant said.\r\n\r\n"I know. But we do. 

We all do."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


But they were pretty slow\r\ncoming in this time."\r\n\r\nThe doctor looked up quizzically, "Is that the only reason you think you\r\nmight need a booster shot?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, no ... of course not!" 

The man leaned forward and placed one hand,\r\npalm up, on the desk. "Last year I had an accident ... stupid ... lost a\r\nthumb." He shrugged apologetically, "It took almost six months to grow\r\nback."\r\n\r\nThoughtfully, the doctor leaned back in his chair, "Hm-m-m ... I see."\r\nAs the man before him made an involuntary movement toward his pocket,\r\nthe doctor smiled, "Go on, smoke if you want to." Picking up the chart,\r\nhe murmured, "Six months ... much too long. Strange we didn\'t catch that\r\nat the time." 

He read silently for a few moments, then began to fill out\r\na form clipped to the folder. "Well, I think you probably are due for\r\nanother booster about now. There\'ll have to be the usual tests. 

Not that\r\nthere\'s much doubt ... we like to be certain."\r\n\r\nThe middle-aged man seemed relieved. Then, on second thought, he\r\nhesitated uneasily, "Why? Is there any danger?"\r\n\r\nAmusement flickered across the doctor\'s face, turned smoothly into a\r\nreassuring half-smile. "Oh, no. 

There\'s absolutely no danger involved.\r\nNone at all. We have tissue-regeneration pretty well under control now.\r\nStill, I\'m sure you understand that accurate records and data are very\r\nnecessary to further research and progress."\r\n\r\nReassured, the patient thawed and became confidential, "I see. Well, I\r\nsuppose it\'s kinda silly, but I don\'t much like shots. It\'s not that\r\nthey hurt ... it\'s just that I guess I\'m old-fashioned. I still feel\r\nkinda \'creepy\' about the whole business." Slightly embarrassed, he\r\npaused and asked defensively, "Is that unusual?"\r\n\r\nThe doctor smiled openly now, "Not at all, not at all. Things have moved\r\npretty fast in the past few years. I suppose it takes people\'s emotional\r\nreactions a while to catch up with developments that, logically, we\r\naccept as matter of fact."\r\n\r\nHe pushed his chair back from the desk, "Maybe it\'s not too hard to\r\nunderstand. Take \'fire\' for example: Man lived in fear of fire for a\r\ngood many hundred-thousand years--and rightly so, because he hadn\'t\r\nlearned to control it. The principle\'s the same; First you learn to\r\nprotect yourself from a thing; then control it; and, eventually, we\r\nlearn to \'harness\' it for a useful purpose." He gestured toward the\r\nman\'s cigarette, "Even so, man still instinctively fears fire--even\r\nwhile he uses it. In the case of tissue-regeneration, where the change\r\ntook place so rapidly, in just a generation or so, that instinctive fear\r\nis even more understandable--although quite as unjustified, I assure\r\nyou."\r\n\r\nThe doctor stood up, indicating that the session was ending. While his\r\npatient scrambled to his feet, hastily putting out his cigarette, the\r\nphysician came around the desk. He put his hand on the man\'s shoulder,\r\n"Relax, take it easy--nothing to worry about. This is a wonderful age we\r\nlive in. Barring a really major accident, there\'s no reason why you\r\nshouldn\'t live at least another seventy-five years. After all, that\'s a\r\nvery remarkable viral-complex we have doing your \'repair\' work."\r\n\r\nAs they walked to the door, the man shook his head, "Guess you\'re right,\r\nDoc. It\'s certainly done a good job so far, and I guess you specialists\r\nknow what you\'re doing, even if folks don\'t understand it.

"\r\n\r\nAt the door he paused and half turned to the doctor, "But say ...\r\nsomething I meant to ask you. This \'stuff\' ... er, this vaccine ...\r\nwhere did it come from? Seems to me I heard somewhere that, way back\r\nbefore you fellows got it \'tamed\' it was something else--dangerous.\r\nThere was another name for it. Do you know what I mean?

"\r\n\r\nThe doctor\'s hand tightened on the doorknob. "Yes, I know," he said\r\ngrimly, "but not many laymen remember. Just keep in mind what I told\r\nyou. 

With any of these things, the pattern is protection, then control,\r\nthen useful application." He turned to face his patient, "Back in the\r\ndays before we put it to work for us--rebuilding tissue, almost ending\r\naging and disease--the active basis for our vaccine caused a whole group\r\nof diseases, in itself."\r\n\r\nReturning the man\'s searching gaze, the doctor opened the door, "We\'ve\r\ncome a long way since then. You see," he said quietly, "in those days\r\nthey called it \'cancer\'."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Analog_ September 1962. Extensive\r\n    research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S. copyright on\r\n    this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and typographical\r\n    errors have been corrected without note. Original punctuation style\r\n    has been retained.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


]\r\n\r\n\r\n"I\'m only here to help you," said the man from Mars.\r\n\r\n"You\'ve proved that," the Secretary admitted. "In the six weeks that\r\nyou\'ve been here, you\'ve wiped out rabies, measles, and the common\r\ncold: but sir, this latest proposal of yours is blasphemous!"\r\n\r\nThe man from Mars waved an appendage in the direction of the\r\nSecretary\'s desk, atop which a newspaper was lying open. 

"After\r\nreading what that paper has to say can you still doubt that what I\r\npropose is necessary?"\r\n\r\nThe young man in uniform crossed the room and picked up the newspaper.\r\nHe read the headlines aloud, bitterly: "INDIAN FAMINE ARMY STORMS NEW\r\nDELHI"; "TASMAN REPUBLIC BIDS FOR PLACE IN SUN"; "PLAGUE DECIMATES\r\nLOWER NILE."\r\n\r\n"You could end that plague." The Assistant\'s voice was accusing.\r\n\r\n"I could, of course. The battles and the starvation would still be\r\nwith you, though. Why do you persist in treating the symptoms instead\r\nof the sickness? I am an objective observer, far enough away from your\r\nproblems to see them clearly, something which no human can ever hope\r\nto do. You Earthlings suffer war and famine and plague for one reason\r\nonly: that there are four and eight-tenths billion of you living on an\r\nEarth which can feed only about two and a half billion of you well.\r\nGentlemen, the population of your planet must be reduced by one-half if\r\nyour race is to survive."\r\n\r\n"Couldn\'t we send our surplus population to Mars, or to Venus?" the\r\nAssistant asked.\r\n\r\nThe man from Mars winced. "The sands of Mars can\'t support cactuses,\r\nmuch less fields of wheat and rice and corn. Venus is a solid sea of\r\nformaldehyde solution." He glanced around to each of the three men in\r\nthe room. 

"To you, my scheme may seem heartless. But would it be more\r\ncruel to kill millions now than to allow billions to die in continual\r\nwar in the next thousand years? Do you remember your last such war?\r\nThe Ukrainian wheatlands scorched to desert by the thermonuclears? New\r\nEngland swept by epidemics of anthrax and tularemia? All China tortured\r\nby starvation and the hundred nagging sicknesses that follow hunger?"\r\n\r\n"Yes, I remember." 

The Secretary rolled his pen between his fingers,\r\nstaring at it. "How do you intend to--liquidate--the excess two\r\nbillions?"\r\n\r\n"I can\'t explain it to you; you lack the basic knowledge. 

It will be\r\nquick and painless though, I promise. 

Then Earth will see peace and\r\nhope; a new start!"\r\n\r\n"I couldn\'t take all the responsibility for this decision upon myself,"\r\nthe Secretary said. He glanced hopefully toward the Assistant and the\r\nyoung man in uniform. Their eyes flinched away.\r\n\r\n"You might take a vote," suggested the man from Mars. He picked up the\r\nSecretary\'s scratch pad and ripped off three sheets of paper. "Just\r\nmark _Yes_ or _No_. 

I will respect your decision: after all, I\'m only\r\nhere to help you."\r\n\r\nThe Secretary stared at the slip of paper lying on his desk. He glanced\r\ntoward the other two humans for encouragement; but the Assistant was\r\nstaring at the wall across the room, and the young man in uniform was\r\nsilently contemplating the carpet at his feet.\r\n\r\nConvulsively the Secretary scooched the paper toward him and scribbled\r\nhis vote. Folding the paper, he looked demandingly toward his two\r\ncompanions. The young man in uniform looked up, then turned to hold his\r\npaper against the wall as he wrote his decision. The Assistant remained\r\nseated, holding the paper on top of a book while he lettered out his\r\nvote.\r\n\r\nThe man from Mars collected the three ballots, unfolded them, and read\r\nthe three votes. "It\'s two to one," he announced. He crushed the papers\r\ninto small, white pellets and tossed them out the open window. "What I\r\nhave to do will be finished by noon tomorrow."\r\n\r\nThe man from Mars left the room, closing the door very softly behind\r\nhim. The other three sat silent a moment and then got up and left\r\nwithout looking one another in the face.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe next day the Secretary and the Assistant sat in the office, staring\r\nat the clock above the door. At twelve-oh-seven the door slammed open\r\nfor the young man in uniform.\r\n\r\n"Is it done?" the Assistant asked.\r\n\r\n"Done? Of course, it\'s done!" The young man in uniform leaned against\r\nthe door and shook with spasmic laughter. "Now there\'s food enough\r\nand room enough for everyone. The man from Mars promised to solve our\r\npopulation problem. 

He did. At twelve noon, Eastern Daylight Saving\r\nTime, every woman and girl on Earth dropped dead."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n
