]\r\n\r\n\r\n10 years of uneasy peace, since the Hour of Tragedy ... ten\r\napprehensive, uneasy years pungent with fear, with hatred, distrust ...\r\nten years like ten thousand in the past of man ... ten units out of the\r\ninfinite, out of time the eternal, immutable, nonexistent dimension....\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n9 planets spinning ... nine spawn of the sun, one of them nascent, a\r\nhairsbreadth from its heritage. But which heritage? It could choose.\r\nThe fertile warmth of the parent star ... or the star's pure fire?\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n8 periods, in the gibberish of the sifters of chaos ... eight:\r\nPre-Cambrian to Triassic--while flame cooled and became stone and lay\r\nlatent, lambent, pent awaiting release--before from the fetid Jurassic\r\ndarknesses the beasts of warm blood crawled.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n7 seas, once the womb of life, then too long its caul ... the common\r\nbirthplace, then a strangling wall between. (Once too, briefly a\r\nhigh road for the courageous, now a new kind of night for marauders,\r\nshadowed shapes armed with pieces of the sun.

)\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n6 masses of land, cradles for the genesis of a myriad species ...\r\nand one of them Man. Man the Creator, the Protector, the Destroyer:\r\nbuilder of shrines, burner of saints, good father, good soldier, good\r\nkiller.... Man, the creature of choice.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n5 nations remaining, sparse ruddy fruit of a thousand wars, nurtured by\r\na billion dead. Five, the bloody consequence of union into pack, into\r\ntribe, into fief, to kingdom, empire and nation. 

The threads of history\r\ngathered finally into five flags, entwined in alliance at this point in\r\ntime by a searing wind: Pan-American, Sino-Russian, Afro-Arabian ...\r\nracial armies, sons of the first beast to kill from anger, fathers of\r\nthe unborn. Armies in the terrible truce of the fusion bomb ... waiting.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n4 farflung networks: metal wire and machines, and vacuum. Interlinked\r\nwebs of detection and retaliation or attack, within the webs bombs ...\r\nwithin the bombs targets, mapped and doomed by a spark. Each alliance\r\na network of aimed and armed missiles, in deserts, on mountaintops,\r\nhidden deep and in the surrounding seas. Each alliance a pattern of\r\ntargets, always an instant from obliteration.\r\n\r\n(Such had come to Britain in its Hour of Tragedy when the last savage\r\nhope of Empire Regained dissolved into vapor, and the Isles became\r\nslag. There the fourth network corroded under a shroud of ash; but the\r\nsurviving three ceaselessly hummed.)\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n3 men, of one species but riven somehow at this point in time by\r\npigment, tongue and details of dress: a man from Brownsville, a man\r\nfrom Vladivostok, a man from Khartoum ... buried deep in the hearts\r\nof the networks, each already entombed, and so safe from death. Each\r\nchosen by his masters to be the nock of the arrow, the final factor;\r\nyet not an arrow, for each network of course was aimed at both the\r\nothers. A moment's trust is fatal once the truce is broken, the masters\r\nreasoned, and so the bombs and the men were trained.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n2 buttons, a choice under the fingers of each of these men: one, red,\r\nto loose deliberately the double pronged torrent of bombs if the\r\nmasters so decreed. The other, white, to cancel the launching command\r\nbroadcast automatically if massive radiation spewed across the\r\nhomeland ... a vast, vicious death reflex. Each man, then, if the\r\ndetectors tolled, had the decision: error or attack. 

Fail or be unable\r\nto press the white instantly, and the counter-attack, if such it was,\r\nbegan. This, then, was the masters' last concession to the human\r\nfactor, their grudging one to humanity.\r\n\r\nAnd like most of the masters' concessions to the masses, it was false.\r\nIdentically, in each network, the white button was a dummy. The real\r\nchoice was as it always was--red button, kill ... or wait yet a while\r\nmore. The men in the tombs, unknowing, knew this was the choice.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n1 man's brain, whosoever, however carefully masters may mold it, is\r\na fragile thing. Ten thousand years have not fitted man to live with\r\nhimself; could a single man live with the lives of two billion? The\r\nchoice, distillate of a hundred centuries of pain, the weariness of a\r\nspecies with race: blame them, blame all. 

One of the men sitting in a\r\ncold tomb sweated. His finger hovered over the red button, trembled ...\r\nand fell.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


The youngster was frightened.\r\n\r\n"Dark, very dark, and big. It moves fast, but we\'ll keep up with it."\r\nThe tone was consciously reassuring.\r\n\r\n"Dark, Grandpa?"\r\n\r\n"Yes, it sucks heat and absorbs light. You\'ll find out when you\'re old\r\nand strong enough to swim down to the bottom and see what\'s there. 

Now\r\nstay with me when we follow it, and don\'t get lost in the crowd; and\r\ndon\'t get ahead of me or get too close to it--you might take in too\r\nmuch, and get overcharged."\r\n\r\n"What\'s \'overcharged,\' Grandpa? Can you really get too much?" The\r\nyoungster jigged up and down a little with excitement and\r\nanticipation.\r\n\r\nFor a moment, the oldster turned his attention from watching for the\r\nthing that was coming, and considered him fondly. "Poor youngling. 

I\r\nforget. You\'ve had no chance to learn what it means to get enough.\r\nYou\'re too young to ride the storms and tap the lightnings.... Listen\r\nnow. When a grownup has to let out a flash of blue light, that means\r\nthat he\'s overcharged and spinning off balance inside, and so he has\r\nto save himself by letting out his energy to let down the pressure. So\r\nbe careful; take enough, but don\'t be greedy and take in too much too\r\nsuddenly. 

Now let\'s just float here with the others and be ready.

"\r\n\r\nIt was a beautiful bright day. The sun poured down its flood of light,\r\nhere and there energizing a molecule of the blue air into little\r\nsparkles of ionization; and below, a mist of bright clouds half veiled\r\nthe darkness that was the bottom.\r\n\r\n"What\'s it mean when someone blinks blue light in lots of flashes, and\r\nthen glows red and starts sinking, huh, Grandpa?"\r\n\r\n"I\'ll tell you later when you\'re older. 

Just be careful and don\'t get\r\ntoo close." He was abruptly excited. 

"Here it comes!"\r\n\r\nOut of the blue translucence far below, a black dot appeared and grew\r\nrapidly, rushing closer until it was a huge fish-shaped object with\r\nwidespread fins, rushing towards them. It would pass slightly to the\r\nleft of them, and already the waiting crowd was moving to intercept\r\nit.\r\n\r\nIt flashed by, and the youngster thought they were going to lose\r\nit--it was going so much faster than they; but as the thought crossed\r\nhis mind, and he saw the two churning glowing openings in its rear, a\r\nburning blast of energy struck him. A multitude of glowing, charged\r\nparticles crackled around him, streamed against him. His fields\r\nshifted to reach out and capture them; the spin of stored energy\r\nwithin spun faster, absorbing the new energy into its drive, its\r\nlife-pulse rising to a deep hum, and he felt strong, stronger than he\r\nhad ever felt before in his life.\r\n\r\nThey were flying faster now, accelerating faster than he had ever\r\nflown, and it was easy. They drew up closer to the dark thing,\r\nmatching it speed for speed, laving in the glowing cloud of\r\nenergy-particles that roared backward from its jets. The youngster was\r\nastounded and exhilarated at the tremendous, effortless speed with\r\nwhich they were driving forward. This was the first time he had ever\r\nhad so much power. It was ten times more than any aurora borealis with\r\nits pale wash of energy waves.\r\n\r\nDrunken in his new found strength, he pulled ahead closer to the\r\nroaring jets.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAt the peak of the arc of climb of the New York-Istanbul stratoliner,\r\nhigh in the ionosphere where the Earth was merely a giant globe far\r\nbelow, the pilot of the stratoliner boredly cut the jets for the\r\nfuel-saving glide that turned their nose toward Earth again.\r\n\r\nThe radar was clanging its usual senseless warning of imminent\r\ncollision with some solid objects, which had approached closer than\r\nthe automatic relays considered safe. It had been clanging for several\r\nminutes. The pilot glanced in annoyance at the radar screen, where\r\nseveral hundred globes--from two to seven feet in diameter--showed\r\nvividly, trailing the ship in a fan-shaped cluster. "Some day I\'m\r\ngoing to take a hammer to that thing."\r\n\r\nThe co-pilot, looking back from the control blister\'s rear window, saw\r\nnothing, as usual, except a few of the shining globes, which showed\r\nthemselves transiently in a brief flash of blue light as they\r\ncarelessly overloaded and discharged--and one, smaller than the rest,\r\nwho blinked on and off rapidly in brilliant flashes of blue. As he\r\nwatched, it ran suddenly down the color-scale to red and began to lag\r\nbehind, a glowing red globe, sinking.\r\n\r\n"I wonder what the hell they think they\'re doing?" he grumbled.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nThe first terrestrial expedition to Mars didn\'t find any Martians.\r\nNeither did the second. Since there are so few Martians left, those\r\nfacts are less surprising than that the third did.\r\n\r\nFor many years before space flight was accomplished, there had been\r\ndiscussions and theories about how to communicate with Martians, if any\r\nexisted. But, of course, nobody was ready when the time came.\r\n\r\nThey fell back on that antiquated gimmick.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nVon Frisch, Riley and Smith watched the half dozen Martians approach,\r\nand their watching was not without some trepidation. Except that they\r\nwere about twenty miles away from their G-boat--the planetary landing\r\ncraft--they probably would have fled. Except that they had their\r\norders, they probably would have shot first and asked questions later.\r\n\r\n"Sir, this is Von Frisch," said the engineer into the microphone of his\r\nhelmet. He was a little breathless about it. 

"We\'re being approached by\r\nMartians!"\r\n\r\n"How do they act?" asked Captains Powers back at the G-boat,\r\nimmediately.\r\n\r\n"They don\'t act hostile, sir."\r\n\r\n"Stand by, then, but don\'t take any chances. 

What do they look like?"\r\n\r\n"They\'re quite a bit taller than we are, but their bodies are round\r\nand not much bigger than a child\'s. They\'ve got real long legs and\r\narms, and big heads with big eyes and ears."\r\n\r\n"Are they intelligent? Are they civilized? How do they breathe?"\r\n\r\n"Wait a minute, Captain," protested Von Frisch. "You\'re going a little\r\ntoo fast, sir. 

They\'ve just come up to us. I don\'t know whether that\'s\r\nfur on them or whether they\'re wearing clothes.

"\r\n\r\n"Well, try to communicate with them, man!" 

exclaimed Powers excitedly.\r\n\r\nVon Frisch did his best. The Martians appeared friendly enough, and\r\ninterested. Von Frisch tried to communicate in the only method he had\r\nheard about.\r\n\r\nWhile his companions watched curiously, he shut his ears to the running\r\nfire of questions from Powers, squatted and drew a right angled\r\ntriangle in the red desert sand. By one of the sides he drew three\r\nmarks, by another four.\r\n\r\nThen he stepped back and looked questioningly at the Martians.\r\n\r\nOne of the Martians squatted in a tangle of pipestem arms and legs, and\r\nwith a long finger drew five lines beside the triangle\'s hypotenuse.\r\n\r\n"They understand the Pythagorean theorem, sir!" exclaimed Von Frisch.\r\n\r\n"Good! They undoubtedly know some astronomy, then. Go on."\r\n\r\nVon Frisch hesitated a moment, then erased the triangle. He drew a\r\nsmall circle with rays from it, for the sun. He drew four larger\r\nconcentric circles around it, with small circles for planets on the\r\nrim of each one.\r\n\r\nHe pointed to the third planet, then at himself, then at his\r\ncompanions, one by one. Then he pointed at the fourth planet and at the\r\nMartians, one by one. To complete the matter, he pointed at the sky.\r\n\r\n"We are Earthmen," he said. "You are Martians."\r\n\r\nThe trouble was that the Earthmen didn\'t realize the things the\r\nMartians had were weapons until they used them. They didn\'t realize it\r\nthen, as a matter of fact, because the Earthmen were dead, all three of\r\nthem.\r\n\r\n_The Martian hunting party came back from the desert with word of the\r\nstrange creatures who came, apparently, from another world._\r\n\r\n_"Whether they have weapons, we do not know," said the leader of the\r\nhunting party. "But they wished to harm our people, so we killed them\r\nall.

"_\r\n\r\n_"That is desperate action," said the patriarch of the village. "In\r\nwhat way were they dangerous to us?"_\r\n\r\n_"Foolishly they disclosed their intention to us," replied the leader\r\nof the hunting party. "They informed us they planned to take over our\r\nworld and to drive our people farther from the sun, to the great planet\r\nJupiter."_\r\n\r\n_"Then you did right," said the patriarch, blinking his big eyes._\r\n\r\nBiggs and Golden were working near the G-boat. Their helmet radios were\r\nset to a different channel from that used by the exploring party, so\r\nthey were unable to hear Captain Powers shouting frantically into his\r\nmicrophone and getting no answer. It was just after sunset, and Biggs\r\nwas looking into the west.\r\n\r\n"We ought to see it now, but it ain\'t there," commented Biggs.\r\n\r\n"What ain\'t there?" demanded Golden.\r\n\r\n"Mercury," said Biggs, who prided himself on being an amateur\r\nastronomer. "I reckon you can\'t see it from Mars without a telescope.\r\nToo close to the sun."\r\n\r\nHe chuckled.\r\n\r\n"If there are any Martians," he added, "I reckon they think _they_ live\r\non the third planet. That\'s funny, ain\'t it?"\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nThere were usually a few Customs Inspectors in the lounge, waiting\r\nto begin their shifts, hanging around trading news and incidents and\r\ndrinking the bad, lukewarm kasser that was a standing joke in the\r\nImmigration-Customs Service.\r\n\r\nOld Grag was telling for perhaps the eightieth time of a success of his\r\nwhen he was young in the Service.\r\n\r\n"... They had this small box of sticky, squashy sweets with them. The\r\nyoung one was eating one. 

Many another Inspector would have passed them\r\nthrough, but I thought the young one chewed too much and too loud. So I\r\nsaid, \'Mind if I have one?\'\r\n\r\n"\'Wah!\' says they together, \'it would set you on edge, Noble Wise\r\nInspector. It is the taste of another world.\' They was Venusers, and\r\nthey started shifting and hopping around, and humming their national\r\nanthem, _you_ know how they used to do back in the old days. I made\r\nquite a nice little find. Almost a half-scree of chamfer in each one\r\nof those sweets. I got a promotion out of that, and the Venusers got a\r\nsix-year close out."\r\n\r\nInspector Flimp blew one of his noses loudly.\r\n\r\n"Hee, that\'s nothing. _I_ recall back when we first opened up for\r\nImmigration, and a whole shipload of earthers came in. They were\r\ncrammed in like tigs in a nest, and as usual they didn\'t know one word\r\nof the language, they didn\'t have any idea of where to go or how to do\r\nanything, and they\'d got separated from their controller. 

They just\r\nstood around, huddled together and jabbering at each other. 

Well, I\r\nchecked out about twenty of them, and then there comes up this big ugly\r\nfemale. Well, I jacks the elevator up some more, and I looks down at\r\nher.\r\n\r\n"\'Name!\', I call. \'Gladdis Cracklegill,\' or some other weird earth name\r\nshe screams at me. \'Too much name,\' I say. \'You\'ve got enough name\r\nthere for five of you. Which will you choose, Glad, Is, Crack, El or\r\nGil?\'\r\n\r\n"Well, it took me a while to make her understand me--my earth accent\r\nwasn\'t too good then, and she was slow-headed, having only one, like\r\nall earthers. But I finally made her understand what I wanted to know,\r\nand then, by Clag, what a ramping frowst she did make!\r\n\r\n"It was while she was screeching at me that I noticed her teeth were\r\npretty big, even for such a huge beast as she was. So I secretly turned\r\non the Dento-Spyer, right into her jaws, and what a sight on the view\r\nscreen! Each of those big teeth was false and filled to the top with\r\nEarth seeds she was trying to smuggle!"\r\n\r\n"Earthers!" exploded young Nask. 

"They make me sick!"\r\n\r\n"I\'m with you, Nask," said Inspector Sprim. "And I don\'t understand why\r\nthey _still_ keep routing earthers through Immigration anyway. They\r\nclaim they\'re a borderline case, but when you\'ve seen as many as I\r\nhave, you know, which side of the border they\'re on."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nNask went off to the kasser dispenser and his place was taken by Brif,\r\nthe head Inspector, who had been listening.\r\n\r\n"Un-edge yourself, Sprim," smiled Brif, contracting one of his heads.\r\n"I have good news, rare news and fine news. The Four Council decision\r\njust came down to us. Earthers are now to be routed through Livestock\r\ninstead of Immigration beginning very soon."\r\n\r\nA cheer went up from the little group of Customs and Immigration\r\nofficials. The one Livestock Inspector in the lounge groaned in despair.\r\n\r\nOld Inspector Flimp seemed bothered.\r\n\r\n"They\'ve made themselves a mistake," he sputtered. "Earthers can be\r\nclever and tricky even after they\'re altered. Why, I seen them pull\r\nevery trick in the book coming through here. 

Did I ever tell you about\r\nthe stunted one with an artificial head who tried to pass himself off\r\nas a rest-park planner? Well, it seems that...."\r\n\r\nTwo young, but large inspectors sneaked away from the group when they\r\nsaw old Flimp was launched into one of his dull yarns again.\r\n\r\nOutside the lounge, after a quick look up and down the hall, they\r\nducked into the robot-cleaner storage closet.\r\n\r\n"Boy," gasped the shorter inspector. "I _had_ to get out of there.\r\nBesides the torture of listening to that two-headed monster babble on\r\nand on about how he outwitted earthers when he was still able to move\r\naround, this miserable thing has started to come loose again."\r\n\r\nHe gave an impatient wrench to his left head, and it wobbled enough to\r\nexpose some of the delicate wires that the earth robotic engineer had\r\nlabored over so many hours.\r\n\r\nThe other began tightening straps and buckles for him.\r\n\r\n"There," he said finally. "You look like one of the boys again."\r\n\r\nLaughing together, the earthers went back into the Customs Lounge.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


He would not\r\nremember the dark spaceways or the red slag of Martian drylands or the\r\npearl-gray days on Venus when he had dreamed of the Earth that had\r\noutlawed him. So he lay, with his eyes closed and the sunlight drenching\r\nhim through, no sound in his ears but the passage of a breeze through\r\nthe grass and a creaking of some insect nearby--the violent,\r\nblood-smelling years behind him might never have been. Except for the\r\ngun pressed into his ribs between his chest and the clovered earth, he\r\nmight be a boy again, years upon years ago, long before he had broken\r\nhis first law or killed his first man.\r\n\r\nNo one else alive now knew who that boy had been. Not even the all\r\nknowing Patrol. Not even Venusian Yarol, who had been his closest friend\r\nfor so many riotous years. 

No one would ever know--now. Not his name\r\n(which had not always been Smith) or his native land or the home that\r\nhad bred him, or the first violent deed that had sent him down the\r\ndevious paths which led here--here to the clover hollow in the hills of\r\nan Earth that had forbidden him ever to set foot again upon her soil.\r\n\r\nHe unclasped the hands behind his head and rolled over to lay a scarred\r\ncheek on his arm, smiling to himself. Well, here was Earth beneath him.\r\nNo longer a green star high in alien skies, but warm soil, new clover so\r\nnear his face he could see all the little stems and trefoil leaves,\r\nmoist earth granular at their roots. An ant ran by with waving antennae\r\nclose beside his cheek. He closed his eyes and drew another deep breath.\r\nBetter not even look; better to lie here like an animal, absorbing the\r\nsun and the feel of Earth blindly, wordlessly.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nNow he was not Northwest Smith, scarred outlaw of the spaceways. Now he\r\nwas a boy again with all his life before him. 

There would be a\r\nwhite-columned house just over the hill, with shaded porches and white\r\ncurtains blowing in the breeze and the sound of sweet, familiar voices\r\nindoors. There would be a girl with hair like poured honey hesitating\r\njust inside the door, lifting her eyes to him. Tears in the eyes. He lay\r\nvery still, remembering.\r\n\r\nCurious how vividly it all came back, though the house had been ashes\r\nfor nearly twenty years, and the girl--the girl ...\r\n\r\nHe rolled over violently, opening his eyes. No use remembering her.\r\nThere had been that fatal flaw in him from the very first, he knew now.\r\nIf he were the boy again knowing all he knew today, still the flaw would\r\nbe there and sooner or later the same thing must have happened that had\r\nhappened twenty years ago. He had been born for a wilder age, when men\r\ntook what they wanted and held what they could without respect for law.\r\nObedience was not in him, and so--\r\n\r\nAs vividly as on that day it happened he felt the same old surge of\r\nanger and despair twenty years old now, felt the ray-gun bucking hard\r\nagainst his unaccustomed fist, heard the hiss of its deadly charge\r\nravening into a face he hated. He could not be sorry, even now, for that\r\nfirst man he had killed. But in the smoke of that killing had gone up\r\nthe columned house and the future he might have had, the boy\r\nhimself--lost as Atlantis now--and the girl with the honey-colored hair\r\nand much, much else besides. It had to happen, he knew. 

He being the boy\r\nhe was, it had to happen. 

Even if he could go back and start all over,\r\nthe tale would be the same.\r\n\r\nAnd it was all long past now, anyhow; and nobody remembered any more at\r\nall, except himself. A man would be a fool to lie here thinking about it\r\nany longer.\r\n\r\nSmith grunted and sat up, shrugging the gun into place against his ribs.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber's Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Fantastic Universe_ January 1957.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Angstrom was known to his students and many of his colleagues on\r\nthe faculty as "The Old Goat." Very appropriate, that name. 

He had the\r\ndisposition of a goat with dyspepsia, he had the cold blue eyes of a\r\ngoat, he had the waggling whiskers of a goat. Perhaps it\'s in memory of\r\nDr. Angstrom that Ivy College has a goat for its mascot now.\r\n\r\nDr. Angstrom was even more goatish than usual that day last summer when\r\nhalf a dozen top scientists in the field gathered to see his preview\r\nexperiment on matter transmission of a live animal. He had been working\r\nhard for weeks on the transmitter and keeping up classes at the same\r\ntime, which did not improve his disposition. Besides, he had a real\r\ngoat for an experimental animal, and goats are notoriously hard on the\r\nnervous system.\r\n\r\nThis particular animal, at the moment the scientists entered, was\r\nstraining at his rope, trying to get a mouthful of a tablecloth which\r\ngraced a nearby table full of jars and retorts. Failing this, the goat\r\nexhibited that typical lack of discrimination in matters edible and\r\nbegan to chew on his rope.\r\n\r\nI felt a little out of place among all these giant brains. My reason\r\nfor being there was that I had been serving, during my college career,\r\nas sort of a factotum and fetch-and-carry man for Dr. Angstrom, and\r\nI was to take notes for him. I had acquired considerable affection\r\nfor The Old Goat. Maybe that\'s one reason I hate to see his great\r\nscientific work kept under wraps because people still insist it\'s\r\ndangerous.\r\n\r\n"I have proved to my own satisfaction that the matter transmitter\r\nworks," Dr. Angstrom told the assembled scientists. "I have made a\r\nnumber of transmissions of inanimate matter. In theory, it should work\r\njust as well for animate objects and I have invited you to be present\r\nat the first test of this theory.\r\n\r\n"I need not go into detail with you about the basic theory of matter\r\ntransmission. The transmitter itself picks up the atomic and\r\nelectronic \'image\' of the object inside it, much as a television\r\nscanner picks up a scene, except that it is done in three dimensions\r\ninstead of two. This is made possible by the four-dimensional element\r\nwhich is the heart of the apparatus and was made available to us\r\nthrough recent intra-atomic research.\r\n\r\n"The receiver picks up the image as a television receiver does, except\r\nagain in three dimensions. The matter is not duplicated because the\r\ntransmitter strips down the object within it as it transmits.\r\n\r\n"Now the question that has been raised by some scientists about the\r\ntransmission of animate objects is whether the \'soul\' or \'life force\'\r\ncan be transmitted. I consider this question ridiculous, and will prove\r\nit so. It is my contention that such \'life force\' is not a thing apart\r\nfrom the physical shell."\r\n\r\nThe matter transmitter was a large closed cylinder on one side of the\r\nroom. 

The receiver was a similar cylinder on the other. Both were\r\nraised slightly from the floor.\r\n\r\nAs sort of _hors d\'oeuvre_, Dr. Angstrom transmitted a large chunk of\r\nlead across the room, then a glass jar. In each case, the object was\r\nplaced in the transmitter and a moment later removed from the receiver\r\nacross the room. There was no possible way for it to have been moved\r\nacross the intervening space except by broadcast transmission.\r\n\r\n"As you see," said Dr. Angstrom, "I have eliminated the necessity for\r\na switch by building the switch into the door of the transmitter. As\r\nsoon as the door is closed, transmission occurs. 

Now we shall send our\r\nanimate object."\r\n\r\nHe untied the goat and, with some difficulty, hauled the animal by its\r\ncollar to the transmitter. There the goat balked and Dr. Angstrom,\r\nhaving got its head through the door, got behind it and shoved\r\nheartily, hanging onto the edge of the door so he could shut it quickly\r\nwhen the goat was inside.\r\n\r\nAs goats will, the goat suddenly changed its mind and leaped into the\r\ntransmitter. Caught off balance, Dr. Angstrom fell in after it--and the\r\ndoor, given a last frantic jerk, slammed on them both.\r\n\r\nThere were gasps of horror and alarm from the scientists, but I held\r\nup my hand to calm them.\r\n\r\n"There\'s no danger, gentlemen," I said. "It\'s just as well this way. 

I\r\nhappen to know that Dr. Angstrom\'s next step, after proving to you with\r\nthe goat that animate objects could be transmitted, was to prove that\r\nhuman beings also could be transmitted. He planned to be his own first\r\nsubject."\r\n\r\nWith serene confidence, I went to the receiver and threw open the door.\r\nJust as I had anticipated, the goat leaped out, unharmed, followed by\r\nDr. Angstrom.\r\n\r\n"I told you animate objects could be transmitted successfully," said\r\nthe goat triumphantly.\r\n\r\n"Baa!" 

said Dr. Angstrom, and began eating the tablecloth.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n

They had reached Venus and Mars and were now\r\nplanning a trip to Jupiter. And this very day, a huge statue of Jacob\r\nClark, the creator and benefactor, was to be dedicated on the site of\r\nwhat once had been his laboratory. It seemed a shame that most of the\r\nrecords concerning him and his time had been lost in one of the great\r\nwars that had helped to extinguish the humans. The statue though was\r\ngood for surely he looked like a robot. One of the few human books still\r\nin existence said that the Creator had created in his own image.\r\n\r\nIt was right at the foot of his own statue that the Guardians of the\r\nShrine found Jacob Clark. They picked up his unconscious, bleeding body\r\nand laid it tenderly on a nearby bench. They bent over him with all the\r\ngentleness and solicitude that had been installed in his very first\r\nmodels and had been handed down from generation to generation of robots.\r\nThey wanted to help him but they were very puzzled.\r\n\r\n"Perhaps it came from a far part of the earth," one of them said.\r\n\r\n"Or maybe a mistake was made at one of the birth factories," said\r\nanother. "See, it is losing oil at a great rate."\r\n\r\n"Perhaps," mused the elder, "it is a new model. At any rate it is a\r\nrobot and has been damaged. 

As our great creator taught us, he must be\r\naided. We will take it to the central repair factory in the city."\r\n\r\n"But," the first robot protested, "it\'s awfully bulky to be carried so\r\nfar."\r\n\r\nBeing creatures of logic, they thought about it for a moment and then\r\nthe elder came to a decision that was both effective and reasonable.\r\n\r\n"Since he is so bulky, we will disassemble him for transportation\r\npurposes," he said as he leaned over and gently twisted off Clark\'s\r\nright arm.\r\n\r\n"Rather primitive and messy construction, I\'d say," said the second\r\nrobot as he tenderly unscrewed Jacob Clark\'s head from his body.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Fantastic Universe_ August 1958.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. There were no eyes visible but\r\nHenderson had the chilly feeling that the flower was surveying the room.\r\nThen, after a moment, the plant jumped to the sill of the window, from\r\nthere to the seat of a chair. ]\r\n\r\n\r\nIt took me less than three thousand years to catch up with Pop; which,\r\nall things considered, was pretty good going. I came out of overdrive\r\nat 018970 hours in orbit around an ugly-looking A3-type planet, and\r\nthere was his ship below me.\r\n\r\nI slammed my cruiser down right alongside--hard enough to pulverize a\r\ncouple of feet of basalt and make Pop and his ship bounce a little.\r\nHe\'d put me to quite a bit of trouble and I was annoyed.\r\n\r\nPop got to his feet and stood there looking kind of sheepish as I\r\nclimbed out of the cruiser. The old fool had his helmet off and was\r\nbreathing in the foul atmosphere as if it were health gas. His gills\r\nhad begun to turn a little blue from the methane and CO2. He was a\r\ncharacter all right.\r\n\r\nHis name wasn\'t really Pop, of course. I guess the nickname had been\r\ntacked on because he was such an eccentric, old codger, and because\r\nhe looked like a couple of billion years old. Actually, of course, he\r\nwasn\'t nearly that old.\r\n\r\n"Welcome aboard planet," he said. "I kind of figured you\'d be along\r\nsooner or later. Or someone like you."\r\n\r\n"Well, I\'m here," I said. He looked harmless, but I kept a 201R\r\nprojector on him just in case. Pop had given Security Division a lot of\r\ntrouble, and I had strict orders.\r\n\r\nI crawled over to his ship and slid inside. The cabin looked neat\r\nenough, but the old fool had so much junk crammed into the ship you\r\ncould hardly turn around. I found what I was looking for toward the\r\nbow--row after row of cylindrical canisters. I broke one open and the\r\nbio-detector on my back began to stutter like crazy. I dropped it and\r\nsprayed them all until they glowed dull green. By then the contents\r\nwere cooked.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nPop was still standing in the same place when I crawled out, looking as\r\ncasual as you please. He only had a few eyes on me. Most of them he had\r\nturned toward the planet\'s oversize satellite and a raw, angry-looking\r\nsea that was breaking a few ship\'s-lengths away.\r\n\r\n"How\'d you catch up with me?" he asked.\r\n\r\n"Space warp. You left a trail a child could follow." I moved around\r\nhis ship and found the reason he was looking so innocent. He\'d already\r\nset up one of his canisters and the seal was about to break. I sprayed\r\nit. So much for several billion one-celled forms of life bottled under\r\npressure.\r\n\r\n"All right," I said. "That\'s the last of them. Let\'s get going."\r\n\r\n"Okay," said Pop. "Never argue with Security Division. Still, you\'ve\r\ngot to admit I gave you a good run for your money. And I seeded quite\r\na mess of planets."\r\n\r\nI shouldn\'t have done it, but I was angry. I snapped a claw across his\r\nnerve center before he could draw it back into his shell. It must have\r\nhurt plenty, because ten or twelve of his eyes began to water.\r\n\r\n"Seeded, hell!" I said. "You touched down on exactly 9080 planets, and\r\nI sterilized every one of them after you left. That\'s what took me so\r\nlong."\r\n\r\nHe seemed to shrink a little inside, and for the first time I realized\r\njust how old the nut really was.\r\n\r\n"All that time," he said. "All that effort wasted. 

Damn. 

Double damn.

"\r\n\r\n"You should have figured that in the first place," I said. "Central\r\nMaxim 0438 clearly states that no life is to be introduced into the\r\nouter galaxies. And don\'t ask me why. 

I\'m no biologist. I just follow\r\norders."\r\n\r\n"Listen," said Pop. 

"_Please_ listen. Back at Central Galaxy they think\r\nwe--our race--is pretty much immortal. But they don\'t _know_. They\r\ndon\'t know for sure if _any_ life will be left in our galaxy after two\r\nor three hundred wars like the last one and--"\r\n\r\n"Hold it," I said. "You\'re wasting your time. 

I\'m not a philosopher and\r\nyou know it."\r\n\r\n"That\'s right," said Pop. "And you\'re not a biologist, either. You\r\ntold me." He waved a claw in gesture of resignation number seven.\r\n"Well, maybe you\'re right. Maybe I have been an old fool. 

Let\'s go\r\nhome. No use hanging around an ugly planet like this one." He made\r\ngesture of contempt number fifteen.\r\n\r\nWell, I thought, that\'s a relief. "I don\'t get it," I said. "Just a while ago you\r\nagreed that was an ugly hunk of rock. You even made contempt gesture\r\nfifteen--you spat on it."\r\n\r\n"That\'s right," said Pop. "I did, didn\'t I? Right into a pool of\r\nbrackish water." 

Then he began to chuckle. He kept on chuckling for\r\nfive years, until I got annoyed and slapped his nerve center again.\r\n\r\nAside from that, the return voyage was uneventful.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nThe rocket waited, a gleaming yellow-finned tube, pointing its nose at\r\nthe depths of space. Time ticked in the control tower which rested in\r\nthe shadow of the great monster. Six minutes left. Sunlight danced on\r\nsilver curves.\r\n\r\nTick, tick, tick, tick. The time was in Charters\' brain like the sound\r\nof a pendulum in a grandfather\'s clock. The end was nearing.\r\n\r\nIt was almost over.\r\n\r\nCharters turned his thick wrist and looked at his watch.\r\n\r\nOutside the sun was a strong white fire in a blue sky. Sand stretched\r\naway endlessly from the circular cluster of buildings, from which the\r\nrocket had been conceived and nurtured and born.\r\n\r\nSeconds crept, and there was a dead silence in the tower room.\r\n\r\n"We\'ve done it," Charters said, his voice like a snapping of brittle\r\nwires.\r\n\r\nLampson, his assistant, nodded and watched the rocket. "Yes," he said.\r\n\r\n"Greatest victory of the age!" said Charters, grinning and gaily wiping\r\nhis hands together.\r\n\r\nLampson watched the way the sun struck the glistening silver body of\r\nthe rocket.\r\n\r\n"Have you nothing to say, man?" Charters asked.\r\n\r\n"I was just thinking."\r\n\r\n"This is no time to think," Charters said, his eyes bright and winking.\r\n"This is a time to let your thoughts drain out of your head. To feel\r\nthe damned meaning of this thing! 

To let it get inside you and fill you\r\nup to the brains! This is the time to laugh and cry, Lampson. To let\r\nyour insides quiver with the pure joy of it! We\'ve done it!"\r\n\r\n"Yes," Lampson said. "Only I was thinking about Randall, sitting out\r\nthere, waiting."\r\n\r\n"He\'ll be all right."\r\n\r\n"I know he will. I don\'t mean that. I mean, the way he feels about\r\nthings, yet sitting there, waiting to guide it to the Moon, to prove\r\nits reality. And all the time, he--"\r\n\r\n"He\'s caught in a stream, Lampson. A swift, driving stream that won\'t\r\nlet him stop. He can\'t help himself."\r\n\r\nLampson shook his head. "I can\'t believe he\'s really going through with\r\nit."\r\n\r\n"He\'s different now," Charters said. "A few months ago, he had all\r\nthese ideas about the rocket being used for military reasons, for\r\nkilling, and all that other nonsense. Now he\'s caught in the grip\r\nof this thing. He\'s watched his own work blossom and turn into a\r\nremarkably beautiful finished miracle."\r\n\r\nCharters watched the rocket, eyes half-closed, seeming to feel the\r\nstrength of it in his own hands as he closed them slowly, tightly.\r\n\r\n"Ah--" he said, lips curling. "The beautiful, beautiful thing!"\r\n\r\nLampson watched through the thick window, unblinking. 

"He was right,\r\nyou know."\r\n\r\n"Who was right?"\r\n\r\n"Randall. He was right about this rocket. We won\'t use it for anything\r\nbut just another weapon. 

All this work and planning. All Randall\'s\r\nsweat and blood. For no reason, but just another weapon."\r\n\r\n"It\'s too late now."\r\n\r\n"Yes. And you knew it, didn\'t you?" Lampson said to Charters, looking\r\nat the man. "You knew what this would mean. 

When Randall wanted to\r\nquit, and you finally got him to go ahead, you knew what we\'d use it\r\nfor."\r\n\r\n"You don\'t quit after ten years." Charters looked at his watch,\r\ncounting silently.\r\n\r\n"He\'s been sold out," Lampson said, thinking of Randall, sitting in the\r\nrocket. "A lifetime of worry and work and prayer. Now he\'s been sold\r\nout."\r\n\r\n"Damn it, man," Charters said, "it\'s nearly ready to happen!"\r\n\r\nThe room was silent, and the ticking was in the air again. A steady,\r\nrhythmic ticking, that got into the brain and beat time with the heart.\r\n\r\nOne minute.\r\n\r\nThe rocket rested on its launch, as though tightening its metallic\r\nmuscles and cords, to spring into the air like a wild frenzied terror,\r\nto cut through the sky, through space, to touch the Moon.\r\n\r\n"Thirty seconds," Charters said, his voice trembling.\r\n\r\nLampson closed his hands and his eyes.\r\n\r\n"Twenty seconds." Charters bent his head over his watch. 

His breathing\r\nshortened and he waited, tensed, crouched. 

"Ten. Five, four, three,\r\ntwo..."\r\n\r\nThe ground shook as though a chasm had split beneath its surface! There\r\nwas a streaking in the air. The rocket sped away and away.\r\n\r\n"Over!" said Charters, his face to the sky. "It\'s over!"\r\n\r\nLampson turned from the window and stood quietly, watching the floor.\r\nHis shoulders were limp, his hands still and quiet at his sides.\r\n\r\n"By God!" said Charters, whirling, slapping his palms together. "What\r\nan entirely immense thing!" He grinned widely and moved his feet as\r\nthough he were dancing.\r\n\r\n"Randall," said Lampson, his voice a lost, dead sound.\r\n\r\n"Randall, Randall," Charters mimicked. He moved about quickly, this\r\nway and that, waving his hands, grinning. "This is much greater than\r\nRandall!"\r\n\r\nLampson was silent while Charters cracked his hands together. "The\r\nMoon," Charters breathed. "The Moon!"\r\n\r\nThere was a loud shuffling outside the door then, and suddenly the door\r\nswung open and a wide-eyed man in the white coveralls stood, staring at\r\nCharters.\r\n\r\n"What\'s the matter?" said Charters, freezing.\r\n\r\n"I can\'t believe it," said the man. "I really can\'t believe it!"\r\n\r\n"What, man?" said Charters, moving toward the door.\r\n\r\n"Mr. Randall. He just climbed out of the rocket and walked away. Six\r\nseconds before it went up."\r\n\r\nCharters stopped, staring with wild eyes. His face colored. Rage choked\r\nhis voice.\r\n\r\n"WHY?" barked the man.\r\n\r\nLampson stood at the window, his eyes lighting. 

He smiled, then\r\nlaughed. And far away, a gleaming yellow-finned rocket drove up, up,\r\nfinding the path through space that would carry it, alone, past the\r\nMoon, to the Sun.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


But like the airy creature she was, Laloi ignored the\r\ncriticism and rippled zephyr-like through a clump of daffodils when they\r\ncompleted their descent.\r\n\r\n"So pretty," she sighed. She flung her incorporeal substance around each\r\nflower, absorbing their unified beauty of scent, sight, and feel. Buos\r\nshrilled himself into a column of wind to express his displeasure at her\r\nattitude.\r\n\r\n"Stupid, silly, shallow thing!" he said. "If the others only knew how\r\nyou behaved--"\r\n\r\n"And you\'ll be glad to tell them, of course," she said, extending her\r\nfingers of air into the roots of the wind-bent grass. She rolled across\r\nthe hill ecstatically, and Buos followed in grumbling billows of energy.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t carry tales," he replied, somewhat mortified. "But we\'re here\r\nas observers, and you insist upon making this world a plaything ..."\r\n\r\n"I love it," she said happily. "It\'s so warm and green."\r\n\r\nBuos whipped in front of her angrily. "This is an assignment," he\r\nsnapped, his emotion crackling the air about him. "We have a purpose\r\nhere."\r\n\r\n"Purpose!" she groaned, settling over a patch of crowded clover. "How\r\nmany centuries will this assignment last?"\r\n\r\n"This world is young," said Buos. "It will take time.

"\r\n\r\n"But how long?" she asked mournfully. "Our world will be shrivelled and\r\ndead before these people have the knowledge to rescue us. Why can\'t we\r\nspend our lives here ..."\r\n\r\n"And leave the others behind?" said Buos stiffly. "Selfish being," he\r\nsaid sadly. "This world cannot support one-fourth our number."\r\n\r\n"Oh, I know, I know," Laloi said. 

"I do not mean to say such things. I\r\nam twisted by my sorrow ..." As if to express her self-abnegation, she\r\ncorkscrewed out of the clover and into a thin spiral of\r\nnear-nothingness.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Settle down, foolish one," said Buos, not unkindly. "I know your\r\nfeelings. 

Do you think I am not tormented as well, by the slow pace of\r\nthese Earth-things? Crude, barbaric beings, like children with the\r\nbuilding blocks of science. They have such a long way to go ..."\r\n\r\n"And so few _know_," said Laloi despairingly. "A handful of seeing\r\nminds, tens of millions of ignorant ones. Not even first\r\nprinciples--they\'re stupid, stupid!"\r\n\r\n"But they will learn," Buos said stubbornly. "That is historical fact.\r\nSomeday, they will know the true meanings of matter and light and\r\nenergy. Slowly, yes, slowly. But in terms of their growth, it will seem\r\nlike great speed to them ..."\r\n\r\n"And in terms of our world," said Laloi, spinning sadly over the ground,\r\n"they may be far too late ..."\r\n\r\n"No!" In his excitement, Buos forgot himself and entwined with the\r\nflowing form of the she-creature, and the result was a rending of the\r\nair that cracked like heat lightning over the field. "No," he repeated\r\nagain. 

"They must not be too late. They must learn. They must build from\r\nthe very ground, and then they must fly. And then their eyes must be\r\nlifted to the stars, and desire must extend them to all the universe ..."\r\n\r\n"It seems so hopeless--"\r\n\r\n"It cannot be! Our destiny is not extinction. They must come to us, in\r\nfleets of silver, and replant our soil, and send towers of green\r\nshooting into our sky, breathing out air."\r\n\r\n"Yes, yes!" Laloi cried pitifully. "It will be that way, Buos. 

It will\r\nbe that way! That man-creature, we will begin with him ..."\r\n\r\nBuos floated earthward disconsolately. "He is a dreamer," he said\r\ncheerlessly. "His mind is good; he thinks of tomorrow; he is one of the\r\nknowing ones. But he cannot be moved, Laloi. His thoughts may fester and\r\ndie in the prison of his brain ..."\r\n\r\n"No, they will not! We have watched him. He understands much. He will\r\nhelp us!"\r\n\r\n"I have seen his like before," said Buos hopelessly. "He thinks and he\r\nworks, and his conclusions will die stillborn, for lack of a moving\r\nforce ..."\r\n\r\n"Then let us provide it, Buos. Let us move him!"\r\n\r\n"With what?" 

said the other disdainfully. "Arms of nothing? Hands of\r\nvacuum? A breeze against his cheek? A rustle of leaves? A meaningless\r\nwhistle in his ear?"\r\n\r\n"Let us try. Let us try! This empty watchfulness is destroying us. Let\r\nus move him, Buos. 

Come!"\r\n\r\nFaster than the sky-sweeping clouds they flew, over the gently swelling\r\nhills, over the yearning branches of the trees, over the calm blue\r\nwaters of the lakes. Swifter than the flight of birds they came,\r\nsearching for a thinking mind ...\r\n\r\nThey found him at last.\r\n\r\n"He knows, he knows," said Laloi. "Only now to say \'this is so because\'\r\nand \'this must happen when\'! Only to think--to understand--"\r\n\r\nThey hovered over his head, in a pandemonium of helplessness. 

They\r\nwhirled, and tumbled, and shrilly circled. And then to Laloi the\r\ninspiration came.\r\n\r\nThe apple, caught by a sudden gust of wind, twisted from the tenuous\r\nhold of the tree and fell to the ground.\r\n\r\nThe man, startled, picked it up.\r\n\r\nHe gazed at it, deep in thought.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Amazing Stories_ January 1957.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. "Boy, will I ever be\r\nglad to get off this cockeyed planet."\r\n\r\nGroverzb pushed at his spectacles, sniffed, and said, "Quite."\r\n\r\nThe big man said, "Ain\'t no native here over three feet tall. And they\r\ngot some crazy kind of communication. 

They don\'t talk."\r\n\r\nGroverzb said, "Quiet."\r\n\r\n"Uh?"\r\n\r\n"Precisely why I am here. I," said Groverzb, sniffing again, "loathe\r\nconversation."\r\n\r\n"Oh. Well." He left.\r\n\r\nAlone, Groverzb surveyed his realm. The house was the shell of what had\r\nformerly been a Little People apartment building. Ceilings, floors and\r\nwalls had been removed to form one large room. The tiny doors and\r\nwindows had been sealed, and a single window and door had been cut into\r\nthe shell for Groverzb\'s use. Crude, but serviceable.\r\n\r\nGroverzb walked to the window and looked down the slope. Little People\r\nbuildings dotted the landscape, and the people themselves scurried\r\nsilently about. Yes, thought Groverzb, it would do nicely. He had\r\nbrought an adequate food-tablet supply. He would finish, without the\r\ndistraction of voices, his beautiful concerto. He would return to Earth\r\nfamous and happy.\r\n\r\nArmed with paper and pencils, he went to the piano, having decided to\r\nenlarge upon the theme in the second movement. His mind knew exactly how\r\nthe passage should run, and he swiftly covered the paper with sharp,\r\nangular notes. Then he triumphantly lifted his hands and began to play\r\nwhat he had written.\r\n\r\nHe jerked back from the keyboard, his hair on end, his teeth, on edge,\r\nhis ears screaming with the mass of sounds he had produced. He looked at\r\nhis hands, peered at the score, adjusted his spectacles and tried again.\r\n\r\nI\'m tired, he thought, recoiling in horror from the racket. A food\r\ntablet and a nap will remedy the situation.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWhen he awoke, Groverzb walked to the window, refreshed. A violet glow\r\nhad replaced the harsh yellow light of day. At the foot of the slope,\r\nthe Little People dashed to and fro, but no voice broke the peaceful\r\nquiet of the evening.\r\n\r\nWith a sigh of satisfaction, Groverzb went to the piano. Gently, he\r\nstruck the keys. Blatant, jumbled noise filled the room.\r\n\r\nBreathing hard, Groverzb rose and gingerly lifted the spinet\'s lid. No,\r\nnothing amiss there. Good felts, free hammers, solid sounding\r\nboard--must be out of tune.\r\n\r\nGroverzb closed the lid, sat down and struck a single note. A clear\r\ntone sang out. He moved chromatically up and down the scale. Definitely\r\nnot out of tune.\r\n\r\nHe shifted the score, glanced uneasily at the keys and began to play.\r\nDiscord immediately pierced his eardrums.\r\n\r\nHe clapped his hands over his ears and leaped wildly from the piano\r\nbench. The trip, he decided frantically. It must have affected my\r\nhearing.\r\n\r\nHe flung himself from the house and down the slope. The Little People\r\nscattered, staring. He charged into the administration building and\r\nclutched the lapels of a uniformed official.\r\n\r\n"A doctor!" he gasped. 

"Now! 

This minute!"\r\n\r\nThe official raised his eyebrows and removed Groverzb\'s hands with\r\ndistaste.\r\n\r\n"It\'s a little late in the day," he drawled, "but maybe the doc up on\r\nthe top floor--"\r\n\r\nGroverzb flew up the stairs and into the doctor\'s office. The doctor\'s\r\nface lit up.\r\n\r\n"A patient!" he exclaimed. 

"Capital! What seems to be the trouble? Food\r\npoisoning? Shouldn\'t eat the food here. Garbage. Appendix? Heart\r\nattack?"\r\n\r\n"Stop talking, you idiot, it\'s my ears!"\r\n\r\nObviously disappointed, the doctor nevertheless poked and peered at\r\nGroverzb\'s ears.\r\n\r\n"No," he said finally. "A trifle big, yes. 

But nothing wrong with them."\r\n\r\n"You\'re sure?"\r\n\r\n"Absolutely. A pity. 

I\'m getting a bit rusty."\r\n\r\nWith a groan, Groverzb staggered out of the building, back through town,\r\nand up the slope to his house. Seating himself firmly on the bench he\r\nbegan to play.\r\n\r\nHe shuddered. The noise was abominable.\r\n\r\nSuddenly his door burst open and a crowd of Little People rushed in.\r\nThey pulled him off the bench and slapped angrily at his hands. Then,\r\nwith cutters, they attacked the piano.\r\n\r\n"Here, stop that!" Groverzb screeched. 

"What do you think you\'re doing?"\r\n\r\nThe Little People pushed and dragged him out of the house, down the\r\nslope, through the town and into the launching bowl at the space-strip.\r\nThe launching agent took one look and yelled, "Get the interpreter! On\r\nthe double!

"\r\n\r\nThe interpreter ran up and whipped something from his pocket. It looked\r\nlike a miniature piano skeleton. He tripped a hammer. There was a faint\r\ntinkle. Instantly one of the Little People produced a single miniature\r\nhammer and tapped it rapidly against his skull. The interpreter tripped\r\nanother hammer. A second little one responded.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nSuddenly one of the Little People ran over and tripped all the\r\ninterpreter\'s hammers simultaneously. The Little People winced.\r\n\r\n"Oh," said the interpreter. "Well, it\'s their planet." He hustled\r\nGroverzb out to a freight ship that was warming up for takeoff.\r\n\r\n"Is everyone insane?" Groverzb croaked. "I demand to know what this is\r\nall about!"\r\n\r\nThe interpreter shoved Groverzb into the ship.\r\n\r\n"They say you talk too much!" he yelled, as he slammed the door.\r\n\r\n\r\nEND\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n

From outside the door he\r\ncaught a thought wave equivalent to a knock, and, glancing at the door,\r\nhe willed it to slide open.\r\n\r\nIt opened. 

"Enter, my friend," he said. He could have projected the idea\r\ntelepathically; but with only two persons present, speech was more\r\npolite.\r\n\r\nEjon Khee entered. "You are up late tonight, my leader," he said.\r\n\r\n"Yes, Khee. Within an hour the Earth rocket is due to land, and I wish\r\nto see it. Yes, I know, it will land a thousand miles away, if their\r\ncalculations are correct. Beyond the horizon. But if it lands even twice\r\nthat far the flash of the atomic explosion should be visible. And I have\r\nwaited long for first contact. For even though no Earthman will be on\r\nthat rocket, it will still be first contact--for them. Of course our\r\ntelepath teams have been reading their thoughts for many centuries,\r\nbut--this will be the first _physical_ contact between Mars and Earth."\r\n\r\nKhee made himself comfortable on one of the low chairs. 

"True," he said.\r\n"I have not followed recent reports too closely, though. Why are they\r\nusing an atomic warhead? I know they suppose our planet is uninhabited,\r\nbut still--"\r\n\r\n"They will watch the flash through their lunar telescopes and get\r\na--what do they call it?--a spectroscopic analysis. That will tell them\r\nmore than they know now (or think they know; much of it is erroneous)\r\nabout the atmosphere of our planet and the composition of its surface.\r\nIt is--call it a sighting shot, Khee. They\'ll be here in person within a\r\nfew oppositions. 

And then--"\r\n\r\nMars was holding out, waiting for Earth to come. What was left of Mars,\r\nthat is; this one small city of about nine hundred beings. The\r\ncivilization of Mars was older than that of Earth, but it was a dying\r\none. This was what remained of it: one city, nine hundred people. They\r\nwere waiting for Earth to make contact, for a selfish reason and for an\r\nunselfish one.\r\n\r\n\r\nMartian civilization had developed in a quite different direction from\r\nthat of Earth. It had developed no important knowledge of the physical\r\nsciences, no technology. But it had developed social sciences to the\r\npoint where there had not been a single crime, let alone a war, on\r\nMars for fifty thousand years. And it had developed fully the\r\nparapsychological sciences of the mind, which Earth was just beginning\r\nto discover.\r\n\r\nMars could teach Earth much. How to avoid crime and war to begin with.\r\nBeyond those simple things lay telepathy, telekinesis, empathy....\r\n\r\nAnd Earth would, Mars hoped, teach them something even more valuable to\r\nMars: how, by science and technology--which it was too late for Mars to\r\ndevelop now, even if they had the type of minds which would enable them\r\nto develop these things--to restore and rehabilitate a dying planet, so\r\nthat an otherwise dying race might live and multiply again.\r\n\r\nEach planet would gain greatly, and neither would lose.\r\n\r\nAnd tonight was the night when Earth would make its first sighting shot.\r\nIts next shot, a rocket containing Earthmen, or at least an Earthman,\r\nwould be at the next opposition, two Earth years, or roughly four\r\nMartian years, hence. The Martians knew this, because their teams of\r\ntelepaths were able to catch at least some of the thoughts of Earthmen,\r\nenough to know their plans. Unfortunately, at that distance, the\r\nconnection was one-way. Mars could not ask Earth to hurry its program.\r\nOr tell Earth scientists the facts about Mars\' composition and\r\natmosphere which would have made this preliminary shot unnecessary.\r\n\r\nTonight Ry, the leader (as nearly as the Martian word can be\r\ntranslated), and Khee, his administrative assistant and closest friend,\r\nsat and meditated together until the time was near. Then they drank a\r\ntoast to the future--in a beverage based on menthol, which had the same\r\neffect on Martians as alcohol on Earthmen--and climbed to the roof of\r\nthe building in which they had been sitting. They watched toward the\r\nnorth, where the rocket should land. The stars shone brilliantly and\r\nunwinkingly through the atmosphere.\r\n\r\n\r\nIn Observatory No. 1 on Earth\'s moon, Rog Everett, his eye at the\r\neyepiece of the spotter scope, said triumphantly, "Thar she blew,\r\nWillie. And now, as soon as the films are developed, we\'ll know the\r\nscore on that old planet Mars." He straightened up--there\'d be no more\r\nto see now--and he and Willie Sanger shook hands solemnly. It was an\r\nhistorical occasion.\r\n\r\n"Hope it didn\'t kill anybody. 

Any Martians, that is. Rog, did it hit\r\ndead center in Syrtis Major?"\r\n\r\n"Near as matters. I\'d say it was maybe a thousand miles off, to the\r\nsouth. And that\'s damn close on a fifty-million-mile shot. Willie, do\r\nyou really think there are any Martians?

"\r\n\r\nWillie thought a second and then said, "No."\r\n\r\nHe was right.\r\n\r\n\r\n  --FREDRIC BROWN\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


Martin Cole."\r\n\r\n"Your profession?"\r\n\r\n"A very important one. I am a literary agent specializing in science\r\nfiction. 

I sell the work of various authors to magazine and book\r\npublishers."\r\n\r\nThe Coroner paused to study Cole; to ponder the thin, mirthless smile.\r\nThe Coroner said, "Mr. Cole, this inquest has been called to look into\r\nthe death of one Sanford Smith, who was found near your home with a gun\r\nin his hand and a bullet in his brain. The theory of suicide has been--"\r\n\r\n"--rather hard to rationalize?"\r\n\r\nThe Coroner blinked. "You could put it that way.

"\r\n\r\n"I would put it even stronger. The theory is obviously ridiculous. It\r\nwas a weak cover-up. 

The best I could do under the circumstances."\r\n\r\n"You are saying that you killed Sanford Smith?"\r\n\r\n"Of course."\r\n\r\nThe Coroner glanced at his six-man jury, at the two police officers, at\r\nthe scattering of spectators. They all seemed stunned. Even the reporter\r\nsent to cover the hearing made no move toward the telephone. The Coroner\r\ncould think of only the obvious question: "Why did you kill him?"\r\n\r\n"He was dangerous to us.

"\r\n\r\n"Whom do you mean by _us_?"\r\n\r\n"We Martians, who plan to take over your world."\r\n\r\nThe Coroner was disappointed. A lunatic. But a lunatic can murder. Best\r\nto proceed, the Coroner thought. "I was not aware that we have Martians\r\nto contend with."\r\n\r\n"If I\'d had the right weapon to use on Smith, you wouldn\'t be aware of\r\nit now. We still exercise caution."\r\n\r\nThe Coroner felt a certain pity. "Why did you kill Smith?"\r\n\r\n"We Martians have found science-fiction writers to be our greatest\r\ndanger. Through the medium of imaginative fiction, such writers have\r\nmore than once revealed our plans. If the public suddenly realized\r\nthat--"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe Coroner broke in. "You killed Smith because he revealed something in\r\nhis writings?"\r\n\r\n"Yes. He refused to take my word that it was unsalable. He threatened to\r\nsubmit it direct. 

It was vital material."\r\n\r\n"But there are many other such writers. You can\'t control--"\r\n\r\n"We control ninety percent of the output. We have concentrated on the\r\nfield and all of the science-fiction agencies are in our hands. This\r\ncontrol was imperative.

"\r\n\r\n"I see." The Coroner spoke in the gentle tones one uses with the insane.\r\n"Any writing dangerous to your cause is deleted or changed by the\r\nagents."\r\n\r\n"Not exactly. The agent usually persuades the writer to make any such\r\nchanges, as the agent is considered an authority on what will or will\r\nnot sell."\r\n\r\n"The writers always agree?"\r\n\r\n"Not always. If stubbornness is encountered, the agent merely shelves\r\nthe manuscript and tells the writer it has been repeatedly rejected."\r\n\r\nThe Coroner glanced at the two policemen. Both were obviously puzzled.\r\nThey returned the Coroner\'s look, apparently ready to move on his order.\r\n\r\nThe thin, mirthless smile was still on Cole\'s lips. Maniacal violence\r\ncould lie just behind it. Possibly Cole was armed. Better to play for\r\ntime--try to quiet the madness within. The Coroner continued speaking.\r\n"You Martians have infiltrated other fields also?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, yes. 

We are in government, industry, education. We are everywhere.\r\nWe have, of course, concentrated mainly upon the ranks of labor and in\r\nthe masses of ordinary, everyday people. It is from these sources that\r\nwe will draw our shock troops when the time comes."\r\n\r\n"That time will be--?

"\r\n\r\n"Soon, very soon."\r\n\r\nThe Coroner could not forebear a smile. "You find the science-fiction\r\nwriters more dangerous than the true scientists?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, yes. The scientific mind tends to reject anything science\r\ndisproves." There was now a mocking edge to Cole\'s voice. "Science can\r\neasily prove we do not exist."\r\n\r\n"But the science-fiction writer?"\r\n\r\n"The danger from the imaginative mind cannot be overestimated."\r\n\r\nThe Coroner knew he must soon order the officers to lay hands upon this\r\nmadman. He regretted his own lack of experience with such situations. 

He\r\ntried to put a soothing, confidential note into his voice. "You said a\r\nmoment ago that if you\'d had the right kind of weapon to use on Smith--"\r\n\r\nCole reached into his pocket and brought out what appeared to be a\r\nfountain pen. "This. It kills instantly and leaves no mark whatever.\r\nHeart failure is invariably stated as the cause of death."\r\n\r\nThe Coroner felt better. Obviously, Cole was not armed. As the Coroner\r\nraised a hand to signal the officers, Cole said, "You understand, of\r\ncourse, that I can\'t let you live."\r\n\r\n"Take this man into custody."\r\n\r\nThe police officers did not move. The Coroner turned on them sharply.\r\nThey were smiling. Cole pointed the fountain pen. The Coroner felt a\r\nsharp chill on his flesh. He looked at the jury, at the newspaperman,\r\nthe spectators. They were all smiling cold, thin, terrible smiles....\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nA short time later, the newspaperman phoned in his story. The afternoon\r\neditions carried it:\r\n\r\n                     CORONER BELL DIES OF HEART ATTACK\r\n\r\n    Shortly after this morning\'s inquest, which resulted in a jury\r\n    verdict of suicide in the case of Sanford Smith, Coroner James Bell\r\n    dropped dead of heart failure in the hearing room of the County\r\n    building. Mr. Bell leaves a wife and--\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _If Worlds of Science Fiction_ July\r\n    1952. And you\'re allowed\r\n only one mistake--your last!\r\n\r\n\r\nMy radar picked him up when he was about five hundred miles to my\r\nnorth-northeast and about forty-five miles above me. I switched the\r\nvelocity calculator on him as fast as I could reach it.\r\n\r\nThe enemy ship was doing sixteen, possibly even sixteen and a half. I\r\ntook the chance that it was most likely an Ivar Interceptor, at that\r\nspeed, and punched out a temporary evasion pattern with my right hand\r\nwhile with my left I snapped an Ivar K-12 card into my calculator along\r\nwith his estimated speed, altitude and distance. It wasn\'t much to go on\r\nas yet but he couldn\'t have much more on me, if as much; inwardly I\r\ncongratulated myself on the quick identification I\'d managed.\r\n\r\nHe was near enough now for my visor screen to pick him up. At least he\r\nwas alone, that was something. My nearest squadron mate was a good\r\nminute and a half away. It might as well have been a century.\r\n\r\nNow, this is what is always hard to get over to a civilian; the time\r\nelement. Understand, it will take me a while to tell this but it all\r\ntook less than sixty seconds to happen.\r\n\r\nHe had guessed my evasion pattern already--either guessed it or had some\r\nnew calculator that was far and beyond anything our techs were turning\r\nout. I could tell he\'d anticipated me by the Bong-Sonic roll he slipped\r\ninto.\r\n\r\nI quickly punched up a new pattern based on the little material I had in\r\nthe calculator. At least I\'d caught the roll. I punched that up,\r\nhurriedly, slipped it into the IBM, guessed that his next probability\r\nwas a pass, took a chance on that and punched it in.\r\n\r\nI was wrong there. He didn\'t take his opportunity for a front-on pass.\r\nHe was either newly out of their academy or insultingly confident. My\r\nlips felt tight as I canceled the frontal pass card, punched up two more\r\nto take its place.\r\n\r\nThe base supervisor cut in on the phone. "It looks like old Dmitri\r\nhimself, Jerry, and he\'s flying one of the new K-12a models. Go get him,\r\nboy!

"\r\n\r\nI felt like snapping back. He knew better than to break in on me at a\r\ntime like this. I opened my mouth, then shut it again. Did he say K-12a?\r\n_Did he say K-12a?_\r\n\r\nI squinted at the visor screen. The high tail, the canopy, the oddly\r\nshaped wing tanks.\r\n\r\nI\'d gone off on the identification!\r\n\r\nI slapped another evasion pattern into the controls, a standard set, I\r\nhad no time to punch up an improvisation. But he was on me like a wasp.\r\nI rejected it, threw in another set. 

Reject. Another!\r\n\r\nEven as I worked, I kicked the release on my own calculator, dumped it\r\nall, selected like a flash an Ivar K-12a card, and what other\r\nestimations I could make while my mind was busy with the full-time job\r\nof evasion.\r\n\r\nMy hands were still making the motions, my fingers were flicking here,\r\nthere, my feet touching here, there. But my heart wasn\'t in it.\r\n\r\nHe already had such an advantage that it was all I could do to keep him\r\nin my visor screen. 

He was to the left, to the right. I got him for a\r\nfull quarter-second in the wires, but the auto gunner was too far\r\nbehind, much too far.\r\n\r\nHis own guns flicked red.\r\n\r\nI punched half a dozen buttons, slapped levers, tried to scoot for home.\r\n\r\nTo the left of my cubicle two lights went yellowish and at the same time\r\nmy visor screen went dead. I was blind.\r\n\r\nI sank back in my chair, helpless.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe speed indicator wavered, went slowly, deliberately to zero; the\r\naltimeter died; the fuel gauge. Finally, even the dozen or so\r\ntrouble-indicators here, there, everywhere about the craft. Fifteen\r\nmillion dollars worth of warcraft was being shot into wreckage.\r\n\r\nI sat there for a long, long minute and took it.\r\n\r\nThen I got to my feet and wearily opened the door of my cubicle.\r\nSergeant Walters and the rest of the maintenance crew were standing\r\nthere. They could read in my face what had happened.\r\n\r\nThe sergeant began, "Captain, I ..."\r\n\r\nI grunted at him. "Never mind, Sergeant. It had nothing to do with the\r\nship\'s condition." I turned to head for the operations office.\r\n\r\nBill Dickson strolled over from the direction of his own cubicle.\r\n"Somebody said you just had a scramble with old Dmitri himself."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know," I said. 

"I don\'t know if it was him or not. Maybe some\r\nof you guys can tell a man\'s flying but I can\'t."\r\n\r\nHe grinned at me. "Shot you down, eh?

"\r\n\r\nI didn\'t answer.\r\n\r\nHe said, "What happened?"\r\n\r\n"I thought it was an Ivar K-12, and I put that card in my calculator.\r\nTurned out it was one of those new models, K-12a. That was enough, of\r\ncourse.

"\r\n\r\nBill grinned at me again. "That\'s two this week. That flak got you near\r\nthat bridge and now you get ..."\r\n\r\n"Shut up," I told him.\r\n\r\nHe counted up on his fingers elaborately. "The way I figure it, you lose\r\none more ship and you\'re an enemy ace."\r\n\r\nHe was irrepressible. "Damn it," I said, "will you cut it out! I\'ve got\r\nenough to worry about without you working me over. This means I\'ll have\r\nto spend another half an hour in operations going over the fight. And\r\nthat means I\'ll be late for dinner again. And you know Molly."\r\n\r\nBill sobered. 

"Gee," he said, "I\'m sorry. War is hell, isn\'t it?"\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Imagination Stories of Science and\r\n    Fantasy_ July 1953. Frederic Max_\r\n\r\n\r\n One final lesson--a dying man\'s last letter to his\r\n only son that completes the young man\'s education.\r\n\r\n\r\nMY DEAR SON:--\r\n\r\nThe doctors have left and I am told that in a few hours I shall die. In\r\nmy lifetime the world has progressed from the chaotic turmoil of the\r\nearly Atomic era to the peacefulness and tranquility of our present age,\r\nand I die content.\r\n\r\nFor ten years I have instructed you in all that you will need for the\r\nfuture. 

One final lesson remains to be taught.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nOn the wall of my bedchamber hangs a citation "from a grateful\r\ngovernment for services too secret to be herein set forth." In past\r\nyears you have asked me repeatedly about this citation, but each time I\r\nhave taken pains to avoid a direct answer. Now it is proper that you\r\nshould know.\r\n\r\nForty years ago I was an obscure Army captain stationed at the Armed\r\nForces Language School in Monterey, California. I had at that time just\r\ncompleted a tour of duty in Korea, a minor skirmish of that era, and\r\ndespite an excellent reputation for resourcefulness, I had drawn\r\nMonterey as my next assignment. An aptitude for foreign languages had\r\nled to an instructorship in the Russian department with additional\r\nduties instructing in the Slavic tongues.\r\n\r\nMy life was pleasant and uneventful, and it was with mixed emotions that\r\nI received orders to report to Washington for a new duty assignment.\r\nThe chain of events which precipitated those orders were to change the\r\nworld....\r\n\r\nFor while you and I were playing on the lawn of our Monterey home, an\r\nunknown Hungarian physicist working under Russian supervision had made a\r\nstartling discovery. Within a matter of days alarming rumors of his work\r\nreached Washington. Our embassies in Moscow and Belgrade reported\r\nfurious activity in the field of psychic research and large-scale\r\nexperiments in mass hypnosis. Four of us were selected to investigate\r\nthe rumors. 

Before we could commence our undertaking, word reached\r\nWashington that the rumors were now actualities. A device capable of the\r\nmass hypnosis of great segments of the world\'s population was rapidly\r\nreaching perfection.\r\n\r\nAfter three months of intensive grooming in the fields of physics and\r\npsychology, we four agents set out individually with orders to track\r\ndown and destroy both the scientist and his machine. I never saw the\r\nother three again....\r\n\r\nDuring the three months of schooling, other members of our vast\r\nintelligence organization had been engaged in laying the groundwork for\r\nour efforts. 

In December 1955, I slipped into Russia and took the place\r\nof a government official who felt that Western civilization offered\r\ngreater reimbursement than Soviet Communism.\r\n\r\nI entered into my new role with trepidation, but my fears were\r\nunfounded. Thanks to a remarkable resemblance (which was the original\r\nreason for my selection) and also due to a most thorough briefing, I\r\nfound myself making the substitution with ease. I pride myself on the\r\nfact that by diligent application I was able to increase my worth to the\r\nRussian government to the extent that I was shortly able to secure my\r\ntransfer to the psychological warfare section of the secret police. From\r\nthere it was a simple procedure to have myself assigned to what was\r\nknown as "Project Parchak."\r\n\r\nThe device was in its final stage of development; only the problem of\r\nincreasing its effective range remained to be solved. Three weeks after\r\nmy assignment to the project, its successful conclusion was\r\naccomplished.\r\n\r\nIn June 1956, the Russian government ordered me to a small house on the\r\noutskirts of Braila, Hungary, where I was to attend a private showing of\r\nthe device. By design, I arrived one day early and made my way to the\r\nlaboratory immediately. 

Dr. Michael Parchak, the inventor, stood facing\r\nme as I entered. On a table between us lay a small complicated mechanism\r\nresembling a radio transmitter. But it was infinitely more than that.\r\nThe device was a thought generator capable of hypnotizing every thinking\r\ncreature on the face of the earth. The power of infinite goodness or\r\nevil which the machine embodied was terrifying to consider.\r\n\r\nI listened to Parchak\'s boasting with revulsion. Although he had the\r\nability to work for the ultimate good of mankind, this creature\r\nintended, instead, to use his newly found power for selfish\r\naggrandizement.\r\n\r\nI drew him out, let him explain the inner workings of his device--and\r\nkilled him. 

My orders were to destroy the machine. I disobeyed them.\r\nUtilizing the machine to make good my escape, I left Hungary and\r\nreturned to the United States. The citation which you have seen was only\r\none of the many honors which were bestowed upon me.\r\n\r\nA few weeks later I resigned my commission and retired to a country\r\nhideaway to experiment further with the device I was supposed to have\r\ndestroyed. The peace and tranquility in which we of the earth now live\r\nmarked the successful culmination of my experiments.\r\n\r\nYou will find the machine walled up in the North alcove of my\r\nbedchamber.\r\n\r\nYour education is now complete my son, use it well. Be kind to our slave\r\npeoples, the world is yours.\r\n\r\nYour affectionate father,\r\n\r\n                                                  FRANCIS I\r\n                                                  EMPEROR OF THE EARTH\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Fantastic Universe_ May 1954.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Especially on the first day.\r\n\r\nEddie breathed easier as he saw that Professor Carner\'s back was to the\r\nclass as he completed a diagram on the blackboard.\r\n\r\n"Now then," Carner said. "Suppose you were writing about the--ah--the\r\nVenusian Threngener, which, as you know, has three legs. How would you\r\ndescribe it?"\r\n\r\nOne of the students raised his hand. "I\'d call it a three-legged\r\nmonstrosity, spawned in the deepest hells of--"\r\n\r\n"No," Carner said quietly. "That kind of writing might have been all\r\nright in the earliest days of our subject. 

But remember: You are no\r\nlonger dealing with a simple, credulous audience. To achieve the proper\r\neffects nowadays, you must _underplay_! Understand? Underplay! 

Now,\r\nsomeone else?"\r\n\r\nMort raised his hand, threw a glance at Eddie, and said: "How about,\r\n\'this tri-pedal blob of orange protoplasm, octopus like in its\r\ngropings--\'"\r\n\r\n"That\'s better," Carner said. "Tri-pedal is very nice, very exact. But\r\nmust you compare it to an octopus?

"\r\n\r\n"Why not?" Mort asked.\r\n\r\n"An octopus," the professor said, "is a well-known form of Earth\r\nlife. It inspires no terror, no wonder. 

You might better compare the\r\nThrengener to _another_ strange monster; a Callistan Eddel-splayer, for\r\nexample." He smiled winningly at the class.\r\n\r\nEddie frowned and scratched his blonde crewcut. He had liked it better\r\nthe first way. But Carner should know, of course. He was one of the\r\nbest-known writers in the entire field, and he had done the college a\r\nfavor by agreeing to teach the course. Eddie remembered reading some\r\nof Carner\'s stuff. It had scared the living daylights out of him when\r\nhe was younger. That description of Saturnian brains immobilizing\r\nEarth-confederation ships, for example. That had been a great yarn.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe trouble is, Eddie thought, I\'m just not interested. He had had\r\nserious doubts about this course. Actually, he had signed up only\r\nbecause Mort had insisted.\r\n\r\n"Any questions at this point?" Carner asked. One of the students--a\r\nserious-looking fellow wearing black horn-rimmed glasses--raised his\r\nhand.\r\n\r\n"Suppose," he asked, "suppose you were writing a story speculating on\r\nan interstellar combine formed with the purpose of taking over Earth?\r\nWould it be permissible, for greater contrast, to make Earth\'s enemies\r\nblack-hearted villains?"\r\n\r\nA political thinker, Eddie thought with a sneer. 

He glanced hopefully\r\nat the clock.\r\n\r\n"It wouldn\'t be advisable." Carner sat casually on the corner of his\r\ndesk. "Make them human also; show the reader that these aliens--whether\r\nthey have one head or five--have emotions understandable to them. Let\r\nthem feel joy and pain. Show them as being misguided. Pure evil in your\r\ncharacters has gone out of fashion."\r\n\r\n"But could I make their leader pure evil?" the young man asked, busily\r\njotting down everything Carner had said.\r\n\r\n"I suppose so," Carner said thoughtfully. "But give him motivations\r\nalso. By the way, in dealing with that sort of story--the panoramic\r\nkind--remember not to oversimplify the aliens\' problems. If they amass\r\nan army of twenty million, all have to be fed. If the rulers of fifty\r\nscattered star systems meet in conclave, remember that different star\r\nsystems have different languages, and different races have different\r\nnervous systems. Bear in mind also, that there would be little logical\r\nreason for attacking earth; the galaxy is filled with so many stars and\r\nplanets, what is the necessity of fighting for one?"\r\n\r\nThe horn-rimmed fellow nodded dubiously, writing his notes with\r\ntremendous speed. Eddie stifled a yawn. He preferred to think of his\r\nvillains as pure unadulterated evil; it made characterization so much\r\neasier. And he was getting tremendously bored.\r\n\r\nCarner answered questions for the next half hour. He told them not to\r\ndescribe Venus as a \'jungle-choked green hell,\' never, never to call\r\nthe moon \'pock-marked,\' \'small-pox pitted,\' or \'scarred from centuries\r\nof meteoric bombardment.\'\r\n\r\n"All this has been said," he explained. "Millions of times. _Do not_\r\nuse cliches."\r\n\r\nHe went on to explain that the red spot of Jupiter need not be called a\r\nmalevolent red eye, that Saturn\'s rings don\'t necessarily resemble a\r\nhalo, and that the inhabitants of Venus are not Venetians.\r\n\r\n"All common errors," he said. "I want a thousand words from each of you\r\nnext time. I suggest that you choose a planet and write a fresh study\r\nof it, avoiding with care all the cliches I mentioned. Class dismissed.

"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Well, whadja think?" Mort asked Eddie in the hall. "Isn\'t he great?
