Wild and desperate, like you\'d say to a\r\nguy if the guy was just kicking over the last jug of water on a desert\r\nisland.\r\n\r\nIt would have been long enough for her to kill us if I hadn\'t had good\r\nreflexes. Even then, all I had time to do was knock the pistol out of\r\nher hand and drag her into the pit.\r\n\r\nWith her play bollixed, she was confused and bewildered. She ain\'t a\r\nfighter, and she sits back against the wall staring at us dead pan with\r\nbig expressionless eyes. She\'s a plenty pretty babe and I could see\r\nexactly what had happened as far as Stillwell was concerned. His spots\r\nhad come to life in very adequate form so to speak.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nStillwell goes over and sits down beside her and I\'m very much on the\r\nalert, because I know where his courage comes from. But I decide it\'s\r\nall right, because I see the babe is not belligerent, just confused kind\r\nof. And friendly.\r\n\r\nAnd willing. Kind of a whipped-little-dog willing, and man oh man! She\r\nwas sure what Stillwell needed.\r\n\r\nThey kind of went together like a hand and a glove--natural-like. And\r\nit followed--pretty natural--that when Stillwell got up and led her\r\naround a wing of the pit, out of sight, she went willing--like that same\r\nlittle dog.\r\n\r\nUhuh. No, you guys. 

Two\'s enough. 

I wouldn\'t rob you. Well, okay, and\r\nthanks kindly.\r\n\r\nWell, there I was, all alone, but happy for Stillwell, cause I know it\'s\r\nwhat the kid needs, and in spots like that what difference does it make?\r\nYank--Ruskie--Mongolian--as long as she\'s willing.\r\n\r\nThen, you guys, Stillwell comes back out--wall-eyed--real\r\nwall-eyed--like being hit but not knocked out and still walking. I know\r\nwhat it is--some kind of shock. I get up and walk over and take a look\r\nat the babe where he\'d left her--and I bust out laughing. I told you\r\nguys there was a yak in this. I laughed like a fool--it was that funny.\r\nAs much as I had time to, before Stillwell cracked. It was enough to\r\ncrack him--the little thing that pushes a guy over the edge.\r\n\r\nHe lets out a yell and screams, "For crisake! For crisake! Nothing but a\r\nbucket of bolts! Nothing but a couple of plastic lumps--"\r\n\r\nThat was when I hit him. 

I had to. He was for the birds, Stillwell was.\r\nAn hour later we got relieved and a couple of medicos carried him away\r\nstrapped to a stretcher--gone like a kite.\r\n\r\nThey took the robot too, and its clothes, but they forgot the brassiere,\r\nso I took it and I been carrying it ever since, but I\'ll leave it with\r\nyou guys if you want--for the coffee. Might make you think about home.\r\nAfter all, like the man says, we got to keep our sense of humor.\r\n\r\nWell, so long, you guys--and thanks.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Amazing Stories_ April-May 1953.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Perhaps they will carry folks\r\n    down the highways at ninety miles an hour in perfect safety. But\r\n    picking up a hitch-hiker will still be as dangerous as it is today._\r\n\r\n HARD\r\n GUY\r\n\r\n By H. B. CARLETON\r\n\r\n\r\nHe was standing at the side of the glassite super-highway, his arm\r\nhalf-raised, thumb pointed in the same direction as that of the\r\napproaching rocket car. Ordinarily Frederick Marden would have passed a\r\nhitch-hiker without stopping, but there was something in the bearing and\r\nappearance of this one that caused him to apply his brakes.\r\n\r\nMarden opened the door next to the vacant seat beside him.\r\n\r\n"Going my way?" he asked.\r\n\r\nA pair of steady, unsmiling blue eyes looked him over. 

"Yeah.

"\r\n\r\n"All right, then. Hop in."\r\n\r\nThe hitch-hiker took his time. He slid into the seat with casual\r\ndeliberateness and slammed the car door shut. The rocket car got under\r\nway once more.\r\n\r\nThey rode in silence for half a mile or so. Finally Marden glanced\r\nquestioningly at his companion\'s expressionless profile.\r\n\r\n"Where are you headed for?" he asked.\r\n\r\n"Dentonville." He spoke from the corner of his mouth, without turning\r\nhis head.\r\n\r\n"Oh, yes. 

That\'s the next town, isn\'t it?"\r\n\r\n"Yeah."\r\n\r\nNot very communicative, reflected Marden, noticing the rather ragged\r\ncondition of the other\'s celo-lex clothing.\r\n\r\n"Have much trouble getting rides?"\r\n\r\nThe passenger turned his head, his blue eyes without emotion.\r\n\r\n"Yeah. Most guys are leery about pickin\' up hitch-hikers. Scared they\'ll\r\nget robbed."\r\n\r\nMarden pursed his lips, nodded.\r\n\r\n"Something to that, all right. I\'m usually pretty careful myself; but I\r\nfigured you looked okay."\r\n\r\n"Can\'t always tell by looks," was the calm reply. "\'Course us guys\r\nmostly pick out some guy with a swell atomic-mobile if we\'re goin\' to\r\npull a stick-up. When we see a old heap like this one there\'s usually\r\nnot enough dough to make it pay."\r\n\r\nMarden felt his jaw drop.\r\n\r\n"Say, you sound, like you go in for that sort of thing! I\'m telling you\r\nright now, I haven\'t enough cash on me to make it worth your while. I\'m\r\njust a salesman, trying to get along."\r\n\r\n"You got nothin\' to worry about," his passenger assured him. "Stick-ups\r\nain\'t my racket."\r\n\r\nAn audible sigh of relief escaped Marden.\r\n\r\n"I\'m certainly glad to hear that! What is your--er--racket, anyway?"\r\n\r\nThe blue eyes frosted over.\r\n\r\n"Look, chum, sometimes it ain\'t exactly healthy to ask questions like\r\nthat."\r\n\r\n"Pardon me," Marden said hastily. "I didn\'t mean anything. It\'s none of\r\nmy business, of course."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe calm eyes flicked over his contrite expression.\r\n\r\n"Skip it, pal. You look like a right guy. I\'ll put you next to\r\nsomethin\'. Only keep your lip buttoned, see?

"\r\n\r\n"Oh, absolutely."\r\n\r\n"I\'m Mike Eagen--head of the Strato Rovers."\r\n\r\n"No!" Marden was plainly awed. "The Strato Rovers, eh? I\'ve heard of\r\nthem, all right.

"\r\n\r\nThe other nodded complacently.\r\n\r\n"Yeah. We\'re about the toughest mob this side of Mars. We don\'t bother\r\nhonest people, though. We get ours from the crooks and racketeers. They\r\ncan\'t squeal to the Interplanetary Police."\r\n\r\n"There\'s a lot in what you say," agreed Marden. "And of course that puts\r\nyour ... mob in the Robin Hood class."\r\n\r\n"Robin Hood--nuts! That guy was a dope! 

Runnin\' around with bows and\r\narrows. Why, we got a mystery ray that paralyzes anybody that starts up\r\nwith us. They\'re all right when it wears off, but by that time we get\r\naway."\r\n\r\nMarden was properly impressed.\r\n\r\n"A mystery ray! With a weapon like that, you should be able to walk into\r\na bank and clean it out without any trouble."\r\n\r\nHis passenger\'s lips curled.\r\n\r\n"I told you, we don\'t bother honest people. We even help the S.P.\r\nsometimes. 

Right now we\'re workin\' with the Earth-Mars G-men in roundin\'\r\nup a gang of fifth-columnists that are plannin\' on takin\' over the\r\ngov\'ment. They\'re led by the Black Hornet. This Black Hornet goes around\r\npretendin\' like he\'s a big business man, but he\'s really a internatural\r\nspy."\r\n\r\n"A--what?"\r\n\r\n"A internatural spy," repeated Marden\'s companion, shortly. "The E-M\r\nG-men say he\'s the most dangerous man in the country. But he won\'t last\r\nlong with the Strato Rovers on his trail."\r\n\r\nMarden nodded.\r\n\r\n"I can believe that. Tell me, Eagen, what are you doing out here around\r\na small Earth town like Dentonville?"\r\n\r\n"The gov\'ment\'s buildin\' some kind of a ammunition place near here, and\r\nI understand the Black Hornet\'s figurin\' on wreckin\' everything. \'Course\r\nhe won\'t get away with it."\r\n\r\nScattered plasticade houses on either side of the road indicated they\r\nhad reached the outskirts of Dentonville. Mike Eagen pointed ahead to a\r\nsmall white house set back among a cluster of trees.\r\n\r\n"There\'s where I\'m holed up. Drop me off in front."\r\n\r\nA young woman in a faded blue satin-glass house-dress was standing at\r\nthe gate of the white picket fence. She watched in silence as the\r\npassenger stepped from the rocket car and lifted his hand to the driver\r\nin careless farewell.\r\n\r\n"Thanks for the lift, chum," said Mike Eagen.\r\n\r\n"Not at all," replied Marden. "Glad to have been of service to Mike\r\nEagen."\r\n\r\nThe woman smiled to him.\r\n\r\n"He\'s told you his name, I see."\r\n\r\nMarden lifted his hat.\r\n\r\n"Indeed he has."\r\n\r\n"Michael is all right," she said. "I do think, though, that he reads too\r\nmany Buck Gordon Interplanetary comic books for a boy of eleven."\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Amazing Stories_ April 1956 and was\r\n    first published in _Amazing Stories_ November 1942. "I\'m picking him up at the spaceway," she said.\r\n"We\'re supposed to go dining and dancing tonight." She stopped pacing.\r\n"It\'s my birthday. I\'m thirty today."\r\n\r\nAnd I was twenty-four and in love. Six years between us. 

So what? 

I\r\ndidn\'t give a damn. I wanted to marry her, to live with her.\r\n\r\n"I\'m thirty," she said again. "Do you mind?"\r\n\r\n"I know your age. Why bring it up?"\r\n\r\n"Someday you\'ll find out you married an old woman. _If_ we ever do\r\nmarry.

"\r\n\r\n"Stop it." I got off the bed, went to her. "Just tell me what to do\r\nand I\'ll do it."\r\n\r\n"Do you love me?" she looked up at me.\r\n\r\n"You know I do."\r\n\r\n"Say it."\r\n\r\n"I love you."\r\n\r\n"Never stop saying that." She put up her face and I kissed her. A\r\nlong hard kiss. She broke away. "You\'ll be in back in the racer. Just\r\ncrouch low. As soon as we\'re away from the spaceway you hit him with\r\nthe wrench. It has to be quick and sure. Then we carry him up to the\r\napartment and drop him out the window."\r\n\r\nI shuddered a little as she talked. She was so calm about the whole\r\nthing.\r\n\r\n"You\'ll have plenty of time to get out. It\'ll be listed as a suicide.\r\nHe\'s been sick for a long time. His doctor will testify to that. He was\r\nso sick and worried he jumped to his death."\r\n\r\nShe stared at me hard. "Is it all clear?"\r\n\r\n"Yes." I looked at her. Her long blond hair, her oval face, the slim\r\nwhite column that was her throat. "It\'s all clear. Like glass."\r\n\r\nI poured myself a drink. I needed it. I was going to need a lot more.\r\n\r\n"We won\'t be able to see each other for a long time," she said. She\r\nwatched me drink. "We don\'t want to give our friends something to talk\r\nabout."\r\n\r\n"I won\'t like not seeing you."\r\n\r\nShe patted my face. I put down my drink, caged her slender hand in\r\nmine, and kissed her wrist. I saw the light blue veins criss-crossing\r\nunder the delicate skin.\r\n\r\nI brought her close to me. I kissed her warm lips. "Baby," I breathed.\r\n"Diane, baby."\r\n\r\n"Paul, listen to me. We haven\'t much time.

"\r\n\r\n"All right, sweet." I kissed her again.\r\n\r\n"Come on. We can\'t afford to get there late."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI crouched low in the back of the racer. I heard the street noises,\r\nthe gab of the night crowds, the not-so-mild cursings of the taxi-jet\r\ndrivers.\r\n\r\nIt all seemed so unreal. Back there, on my haunches, a wrench gripped\r\ntight in my sweaty hand. I was going to kill a man. A man I knew, a man\r\nI respected. And for a woman. 

All for a woman. I thought about getting\r\nup and telling Diane to go to hell and to get herself another stooge. I\r\nthought about a lot of things. Then I thought of Diane. Her sweet white\r\nbody. The way she sighed when I kissed her hard. And I knew I was going\r\nto go through with it.\r\n\r\nThe racer stopped, its jets cut off. I heard the hum as the door opened\r\nand she got out.\r\n\r\nThis was it. I sweated. It dripped down in an endless stream.\r\n\r\nThe seconds went by. Then the minutes.\r\n\r\nThey got in and the door hummed shut and I heard their laughter\r\nblending together. They settled back and the jets roared. The racer\r\nwoke up to new life and it shot away.\r\n\r\n"How was the trip?" I heard Diane asking.\r\n\r\n"Cold. And I\'m not sure it was worth it. Those Martians drive a hard\r\nbargain." He coughed. "Diane, you\'re not too set on going out tonight,\r\nare you?"\r\n\r\n"Why?" she asked.\r\n\r\n"I thought how nice it would be if we spent the evening at home."\r\n\r\n"Just as you say, Roger."\r\n\r\n"You don\'t care?"\r\n\r\n"Of course not.

"\r\n\r\nShe was so calm, so damn calm. There would never be another like Diane.\r\n\r\n"You won\'t regret it," Roger promised.\r\n\r\n"My, but this boulevard is deserted," she said. "Not a soul in sight.

"\r\n\r\nThat was for my benefit. It was my cue.\r\n\r\nI sat up silently.\r\n\r\nHe saw me then in the rear-view mirror. "What the hell?" He started to\r\nturn.\r\n\r\nMy arm sprang alive. The wrench thudded against his skull. A half cry\r\nspilled from his lips. Then his head fell forward on his chest.\r\n\r\n"Hit him again," Diane urged.\r\n\r\n"But--"\r\n\r\n"Do as I say."\r\n\r\nI hit him again, hard.\r\n\r\nIt was done. I settled back. The wrench was still in my hand. I looked\r\nat it, then let it fall.\r\n\r\n"Are you all right?" Diane asked.\r\n\r\n"Yes," I said. "Why shouldn\'t I be?"\r\n\r\n"You\'re not going to be sick, are you?"\r\n\r\n"No! You think I\'m a kid?"\r\n\r\n"You did it for an old woman."\r\n\r\n"Stop it."\r\n\r\n"Today is my birthday, don\'t you know? I\'m thirty."\r\n\r\n"Shut up."\r\n\r\n"I wonder what he got for my birthday."\r\n\r\n"Please."\r\n\r\n"I\'m sorry. 

Really I am. 

I feel like talking. If I don\'t I think I\'d\r\nscream."\r\n\r\nSo I let her talk. I didn\'t answer her. She babbled away like she was\r\ncrazy. She kept it up till we got to their apartment.\r\n\r\nDiane got out first and made sure the way was clear. "We\'ll use the\r\nback stairs," she said when she got back. "We both can manage him."\r\n\r\nIt was dark and it was late and we didn\'t see anybody. We went through\r\nthe service entrance. It was too heavy a load for me to do it alone.\r\nTwo flights up. Diane helped me with him.\r\n\r\nI breathed easier when we were in the marble hall outside the\r\napartment. 

She quickly unlocked the heavy plastic door and we got him\r\ninside. She fumbled for the inner-lighting switch.\r\n\r\n"Happy birthday," they shouted.\r\n\r\nNow I knew why Roger had wanted to spend the evening at home.\r\n\r\nWe stood there, Diane and myself, with Roger between us.\r\n\r\nThen they stopped shouting and stared at us. I thought they would never\r\nstop staring.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


We\'ll have to put Edwards to work on it\r\nwhen we go back upstairs."\r\n\r\nWe spotted an airport on the outskirts of a large city. The runways were\r\nlaid out with the precision of Earth\'s finest. I put our ship\'s nose\r\neastward on a runway and took it down fast through a lull in the\r\natmosphere ship traffic.\r\n\r\nAs we went down I saw tiny buildings spotted on the field which surely\r\nhoused electronic equipment, but our receivers remained silent.\r\n\r\nI taxied the shuttle up to an unloading ramp before the airport\'s\r\nterminal building and I killed the drive.\r\n\r\n"Harry," I said, "if it weren\'t that their ships are so outlandishly\r\nstubby and their buildings so outflung, we might well be on Earth!"\r\n\r\n"I agree, Captain. 

Strange, though, that they\'re not mobbing us. 

They\r\ncouldn\'t take this delta-winged job for one of their ships!"\r\n\r\nIt _was_ strange.\r\n\r\nI looked up at the observation ramp\'s occupants--people who except for\r\ntheir bizarre dress might well be of Earth--and saw no curiosity in the\r\neyes that sometimes swept across our position.\r\n\r\n"Be that as it may, Harry, we certainly should cause a stir in these\r\npressure suits. Let\'s go!

"\r\n\r\nWe walked up to a dour-looking individual at a counter at the ramp\'s\r\nend. 

Clearing my throat, I said rather inanely, "Hello!"--but what\r\n_does_ one say to an extrasolarian?\r\n\r\nI realized then that my voice seemed thunderous, that the only other\r\nsounds came from a distance: the city\'s noise, the atmosphere ships\'\r\nengines on the horizon--\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe Centaurian ignored us.\r\n\r\nI looked at the atmosphere ships in the clear blue sky, at the\r\nCentaurians on the ramp who appeared to be conversing--and there was no\r\nsound from those planes, no sound from the people!\r\n\r\n"It\'s impossible," Harry said. "The atmosphere\'s nearly Earth-normal. It\r\nshould be--well, damn it, it _is_ as sound-conductive; _we\'re_ talking,\r\naren\'t we?"\r\n\r\nI looked up at the Centaurians again. They were looking excitedly\r\nwestward. 

Some turned to companions. Mouths opened and closed to form\r\nwords we could not hear. 

Wide eyes lowered, following something I could\r\nnot see. Sick inside, I turned to Albrecht and read confirmation in his\r\ndrawn, blanched face.\r\n\r\n"Captain," he said, "I suspected that we might find something like this\r\nwhen we first came out of hyperspace and the big sleep. The recorders\r\nshowed we\'d exceeded light-speed in normal space-time just after the\r\ntransition. Einstein theorized that time would not pass as swiftly to\r\nthose approaching light-speed. We could safely exceed that speed in\r\nhyperspace but should never have done so in normal space-time. Beyond\r\nlight-speed time must conversely accelerate!\r\n\r\n"These people haven\'t seen _us_ yet. They certainly just observed our\r\nlanding. As we suspected, they probably do have speech and radio--but we\r\ncan\'t pick up either. We\'re seconds ahead of them in time and we can\'t\r\npick up from the past sounds of nearby origin or nearby signals radiated\r\nat light-speed. They\'ll see and hear us soon, but we\'ll never receive an\r\nanswer from _them_! Our questions will come to them in their future but\r\nwe can never pick answers from their past!"\r\n\r\n"Let\'s go, Harry," I said quickly.\r\n\r\n"Where?" he asked. "Where can we ever go that will be an improvement\r\nover this?" He was resigned.\r\n\r\n"Back into space," I said. "Back to circle this system at a\r\nnear-light-speed. The computers should be able to determine how long and\r\nhow slow we\'ll have to fly to cancel this out. If not, we are truly and\r\nforever lost!"\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Fantastic Universe_ January 1954.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Another. The city yawned.\r\n\r\nRows of houses lay like square ivory beads on patches of green felt. A\r\nboy drove his bicycle down the middle of an elm-bordered avenue,\r\nwhistling loudly, while tightly rolled newspapers arced from his hand\r\nand slapped against porches.\r\n\r\nLights snapped on in a thousand windows, shining yellowly against the\r\ncool whiteness of dawn. Men blinked and touched beard-stubbled chins.\r\nWomen moved sleepily toward porcelain and chrome kitchens.\r\n\r\nA truck roared and garbage pails rattled. There was a smell of sour\r\norange rinds and wet leaves and unfolding flowers. Over this came the\r\nsmell of toasting bread and frying bacon.\r\n\r\nDoors swung open, slippered feet padded across porches and hands groped\r\nfor the rolled newspapers. The air was stricken with the blaring sound\r\nof transcribed music and the excited voices of commercial announcers.\r\nThe doors swung shut and the sounds were muted.\r\n\r\nA million people shifted and stretched and scratched. The sun rose above\r\nthe horizon.\r\n\r\nCelebrity day.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nDoors slammed again, and half-consumed cups of coffee lay cooling\r\nbehind. Children wiped at sleepy eyes and mothers swept crumbs, touching\r\nself-conscious fingers at their own bed-ruffled hair. 

Laborers and\r\nclerks and lawyers and doctors strode down sidewalks and climbed into\r\nautomobiles and busses and sleek-nosed elevated trains. The city moved.\r\n\r\nTo the center of the city, where the tall buildings stretched to the\r\nlighting sky, came the horde, like thousands of ants toward a comb of\r\nhoney. Wheels sang and whined. 

Horns blasted. Whistles blew.\r\n\r\nAnd waiting, strung above the wide streets between the cold marquees and\r\nthe dead neon tubes, were the banners and the flags and the bunting.\r\n\r\nThe air warmed and the sun brightened. Voices chattered. Elbows nudged.\r\nMouths smiled, teeth shone, and there was the sound of laughter, rising\r\nover the pushing throngs. The city was happy.\r\n\r\nThe bunting dipped and the banners fluttered and the flags whipped. At\r\nthe edge of the city, the airport tightened itself. Waiting, waiting for\r\nthe silver and blue rocket. The rocket of the Celebrity.\r\n\r\nA large hotel, towering above the pulsing streets, began the quiver of\r\nactivity. As though a great electric current had been run through its\r\ncubes and shafts and hollows, the hotel crackled. Desk clerks clicked\r\nbells and bell boys hopped. Elevators rose and fell. In the cellar, wine\r\nbottles were dusted by quick, nervous hands. In the kitchen, a towering\r\ncake was frosted and decorated. Orders cracked. Hands flew and feet\r\nchattered against tile. In one rich expansive suite a giant hoop of\r\nmulti-colored flowers was placed in the center of a room.\r\n\r\nIt was in the air. Laughter, awe, worship, _excitement_!\r\n\r\nRopes went up and stretched between lamp posts. Blue-coated men on\r\nhorses began blocking streets. Old women with wooden boxes, children\r\nwith flashing eyes, men in rich suits and tattered suits began filling\r\nthe sidewalks.\r\n\r\nCurbs became lined with people. Bars threw open doors and fresh air met\r\nstale air. Men with fat faces, thin faces, white faces, red faces,\r\ntwitching with the anticipation of holiday freedom, gulped jiggers of\r\nraw whiskey and shuddered happily.\r\n\r\nChildren giggled and yelled and sprinted in crazy zig-zags. Men in white\r\ncaps hustled in front of the lined curbs, shouting, carrying their boxes\r\nof ice-cream. Men with buttons, men with pennants, men with balloons\r\njoined the shouting, and the sound rose in the air and the city smiled\r\nand shifted and its heart pounded.\r\n\r\nThe hotel whirred inside itself. The airport tensed and searched the\r\nsky.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nTime moved and the swelling throngs jammed the sidewalks, raising their\r\nstrengthening sound between the tall buildings. Windows popped open and\r\nfaces beamed. Tentative showers of confetti drifted down through the\r\nair.\r\n\r\nThe city waited, its pulse thumping.\r\n\r\nThe rocket was a black point in the sky. It grew. 

White-suited men\r\nscattered over the landing strip. Photographers crouched. Bulbs snapped\r\ninto reflectors. Cameras pointed.\r\n\r\nThe rocket landed. A door snapped open. Blue uniforms converged and\r\nflash bulbs popped. There were shouts and orders and men running. Gates\r\nswung and there was a blue-rimmed movement to a black open car. Sirens\r\nmoaned, screamed. And the black car was moving swiftly into the city.\r\n\r\nBeneath the buildings, marching bands in red and blue and yellow\r\nuniforms stood assembled. Girls in short skirts and tasseled hats spun\r\nsilver batons into the warm air. Bare legs kicked. Black boots flashed.\r\n\r\nThe crowd swayed against the ropes, and there was laughter and sweating\r\nand squinting.\r\n\r\nThe black car reached the heart of the city. Sirens died. 

Rows of men\r\nsnapped to attention. Policemen aligned their motorcycles.\r\n\r\nA baton shimmered high against the sun and came down.\r\n\r\nA cymbal crashed. Drums cracked. 

Music blared. And there was a movement\r\ndown the street.\r\n\r\nThe black car rolled along, while tape swept down from the buildings in\r\nlong swirling ribbons. There was a snow of confetti. 

And from the\r\nthroats of the people came the first roar. It grew, building, building\r\nin volume, and the city thundered its welcome to the man sitting upon\r\nthe back of the open car, the small man who tipped his hat and smiled\r\nand blinked behind his glasses: Joseph S. He stopped at the desk of\r\nthe editor, Art Holderness.\r\n\r\n"Holderness," he roared, his chins quivering, "you\'re fired!"\r\n\r\nHolderness looked up in surprise.

"What\'s the matter with it?"\r\n\r\n"Don\'t you see anything wrong?"\r\n\r\n"No. What shouldn\'t be there?"\r\n\r\n"There isn\'t anything shouldn\'t be there, you idiot. There\'s something\r\nmissing!"\r\n\r\n"What?"\r\n\r\n"Our announcement that the characters and situations in these stories\r\nbear no resemblance to actual persons living or dead."\r\n\r\n"Oh."\r\n\r\n"Is that all you have to say? Think of the libel suits! 

We\'ll be\r\nruined. I don\'t know why I let myself be talked into adding a science\r\nfiction book anyway. Holderness, you\'re fired.

"\r\n\r\n"But Mr. Young--"\r\n\r\n"You have no idea the trouble we can get into leaving that announcement\r\noff. Get out of this office!"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nK-17 removed a copy of _Atomic Science Stories_ from the newsstand and\r\nwent up to his hotel room. He sat down to read it.\r\n\r\nHe had been attracted by the picture of the space ship on the cover,\r\nbecause it reminded him very much of the one in which he had come\r\nto Earth from Rigel IV. And then, when he looked closer at it, he\r\ndiscovered that the four-tentacled purple creatures in the ship looked\r\nnot a little like his fellow Rigelians.\r\n\r\nThis made him homesick, and so, in direct defiance of the orders he had\r\nreceived from his superiors, he pulled down the shades and turned off\r\nthe gadget that set up the hypnotic field around him. Once more he was\r\nfour-tentacled and purple, instead of two-armed and pink, and it felt\r\ngood.\r\n\r\nHe began to read through the stories. The first of them concerned an\r\ninvader from another planet who was on Earth disguised as a man.\r\n\r\nGood Vog! K-17 thought to himself. 

They\'re on to us.\r\n\r\nHe looked over the story again. They had some of the details wrong,\r\nof course, such as saying that the Rigelians--whom they called the\r\nCapellans, for some strange reason--had mouths like octopi, whereas\r\nactually they had no mouths at all. But on the whole it was a\r\ncircumstantial and convincing account of the capture of a Rigelian spy.\r\n\r\nThe story had taken place in Philadelphia. That meant they had M-22.\r\nThis was serious. He picked up his magneto-oscillophone and called the\r\nhome base on the other side of the moon.\r\n\r\n"This is K-17," he reported. "I have just read in a Terran publication\r\ndetails of the capture of M-22."\r\n\r\n"Impossible!" the voice snorted in his auditory nerve. "We have been\r\nreceiving regular reports from M-22."\r\n\r\n"They must have replaced him with a human spy," K-17 mused.\r\n\r\n"Good Vog! Do you really think so?

"\r\n\r\n"It\'s the only explanation."\r\n\r\n"Good work, K-17. We\'ll be on our guard.

"\r\n\r\nK-17 hung up and sat down again to read further. The next story dealt\r\nwith an Earth landing on Mars.\r\n\r\nBut Earthmen _hadn\'t_ landed on Mars.\r\n\r\nOr had they?\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThis situation was becoming complicated. K-17 thought over all the\r\npossibilities. Was it possible that this magazine contained only\r\nFiction? The title of the thing was _Atomic Science Stories_. He\r\nremembered that he had read a similar magazine called _Impossible\r\nScience Fiction_. Was the distinction between "stories" and "fiction"\r\nsignificant? A fiction was obviously false; but a story could be any\r\nnarrative, true or not. Did this mean--? Good Vog, he wished he knew\r\nmore about Earth culture. But that was what he was here to find out.\r\nThey knew nothing, absolutely nothing, about Earth people. And they\r\ndidn\'t want to try to kill the inhabitants and take over the planet\r\nwithout knowing more about them.\r\n\r\nHe looked closely at the title page of _Atomic Science Stories_. He\r\nrecalled that _Impossible Science Fiction_, which he had, of course,\r\nread every word of, carried an announcement that all the stories were\r\nfiction. He did not see any such announcement on the title page of\r\n_Atomic_. Doubt was wavering into certainty in his mind.\r\n\r\nHe telephoned the offices of the Young Publishing Co., which published\r\nthe magazine. The secretary informed him that the editor, Mr.\r\nHolderness, had been discharged that very morning.\r\n\r\nDischarged, K-17 meditated. Why discharged? Well, he told himself, if\r\nEarth had space travel and was keeping it a secret, and if a magazine\r\nviolated its security precautions and published a story about it, of\r\ncourse they\'d discharge the editor. If it was a fiction magazine, that\r\nwould be different. But a magazine that printed _stories_--some of them\r\ntrue, like the one about the capture of M-22....\r\n\r\nHe called headquarters again, on his magneto-oscillophone. "Earth has\r\nspace travel!" he announced breathlessly.\r\n\r\n"What? 

Don\'t be silly." The voice in his auditory nerve was irritated.\r\n\r\n"A magazine published an account of it, and the editor was discharged\r\nthis morning for security reasons."\r\n\r\n"What? Are you sure?"\r\n\r\n"I just telephoned the office of the magazine and verified everything."\r\n\r\n"Report to the saucer station immediately. You\'re coming back to\r\nheadquarters. We\'ll get out the word to all our other operatives."\r\n\r\n"Except M-22."\r\n\r\n"Yes, of course. We\'ll have to leave him behind. It\'s really too bad.\r\nThe planet offered such nice possibilities.

"\r\n\r\nThey hung up.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"No, Holderness," Mr. Fribble said, "our magazine can\'t use you either.\r\nWe can\'t have an editor who\'s careless enough to leave off the standard\r\ndisclaimer. Why, there\'s no end of trouble we\'d get into without that\r\nlittle announcement."\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n

The captain\r\nwanted to ask but something stopped him. 

Behind him Doctor\r\nJohannsen sat at his desk, his gnarled old hand tight about a\r\nwhiskey bottle, the bottle the doctor always had in his desk but\r\nnever brought out except when he was alone, and waited for Captain\r\nBaird to ask his question. Captain Baird turned at last.\r\n\r\n"They are our markings?" Captain Baird asked. It was not the\r\nquestion. Captain Baird knew the markings of the Rocket Testing\r\nStation as well as the doctor did.\r\n\r\n"Yes," the doctor said, "they are our markings. Identical. 

But not\r\nour paint."\r\n\r\nCaptain Baird turned back to the window. 

Six months ago it had\r\nhappened. Ten minutes after launching, the giant test rocket had\r\nbeen only a speck on the observation screen. Captain Baird had\r\nturned away in disgust.\r\n\r\n"A mouse!" the captain had said, "unfortunate a mouse can\'t\r\nobserve, build, report. My men are getting restless, Johannsen."\r\n\r\n"When we are ready, Captain," the doctor had said.\r\n\r\nIt was twelve hours before the urgent call from Central Control\r\nbrought the captain running back to the laboratory. The doctor was\r\nthere before him. Professor Schultz wasted no time, he pointed to\r\nthe instrument panel. "A sudden shift, see for yourself. We\'ll\r\nmiss Mars by a million and a quarter at least."\r\n\r\nTwo hours later the shift in course of the test rocket was\r\napparent to all of them and so was their disappointment.\r\n\r\n       *     *     *     *     *\r\n\r\n"According to the instruments the steering shifted a quarter of an\r\ninch. No reason shows up," Professor Schultz said.\r\n\r\n"Flaw in the metal?" Doctor Johannsen said.\r\n\r\n"How far can it go?" 

Captain Baird asked.\r\n\r\nProfessor Schultz shrugged. "Until the fuel runs out, which is\r\nprobably as good as never, or until the landing mechanism is\r\nactivated by a planet-sized body."\r\n\r\n"Course? Did you plot it?" The doctor asked.\r\n\r\n"Of course I did," Professor Schultz said, "as close as I can\r\ncalculate it is headed for Alpha Centauri."\r\n\r\nCaptain Baird turned away. The doctor watched him.\r\n\r\n"Perhaps you will not be quite so hasty with your men\'s lives in\r\nthe future, Captain?" the doctor said.\r\n\r\nProfessor Schultz was spinning dials. "No contact," the professor\r\nsaid, "No contact at all."\r\n\r\nThat had been six months ago. Three more test rockets had been\r\nfired successfully before the urgent report came through from\r\nAlaskan Observation Post No. 4. A rocket was coming across the\r\nPole.\r\n\r\nThe strange rocket was tracked and escorted by atomic armed\r\nfighters all the way to the Rocket Testing Station where it cut\r\nits own motors and gently landed. In the center of a division of\r\natomic-armed infantry the captain, the doctor, and everyone else,\r\nwaited impatiently. There was an air of uneasiness.\r\n\r\n"You\'re sure it\'s not ours?" Captain Baird asked.\r\n\r\nThe doctor laughed. "Identical, yes, but three times the size of\r\nours.

"\r\n\r\n"Perhaps one of the Asian ones?"\r\n\r\n"No, it\'s our design, but too large, much too large."\r\n\r\nProfessor Schultz put their thoughts into words. "Looks like\r\nsomeone copied ours. Someone, somewhere. 

It\'s hard to imagine, but\r\ntrue nevertheless."\r\n\r\nThey waited two weeks. 

Nothing happened. Then a radiation-shielded\r\nteam went in to examine the rocket. Two more weeks and the strange\r\nrocket was dismantled and spread over the field of the testing\r\nstation. The rocket was dismantled and the station had begun to\r\ntalk to itself in whispers and look at the sky.\r\n\r\nCaptain Baird stood now at the window and looked out at the\r\ndismantled rocket. He looked but his mind was not on the parts of\r\nthe rocket he could see from the window.\r\n\r\n"The materials, they\'re not ours?" the captain asked.\r\n\r\n"Unknown here," the doctor said.\r\n\r\nThe captain nodded. "Those were our instruments?"\r\n\r\n"Yes." The doctor still held the whiskey bottle in a tight grip.\r\n\r\n"They sent them back," the captain said.\r\n\r\n       *     *     *     *     *\r\n\r\nThe doctor crashed the bottle hard against the desk top. "Ask it,\r\nCaptain, for God\'s sake!!"\r\n\r\nThe captain turned to face the doctor directly. "It was a man, a\r\nfull grown man."\r\n\r\nThe doctor sighed as if letting the pent-up steam of his heart\r\nescape. "Yes, it is a man. It breathes, it eats, it has all the\r\nattributes of a man. 

But it is not of our planet."\r\n\r\n"Its speech ..." the captain began.\r\n\r\n"That isn\'t speech, Captain," the doctor broke in, breaking in\r\nsharply, "It\'s only sound." The doctor stopped; he examined the\r\nlabel of his bottle of whiskey very carefully. A good brand of\r\nwhiskey. "He seems quite happy in the storeroom. You know,\r\nCaptain, what puzzled me at first? He can\'t read. He can\'t read\r\nanything, not even the instruments in that ship. In fact he shows\r\nno interest in his rocket at all."\r\n\r\nThe captain sat down now. He sat at the desk and faced the doctor.\r\n"At least _they_ had the courage to send a man, not a mouse.\r\nDoctor, a man."\r\n\r\nThe doctor stared at the captain, his hand squeezing and\r\nunsqueezing on the whiskey bottle. "A man who can\'t read his own\r\ninstruments?" The doctor laughed. "Perhaps you too have failed to\r\nsee the point? Like that stupid general who sits out there waiting\r\nfor the men from somewhere to invade?"\r\n\r\n"Don\'t you think it\'s a possibility?"\r\n\r\nThe doctor nodded. "A very good possibility, Captain, but they\r\nwill not be men." The doctor seemed to pause and lean forward.\r\n"That rocket, Captain, is a test rocket. A test rocket _just like\r\nours_!"\r\n\r\nThen the doctor picked up his whiskey bottle at last and poured\r\ntwo glasses.\r\n\r\n"Perhaps a drink, Captain?"\r\n\r\nThe captain was watching the sky outside the window.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


It may not take\r\n so long for a spaceman to learn ..._\r\n\r\nBy JOHN CORY\r\n\r\nIllustrated by Gardner\r\n\r\n\r\nNear the end of his fifteenth orbit as Greenland slipped by noiselessly\r\nbelow, he made the routine measurements that tested the operation of his\r\nspace capsule and checked the automatic instruments which would transmit\r\ntheir stored data to Earth on his next pass over Control. Everything\r\nnormal; all mechanical devices were operating perfectly.\r\n\r\nThis information didn\'t surprise him, in fact, he really didn\'t even\r\nthink about it. The previous orbits and the long simulated flights on\r\nEarth during training had made such checks routine and perfect results\r\nexpected. The capsules were developed by exhaustive testing both on the\r\nground and as empty satellites before entrusting them to carry animals\r\nand then the first human.\r\n\r\nHe returned to contemplation of the panorama passing below and above,\r\nalthough as he noted idly, above and below had lost some of their usual\r\nmeaning. Since his capsule, like all heavenly bodies, was stable in\r\nposition with respect to the entire universe and, thanks to Sir Isaac\r\nNewton and his laws, never changed, the Earth and the stars alternated\r\nover his head during each orbit. "Up" now meant whatever was in the\r\ndirection of his head. He remembered that even during his initial orbit\r\nwhen the Earth first appeared overhead he accepted the fact as normal.\r\nHe wondered if the other two had accepted it as easily.\r\n\r\nFor there had been two men hurled into orbit before he ventured into\r\nspace. Two others who had also passed the rigorous three-year training\r\nperiod and were selected on the basis of over-all performance to precede\r\nhim. 

He had known them both well and wondered again what had happened on\r\ntheir flights. 

Of course, they had both returned, depending upon what\r\nyour definition of return was. The capsules in which they had ventured\r\nbeyond Earth had returned them living. But this was to be expected, for\r\neven the considerable hazards of descent through the atmosphere and the\r\nterrible heating which occurred were successfully surmounted by the\r\ncapsule.\r\n\r\nNaturally, it had not been expected that the satellites would have to be\r\nbrought down by command from the ground. But this, too, was part of the\r\ncareful planning--radio control of the retro-rockets that move the\r\nsatellite out of orbit by reducing its velocity. Of course, ground\r\ncontrol was to be used only if the astronaut failed to ignite the\r\nretro-rockets himself. He remembered everyone\'s surprise and relief when\r\nthe first capsule was recovered and its occupant found to be alive. They\r\nhad assumed that in spite of all precautions he was dead because he had\r\nnot fired the rockets on the fiftieth orbit and it was necessary to\r\nbring him down on the sixty-fifth.\r\n\r\nRecovery alive only partially solved the mystery, for the rescuers and\r\nall others were met by a haughty, stony silence from the occupant.\r\nBatteries of tests confirmed an early diagnosis: complete and utter\r\nwithdrawal; absolute refusal to communicate. Therapy was unsuccessful.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe second attempt was similar in most respects, except that command\r\nreturn was made on the thirty-first orbit after the astronaut\'s failure\r\nto de-orbit at the end of the thirtieth. His incoherent babble of moons,\r\nstars, and worlds was no more helpful than the first.\r\n\r\nTest after test confirmed that no obvious organic damage had been\r\nincurred by exposure outside of the Earth\'s protective atmosphere.\r\nBiopsy of even selected brain tissues seemed to show that microscopic\r\ncellular changes due to prolonged weightlessness or primary cosmic-ray\r\nbombardment, which had been suggested by some authorities, were\r\nunimportant. Somewhat reluctantly, it was decided to repeat the\r\nexperiment a third time.\r\n\r\nThe launching was uneventful. He was sent into space with the precision\r\nhe expected. The experience was exhilarating and, although he had\r\nanticipated each event in advance, he could not possibly have foreseen\r\nthe overpowering feeling that came over him. Weightlessness he had\r\nexperienced for brief periods during training, but nothing could match\r\nthe heady impression of continuous freedom from gravity.\r\n\r\nEarth passing overhead was also to be expected from the simple laws of\r\ncelestial mechanics but his feeling as he watched it now was\r\ninexpressible. It occurred to him that perhaps this was indeed why he\r\nwas here, because he could appreciate such experiences best. He had been\r\ntold the stars would be bright, unblinking, and an infinitude in extent,\r\nbut could mere descriptions or photographs convey the true seeing?\r\n\r\nOn his twenty-first orbit he completed his overseeing the entire surface\r\nof the planet in daylight. He had seen more of Earth than anyone able to\r\ntell about it, but only he had the true feeling of it. The continents\r\nwere clearly visible, as were the oceans and both polar ice caps. The\r\nshapes were familiar but in only a remote way. 

A vague indistinctness\r\nborne of distance served to modify the outlines and he alone was seeing\r\nand understanding. On the dark side of the planet large cities were\r\nmarked by indistinct light areas which paled to insignificance compared\r\nto the stars and his sun.\r\n\r\nHe speculated about the others who had only briefly experienced these\r\nsights. 

Undoubtedly they weren\'t as capable of fully grasping or\r\nappreciating any of these things as he was. It was quite clear that no\r\none else but he could encompass the towering feeling of power and\r\nimportance generated by being alone in the Universe.\r\n\r\nAt the end of the twenty-fifth orbit he disabled the radio control of\r\nthe retro-rockets and sat back with satisfaction to await the next\r\ncircuit of his Earth around Him.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Astounding Science Fiction_ May 1960.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. ]\r\n\r\n\r\nCoxe, an unusually phlegmatic citizen, came to buy the new refrigerator\r\nin the usual fashion. He was looking for a bargain. It was the latest\r\nmodel, fresh from the new production line in Los Angeles, and was\r\nmarked down considerably below standard. The freezing compartment held\r\n245 lbs. of meat.\r\n\r\n"How come so cheap?" Coxe wanted to know.\r\n\r\n"Frankly," the salesman said, "I asked myself that. Usually there\'s a\r\ndent in them or something, when they have that factory tag on them. But\r\nI checked it over and I can\'t find anything wrong with it. 

However,\r\nshe goes as is."\r\n\r\n"At that price," Coxe said, "I\'ll take it."\r\n\r\nIt arrived, refinished in a copper color to his specifications, the\r\nfollowing Tuesday. 

It was plugged in and operated perfectly. He checked\r\nit out by freezing ice cubes.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWednesday evening, when he opened the door to chill some beer, there\r\nwas a package in the freezing compartment. He took out the package.\r\n\r\nIt was some sort of plastic and appeared to contain fish eggs.\r\n\r\nCoxe had not seen fresh fish eggs, considered by some a delicacy, for\r\na number of years.\r\n\r\nHe chilled the beer and fried the eggs.\r\n\r\nBoth tasted about right.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe following Friday, his girl friend came over to fix dinner for him,\r\nand when she looked in the freezing compartment, she said, "What\'s\r\nthis?"\r\n\r\n"Fish eggs," Coxe said. "How many of them?"\r\n\r\n"Two packages."\r\n\r\n"We\'ll fry them up for breakfast," he said.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nSaturday morning, there were three packages of eggs in the refrigerator.\r\n\r\n"Where do they come from?" his girl friend wanted to know.\r\n\r\n"They just appear. I ate some and they\'re very good."\r\n\r\nShe was reluctant, but he talked her into preparing a package.\r\n\r\nShe agreed they were very good.\r\n\r\n"What are you going to do about it?" she asked.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t think there\'s anything to do about it," he said. "I like fish\r\neggs."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nOn Sunday, the package they had eaten Saturday had been replaced. They\r\nwere coming in at a steady rate of one a day. Coxe cooked a package for\r\nbreakfast and took the other two to his parents.\r\n\r\nBy Tuesday, he was getting tired of the eggs, and by the end of the\r\nweek, he had four more packages. He succeeded in giving two packages to\r\nthe neighbors.\r\n\r\nAt the end of another week, he had eight packages.\r\n\r\nHe explained to his girl friend. She suggested they visit all their\r\nfriends, leaving a package with each of them.\r\n\r\nAt the end of another two weeks, this method for disposing of the eggs\r\nhad worn thin. They finally managed to give the last two packages to\r\nthe landlady.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAt the end of still another week, there were seven more packages.\r\nOtherwise, the refrigerator was a good buy.\r\n\r\nCoxe calculated that, at the present rate, had he left the packages in\r\nthe compartment, it would have been filled by the end of the month.\r\nHe felt that once that point was reached, the eggs would stop coming.\r\nShould this prove to be incorrect, he was prepared to arrange for some\r\nmethod of commercial distribution for the product.\r\n\r\nOn schedule, the eggs stopped coming.\r\n\r\nHe waited two days. No more came. It was over.\r\n\r\nHe ate the last package.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe refrigerator worked perfectly, and he began to stock it with things\r\nfreezers are conventionally stocked with.\r\n\r\nIt was almost two weeks after the last package had appeared, early one\r\nSunday morning, when the doorbell rang.\r\n\r\nAt the door was a small, nondescript man with a vaguely--and really\r\nindefinably--unpleasant aspect. His head was bandaged.\r\n\r\n"Mr. 

Coxe?" he asked.\r\n\r\n"That\'s me."\r\n\r\n"May I come in?"\r\n\r\n"Come on."\r\n\r\nThe man seated himself. "Something terrible has happened," he said. "A\r\nhorrible mistake has been made."\r\n\r\n"I\'m sorry to hear that. You look as if you were in an accident."\r\n\r\n"I was. I\'ve been in the ... hospital ... for nearly two months. But\r\nto come to the point, Mr. 

Coxe. I\'ve come about the refrigerator you\r\nrecently purchased. It was a special refrigerator that was erroneously\r\nshipped out of the plant as a second. When I didn\'t come in, it got\r\nshipped out and sold."\r\n\r\n"Good refrigerator," Coxe said.\r\n\r\n"Perhaps you\'ve noticed ... ah ... something unusual about it?"\r\n\r\n"It runs okay. For a while there were a bunch of packages of fish eggs\r\nin it."\r\n\r\n"Fish eggs!" the little man cried in horror. After he had recovered\r\nsufficiently, he asked, "You do, of course you do, I\'m sure you still\r\nhave all the ... little packages?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, no," said Coxe.\r\n\r\n"NO? Oh, my God. What did you do with them, Mr. Coxe?"\r\n\r\n"Ate them."\r\n\r\n"You ... ate ... them? Ate--? No. 

You didn\'t. Not all of them. You\r\ncouldn\'t have done that, Mr. Coxe. Please tell me that you could not\r\nhave done that."\r\n\r\n"I had to give a lot of them away, and everybody said they were\r\ndelicious. And really.... Uh, Mr.--? Mr., uh...."\r\n\r\nThe little man got unsteadily to his feet. His face was ashen. "This is\r\nhorrible, horrible." He stumbled to the door. 

"You are a fiend. All our\r\nwork ... all our plans ... and you, you...." He turned to Coxe. "I hate\r\nyou. 

Oh, I hate you."\r\n\r\n"Now, see here."\r\n\r\n"... 

Mr. Coxe, you\'ll never realize the enormity of your crime. _You\'ve\r\neaten all of us!_" With that, he slammed the door and was gone.\r\n\r\nCoxe went back to the other room.\r\n\r\n"Who was it, honey?"\r\n\r\n"Ah, some nut. Seems he had first claim on the refrigerator."\r\n\r\n"I\'ll bet it was about the fish eggs."\r\n\r\n"Yeah, he wanted them.

"\r\n\r\n"Oh, dear. Do you think he can do anything to us?"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t think so, not now. It\'s too late," Coxe concluded. "We ate\r\nthem all."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                They didn\'t have to worry about a thing\r\n                for the rest of their natural lives....\r\n\r\n\r\nJames Ypsilanti swung at the door with the steak cuber. Or was it\r\nthe cube steaker? No matter. The door was a good, hardwood door and\r\nresisted his onslaught well. But time was on his side.\r\n\r\nHe had the energy and the time, he knew, and sooner or later the door\r\nwould be kindling.\r\n\r\nIt was the door to his room. It was evident to him that he did not need\r\nthe door to his room and that he _did_ need heat. In fact he had better\r\nget some heat pretty soon--although he was keeping warm enough for the\r\npresent by beating on the door. So he would beat this door to kindling,\r\nand then he would build a nice, cozy fire in the hall that would keep\r\nhim warm for a long time ... if he was stingy with his fuel.\r\n\r\nThe carpenter came by. The carpenter was always coming by, except when\r\nyou wanted him, Jim realized. The carpenter was a mighty, mighty busy\r\nfellow.\r\n\r\nThe carpenter stopped short when he saw Jim demolishing the door. In\r\nfact he came to a grinding halt.\r\n\r\n"Jim, why didn\'t you tell me!"\r\n\r\n"Carpenter, how was I to know where you were? Who can ever find you?"\r\n\r\n"I know Jim. 

Jim, you work so hard!"\r\n\r\n"Yes!" he said, pounding.\r\n\r\n"Take this hatchet, Jim. A hatchet is what you demolish doors with!\r\nGood-by." The carpenter departed.\r\n\r\nJames Ypsilanti swung on the door with his newly acquired hatchet. Soon\r\nhe was ready for his fire. He struck a match, and in no time had the\r\npile of varnished kindling blazing smokily in the hall. He held his\r\nhands over the blaze.\r\n\r\n"Ah, good, good. Good." 

He closed his eyes. "What could be better than\r\nthis?" Then he opened them again regretfully. "It\'s dinner time. I\'d\r\nbetter fix it while I have my fire going." He hurried to the kitchen\r\nand chose a can of eggs-bacon-and-pancakes from the massive stores.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nOpening the large can, he heated it over his hall fire. Then he dumped\r\nthe contents on his tin plate and ate.\r\n\r\n"Murder," he thought somberly. "That\'s what I\'m in for. 

Practically\r\nmurder with consent. She said she couldn\'t live without me. Margie\r\nbegged me to kill her, you might as well say. Good old Margie; a good\r\nkid, but I killed her. And now.... Well, that\'s life!" He speared a\r\npancake.\r\n\r\n"Damn, but it\'s _cold_!" He threw an armload of wood on the fire and it\r\nblazed up. "Sure wish these carpenters had feelings. My lord, they got\r\nno feelings at all!"\r\n\r\nThe carpenter arrived with a new hardwood door. Whistling cheerily, he\r\nbegan to install it where the other one had just been hatcheted away.\r\n\r\n"Carpenter, that door won\'t be staying there long. I\'m almost out of\r\nfuel."\r\n\r\n"I hope you don\'t expect me to be surprised, Jim, if this door doesn\'t\r\nlast very long. The previous twenty-two doors at this location,\r\nJim, did not last very long either." Still whistling to himself, he\r\ninstalled the last of the hinge screws.\r\n\r\n"Why don\'t you just _give_ me the doors, instead of causing yourself\r\nall this work?" demanded James Ypsilanti.\r\n\r\n"\'Inmates will not be issued materials,\' Jim. I\'ve quoted that section\r\nof the rules to you many times, Jim."\r\n\r\n"But couldn\'t you just _lean_ the door up against the door jamb and\r\nleave it?" argued the inmate. "You go to a ridiculous amount of\r\ntrouble."\r\n\r\n"It is not ridiculous, Jim. I am a carpenter, Jim. 

Good-by."\r\n\r\nAfter lunch, James Ypsilanti crawled into his escape tunnel.\r\n\r\nHe liked to go in there every day and daydream. The tunnel ended\r\nabortively at the wall of the prison, for the prison wall extended down\r\ninto solid bed rock for a meter, and it was fabricated of one-meter\r\nthick compressed steel. It was the nearest thing to an exit that the\r\nprison had.\r\n\r\nOfficials had always come and gone through the massive, englobing wall\r\nby matter transmitters. "Smarties couldn\'t find me though, when I was\r\nin my escape tunnel," he chortled, as he stretched out in the cave\r\nunder the concrete. "They can walk through walls, but they couldn\'t\r\nfind _me_." Then his tone became baleful. 

"The smarties\'ll never find\r\nme."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAs James Ypsilanti chopped on the door next day, the carpenter stood\r\ncheerily watching.\r\n\r\n"Carpenter, why don\'t you fix the damn heating plant? Then I wouldn\'t\r\nhave to be chopping up your doors all the time to keep warm."\r\n\r\n"I am a carpenter, Jim, not a heat-plant fixer, as you well know from\r\nour previous negotiations on the subject."\r\n\r\n"What will you do, carpenter, when I have used up all your doors?" the\r\nconvict jibed.\r\n\r\n"Why, Jim, we will have to send out for some more," the carpenter\r\nanswered condescendingly.\r\n\r\n"Still, I wish you would let _me_ work on that heat plant," urged\r\nYpsilanti. "I might fix it."\r\n\r\n"\'Inmates will not be permitted to disassemble or otherwise interfere\r\nwith the machinery of the institution,\'" quoted the carpenter. "Need I\r\nsay more, Jim?"\r\n\r\n"Okay," said James Ypsilanti, resuming his destructive work on the new\r\ndoor. "Scram, stupid." The carpenter departed.\r\n\r\n"That dope," Jim said between blows, "is even foggier in the head than\r\nmy lousy lawyer was, and that\'s going some."\r\n\r\n"Jim," said the carpenter, returning and sounding very pleased with\r\nhimself, "look here at what I have found, Jim."\r\n\r\nJames Ypsilanti turned to look at what the carpenter held in his hand.\r\nIt was a carpenter\'s square sheathed in plastic.\r\n\r\n"Found enough of them to last me a lifetime, Jim," said the carpenter\r\ncomplacently. "I\'ll never have to buy any.

"\r\n\r\n"No, you won\'t," agreed James Ypsilanti bitterly. "Can\'t you get it\r\ninto your head that you and I are the only ones left on Earth? After\r\nthe war the rest left. They couldn\'t _find_ us when they evacuated this\r\natomic-explosion wrecked planet, because we were in this escape-proof\r\njug. So they went away and _left_ us!

"\r\n\r\n"I know, Jim."\r\n\r\nYpsilanti studied the mobile features of the carpenter, searching\r\nintently for a sign.\r\n\r\nBut the carpenter robot strolled away, whistling.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


"If it is favorable, there is certain technical aid\r\naboard ship which will be made available to you at once. 

Of course, you\r\nwill not receive advanced equipment from the Solar Council until there\r\nis a more thorough investigation."\r\n\r\n"I\'m afraid our culture is too simple and agrarian to win your\r\napproval," said Saranta modestly.\r\n\r\n"That isn\'t a major consideration. The Council understands the\r\ndifficulties that have faced colonies in other star systems. Pulling a plow is hard work for a man."\r\n\r\n"But you were able to solve this situation in a humanitarian way?" asked\r\nTardo, peering at him keenly. 

"That is to say, you didn\'t resort to\r\nslavery?"\r\n\r\nSaranta smiled and spread his hands slightly.\r\n\r\n"Does this look like a slave society to you?" he countered. "The\r\ncolonists were anxious to co-operate to make the planet liveable. No one\r\nobjected to work."\r\n\r\n"It\'s true we\'ve seen no slaves, that we know about," said Tardo. "\r\n\r\nTardo laughed.\r\n\r\n"A carry-over from Earth, no doubt," he commented. "An unusual one, too,\r\nfor a culture without technology."\r\n\r\nWhen the meal was over, the two men from the ship were conducted on a\r\ntour of the area. It was a neat agricultural community, with broad\r\nfields, well-constructed buildings and, a short distance from Saranta\'s\r\ncastle-like home, a village in which artisans and craftsmen plied their\r\npeaceful trades.\r\n\r\nPeo tried to notice what he thought Tardo would look for on such a short\r\ninspection. The Council agent, he knew, had had intensive training and\r\nmany years of experience. It was hard for Peo to judge what factors\r\nTardo would consider significant--probably very minor ones that the\r\naverage man would not notice, he thought.\r\n\r\nTardo had seemed most intent on the question of slavery, and Peo looked\r\nfor signs of it. He could see none. 

The people of the planet had had\r\ntime to conceal some things, of course. But the people they saw in the\r\nvillage wore a proud air of independence no slave could assume.\r\n\r\nSaranta apologized for their having to walk, explaining that there was\r\nno other means of transportation on the planet.\r\n\r\n"And, without transportation, you can understand why we have not been\r\nable to develop a technology," he added. "We hope transport will be\r\nincluded in the first assistance you will give us."\r\n\r\nTardo asked about the fields.\r\n\r\n"I see there is no one working them," he said. "The laborers who will work our fields--for a wage, of\r\ncourse--are probably in the next town or the one beyond it now."\r\n\r\nAlpha Persei was sinking in the western sky when Tardo and Peo took\r\ntheir leave of Saranta and made their way down the road toward their\r\nplanetary landing craft.\r\n\r\n"It looks like a good world to me," said Peo. "If tomorrow\'s inspection\r\nis as satisfactory, I suppose you will recommend the beginning of\r\ntechnical aid?"\r\n\r\n"There will be no inspection tour tomorrow, and I shall recommend\r\nagainst aid at this time," replied Tardo. "I\'ve seen enough."\r\n\r\n"Why?" asked Peo, surprised.\r\n\r\n"There are two classes of people on this planet, and we\'ve seen only\r\none," said Tardo. "Those we have seen are freemen. The others are no\r\nbetter than animals. "\r\n\r\n"The evidence is well hidden. But if you think your stomach can take it\r\nnow, I\'ll tell you. This would be a\r\n"green light" customer--a first-time prospect, and three blinks\r\nindicated a very difficult individual. Anson quickly practiced his\r\nmost beguiling smile.\r\n\r\n"Welcome to Tracy\'s Roboid Department," he said, enthusiastically, as\r\nthe elevator doors slid open. His practiced smile was just right.\r\n\r\nHe quickly noted the man\'s conservative dress, the flaming red tie.\r\nAggressive type, Anson decided. A shock of red hair that didn\'t want\r\nto lie down hinted that he was stubborn as well.\r\n\r\n"Heard you\'ve got a sale on robots," Red-tie said, challengingly, as\r\nhe stepped aside for his wife.\r\n\r\nThe woman who stepped off the elevator smiled, showing a lovely\r\ndimple, and Anson beamed on her. The tiny flake of a hat perched atop\r\nher auburn hair reminded Anson of the comb on a Rhode Island Red.\r\n\r\n"Not robots, sir," Anson corrected diplomatically. "The Plasti-Cast\r\nRoboid is not exactly a robot."\r\n\r\n"Well, anyhow, trot one out, and let\'s see what it looks like.\r\nMillicent will never be satisfied until she\'s seen one of the things."\r\nHe glared dramatically in the general direction of his wife, who\r\npretended not to notice.\r\n\r\nAnson led them into the Gray Room. He mentally went over the\r\napplicable rule: _Rule 23; Always introduce the marked-down\r\nmerchandise first. It may provide the customer with an incentive for\r\nbuying something better._\r\n\r\n"These are last year\'s models," he said, with just the right flavor\r\nof distaste in his voice. "Of course, you may expect a slight\r\nreduction ... a small percentage...."\r\n\r\nRed-tie was muttering. "Damned mechanical things, full of wheels and\r\nwires. What\'s to keep \'em from running amok and killing us all!

"\r\n\r\n"But dear, they don\'t have wheels anymore," protested the woman,\r\ntimidly. Her face was pretty, Anson decided, but it was obvious that\r\nthe man would be the deciding factor in this sale.\r\n\r\nHe made a mental note: _Rule 31: Pick the individual of a family group\r\nwho seems to hold the deciding voice, and SELL!_ He remembered a\r\nportion of a sales talk he had memorized a few days before, and took\r\nit up, almost chanting:\r\n\r\n"... our Roboids are grown, much as crystals are grown, in great vats\r\nin New Chicago. A Plasti-Cast Roboid is guaranteed...."\r\n\r\n"A fat chance we\'d have of collecting the guarantee if we were chopped\r\ninto mincemeat," Red-tie interrupted, shuddering slightly as the\r\nimplication of his own words hit him.\r\n\r\nAnson felt a moment of panic as he failed to remember an applicable\r\nrule from the Salesman\'s Guide, but it formed in his mind at the last\r\nmoment: _Rule 18: Never argue with a customer--change the subject._\r\n\r\n"Why don\'t you come with me to the Green Room?" he asked. 

"The very\r\nlatest models are on display." He walked slowly at first, then more\r\nquickly as the couple allowed themselves to be led. He slid his hand\r\nnear a hidden switch in the archway, and floodlights came on just as\r\nthey entered.\r\n\r\nThe woman uttered a little squeal of delight at the sight of a very\r\nhandsome figure dressed in a cutaway, standing in an attitude of\r\nservice.\r\n\r\n"Oh!" she breathed dreamily. "He would make such a wonderful butler."\r\n\r\n"Well, wind him up and let\'s see what he\'ll do," growled the man, his\r\nface florid in the colored light of the Green Room.\r\n\r\n"I\'m so very sorry," Anson said, slightly flustered, remembering that\r\nthis was always the crucial moment in a sale. "The Roboid cannot be\r\nactivated for demonstration purposes."\r\n\r\n"What?" roared Red-tie, incredulously. "Do you mean to say you want me\r\nto buy the damned thing without knowing whether it ticks or not?"\r\n\r\nAnson tried desperately to remember the best rule for such an answer,\r\nbut failed. He plunged desperately into his own explanation.\r\n\r\n"You see, our Roboids are matched to your family personality at the\r\ntime of purchase, and activated then. We cannot erase a personality\r\nonce it has been transferred to their sensitive minds." He saw the\r\ndisbelieving smirk on the man\'s mouth and felt that the sale was\r\nindeed lost. But he plunged on, desperately.\r\n\r\n"They\'re very economical. They don\'t require any upkeep, like food.\r\nWhen they become tired they will sit or lie down near an electric\r\noutlet and plug in a power cord, and in a few minutes they are as\r\nrested and tireless as...."\r\n\r\n"Bosh!" Red-tie retorted. 

"I\'ve heard enough. Come, Millicent, we\r\nstill have time to try Bonn\'s new Helio-rotor. At least they\'ll give\r\nus a demonstration.

"\r\n\r\nAnson escorted them to the Magna-lift. He felt better as he recalled\r\nthe last rule in the Guide, the one that seemed to cover the situation\r\nso well: _Rule 50: If they balk because of the no-demonstration rule,\r\nlet them go. Remember\r\nthe First Law?"\r\n\r\n"Center!"\r\n\r\n"We\'re marooned in the Twentieth Century. You have to accept it.

"\r\n\r\n"But what will we _do_?" Kial\'s mind was reeling again.\r\n\r\n"Since we\'ve already broken the First Law," Broyk said, "we may just as\r\nwell break the Second: \'No Thek-traveler may enter the body of a native\r\nof a foreign space-time ...\'"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe young lovers kissed again and this time there seemed to be an added\r\nzest, even to their passionate embrace.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _If Worlds of Science Fiction_ May\r\n    1953.
