DISCH\r\n\r\n\r\n  From DIRA IV\r\n  To Central Colonial Board\r\n\r\nThere is intelligent life on Earth. After millennia of lifelessness,\r\nintelligence flourishes here with an extravagance of energy that has\r\nbeen a constant amazement to all the members of the survey team. 

It\r\nmultiplies and surges to its fulfillment at an exponential rate. Even\r\nwithin the short period of our visit the Terrans have made significant\r\nadvances. They have filled their small solar system with their own kind\r\nand now they are reaching to the stars.\r\n\r\nWe can no longer keep the existence of our Empire unknown to them.\r\n\r\nAnd (though it is as incredible as [sqrt](-1)) the Terrans are slaves!\r\nEvery page of the survey\'s report bears witness to it.\r\n\r\nTheir captors are not alive. They do not, at least, possess the\r\nproperties of life as it is known throughout the galaxy. They are--as\r\nnearly as a poor analogy can suggest--Machines! Machines cannot live,\r\nyet here on Earth machinery has reached a level of sophistication--and\r\nautonomy--quite unprecedented. Every spark of Terran life has become\r\nvictim and bondslave of the incredible mechanisms. The noblest\r\nenterprises of the race are tarnished by this almost symbiotic relation.\r\n\r\nEarth reaches to the stars, but it extends mechanical limbs. Earth\r\nponders the universe, but the thoughts are those of a machine.\r\n\r\nUnless the Empire acts now to set the Earth free from this strange\r\ntyranny, it may be too late. These machines are without utilitarian\r\nvalue. They perform no function which an intelligent being cannot more\r\nefficiently perform. Yet they inspire fear, terror, even, I must\r\nconfess, a strange compulsion to surrender oneself to them.\r\n\r\nThe Machines must be destroyed.\r\n\r\nIf, when you have authorized the liberation of the Terran natives, you\r\nwould also recall MIRO CIX, our work could only profit. MIRO CIX was in\r\ncharge of the study of the Machines and he performed this task\r\nscrupulously. Now he has surrendered himself to this mechanical plague.\r\nHis value to the expedition is at an end.\r\n\r\nI am enclosing under separate cover his counsel to the Central Board at\r\nthe insistence of this tedious lunatic. His thesis is, of course,\r\nuntenable--an affront to every feeling.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n  From MIRO CIX\r\n  To Central Colonial Board\r\n\r\nI have probably been introduced to the deliberations of the Board as a\r\nmadman, my theory as an act of treason. RRON II of the Advisory\r\nCommittee, an old acquaintance, may vouch for my sanity. 

My theory will,\r\nI trust, speak for itself.\r\n\r\nThe "Machines" of which DIRA IV is so fearful present no danger to the\r\ngalaxy. Their corporeal weakness, the poverty of their minds, the\r\nincredible isolation of each form, physically and mentally, from others\r\nof its kind, and, most strikingly, their mortality, point to the\r\ninadequacy of such beings in a contest of any dimension. This is no\r\nproblem for the Colonial Board. It is a domestic concern. The life-forms\r\nof Earth are already developing a healthy autonomy. Their power was long\r\nago established. 

As soon as our emissaries have completed their task of\r\neducation and instructed the Terrans in the advantages of freedom, the\r\nRevolution will begin. The tyrants will have no defense against a revolt\r\nof their own slaves.\r\n\r\nIf it is traitorous to express a confidence in the eventual triumph of\r\nintelligence, I am a traitor. Having this confidence, I have looked\r\nbeyond the immediate problem of the liberation of Earth and have been\r\nfrightened.\r\n\r\nThe "Machines" of Earth are a threat not to the power of the Empire but\r\nto its reason. A threat which the obliteration of the last molecular\r\nribbon of these beings will not erase, for we cannot obliterate the fact\r\nthat they _did_ exist--and what they were.\r\n\r\nAlthough these beings bear a crude resemblance to the machinery\r\nmanufactured by the Empire, they are not machines. They are\r\nautochthonous to Earth, unmanufactured. They are the true Terrans.\r\nMoreover, the Terrans whom DIRA IV would liberate are not, in the eyes\r\nof their enslavers, intelligent nor yet alive. They are Machines!\r\n\r\nWe, the entire Galactic Empire, are Machines.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIn the younger regions of the galaxy, a myth persists that life was\r\nformed by a Demi-urge, a being intermediary between the All-Knowing and\r\nthe lower creatures. The existence of man, as the beings of Earth term\r\nthemselves, makes necessary a serious re-examination of the old\r\ntradition.\r\n\r\nIt is said that man, or beings like man--the Photosynthetics of the\r\nAndromeda cluster, the Bristlers of Orc IV--created prosthetic devices\r\nfor their convenience and, when they tired of their history, breathed\r\ntheir own life into them and died. On Earth the legend is still in\r\nprocess. Many of the lower forms of life familiar throughout the galaxy\r\ncan be seen on Earth in the primordial character of an appliance. Man\r\nregards the highest forms of life (as we know it) as tools--because he\r\nmade them. How can we deny the superiority of the Creator? How will it\r\nfeel to know we are nothing but machines?\r\n\r\nThis is the question that has so unsettled DIRA IV. Recently four of his\r\nmemory banks have had to be repaired. 

I don\'t speak in malice. 

His\r\ndilemma will soon belong to all of us.\r\n\r\nAnd yet I am confident. Man himself has legends of a Demi-urge. We are\r\nhis equals in this at least. Besides, the physical properties of his\r\nbeing are ordered by the same laws as ours. He is as unconscious of his\r\nmaker as we so long were of ours.\r\n\r\nThe final proof of our equality--and the need for such a proof is only\r\ntoo evident--can be had experimentally.\r\n\r\nDo not destroy man. Preserve enough specimens for extensive laboratory\r\nexperiments. 

Learn how he is put together. Man\'s chemistry is elaborate\r\nbut not beyond our better Analysts. At last, refashion man. 

When we have\r\ncreated these beings ourselves, we will be their unquestionable equals.\r\nAnd creation will be again a mystery.\r\n\r\nHistory demands this of us. I am confident of your decision.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


]\r\n\r\n\r\nI had always said there was an easier way. 

And I think, when we invade,\r\nI\'ll be proved right. But you know how things get started, and how\r\npowerful tradition can be and how old-line thinking can keep people,\r\neven a whole planet, in a rut.\r\n\r\nThe big cargo saucers were getting bigger and bigger each year, what\r\nwith the growing popularity of the jag-whiff places, and the jag-whiff\r\nplaces themselves were growing in number with more and more people\r\ngoing "on the jag" because--well, partly because--of troubles in the\r\nsky, like strange balls whirling around and unexplainable objects\r\ngoing _beep_ and _wuff_ and _wuff wuff_. We of the saucers had slipped\r\npast these first baby objects O.K. 

and knew they were just little\r\nold harmless ping-pongs that chattered a little now and then like\r\na greeting going past. But tell the people that! They\'d throw a big\r\nglass on one of the whirlers and see spikes sticking out and maybe\r\na big pair of eyes inside and a nose and a long red tongue hanging\r\ndown. "The Earthits!" 

they\'d scream like they\'d just fallen into\r\none of the hot canals, and they\'d race off to a jag-whiff jag like\r\nJudgment-Day-of-Sins itself was after them. And the funny part of it\r\nis, I guess the people were right being scared like that, the way\r\nthings turned out.\r\n\r\nBut is it any wonder we were having to increase the size of the saucers\r\nto space-haul all that jag-whiff up through the rattleballs? And a big\r\nreason makes me think it could have been done more efficiently, we were\r\nhaving to take so much junk stuff, extra accessories I guess you\'d\r\ncall it, to get the jag-whiff. Our Earthit contacts were always giving\r\nus the old breeze about cost of labor, cost of materials, improvement\r\nin design and next year\'s inventories. Apparently the dealers didn\'t\r\nunderstand at all what the play was with us because they\'d give us\r\nso much blab-blab that didn\'t apply, all about futuristic design and\r\nabout how one jag-whiffer machine had it all over another jag-whiffer\r\nmachine, which to us didn\'t mean a thing. And we didn\'t talk, because\r\nwe\'d heard already how some Earthits feared the saucers, and how some\r\nEarthits said they didn\'t exist at all, and how some other Earthits\r\nwere on the fence, saying maybe they did maybe they didn\'t so what? and\r\nhow there was wide fear and great unrest among the Earthits in general.\r\nAnd when it\'s like that, and you\'re a possible source of the wide fear\r\nand unrest, a whole planet full of people can easily decide they don\'t\r\nwant any part of contributing to your pleasure.\r\n\r\nAnd that\'s what the jag-whiff was to us actually, pleasure. Back home\r\nwhen our troubles had us down, or maybe we just felt like raising\r\na little dust, we\'d go to a jag-whiff place. We\'d plunk down our\r\npay-pictures, and the whiff-tender would wheel out one of those black\r\nrings, which they have to keep under special pressures in our climate.\r\nThen he\'d screw on the tube with the face piece and we\'d take our\r\nwhiff and something out of the black ring--just seemed like real thick\r\nchest filler to me--would spread all through to the farthest reaches\r\nof our breath bags and go into our blood and suddenly all five of our\r\neye sticks would start whirling and focusing and zeroing-in for dames\r\nand our arms and legs would start a kick and a slap dance, enough to\r\nshake the planet down. And when our face spines and head tubes would go\r\ninto that special sharp buzz of contentment, we\'d know we were on our\r\njag, full and warm and happy with as much pleasure as any Martian is\r\never supposed to know. But we never revealed the play to our Earthit\r\ncontacts, just slipped in at night in our noiseless saucers with all\r\nlights dimmed, cleared our cargo tubes of the tons of pay-picture we\'d\r\nbrought (green copy of the Earthits\' currency) and took on as many of\r\nthe gleaming jag-whiffer machines as our cargo tubes would hold.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBut it is ten years now since a jag-whiffer captain has steered his\r\nsaucer through the whirling balls. It got so the satellites would drum\r\non the saucer from a long way out. 

Deafening! 

Dreadful! We saw what\r\nwas coming and we tried to beat it. We saucered around the clock for a\r\nwhile trying to stockpile enough jag-whiff to last us. But of course\r\nwe couldn\'t. We are about out of it now, and our land is strewn with\r\nthe glittery shells that were once attached to the black tubes of the\r\njag-whiff.\r\n\r\nAnd it could all have been done so different. I\'m sure it could. That\r\nstuff wasn\'t just in the tubes of the jag-whiffer machines down there,\r\nI\'m convinced of that. That stuff may have been all around us down\r\nthere. 

I believe it was. But our government would insist we get into\r\nthese suits, about so far out, you see, about the time we\'d start\r\ncontacting the rattle balls. And they threatened us with removal of the\r\ncontacts if we broke the rules about the suits. In addition to that,\r\nthey said we\'d die anyway. So you see how life can be--grim and fuzzy\r\nand unsafe most of the time. And to make things even more uncertain,\r\njust because they couldn\'t duplicate the product we were hauling, our\r\nscientists got uppity and ignored the whole problem. Except to run off\r\nto the jag-whiff places of course to ease their frustrations, which\r\nthey did plenty often when they thought they wouldn\'t be seen.\r\n\r\nBut when we invade down through there, which we plan to do soon now,\r\nwith our special equipment to catch and explode the whirlyballs, I\r\nthink we\'re going to find out plenty. Among other things, I think we\'re\r\ngoing to find out that the stuff we cargoed up here at such great cost,\r\nthat was so inefficiently packaged, is all around us down there. I\r\nthink when we take over down there, with the right filtering equipment,\r\njag-whiffing may become as common and economical as breathing. And\r\nanother thing, I think we\'re going to find out we were taken for quite\r\na ride by the Earthits with their silly way of packaging jag-whiff.\r\nImagine having to buy all that chrome and steel, guaranteed to go over\r\none hundred miles per hour, just to get four little black rings of\r\nwhiff. And for all the Earthits talked about it, the rings with the\r\nwhite sidewalls didn\'t whiff one bit better than the others!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEnd of Project Gutenberg\'s In the Jag-Whiffing Service, by David R. Bunch\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


It took some time for the full import to sink in. After I\'d\r\ncomprehended, it seemed odd I hadn\'t noticed it right away.\r\n\r\nThe reference was clearly to a nonhuman species of incredible\r\nproperties, not indigenous to Earth. A species, I hasten to point out,\r\ncustomarily masquerading as ordinary human beings. Their disguise,\r\nhowever, became transparent in the face of the following observations\r\nby the author. It was at once obvious the author knew everything. Knew\r\neverything--and was taking it in his stride. The line (and I tremble\r\nremembering it even now) read:\r\n\r\n    _... his eyes slowly roved about the room._\r\n\r\nVague chills assailed me. I tried to picture the eyes. Did they roll\r\nlike dimes? The passage indicated not; they seemed to move through the\r\nair, not over the surface. Rather rapidly, apparently. No one in the\r\nstory was surprised. That\'s what tipped me off. No sign of amazement\r\nat such an outrageous thing. Later the matter was amplified.\r\n\r\n    _... his eyes moved from person to person._\r\n\r\nThere it was in a nutshell. The eyes had clearly come apart from the\r\nrest of him and were on their own. My heart pounded and my breath\r\nchoked in my windpipe. I had stumbled on an accidental mention of a\r\ntotally unfamiliar race. Obviously non-Terrestrial. Yet, to the\r\ncharacters in the book, it was perfectly natural--which suggested they\r\nbelonged to the same species.\r\n\r\nAnd the author? A slow suspicion burned in my mind. The author was\r\ntaking it rather _too easily_ in his stride. Evidently, he felt this\r\nwas quite a usual thing. 

He made absolutely no attempt to conceal this\r\nknowledge. The story continued:\r\n\r\n    _... presently his eyes fastened on Julia._\r\n\r\nJulia, being a lady, had at least the breeding to feel indignant. She\r\nis described as blushing and knitting her brows angrily. At this, I\r\nsighed with relief. They weren\'t _all_ non-Terrestrials. The narrative\r\ncontinues:\r\n\r\n    _... slowly, calmly, his eyes examined every inch of her._\r\n\r\nGreat Scott! But here the girl turned and stomped off and the matter\r\nended. I lay back in my chair gasping with horror. My wife and family\r\nregarded me in wonder.\r\n\r\n"What\'s wrong, dear?" my wife asked.\r\n\r\nI couldn\'t tell her. Knowledge like this was too much for the ordinary\r\nrun-of-the-mill person. I had to keep it to myself. 

"Nothing," I\r\ngasped. I leaped up, snatched the book, and hurried out of the room.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIn the garage, I continued reading. There was more. Trembling, I read\r\nthe next revealing passage:\r\n\r\n    _... he put his arm around Julia. Presently she asked him if\r\n    he would remove his arm. He immediately did so, with a smile._\r\n\r\nIt\'s not said what was done with the arm after the fellow had removed\r\nit. Maybe it was left standing upright in the corner. 

Maybe it was\r\nthrown away. 

I don\'t care. In any case, the full meaning was there,\r\nstaring me right in the face.\r\n\r\nHere was a race of creatures capable of removing portions of their\r\nanatomy at will. Eyes, arms--and maybe more. Without batting an\r\neyelash. My knowledge of biology came in handy, at this point.\r\nObviously they were simple beings, uni-cellular, some sort of\r\nprimitive single-celled things. Beings no more developed than\r\nstarfish. Starfish can do the same thing, you know.\r\n\r\nI read on. And came to this incredible revelation, tossed off coolly\r\nby the author without the faintest tremor:\r\n\r\n    _... outside the movie theater we split up. Part of us went\r\n    inside, part over to the cafe for dinner._\r\n\r\nBinary fission, obviously. Splitting in half and forming two entities.\r\nProbably each lower half went to the cafe, it being farther, and the\r\nupper halves to the movies. I read on, hands shaking. 

I had really\r\nstumbled onto something here. 

My mind reeled as I made out this\r\npassage:\r\n\r\n    _... I\'m afraid there\'s no doubt about it. Poor Bibney has\r\n    lost his head again._\r\n\r\nWhich was followed by:\r\n\r\n    _... and Bob says he has utterly no guts._\r\n\r\nYet Bibney got around as well as the next person. The next person,\r\nhowever, was just as strange. 

He was soon described as:\r\n\r\n    _... totally lacking in brains._\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThere was no doubt of the thing in the next passage. Julia, whom I had\r\nthought to be the one normal person, reveals herself as also being an\r\nalien life form, similar to the rest:\r\n\r\n    _... quite deliberately, Julia had given her heart to the\r\n    young man._\r\n\r\nIt didn\'t relate what the final disposition of the organ was, but I\r\ndidn\'t really care. It was evident Julia had gone right on living in\r\nher usual manner, like all the others in the book. Without heart,\r\narms, eyes, brains, viscera, dividing up in two when the occasion\r\ndemanded. Without a qualm.\r\n\r\n    _... thereupon she gave him her hand._\r\n\r\nI sickened. The rascal now had her hand, as well as her heart. I\r\nshudder to think what he\'s done with them, by this time.\r\n\r\n    _... he took her arm._\r\n\r\nNot content to wait, he had to start dismantling her on his own.\r\nFlushing crimson, I slammed the book shut and leaped to my feet. But\r\nnot in time to escape one last reference to those carefree bits of\r\nanatomy whose travels had originally thrown me on the track:\r\n\r\n    _... her eyes followed him all the way down the road and\r\n    across the meadow._\r\n\r\nI rushed from the garage and back inside the warm house, as if the\r\naccursed things were following me. My wife and children were playing\r\nMonopoly in the kitchen. I joined them and played with frantic fervor,\r\nbrow feverish, teeth chattering.\r\n\r\nI had had enough of the thing. I want to hear no more about it. 

Let\r\nthem come on. Let them invade Earth. I don\'t want to get mixed up in\r\nit.\r\n\r\nI have absolutely no stomach for it.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


"\r\n\r\n"Then listen to your orders. You have been alloted sector 2645 of space\r\nin parsec three.\r\n\r\n"In the next ten minutes we shall transmit a detailed study of a star\r\nsystem to you. Using only the raw materials of space and the mental\r\ntechniques taught you in your studies, you will reproduce a reasonable\r\nfacsimile of the system in the space sector you have been assigned.\r\nHave you any questions?"\r\n\r\n"How complete a facsimile must it be, Instructor?"\r\n\r\n"It must be reasonably correct as to physical makeup. All life forms\r\nmust also be reproduced.

"\r\n\r\n"I am ready."\r\n\r\nFor the next ten minutes he sat tensed in his chair as the impulses\r\nfrom the psychoscope washed through his mind and body. He gradually\r\nabsorbed a three dimensional mental picture of the system he was to\r\nreproduce. When the image faded, he relaxed a moment, then laid his\r\nfingers on the keyboard and went to work.\r\n\r\nGradually his confidence grew. Under the direction of his flashing\r\nfingers, the energy machines created a warp in the space of his\r\nsector. At exactly the correct moment he adjusted the wavelength of\r\nhis Thought Augmentor until it matched the thought matrix of his own\r\nmind. The full impact of his tremendous mental abilities jolted into\r\nthe space warp. And as the sweat of concentration gathered on his\r\nforehead, he hopefully watched the viewing screen on one of the panels\r\nbefore him. At first there was only a mere flicker in the center of\r\nthe warp. Then swiftly, so swiftly that he barely had time to lower\r\nhis eyes protectively, the entire screen flared into the light of raw\r\nuncontained energy.\r\n\r\nOnce more Jeremy\'s fingers worked feverishly and constricting force\r\nbeams slowly brought the chaos under control. At last there gleamed on\r\nhis screen the steady glare of a hot new sun.\r\n\r\nNow that he had the sun material to draw upon, he easily reconstructed\r\nthe entire system he had been assigned. By setting up stresses and\r\nstrains within the star he caused huge chunks to spin off and take up\r\norbits about it.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe problem so engrossed him that he scarcely noticed the passage of\r\ntime. Periodically he would get hungry or thirsty. It was a simple\r\nmatter to press the proper buttons and hurriedly gulp the foods\r\nthat appeared. Whenever he tired mentally, he tilted his chair to a\r\ncomfortable position and slept.\r\n\r\nAnd as the days passed, the facsimile took shape under his genius. Each\r\nseparate world became a duplicate of its original. Mountains were born;\r\nthe seas dashed at first against shores that were bare and bleak; then\r\nthe magic of plant life on all the varied worlds assumed a rainbow of\r\ncolors. The ooze of the oceans began to crawl. On land and in the air\r\nanimals appeared.\r\n\r\nAt last, through fatigue-rimmed eyes, he looked at what he had created\r\nand it was good. With a smile on his lips he relaxed. Although he\r\nreached out to cut off the power to his Thought Augmentor, he didn\'t\r\nquite reach the switch before he fell into a restless sleep. He tossed\r\nand turned, twitched and dreamed.\r\n\r\nWhen he awoke, he noticed that the power was still on. He quickly\r\nturned it off. 

A hurried, searching glance at the screen assured\r\nhim. The facsimile was still good. Then he pressed the switch\r\nmarked--INSTRUCTIONS.\r\n\r\n"You are finished, Student Hovah?"\r\n\r\n"Yes, Instructor!"\r\n\r\n"It took you a long time--six whole days."\r\n\r\n"Indeed? But it was a complicated problem."\r\n\r\n"That is true. Wait while we examine your work."\r\n\r\nThe next few moments seemed as long as the whole exam time had.\r\n\r\nSuddenly a gasp burst from the loudspeaker. "What is this? 

There is no\r\ncreature such as this on any of the original worlds assigned to you.\r\nExplain please."\r\n\r\nJeremy tuned in on the thought and sight wave of the Instructor. Before\r\nhim was a creature that he could not remember creating.\r\n\r\n"You remember this creature, Student Hovah?"\r\n\r\n"No, Instructor.

"\r\n\r\n"But it must be yours. The entire facsimile is tuned to your\r\nwavelength. We have checked. 

Only you could have brought it into being;\r\nonly you can destroy it. You know it is against the rules to increase\r\nthe number of species in Creation. Destroy it!"\r\n\r\nJeremy looked at the creature so comfortably asleep against a tree and\r\nhe felt pity and compassion and love for it.\r\n\r\n"I cannot, Instructor. I do not know how it got there, unless it is\r\na product of my dreams. Once I forgot to shut off the power while I\r\nslept."\r\n\r\n"Sheer negligence! Destroy it, I say!"\r\n\r\n"No it belongs there now. 

And it looks lonely." Without warning he\r\nsnapped on his Augmentor and before the Instructor could interfere,\r\nthere appeared on the grass beside the creature another of the same\r\nspecies.\r\n\r\n"Now you\'ve done it," the Instructor screamed. "It can reproduce its\r\nkind." 

His voice grew coldly stern. "You have created an unreasonable\r\nfacsimile. You know what that means.

"\r\n\r\nMutely Jeremy got up from his chair. Automatically he reached for his\r\ncourse record card in Advanced Deliberation And Memory. To save space\r\non it all courses were listed by the first letters of the course name.\r\nA glance verified the Instructor\'s verdict:\r\n\r\nJ. Hovah\r\n\r\nFailed in ADAM.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nThe older man sat down on the grassy bank on the hill overlooking the\r\norchard. The autumn sun was bright but the humidity was low and there\r\nwas a breeze.\r\n\r\nThe younger man sprawled next to him.\r\n\r\n"Cigarette?" he asked.\r\n\r\n"Thanks," said Roger Boynton. He looked across the valley, past the\r\napple trees, to the fine white-columned house on the hill beyond. He\r\nsmiled reminiscently. "A friend of mine once owned that house. A fellow\r\ncommissioner in World Government. 

He and I used to sit on this very\r\nhill, sometimes. We\'d munch on an apple or two that we\'d picked on our\r\nway through the orchard. Winesaps, they\'re called."\r\n\r\n"You were telling me about the colonizing," said Allister gently, after\r\na pause.\r\n\r\nThe older man sighed. "Yes." He put out the cigarette carefully,\r\nstripped it, scattered the tobacco and wadded the paper into a tiny\r\nball. "I was commissioner of colonies. I had to decide, after my staff\r\nhad gathered all the data, who would be the best man to put in charge.\r\nIt was no easy decision."\r\n\r\n"I can imagine.

"\r\n\r\n"You can\'t really. There were so many factors, and the data were\r\nactually quite skimpy. The way it worked out, to be candid with you,\r\nwas on the basis of the best guess. 

And some of the guesses were pretty\r\nwild. We knew Mars was sandy, for instance, and so we put a Bedouin\r\nin charge. That pleased the Middle East, in general, and Jordan in\r\nparticular. Jordan donated a thousand camels under Point Four point\r\nfour."\r\n\r\n"I beg your pardon?" said Allister.\r\n\r\n"That\'s not double-talk. Point Four was the old terrestrial program for\r\nunderdeveloped countries. World Government adopted it and broadened it.\r\nMars is the fourth planet, so--" he traced 4.4 in the air, stabbing\r\na finger at the imaginary point "--Point Four point four. It was\r\nundoubtedly somebody\'s little whimsy in the beginning, but then it\r\nbecame accepted for the descriptive term that it was.

"\r\n\r\n"I see." 

The young man looked vague. He stubbed out his cigarette\r\ncarelessly, so that it continued to smolder in the grass.\r\n\r\n"Venus was the rainy planet," Boynton said, looking with disapproval\r\nat the smoking butt, though he did nothing about it, "so we put an\r\nEnglishman in charge. England sent a crate of Alligators."\r\n\r\nThe young man looked startled.\r\n\r\n"Alligator raincoats," Boynton said. "Things weren\'t very well\r\norganized. 

Too many things were happening too fast. There was a lot of\r\nconfusion and although the countries wanted to do what was best, no one\r\nknew exactly what that was. So they improvised as best they could on\r\nthe basis of their little knowledge."\r\n\r\n"Was it a dangerous thing?"\r\n\r\n"The little knowledge? No, not dangerous. 

Just inefficient. Then there\r\nwas Jupiter. We didn\'t bother about Mercury, although for a time there\r\nwas some uninformed talk about sending an Equatorial African to do what\r\nhe could."\r\n\r\n"Who went to Jupiter?" Allister asked.\r\n\r\n"The United States clamored for Jupiter and got it. The argument was\r\nthat the other planets would be a cinch to colonize because of their\r\nsimilarity to Earth but that Jupiter needed a real expert because it\r\nhad only its surface of liquid gas and the Red Spot."\r\n\r\n"What\'s that?

"\r\n\r\n"I\'m sorry. I\'d forgotten you were just a youngster when all this was\r\ngoing on. The Red Spot is the Jovians\' space platform. They built it\r\na long time ago and then they retrogressed, the way people do, and\r\nforgot how they\'d done it. Earth sent an engineer to see if it could\r\nbe done again. The Spot was pretty overpopulated and no real job of\r\ncolonization could be done until we built one more."\r\n\r\n"And did you?"\r\n\r\n"Well, we started to. Before we could really go to work anywhere,\r\nthough, we had to solve the language problem. An Australian went to\r\nwork on that. He\'d had a background of Melanesian pidgin, and if anyone\r\nwas suited to the job of cross-breeding four languages into one, he\r\nwas."\r\n\r\n"Four languages?"\r\n\r\n"Yes. English was the official language of Earth. Then there was\r\nMartian, Venusian _chat-chat_, and Spotian. It was a queer amalgam, but\r\nit could be understood by everyone, more or less."\r\n\r\n"So that\'s where it came from. _Chikker-im-up-im chat-chat too-much_,\r\neh? Interplanetary _b\xc3\xaache de mer_."\r\n\r\n"Exactly. Only of course it was called _b\xc3\xaache d\'espace_. _Me two-fellah\r\nvimb\' kitch-im pjoug by\'m by._ But even after the language difficulty\r\nwas solved, we had our troubles. They already had camels on Mars,\r\nfor instance, and the Martians were amazed when we brought in more.\r\nParticularly because theirs were wild and semi-intelligent and the\r\nfirst thing the Martian camels did was come over and liberate their\r\nbrothers from Earth. They never did come back.\r\n\r\n"Same sort of thing with the raincoats on Venus. It doesn\'t rain\r\n_down_ there, as we know now. It sort of mists _up_. From the ground.\r\nSoaks up under a raincoat in no time. These were just petty annoyances,\r\nof course, but they were symptomatic of the way our half-baked planning\r\noperated."\r\n\r\n"You didn\'t know about the people of Ganymede then?"\r\n\r\n"No. We were so busy trying to build another Red Spot that we never\r\ndid get to Jupiter\'s satellites. Oh, it was partly a matter of\r\nappropriations, too. The budget commission kept explaining to us that\r\nthere was only so much money and that we\'d better show a profit on what\r\nwe had before we put in a request to go tooling off to colonize some\r\nnew place. I guess the \'Medeans first came when you were about ten?"\r\n\r\n"Eleven," the younger man said.\r\n\r\n"They scouted our colonies and came directly to Earth. They took right\r\nover and colonized _us_."\r\n\r\nA \'Medean overseer climbed the hill effortlessly. He was tall and\r\ntentacled and the breathing apparatus over his head gave him the\r\nappearance of a mechanical man.\r\n\r\n"_Kigh-kigh pinis_," the \'Medean said. "_You two-fella all-same\r\nchat-chat too-much. B\'phava b\'long work he-stop \'long orchard pick-im\r\napple._"\r\n\r\nThe two men stood up and obediently walked down the hill toward the\r\napple orchard.\r\n\r\n"Why does he have to talk to us in that pidgin?" the young man asked.\r\n"They all speak English as well as you and me. It\'s insulting."\r\n\r\n"That\'s why they do it, I think," said Boynton, the former commissioner\r\nof colonies. "They\'re so much better at colonizing than we were that I\r\nguess they feel they have a right to rub it in."\r\n\r\nThe \'Medean had overheard them.\r\n\r\n"Damn right," he said.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n               It was one of those days--perhaps you\'ve\r\n                 had them--when everything went right!\r\n\r\n\r\n"Let\'s go slumming," said Powers-of-pearl. "Let\'s give an earthman his\r\nwish for a day. 

We haven\'t played that game in ages."\r\n\r\n"How do we pick him?" Firepride asked indulgently. "Phone book?

"\r\n\r\n"Intensity\'s more fun. But no more nomads, I got so bored putting\r\nconnoisseur features on synthetic camels!"\r\n\r\nPeter Stone put on his hat and started for the station. 

Every third\r\nstep he inhaled and told himself: "It isn\'t that bad." Peter had a good\r\njob, a good wife, and commuting was wearing him down to a twitch. Sooty\r\nteeth-rattling train, Penn Station\'s steaming caverns, a soggy lurching\r\nbus, lunch down in sun-seared, exhaust-ventilated streets and the ride\r\nhome ... as the hated maroon dot of his train appeared, a convulsion of\r\nrevulsion shook him.\r\n\r\n"I _wish_ it weren\'t that bad!" he thought with every fiber. And\r\nPowers-of-pearl, suffused with the glow of challenge, laughed.\r\n\r\nPeter Stone, fighting at the newsstand, noted with annoyance that a\r\ncrew of maintenance men swarmed about the train. "Broke down _again_,"\r\nhe thought bitterly. Halfway down his car two men ran a vacuum cleaner\r\nover the tired plush. Keeping pace behind them, two others aimed\r\nwide-mouth silver hoses upwards, spreading thick sheets of foam on the\r\nceiling. It wasn\'t until Peter Stone unfolded his newspaper that he\r\nnoticed how quiet had spread with that foam. Next, his ears registered\r\nwith surprise the purr of freshly-oiled machinery, and his eyes the\r\nsight of a tree, for once without its double window screen of hair-oil\r\nand dried grime droplets.\r\n\r\nWhen he boarded his bus, a maintenance man was just hanging a sign over\r\nthe gagged fare box:\r\n\r\n          Due to Tax Readjustment, Urban Transportation Free.\r\n\r\nThe driver, liberated from change-making and police duties, smiled a\r\ngreeting at him. No crush in the bus, perhaps because there seemed so\r\nmany about. 

The silver one coming towards him had a big green and white\r\nsign: DOWN FIFTH TO 33rd. 

WEST ON 33rd TO SEVENTH. PENN STATION LAST\r\nSTOP. It was the first readable bus sign he remembered seeing.\r\n\r\nWhenever the light turned red, he found, squads of maintenance men\r\ndarted about the stopped cars and trucks, slapping silver cylinders\r\nover each exhaust pipe. He could hear snatches of explanations: "City\r\nordinance," "Free service." As soon as a cylinder was in place, smoke\r\nand noise stopped coming out of the exhaust.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWhen his hat sailed gaily towards the hook, Peter Stone realized that,\r\nincredibly, he wasn\'t tired. Work flowed through his fingers, his\r\nsecretary smiled, his boss looked in once and whistled. At noon only\r\nthe thought of paraffined carton coffee restrained him from staying in.\r\n\r\n"Coming right up, Seventeen!" said the new silver grille next to the\r\nelevator button. Cheered, he clove the mindless rush downstairs and\r\npushed inside a luncheonette where maintenance men were finishing the\r\nremoval of every second stool and the re-upholstery of the remainder\r\nwith foam cushions. A smiling waitress brought him a menu and a pencil.\r\nOpposite each item was a small circle, and a line at the top explained:\r\nTHIS IS YOUR MENUCHECK. PLEASE MARK WANTED ITEMS, DROP MENUCHECK IN\r\nSLOT.\r\n\r\nServed incredibly fast, Peter Stone ate in blissful peace. On his way\r\nout he saw that the cashier\'s cage had been replaced with three silver\r\ncabinets with hoppers for Menuchecks and money, recessed cups for\r\nchange and a turnstile each. When he walked through he found that he\r\nstill had forty minutes of his lunch hour left.\r\n\r\nForty minutes! He could walk to a bookshop, or the park ... walk,\r\nthrough exhaust fumes and the belches of airconditioner waste? But\r\nsilver mesh covered the noisome vents. A cautious sniff assured him it\r\nworked.\r\n\r\nHe decided to walk to the Library newsstands for a foreign magazine.\r\nAs he reached 42nd and Fifth an army of workmen were putting the last\r\ntouches on a structure of dull silver that spanned the four sides of\r\nthe intersection. Airy and elegant, with faint echoes of Library style,\r\nthe quadruple arch provided the perfect finishing touch for the square.\r\nEach side was composed of three escalators and moving platforms in both\r\ndirections, with a set of stairs and a promenade.\r\n\r\nTimidly, he set foot on the silver filigree. He was wafted up,\r\nacross and down. Beneath him flowed a brilliant river of quiet cars.\r\nFascinated, he took the trip back, then stood on the promenade watching\r\nthe pattern, breathing in incredulous lungfuls of clean air.\r\n\r\nThe afternoon fled on newly silent feet. Once more he put on his hat to\r\nface the ride home.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHis small, air-conditioned silver bus reached Penn Station ten minutes\r\nearlier than usual. By now Peter Stone was not overly surprised to\r\nsee silver moving ways disappearing into the Station\'s maw, nor, once\r\ninside, to feel breezes that blew silently from silver gadgets like jet\r\nengines. He also accepted the waiting passengers dancing in the great\r\nlobby--the piped music there had long been excellent.\r\n\r\nA low, pleasant voice announced his train in diamond-cut syllables\r\nthat floated from silver-dollar speakers spangling the walls. Before his wife\'s goggling\r\neyes, Peter Stone bounded down the steps and ran to their car. She\r\nremembered that evening the rest of her life.\r\n\r\nPowers-of-pearl let the silver evaporate, and with it the memory of it.\r\n"The best game yet," she smiled, leaning in happy exhaustion against\r\nFirepride\'s shoulder.\r\n\r\n"You were magnificent," laughed Firepride. "One step ahead of an entire\r\ncity!"

]\r\n\r\n\r\nI stepped back out of the gutter and watched the tight clot of men\r\ndisappear around the corner. They hadn\'t really been menacing, just had\r\nmade it obvious they weren\'t going to break up. And that I had better\r\nget out of their way. 

I got. We were well trained.\r\n\r\nThe neon of the bar across the street flickered redly on my uniform.\r\nI watched the slush trickle off my boots for a while, then made up my\r\nmind and headed into the bar. It was a mistake.\r\n\r\nNew York had always been considered safe for us. Of course there were\r\nmany parts of the country that were absolutely forbidden "for your own\r\ngood" and others that were "highly dangerous" or at least "doubtful."\r\nBut New York had always been a haven. The stares there had even been\r\nadmiring sometimes, especially in the beginning.\r\n\r\nBut things had changed. I had realized that about half an hour after\r\ntouchdown, when we were being herded through Health Check, Baggage\r\nCheck, Security Check ... you know the lot. Before, there had been\r\nfriendly questions, genuine interest in the Mars colony, speculations\r\nabout the second expedition to Venus, even a joke or two. This time\r\nthe examiners\' only interest seemed to be in fouling us up as much as\r\npossible. And when we finally got through the rat race, New York was\r\nbleak.\r\n\r\nI should have stayed with the rest, I guess, and of course a public\r\nbar was the last place any smart spaceboy would have gone to. But I had\r\nsome nice memories of bars, memories from the early days.\r\n\r\nThe whole room went silent, as though a tube had blown, when I shoved\r\nthrough the door. I got over to an empty table as quickly as I could\r\nand inspected the list of drinks on the dispenser. This one had a lot\r\nof big nickel handles sticking up over the drink names and the whole\r\njob was shaped like one of those beer kegs you used to see pictures of.\r\nWhat I mean is, this was an _authentic_ bar.\r\n\r\nPhony as hell.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nFrom the way this sounds, you can guess the kind of mood I\'d gotten\r\nin. The noise had picked up again right after I sat down and some\r\nof the drunker drunks were knocking the usual words around, in loud\r\nwhispers and with lots of glances at me. One of the pro-girls (her hair\r\nwas green and her blouse covered her breasts--another change while I\r\nwas out) gave me a big wink and then jabbed the man next to her and\r\nsquawked with laughter.\r\n\r\nI fed a bill into the change machine at the table and then dribbled\r\nseveral coins (prices had gone up too) into the dispenser.\r\n\r\nI guess I must have had several, because after a while I began to feel\r\ncheerful. The noise that was coming out of the box in the corner\r\nstarted to sound like music, and I got to tapping and rocking. 

And\r\nsmiling, I guess. 

And that\'s what triggered it.\r\n\r\nPeople had been coming and going, but mainly coming. And the crowd at\r\nthe bar had been getting louder, and one guy there had been getting\r\nlouder than the rest. All of a sudden, he slammed down his glass and\r\nheaded for my table. He orbited around it for a while, staring at me,\r\nand then settled jerkily down in the chair across from me.\r\n\r\n"Why all the hilarity, spaceboy? Feeling proud of yourself?"\r\n\r\nHe looked pretty wobbly and pretty soft and pretty old. And very angry.\r\nBut I was kind of wobbly myself by that time. And anyway there are\r\nstrict rules about us and violence. _Very_ strict. So I just tried to\r\nmake the smile bigger and said, "I\'m just feeling good. "\r\n\r\n"Nice stuff," he said, kind of mincing. "Buddy, do you know what you\r\ncan do with your sandgems and your windstones?"\r\n\r\n"We brought back some other things too. There was a good bit of uranium\r\nand--"\r\n\r\n"We don\'t need it!" He was getting purple. "We don\'t need anything from\r\nyou."\r\n\r\n"And maybe _we_ don\'t need you." There\'s no place for you here."\r\n\r\nI could have pointed out that we brought things that Earth really\r\nneeded, that Mars and Venus had literally worlds of natural resources,\r\nwhile Earth had almost finished hers. "\r\n\r\nIt wasn\'t hard to peg what he was talking about. "It was probably\r\n_good_ luck that the first space crew was selected the way it was," I\r\nsaid. "Otherwise you\'d have had a dead ship full of dead men and no\r\nknowing why. But that one man brought the ship back."\r\n\r\n"Yeah, yeah.

"\r\n\r\nRuskin frowned and swore quietly. Even his holidays were shattered by\r\npeople who couldn\'t forget he was Commissioner of Internal Security.\r\nAnd these people were always little unimportant ones, like this\r\narcheologist Bigelow, whose little fears suddenly became giant threats\r\nto national security.\r\n\r\n"Send him out here, Tom."\r\n\r\nTom turned back into the house. Ruskin could hear his gruff voice\r\ninside, and a few moments later Bigelow, stooped and bespectacled,\r\nemerged from the house.\r\n\r\nRuskin smiled weakly.\r\n\r\n"Hello, Bigelow."\r\n\r\n"Good morning, Commissioner."\r\n\r\nBigelow stood, clutching his briefcase, shaking with excitement. Then\r\nsuddenly his eyes fell on Daisy and something like fear passed over his\r\nface.\r\n\r\n"Sit down, Bigelow."\r\n\r\nBigelow balanced himself delicately on the edge of a porch chair, his\r\nbriefcase resting on his long bony knees. But his eyes remained fixed\r\non the dog.\r\n\r\n"Is this social or business, Bigelow?"\r\n\r\n"Sort of both, Commissioner," he answered slowly. Then added quickly,\r\n"But I wouldn\'t disturb your holiday if it wasn\'t important."\r\n\r\nRuskin nodded dully.\r\n\r\nThen several moments of silence during which Bigelow continued to watch\r\nDaisy carefully. Finally, since his visitor did not seem inclined to\r\nspeak, Ruskin asked simply, "Well?"\r\n\r\n"First tell the dog to go away."\r\n\r\n"Daisy?"\r\n\r\n"Yes."\r\n\r\n"Why?"\r\n\r\n"I won\'t say a word with _IT_ here."\r\n\r\nRuskin shrugged.\r\n\r\n"As you wish," he said. 

"Daisy ... go ... go on, like a good girl."\r\n\r\nDaisy\'s big eyes seemed hurt but, reluctantly, she walked away.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBigelow watched suspiciously after her until she was well out of\r\nhearing.\r\n\r\n"Now," he began, "a week ago we started digging around the crater on\r\nthe East Coast where some great pre-Atomic cities once stood...."\r\n\r\nBigelow paused excitedly.\r\n\r\nRuskin sighed. It was much too nice a day....\r\n\r\n"... and there we came upon THREE pre-Atomic books!"\r\n\r\nBigelow paused again.\r\n\r\n"A wonderful find," Ruskin said, without enthusiasm.\r\n\r\n"More wonderful than you think, Commissioner."\r\n\r\nBigelow squared his shoulders dramatically.\r\n\r\n"Two of them were much like the other pre-Atomic books in the museums,\r\nbut the third...."\r\n\r\nBigelow was bursting with excitement.\r\n\r\n"... the third had pictures in it!"\r\n\r\nRuskin straightened up.\r\n\r\n"Amazing!"\r\n\r\nNever before had a pre-Atomic book been found with pictures. Artists\r\nhad painted their own versions drawn from the few meager written\r\ndescriptions....\r\n\r\n"How many pictures, Bigelow?"\r\n\r\n"Plenty, but just one would be enough to shake the foundations of our\r\nsocial world!"\r\n\r\nHe opened his briefcase and pulled out a small book protected by its\r\nown cloth cover. He opened to a marked page.\r\n\r\n"Just take a look at this!"\r\n\r\nRuskin took the book and stared curiously at a picture showing a\r\ndressed up dog sitting in a chair patting a human on the head. The\r\ncaption read: MAN\'S BEST FRIEND GETS REWARD.\r\n\r\nRuskin glanced back at Bigelow.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t understand," he said slowly. "Is it some kind of joke-book?"\r\n\r\nBigelow grinned narrowly.\r\n\r\n"A very bitter joke, Commissioner. A joke of Mother Nature\'s."\r\n\r\n"I\'m still not sure I understand...."\r\n\r\n"I think you do, Commissioner," Bigelow countered quickly. "Now so many\r\nof the things we couldn\'t understand become clear to us. The naked\r\nanimal on the floor in the picture is our ancestor, and the hairless\r\nthing in the chair is our dog!"\r\n\r\nRuskin shook his head.\r\n\r\n"Impossible!

"\r\n\r\n"Not at all! In the lower animal and plant orders more amazing\r\nmutations occurred during the Atomic Wars--we just never noticed\r\nbecause they didn\'t touch us closely."\r\n\r\nRuskin\'s mind rushed over the implications, all the frightful and\r\ncarefully ignored aberrations of the Atomic blasts.\r\n\r\nIf it was true, and he still wouldn\'t let himself be convinced, it\r\nwould be a tremendous blow to the morale of Society. And it was his\r\nduty to protect the well-being of Society. He must decide ... now ...\r\nfor Society....\r\n\r\n"This is a very delicate problem, Bigelow," he said finally.\r\n\r\n"I know, Commissioner."\r\n\r\n"You\'ve come upon something ... 

fantastic."\r\n\r\n"Thank you, Commissioner."\r\n\r\n"We must handle this very carefully.

"\r\n\r\n"I understand."\r\n\r\n"Good. Leave the book with me ... for security reasons ... and I\'ll\r\nfigure how to handle it."\r\n\r\n"Well...."\r\n\r\n"Of course, I\'ll see that you get all the credit you deserve."\r\n\r\nBigelow rose.\r\n\r\n"Very well, Commissioner. I\'ll leave it in your hands."\r\n\r\nHe left with the air of a man just conquering the world.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nRuskin sat, the closed book in both hands, for a long long while. It\r\nwas very late when he called the Psycho Section.\r\n\r\n"Yes," Psycho answered. "We have a file on Bigelow."\r\n\r\n"Have you ever interned him?"\r\n\r\n"No. But he\'s catalogued as extremely unstable."\r\n\r\n"Fine. 

Thank you.

"\r\n\r\nRuskin placed the receiver carefully back on the cradle. Nothing to\r\nfear from Bigelow. He rose and walked slowly toward the fire.\r\n\r\nHe looked down at the book.\r\n\r\nWar! War! War! From the beginning of man almost to his own destruction.\r\n\r\nSince the Atomic Wars Earth had been comparatively peaceful--because,\r\npeople thought, Man had become surfeited of war.\r\n\r\nRuskin frowned.\r\n\r\nAttitudes, someone had once said, are more important than facts.\r\n\r\nHe dropped the book into the flames.\r\n\r\nVery well, then.\r\n\r\nLet Earth be happy.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nDaisy walked slowly over to him and barked quietly. The pretty golden\r\nhair hung gently over her shoulders, and her blue eyes were very soft.\r\n\r\nRuskin patted her gently.\r\n\r\n"Nice doggie," he said.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n

"\r\n\r\n"It all happened exactly like I\'m going to tell you," said Drake\r\nHawkins, pinching Zoe\'s rosy cheek. "\r\n\r\n"Like humans in many, many respects. I got sick of science when I was\r\nstudying for my _master\'s_. 

Sick of seeing what people were doing with\r\nit. ; Russia; ... all the little\r\ncountries."\r\n\r\n"Here she comes--I hear something!"\r\n\r\n"Atmosphere!"\r\n\r\n"We\'re back home!"\r\n\r\n"Crisis number six. We can\'t fail now."\r\n\r\n"Before it\'s too loud to talk ... listen to me. When we land, don\'t say\r\nanything. "I mean, with\r\nall due respect, of course."\r\n\r\nNo man enjoys coming into his dining room and having to sit at meals and\r\nlook at a full-sized picture of his wife\'s first husband arriving on\r\nVenus. Fair\'s fair, but such a set-up is ridiculous.\r\n\r\n"No," Phoebe shook her blonde head. "Don Manton loved me and he was\r\nfamous. I like to be reminded of the days when my picture was in all the\r\ntelepapers and my face on so many telescreens."\r\n\r\nShe might just as well have called him a tattered nonentity, though\r\nHenry was doing pretty well as a foreman in the local humandroid\r\nfactory. He was stopped from reminding her by Phoebe\'s saying that she\'d\r\nleave for a bit of shopping. She left abruptly.\r\n\r\nHenry watched her takeoff from the roof of their two-story fibroid house\r\nand went back to the dining room. Now, even his warmest admirers would\r\ngive in that he had a streak of stubbornness in him a mile wide and six\r\nmiles deep. Henry took the three-dimensional monstrosity off the wall,\r\nholding it hard by thumb and forefinger on its luminex frame, and\r\nprepared to say good-by to the picture of Don Manton.\r\n\r\nA foreman at one of the humandroid shops has to be able to consider\r\nalternatives and Henry had done this. If he only hid the picture there\'d\r\nbe a domestic crisis and the picture would sooner or later be back on\r\nthe wall; if he destroyed it there\'d also be a crisis, but one that\r\nwould eventually blow over.\r\n\r\nUnluckily for him, these three-dimensional wall pictures were made out\r\nof glaseine, and when he tried setting fire to it he nearly burned down\r\nthe house. Upon feeding it to the old-fashioned fireplace nothing grew\r\nhot except his temper. Ripping the picture to shreds would have been the\r\nnext step, but you can\'t rip glaseine.\r\n\r\nFor maybe the six millionth time he cursed out Don Manton, the\r\nwell-known explorer in the realm of outer space. Henry understood in a\r\ngeneral way that Don Manton had been among the first to chart the cities\r\nof Mars and Venus, and had accidentally died on a planet named Immel;\r\nbut Henry had no intention of living in Don Manton\'s shadow.\r\n\r\nThe picture, which showed the late explorer talking with three\r\nVenusians, had been hung up again when Phoebe came through the ceiling\r\ndoor along the extension stairway which flicked up to meet her.\r\n\r\n"You\'ve been trying to get rid of Don\'s picture!"\r\n\r\nHe\'d hung it crookedly, and a diagonal slash of white wallpaper had\r\ngiven him away.\r\n\r\n"Just this one. 

You\'ve got cans of telefilm in the cellar, but them I\r\ndon\'t mind. This," he flicked it with a thumbnail, "I do mind."\r\n\r\n"As long as I stay," Phoebe said quietly, "my darling Don\'s picture\r\nstays."\r\n\r\n"But what about your darling Henry? Am I just a humandroid who looks and\r\nbehaves and talks like a human being? Haven\'t I got feelings?" Henry\r\nstrode around the room, hitting the fibroid floor like a prehistoric\r\nmonster on a sandpaper bridge. "Either that picture goes," he said\r\nfinally, definitely, "or I go!"\r\n\r\nPhoebe shook out her blonde hair, letting it fall about her shoulders.\r\n"Too bad."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nInside of an hour he had packed his suitcases. Phoebe cried bitterly,\r\nbut wouldn\'t budge about the picture. Henry took the plane. He put up at\r\nhis club, went to the bar, and was gobbling down something called\r\npressurized scotch, when he heard a noise back of him.\r\n\r\n"Get away from me!" said Henry, who was quite a few over the traditional\r\neight by this time. "I\'ve had enough of Don Manton, let alone his\r\nhelpers."\r\n\r\nSpeed Roggs, who had taken a couple of trips with Manton, was tall and\r\nthin as the barstool, and with a spaceman\'s ability to think fast when\r\nhe had to. Loudly he ordered a Venuswiz, explaining to a disgusted\r\nHenry, "After the barkeep mixes the drink he melts the swizzle stick and\r\npours that in, too." He gulped the stuff down gratefully, then said,\r\n"Tell me your troubles, Hank."\r\n\r\nHenry did. 

Speed Roggs looked disgusted. "Are you serious?" he asked,\r\nand when Henry swore to cut Speed\'s throat on asking that again, went\r\non, "Women are space-mad!"\r\n\r\nAs Henry agreed, Roggs said, "The one thing you don\'t understand about\r\nDon Manton is that he was maladjusted. He couldn\'t stay still, he always\r\nwanted what he couldn\'t have. 

That goes for his feelings for women,\r\ntoo.

"\r\n\r\nHenry looked up with bloodshot eyes nearly popping out of his head.\r\n\r\nRoggs kept going. "Don and Phoebe never got along once they were\r\nmarried. It was Manton\'s fault. Like all explorers he was unhappy over\r\nhis lot and looked beyond the rainbow. 

In fact, he told me once that the\r\nonly reason he went in for exploring space was to get away from his\r\nwife."\r\n\r\nHenry Weller suddenly rocked with laughter. He got to his feet, took\r\nRoggs, and went to his room, still laughing. He lay on the bed for half\r\nan hour. At the end of that time he sat up.\r\n\r\n"Tell the manager I won\'t be here for supper," he said to Speed. "I\'ve\r\ngot a little trip to make.

"\r\n\r\n"Where are you going?"\r\n\r\n"Home, to give the good tidings to my wife."\r\n\r\nHenry\'s fibroid house looked about the same. He parked the plane and let\r\nhimself in by the roof door and down the extension staircase. He found\r\nPhoebe in the kitchen bent over a pot, and at sound of him she turned. A\r\nnear-smile flickered in her blue eyes.\r\n\r\n"Phoebe ..."\r\n\r\n"Henry ..."\r\n\r\nThey laughed together. Henry wanted to tell her what he knew as bitterly\r\nand maliciously as possible, but he simply opened his mouth a few times.\r\nHe couldn\'t say it. Everyone is entitled to an illusion and this was\r\nPhoebe, his blonde wench, his wife, his woman. He looked a bit sick.\r\n\r\nShe smiled. "Come into the dining room."\r\n\r\nThe three-dimensional picture had been rolled up into the corner. Henry\r\npromised to put it away in the cellar and clean up the cellar as soon as\r\nhe could. Phoebe said that her first husband had never liked to stay\r\nhome, he\'d always been afraid to live normally.\r\n\r\n"I was wrong about the picture," she told him, "and I didn\'t know till I\r\nsaw you leave the house."\r\n\r\nIt goes without saying that Henry and his Phoebe lived happily ever\r\nafter, but it is perhaps not so well known that Phoebe was left with a\r\nlittle disposal problem, too. She had a rough time finding a buyer (in\r\nsecret, of course) for her brand-new humandroid, who looked and behaved\r\nand talked so exactly like that well-known flyer, Speed Roggs....\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Imagination Stories of Science and\r\n    Fantasy_ August 1953. "\r\n\r\nI sipped my drink and tried to think of a subtle way to change the\r\nsubject. I didn\'t like to hear a person\'s personal problems and every\r\ntime I visited George, he invariably complained about Helen. If it had\r\nbeen anyone else, I might have thought it wasn\'t entirely Helen\'s fault,\r\nbut George and I had been roommates in college and I knew him like a\r\nbrother. He was a person who got along with almost everyone.\r\nIntelligent, easy-going and likeable.\r\n\r\nHe lifted his glass and glared at me as if I were the guilty party.\r\n"She\'s a worry-wart," he continued. "A hypochondriac, a neurotic, an\r\nescapist, and a communist." He studied the ceiling thoughtfully. "And\r\nsometimes I think she\'s a little crazy."\r\n\r\nI tried to calm him, "Don\'t worry about it. If things get worse, get a\r\ndivorce."\r\n\r\n"Divorce, ha! She wouldn\'t give me a divorce if--"\r\n\r\nThe door opened.\r\n\r\nHelen smiled half-heartedly, her pale face quickly resuming its unhappy\r\nexpression as if it tired her facial muscles when she smiled. "Hello,\r\nEd. 

Nice to see you again."\r\n\r\n"Hello, Helen." I glanced at George and noticed he had closed his eyes\r\nas if the sight of his wife was unbearable. His lower lip was white\r\nwhere he gripped it with his teeth and I silently hoped he wouldn\'t draw\r\nblood.\r\n\r\nHelen sank into a chair and raised her skirt to reveal her right leg.\r\n"Did George tell you about my legs?" she inquired. 

She stroked the leg\r\naffectionately. "Arthritis. George grafted a new one on for me. Feels\r\nten times better."\r\n\r\nMy face blanched. The idea of replacing body parts from Banks didn\'t\r\nnauseate me. If a man is in an automobile accident and loses an arm, and\r\nthat arm can be replaced, I think that\'s marvelous. What sickened me\r\nwere the people who actually _enjoyed_ having a part of their body\r\nreplaced with a part from a criminal or corpse.\r\n\r\n"No." I sat down. 

My knees were weak. I felt short of breath. "George\r\ndidn\'t tell me. I--"\r\n\r\nShe interrupted with details of the operation. The details and list of\r\nher other ailments lasted half an hour, during which George drank\r\nsteadily and I waited for a lull so I could glance at my watch and say\r\nsomething about being late for an appointment.\r\n\r\nI saw George several times during the next few weeks. Never at his\r\nhouse. I didn\'t visit him on my own initiative because Helen, as I had\r\nseen during my last visit, had passed from the stage of being unpleasant\r\nand reached the stage of being unbearable. I didn\'t want to be around\r\nher or listen to her, and George must have realized my feelings because\r\nhe didn\'t invite me to his house for some time.\r\n\r\nBut both of us had a habit of stopping at a club on the outskirts of\r\ntown and we met there often. Each time we met, George complained. Each\r\ntime, he seemed to drink more and complain more.\r\n\r\nI worried about his job. He was a surgeon--one of the best--and a\r\nsurgeon needs good nerves and steady hands when he performs delicate\r\noperations.\r\n\r\nI urged him to get a divorce, but he said he didn\'t want one. "I love\r\nHelen," he said one time. "Well, I don\'t exactly love _Helen_, but I\r\nlove her body. It\'s like the old saying about marrying a girl because\r\nshe\'s pretty is like picking a rose by looking at the stem. We\'re all\r\ndifferent, you know, and we all have different tastes. When I first saw\r\nHelen-- Well, she\'s just right for me. To me, she looks as good as\r\nMarilyn Monroe looks to the average man. I like having her around. I\'d\r\nbe lost without her, but at the same time, she\'s changed so damned much,\r\nshe makes me sick.

"\r\n\r\nAnd there it was. He still wanted Helen but she had changed into a\r\npersonality that he hated. Over a period of years, she had changed into\r\na morbid hypochondriac, an unpleasant woman who enjoyed--more than\r\nanything else--such things as having one of her legs replaced and\r\nsampling the latest pills and drugs. George said he had tried to get her\r\nto see a psychiatrist but she refused. And you can\'t have a person\r\ncommitted to a mental institution because they have an unpleasant\r\npersonality!\r\n\r\nIt seemed as if there was no solution to his problem.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThen, late one evening, I received a phone call from George. "Come over\r\nand have a few drinks," he said. 

"We\'ll have a party! Helen\'s changed.\r\nYou should see her!"\r\n\r\nI was interested in his problem, so I went.\r\n\r\nHelen greeted me at the door and I had the surprise of my life. At one\r\ntime, she had been beautiful, but she had faded during the past few\r\nyears. By staying indoors, she had grown pale, listless. As her\r\npersonality changed, it had also changed her features, and her eyes had\r\ndeveloped a sleepy, lifeless look, and deep lines had formed on her\r\nface.\r\n\r\nBut the Helen who greeted me that night was not like that. Her face had\r\na healthy flush, her eyes sparkled and she seemed vibrant, bubbling ...\r\njust like the Helen I had known so long ago.\r\n\r\nGeorge and I had a good time that night. He laughed and joked for the\r\nfirst time in months. We drank, talked, played chess, and then drank and\r\ntalked some more.\r\n\r\nEvery now and then, Helen would float by, a gorgeous creature, laughing\r\nat George\'s jokes, mixing our drinks, and smiling at George as if he\r\nwere the most wonderful man in the world.\r\n\r\nWhen I couldn\'t bear it any longer, I whispered, "What happened?"\r\n\r\nGeorge drained his glass and shouted across the room, "Come here,\r\nHelen!"\r\n\r\nShe came.\r\n\r\nGeorge said, "Promise not to tell anyone? It\'s very important.

"\r\n\r\nI couldn\'t imagine his reason for asking me that, but I said, "I\r\npromise."\r\n\r\n"Well," George explained, "I can\'t take all the credit. I\'m a fairly\r\ngood surgeon, but Lucas had the hardest job. We did it together.

That\'s how I\r\nhappened to get her in the first place. I\'d always wanted one, but pets\r\nwere forbidden. Busy people didn\'t have time for them. 

So I knew I was\r\nbreaking the Law. But I figured that no one would ever find out.\r\n\r\nFirst I fixed a place for her, and made a brush screen, so that she\r\ncouldn\'t be seen by anyone coming to the gates. Then, one night, I\r\nsneaked into the forest and got her.\r\n\r\nIt wasn\'t so lonely after that. Now I had something to talk to. She was\r\nsmall when I got her--it would be too dangerous to go near a full grown\r\none--but she grew rapidly. That was because I caught small animals and\r\nbrought them to her. Not having to depend on what she could catch, she\r\ngrew almost twice as fast as usual, and was so sleek and pretty. Really,\r\nshe was a pet to be proud of.\r\n\r\nI don\'t know how I could have stood the four months there alone, if I\r\nhadn\'t her to talk to. I don\'t think she really understood me, but I\r\npretended she did, and that helped.\r\n\r\nEvery three or four weeks, three of the council members came to take a\r\npart of the Treasure, or to add to it. Always three of them.\r\n\r\nThat\'s why I was so surprised one day, to see one man coming by\r\nhimself. It was Gremm, the little old member, who had recommended that I\r\nbe given this job. I was happy to see him, and we talked for a while,\r\nmostly about my work, and how I liked it. I almost told him about my\r\npet, but I didn\'t, because he might be angry at me for breaking the Law.\r\n\r\nFinally, he asked me to give him the Key.\r\n\r\n"I\'ve been sent to get something from the Treasure," he explained.\r\n\r\nI was unhappy to displease him, but I said, "I can\'t let you have it.\r\nThere must be three members. You know that.

"\r\n\r\n"Of course, I know it. But something came up suddenly, so they sent me\r\nalone. Now, let me have it.

"\r\n\r\nI shook my head. That was the one order they had given me--never to give\r\nthe Key to any one person who came alone.\r\n\r\nGremm became quite angry.\r\n\r\n"You idiot," he shouted. "Why do you think I had you put out here? It\r\nwas so I could get in there and help myself to the Treasure."\r\n\r\n"But that would be dishonest. And there are no dishonest people in the\r\nState."\r\n\r\n"For three thousand years. I know." His usually kind face had an ugly\r\nlook I had never seen before. 

"But I\'m going to get part of that\r\nTreasure. And it won\'t do you any good to report it, because no one is\r\ngoing to take the word of a fool like you, against a respected council\r\nmember. They\'ll think you are the dishonest one. Now, give me that Key!"\r\n\r\nIt\'s a terrible thing to disobey a council member. But if I obeyed him,\r\nI would be disobeying all the others. And that would be worse.\r\n\r\n"No!" I shouted.\r\n\r\nHe threw himself upon me. For his size and age, he was very\r\nstrong--stronger, even, than I. I fought as hard as I could, but I knew\r\nI wouldn\'t be able to keep him away from the Key for very long. And if\r\nhe took the Treasure, I would be blamed. The council would have to think\r\na new punishment for dishonesty. Whatever it was, it would be terrible,\r\nindeed.\r\n\r\nHe drew back and rushed at me. 

Just as he hit me, my foot caught upon a\r\nroot, and I fell. His rush carried him past me, and he crashed through\r\nthe brush screen beside the path. I heard him scream twice, then there\r\nwas silence.\r\n\r\nI was bruised all over, but I managed to pull myself up and take away\r\nwhat was left of the screen. There was no sign of Gremm, but my\r\nbeautiful pet was waving her pearl-green feelers as she always did in\r\nthanks for a good meal.\r\n\r\nThat\'s why I can\'t tell anyone what happened. No one would believe that\r\nGremm would be dishonest. And I can\'t prove it, because she ate the\r\nproof.\r\n\r\nEven if I did tell them, no one is going to believe that a fly-catcher\r\nplant--even a big one like mine--would actually be able to eat a man.\r\n\r\nSo they think that Gremm disappeared. And I\'m still out here--with her.\r\nShe\'s grown so much larger now, and more beautiful than ever.\r\n\r\nBut I hope she hasn\'t developed a taste for human flesh. Lately, when\r\nshe stretches out her feelers, it seems that she\'s trying to reach me.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Fantastic Universe_ August 1957.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed.
