Only...._\r\n\r\n           [Transcriber\'s Note: This etext was produced from\r\n              Worlds of If Science Fiction, January 1955.\r\n         Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that\r\n         the U.S. copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen the Travelers from Outer Space dug into the pile of moldering\r\nrock, they found the metal capsule their senses had told them was\r\nthere. Battered and corroded though it was, the shadow vibrations\r\nshowed that it had once been smooth and shiny. As smooth, shiny and\r\nimpervious to wear as Twentieth Century Earth technology could make it.\r\n\r\nAt the time the Mayor of Chicago had ceremoniously tossed a handful\r\nof lake sand into the hole, had his picture taken smiling against\r\nthe skyline, and had moved away to let the workmen fill the hole with\r\ncement and place the marker, the Time Capsule had been bright with the\r\nhopes of civilization sending its proud present into the uncertain\r\nfuture.\r\n\r\nTime passed....\r\n\r\nThe tiny radio transmitter in the capsule began throwing out its wide\r\nsignal at the exact instant planned for it many centuries before. No\r\none heard. 

Eventually, the tiny powerful batteries gave out. The signal\r\ndied.\r\n\r\nTime passed....\r\n\r\nWhen the Travelers from Outer Space took the capsule back to their ship\r\nand opened it, they found the contents in perfect order. Even the reel\r\nof magnetic tape had not succumbed to the centuries.\r\n\r\nIn due course, the Travelers examined the tape, divined its purpose,\r\nand constructed a machine that would play back the recording.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nOut of a million evolutionary possibilities in a Universe of planets,\r\nthe chances of two intelligent races being even roughly similar are\r\nastronomically remote.\r\n\r\nA being develops sense organs for no other reason than to make it aware\r\nof its environment. The simplest primitive being\'s awareness of its\r\nenvironment centers around food, its means of survival. It develops\r\norgans and appendages that will enable it to ferret out, obtain and\r\ningest its food. As the food differs, so, then, does the eater.\r\n\r\nThe Travelers had no ears or eyes, as such. They had other organs for\r\nother purposes, but the net result was that they "saw" and "heard"\r\nquite as well--even better--than Earthmen.\r\n\r\nPerhaps that explains why the Travelers gleaned so much more from the\r\ntape recording in the Twentieth Century capsule than its originators\r\nhad planned or intended.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nNot just any radio show could be placed in the Time Capsule. What\r\npicture of contemporary 1960 mankind would the men of the future derive\r\nfrom a soap opera? A news analysis? 

Or top comedy show? Certainly not\r\na flattering one, and so, reasoned the brass in charge of the project,\r\nnot a true one.\r\n\r\nNo, the only answer was to produce a special documentary program,\r\npainting on a broad canvas the glories that were the common man\'s\r\nbirthright in an enlightened democracy. As July 4th was only a\r\nmonth away, the idea was a natural. The program would be carried\r\nsimultaneously on four networks, then placed in the Time Capsule so\r\nthat historians of the future would have something solid on which to\r\nbase their conclusions.\r\n\r\nA famous poet-radio writer was hired to write the script. Hollywood\'s\r\ngreatest young male star donated his services (with much attendant\r\npublicity) as narrator. A self-acknowledged genius who directed radio\r\nshows for a living condescended to lend his talents to the production.\r\nNumerous other actors, musicians, technicians and assistants were\r\nhired ... none well-known, but all quite competent.\r\n\r\nJuly 4th, the big day, arrived. The cast went into rehearsal early in\r\nthe morning. 

By the second complete run-through, just before the break\r\nfor lunch, the show was hanging together nicely. After four hours of\r\npolishing in the afternoon, it was ready to go on the air. Everyone\'s\r\nnerves were raw, but the show sounded great.\r\n\r\nNaturally, when a room full of creative people have been rubbing\r\nagainst one another for a full day, a lot of emotions are generated.\r\nThe listening audience never knew about it, but it took the actors,\r\ndirectors, musicians and technicians several days to get the session\r\nout of their systems. During rehearsals, the young Hollywood star\r\ndeveloped a consuming lust for one of the minor actresses. One of the\r\nminor actors developed a consuming lust for the young Hollywood star.\r\nEveryone immediately hated the director, and he, lofty and all-wise,\r\ncontemptuously hated them in return. By eight o\'clock that night, show\r\ntime, the splendid documentary on the splendid American people was not\r\nthe only thing that was at peak pitch.\r\n\r\nIt was the only thing, however, that the radio audience heard. It was\r\nmagnificent. Future students hearing the tape could not but conclude\r\nthat here was the Golden Age. Man, at least American man, circa 1960,\r\nnoble, humble and sincere, was carrying in his bosom the seeds of\r\ngreatness. Difficulties still existed, of course, but they were not\r\ninsurmountable. 

A few deluded people seemed to be working against the\r\ncommon good, but the program left no doubt that this would be cleaned\r\nup in short order. The millenium was at hand!\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWhen the Travelers from Outer Space, who were a team of historians\r\ndoing research on the history of life throughout the Universe, listened\r\nto the tape recording, their "ears" heard none of the program as it had\r\nbeen originally broadcast. They were no less fascinated, however, for\r\nwhat they heard was the thought patterns of the people who had been\r\nconnected with the program. These thoughts, in the form of electrical\r\nimpulses, were also recorded on the magnetic surface of the tape, and\r\nwere the only sounds audible to the Travelers.\r\n\r\nWhat a pity these future historians didn\'t get mankind\'s version of\r\nthe life of mankind in 1960, after the producers had gone to so much\r\ntrouble to tie it up in a package for them. Their conception of Earth\r\nculture was based on the thought impulses they "heard", and their\r\nHistory of Earth was written accordingly. The last paragraph is worth\r\nnoting:\r\n\r\n"In the main, it is quite fortunate for life in the Universe that these\r\nprimitive people destroyed themselves before they learned how to leave\r\ntheir planet. Lustful, murderous and guilt-ridden, they are perhaps the\r\nworst examples of intelligent life that we have ever discovered. 

And\r\nyet, paradox supreme, they had one quality that we ourselves would do\r\nwell to emulate. That quality we can only surmise, for nothing on the\r\nrecording spoke of it, yet it is obvious, for if they hadn\'t had this\r\nquality, there would have been no recording left for us at all.\r\n\r\n"_How strange that these tortured people should practise an\r\nunparalleled example of Life\'s highest achievement ... complete honesty\r\nwith themselves and others._"\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


And with good reason. Here was a man who\'d\r\nspent his life in a machine shop coming down one morning to say in all\r\napparent sincerity, "I\'ve decided to be a concert pianist."\r\n\r\nJan Grabowski, on the turret lathe grinned and said, "Sure, John.\r\nThey\'ll bring in a grand piano and you can practice between cuts."\r\n\r\n"They laughed when I sat down to the piano," someone bellowed and there\r\nwas general laughter and the thing was forgotten.\r\n\r\nBut later, when he told the boss he was quitting, they looked at each\r\nother in amazement. He\'d evidently gone mad and that was no laughing\r\nmatter because they liked John.\r\n\r\nSam Paine, harassed plant manager still found time to be human. When he\r\ndiscovered John was serious, he sat down and gave him half an hour,\r\nfiguring he could find the quirk and straighten the man out. As they\r\nwent to his office, he swiftly classified his employee: John Harper--33\r\nyears old--introverted--intelligent over and above his job. Harper\r\nseemed to be without ambition, though and Sam wondered about this but\r\nhad never had time to talk with him much.\r\n\r\nAfter the half hour was up, Paine sighed and let him go. Obviously the\r\nconcert pianist gag was a coverup for something else--some fancied\r\nwrong--perhaps plain restlessness.\r\n\r\nAlone, Paine went back over the conversation, intrigued by John\r\nHarper\'s strange determination.\r\n\r\n"This talk about being a concert pianist is a gag of course, isn\'t it,\r\nJohn?"\r\n\r\n"No, Mr. 

Paine."\r\n\r\n"But man--you\'re too old to start a thing like that. You never in your\r\nlife studied music did you?"\r\n\r\n"No, sir."\r\n\r\n"Then let me tell you--first, in a thing like that, you\'ve got to have\r\ntalent. Have you got talent?"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know."\r\n\r\nIt had seemed ridiculous, seriously pinpointing things that should have\r\nbeen obvious. 

"Well let\'s say you have--just for argument\'s sake. 

All\r\nright--talent has to be caught early and nourished--like a seed--get\r\nwhat I mean? A man can\'t start at your age and get any place in a game\r\nthe experts started in at eight or nine--as children."\r\n\r\n"You may be right, Mr. 

Paine, but maybe that doesn\'t apply to me. Maybe\r\nit does, of course, but I\'ve got to find out."\r\n\r\nSam Paine gave up. He told John Harper his job would be waiting when\r\nhe wanted it again--even gave him an extra week\'s pay, but that was to\r\nsalve his conscience because he felt he should bring in a psychiatrist\r\nat company expense to see what had gone wrong with Harper. Then he\r\nshrugged and put the thing out of his mind. Funny things happen in this\r\nday and age, he thought.\r\n\r\nThe trouble was he didn\'t really know John Harper. No one did. A\r\nbachelor, Harper lived alone, thought alone--and suffered alone. He\r\nhated the futility of his life, the work he was doing, the passing of\r\nunfulfilled days and nights. He felt a strong pull of destiny he could\r\nneither explain nor deny; an unreasoning certainty that he, John Harper\r\nwas meant for better things; or perhaps a single better thing.\r\n\r\nHe lived with this certainty while the unfulfilled days and nights\r\npiled up. Until the misery became a pain and possibly demanded some\r\nsort of recognition by its very existence.\r\n\r\nAt any rate, the morning of the day he quit his job, he had just\r\nawakened to the old familiar dread of the day ahead; a dread almost\r\nakin to a physical sickness. 

He was sure he did not go back to sleep,\r\nbut he clearly saw, on the floor within range of his eyes, a television\r\nset. The picture was bright and clear--a famous newscaster with the\r\nsmile known from coast to coast and the rat-tat-tat voice that was his\r\ntrademark.\r\n\r\nHe was beginning his broadcast with the standard opening line: "_And\r\nnow, folks--what\'s been going on in the world? John Harper, the great\r\nconcert pianist--the man who brought long-hair music into the home--the\r\nman loved by millions, will--_"\r\n\r\nThe voice and the image vanished. Then the set faded, and John Harper\r\nlay tense in the bed in his shoddy little room. 

But a different John\r\nHarper now. In an instant he became a dedicated man knowing he had been\r\nbuilding up to this moment for years.\r\n\r\nThis was the incident Sam Paine did not know of; nor did anyone except\r\nJohn Harper himself. He had a little money saved up--a few hundred\r\ndollars--and he went straight to a music school. His difficulty was\r\nthat he could not camouflage his ambition--or rather his intent--and\r\nafter stating exactly what he proposed to do, he was turned down by\r\nfive reputable maestros in a row.\r\n\r\nSo he gave up seeking instruction and rented a piano. He was\r\nfortunately situated in that his room lay at the back of the resident\r\nhotel where he lived and the walls were as thick as the building was\r\nold and shoddy looking.\r\n\r\nHe bought some instruction books at a second hand store and went to\r\nwork. He practiced, plowing doggedly through the intricacies of the\r\nnotes and scales until his money ran out. Then he got a job washing\r\ndishes and practiced all night.\r\n\r\nUntil he was able to present himself again at a music school where the\r\nmaestro was, fortunately, both honest and possessed of a conscience.\r\nHis honesty said, send this man away. But John Harper had just enough\r\npathetic skill and foggy talent that the instructor\'s conscience\r\ndictated the final policy.\r\n\r\n"I will teach you," he said. Adding to himself, _It will be an act of\r\ncharity. Nothing more._ He would have been astounded, however, had he\r\nknown that four short months before John Harper had not known even the\r\nscale.\r\n\r\nJohn told no one this. He told no one anything. But he applied himself\r\nto the piano with a single-mindedness that made a fanatic seem\r\nchangeable as the wind by comparison.\r\n\r\nAnd soon, Professor Heinrich, he of the conscience, was confronted with\r\nsomething he could not understand. Genius was blooming and functioning\r\nbefore his eyes.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe rest is history. It is told in hushed tones how this sad-faced,\r\nmiddle-aged man with no background--he was called "The Man From\r\nNowhere," by certain romantically inclined critics--gave his first\r\nrecital in New York City. It was given exactly seven years from the day\r\nhe told Sam Paine, "I\'m quitting to become a concert pianist."\r\n\r\nThe television networks found him quickly and he rocketed to fame by\r\ngiving classical music an interpretation that made it understood and\r\nloved by millions.\r\n\r\nIt was said that John Harper gave more musical pleasure to the world in\r\nhis brief two-year career than had any other genius in a natural span.\r\n\r\nBut of course, the seven years had taken their toll. The punishment of\r\nlearning would have killed a far younger and stronger man than John\r\nHarper. So, after a tragically brief time at the top of his ladder,\r\nJohn Harper was the subject of a newscast.\r\n\r\nBy a famous newscaster with the smile famous from coast-to-coast and a\r\nrat-tat-tat voice that was his trademark.\r\n\r\nBut not smiling as he finished his first item. "_--be buried tomorrow\r\nin New York City._"\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nI lit the last cigarette I would ever smoke and took my airsuit out\r\nof the compartment under the control-board. The two-man cubicle was\r\ncoffin-cold even under the blast of sunlight pouring through the\r\nforward port, and the air smelled of stale tobacco and machine oil.\r\nBeside me Charlie Kosta\'s voice droned into the communicator, winging\r\nback two-hundred thirty thousand miles to the listening millions of\r\nEarth.\r\n\r\n"Our air is nearly gone," Charlie said. "We have about twelve minutes\r\nleft for deceleration, but we\'ll never make landing. The Luna V is\r\nriddled like a sieve, spewing out heavy-water fuel along with her\r\nair ... it\'s a miracle that a chunk hasn\'t crashed through our fuel\r\npile or the communicator--or through us. That\'s what blew up the first\r\nfour ships, we know now ... if men ever reach the moon they\'ll first\r\nhave to develop some sort of armor that will turn this barrage of\r\nmeteoric dust."\r\n\r\nI got my feet into the plastoid suit and pulled it on, letting\r\nthe transparent headpiece dangle over one shoulder like a parka\r\nhood. Charlie watched me with his tight grin, waiting through the\r\nthree-second lag of time for Earth\'s answer. Some high-ranking general\r\ndown there had pushed aside the Moon Foundation scientists to make\r\nhimself heard; his voice came over the hiss of static with a tinny,\r\nfrantic ring.\r\n\r\n"_Meteoric dust couldn\'t possibly pierce that alloy hull! It was tested\r\nover and over--_"\r\n\r\nWe waited him out, knowing that his frenzy was not for us nor for the\r\nsuccess of space flight. He was concerned, like all the military,\r\nonly with the establishing of a moon base to overlook Earth, an\r\nall-commanding launching site that would control a world. Once that\r\nbase was established, the ferment of war would come to a bitter end;\r\none nation would own the planet.\r\n\r\n"But you didn\'t test the hull out here," Charlie said patiently when\r\nthe general had finished. "You can\'t imagine the _speed_ of these\r\nparticles. We\'ve no protecting atmosphere to vaporize them, as Earth\r\nhas, and they streak through the ship so fast that they seem to strike\r\nboth sides of the hull at once.... I\'m cutting you over to Leonard\r\nNugent now. Ready, Len?

"\r\n\r\nIt was what I was waiting for. I had looked forward to this moment\r\nevery day of the nine years I had spent being groomed for the flight,\r\nand for half a lifetime of drilling before that. The waiting was almost\r\nover.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"I\'m ready," I said, and took the microphone. 

"But there\'s not much\r\npoint in reporting further, is there? With her fuel leaks the Luna V\r\nwill go like an A-bomb the instant we try to use the landing jets,\r\njust as the first four Lunas did ... the air is getting thinner, so\r\nthin that I\'ll have to put on my pressure suit soon. Are there any\r\nquestions?"\r\n\r\nMy only answer was the grind and roar of static.\r\n\r\nI could guess why; they were bickering and quarrelling among themselves\r\ndown there, the military men snarling at the scientists and the\r\nscientists snarling back, each blaming the other for this new failure.\r\nThe loss of the first four ships had been a mystery until they sent the\r\nLuna V out with co-pilots, equipped for full two-way communication.\r\nCharlie and I had reported from the beginning of the flight in\r\nalternate thirty-minute relays, keeping the Foundation posted so that\r\nif anything threatened us they would know the nature of the danger. Now\r\nthey were getting what they had asked for, and the problem would keep\r\nthem busy for another ten or fifteen years while the conquest of space\r\nmarked time. But they couldn\'t accept even temporary defeat calmly,\r\nof course--they had to quarrel among themselves, just as men have\r\nquarrelled since they first climbed down out of their trees and set\r\nabout organizing the business of killing each other.\r\n\r\n"We\'re going to try for a landing anyway," I said into the microphone.\r\n"We\'re going to cut in the decelerator jets as soon as we pass out of\r\nthe sun glare and into the moon\'s penumbra, where we can see."\r\n\r\nWe flashed suddenly into darkness, lost instantly in the vast conical\r\nshadow of the moon. The night half of the pocked globe loomed below,\r\nfaint and ghostly in the blue Earthshine, craggy and desolate, cold\r\nas space and as old as time. Earth hung above and behind us, and I\r\ncouldn\'t help thinking of the astronomers who had followed our flight\r\npatiently every inch of the way. They couldn\'t see us now; the daylight\r\ncrescent of the moon lay between the Luna V and the sun, burying us\r\ndeep in the utter darkness of space.\r\n\r\nCharlie took the microphone, speaking this time not to the Foundation\r\nbut to the millions who sat gaping at their radios. Some of them would\r\nbe muttering maudlin prayers for our safety, some would be gleefully\r\ncollecting the bets they had made on our chances of getting across; all\r\nof them would be thrilled to the core by the vicarious imminence of\r\ndanger and death.\r\n\r\n"We don\'t want mourning and demonstrations," Charlie said. "If you\r\npeople listening to me would like to honor our memory and the memory of\r\nthe men lost before us, then forget space travel for a while and try to\r\nwork out a lasting peace down there on Earth. Because it\'s inevitable\r\nthat you\'ll conquer space some day, and if you aren\'t ready for it when\r\nit comes--"\r\n\r\nHe clicked off the communicator, and we turned to the port together to\r\nwatch the little metal sphere that hurtled up out of the darkness past\r\nthe Luna V. From behind and above us there came a great white flash of\r\natomic fire that must have blinded for the moment every watching eye on\r\nEarth.\r\n\r\n"Right on schedule," Charlie said, and swung the Luna V over the\r\ndarkside rim and across the mysterious other side of the moon, the\r\nhidden hemisphere that no man has ever seen.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe ship was waiting for us there, a sleek, familiar cylinder with\r\nairlock standing open.\r\n\r\nWe went inside and closed the lock and stripped off our cumbersome\r\nairsuits, and Charlie flexed his arms and grinned at me. "Lord, I\'m\r\nglad to get that over with--it\'s been like nine years of prison!

"\r\n\r\n"It was worth it," I said. I was remembering the grim green world we\r\nhad left, shivering a little when I considered the brawling simian\r\nhordes who battered their way up the scale toward a culture that\r\nmight, unchecked, some day rule the Universe.\r\n\r\n"It gives us a few more years before they come swarming down on us with\r\ntheir atomic bombs and politics and their gaping tourists," I said,\r\nstill using the speech patterns that had been drilled into me for half\r\nmy life. "We\'ve marked time long enough, hoping for the best. 

We\'ll\r\nneed every minute we\'ve gained to get ready for them.

"\r\n\r\nWe went forward then to watch the purple-skinned pilot, hairy and\r\nmany-limbed and beautifully wrinkled, engage the magnetic drive that\r\nwould send us flashing toward the planet that was home. Later, in our\r\nnatural bodies, we would speak the name of that world with reverence,\r\nbut our clumsy synthetic Earth-tongues could not master its lovely\r\nsonic extensions, and so we used another term.\r\n\r\nFor the time being, we called it Mars....\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


The charred stumps. The jungle beyond--the visible mask of those\r\nmonstrous genes--rank, dark, utterly alien.\r\n\r\nAt the third dawn, Lance Llandark took two of us out in a \'copter.\r\nFlying a grid over the landing area, we mapped six shallow pock-marks\r\non that scowling wilderness, where our ships must have landed.\r\n\r\nWe dropped into the newest crater, where black stumps jutted like\r\nbroken teeth out of queerly bare red muck. A yellow-scummed stream\r\noozed across it. By the stream we found a fine-boned human skeleton.\r\n\r\nA nightmare plant stood guard beside the bones. Its thick leaves were\r\nstrangely streaked, twisted with vegetable agony, half poison spine and\r\nhalf blighted bloom. Shapeless blobs of rotting fruit were falling from\r\nit over those slender bones.\r\n\r\nLance Llandark stood up.\r\n\r\n"Her turquoise thunderbird." He showed us the bit of blackened silver\r\nand blue-veined stone. "Back on Terra.... Back when we were student\r\npilots.... We bought it from an Indian in an old, old town called Sante\r\nFe."\r\n\r\nHe bent again.\r\n\r\n"Lilith?" 

he whispered. "Lilith, what killed you?"\r\n\r\nWe found no other bones, nothing even to tell us what force or poison\r\nkept the creeping jungle back from that solitary plant. We left at\r\ndusk. Tenderly, Lance Llandark brought the gathered bones. Carefully we\r\ncarried a few leaves and dried pods from that crazy sentinel plant. We\r\nfound no other clue.\r\n\r\nPatiently, day by forty-hour day, we searched the other sites. We found\r\njet marks and stumps and teeming weeds, but nothing like that tormented\r\nnightmare over Lilith Llandark\'s skeleton. We found no wreckage.\r\nNothing to show how the planet had murdered the lost expeditions.\r\n\r\nDay by eternal day, the unknown leered from the secret places of its\r\ngenes. It was all vegetable. 

We saw no animal movement, heard no cry or\r\ninsect hum. The silence became suffocating.\r\n\r\nDay after desperate day, we returned to the micro-probe.\r\n\r\n"The answer\'s in the genes," Lance Llandark whispered grimly. "We\'ve no\r\nother chance."\r\n\r\nHe kept the probe running on the strangest genes of all; those from the\r\nplant nightmare that had grown beside his wife. They were like nothing\r\nelse on the planet. The double-stranded chains of DNA were monstrously\r\nlong; many of the nucleotide links held copper or arsenic atoms.\r\n\r\n"Queer!" Lance kept muttering. "No copper or arsenic in other plants\r\nhere. I\'d like to know why.

"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe was running when we heard the woman scream. In that stifling quiet,\r\nher cry unnerved us all. We crowded down to the lock.\r\n\r\nTattered, stained with blood-colored juices, she slipped through those\r\ncoiled, constricting creepers. She splashed out into the open ditch,\r\nwaving a filthy rag. Halfway to the ship, she fell into the mud.\r\n\r\nLance Llandark led three of us to bring her in. She whimpered and\r\nlooked up. Tears streaked the grime on her wasted face.\r\n\r\n"Lance!" she gasped. 

"My dear."\r\n\r\n"Lilith--" But he shrank back suddenly. "I found Lilith dead!"\r\n\r\n"I am nearly dead." She tried weakly to get up. "You see, we\'re all\r\nmarooned out there in the bush. Emergency landing, when we tried to get\r\noff. Wrecked our astrogation gear. Need your spare astro-pilot--"\r\n\r\n"Back." He swung on us. "Back aboard!

"\r\n\r\n"What\'s wrong?" We were stunned, "She\'s your wife--"\r\n\r\n"Aboard! Instanter!"\r\n\r\nWe obeyed his deadly voice.\r\n\r\n"Help--" she whispered faintly behind us in the mud. "Survivors--need\r\nastro-pilot-to plot our way home--"\r\n\r\nThe clanging lock cut off her voice.\r\n\r\nAngrily we turned on Lance Llandark.\r\n\r\n"Hold it!" he snapped. 

"I\'m not crazy--the planet is. Come along to the\r\nmicro-probe. I\'m probing a seed from the plant we found by Lilith\'s\r\nbones. It puzzled me. So much of it was--"\r\n\r\nIn spite of the tension, he had to grope for a word to express meaning.\r\n\r\n"Arbitrary! Those shapeless leaves, twisted stalk, that sterile seed.\r\nThe copper and arsenic in those needless links. Too many genes had no\r\nfunction. No use at all!\r\n\r\n"I\'d just got the key, when that thing screamed. The copper and arsenic\r\natoms are not genetic instructions to the plant. They\'re a message to\r\nus--words replicated a trillion times, and concealed in every cell of\r\nthe plant!"\r\n\r\n"Words?" someone whispered blankly. "Words in the atoms?"\r\n\r\n"Written in binary code." His scowl was bleakly triumphant. "That\r\nweed\'s a mutant, you see. The real Lilith formed the first cell with\r\nher micro-probe. She left it--I suppose in her own body--as a message\r\nthat no pseudo-Lilith could intercept."\r\n\r\nOutside that something screamed again.\r\n\r\n"Call each copper atom a dot," he whispered. "Call each arsenic a dash.\r\nTaken in order along the chains of DNA, they do encode a message. 

The\r\ncomputer\'s decoding it now."\r\n\r\nHe punched a button, and the printer whirred.\r\n\r\nTO WHOEVER COMES.... GIVE NO AID TO ANYONE.... GET OFF THIS PLANET....\r\nITS LIFE IS PSEUDOMORPHIC.... DON\'T LET IT LEAVE.... JUST TAKE MY\r\nLOVE TO LANCE LLANDARK.... FROM LILITH, HIS WIFE.... AND GET OFF THIS\r\nPLANET, FAST....\r\n\r\nOutside, it uttered a frantic, bubbling screech.\r\n\r\nWe did get off the planet, and we expect to stay away.\r\n\r\nEND\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


"Thank you. 

But, dammit, I\r\nwish you didn\'t have that everlasting smile!"\r\n\r\n"I am very sorry, Miss Alice, but I am unable to alter myself in any\r\nway," replied Herbert in his polite, hollow voice.\r\n\r\nHe retired to a corner and stood impassively, still holding the tray.\r\nHerbert had found a silver deposit and made the tray. Herbert had found\r\nsand and made the cocktail glass. Herbert had combined God knew what\r\natmospheric and earth chemicals to make what tasted like gin and\r\nvermouth, and Herbert had frozen the ice to chill it.\r\n\r\n"Sometimes," said Thera wistfully, "it occurs to me it would be better\r\nto live in a mud hut with a real man than in a mansion with Herbert."\r\n\r\nThe four women lolled comfortably in the living room of their spacious\r\nhouse, as luxurious as anything any of them would have known on distant\r\nEarth. The rugs were thick, the furniture was overstuffed, the paintings\r\non the walls were aesthetic and inspiring, the shelves were filled with\r\nbooktapes and musictapes.\r\n\r\nHerbert had done it all, except the booktapes and musictapes, which had\r\nbeen salvaged from the wrecked spaceship.\r\n\r\n"Do you suppose we\'ll ever escape from this best of all possible manless\r\nworlds?" asked Betsy, fluffing her thick black hair with her fingers and\r\ninspecting herself in a Herbert-made mirror.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t see how," answered blond Alice glumly. "That atmospheric trap\r\nwould wreck any other ship just as it wrecked ours, and the same\r\nmagnetic layer prevents any radio message from getting out. 

No, I\'m\r\nafraid we\'re a colony."\r\n\r\n"A colony perpetuates itself," reminded sharp-faced Marguerite, acidly.\r\n"We aren\'t a colony, without men."\r\n\r\nThey were not the prettiest four women in the universe, nor the\r\nyoungest. The prettiest women and the youngest did not go to space. But\r\nthey were young enough and healthy enough, or they could not have gone\r\nto space.\r\n\r\nIt had been a year and a half now--an Earth year and a half on a nice\r\nlittle planet revolving around a nice little yellow sun. Herbert, the\r\nrobot, was obedient and versatile and had provided them with a house,\r\nfood, clothing, anything they wished created out of the raw elements of\r\nearth and air and water. But the bones of all the men who had been\r\naspace with these four ladies lay mouldering in the wreckage of their\r\nspaceship.\r\n\r\nAnd Herbert could not create a man. Herbert did not have to have direct\r\norders, and he had tried once to create a man when he had overheard them\r\nwishing for one. They had buried the corpse--perfect in every detail\r\nexcept that it never had been alive.\r\n\r\n"It\'s been a hot day," said Alice, fanning her brow. "I wish it would\r\nrain."\r\n\r\nSilently, Herbert moved from his corner and went out the door.\r\n\r\nMarguerite gestured after him with a bitter little laugh.\r\n\r\n"It\'ll rain this afternoon," she said. "I don\'t know how Herbert does\r\nit--maybe with silver iodide. But it\'ll rain. Wouldn\'t it have been\r\nsimpler to get him to air-condition the house, Alice?"\r\n\r\n"That\'s a good idea," said Alice thoughtfully. "We should have had him\r\ndo it before."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHerbert had not quite completed the task of air-conditioning the house\r\nwhen the other spaceship crashed. They all rushed out to the smoking\r\nsite--the four women and Herbert.\r\n\r\nIt was a tiny scoutship, and its single occupant was alive.\r\n\r\nHe was unconscious, but he was alive. And he was a man!\r\n\r\nThey carted him back to the house, tenderly, and put him to bed. They\r\nhovered over him like four hens over a single chick, waiting and\r\nwatching for him to come out of his coma, while Herbert scurried about\r\ncreating and administering the necessary medicines.\r\n\r\n"He\'ll live," said Thera happily. Thera had been a space nurse. "He\'ll\r\nbe on his feet and walking around in a few weeks.

"\r\n\r\n"A man!" 

murmured Betsy, with something like awe in her voice. "I could\r\nalmost believe Herbert brought him here in answer to our prayers."\r\n\r\n"Now, girls," said Alice, "we have to realize that a man brings\r\nproblems, as well as possibilities."\r\n\r\nThere was a matter-of-fact hardness to her tone which almost masked the\r\nquiver behind it. There was a defiant note of competition there which\r\nhad not been heard on this little planet before.\r\n\r\n"What do you mean?" asked Thera.\r\n\r\n"I know what she means," said Marguerite, and the new hardness came\r\nnatural to her. "She means, which one of us gets him?"\r\n\r\nBetsy, the youngest, gasped, and her mouth rounded to a startled O.\r\nThera blinked, as though she were coming out of a daze.\r\n\r\n"That\'s right," said Alice. "Do we draw straws, or do we let him\r\nchoose?"\r\n\r\n"Couldn\'t we wait?" suggested Betsy timidly. 

"Couldn\'t we wait until he\r\ngets well?"\r\n\r\nHerbert came in with a new thermometer and poked it into the unconscious\r\nman\'s mouth. He stood by the bed, waiting patiently.\r\n\r\n"No, I don\'t think we can," said Alice. "I think we ought to have it all\r\nworked out and agreed on, so there won\'t be any dispute about it."\r\n\r\n"I say, draw straws," said Marguerite. Marguerite\'s face was thin, and\r\nshe had a skinny figure.\r\n\r\nBetsy, the youngest, opened her mouth, but Thera forestalled her.\r\n\r\n"We are not on Earth," she said firmly, in her soft, mellow voice. "We\r\ndon\'t have to follow terrestrial customs, and we shouldn\'t. 

There\'s only\r\none solution that will keep everybody happy--all of us and the man.

"\r\n\r\n"And that is...?" asked Marguerite drily.\r\n\r\n"Polygamy, of course. He must belong to us all."\r\n\r\nBetsy shuddered but, surprisingly, she nodded.\r\n\r\n"That\'s well and good," agreed Marguerite, "but we have to agree that no\r\none of us will be favored above the others. He has to understand that\r\nfrom the start."\r\n\r\n"That\'s fair," said Alice, pursing her lips. "Yes, that\'s fair. But I\r\nagree with Marguerite: he must be divided equally among the four of us."\r\n\r\nChattering over the details, the hard competitiveness vanished from\r\ntheir tones, the four left the sickroom to prepare supper.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAfter supper they went back in.\r\n\r\nHerbert stood by the bed, the eternal smile of service on his metal\r\nface. As always, Herbert had not required a direct command to accede to\r\ntheir wishes.\r\n\r\nThe man was divided into four quarters, one for each of them. It was a\r\nvery neat surgical job.\r\n\r\n\r\n                                                                   END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _If Worlds of Science Fiction_ June\r\n    1958. ]\r\n\r\n\r\nThe sign on the door said Ernest H. Smith, Private Investigator.\r\nThe door opened and a woman came in. She was a brunette, about\r\nfive-feet-two, wearing a yellow dress with black buttons. She carried a\r\nbrown alligator handbag. "I am Mrs. Wilma Rogers," she said. "You were\r\nrecommended to me."\r\n\r\nSmith motioned to a chair in front of his desk. "Sit down, Mrs. Rogers.\r\nDo you have a card?"\r\n\r\nShe sat down and opened her handbag. She took out a small card and\r\nhanded it to him. He looked at the printed words, "Recommended to\r\nSmith." He opened a desk drawer and removed a small bottle of red\r\nliquid, spilling a few drops on the blank side of the card. Soon there\r\nwas visible writing on it. 

"Okay for any service," it said.\r\n\r\n"All right," Smith nodded, "what can I do for you?"\r\n\r\n"I want you to kill my husband," she said pleasantly.\r\n\r\nSmith swiveled his chair around to face the typewriter, inserted a\r\nblank sheet of white paper, and began to type. "Why do you want him\r\nkilled?"\r\n\r\n"He\'s stingy--he won\'t give me enough money."\r\n\r\n"How much money will he leave you, Mrs. Rogers?"\r\n\r\n"Roughly two hundred thousand," she said. "There\'s insurance, of\r\ncourse, but I understand we can\'t count on that."\r\n\r\nSmith smiled. 

"That\'s a nice sum. Now what time would be most\r\nconvenient?"\r\n\r\nShe shrugged her shoulders. "Any time suits me."\r\n\r\nSmith laughed. "I mean for your husband. What time would be best for\r\nkilling him?"\r\n\r\n"Oh," she said. Her brow wrinkled and she began to mutter, "Let\'s see,\r\nnow ... home at five-fifteen, reads the paper ... takes a shower ...\r\ndinner at six-fifteen ... I can send the servants out at\r\nseven-thirty ... oh, I think eight will be perfect."\r\n\r\n"Eight it is," said Smith, putting the information on paper. "Now for a\r\nbit of information about the house and grounds. Can\'t afford to bungle\r\ninto the wrong place and foul up the job."\r\n\r\nMrs. Rogers opened her purse again and withdrew a folded sheet of\r\npaper. "I\'ve got a floor-plan of the house here, with the address and\r\neverything marked off."\r\n\r\nSmith took the paper and looked at it. "You don\'t overlook anything, do\r\nyou? Why didn\'t you just go ahead and do the job yourself?"\r\n\r\nShe smiled and shrugged. "I understand you can perform a perfect\r\nmurder. I\'m afraid I couldn\'t."\r\n\r\nSmith removed the typewritten sheet from the machine and inserted a\r\nfresh sheet. He filled it in with names, dates, and figures. When he\r\nfinished he handed it to her. "Sign on the bottom line."\r\n\r\nShe took the paper and looked at it.\r\n\r\n"It\'s our contract," said Smith. "I have to have a guarantee that\r\nyou\'ll go through with your part of the bargain. If you don\'t, I\'ll\r\nhave that signed confession."\r\n\r\nMrs. Rogers looked at him in silence for a moment, then she laughed and\r\nsigned the paper. 

"You don\'t overlook anything, yourself."\r\n\r\n"No, Ma\'am," said Smith.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAt exactly five minutes before eight, Smith drove his panel truck\r\nthrough the gate to the Rogers home, turned out the lights, and drove\r\nsilently to the house. He parked near the side entrance, got out, went\r\naround the truck, which was labeled, "Smith\'s TV Repair," and opened\r\nthe back doors. He lifted a pile of ragged quilts from the floor and\r\npicked up a small air-pistol. Wrapped carefully in the quilts was a\r\ntiny bottle of dark green liquid, marked "Poison." He took a small\r\ndart from his pocket, opened the bottle and applied a small amount of\r\nthe liquid to the tip of the projectile. Then he loaded the pistol with\r\nthe dart, stuck it in his coat pocket, and replaced the bottle.\r\n\r\nHe walked rapidly to the door of the house, stopped at the steps to\r\nconsult the floor-plan, and then entered. He went up the stairs and\r\ndirectly to the second door on the left. He turned the knob silently\r\nand eased inside.\r\n\r\nA small man, dressed in a dark suit, was seated at a desk, writing with\r\na fountain pen on light blue paper. He looked up and said, "Who are\r\nyou?

"\r\n\r\n"I\'m Smith, the TV repairman--are you Rogers?"\r\n\r\n"Yes, but I--"\r\n\r\nThen Smith killed him.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe emerged from the house with Rogers draped over his shoulder and\r\nstaggered over to the truck. He shoved the corpse in and crawled in\r\nafter. Moving rapidly, he opened the door of a trim metal cabinet\r\ndirectly behind the cab and shoved Rogers inside. Then he pushed a\r\nbutton on the side of the contraption and it began to hum.\r\n\r\nAfter two minutes he cut the power and opened the cabinet. It was empty.\r\n\r\nSmith whistled softly as he walked back to the house. He strode noisily\r\nin and called, "Hey, Mrs. Rogers!"\r\n\r\nShe emerged from a door near the head of the stairs and came down.\r\n"Yes?" she said.\r\n\r\nSmith grinned at her. "It\'s okay, lady--the job is over."\r\n\r\n"Good! Let me fix you a drink, and you can tell me all about it."\r\n\r\nSmith sat down on a couch. 

She prepared the drinks and brought his\r\nover. They sat together and sipped the liquor.\r\n\r\n"Science is wonderful," she said.\r\n\r\n"Yeah, it sure is," said Smith. "They spend millions figuring out fancy\r\nways to catch crooks, and then some dumb professor invents a way so I\r\ncan kill people and never be caught."\r\n\r\n"I wonder what the cops a hundred years in the future will think when\r\nbodies start popping up all over the place?" she observed.\r\n\r\n"Who cares?" 

said Smith. "I\'m making my dough, even if I will have to\r\nwait seven years for the heirs to collect."\r\n\r\n"It won\'t be too hard to wait," she said, "since we know for certain\r\nwe\'ll get it."\r\n\r\n"Let\'s drink to our success," Smith said.\r\n\r\n"Let\'s," she smiled.\r\n\r\n"Here\'s to a fine old professor, who invented a time machine and\r\nkindly let me kill him and take it away. Here\'s to a policeman\'s\r\nnightmare--the perfect murder."\r\n\r\nThey drank.\r\n\r\nSmith got to his feet then and put the glass down. "Well, I\'ve got to\r\ngo now, I--"\r\n\r\nHe saw the blank look of astonishment on her face. Her mouth had\r\ndropped open and her eyes were wide, staring. But they weren\'t looking\r\nat him--they were looking _behind_ him.\r\n\r\nAnd then he heard the polite cough.\r\n\r\nSmith spun around. He stared in amazement at the figure of a man\r\nstanding there. A man clad in a strange shimmering metallic uniform.\r\nThe man held an odd-looking weapon in his hand. He was smiling.\r\n\r\n"Mr. 

Smith, I believe?"\r\n\r\nSmith nodded automatically. "Yes, but who--"\r\n\r\n"--am I?" the stranger completed the sentence for him. "It\'s quite\r\nsimple. I\'m Inspector Graevod, homicide. I\'m arresting you for murder."\r\n\r\nSmith shook his head dully. 

"But that\'s impossible. There\'s no\r\nmurder--no body.... Where did you come from?"\r\n\r\nThe shimmering man smiled pleasantly. "Oh but there is a body. Matter\r\nof fact there are quite a few. We\'ve had quite a bit of difficulty in\r\ntracing you down. I\'ve come all the way from 2035 to find you." He\r\nturned his eyes to the woman. "As an accessory to the fact you are also\r\nunder arrest. 

Come along, both of you.

"\r\n\r\nHe pointed the strange weapon at them and a silver radiance swept from\r\nit to envelope their bodies.\r\n\r\nBut only for a moment. Then they were gone....\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nIt\'s still very clear in my mind. 

The whole episode. The afternoon\r\nvisit to Marsten\'s office, the trip to Mars, and the journey back.\r\n\r\nIt was one of those warm summer afternoons. All one craved for was a\r\npatch of green grass to recline on and maybe a faint breeze to tingle\r\none\'s forehead. I was sure of the grass and hopeful for the breeze.\r\nBut one of Marsten\'s messengers popped up and the grass and the breeze\r\nwould have to wait. After all, Marsten was my boss.\r\n\r\nHe had his office in the Empire State Building. Norbert Marsten was the\r\nowner of the Marsten Circus, the greatest, biggest, loudest circus in\r\nthe world. And if you don\'t believe it, ask Mr. Marsten.\r\n\r\n"Sit down, Nick," he invited, speaking from one corner of his mouth as\r\nthe other corner was busy chewing a dollar cigar. Marsten was a small\r\nman with sleek black, hair. A small man with big ideas.\r\n\r\nI sat down.\r\n\r\n"Nick, you\'re the best \'bring \'em back alive\' man I\'ve got. The best.

"\r\n\r\nThis was very true. "You\'ve got a job for me," I said.\r\n\r\n"That\'s correct."\r\n\r\n"So why the buildup? Tell me what you want."\r\n\r\n"I want something that no other circus has."\r\n\r\n"You must be kidding. You have every known animal there is. Why, the\r\nbushmaster I brought you two months ago is the longest--"\r\n\r\n"It isn\'t exactly an animal I want."\r\n\r\n"Oh? You mean you want a performer? What the hell have I got to do--"\r\n\r\n"What I want is out of this world."\r\n\r\n"A different kind of act? I still say--"\r\n\r\n"I want a Martian."\r\n\r\nI was glad I didn\'t have a mirror in front of my face. I could imagine\r\nhow foolish I looked with my mouth hanging open.\r\n\r\n"I even have a name picked out for him," Marsten persisted. "Marty, the\r\nMartian. What do you think of that?"\r\n\r\nI stood up slowly. "Let me know when you\'ve recovered."\r\n\r\nMarsten came around the desk. "Sit down. 

Now listen to me. Did you ever\r\nhear of a man named Hendrick Ritter?"\r\n\r\n"No."\r\n\r\n"The greatest scientist in the world. He\'s been working for me for over\r\na year. I hired him to do one particular job for me: to concoct a fuel\r\nthat will get a space ship to Mars and back. Well, it\'s done. Did you\r\never hear of a man named Sam Young?"\r\n\r\n"Same answer as before."\r\n\r\n"He\'s a designer for air ships. The best in the business. 

He\'s finished\r\na job for me. And, Nick, it\'s already built. 

And I\'ve got Joe Roane\r\nworking for me."\r\n\r\n"I\'ve heard of him," I said.\r\n\r\n"The greatest pilot in the world," Marsten said.\r\n\r\n"The greatest this, the greatest that. And for what? 

Why, the ship\r\nprobably won\'t get off the ground."\r\n\r\nMarsten chewed furiously on his cigar. "But what if it does get off\r\nthe ground? What if it does get to Mars?"\r\n\r\n"All right. So what? How do you know there\'s life on Mars?"\r\n\r\n"There is. I hired the greatest--"\r\n\r\n"Oh, no," I groaned. "I believe you, I believe you. 

So now we\'re on\r\nMars."\r\n\r\n"You capture a Martian and bring him back."\r\n\r\n"What if he doesn\'t care to be captured?"\r\n\r\n"What do I pay you for?"\r\n\r\nI thought this out, then said, "To capture Martians."\r\n\r\n"Exactly."\r\n\r\n"You wouldn\'t settle for a moon maiden, would you? I heard they\'re\r\ncute. 

And sexy."\r\n\r\n"A Martian." He was very adamant. "I\'ll have the greatest attraction in\r\nthe world. Nick, I\'m the kind who gets what he wants. I\'ve spent over\r\nthree million dollars on this project and I\'m ready to spend another\r\nthree million. Just get me my Martian and you\'ll be a rich man. You\'ll\r\nbe rich enough to quit working for me and to tell me to go to hell.\r\nYou\'d like that, wouldn\'t you?"\r\n\r\n"I\'d like that very much."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nTwo weeks later we went to Arizona. A week after that we took off. I\r\ndidn\'t really think we would. But we did.\r\n\r\nJust me and Joe Roane. Two men in a space ship.\r\n\r\nA huge metal tube hurtling through the longest and blackest of nights.\r\n\r\nJoe Roane was a good-looking chap. Good-looking, young, and excited.\r\nHe was the first to pilot a ship to Mars. He was looking ahead to the\r\nglory that awaited him.\r\n\r\nWe landed on Mars.\r\n\r\nWe put on helmets that Ritter and Young had made for us. We stepped\r\ndown the metal ladder.\r\n\r\nThey were there, waiting for us.\r\n\r\nI\'d rather have faced a bushmaster or a rhino.\r\n\r\nThey stood on three legs. They had globe bellies, tiny heads, and no\r\nnecks. They were of a color I had never seen before. They had two arms\r\nwith two hands attached to each arm. I suppose they were hands. They\r\nwere more like claws.\r\n\r\nI stood frozen solid. Joe Roane screamed and turned to run back up the\r\nladder. A beam flashed and Joe fell forward, silent and very dead.\r\n\r\nAfter that it was all a blank.\r\n\r\nWhen I came to I was strapped down by metal clasps on a long board made\r\nof some kind of marble. I was alone for some time.\r\n\r\nI don\'t remember how long it was before one of them appeared. 

He stood\r\nby my side, looking down at me. His eyes were purple. 

There were no\r\nwhites. "You have come a long way," he said.\r\n\r\n"You--you speak English?"\r\n\r\n"We used a 64-V machine on you. We learned your language, your\r\nthoughts, your name. We know about Norbert Marsten. A very enterprising\r\nman, it seems."\r\n\r\n"What are you going to do with me?"\r\n\r\n"We haven\'t decided yet. So you were going to take one of us back with\r\nyou for Marsten\'s circus. To exhibit one of us to your stupid race. My\r\nfollowers wanted to kill you when this information was learned. But I\r\nbelieve I have a better idea."\r\n\r\nHe went away. I yelled for him to come back. I yelled till my throat\r\nwas dry. Eventually he did come back. He came back with Joe Roane\r\nand ... myself.\r\n\r\n"I want you to meet Klar and Grat," he said. "They have taken over\r\nyour bodies; you will take theirs--and return to Marsten. We have\r\na transformer machine to accomplish this. Only we never had an\r\nopportunity to use it until you were so gracious as to visit us." He\r\nspoke on, telling me of his idea. I shuddered and wished for death. I\r\nbegged him to kill me.\r\n\r\nThen a contraption was fitted over me and it hummed and I passed out. I\r\nremember the trip back to earth.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI\'m no longer Nick Faber. I\'m Marty the Martian. What a cute title\r\nMarsten had hung on me. I\'ve got a nice home and I get plenty to eat.\r\nOnly my home is a cage and it\'s made of glass. People come from all\r\nover the world just to see me. And Marsten has been to see me every\r\nday. He chews on his big cigar and there\'s a smile on his face a yard\r\nwide.\r\n\r\nI\'ve tried to talk to my keepers but all I can manage is some crazy\r\nkind of gibberish. I also see Klar and Grat. But they\'re only there\r\nwhen Marsten is around. They\'re keeping very close to him. My being\r\ntransformed into a Martian was just part of it. Klar and Grat were\r\ngoing to carry out the rest of it.\r\n\r\nOn one dark night, and very soon, Klar, Grat, and Marsten were going to\r\ndisappear.\r\n\r\nMaybe I was the greatest attraction on earth. But Norbert Marsten was\r\ngoing to be the greatest attraction on Mars.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nJoe had quite a day for himself Thursday and as usual I had to tag\r\nalong. If I had a right arm to give I\'d give it for a day off now and\r\nthen. Like on Thursday. On Thursday he really outdid himself.\r\n\r\nHe woke up in the hotel room and had a shower. He wasn\'t going to shave\r\nuntil I told him he looked like a bum. So he shaved and then he stood\r\nfor a whole minute admiring his beauty in the mirror, forgetting whose\r\nidea it was in the first place.\r\n\r\nSo down to the coffee shop for breakfast. A hard-working man needs a\r\ngood breakfast. So getting ready for a backbreaking day of copying\r\nreferences at the library, he had tomato juice, two fried eggs, three\r\nsausages, a sugared doughnut and coffee--with cream and sugar.\r\n\r\nHe couldn\'t work that off his pot in a week of ditch-digging under\r\na July sun, but a hard-working man needs a good breakfast. I was\r\ntoo disgusted to argue with him. He\'s hopeless when he smells that\r\nshort-order smell of smoking grease, frying bacon and coffee.\r\n\r\nHe wanted to take a taxi to the library--eight blocks!\r\n\r\n"Walk, you jerk!" I told him. He started to mumble about pulling down\r\nsix hundred bucks for this week\'s work and then he must have thought\r\nI was going to mention the high-calorie breakfast. To him that\'s\r\nhitting below the belt. 

He thinks he\'s an unfortunate man with an\r\naffliction--about twenty pounds of it. He walked and arrived at the\r\nlibrary glowing with virtue.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nMaking out his slip at the newspaper room he blandly put down next to\r\n_firm_--_The Griffin Press, Inc._--when he knew as well as I did that\r\nhe was a free lance and hadn\'t even got a definite assignment from\r\nGriffin.\r\n\r\nThere\'s a line on the slip where you put down _reason for consulting\r\nfiles (please be specific)_. It\'s a shame to cramp Joe\'s style to\r\njust one line after you pitch him an essay-type question like that.\r\nHe squeezed in, _Preparation of article on year in biochemistry for\r\nGriffin Pr. Encyc. 1952 Yrbk._, and handed it with a flourish to the\r\nlibrarian.\r\n\r\nThe librarian, a nice old man, was polite to him, which is usually\r\na mistake with Joe. After he finished telling the librarian how his\r\nmicrofilm files ought to be organized and how they ought to switch from\r\nmicrofilm to microcard and how in spite of everything the New York\r\nPublic Library wasn\'t such a bad place to research, he got down to work.\r\n\r\nHe\'s pretty harmless when he\'s working--it\'s one of the things that\r\nkeeps me from cutting his throat. With a noon break for apple pie and\r\ncoffee he transcribed about a hundred entries onto his cards, mopping\r\nup the year in biochemistry nicely. He swaggered down the library\r\nsteps, feeling like Herman Melville after finishing Moby Dick.\r\n\r\n"Don\'t be so smug," I told him. "You still have to write the piece. 

And\r\nthey still have to buy it."\r\n\r\n"A detail," he said grandly. "Just journalism. I can do it with my eyes\r\nshut."\r\n\r\nJust journalism. Somehow his three months of running copy for the A.P.\r\nbefore the war has made him an Ed Leahy.\r\n\r\n"_When_ are you going to do it with your eyes...?" I began but it\r\nwasn\'t any use. He began telling me about how Gautama Buddha didn\'t\r\nbreak with the world until he was 29 and Mohammed didn\'t announce that\r\nhe was a prophet until he was 30, so why couldn\'t _he_ one of these\r\ndays suddenly bust loose with a new revelation or something and set the\r\nworld on its ear? What it boiled down to was he didn\'t think he\'d write\r\nthe article tonight.\r\n\r\nHe postponed his break with the world long enough to have a ham and\r\ncheese on rye and more coffee at an automat and then phoned Maggie. She\r\nwas available as usual. 

She said as usual, "Well then, why don\'t you\r\njust drop by and we\'ll spend a quiet evening with some records?"\r\n\r\nAs usual he thought that would be fine since he was so beat after a\r\nhard day. As usual I told him, "You\'re a louse, Joe. You know all she\r\nwants is a husband and you know it isn\'t going to be you, so why don\'t\r\nyou let go of the girl so she can find somebody who means business?"\r\n\r\nThe usual answers rolled out automatically and we got that out of the\r\nway.\r\n\r\nMaybe Maggie isn\'t very bright but she seemed glad to see him. She\'s\r\nshooting for her Doctorate in sociology at N.Y.U., she does part-time\r\ncase work for the city, she has one of those three-room Greenwich\r\nVillage apartments with dyed burlap drapes and studio couches and\r\nhome-made mobiles. She thinks writing is something holy and Joe\'s\r\ncareful not to tell her different.\r\n\r\nThey drank some rhine wine and seltzer while Joe talked about the\r\nday\'s work as though he\'d won the Nobel prize for biochemistry. He got\r\ndownright brutal about Maggie being mixed up in such an approximate\r\nunquantitative excuse for a science as sociology and she apologized\r\nhumbly and eventually he forgave her. Big-hearted Joe.\r\n\r\nBut he wasn\'t so fried that he _had_ to start talking about a man\r\nwanting to settle down--"not this year but maybe next. Thirty\'s a\r\ndividing point that makes you stop and wonder what you really want and\r\nwhat you\'ve really got out of life, Maggie darlin\'." It was as good as\r\ntelling her that she should be a good girl and continue to keep open\r\nhouse for him and maybe some day ... maybe.\r\n\r\nAs I said, maybe Maggie isn\'t very bright. But as I also said,\r\nThursday was the day Joe picked to outdo himself.\r\n\r\n"Joe," she said with this look on her face, "I got a new LP of the\r\nBrahms Serenade Number One. It\'s on top of the stack. 

Would you tell me\r\nwhat you think of it?"\r\n\r\nSo he put it on and they sat sipping rhine wine and seltzer and he\r\nturned it over and they sat sipping rhine wine and seltzer until both\r\nsides were played. And she kept watching him. Not adoringly.\r\n\r\n"Well," she asked with this new look, "what did you think of it?

"\r\n\r\nHe told her, of course. There was some comment on Brahms\'\r\narchitectonics and his resurrection of the contrapuntal style. Because\r\nhe\'d sneaked a look at the record\'s envelope he was able to spend a\r\ncouple of minutes on Brahms\' debt to Haydn and the young Beethoven in\r\nthe fifth movement (_allegro_, D Major) and the gay _rondo_ of the--\r\n\r\n"Joe," she said, not looking at him. "Joe," she said, "I got that\r\nrecord at one hell of a discount down the street. It\'s a wrong\r\npressing. Somehow the first side is the first half of the Serenade but\r\nthe second half is Schumann\'s Symphonic Studies Opus Thirteen. Somebody\r\nnoticed it when they played it in a booth. 

But I guess you didn\'t\r\nnotice it."\r\n\r\n"Get out of _this one_, braino," I told him.\r\n\r\nHe got up and said in a strangled voice, "And I thought you were my\r\nfriend. I suppose I\'ll never learn." He walked out.\r\n\r\nI suppose he never will.\r\n\r\nGod help me, I ought to know.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nThe three crew members of the Ad Astra looked at one another, grinning\r\nweakly, in the whispering silence after the motors had kicked off. This\r\nwas the culminating point of a half-century of preparation; behind them\r\nwas the satellite launching station--ahead of them, a faint red dot,\r\nwas Mars.\r\n\r\nBryan, nominal head of the expedition, touched the shutter studs that\r\nopened their windows on the universe. They stood silently, the three of\r\nthem; Bryan and Hughes looking back at the majesty of the retreating\r\nEarth--Williams, rigid with ecstasy at the forward port.\r\n\r\nThe stars were his passion and his joy. Women filled a momentary\r\nneed, men he accepted or rejected as they could help him to achieve\r\nhis goal. Now, as astrogator of the Ad Astra he had fulfilled his\r\ndream; and now before him Canopus, Rigel, Cassiopeia and Aldebaran lay\r\njewel-like on the dark velvet of space.\r\n\r\nHow stars had absorbed the thoughts of mankind since the beginning, he\r\nthought happily, and what dreams had the ancient Chaldeans known as\r\nthey mapped the routes of the galleons of space? And the poets.... "See\r\nhow the floor of Heaven is thick inlaid with patines of bright gold--"\r\nhe quoted softly.\r\n\r\n"My, that\'s pretty," Bryan said solemnly behind him. 

"Who said that?

"\r\n\r\n"Williams did--" returned Hughes equally dead-pan.\r\n\r\nWilliams flushed under their good-natured grins. "Shakespeare said it,\r\nyou uneducated yokels," he said loftily. "How come you aren\'t cheating\r\neach other at gin rummy yet? 

Last I heard one of you owed the other a\r\nmillion dollars."\r\n\r\n"It was only six hundred thousand," Hughes grinned, "and I\'m about to\r\ntake him double or nothing!"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe weeks passed slowly. 

Barely audible, the computers ticked, keeping\r\nthe ship on course. Bryan and Hughes wrangled amiably over their\r\ninterminable card-games, throwing an occasional, joking aside to\r\nWilliams watching the stars, absorbed as a miser fingering his jewels.\r\n\r\nMars, from a minute speck, grew to a planet lying bloody in the\r\ncold rays of the distant sun. Strapped down in obedience to the\r\ncomputer-given signal, the ship reversed, fired its rockets and touched\r\ndown on her supporting pillars of flame and became only a shining\r\nneedle dwarfed in the immensity of the pinkish-red desert.\r\n\r\nThey looked at each other doubtfully, conscious of anti-climax. This\r\nwas little different from the far reaches of the Gobi plateau where\r\nthey had trained for weary, boring months. Bryan and Hughes drew the\r\nlots as the two to don their heated, protective suits and explore\r\nwithin cautious distance of the ship. Williams, restless and bored,\r\nwatched their horseplay resentfully. Even the tenuous atmosphere of the\r\ndead world dimmed the splendor of the heavens; why didn\'t they hurry\r\nand get it over with? He shivered a little watching Bryan and Hughes\r\ntrudging clumsily in the sand, throwing out a comment occasionally for\r\nthe benefit of the tape recorder in the cabin.\r\n\r\n"This is different from the deserts back home," Hughes said. "Back\r\nthere you get the feeling they\'re just waiting for somebody to move in,\r\nbut here...."\r\n\r\n"It\'s more like a haunted house," Bryan finished for him. Williams,\r\nadjusting his headphones, was conscious of a deepening of his faint\r\nuneasiness--why didn\'t they hurry up and get back! All they really had\r\nto do was build a cairn and plant the Federation flag. They had found a\r\nfew rocks and Bryan was stooping to bury the prepared canister with the\r\ndata of the flight--\r\n\r\nWilliams watching incredulously as Bryan and Hughes reeled and\r\nstaggered, was dimly conscious of a sudden faint tremor along the ship.\r\nThere was an abrupt metallic shrieking in his headset, a background of\r\nthundering, grinding bedlam, and over it Bryan\'s voice frantic--\r\n\r\n"Cave-in! Lift ship--_lift ship_!"\r\n\r\nIt had been the one constant in the shifting, nebulous mass of theory\r\ndrilled into them. _They_ were valuable--the _ship_ was irreplaceable.\r\nWith a last unbelieving look of horror at the gigantic crack widening\r\nunder the very feet of his companions, Williams threw himself into\r\nthe control seat and threw the lever over to "takeoff" position. The\r\nrockets fired and the ship rose majestically, the thousand foot fiery\r\nsplendor of her trail blotting out the space-suited figures toppling\r\ninto the thundering chasm.\r\n\r\nHours later, Williams pulled himself up, looking around dazedly. The\r\nmotors had shut off and the great ship was coasting noiselessly along\r\nthe return track; only the computers ticked steadily and the air-valves\r\nmade a muted shushing in the silence. Funny he hadn\'t noticed the\r\nsilence on the way out--sometimes he had even been irritated with the\r\nnoise Bryan and Hughes had made with their eternal wrangling over their\r\ncards. Automatically he pushed the forward viewing plate button feeling\r\nthe familiar sense of timeless peace as he looked out on the eternal\r\nsuns.\r\n\r\nMechanically he ate and slept in the days that followed, dimly aware\r\nof a giggling, wild-eyed stranger in some remote corner of his mind,\r\nwaiting to overtake him if he showed awareness of his presence. He\r\npushed away too, the thought of Bryan and Hughes, forgetting in the\r\nsameness of his days that he had ever been anything but alone. At first\r\nhe had cried a little in his lonesomeness, but as the weeks went on\r\nhe remembered only that once there had been others who had deserted\r\nhim. He nodded familiarly to the stars, smiling a little; there was\r\nonly himself and them, shining steadfastly above him. They would never\r\nchange--never desert him!\r\n\r\nTime went by unnoticed. 

The green dot of Earth became a glowing green\r\nand blue orb, circled by a tiny white dot. The computer changed its\r\nrhythm--above the control board the "strap-in" warning flashed unseen\r\nas the rockets fired swinging the ship into the turnover, ready for\r\norbit with the satellite ferry station. Williams gazing with dreamy\r\npleasure at the jewelled curtain above him was hurled against the port\r\nby the sudden surge of acceleration. The ship heeled over, twisted,\r\nthen turned----\r\n\r\nWilliams hung head down, screaming, as the black curtain tore, the\r\nstars falling dizzily away--_below_ him....\r\n\r\n[Illustration: _He screamed once, falling face down through the stars,\r\nthrough the gold-inlaid, dizzying, beautiful, sickening...._]\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nA year later, the psychiatrists, quite pleased with themselves found\r\nhim ready for duty again; not in Space of course, but the hero of the\r\nfirst Mars expedition was always sure of a job with Space Authority.\r\nNow he could even look up at the stars at night without screaming with\r\nvertigo.\r\n\r\nTonight walking confidently along the country road, fragrant and\r\ndotted with shining pools after the recent rain, he looked up thinking\r\nnostalgically, "the patines of bright gold...."\r\n\r\nA coldness about his feet halted him. He looked down and once again the\r\nblack curtain tore before his eyes--once more they were there, the cold\r\nunfriendly stars, swinging in the empty void--\r\n\r\nBelow him.\r\n\r\nFalling downward past the whirling suns, he screamed, hardly aware of\r\nthe choking wetness in his lungs....\r\n\r\nAbout him the inch-deep shining pool rippled for a moment and was\r\nstill, reflecting once more the floor of Heaven.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nThe storm ruined my plan.\r\n\r\nNot by seasickness. I\'d come prepared for the worst, knowing how rough\r\nit could get on a sailing ship of the Nineteenth Century. I outrode the\r\nstorm easily, stowed away in the hold. Not even the breakage of some of\r\nthe 1700 barrels of alcohol carried as a cargo bothered me although the\r\nstench was terrific.\r\n\r\nBut on the morning of 25 November 1872, the first mate, Albert\r\nRichardson sent the second mate, Andrew Gilling below with two of the\r\nGerman seamen to assay the storm damage. They found me and I was hauled\r\naloft before Captain Briggs as a stowaway.\r\n\r\nCaptain Briggs of the _Mary Celeste_ eyed my strange clothing with\r\ndeep curiosity, but his interest was obviously more concerned with my\r\nunauthorized presence. He said sternly, "When did you get aboard?"\r\n\r\nI realized that I had to impress him. I smiled. "You delayed your\r\nsailing from the Fifth November to the Sixth so that you and Mrs.\r\nBriggs could have dinner aboard _Die Gratia_ with Captain\r\nMorehouse," I said.\r\n\r\n"How can you know so much?" he exclaimed. "How can you live as a\r\nstowaway for almost twenty days?"\r\n\r\nI held up my chronithon contactor, knowing that now I could impress him\r\nindeed. "Captain Briggs," I said, "I am a time-travelling historian\r\nfrom the Twenty-Second Century." I pointed to the big red button on the\r\ntop. "Until I depress this button and return to my own day and age,\r\nevery morning I receive my daily ration of food and water. It\'s about--"\r\n\r\nI\'d timed it close. I was interrupted by the click of the chronithon as\r\nit time-transferred my daily ration. I opened the cabinet and offered a\r\nbite of twenty-second century breakfast to the captain.\r\n\r\nHe said, "This is a sailor\'s tall tale, I think. You claim that you\'re\r\na time-travelling historian? Then tell me, why are you here on _Mary\r\nCeleste_?"\r\n\r\n"Captain Briggs," I said, "the Time Machine was invented in Nineteen\r\nEighty-Seven. Within twenty years every historical event had been\r\npainstakingly researched and authentically written--re-written--by\r\ntime-travelling historians who viewed the event as partaking\r\neye-witnesses. By my time, fame and fortune awaits any man who has\r\nthe luck and dogged determination to scour historic time to locate\r\nsome event that has not been recounted faithfully to the last niggling\r\nlittle detail. Why, Captain Briggs, in Jim Bishop\'s famous \'The Day\r\nColumbus Landed\' they record the name of the man who owned the hen that\r\nlaid the egg that Columbus stood on end to impress Isabella with his\r\nability. And so, Captain Briggs, I stowed away because I--"\r\n\r\nA woman\'s voice interrupted me, I turned to look at the captain\'s wife\r\nwho, of course, was the only woman aboard _Mary Celeste_. She was\r\ncarrying little Sophia Matilda in her arms. She said, "Edward, what\r\nunearthly manner of ship is that?"\r\n\r\nThe steward, Edward Head replied, "I don\'t rightly know, ma-am."\r\n\r\nI turned to look. No more than fifty feet from the starboard rail was\r\na vast barge. Upon the barge were serried rows of seats that stretched\r\nupwards and backwards for hundreds of feet. The seats were filling\r\nrapidly; ushers were escorting the spectators efficiently, vendors\r\nwere selling refreshments and programs. A thrumming sound came from\r\noverhead and I looked up to watch the materialization of jetcopters and\r\npersonnel carriers and even a poised spacecraft hanging in a dome above\r\nour heads.\r\n\r\nOver the lee rail came a crew of technicians carrying the heavy\r\nWard-Workman tridi recorders of the twenty-seventh century, and their\r\ndirector pulled a script from his pocket and said:\r\n\r\n"Joe, you and Pete dislocate the binnacle and break the compass. Al,\r\nopen the fore hatch and lazarette. Tony, that spring-wound chronometer\r\nis a pre-atomic clock and worth a fortune to the National Museum,\r\nput it among my personal loot, along with the sextant. You can keep\r\nthe ship\'s register, but give the navigation books to George with my\r\ncompliments. 

Let\'s see, um. 

Sails, jib and fore-topmast. Now toss\r\nthe yawl overboard; get it out of the way. It\'s missing." 

One of his\r\nmen came up and said something to him that I could not hear. "No,"\r\nhe replied, "It would not be more dramatic to dummy-up a half-eaten\r\nbreakfast and a pan of milk warming on the stove for the baby. Too\r\nmany writers tried to make it that way in the beginning. 

I know what\'s\r\nauthentic."\r\n\r\nThen he paused as the Ward-Workman cameramen panned around _Mary\r\nCeleste_ making close-up and approach shots. One by one they\r\nfinished their work and reported to him.\r\n\r\n"Fine," he said, looking at his strapwatch. "Now let\'s back off for\r\nsome long shots. 

And remember, we don\'t know what kind of a catastrophe\r\nthis is going to be, so keep those tridi recorders running constantly\r\nuntil I tell you to stop!"\r\n\r\nCaptain Benjamin Spooner Briggs of _Mary Celeste_ put an arm\r\naround his wife. To me he said, "I don\'t completely understand, but I\r\ndo get enough to realize that we\'re the subject of something evil."\r\n\r\n"Yes," I replied, "you--"\r\n\r\n"We\'re not waiting here to let it happen to us!" he snapped.\r\n\r\n"But you can\'t change history!" 

I objected.\r\n\r\n"Watch," he said roughly. And then with a stentorian voice, Captain\r\nBriggs roared: "_Abandon ship!_"\r\n\r\nThe captain and his wife, still carrying their daughter Sophia Matilda,\r\nmingled with the photorecording crew. The two mates, the steward,\r\nand the four German seamen went over the side and swam swiftly for\r\nthe barges. There were flurries of activity when they went aboard\r\nthe barges, but then the activity stilled and I was alone on _Mary\r\nCeleste_.\r\n\r\nI looked around me and realized that Captain Briggs hadn\'t changed\r\nhistory. He\'d made it!\r\n\r\nSlowly the barges emptied, the spectators returned to their own time\r\nand place among the Centuries. Sorrowfully I pressed my button and went\r\nhome. My fame would never be, my fortune would never start. My book\r\nwould remain unwritten, for I knew full well that potential customer\r\nfor this historic event had been here as an eye-witness. After seeing\r\nit, who\'d bother to buy my book?\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nOn 4 December, 1872, Captain Morehouse of _Die Gratia_ sighted\r\n_Mary Celeste_ yawing in a mild sea with jib and fore-topmast\r\nsails set, no one at the helm and no one aboard. The binnacle was\r\nknocked out of place, the compass was broken. The sextant, the\r\nchronometer, ship\'s register and navigation books were missing. The\r\nship\'s yawl, lashed to the main hatch was missing. The fore hatch\r\nand lazarette were open and about a dozen of the ship\'s cargo of 1701\r\nbarrels of alcohol were broken or leaking badly.\r\n\r\nThe last notation in the ship\'s deck log had been made early in the\r\nmorning of 25 November 1872, and the account of the previous hours\r\nindicated that _Mary Celeste_ had come through a severe storm on\r\nthe previous day and most of the night.\r\n\r\nAccounts that include half-eaten plates of food, half-packed bags and\r\nother evidences of an abrupt interruption and panicky flight for safety\r\nare false.\r\n\r\nNo survivors have ever turned up, no explanation can be given.\r\nResearchers in the "Mystery of _Mary Celeste_" suggest that the\r\nstorm, the leaking alcohol, combined to frighten Captain Briggs with a\r\nthreat of fire or explosion and that they all took off in the ship\'s\r\nyawl, which floundered.\r\n\r\nWe will not know the truth until someone invents the Time Machine.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n
