]\r\n\r\n\r\nWith his explanations to the reporters completed, Dr. King felt that\r\nwhen he pulled the switch he would automatically restore his good name\r\nand bring to a close a career of solid scientific achievement. Most of\r\nall, he would bring to an end the practice of referring to him as "Side\r\nEffect Charlie."\r\n\r\nDr. Charles King was willing to admit that there were excellent reasons\r\nfor his acquiring this hated nickname. The facts were that the bulk of\r\nhis scientific achievements were made inadvertently--that is to say,\r\nhis discoveries were all made through investigation of unexpected\r\nside effects of his experiments. In a career conspicuous for unusual,\r\nunanticipated side effects, two in particular stand out.\r\n\r\nThe first discovery resulted in rendering the entire heat-oriented\r\nmetallurgical industry obsolete, and founding upon its corpse a new\r\nindustry. This was based on the extracting of metal from ore and\r\nits subsequent shaping by first eliminating the bonds that hold the\r\nmolecules of metal together, and then reversing the process when the\r\ndesired shape was attained. Dr. King did not discover this process\r\ndirectly. He thought he had discovered a method of making metal\r\nsurfaces self-lubricating and 100% friction free. It was not until\r\nseveral installations utilizing his lubrication method became pools\r\nof liquid metal that Dr. King bothered to discover how his method\r\nworked, and of course the means to reverse his process. The resulting\r\nrevolution in metal-processing methods endeared him to everyone--except\r\na few vested interests like the shareholders in existing metal\r\ncompanies, who were uniformly glum.\r\n\r\nThe second discovery, although monumental in itself, is important\r\nbecause it indirectly led to the special project which Dr. King was\r\njust completing. 

Dr. King succeeded in growing some crystals in a\r\nnutrient solution. What actually happened was that while eating lunch\r\nat a lab table he managed to knock something into something else and a\r\ncrystal developed. Dr. King became fascinated with the odd structure\r\nof these crystals as revealed to him under an electron microscope. (He\r\nhad incidentally placed the crystal under the microscope in error.)\r\nAs a result, he took to investigating the properties of the crystals\r\nwhenever he could find time. Despite his well earned reputation as an\r\naccidental discoverer, it should be pointed out that Dr. King is a\r\nvery methodical man. This means he is capable of repeating the same\r\nmistake twice, or for that matter any number of times. Therefore, Dr.\r\nKing produced all the crystals he needed.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIt was during a vacation in the Adirondacks that Dr. King discovered\r\nthe propulsive qualities of the crystals.\r\n\r\nThis discovery, of course, is what led to the perfection of the "King\r\nPropulsor Unit," the heart of our starship drive systems. Dr. King\r\nwas investigating the piezo-electric properties of the crystals in a\r\nmakeshift device of his own design when he was disturbed by a sudden\r\ndraft in the room. He looked up to discover that one wall of his\r\nworkshop and the top one thousand feet of a mile-thick mountain (the\r\nsame mountain that his cabin was located upon) were no longer in the\r\nimmediate vicinity.\r\n\r\nAs it turned out, his crude device did not impart to the mountain\r\nall of the thrust inherent in the crystal. The mountain top reached\r\nonly to the orbit of Jupiter, where it settled down to become its\r\nnewest satellite. Coincidental with Dr. King\'s experiment, intensive\r\nastronomical work was going on with Jupiter as its prime object. The\r\ncapturing of the satellite was observed and recorded independently by\r\nat least six observatories, including the one on Tycho.\r\n\r\nSubsequent investigation of the time involved to project this mass\r\ndisclosed that Dr. King had invented a faster than light drive. (It\r\nshould be pointed out that, while the discovery of the faster than\r\nlight drive made the name of Dr. King world renowned, it did not in any\r\nway endear him to the relatives of those thousand-odd persons who lived\r\nin the hamlet located on the mountain top that ended up a satellite of\r\nJupiter. They also were quite glum.

)\r\n\r\nFurther work, all of a mathematical nature, disclosed to Dr. King the\r\nproper method of enclosing these crystals in a unit to drive space\r\nships to the stars. Coincidental with his work on the propulsor units\r\nhe made a startling discovery which led to his special project.\r\n\r\nDr. King invented perpetual motion.\r\n\r\nA series of complicated equations indicated to Dr. King that if he\r\nenclosed six of the crystals in the business end of a pendulum, and\r\nstarted the pendulum oscillating, it would tick-tock for all eternity.\r\n\r\nThis discovery began a five-year program that ended with a full scale\r\npress conference. The purpose was to unveil the building designed to\r\nprotect this pendulum for all eternity, and of course to unveil the\r\ndiscovery of perpetual motion at the same time.\r\n\r\nThis building was designed to be Dr. King\'s monument to his own genius.\r\nIt was a large rambling structure in which the pendulum was displayed\r\nby viewing it through a large hole in a brick wall. All of Dr. King\'s\r\nconsiderable savings had gone into designing a computer, the heart\r\nof his protective system. The computer was programmed to protect the\r\nticking of the pendulum under every conceivable circumstance. So\r\nthorough was this programming that special devices were installed to\r\nkeep the building and its precious cargo moving in earth\'s projected\r\norbit if, through some gigantic mishap, the earth was reduced to cosmic\r\ndust. The switch that would impart the initial pulse to the pendulum\r\nwould also start the computer operating, rendering the entire structure\r\ntotally inviolable.\r\n\r\nWith a flourish, Dr. King pulled the switch.\r\n\r\nNothing happened.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThere was an embarrassed shuffling of feet by the reporters. Then, as\r\nDr. King became more exasperated, the reporters became amused. 

The\r\namusement turned to open laughter when Dr. King, frantic with fear,\r\nrushed to the door to check the wiring on the inside of the building.\r\n\r\nThe door would not open. The computer was at work guarding a\r\nnonfunctioning machine.\r\n\r\nHe rushed to the open hole in the wall, intending to provide the\r\ninitial pulse necessary to start the pendulum swinging by pushing.\r\nHe found that the computer had designed a force field to keep him\r\nfrom entering. Frustrated and at his wit\'s end, he flew into a rage\r\nwhich ended in a fatal heart attack when he heard one reporter\r\nlaughingly say to him: "Don\'t let it get you down, Doctor. 

You\'ve\r\nbeat the jinx. In one step you\'ve gone from \'Side-Effect-Charlie\' to\r\n\'No-Effect-Charlie.\'"\r\n\r\nIt would be comforting to be able to assure everyone that the reporter\r\nin question was correct. Unfortunately Dr. King\'s monument did work,\r\nand probably will work for all eternity. 

The day after Dr. Charles\r\nKing had his unfortunate heart attack a homesick astronomer on Sirius\r\nreported to his superior, and subsequently to the entire populated\r\nuniverse, that when he turned his telescope on the Solar System he\r\ndiscovered that it had acquired a new motion.\r\n\r\nThe entire system swung back and forth like a pendulum.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


Thinking back on it, the whole morning had been like\r\nthat. Nervous and excited.\r\n\r\nRight after breakfast, Max had given me a good bath and loaded me in\r\nthe car. I always like to ride in the car and this time Max even\r\nallowed me to stick my head out the window. He doesn\'t usually let me\r\ndo that, but I was too engrossed in the exhilarating rush of air to\r\npay any attention to the change of routine. When we drew up in front\r\nof a large brick building a multitude of strange and peculiar odors\r\nassailed my nose, tantalizingly anonymous. Max\'s big hand caught me\r\nbefore I got halfway through the window. 

That disgusted me, because I\r\nwanted to investigate the funny smells, and I pouted all the way into\r\nthe building. As the events of the next hour progressed I got madder\r\nand madder.\r\n\r\nFirst there was the doctor, poking around in my mouth, stabbing my\r\neyes with a blinding beam of light, and prodding and squeezing my\r\nbody. It reminded me of the day I came to live with Max and I was\r\ntempted to take a hunk out of this doctor\'s hand like I did the other\r\none. 

But Max was there and that stopped me. I didn\'t want to see the\r\nhurt look that would come to his eyes every time I did something\r\nwrong.\r\n\r\nAfter the doctor finished Max led me into a gleaming white room where\r\nI was surrounded by a gushing mob of women dressed in white uniforms.\r\nTheir "Ohs!" and "Ahs!" 

and "Isn\'t he beautiful!"--I\'m not beautiful\r\nand I detest the description--put the finishing touch to what had once\r\nbeen a wonderful day. I flopped to the floor, trying to ignore them.\r\nThen, indignities of indignities, one of the "girls" tried to pick up\r\nmy eighty pounds of blue-gray masculinity. That was the last straw!\r\n\r\nI let out a deep-throated growl, and sprang clear of her encircling\r\narms. Fangs bared, ears flat against my head, I must have presented a\r\nterrifying appearance to the women, because they fled to all corners\r\nof the room, squealing and bleating like a bunch of sheep.\r\n\r\nFor the fun of it, I made a short dash at the one who had tried to\r\npick me up. With a high-pitched scream she slumped to the floor in a\r\ndead faint. I could hardly keep from laughing as I turned to search\r\nfor a new victim. About this time Max came barging through the door\r\nand grabbed me by the scruff of the neck, putting an end to my fun. He\r\nwasn\'t mad, although he pretended to be, and I could detect the humor\r\nin his voice while he scolded me.\r\n\r\nBack in the car again, Max roared with laughter while patting me on\r\nthe head and saying, "You old devil, you!" in that special way he has\r\nwhen amused at something I\'ve done. When he finally got control of\r\nhimself, he started the car and drove in the direction of the funny\r\nsmells. As the smells got stronger, I began to get uneasy. Looking at\r\nMax, I sensed that he was uneasy too. "What was going on?" I wondered\r\nas the car dipped down a ramp and entered a dimly lit cave where the\r\nsmells became overpowering.\r\n\r\nThe cave was jammed with huge tank-trucks and that was where the\r\nstrange smells were coming from. I don\'t know what was in the trucks,\r\nbut Max said something about nitric acid and hydrozine fuel when he\r\nnoticed my interest in them. Leaving the car, we walked down a short\r\npassage branching off the cave, climbed a couple flights of stairs and\r\nemerged in the bright sunlight. I nearly yipped in surprise as I\r\ncaught sight of the over-grown thing beside me. It looked for all the\r\nworld like a giant cigar that had been cut in half and stood on end.\r\nThere were still three or four trucks around the base of the thing and\r\na kind of fear spread through my mind. The magic of the strange smells\r\nwas gone and here, at close quarters, the smell was raw and\r\nuninviting.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nMax led me to a group of men and they talked for a few minutes. I\r\ndidn\'t pay much attention to what they said until one of them, a big\r\nman with a lot of stars on his shoulder, reached down and patted my\r\nback. "Better get him loaded," said the Starman. "Only ten minutes\r\ntill blast-off."\r\n\r\nMax led me to a kind of open-air elevator and started up the side of\r\nthe gleaming monster. At the top Max put me into a padded cage inside\r\nthe cigar, fastened the straps, and patted me. Then he was gone and a\r\nlarge door slid into place, leaving me in vile smelling, pitch\r\ndarkness. I lay there quietly, but the uneasy feeling kept getting\r\nworse. A sudden hissing noise nearly scared me to death; then I\r\nremembered my training. The hissing was only air, the same as had been\r\nin the cage at home, and wouldn\'t hurt me. Even so, I struggled\r\nagainst the straps, trying to reach them with my teeth. Nothing doing\r\nand again I lay quiet--waiting.\r\n\r\nI must have dozed off because the next thing I knew my cage was\r\ntrembling violently and a powerful roaring dinned in my ears. This\r\nlasted only a second, then something crushed my body flat in the cage.\r\nMy legs grew heavy and a racking, tearing pain ripped at my muscles. A\r\nblack film blotted out the lighter blackness of my cage.\r\n\r\nI don\'t know what happened in the interval, but when I came to the\r\nroar was gone and my body felt like it was floating in the air. My\r\nhead felt swollen and I experienced some difficulty in swallowing. I\r\ncouldn\'t hear a thing except the hiss of air and I was suddenly\r\novercome by the feeling that I was a long way from home.\r\n\r\nSlowly I became aware that my body was regaining its weight. The cage\r\nwas becoming quite warm now and I licked my nose, wishing for a cold\r\ndrink of water. Suddenly I was jerked against the straps and I forgot\r\nall about my other troubles. The jerks didn\'t hurt me as much as they\r\nscared me. I had experienced somewhat the same thing when Max hit the\r\ncar brakes hard, but he wasn\'t here to pat me reassuringly.\r\n\r\nThe cage was getting real hot now and the jerks were coming with\r\nincreasing frequency. The air had stopped too and I desperately wanted\r\na drink. The last thing I remember before the crash was wishing that\r\nMax would open the door and let me out like he always had at home.\r\n\r\nMax\'s gentle voice sounded a long way off. "Good boy!" 

he kept\r\nrepeating. 

"Good boy!" I couldn\'t find the strength to open my eyes so\r\nI just lay quietly and listened to the talk, thankful that the smell,\r\nthat had penetrated the entire day, was gone now.\r\n\r\n"I was afraid that those parachutes wouldn\'t cut the speed enough to\r\nget him down alive," said the Starman who had patted my back earlier.\r\n\r\n"No sign of radiation," said a strange voice. "His blood count is\r\nnormal and he isn\'t hurt physically unless there are internal\r\ninjuries.

"\r\n\r\n"What about his weakness?" asked Max, patting me.\r\n\r\n"You\'d be weak too, if you had been through the ordeal he has," said\r\nStrange-voice. "He\'ll get over that soon and live to father a good\r\nmany space-puppies."\r\n\r\nStrange-voice was absolutely right in his forecast and it\'s with\r\npardonable fatherly pride that I lead each new family to the great\r\nstone monument which reads: "_In honor of Rex, a German Shepherd dog,\r\nwho pioneered man\'s first flight into outer space._"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


]\r\n\r\n\r\nRight then he was the scaredest he\'d ever been in his life. Yet even as\r\nhe watched the spaceship turning within the glow of its flaring jets,\r\nhe kept thinking of his father\'s warning:\r\n\r\n"A boy\'s duty, son, is to keep his eyes and ears open and to give the\r\nalarm. We must be alerted ... or we\'re doomed."\r\n\r\nIt had been drummed into him ever since the landing and explosion of\r\nthe rockets. He\'d been very little then and it was hard to understand.\r\nBut they\'d explained it carefully--over and over again.\r\n\r\nThe rockets were a test. They\'d been fired by beings on another planet.\r\nSome day the beings themselves would come to invade.\r\n\r\nHe\'d often thought about it--especially at night in bed. 

And he\'d\r\ndreamed about it, too. Horrible dreams. And now the dreams had come\r\ntrue!\r\n\r\nTrembling, he watched the silver hulk aim its jets at the ground and\r\nbegin to come down. It slipped past him with a roar. 

Its fires reddened\r\nthe hillside. It settled with a jarring thud. Then all was silence.\r\n\r\nEdging forward, he peered down into the glen. The dust and smoke was\r\nclearing and he could see most of the ship gleaming evilly in the\r\ntwilight....\r\n\r\nOthers, he thought, must have seen or heard the landing. Soon they\'d\r\ncome to fight off the invaders. He\'d be found, quivering with fear, and\r\nbranded a coward. He must do something....\r\n\r\nA sudden metallic clanging made him jump. A light flicked on. He sucked\r\na deep breath. The beings!\r\n\r\nThey stood on a platform next to a trap-door. Three of them: squat,\r\nfat, and silvery-white ... like the insects he often found under flat\r\nrocks.\r\n\r\nOne held the light. The other two carried strange looking boxes. They\r\nmade their way down a ladder and began to set up the boxes on the\r\nground. 

This was his chance, he told himself. While they were busy, he\r\ncould climb to the top of the hill and escape down the other side.\r\n\r\nBut he\'d only taken three steps when he stubbed his toe on a rock,\r\njarred it loose, and sent it pelting into the glen.\r\n\r\nThey hurried over to see what it was and he got a better look at them.\r\nTheir wrinkled skin hung from their bulgy bodies in thick folds. Insect\r\nfeelers waved over their humped backs. Flat expressionless faces\r\nglittered in the light of their lamp.... He shuddered.\r\n\r\nAfter they\'d looked at the rock, two of them started climbing in the\r\ndirection from which it had rolled. The third stayed behind, beaming\r\nthe light to guide the way.\r\n\r\nCringing against the hill, he moved along the ledge to a point where it\r\ncurled past a jutting crag. On the other side of that he\'d be hidden\r\nfrom view and could make a run for it.\r\n\r\nBut as soon as he\'d made it, he gasped, horror-stricken.... The vague\r\nshadow of the ledge pinched inward till it became the gulfing black of\r\na sheer cliff. He was trapped!\r\n\r\nHis only hope now was the coming of the town people and he listened\r\nfor noises of their approach. But all he heard was the scuffle of two\r\nbeings cresting the ledge.\r\n\r\nWas it possible that he alone knew of the landing? The town people\r\nshould have come by now.\r\n\r\nAs it was, a lot of lives depended on him. His father and mother, the\r\nother kids, and all the people, too. He couldn\'t let them down!\r\n\r\nThe beam of light, moving along the ledge ahead of the two beings, now\r\ntouched the crag and spilled over to where he stood. Then, almost as\r\nif Fate had taken charge again, his eyes were drawn to the gleam of a\r\nsharp-edged rock....\r\n\r\nHe was gripping it, poised to strike, when the first of the beings came\r\naround the bend.\r\n\r\nTwo things made him hesitate. First, size. The being was tiny--fully a\r\nthird shorter than himself.\r\n\r\nNext, the way the being acted. It had stopped and raised its hand, palm\r\nout, as if trying to make friends.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIt must be a trick, he told himself. Never had he heard the beings\r\nspoken of as friends--only as vicious destroyers. He took a tighter\r\ngrip on the rock.\r\n\r\nNow he noticed something that filled him with a new loathing. 

He\'d been\r\nwrong about their appearance. The sagging skin was really a bulky suit.\r\nThe big head a helmet. And back of the helmet\'s face he could see the\r\nactual being. He felt like vomiting.\r\n\r\nHe bashed the rock against the faceplate. It webbed with a cluster of\r\ntiny cracks. He struck again and again, until the helmet split open and\r\nhe was pulping the face itself to a reddish smear....\r\n\r\nSuddenly a roaring filled his ears. His side was laced with terrible\r\npain. 

He reeled backward. Saw the second of the beings pointing at him\r\nwith something long and rodlike. He flipped the rock.\r\n\r\nIt caught the being in the chest and drove it over the side. He could\r\nsee it clawing the air all the way down to the glen.\r\n\r\nThere, the third being, with the light, took one look at the still\r\nform, turned and raced madly for the ship.\r\n\r\nWatching, he was overcome with a peculiar feeling of excitement. The\r\npain in his side had ebbed and he felt hot and feverish. 

He wanted to\r\ndo something--to act. Without thinking, he scurried down the hill and\r\ntook after the fleeing figure.\r\n\r\nHe caught it on the ladder, just below the trap-door, grabbed its leg,\r\nand jerked. It plunged to the ground and hit with a crash. The light\r\nblinked out.\r\n\r\nNow he heard a thin grating noise. Above him the trap-door, dimly\r\noutlined by a light from a cubbyhole beyond, had begun to move. He\r\nswung himself to the platform, dove into the cubbyhole, and heard the\r\ntrap clang shut behind him.\r\n\r\nStraight ahead was a short length of ladder and overhanging it a second\r\ntrap-door which had already begun to gape open. This, he guessed, was\r\nsome sort of air-lock--a way of getting in and out of the ship without\r\nlosing the built up pressure. It would account for the suits worn on\r\nthe outside.\r\n\r\nThe trap had swung wider and he could see two beings in suits getting\r\nready to come down. They probably were trying to help their buddies.\r\n\r\nHe got the first one as it started down the ladder with its back to\r\nhim. He just threw an arm around its helmet and pulled until he heard a\r\nsnap.\r\n\r\nThen he went up the ladder to get at the second one. He hit it, watched\r\nit spin across the chamber, crunch against the bulkhead, and collapse.\r\n\r\nNow a third one darted away from a bank of levers and tried to reach\r\nthe spiral stairs, rising to the next level. It wore no suit and its\r\nthin body made him think of some horrible creeping plant. He leapt for\r\nit, clutched the skinny neck with one hand, and squeezed.\r\n\r\nHe rushed to the bank of levers, then, and pushed one after another\r\nuntil he heard the scraping of the lower trap-door and the hiss of\r\nescaping air.\r\n\r\nWhen he climbed to the upper levels, all the beings were dead except\r\ntwo. He found a short piece of metal and hit them both on the head.\r\n\r\nAnd now his side had begun to ache and he felt bruised and shaky and\r\nvery weary. He must get back to town ... tell them what he\'d done ...\r\nbring them to look....\r\n\r\nBut he should take something back with him to prove the ship was there.\r\nHe noticed a bright piece of metal sunk into the bulkhead. It was\r\ncovered with symbols ... a sort of nameplate.\r\n\r\nGrasping it with the thin, flat part of two hands, he braced himself\r\nagainst the bulkhead with his other two hands and ripped it loose.\r\n\r\nOn the way back, he memorized the shape of the symbols. He might want\r\nto draw them sometime to show off:\r\n\r\n_Taggert Steel Company, Cleveland, Ohio, U.S.A._\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


It could be man\'s--\r\n\r\n\r\nPrelude To Space\r\n\r\n_By Robert W. Haseltine_\r\n\r\n\r\nI was climbing the steep side of a central Wisconsin hill, holding my\r\nbow away from my body for balance, when I first saw the stranger. He sat\r\non a stump at the crest and watched me struggle up. 

As I drew nearer I\r\npanted out a greeting and received his cheerful "Hi" in return. When I\r\nfinally reached the top, I threw myself on the ground and began catching\r\nmy breath.\r\n\r\nHe didn\'t say anything at first, just looked at the bow and the quiver\r\nof arrows on my back. Finally he said, "May I look at it?" and reached\r\nfor the bow. I handed it to him. He examined it carefully and returned\r\nit.\r\n\r\n"Beautiful workmanship. Is that all you use?" he asked.\r\n\r\n"I never cared much for guns," I answered. "I\'ve always thought a bow\r\ngave the animal more of an even chance for his life."\r\n\r\nWe talked then on the various aspects of hunting and how the crisp fall\r\nair seemed to make the deer seem closer than during the heat of summer.\r\nWhile we talked I tried to place the reason he disturbed me, but I\r\ncouldn\'t seem to do it. He was dressed in an old plaid shirt and\r\ndungarees and his blond hair wasn\'t many shades removed from my own\r\nstraw thatch. But there was something odd about him that I couldn\'t\r\nquite find.\r\n\r\n"Perhaps it\'s the cloth." His words surprised me. "You see, it hasn\'t\r\nbeen discovered on this planet as yet." My face must have shown\r\nastonishment because he went on in the same vein. "I admit it\'s\r\nconfusing, but it\'s also true. My clothes weren\'t made on Earth." He\r\nchuckled then, deep in his throat. "I don\'t blame you for being\r\nconfused. I know how I would feel if I met an extraterrestrial being\r\nbefore space travel was a reality."\r\n\r\nI kept staring at him. Finally I blurted out, "What in Sam Hill are you\r\ntalking about?"\r\n\r\nHe leaned forward on the stump and his face grew earnest. "You might say\r\nI\'m a poll taker. I have to decide certain things from various\r\ninterviews with individuals I meet."\r\n\r\n"What are you trying to prove?" I asked.\r\n\r\n"I\'m sorry, but I can\'t tell you that until I\'m finished with the\r\ninterview. If I told you, your interest in the subject would tend to\r\nprejudice your answers."\r\n\r\n"Fair enough. 

What do you want to ask me?"\r\n\r\nHe pulled out a notebook and smiled. "These questions may seem a little\r\nsilly but I must have straight answers to them. 

Will you go along with\r\nme?"\r\n\r\nI nodded my head.\r\n\r\n"Let\'s see now. If you were the head of a government and wanted to\r\nascertain whether another country was ready for admission into the\r\nUnited Nations, what would you do?"\r\n\r\nI shrugged. "I suppose I would read books and magazines from the country\r\nand possibly have an interview with the heads of the government. After I\r\nhad collected my data I could then act upon it."\r\n\r\n"For the sake of argument suppose the books and other periodicals were\r\nwritten so as to be prejudicial in favor of the government, and the\r\nheads also were coloring what they said."\r\n\r\nI thought for a minute. "In that case I suppose I would secretly place\r\nsomeone inside the country to interview the people and get a first hand\r\nview of the situation. Then I would act on his data."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe nodded his head. "Yes, the people themselves and the conditions they\r\nlive in will give you the needed data." He turned a page in the book.\r\n"Now suppose that you wished to know if a certain planet was ready to\r\nenter into an organization such as the Galactic Federation, what would\r\nyou do?"\r\n\r\n"I suppose I\'d act as I did before. Place people inside the various\r\nareas of the planet to interview and observe. They would bring back the\r\ninformation needed to ascertain whether they would be an asset or a\r\ndetriment to the organization."\r\n\r\nI thought to myself that the question was a trifle silly; after all,\r\nhadn\'t science proved that life couldn\'t exist on the other planets in\r\nour system?\r\n\r\nHe relaxed after I answered and his smile was brighter than the previous\r\nones. "Right," he said. 

"Naturally we had to learn the language first,\r\nbut now a first-hand check can be made. You see, there is a civilization\r\nout there," he raised his hand and swept the sky, "and we have to check\r\nto see if this planet is ready to take its place as an adult\r\ncivilization with the rest of us.\r\n\r\n"Earth, within a very short time, will be reaching her fingers into\r\nspace. Once she gets there she will be eligible to join the Galactic\r\nFederation."\r\n\r\n"That\'s all right," I said, "then we can exchange culture and knowledge\r\nwith other civilizations."\r\n\r\n"Yes, if you are eligible to join."\r\n\r\n"But you said that once we reach space we will be eligible."\r\n\r\n"Look at it this way," he said. "The main purpose of the Galactic\r\nFederation is to promote peace and understanding among the various\r\nplanets. Earth would have to be prepared to take its place as just\r\nanother member, and not an important member at that. Earth, you see, is\r\none of the smaller planets and also would be the latest one to join.\r\n\r\n"In times past some planets have reached space without being fully\r\nprepared for what they would find. They still had internal troubles on\r\ntheir own worlds. We had to place them in quarantine until they reached\r\nthat degree of civilization where they were ready to live in peace. Now\r\nwe check a planet before it reaches the space-travel stage. We find out\r\nthe reactions of the inhabitants to certain situations.

"\r\n\r\n"What sort of situations?" I asked.\r\n\r\n"Well, naturally we want to see their artifacts as an indication as to\r\ntheir advancement. We have to know what the average man thinks of space\r\ntravel and trade with other planets. And their ideas on peace and their\r\nfeelings towards their fellow men. All are very important.\r\n\r\n"Actually, when a planet once enters the Federation the people are the\r\nones to decide on peace and war. So if the majority of the people on a\r\nplanet are peace-loving that planet is ready to enter the Federation."\r\n\r\n"But how do you find out all these things?" 

I asked. "When a man finds\r\nout what you are trying to prove he may lie because he wants to get into\r\nspace."\r\n\r\nHis eyes held a mischievous glint as he answered. "Simple, the art of\r\ntelepathy has been highly developed among my race. I have your thoughts\r\non everything I\'ve mentioned. Later, when all the data from thousands of\r\nsimilar interviews is in it will be evaluated and the decision made as\r\nto whether your world will be allowed to reach space. We have the means\r\nof keeping you from it if we decide you aren\'t yet ready.

"\r\n\r\nHe stood up and I followed suit. 

"I must be going now," he sighed. "This\r\nwork keeps me on the run and I have many more interviews to make.\r\nBelieve me, it was a pleasure meeting you. I hope we meet again--later."\r\nWe shook hands and he strolled over the hill into the valley.\r\n\r\nPerhaps I should have followed him, but it wouldn\'t have done any good,\r\nreally. Because a few moments later I saw something shimmering over the\r\ntop of the hill. It was big and disc-shaped and shot into the sky with a\r\nspeed that was unbelievable.\r\n\r\nI still don\'t know what to think about him or what we talked about. I\'m\r\ngoing to keep watching the papers though, and hoping he got the right\r\nanswers. You and your chess-playing! Hollis\r\ndid make one concession--moving in with us, instead of making us live\r\nin that dismal bachelor\'s hole of his. Let\'s not make him regret it.

"\r\n\r\nThey heeded Sue and got busy. Sue was the arbiter. She ruled the\r\nquartet with a gentle but confident mind. All four knew that her lithe,\r\nathletic body with its soft curves and golden hair was the greatest\r\nasset in this transaction of matrimony.\r\n\r\nThere had been no dissension on this point, nor could there have been.\r\nThe bureau would never have allowed them to be together and form a\r\nmarriage cell had there been the slightest dispute.\r\n\r\nMany differences of opinion were allowable, but the four had been\r\ncarefully screened in certain matters of basic tastes. They liked the\r\nsame colors, foods, styles of clothing, video programs, sports and\r\nvacation activities. All were carefully schooled ambiverts of roughly\r\nequal education. Instead of conflicting, their differences of skills,\r\ntalents and personality traits complemented each other.\r\n\r\nEven with all this care in selecting and matching, however, the big\r\ntest was the culmination of the marriage, itself--the whole purpose of\r\nthis banding together. The unpredictable quality of the most stable\r\nfeminine emotions made the choice of a mate most difficult of all.\r\n\r\nThis awareness was in all their minds this day, and it made them a\r\nlittle nervous. Even the argument that had started over the coffee had\r\nbeen faintly alarming to Sue. They were a team, welded together by the\r\nwonderful gift of telepathy, which was only possible through formation\r\nof a marriage cell. The most complete intimacy of thought and feeling\r\nhad been nurtured for a whole year before marriage was permissible.\r\nSympathy, tolerance and sharing a common experience with mutual\r\nenjoyment and happiness was the keystone of the polygamous unions.\r\nNothing must spoil it now.\r\n\r\nThe delivery vault thumped, and the signal light flicked on. Sue rushed\r\nto slide up the door.\r\n\r\n"Orchids!" they chorused mentally, and Sue noticed with satisfaction\r\nthat June\'s thought was as strong as the others. The lovely flowers\r\nwere put in the cooler, the apartment was tidied and they turned to the\r\nexciting task of becoming beautiful for their handsome husband.\r\n\r\nThe tiff over the coffee was forgotten as they became immersed in\r\nsprays, powders, tints, cosmetics, body ornaments and the precious\r\nnuptial perfume. This latter, issued to them only yesterday when they\r\nsigned the register and received the license, was now as traditionally\r\nexclusive to weddings as trousseaus had been centuries ago.\r\n\r\nFeminine clothing, of course, had long since been eliminated from the\r\noccasion, along with other redundancies such as waggish and mischievous\r\nguests, old shoes, rice and hectic honeymoon trips.\r\n\r\nThe official and religious arrangements had been completed yesterday at\r\nthe registry and the chapel, the union to become legal and effective\r\nat noon on this day. "\r\n\r\nJune and Polly were game, but Sue cut them off. "Not on your life! I\r\nused to know a chemist at the hormone labs where they compound this\r\nstuff, and he told me about it. We have things to do, and if what he\r\ntold me is true--well, it\'s very distracting.

"\r\n\r\nPolly backed her up, "I hear it is terribly volatile. I guess we\r\nwouldn\'t want it to wear off before Hollis came."\r\n\r\n"Hollis!" Arak Miller ached\r\n                  for it--too eagerly; too swiftly._\r\n\r\n           [Transcriber\'s Note: This etext was produced from\r\n                      Planet Stories Winter 1954.\r\n         Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that\r\n         the U.S. copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nTwenty-five years later a ship appeared, on an afternoon in the\r\nplanet\'s summer.\r\n\r\nArak Miller watched it from the mesa.\r\n\r\n_From Earth_, he thought. _From Earth!_\r\n\r\nBut Arak Miller was an ordered man. Even now, in the face of resurging\r\nvisions of his wife, and his sons, and his work, and the mighty\r\ncivilization from which he had been cut adrift, his thoughts were\r\nordered: probably the ship had arrived from Earth to resurvey one of\r\nthe Class II uninhabitable planets of the Alpha Centaurus System.\r\nTomorrow its scout ships would whip along the day sides at five\r\nthousand feet. Tomorrow atop the mesa he must light his pyres, some\r\nhundred-odd gigantic piles of pine trees and brush that would burn with\r\nbillowing smoke. He must signal the presence of a lone Earthman.\r\n\r\nWith a hypnotic intensity he stood watching the ship until, toward\r\nevening, it merged into the gray sky over the horizon. Then he ran\r\nacross the clearing and down to his house by the river that wound\r\nthrough the valley a thousand feet below. 

"Come on, you fool!" he\r\nshouted to Marbach, sitting beneath a tree. Arak Miller threw the\r\nfigure over his shoulder and carried him to the house. He sat Marbach\r\non a chair and went into the kitchen to eat.\r\n\r\nArak Miller had been nomadic the first few years after he crashed and\r\nhad been abandoned for dead, until he found in the planet\'s narrow\r\ntemperate zone one of the few arable regions capable of sustaining him.\r\nThere was sufficient small game, the river was cool, and because the\r\nrain fell mainly in the valley, his pyres were safe.\r\n\r\nIn recent years he was always building. He had added a front porch to\r\nthe cabin he had started with, then more rooms which he had never\r\nused, then an attic into which he never went. Now it was a house. It\r\nhad chairs and tables, a bed, a rug of vines, a garden for vegetables\r\nand tobacco, and a garden for flowers.\r\n\r\nHe ate a leisurely meal of potatoes and corn and meat of the\r\nrabbit-like creatures which he trapped. Miss Gormeley was sitting on\r\nthe porch as he went out. "A ship\'s come," he shouted. "I may be saved,\r\nyou understand?"\r\n\r\nHe recalled he had intended to do something about Miss Gormeley\'s\r\nnostril. With one of his knives he scraped a little against the wall of\r\nher left nostril. Then he stood back, satisfied. "Now you look better,"\r\nhe said. With a wry grin he added, "You can smell better, too."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nFor a long time he could not sleep, remembering that he had been cut\r\noff in the prime of his life. He had been the Senior Astrophysicist\r\nin the Systems War Office on Earth, working on the Second Einstein\r\nModifications that promised travel to the more distant galactic\r\nSystems. He had completed six months of comparison spectography in the\r\nbarren Centaurus System and had been about to take the year\'s return\r\njourney to Earth, looking forward to a vacation trip with his family to\r\nVenus City. He had been in the forefront of the free world\'s pushing\r\nback of the last frontiers of man.\r\n\r\nHe twisted on his bed in a wild agony of hope and yearning. "Someday\r\nsoon," he shouted to the walls, "I\'ll ride the monorail across the\r\nWestern plains." He had discovered that it helped, to talk aloud,\r\nthough none of his devices could make him forget he was a prisoner. To\r\nfeel the Centaurus skies closing down on him and the alien mountains\r\ncrushing him, so far from his work and those he loved, was to feel a\r\nterrible suffocation from which there was no release.\r\n\r\nBut then he would go doggedly to work, or else carve the life-size\r\nfigures to keep him silent company, and try to forget.\r\n\r\nHe talked on and on, and finally he could talk no more. He slept.\r\n\r\nHe was awakened by a pattering on the roof.\r\n\r\n"Rain!" he shouted. He jumped up and ran to the window socket. The rain\r\nclouds were high, and heavy with storm.\r\n\r\nIt struck him like a blow: they hung above the mesa.\r\n\r\nAbove his pyres.\r\n\r\nIn a panic he clambered up to the mesa, forgetting his breakfast,\r\nforgetting his outer clothing, his mind in disorder.\r\n\r\nThe shock wave pounded his eardrums.\r\n\r\nHe was too startled to make words. With unbelieving eyes he saw, about\r\nfive miles away where the river emptied into the sea, the black cloud\r\nof an atomic explosion rise into the sky to spread out under the rain.\r\n\r\nThen suddenly he was running blindly through the rain. The scout must\r\nhave come down. 

They must be testing. The area was ideal for testing\r\natomic weapons. _I must reach them before they leave._\r\n\r\nThrough heavy undergrowth he pushed his way down the slope to the\r\nvalley. His foot slipped on an exposed root. With a sharp crack of\r\nbone, he fell.\r\n\r\n"My ankle!" he screamed, with terror smashing at his mind. He managed\r\nto find two thick lengths of branch that would serve as crutches. Then\r\nhe started hobbling awkwardly toward the river.\r\n\r\nFor an hour he forced himself on urgently along the river bank, now\r\nfeeling knife-like pains slicing up through his body. The effort of\r\nmoving was beginning to exhaust him.\r\n\r\nHe fell down, and rested a moment. He heard a tree crash in the forest\r\nahead. He heard someone shout.\r\n\r\nA human voice!\r\n\r\nHe began to sob, softly at first, then uncontrollably. A human voice!\r\nIt had never been so sweet a sound.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe climbed painfully to his feet, crashed on through the undergrowth.\r\nThe density of trees ended abruptly and he stopped. Around the scout\r\nship in the clearing beyond, robot dredges were digging the foundations\r\nfor buildings. Gray-uniformed men were setting up new-type atomic\r\nartillery at the perimeters.\r\n\r\nArak Miller drew a deep breath. "I\'m saved," he said, his voice\r\nbreaking. "I\'m going to be a free man!" He tottered on the edge of\r\nhysteria, but controlled himself with a mighty effort of will.\r\n\r\nHe took a step forward to reach the clearing. Then he stopped.\r\n\r\nSomething was wrong.\r\n\r\nHe tried to put together the pieces of his mind. Everything looked\r\nnormal. Construction going on, stores being transferred to temporary\r\nwarehouses, all the usual activities of a scout party on an atomic\r\ntesting mission. The artillery was pointing--\r\n\r\nThat was the flaw.\r\n\r\nThe artillery faced inward.\r\n\r\nHe looked back at the construction work. "Not foundations for\r\nbuildings," he said dully. "Ditches.

"\r\n\r\nAs he watched, a flag was run up on a pole. The dreams of Arak Miller\r\ncrashed in his mind.\r\n\r\nIt was the flag of the slave world, super-imposed upon the symbol of\r\nthe Systems. The world controlled by the dictators, which for centuries\r\nhad existed alongside the free world in a perpetual cold war. During\r\nsome stage of Arak Miller\'s long imprisonment, from Venus to Centaurus\r\nthe dictators had taken over.\r\n\r\nHidden from guards, he lay on the ground and watched for a long time.\r\nOnly when the next batch of captives was taken out of the scout ship\r\nand lined up in front of the ditch, did he turn his gaze away.\r\n\r\nHe waited till the next shock wave had passed, then with tears\r\nstreaming down his face, hobbled back in the rain toward the river.\r\nHe crawled the last two miles to his house. Miss Gormeley was sitting\r\nwhere he had left her. 

"I am sorry," he said painfully. 

"I will have to\r\ndestroy you. And Marbach. And our house, and the pyres. And when all\r\nthat is done, I will have to leave this area. 

Otherwise they might find\r\nme."\r\n\r\nMiss Gormeley stared blindly out at the river.\r\n\r\nHe lay still on the floor, gasping for breath. "You see," he explained,\r\n"I am not a prisoner. They are the prisoners. All of them. 

All the\r\nworld--but me."\r\n\r\nHis eyes closed in exhaustion. "I like it here now," he said, almost in\r\na whisper. "I intend to stay. 

There must be some place here where they\r\ncan never find me, you understand?"\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


He was thin,\r\ntoo, like his wife, but tall and tough-skinned. His face, with its\r\nleather look was immobile.\r\n\r\n"Why?" asked his wife.\r\n\r\n"Good reasons," the farmer said.\r\n\r\nHe poured yellow cream into a cup of coffee. He let the cup sit on the\r\ntable.\r\n\r\n"Henry?" said the woman, as though she were really speaking to someone\r\nelse. She walked around the kitchen in quick aimless bird steps.\r\n\r\n"My right," said Henry. He lifted his cup, finally, tasting.\r\n\r\n"We\'ll starve."\r\n\r\n"Not likely. 

Not until everybody else does, anyway."\r\n\r\nThe woman circled the room and came back to her husband. Her eyes\r\nwinked, and there were lines between them. Her fingers clutched the edge\r\nof the table. "You\'ve gone crazy," she said, as though it were a\r\nhalf-question, a half-pronouncement.\r\n\r\nThe farmer was relaxing now, leaning back in his chair. "Might have.\r\nMight have, at that."\r\n\r\n"_Why?_" she asked.\r\n\r\nThe farmer turned his coffee cup carefully. "Thing to do, is all. Each\r\nman in his own turn. This is my turn."\r\n\r\nThe woman watched him for a long time, then she sat down on a chair\r\nbeside the table. The quick, nervous movement was gone out of her, and\r\nshe sat like a frozen sparrow.\r\n\r\nThe farmer looked up and grinned. "Feels good. 

Just to sit here. Does\r\nwell for the back and the arms. 

Been working too hard."\r\n\r\n"Henry," the woman said.\r\n\r\nThe farmer tasted his coffee again. He put the cup on the table and\r\nleaned back, tapping his browned fingers. "Just in time, I\'d say. 

Waited\r\nany longer, it wouldn\'t have done any good. Another few years, a farmer\r\nwouldn\'t mean anything."\r\n\r\nThe woman watched him, her eyes frightened as though he might suddenly\r\ngnash his teeth or leap in the air.\r\n\r\n"Pretty soon," the farmer said, "they\'d have it all mechanical. Couldn\'t\r\nstop anything. Now," he said, smiling at his wife, "we can stop it all."\r\n\r\n"Henry, go out to the fields," the woman said.\r\n\r\n"No," Henry said, standing, stretching his thin, hard body. "I won\'t go\r\nout to the fields. Neither will August Brown nor Clyde Briggs nor Alfred\r\nSwanson. None of us. 

Anywhere. Not until the food\'s been stopped long\r\nenough for people to wake up."\r\n\r\nThe farmer looked out of the kitchen window, beyond his tractor and the\r\ncow barn and the windmill. He looked at rows of strong corn, shivering\r\ntheir soft silk in the morning breeze. "We\'ll stop the corn. Stop the\r\nwheat. Stop the cattle, the hogs, the chickens."\r\n\r\n"You can\'t."\r\n\r\n"_I_ can\'t. But all of us together can."\r\n\r\n"No sense," the woman said, wagging her head. "No sense."\r\n\r\n"It\'s sense, all right. Best sense we\'ve ever had. Can\'t use an army\r\nwith no stomach. Old as the earth. Can\'t fight without food. Takes food\r\nto run a war."\r\n\r\n"You\'ll starve the two of us, that\'s all you\'ll do. Nobody else will\r\nstop work."\r\n\r\nThe farmer turned to his wife. "Yes, they will. Everywhere a farmer is\r\nthe same. He works the land. He reads the papers. He votes. He listens\r\nto the radio. He watches the television. Mostly, he works the land.\r\nAlone, with his own thoughts and ideas. He isn\'t any different in Maine\r\nthan he is in Oregon. We\'ve all stopped work. 

Now. 

This morning."\r\n\r\n"How about those across the ocean? Are they stopping, too? They\'re not\r\ngoing to feed up their soldiers? To kill us if we don\'t starve first?\r\nTo--"\r\n\r\n"They stopped, too. A farmer is a farmer. Like a leaf on a tree. No\r\nmatter on what tree in what country on whose land. A leaf is a leaf. A\r\nfarmer\'s the same. A farmer is a farmer."\r\n\r\n"It won\'t work," the woman said dully.\r\n\r\n"Yes, it will."\r\n\r\n"They\'ll _make_ you work."\r\n\r\n"How? It\'s our own property."\r\n\r\n"They\'ll take it away from you."\r\n\r\n"Who\'ll work it then?"\r\n\r\nThe woman rocked in her chair, her mouth quivering. "They\'ll get\r\nsomebody."\r\n\r\nThe farmer shook his head. "Too many people doing other things, like\r\nmaking shells and guns, like sitting in fox-holes or flying planes."\r\n\r\nThe woman sat rocking, her hands together in her lap. "It won\'t work,"\r\nshe repeated.\r\n\r\n"It\'ll work," said the farmer. "Right _now_, it\'ll work. Yes, we\'ve got\r\nmilkers and shuckers, and we\'ve got hatchers for the chickens. We\'ve got\r\ntractors and combines and threshing machines. They\'re all mechanical,\r\nall right. But we don\'t have mechanical farmers, yet. The pumps, the\r\ntractors, the milkers don\'t work by themselves. In time, maybe. Not now.\r\nWe\'re still ahead of them on that. 

It\'ll work."\r\n\r\n"Go out to the fields, Henry," his wife said, her voice like the sound\r\nof a worn phonograph record.\r\n\r\n"No," the farmer said, taking a pipe from his overalls. "I think\r\ninstead, I\'ll just sit in the sun and watch the corn. Watch the birds on\r\ntop of the barn, maybe. I\'ll fill my pipe and sit there and smoke and\r\nwatch. And when I get sleepy, I\'ll sleep. After a while I might go see\r\nAugust Brown or Clyde Briggs or maybe Alfred Swanson. We\'ll sit and\r\ntalk, about pleasant things, peaceful things. 

We\'ll wait."\r\n\r\nThe farmer put the pipe between his teeth and walked to the door. He put\r\non his straw hat, buttoned the sleeves of his blue shirt and stepped\r\noutside.\r\n\r\nHis wife sat at the table, staring at nothing in the room.\r\n\r\nThe farmer walked across the barnyard, listening to the sound of the\r\nchickens and the sound of the breeze going through the corn. Near the\r\nbarn, he sat upon an old tree stump and filled his pipe with tobacco. He\r\nlit the pipe, cupping his hands, and sat there, smoking, the smoke\r\nspiraling up into the bright warm air.\r\n\r\nHe took his pipe from his teeth and looked at it. "Pipe of peace," he\r\nsaid, laughing inside himself.\r\n\r\nThe breeze was soft and the sun warm on his back. He sat there, smoking,\r\nfeeling the quiet of the morning, the peace of the great sky above.\r\n\r\nHe had no time to stand or to take his pipe from his mouth, when the two\r\nmen crossed the yard and lifted him up by the arms. He dropped the pipe,\r\nwhile he was dragged past the house, to the road beyond. He had no time\r\nto yell or scream, before his hat was swept from his head, the overalls\r\nand the blue shirt stripped from his body.\r\n\r\nHe had not even thought about what it was that had happened, before he\r\nwas thrust inside a white truck, with strong steel sides and with\r\ngrilled windows like those of a cell.\r\n\r\nHe was just sitting there, in the truck, without his clothes, speeding\r\naway with August Brown and Clyde Briggs and Alfred Swanson.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nOutside, the sun was warm upon the earth. Chickens clucked in their\r\npens, while birds fluttered about the top of the barn. 

A pig squealed.\r\nThe corn rustled. And beside the farmhouse, on the ground, lay a pipe,\r\nits tobacco spilled, the last of its smoke swirling out of its bowl into\r\nthe air, disappearing.\r\n\r\nThe woman sat in the kitchen of the farmhouse and turned her head when\r\nthe door opened. She widened her eyes and caught at her throat with her\r\nhand.\r\n\r\nThe sun through the doorway shone down on metallic hands and a metallic\r\nface, gleaming on the surface which the straw hat and the overalls and\r\nthe blue shirt didn\'t hide. The door snapped shut, and there was a sound\r\nof heavy metal footsteps against the kitchen floor.\r\n\r\nThe woman pressed against her chair. "Who are you?" she screamed.\r\n\r\n"Henry," said the mechanical thing.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _If Worlds of Science Fiction_ May\r\n    1953. Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Our space was remarkably limited. This shelter had been\r\na part of the cellar. It had been blocked off and roofed over, but\r\neven so, part of it fell in--the part with the supplies and stuff--the\r\npart opening on the exit.\r\n\r\n"Well," I said, just to say something, "what do we do now? Sit around\r\nand wait to die?"\r\n\r\nThe little old man wrinkled his brow in thought. He didn\'t seem too\r\nworried about dying. I guess when you\'re his age and have a long gray\r\nbeard you get reconciled to the prospect. But I was young, and frankly\r\nI didn\'t like the idea at all.\r\n\r\n"I think I know a way," the little old man said finally, "but it will\r\nseem like madness. Probably it is. 

It\'s never been tried. It may never\r\nwork."\r\n\r\nI seized him by the lapels. "Any way is better than none. 

I\'d rather\r\ndie trying than sitting down moping my life away. Tell it to me."\r\n\r\n"You won\'t laugh? You will take whatever I say seriously?" the little\r\nold man asked anxiously.\r\n\r\nI saw he didn\'t want to die the object of scorn, and I saw also that he\r\nmust have something pretty odd up his sleeve. "No," I answered, "you\r\nwon\'t hear a peep out of me."\r\n\r\n"Then," said the old man, "if you can prepare yourself, you could walk\r\nout through the rocks."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIn spite of my promise, I gasped. But then I squelched myself and\r\nthought that if I was with a lunatic, I might as well make the most\r\nof it. He was now the other half of my universe and so standards had\r\nchanged. Facing death, any straw will do.\r\n\r\n"Proceed," I said. 

"Explain further."\r\n\r\n"Rocks," said the little old man--I guess he must have been a scientist\r\nof some sort--"and all other matter are composed of nothing mainly,\r\nwith a little vibration thrown in."\r\n\r\nI kept my mouth shut. I wasn\'t going to say anything to the contrary\r\neven if he claimed black was white.\r\n\r\n"Matter," he went on, "is composed entirely of atom. Atoms are broken\r\ndown to electrons and protons and their kin. They, in turn, appear to\r\nbe nothing but charges of electricity, charges of energy, not matter.\r\nSo that all matter is really just a manifestation of energy in a\r\npeculiar state of stress."\r\n\r\nI waited. 

This made sense. I began to recognize some of the things I\r\nhad learned years ago in high school physics.\r\n\r\n"Between the vortices of energy which make up the building-blocks of\r\nmatter, there are comparatively vast stretches of just plain empty\r\nspace. Within the atom, almost all is vacuum. Between molecules, more\r\nvacuum. In a so-called solid mass, it could be demonstrated that less\r\nthan a quadrillionth part of its mass has any reality and that only\r\nin the form of disturbances of energy. And that figure is grossly\r\nexaggerated.

"\r\n\r\nI waited. 

This was still making sense. And anyway, when you are\r\nhopelessly trapped there is no sense in being impatient.\r\n\r\n"If," went on the professor, "you understand this and project the\r\npicture of it in your mind, you can mentally resolve all things into\r\nswirls of nothingness, into less than air. If you can do so, you can\r\nattain complete control over your own body--for we alone are able to\r\ncontrol our own masses by means of will.\r\n\r\n"And if you can picture these masses of rock as pools of nothing and\r\nyourself as the same, you can pass yourself through these rocks as a\r\nwhiff of smoke in air. You can revisualize yourself as solid outside\r\nthis trapping pile."\r\n\r\nI thought about it. Wild it was and yet based on real reasoning.\r\n\r\n"If you will give your mind to me, let me hypnotize you with your\r\ncooperation, I think I can cause that to happen. You will then pass\r\nthrough the rocks and appear outside. 

Then you will send for me," he\r\nsaid.\r\n\r\nI thought that over. "Why don\'t you do it yourself?" I asked.\r\n\r\n"I am old and it is better done with an outside subject. Do not forget\r\nthat this has never been done."\r\n\r\n"Okay. Start," I said, suddenly making up my mind. I didn\'t want to die\r\nand I would do anything, however wild, to avoid it. When one sits alone\r\nin darkness beneath a ruined house and knows that there is no hope, a\r\ndecision like this comes normally.\r\n\r\nAll is logical according to the conditions given.\r\n\r\nI gave him my flashlight and he shone it in my eyes. Then he started\r\nweaving it and repeating what he had said about atoms and electrons and\r\nmasses of nothing.\r\n\r\nI watched him fascinated, and I thought of little whirlpools in empty\r\nblack space. I saw flashing ripples on a void. I saw lone lights\r\nuntended in nothingness and reflected from nothing. And I saw that they\r\nwere glowing from nothing. Light, just light.\r\n\r\nI saw a solitary mote pursuing an endless track across a vast area that\r\nwas utter abyss.\r\n\r\nGradually the flashlight seemed to flicker and die. I felt wavy and\r\nmistlike. I understood the meaning of matter and I saw indeed that\r\nmatter has very little real existence.\r\n\r\nI felt that I was upon my feet, and they were long columns of\r\nimagination having no reality save for endless electric foam.\r\n\r\nI felt myself moving forward and I felt other disturbances passing\r\nbetween me and around me and through me.\r\n\r\nThen I saw that scenes were passing before my vision and the globules\r\nof vacua that were my eyes seemed to register as they passed through\r\nother globules of vacua.\r\n\r\nI saw what seemed like a tiny planet spinning on its axis, while a\r\nstrange blue sun shone down and a dozen other planets swirled.\r\n\r\nI saw a figure indescribable, mounted upon a thing incredible, pursuing\r\nthe unknowable across a vast and meaningless place.\r\n\r\nI saw dozens of things like this--none of which can be described. Once\r\nI saw a large machine with churning arms and it was all bubbly and yet\r\nhard and mechanical.\r\n\r\nAll about me moved a great current and a wave of feelingless substance.\r\n\r\nThen I felt a beating of forces upon me, I felt a hammering at me and I\r\nfelt a pressure pushing upon the whirling, imaginary pools of my being\r\nand a curious coldness setting in.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI shivered and looked around. I was naked in the middle of the street;\r\nthe stars were out and the drone of airplanes audible. People were\r\nrunning up and down and a hose was playing upon the front of a burning\r\nbuilding. The wardens were digging in some ruins with crowbars and\r\nshovels.\r\n\r\nA man came running up to me and threw a blanket over my trembling\r\nshoulders.\r\n\r\n"Where\'d you come from? Bomb blow your clothes off? It happens."\r\n\r\nI pointed to the pile of bricks and junk that marked my house.\r\n\r\n"There\'s a man buried in those ruins, but he\'s alive," I said. "Just\r\ntrapped. 

You\'ll have to dig him out."\r\n\r\nThe warden blew his whistle and out of the turmoil three other men came\r\nwith picks and equipment and began to dig.\r\n\r\nBut it was two days before they finally got to him--and by that time he\r\nwas dead.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


In fact, every possible\r\n    factor was covered--except one of the flaws of human nature...._\r\n\r\n\r\nDaptine is the secret of it. Adaptine, they called it first; then it got\r\nshortened to daptine. It let us adapt.\r\n\r\nThey explained it all to us when we were ten years old; I guess they\r\nthought we were too young to understand before then, although we knew a\r\nlot of it already. They told us just after we landed on Mars.\r\n\r\n"You\'re _home_, children," the Head Teacher told us after we had gone\r\ninto the glassite dome they\'d built for us there. And he told us there\'d\r\nbe a special lecture for us that evening, an important one that we\r\nmust all attend.\r\n\r\nAnd that evening he told us the whole story and the whys and wherefores.\r\nHe stood up before us. He had to wear a heated space suit and helmet, of\r\ncourse, because the temperature in the dome was comfortable for us but\r\nalready freezing cold for him and the air was already too thin for him\r\nto breathe. His voice came to us by radio from inside his helmet.\r\n\r\n"Children," he said, "you are home. This is Mars, the planet on which\r\nyou will spend the rest of your lives. You are Martians, the first\r\nMartians. You have lived five years on Earth and another five in space.\r\nNow you will spend ten years, until you are adults, in this dome,\r\nalthough toward the end of that time you will be allowed to spend\r\nincreasingly long periods outdoors.\r\n\r\n"Then you will go forth and make your own homes, live your own lives, as\r\nMartians. You will intermarry and your children will breed true. 

They\r\ntoo will be Martians.\r\n\r\n"It is time you were told the history of this great experiment of which\r\neach of you is a part."\r\n\r\nThen he told us.\r\n\r\nMan, he said, had first reached Mars in 1985. It had been uninhabited by\r\nintelligent life (there is plenty of plant life and a few varieties of\r\nnon-flying insects) and he had found it by terrestrial standards\r\nuninhabitable. Man could survive on Mars only by living inside glassite\r\ndomes and wearing space suits when he went outside of them. Except by\r\nday in the warmer seasons it was too cold for him. The air was too thin\r\nfor him to breathe and long exposure to sunlight--less filtered of rays\r\nharmful to him than on Earth because of the lesser atmosphere--could\r\nkill him. The plants were chemically alien to him and he could not eat\r\nthem; he had to bring all his food from Earth or grow it in hydroponic\r\ntanks.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nFor fifty years he had tried to colonize Mars and all his efforts had\r\nfailed. Besides this dome which had been built for us there was only one\r\nother outpost, another glassite dome much smaller and less than a mile\r\naway.\r\n\r\nIt had looked as though mankind could never spread to the other planets\r\nof the solar system besides Earth for of all of them Mars was the least\r\ninhospitable; if he couldn\'t live here there was no use even trying to\r\ncolonize the others.\r\n\r\nAnd then, in 2034, thirty years ago, a brilliant biochemist named\r\nWaymoth had discovered daptine. A miracle drug that worked not on the\r\nanimal or person to whom it was given, but on the progeny he conceived\r\nduring a limited period of time after inoculation.\r\n\r\nIt gave his progeny almost limitless adaptability to changing\r\nconditions, provided the changes were made gradually.\r\n\r\nDr. Waymoth had inoculated and then mated a pair of guinea pigs; they\r\nhad borne a litter of five and by placing each member of the litter\r\nunder different and gradually changing conditions, he had obtained\r\namazing results. When they attained maturity one of those guinea pigs\r\nwas living comfortably at a temperature of forty below zero Fahrenheit,\r\nanother was quite happy at a hundred and fifty above. A third was\r\nthriving on a diet that would have been deadly poison for an ordinary\r\nanimal and a fourth was contented under a constant X-ray bombardment\r\nthat would have killed one of its parents within minutes.\r\n\r\nSubsequent experiments with many litters showed that animals who had\r\nbeen adapted to similar conditions bred true and their progeny was\r\nconditioned from birth to live under those conditions.\r\n\r\n"Ten years later, ten years ago," the Head Teacher told us, "you\r\nchildren were born. Born of parents carefully selected from those who\r\nvolunteered for the experiment. And from birth you have been brought up\r\nunder carefully controlled and gradually changing conditions.\r\n\r\n"From the time you were born the air you have breathed has been very\r\ngradually thinned and its oxygen content reduced. Your lungs have\r\ncompensated by becoming much greater in capacity, which is why your\r\nchests are so much larger than those of your teachers and attendants;\r\nwhen you are fully mature and are breathing air like that of Mars, the\r\ndifference will be even greater.\r\n\r\n"Your bodies are growing fur to enable you to stand the increasing cold.\r\nYou are comfortable now under conditions which would kill ordinary\r\npeople quickly. Since you were four years old your nurses and teachers\r\nhave had to wear special protection to survive conditions that seem\r\nnormal to you.\r\n\r\n"In another ten years, at maturity, you will be completely acclimated to\r\nMars. Its air will be your air; its food plants your food. 

Its extremes\r\nof temperature will be easy for you to endure and its median\r\ntemperatures pleasant to you. Already, because of the five years we\r\nspent in space under gradually decreased gravitational pull, the gravity\r\nof Mars seems normal to you.\r\n\r\n"It will be your planet, to live on and to populate. You are the\r\nchildren of Earth but you are the first Martians."\r\n\r\nOf course we had known a lot of those things already.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe last year was the best. 

By then the air inside the dome--except for\r\nthe pressurized parts where our teachers and attendants live--was almost\r\nlike that outside, and we were allowed out for increasingly long\r\nperiods. It is good to be in the open.\r\n\r\nThe last few months they relaxed segregation of the sexes so we could\r\nbegin choosing mates, although they told us there is to be no marriage\r\nuntil after the final day, after our full clearance. Choosing was not\r\ndifficult in my case. 

I had made my choice long since and I\'d felt sure\r\nthat she felt the same way; I was right.\r\n\r\nTomorrow is the day of our freedom. Tomorrow we will be Martians, _the_\r\nMartians. Tomorrow we shall take over the planet.\r\n\r\nSome among us are impatient, have been impatient for weeks now, but\r\nwiser counsel prevailed and we are waiting. We have waited twenty years\r\nand we can wait until the final day.\r\n\r\nAnd tomorrow is the final day.\r\n\r\nTomorrow, at a signal, we will kill the teachers and the other Earthmen\r\namong us before we go forth. They do not suspect, so it will be easy.\r\n\r\nWe have dissimulated for years now, and they do not know how we hate\r\nthem. They do not know how disgusting and hideous we find them, with\r\ntheir ugly misshapen bodies, so narrow-shouldered and tiny-chested,\r\ntheir weak sibilant voices that need amplification to carry in our\r\nMartian air, and above all their white pasty hairless skins.\r\n\r\nWe shall kill them and then we shall go and smash the other dome so all\r\nthe Earthmen there will die too.\r\n\r\nIf more Earthmen ever come to punish us, we can live and hide in the\r\nhills where they\'ll never find us. And if they try to build more domes\r\nhere we\'ll smash them. We want no more to do with Earth.\r\n\r\nThis is our planet and we want no aliens. Keep off!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Amazing Stories_ March 1954.

I thought few wiser or greater men ever lived. In my eyes he\r\nwas greater than Babe Ruth, Lindy, or the President.\r\n\r\nOf course, time, and my growing up caused me to bring him into a\r\nperspective that I felt to be more consonant with his true position in\r\nhis field of endeavor. When he died his friends mourned for fond\r\nremembrance of things past, but privately many of them felt that he had\r\noutlived his best days. Now with this glorious vindication, I wonder how\r\nmany of them are still alive to feel the twinge of conscience....\r\n\r\nOh, we\'re delighted of course, but it seems incredible even today to us\r\nelated oldsters. Although we were always his staunchest admirers, in\r\nretrospect we can see now that no one believed more than we that he did\r\nit strictly for the dollar. It is likely there was always a small corps\r\nof starry-eyed adolescents who found the whole improbable saga entirely\r\nbelievable, or at least half believed it might be partly true. The\r\nattitude of the rest of us ranged from a patronizing disparagement that\r\nwe thought was expected of us, through grudging admiration, to\r\nout-and-out enthusiasm.\r\n\r\nCertainly if anybody had taken the trouble to consider it--and why\r\nshould they have?--the landing of the first manned ship on our satellite\r\nseemed to render him as obsolete as a horde of other lesser and even\r\ngreater lights. At any rate, it was inevitable that the conquest of the\r\nmoon would be merely a stepping-stone to more distant points.\r\n\r\nOh, no, I had nothing to do with the selection of the Red Planet. Coming\r\nin as head of Project P-4 in its latter stages, as I did when Dr.\r\nFredericks died, the selection had already been made. Yes, it\'s quite\r\nlikely I may have been plugging for Mars below the conscious level. A\r\ncombination of chance, expediency and popular demand made Mars the next\r\ntarget, rather than Venus, which was, in some ways, the more logical\r\ngoal. I would have given anything to have gone, but the metaphorical\r\nstout heart that one reporter once credited me with is not the same as\r\nan old man\'s actual fatty heart.\r\n\r\nAnd there were heartbreak years ahead before the _Goddard_ was finally\r\nready. During this time he slipped further into obscurity while big,\r\nimportant things were happening all around us. 

You\'re right, that one\r\nreally big creation of his _is_ bigger than ever. It has passed into the\r\nlanguage, and meant employment for thousands of people. Too few of them\r\nhave even heard of him. Of course, he was still known and welcomed by a\r\nsmall circle of acquaintances, but to the world at large he was truly a\r\n"forgotten man."\r\n\r\nIt is worthy of note that one of the oldest of these acquaintances was\r\npresent at blast-off time. He happened to be the grandfather of a\r\ncertain competent young crewman. The old man was a proud figure during\r\nthe brief ceremonies and his eyes filled with tears as the mighty rocket\r\nclimbed straight up on its fiery tail. He remained there gazing up at\r\nthe sky long after it had vanished.\r\n\r\nHe was heard to murmur, "I am glad the kid could go, but it is just a\r\nlark to him. 

He never had a \'sense of wonder.\' How could he--nobody\r\nreads anymore."\r\n\r\nAfterward, his senile emotions betraying him, he broke down completely\r\nand had to be led from the field. It is rumored he did not live long\r\nafter that.\r\n\r\nThe _Goddard_ drove on until Mars filled the viz-screen. It was planned\r\nto make at least a half-dozen braking passes around the planet for\r\nobservational purposes before the actual business of bringing the ship\r\nin for landfall began. 

As expected the atmosphere proved to be thin. 

The\r\nspeculated dead-sea areas, oddly enough, turned out to be just that. To\r\nthe surprise of some, it was soon evident that Mars possessed, or had\r\npossessed, a high civilization. The _canali_ of Schiaparelli were indeed\r\nbroad waterways stretching from pole to pole, too regular to be anything\r\nbut the work of intelligence. But most wonderful of all were the\r\nscattered, but fairly numerous large, walled cities that dotted the\r\nworld. Everybody was excited, eager to land and start exercising their\r\nspecialties.\r\n\r\nOne of the largest of these cities was selected more or less at random.\r\nIt was decided to set down just outside, yet far enough from the walls\r\nto avoid any possibility of damage from the landing jets in the event\r\nthe city was inhabited. Even if deserted, the entire scientific\r\npersonnel would have raised a howl that would have been heard back on\r\nEarth if just a section of wall was scorched. When planet-fall was\r\ncompleted and observers had time to scan the surroundings it was seen\r\nthat the city was very much alive.\r\n\r\n"What keeps them up!" marvelled Kopchainski, the aeronautics and\r\nrocketry authority.\r\n\r\nThe sky swarmed with ships of strange design. The walls were crowded\r\nwith inhabitants, too far away for detailed observation. 

Even as they\r\nlooked an enormous gate opened and a procession of mounted figures\r\nemerged. In the event the place was deserted, the Captain would have had\r\nthe honor of being the first to touch Martian soil. While atmospheric\r\nand other checks were being run, he gave orders for the previously\r\ndecided alternative. Captain, semanticist and anthropologist would make\r\nthe First Contact.\r\n\r\nWith all checks agreeing that it was safe to open locks, soon the three\r\nrepresentatives of Earth were walking shoulder to shoulder down the\r\nramp. It was apparent that the two scientists purposely missed stride\r\ninches from the end, so that it was the Captain\'s foot that actually\r\ntouched ground first.\r\n\r\nThe cavalcade--though these beasties were certainly not horses--was now\r\nnear enough to the ship for details to be seen. Surprise and wonderment\r\nfilled the crew, for while the multi-legged steeds were as alien as\r\nanyone might expect to find on an alien world, the riders were very\r\ndefinitely humanoid. Briefly, brightly and barbarically trapped as they\r\nwere by earthly standards, they seemed to be little distinguishable from\r\nhomegrown homo saps.\r\n\r\nThe approaching company appeared to be armed mainly with swords and\r\nlances, but also in evidence were some tubular affairs that could very\r\nwell be some sort of projectile-discharging device. The Captain suddenly\r\nfelt unaccountably warm. It was a heavy responsibility--he hoped these\r\nMartians wouldn\'t be the type of madmen who believed in the "shoot\r\nfirst, inquire later" theory.\r\n\r\nEven as he stood there, outwardly calm but jittering internally, the\r\nMartian riders pulled up ten feet from the Earthmen. Their leader, tall,\r\ndark-haired, and subtly lighter in hue than his companions, dismounted\r\nand approached the Captain. With outstretched hand he took the Captain\'s\r\nin a firm grip.\r\n\r\nLet it be recorded here, to the shame of an Earth where reading for\r\npleasure is virtually a lost pastime, that not one man on the _Goddard_\r\nrealized the significance of what followed.\r\n\r\n"How do you do?" he said in perfect English, with an unmistakable trace\r\nof Southern accent.\r\n\r\n"Welcome to Barsoom! My name is John Carter.

We had corn to get in, besides which we had a bit of\r\na scare around here with lights flashing in the hills and funny noises\r\nat night. The fellows who know call that sort of thing by some fancy\r\nname. "Mass illusionations," I guess they\'d say.\r\n\r\nWell, one night we sat down to chow. We\'d worked hard all day, so we\r\nwere filling ourselves as full as we could. Ma is a right good cook\r\nwhen she bothers, and the girls do all right by themselves. When we\r\nfinished, Joey pops up. 

I think it was Joey. I can\'t rightly remember.\r\nWhen you got ten kids and ten names to keep track of you\'re bound to\r\nhave a hard time remembering.\r\n\r\nAnyhow, one of the kids pops up and says, "Look, Pa! Willie\'s plate is\r\nall full up with chow and no Willie."\r\n\r\nMa looks down the row and tallies them up. Sure thing, nine kids and no\r\nWillie. I kind of wondered why Willie wasn\'t around. He\'s usually the\r\nfirst to eat and the last to stop. 

Ma looked worried.\r\n\r\n"Well," I says. "Pass his plate. Don\'t want any food to go to waste."\r\nSo, the plate is passed down to me. By the time it goes down the line\r\nof kids there\'s one porkchop left. I eat the porkchop and forget about\r\nWillie for a while.\r\n\r\nNext morning, Joey comes up and says Willie wasn\'t home last night.\r\n\r\n"So," I says. "Willie wasn\'t home last night. Where\'s breakfast?" Ma\r\nlooks worried. Like I say Ma always liked Willie.\r\n\r\n"OK, Ma," I pipes up. "We\'ll ask the neighbors. It\'d be easy to spot\r\nWillie anywhere." 

That\'s what I figured. Even though I hate to say it\r\nabout my own son, Willie was plumb peculiar to look at. He had a head\r\nthat looked like it belonged on a man a hundred pounds heavier. It sat\r\nlike a knob on the end of a scrawny, skinny body. A body too scrawny to\r\nbe much use in farming.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe sure was dumb too, that Willie. If you put him out to plow a\r\nstraight line, he\'d plow a circle. If you wanted him to plow a curve,\r\nhe\'d plow a zig-zag line. He wasn\'t like the other boys. Willie got\r\nkicked out of school when he was eight. Not that the other boys\r\nfinished school, but he got kicked out real disgraceful-like. Now\r\nBennie, he set fire to the teacher\'s chair; Joey burned down the whole\r\nschool building. But Willie, guldurn Willie, he read all the books he\r\ncould get ahold of till he knew more than the teacher: so of course,\r\nthe teacher had to kick him out to save her face. Take Willie to pull\r\na trick like that. Asked her such fool questions that she had to close\r\nthe school for a couple months to take a rest cure. That was Willie for\r\nyou.\r\n\r\nSometimes I wonder myself why Willie don\'t mean as much to me as some\r\nof the other kids do. Maybe it\'s because I wasn\'t around when Willie\r\nwas born. Just happened the draft, the war draft that is, called my\r\nnumber. That was for the second world war. 

Well anyhow they didn\'t want\r\nme. 

I guess the government didn\'t want to support my kids. Don\'t blame\r\nthem though.\r\n\r\nI go to the city and two weeks later I come back and there is Willie.\r\nHe\'s just an ordinary baby, no hair and no teeth.\r\n\r\n"Kinda homely," I says to Ma. But she doesn\'t seem to care, so I figure\r\nI don\'t care either.\r\n\r\nWillie grew up and Willie kept getting in the way. Asked all kinds of\r\nsilly questions. Sure, the others always wanted to know why the grass\r\nis green; but not Willie. Willie asks some silly question about "the\r\nrelative merits of transistor amplifiers as compared to vacuum tubes."\r\nThat ain\'t all the questions he asked. 

But you get the idea. Willie\r\nalways acted kind of big for his breeches.\r\n\r\nMa always seemed to encourage him too. Keeps saying Willie ain\'t my\r\nson. I know she\'s kidding, of course. I reckon she means sort of\r\nlike, in spirit he ain\'t my son. In that respect, I agree with her.\r\nWillie sure ain\'t my son. It\'ll be great."\r\n\r\n"They... er... weren\'t detected flying over?"\r\n\r\n"They use an anti-radar beam."\r\n\r\n"Oh."\r\n\r\n"They can speak every language under the sun."\r\n\r\n"Look, David. I\'m tired and I want to go to bed. So be nice and go\r\nsober up."\r\n\r\n"You don\'t believe me?"\r\n\r\n"No. In plain language, no."\r\n\r\nHe extracted a square shaped box from a pocket. "See this gadget? I can\r\nmake myself disappear."\r\n\r\n"Do that."\r\n\r\nAnd he did.\r\n\r\n"Yow!" I screamed.\r\n\r\nHe reappeared.\r\n\r\nI staggered to the liquor cabinet and made myself a double triple\r\nwhiskey and soda.\r\n\r\n"Well?" There was a look of triumph on his face.\r\n\r\n"They give you that?"\r\n\r\n"A present."\r\n\r\n"I\'ve got nothing doing for a week. I\'ll be there tomorrow morning."\r\n\r\n"No. Tonight. You\'re liable to blab about it."\r\n\r\n"Don\'t you trust me?"\r\n\r\n"No. I know you went to see Dwight Howard about me."\r\n\r\n"Then why do you want me to write the story?"\r\n\r\n"I feel you owe me that. You\'re honest in some ways. Well?"\r\n\r\n"Right. I\'ll pack a grip if I\'m staying over."\r\n\r\n"Do that. 

I\'ve got my car downstairs."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nDavid Fry\'s home was a Spanish-style ranch which consisted of a herd of\r\ncattle and horses.\r\n\r\nThe Martians looked like us except they had no necks and no finger or\r\ntoe nails. Their leader was a giant of a Martian with the name, Dooma.\r\nThey wore slacks and sport jackets which Fry had bought for them. They\r\nseemed pleasant enough.\r\n\r\nI got some sleep and woke that afternoon. Dooma, Fry, and myself sat in\r\nthe front room and talked over the story we were to do.\r\n\r\n"We can\'t trust anyone," Fry said, "so you and I will play the\r\nearthlings in it. We\'ll land on Mars and discover life on the planet.\r\nDooma and his crew will play the Martians. Real type casting."\r\n\r\n"What about sets?" I asked.\r\n\r\n"Plenty of background on Mars," Dooma said.\r\n\r\n"What?" I exploded.\r\n\r\n"Sure," Fry said. "We\'ll go to Mars and shoot most of the picture\r\nthere. Has anyone ever done that before?"\r\n\r\n"Sure," Dooma said.\r\n\r\n"I mean anyone on earth," Fry said.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t like it," I said.\r\n\r\n"We\'ll bring you back," Dooma said.\r\n\r\n"I still don\'t like it."\r\n\r\n"And we\'ll do that nude scene," Fry said. "We\'ll have a couple of\r\nMartian girls taking a bath nude."\r\n\r\n"Oh, no," Dooma said. 

"That\'s out."\r\n\r\n"But why?" Fry wanted to know.\r\n\r\n"The Martian Censors. They won\'t go for it.

"\r\n\r\nI grinned. 

"There too?"\r\n\r\n"But I want to film life in the raw," Fry said.\r\n\r\nDooma shook his head. "Out of the question."\r\n\r\n"We\'ll do it my way," Fry snarled, "or we won\'t do it at all."\r\n\r\nDooma stood up. "Well if that\'s the way you feel about--"\r\n\r\n"Now wait a minute," I said.
