"\r\n\r\nActivity brought me to the window. I looked out and saw the Martians\r\nputting their ship together.\r\n\r\nFry came up behind me.\r\n\r\nThe ship blasted off and the Martians went back home.\r\n\r\n"They were hammy actors anyway," Fry rationalized.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


Her feet were tucked\r\ninto orange slippers, her blonde hair was done up in a neat bun. She was\r\ndressed as the government had ordered for that week.\r\n\r\nThe man said, "You are Mrs. Christopher Nest?"\r\n\r\nThere was a trace of anxiety in her voice as she answered. "Yes. 

And you\r\nare...?"\r\n\r\n"My name is Maxwell Hanstark. As you may already know, I am the official\r\npsychiatrist for this district. My appointment will last until the end\r\nof this year."\r\n\r\nMrs. Nest invited him in. They stepped into a clean living-room. At one\r\nend was the television set, at the other end were several chairs. There\r\nwas nothing between the set and the chairs except a large grey rug\r\nwhich stretched from wall to wall. They walked to the chairs and sat\r\ndown.\r\n\r\n"Now, just what is the matter with your husband, Mrs. Nest?"\r\n\r\nMrs. Nest reached into a large bowl and absently picked up a piece of\r\nstale popcorn. She daintily placed it in her mouth and chewed\r\nthoughtfully before she answered.\r\n\r\n"I wish I knew. All he does all day long is sit in the backyard and\r\nstare at the grass. He insists that he is standing on top of a cliff."\r\n\r\nHanstark took out a small pad and a short ball-point pen. 

He wrote\r\nsomething down before he spoke again. "Is he violent? Did he get angry\r\nwhen you told him there was no cliff?"\r\n\r\nMrs. Nest was silent for a moment. 

A second piece of popcorn joined the\r\nfirst. Hanstark\'s pen was poised above the pad. 

"No. He didn\'t get\r\nviolent."\r\n\r\nHanstark wrote as he asked the next question. "Just what _was_ his\r\nreaction?"\r\n\r\n"He said _I_ must be crazy."\r\n\r\n"Were those his exact words?"\r\n\r\n"No. He said that I was"-- She thought for a moment--"loco. Yes, that\r\nwas the word."\r\n\r\n"Loco?"\r\n\r\n"Yes. He said it just like those cowboys on the television."\r\n\r\nHanstark looked puzzled. "Perhaps you had better tell me more about\r\nthis. When did he first start acting this way?"\r\n\r\nMrs. Nest glanced up at the television set, then back at Hanstark. "It\r\nwas right after Texas Week. You remember--they showed all of those old\r\ncowboy pictures."\r\n\r\nHanstark nodded.\r\n\r\n"Well, he stayed up every night watching them. Some nights he didn\'t\r\neven go to sleep. Even after the set was off, he sat in one of the\r\nchairs, just staring at the screen. This morning, when I got up, he\r\nwasn\'t in the house. I looked all over but I couldn\'t find him. I was\r\njust about ready to phone the police when I glanced out the window into\r\nthe backyard. And I saw him."\r\n\r\n"What was he doing?"\r\n\r\n"He was just sitting there in the middle of the yard, staring. I went\r\nout and tried to bring him into the house. He told me he had to watch\r\nfor someone. When I asked him what he was talking about he told me that\r\nI was crazy. That was when I phoned you, Mr. Hanstark."\r\n\r\n"A very wise move, Mrs. Nest. And would you show me where your husband\r\nis right now?"\r\n\r\nShe nodded her head and they both got up from the chairs. They walked\r\nthrough the dining-room and kitchen. On the back porch Hanstark came to\r\na halt.\r\n\r\n"You\'d better stay here, Mrs. Nest." He walked to the door and opened\r\nit.\r\n\r\n"Mr. Hanstark," Mrs. Nest called.\r\n\r\nHanstark turned and saw her standing next to the automatic washing\r\nmachine. "Yes?

"\r\n\r\n"Please be careful."\r\n\r\nHanstark smiled. "I shall be, Mrs. Nest."\r\n\r\nHe walked out the door and down three concrete steps. Looking a little\r\nto his right, he saw a man squatted on his heels. He walked up to the\r\nman. 

"You are Mr. Christopher Nest?"\r\n\r\nThe man looked up and stared for a moment at Hanstark. "Yep," he\r\nanswered. Then he turned and stared at the grass again.\r\n\r\n"And may I ask you what you are doing?"\r\n\r\nNest answered without looking up. "Guardin\' the pass."\r\n\r\nHanstark scribbled something in his notebook. "And why are you guarding\r\nthe pass?"\r\n\r\nNest rose to his feet and stared down at Hanstark. "Just what are you\r\naskin\' all of these questions for, stranger?"\r\n\r\nHanstark saw Nest was bigger than he and decided to play along for a\r\nwhile. After all, strategy ...\r\n\r\n"I\'m just interested in your welfare, Mr. Nest.

"\r\n\r\nNest shrugged his shoulders. He reached into his shirt pocket and pulled\r\nout a sack of tobacco and some paper. Holding a piece of paper in one\r\nhand, he carefully poured a little tobacco onto it. In one quick\r\nmovement he rolled the paper and tobacco into a perfect cylinder.\r\n\r\nHe put the sack of tobacco and paper back into his pocket and took out a\r\nwooden kitchen match. He scraped it to life on the sole of his shoe and\r\napplied the flame to the tip of the cigarette. He puffed it into life\r\nand threw the match away. It burned for a few moments in the moist\r\ngrass, then went out. A thin trail of smoke rose from it, and then was\r\ngone.\r\n\r\n"Why are you guarding the pass?" Hanstark asked again.\r\n\r\nNest resumed his crouch on the grass. "News is around that Dirty Dan the\r\ncattle rustler is gonna try to steal some of my cattle." He patted an\r\nimaginary holster at his side. 

"And I aim to stop him."\r\n\r\nHanstark thought for a moment. Strategy--he must use strategy ... "Mr.\r\nNest." He waited until Nest had turned to him. "Mr. 

Nest. What would you\r\nsay if I told you that there was no pass down there?"\r\n\r\n"Why shucks, pardner. I\'d say you\'d been chewin\' some loco weed."\r\n\r\n"And if I could prove it?"\r\n\r\nNest answered after a moment\'s pause. "Why then, I guess _I\'d_ be loco."\r\n\r\nHanstark thought it was going to be easy. 

"Mr. Nest, it is a well known\r\nfact that no one can walk in mid-air. Is that not true?"\r\n\r\nNest took a deep drag on his cigarette and blew the smoke out of his\r\nnostrils. "Shore."\r\n\r\n"Then if I were to walk out above your pass you\'d have to admit there is\r\nno pass."\r\n\r\n"Reckon so.

"\r\n\r\nHanstark began to walk in the direction of Nest\'s "cliff." "Mr. Nest, I am not going to kill\r\nmyself. I am merely going to walk in that direction." He pointed to\r\nwhere the cliff was supposed to be. "To you it will look as if I were\r\nwalking in mid-air."\r\n\r\nNest dropped his hands to his sides. "Shucks, I don\'t care if you kill\r\nyourself. It\'s just that it\'s liable to make the cattle nervous."\r\n\r\nHanstark gave him a cold glare and began to walk. He took three paces\r\nand stopped. "You see, Mr. 

Nest. There is no cliff."\r\n\r\nNest looked at him and laughed. "You just take one more step and you\'ll\r\nfind there _is_ a cliff!"\r\n\r\nHanstark took another step--a long one. His face bore a surprised look\r\nas he disappeared beneath the grass. His screams could be heard for a\r\nmoment before he landed on the rocks below.\r\n\r\nNest walked to the edge of the cliff and looked down at the mangled\r\nbody. He took off his hat in respect. "Little feller had a lotta guts."\r\nThen he added, "Poor little feller."\r\n\r\nHe put his hat back on and looked down at the entrance to the valley. A\r\nhorse and rider appeared from behind several rocks.\r\n\r\n"Dirty Dan!" Nest exclaimed. When you finally reach\r\n           Mars, please be very careful what you look like!\r\n\r\n\r\nIn the shadows of a crater-wall on Phobos, moon of Mars, Grg and Yrl\r\nwaited to greet the God.\r\n\r\nIf the God continued its present rate of approach, it would land within\r\nmoments.\r\n\r\nGrg and Yrl had journeyed all night, with their eyes on that distant\r\nglinting speck in the sky. Over cold-crusted sand dunes and jagged\r\ncrater walls they had flowed, crept, bounded, oozed, toward the spot\r\nwhere the God must land if its course held true.\r\n\r\nGrg was a Fsgh, which is the equivalent of High Priest, Yrl was a\r\nFfssgghh, or Much Higher Priest. The best wishes of their people had\r\ngone with them on their tremendous mission.\r\n\r\nNow, at the place, they trembled in every tentacle as they peered\r\nupward. The rust-red orb of Mars rode the black horizon.\r\n\r\nMars was, as Grg and Yrl had learned from their Elders and now taught\r\ntheir Youngers, the stern Seeing-All Eye of It Who Was the Universe.\r\n\r\nFrom that great Eye, a day ago, had sprung a shining Messenger, an\r\nEmissary, a God that must be coming on a purposeful visit.\r\n\r\nIt had been detected at the half-way point of its trip. But there\r\ncould be no doubt regarding its origin, its nature, its destination--\r\n\r\nFor, in the matter of form, the God was a close replica of Grg and\r\nYrl--of all the creatures of their race! It was octopidal, with sinewy\r\ndouble tentacles, and a thinking trunk, and a reproduction pouch!\r\n\r\nThe only significant difference was that the God gleamed mysteriously,\r\nas if its angular, hard-line representation of normal form were cast in\r\nshining stone. As it flew it reflected starlight--and the red glow of\r\nthe Universal Eye behind it--from its sleek surfaces.\r\n\r\nGrg and Yrl blinked their own dull-surfaced, astronomically\r\nfar-sighted, rust-red eyes at each other in supreme excitement and\r\nanticipation.\r\n\r\nWhat would the God tell them? What would it reveal? 

Would it divulge\r\nthe Cosmic Secret? Would it tell them the place and destiny of their\r\nlowly race? Had it come to punish them for not being good enough, for\r\nover-reproducing, for worshipping improperly?\r\n\r\nFrom a selfish standpoint, it might even tell them how to get rid of\r\nthe _plllnk_--a subject of constant prayer.\r\n\r\nHow smoothly it flew! While Grg and Yrl and their people could bound\r\nabout with a great agility in Phobos\' light gravity, they could not\r\n_fly_.\r\n\r\n"How wonderful it would be to fly," said Yrl.\r\n\r\n"Perhaps," said Grg, "we have been found ready to be taught!"\r\n\r\nThen Grg twitched as a _plllnk_ bit him, just under the front left\r\ndouble-tentacle. He combed the light fur there, found the _plllnk_,\r\nand shredded it, casting the pieces round-about so that no two of them\r\nmight combine to form another _plllnk_.\r\n\r\nHow wonderful it would be also if the God could tell them how to get\r\nrid of the itching, crawling, parasitic _plllnk_, whose bite, in\r\nsufficient numbers, was often fatal!...\r\n\r\nThe God began to land.\r\n\r\nIt shot red flame downward from its mouth, on the underside of its\r\ngleaming body. Red flickers and sharp-edged black shadows danced about\r\nthe two who waited below. 

They shrank back, fearful that the display\r\nmight be a disapproving communication--yet they held their ground,\r\nknowing they had lived good lives and deserved no condemnation on any\r\nscore they could imagine.\r\n\r\nThe God lowered, on its belching tongue of flame--the flame that seemed\r\na tiny part, a sliver, of the Universal Eye that Watched.\r\n\r\nStrange marks were on the side of the God\'s body. They were: 1st MARS\r\nEXPEDITION--U. S. SPACE FORCE--PLANET-TO-SATELLITE CREWBOAT NO. 2.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe last few moments of the God\'s descent were quite rapid.\r\nSimultaneously, the darting red flames seemed to lessen in intensity\r\nand length. Then, at the second of impact, they brightened again to\r\nprevious power--but too late. The impact was hard.\r\n\r\nGrg and Yrl gasped as one of the God\'s double-tentacles buckled,\r\ncrumpled, with a glinting of shiny-hard material. The flames stopped.\r\n\r\nThe God, unable to remain erect with its injury, slowly toppled. Its\r\nbody thudded silently, stirring pumice dust. It was motionless.\r\n\r\nGrg and Yrl stared at each other.\r\n\r\nWas the God fatally injured? Dying? 

Dead? (For a broken tentacle meant\r\nthat fluids would seep out, and soon the dry-death would occur.)\r\n\r\nThe God stirred.\r\n\r\nIt braced two sets of tentacles against the ground, as if trying\r\nto push itself erect. The effort was not successful. Again it\r\nwas motionless. The two double-tentacles remained outstretched,\r\nhowever--and they pointed at the shadows where Grg and Yrl waited and\r\nwatched.\r\n\r\nGrg and Yrl sighed in relief.\r\n\r\nThe God had assumed conversation-position.\r\n\r\nIt must have healed its broken tentacle--truly a God! Soon it would be\r\nas good as new; for otherwise, agony would forbid conversation.\r\n\r\nIt was ready to address them. Now.\r\n\r\nThis was the greatest moment of Grg\'s and Yrl\'s lives.\r\n\r\nThey waited for the God to speak.\r\n\r\nIt was silent.\r\n\r\nA long time passed. The God remained motionless, though in\r\nconversation-position, and silent. A _very_ long time passed.\r\n\r\nThen a tiny hole appeared in the God\'s side. 

It grew\r\nlarger--larger--and then it stopped growing larger.\r\n\r\nSomething appeared at the hole. It paused, then dropped to the surface\r\nof Phobos, where it began to crawl about.\r\n\r\nIt bore considerable resemblance to a _plllnk_, except for its\r\nshiny-wrinkled grey skin (_plllnks_ were purple.) And this thing was\r\nhuge--_Huge_. It was one-fifth the size of the God\'s body.\r\n\r\nCaught by horror, and fearing the worst, Grg and Yrl waited for the God\r\nto speak.\r\n\r\n(_Damn_, John Cotter was thinking. _That was a neat bit of sloppiness,\r\nthat landing.... Carruthers will chew me out and in again!_ Pause:\r\n_Holy cats, I hope the radio isn\'t busted, or I\'ll have a helluva wait\r\nbefore they follow up and find me!..._)\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe God was dead.\r\n\r\nKilled by the giant _plllnk_--a scourge from which, evidently, even\r\nthe Gods were not spared. It silently circled Phobos\r\nfrom the Universal Eye.\r\n\r\nIt did not land. It silently circled Phobos, and then returned to the\r\nEye.\r\n\r\nWithin the day, it was back, in the company of eleven other Gods. They\r\nlanded. And then\r\nthe thoughts would vanish as that familiar tug on the line meant a\r\nstruggle was coming up. A battle between man and fish.\r\n\r\nI love deep sea fishing. I was on a vacation with nothing to do but\r\nrelax. Oh, there were women, all right. But one gets tired of women.\r\nBut not fishing.\r\n\r\nSo here I was, this bright sunny afternoon, in my motor launch, when\r\nthat tug on my line made me sit erect, and my brain became alert. You\r\nhave to think clearly. You have to know when to let out line and when\r\nto pull in line. When the fish got tired you could tell. It all comes\r\nthrough experience.\r\n\r\nFrom the pull of the line I thought I\'d hooked a sailfish.\r\n\r\nI reeled in fast, then started letting out line. But the line didn\'t\r\nget taut. It was loose. At first I thought I\'d lost it.\r\n\r\nAnd then it climbed into the launch.\r\n\r\nI got up fast and made ready to dive overboard.\r\n\r\n"Hold on, fella," it said. "Don\'t get into a panic.

"\r\n\r\nI stared at it. 

It was about four feet tall, with scales and two thick\r\nstubs that was supposed to be tails. It stood on its tails and blinked\r\nenormous eyes at me.\r\n\r\n"The creature from the black lagoon," I said.\r\n\r\n"To you I\'m a creature," he said. "To me you\'re a creature."\r\n\r\n"What kind of a fish are you?"\r\n\r\n"I\'m not a fish. I\'m a Grenarian."\r\n\r\n"You mean you eat vegetables?"\r\n\r\n"I\'m from the planet Grenaria."\r\n\r\n"Look," I said. "You want this boat? Keep it. 

I\'m off for Tampa. It\'s\r\nabout time I took up drinking."\r\n\r\n"You hate me."\r\n\r\n"No, I don\'t. 

Honest. I\'m just not used to these things."\r\n\r\n"It happens all the time. What you don\'t understand you hate."\r\n\r\n"But I don\'t. Honest. And where did you learn to talk?"\r\n\r\n"I learned English from a professor. He understood my plight and tried\r\nto help. He was fishing the same as you when I caught hold of his line\r\nand we met."\r\n\r\n"What happened to him?"\r\n\r\n"He went back to tell his colleagues. I never saw him again."\r\n\r\n"He\'s probably in the booby hatch," I said.\r\n\r\n"What\'s that?"\r\n\r\n"Where I\'ll be if I ever tell anyone this."\r\n\r\n"This is a cruel world," he said. "By the way my name is Hrodes."\r\n\r\n"And mine is Carol Engelholtz. Now that the formalities are over, what\r\nthe hell are you doing here?"\r\n\r\n"My orders were to make contact with this solar system. My ship is at\r\nthe bottom of the sea. I have to be near water or die. And every time I\r\ntry to make contact I\'m left alone on a craft of this sort."\r\n\r\n"You mean they jump overboard?"\r\n\r\n"That\'s exactly what I mean."\r\n\r\n"You\'re from another galaxy?"\r\n\r\n"Yes. My planet is covered with water. Your planet is the best one in\r\nthis system which has water on it. That\'s why I\'m here."\r\n\r\n"But you\'re not in water now."\r\n\r\n"My gills can still absorb it. As long as I\'m near it.

"\r\n\r\n"Well, what do you want me to do?"\r\n\r\n"I want to meet someone with responsibility."\r\n\r\n"I wouldn\'t be able to get anyone to come out here with a story like\r\nthat. They wouldn\'t believe me. I\'d end up with the professor."\r\n\r\n"Then take me with you."\r\n\r\n"But you wouldn\'t be near water. Wait a minute. I can leave you in the\r\ntub."\r\n\r\n"Anything. I just want to get this mission over with."\r\n\r\n"I can wrap you up in wet towels. I can drive you to my place and go\r\nbring someone back with me."\r\n\r\n"Anything. Anything. 

Just let\'s get on with it."\r\n\r\n"Why, I might be making history. I may become famous."\r\n\r\n"Will you please start this craft back to land?"\r\n\r\n"Sure thing. Just a second," I started the motor and headed for land.\r\n\r\nMe. Carol Engelholtz. A liaison between two planets. 

I never felt so\r\nexcited in my life. Why, it was more exciting than hooking a sailfish.\r\n\r\n"There\'s my lodge," I shouted, pointing at the bluff just over a rise.\r\n\r\n"You stay there alone?" Hrodes asked.\r\n\r\n"I have a cook and a housekeeper. But they won\'t bother you. You\'ll\r\nstay in the tub in my bathroom while I go fetch somebody. But who do I\r\ngo fetch?"\r\n\r\n"Anyone with responsibility. I want to get this over with."\r\n\r\n"Yes, yes, I know. 

Your mission." I docked the launch, soaked towels,\r\nwrapped them around Hrodes, carried him--or she--to my car, and in\r\nfifteen minutes I was home.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI left Hrodes in the tub and went back to the car. Miami was too far\r\noff. There was a small town called Chesterville a few miles away. It\r\nseemed the only place to go.\r\n\r\n"There ain\'t no F.B.I. branch here," a deputy behind a battered desk\r\nsaid. He was about sixty, with a skinny neck that was covered with\r\nhalf dollar size blotches. "Better try Miami. 

Why? What\'s the matter?\r\nFind some subversives? A lot of subversives in Florida."\r\n\r\n"No, no, nothing like that. Look, there must be a school or some kind\r\nof place for learning here."\r\n\r\n"Shore thing. We gotta school."\r\n\r\n"Isn\'t there a professor teaching there, maybe?"\r\n\r\n"Nope. But we got old Mrs. 

Henshaw. Husband died about six years ago.\r\nOld bag. I think she\'s been running around lately with some tourist\r\nfrom Iowa. Now if you\'re just lookin\' for any old professor, then--"\r\n\r\n"That\'s right," I said, grasping at a straw. "Any old professor. Is\r\nthere one in town?"\r\n\r\n"Professor Klugelmeyer. Used to teach at some eastern college. Kind of\r\ndopey, though, I think. Funny old gaffer. Believes in flyin\' saucers.\r\nCan you imagine?"\r\n\r\n"Where do I reach him?"\r\n\r\n"He\'s stayin\' at Mrs. Kirpatrick\'s roomin\' house. Poor Mrs. Kirpatrick.\r\nGot a bad case of food poisoning. She ate--"\r\n\r\nI ran out of the building and inquired for the rooming house. I found\r\nit and Professor Klugelmeyer.\r\n\r\n"What? What? Hard to believe--Hard to believe. Once heard the same\r\nstory from Professor Dickson. The poor fellow was put away. You must be\r\nmistaken, old man. You must be. 

Take my advice. Give up drinking. Bad\r\nfor the liver, too, you know."\r\n\r\n"That old deputy told me you believe in flying saucers," I said.\r\n\r\n"I do. I really do. 

From Mars, probably. But they certainly won\'t turn\r\nout to be fish. Fish talking? Come now."\r\n\r\n"I didn\'t believe it at first myself. Listen, Professor, come with me.\r\nSee and hear for yourself."\r\n\r\n"Well, I don\'t know."\r\n\r\nIt took me an hour before I had him half convinced. I almost dragged\r\nhim to my car.\r\n\r\n"This had better not turn out to be a practical joke," he said. The\r\nprofessor was somewhere between sixty and seventy. He was kind of thin\r\nand he sported a long white mustache.\r\n\r\nIt was getting toward evening when we got to the lodge.\r\n\r\nI ushered him in to my room. "There," I said, flinging open the\r\nbathroom door.\r\n\r\n"Where?" he said.\r\n\r\n"There."\r\n\r\n"Where?"\r\n\r\nI looked. I blinked. 

I looked again. The tub was empty.\r\n\r\nI raced through the house.\r\n\r\nIn the front room I saw Mrs. O\'Brien, my housekeeper.\r\n\r\n"Where\'s Hrodes?" I asked her.\r\n\r\n"Who?"\r\n\r\n"He was in the tub. I left him there."\r\n\r\n"You mean that big fish?"\r\n\r\n"Yes, yes. Where is he?"\r\n\r\n"He\'s in the kitchen. We\'re having him for dinner."\r\n\r\n"What!"\r\n\r\n"Sure. Yat has it in the oven now."\r\n\r\n"You murderer!"\r\n\r\n"What are you talking about? It\'s only a fish. Didn\'t you catch him so\r\nwe\'d have fish for dinner?"\r\n\r\n"No. Didn\'t he tell you who he was?"\r\n\r\n"Are you crazy? He didn\'t tell me nothin\'. Besides, I didn\'t see it\r\ntill Sun Yat had it all cut up and laid out for cookin\'."\r\n\r\nSun Yat, my Chinese cook. Hrodes had met someone who couldn\'t\r\nunderstand his plight or be scared out of his wits. Sun Yat was a deaf\r\nmute!\r\n\r\nThe professor was clucking sadly at me as he stomped out of the house.\r\n\r\nMe? There was nothing to do but eat my dinner....\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


More when he goes along by\r\nhimself; less when you try to pin him down to it. And since the subject\r\nof tonight\'s revelations would be the pre-Mohammed Arabian Culture, I\'d\r\nfind Alva inclined toward my side of the debate, which is strictly\r\nmorphological and without any pious theories of "progress".\r\n\r\nI\'d completely forgotten that Jocelyn had mentioned something about\r\nhaving a special attraction: a "Mr. Fayliss", who, she insisted, was a\r\ntroubadour. I didn\'t comment, not wanting to spend a day with Jocelyn on\r\nthe phone, exploring the Provence.\r\n\r\nThe night wasn\'t too warm for August, and there were occasional gusts of\r\nair seeping through the layers of tobacco smoke that hovered over the\r\nassemblage. As usual, it was a heterogeneous crowd, which rapidly formed\r\nnumerous islands of discourse. The trade winds carried salient gems of\r\nintelligence throughout the entire archipelago at times, and Jocelyn\r\nwalked upon the water, scurrying from one body to another, sopping up\r\nthe overflow of "culture". She visited our atoll, where Kutrov\'s\r\npassionate exposition had already raised the mean temperature some\r\ndegrees, but didn\'t stay long. Such debates didn\'t suggest any course of\r\nsocial or political action, and couldn\'t be trued in to any of her\r\ncauses.\r\n\r\nMy attention was wandering from the Kutrov-Alva variations, for Bill had\r\nonly been speaking for ten minutes, and could not be expected to arrive\r\nat any point whatsoever for at least another fifteen. From the east of\r\nus came apocalyptic figures of nuclear physics; from the west, I heard\r\nthe strains of Mondrian interwoven with Picasso; south of us, a post\r\nmortem on the latest "betrayal" of this or that aspiration of "the\r\npeople", and to the north, we heard the mysteries of atonality. 

It was\r\nwhile I was looking around, and letting these things roll over me, that\r\nI saw the stranger enter. Jocelyn immediately bounced up from a couch,\r\nleaving the crucial problem of atmosphere-poisoning via fission and/or\r\nfusion bombs suspended, and made effusive noises.\r\n\r\nThis, then, was the "troubadour"--Mr. Fayliss. 

The Main Attraction was\r\ndecidedly prepossessing. Tall, peculiarly graceful both in appearance\r\nand manner, dressed with an immaculateness that seemed excessive in this\r\npost-Bohemian circle. There was a decided musical quality to his speech,\r\nas he made polite comments upon being introduced to each of us, and an\r\nexactness in sentence-structure, word-choices and enunciation that\r\nbespoke the foreigner. Jocelyn took him around with the air of\r\nconducting a quick tour through a museum, then settled him momentarily\r\nwith the music group, now in darkest Schoenberg, only partially\r\nilluminated by "Wozzek". I watched Fayliss long enough to solidify an\r\nimpression that he was at ease here--but not merely in this particular\r\ndiscussion. It was a case of his being simply at ease, period.\r\n\r\nKutrov was watching him, too, and I saw now that there would be a\r\nmost-likely permanent digression. Too bad--I\'d had a feeling that when\r\nhe came to his point, it would have been a strong one. "Hungarian, do\r\nyou suppose?" 

he asked.\r\n\r\nAlva examined the evidence. Fayliss had high cheekbones, longish eyes,\r\nwith large pupils. He was lean, without giving an impression of\r\nthinness. He had not taken off his gloves, and I wondered if he would\r\ncome forth with a monocle; if he had, it would not have seemed an\r\naffectation.\r\n\r\n"I wouldn\'t say Slavic," Alva said. He started off on ethnology, and we\r\ntoured the Near East again. I jumped into the break when Kutrov was\r\nswallowing beer and Alva lighting a cigaret to observe that Fayliss\r\nreminded me of some Egyptian portraits--although I couldn\'t set the\r\nperiod. "If those eyes of his don\'t shine in the dark," I added, "they\r\nought to."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nA brief pause for appreciation, then Jocelyn was calling for all men\'s\r\nattention. 

She managed to get it in reasonably short order, took a deep\r\nbreath, then dived into announcing that our "special guest, Mr. Fayliss"\r\nwas going to deliver a song-cycle.\r\n\r\nFayliss arose, bowed slightly, then nodded to Mark Loring, who brought\r\nforth his oboe. "These songs were not conceived or composed in the form\r\nI am presenting them," he said. "But I believe that the arrangement I\r\nuse is an effective one.\r\n\r\n"I call this, \'Song of the Last Men\'." He nodded again to Loring, and\r\nthe performance began. 

His voice was affecting, and his artistry\r\nunmistakable. And there were overtones in his voice that gave an added\r\neeriness to the weird music itself.\r\n\r\nThe songs told of the feelings, the memories, and despair of a\r\nnearly-extinct people--one which had achieved a great culture and a\r\nworld-wide civilization. The singer knows that the civilization has been\r\ndestroyed; that the people created by this culture and civilization are\r\ngone, the few survivors being pitiful fellaheen, unable to rebuild or\r\nbring forth a culture of their own. There is despair at the loss of the\r\ncomforts the civilization they knew brought them, sorrow at their\r\ninability to share in its greatness--even in memory; and a resigned\r\ncertainty that they are the last of the race--they will soon be gone,\r\nand no others shall arise after them.\r\n\r\nThere was silence when Fayliss finished, then discreet but firm\r\napplause, as if the audience felt that giving full reign to their\r\napproval would make an impious racket. Fayliss seemed to sense this\r\nfeeling, and smiled as he bowed.\r\n\r\n"These are not songs of your people, are they?" asked Jocelyn.\r\n\r\nFayliss shook his head. "Oh no--they are far removed from us. I am\r\nmerely an explorer of past cultures and civilizations, and I enjoy\r\nadapting such masterpieces of the past as I can find. This arrangement\r\nwas made for you; I shall make a different one for my own people, so\r\nthat the sonic values of the music and the words agree with each other."\r\n\r\nKutrov blinked, then asked him--"Well, can you tell us something more\r\nabout the people who created this cycle? It has a familiar ring to it,\r\nyet I cannot tie it in with any past culture I have heard of.

"\r\n\r\nJocelyn cut in with the regretful announcement that Mr. Fayliss had\r\nanother appointment, and called for a note of thanks to him for coming.\r\nMore applause--this time unrestrained. Fayliss smiled again and swept\r\nhis eyes around us, as if filled with some amusing secret. Then he said\r\nto Kutrov, "You would find them quite understandable."\r\n\r\nI wandered over to the window, in search of air, and noted that someone\r\nhad indiscreetly left a comfortable chair vacant. I was near the door,\r\nso that I could hear Jocelyn say to Fayliss: "It was--very moving. Why,\r\nI could almost feel that you were singing about us."\r\n\r\nFayliss smiled again. 

"That is as it should be."\r\n\r\n"Of course," chimed in Loring, who\'d come up to ask Fayliss if he could\r\nhave a copy of the score, "that\'s the test of expert performance."\r\n\r\nThe lights were dimmed again by the fog of tobacco smoke, and I could\r\nsee the street quite clearly by moonlight. I decided I would watch\r\nFayliss, and see if his eyes did glow in the dark. I saw him go down the\r\nsidewalk, with that graceful stride of his, his hands in his pockets.\r\nBut I couldn\'t see his eyes at all.\r\n\r\nThen a gust of wind tugged his hat, and, for an instant I thought he\'d\r\nhave to go scrambling after it. But, quick as a rapier thrust, a tail\r\ndarted out from beneath his dress coat, caught the hat, and set it back\r\nupon his head.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Future combined with Science Fiction\r\n    Stories_ September 1951. There had been times when the Galactic\r\nHistorian had doubted whether even his renowned abilities were up to the\r\nassignment that the Galactic Board of Education had so lightly tossed\r\nhis way, times when he had thrown up his hands--all five of them--in\r\ndespair. But at last the completed manuscript lay before him on his desk\r\nwith nothing but the final reading remaining between it and publication.\r\n\r\nThe Galactic Historian repeatedly wiped his brows as he turned the\r\npages. It was a warm night, even for Mixxx Seven. Now and then, a tired\r\nbreeze struggled down from the hills and limped across the lowlands to\r\nthe Galactic University buildings. It crept into the Galactic\r\nHistorian's study via the open door and out again via the open windows,\r\nfingering the manuscript each time it passed but doing nothing\r\nwhatsoever about the temperature.\r\n\r\nThe manuscript was something more than a hammered-down history of\r\ngalactic achievement. It was the ultimate document. The two and seventy\r\nthousand jarring texts that it summarized had been systematically\r\ndestroyed, one by one, after the Galactic Historian had stripped them of\r\ntheir objective information. If an historical event was not included in\r\nthe manuscript, it failed as an event. It ceased to have reality.\r\n\r\nThe responsibility was the Galactic Historian's alone and he did not\r\ntake it lightly. But he had a lot on his minds and, of late, he hadn't\r\nbeen sleeping well. He was overworked and over-tired and over-anxious.\r\nHe hadn't seen his wives for two Mixxx months and he was worried about\r\nthem--all fifty of them.\r\n\r\nHe never should have let them take the Hub cruise in the first place.\r\nBut they'd been so enthusiastic and so eager that he simply hadn't had\r\nthe hearts to let them down. Now, despite his better judgments, he was\r\nbeginning to wonder if they might not be on the make for another\r\ncoordinator.\r\n\r\nWives trouble, on top of all his chronological trouble, was too much.\r\nThe Galactic Historian could hardly be blamed for wanting to see the\r\nlast of the manuscript, for wanting to transmit it to his publishers,\r\npotential hiatuses and all, and take the next warp for the Hub.\r\n\r\nBut he was an historian--_the_ historian, in fact--and he persisted\r\nheroically in his task, rereading stale paragraphs and checking dreary\r\ndates, going over battles and conquests and invasions and interregnums.\r\nDespite his mood and despite the heat, the manuscript probably would\r\nhave arrived at his publishers chronologically complete. So complete, in\r\nfact, that schoolteachers all over the galaxy would have gotten the\r\ntextbook they had always wanted--a concise chronicle of everything that\r\nhad ever happened since the explosion of the primeval atom, a history\r\ntextbook that no other history textbook could contradict for the simple\r\nreason that there were no other history textbooks.\r\n\r\nAs it was, they got the textbook, but it did not contain everything that\r\nhad ever happened. Not quite.\r\n\r\nTwo factors were responsible for the omission. 

The first was an\r\noversight on the part of the Galactic Historian. With so much on his\r\nminds, he had forgotten to number the pages of the manuscript.\r\n\r\nThe second factor was the breeze.\r\n\r\nThe breeze was the ultimate archfiend and there can be no question as to\r\nits motivation. Nothing short of sheer malice could have caused it\r\nsuddenly to remember its function after neglecting that function all\r\nevening.\r\n\r\nAll evening it had been tiptoeing down the hillsides and across the\r\nlowlands as though it was afraid of disturbing a single blade of grass\r\nor a single drooping leaf. And then, at the crucial moment, it huffed\r\nand puffed itself up into a little hurricane, charged down upon the\r\nGalactic University buildings and whooshed through the Galactic\r\nHistorian's study like a band of interstellar dervishes.\r\n\r\nUnfortunately, the Galactic Historian had begun to wipe his brows at the\r\nvery moment of the breeze's entry. While the act was not a complicated\r\none, it did consume time and monopolize attention. It is not surprising,\r\ntherefore, that he failed to witness the theft. Neither is it surprising\r\nthat he failed to notice afterwards that the page he had been checking\r\nwas gone.\r\n\r\nHe was, as previously stated, overworked, over-tired, and over-anxious\r\nand, in such a state, even a Galactic Historian can skip a whole series\r\nof words and dates and never know the difference. A hiatus of twenty\r\nthousand years is hardly noticeable anyway. Galactically speaking,\r\ntwenty thousand years is a mere wink in time.\r\n\r\nThe breeze didn't carry the page very far. It simply whisked it through\r\na convenient window, deposited it beneath a xixxix tree and then\r\nreturned to the hills to rest. But the choice of a xixxix tree is highly\r\nsignificant and substantiates the malicious nature of the breeze's act.\r\nIf it had chosen a muu or a buxx tree instead, the Galactic Historian\r\nmight have found the page in the morning when he took his constitutional\r\nthrough the university grounds.\r\n\r\nHowever, since a xixxix tree was selected, no doubt whatever can remain\r\nas to the breeze's basic motivation. Articles of a valuable nature just\r\naren't left beneath xixxix trees. 

Everybody knows that squixes live in\r\nxixxix trees and everybody knows that squixes are collectors. They\r\ncollect all sorts of things, buttons and pins and twigs and\r\npebbles--anything at all, in fact, that isn't too big for them to pick\r\nup and carry into their xixxix tree houses.\r\n\r\nThey have been called less kind things than collectors. Thieves, for\r\nexample, and scavengers. But collectors are what they really are.\r\nCollecting fulfills a basic need in their mammalian makeup; the\r\npossession of articles gives them a feeling of security. They love to\r\nsurround their little furry bodies with all sorts of odds and ends, and\r\ntheir little arboreal houses are stuffed with everything you can think\r\nof.\r\n\r\nAnd they simply adore paper. They adore it because it has a practical as\r\nwell as a cultural value.\r\n\r\nSpecifically, they adore it because it is wonderful to make hammocks out\r\nof.\r\n\r\nWhen the two squixes in the xixxix tree saw the page drift to the\r\nground, they could hardly believe their eyes. They chittered excitedly\r\nas they skittered down the trunk. The page had hardly stopped fluttering\r\nbefore it was whisked aloft again, clenched in tiny squix fingers.\r\n\r\nThe squixes wasted no time. It had been a long while since the most\r\ncherished of all collector's items had come their way and they needed a\r\nnew hammock badly. First, they tore the page into strips, then they\r\nbegan to weave the strips together.\r\n\r\n_--1456, Gut. Bi.

"Now, then! 

What\r\nseems to be the trouble?"\r\n\r\nWheatley had been palpitating for five days straight at the prospect of\r\ncoming here. "I know it\'s silly," he said. "But I\'ve been having a pain\r\nin my toe."\r\n\r\n"Indeed!" said the doctor. "Well, now! How long have you had this pain,\r\nmy man?"\r\n\r\n"About six months now, I\'d say. "But this is incredible. You haven\'t had a checkup in almost ten\r\nyears!"\r\n\r\n"I guess I haven\'t," said Wheatley, apologetically. This\r\nis 1972."\r\n\r\n"Well, of course--"\r\n\r\n"Of course you may be _feeling_ well enough, but that doesn\'t mean\r\neverything is just the way it should be. Been growing short\r\nof breath when you hurry upstairs?"\r\n\r\n"Well--I _have_ been bothered a little."\r\n\r\n"I thought so! Heart pound when you run for the subway? Feel tired all\r\nday? 

Pains in your calves when you walk fast?"\r\n\r\n"Uh--yes, occasionally, I--" Wheatley looked worried and rubbed his toe\r\non the chair leg.\r\n\r\n"You know that fifty-five is a dangerous age," said the doctor gravely.\r\n"Do you have a cough? Heartburn after dinner? 

Prop up on pillows at\r\nnight? 

Just as I thought! And no checkup for ten years!" He sighed\r\nagain.\r\n\r\n"I suppose I should have seen to it," Wheatley admitted. "But you see,\r\nit\'s just that my toe--"\r\n\r\n"My dear fellow! Your toe is _part_ of you. It doesn\'t just exist down\r\nthere all by itself. "Now, if we could\r\nsee you there next Monday morning at nine--"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Very interesting X rays," said the young doctor with the red hair.\r\n"_Very_ interesting. See this shadow in the duodenal cap? 

See the\r\nprolonged emptying time? And I\'ve never seen such beautiful\r\npylorospasm!"\r\n\r\n"This is my toe?" asked Wheatley, edging toward the doctors. It seemed\r\nhe had been waiting for a very long time.\r\n\r\n"Toe! Oh, no," said the red-headed doctor. "No, that\'s the Orthopedic\r\nRadiologist\'s job. I\'m a Gastro-Intestinal man, myself. Upper. Dr.\r\nSchultz here is Lower." The red-headed doctor turned back to his\r\nconsultation with Dr. Schultz. Mr. Wheatley rubbed his toe and waited.\r\n\r\nPresently another doctor came by. He looked very grave as he sat down\r\nbeside Wheatley. "Tell me, Mr. Wheatley, have you had an orthodiagram\r\nrecently?"\r\n\r\n"No."\r\n\r\n"An EKG?"\r\n\r\n"No."\r\n\r\n"Fluoroaortogram?"\r\n\r\n"I--don\'t _think_ so."\r\n\r\nThe doctor looked even graver, and walked away, muttering to himself. In\r\na few moments he came back with two more doctors. "--no question in _my_\r\nmind that it\'s cardiomegaly," he was saying, "but Haddonfield should\r\nknow. He\'s the best Left Ventricle man in the city. Excellent paper in\r\nthe AMA Journal last July: \'The Inadequacies of Modern Orthodiagramatic\r\nTechniques in Demonstrating Minimal Left Ventricular Hypertrophy.\' A\r\nbrilliant study, simply brilliant! Now _this_ patient--" He glanced\r\ntoward Wheatley, and his voice dropped to a mumble.\r\n\r\nPresently two of the men nodded, and one walked over to Wheatley,\r\ncautiously, as though afraid he might suddenly vanish. "Now, there\'s\r\nnothing to be worried about, Mr. Wheatley," he said. "We\'re going to\r\nhave you fixed up in just no time at all. Just a few more studies. Now,\r\nif you could see me in Valve Clinic tomorrow afternoon at three--"\r\n\r\nWheatley nodded. "Nothing serious, I hope?"\r\n\r\n"Serious? Oh, no! 

Dear me, you _mustn\'t_ worry. Everything is going to\r\nbe all right," the doctor said.\r\n\r\n"Well--I--that is, my toe is still bothering me some. It\'s not nearly as\r\nbad, but I wondered if maybe you--"\r\n\r\nDawn broke on the doctor\'s face. "Give you something for it? Well now,\r\nwe aren\'t Therapeutic men, you understand. Always best to let the expert\r\nhandle the problem in his own field." He paused, stroking his chin for a\r\nmoment. "Tell you what we\'ll do. 

Dr. Epstein is one of the finest\r\nTherapeutic men in the city. He could take care of you in a jiffy. 

We\'ll\r\nsee if we can\'t arrange an appointment with him after you\'ve seen me\r\ntomorrow."\r\n\r\nMr. Wheatley was late to Mitral Valve Clinic the next day because he had\r\ngone to Aortic Valve Clinic by mistake, but finally he found the right\r\nwaiting room. A few hours later he was being thumped, photographed, and\r\nlistened to. Substances were popped into his right arm, and withdrawn\r\nfrom his left arm as he marveled at the brilliance of modern medical\r\ntechniques. Before they were finished he had been seen by both the\r\nMitral men and the Aortic men, as well as the Great Arteries man and the\r\nPeripheral Capillary Bed man.\r\n\r\nThe Therapeutic man happened to be in Atlantic City at a convention and\r\nthe Rheumatologist was on vacation, so Wheatley was sent to Functional\r\nClinic instead. "Always have to rule out these things," the doctors\r\nagreed. 

"Wouldn\'t do much good to give you medicine if your trouble\r\nisn\'t organic, now, would it?" The Psychoneuroticist studied his sex\r\nlife, while the Psychosociologist examined his social milieu. Then they\r\nconferred for a long time.\r\n\r\nThree days later he was waiting in the hallway downstairs again. Heads\r\nmet in a huddle; words and phrases slipped out from time to time as the\r\ndiscussion grew heated.\r\n\r\n"--no doubt in my mind that it\'s a--"\r\n\r\n"But we can\'t ignore the endocrine implications, doctor--"\r\n\r\n"You\'re perfectly right there, of course. Bittenbender at the University\r\nmight be able to answer the question. No better Pituitary\r\nOsmoreceptorologist in the city--"\r\n\r\n"--a Tubular Function man should look at those kidneys first. He\'s\r\nfifty-five, you know.

"\r\n\r\n"--has anyone studied his filtration fraction?"\r\n\r\n"--might be a peripheral vascular spasticity factor--"\r\n\r\nAfter a while James Wheatley rose from the bench and slipped out the\r\ndoor, limping slightly as he went.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe room was small and dusky, with heavy Turkish drapes obscuring the\r\ndark hallway beyond. A suggestion of incense hung in the air.\r\n\r\nIn due course a gaunt, swarthy man in mustache and turban appeared\r\nthrough the curtains and bowed solemnly. "You come with a problem?" 

he\r\nasked, in a slight accent.\r\n\r\n"As a matter of fact, yes," James Wheatley said hesitantly. "You see,\r\nI\'ve been having a pain in my right little toe...."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


That had been the last wish of each as he had\r\npassed away, dying from sheer old age. True they had fought on as long\r\nas they could to save their kind from utter extinction but the comet\r\nthat had trailed its poisoning wake across space to leave behind it,\r\nupon Earth, a noxious, lethal gas vapor, had done its work too well."\r\n\r\nNo living soul breathed upon the Earth. No one lived here now, but Kiron\r\nand his kind.\r\n\r\n"And," so thought Kiron to himself, "he might as well be a great\r\nunthinking robot able to do only one thing instead of the mental giant\r\nhe was, so obsessed had he become with the task he had set himself to\r\ndo."\r\n\r\nYet, in spite of a great loneliness and a strong fear of a final\r\nfrustration, he worked on with the others of his people, hardly stopping\r\nfor anything except the very necessities needed to keep his big body\r\nworking in perfect coordination.\r\n\r\nTirelessly he worked, for The Masters had bred, if that is the word to\r\nuse, fatigue and the need for restoration out of his race long decades\r\nago.\r\n\r\nSometimes, though, he would stop his work when the great red dying sun\r\nbegan to fade into the west and his round eyes would grow wistful as he\r\nlooked out over the great city that stretched in towering minarets and\r\nlofty spires of purest crystal blue for miles on every side. A fairy\r\ncity of rarest hue and beauty. 

A city for the Gods and the Gods were\r\ndead. Kiron felt, at such times, the great loneliness that the last\r\nMaster must have known.\r\n\r\nThey had been kind, The Masters, and Kiron knew that his people, as they\r\nwent about their eternal tasks of keeping the great city in perfect\r\nshape for The Masters who no longer needed it, must miss them as he did.\r\n\r\nNever to hear their voices ringing, never to see them again gathered in\r\ngroups to witness some game or to play amid the silver fountains and\r\nflowery gardens of the wondrous city, made him infinitely saddened. It\r\nwould always be like this, unless....\r\n\r\nBut thinking, dreaming, reminiscing would not bring it all back for\r\nthere was only one answer to still the longing: work. The others worked\r\nand did not dream, but instead kept busy tending to the thousand and one\r\ntasks The Masters had set them to do--had left them doing when the last\r\nMaster perished. He too must remember the trust they had placed in his\r\nhands and fulfill it as best he could.\r\n\r\nFrom the time the great red eye of the sun opened itself in the East\r\nuntil it disappeared in the blue haze beyond the crysolite city, Kiron\r\nlabored with his fellows. Then, at the appointed hour, the musical\r\nsignals would peal forth their sweet, sad chimes, whispering goodnight\r\nto ears that would hear them no more and all operations would halt for\r\nthe night, just as it had done when The Masters were here to supervise\r\nit.\r\n\r\nThen when morning came he would start once more trying, testing,\r\nexperimenting with his chemicals and plastics, forever following\r\nlabyrinth of knowledge, seeking for the great triumph that would make\r\nthe work of the others of some real use.\r\n\r\nHis hands molded the materials carefully, lovingly to a pattern that was\r\nset in his mind as a thing to cherish. Day by day his experiments in\r\ntheir liquid baths took form under his careful modeling. He mixed his\r\nchemicals with the same loving touch, the same careful concentration and\r\npainstaking thoroughness, studying often his notes and analysis charts.\r\n\r\nEverything must be just so lest his experiment not turn out perfectly.\r\nHe never became exasperated at a failure or a defect that proved to be\r\nthe only reward for his faithful endeavors but worked patiently on\r\ntoward a goal that he knew would ultimately be his.\r\n\r\nThen one day, as the great red sun glowed like an immense red eye\r\noverhead, Kiron stepped back to admire his handiwork. In that instant\r\nthe entire wondrous city seemed to breathe a silent prayer as he stood\r\ntransfixed by the sight before him. 

Then it went on as usual, hurrying\r\nnoiselessly about its business. The surface cars, empty though they\r\nwere, fled swiftly about supported only by the rings of magnetic force\r\nthat held them to their designated paths. The gravoships raised from the\r\ntower-dromes to speed silently into the eye of the red sun that was\r\ndying.\r\n\r\n"No one now," Kiron thought to himself as he studied his handiwork. Then\r\nhe walked unhurriedly to the cabinet in the laboratory corner and took\r\nfrom it a pair of earphones resembling those of a long forgotten radio\r\nset. Just as unhurriedly, though his mind was filled with turmoil and\r\nhis being with excitement, he walked back and connected the earphones to\r\nthe box upon his bench. The phones dangled into the liquid bath before\r\nhim as he adjusted them to suit his requirements.\r\n\r\nSlowly he checked over every step of his experiments before he went\r\nfarther. Then, as he proved them for the last time, his hand went slowly\r\nto the small knife switch upon the box at his elbow. Next he threw into\r\nconnection the larger switch upon his laboratory wall bringing into his\r\nlaboratory the broadcast power of the crysolite city.\r\n\r\nThe laboratory generators hummed softly, drowning out the quiet hum of\r\nthe city outside. As they built up, sending tiny living electrical\r\nimpulses over the wires like minute currents that come from the brain,\r\nKiron sat breathless; his eyes intent.\r\n\r\nCloser to his work he bent, watching lovingly, fearful least all might\r\nnot be quite right. Then his eyes took on a brighter light as he began\r\nto see the reaction. He knew the messages that he had sent out were\r\nbeing received and coordinated into a unit that would stir and grow into\r\nintellect.\r\n\r\nSuddenly the machine flashed its little warning red light and\r\nautomatically snapped off. Kiron twisted quickly in his seat and threw\r\nhome the final switch. This, he knew, was the ultimate test. On the\r\nresults of the flood of energy impulses that he had set in motion rested\r\nthe fulfillment of his success--_or failure_.\r\n\r\nHe watched with slight misgivings. This had never been accomplished\r\nbefore. 

How could it possibly be a success now? Even The Masters had\r\nnever quite succeeded at this final test, how could he, only a servant?\r\nYet it must work for he had no desire in life but to make it work.\r\n\r\nThen, suddenly, he was on his feet, eyes wide. From the two long,\r\ncoffin-like liquid baths, there arose two perfect specimens of the _Homo\r\nsapiens_. Man and woman, they were, and they blinked their eyes in the\r\nlight of the noonday sun, raised themselves dripping from the baths of\r\ntheir creation and stepped to the floor before Kiron.\r\n\r\nThe man spoke, the woman remained silent.\r\n\r\n"I am Adam Two," he said. "Created, by you Kiron from a formula they\r\nleft, in their image. I was created to be a Master and she whom you also\r\nhave created is to be my wife. We shall mate and the race of Man shall\r\nbe reborn through us and others whom I shall help you create."\r\n\r\nThe Man halted at the last declaration he intoned and walked smilingly\r\ntoward the woman who stepped into his open arms returning his smile.\r\n\r\nKiron smiled too within his pumping heart. The words the Man had intoned\r\nhad been placed in his still pregnable mind by the tele-teach phones and\r\nrecord that the last Master had prepared before death had halted his\r\nexperiments. The actions of the Man toward the Woman, Kiron knew, was\r\ncaused by the natural constituents that went to form his chemical body\r\nand govern his humanness.\r\n\r\nHe, Kiron, had created a living man and woman. The Masters lived again\r\nbecause of him. 

They would sing and play and again people the\r\nmagnificent crysolite city because he loved them and had kept on until\r\nsuccess had been his. But then why not such a turnabout? Hadn\'t they,\r\nThe Masters, created him a superb, thinking _robot_?\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\nThis etext was produced from _Comet_ July 1941. How many saw the\r\nships?"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nA chorus answered him. "I see," Clayton mused. "You all agree on the\r\nbehavior. But the Gale Hoax--what can we call it but what is loosely\r\nknown as the continuing gullibility of human beings?\r\n\r\n"We trust that this demonstration you have just observed will help you\r\nto remember that while seeing may be believing, it\'s wise not to believe\r\nuntil it has been established just what you saw."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIn his private office, Dr.

Brief panic when several Terrestrials sighted\r\nships; all clear now. Full report, containing details on latest\r\nsuccessful persuasion of Earthlings that Martians or other aliens are\r\nimaginary, will follow."_\r\n\r\nFrom the speaker beneath the desk came sounds of gasps, heavy breathing,\r\nthen shuffling footsteps. After all\r\nthe risk we went to, to convince the public that there ain\'t no\r\nghosts--as the old saying goes--you arrange to have students hear you\r\ngoing into a \'report to the home planet\' act.
