"\r\n\r\nWalt Granger stomped over to the enclosure and swung a heavy boot\r\nagainst one of the two-by-fours that stood like a crooked row of\r\nsentries. "That\'s my worry," he grunted.\r\n\r\nHe had stumbled upon the whole business just two hours before, right in\r\nthe middle of his part of the geoglogic survey that was going on in the\r\nrock strewn hills and gullies known on the maps as the Millsport Range.\r\nHe had seen the ship the moment it left the ground, and a few yards\r\nfrom the burned circle of grass that was still smoldering from the\r\nrocket blast, there sat the fat little specimen of life from another\r\nworld. Granger had caught the thing by surprise and had a rope around\r\nits middle before it could scamper into the brush.\r\n\r\n"My comrades will return for me," warned the thing, its yellowish\r\neyes slowly and rhythmically protruding and withdrawing within their\r\nsockets. "They\'ll have no trouble finding you, and when they do...."\r\n\r\n"Shut up!" snapped Granger, pulling on his leather jacket. He turned\r\nto the cement fireplace and gave the embers a poke with a charred\r\nstick, looking around at the cage every few seconds as though he feared\r\nleaving his back turned for more than instant.\r\n\r\nHe looked at his watch. Eight o\'clock, and night was fast spreading a\r\nblanket of charcoal shadows over the hillsides. He\'d wait till morning\r\nto move this crazy beast to the next camp six miles away. A night trip\r\nmight entail chances he wasn\'t willing to take.\r\n\r\nAfter a couple of nervous fumbles with a match, he lit a cigarette\r\nand glanced uneasily out the one window in the rough cabin. What if\r\nthe alien, or whatever it was, wasn\'t kidding about the danger he was\r\nin? What if his buddies did decide to come back before morning with\r\nthe extermination of a human on their minds? Think of it, Granger, he\r\ntold himself laconically, you\'d be a hero! A nice, cold, dead one. 

And\r\nthey\'d never find the bunch who\'d have knocked him off. He\'d be one of\r\nthose "mysterious deaths" the papers played up.\r\n\r\n"Free me immediately!" screeched the angry captive, his head swaying\r\nlike a balloon on a stick. "You haven\'t much time left!"\r\n\r\n"You\'re a nasty tempered little imp, aren\'t you?" growled Granger as he\r\nstrode across the room and peeked curiously inside the crate.\r\n\r\n"I loathe you," growled the thing. "I have no intentions of deceiving\r\nyou. 

This whole situation is simply a matter of pure logic so far as\r\nyour plight is concerned."\r\n\r\n"You\'re forgetting," said Granger, his voice lacking a certain amount\r\nof its previous confidence, "that you\'re the one who\'s in a mess."\r\n\r\n"Only temporarily, you fool!" raved the creature, jumping frantically\r\nup and down. 

"Look!" he screamed, pointing a tiny hand toward the\r\nwindow over Granger\'s left shoulder.\r\n\r\nThe geologist gasped as he shot a quick glance in the direction of the\r\nthing\'s outstretched arm. A pale green light had turned the surrounding\r\nland and sky into an eerie dawn that extended its weird phosphorescence\r\ninto the cabin itself. And two hundred yards from the cabin, in a small\r\narea relatively clear of major obstructions, was the same ship he had\r\nseen a few hours before.\r\n\r\n"They\'re here!" shouted the alien. "Let me out!"\r\n\r\nGranger slammed shut the door and lifted a massive oak bar into iron\r\nbrackets on either side. Then he was at the window again. A hatch near\r\nthe bottom of the craft was open, but there was no sign of movement.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThen he saw one of them, an exact duplicate of his captive, running\r\nfrom bush to bush about fifty feet from the ship. A few steps behind\r\nhim was another. 

Two more nearby scrambled over an immense boulder and\r\nscurried into the brush. Another five were emerging, like a patrol of\r\nmidgets, from a ravine to the north of the cabin.\r\n\r\n"Be sensible, you idiot!" snarled the thing in the crate. 

"I\'m giving\r\nyou this final chance. Unlock this contrivance, and all will be well\r\nwith you. I\'ll speak on your behalf.

"\r\n\r\n"So you can lead your buddies right back here? Sure," said Granger,\r\n"that\'s all I\'d have to do to finish myself off in a real hurry."\r\n\r\n"Do as I say!" yelled the alien. "For your own sake!

"\r\n\r\n"Look," panted Granger, "I know I was crazy to fool with you in the\r\nfirst place, but now that you\'re here and they\'re outside, you\'re\r\nstaying, see?"\r\n\r\nHe reached under the lumpy pile of cotton that served as a mattress\r\nand pulled out his .30-30 rifle. Little Boy Blue and his pop gun, he\r\nthought. He grabbed a handful of cartridges from a box under the bed\r\nand began jamming them into the magazine.\r\n\r\n"That will be of no use, my friend," droned a hollow voice behind him.\r\n\r\nGranger spun himself around just as a pane of glass in the window flew\r\nto pieces under the impact of a short, shiny gun barrel. A perfect\r\nreproduction of the face of the creature in the cage centered itself\r\nin the jagged frame of the broken window and gave him the shadow of a\r\nsmile that was closer to a victorious leer.\r\n\r\n"Put down your weapon," the newcomer ordered coldly.\r\n\r\nGet that rifle up fast, Granger commanded himself.\r\n\r\n"I repeat," said the face at the window. "Lower your weapon."\r\n\r\nThey\'ll let you have it anyway, Granger thought grimly. He slowly\r\ncurled his finger around the trigger and started to move when he was\r\njarred off his feet by a roaring blast that ripped the door from its\r\nhinges and sent it crashing against the rear wall of the cabin.\r\n\r\nOutside the ruined entrance stood a group of aliens all armed.\r\nFearfully, he looked to the window, but their leader was gone. In a\r\nsecond he appeared at the door, moved inside the cabin, and Granger\r\nautomatically stepped back, his hazy mind calculating roughly the few\r\nfeet of escape route remaining to him. In a moment he was there, his\r\nback flattened against the cabin wall.\r\n\r\nThe short creature kept coming on, its murky orbs fixed on Granger\'s\r\nwhite, drawn countenance. Then it stopped its advance.\r\n\r\n"So you have one of our people," it said in a voice that twanged like\r\npiano wire.\r\n\r\nGranger tried once in vain for his voice, then gave up. He stared over\r\nthe head of his foe at the silent assembly outside the cabin, then at\r\nthe thing in the packing crate. It was sitting there, quiet, immobile,\r\nbut intently watching the scene between the earthman and his visitor.\r\n\r\n"You are holding one of us captive," the commander remarked. "This is\r\na most unfortunate situation, indeed." The small figure stepped aside\r\nquickly and waved an arm.\r\n\r\nGranger, perspiration trickling down his face, watched a score of\r\nglistening weapons raised and pointed inside the cabin. For a second\r\nhe looked directly at the menacing horde. Then his eyes saw nothing. A\r\nblazing flash of white light burst forth from the doorway, and it was\r\nall over.\r\n\r\nGranger forced open his aching eyes and squinted in the direction of\r\nthe fiery blast, but the doorway was empty. The commander was still\r\nthere, though, walking slowly to the door.\r\n\r\nWhy am I alive? Granger asked himself incredulously. 

Or am I dead? He\r\nbumped his fist against his forehead once or twice and gave his head\r\na vigorous shake. Suddenly, he turned his gaze to the cage. But he saw\r\nnothing that resembled the rebuilt packing crate; only a mound of ashes\r\nand twisted spikes. In the center of the heap, like a fat, dwarfish\r\nking astride his fallen kingdom, was the charred, blackened shell of\r\nthe grotesque creature that had once occupied the wooden cell.\r\n\r\nThen he moved cautiously toward the door and stared, speechless, at the\r\nleader of the expedition.\r\n\r\n"We shall depart now," said the being. "Thank you for helping us."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nNot much later, across the silent reaches of space, a communications\r\noperator on another planet looked up from his receiving equipment and\r\nhanded his superior a message just transmitted from a ship leaving the\r\nplanet Earth: RETURN MISSION SUCCESSFUL. DESERTER LOCATED AND EXECUTED.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


Prosecutor."\r\n\r\n"Roll in the Very Complicated Monstrous Proximilator machine,"\r\ncommanded the prosecutor. Two burly laborers, panting, rolled the\r\nmachine on its creaky casters across the court room floor to Fannie\'s\r\nhead. The machine was six feet tall, three feet wide, and twelve inches\r\ndeep; on its face were forty-three meters and an on/off switch.\r\n\r\nThe laborers plugged the machine\'s line cord into an outlet and got out\r\nof the way.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe prosecutor flipped the switch from off to on. Then he folded his\r\narms and waited until all the forty-three meters ceased their dancing\r\nand went back to zero. That done, he turned to the jury.\r\n\r\n"In this machine rests the proof of the crime charged against the\r\ndefendant," he said dramatically, patting the smooth gray side of the\r\nmachine. "This machine will tell you _all_ you need to know about the\r\nmurder. Oh, to be sure, I shall show you the corpus delicti presently;\r\nbut _why_ and _how_ this crime was committed shall be revealed only by\r\nthis machine\'s stimulation of the deceased\'s brain. _She will herself\r\nrelate who her killer was!_"\r\n\r\nThere was a shocked gasp from the jurors and the spectators in the\r\ncourt room when the prosecutor pulled back the sheet from the body,\r\nuncovering her head and chest. "The jury will note that the government\r\nhas removed her skull down to her eyebrows so that we could contact her\r\nbrain\'s recordings with the machine\'s probe. The jury will also note\r\nthe four bullet holes in the deceased\'s chest, which we intend to prove\r\nwere put there by John Bork."\r\n\r\n"I missed twice," said John Bork, nodding.\r\n\r\n"Silence!" shouted the suddenly enraged judge. "This court depends\r\nentirely on the Very Complicated Monstrous Proximilator machine for\r\nits evidence." He turned to the jury, still seething. "The jury will\r\ncompletely disregard the defendant\'s utterly uncalled-for admission.\r\nProceed, Mr. Prosecutor."\r\n\r\nThe prosecutor fastened the ground cable of the machine to Fannie\'s big\r\ntoe by means of an immense alligator clamp. Then taking the bulbous\r\nradio-frequency probe in his hand he said portentously, "Now we shall\r\nsearch for the memory-recording of Fannie Bork\'s moment of death!"\r\n\r\nHe touched her brain lightly with the probe.\r\n\r\nThose seeing it for the first time were chilled by the dead body\'s\r\nsudden animation.\r\n\r\n"Oh, Winston!" cooed dead Fannie Bork, her aims raising from the cot to\r\nembrace an invisible something. She kissed. 

"You tastes good!"\r\n\r\nThe prosecutor moved the probe.\r\n\r\n"George?" called Fannie, her slim arms searching at the side of her\r\ncot. "I didn\'t hear you leave, George." She relaxed. 

"Oh, I hope he\r\nfound his shoes."\r\n\r\n"He didn\'t though," contributed John Bork.\r\n\r\nThe prosecutor moved the probe, hurrying on by emotion-stirred quavers:\r\nAngelo, Moose, Maudie, Deacon and Quasimodo.\r\n\r\n"Speed, darlin\', what\'s your _hurry_?" asked Fannie in her plaintive,\r\nmetallic voice as she held out her hands beseechingly.\r\n\r\n"I never got to know him very well," interjected John Bork. "His visits\r\nwere all so short."\r\n\r\nThe prosecutor moved his probe.\r\n\r\n"Bork! Bork!"\r\n\r\n"Ah," said the prosecutor. "Now we are getting down to cases. I shall\r\ntry that spot again."\r\n\r\n"Bork! Bork!"\r\n\r\n"She\'s not calling for me," advised Bork. "She just had a cold that\r\nweek."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe prosecutor moved his probe. At each touch, the body broke into\r\nquaking action: Ferdinand, Frenchy, Yacob; Peyton, Rebel, Young foo\r\nYum; and John.\r\n\r\n"Ah!" said the prosecutor. "Here we are now."\r\n\r\n"John!" whispered Fannie. "John, John, John! Oh, Johnny Johnson, my\r\nlove! 

_Stay_ here forever!"\r\n\r\n"Wife\'s other John," said John Bork succinctly.\r\n\r\nThe prosecutor moved his probe: Sinclair, Henrik, Sitting Duck, Oscar,\r\nKenny, and Aqueduct.\r\n\r\n"That Aqueduct is Sitting Duck\'s educated brother," confided John Bork.\r\n"Before he went to Princeton his name was Wet Duck."\r\n\r\nThe prosecutor moved his probe: Pease, Reese and Meese, Acuff, Eyolf\r\nand Beowulf; Bork! Bork!\r\n\r\n"That cough again?" muttered the prosecutor, ready to move on.\r\n\r\n"No, she\'s calling for me that time," corrected Bork.\r\n\r\n"How can you tell?"\r\n\r\n"It has more of a snarl in it than her cough has."\r\n\r\nThe prosecutor tried the spot once more.\r\n\r\n"Bork! Bork! Why are you pointing that at me, Bork? What are you going\r\nto _do_, Bork?" She held out her hands to ward him off. "Oh! 

Oh! 

Oh!\r\nOh!" Then she dropped her hands.\r\n\r\n"I missed twice," John said, nodding.\r\n\r\n"The defendant will keep his lousy confessions to himself!" shrieked\r\nthe judge. "I will not have the importance of our Very Complicated\r\nMonstrous Proximilator machine vitiated by these unwanted confessions!"\r\n\r\nBork shrugged. 

"I just wanted to clear up a couple of details, your\r\nhonor. 

I just like to be tidy."\r\n\r\n"We don\'t _need_ your help," responded the judge crushingly. "The Very\r\nComplicated Monstrous Proximilator machine tells us _all_ we want to\r\nknow." He turned to the prosecutor. 

"You may proceed."\r\n\r\n"The state rests."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBork\'s lawyer advised the court that no defense would be presented.\r\nThe prosecutor exhorted the jury that its duty was plain. The judge\r\ngave final instructions, and the jury filed out. It returned in four\r\nminutes.\r\n\r\n"Gentlemen of the jury, have you reached a verdict in such a\r\ngratifyingly short space of time?" the judge asked, beaming.\r\n\r\nThe foreman arose. "We have, your honor."\r\n\r\n"Just for the record, what is your verdict?" twinkled the judge.\r\n\r\n"Not guilty, your honor."\r\n\r\nThe prosecutor jumped up. "Why, that can\'t be!" 

he shouted. "It\'s a\r\n_prima facie_ case, unrefuted and therefore patent. What else do you\r\n_need_?"\r\n\r\n"Yeah!" agreed the judge, outraged.\r\n\r\n"We need some plain, old-fashioned evidence of a crime," answered the\r\njuryman, unperturbed.\r\n\r\n"Old-fashioned?" The fuming prosecutor rejected the heresy, pushing\r\nit away from him with both hands. "This is all unscientific\r\nnow," he warned. "The Very Complicated Monstrous Proximilator\r\nmachine--especially the new model with the forty-three meters which\r\nreplaces the old thirty-nine meter machine--is the _ne plus ultra_ of\r\njustice!"\r\n\r\n"Oh, no, it isn\'t," dissented the foreman. "Did your evidence place\r\nthe deadly weapon in the defendant\'s hand? Did your evidence even tend\r\nto show the holes in the woman\'s chest were _made_ by a gun? She said\r\nnothing about a weapon, if you will recall. She merely said, \'Why are\r\nyou pointing that at me, Bork? What are you going to do, Bork?\'"\r\n\r\n"But he had plenty of motive," pleaded the prosecutor.\r\n\r\n"Oh, we\'ll go along with _that_," assented the foreman.\r\n\r\n"And the defendant admitted it!" pursued the prosecutor triumphantly.\r\n\r\nThe foreman shook his head. "Admissions don\'t count. The judge said so\r\nhimself."\r\n\r\n"So even though you know he\'s guilty," the prosecutor said hollowly,\r\n"you\'re going to let him go?"\r\n\r\n"That\'s right," agreed the foreman happily, and cleared his throat.\r\n"We, the jury," he pronounced, "find this fellow innocent of what he\r\ndid!"\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


When a man of the future wants solitude he picks a slab of\r\n    rock floating in space four light years east of Andromeda. Here is a\r\n    gentle little story about a man who sought the solitude of such a\r\n    location. And who did he take along for company? None other than\r\n    Charles the Robot._\r\n\r\n\r\nMark Rogers was a prospector, and he went to the asteroid belt looking\r\nfor radioactives and rare metals. He searched for years, never finding\r\nmuch, hopping from fragment to fragment. After a time he settled on a\r\nslab of rock half a mile thick.\r\n\r\nRogers had been born old, and he didn\'t age much past a point. His face\r\nwas white with the pallor of space, and his hands shook a little. He\r\ncalled his slab of rock Martha, after no girl he had ever known.\r\n\r\nHe made a little strike, enough to equip Martha with an air pump and a\r\nshack, a few tons of dirt and some water tanks, and a robot. Then he\r\nsettled back and watched the stars.\r\n\r\nThe robot he bought was a standard-model all-around worker, with\r\nbuilt-in memory and a thirty-word vocabulary. Mark added to that, bit\r\nby bit. He was something of a tinkerer, and he enjoyed adapting his\r\nenvironment to himself.\r\n\r\nAt first, all the robot could say was "Yes, sir," and "No, sir." He\r\ncould state simple problems: "The air pump is laboring, sir." "The corn\r\nis budding, sir." He could perform a satisfactory salutation: "Good\r\nmorning, sir."\r\n\r\nMark changed that. He eliminated the "sirs" from the robot\'s vocabulary;\r\nequality was the rule on Mark\'s hunk of rock. Then he dubbed the robot\r\nCharles, after a father he had never known.\r\n\r\nAs the years passed, the air pump began to labor a little as it\r\nconverted the oxygen in the planetoid\'s rock into a breathable\r\natmosphere. The air seeped into space, and the pump worked a little\r\nharder, supplying more.\r\n\r\nThe crops continued to grow on the tamed black dirt of the planetoid.\r\nLooking up, Mark could see the sheer blackness of the river of space,\r\nthe floating points of the stars. Around him, under him, overhead,\r\nmasses of rock drifted, and sometimes the starlight glinted from their\r\nblack sides. Occasionally, Mark caught a glimpse of Mars or Jupiter.\r\nOnce he thought he saw Earth.\r\n\r\nMark began to tape new responses into Charles. He added simple responses\r\nto cue words. When he said, "How does it look?" Charles would answer,\r\n"Oh, pretty good, I guess."\r\n\r\nAt first the answers were what Mark had been answering himself, in the\r\nlong dialogue held over the years. But, slowly, he began to build a new\r\npersonality into Charles.\r\n\r\nMark had always been suspicious and scornful of women. But for some\r\nreason he didn\'t tape the same suspicion into Charles. Charles\' outlook\r\nwas quite different.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"What do you think of girls?" Mark would ask, sitting on a packing case\r\noutside the shack, after the chores were done.\r\n\r\n"Oh, I don\'t know. 

You have to find the right one." The robot would\r\nreply dutifully, repeating what had been put on its tape.\r\n\r\n"I never saw a good one yet," Mark would say.\r\n\r\n"Well, that\'s not fair. Perhaps you didn\'t look long enough. 

There\'s a\r\ngirl in the world for every man."\r\n\r\n"You\'re a romantic!" 

Mark would say scornfully. The robot would pause--a\r\nbuilt-in pause--and chuckle a carefully constructed chuckle.\r\n\r\n"I dreamed of a girl named Martha once," Charles would say. "Maybe if I\r\nwould have looked, I would have found her.

"\r\n\r\nAnd then it would be bedtime. Or perhaps Mark would want more\r\nconversation. "What do you think of girls?" he would ask again, and\r\nthe discussion would follow its same course.\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\nCharles grew old. His limbs lost their flexibility, and some of his\r\nwiring started to corrode. Mark would spend hours keeping the robot in\r\nrepair.\r\n\r\n"You\'re getting rusty," he would cackle.\r\n\r\n"You\'re not so young yourself," Charles would reply. He had an answer\r\nfor almost everything. Nothing involved, but an answer.\r\n\r\nIt was always night on Martha, but Mark broke up his time into mornings,\r\nafternoons and evenings. Their life followed a simple routine.\r\nBreakfast, from vegetables and Mark\'s canned store. Then the robot would\r\nwork in the fields, and the plants grew used to his touch. Mark would\r\nrepair the pump, check the water supply, and straighten up the\r\nimmaculate shack. Lunch, and the robot\'s chores were usually finished.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe two would sit on the packing case and watch the stars. They would\r\ntalk until supper, and sometimes late into the endless night.\r\n\r\nIn time, Mark built more complicated conversations into Charles. He\r\ncouldn\'t give the robot free choice, of course, but he managed a pretty\r\nclose approximation of it. Slowly, Charles\' personality emerged. But it\r\nwas strikingly different from Mark\'s.\r\n\r\nWhere Mark was querulous, Charles was calm. Mark was sardonic, Charles\r\nwas naive. Mark was a cynic, Charles was an idealist. Mark was often\r\nsad; Charles was forever content.\r\n\r\nAnd in time, Mark forgot he had built the answers into Charles. He\r\naccepted the robot as a friend, of about his own age. A friend of long\r\nyears\' standing.\r\n\r\n"The thing I don\'t understand," Mark would say, "is why a man like you\r\nwants to live here. I mean, it\'s all right for me. 

No one cares about\r\nme, and I never gave much of a damn about anyone. 

But why you?"\r\n\r\n"Here I have a whole world," Charles would reply, "where on Earth I had\r\nto share with billions. I have the stars, bigger and brighter than on\r\nEarth. I have all space around me, close, like still waters. And I have\r\nyou, Mark."\r\n\r\n"Now, don\'t go getting sentimental on me--"\r\n\r\n"I\'m not. Friendship counts. Love was lost long ago, Mark. The love of a\r\ngirl named Martha, whom neither of us ever met. And that\'s a pity. 

But\r\nfriendship remains, and the eternal night."\r\n\r\n"You\'re a bloody poet," Mark would say, half admiringly. "A poor poet."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nTime passed unnoticed by the stars, and the air pump hissed and clanked\r\nand leaked. Mark was fixing it constantly, but the air of Martha became\r\nincreasingly rare. Although Charles labored in the fields, the crops,\r\ndeprived of sufficient air, died.\r\n\r\nMark was tired now, and barely able to crawl around, even without the\r\ngrip of gravity. He stayed in his bunk most of the time. Charles fed him\r\nas best he could, moving on rusty, creaking limbs.\r\n\r\n"What do you think of girls?"\r\n\r\n"I never saw a good one yet."\r\n\r\n"Well, that\'s not fair."\r\n\r\nMark was too tired to see the end coming, and Charles wasn\'t interested.\r\nBut the end was on its way. The air pump threatened to give out\r\nmomentarily. There hadn\'t been any food for days.\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\n"But why you?" Gasping in the escaping air. Strangling.\r\n\r\n"Here I have a whole world--"\r\n\r\n"Don\'t get sentimental--"\r\n\r\n"And the love of a girl named Martha."\r\n\r\nFrom his bunk Mark saw the stars for the last time. Big, bigger than\r\never, endlessly floating in the still waters of space.\r\n\r\n"The stars ..." Mark said.\r\n\r\n"Yes?"\r\n\r\n"The sun?"\r\n\r\n"--shall shine as now."\r\n\r\n"A bloody poet."\r\n\r\n"A poor poet."\r\n\r\n"And girls?"\r\n\r\n"I dreamed of a girl named Martha once. Maybe if--"\r\n\r\n"What do you think of girls? And stars? 

And Earth?" And it was bedtime,\r\nthis time forever.\r\n\r\nCharles stood beside the body of his friend. He felt for a pulse once,\r\nand allowed the withered hand to fall. 

He walked to a corner of the\r\nshack and turned off the tired air pump.\r\n\r\nThe tape that Mark had prepared had a few cracked inches left to run. "I\r\nhope he finds his Martha," the robot croaked, and then the tape broke.\r\n\r\nHis rusted limbs would not bend, and he stood frozen, staring back at\r\nthe naked stars. Then he bowed his head.\r\n\r\n"The Lord is my shepherd," Charles said. "I shall not want. He maketh me\r\nto lie down in green pastures; he leadeth me ..."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Amazing Stories_ Oct.-Nov. 1953.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and\r\n    typographical errors have been corrected without note.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


]\r\n\r\n\r\n[Illustration: _His thin scream keened away in the distance._]\r\n\r\nHe was too late to stop them. Old Kaliz dropped his upraised arm, and\r\nat his signal the four naked under-priests flung the bound body of Gor\r\nZan over the precipice. Ortho heard his friend\'s thin scream keening\r\naway until it dwindled in the distance and the muted roar of the falls\r\nboiling at the cliff\'s bottom floated upward and drowned it.\r\n\r\nHe turned to run, but the horror of what he had seen numbed his limbs\r\nto nightmare slowness. Kaliz and the four under-priests caught him\r\nbefore he had taken a dozen steps.\r\n\r\n"You are still a neophyte," old Kaliz said gently. "You have only begun\r\nto learn, and so you cannot understand why Gor Zan had to die. 

The\r\nanswer lies there." He pointed a wrinkled hand to the Valley below.\r\n\r\nOver the heads of the four priests who squatted on the ledge outside\r\nthe priest-cave Ortho looked down into the Valley, the lush green miles\r\nof its even floor clothed in a faint rosy haze of vapor. The sun sat\r\nred upon the western wall; above the eastern rim the rising moon hung\r\nwarm and turquoise-blue, its great encircling ring pulsing like an aura\r\nof living light. Under its glow the Valley-haze turned violet and then\r\nblue, and on the heels of its rising came the faint elfin voices of the\r\nPeople, leaving their caves to play in the meadow.\r\n\r\nOrtho sat back upon his polished sitting-stone and met the\r\nhigh-priest\'s eyes defiantly.\r\n\r\n"There is no reason down there," he said sullenly. "It is only the\r\nPeople, coming out to play under the moon. You killed Gor Zan because\r\nhe was wiser than you, because he talked to the People and made clear\r\nto them things they did not understand before. You were jealous of him\r\nand you killed him lest he make your own wisdom seem small in the eyes\r\nof the People."\r\n\r\nKaliz sighed and seated himself stiffly on his own sitting-stone.\r\n\r\n"The young do not learn easily," he said. "But believe this,\r\nOrtho--your friend Gor Zan was a snare to the People and a deadly\r\nmenace to their way of life. We took him from them reluctantly and only\r\nas a last resort, before he could start the People again on the bloody\r\npath of ambition, progress and the Machine."\r\n\r\nOrtho cupped his still beardless chin in his hands and stared\r\ndisconsolately down into the blue-hazed Valley where the People played.\r\n\r\n"Empty talk," he said contemptuously. "Priest-talk--ambition, progress,\r\nthe Machine! I do not know the words. There is nothing but the Valley\r\nand the People, who have always been and who will always be. Your words\r\nhave no meaning.

"\r\n\r\n"I have taught these others," Kaliz murmured. The blue moonlight pulsed\r\nwarm across his wrinkled face, made his hooded eyes pools of reflected\r\nlight. 

"I can teach you, too. You would know these things soon, because\r\nyou are almost ready to read the Books; but I shall tell you now, that\r\nyou may not be rebellious for lack of understanding."\r\n\r\nHe pointed again, this time at the moon with its restless blue halo.\r\n\r\n"It was not always so," he said. His voice softened as his memory\r\ndrifted back across the ages. 

"Once it was yellow, pitted and airless\r\nand dead, shining only with light reflected from the sun. Men changed\r\nthat, as they changed the face of their world, by the power of their\r\nscience, which in the end defeated the aims they strove for and\r\ndestroyed them almost utterly. The handful that remained of them found\r\nhaven in the Valley and began a new civilization, which is today the\r\nPeople. This time, being wiser, they outlawed the practice of science."\r\n\r\nUnder Kaliz\' calm assurance Ortho\'s resentment dwindled, and his\r\nloathing of the high-priest gave way to bewilderment.\r\n\r\n"Science?" he repeated. 

"It is another strange word. 

I do not\r\nunderstand."\r\n\r\n"In another age Gor Zan would have been a scientist," Kaliz said. "I\r\nhave seen them with my own eyes in the ancient days, puttering in\r\ntomblike shops that shut other men away from them, denying all pleasure\r\nwhile they spent their lives improving what other scientists had\r\nalready discovered. They were never satisfied, and in the end it was\r\ntheir insatiable lust for perfection that killed them, that set the\r\nvery moon aflame and flung mankind back into the savagery from which it\r\nhad risen.\r\n\r\n"For there was a time," he went on sombrely, shifting his sitting-stone\r\nto follow Ortho\'s troubled gaze down into the blue depths of the\r\nValley, "long before my own, when men lived as simply as we, but\r\nwithout our peace and security. The world then was a savage place,\r\nfull of frightful beasts which killed men for food because they were\r\nno more than weaker animals. Men, being weak and soft, sought communal\r\nsafety in numbers and gained an advantage over the beasts because they\r\ndeveloped intelligence and logic by exchanging ideas and experiences.\r\n\r\n"They learned to use this intelligence to develop weapons which\r\neventually wiped out the dangerous beasts and made the world safe;\r\nbut they were not content with safety, and fought savagely among\r\nthemselves. Nations numbering millions of men came into being and\r\nwarred with each other, and with each war their ingenuity grew and the\r\ndeadliness of their weapons kept pace with their ingenuity."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nKaliz was quiet for a moment, listening to the faint laughter of the\r\nPeople that drifted up faintly from the Valley floor.\r\n\r\n"Men were not happy then as they are now," he said. "I remember them,\r\nOrtho, because I was one of them, and by a miracle escaped the great\r\nholocaust that destroyed mankind. Men had developed a weapon whose\r\ndestructiveness was beyond the power of the mind to conceive, and it\r\nescaped control; nation after nation died in a breath, whole continents\r\nvanished under the impact of robot missiles whose explosions destroyed\r\nmatter itself. One of these, perhaps by intent, struck the moon, and\r\nits reaction under the moon\'s lighter gravity set up a conflagration\r\nwhich never went out.\r\n\r\n"Those of us who survived the holocaust were greatly changed by the\r\nradiations of the explosions, and most of us soon died. I alone, by\r\nchance, was rendered deathless. More ages have passed than I can\r\nnumber, but I live on, perhaps eternally, to see that the People do not\r\nerr and fall again into the trap which science with its Machines would\r\nplace in their way.\r\n\r\n"Gor Zan was a throwback to my own savage day, a natural scientist who\r\nbelieved nothing he was told and reasoned with a deadly logic that\r\nnothing created by nature can be perfect, but must be improved by the\r\nthought and effort of man. Today we slew him, reluctantly, because he\r\nhad taken the final irrevocable step that branded him a heretic and an\r\noutlaw.\r\n\r\n"Gor Zan made a Machine."\r\n\r\nHe stretched out a hand to Ortho and they rose together, the abashed\r\neyes of the neophyte not meeting those of the high-priest.\r\n\r\n"Come," Kaliz said, "and behold the thing with your own eyes. I have\r\nkept it intact to convince you beyond doubt of Gor Zan\'s heresy."\r\n\r\nThey went back into the priest-cave, past the long tiers of Books,\r\ncrumbling and yellow with age, to stand in awed silence over the thing\r\nGor Zan had made. Ortho stared, shivering, feeling the cold aura of\r\nunsentient, alien power that radiated from the Machine.\r\n\r\nIt was a crude affair, built upon two wooden shafts that slanted upward\r\nto end in a pair of rough handles. Across them were lashed shorter\r\nsticks that supported a woven basket. At the forward end was a thin\r\ndisc made of wooden segments, a little wooden axle running through the\r\ncenter and holding the disc upright between the joined ends of the\r\nshafts.\r\n\r\n"Gor Zan tired of making two trips to his cave with firewood and\r\nfruit," old Kaliz said sombrely, "so he created a Machine which would\r\ncarry a greater load than his shoulders would bear. In my own age the\r\nthing was called a Wheelbarrow, but the name of it is not important now\r\nbecause there will never be another.\r\n\r\n"We will destroy it now, and with its destruction we will forget what\r\nGor Zan had rediscovered, which is the first principle of the Machine\r\nthat enslaved and then destroyed mankind--the Wheel."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


From memory to memory\r\nher dream-fogged mind drifted, and to the yet-to-be. It was good to\r\nremember, and to imagine, and to see and feel and hear....\r\n\r\nShe smiled. She was Ruth Halsey, fourteen, brunette, and pretty. Earl,\r\nand Harry, and Buhl had told her she was pretty. Especially Buhl. Buhl\r\nwas her favorite date now.\r\n\r\nThe room closed around her with its familiar colors and furnishings.\r\nSometimes she would dream that she was elsewhere, unfamiliar, ugly\r\nplaces, but then she would awaken to the four long windows with their\r\ncoarse beige drapes of monk\'s cloth and the fantasies were forever\r\ndispelled.\r\n\r\nHer eyes loved the two paintings, the dark curls of the pink-and-white\r\ndoll sitting prissily atop the dresser, and the full-length mirror on\r\nthe open closet door.\r\n\r\nThe pictured design of the wallpaper, its background merging with the\r\npastel blue of the slanted ceiling.... Almost as they had blended\r\ntogether that first day when she was twelve. Yet not the same, she\r\ncorrected her thoughts, frowning. 

Sometimes, as today, the design seemed\r\nfaded and changed. The gay little bridges and the flowered, impossibly\r\nblue trees seemed to change and threaten to vanish.\r\n\r\nShe laughed over at the demurely sitting doll. Essie had been her\r\nfavorite doll when she was younger. Of course now that she was fourteen\r\nshe did not play with dolls any more. But it was permissible that she\r\nkeep her old friend neatly dressed and ever at hand as a confidant. 

She\r\nsmiled at the thought. Essie never tattled.\r\n\r\n"It must be from that polio," she told Essie, knowing all the time that\r\nshe was almost well now and needed plenty of rest and careful doses of\r\nexercise. "It makes my eyes--funny."\r\n\r\nEssie smiled back glassily and Ruth laughed. It was good to awaken and\r\nsee the thick black arms of the maple tree outside the windows. It was\r\ngood to have the cool green leaves waving at her, and see the filtered\r\ndapplings of sunshine cross and recross them.\r\n\r\nShe loved that old tree. She had played among its long horizontal\r\nbranches from childhood. Her brother, Alex, who had been killed in the\r\nNormandy Landing during World War Three, had loved the tree too. He had\r\nbuilt the railed, shingled-roofed little nest high up in the tree\'s\r\ncrotched heart where Ruth kept some of her extra-special notes and\r\njewelry and a book of poems.\r\n\r\nOne of the two paintings on the bedroom walls was of the old tree. The\r\ntree dominated the old story-and-a-half white house with the green\r\nshutters that was the Halseys\' home. Her home. Alex had painted that\r\npicture as well as the other showing the graceful loop of the river and\r\nthe roofs of the village of Thayer in the distance. Ruth had been with\r\nhim as he painted that second picture from the jutting rock ledge five\r\nhundred feet above the river.\r\n\r\n"I was just ten then, Essie," she chirped gaily. "I remember how afraid\r\nI was of the height and how Alex scolded."\r\n\r\nBut Alex was dead now and all she had to remember of him was the\r\npaintings and the photographs that Mother kept in a battered brown\r\nleather folder. For a moment the bright sunlight in her beloved maple\r\ntree\'s leaves seemed to dim and the room wavered about her. 

She wondered\r\nabout that. She must tell her father or her mother.\r\n\r\nPerhaps the polio, light touch of it or not, had hurt her eyesight.\r\nGlasses! She shuddered at the thought.\r\n\r\nThe room shimmered and blurred--and suddenly broke apart to reform into\r\nsomething.... She squinched her eyes shut to the hideous vision. And\r\nthen opened them the merest slit.\r\n\r\nNothing had changed....\r\n\r\n"MOTHER!" she cried. "Daddy!" she cried. "What has happened?"\r\n\r\nShe heard the door to--to this hideous travesty of a room opening. Her\r\neyes darted around the shrunken metal-walled shell, even the ceiling\r\ncurved overhead, and she saw two grotesque daubs taped to the walls that\r\nparodied the paintings of her dead brother Alex. The coloring was ugly\r\nand the proportions out of line. And it was not canvas but curling\r\nsheets of paper taped and painted to resemble frames!\r\n\r\nA big man, sandy-haired and with vertical wrinkles deep between piercing\r\nblue eyes, came into the room. She shrank into the bed, seeing that the\r\nsheet she tugged taut across her breast was ragged and blue.\r\n\r\n"Ruth," he said, a slow smile making his face almost handsome, "you\'re\r\nbetter. You haven\'t spoken in weeks."\r\n\r\nRuth wanted to giggle. 

As though they could keep her quiet. Daddy was\r\nalways shushing her.... But who was this big man in his dusty drab\r\ncoveralls and dropped dust mask dangling upon his chest?\r\n\r\n"Don\'t you know me, Dear? It\'s Buhl, your husband."\r\n\r\nBuhl was fifteen and only a couple of inches taller than Ruth. Of course\r\nhe had sandy hair like this man. But this man was old enough to be\r\nBuhl\'s father. This was crazy--like one of the dreams that always made\r\nher unhappy.\r\n\r\nSo? 

So it was a dream. She felt warmth and release. Why not see what\r\nthis dream had to offer that might be amusing to remember and tell Buhl\r\nsometime soon. Wouldn\'t he laugh when he heard she had dreamed about\r\nhim? And been married to him.\r\n\r\nShe saw the strip of shiny metal that masqueraded as her mirror, and\r\nwhere her four long windows, with their thick, loose-woven drapes, had\r\nbeen there were only four taped strips of paper with crude pictures of\r\ndraped windows daubed on them. There were even green dabs of paint and\r\nblack splashes to stimulate her beloved maple tree.\r\n\r\n"Ruth! Do you feel better now? 

Please don\'t smile at me like that. I\r\nknow you loved the baby, but this Martian atmosphere is tough even for\r\nmen. It wasn\'t your fault."\r\n\r\n"Go ahead and talk," Ruth laughed gaily. "This is just another bad dream\r\nand I know it. I\'ll wake up in a little while and be back in my cool old\r\nroom."\r\n\r\n"Blast your room and your dreams!"\r\n\r\nThe man went across the room in a swift rush and tore down one of the\r\nfalse windows, the painted strip of paper. And beyond, through a dusty\r\noval glass window, Ruth could see a reddish brown wasteland, where dust\r\nclouds spun and shifted slowly, and a dusty huddle of what looked like\r\nquonset huts or storage sheds of metal.\r\n\r\n"That is reality, Ruth. You must face it. This pretense, this sleazy\r\nimitation of your old room is wrong. You\'re strong enough, and I love\r\nyou--you can accept truth."\r\n\r\nHis face changed, all expression sponged from it in an instant as he\r\nlooked into her eyes, and then it seemed to dissolve into something ugly\r\nand yet childish. She saw tears burst through and furrow the dust on his\r\ncheeks.\r\n\r\n"Dear Lord," he cried, almost reverently, "must this go on forever? 

Will\r\nshe ever come back to me?"\r\n\r\nHis voice choked off and he stumbled across the room and out the door.\r\nShe heard it shut behind him, and she was hunting for Essie, already\r\nhaving forgotten the ill-mannered intruder.\r\n\r\nThere was no Essie, only a mannikin of cloth-stuffed white nylon and\r\nlipstick, with black nylon for hair.\r\n\r\nAnd then the room shimmered and broke apart and reformed and she was\r\nback in her bed with the sun on the slowly dancing green leaves outside\r\nthe four long windows. Essie was smiling down at her from the dresser,\r\nand the paintings were as always, soft colors and perfectly drafted.\r\n\r\nHad she thought there were four windows? How silly of her. 

The second\r\nfrom the right was a small oval of glass, or rather, a glass-covered\r\npicture of desert scene. Odd that she had forgotten about that picture.\r\nOh well, what did it matter.\r\n\r\nIn a few days she would be well enough again to climb out on the giant\r\nlimbs and into the tree nest that her brother, Alex, had built. And the\r\nboys would come to see her and take her to the drugstore for sodas and\r\nsundaes.\r\n\r\nYes, she was sure now. She _did_ like Buhl Austin best....\r\n\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Fantastic Universe_ December 1957.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and\r\n    typographical errors have been corrected without note.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


And I liked to drink....\r\n\r\n"Problem of killing grandparents before parents were born," I said,\r\npouring myself another. "Question if you can be born after that.\r\nQuestion if you can\'t be born, how did you do it? Not really possible,\r\nPangborn. 

You can\'t test it." I made a mental note to bring up the\r\nlow quality of Faculty Club whiskey at the next business meeting. It\r\nhad everything else a good faculty club should have: brown leather\r\narmchairs, old magazines, fresh newspapers, a dusty chess board, cut\r\nglass decanters ... it was a place well suited for comfortable reading,\r\ntalking and drinking--except for the quality of the whiskey.\r\n\r\n"Can\'t kill grandpa," Doctor Randall said, from far down in his\r\ncomfortable chair. "No such thing as time travel."\r\n\r\n"You underestimate the Physics department," Pangborn told us coldly.\r\n"In spite of heavy losses to our staff--last year\'s treason trials\r\ncost us three of our most brilliant young men--we\'ve made some\r\nvery remarkable strides. We have what is crudely termed a time\r\nmachine--although the correct term is temporal transducer. In fact we\r\nare currently conducting some very interesting researches with it."\r\n\r\n"Then you have tried the killing of a grandfather, Herr Doctor?" Von\r\nJuntz inquired. "You have found why it cannot be done, yes?"\r\n\r\n"We have not yet gotten around to such minor matters," Pangborn\r\nsaid. "But in time...." He began to look interested, "Ah ... wait a\r\nminute.... In practice that would be.... Whose grandfather should we\r\nchoose?" His eyes glittered. "There is always the question of risk, of\r\ncourse, but it would be difficult for the law to legally consider it as\r\nactually murder. My grandfather is already dead." He hesitated. 

"There\r\nis the possibility of disappearing."\r\n\r\n"But," Von Juntz reminded him, "by your own statement you said it, that\r\nthere is no paradox, and no risk. Grandpa would be dead, you would be\r\nalive, and there is no paradox, yes?"\r\n\r\n"Q. E. 

D." Pangborn snapped. "Reduction ad absorbum."\r\n\r\n"Et pons asinorum," Von Juntz snapped back, his beard bristling.\r\n\r\nThese exchanges would have been ever so much better if any of us had\r\never taken Latin. But I could see that Pangborn was ruffled.\r\n\r\n"Very well." He bit off the words. 

"We\'ll do it."\r\n\r\n"Whose grandfather?" asked Doctor Randall.\r\n\r\nPangborn\'s eyes glittered. "Mine, naturally. I wouldn\'t want to\r\nendanger any of you gentlemen. After all, it is my demonstration. I\r\nremember my grandfather jabbing me in the belly with a great horny\r\nfinger when I was too young to defend myself. Giddygiddy, he used to\r\nsay, the old buzzard. Died naturally. Apoplexy with a fan dancer it\r\nwas, in a hotel room at the age of ninety-three. Disgraceful. 

Nobody\r\never shot him. Don\'t understand why not. 

Long overdue." Pangborn rubbed\r\nhis hands together and started for the door. "How about it? Will you\r\ngentlemen accompany me to the Physics department?"\r\n\r\n[illus]\r\n\r\nOn the way over Randall nudged me and spoke out of the side of his\r\nmouth.\r\n\r\n"Three to one Pangborn vanishes."\r\n\r\nIt seemed like good odds. If Pangborn managed to prevent his father\r\nfrom being born, logically he should prevent himself from being born.\r\nBut I couldn\'t visualize him vanishing. Common sense was against it.\r\n"I\'ll cover that." I gave Randall three dollars.\r\n\r\nIf Pangborn did not vanish, Randall would owe me nine. If Pangborn did\r\nnot vanish I would be disappointed, and money would be some consolation.\r\n\r\nPangborn passed us through the security guards and into the Physics\r\nlaboratories. No need to describe the temporal transducer, it looked\r\nlike the usual thing in gadgets--coils, tubes, pipes, condensers,\r\nwires, tubes--with a little screen overhead that lets the operator,\r\nwho stays behind, watch what is happening to his passenger. Pangborn\r\nwas extremely proud of it. He showed us all over the machine, pointing\r\nand naming every part. Von Juntz got his beard caught in a control\r\nwheel.\r\n\r\nThat made Pangborn almost good-natured.\r\n\r\nThen he wanted to choose someone to operate the machine for him. He\r\nsaid my hands shook too much, and Von Juntz would not allow his beard\r\nto get within five feet of the controls, so we steadied Doctor Randall\r\nagainst a safety railing and instructed him how to operate the machine.\r\nPangborn set the dials.\r\n\r\n"There\'s one place where I\'m certain to find Grandfather any time\r\nbetween 1893 and 1906," Pangborn told us. "The Andrew Jackson Saloon\r\nBar on Decatur Street. He spent a lot of time there. Used it for his\r\noffice they tell me. He was a lawyer. I\'ve set the machine for there,\r\nfor the month of September 1896. A good month to die in. 

Ha!" Pangborn\r\nostentatiously checked the cylinders of a huge antique revolver.\r\n\r\n"Forty-five caliber," Pangborn said grimly. "Poke me, will he? 

Ha!"\r\n\r\nAnd he climbed into the machine.\r\n\r\nAll of us crowded around the screen, Von Juntz carefully holding his\r\nbeard. We saw the picture forming, the cut glass and bright gas lamps\r\nand polished wood of the Saloon Bar.\r\n\r\n"_Four_ to one Pangborn vanishes," Randall said suddenly, "Any takers,\r\nspeak now."\r\n\r\nI reached for my wallet.\r\n\r\nVon Juntz said, "If he vanishes, it will be because he was never born.\r\nAnd if he was never born, you won\'t remember taking bets on him."\r\n\r\n"Here," I said hastily to Randall, "I gave you some already. I\'ll hold\r\nmy money, hand it back."\r\n\r\nRandall withdrew a little. "Don\'t you trust me?" he asked in a hurt\r\ntone. "I\'ll pay you if he doesn\'t vanish."\r\n\r\n"Shhh," Von Juntz said. We crowded around the screen again.\r\n\r\nThe screen looked down on the bar from above and behind it, like\r\nlooking in through a window set above the mirror. And at the bar was\r\nonly one solitary customer, a tall lean man in a frock coat and plug\r\nhat with a cigar from which smoke curled richly, and a schooner of\r\nbeer before him. He looked up at the bar mirror, and we saw a lean,\r\nevilly humorous face with the Pangborn features clearly marked on it.\r\n"Grandpa," Von Juntz whispered.\r\n\r\nIn a dark angle of the place, Pangborn himself materialized from the\r\nmachine. We saw a glimmer as he raised the gun.\r\n\r\n"See," Von Juntz whispered. "He has forgotten to uncock the safety. Now\r\nhe has. Now he creeps closer. Soon now we shall know the paradox."\r\n\r\nGrandpa Pangborn had put down his cigar. His hand had slid under the\r\nlapel of his frock coat. Just before he whirled, I realized that he had\r\nbeen watching Pangborn in the mirror all the time.\r\n\r\nHe whirled, his hand whipped out from beneath his lapel, and the sound\r\nof a gunshot echoed in the saloon. We had a clear view of the angry\r\nsurprise on Pangborn\'s face before he toppled nose down into the\r\nsawdust. He was quite obviously dead.\r\n\r\n"Whippersnapper," Grandpa Pangborn muttered. He holstered his gun and\r\nlooked up, and his lean face oddly seemed to be looking straight into\r\nthe peering eye of the time viewer, and into our staring eyes. We could\r\nnot be seen.... Or could we?\r\n\r\nLooking at us, he spoke.\r\n\r\n"Figure that one out!" said Grandpa Pangborn. I cut the switch, and the\r\nviewer went black.\r\n\r\nThe way I see it, Pangborn vanished, but not in the right way, so\r\nRandall owes me nine dollars. But he says he won the bet, and he won\'t\r\neven give me back the three I handed him before Pangborn got into that\r\nfool machine.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nThat morning, the sun rose bright and clear over the Tower. Jon woke,\r\nclambered to his feet, and rolled his sleeping-blanket. Within five\r\nminutes, he was fully awake and ready to protect the Tower against its\r\nenemies.\r\n\r\nHe took his station and stared out over the sea. Far in the distance,\r\nhe could make out the bomb-blackened city; off to the left was the\r\nspot of green that indicated the village of the Free People. Somewhere\r\nbeyond were the lands of the Wild Ones--the ones Jon was here to defend\r\nthe tower against.\r\n\r\n"All well to the East!" he cried, when his turn came. The other\r\nGuardsmen, stationed in a circle around the Tower, called off their\r\nobservations in turn.\r\n\r\nThe morning passed slowly. A little before noon, the man at the top of\r\nthe Tower cried, "Enemy boat approaching! Prepare to defend the Tower!"\r\n\r\nJon\'s mouth tightened, and he squinted toward the dot of light on the\r\nsea that was the boat of the Wild Ones. Slowly, he drew his sword,\r\nwhisked it through the air a few times, loosened his wrist. It was the\r\nfirst time in over a month that he had been called upon to do battle in\r\nthe name of the Tower.\r\n\r\nFrom within the Tower, the auxiliary guard-force came running out and\r\ntook battle-stations. They stood ready, waiting for the Wild Ones to\r\ncome.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nNo one knew what the Tower was. It had been there as long as any of the\r\nFree People could remember, and probably had been there forever. It was\r\nsacred to them, and for that reason was under constant attack by their\r\nenemies from the Wild Places.\r\n\r\nAt twenty-three, Jon had been a Tower guard for nearly three years, had\r\ntaken part in almost twenty defenses. The Wild Ones had practically\r\ncaptured the Tower twice, but each time the guardians had driven them\r\noff.\r\n\r\nNow, they were back for another try. Jon waited tensely as they drew\r\nnear.\r\n\r\nTime passed slowly. Five minutes, ten, while the enemy attacking-party\r\napproached. The look-out at the top of the Tower sang out periodically,\r\nkeeping the guards below informed of the boat\'s progress.\r\n\r\nFinally: "They\'re here! Prepare to defend the Tower!"\r\n\r\nThe great sailing-ship pulled up on the shore, and men began to pour\r\nforth--ten, twenty, thirty men. It was a good-sized army. And Jon\r\ngasped when he saw who led them.\r\n\r\nHe was a giant, topping seven feet by several inches. His sword\r\nglittered in the sunlight as he slashed it savagely through the air,\r\nand his hair was a coarse, matted mane. He growled some barbaric\r\ncommand and the Wild Ones charged onward. The ring of defenders\r\ntightened and stood firm, waiting for the attack.\r\n\r\nSwords rang. Jon found himself opposing a brawny youth with fierce,\r\nwidely-set eyes and a good sword-hand. He parried a two-handed chop\r\nthat could have cut him in half, and smashed back with a quick lunge\r\nthat drew blood.\r\n\r\n"Dog!" The Wild One flicked blood from the flesh wound and drove\r\nforward. Jon parried again, drove in, crashed his sword off the\r\nother\'s hilt. His hand numbed, the Wild One dropped his sword. Without\r\nhesitating, Jon cut the unarmed man down and turned to seek his next\r\nopponent.\r\n\r\nHe glanced over and saw Len, the Tower Captain, in tight combat with a\r\ngigantic Wild One. The giant was driving Len back toward the sea with\r\nsweeping swings of his huge broadsword.\r\n\r\nJon turned and started to go to Len\'s assistance when another barbarian\r\ninterposed himself. Jon whirled and leaped forward for the battle, just\r\nas he saw Len fall to the giant\'s sword.\r\n\r\n"Give back! Give back!" 

someone yelled. 

"They\'re beating us!"\r\n\r\n_They\'re not beating me_, Jon thought fiercely, as he laid open his\r\nopponent\'s arm with a savage slash and followed immediately with a\r\nquick swipe that ripped open the Wild One\'s throat.\r\n\r\nBreathing hard, now, Jon turned to look for his next opponent. He had\r\nbut one thought: the Tower must be defended. The Tower was sacred to\r\nthe Free People; the Tower must be defended.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe found himself embroiled in another duel quickly enough. The\r\nbarbarians seemed to be all over the place, cutting and slashing with\r\ntheir wild, untrained manner. A quick glance around told Jon that the\r\nTower guards were being driven back; half a dozen of his childhood\r\nfriends lay slain near him, and a river of blood trickled slowly\r\nthrough the grass.\r\n\r\nThe barbarians were falling too--but their giant leader was\r\nindomitable, was wreaking death right and left in the ranks of the\r\nGuardians.\r\n\r\nJon killed his opponent and looked around. The thick of the battle was\r\non the other side of the Tower, he saw. It was now nearly noon, and the\r\nsun blazed brightly off the Tower\'s metal sides.\r\n\r\nWhen he reached the other side of the Tower, he was surprised to see\r\nthat barely half a dozen guards remained alive. Half a dozen, out of\r\nnearly forty.\r\n\r\nHe plunged into the fray with furious energy, cutting down three\r\nWild Ones before they realized he was there. 

That narrowed the odds\r\nconsiderably.\r\n\r\nOnly three of the Free People remained--and four of the Wild Ones. It\r\nhad been a bloody, fierce battle, with heavy loss of life on both sides.\r\n\r\nJon\'s sword plunged into a barbarian\'s throat, and in that instant the\r\ngiant\'s weapon cut the life from the man at Jon\'s side. Two against\r\nthree, now.\r\n\r\n"Now!" Jon yelled and drove down against one of the remaining Wild\r\nOnes. His slash ripped open the man\'s leg, but before Jon could apply\r\nthe finishing touch one of the other barbarians killed his man and\r\nlunged at Jon, who parried and dropped the man with a swift chop.\r\n\r\nThe realization hit him suddenly: _I\'m all alone._\r\n\r\nAnd the gigantic Wild One was moving slowly toward him to finish off\r\nthe last of the Tower guards.\r\n\r\nJon set his lips grimly. So the Tower would fall, after all, to the\r\nbarbarians? _Not lightly_, he thought, and waited for the giant\'s\r\nadvance.\r\n\r\nThe sword the giant swung was nearly four feet long. It cut a sizzling\r\nswath through the air as he approached.\r\n\r\nJon moved back, up against the comforting bulk of the Tower itself, and\r\nprepared to defend the Tower to the death. The giant charged.\r\n\r\nJon parried his wild blow, felt the stinging shock ripple up his arm as\r\ntheir swords clanged together. He initiated an assault of his own, but\r\nthe Wild One laughed derisively and parried as if he were fighting a\r\nchild.\r\n\r\n"Ho, Free One! The Tower is ours!"\r\n\r\n"Not yet," Jon said. "Not while I live!"\r\n\r\n"How long will that be?" the giant asked. "Another minute perhaps?"\r\n\r\nHis sword spun through the air in a shining arc. Jon parried\r\ndesperately, but the force of the blow was too great for him and his\r\nsword went flying out of his numbed hands. He stood there, helpless,\r\nwhile the giant raised his sword for the final blow.\r\n\r\nAnd suddenly six inches of bright steel protruded from the giant\'s\r\nchest. A red fountain of blood bubbled forth. The giant stared in\r\namazement for a second, then began to topple like a felled oak.\r\n\r\nAstonished, Jon looked up and saw the Wild One he had wounded standing\r\nthere, holding a bloody sword.\r\n\r\n"You ... killed him!" Jon said uncomprehendingly. 

"Why?"\r\n\r\nThe Wild One shook his head uncertainly. "I don\'t know," he said. "I--I\r\nsuddenly realized he had to die."\r\n\r\nExhausted, Jon leaned against the Tower to support himself, and shook\r\nhis head. "Why did you save me? The Tower was yours. Why?

"\r\n\r\n"I think I understand," the Wild One said slowly. He threw his sword\r\nto the ground. 

"It is something I have long thought of. We fight\r\nyou because we hate you--because we envy your free life. You have\r\nsomething to fight for, in this Tower. I--I want to join you. 

I want to\r\njoin the Free People!"\r\n\r\nJon smiled. "You\'re welcome to come to our village with me," he said.\r\n"We believe in freedom--the way the Old Ones did."\r\n\r\n"And the Tower? 

What is its meaning?"\r\n\r\nJon shrugged. "That we do not know, but we defend it because we think\r\nit is sacred to us--to freedom. An old legend, perhaps." He clapped the\r\nother on the back. 

"Come, friend. Let\'s signal the mainland that the\r\nbattle is over and the Tower still in free hands."\r\n\r\nHe glanced up at the massive Tower, at the huge statue of the woman\r\nwith her hand outraised, stretching a torch out over the harbor. "I\r\nsuppose we\'ll never know what the Tower really was, to the Ancients.\r\nBut to us--to us, it\'s a symbol of liberty."\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


Why not?"\r\n\r\n"It can\'t be done," the big man stated simply. "Maybe sometime in the\r\nfuture, but certainly not now."\r\n\r\nSaunders stretched a bony hand out from the cuff of his tweeds. "It\r\ncan be done," he said, slapping that hand on the table. "It\'s all\r\nhere. You\'ve just seen it; you\'ve studied it. Damn it, this isn\'t a\r\nfly-by-night affair! I\'ve worked on these plans for more than eight\r\nyears. 

I _know_ it will work."\r\n\r\nA man in blue serge shrugged and said, "I\'m afraid Bragg is right,\r\nDr. Saunders." He tugged at his collar, the fat hanging in loose folds\r\naround his neck.\r\n\r\nSaunders turned to eye the newcomer. "You agree?" 

he asked defiantly.\r\n"Even after studying my work? You agree that my proposed rocket\r\ncouldn\'t possibly reach the Moon?"\r\n\r\n"It might," the man in blue serge admitted, "but we can\'t speculate\r\non a thing of this nature. After all, Dr. Saunders, there\'ll be money\r\ninvolved and...."\r\n\r\n"Money!" Saunders snorted in disgust. "Is that all you\'re worried\r\nabout? You\'re one of the richest men on Earth, Mr. Peterson. How can\r\nyou let money stand in the way of what may well be man\'s greatest\r\nachievement?"\r\n\r\nBragg spoke again, peering from behind the thick lenses of his\r\neyeglasses. "Peterson is right; this thing would cost millions--more\r\nthan any of us would be willing to risk. We appreciate your considering\r\nus, but...."\r\n\r\nSaunders cut in sharply, "Does that go for all of you? 

Is Mr. Bragg\r\nspeaking for all of you?"\r\n\r\nA heavy silence crowded into the room. Saunders confronted Peterson\r\nagain.\r\n\r\n"He speaks for me," Peterson said.\r\n\r\n"And you, Mr. Thorpe?" Saunders asked.\r\n\r\n"Yes, yes, I\'m inclined to agree," a balding man in glen plaid\r\nannounced.\r\n\r\n"Mr. Slade?" Saunders turned to a weasel-like man dressed in solemn\r\nblack.\r\n\r\nSlade nodded, his face chalky white against the black of his garb.\r\n\r\n"I\'ve asked you four men because you were probably the richest men\r\non Earth. I\'ve asked you because I thought perhaps you would see the\r\nsignificance of such a project. To reach the Moon." Saunders\' eyes\r\ngleamed with an intense light. "To reach the Moon."\r\n\r\n"And when we reach it?" Peterson asked. "Then what?"\r\n\r\n"Unlimited space," Saunders answered with feeling. "New worlds, worlds\r\nbeyond the imagination of man. The Moon is only the first step, the\r\nexperimental step. From there, Mars ... or Venus ... or a new solar\r\nsystem."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBragg said, "Rubbish. Even if this should work--I\'m not at all\r\nconvinced it will, but even if it should--what\'s on the Moon for us?\r\nBare crags and lonely craters. Cold, bleak atmosphere. 

Nothing."\r\n\r\n"Nothing that would bring in money, true," Saunders said. "But look at\r\nCopernicus and Galileo. Look at Pasteur and Edison and Curie. Look\r\nat ... oh, I could go on all night. What these men contributed to\r\nmankind can never be measured in terms of gold or silver. Can\'t you see\r\nthat?

"\r\n\r\n"Who wants to go to the Moon, anyway?" Thorpe asked, passing a hand\r\nover his bald head. "We\'ve got troubles of our own right here on\r\nEarth. Plenty to settle right here, man. Plenty. In a little while\r\nperhaps. Sometime in the future. Twenty, twenty-five years. But now,\r\nunthinkable."\r\n\r\n"We\'ve been saying that too long," Saunders snapped. "Now is the time!\r\nNot twenty or twenty-five years from now, but _right_ now! Science has\r\ngiven us the means; it\'s up to us to take the opportunity and use it."\r\n\r\n"It couldn\'t be done profitably," Peterson said drily.\r\n\r\n"Profitably," Saunders said bitterly. "Are your wars profitable?" he\r\nsuddenly shouted, bringing his bony fist crashing to the table top.\r\n\r\n"Let\'s not get violent," Slade said. It was the first thing he\'d said\r\nall night. Saunders somehow had the feeling that a corpse had spoken.\r\n\r\n"Exactly," he said, "Let\'s not get violent; let\'s spend some of the\r\nmoney that\'s been buying munitions and lives. Instead of razing cities\r\nto the ground, let\'s go up into the skies. Let\'s spend that money for\r\na project that\'s worthwhile. For once, forget the profit and think of\r\nthe meaning to mankind." He paused and his voice grew lower. "We\'ve\r\nbeen ravaged by too many wars, gentleman. Can\'t we stop this useless\r\nbutchery and devote our time and energy to something constructive?\r\nCan\'t we? I know my rocket will work. It\'s scientifically sound. I\r\nknow, too, that I can get a crew of scientists and technicians to take\r\nit to the Moon and back. All I need is the money and a little time.\r\nJust a little time."\r\n\r\n"There\'s a war going on, Saunders," Bragg reminded him. He had lit\r\na cigar with a gold lighter and was sitting now, puffing leisurely,\r\nblowing smoke at the ceiling.\r\n\r\n"I know," Saunders said. "Two wars in the past thirty years and now\r\nanother one. 

But consider this a moment. A trip to the Moon would\r\nprobably end all hostilities on Earth. It would probably unify this\r\nplanet as no other force has ever done. It will galvanize humanity into\r\nconstructive action. It will open new vistas that cannot possibly admit\r\nplans for war."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nPeterson yawned openly. 

"Mmmm. I must say you\'re an idealist, Saunders.\r\nI doubt very much if anything short of a trip to the Sun would unify\r\nthe people of Earth." He chuckled a little at this and looked to the\r\nothers for approval.\r\n\r\n"That\'s right," Bragg agreed. "There\'ll always be wars, Saunders; the\r\nEarth is overpopulated, always will be."\r\n\r\n"More reason to find new worlds," Saunders said tiredly.\r\n\r\n"The only solution is war," Bragg insisted. "Survival of the fittest.\r\nForget your crazy ideas about new worlds. There\'s plenty of room right\r\nhere ... for the people who win.

"\r\n\r\n"And suppose we lose this time?" Saunders asked.\r\n\r\n"We\'ll never lose," Bragg said with certainty.\r\n\r\nSlade smiled a thin, wry smile. "Exactly, Bragg," he said. "As for me,\r\nwhenever people are ready to fight, I\'ll be ready to supply them with\r\nthe goods they\'ll need. In the meantime, the Moon can wait."\r\n\r\n"A year, maybe two," Saunders pleaded, "and the Universe will be open\r\nto us. Think of it, think of it...." Again his eyes lit with intense\r\nardor.\r\n\r\n"You think of it," Bragg said, "I\'m going home."\r\n\r\nThe other men nodded and began bustling into their overcoats. Saunders\r\nstood by helplessly, feeling his last ounce of strength seep from his\r\nbody.\r\n\r\n"Nice of you to think of us," Thorpe said cheerily. "Business is\r\nbusiness, though."\r\n\r\n"Yes," Saunders said quietly.\r\n\r\n"If you can figure a way to put a warhead on that rocket of yours,"\r\nSlade suggested.\r\n\r\n"Not a bad idea," Bragg admitted.\r\n\r\n"Well, Saunders," Peterson said, "we\'ve got to be running. No hard\r\nfeelings, of course; in fact, I wish you lots of luck." 

He chuckled\r\nagain and opened the door. 

"Good night."\r\n\r\nThe rest of the men filed out after him, nodding their farewells.\r\nSaunders watched them through the window of his laboratory, watched\r\nchauffeurs open the doors to long limousines, watched tail lights\r\ndisappear into the blackness of the night, little red pin-points\r\nemphasizing his failure.\r\n\r\nHe walked back to the table and sat, cradling his head in his arms,\r\nleaning on the blueprints of his ship.\r\n\r\n_All I needed was money_, he thought, _money and a little time. A year\r\nor two at the most. A year or two._\r\n\r\nSlowly he rose and brushed a thin hand over his wet eyes. There was\r\nwork to be done, and tomorrow was another day. He walked to the door\r\nleading to his inner laboratory and paused. It was past midnight, and\r\nbeing a punctilious person, Saunders ripped the day\'s page from the\r\ncalendar, exposing the new day to view. The new day was September 21st,\r\nthe year 3951.\r\n\r\nHe snapped off the lights and stepped quickly into the other room.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


He\'d missed the boat at every turn.\r\n           But now there were no turns left, with raw space\r\n         around him and death waiting on a lonely asteroid....\r\n\r\n           [Transcriber\'s Note: This etext was produced from\r\n                      Rocket Stories, July 1953.\r\n         Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that\r\n         the U.S. copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nJubil drifted slowly, alone except for the phosphorescent star shine\r\nthat filtered through the face-plate of his suit. He was resting,\r\nconserving the oxygen that hissed steadily and quietly through the\r\nvalve near his neck. It was time for peace; there had been too much\r\nviolence already.\r\n\r\nOnce, as his body continued its involuntary and aimless turning, Jubil\r\nsaw the dark hull of the _Mercury II_, the outer access door firmly\r\nclosed now and the stern beginning to fluoresce with the secondary\r\nradiation that betokened the firing of the drives. Still, Jubil could\r\nfeel no anger at Radik.\r\n\r\nWhen the crew had conspired to mutiny, when Radik, Olgan and the rest\r\nhad decided to take over the operation of the _Mercury II_, at that\r\ntime had been the need for honest anger. Jubil had hesitated weakly\r\ninstead, had chosen to be a bystander and had suffered the fate of the\r\naverage non-participant; he had been outcast from the closed circle\r\nof both friend and enemy. Kane, once Captain of the _Mercury II_, was\r\nnow dead and his _dis_-charred body drifting somewhere in the spatial\r\nwilderness.\r\n\r\n"Have you changed your thinking, Jubil?" It was Radik\'s voice in the\r\nhelmet phones and Jubil could almost see the heavy face with its\r\nfringe of space-black beard. Jubil rested, listening to the cosmic\r\ninterference in his R-link equipment.\r\n\r\n"Jubil! Jubil Marken! 

Have you changed your mind?"\r\n\r\n"Radik--" Jubil formed the words slowly, using his lips only and\r\nbreathing shallowly. "Piracy suits you, Radik. You are one of the\r\nruthless...."\r\n\r\nJubil could hear Radik\'s throaty chuckle. "A dead man of honor is still\r\ndead, Jubil." The communication circuit went silent except for the buzz\r\nof voices in the background. Jubil drifted on, conscious of the fact\r\nthat he was moving but so full of the lethargy of the moment that he\r\nneglected it. What would it be like, this bit of time that was left? It\r\nhad been an hour since Jubil had been forcibly ejected from the access\r\ndoor of the _Mercury II_; the flask at his back carried oxygen for\r\nfour. Three hours of life--while around his slowly turning body was the\r\nagelessness of endless space. Jubil smiled, just a little, conscious\r\nof the fact that he felt no fear. The die was cast now; he had made his\r\ndecision finally, and he did not regret it.\r\n\r\n"There is space-craft in Sector 180, Jubil," it was Radik again, "Racon\r\nhas just reported it. But they\'ll miss you by at least ten parsecs.\r\nHave you changed your mind?"\r\n\r\n"No.

"\r\n\r\n"Very well." 

Jubil could see the pulsing of the _Mercury\'s_ drives,\r\nnow. Radik was taking no chances on the strange ship still light years\r\naway from his stern being patrol. "Good news for you, Jubil. You are\r\nin the gravitational field of an asteroid. You can\'t see it, yet; it\'s\r\ndirectly above you. But you\'ll drift to it and cling like a snail on a\r\nstone for as long as time itself. Good-bye, Jubil."\r\n\r\nStrange, Jubil thought, that there was no anger in him now. There\r\nshould be oxygen enough for a good two hours yet, so this eerie ennui\r\ncould not be the prelude to a rising carbon dioxide quotient. A normal\r\nman would be bitter, perhaps even hysterical in his anger and his\r\nfear of death. Yet there was only this peaceful drifting toward the\r\nstill-invisible asteroid that hung in space above his own head. 

Jubil\r\nclosed his eyes, shutting out the phosphorescence of the velvet that\r\nwas space. The exhaust of the _Mercury II_ might still be in sight.\r\nIf so, it was not visible through the restriction of the plastic\r\nface-plate of Jubil\'s suit.\r\n\r\nJubil found himself wondering where Kane could have drifted since the\r\ncaptain\'s inert body had been shoved out of the _Mercury II\'s_ access\r\ndoor. Perhaps, even now, it was bound, like a rudderless ship, toward\r\nthe selfsame asteroid that would be Jubil\'s last and permanent home.\r\n\r\nThinking of Kane, Jubil remembered also Schoenbirk, the erratic\r\ngenius whose mathematical theorizing was used in the design of the\r\nSchoenbirk-Halsted De-Fouling Gear. Had it been years, or lifetimes\r\nago, when the three of them had been undergraduates together at the\r\nAcademy?\r\n\r\nSchoenbirk, working with the high electrostatic potentials necessary\r\nto insure the exhaust of opposite-sign waste from the complex guts of\r\nthe atomic drive had been blown to pieces by the accumulation of the\r\nvery thing his device was designed to prevent. Random electrical forces\r\ngathering around the discharge ring until their workable mass became\r\ngreat enough to enter and initiate a chain reaction in the fuel storage\r\ntank. Along with Schoenbirk had gone even the tremendously heavy\r\nconcrete walls of the laboratory. 

All that, however, had been after\r\nJubil had washed out of the Academy and gone into the space-freighters\r\nas a Drive-Engineer. In the intervening years, Jubil had become\r\nthoroughly familiar with the perfected Schoenbirk-Halsted....\r\n\r\nKane! There was a man who had made the Academy his own playground.\r\nKane had passed with the greatest of ease, worked his way through\r\nastro-navigation, the Allen Drives, space-time computations....\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nJubil grimaced wryly. It had been the latter with its advanced\r\nmathematics that had been his own downfall. So Kane had gone on to the\r\nfirst officer berth in a gilded passenger liner while Jubil developed\r\nradiation scars on his hands from "in the hole" engineering on decrepit\r\nfreighters.\r\n\r\nAnd the great leveller had met and conquered them all....\r\n\r\nSchoenbirk, even in the explosion that took his life had accomplished\r\na great thing: the discovery of the final flaw in the De-Fouling\r\nGear that had lived after him. For without proper removal of the\r\nionized waste from its drive engines, the largest freighter became an\r\never-accumulating and treacherously unstable fissionable pile.\r\n\r\nKane--one of the legendary figures of the history of astro-navigation.\r\nKane with his Academy background and his proud but personable air had\r\nbecome one of the most talked-of Space captains who had ever lived.\r\nJubil could still, in memory, see Kane, standing spread-kneed on the\r\nbridge of the _Comet_, one of the first; later the _Wanderer_, the\r\nfirst of the luxury space liners. The _Mercury_, and the _Mercury II_,\r\nthe super-ships that made week-end excursion flights that spanned from\r\ngalaxy to galaxy.\r\n\r\nA misplaced decimal point and a misplaced trust and the greatness\r\nof Schoenbirk and Kane lay behind them. Even as his drifting body,\r\ncumbersome in the space-suit, touched the asteroid, Jubil was aware of\r\na strange weariness that invaded every part of him except his mind. At\r\nleast, the waning oxygen would leave him his thoughts.\r\n\r\nHe rested, conserving his strength. For what reason? 

The thing that was\r\nto happen was as certain as Fate and as unavoidable by the machinations\r\nof man. Was it, after all, because Jubil was prey to anger? No. He was\r\nnow too near death for anger to seem important.\r\n\r\nThe face of the asteroid was cold and Jubil lay against it, held as\r\nlightly as a maiden\'s kiss by the ounce or so of gravity.\r\n\r\nHe was smiling as the darkness of space was suddenly brilliantly\r\nlighted. Spears of bluish flame, each with its tip of crimson, spread\r\nacross the warp of time, and subconsciously Jubil found himself waiting\r\nfor the shock wave. Then he laughed. In space there was no atmosphere;\r\nhe would never be buffeted by the blast that had destroyed the _Mercury\r\nII_ and the mutineer Radik.\r\n\r\nJubil thought again of the hellish radiation to which he had exposed\r\nhimself. There was no other way. To destroy the delicate regulating\r\nlinkage of the Schoenbirk-Halsted, a man must enter the combustion\r\nchamber where the pilot-piles idled. There had been just time enough\r\nfor that, before Radik had sent for him.\r\n\r\nHad there been ample oxygen, Jubil Marken knew that he would only have\r\nlived until his radiation-seared heart painfully failed to function.\r\nBut, thanks to Radik, Jubil had been spared both the disintegration of\r\nthe _Mercury II_ and an agonizing death from slow radiation burn.\r\n\r\nHe was, Jubil reflected, as effective in his own way as was Schoenbirk\r\nand Kane. In the end, he was still an Academy man with them. He\r\nwas peacefully smiling as he twisted tight the oxygen valve at his\r\nthroat....\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n
