Anthony Ferlaine_\r\n\r\n\r\n There may be a town called Mars in Montana. But\r\n little Mrs. Freda Dunny didn\'t come from there!\r\n\r\n\r\nI watched Don Phillips, the commercial announcer, out of the corner of\r\nmy eye. The camera in front of me swung around and lined up on my set.\r\n\r\n"... And now, on with the show," Phillips was saying. "And here, ready\r\nto test your wits, is your quizzing quiz master, Smiling Jim Parsons."\r\n\r\nI smiled into the camera and waited while the audience applauded. The\r\ncamera tally light went on and the stage manager brought his arm down\r\nand pointed at me.\r\n\r\n"Good afternoon," I said into the camera, "here we go again with another\r\nhalf hour of fun and prizes on television\'s newest, most exciting, game,\r\n\'Parlor Quiz.\' In a moment I\'ll introduce you to our first contestant.\r\nBut first here is a special message to you mothers ..."\r\n\r\nThe baby powder commercial appeared on the monitor and I walked over to\r\nthe next set. They had the first contestant lined up for me. I smiled\r\nand took her card from the floor man. She was a middle-aged woman with a\r\nfaded print dress and old-style shoes. I never saw the contestants\r\nuntil we were on the air. They were screened before the show by the\r\nstaff. They usually tried to pick contestants who would make good show\r\nmaterial--an odd name or occupation--or somebody with twenty kids.\r\nSomething of that nature.\r\n\r\nI looked at the card for the tip off. "Mrs. Freda Dunny," the card said.\r\n"Ask her where she comes from."\r\n\r\nI smiled at the contestant again and took her by the hand. The tally\r\nlight went on again and I grinned into the camera.\r\n\r\n"Well, now, we\'re all set to go ... and our first contestant today is\r\nthis charming little lady right here beside me. Mrs. 

Freda Dunny." I\r\nlooked at the card. "How are you, Mrs. Dunny?"\r\n\r\n"Fine! Just fine."\r\n\r\n"All set to answer a lot of questions and win a lot of prizes?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, I\'ll win all right," said Mrs. Dunny, smiling around at the\r\naudience.\r\n\r\nThe audience tittered a bit at the remark. I looked at the card again.\r\n\r\n"Where are you from, Mrs. Dunny?"\r\n\r\n"Mars!" said Mrs. Dunny.\r\n\r\n"Mars!" I laughed, anticipating the answer. "Mars, Montana? Mars, Peru?"\r\n\r\n"No, _Mars_! Up there," she said, pointing up in the air. "The planet\r\nMars. The fourth planet out from the sun."\r\n\r\nMy assistant looked unhappy.\r\n\r\nI smiled again, wondering what the gag was. I decided to play along.\r\n\r\n"Well, well," I said, "all the way from Mars, eh? And how long have you\r\nbeen on Earth, Mrs. Dunny?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, about thirty or forty years. I\'ve been here nearly all my life.\r\nCame here when I was a wee bit of a girl."\r\n\r\n"Well," I said, "you\'re practically an Earthwoman by now, aren\'t you?"\r\nThe audience laughed. "Do you plan on going back someday or have you\r\nmade up your mind to stay here on Earth for the rest of your days?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, I\'m just here for the invasion," said Mrs. Dunny. "When that\'s over\r\nI\'ll probably go back home again."\r\n\r\n"The invasion?"\r\n\r\n"Yes, the invasion of Earth. As soon as enough of us are here we\'ll get\r\nstarted."\r\n\r\n"You mean there are others here, too?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, yes, there are several million of us here in the United States\r\nalready--and more are on the way."\r\n\r\n"There are only about a hundred and seventy million people in the United\r\nStates, Mrs. Dunny," I said. "If there are several million Martians\r\namong us, one out of every hundred would have to be a Martian."\r\n\r\n"One out of every ten!" said Mrs. 

Dunny. 

"That\'s what the boss said just\r\nthe other day. \'We\'re getting pretty close to the number we need to\r\ntake over Earth.\'"\r\n\r\n"What do you need?" I asked. 

"One to one? One Martian for every\r\nEarthman?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, no," said Mrs. Dunny, "one Martian is worth ten Earthmen. The only\r\nreason we\'re waiting is we don\'t want any trouble."\r\n\r\n"You don\'t look any different from us Earth people, Mrs. Dunny. How does\r\none tell the difference between a Martian and an Earthman when one sees\r\none?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, we don\'t _look_ any different," said Mrs. Dunny. "Some of the kids\r\ndon\'t even know they\'re Martians. Most mothers don\'t tell their children\r\nuntil they\'re grown-up. And there are other children who are never told\r\nbecause they just don\'t develop their full powers."\r\n\r\n"What powers?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, telepathy, thought control--that sort of thing."\r\n\r\n"You mean that Martians can read people\'s thoughts?"\r\n\r\n"Sure! It\'s no trouble at all. It\'s very easy really, once you get the\r\nhang of it."\r\n\r\n"Can you read my mind?" I asked, smiling.\r\n\r\n"Sure!" said Mrs. Dunny, smiling up at me. "That\'s why I said that I\'d\r\nknow the answers. I\'ll be able to read the answers from your mind when\r\nyou look at that sheet of paper."\r\n\r\n"Now, that\'s hardly sporting, is it, Mrs. Dunny?" 

I said, turning to the\r\ncamera. The audience laughed. "Everybody else has to do it the hard way\r\nand here you are reading it from my mind."\r\n\r\n"All\'s fair in love and war," said Mrs. Dunny.\r\n\r\n"Tell me, Mrs. Dunny. Why are you telling me about all this? Isn\'t it\r\nsupposed to be a secret?"\r\n\r\n"I have my reasons," said Mrs. Dunny. "Nobody believes me anyhow."\r\n\r\n"Oh, I believe you, Mrs. Dunny," I said gravely. "And now, let\'s see how\r\nyou do on the questions. 

Are you ready?"\r\n\r\nShe nodded.\r\n\r\n"Name the one and only mammal that has the ability to fly," I asked,\r\nreading from the script.\r\n\r\n"A bat," she said.\r\n\r\n"Right! Did you read that from my mind?

"\r\n\r\n"Oh, yes, you\'re coming over very clear!" said Mrs. 

Dunny.\r\n\r\n"Try this one," I said. "A princess is any daughter of a sovereign. What\r\nis a princess royal?"\r\n\r\n"The eldest daughter of a sovereign," she said.\r\n\r\n"Correct! 

How about this one? Is a Kodiak a kind of simple box camera; a\r\ntype of double-bowed boat; or a type of Alaskan bear?"\r\n\r\n"A bear," said Mrs. 

Dunny.\r\n\r\n"Very good," I said. "That was a hard one." I asked her seven more\r\nquestions and she got them all right. None of the other contestants even\r\ncame close to her score, so I wound up giving her the gas range and a\r\nlot of other smaller prizes.\r\n\r\nAfter we were off the air I followed the audience out into the hall.\r\nMrs. Dunny was walking towards the lobby with an old paper shopping bag\r\nunder her arm. An attendant was following her with an armful of prizes.\r\n\r\nI caught up with her before she reached the door.\r\n\r\n"Mrs. Dunny," I said, and she turned around. 

"I want to talk to you."\r\n\r\n"When do I get the gas stove?" she said.\r\n\r\n"Your local dealer will send it to you in a few days. Did you give them\r\nyour address?"\r\n\r\n"Yes, I gave it to them. My Philadelphia address, that is. I don\'t even\r\nremember my address at home any more."\r\n\r\n"Come, now, Mrs. Dunny. You don\'t have to keep up that Mars business now\r\nthat we\'re off the air."\r\n\r\n"It\'s the truth and I didn\'t come here just by accident," said Mrs.\r\nDunny, looking over her shoulder toward the attendant who was still\r\nholding the prizes. "I came here to see you."\r\n\r\n"Me?"\r\n\r\nMrs. Dunny set the paper bag down on the floor and dug down into her\r\npocketbook. She took out a dog-eared piece of white paper and bent it up\r\nin her hand.\r\n\r\n"Yes," she said finally. "I came to see you. And you didn\'t follow me\r\nout here because you wanted to. I commanded you to come."\r\n\r\n"Commanded me to come!" I spluttered. "What for?"\r\n\r\n"To prove something to you. Do you see this piece of paper?" She held\r\nout the paper in her hand with the blank side toward me. "My address is\r\non this paper. I am reading the address. 

Concentrate on what I\'m\r\nreading."\r\n\r\nI looked at her.\r\n\r\nI concentrated.\r\n\r\nSuddenly, I knew.\r\n\r\n"Two fifty-one South Eighth Street, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania," I said\r\naloud.\r\n\r\n"You see, it\'s very easy once you get the hang of it," she said.\r\n\r\nI nodded and smiled down at her. Now I understood. I picked up her bag\r\nand put my hand on her shoulder.\r\n\r\n"Let\'s go," I said. "We have a lot to talk about."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Fantastic Universe_ November 1956.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. ]\r\n\r\n\r\nJimmy Lorre saw the Earth spinning away from under him. It was odd,\r\nthis sensation of having nothing under you, nothing to keep you from\r\nfalling back upon the world from which the sleek grey space ship had\r\nlifted you. Lorre felt uneasy. He had traveled in rockets hundreds of\r\ntimes, of course; but this was his first flight into space.\r\n\r\nRockets had already been in use for nearly a century; but none had ever\r\nbefore ventured into outer space since the first one had met a horrible\r\nend in the Heaviside Layer. As a result of that incident, small rockets\r\nhad been developed for flight between cities, and, unhappily, for war.\r\n\r\nFinally a large space cruiser, equipped with the Lorre\r\npolari-neutralizer, set out in a second attempt to pierce the H-layer.\r\nAppropriately named the _New Hope_, it had just left Earth on its way\r\nto the Moon.\r\n\r\nLorre felt that some weird, alien menace confronted them. The details\r\nof the outcome of the first attempted flight to the moon lingered in\r\nhis mind. He had looked forward to this day with eagerness; yet now\r\nhe wished that he hadn\'t come along. Crushed down into the pneumatic\r\ncushions by the acceleration, his vision was so restricted that he\r\ncould see nothing but the Earth falling away from the ship, down, down.\r\n\r\nThe Lorre polari-neutralizer had been designed to send out a powerful\r\nfield of polarized force that neutralized the energy charge of the\r\nLayer, and so shield the ship from the raging storm of ions that\r\ncompose the ionosphere. James "Jimmy" Lorre, the inventor, had made\r\nsure of that. But the ionoscreen, which was to keep cosmic rays and\r\nother harmful radiations from the vessel\'s occupants beyond the Layer,\r\nhad been impossible to test. Math, however, had proved that it would\r\nfunction correctly.\r\n\r\n"Dr. 

Lorre!"\r\n\r\nThe ship had stopped accelerating, so that the pilot might have the\r\nfullest co-operation from his reflexes while passing the ionosphere.\r\n\r\n"Call me Jimmy," Lorre said succinctly. "Everybody does. What is it?"\r\n\r\nThe pilot motioned toward the complex mechanism that stood between\r\nthem and annihilation in the turbulent ionic sea they were swiftly\r\napproaching. "I wanted you to be on hand in case anything goes wrong.\r\nEven without the polari-neutralizer, the hull will stand up a few\r\nminutes, in case a wire comes loose in your machine, or something."\r\n\r\nLorre nodded. The pilot, always a thorough man, was taking no chances.\r\n\r\nHammond, at the controls of the _New Hope_, watched the chronometer\r\nlike a hawk. If the shield were applied too soon, the power would not\r\nlast; if too late, the ship would be destroyed.\r\n\r\nHe signaled the physicist. Lorre flipped the switch, gaining\r\nsatisfaction from the humming drone that came from the generators. An\r\ninstant later, they hit the Layer.\r\n\r\nLivid sheets of flame danced outside the portholes as the surging ions\r\nfought to break the shield that enveloped the ship with the intrepid\r\nband of spacefarers aboard. Could they cheat nature with their science?\r\nThe hull began to grow hot. Lorre increased the power.\r\n\r\n[Illustration: _Lurid sheets of flame danced outside the portholes as\r\nthe surging ions sought to break the shield._]\r\n\r\nThen they were through! The tremendous velocity gained before\r\ncutting the acceleration had carried them through! They were now in\r\nthe star-specked blackness of outer space, their ionoscreen, which\r\nduplicated conditions in the H-layer, surrounding the craft at a safe\r\ndistance. Apparently it was keeping the cosmic rays out as predicted.\r\n\r\nIt had been done at last! Space travel was an accomplished thing. Mars,\r\nVenus, the Major Planets, all were within man\'s reach. It was the dawn\r\nof a new era!\r\n\r\nHammond, the pilot, turned to congratulate the physicist who had made\r\nall this possible. But his grin faded, he raised his eyebrows in\r\nastonishment at what he saw. Lorre, having experienced the successful\r\nculmination of years of effort, lay on the floor of the control room,\r\napparently fast asleep!\r\n\r\nThat the polari-neutralizer would be a success, Lorre had felt certain.\r\nBut he could not control the elation he felt as they passed the outer\r\nedge of the Layer. _He_ had made it possible!\r\n\r\nSomeone whispered. The physicist looked at Hammond. The pilot was\r\nstaring out the port. Then he heard it again. 

But this time it\r\nwas--commanding! Commanding him to lie down!\r\n\r\nLorre did so. He seemed unable to summon the will power to resist.\r\nThe whisper went on. It seemed to be communicating directly with his\r\nmind, without the use of the indirect route through sense organs. When\r\nLorre realized that the whisper began to form coherent words. He became\r\noblivious to all else.\r\n\r\nThus it was that when Hammond tore his gaze from the port, he found the\r\nphysicist in a comatose condition. Rapidly, he summoned the rest of the\r\ncrew.\r\n\r\nIt consisted of--a doctor, a bio-chemist, a metallurgist, and a\r\nmechanic. They had been picked out of hundreds of volunteers. Able men,\r\nthey were ready for any emergency that might arise.\r\n\r\nThe doctor immediately tried to bring the seemingly unconscious man\r\naround. Lorre came to suddenly.\r\n\r\n"What\'s wrong?" he inquired of the doctor, who explained as much as he\r\nknew, which was little.\r\n\r\n"Of course," said Lorre. "I might have known." Then, "Hammond!"\r\n\r\n"Yes?"\r\n\r\n"Decelerate immediately. We must return to Earth as soon as possible."\r\n\r\n"But the moon?"\r\n\r\n"The moon is comparatively unimportant now. Besides, I can tell you\r\nexactly what we would find there. 

I\'ll explain everything as we go\r\nback. Start the generators. We must accumulate power to penetrate the\r\nH-layer on our return."\r\n\r\nLorre being the leader, the pilot adjusted the jets to turn.\r\n\r\n"Now, would you explain this rather--er--abrupt alteration in our\r\nplans, Dr. Lorre?"\r\n\r\n"Certainly. 

Call the rest of the men back.

"\r\n\r\nHammond did so. 

The mechanic appeared undisturbed; he wasn\'t even\r\ncurious. The bio-chemist and the metallurgist were greatly interested;\r\nthe doctor wondered whether the success of the polari-neutralizer had\r\nshaken the sanity of its inventor.\r\n\r\n"The universe," began Dr. Lorre, "is full of mysteries as yet unsolved.\r\nOne of these is the cosmic rays.\r\n\r\n"We know little of their origin or their properties. It seems, however,\r\nthat they have a marked effect on evolution.\r\n\r\n"The Kennelly-Heaviside Layer screens out most of these rays. It is as\r\na result of this that evolution can go slowly forward toward its goal.\r\nFor should all the cosmic rays reach Earth, life would devolve back\r\ninto protoplasm!\r\n\r\n"In the back of the so-called Horse\'s Head dark nebula is a dying star.\r\nThe nebula shields us from the cosmic rays it gives off. But in only\r\na few years our sun will carry us directly in the path of a deluge of\r\nthese rays against which our ionosphere will be too weak! Man will go\r\nback to the caveman days from which he emerged. But he will not stop\r\nthere. He will go back to primal protoplasm. Then, because the ray\r\nbarrage will be too strong for it, it will die. All life will go the\r\nsame way. In less than one million years, the world will be devoid of\r\nlife!\r\n\r\n"There is a way out. We can build a machine to strengthen the Heaviside\r\nLayer. It will be merely an ionoscreen around the entire world, to hold\r\nback the rays that pass the natural ionosphere. I have been given the\r\ndetails of the machine, and by the time we arrive on Earth I will have\r\nthem down on paper--"\r\n\r\n"But how do you know all this?" 

the doctor interrupted. He was still in\r\ndoubt about Lorre\'s sanity.\r\n\r\n"On Mars there is an age old civilization that faces the same peril,"\r\nwas the reply. "For years they have been trying to warn us of what\r\nthey knew would come. 

Their telepathy, however, was unable to pierce\r\nour H-layer. When we emerged from it, they immediately detected our\r\nthought vibrations, which are not stopped by the ionoscreen, and began\r\ncommunication with the most receptive mind aboard. It happened to be\r\nmine."\r\n\r\n"So when I found you lying in a comatose condition, you were talking to\r\nthe Martians?" asked Hammond, dazedly.\r\n\r\n"That\'s right. The sooner we can start building the ionoscreen machine\r\nas the Martians have already done, the better we\'ll be off.\r\n\r\n"It is likely that you are wondering as to whether I am in full\r\npossession of all my mental faculties, doctor. You will find that I am\r\nquite sane when the first Earth-Mars trip is made. The Martians are\r\neven now preparing to receive visitors from Earth. They have no space\r\nships; their science of mechanics is not as highly developed as ours."\r\n\r\nRocket tubes flaring silently in the void, the _New Hope_ turned its\r\nnose Earthward, bearing the timely warning that would save mankind from\r\na terrible fate.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


"All clear," and both men removed their helmets. They wiped sweat\r\nfrom their faces and glanced at each other.\r\n\r\nThe blonde man said, "The air\'s okay, Jarvis. Everything seems all\r\nright. 

I don\'t get it."\r\n\r\nJarvis, his dark eyes wary, scowled as he looked about. "It seems all\r\nright. 

But we know it isn\'t. 

It can\'t be."\r\n\r\n"I\'m shucking this suit."\r\n\r\n"Don\'t be a fool, Mark!"\r\n\r\n"But the dial read _clear_, man! And we know nobody is going to shoot\r\nus. All life _had_ to be wiped out.

"\r\n\r\n"How about minor power installations?"\r\n\r\nJarvis took a chocolate bar from his pocket, sat down on a piece of\r\nbroken rubble and began to eat. "You\'re too careless--far too careless,\r\nMark."\r\n\r\nMark laughed. "You\'ve always been cautious enough for both of us. Got me\r\nout of plenty of scrapes back in school, too. Don\'t think I\'ve\r\nforgotten." Affection warmed his blue eyes as they rested on the face of\r\nhis friend.\r\n\r\n"Okay! Okay! 

But what happened to them? 

Where did they go?" Jarvis took\r\nnervous bites from his second chocolate bar. Then he, too, peeled off\r\nhis suit. He sniffed the air distrustfully, as he wiggled his shoulders\r\nto free them from the clinging, damp shirt. Then he took a few\r\nexperimental steps forward.\r\n\r\n"Seems all right, Mark. But how do you explain about Hank and Garland?\r\nNever were two more careful guys."\r\n\r\n"Probably a simple miscalculation. Or an accident. We know it couldn\'t\r\nhave been enemy action. Tests prove conclusively that we wiped them\r\nout--to a man." He took deep gulps of air into his lungs, and stretched\r\nlike a cat. "We\'ll find out soon enough. 

Boy, I feel great!"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThey deflated and folded their safety suits and added the bundles to the\r\nother equipment on their backs. Then, with their instruments held before\r\nthem, they probed their way into the twisted wreckage, still following\r\nthe faint, dust-filled footprints.\r\n\r\nBent and rusted girders rose on all sides like the bones of prehistoric\r\nmonsters. Nothing stirred. The dust lay ages-thick on everything.\r\n\r\n"Gives you the spooks, doesn\'t it?" Jarvis was still tense, poised to\r\nrespond to the first signal of danger. "Feels like we\'re the last men\r\nalive!"\r\n\r\n"Funny about Hank and Garland. There\'s nothing here to harm anyone."\r\n\r\nJarvis looked at his watch. "Better contact HQ for instructions."\r\n\r\nThe two stepped off the path, into the shade of a grotesque chunk of\r\nbroken masonry. Mark set up the radio and twirled the dials. "Team Four,\r\ncalling HQ. Team Four, reporting!"\r\n\r\n"HQ here." The voice from the radio blared loud in the stillness. "Give\r\nyour report, Team Four."\r\n\r\n"Looks like nothing\'s moved here in a thousand years. Safe as a baby\'s\r\ndream. Rock-solid, air morning-pure. But--" He hesitated, trying not to\r\nsound like a scared school boy. "No sign of Team Three. Or of Teams One\r\nand Two, either. Over."\r\n\r\n"Look here, Team Four. It\'s your job to find out. The earth didn\'t just\r\nswallow them. Final report from each team placed them well within the\r\ncity. It\'s been ten days since the last contact. Probe every inch of the\r\nplace."\r\n\r\n"Right!"\r\n\r\n"But be careful. We can\'t afford to lose any more men! Roger!"\r\n\r\n"Roger!"\r\n\r\nThere was only one way now--ahead. It lay clearly marked. 

The dim\r\nfootsteps never strayed or faltered. Three hours of search revealed no\r\npitfalls, no dangers, and no trace of the missing men. Then night was\r\nupon them and they bedded down gratefully.\r\n\r\n"Strange, isn\'t it? The war over. The invaders blasted from the earth.\r\nAll peril gone. And yet--men disappear."\r\n\r\nJarvis stared at the ruins around them. "I can\'t take much more, Mark.\r\nTwelve years of war is enough. Are we never to have a life--have our\r\nhome and women back, and--_peace_?"\r\n\r\n"Sure, it\'s been tough. But think of the women and children isolated on\r\nthat sub-satellite. It\'s tougher for them--just waiting." Stretched on\r\nhis back, Mark stared at the cloudless, evening sky. "But pretty soon\r\nwe\'ll get this planet cleaned up and bring them in. Christ! Four years\r\nwithout even seeing a woman. I remember the last time--"\r\n\r\n"Okay!" Jarvis interrupted impatiently. "Let\'s get to sleep."\r\n\r\n"Sure, pal. Goodnight."\r\n\r\nThey fell asleep to dream of green hills, corn ripening, apples roasting\r\nover an open fire. Peace, and home, and girls, their firm legs flashing\r\nin the sun.\r\n\r\nSoldierlike, Mark was suddenly awake. He lay without motion, sensitive\r\nto some subtle change in the surroundings. From the corner of his eye he\r\ncould see Jarvis wrapped in sleep. The silence seemed eternal.\r\n\r\nThen, whisper-soft, came a murmur, a sound, a voice. A girl\'s voice,\r\nsighing and singing, from deep in that devastated spot.\r\n\r\nA woman!\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nInstantly, Mark was on his feet. No need to wake Jarvis. Plenty of time\r\nfor Jarvis to find out--afterwards. But not yet! A miracle that a girl\r\nhad survived in all that wreckage. But a miracle he wanted to savour\r\nalone!\r\n\r\nAhead, the path turned and Mark followed it as it went forward again,\r\ndownhill, between the massed walls of rubble. Now the voice swelled, a\r\nmelancholy song. Well, she won\'t be melancholy for long, Mark thought.\r\nHer solitary ordeal was over.\r\n\r\n"Mark!" Jarvis stood on an upturned lintel, ten feet above Mark\'s head.\r\nAs Mark jerked to a stop at the cry, Jarvis jumped into his path. "You\r\nfool! 

Don\'t you know it\'s a trap?"\r\n\r\n"So that\'s how you want to play it? The noble friend, protecting me from\r\nmyself!" He slammed a fist into the side of Jarvis\' head. "Well, I won\'t\r\nbite! 

She\'s mine! I found her!"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIn silence, in the narrow passage between the rocks, the two fought.\r\nSuddenly, above the sound of fist on flesh, came the voice of the girl\r\nagain, clear, young. "She _is_ there," thought Jarvis. He could almost\r\ntaste her lips on his. The sensation came as a shock. How did he know?\r\nHe\'d never had a woman. That\'s what came from listening to the tales of\r\nMark\'s exploits with women. Now he had to have that girl!\r\n\r\nThe mounting tension of the fighting snapped something in Jarvis\'\r\nseething mind. Danger, friendship, duty, all meant nothing. Only one\r\nthing mattered. The girl! Mark had had more than his share of girls. He,\r\nJarvis, was the one who should have her! He\'d been deprived of his\r\nmanhood long enough! His frenzied brain hunted a trick to gain his ends.\r\n\r\nMark\'s superior strength began to force Jarvis to give ground. Then a\r\nfinal blow sent him reeling, he reached out to break his fall, his hand\r\nclosed on a rock. He threw it. Mark crashed to the ground, his knee\r\nsmashed, his leg useless. Then the tomb stillness of the dead city took\r\nover. The dust settled slowly. Mark came to his feet.\r\n\r\nJarvis was gone.\r\n\r\nDragging his useless leg, Mark forced himself to crawl forward. Jarvis\r\nhad to be stopped.\r\n\r\nAhead, a shadow moved, and for a moment the moon threw the silhouette of\r\na man against a cavernous opening in the debris.\r\n\r\n"Jarvis!"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAn electric flash shattered the darkness. The jagged teeth of the bolt\r\nspit tongues of fire. Cordite mingled with the raw, nauseant, revolting\r\nsmell of scorched flesh and hair. The figure tottered and fell into the\r\nblack mouth of the cave. Then, as the flame faded, it lit up small\r\nbundles of charred bones near the fallen body.\r\n\r\nThere was a whir and a click of a mechanism. Fifteen feet away, Mark\r\nwatched as the arm of a phonograph rose, moved slowly back to the\r\nstarting point. Then the record began once more to grind out its\r\ndeath-trap melody.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Amazing Stories_ March 1954. ]\r\n\r\n\r\nIt is infinitely more satisfactory to purchase wives when they are\r\nyoung. They are vastly more respectful.\r\n\r\nTwelve is a good purchasing age. Lisa was twelve when I bargained for\r\nher, and she is an illustrious argument for the system.\r\n\r\nI recall her excellent father and I facing each other across his\r\ngleaming synthol marble table that day. On the table were small metal\r\nshells of sweet liquor. And beside the shells were the sedulously\r\ngathered treasures I was formally offering for Lisa: A control knob,\r\nand a folded painting of one of our Navigator\'s other-ship visions.\r\n\r\nLisa\'s father eagerly examined the mirror-bright, chrome surface\r\nof the control knob--which I had handed to him with a pretense of\r\ncasualness--trying to still the trembling of his fingers.\r\n\r\n"The last knob on the control board!" he said in an emotion-cracked\r\nvoice. 

"How could you have broken it off? We\'ve all been tugging at it\r\nfor years."\r\n\r\nI answered--I hope with no more than legitimate pride--"I managed to\r\nget a thin hacksaw blade between the knob and the control board. Then I\r\nsawed off the shaft."\r\n\r\nHe nodded approvingly. "With knuckle-headed men like you aboard ship we\r\nwill certainly all go to _Hell_."\r\n\r\nI bowed, but I did not let his flattery relax my caution. After all, we\r\nwere bargaining for his prettiest daughter. What flattering words bear\r\nweight in the midst of a sale? He, of course, referred to the ringing\r\nsincerity of our Navigator\'s dying words: "If you knuckle-heads all\r\nwant to go to _Hell_, just keep dismantling the ship!"\r\n\r\nSwinging adroitly to my other item of barter, I mused aloud, "Our\r\nNavigator! What a strange, frantic creature he was. Full of the wild,\r\nlovely visions which effervesced from his books of fantasy. Imploring\r\nus not only to read the books but to believe them--and, failing that,\r\ndrawing immortal paintings of the fantasies for us to see."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nTherewith I opened the folded painting and handed it reverently to him.\r\nIt showed a large globular ship with people living on the _outside_ of\r\nit. The title of the painting was _Planet_.\r\n\r\nPrivately I had always thought the thing was wholly unnatural--a\r\ncurious off-beat of the master\'s imagination. I was quite willing,\r\ndespite its great beauty and its origin, to exchange it for something\r\nwhich to me was far more attractive at the moment. Namely a woman.\r\n\r\nLisa lay curled up on the narrow, in-wall couch, with her head propped\r\nup by a slim arm. She chewed her synthel-gum lazily and surveyed me\r\nwith mild interest. 

She was a tender-featured girl, with shimmering\r\nblack, shoulder-length hair. It was possible to forecast that she would\r\nsome day be a lovely and gentle-hearted woman.\r\n\r\nHer father, notwithstanding his habitually rigid integrity, saw my\r\nlively interest in her and tried to increase my generous bid for her by\r\nan artifice of delay.\r\n\r\nHolding the painting of the master at arm\'s length, he grumbled\r\ncritically, "A vision of _Hell_ would have been more to my liking.\r\nUnhappily our Navigator did not paint one of his radiant visions of\r\nthat ship. Now, why would he prefer _Planet_ to _Hell_--particularly\r\nwhen he described _Hell_ as warm and enclosed like our own ship?"\r\n\r\nI did not answer his frivolous complaint, knowing full well it was only\r\nbartering talk.\r\n\r\nHe handled the immortal painting with crudely feigned indifference. He\r\ncould not quite bring himself to let go of it. He was determined to own\r\nit, I knew, and he sensed also my resolve to offer no more for Lisa.\r\nYet slyly he determined on an evil course.\r\n\r\nFor, incredibly, he turned to tranquil Lisa and asked: "What is your\r\nvalue, lovely child? Does he offer enough?"\r\n\r\nAnd slowly lifting her candid eyes to him she shook her head NO!\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Shall I bargain with _her_ then?" I asked my friend caustically. I\r\nwill own I was vexed.\r\n\r\nShrewdly he nodded. "Whatever she accepts will be our bargain." Then,\r\nlaughing at my undignified discomfiture, "It is manifest she is more\r\naware of her value than I."\r\n\r\n"Will you be serious? It is not kindly to banter with a woman-child in\r\nsuch an important matter as her future."\r\n\r\nBut greed now fully possessed him. "I do not joke. Whatever she demands\r\nshall be her price." He sipped his sweet wine, hiding his eyes from my\r\ndispleasure.\r\n\r\nConcealing my fury, I turned to Lisa, who now sat up straight on the\r\nnarrow couch with her long, slender legs folded under her. In the pace\r\nof grievous mortification I was not bitter toward her. 

It was not her\r\nfault. For her I extended the tolerance due the innocent.\r\n\r\n"What is your cost, child?" I asked. "This control knob and other-ship\r\nvision of our Navigator are sufficient to purchase any girl-woman. What\r\nwill you have?"\r\n\r\nLisa chewed her gum slowly while she formed her serene thought. Then,\r\nshaking her oval head, she let fall in a dreamy, singsong voice,\r\n"Neither of these! Neither of these!

"\r\n\r\nHer father leaned forward anxiously. I told her, "There is a limit to\r\nyour value. I will not give all of my treasures for you, lovely though\r\nyou are. Choose what thing you will have, and if I can procure it, your\r\nfather shall have it."\r\n\r\n"I\'ll know it when I see it!" she said, smiling impudently.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThere was nothing for me to do but go to my apartments and look for\r\nother treasures to show her. My thoughts were exceedingly bitter as I\r\ngathered the coveted articles one by one in my arms.\r\n\r\n"Here." I displayed it to her when I had arrived back at her father\'s\r\nabode. "It is the steering wheel from the lifeboat. Feel its smooth\r\ntexture, see its ebony luster. It is the only lifeboat steering wheel\r\naboard ship. I had a terrible struggle with it until I broke off the\r\nshaft.

"\r\n\r\nShe seemed interested. I passed hurriedly on to another object. "Here\r\nis the handle of the atomic-pile damping rod. It was threaded inside.\r\nHowever, I have managed to grind the interior smooth."\r\n\r\nShe seemed definitely interested, but I did not linger. 

I unrolled the\r\nlast treasure I had brought with me. At the sight of it her father\r\nburst into merry chuckles.\r\n\r\n"Yes," I said, smiling with a hint of sadness. "It is the inscrutable\r\nmessage we found protruding from the mouth of a machine some years ago.\r\nThe machine has the name Teletype engraved upon it. We cannot imagine\r\nwho put the message inside the machine--if indeed it is a message.\r\nBut listen to the poetry of its words! I shall read it to you as\r\nthough it were properly set out on paper instead of being cramped into\r\ncontinuous, senseless lines:\r\n\r\n    "Colony ship, colony ship,\r\n    Turn around before it is too late.\r\n    You have left the Galaxy.\r\n    We are the last planetary system\r\n    You will encounter,\r\n    For ten thousand years."\r\n\r\nThen, seeing her puzzlement, I said hastily, "But, of course, it is\r\ntoo adult for you, Lisa. Its mystery is for the scholar, its abstract\r\nbeauty for the man of mature years. Come, let us turn back to these\r\nother treasures...."\r\n\r\nIt was not easy for her to choose, seemingly, with so much wealth about\r\nher. The control knob, the painting, the lifeboat steering wheel, the\r\natomic-pile damping-rod handle, the inscrutable poetry--all claimed her\r\ninterest. But in the end she chose as I wanted her to, and the bargain\r\nwas struck.\r\n\r\nLisa went to live in the compartment of my concubines that day, and at\r\nmaturity became a concubine of exotic beauty. She bore her dark-haired\r\nchildren well.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBy the excellence of her father, he and I continued to be good friends.\r\nAt least once a year I invite him to view the master\'s painting of\r\n_Planet_. We spend many contented hours together. 

Often through a\r\nporthole we watch the rapid movement of distant ships which our\r\nNavigator called _stars_, revolving in tiny circles at the side of the\r\nship, making a complete circle in about two minutes. What prompts the\r\nbehavior of these ships? It is all very curious, and I account myself\r\nfortunate that I have in my friend an intense capacity for speculation.\r\nLike myself, he is a scholar of honor, capable of long sustained\r\ndiscourse on lofty subjects which round out and deepen the mind. I\r\nforgive him his greed.\r\n\r\nAs I had intended, Lisa took the teletype nonsense message to be\r\nher value to her father. May I reiterate, it is infinitely more\r\nsatisfactory to purchase wives when they are very young ladies? 

They\r\nare vastly more respectful. Admittedly they are saucy.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nOld Thak watched fondly as the new telescope was being put into its\r\nplace. He had been a long time persuading the elders to build this\r\ninstrument, a duplicate of the one destroyed in the latest great war.\r\nIt was as fine a telescope as Mars could produce, and only Thak\'s\r\nassurances that the work was of the greatest importance had secured\r\nhim this luxury.\r\n\r\nHis project must succeed, he felt, glancing at his students. Like him,\r\nthey were almost spherical in shape, with fine arm-like appendages\r\nringing their middles. They were young and enthusiastic, and Thak\r\nbelieved they could revive the science of astronomy. He, the last\r\nastronomer of Mars, would teach them all he knew.\r\n\r\nThe overseer of the workers was disgusted. "You waste our resources,\r\nThak," he declared. "You have taken two years of labor by dozens of\r\nworkers, and for what? So that you may look at the sky!"\r\n\r\nThak\'s tentacles purpled, a sign of irritation. "You military men!" 

he\r\nretorted. "It was your kind, Mitfpa, that destroyed our civilization\r\nand reduced our race to a few hungry thousands. You have ruined\r\nprogress and science forever. You have hastened the death of our race.\r\nUnless--"\r\n\r\nHe waved through the open doorway, pointing out the early evening sky.\r\nJust rising over the horizon was a blue body that was of a dazzling\r\nbrilliance, outshining all the other heavenly bodies. Thak\'s voice\r\nbecame emotional.\r\n\r\n"On that planet," he said, "are civilized beings. They hold the only\r\nhope for the salvation of our race. We must work to contact them, as\r\nlong as there is one of us to carry on!

"\r\n\r\n"What is this, Thak?" 

Mitfpa demanded angrily. "How can you say, old\r\none, that people of intelligence live on the blue planet? 

You will tell\r\nme next that you have been there!"\r\n\r\nThe soldier laughed scornfully, but Thak\'s voice was unruffled as he\r\nexplained. "This is no mere fancy of mine. 

These people have been\r\nsignalling to us for some time. And when I signalled back by creating\r\na network of space-warping lines through our entire power system, they\r\nstrengthened their signals. Then came your war--"\r\n\r\n"Space warps?" Mitfpa growled. "More power wasted? 

How was this\r\naccomplished?"\r\n\r\nThe workers were bolting the last legs of the telescope into position,\r\nand the students were making happy squeaks. Thak looked gratefully\r\ntoward his new instrument, and toward the scholars. A fine lot of young\r\nones, these. Perhaps, in them, astronomy would become once more a\r\nscience of great importance. Perhaps they would be the salvation of\r\nMars.\r\n\r\nHe answered Mitfpa\'s questions. "The power used was very small. You\r\nhave heard of controlled space warps?"\r\n\r\n"What about it?" grumbled the soldier.\r\n\r\n"An interesting laboratory trick. But it also occurs in nature.\r\nAs a youth I once saw the light of stars bent around the sun in a\r\nselector-scope; indeed, it was this very phenomenon that showed our\r\nscientists how to make their own warps."\r\n\r\n"Enough of your lecture, old one. What was the result of this\r\nscientific trickery?"\r\n\r\n"One as stupid as you would not understand the method," Thak replied\r\nlevelly, "but the result of warping all of our power beams was a\r\nnetwork of opaque lines that to an observer would be an obvious signal.\r\nAnd now, if you are quite ready to leave--?"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nGrumbling, Mitfpa departed, taking his soldier-worker with him. Thak\r\nchecked the placement of the telescope, finally nodding in satisfaction\r\nas he found everything in proper order. The four students crowded\r\naround, watching with interest. He gazed good-naturedly at them.\r\n\r\n"Our work is a great one," he declared. "We must communicate with\r\nthe third planet by means of a system of signals that we shall work\r\nout--in time. But there is so little time...." His tentacles curled\r\nthoughtfully about him. "You have followed the work of our last great\r\nphysicist, _Mor_ Gran?"\r\n\r\n"You mean," asked an alert youngster named Rofan, "the probability\r\ntables worked out by him? Showing that the end is near for our race?"\r\n\r\nThak nodded sadly. "Indeed, lad, the future appears dark. War and its\r\ndisorganization must inevitably strangle civilization. Even now our\r\nrace is thinned in numbers, and the beasts of the desert multiply."\r\n\r\n"There," he went on, waving toward the blue planet, "is our only hope.\r\nIf we can effect communication with them, and be guided by their\r\nsuperior wisdom, we may yet rally. They may have some secret--some way\r\nto prevent wars--"\r\n\r\n[Illustration: _"There!" Thak said. "There lies our only hope."_]\r\n\r\n"You continue to speak of their superior wisdom, _Mor_ Thak," said\r\nRofan. "How can you be so very sure of that?

"\r\n\r\n"It is obvious, lad. Their signal system consists of spots of light\r\nover the greater part of the land surface of their planet. I have shown\r\nyou the old photographs, taken before the last war, showing these\r\nlights. Even with the small telescope I have been forced to use during\r\nthese lean years, I have watched the lights. What a mighty science\r\ntheirs must be that can make the night time light merely to signal\r\nanother planet! For that can be the only purpose of the lights."\r\n\r\nRofan let his tentacles curl about him as he concentrated. "You must be\r\nright," he finally agreed. "I was going to suggest that they might be\r\nthe lights of cities. I noticed many of them were situated where a city\r\nwould be likely--but there must be millions of beings to populate so\r\nmany cities--"\r\n\r\nOne of the other pupils made a loud amused noise. "Whoever heard of\r\na city without a roof?" he demanded. "Could lights be seen through a\r\nroof?"\r\n\r\nRofan was embarrassed, and he remained very quiet for a while,\r\nwondering how he could have made such a stupid error. Of course lights\r\ncould not be seen through a roof. And who had ever heard of a city\r\nwithout a roof!\r\n\r\nThak, paying no attention to the byplay, focused his lens with great\r\ncare. The students gathered about the concave bowl of white quartz.\r\nThe lights were lowered, and into the bowl moved a blurred sphere. As\r\nThak\'s tentacles moved the lenses closer and closer into focus, the\r\nsphere resolved itself with more and more clarity, until it was a fine\r\nimage of the third planet.\r\n\r\nAwed by the splendor of the sight, the students could only stare. And\r\nindeed it was a breathtaking spectacle, as if they were gathered in the\r\nimmense void of space itself, looking at the planet from a height of\r\nseveral thousand miles.\r\n\r\nThere were five continents in two major land masses, Thak had told\r\nthem. In addition, there were several islands of great size, at last\r\none being practically of continental dimensions, besides a host of\r\nislands large and small which dotted the surface of the planet.\r\n\r\nThe hemisphere on which they gazed was mostly water. The larger land\r\nmass was passing from sight. And half of the smaller mass was presented\r\nto their vision, a double continent that spread almost from pole to\r\npole, with a narrow isthmus joining north and south.\r\n\r\nLike all Martians, they thrilled to a scene of fearful beauty, and they\r\nstood around the quartz bowl for a long time, not speaking, merely\r\nwatching the twin continents come into full view. None noticed old\r\nThak\'s eyes peering desperately at the image of the third planet. 

Nor\r\ndid they see the look of utter despair that grew in his face. They were\r\ntoo intent on the strange scene.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIt was Rofan who first felt that something was wrong. The novelty was\r\nwearing off, and an elusive thought made him uncomfortable. Something\r\nwas wrong with the picture ... what was it?\r\n\r\nSuddenly he realized. He turned to Thak. "But--the lights, _Mor_ Thak?\r\nThe signals--"\r\n\r\nThak\'s face looked as old as Mars itself as he gazed at his pupil. He\r\nstarted to speak several times before he could manage.\r\n\r\n"We have failed," he said, in heavy tones. "Our signals must have been\r\ntoo weak for the beings of the blue planet to detect. I had hoped--"\r\n\r\nHe arose and looked sadly into the evening sky. "I had hoped I was\r\nwrong. For two years now--our years--I have watched through my\r\nsmall telescope, and the lights have been disappearing, one by one,\r\nsometimes, but more often several at a time. I thought it was the\r\nweakness of my instrument. 

I was wrong. Every light on the blue planet\r\nhas been blacked out..."\r\n\r\nHis voice was a low wail. "_And--the blacking out of those lights means\r\na blackout of life on Mars. A planet-wide blackout...._"\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nThe grizzled old space veteran leaned back in his chair and stared up\r\nthrough the transparent dome. In the black sky myriad white specks\r\ngleamed without twinkling, their light unbent by atmosphere or dust.\r\nThe steady pulse of the airmakers kept rhythm with the heartbeats of\r\nthe young men seated in a semi-circle, listening with glistening eyes\r\nto these ancient tales of an Earth they\'d never seen--the home of their\r\nspecies.\r\n\r\nThey stared hungrily at the old man\'s face. There was a silvery spot on\r\nthe chin where Venusian fungus had nearly gotten into his bloodstream\r\nand had had to be burned away. Over one eye an eyebrow was gone,\r\nreplaced by scar tissue grown on a planet at the other end of the\r\ngalaxy where the light of enormous fireflies wasn\'t cold, as on ancient\r\nearth, but searing with heat.\r\n\r\n"Imagine," they marveled, "such weak flame in fireflies."\r\n\r\n"Not weak," corrected the old man. "Just different. Those insects on\r\nEarth didn\'t have to fight off intense cold. They had a much thicker\r\natmosphere and were close to the sun. And they didn\'t feed on alcohol."\r\n\r\nThe young men\'s eyes glittered. They were an odd group. Small--most of\r\nthem, none over five feet five inches--and pale, unlike the old man\r\nwho was bulky around the shoulders and had skin virtually leathered by\r\nvarious radiations and temperatures and winds.\r\n\r\nEach day this group waited hungrily for the old man to come and talk to\r\nthem. The stories he told were the breath of life to them. And of all\r\nthe tales of adventures in the far ends of the universe, the one that\r\nwas most repeatedly called for was the story of what had happened to\r\nEarth.\r\n\r\n"Tell us about Earth," said one of them, now, in a low voice.\r\n\r\n"About how great we were?" said the old man. "About what love was like?\r\nAbout homes and children and how a man went to work in the morning at\r\ntasks of his own choosing? Or...."\r\n\r\n"No. About what happened. 

You know. 

At the finish."\r\n\r\nThe old man looked up again. His eyes were dreamy.\r\n\r\n"Earth," he said, softly. "Earth. I\'ve been through the galaxies these\r\nlast forty years and I\'ve seen planets by the thousand. And there never\r\nwas one like Earth."\r\n\r\n"Tell us," they said, each in urgent, differing words, but all with the\r\nsame tortured look. "Tell us about what went wrong."\r\n\r\n"I\'ve told you that a hundred times," he said.\r\n\r\nBut they wanted it again. Like a man who relives an incident to examine\r\neach moment with incredulity, as if in hope that it will fade and not\r\nhave happened, as if in unconscious attempt to move sideways from that\r\npoint into another time stream probability where a different course of\r\naction will be true.\r\n\r\n"All right," said the old man.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe first they had heard of the strangers from outer space was when\r\nthe new ultra short-wave frequencies were used. Professor Kennicot of\r\nPalmira University was the first to find how to generate and control\r\nthem. He tried to transform the wavelengths upward to a range either\r\nauditory or visual but for some reason power was lost in the process.\r\n\r\nApparently he gave them a sufficient jolt with extra voltage, however,\r\nbecause they were picked up by the strangers in outer space as a\r\nsignal. The heaviside layer did not stop these wavelengths.\r\n\r\nProfessor Kennicot was startled one day when he heard, or thought he\r\nheard, a soundless voice in his mind. It said:\r\n\r\n"Interesting. We didn\'t know there was life on your planet or in your\r\nsolar system."\r\n\r\nProfessor Kennicot shook his head and looked around. Nobody was in the\r\nlaboratory.\r\n\r\n"Of course," said the voice, "We detected atomic radiations from the\r\narea, but Zeetal thought it might come from your sun. Tell us, please,\r\nare you a Grade Three society?"\r\n\r\n"My God," muttered Professor Kennicot. "I\'m having hallucinations."\r\n\r\n"There seems to be some difficulty establishing telepathic\r\ncommunication," came the puzzled thought. And then, after a pause,\r\n"Could it be we\'re in communication with creatures of zero grade?"\r\n\r\nAnother thought from elsewhere answered, and yet Professor Kennicot,\r\nsomewhat, was tuned in: "Impossible. The signal picked up was very\r\nclose to telepathic frequency."\r\n\r\nIt wasn\'t until two days later that Professor Kennicot discovered that\r\nhe wasn\'t the only one who had experienced the auditory hallucination.\r\nThe entire college was babbling about how Professor Johnson had come\r\nrunning out of the Chemistry Lab, which was two doors away from\r\nPhysics, holding his head and babbling nonsense.\r\n\r\nProfessor Kennicot made a beeline for the hospital and had a quiet\r\ndiscussion with Professor Johnson, a discussion which is now historic.\r\nThey discovered that not only were both their I.Q.s over one hundred\r\nand eighty, but that both of them, sitting together discussing the\r\nmatter, were simultaneously getting new messages which nobody around\r\nthem was receiving.\r\n\r\nIt wasn\'t long after that, of course, that many of the most brilliant\r\nmen on Earth were reporting the same hallucinations, and as news of\r\nit spread it became obvious that not all could be insane in exactly\r\nthe same way with the same thoughts. Excitement and puzzlement ran\r\ntremendously high because, although these intellects of Earth could\r\nreceive telepathic messages, they were not advanced enough to send.\r\nThey only knew what was being messaged to them; and this continued to\r\nbe so until feverishly working physicists pinned down the telepathic\r\nwavelength mechanically. That was when conversations were begun and\r\nthe entire Earth was able to listen in, by translation and regular\r\nbroadcast.\r\n\r\nThe discussions did not go well. The beings from outer space would not\r\nanswer questions. They only asked. The first thing, apparently, that\r\nmade them cautious, was the first official question from Earth.\r\n\r\n"How is it that we understand your thought even though many of our\r\nscientists speak different languages?"\r\n\r\nThe whole world awaited the first answer. 

None came. 

There was a\r\nsilence lasting four hours. Then came a message:\r\n\r\n"Your question indicates you may be a low grade of developed life.\r\nWe shall investigate and fit you into our needs according to your\r\ncapabilities."\r\n\r\nA thrill of horror went around the world. What kind of monsters were\r\nthese? What would they do? The uproar that ensued was full of frantic\r\nmilitary preparations. Bombs were readied in the atomic planes, rockets\r\nwere raised in their cradles adjustable to any orbit. Unfortunately,\r\nnobody thought to conceal this, and some fool had failed to shut\r\noff the telepathic wavelength. One morning the world awoke to a\r\nnon-electrical society in which nothing electrical would work.\r\n\r\n"We have put a field of force around your planet," came the message.\r\n"There must be no violence. Be not afraid. 

We come as friends. We will\r\nappear now and investigate. 

Be calm."\r\n\r\nThe leaders of each nation spoke to their people, and the world waited\r\nin tense silence. One day an enormous sphere appeared and landed. The\r\ncreatures that emerged couldn\'t be clearly discerned because they were\r\nin space-suits which gave them comfortable air-pressures and what was\r\nto them breathable atmosphere. They were four-legged creatures but\r\ncould walk on two, if necessary.\r\n\r\nA delegation of picked dignitaries started to show them our world, our\r\ncustoms, the way we dressed, what we lived in, what we ate. Almost\r\nimmediately the strangers turned and left our world.\r\n\r\nWithin two days Earth was in bondage.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe old space veteran stopped. He looked around at the tense faces.\r\n\r\n"We found out later," he said. 

"It was the banquet they watched on a\r\nfilm which we ran off, that did it. There was a scene where a waiter\r\nbrings in a whole roast pig with an apple in its mouth and then it\'s\r\neaten."\r\n\r\nAll the boys drew a deep horrified breath. The old man nodded heavily.\r\n"Well," he said, "how were we to know these beings from outer space had\r\nevolved from pigs, or creatures very similar?" He sighed, and stood\r\nup. "Well, maybe in fifty years they\'ll feel we\'re advanced enough for\r\nfreedom." He smiled. "I\'ll leave you to your telepathy classes and\r\nconditioning."\r\n\r\nHe moved toward the door and a portion of glass wall slid aside to let\r\nhim through. 

But before he exited he turned and said softly, "Now don\'t\r\nlet it get you, boys. Being exhibited in a zoo isn\'t too bad. Serve\r\nyour time and you\'ll get servant status like me and get out into space."\r\n\r\nHe waved and walked out through the spectators gathered around the\r\nglass cage. They moved aside to let him through, staring at him with\r\nbrilliant brown eyes, their snoutlike noses twitching in sympathy and\r\nkindness, their pig-like faces gentle with the expression a man gives a\r\ntrained dog.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nAlone within the humming ship, deep in its honeycombed metal chambers,\r\nMurdock waited for death. While the rocket moved inexorably toward\r\nEarth--an immense silver needle threading the dark fabric of space--he\r\nwaited calmly through the final hours, knowing that the verdict was\r\nabsolute, that hope no longer existed.\r\n\r\nElectronically self-sufficient, the ship was doing its job perfectly,\r\nthe job it had been built to do. After twenty years in space, the ship\r\nwas taking Robert Murdock home.\r\n\r\nHome. Earth. Thayerville, a small town in Kansas. Clean air, a shaded\r\nstreet, and a white, two-story house at the end of the block.\r\nHome--after two decades among the stars.\r\n\r\nSitting quietly before the round port, seeing and not seeing the\r\nendless darkness surrounding him, Murdock was remembering.\r\n\r\nHe remembered the worried face of his mother, her whispered prayers for\r\nhis safety as he mounted the rocket ramp those twenty years ago; he\r\ncould still feel the final, crushing handshake of his father moments\r\nbefore the outer airlock slid closed. His mother had been 55 then, his\r\nfather 63. It was almost impossible to believe that they were now old\r\nand white-haired.\r\n\r\nAnd what of himself?\r\n\r\nHe was now 41, and space had weathered him as the plains of Kansas\r\nhad weathered his father. He, too, had labored as his father had\r\nlabored--but on strange, alien worlds, under suns far hotter than Sol.\r\nMurdock\'s face was square and hard-featured, his eyes dark and deep\r\nunder thrusting ledges of bone. He had changed as they had changed.\r\n\r\nHe was a stranger going home to strangers.\r\n\r\nCarefully, Murdock unfolded his mother\'s last letter, written in her\r\nflowery, archaic hand, and received just before Earth take-off.\r\n\r\n    _Dearest Bob,_\r\n\r\n    _Oh, we are so excited! Your father and I listened to your voice\r\n    on the tape over and over, telling us that you are coming home to\r\n    us at last. We are both so eager to see you, son. As you know, we\r\n    have not been too well of late. Your father\'s heart does not allow\r\n    him out much any more, and I have had a few fainting spells over\r\n    the past month. But Doctor Thom says that we are all right, and you\r\n    are_ not _to worry. Just hurry home to us, Bob. We both pray\r\n    God you will come back safely._\r\n\r\n                                                         _All our love,\r\n                                                                Mother_\r\n\r\nRobert Murdock put the letter aside and clenched his fists. Only brief\r\nhours remained to him, and the small Kansas town of Thayerville was an\r\nimpossible distance across space. He knew he would never reach it alive.\r\n\r\nThe lines of an ancient poem by Robert Frost whispered through his mind:\r\n\r\n    But I have promises to keep,\r\n    And miles to go before I sleep\r\n\r\nHe had promised his parents that he would come home--and he meant to\r\nkeep that promise.\r\n\r\nThe doctors had shown him that it was impossible. They had charted his\r\ndeath; they had told him when his heart would stop beating, when his\r\nbreathing would cease. Death, for Robert Murdock, was a certainty. His\r\nalien disease was incurable.\r\n\r\nBut they had listened to his plan. They had listened, and agreed.\r\n\r\nNow, with less than a half-hour of life remaining, Murdock was walking\r\ndown one of the ship\'s long corridors, his boot-heels ringing on the\r\nnarrow metal walkway.\r\n\r\nHe was ready, at last, to keep his promise.\r\n\r\nMurdock paused before a wall storage locker, twisted a small dial.\r\nA door slid smoothly back. He looked up at the tall man standing\r\nmotionless in the darkness. Reaching forward, Murdock made a quick\r\nadjustment.\r\n\r\nThe tall man stepped down into the corridor, and the light flashed in\r\nhis deep-set eyes, almost hidden behind thrusting ledges of bone. The\r\nman\'s face was hard and square-featured.\r\n\r\n"My name is Robert Murdock," said the tall figure in the neat patrol\r\nuniform. "I am 41 years of age, a rocket pilot going home to Earth." He\r\npaused. 

"And I am sound of mind and body."\r\n\r\nMurdock nodded slowly. "Indeed you are," he said.\r\n\r\n"How much longer do you have, sir?"\r\n\r\n"Another ten minutes. Perhaps a few seconds beyond that," replied\r\nMurdock.\r\n\r\n"I--I\'m sorry," said the tall figure.\r\n\r\nMurdock smiled. He knew that a machine, however perfect, could not\r\nexperience the emotion of sorrow, but it eased him to hear the words.\r\n\r\nYou will be fine, he thought. You will serve well in my place and my\r\nparents will never suspect that their son has not come home to them.\r\n\r\n"It must all be perfect," said Murdock.\r\n\r\n"Of course," said the machine. "\r\n\r\nYes, Murdock told himself, it _will_ go well; every detail has been\r\nconsidered. My voice is his voice, my habits his own. The tapes I have\r\npre-recorded will continue to reach them at specified intervals until\r\ntheir death. They will never know I\'m gone.\r\n\r\n"Are you ready now, sir?" the tall figure asked gently.\r\n\r\nMurdock drew in his breath. 

"Yes," he said, "I\'m ready now."\r\n\r\nAnd they began to walk down the long corridor.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nMurdock remembered how proud his parents had been when he was finally\r\naccepted for Space Training--the only boy in Thayerville to be chosen.\r\nBut then, it was only right that he should have been the one. The other\r\nboys, those who failed, had not _lived_ the dream as he had lived it.\r\nFrom the moment he\'d watched the first moon rocket land he had known,\r\nbeyond any possible doubt, that he would become a rocketman. "I _still_ don\'t think it\'s\r\nright somehow. 

It just doesn\'t seem right to me."\r\n\r\n"It\'s what they wanted, isn\'t it?" asked the other. "It\'s what they\r\nwrote in their wills. They vowed their son would never come home to\r\ndeath. In another month he\'ll be gone anyway. 

Back for another twenty\r\nyears. 

Why ruin it all for him?" The man paused, shading his eyes\r\nagainst the sun. "And they _are_ perfect, aren\'t they? He\'ll never\r\nknow."\r\n\r\n"I suppose you\'re right," nodded the second man. 

"He\'ll never know."\r\n\r\nAnd he watched the old man and the old woman and the tall son until\r\nthey were out of sight.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


Vaguely, he could sense--"remember" was too\r\ndefinite--much tugging and hauling upon his supine body. It doubtless\r\nseemed justifiable, but he flinched from recalling more clearly that\r\nwhich must have been so extremely unpleasant.\r\n\r\nGently, now, he tried rolling his head a few inches right, then left.\r\nWhen it hurt only one-tenth as much as he feared, he let his eyes\r\nopen.\r\n\r\n"Hel-lo!" rasped the bulbous creature squatting beside his pallet.\r\n\r\nCharlie shut his eyes quickly, and very tightly.\r\n\r\nSomething with a dampish, spongy tip, probably one of the grape-red\r\ntentacles he had glimpsed, prodded his shoulder.\r\n\r\n"_Hel-lo!_" insisted the scratchy voice.\r\n\r\nCharlie peeped warily, was trapped at it, and opened his eyes\r\nresignedly.\r\n\r\n"Where\'n\'ell am I?" he inquired.\r\n\r\nIt sounded very trite, even in his confused condition. Everything seemed\r\nto be in place.\r\n\r\nHe lay in a small room, on a thin pallet of furs. Look again, Earthman!"\r\n\r\n_Earthman!_ thought Charlie. _It must be real: I can still see him.\r\nWhat a whack on the head I must have got!_\r\n\r\n"You are in pain?" asked the creature solicitously.\r\n\r\n"Oh ... no. 

Just ... I can\'t remember. The crash ... and then--"\r\n\r\n"Ah, yes. You have not been conscious for some time." ]\r\n\r\n\r\nThe subway train announced its arrival with a screech of grating steel.\r\nThe man was shoved from the car onto the platform by the eight p.m.\r\ncrowd. The noise and the abrupt handling of his body brought him to\r\nawareness.\r\n\r\nNot that he had been asleep or unconscious. 

Although he might have\r\nbeen. He didn\'t know for sure.\r\n\r\nHe found it hard to concentrate, but soon a sign over the platform came\r\ninto focus:\r\n\r\n                               WESTBORO\r\n\r\nIt meant nothing to him. The second thing he became aware of did.\r\n\r\nAnother train had replaced his, and directly in front of him was\r\nan army of people, dispassionate towards everything but its one\r\nobjective--to get on.\r\n\r\nThey came at him all at once, forming a pushing, elbowing, cursing,\r\njarring mass of humanity. He glanced off one to collide with another.\r\nHe escaped the punishment by a lunge to one side which ended with a\r\ncrash to the cold cement floor.\r\n\r\nHe regained some semblance of steadiness on his feet and looked at the\r\nsign. It was still Westboro. It still meant nothing to him.\r\n\r\nHe was lost.\r\n\r\nWhat was worse, he couldn\'t remember where he was lost _from_.\r\n\r\nHe turned to walk, he didn\'t know exactly where, when he smashed into a\r\nlittle boy eating an apple.\r\n\r\nThe boy reacted in a strange manner.\r\n\r\n"Leave me alone, you dirty man, you," the boy said. Somebody must have taken it, or he might\r\nhave lost it. In that crowd or on the subway or before.... ]\r\n\r\n\r\nZurg thwirmed, and admitted to himself that he was uneasy. Arching his\r\nthorax, he unrolled his antennae slowly in a lazy gesture he hoped\r\nwould conceal the unseemly nervousness he felt now that the ship had\r\nswung into an orbit around the strange planet. When a commander briefs\r\nhis officers, he must radiate confidence and calm.\r\n\r\n"Companions, an historic moment has arrived," he began pompously, his\r\nantennae moving in the deliberate, stylized movements of the Court\r\nlanguage. "Below us lies the verdant expanse of the third planet, green\r\ngem of the heavens."\r\n\r\nAt this, several of his subordinates turned a rather puzzled yellow\r\naround their head orifices, obviously unable to understand a gesture\r\nof what he was saying. Only the second-in-command seemed unconcerned;\r\nhe knew from long experience that his commander would revert to common\r\nvernacular when he had finished the usual ceremonial preamble.\r\n\r\nZurg did so, noting the relieved hues of his officers as he continued:\r\n"As you all know, our scouts have reconnoitered this world on several\r\noccasions. But now the time has arrived to make an actual landing. In\r\nfact, companions, we are the vanguard of an invasion." 

Pausing to let\r\nthis register, he was pleased to see that none of the officers seemed\r\nto be suppressing thwirms. If anything, they were calmer than he was.\r\n\r\n"Not a great deal is known about the inhabitants of the planet,\r\nbut the dominant form of life, strangely enough, is mammalian, and\r\npossesses some intelligence. Her Majesty desires conquest without undue\r\ndestruction. 

As the Queen wills, her servants shall act."\r\n\r\nAll dipped their antennae at this formula, and watched in attentive\r\nhues as the commander went on to explain that due to the high\r\npercentage of oxygen in the atmosphere, special coverings would have\r\nto be worn. They would filter the air before it reached the ventral\r\ntracheae, and leaving the head exposed, would shield all the rest\r\nof the body. A bit clumsy, the commander admitted, but absolutely\r\nessential.\r\n\r\n"Now as to our behavior toward the natives--previous experience with\r\nmammalian life-types shows that they are susceptible to panic and fear\r\nwhen confronted with something totally strange, so we will use tactics\r\nwhich basically are very simple. First, we will land near a native\r\nsettlement. When we march into the area, our alien appearance will stun\r\nthe natives. Our detachment of all-range telepathic sensitives will\r\nnotify us when the state of shock has set in, then our attack support\r\nwill open up with full-scale mental assault, and keep the creatures\r\nparalyzed while we seize the area before a defense can be organized.\r\nThen the Grand Fleet will proceed here at top speed."\r\n\r\n"Remember that in this, as in all operations where the powers of the\r\ncollective mind are used, we must first trigger the enemy\'s reaction by\r\nphysical means, therefore nothing can be done until we _know_ that they\r\nare in the needed state of shock. Now are there any questions?"\r\n\r\nHow strange actually, mused the commander as he returned to his\r\ncubicle, that a race like his own, so gifted at pure mental contact\r\nwith other life-forms, should still use signals and colorations to\r\ncommunicate among themselves. The chafed spot on his left antenna was\r\npaining again after the exercise of the briefing. The report had said\r\nthat these mammalians were believed to converse through some kind\r\nof atmospheric vibrations.... Odd too, that mental warfare, refined\r\nand developed though it was, could still only be used against minds\r\nagitated by a specific physical stimulus. And that physical stimulus\r\nhad to be provided by the invaders appearing on the scene, and if\r\nnecessary performing the Dra, a series of dances and contortions so\r\nrepulsive to most life-forms that all thinking would fade into panic.\r\nHaving once thwirmed himself at a performance of the Dra, he hoped it\r\nwouldn\'t be necessary ... his musings were interrupted as the ship\'s\r\nlights flickered to orange, signalling hands to stations for planetfall.\r\n\r\nLeaving the con of the ship to his second-in-command, he shut himself\r\nin his cubicle and made preparations to be miserably sick, as he always\r\nwas during deceleration. Stroking the chafed spot on his antenna with\r\nthe smooth edge of his left forearm\'s prehensile claw, Zurg raised his\r\nmedicine kit in his secondary tentacles and snapped off the heavy lead\r\nseal with his jagged incisor mandibles. I wonder, he speculated, why\r\nalien races always find us so frightening....\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe brilliant orange sun was high in the sky, but only a few filtered\r\nbeams penetrated to the sheltered copse where the slate-colored ship\r\nlay partially concealed by artfully placed vines and underbrush. Drawn\r\nup in three ranks beside the ship, only their heads protruding from\r\nthe loose-fitting coveralls, stood the detail picked to make the entry\r\ninto the native settlement. 

Zurg led them out through the underbrush\r\nbarrier they had thrown up the night before, and they emerged onto\r\na little-traveled dirt road leading off across the fields toward a\r\ncluster of buildings that marked the edge of town.\r\n\r\nNo creatures appeared as the invading column lumbered along. As they\r\nneared the edge of the settlement, Zurg, his antennae drooping slightly\r\nfrom the unusual heat, turned to remind the others: "Remember, the\r\nmental assault won\'t begin until we are well into the area and shock\r\nreaction is effected, so _stay in formation_ until I order otherwise."\r\n\r\nThere were still no natives in sight on the small side street by which\r\nthey entered town; but as they turned a corner and swung on to the\r\nbroad central thoroughfare, the commander saw that the street was\r\nclogged with natives, a great milling mass of them moving up the\r\nstreet in the same direction as his column, about a hundred yards ahead.\r\n\r\nFor a moment they didn\'t appear to notice the newcomers, but soon a\r\ngrowing number had turned and were gesturing excitedly to each other,\r\npointing at the approaching troop. Watching them anxiously, Zurg saw no\r\nevidence of panic.\r\n\r\nThe column kept moving, and the crowd began parting to let them pass\r\nthrough. Some darted forward as though to get a closer look at the\r\nstrangers. The commander fought off a thwirm as he realized the crowd\r\nwas now all around them, pressing in more closely on every side. The\r\natmosphere itself seemed to vibrate strangely, and looking around, he\r\nsaw that the creatures were opening small head orifices and striking\r\nthe ends of their forward limbs together. Were they communicating--or\r\nwas it something else? Colors were flushing their faces in meaningless successions.\r\nOne or two seemed to be staggering. The shock threshold of these beings\r\nhas been horribly underestimated, thought Zurg desperately. Only one\r\nthing left to do--turning again, he signalled the detail to begin the\r\nDra. Perhaps that would overcome this incomprehensible counterattack....\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"I tell you Charlie, you\'ve got to discipline that gang! Then they all reeled off\r\ninto a side street. They must have been drunk to a man--I understand\r\nabout half of them had to be carried! _And_ when I confronted Andy\r\nSharpe, he swore up and down that they weren\'t out of their hotel that\r\nmorning. 

All sleeping off that spree they had the night before. We\'re even getting\r\ncredit for having a flying saucer. Some farmer out at the edge of town\r\nclaims he saw one take off after the parade last night. ]\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was the hour before dawn. In the middle of the night the big ship\r\nhad landed on the new planet, the satellite of the sun Proxima. Now\r\nthey sat in the dark waiting, and they talked.\r\n\r\n"I wish we hadn\'t killed them," Rossiter said softly. His profile was\r\nfaintly visible against the diffused light of the stars. "It\'s a bad\r\nsign, a bad start for a new life."\r\n\r\n"They attacked us," Bernard answered quickly.\r\n\r\n"Two spears, against forty blasters and stun guns?" Rossiter laughed.\r\n"An attack! We should have met them with stunners at low charge. 

But\r\nMcNess ordered us to blast. The woman and the baby stick in my craw."\r\n\r\n"All our nerves were on edge," Bernard answered thoughtfully. "I know I\r\nwas afraid when we first stepped out of the ship. There was something\r\nterrifying about air, and space, and the sky. 

But you\'re right, of\r\ncourse. We shouldn\'t have been ordered to blast." He was shivering.\r\n\r\n"You could go back inside the ship," Bernard said half-humorously.\r\n\r\n"I\'m sick of the _Elpis_. We all are. 

Eight years of it--it\'s too much.\r\nWe\'ll get used to the wind, I suppose. There\'s going to be lots of\r\nwind, with so much water and only this one land mass on our new world.\r\nIt\'s not like Earth."\r\n\r\nBernard made an involuntary movement. Then he relaxed. "I suppose the\r\ntaboo is lifted now that we\'ve landed," he said heavily. "We can talk\r\nabout Earth again, and wonder, and speculate. This was not strange because they\r\nquarreled often. But it bothered him after he\'d called for his car and\r\nwas on the way to his office, he realized she was the only one left.\r\n\r\nThe realization came suddenly and now he was frightened--this strange\r\nman who needed friends as a spider needs flies--in order to survive.\r\nHis wealth had drawn them of course; a fact he refused to believe.\r\nBut even unlimited resources could not hold them and insult and abuse\r\ndrove them all finally away. Because that was the kind of man he was.\r\n\r\nUntil now they were all gone, the dear ones, the relatives, even the\r\nfawners and he realized in panic that only Dolores was left.\r\n\r\n_But she will stay. She had\r\neverything. Another diamond necklace? Another ruby ring? Somehow he\r\nfelt neither would do the trick this time. The quarrel had been very\r\nbitter.\r\n\r\nThen he remembered and smiled and told his chauffeur, "There is a store\r\nI noticed in the International Building. Kamiss and Company. Mr. Billions\r\nhimself! If he could get him on the customer list it would be a\r\ntremendous prestige boost. "Indeed we have, sir.

Potted palms and formal chairs reminded one of a\r\nHuman Disposal unit.\r\n\r\n"I have a confession to make, darling," he said.\r\n\r\n"Oh, no, Howard. Not now.
