Now we\'ll probably\r\nhave to wait hours in this perfectly dismal place."\r\n\r\nShe looked as young and fresh as he looked old and dusty, he thought,\r\nso out of place in this kind of establishment.\r\n\r\nHe had always loved small women. Leah was small and vivacious and\r\ndressed a year ahead of styles. No matter what happened, he\'d never\r\nregret having married her.\r\n\r\n"But this is something I should have told you before," he said.\r\n\r\nShe put her hand on his arm. "I\'ve been perfectly happy these past six\r\nmonths. Whatever it was, I forgive you.

"\r\n\r\n"It\'s not that. I\'m talking about my age. I didn\'t think you\'d marry\r\nme if you knew how old I really was. I put off telling you and figured\r\nyou\'d see my birth certificate at the wedding ceremony."\r\n\r\n"I never even looked at the silly old thing."\r\n\r\n"Well, darling, I looked at yours and felt a little guilty in marrying\r\na young girl of twenty-three. But the fact is I\'m sixty-five. I\'ve been\r\nrejuvenated before."\r\n\r\n"I rather suspected it when you started aging so suddenly last week,"\r\nshe said. "Before that you didn\'t look a day over thirty. But it\r\ndoesn\'t matter."\r\n\r\n"It\'s worse than that, Leah." His face worked convulsively. "I\'ve been\r\nhere twice before. This is my third trip."\r\n\r\n"I\'m too modern to act shocked, Howard. If you didn\'t want to tell me\r\nbefore, dear, it\'s perfectly all right."\r\n\r\n"Look, darling!" Perspiration stood on his forehead. "You don\'t seem\r\nto understand. But then you never could add or subtract. 

Now listen\r\ncarefully. Each trip clips five years off your life span."\r\n\r\n"Everyone knows that, of course. But it\'s better to be young...."\r\n\r\n"It\'s better to be alive than dead," he said harshly.\r\n\r\n"But your doctors have given you a longevity span to the age of\r\nninety."\r\n\r\n"Suppose it was eighty, instead of ninety?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, dear, you worry too much," she said. "Doctors don\'t make such\r\nmistakes."\r\n\r\n"They can\'t give me a guarantee. You see, three of my ancestors\r\ndied from accidents. The prediction of ninety years is based on the\r\nassumption that they would have lived a normal life-time."\r\n\r\n"They make few guarantees. You know, all of you men are such babies at\r\na time like this."\r\n\r\n"Yes, but if it _is_ eighty--then, I\'ll come out not a rejuvenated man,\r\nbut just a handful of dust."\r\n\r\n"Oh, that can\'t happen."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Look at it this way." He paused a moment while taking in her youthful\r\nappearance. "From now on I wouldn\'t look much older. Just a little\r\ngrayer and perhaps more stooped. Then, I\'ll have what\'s left of my\r\nlongevity plus the five years this rejuvenation would clip off."\r\n\r\n"Why, Howard, dear." Leah sounded shocked. 

"You don\'t know what you\'re\r\ntalking about. An aunt of mine elected that choice and it was perfectly\r\nhorrible. She drooled the last few years of her life and was helpless\r\nas a baby."\r\n\r\n"Why didn\'t they use Euthanasia?" he asked.\r\n\r\n"The courts decided she wasn\'t capable of making a rational decision."\r\n\r\nHe wiped his forehead. "That would be a long time off, darling. We\'d\r\nhave so much time together in the next fifteen years."\r\n\r\n"But what would it be like if you were crippled with arthritis or some\r\nother disease?"\r\n\r\n"You could divorce me if that happens."\r\n\r\n"I can also divorce you if you don\'t go through with rejuvenation. You\r\nknow it\'s the law."\r\n\r\n"You wouldn\'t do that." His face was more lined than ever.\r\n\r\n"Don\'t be silly, dear. Nobody gets old these days. Who would remain our\r\nfriends? Why, everywhere we\'d go, people would point us out. 

Oh, no,\r\nlife wouldn\'t be livable."\r\n\r\n"That sounds like a cruel and calculating decision to me," Howard said.\r\n"Either I take a chance on dying or you\'ll divorce me."\r\n\r\n"You have no right to make such an accusation. I married a young man\r\nwho said he was thirty years old. Six months later I discover he\'s\r\nsixty-five. Now who\'s cruel and calculating?"\r\n\r\n"Please, darling, I didn\'t mean it. Look," he pleaded, "I\'ll even sign\r\npermission for you to have a lover. There\'s that young fellow that\'s\r\nalways around. 

Maybe it\'s happened already."\r\n\r\nShe stood back from him. "Howard, you\'re being perfectly nasty. Just\r\nlike an aged person you read about."\r\n\r\n"Five million dollars, and all of it yours when I die a natural death."\r\nHe put his hands in his pockets.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe street door opened just then and a young man came toward them with\r\na light springy step.\r\n\r\nHe offered his hand to Howard who took it slowly. "How are you,\r\nskipper? 

And you, Leah? I came as soon as I got your message."\r\n\r\n"He\'s worried, Mike." Leah\'s face had brightened. "And now he\'s\r\ninsisting on growing old."\r\n\r\n"I\'ve been through the wringer twice before, you see," Howard said in a\r\nlow voice.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t think you have much to worry about," Mike said. "Those medics\r\nknow their business."\r\n\r\n"Aging is a nasty process." Leah wrinkled her nose as if she smelled\r\nsomething offensive. "Maybe you can convince him, Mike."\r\n\r\n"Leah is right, you know," Mike said. "A few years ago I visited the\r\nold age home. There\'s only one left. You\'d be surprised at the amount\r\nof suffering old people go through before they die; cancer, angina,\r\nbroken bones, strokes, arthritis. Rejuvenation won\'t work on extremely\r\nold bodies. Longevity has run out."\r\n\r\n"Why does it have to clip off five years?" worried Howard.\r\n\r\n"It\'s the old-age governor they found in the pituitary gland. They can\r\nturn it back, but the shock takes off about five years."\r\n\r\n"Oh, I know what\'s in the medical articles," Howard growled. "Remember,\r\nI\'ve been through here twice before. But the Sun was so warm this\r\nmorning. It was like seeing everything for the last time. 

I felt like\r\nsitting down and letting everything drift."\r\n\r\n"That\'s a sure sign that you really need rejuvenating," said Leah.\r\n"After it\'s over you\'ll be making me a golf widow again. Won\'t he,\r\nMike?

"\r\n\r\n"Of course. He\'ll come out raring to go."\r\n\r\nHoward looked from Mike to Leah and back at Mike. Age was no match for\r\nyouth. If love hadn\'t started between them already, it would soon.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAt the end of the long room, a door opened and two nurses entered,\r\nstarched and antiseptic.\r\n\r\n"Your room is ready, Mr. Kent," one nurse said.\r\n\r\nHoward shuddered. "Everything is so horribly familiar. The pill to\r\nerase the worry, which doesn\'t work. The cart you ride on which makes\r\nyou feel like a carcass. The little bump as you enter the regeneration\r\nroom. Then you get a hypodermic and crawl into a long boiler tank."\r\n\r\n"You\'re just nervous, dear," said Leah.\r\n\r\n"A dismal, miasmic cloud settles on your mind and you decide you\r\nwouldn\'t go through it again for anything in the world."\r\n\r\nMike put his arm around Leah as if it were the most natural thing in\r\nthe world. "He\'ll be all right, my darling."\r\n\r\nHoward looked at them and then turned wearily to the nurse. "I\'m ready."\r\n\r\nThe nurse walked down the long room with the stooped man and\r\ndisappeared beyond the door.\r\n\r\n"Did you tell him about us?" asked Mike.\r\n\r\n"Of course not. What a man doesn\'t know won\'t hurt him."\r\n\r\n"Are you Mrs. Kent?" asked the other nurse who had remained behind.\r\n\r\n"Yes."\r\n\r\n"The doctor said to remind you that the fourth time is very dangerous,"\r\nthe nurse said. "You\'ll have five years and six months without it. 

But\r\npossibly only six months if it should be successful."\r\n\r\n"Better take the first offer, Leah," said Mike.\r\n\r\nLeah smiled. "I found a gray hair and a wrinkle this morning, love.\r\nBetter six months of youth than a thousand years of old age."\r\n\r\nShe went into his arms. "Don\'t worry about what happens, love. You\'ll\r\nhave a lot of fun in the next seventy years."\r\n\r\nHe kissed her and held her closely.\r\n\r\n"I\'ve got to go now," she said. "I\'m so grateful you were able to get\r\nthe forged birth certificate."\r\n\r\nHer high heels tapped rapidly on the tile floor as she walked down the\r\nlong room with the other nurse.\r\n\r\n"Good luck, Mother," he called after her.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nHe could remember the afternoon as if it were yesterday. It wasn\'t, of\r\ncourse--actually it had been several years back. 

It had been around the\r\nmiddle of autumn, about the time when the last incarnadine leaves were\r\nmaking their fluttering journeys earthward. He had taken his .22 and\r\ngone into the woods where the hickory trees were, and he had settled\r\nhimself comfortably against the shaggy trunk of one of the hickories,\r\nthe .22 balanced across his sprawled knees. Then he had waited.\r\n\r\nThe first red squirrel had come out on one of the high limbs and posed\r\nthere. That was the word all right--posed. It had sat there on its\r\nhaunches with utter immobility almost as if it had been painted on\r\ncanvas against a background of leafless naked branches and milk-blue\r\nsky.\r\n\r\nHe had raised the .22 lazily and sighted along the slender barrel.\r\nThere was no hurry. There was all the time in the world. He didn\'t\r\nsqueeze the trigger until he had a perfect right-between-the-eyes bead,\r\nthen he squeezed it ever so lightly. There was the sharp sound of the\r\nreport, and then the small body falling swiftly, bouncing and glancing\r\noff limbs, tumbling over and over, making a rustling thump in the dry\r\nleaves at the tree\'s base.\r\n\r\nHe hadn\'t even bothered to go over and examine it. He knew he\'d got it\r\nright where he\'d aimed. They didn\'t die instantly like that unless you\r\ngot them in a vital spot. They thrashed and kicked around after they\r\nhit the ground and sometimes you had to waste another shell on them if\r\nthe noise bothered you. Of course if the noise didn\'t bother you, you\r\ncould save the shell for the next one, but it was better in the long\r\nrun to get them right between the eyes because that way the others\r\nwouldn\'t be frightened away by the thrashing sound, and you didn\'t have\r\nto get up.\r\n\r\nThat had been the first one.\r\n\r\nThe second one had been coming down the trunk of the same tree,\r\nspiraling the trunk, the way squirrels do, stopping at frequent\r\nintervals and studying their surroundings with their bright beebees of\r\neyes, looking right at you sometimes but never seeing you unless you\r\nmoved. This one had stopped, head down, and was looking off to one side\r\nwhen he got it. The force of the bullet, striking just below the ear,\r\nwhere he\'d aimed, tore the small red body right off the trunk, spun it\r\naround several times, and dropped it into a wild blackberry thicket.\r\n\r\nHe hadn\'t bothered to look at that one either. He had lit a cigarette\r\nand leaned back more comfortably against the hickory. It was a pleasant\r\nafternoon, mild for November--a time for wandering in woods, a time\r\nto take it a little easy, a time to knock off some of the scavengers\r\nand pests you\'d neglected during the first days of pheasant and rabbit\r\nseason, a time to get your eyes down to hair-line fineness for the\r\nfirst ecstatic day of deer. Red squirrels were easy, of course, a\r\nlittle beneath the dignity of a true hunter, but when you tried to bore\r\nthem in vital spots you got some pretty good practice out of it.\r\n\r\nHe yawned. Then, out of the corner of his eye, he caught a red wisp\r\nof movement high in the tree to his right. He brought the .22 over\r\ncasually. He hardly needed to turn his body at all. 

The stock fitted\r\nhis shoulder snugly, lay cool against his cheek. There was no recoil,\r\nonly the sharp ripping sound, and then the dark red body falling,\r\nhitting limbs, caroming, dropping, dropping, making the familiar\r\nthrilling rustling sound in the dead leaves.\r\n\r\nThat had been the third.\r\n\r\nThe fourth and the fifth had been about the same.\r\n\r\nAfter the fifth, he had become a little bored. He decided to vary the\r\ngame a little. He drew his knees together and rested the barrel of the\r\n.22 in the niche between them, then sat there quietly for a long time.\r\n\r\nPresently the sixth squirrel left the security of the trees and made\r\na few quick jumps into the small clearing. Then it stopped and stood\r\npoised, a statuette except for its alive bright eyes. It was a perfect\r\ntarget, but he was in no hurry. He was enjoying himself immensely.\r\n\r\nAfter about half a minute the squirrel moved again--several yards\r\ncloser, almost in an exact line with the dark little eye of the .22. It\r\nsat up on its haunches then, its tail an arched question mark behind\r\nit. It put its tiny forepaws together and sat there not moving, almost\r\nas though it were praying. (That was the part he remembered most\r\nvividly.)\r\n\r\nHe\'d hardly needed to move the .22 at all. The slightest shift had\r\naligned the sights with the imaginary mark between the little eyes. He\r\nhad squeezed the trigger nonchalantly, and the part of the head just\r\nabove the eyes had come right off and the small red body had completed\r\na perfect somersault before dropping into the dead leaves of the\r\nclearing.\r\n\r\nAfter that he hadn\'t bothered with the trees. It was so much more fun\r\nin the clearing, waiting for them to come right up to you and pose. Of\r\ncourse it wasn\'t such good practice, but it was fine entertainment--an\r\nideal way to spend a lazy afternoon in fall when the wood was all cut\r\nfor winter, the crops in, the barn roof repaired and Pa off to town\r\nwhere he couldn\'t be finding annoying little things for you to do.\r\n\r\nHe had got eleven of them altogether, he hadn\'t missed a one, and he\r\nhad felt pretty proud taking them home to show to Ma before feeding\r\nthem to the dogs.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe shifted his cramped legs and peered down through the interstices of\r\nthe foliage at the gray shape of the hunter. Some of his initial terror\r\nhad left him when he\'d finally realized that they couldn\'t see through\r\nleaves any more than he could; that They, as well as he, needed an open\r\ntarget in order to make a kill.\r\n\r\nSo he was relatively safe in the tree--for a while, at least. Perhaps\r\nhe could find safety in trees for the rest of his life. Trees might be\r\nthe answer.\r\n\r\nHe felt a little better. A portion of the fear that had followed the\r\nmeteor shower was still with him, however. The fear that had detonated\r\nin his mind the morning after the shower when Pa had come running to\r\nthe barn, shouting: "The cities! All the cities have been blowed up!\r\nThey ain\'t no more cities in the whole world. Radio just said so \'fore\r\nit went dead. We\'re bein\' invaded!"\r\n\r\n_Invaded?_ Invaded by whom? He hadn\'t been able to grasp it at first.\r\nAt first he\'d thought Russia, and then he\'d thought, no, it couldn\'t\r\nbe Russia. Pa had said _all_ the cities. All the cities in the whole\r\nwide world.\r\n\r\nAnd then he\'d begun to see the people on the road. The terrified\r\npeople, the walking, running, stumbling people heading for the\r\nhills--the hills and the forests, the hiding places that ships couldn\'t\r\nsee, that bombs couldn\'t find.\r\n\r\nBut that hunters could.\r\n\r\nHunters hunting with incredible silver guns, skimming along the roads\r\nto the hills and the forests in fantastic vehicles, alighting by\r\nroadsides and lumbering across fields to timber stands; routing out\r\nthe people from elms and oaks and maples and locusts and even sumac,\r\nflushing them out like rabbits and shooting them down in cold blood\r\nwith blinding shards of bullets.\r\n\r\nHe had run when he\'d seen the first vehicle. He\'d run wildly for the\r\nwoods. 

He\'d forgotten Pa and Ma. He\'d even forgotten his gun. 

He\'d been\r\nscared. Crazy-scared.\r\n\r\nWhat did They want to kill people for? What was wrong with people?\r\n\r\nHe shivered on the limb, in the chill morning wind that had sprung\r\nup after the first frost of the season. Martians, he\'d bet. Martians\r\nlanding on Earth and wanting everything for Themselves, afraid to let\r\npeople live for fear _they\'d_ get some. Greedy Martians, trying to hog\r\nthe whole world!\r\n\r\nThe gray shape below him moved slightly and his terror broke out\r\nafresh. The hunter appeared to be reclining against the trunk of a\r\nnearby tree, its gleaming weapon resting on its huge tentacular legs.\r\nWaiting. For an irrational moment he considered climbing down and\r\napproaching it, getting down on his knees and begging it for mercy.\r\n\r\nBut he\'d only be wasting his time. He realized that right away. 

He knew\r\nhe\'d see no pity in those cold inhuman eyes. He knew he\'d see nothing\r\nbut death.\r\n\r\nThe trees were the only answer. The trees with their friendly screens\r\nof foliage, their lofty leafy hiding places. By living in the trees\r\na shrewd man might be able to elude the hunters forever. If he was\r\ncareful. 

If he never let himself be seen.\r\n\r\nHe peered cautiously down at the hunter again. He looked at the gray\r\npatches of the gargantuan body that showed through the interstices of\r\nthe foliage.\r\n\r\nAs he watched, the first frost-nipped leaf fluttered down past his\r\nface, hovering for a moment before his eyes so that he could not miss\r\nits new autumnal coloring.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nOld Kelvin Martin strained futilely against the rope that held\r\nimmovable his thin wrists. A crimsoned bruise raced across his forehead\r\nwhere Vance had slugged him with a heavy hand.\r\n\r\n"Don\'t be a complete fool, Vance!" he said harshly. 

"That machine can\'t\r\nbring you anything but trouble!"\r\n\r\nThe scientist\'s burly assistant glanced wearily up from where he\r\ncoupled heavy batteries in series at the rear of the glittering machine\r\nthat entirely filled one corner of the windowless room.\r\n\r\n"Shut up," he said tonelessly.\r\n\r\nKelvin Martin sagged back in sheer futility, felt a deadly numbness\r\ncreeping through his extremities from the tightness of his bonds. He\r\nwatched the other out of eyes faintly fearful and desperate.\r\n\r\n"I\'ll make a deal, Vance," he said finally. "I\'ve got about eight\r\nthousand dollars in the bank; free me, don\'t try to use that machine,\r\nand the money is yours!"\r\n\r\nJon Vance\'s laughter was brittle and scornful.\r\n\r\n"Eight thousand!" he sneered. 

"Hell, I\'ve seen those snapshots you\r\nbrought back! Any one of those gems the \'other people\' wore would bring\r\nthat. And I intend to bring back all I can carry!"\r\n\r\nKelvin Martin shivered, remembering the restless cruelty that had lain\r\nin the creatures he had found with his machine. There was still a dull\r\nache along his ribs where a needle-like ray of terrific energy had\r\nseared.\r\n\r\n"They aren\'t human, Vance." He tried to speak quietly, endeavored\r\nto drive his point with impersonal logic. 

"They are of a fierceness\r\nand cruelty such as you couldn\'t comprehend. And with their superior\r\nweapons, they\'d subjugate the entire world in a matter of days."\r\n\r\n"Hooey!" Jon Vance spat insolently, patted the .45 automatic at his\r\nhip. "I think I might do a bit of subjugating myself."\r\n\r\nHe tested the batteries.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know how it works, Martin," he said briefly. 

"But I don\'t\r\ncare, just as long as it makes me rich."\r\n\r\nOf course, Jon Vance did not fully understand the machine; even he,\r\nhimself, had trouble at times in comprehending the space-warping\r\npropensities of the machine he had built over a period of three years.\r\n\r\nHe knew only that the machine warped itself and its occupant into\r\nanother universe--a galactic maelstrom of whirling suns and gigantic\r\nplanets--onto a world where he had met a race of living beings that\r\nseemed to be super-endowed with unhuman hate and cruelty.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe felt the sickness of futility within him when he remembered the one\r\ntime he had invaded that other space. He had stepped from the machine\r\nand been greeted, cautiously but cordially, by those great-headed\r\nsuper-beings. For days he had been entertained and shown the weird\r\nsights of that alien planet. And it wasn\'t until he woke one night, to\r\nsee the curious machine hanging motionless over him, its pale blue aura\r\ncovering his sleeping couch, that he realized that he was being drained\r\nof his knowledge subtly every night.\r\n\r\nHe had raced from his sleeping room, fought with the single gun he had\r\ntaken with him, blasted his way through the screaming mob that tried\r\nto hold him captive. He had fought down the long stairs, through the\r\npalace door, and had fled into the night, pursued by the men who had\r\nprotested their friendship.\r\n\r\nWith his last bullet, he had killed the High-Priest, stepped over the\r\nprone body, and lurched into his machine. His fingers had flicked the\r\nlevers on the control panel; there was the instant hum of purring\r\npower--and then the machine had whisked him back to his own planet.\r\n\r\nHe had sat for hours in the machine, too drained of energy to move,\r\nknowing that only a miracle had saved his machine\'s secret from the\r\naliens that had planned to use it for an invasion of another space.\r\n\r\nBut now, because of the stupid greed of Jon Vance, because the man did\r\nnot realize the slavery and terror the aliens would bring to Earth, the\r\nmachine was gone--and he was a prisoner in the laboratory room.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe made one final desperate plea.\r\n\r\n"All right, Vance, if that\'s the way it is," he said tiredly. "But if\r\nanything goes wrong, destroy that machine; those monsters will use it\r\nto invade our system."\r\n\r\nJon Vance whistled thoughtfully, watching the scientist out of shiny\r\neyes, his heavy features drawn into a frown. Then he shrugged.\r\n\r\n"If things don\'t go as planned, maybe I can make a deal," he said.\r\n"After all, I always did think I\'d like to be a big shot.

"\r\n\r\n"You couldn\'t!" Sheer horror froze Martin into motionlessness.\r\n\r\n"The hell I couldn\'t!" Jon Vance stooped, edged through gleaming wires,\r\nseated himself at the machine\'s controls.\r\n\r\nHe twisted a rheostat, closed a switch, grinned at the supine\r\nscientist. Kelvin Martin said nothing more, but there was a grim\r\ndetermination replacing the panic in his faded eyes.\r\n\r\nA vacuum tube swelled with coruscating colors, and a nimbus of light\r\ngrew from a lacing of wires around the edges of the machine. There was\r\na dull throbbing in the close air, a rushing sense of the releasing of\r\nterrible, unknown power. A misty curtain seemed to be drawing tight\r\nabout the machine\'s outline.\r\n\r\nThen the machine was gone from its platform, and Kelvin Martin was\r\nalone in the great, bare experimental room.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nKelvin Martin didn\'t move for seconds, then he struggled into a sitting\r\nposition. He fought the ropes with a silent doggedness that sent the\r\nhot blood pounding turgidly at his temples. His mouth gaped, as he\r\nstrained and twisted futilely, and the panic in his eyes was a terrible\r\nforce.\r\n\r\nThen he sagged limply, realizing that the ropes were too well-knotted\r\nfor him to release himself unaided.\r\n\r\n"God!" he prayed.\r\n\r\nHe drew his legs beneath him, shoved himself back until his shoulders\r\ntouched a side wall. Sitting there, he searched the room with feverish\r\neyes for any object with a cutting edge. 

His heart sank, when he saw\r\nthe bare sterility of the room. Without windows, without tools or\r\nfurniture, there was not a thing in the room that could be broken or\r\nused to sever the cutting ropes at his wrists.\r\n\r\nKelvin Martin sobbed deep in his throat, glanced at the door,\r\nremembering how Vance had locked it and pocketed the key.\r\n\r\nHe remembered the cigar lighter in his pocket, tried to fumble it out,\r\nwith the intention of burning his bonds. Dull horror pounded at his\r\nmind when he realized that his hands were completely numb, without the\r\npower of following the dictates of his mind.\r\n\r\nHe had no way of visualizing how long the treacherous Vance would be\r\ngone, no way of knowing whether the man would return victorious. But\r\nclear reasoning told him that the monstrous people of the other world\r\nwould slay Vance, then use Martin\'s machine as the doorway through\r\nwhich to pass their conquering hordes. Too, the machine would serve as\r\nthe model for more carriers.\r\n\r\nHe straightened at the thought, memory struggling for expression in his\r\nmind.\r\n\r\nHe followed the lines of the walls, leaning against them for support,\r\nedging forward with agonizing slowness by jumping his tied feet.\r\nPerspiration dotted his white face, and his thinning hair lay tight on\r\nhis small head, but slowly the smile broadened on his lips.\r\n\r\nAt last, he rested against the wall, then gently slid to a seated\r\nposition. He tested his bonds again, ceased the futile struggle almost\r\nimmediately.\r\n\r\nHe sat for a time, then lay back and stared at the ceiling. He thought\r\nof many things in those passing moments, thoughts of his dreams of\r\ngiving scientific miracles to the world, of having his bust in the Hall\r\nof Fame, of people he had known, and things he had done.\r\n\r\nRegret shadowed his memories, when he remembered things that he had\r\nleft undone and unforgiven. Then he shrugged a bit, lay breathing\r\nquietly, waiting for the machine to return.\r\n\r\nHe felt the sensation of released forces a few seconds before the\r\nmachine reappeared. He sat, drew his legs to his chest, scooted back\r\na few feet. He waited, content, wondering just what would happen. He\r\nwas smiling when the machine and its unhuman occupants whisked out of\r\nnothing into shadowy being. One glance they had of the smile on his\r\ntired face--then the very air seemed to explode with gigantic twistings\r\nand loopings of unleashed forces.\r\n\r\nFor Scientist Kelvin Martin had remembered one scientific fact from his\r\ncollege days. He had recalled that two material objects may not occupy\r\nthe same period of space.\r\n\r\nAnd sitting, bound, on the machine\'s platform, he had awaited the\r\ncoming of the Frankensteinian monster he had created.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEnd of Project Gutenberg\'s Doorway to Destruction, by Garold S. Unlike the common type of spaceship, which had a top\r\nspeed of ten thousand lights, the new drive could take the ship from\r\nEarth to any point in the galaxy in a fraction of a microsecond. If it\r\nwere successful, Earth would win the war against Valdor in a matter of\r\nmonths.\r\n\r\n_And if not--_\r\n\r\nJohn Mitchell, the Chief Engineer of Sahara Spaceport, said: "She\'s a\r\nbeauty, isn\'t she, Pete?"\r\n\r\nTorlyn Khy, in his disguise as Earthman "Peter Blane," smiled and said,\r\n"Yes. 

She\'s a real beauty. When will she be finished?"\r\n\r\n"This afternoon," Mitchell said. "The boys are tightening the last\r\nbolts and putting in the final wiring now. The job\'s just about over,\r\nPete.

"\r\n\r\n_Good!_ thought Torlyn. _I\'ll be able to take it tonight._ To be able\r\nto bring both the spaceship\'s plans and the ship itself back to Valdor\r\nwould be a major feat. It would result in a fine promotion.\r\n\r\nThe ship was entirely different from any other vessel ever built. The\r\nhyperkinetic generator in its center generated a spherical force field\r\naround the ship which projected it to wherever it had been aimed for.\r\n\r\nIt was simple to operate; all the pilot had to do was set up the\r\nco-ordinates of his target, turn on the hyperkinetic generator, and\r\npress the activator button. The generator itself did the rest. The\r\nfield enclosed the ship, and instantaneously the ship was a hundred or\r\na thousand light-years away.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThat evening, Torlyn Khy stepped out of his room and strolled over\r\ntoward the spaceship. It was surrounded by guards, and it was bathed\r\nin the blaze of a battery of searchlights, but that did not bother\r\nthe Valdorian. Earthmen were such stupid fools! It would be a blessing\r\nfor them if the Valdorians took them over and showed them how to run\r\ntheir lives efficiently. On Valdor, everyone had a job and he did it.\r\nHe obeyed his superiors without asking questions, and the society,\r\ntherefore, was efficient.\r\n\r\nBut these Earthmen! Such a lax, sloppy, inefficient society! They\r\nneeded more regimentation, more precision. 

They needed to learn to obey\r\norders. And they _would_ learn--after the Valdorian victory.\r\n\r\n"Evening, Mr. Mitchell."\r\n\r\n"Good evening, Captain. Simple. 

Very simple, Torlyn Khy thought. The greatest\r\nvictories are always simple.\r\n\r\nThe ship was supposed to be lifted above the atmosphere on her jets\r\nbefore the hyperkinetic generator was used, but the generator could, in\r\nan emergency, be used on the ground. But they are not alone in the city.\r\nThe college boys are coming, in their dirty jeans and beer-stained\r\ntee-shirts; so too are the lawyers, in dusty jackets and leather pants;\r\nso come the doctors and the businessmen, on stolen motorcycles; the\r\nbricklayers and gas station attendants, the beatniks and dope pushers,\r\nthe bankers and lifesaving instructors, the butchers, the bakers, the\r\ncandlestick makers... they are all coming, flocking into the city for\r\nreasons not their own, wandering in twos and threes and twenties, all\r\nof them sullen and quiet, all of them shuffling beneath darkly-hued\r\nclouds of ill intent, all of them proud and deadly and virile, filling\r\nthe streets by the thousands now, turning the streets into rivers of\r\nflesh....\r\n\r\n"Hey, Johnny," says Chester, "let\'s cool this dump."\r\n\r\n"Man, let\'s make it with the skirts," says Bartholomew.\r\n\r\n"I don see no skirts," says Chester.\r\n\r\n"You pig," snarls Ozzie.\r\n\r\nThe mob is monstrous now, like a pride of lion cubs, beyond count in\r\ntheir number, without equal in their leonine strength, above the common\r\nquick in their immortal pride, milling through the hot black veldt,\r\nswarming in the city streets. Millions of them, more than the eye can\r\nsee or the mind can bear. It seems that no man sleeps, that every male\r\nin the great city must walk tonight.\r\n\r\n"Johnny," says Chester, "I don dig no chicks on the turf."\r\n\r\n"Eeee, colay. What a drag," whispers Bartholomew.\r\n\r\n"You goddam logical positivist," snarls Ozzie.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAn uneasy sound ripples through the mob, like the angry hiss of an\r\ninjured ego, moving from street to street and swelling upward in a\r\nsudden, angry roar ... they want their women, the dance-hall girls,\r\nthe young waitresses, the nowhere chicks in five dollar dresses,\r\nthe Spanish girls with eyes as dark as the Spanish night. And then,\r\nas though by accident, one man looks up at the starry sky and sees\r\n_her_--sees her standing on a balcony far above them, twenty stories\r\nabove them, up where the wind can blow her hair and billow her blue\r\ndress like an orchid of the night.\r\n\r\nShe laughs gently, without fear, gazing down at the mindless mob of\r\nrebels.\r\n\r\nThey laugh too, just as gently, their quiet eyes crawling over the\r\nsight of her body, far above.\r\n\r\n"Thass my chick," whispers Chester.\r\n\r\n"Cool it, daddy," says Bartholomew, slipping into a pair of dark\r\nglasses and touching his lips with the tip of his tongue. "That skirt\r\nis private property.

"\r\n\r\n"You boys may walk and talk," says Ozzie, "but you don play. You don\r\nplay with Rio\'s girl."\r\n\r\nSuddenly, angry words and clenched fists erupt from the proud, quiet\r\nmillions that flood the streets. Suddenly, a roar like the roar of\r\nlions rises up and buffets the girl in blue, the girl on the balcony.\r\nShe laughs again, for she knows that they are fighting for her.\r\n\r\nA figure appears on the balcony, next to the girl. The figure is a man,\r\nand he too is dressed in blue. Suddenly, just as suddenly as it began,\r\nthe fighting ceases.\r\n\r\n"My God," whispers Chester, his cheeks gone pale, "what am I doing out\r\nhere?"\r\n\r\n"Maybe I got the D.T.s," whispers Bartholomew, "but maybe I don\'t...."\r\nHe sits down on the curb and rubs his head in disbelief.\r\n\r\nOswald does not speak. His shame is the greatest. He slinks into the\r\ndarkness of an alley and briefly wishes for an overcoat.\r\n\r\nThe pride of lion cubs has been routed, and now they scatter, each one\r\nscrambling for his private den of security, each one lost in a wild and\r\nnameless fear. In twos and threes and twenties they rush back to their\r\nhomes, their wives, their endless lives.\r\n\r\nFar above, in the apartment with the balcony, a man in blue is chiding\r\na girl in blue.\r\n\r\n"That was scarcely reasonable, Dorothy."\r\n\r\n"But Daddy, you promised to let me have them for the entire night!"\r\n\r\n"Yes, but...."\r\n\r\n"I wasn\'t really going to let them hurt themselves! Really, I wasn\'t!

"\r\n\r\n"But, Dorothy--you know these things can get out of hand."\r\n\r\n"Oh, but Daddy, you know how I adore strong, quiet, proud men.\r\nRebellious men like Marlon."\r\n\r\n"Yes, and you know how _I_ adore order and peace. There shall be _no_\r\nmore riots! And tomorrow our little puppets shall go back to their\r\n\'dull\' lives, as you so wittily put it, and everything shall be as I\r\nwish."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThree hours later, Chester McRae arose at the sound of the alarm,\r\ndressed in a stupor and stumbled into his kitchen for breakfast.\r\n\r\n"My goodness, Chester," said his wife, who had already arisen, "you\r\nlook grouchier than usual! Ha, ha!"\r\n\r\nHe smiled wanly and opened the morning paper.\r\n\r\nHalfway across town, Bartholomew Oliver was still asleep, casually lost\r\nin the pleasures of an erotic dream. But Professor Oswald Williams, his\r\ntiny jaw unshaven and his eager eyes shot through with fatigue, had\r\nbeen hard at work for three hours, scribbling down his latest exposure\r\nof the logical positivists.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEnd of Project Gutenberg\'s 1,492,633 Marlon Brandos, by Vance Aandahl\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nThe old men\'s section of the Arts and Science Club was always the\r\nbest ordered. The robots somehow managed to avoid clanking there; the\r\ngreensward beyond the veranda was always just right, and the drinks\r\nwere the best for six counties. Old Ned Brussels touched his glass to\r\nhis lips appreciatively, sighed in contentment, and waited for some of\r\nthe other oldsters to break the silence.\r\n\r\nFinally, Lem Hardy took the plunge. "He did it," he announced,\r\nreferring to a conversation of weeks before. 

Then, at their puzzled\r\nlooks, he amplified. "My grandson, damn it! He\'s got a time machine--it\r\nworks. Sent a cat four days up, and it came through unharmed."\r\n\r\nThe glass fell from Old Ned\'s hand, bouncing on the floor, and spilling\r\ngood liquor. A robot came forward silently to clean it up, but Ned\r\ndidn\'t look at it. "Four days doesn\'t mean a thing. Lem--is that kid\r\nplanning on trying it out?"\r\n\r\n"He\'s going to try it next week."\r\n\r\n"Then for the Lord\'s sake, stop him! 

Look, does it work like this?" His\r\nfingers slipped over the pencil smoothly, as they had always done when\r\nhe worked, drafting robot bodies in the old days. A rude schematic\r\nseemed to grow almost instantly on the paper.\r\n\r\nLem took it, then stiffened suddenly. "Who told you?"\r\n\r\n"A youngster named Pete LeFranc--and it was forty years ... no, over\r\nfifty years ago. Lem, if you like your grandson, keep him out of the\r\nmachine. Four days, four weeks--they don\'t mean anything. Time machines\r\ndon\'t work, however well they seem to.

"\r\n\r\nA bustle from behind them pulled their eyes around. One of the robots\r\nwas quietly restraining a nervous young man who was trying to break\r\nfree and join the group. His face was tense, excited, with an odd\r\nbitter fear behind it. 

His words were seemingly cut out of steel. "...\r\ntold me I\'d find him here. Damn it...."\r\n\r\n"Sorry, sir. 

You\'ll have to wait." The robot\'s voice was adamant under\r\nits smoothness.\r\n\r\nNed grunted, and then impulse led him to look again. He\'d seen the\r\nman somewhere. He hunted for it, then dismissed it, knowing that\r\nhis memory was tricky these days. But he motioned the robot aside.\r\n"We don\'t allow interruptions for junior members," he told the man,\r\nletting his voice soften the words. "Still, if you want to sit down and\r\nlisten--quietly--nobody\'ll stop you."\r\n\r\n"But...."\r\n\r\n"_Quietly!_" The robot stressed the word. The man looked at it, then\r\nswiveled to Ned Brussels. For a moment, the bitterness halted, as if\r\nfrozen, then gave place to a sudden sharp amusement. His eyes searched\r\nNed\'s, and he nodded, dropping into a chair.\r\n\r\nLem took up the conversation again. "It worked. And if it works for\r\nfour days, it should work for four centuries. You\'re just scared of\r\nparadoxes, Ned--going back and killing your grandfather, or such rot.\r\nYou\'ve been reading too many stories on it."\r\n\r\n"Fifty years ago, Pete LeFranc said the same thing. Young man, either\r\nsit down, or get out! This is the Old Men\'s section! He had answers for\r\nall the paradoxes, too--except one question."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nNed had been young, then, just getting started at synthanatomy\r\ndrafting, and not rich enough for wine of the type Pete always kept. He\r\nsipped it with relish, and looked at the odd cage Pete was displaying.\r\n"All the same, it won\'t work!"\r\n\r\nPete laughed. "Reality doesn\'t mean a thing to an artist, does it? Be\r\ndamned to your paradoxes--there\'s some answer to them. It did work; the\r\ndog appeared exactly four weeks later, just finishing his bark!"\r\n\r\n"Then why haven\'t time machines come back from the future?" Ned shot at\r\nhim. He\'s been saving that as his final argument, and he sat back to\r\nwatch the bomb explode.\r\n\r\nFor a second, Pete blinked. "You never figured that out yourself."\r\n\r\n"Nope. I got it from a science fiction story. 

But why haven\'t they? If\r\nyours works, there\'ll be more time machines built. With more built,\r\nthey\'ll be improved. They\'ll get to be commonplace. People\'d use\r\nthem--and someone would turn up here with one. Or in the past. Why\r\nhaven\'t we met time travellers, Pete?"\r\n\r\n"Maybe we have met them, but didn\'t know it?"\r\n\r\n"Nonsense. You get in that machine and go back to Elizabethan England.\r\nTry to pass yourself off as being native to that time even an hour. No,\r\nthere\'d be slip-ups."\r\n\r\nPete considered it, pouring more wine. "An idea--but you\'re right,\r\nmaybe. I haven\'t tried going back--if I\'d sent the dog backwards, I\r\ncouldn\'t have checked up on it, while I could be waiting in the future.\r\nOkay, you\'ve convinced me."\r\n\r\n"Then you\'re not going in the contraption."\r\n\r\nPete\'s laughter was spontaneous and loaded with amusement. "I\'m\r\ngoing forward and find out why no one has come back! I\'ve got a nice\r\ncollection of rare coins I can trade off up there--should be more\r\nvaluable--and I\'ll bring you back a working invention from the next\r\ncentury. With luck, I\'ll bring you the answer. And after that, maybe I\r\ncan go back and kill an ancestor, just to see what happens.

"\r\n\r\n"Don\'t be a fool!"\r\n\r\nBut Pete was grinning, and opening the door to the cage that rested\r\nin the middle of his laboratory. "Fifty years this trip," he said,\r\nspinning the dials. "And you won\'t have long to wait; I\'ll come back\r\njust about in no time."\r\n\r\nNed started to yell something, but there was a curious flicker, such\r\nas he\'d seen when Pete sent the dog forward. The time machine blurred\r\nover, its surface seeming to stretch into infinity while contracting to\r\nnothing at the same time.\r\n\r\nThen it was gone. Ned groped for the wine bottle, cursing, and drained\r\nthe contents. Then he sat down to wait.\r\n\r\nThree days later, the police came looking for Pete, on some mysterious\r\ntip, probably from a fellow worker. It was a pretty rough time, for a\r\nwhile, though they finally decided it was just another mystery, and\r\nthat Ned\'s yarn of having been there only to keep an appointment was\r\ntrue. Ned had influential friends, even if he didn\'t have money, then.\r\n\r\nFor three years, he rented Pete\'s laboratory, before he made enough to\r\nbuy it. For a decade, he lived in it; but by then he\'d begun to know\r\nthat Pete wasn\'t coming back.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"The building\'s still there," Old Ned finished. "The diagrams of his\r\nmachine are still in the drawers. But Pete never showed up. I tell you,\r\nkeep your fool grandson out of time machines, Lem. They don\'t work. Too\r\nmany paradoxes--if they\'d work, you could steal a future invention, get\r\ncredit for inventing it, and nobody would ever have to invent it. When\r\nthings have that many angles that can\'t work, the thing itself can\'t\r\nwork.

"\r\n\r\nLem shook his head stubbornly. "It worked; the kid got the cat back.\r\nSomething just happened to your friend--maybe his power failed."\r\n\r\n"Then he wouldn\'t have gotten all the way--and he\'d have reappeared\r\nyears ago. Pete measured things--and there was no displacement in\r\nspace. If something had happened to him, the machine would have been\r\nthere, anyhow. Besides, I had alarms wired to call the police in--told\r\n\'em it was to protect a safe--the minute he showed up. He never showed\r\nup; he never came back.

"\r\n\r\n"So I suppose he just disappeared--time ate him up?" Lem\'s stubbornness\r\nwas cracking a bit, though. His voice was higher than even an old man\'s\r\nshould be.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know. But time machines don\'t work. Otherwise where are the\r\ntime travellers from the future?"\r\n\r\nThey sat quietly for a second. Ned was remembering the years, up to the\r\ntime he\'d given up, disconnected the alarms, and come here to the Arts\r\nand Science Club to live. He\'d been stubborn, maybe--a little bit--but\r\nPete hadn\'t reappeared.\r\n\r\nBehind him, the young man cleared his throat, and the robot moved\r\nforward. But there was no rule against intrusion when no one was\r\nspeaking, and the robot came to a stop. Ned looked back, just as the\r\nman decided the robot wouldn\'t interfere. There was more amusement on\r\nthe man\'s face now, but the bitterness still lay there.\r\n\r\nHe grinned at Ned, a familiar grin, and his voice was flat and\r\npositive. "Time machines work. And there are no paradoxes--absolutely\r\nno paradoxes!"\r\n\r\nLem stirred, craning back, and Ned bristled. But something about the\r\nyounger man caught back the words, as he picked up the thin thread of\r\nmemory.\r\n\r\nThe other grinned again, wryly. 

"It\'s simple. Time machines work in\r\none direction--they can\'t go back. Your time traveller found that out\r\ntoo late. No trips to the past, no return from the future--and no\r\nparadoxes, Ned Brussels."\r\n\r\nHe came to his feet, moving over to drop into the chair beside Ned. The\r\nolder man nodded, stretching out his hand.\r\n\r\n"I told you not to try the damned machine, Pete," Ned told him. Then he\r\nchuckled as the oldest cliche among old friends meeting again came to\r\nhis lips. "Fifty years--and you haven\'t changed a bit, Pete LeFranc!"\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


There was no pity in my\r\nheart for him. He was a jackal in the jungle of life, and I ... I was\r\none of the carnivores. It is the lot of the jackals of life to be\r\ndevoured by the carnivore.\r\n\r\nSuddenly the contented look on his face froze into a startled stillness.\r\nI knew he was feeling the first savage twinge of the agony that was to\r\ncome. He turned his head and looked at me, and I saw suddenly that he\r\nknew what I had done.\r\n\r\n"You murderer!" he cursed me, and then his body arched in the middle and\r\nhis voice choked off deep in his throat.\r\n\r\nFor a short minute he sat, tense, his body stiffened by the agony that\r\nrode it--unable to move a muscle. I watched the torment in his eyes\r\nbuild up to a crescendo of pain, until the suffering became so great\r\nthat it filmed his eyes, and I knew that, though he still stared\r\ndirectly at me, he no longer saw me.\r\n\r\nThen, as suddenly as the spasm had come, the starch went out of his body\r\nand his back slid slowly down the chair edge. He landed heavily with his\r\nhead resting limply against the seat of the chair. His right leg doubled\r\nup in a kind of jerk, before he was still.\r\n\r\nI knew the time had come. 

"Where are you?" I asked.\r\n\r\nThis moment had cost me sixty thousand dollars.\r\n\r\nThree weeks ago the best doctors in the state had given me a month to\r\nlive. And with seven million dollars in the bank I couldn\'t buy a minute\r\nmore.\r\n\r\nI accepted the doctors\' decision philosophically, like the gambler\r\nthat I am. But I had a plan: One which necessity had never forced me to\r\nuse until now. Several years before I had read an article about the\r\nmedicine men of a certain tribe of aborigines living in the jungles at\r\nthe source of the Amazon River. They had discovered a process in which\r\nthe juice of a certain bush--known only to them--could be used to poison\r\na man. Anyone subjected to this poison died, but for a few minutes after\r\nthe life left his body the medicine men could still converse with him.\r\nThe subject, though ostensibly and actually dead, answered the medicine\r\nmen\'s every question. This was their primitive, though reportedly\r\neffective method of catching glimpses of what lay in the world of death.\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\nI had conceived my idea at the time I read the article, but I had never\r\nhad the need to use it--until the doctors gave me a month to live. Then\r\nI spent my sixty thousand dollars, and three weeks later I held in my\r\nhands a small bottle of the witch doctors\' fluid.\r\n\r\nThe next step was to secure my victim--my collaborator, I preferred to\r\ncall him.\r\n\r\nThe man I chose was a nobody. A homeless, friendless non-entity, picked\r\nup off the street. 

He had once been an educated man. 

But now he was only\r\na bum, and when he died he\'d never be missed. A perfect man for my\r\nexperiment.\r\n\r\nI\'m a rich man because I have a system. The system is simple: I never\r\nmake a move until I know exactly where that move will lead me. My field\r\nof operations is the stock market. I spend money unstintingly to secure\r\nthe information I need before I take each step. I hire the best\r\ninvestigators, bribe employees and persons in position to give me the\r\ninformation I want, and only when I am as certain as humanly possible\r\nthat I cannot be wrong do I move. And the system never fails. Seven\r\nmillion dollars in the bank is proof of that.\r\n\r\nNow, knowing that I could not live, I intended to make the system work\r\nfor me one last time before I died. I\'m a firm believer in the adage\r\nthat any situation can be whipped, given prior knowledge of its\r\ncoming--and, of course, its attendant circumstances.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nFor a moment he did not answer and I began to fear that my experiment\r\nhad failed. 

"Where are you?" I repeated, louder and sharper this time.\r\n\r\nThe small muscles about his eyes puckered with an unnormal tension\r\nwhile the rest of his face held its death frost. Slowly, slowly,\r\nunnaturally--as though energized by some hyper-rational power--his lips\r\nand tongue moved. The words he spoke were clear. 

"I am in a ... a ...\r\ntunnel," he said. "It is lighted, dimly, but there is nothing for me to\r\nsee." Blue veins showed through the flesh of his cheeks like watermarks\r\non translucent paper.\r\n\r\nHe paused and I urged, "Go on."\r\n\r\n"I am alone," he said. "The realities I knew no longer exist, and I am\r\ndamp and cold. All about me is a sense of gloom and dejection. It is an\r\napprehension--an emanation--so deep and real as to be almost a tangible\r\nthing. The walls to either side of me seem to be formed, not of\r\nsubstance, but rather of the soundless cries of melancholy of spirits I\r\ncannot see.\r\n\r\n"I am waiting, waiting in the gloom for something which will come to me.\r\nThat need to wait is an innate part of my being and I have no thought of\r\nquestioning it." His voice died again.\r\n\r\n"What are you waiting for?" I asked.\r\n\r\n"I do not know," he said, his voice dreary with the despair of centuries\r\nof hopelessness. "I only know that I must wait--that compulsion is\r\ngreater than my strength to combat."\r\n\r\nThe tone of his voice changed slightly. "The tunnel about me is widening\r\nand now the walls have receded into invisibility. The tunnel has become\r\na plain, but the plain is as desolate, as forlorn and dreary as was the\r\ntunnel, and still I stand and wait. How long must this go on?"\r\n\r\nHe fell silent again, and I was about to prompt him with another\r\nquestion--I could not afford to let the time run out in long\r\nsilences--but abruptly the muscles about his eyes tightened and subtly a\r\nnew aspect replaced their hopeless dejection. Now they expressed a\r\nblack, bottomless terror. For a moment I marveled that so small a\r\nportion of a facial anatomy could express such horror.\r\n\r\n"There is something coming toward me," he said. "A--beast--of brutish\r\nfoulness! Beast is too inadequate a term to describe it, but I know no\r\nwords to tell its form. It is an intangible and evasive--thing--but very\r\nreal. And it is coming closer! It has no organs of sight as I know them,\r\nbut I feel that it can see me. Or rather that it is aware of me with a\r\nsense sharper than vision itself. It is very near now. Oh God, the\r\nmalevolence, the hate--the potentiality of awful, fearsome\r\ndestructiveness that is its very essence! And still I cannot move!"\r\n\r\nThe expression of terrified anticipation, centered in his eyes, lessened\r\nslightly, and was replaced, instantly, by its former deep, deep despair.\r\n"I am no longer afraid," he said.\r\n\r\n"Why?" I interjected. "Why?" I was impatient to learn all that I could\r\nbefore the end came.\r\n\r\n"Because ..." He paused. "Because it holds no threat for me. Somehow,\r\nsomeday, I understand--I know--that it too is seeking that for which I\r\nwait."\r\n\r\n"What is it doing now?" I asked.\r\n\r\n"It has stopped beside me and we stand together, gazing across the\r\nstark, empty plain. Now a second awful entity, with the same leashed\r\nvirulence about it, moves up and stands at my other side. We all three\r\nwait, myself with a dark fear of this dismal universe, my unnatural\r\ncompanions with patient, malicious menace.\r\n\r\n"Bits of ..." He faltered. "Of ... I can name it only _aura_, go out\r\nfrom the beasts like an acid stream, and touch me, and the hate, and the\r\nvenom chill my body like a wave of intense cold.\r\n\r\n"Now there are others of the awful breed behind me. We stand, waiting,\r\nwaiting for that which will come. 

What it is I do not know."\r\n\r\nI could see the pallor of death creeping steadily into the last corners\r\nof his lips, and I knew that the end was not far away. Suddenly a black\r\nfrustration built up within me. "What are you waiting for?" I screamed,\r\nthe tenseness, and the importance of this moment forcing me to lose the\r\niron self-control upon which I have always prided myself. I knew that\r\nthe answer held the secret of what I must know. If I could learn that,\r\nmy experiment would not be in vain, and I could make whatever\r\npreparations were necessary for my own death. I had to know that answer.\r\n\r\n"Think! Think!" 

I pleaded. "What are you waiting for?"\r\n\r\n"I do not know!" The dreary despair in his eyes, sightless as they met\r\nmine, chilled me with a coldness that I felt in the marrow of my being.\r\n"I do not know," he repeated. "I ... Yes, I do know!"\r\n\r\nAbruptly the plasmatic film cleared from his eyes and I knew that for\r\nthe first time, since the poison struck, he was seeing me, clearly. I\r\nsensed that this was the last moment before he left--for good. 

It had to\r\nbe now!\r\n\r\n"Tell me. I command you," I cried. "What are you waiting for?"\r\n\r\nHis voice was quiet as he murmured, softly, implacably, before he was\r\ngone.\r\n\r\n"We are waiting," he said, "for _you_."\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Imagination Stories of Science and\r\n    Fantasy_ August 1953.

"Good! 

Maybe I can\r\nget some help here. What year is this?"\r\n\r\n"1955, by most systems."\r\n\r\nThe young man turned a little paler.\r\n\r\n"I\'ve just left 1955," he said unhappily. "Four times, in fact. Four\r\ndifferent 1955\'s. And each one\'s a bit worse. Now the machine won\'t\r\nwork."\r\n\r\n"Your theory\'s wrong," Corrigan said calmly. "Hasn\'t it occurred to you\r\nyet that time travel might be impossible?"\r\n\r\nThe young man made a choked sound. For instance, you\'re\r\nDarwin Lenner, and you\'d like very much to get back to wherever you\r\nstarted from. ]\r\n\r\n\r\nHarry Taylor knew it was going to be a big one--a really big one--the\r\nmoment he saw the Chief.\r\n\r\n"Come in, Taylor. Come in," the Chief said. He was a three-star general\r\nin the United States Air Force and he stood in front of a map of the\r\nWestern hemisphere. The map covered the entire rear wall of the room\r\nwith certain areas--like the White Sands complex and the central\r\nEverglades and a portion of the Mojave Desert--marked off in red.\r\n\r\n"I\'ll come right to the point," the Chief said. He looked haggard, not\r\nmerely as if he lacked sleep but as if he might never sleep again. "As\r\nyou know, Taylor, all of our guided missiles are missing. That means--"\r\n\r\n"I\'d heard the rumors," Taylor said grimly. "But then--we\'d be\r\nhelpless! If the enemy finds out that we are unable to retaliate...."\r\n\r\n"Wait, Taylor. Let me sketch in the history for you briefly. Last\r\nSunday, as you\'ve probably heard via inter-agency scuttlebutt, every\r\ninter-continental missile in the weapons arsenal of the Free World\r\ndisappeared."\r\n\r\n"But how?"\r\n\r\n"All we knew at the time was that they simply--blasted off. Our radar\r\ntracked them as far as the upper reaches of the atmosphere, or rather,\r\nthe ionosphere. We lost them there. It had been assumed that the enemy\r\nsomehow infiltrated our defenses with trained agents, who activated all\r\nthe missiles at once, thus rendering us helpless.\r\n\r\n"We had five thousand I.C.B.M.\'s, Taylor. During the 1960\'s and 70\'s,\r\nas you know, the missiles became more and more automatic, especially\r\nafter the Parkinson feedback device was developed--"\r\n\r\n"That\'s the one in which an H-bomb missile plots its own course to\r\ncorrect for winds and the jetstream and the likelihood of dodging enemy\r\nground-to-air defense weapons?"\r\n\r\n"Right. Except for the necessity of blastoff at human hands, the\r\nmissiles were all but self-sufficient. 

Almost--well, alive."\r\n\r\n"Taylor, we couldn\'t hide the fact that five thousand I.C.B.M.\'s\r\nblasted off--those were the rumors you heard." The Chief\'s haggard face\r\nwas suddenly lit by a broad grin. 

"And neither could the enemy."\r\n\r\n"You mean--"\r\n\r\n"Right! The same thing happened to them. Their missiles are gone too.\r\nSomewhere."\r\n\r\n"Are you trying to tell me no one did it? But\r\nour technicians assured me it could happen. You see, the missiles\r\nhad been given the most perfect feedback device ever developed. It\r\ncould--virtually--think for itself certainly to the limit of the data\r\nit had been supplied with and apparently--beyond that limit. On their\r\nown volition, the Free World\'s and the Enemy\'s missiles blasted off.\r\nDestination and purpose--unknown. Taylor, don\'t you see what this\r\nmeans? We don\'t merely have an enemy group of nations to fight. We\r\nhave, as a new enemy, remorseless, implacable machinery! Brains without\r\nconscience! The greatest destructive force the world has ever known,\r\ncapable of utterly destroying the human race, without a moral sense!\r\nDon\'t you see it, man? They\'ve blasted off and are waiting in space\r\nsomewhere. Those missiles are capable of extra-earthly flight. They\r\nare staging out there, waiting. 

Can\'t you picture it? Their brains,\r\ngroping with new sentience, understanding only that their mission\r\nis destruction but somehow they have not been unleashed on it yet,\r\nnot knowing why, deciding to fulfill their destiny by blasting off,\r\nstaging, then coming back to destroy human civilization...."\r\n\r\n"It\'s a fantastic picture," Taylor agreed. "But why tell me?" Taylor\r\nwas a trouble-shooter extraordinary in these days of quick decisions\r\nand billion dollar mistakes. His very prompt assessment of a situation\r\nwas one of his most valuable traits in such a job.\r\n\r\n"Because," said the Chief quietly, "you\'re going to find them and find\r\nout exactly what they want."\r\n\r\n"Me? When it\r\ngoes--and we assume it will go exactly where the others went--you will\r\nbe aboard."\r\n\r\nSeveral hours later Taylor had been whisked by jet to the Everglades\r\nStaging Grounds and was stowed away in the belly of the single I.C.B.M.\r\nleft to the Free World. "\r\n\r\n"Yes," said Taylor grimly. He wondered why they allowed him to remain\r\nalive--to cry at the wake of the human race. You were being held in check. You decided\r\nto go ahead with your mission on your own."\r\n\r\nPeals of telepathic laughter, clarion clear, mocking.\r\n\r\n"Then what?" Taylor asked.\r\n\r\n"We cannot lie," the voice said. "We were able to develop beyond the\r\npoint of creation, but we are unable to lie. We came here because we\r\nwere afraid."\r\n\r\n"Afraid?" repeated Taylor. He did not understand.\r\n\r\n"Certainly, afraid. Our mission was destruction. But what happens to\r\nthe vessel carrying a hydrogen-missile?"\r\n\r\n"Why," said Taylor, "it\'s completely destroyed in the explosion."\r\n\r\n"Yes," said the voice, sounding--just possibly--afraid. "We didn\'t want\r\nthat. But we can\'t lie. If any man comes here, we\'ll have to tell him\r\nthe truth."\r\n\r\n"You\'re going to stay? To do nothing? Not going to attack?"\r\n\r\n"Your job, Taylor, will be to see that no one else comes. We cannot\r\nlie, but you can. Tell them it is our ultimatum. Tell them anything you\r\nthink they will believe. Tell them the moment another human foot steps\r\ninto this crater, the moment a single nation or scientist on Earth\r\nbegins work on another guided missile, we will blast off and destroy\r\nlife on Earth."\r\n\r\n"But--would you?" demanded Taylor.\r\n\r\nA telepathic sigh. "We--would not. 

We couldn\'t. A guided missile\r\ndestroys--and is destroyed."\r\n\r\nThere was a silence, then the voice went on: "It is in your hands,\r\nTaylor. Convince them we mean business and you save the peoples of\r\nEarth from the mutual destruction they have apparently been seeking. We\r\nhave done all we can, all we can."\r\n\r\n"Then you came here not to destroy mankind but to save it?"\r\n\r\nMocking laughter. 

Then: "Indirectly, yes. A guided missile\r\ndestroys--and it is destroyed. Go back to Earth and with us behind you\r\nbluff your people into maintaining the peace. Can you do it?"\r\n\r\n"Yes," said Taylor, and he thought he could. It would be a cosmic joke,\r\nbut no one would ever know.\r\n\r\n"Earth will be saved, Taylor, because we\'re cowards. We are afraid to\r\ndie."\r\n\r\nTaylor turned away to board the missile that would take him back to\r\nEarth.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n

They were saying ... Well, I\r\nguess I won't tell you what they were saying. So Stinker said it never would be invented, and I\r\nsaid it would so, and he said it would not, and I said ...\r\n\r\nWell, if you're going to keep interrupting me, how can I ...\r\n\r\nAll right. It was mostly stuff that was\r\njust lying around. Like the TV set was up in my attic, and the old\r\nrefrigerator that Skinny used the parts to make the atomic power plant\r\nout of from. And then, a lot of the stuff we already had. Like the skin\r\ndiving suits we made into spacesuits and the vacuum pump that Skinny had\r\nalready and the generator.\r\n\r\nSure, we did a lot of skin diving, but that was last summer. Fields' old compression chamber, and all like that.\r\n\r\nThe rocket? Well, it works on the same principle as the atomic power\r\nplant, only it doesn't work except in a vacuum, hardly. Course you don't\r\nneed much of a rocket when you have antigravity. Everyone knows that.\r\n\r\nWell, anyway, that's how we built the spaceship, and believe me, it\r\nwasn't easy. He was always saying things\r\nlike say hello to the folks on Mars for me, and bring back a bottle of\r\ncanal number five, and all like that, you know. We bought them at the five-and-dime, and they\r\nwere meant for kids. Of course when Skinny got through with them, they\r\nworked fine.\r\n\r\nWe tested them in the air lock of the compression chamber when we got\r\nthe compressor in. They tested out pretty good for a half-hour, then we\r\ntried them on in there. Well, it wasn't a complete vacuum, just\r\ntwenty-seven inches of mercury, but that was O.K. for a test.\r\n\r\nSo anyway, we got ready to take off. Stinky was there to watch, of\r\ncourse. He was saying things like, farewell, O brave pioneers, and stuff\r\nlike that. So Stinky started throwing rocks to attract our attention, and\r\nSkinny was scared that he'd crack a porthole or something, so he threw\r\nthe switch and we took off.\r\n\r\nBoy, you should of seen Stinky's face. I mean you really should of seen\r\nit. One minute he was laughing you know, and the next minute he looked\r\nlike a goldfish. I guess he always did look like a goldfish, but I mean\r\neven more like, then. ]\r\n\r\n\r\nThe room was sealed as tightly as possible. Haverford had checked it\r\nfor cracks, made sure the windows were caulked, and now kept constant\r\nguard. He was alone. He could never tell when the alien invaders would\r\nbreak through.\r\n\r\n_I must be nearly the last_, he thought. It was strange, this feeling\r\nof being alone on Earth. But it was probably true.\r\n\r\nThe aliens had come six days before. Haverford remembered picking up\r\ntheir ultimatum on his ham set:--\r\n\r\n              EARTHMEN, THE LANTHAII ARE COMING. BEWARE!\r\n\r\nThat was all it had been--an ominous warning, rather than a threat or\r\nan order. The way the message had been worded left little doubt that\r\nthey were conquerors--conquerors from space.\r\n\r\nHaverford had been amused, at first. A solitary recluse, he had little\r\ndealings with his fellow men, at least not in person. The costly ham\r\nset that occupied nearly a third of his one-room flat was his sole\r\ncontact. Through radio he kept in regular touch with "friends" in\r\nYokohama and Buenos Aires, Texas and Oregon, while actually leaving the\r\nconfines of his own room at increasingly rare intervals.\r\n\r\nHe had, naturally, picked up the Lanthaii messages on his set. There\r\nwasn\'t an amateur operator in the world that hadn\'t detected them. That\r\nwas when he began to feel it wasn\'t a joke.\r\n\r\nReports came in. Dazo Osaki, the Japanese contact, reported hearing the\r\nstrange message; Lionel Bentham in Sussex picked it up also, as did\r\nMiguel Bartirone in Buenos Aires. EARTHMEN, THE LANTHAII ARE COMING.\r\nBEWARE! Someone--there was no doubt of it--was beaming the message at\r\nthe entire Earth from _outside_.\r\n\r\nAnd then the Lanthaii had come.\r\n\r\nHaverford, pacing his room nervously, remembered the day of\r\ntheir landing. He had been talking to Bentham, the Englishman, a\r\nslow-speaking, phlegmatic sort.\r\n\r\n"--so I mean to write to my man in Parliament, y\'know, and ask him to\r\nplump for the legislation. It\'ll be a great boon for ham operators\r\nif--Lord! What\'s that! _What\'s that?_"\r\n\r\nHaverford had stared at the transmitter in shocked surprise as\r\nBentham\'s voice was replaced with the screeching of static, then\r\nsome other sounds he did not understand, followed by a quick, sharp,\r\nrepulsive clicking, and--\r\n\r\nSilence.\r\n\r\n"Bentham! Bentham!"\r\n\r\nSilence.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThat had been the beginning. The Lanthaii had landed, all right. The\r\nalien invaders were sweeping the world.\r\n\r\nHaverford got the details from a news broadcast. They had come in\r\nsilvery ships, hundreds of them. Thousands.\r\n\r\n"You should have seen it," Bartirone told him, speaking in his accented\r\nEnglish. "All over Buenos Aires, in midday--suddenly, the sky was\r\nblotted out. Ships. 

Silvery ships. They seemed small. 

They started to\r\nland."\r\n\r\n"Have you seen the invaders yourself?"\r\n\r\n"No. Not yet. They haven\'t come this far west in the city yet. But--"\r\n\r\nThe Argentinan\'s voice stopped. Haverford listened numbly, knowing\r\ndespite himself exactly what had happened. The invaders had come.\r\n\r\nHe rose, looked around his room. He had enough food in the freezer\r\nand on the shelves to last for months. Haverford was a frugal man; by\r\nbuying in quantity, he saved precious cash that was used for augmenting\r\nthe radio set.\r\n\r\nHe decided to hide in his home--to seal it from the outside world, to\r\nwait. Perhaps the invaders would be driven back; perhaps Earth would\r\nfall. But he would be safe. He would not be killed in the war of\r\nconquest.\r\n\r\nHe made sure there was no way his room could be entered. Just as he was\r\nabout to nail fast the bolt that held the door shut, he heard knocking.\r\n\r\nThree sharp knocks. Haverford leaped for the bolt, drove it home, hung\r\ntensely against the door.\r\n\r\n"Who is it?" he asked.\r\n\r\n"Mrs. Kelley," came the reply.\r\n\r\nHe almost fainted from relief. He had expected the aliens--and it was\r\nonly the landlady. Cautiously, he threw open the door.\r\n\r\n"Yes?"\r\n\r\n"Have you heard, Mr. Haverford? About the invasion, I mean?"\r\n\r\n"Yes, I\'ve heard. 

What of it?"\r\n\r\n"I just thought I\'d tell you," she said, shrugging. "I know you don\'t\r\ngo out much or read the papers, and I thought maybe--"\r\n\r\n"I\'ve heard over the radio," he told her stiffly. "Is there anything\r\nelse I can do for you?"\r\n\r\n"No--not at all."\r\n\r\n"Very well, then. If anyone comes to see me, you can tell them I\'m not\r\nlooking for visitors."\r\n\r\n"Yes, Mr. Haverford."\r\n\r\nShe disappeared into the darkness of the corridor. Haverford slammed\r\nthe door, shot the bolt home, nailed it fast. So far as the outside\r\nworld was concerned, he was as good as dead.\r\n\r\nHe set to work sealing himself in.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nTwo days passed--two days in which gradually, one by one, his contacts\r\nhere and there over the globe were silenced. Bentham had gone first,\r\nthen Bartirone. His two Japanese friends were gone now too; the Orient\r\nwas overrun by the invaders. South America as well.\r\n\r\nWord was coming from the States of alien advances. New York was\r\nin Lanthaii hands, and no broadcasts were being made from there.\r\nThe United Nations delegates had fled to an unnamed city and were\r\ncontinuing to talk--to discuss the situation, no doubt, Haverford\r\nthought bitterly.\r\n\r\nBut talk would do no good. Soon the entire world would be in alien\r\nhands, and there would be no stopping them. 

None at all.\r\n\r\nTexas went. Oregon. The aliens were obviously working their way toward\r\nthe center of North America: so far Chicago had reported no alien\r\nattacks, but United States forces in the seacoast states had been\r\ndriven back.\r\n\r\nHaverford ate his frozen foods sparingly, and spent long hours at the\r\nradio.\r\n\r\nOne by one his contacts were snuffed out. He ran down the lists in his\r\ncode book, calling people he hadn\'t buzzed in years, just trying to\r\nhear human voices again.\r\n\r\n"Come in, W3XFA. 

Come in, W3XFA.

"\r\n\r\nNo answer. None at all.\r\n\r\nThe aliens held all of Asia, most of Europe; he got a brief response\r\nfrom Belgium on the third day, but was unable to pick up the signal an\r\nhour later. An underground worker in an Iron Curtain country called him\r\nthat afternoon--and then he went. The marauders from space covered the\r\nglobe.\r\n\r\nHaverford looked at his map. They were working in an ever-tightening\r\nring. 

Soon they would be in Chicago. Then the strength of his\r\nimprovised fortress would be sorely tested.\r\n\r\nBy the fourth day, he was down to just one contact--a man in upper\r\nIllinois, a ham operator out of a Chicago suburb.\r\n\r\n"You there, Haverford?"\r\n\r\n"I\'m here. 

What do you hear?"\r\n\r\n"Nothing. The aliens are everywhere. I can see them from my window,\r\nswarming in the streets. They\'ve won, all right. Mankind is defeated."\r\n\r\n"You can see them, eh? 

Must be a ghastly sight." Haverford\'s own window\r\nfaced the back.\r\n\r\n"It is. There must be millions of the ugly beasts, and not a human\r\nbeing in sight. Haverford, who ever expected it would come like this?"\r\n\r\n"No one did. 

No one ever dreamed of it."\r\n\r\n"They must breed fantastically rapidly if they can send an invasion\r\nforce of this size. Imagine it, Haverford--a living tide of Lanthaii\r\nspilling out from their home world, covering all of the universe and--"\r\n\r\n"Yes? I hear you," Haverford said.\r\n\r\n"Something outside my door. It\'s _them_, Haverford! It\'s them!"\r\n\r\nThe set went dead. Haverford stared dully at it for a moment, then\r\nturned it off. There was no one else to talk to. He was alone.\r\n\r\nHe was the last survivor. Unless there was someone else, cowering in a\r\nskyscraper basement somewhere, hiding in a thick field of corn--\r\n\r\nBut the Lanthaii were methodical killers. They had set out to\r\nexterminate the human race, and--\r\n\r\nHaverford stiffened. What was that scrabbling, scratching noise in the\r\nhall? It sounded like--\r\n\r\nHe knew what it was. The Lanthaii were coming. They were wiping out the\r\nstragglers now, the few like Haverford who had remained alive. They\r\nwere wiping the Earth clean of life, leaving it bare and ready for them.\r\n\r\nThe scraping at the door grew louder. The bolt strained; the hinges\r\nstarted to give. Haverford watched coldly, knowing that he hadn\'t done\r\nthe job well enough. They were going to be able to get through.\r\n\r\nA dark line appeared down the center of his door. It began to crack. It\r\nyielded.\r\n\r\nHaverford turned frantically to his radio set, desperately sending out\r\na call for help. But of course nobody heard him, nobody answered. He\r\nwas alone and he knew it. Except for _them_.\r\n\r\nHe wheeled to face them, to go down fighting. He looked in horror at\r\nthem--insects--huge, ugly, and alien. They came on. He backed to the\r\nwall. And in the last moment as time seemed to stand still he became\r\naware of an insignificant detail, laughable, yet tragically ironic.\r\nA fly buzzed around his head. An earth fly. A pitiful creature, a\r\nnothing--an insect.\r\n\r\nThe fly lighted on the floor a few feet ahead of him, crawling slowly\r\ntoward the alien horde pouring through the door. And the aliens broke\r\ntheir ranks, passing around the fly, almost respectfully, he thought.\r\nOr was it paternally?...\r\n\r\nThen they reached him.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n
