What cosmic\r\n          joke made them drop their weapons and die laughing?\r\n\r\n           [Transcriber\'s Note: This etext was produced from\r\n                     Planet Stories January 1951.\r\n         Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that\r\n         the U.S. copyright on this publication was renewed.

]\r\n\r\n\r\nThe rockets started almost simultaneously. From two widely separated\r\npoints on the great curving surface of Earth they reached upward and\r\noutward--toward the Moon.\r\n\r\nIt wasn\'t really so strange a coincidence. Space navigation is governed\r\nby mathematics and logic, not politics. The fact that man-carrying\r\nspaceships happened to be developed concurrently on two sides of an\r\niron curtain meant little to the Universe. It happened, that\'s all. And\r\nthere is a proper time to launch such missiles. When that time came,\r\nthey were launched.\r\n\r\nIn a manner of speaking it was a race. A race wherein the prizes\r\nwere such things as: "gravity gauge" and "surveillance point" and\r\n"impregnable launching sites." The contestants were earnest, capable\r\nmen; each certain that the Moon must not fall into the hands of\r\nthe opponent. It made a stirring and patriotic picture, vivid with\r\nnationalistic fervor. It was thrilling with its taste of high adventure\r\nand self-sacrifice. For each rocket pilot it was a personal crusade\r\nagainst the thing he had been raised to regard as _the enemy_....\r\n\r\nBut somehow under the steady, cold scrutiny of the eternal stars,\r\nthey must have looked a little ridiculous ... perhaps just a tiny bit\r\ntragic, too.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHarsh was the moon. There was black and there was white. Great jagged\r\ncliffs and razor-backed mountains slashed the pocked surface of the\r\ncrater floor, humping themselves at the huge unwinking stars. The sun\r\nwas a stark disc of fire, incredibly white, hung in the black sky. The\r\nshadows were bottomless pools. Within them there was nothing. In the\r\nsunlight, the pumice soil glared white.\r\n\r\nThe Russian rocket had crashed on landing. Randick could see the tiny,\r\nbuckled shape of it high on the mountain. No doubt the pilot was dead,\r\nbut he had to be sure. The risks were too great for any unsupported\r\nassumptions. He had to go up there and see for himself.\r\n\r\nPonderous in his pressure suit, Randick emerged from the open lock of\r\nthe Anglo-American rocket. He slogged across the pumice of the crater\r\nfloor toward the spot where the mountain\'s sheer talus erupted skyward.\r\nIf there were no trouble from the Russki, he would return to his own\r\nship and begin setting up the first cell of what would soon be the\r\nAnglo-American Moon Base. As soon as he signalled a safe landing and\r\nno opposition from the Russian, other rockets would come to add their\r\ncells, and presently there would be an atomic rocket pointed dead at\r\nthe heart of every Russian population center. A rocket each for Moscow,\r\nLeningrad, Kiev, Vladivostok....\r\n\r\nRandick frowned. It would be a lot simpler if the crash had finished\r\nthe Russian pilot. He knew the Russians had exactly the same plan for\r\nthe Moon. 

Only the rockets would be aimed at Washington, London, Paris,\r\nSan Francisco. The slight weight of the one-man bazooka on Randick\'s\r\nback seemed suddenly very comforting.\r\n\r\nRandick knew himself to be on the very edge of known territory. His map\r\nshowed him that he was in the highest part of the Doerfel Mountains.\r\nBehind him lay the two great bowls of Bailly and Schickard, and far to\r\nthe north he could see, as he climbed higher, the smooth surface of the\r\nMare Humorum. He looked up to the spinelike ridge beyond and slightly\r\nabove the wreck of the Russian ship. 

There was a deep pass that slashed\r\nlike a wound into the backbone of the range. He felt a slight thrill.\r\nBeyond that cleft lay ... mystery. The other side of the Moon.\r\n\r\nThe sun\'s rays beat down brutally. Even through the heavily insulated\r\nsuit Randick could feel their searing touch. All around him stretched\r\na jumbled nightmare of black and white. He was suddenly very glad\r\nthat he could not see the Earth in the sky. The homesickness would be\r\nunbearable.\r\n\r\nRandick found himself frowning. He had no time for such thoughts.\r\nHe was a soldier. He reminded himself that up there in the tangled\r\nwreckage of the Russian spaceship there might be another soldier, ready\r\nto kill him. Two human beings on the Moon. Each eager to kill. 

Randick\r\nshook his head angrily. He had no right to let his mind dwell on such\r\nthings....\r\n\r\nHe was within a hundred yards of the wreck when a streak of fire and a\r\nsoundless blast drove him into the shadows. Pumice showered him from\r\nthe starshaped depression where the explosive missile had struck.\r\nRandick cursed heartily. The Russki was very much alive, and there\r\nwasn\'t a thing wrong with his eyesight. The shot had been uncomfortably\r\nclose.\r\n\r\nUnslinging his bazooka, Randick began to work his way around behind the\r\nRussian rocket. A slight movement among the wreckage caught his trained\r\neye and he launched a projectile at it. It flared wickedly, tearing\r\nfragments of metal loose and flinging them fantastic distances down the\r\nsheer slope of the ridge. There was no return fire.\r\n\r\nRandick broke out of the shadow and ran for the cover of a large\r\npumicestone boulder farther up the draw. A sun-bright flash of fire\r\nspattered the loose soil a dozen feet from him. He slid for the\r\ndarkness on his belly. That one had been a near thing!\r\n\r\nBehind the boulder lay a trench-like depression that sloped away up\r\nthe draw toward the pass. Randick dropped into it and began to crawl\r\nlaboriously upward. If he could flank the Russki he could finish this\r\nwith one good shot. Another explosion rocked the boulder he had just\r\nleft. Randick didn\'t even look back.\r\n\r\nHe felt his breath rasping in his throat and his body felt hot and\r\nsticky inside the bulky pressure suit. Glancing down and to his right,\r\nhe could see the proudly erect shape of his own rocket far below on the\r\nfloor of the crater.\r\n\r\nIt took him almost thirty minutes to reach the edge of the shadow that\r\nspilled from the side of the mountain pass. To his left, not ten feet\r\naway, was the sudden white glare of the pumice floor. He was well above\r\nand almost behind the wreck of the Russian\'s ship. His flanks were\r\nheaving with the exertion of the climb as he searched the buckled mass\r\nof the crash for his opponent.\r\n\r\nThere seemed to be a dark shape wedged in between two twisted\r\nbulkheads. 

It looked like a man. With pounding heart, Randick murmured\r\na prayer and lifted his bazooka, aimed, and pressed the firing stud.\r\nThe shadow vanished in silent white fire.\r\n\r\nThe return blast almost knocked him down. For a moment Randick was\r\nstunned, wondering foggily where the shot had come from. Then his brain\r\ncleared and he realized that the Russki too had climbed to the pass,\r\nleaving Randick to fire at shadows.\r\n\r\nRandick cursed himself for his dangerous stupidity. The other must be\r\namong those shadowy rocks directly across the bright floor of the pass.\r\nHe raised his bazooka carefully, searching the Stygian blackness for\r\nsome sign of movement. His finger curled around the firing stud....\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nOut of the corner of his eye he saw the flare. The Russian rocket\r\nerupted in a gout of bluish flame and the whole mountain seemed to\r\nrock. Randick stared stupidly at the glowing crater where the ship\r\nhad been. For just an instant he thought that perhaps a meteorite had\r\nstruck it, but the explosion had been unquestionably ... atomic.\r\n\r\nThe Russian must have been stunned, too. For he moved out into the\r\nlight, empty-handed, his helmet turned woodenly toward the rapidly\r\ncooling lake of magma where his space ship had been.\r\n\r\nThey both saw the bright arc of fire that raced up from beyond the\r\nridge and curved down gracefully toward the floor of the crater far\r\nbelow. Openmouthed, Randick watched his ship vanish into flame and he\r\nfelt the vague tremor of the ground under him as the shock rumbled\r\nacross the face of the Moon.\r\n\r\nThe Russian rocket was gone. The Anglo-American rocket was gone.\r\nMoon Base was gone before it had ever been.\r\n\r\nThe weapon fell from Randick\'s hand, and he stepped unsteadily into the\r\nlight toward the Russian. Suddenly human companionship was very, very\r\nimportant. Panicky terror was plucking at his throat.\r\n\r\nThe two men stumbled toward each other across the pass cut deep into\r\nthe jagged back of the Doerfel mountains. As one they turned and looked\r\nout across the vast expanse of the Moon\'s hidden face.\r\n\r\nThey were soldiers. They knew an invasion base when they saw one. 

As\r\nfar as the eye could see, lines of sleek mammoth spaceships of unknown\r\ndesign stretched away into the distance. The face of the vast unnamed\r\n_mare_ was covered with them.\r\n\r\n[Illustration: Their sides hurt with laughter, tears rolled down their\r\nfaces....]\r\n\r\nSuddenly Randick felt himself beginning to giggle. He tried to stop,\r\nbut the laughter welled up inside of him, echoing wildly within his\r\nconfining helmet. He could see that the Russian was laughing too, white\r\nteeth gleaming behind the plexiglass faceplate. 

They laughed until they\r\ngasped. Their sides hurt with laughter, tears rolled down their faces.\r\nThey were arm in arm and still laughing when the third rocket arced\r\ndown on them from out of the black and star-flecked sky.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


He didn\'t\r\ntalk much, just an occasional "Oh," "Mm" or "Ah." 

Krayton figured he\r\nmust be all right, though. After all he\'d been sent to Computer City by\r\nthe Information Department itself, and his credentials must have been\r\nchecked in a hundred ways and places.\r\n\r\n"Essentially each computer is the same," said Krayton, "but adjusted to\r\ntranslate problems into the special terms of the division it serves."\r\n\r\nKrayton had a pleasant, well-behaved impersonal voice. He was in his\r\nthirties and mildly handsome. He considered himself a master of the\r\ntechnique of building a career in Computer City--he knew how to stay\r\nwithin the limits of directives and regulations and still make\r\ndecisions, or rather to relay computer decisions that kept his\r\nresponsibility to a minimum.\r\n\r\nNow Krayton spoke easily and freely to the little man. As public liaison\r\nofficer he had explained the computer system hundreds of times. He knew\r\nit like a tech manual.\r\n\r\n"But is there any _real_ central control, say in case of a breakdown or\r\nsomething of that sort?" The little man\'s voice was dry as lava ash, dry\r\nas the wastes between and beyond the cities. Tanter, was the name he\'d\r\ngiven--Mr. Tanter. His contact lenses were so thick they made his eyes\r\nseem to bulge grotesquely. He had a faint stoop and wore a black tunic\r\nwhich made his look like one of the reconstructed models of prehistoric\r\nbirds called crows that Krayton had seen in museums.\r\n\r\n"Of course, of course," said Krayton, answering the question. "It\'s\r\nnever necessary to use the _All_ circuit. But we could very easily in\r\ncase of a great emergency."\r\n\r\n"The _All_ circuit? What is that?" 

Mr. Tanter asked.\r\n\r\nKrayton gestured and led the little man down the long control bank.\r\nTheir steps made precise clicks on the layaplast floor. The stainless\r\nsteel walls threw back tinny echoes. The chromium molding glistened,\r\nalways pointing the way--the straight and mathematical way. They were in\r\nthe topmost section of the topmost building of Computer City. The\r\nseveral hundred clean, solid, wedding-cake structures of the town could\r\nbe seen from the polaflex window.\r\n\r\n"The _All_ circuit puts every machine in the city to work on any\r\nselection-problem that\'s fed into our master control here. Each machine\r\nwill give its answer in its own special terms, but actually they will\r\nall work on the same problem. To use a grossly simple example, let us\r\nsay we wish to know the results of two-and-two, but we wish to know it\r\nin terms of _total security_. That is, we wish to know that two-plus-two\r\nmeans twice as many nourishment units for the Department of Foods, twice\r\nas many weapons for the Department of War, but is perhaps not\r\nnecessarily true according to the current situational adjustment in the\r\nDepartment of Public Information.\r\n\r\n"At any rate, we would set up our problem on the master, pushing the\r\nbutton _Two_, then the button _Plus_, and the button _Two_ again as on a\r\nprimitive adding machine. Then we would merely throw the _All_ switch. A\r\nshort time later the total answer to our problem would be relayed back\r\nfrom every computer, and the cross-comparison factors canceled out, so\r\nthat we would have the result in terms of the familiar _Verdict\r\nStatement_. And, as everyone knows, the electronically filed _Verdict\r\nStatements_ make the complete record of directives for the behavior of\r\nour society."\r\n\r\n"Very interesting," said Mr. Tanter, the little crow-like man. He\r\nblinked rapidly, stared at the switch marked _All_ that Krayton was\r\npointing out to him.\r\n\r\nKrayton now folded his hands in front of his official gold-and-black\r\ntunic, looked up into the air and rocked gently back and forth on his\r\nheels as he talked. He was really talking to himself now although he\r\nseemed to address Tanter. "You can see that the Computer System is quite\r\nunder our control in spite of what these rebellious, underground groups\r\nsay."\r\n\r\n"Underground groups?" asked Mr. 

Tanter mildly. Just his left eye seemed\r\nto blink this time. And the edge of his mouth gave the veriest twitch.\r\n\r\n"Oh, you know," said Krayton, "the organization that calls itself the\r\nPrims. Prim for Primitive. They leave little cards and pamphlets around\r\ndamning the Computer System. I saw one the other day. It had a big title\r\nsplashed across it: OUR NEW TYRANT--THE COMPUTER. The article complained\r\nthat some of the new labor and food regulations were the result of\r\nconscious reasoning on the part of The Computer. Devices to build the\r\nComputer bigger and bigger and bigger at the expense of ordinary\r\nworkers. 

You know the sort of thing."\r\n\r\n"But it is true that the living standard is going down all the time,\r\nisn\'t it?" asked Mr. 

Tanter, keeping his ephemeral smile. "What about\r\nthose three thousand starvation deaths up in Hydroburgh?"\r\n\r\nKrayton waved an impatient hand. 

"There will always be problems like\r\nthat here and there." He turned and stared almost reverently at the long\r\ncontrol rack. "Be thankful we have The Computer to solve them."\r\n\r\n"But the deaths were due to diverting that basic carbon shipment down\r\nhere to Computer City for computer-building, weren\'t they?"\r\n\r\n"Now, there--you see how powerful the propaganda of the Prims can be?"\r\nKrayton put his hands on his hips. "That statement is not true! 

It\r\nsimply isn\'t true at all! 

It was analyzed on The Computer some days ago.\r\nHere, let me show you." He took several steps down the corridor again\r\nand stopped at another panel.\r\n\r\n"We first collected from the various departments--Food, Production,\r\nLabor and so forth--all the _possible_ causes of the starvation deaths\r\nin Hydroburgh. Computer Administration had its machine translate them\r\ninto symbols. We\'re getting a huge new plant and machine addition over\r\nat Administration, by the way.\r\n\r\n"At any rate, we simply registered all the possible causes with the\r\nMaster Computer, threw in this circuit marked _Validity Selector_. Out\r\nof all those causes The Computer picked the one that was most valid. The\r\nHydroburgh tragedy was due to lack of foresight on the part of\r\nHydroburgh\'s planners. If they\'d had a proper stockpile of basic carbon\r\nthe thing never would have happened."\r\n\r\n"But no community ever stockpiles," said the little man.\r\n\r\n"That," said Krayton, "doesn\'t alter the fundamental fact. The Computer\r\nnever lies." He drew himself up stiffly as he said this. Then abruptly\r\nhe consulted the chronometer on the far wall.\r\n\r\n"Excuse me just a moment, Mr. Tanter," he said. "It\'s time to feed the\r\ndaily tax computation from Finance. We have to start a little earlier on\r\nthat these days--the new taxes, you know."\r\n\r\nAs Krayton moved off Tanter\'s thin smile widened just a little. As soon\r\nas Krayton was out of sight he stepped with his odd, crow-like stride to\r\nthe numerical panel, punched two-plus-two, then adjusted the Operations\r\npointer to HOLD. After that he punched three-plus-one, and HOLD once\r\nmore.\r\n\r\nHe moved over to the _Validity Selector_, switched the numerical panel\r\nin, closed the circuit.\r\n\r\nIn his dry voice he murmured to the whole control rack: "Three-plus-one\r\nmakes four, two-plus-two makes four. Three-plus-one, two-plus-two--tell\r\nme which is really true."\r\n\r\nAll through the master computer relays clicked and tubes glowed as the\r\nproblem was sent to all the sub-computers in their own special terms.\r\nFood, Production, Labor, Public Information, War, Peace, Education,\r\nScience and so forth.\r\n\r\nAll over Computer City the solenoids moved their contacts and the\r\nfilaments turned cherry red. Oscillating circuits hummed silently to\r\nthemselves in perfect Q. The life warmth of hysteresis pulsed and\r\nthrobbed along wires and channels. _Three-plus-one, two-plus-two--tell\r\nme which is really true._ The problem criss-crossed in and out, around,\r\nabout, checking, cross-checking, re-checking as The Computer \'thought\'\r\nabout the problem.\r\n\r\nWhich was really true?\r\n\r\nEven before Krayton returned parts of The Computer had begun to get red\r\nhot. It hummed in some places and in the other places relays going back\r\nand forth in indecision made an unhealthy rattling noise.\r\n\r\nLittle Mr. Tanter beamed happily to himself as he recalled the words of\r\nan old directive The Computer itself had issued in the matter of public\r\nthought control. _When a brain is faced with two absolutely equal\r\nalternatives complete breakdown invariably results._\r\n\r\nMr. Tanter kept smiling and rocked back and forth on his feet as Krayton\r\nhad done. Before nightfall The Computer would be a useless and\r\noverheated mass of plastic and metal!\r\n\r\nHe took a printed folder from his pocket and casually dropped it on the\r\nfloor where someone would be sure to find it. It was one of the\r\npamphlets the Prims were always leaving around.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Fantastic Universe_ March 1954.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. ]\r\n\r\n\r\nYou know Rosemary Brooks. You have known her for many years.\r\n\r\nIt is said that when she was a little girl her favorite poem was\r\n_Barbara Frietchie_, and it is told how she would sometimes poke her\r\npretty head out of her bedroom window, survey the suburban street with\r\nher blue-sky eyes, and cry, "_Shoot, if you must, this old gray head,\r\nbut spare your country\'s flag!_"\r\n\r\nYes, you know Rosemary. You know her very well.\r\n\r\nLike all little girls, Rosemary grew up. But Rosemary did not change.\r\nThis is not to say that she did not turn into an attractive young lady.\r\nShe turned into a most attractive one indeed. Fragilely beautiful, airy\r\nof tread, she should have been the reigning rose of every dance she\r\nwent to, but she was not. Rarely did the young men of her acquaintance\r\nask her to dance, and never did one of them approach her and say,\r\n"Come into the garden, Rosemary, for the black bat, night, has flown."\r\nShe did not go to very many dances in any event, and looking back, one\r\nrealizes that the few she did attend, she attended primarily to please\r\nher mother. The reason behind Rosemary\'s wallflowerhood is simple: the\r\nyoung men of her acquaintance knew that with her, God and the United\r\nStates of America came first, and that accompanying her through life,\r\nor even accompanying her home from a dance for that matter, meant being\r\nrelegated to a back seat. It is alright for little girls to be Barbara\r\nFrietchies, you see, but not for big ones.\r\n\r\nDuring her short and dedicated life, Rosemary poked her pretty head\r\nout of quite a number of windows. After the Barbara Frietchie window\r\ncame the Girl Scouts of America window, and after the Girl Scouts of\r\nAmerica window came the Young Peoples\' Civil War Society window, and\r\nafter the Young Peoples\' Civil War Society window came the Citizens for\r\nPatriotic Progress window. Last of all came the Astronette Training\r\nCenter window.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nSet up by Project Rain Dance in 1969 after prejudice against women\r\ngoing into space had abated, the Astronette Training Center had for\r\nits purpose the finding, training, and conditioning of six female\r\npilots for a series of six manned weather-control satellite shots, the\r\nfirst of which was scheduled to take place some time in February of\r\n\'71. After exhaustive screening, one hundred volunteers were accepted.\r\nFifteen of them passed the exacting physical and psychological tests,\r\nand from the ranks of the fifteen, the six astronettes were chosen.\r\nIncredibly, when one considers her delicateness (and fails to consider\r\nher patriotic fervor), Rosemary not only made the grade but was\r\nselected to accompany the first weather-control satellite to be placed\r\nin orbit.\r\n\r\nAll of this is history now--faded words on newsprint, old photographs,\r\na dozen dusty articles in as many magazines--but at the time, it\r\ncaptured the attention of the whole wide world. It is said that\r\nMadison Avenue nearly went out of its mind trying to circumvent the\r\nregulation that prohibited astronettes from underwriting testimonials\r\nto toothpaste, cosmetics, and cigarettes. This is not to be wondered\r\nat. If Rosemary could have been legally enticed, for example, into\r\nletting her picture appear in a cigarette ad, cigarette consumption\r\nprobably would have doubled overnight. It is one thing to be an\r\nobscure Barbara Frietchie and quite another to be a famous one, and\r\nthe patriotic devotion shining in a person\'s eyes can, through the\r\nthaumaturgy of photography and touch-up, be transmuted into a sensual\r\ngleam.\r\n\r\nFebruary of \'71 arrived at last, as all months must, and a specific\r\ndate was set for the launching. Psychological winter had come and gone,\r\nbut no singing of birds could be heard. 

Even as far south as Canaveral,\r\ngray skies were the rule, and gray rain fell intermittently. 

Countdown\r\nwas begun regardless. And then, miraculously it seemed, the skies\r\ncleared, and the day of the launching dawned bright and clear. There\r\nis a photograph of Rosemary standing in her snow-white spacesuit at\r\nthe base of the gantry, her space helmet resting in the crook of her\r\narm. The photograph is in color, and the blueness of her eyes is not\r\none whit different in shade and texture from the blueness of the sky\r\nbehind her. 

This is as it should be. Looking at her hair, one thinks\r\nof sunrises and sunsets. This is as it should be too. When remembering\r\nRosemary, it is fitting that one should think of the sun and the sky.\r\nIt is equally fitting that one should think of the snow and the rain.\r\nFor Rosemary is nothing if she is not all of these things.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe launching was a good one. The _Rainbow 6_ rode its Saturn booster\r\nlike a bird on jet-fire wings, and the bright star of its passage\r\nseemed to linger in the morning sky long after the booster had\r\nfallen away. The television cameras caught the action beautifully,\r\nand the American public, reminded once again that the noblest thing\r\na person can do is to risk his life for his country, looked on in\r\nawe and admiration. The orbit was a good one too: apogee--203 miles;\r\nperigee--191 miles. Rosemary radioed back that she was A-okay.\r\n\r\nShe was supposed to complete three orbits, then climb into the escape\r\ncapsule, jettison it and herself, re-enter the atmosphere, and\r\nparachute into the Atlantic. There, a task force waited eagerly to pick\r\nher up. Her mission was to orientate the satellite\'s weather-factor\r\ninstruments to the existent cloud patterns and jet streams. Once this\r\nwas accomplished, the telemetric readings would, through the medium of\r\nthe Main Weather Control Station in Oregon, dictate future weather.\r\nWeather control had been in effect since the middle sixties, but the\r\ntelemetric readings of the unmanned weather-control satellites, owing\r\nto faulty orientation, had fallen far short of the one-hundred percent\r\naccuracy needed to make the regulation of rain and sunshine something\r\nmore than a half-realized dream, and it was hoped that the present\r\nsatellite, given a human boost, would bring the dream to fruition.\r\n\r\nOne can picture Rosemary high in the sky, faithfully carrying out her\r\nassignment. One can see her sitting there before the instrument panel\r\nof the _Rainbow 6_ looking at dawns and sunsets and stars. 

One can\r\nsee the slow drift of cloud and continent beneath her. Australia now,\r\nand now the vast blueness of the Pacific ... and now the west coast\r\nrising out of mists of distances and air, and beyond it, the vast green\r\nblur of the land that gave her birth. Little Barbara Frietchie riding\r\non a star.... Far beneath her now, highways wind; rivers run down to\r\nseas. Patternings of field and forest blend into pale blue-greens.\r\nFresh-water lakes look up at her with blue and wondering eyes. Now the\r\nsea of night drifts forth to meet her. 

Bravely she sets sail upon the\r\ndark waves in her little silvery ship. Brief night, soft sunrise, new\r\nday.\r\n\r\n    _I bring fresh showers for the thirsting flowers,\r\n    From the seas and the streams;\r\n    I bear light shade for the leaves when laid\r\n    In their noonday dreams._\r\n\r\nLittle Barbara Frietchie riding on a star....\r\n\r\nJettisoning took place exactly on schedule. The weather-control\r\nsatellite continued on its orbital way, and Rosemary plummeted\r\nearthward in the escape capsule. That much, at least, is known. But\r\nwhat took place during re-entry--whether the retro rockets failed to\r\nfire, whether the attitude controls malfunctioned, or whether the heat\r\nshield proved to be defective--is not known and never will be known.\r\nAll that is known is that Rosemary became a falling star.\r\n\r\nThe nation mourned. The whole wide world mourned. Project Rain Dance\r\nwas discontinued. It would have been discontinued in any event, for\r\nRosemary had obviated any further need for it. She had done her job\r\nwell, Rosemary had, and in the doing of it, she had placed the weather\r\nin the palm of mankind\'s out-stretched hand.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThat spring, the rains were soft and warm and the flowers grew\r\nriotously upon the face of the earth. Grass knew a greenness it had\r\nnever known before, and trees dressed each day in lovelier and lovelier\r\ndresses. The rains fell in the cities and on the plains. In valleys and\r\nin little towns. 

On fields and forests and lawns. And when the land had\r\ndrunk its fill, the sun came out as warm and as bright as Rosemary\'s\r\nhair, and the sky turned as blue as her eyes.\r\n\r\nYes, you know Rosemary, and you are in love with her in a way. If you\r\nare not, you should be. She is the sun coming up in the morning and\r\nthe sun going down at night. She is the gentle rain against your face\r\nin spring. She is the snow falling on Christmas Eve. She is every\r\nglorious rainbow you see in the rain-washed sky. She is that pattern\r\nof tree-shade over there. Each morning, when you are lying fast asleep\r\nin your trundle bed, she tiptoes into your room, her golden sandals\r\nsoundless on the bedroom floor, and wakes you with a golden kiss.\r\nSunlight is her laughter, her voice the patter of the rain--Soft you\r\nnow!--she speaks:\r\n\r\n    _I am the daughter of the earth and water,\r\n    And the nursling of the sky;\r\n    I pass through the pores of the ocean and shores;\r\n    I change, but I cannot die...._\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


"Do you have your\r\ninstruments set up?

"\r\n\r\n"Not quite. But we have plenty of time. The light won\'t reach us for\r\nseveral hours yet. Remember, we were outracing it at ten lights."\r\n\r\nThe commander finally turned, slowly letting his breath out in a soft\r\nsigh. 

"Dr. Leicher, I would say that this is just about the foulest\r\ncoincidence that could happen to the first interstellar vessel ever to\r\nleave the Solar System."\r\n\r\nLeicher shrugged. 

"In one way of thinking, yes. It is certainly true\r\nthat we will never know, now, whether Alpha Centauri A ever had any\r\nplanets. But, in another way, it is extremely fortunate that we should\r\nbe so near a stellar explosion because of the wealth of scientific\r\ninformation we can obtain. As you say, it is a coincidence, and\r\nprobably one that happens only once in a billion years. The chances of\r\nany particular star going nova are small. That we should be so close\r\nwhen it happens is of a vanishingly small order of probability."\r\n\r\nCommander Benedict took off his cap and looked at the damp stain in the\r\nsweatband. "Nevertheless, Doctor, it is damned unnerving to come out of\r\nultradrive a couple of hundred million miles from the first star ever\r\nvisited by man and have to turn tail and run because the damned thing\r\npractically blows up in your face."\r\n\r\nLeicher could see that Benedict was upset; he rarely used the same\r\nprofanity twice in one sentence.\r\n\r\nThey had been downright lucky, at that. If Leicher hadn\'t seen the star\r\nbegin to swell and brighten, if he hadn\'t known what it meant, or if\r\nCommander Benedict hadn\'t been quick enough in shifting the ship back\r\ninto ultradrive--Leicher had a vision of an incandescent cloud of\r\ngaseous metal that had once been a spaceship.\r\n\r\nThe intercom buzzed. The commander answered, "Yes?"\r\n\r\n"Sir, would you tell Dr. Leicher that we have everything set up now?"\r\n\r\nLeicher nodded and turned to leave. 

"I guess we have nothing to do now\r\nbut wait."\r\n\r\nWhen the light from the nova did come, Commander Benedict was back at\r\nthe plate again--the forward one, this time, since the ship had been\r\nturned around in order to align the astronomy lab in the nose with the\r\nstar.\r\n\r\nAlpha Centauri A began to brighten and spread. It made Benedict think\r\nof a light bulb connected through a rheostat, with someone turning that\r\nrheostat, turning it until the circuit was well overloaded.\r\n\r\nThe light began to hurt Benedict\'s eyes even at that distance and he\r\nhad to cut down the receptivity in order to watch. After a while, he\r\nturned away from the plate. Not because the show was over, but simply\r\nbecause it had slowed to a point beyond which no change seemed to take\r\nplace to the human eye.\r\n\r\nFive weeks later, much to Leicher\'s chagrin, Commander Benedict\r\nannounced that they had to leave the vicinity. The ship had only been\r\nprovisioned to go to Alpha Centauri, scout the system without landing\r\non any of the planets, and return. At ten lights, top speed for the\r\nultradrive, it would take better than three months to get back.\r\n\r\n"I know you\'d like to watch it go through the complete cycle," Benedict\r\nsaid, "but we can\'t go back home as a bunch of starved skeletons."\r\n\r\nLeicher resigned himself to the necessity of leaving much of his work\r\nunfinished, and, although he knew it was a case of sour grapes,\r\nconsoled himself with the thought that he could as least get most of\r\nthe remaining information from the five-hundred-inch telescope on Luna,\r\nfour years from then.\r\n\r\nAs the ship slipped into the not-quite-space through which the\r\nultradrive propelled it, Leicher began to consolidate the material he\r\nhad already gathered.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nCommander Benedict wrote in the log:\r\n\r\n_Fifty-four days out from Sol. Alpha Centauri has long since faded back\r\ninto its pre-blowup state, since we have far outdistanced the light\r\nfrom its explosion. It now looks as it did two years ago. 

It_--\r\n\r\n"Pardon me, Commander," Leicher interrupted, "But I have something\r\ninteresting to show you."\r\n\r\nBenedict took his fingers off the keys and turned around in his chair.\r\n"What is it, Doctor?"\r\n\r\nLeicher frowned at the papers in his hands. "I\'ve been doing some work\r\non the probability of that explosion happening just as it did, and I\'ve\r\ncome up with some rather frightening figures. As I said before, the\r\nprobability was small. A little calculation has given us some\r\ninformation which makes it even smaller. For instance: with a possible\r\nerror of plus or minus two seconds Alpha Centauri A began to explode\r\nthe instant we came out of ultradrive!\r\n\r\n"Now, the probability of that occurring comes out so small that it\r\nshould happen only once in ten to the four hundred sixty-seventh\r\nseconds."\r\n\r\nIt was Commander Benedict\'s turn to frown. 

"So?"\r\n\r\n"Commander, the entire universe is only about ten to the seventeenth\r\nseconds old. But to give you an idea, let\'s say that the chances of its\r\nhappening are _once_ in millions of trillions of years!"\r\n\r\nBenedict blinked. The number, he realized, was totally beyond his\r\ncomprehension--or anyone else\'s.\r\n\r\n"Well, so what? Now it has happened that one time. 

That simply means\r\nthat it will almost certainly never happen again!"\r\n\r\n"True. But, Commander, when you buck odds like that and win, the thing\r\nto do is look for some factor that is cheating in your favor. If you\r\ntook a pair of dice and started throwing sevens, one right after\r\nanother--_for the next couple of thousand years_--you\'d begin to\r\nsuspect they were loaded."\r\n\r\nBenedict said nothing; he just waited expectantly.\r\n\r\n"There is only one thing that could have done it. 

Our ship." Leicher\r\nsaid it quietly, without emphasis.\r\n\r\n"What we know about the hyperspace, or superspace, or whatever it is we\r\nmove through in ultradrive is almost nothing. Coming out of it so near\r\nto a star might set up some sort of shock wave in normal space which\r\nwould completely disrupt that star\'s internal balance, resulting in the\r\nliberation of unimaginably vast amounts of energy, causing that star to\r\ngo nova. We can only assume that we ourselves were the fuze that set\r\noff that nova."\r\n\r\nBenedict stood up slowly. When he spoke, his voice was a choking\r\nwhisper. "You mean the sun--Sol--might...."\r\n\r\nLeicher nodded. "I don\'t say that it definitely would. But the\r\nprobability is that we were the cause of the destruction of Alpha\r\nCentauri A, and therefore might cause the destruction of Sol in the\r\nsame way."\r\n\r\nBenedict\'s voice was steady again. "That means that we can\'t go back\r\nagain, doesn\'t it? Even if we\'re not positive, we can\'t take the\r\nchance."\r\n\r\n"Not necessarily. We can get fairly close before we cut out the drive,\r\nand come in the rest of the way at sub-light speed. It\'ll take longer,\r\nand we\'ll have to go on half or one-third rations, but we _can_ do it!"\r\n\r\n"How far away?"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know what the minimum distance is, but I do know how we can\r\ngage a distance. Remember, neither Alpha Centauri B or C were\r\ndetonated. We\'ll have to cut our drive at least as far away from Sol\r\nas they are from A."\r\n\r\n"I see." The commander was silent for a moment, then: "Very well, Dr.\r\nLeicher. If that\'s the safest way, that\'s the only way."\r\n\r\nBenedict issued the orders, while Leicher figured the exact point at\r\nwhich they must cut out the drive, and how long the trip would take.\r\nThe rations would have to be cut down accordingly.\r\n\r\nCommander Benedict\'s mind whirled around the monstrousness of the whole\r\nthing like some dizzy bee around a flower. What if there had been\r\nplanets around Centauri A? What if they had been inhabited? Had he, all\r\nunwittingly, killed entire races of living, intelligent beings?\r\n\r\nBut, how could he have known? The drive had never been tested before.\r\nIt couldn\'t be tested inside the Solar System--it was too fast. He and\r\nhis crew had been volunteers, knowing that they might die when the\r\ndrive went on.\r\n\r\nSuddenly, Benedict gasped and slammed his fist down on the desk before\r\nhim.\r\n\r\nLeicher looked up. "What\'s the matter, Commander?"\r\n\r\n"Suppose," came the answer, "Just suppose, that we have the same\r\neffect on a star when we _go into_ ultradrive as we do when we come\r\nout of it?"\r\n\r\nLeicher was silent for a moment, stunned by the possibility. 

There was\r\nnothing to say, anyway. They could only wait....\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nA little more than half a light year from Sol, when the ship reached\r\nthe point where its occupants could see the light that had left their\r\nhome sun more than seven months before, they watched it become\r\nsuddenly, horribly brighter. _A hundred thousand times brighter!_\r\n\r\n...
