Extensive research did not uncover any evidence\r\nthat the U. S. Copyright on this publication was renewed.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


You know the one. Phil\r\nHarris singing about a thing that you couldn\'t get rid of, no matter\r\nwhat you did, a thing so repulsive it made you a social outcast. Never\r\nthought I\'d see one, though. Dirty Pete found it.\r\n\r\nDon\'t rush me. I\'ll tell you about it.\r\n\r\nWe\'re hobos, understand? Now a hobo is a different breed of cat than\r\nyou think. Oh, people are getting educated to the idea that a hobo will\r\nwork and move on, whereas a tramp will mooch and move on, and a bum will\r\nmooch and hang around, but you still find folks who are ignorant enough\r\nto call us bums.\r\n\r\nWe\'re aristocrats, yes sir. If it wasn\'t for us, you wouldn\'t enjoy half\r\nthe little luxuries you do. Oh, don\'t believe me--talk to your experts.\r\nThey know that, without the migratory worker, most of the crops wouldn\'t\r\nget harvested. And, if I talk highfalutin\' once in a while, don\'t blame\r\nme. Associating with the Professor improves any man\'s vocabulary, in\r\nspite of themselves.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThere was the four of us, see? We\'d been kicking around together for\r\nlonger than I care to think about. There was the Professor and Dirty\r\nPete and Sacks and Eddie. I\'m Eddie. Nicknames are funny things. Take\r\nthe Professor--he was a real professor once, until he began hitting the\r\nbottle. Well, he lost his job, his home, his family, and his rep.\r\n\r\nOne morning, he wakes up on Skid Row without a nickel in his jeans and\r\nthe great-granddaddy of all hangovers. He comes to a decision. Either he\r\ncould make a man out of hisself, or he could die. Right then, dying\r\nlooked like the easiest thing to do, but it took more guts that he had\r\nto jump off a bridge, so he went on the Road instead.\r\n\r\nAfter he got over his shakes--and he sure had \'em bad--he decided that,\r\nif he never took another drink, it\'d be the best thing for him. So he\r\ndidn\'t. 

He had a kind of dignity, though, and he could really talk, so\r\nhe and I teamed up during the wheat harvest in South Dakota. We made all\r\nthe stops and, when we hit the peaches in California we picked up Sacks\r\nand Dirty Pete.\r\n\r\nSacks got his monicker because he never wore shoes. He claimed that\r\ngunny-sacks, wrapped around his feet and shins, gave as much protection\r\nand more freedom, and they were more comfortable, besides costing nix.\r\nSince we mostly bought our shoes at the dumps, at four bits a pair, you\r\nmight say he was stretching a point, but that\'s one of the laws of the\r\nRoad. You don\'t step on the other guy\'s corns, and he don\'t step on\r\nyours.\r\n\r\nSo guess why Dirty Pete was called that. Yeah. He hadn\'t taken a bath\r\nsince \'forty-six, when he got out of the army, and he didn\'t figure on\r\never takin\' another. He was a damn\' good worker, though, and nobody\'d\r\never try anything with him around. He wasn\'t any bigger than a Mack\r\ntruck. Besides, he was quiet.\r\n\r\nOh, sure. You wanna know why I\'m on the Road. 

Well, it happens I like\r\nwhiskers. Trouble is, they\'re not fashionable, unless you\'re some kind\r\nof an artist, which I\'m not. You know, social disapproval. 

I didn\'t have\r\nthe guts to face it, so I lit out. Nobody cares on the Road what you do,\r\nso I was okay with my belt-length beard.\r\n\r\nA beard\'s an enjoyable thing, too. There\'s a certain kind of thrill you\r\nget from stroking it, and feeling its silkiness run through your\r\nfingers. And besides, combing it, and keeping it free of burrs, snarls\r\nand tangles, sort of keeps your spare moments so full that the devil\r\ndon\'t find any idle time to put your hands to work in. If you ask me, I\r\nthink that the razor has been the downfall of society. And I\'m willing\r\nto bet I have plenty of company with the same opinion.\r\n\r\nShow me a man who doesn\'t let his beard grow once in a while, even if\r\nit\'s only for a day or so, and you\'ve shown me a man who thinks more of\r\nsocial pressure than he does of his own comfort. And show me a man who\r\nsays he likes to shave, and you\'ve shown me a man who is either a liar\r\nor is asking for punishment.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThat\'s enough about us. Now to get on with the story. You know, if the\r\nProfessor hadn\'t been around, there would probably have been murder done\r\nover the Thing, or at least our little group would\'ve split up, \'cause\r\nnone of us had the brains to figure it out.\r\n\r\nPete\'s an expert scrounger. His eyes are sharp, and he\'s always on the\r\nlookout for a salable piece of goods, even if he can only get a nickel\r\nfor it. One night, we\'re sitting in a jungle near Sacramento, trying to\r\nfigure out whether to go north for the grapes, or south for the grapes.\r\nThey\'re all over California, you know, and they pay pretty well.\r\n\r\nPete, as usual, is out looking, and pretty soon he comes back into camp\r\nwith this thing in his hand. He handles it like it was hot, but he\'s\r\npleased he\'s found it, because he hopes to merchandise it. So he walks\r\nup to me, and says, "Hey, Eddie. What\'ll you gimme for this, huh?"\r\n\r\nI say, "Get that to hell away from me! I\'ll give you a swift kick in the\r\npants if you don\'t."\r\n\r\nHe looks real surprised. He says, "Huh, I thought maybe you could use\r\nit."\r\n\r\nI get up on my feet. I say, real low and careful, because maybe he\'s\r\njoking, "Look, Pete--you oughtta know by this time, I _like_ my beard.\r\nNow will you go away?"\r\n\r\nHe mooches off, looking like I\'d kicked him, and goes over to the\r\nProfessor. I figure maybe the Professor could use it, so I listen. The\r\nProf looks like he was being offered a live rattlesnake.\r\n\r\n"No, thanks, really, Pete. I have resolved never to touch it again. 

I\r\nhope you don\'t mind."\r\n\r\nWell, for some reason Pete don\'t look pleased, and he\'s real unhappy by\r\nthis time, but he tries again.\r\n\r\n"Hey, Sacks, what\'ll you gimme for--"\r\n\r\nHe don\'t get a chance to finish. I\'m only listening with half an ear,\r\nbut I\'m so surprised I stand up like I been stuck with a pin. Sacks\r\nsays, "Whatinell would I do with a left shoe? You know I don\'t use \'em."\r\n\r\nPete looks at the thing in his hand, and the Prof and I go over there.\r\n\r\nThe Professor looks at the thing real carefully and speaks up. "Say,\r\nPete, look at that thing and tell me what it is."\r\n\r\n"Why, it\'s a brand new bar of soap, of course. I don\'t use it, but one\r\nof you might want to. What\'s all the beef about?"\r\n\r\n"Soap?" 

I say. "Why, you poor fish, something must have happened to your\r\neyes. When you offered me that straight razor, I thought you\'d gone off\r\nyour nut. Now I _know_ it."\r\n\r\nThe Professor interrupts. He looks excited. 

"Wait a minute, Eddie. To me\r\nthat item looks exactly like a full fifth of Old Harvester, 100 proof.\r\nUsed to be my favorite, before I became an abstainer. To Pete, it looks\r\nlike soap. To you, it looks like a straight razor while, to Sacks, it\r\nresembles a shoe. Does that give you any ideas?"\r\n\r\n"Means we\'re all having hallucinations," I grunts.\r\n\r\n"Exactly. Pete, was there anything else in the location where you found\r\nthis thing?"\r\n\r\n"Nothing but some scrap tin."\r\n\r\n"Show us."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nSo, the four of us wanders across the field and, sure enough, there was\r\nthis silly-looking object lying there. It was about eighteen or twenty\r\nfeet across, and two feet thick, and I nearly made a fool of myself. I\r\nalmost screamed when I saw six straight razors _crawling_ out of a hole\r\nin its side.\r\n\r\nThe Professor whistled. "Grab them, boys. 

We want them."\r\n\r\nWell, Sacks sacrifices one of his sacks, and we rounded up fifteen of\r\nthe useless things. We went back to the jungle, where the Prof explained\r\nit.\r\n\r\n"Look, fellows, suppose you were a being from another planet that wanted\r\nto take over here. Suppose, further, that you were rather small and\r\nrelatively defenseless. To finish the suppositions, suppose you were a\r\npositive telepath, with not only the ability to read minds, but also the\r\nability to create visual and tactile hallucinations. How would you\r\nprotect yourself?"\r\n\r\nA light began to dawn, but I didn\'t say a word about it.\r\n\r\nThe Professor continued. "If you could do all this, you\'d make yourself\r\nlook just as useless as possible. 

To Pete, you\'d look like a bar of\r\nsoap, because he never uses the stuff. To Sacks, you\'d look like a shoe,\r\nbecause his dislike for shoes is evident in his mind. To Eddie, who is\r\nproud of his beard, you\'d look like a razor, while to me, you\'d look\r\nlike a bottle of booze, because I dislike its effects intensely. In\r\nother words, you would assume an imposture that would assure you\'d never\r\nbe picked up, except by someone like Pete, who would see in you a\r\nsalable item, even though not a usable one. It may be, Pete, that you\r\nhave saved the world."\r\n\r\nSo, that\'s the story. We\'re all still on the Road, of course, but now we\r\nare the "Commission for the Investigation of Extraterrestrial Invasion."\r\nCongress named us as that, when we got the data to them.\r\n\r\nNow, Mr. Mayor, you see our problem. 

Have your citizens seen anything\r\naround that they don\'t want? If they have, we want to look at it.\r\n\r\n                                               --EDWARD G. ROBLES, JR.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Galaxy Science Fiction_ June 1954.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and\r\n    typographical errors have been corrected without note.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


He tried to burrow deeper into the\r\nprotectively warm, cave-like place where he\'d been safe from them for\r\nso long. But he couldn\'t escape them. Their hands, their big, red,\r\nhideously smooth hands had him, now. They were tugging and pulling at\r\nhim with a strength impossible to fight. Still he struggled.\r\n\r\nHe tried to cry out but there was no sound from his constricted\r\nthroat. There were only the frightening noises from outside, louder,\r\nnow. He tried to twist and squirm against the hands dragging him\r\ntoward that harsh, blinding light. He was too small, too weak,\r\ncompared to them. He couldn\'t fight them off. He felt himself being\r\nstretched and strained and forced with cruel determination. He didn\'t\r\nwant to go _out there_. 

He knew what was waiting for him _out there_.\r\nHe _couldn\'t_ go. Not _out there_, where....\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWhen Jeff McKinney was three years old he tipped a pot of scalding\r\nwater from the stove onto himself. He was badly burned and scarred. He\r\nhovered between life and death for several weeks. Jeff\'s father was\r\nout of work at the time and they were living in a cold water tenement.\r\nSomething about the case caught a tabloid\'s attention and it was\r\nplayed up as a human interest sob story. It came to the attention of a\r\nwealthy man who volunteered to pay for plastic surgery. Then followed,\r\nlong months of that kind of torture, but Jeff McKinney came out of it\r\nnot too badly scarred. Not on the surface, anyhow. 

But his face had a\r\nstrange hue. There was a frozen, mask-like cast to his features when\r\nhe smiled.\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\nHe was eight when he saw his father killed. He was in the taxi the\r\nolder McKinney now drove for a living when the father stepped out of\r\nthe driver\'s side onto a busy street without looking back first. The\r\nspeeding truck took the car door and Jeff\'s father with it for half a\r\nblock, wedged between front wheel and fender. Jeff never forgot the\r\nsound of that, and the screaming. Nor his shock when he suddenly\r\nrealized that the screams were his own.\r\n\r\nJeff was a strange boy. He didn\'t have an average childhood. The\r\npoverty was more extreme after his father\'s death. He stayed home\r\nalone while his mother was out working at whatever job she could get,\r\nreading too much and thinking too much. Once, he looked at her with\r\nhaunted eyes and said: "Mother, why is life so bad? Why are people\r\neven born into a world like this?"\r\n\r\nWhat could she say to a question like that? She said: "Please,\r\nJefferson! Please don\'t talk that way. Life isn\'t all bad. You\'ll see.\r\nSome day, in spite of everything, you\'ll be somebody and you\'ll be\r\nhappy. The good times will come."\r\n\r\nThey did, of course. 

A few of them. There was the day he went upstate\r\non an outing for underprivileged boys and went fishing for the first\r\ntime. He caught a whopping trout and won a prize for it. That was\r\nnice; that was fun. That was when he was thirteen. That was the year\r\nthe gang of kids caught him on the way home from school and beat him\r\nunconscious because he never laughed; because they couldn\'t _make_ him\r\nlaugh. The year before his mother died.\r\n\r\nAt the orphanage he didn\'t mingle much with the other boys. He spent\r\nmost of his after-classes hours alone in the school\'s chemistry lab.\r\nHe liked to tinker with chemicals. They were cold, emotionless, immune\r\nto joy and sadness, yet they had purpose. He played the cello, too,\r\nwith haunting beauty, but not in the school band, only when he wanted\r\nto, when nobody was around and he could really feel the music.\r\n\r\nOnce, on the way home from his cello lesson in the music building, he\r\nsaw some boys playing football on the orphanage athletic field. He was\r\nsuddenly seized with a fierce determination to belong, to grab at some\r\nof the shouting, laughing happiness these boys seemed to have. He told\r\nthem he wanted to join in and play, too. He didn\'t understand why they\r\nlaughed so at this idea.\r\n\r\nThey stopped laughing, though, after the first time he ran with the\r\nball, and they all piled up on him and he didn\'t get up. He lay there,\r\nlooking so ghostly and breathing so harshly and with the trickle of\r\nblood coming out of his ears. But Jeff didn\'t know they had stopped\r\nlaughing.\r\n\r\nHe recovered from that skull fracture, all right. Worse, though, than\r\nany of the unhappiness he suffered during his life, worse even than\r\nthe shocks of his father\'s and mother\'s deaths, was the thing that\r\nhappened to him when he was twenty and working at the laboratories of\r\na big drug company.\r\n\r\nHe met and fell hopelessly in love with a girl named Nina, a girl a\r\nfew years older than he was. They married and for the first few weeks\r\nJeff McKinney had happiness he\'d never known before. Until he came\r\nhome from work sick, one afternoon and saw Nina with the man from the\r\napartment over them. She didn\'t whine and beg for forgiveness, Nina\r\ndidn\'t. She stood boldly while the other man laughed and laughed and\r\nshe screamed invective upon Jefferson McKinney, telling him what she\r\nreally thought of him, a gloomy, puny weakling who couldn\'t even make\r\na decent living, telling him that she was through with him.\r\n\r\nA blank spot came into Jeff\'s life right then. When it was over, Nina\r\nand the other man were on the floor and there was blood on the kitchen\r\ncarving knife in Jeff\'s hand.\r\n\r\nThey didn\'t find him for awhile. He changed his name and appearance\r\nand hid in the soiled seams and ragged fringes of society. He learned\r\nthe anaesthetic powers of drugs and alcohol. He gave up trying to get\r\nanything out of this life. Then they finally picked him up, fished him\r\nfrom the river into which he\'d jumped. There were days of torture\r\nafter that, without the alcohol and drugs his wrecked system craved.\r\nRight there was the final hell that could have broken him completely.\r\nBut it didn\'t. It was like the terrible crisis after a long illness.\r\nThings began to get better, to go to the other extreme after that.\r\n\r\nA state psychiatrist brought Jeff\'s case to the attention of a noted\r\ncriminal lawyer. Neither Nina nor her lover had died from their knife\r\nwounds. On the plea of the unwritten law, Jeff McKinney got off with a\r\nsuspended sentence. The lawyer and psychiatrist learned of his\r\ninterest and knowledge and talent for chemistry and got him another\r\njob in the experimental laboratory of a big university.\r\n\r\nLater he married a girl named Elaine, who worked at the lab with him.\r\nThey had two children, and lived in a small comfortable cottage just\r\noff the University campus. For several years, they had all they wanted\r\nof life--comfort, health, happiness. Jeff thought that life could\r\nnever be more wonderful. All of his former, bitter, cynical views fell\r\naway from him. Hadn\'t he, with all odds against him, finally won out\r\nand acquired peace and contentment and a purpose in life? 

What was\r\nwrong with a world in which that could happen?\r\n\r\nThen there was the topper. Jefferson McKinney discovered a new drug\r\nwhich would cure and eventually eliminate a disease that was one of\r\nthe world\'s worst killers, the drug for which thousands of scientists\r\nhad been seeking for years.\r\n\r\nHe was feted and honored, became a national hero. The story of his\r\nlife and his discovery temporarily pushed even the doleful forecasts\r\nof an early Third War, the Big War, off the front pages. And Jeff was\r\nhumbly proud and grateful that he had paid now the debt he owed to a\r\nsociety that could make a final victory, like his, possible.\r\n\r\nIn a zenith of almost holy happiness, he stood one evening on a\r\nlecture platform in a huge auditorium in a great city, before\r\nthousands of worshipping people to make a thank-you speech after being\r\nawarded a world prize for his great scientific discovery.\r\n\r\nBut in the middle of his talk he broke off suddenly. A flash of\r\nblinding brilliance slashed through the windows. 

Horror painted his\r\nface. In a whisper, he cried: "No! 

No! It would make it all so\r\nsenseless!" His eyes looked like the eyes of a man with flaming\r\nsplinters jammed under his fingernails. His face seemed to pucker, and\r\ngrow infantile. Then he screamed: "No! Leave me alone! I _told_ you I\r\ndidn\'t want to come _out here_, to be one of _you_! Damn you, why did\r\nyou bring me _out here_? 

For--for _this_?..."\r\n\r\nThere were the shards of glass from the great auditorium windows,\r\nfloating inward, turning lazily. There were the brick walls crumbling,\r\ntumbling inward, scattering through the air in the same seeming slow\r\nmotion. The dust cloud and the sound, the flat blast-sound, came after\r\nthat, as the entire building--perhaps the world--disintegrated in the\r\neye-searing light....\r\n\r\n\r\n_December 8th, 1952, Two-Thirty A. M._\r\n\r\nThe flat of a rubber-gloved hand striking flesh made a splatting\r\nnoise. A thin, breathless but concentrated crying followed. The doctor\r\nlooked down at his charity clinic patient, the woman under the bright\r\ndelivery room lights.\r\n\r\n"Look at him--fighting like a little demon!" the doctor said. "Seemed\r\nalmost as though he didn\'t want to come out and join us.... What\'s the\r\nmatter, son? This is a bright, new, wonderful world to be born\r\ninto.... What are you going to call the boy, Mrs. McKinney?"\r\n\r\nThe woman under the lights forced a tired smile. "Jeff. 

Jefferson\r\nMcKinney. That\'s going to be his name," she whispered proudly.\r\n\r\nThe baby\'s terrified squalling subsided into fretful, whimpering\r\nresignation.\r\n\r\n\r\n--THE END--\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


]\r\n\r\n\r\nWinant followed the lanky sheriff down the jail corridor past rows of\r\nempty, plank-walled cells and drew a sharp breath of relief when they\r\nfound the last cubicle still tenanted.\r\n\r\n"That\'s Uncle Ivor, all right," Winant said. "Sorry he caused you so\r\nmuch trouble, sheriff, but I\'ll be glad to pay his fine. What\'s the\r\ncharge against him?"\r\n\r\nThe sheriff rubbed a palm across his drooping mustaches and looked\r\ndoubtfully at the old man who sat on the edge of the cell bunk, the\r\nbald dome of his head cradled dejectedly in his hands.\r\n\r\n"You couldn\'t rightly say there _is_ a charge, mister," he admitted.\r\n"Your uncle popped into Ben Stuart\'s Drop Inn restaurant night before\r\nlast with a little black box under his arm, naked as a jaybird and\r\ntalking like a crazy man.\r\n\r\n"\'I\'m a visitor from Mars,\' he says. \'Take me to your president, and\r\nquick!\' Ben thought he was crazy, or drunk, and ran him out with a meat\r\ncleaver, and the old duck went down to the Warner Hotel and pulled the\r\nsame goofy act. Pop Warner called me, and I went down and threw the old\r\ncoot into the cooler. I knew right off that he was cracked, because I\r\neven had to show him how to put on the clothes I brought him. And the\r\nwingding he pitched when I took that black box away from him--wow!

"\r\n\r\nWinant shook his head. 

"Poor Uncle Ivor," he said commiseratingly. "The\r\nlast time he got away from us he thought he was Mahatma Ghandi, and\r\ntried to buy a bus ticket from Cincinnati to New Delhi, India. I found\r\nhim, finally, in Evansville, Indiana. It\'s amazing how he got this far\r\nsouth, but then a mentally-unbalanced person can do surprising things,\r\nsometimes."\r\n\r\nThe sheriff snorted. "Unbalanced, hell," he said. "The old coot\'s\r\ncrazy as a bed-bug. Just got in from Mars, he says, and he wants the\r\npresident of the United States--on the double!"\r\n\r\nHe unlocked the door and Winant went inside.\r\n\r\n"It\'s all right now, Uncle Ivor," he said gently. The old man raised\r\na wrinkled, leathery face and stared at him uncomprehendingly. "Let\'s\r\ngo over to my hotel and get a good meal and a hot bath," Winant urged.\r\n"Then we\'ll go home again. 

Ready, now?"\r\n\r\nA few minutes later in the jail office the sheriff pocketed the bill\r\nWinant gave him and handed over a small lacquered metal box that was\r\nsurprisingly heavy for its size.\r\n\r\n"Here\'s your uncle\'s radio," he said. "New-fangled model, I reckon. I\r\ncouldn\'t make head nor tail of it, so I just left it alone."\r\n\r\nWinant lifted the hinged cover and looked inside the box at the neat\r\narray of tiny meters and knobs that covered the control panel.\r\n\r\n"A wise decision, sheriff," he said dryly. "Wiser, perhaps, than you\'ll\r\never know."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe old man stood in the center of Winant\'s hotel room, the sheriff\'s\r\nill-fitting denims hanging on his slight frame like the castoff\r\nclothing of a scare-crow.\r\n\r\n"The box," he said. His voice, after talking for so long, was a hoarse,\r\nrasping croak. "Give me the box."\r\n\r\nWinant sat in a decrepit wicker chair, holding the box in his lap, his\r\neyes missing no detail of the old man\'s shrunken figure with its bald\r\ndome-like head and wrinkled parchment face.\r\n\r\n"I\'ll give you the box when you tell me something that makes sense," he\r\nsaid. "What you\'ve just told me is nothing but a rehash of the story\r\nyou told the sheriff--that your name is Yardana and that you are an\r\nenvoy from Mars, sent to Earth to help scientific authorities develop\r\nsafe atomic power. Look--I\'m a news writer, down here to investigate\r\nthe rumors of a blue meteorite landing in the hills just north of here\r\nand to check up on the comic accounts I read of your appearance. I went\r\nto a lot of trouble and some risk to get you out of jail, and I want a\r\nreasonable story for my trouble. 

What about it, now?

"\r\n\r\nThe old man wrung his hands. "Give me the box. Give me the box!"\r\n\r\n"Later," Winant promised. "When you give me the real story behind this\r\nthing I\'ll not only give you back your box, I\'ll give you a lift out of\r\nthis burg as well."\r\n\r\nHe looked at the old man sharply. "How could a Martian speak the kind\r\nof English you\'ve been using? Why should a Martian look so much like an\r\nordinary human being? It doesn\'t add up."\r\n\r\n"We are of the same root stock," Yardana said. "Intelligent life\r\nfollows the same evolutionary pattern, no matter where it develops, so\r\nlong as conditions are the same. As for the language, my people have\r\nfollowed your experiments with electro-magnetics since their beginning.\r\nWe know every language of Earth intimately, through long study of your\r\nradio programs."\r\n\r\nWinant laughed. 

"Maybe the sheriff was right, at that," he said. 

"It\'s\r\na goofy story, too fantastic for belief."\r\n\r\nHe shrugged and handed the old man the black box.\r\n\r\n"Here\'s your toy," he said resignedly. "I guess that\'s all I\'m\r\ngoing to get for my trouble; just enough misinformation for another\r\ntongue-in-cheek article for Sunday supplements."\r\n\r\nHe picked up his brief-case from the floor and laid it on the corner of\r\nthe writing table at his elbow. "The lift I promised you still goes, if\r\nyou want it, but it\'ll have to wait until tomorrow."\r\n\r\nThe old man took the black box eagerly and threw back the cover. His\r\nfingers flickered over the controls with practised familiarity.\r\n\r\n"I shall not need your assistance--now," he said. 

His pale eyes met\r\nWinant\'s triumphantly. "Now that I have the Bubble again I have a means\r\nof return to my ship better than any Earthly conveyance could offer.\r\nWatch!"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nFrom the black box swelled a pulsing radiance, a misty rose-tinted\r\nsphere that grew swiftly until it enveloped Yardana in a six-foot\r\nbubble of iridescent light. Through its wavering envelope the old\r\nman\'s face showed taut and purposeful, its pleading replaced by grim\r\ndetermination.\r\n\r\n[Illustration: _From the black box swelled a pulsing bubble of\r\niridescent light._]\r\n\r\n"Print your story," he said. "Tell your people about Yardana and his\r\nmission. Tell them too that their days are numbered from this minute,\r\nfor in their savage perversion of natural principles to warlike uses\r\nthey have forged a menace that threatens the peace of the Solar System\r\nand, eventually, of the universe itself."\r\n\r\nHe moved toward the window, the rosy Bubble glowing about him. Winant\r\nturned his chair slightly, watching, but he did not rise.\r\n\r\n"My people knew the secrets of the atom," Yardana said, "before your\r\nown learned the use of fire. We built great cities and telescopes\r\nwhen your ancestors were troglodytes, living in caves and eating\r\nuncooked meat. We expected no dangerous intelligence to arise on your\r\nplanet for thousands of years as yet, and we paid little attention\r\nto your progress until recently, when we learned through your radio\r\nbroadcasts that you had cracked the atom. We knew then that something\r\nwas dangerously wrong, and that we must investigate quickly before your\r\nsudden wisdom put you upon equal footing with us.\r\n\r\n"Today, when you should be only learning to compound gunpowder, we\r\nfind you applying electromagnetic principles which you cannot possibly\r\nunderstand, and harnessing the atom for the sole purpose of killing\r\ngreater numbers of your fellow beings. I came here, not to aid your\r\nscientists in developing the rudiments of the atomic power they\r\nhave discovered, but to find the reason behind the sudden freakish\r\nintelligence they are displaying. I have discovered that reason--the\r\nscientific and political powers of Earth are under the domination and\r\nguidance of alien intelligences, entities bent upon developing a race\r\nof Earthmen so warlike and so technically proficient in the waging of\r\nwar that it must endanger our own Martian culture."\r\n\r\nWinant sat unmoving, his eyes not leaving the Martian\'s wrinkled face.\r\nThe Bubble hissed audibly, its tiny sussuration suddenly loud in the\r\nroom.\r\n\r\n"Therefore I shall recommend in my report that the human race be\r\ncompletely destroyed," Yardana said. "Alone it could not offer\r\na serious threat against us for ages, but led and instructed by\r\nthese outside intelligences it must soon surpass our own scientific\r\ndevelopment. And we must destroy you before you learn the secret of\r\nspace travel, or we shall be too late to save ourselves.\r\n\r\n"We fought with the peoples of Venus once in ages past for the same\r\nreason, and reduced them to inconsequence if not to extinction, for no\r\nsign of intelligent life has been detected upon their world since we\r\nblasted it three thousand years ago. When I have made my report the\r\ncouncil of Elders will recommend the blasting of Earth, and the solar\r\nsystem will be safe again for our superior Martian civilization--this\r\ntime forever."\r\n\r\n"When you have made your report," Winant said. His smile was edged with\r\na sudden secret amusement. "But suppose these \'alien entities\' prevent\r\nyour return?"\r\n\r\nHe opened the brief-case on the table and put a hand inside it. The\r\nMartian laughed harshly.\r\n\r\n"No missile can penetrate a Bubble, you fool," he said contemptuously.\r\n"It is impervious to any Earthly weapon."\r\n\r\nWinant laughed in turn, his lips pressed back flat against his teeth.\r\nThe repressed hatred of three thousand years spoke in his voice, added\r\npressure to the thrust of his thumb on the stud of the little silver\r\ntube in his hand.\r\n\r\n"Of course it is," he said, as the sullen crimson ray from the tube\r\ndisintegrated Martian, box and Bubble alike in a breath. "That\'s why I\r\ncame prepared--with a Venusian weapon!"\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n             As pretty as a picture? Yes, because that was\r\n               all she was ... or would become some day!\r\n\r\n\r\nMy brother, Perry, always was a bit cracked. As a kid, he almost blew\r\nup our house doing experiments. When he was eighteen, he wrote poetry,\r\nbut fortunately that didn\'t last long and he went back to science.\r\n\r\nNow, when he showed me this picture, I figured he\'d had a relapse of\r\nsome kind. "This is the girl I\'m in love with," he said.\r\n\r\nShe wasn\'t bad. Not bad at all, even if her clothes were crazy. She\r\nwasn\'t my type--too brainy-looking--although I could see how some guys\r\nwould go for her. "I thought you liked blondes."\r\n\r\n"I wouldn\'t give you two cents for all the blondes in Hollywood," he\r\nanswered. "This is the only girl for me."\r\n\r\n"You sound as if you\'ve got it bad," I said. "You going to marry her?"\r\n\r\nHis face dropped about a mile. "I can\'t."\r\n\r\n"You mean she\'s married already?" I was surprised. This wasn\'t like\r\nPerry at all.\r\n\r\nHe sort of hesitated, as if he was afraid of saying too much. "No,\r\nshe isn\'t married. I asked her about that. But I can\'t marry her\r\nbecause--well, I\'ve never met her. All I\'ve seen of her is this\r\npicture and a few more. She doesn\'t live here."\r\n\r\n"You mean she\'s in Europe?" I\'ve heard of these love affairs by mail,\r\nand they never made much sense to me. I said to Perry, "Why can\'t she\r\ncome to this country?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, there are a lot of things in the way."\r\n\r\nIt sounded worse and worse. I said, "Look, Perry, this smells like a\r\nracket to me. It\'s the kind of thing a couple of shrewd operators cook\r\nup to take some hick for a ride. I\'m surprised at you falling for it.\r\nHow do you know there really is a dame like that in Europe? Anybody can\r\nsend pictures----"\r\n\r\n"You\'ve got it all wrong," he said. 

"I\'ve spoken to her."\r\n\r\n"By phone? How do you know who\'s on the other end? You hear a dame\'s\r\nvoice you never heard before. 

What makes you think it\'s hers?"\r\n\r\nAgain he didn\'t seem to want to talk, as if he had some secret to hide.\r\nBut I guess he felt like getting things off his chest, too, or he\r\nwouldn\'t have opened up in the first place. And he had already told me\r\nenough so that if he didn\'t tell me more he\'d sound like a dope.\r\n\r\nSo after hesitating even longer than before, he said, "Let\'s get this\r\nstraight, George. This is no racket. 

I\'ve seen and talked to her at\r\nthe same time. And the things she talked about, no con man would know."\r\n\r\n"You\'ve seen and talked to her at the same time? You mean by TV? 

I\r\ndon\'t believe it. They can\'t send TV to Europe."\r\n\r\n"I didn\'t say it was TV. And I didn\'t say she lived in Europe."\r\n\r\n"That\'s exactly what you did say. Or maybe you meant she lived on Mars?"\r\n\r\n"No. She\'s an American."\r\n\r\n"This makes less and less sense to me. 

Where did you meet her?"\r\n\r\nHe turned red, and squirmed all over the place. Finally he said, "Right\r\nhere in my own laboratory."\r\n\r\n"In your own laboratory! But you said you never met her in the flesh!"\r\n\r\n"I didn\'t. Not really by TV either. The fact is--she isn\'t born yet."\r\n\r\nI backed away from him. 

When he was a kid and blew up our kitchen, I\r\ndidn\'t like it. When he wrote poetry, I was kind of ashamed and didn\'t\r\nwant my pals to know he was my brother. Now, I was really scared.\r\nEverything he had been saying in the last ten minutes began to make\r\nsense, but a screwy kind of sense.\r\n\r\nHe saw how I felt. 

"Don\'t worry, George, I haven\'t gone crazy. Her time\r\nis 2973, more than a thousand years from now. The only way I\'ve seen\r\nand talked to her is on a time-contact machine."\r\n\r\n"Come again?"\r\n\r\n"A kind of time machine. It can\'t send material objects back and\r\nforth across time, as far as I know, but it can send certain waves,\r\nespecially the kind we use to transmit signals. That\'s how she and I\r\ncould talk to each other and see each other."\r\n\r\n"Perry, I think you ought to see a good doctor."\r\n\r\n"It\'s a remarkable device," he said, paying no attention to how I\r\nwas trying to help him. "She\'s the one who first constructed it and\r\ncontacted me. It\'s based on an extension of Einstein\'s equations----"\r\n\r\n"You think you can explain so much," I said. "Okay, then, explain this.\r\nThis dame isn\'t going to be born for a thousand years. And yet you\r\ntell me you\'re in love with her. What\'s the difference between you and\r\nsomebody that\'s nuts?" I asked, as if anybody knew the answer.\r\n\r\nHe certainly didn\'t. 

In fact, he went ahead and proved to me that they\r\nwere the same thing. Because for the next couple of weeks, the only\r\nthing he\'d talk about, outside of equations I couldn\'t understand,\r\nwas this dame. How smart she was, and how beautiful she was, and how\r\nwonderful she was in every way that a dame can be wonderful, and how\r\nshe loved him. For a time he had me convinced that she actually existed.\r\n\r\n"Compared with you," I said, "Romeo had a mild case."\r\n\r\n"There are some quantities so great that you can\'t measure them," he\r\nsaid. "That will give you some idea of our love for each other."\r\n\r\nThere it went, the old poetry, cropping out in him just like before.\r\nAnd all the time I\'d been thinking it was like measles, something that\r\nyou get once and it builds up your resistance so you don\'t get it\r\nagain, at least not bad. It just goes to show how wrong I could be.\r\n\r\n"What preacher are you going to get to marry you?" I asked. "A guy born\r\nfive hundred years from now?"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t think that\'s funny," he said.\r\n\r\n"You\'re telling me. Look, Perry, you\'re smart enough to know what I\'m\r\nthinking----"\r\n\r\n"You still think I\'m crazy."\r\n\r\n"I got an open mind on the subject. Now, if you won\'t see a\r\ndoctor--then how about letting me take a look at this dame, so I can\r\nconvince myself?"\r\n\r\n"No," he said. "I\'ve considered doing that, and decided against it.\r\nHer voice and image come through for only about five minutes a day,\r\nsometimes less. And those minutes are very precious to us. 

We don\'t\r\nwant any one else present, any one at all."\r\n\r\n"Not even to convince me she actually exists?"\r\n\r\n"You wouldn\'t be convinced anyway," he said very shrewdly. "No matter\r\nwhat I showed you, you\'d still find a reason to call it a fraud."\r\n\r\nHe was right at that. It would take a lot of convincing to make me\r\nbelieve that a babe who wasn\'t going to get born for a thousand years\r\nwas in love with him.\r\n\r\nBy this time, though, I was sure of one thing--there was something\r\nscrewy going on in that laboratory of his. For five minutes a day he\r\nwas watching some dame\'s picture, listening to her voice. If I had an\r\nidea what she was like, I might figure out where to go from there.\r\n\r\nI began keeping an eye on Perry, dropping in at the laboratory to pay\r\nhim visits. There was what looked like a ten-inch TV tube in one corner\r\nof his place, not housed in a cabinet, but lying on the table among\r\ndozens of other tubes and rheostats and meters and other things I\r\ndidn\'t know about. Along the wall that led from this corner was a lot\r\nof stuff which Perry said was high voltage, and warned me not to touch.\r\n\r\nI kept away. I wasn\'t trying to figure out how to get myself killed.\r\nAll I wanted to know was when he saw this girl.\r\n\r\nFinally I managed to pin the time down to between three and four in the\r\nafternoon. For five minutes every day, during that hour, he locked the\r\ndoor and didn\'t answer phone calls. I figured that if I dropped in then\r\nI might get a glimpse of her.\r\n\r\nAnd that\'s what I did.\r\n\r\nAt first, when I knocked on the door, there was no answer. In a minute,\r\nthough, I heard Perry\'s voice, but he wasn\'t talking to me. He was\r\nsaying, "Darling," and he sounded kind of sick, which I figured was\r\ndue to love. Come to think of it, he might have been scared a little.\r\nI heard him say, "Don\'t be afraid," and it was quiet for about fifteen\r\nseconds.\r\n\r\nThen I heard a terrific crash, like lightning striking. The door shook,\r\nand I smelled something sharp, and the first thing I wanted to do was\r\nget out of that place. But I couldn\'t leave my brother in there.\r\n\r\nI put my shoulder to the door and had no trouble at all. The explosion,\r\nor whatever it was, must have weakened the hinges. As the door crashed\r\nin, I looked for Perry.\r\n\r\nThere was no sign of him. But I could see his shoes, on the floor in\r\nfront of that TV tube, where he must have been standing. No feet in\r\nthem, though, just his socks. All the high-voltage stuff was smoking.\r\nThe TV screen was all lit up, and on it I could see a girl\'s face, the\r\nsame girl whose picture Perry had shown me. She was wearing one of\r\nthose funny costumes, and she looked scared. It was a clear picture,\r\nand I could even see the way she gulped.\r\n\r\nThen she broke out into a happy smile and, for about half a second,\r\nbefore the second explosion, I could see Perry on the screen. After\r\nthat second explosion--even though it wasn\'t near as big as the\r\nfirst--that TV set was nothing but a mess of twisted junk, and there\r\nwas no screen left to see anything on.\r\n\r\nPerry liked to have everything just so, and he\'d never think of going\r\nanyplace without his tie being knotted just right, and his socks\r\nmatching, and so on. And here he\'d traveled a thousand years into the\r\nfuture in bare feet. I felt kind of embarrassed for him.\r\n\r\nAnyway, they were engaged, and now they must be married, so I guess she\r\nhad slippers waiting for him. I\'m just sorry I missed the wedding.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


"Something to eat while you\'re\r\nwaiting, folks?"\r\n\r\nThe tall, dark girl glanced out at the closed doors of the Repair shop.\r\n\r\n"How long\'s that car going to take?" she asked in a tired voice. "I\r\nwanted to get home tonight."\r\n\r\n"Not long," Sam said. "It didn\'t look like anything complicated."\r\n\r\n"How can you tell?" the man asked, sitting down. "It could take all\r\nnight."\r\n\r\n"Like something to eat while you\'re waiting?" Sam asked.\r\n\r\nThe woman stared at the lunch racks critically.\r\n\r\n"I never like these places to eat in," the woman said, curling her lip.\r\n"You never know how long the food\'s been stored in the robot."\r\n\r\n"Oh, hell, Grace," the man said wearily. 

To Sam he gave an apologetic\r\nshrug. "Just coffee."\r\n\r\n"Well, you don\'t know," the woman insisted. "I mean...." She watched\r\nSam drawing the coffee into a cup. "I used to cook a lot, by hand, till\r\nJack had the autokitchen put in. He never had any stomach trouble till\r\nthen. It\'s getting so everything\'s ... oh, I don\'t know. 

It\'s all out\r\nof reach. You don\'t know what\'s happening any more. 

Like the car."\r\n\r\n"I wish I knew what she\'s talking about half the time," Jack said,\r\nblowing on his coffee. Sam leaned on the counter, looking past the\r\ncouple toward the empty road.\r\n\r\n"I know what the lady means," Sam said, almost to himself. "You get\r\nto thinking ... well, I can remember when people used to drive their\r\nown cars. Themselves. Steering and everything, except on the biggest\r\nhighways. And everything got done with people. People made things, and\r\ncooked food, and grew plants. Everybody was busy all the time. 

It was\r\nbetter then."\r\n\r\nThe man called Jack shrugged. "Sure, sure. Everybody always talks about\r\nthe good old days. But I don\'t see many of \'em going to live in the\r\nwoods. Like Grace--she says she doesn\'t like the autokitchen, but she\r\nuses it."\r\n\r\n"It saves time," Grace said. "I guess I will have coffee, too, mister."\r\n\r\n"It saves time, she says," Jack said. "For what? 

She\'s got too much\r\ntime now."\r\n\r\n"I wonder what it must have been like in the old days, here," Grace\r\nsaid vaguely, staring around the lunchroom. "Everybody running in and\r\nout. All the drivers--trucks, with men in them, the way you read about\r\nit in the historical novels. Men that drove their own cars, in all\r\nkinds of weather ... 

gee."\r\n\r\n"Just like on TV," Sam said, grinning.\r\n\r\n"I hope we get the car out of there pretty soon," Jack said anxiously.\r\nHe glanced out toward the silent garage. "I always wonder what would\r\nhappen if the machinery stuck, or something. How would you ever get\r\nyour car out?"\r\n\r\n"It doesn\'t get stuck," Sam said. A peculiar look crossed his face as\r\nhe added, "Not any more."\r\n\r\n"Did it ever?"\r\n\r\nSam shrugged. "Oh, well, you know twenty or thirty years ago all this\r\nautomatic stuff wasn\'t quite so good as it is now. Cars, repair\r\nshops ... things went wrong, sometimes. Like ... like the Traveler."\r\n\r\n"The Traveler?" The woman looked up. "Oh, that\'s just a ghost story.\r\nLike the Flying Dutchman. Isn\'t it?"\r\n\r\nThe lunchroom was completely silent. Sam was no longer paying any\r\nattention to the couple sitting at the counter. He was close to the\r\nbig window, standing stiffly, feet apart, like an admiral on a ship\'s\r\nbridge, his eyes studying the empty horizon. There, where the lines\r\nof the road met with the precision of a drawing-board exercise in\r\nperspective, he thought he saw a fleck of light.\r\n\r\n"It isn\'t when it goes past," Sam said, in a quiet tight voice. He\r\ntalked at the window, his back to the other two, his words meant\r\nmostly for himself.\r\n\r\n"It\'s not its going by. That doesn\'t bother me," he repeated. "It came\r\nby my old place five or six times, I remember. That\'s why I finally\r\nasked to be transferred out here, where it hardly ever goes by. But I\r\ncould have gotten used to it. I mean, you don\'t have to look at it, or\r\nanything. It\'s just another car. Old, sure, but there\'s no difference.\r\nA car goes by, that\'s all. Only...."\r\n\r\n"You mean it\'s real?" the woman asked, in a low voice.\r\n\r\nHer husband\'s eyes were looking out, toward the empty road, following\r\nSam\'s look.\r\n\r\n"The Traveler," he said, without looking at his wife. "Sure, it\'s real.\r\nWhy\'d you think they don\'t make that model of car any more? It\'s real.\r\nI knew somebody who saw it, once."\r\n\r\n"There might even be two or three Travelers," Sam said, watching the\r\ndistant glitter of light. There was certainly a car coming. Just a\r\ncar ... although it was still too far away to tell for sure.\r\n\r\n"A haunted car!" the woman said, her eyes wider. "Gee!"\r\n\r\n"It isn\'t a haunted car," her husband said. "It\'s just one of the\r\nearliest makes of automatic highway cars. Everything automatic,\r\nsteering, destination set ... just like any car is, nowadays. Only it\r\nwasn\'t quite perfect, somehow."\r\n\r\n"They got into their car," Sam said, his eyes picking out distant,\r\nmicroscopic details. The high flaring fins, the double headlamps ...\r\nlit up, although it was broad daylight on the road. He knew what the\r\nrest would be. It was moving so slowly. But it always moved slowly,\r\nbarely thirty miles an hour. As if somebody wanted you to look and\r\nsee....\r\n\r\n"They just got in, the way anybody would do," Sam said. "They set a\r\ndestination, and the windows closed up, and the airconditioner went on,\r\nand the car went out on the road."\r\n\r\n"Only it never got there," the other man said. "Wherever it was going\r\nto go."\r\n\r\n"But ..." the woman looked puzzled. "Wouldn\'t anybody stop it? I mean,\r\nwouldn\'t it run out of fuel, or ... well, how did the people in it get\r\nout?"\r\n\r\n"It does just what any car does," her husband told her. "It gets fuel\r\nwhen it needs it. You can\'t just stop a robot control device. Not till\r\nit\'s good and ready.

"\r\n\r\n"But the people in it," she said. "They\'d starve, or something...."\r\n\r\nThe car called the Traveler, rolling at the stately thirty miles an\r\nhour it always held, was coming down the road now, and the two men\r\nstood, watching. The woman, a little behind them, watched too, her face\r\ngrowing whiter. No one said anything as the old fashioned car rolled\r\nby, straight and steady down the highway, holding the center of the\r\nlane as sharply as it always did.\r\n\r\nThere was a film of dust inside the windows, though the Traveler was\r\nclean and shining outside. But the film did hide the white bone faces,\r\nthe despairing hands that had long ago stopped trying to break through\r\nthose closed windows.\r\n\r\n"They never did get out," the man named Jack said, as the Traveler\r\nrolled on, growing smaller along the endless road.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t mind it when it goes past," Sam said, his voice thinner edged.\r\n"I really don\'t. It\'s just a car. 

Things like that used to happen. I\r\nmean, it\'s a car. Even when it stops to get gas, I don\'t have to pay\r\nany attention."\r\n\r\nHe looked at the couple, his mouth loose. "As long as it just goes on.\r\nThat\'s all right. 

But I keep thinking some day it\'ll stop. And the door\r\nwill open. 

And maybe ... maybe they\'ll want lunch."\r\n\r\nHe giggled uncontrollably, and then choked it back.\r\n\r\nOutside, the big hangar doors of the repair shop opened. The car that\r\nhad been inside appeared; it moved out and stopped, its doors open\r\ninvitingly.\r\n\r\n"Your car\'s ready now," Sam told the couple. "So long, folks. 

Have a\r\nnice trip."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n

]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                   Have you found out about the Big\r\n                    Engine? It\'s all around us, you\r\n                   know--can\'t you hear it even now?\r\n\r\n\r\nThere are all sorts of screwy theories (the Professor said) of what\r\nmakes the wheels of the world go round. There\'s a boy in Chicago who\r\nthinks we\'re all of us just the thoughts of a green cat; when the green\r\ncat dies we\'ll all puff to nothing like smoke. There\'s a man in the\r\nwest who thinks all women are witches and run the world by conjure\r\nmagic. There\'s a man in the east who believes all rich people belong to\r\na secret society that\'s a lot tighter and tougher than the Mafia and\r\nthat has a monopoly of power-secrets and pleasure-secrets other people\r\ndon\'t dream exist.\r\n\r\nMe, I think the wheels of the world just go. I decided that forty\r\nyears ago and I\'ve never since seen or heard or read anything to make\r\nme change my mind.\r\n\r\nI was a stoker on a lake boat then (the Professor continued, delicately\r\nsipping smoke from his long thin cigarette). 

I was as stupid as they\r\nmake them, but I liked to think. Whenever I\'d get a chance I\'d go to\r\none of the big libraries and make them get me all sorts of books.\r\nThat was how guys started calling me the Professor. I\'d get books on\r\nphilosophy, metaphysics, science, even religion. I\'d read them and try\r\nto figure out the world. 

What was it all about, anyway? Why was I here?\r\nWhat was the point in the whole business of getting born and working\r\nand dying? What was the use of it? Why\'d it have to go on and on?\r\n\r\nAnd why\'d it have to be so complicated?\r\n\r\nWhy all the building and tearing down? Why\'d there have to be cities,\r\nwith crowded streets and horse cars and cable cars and electric cars\r\nand big open-work steel boxes built to the sky to be hung with stone\r\nand wood--my closest friend got killed falling off one of those steel\r\nboxkites. Shouldn\'t there be some simpler way of doing it all? 

Why did\r\nthings have to be so mixed up that a man like myself couldn\'t have a\r\nsingle clear decent thought?\r\n\r\nMore than that, why weren\'t people a real part of the world? Why didn\'t\r\nthey show more honest-to-God response? When you slept with a woman,\r\nwhy was it something you had and she didn\'t? Why, when you went to a\r\nprize fight, were the bruisers only so much meat, and the crowd a lot\r\nof little screaming popinjays? Why was a war nothing but blather and\r\nblowup and bother? Why\'d everybody have to go through their whole lives\r\nso dead, doing everything so methodical and prissy like a Sunday School\r\npicnic or an orphan\'s parade?\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAnd then, when I was reading one of the science books, it came to me.\r\nThe answer was all there, printed out plain to see only nobody saw it.\r\nIt was just this: Nobody was really alive.\r\n\r\nBack of other people\'s foreheads there weren\'t any real thoughts or\r\nminds, or love or fear, to explain things. The whole universe--stars\r\nand men and dirt and worms and atoms, the whole shooting match--was\r\njust one great big engine. 

It didn\'t take mind or life or anything else\r\nto run the engine. It just ran.\r\n\r\nNow one thing about science. It doesn\'t lie. Those men who wrote those\r\nscience books that showed me the answer, they had no more minds than\r\nanybody else. Just darkness in their brains, but because they were\r\nmachines built to use science, they couldn\'t help but get the right\r\nanswers. They were like the electric brains they\'ve got now, but hadn\'t\r\nthen, that give out the right answer when you feed in the question. I\'d\r\nlike to feed in the question, "What\'s Life?" to one of those machines\r\nand see what came out. 

Just figures, I suppose. I read somewhere that\r\nif a billion monkeys had typewriters and kept pecking away at them\r\nthey\'d eventually turn out all the Encyclopedia Brittanica in trillions\r\nand trillions of years. Well, they\'ve done it all right, and in jig\r\ntime.\r\n\r\nThey\'re doing it now.\r\n\r\nA lot of philosophy and psychology books I worked through really fit\r\nin beautifully. There was Watson\'s _Behaviorism_ telling how we needn\'t\r\neven assume that people are conscious to explain their actions. There\r\nwas Leibitz\'s _Monadology_, with its theory that we\'re all of us lonely\r\natoms that are completely out of touch and don\'t effect each other in\r\nthe slightest, but only seem to ... because all our little clockwork\r\nmotors were started at the same time in pre-established harmony. We\r\n_seem_ to be responding to each other, but actually we\'re just a bunch\r\nof wooden-minded puppets. Jerk one puppet up into the flies and the\r\nothers go on acting as if exactly nothing at all had happened.\r\n\r\nSo there it was all laid out for me (the Professor went on, carefully\r\npinching out the end of his cigarette). That was why there was no\r\nhonest-to-God response in people. They were machines.\r\n\r\nThe fighters were machines made for fighting. The people that watched\r\nthem were machines for stamping and screaming and swearing. The bankers\r\nhad banking cogs in their bellies, the crooks had crooked cams. A woman\r\nwas just a loving machine, all nicely adjusted to give you a good time\r\n(sometimes!) but the farthest star was nearer to you than the mind\r\nbehind that mouth you kissed.\r\n\r\nSee what I mean? People just machines, set to do a certain job and\r\nthen quietly rust away. If you kept on being the machine you were\r\nsupposed to be, well and good. Then your actions fitted with other\r\npeople\'s. But if you didn\'t, if you started doing something else, then\r\nthe others didn\'t respond. They just went on doing what was called for.\r\n\r\nIt wouldn\'t matter what you did, they\'d just go on making the motions\r\nthey were set to make. They might be set to make love, and you might\r\ndecide you wanted to fight. They\'d go on making love while you fought\r\nthem. Or it might happen the other way--seems to, more often!\r\n\r\nOr somebody might be talking about Edison. And you\'d happen to say\r\nsomething about Ingersoll. But he\'d just go on talking about Edison.\r\n\r\nYou were all alone.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nExcept for a few others--not more than one in a hundred thousand, I\r\nguess--who wake up and figure things out. And they mostly go crazy and\r\nrun themselves to death, or else turn mean. 

Mostly they turn mean. They\r\nget a cheap little kick out of pushing things around that can\'t push\r\nback. All over the world you find them--little gangs of three or four,\r\nhalf a dozen--who\'ve waked up, but just to their cheap kicks. Maybe\r\nit\'s a couple of coppers in \'Frisco, a schoolteacher in K.C., some\r\nartists in New York, some rich kids in Florida, some undertakers in\r\nLondon--who\'ve found that all the people walking around are just dead\r\nfolk and to be treated no decenter, who see how bad things are and get\r\ntheir fun out of making it a little worse. Just a mean _little_ bit\r\nworse. They don\'t dare to destroy in a big way, because they know the\r\nmachine feeds them and tends them, and because they\'re always scared\r\nthey\'d be noticed by gangs like themselves and wiped out. They haven\'t\r\nthe guts to really wreck the whole shebang. But they get a kick out of\r\nscribbling their dirty pictures on it, out of meddling and messing with\r\nit.\r\n\r\nI\'ve seen some of their fun, as they call it, sometimes hidden away,\r\nsometimes in the open streets.\r\n\r\nYou\'ve seen a clerk dressing a figure in a store window? Well, suppose\r\nhe slapped its face. Suppose a kid stuck pins in a calico pussy-cat, or\r\nthrew pepper in the eyes of a doll.\r\n\r\nNo decent live man would have anything to do with nickel sadism or dime\r\nparanoia like that. He\'d either go back to his place in the machine and\r\nact out the part set for him, or else he\'d hide away like me and live\r\nas quiet as he could, not stirring things up. Like a mouse in a dynamo\r\nor an ant in an atomics plant.\r\n\r\n(The Professor went to the window and opened it, letting the sour old\r\nsmoke out and the noises of the city in.)\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nListen (he said), listen to the great mechanical symphony, the big\r\nblack combo. The airplanes are the double bass. Have you noticed how\r\nyou can always hear one nowadays? When one walks out of the sky another\r\nwalks in.\r\n\r\nPresses and pumps round out the bass section. Listen to them rumble\r\nand thump! Tonight they\'ve got an old steam locomotive helping. Maybe\r\nthey\'re giving a benefit show for the old duffer.\r\n\r\nCars and traffic--they\'re the strings. Mostly cellos and violas. They\r\npurr and wail and whine and keep trying to get out of their section.\r\n\r\nBrasses? To me the steel-on-steel of streetcars and El trains always\r\nsounds like trumpets and cornets. Strident, metallic, fiery cold.\r\n\r\nHear that siren way off? It\'s a clarinet. The ship horns are tubas,\r\nthe diesel horn\'s an oboe. And that lovely dreadful french horn is an\r\nelectric saw cutting down the last tree.\r\n\r\nBut what a percussion section they\'ve got! The big stuff, like\r\nstreetcar bells jangling, is easy to catch, but you have to really\r\nlisten to get the subtleties--the buzz of a defective neon sign, the\r\nclick of a stoplight changing.\r\n\r\nSometimes you do get human voices, I\'ll admit, but they\'re not like\r\nthey are in Beethoven\'s _Ninth_ or Holst\'s _Planets_.\r\n\r\n_There\'s_ the real sound of the universe (the Professor concluded,\r\nshutting the window). That\'s your heavenly choir. 

That\'s the music\r\nof the spheres the old alchemists kept listening for--if they\'d just\r\nstayed around a little longer they\'d all have been deafened by it. Oh,\r\nto think that Schopenhauer was bothered by the crack of carters\' whips!\r\n\r\nAnd now it\'s time for this mouse to tuck himself in his nest in the\r\ndynamo. Good night, gentlemen!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nThe big man with the iron grey hair stared morosely out the quartz\r\nwindow and across the roofs of Greater New York. Far down the canyon\r\nstreets a few motor cars still ran and over the swinging aerial bridges\r\nscattered pedestrians carefully wended their way. Their grotesque\r\nfigures with the heavy metal helmets that reminded the watching man\r\nof the half-mythical sea monsters of the past or divers that used to\r\nexplore wrecks were far different from the jostling crowds that had\r\ncrowded the ways only a few short days ago. But that was before the\r\nplague--the plague of the whispering death.\r\n\r\nJohn Cortland, United Utilities Power magnate, sighed as he turned\r\nfrom the quiet streets below. Somberly he regarded a tiny light beam\r\nthat came from the mirror of a galvanometer that trembled and danced\r\ncontinually. 

He mused over the events of the past few days and wondered\r\nat their meaning. Like a caged tiger he paced the metal lined room\r\nwaiting for the word that would spell success or disaster. Five days\r\nbefore it had first appeared. A whispering, a singing and vibrating had\r\nmanifested itself. It was not local but appeared simultaneously all\r\nover the earth. This whispering, as of elfish voices, was not annoying\r\nat first; but it changed and alternated from a shrill whine back to the\r\neery murmuring that was first noticed. Young Cavendish at the Black\r\nLaboratories had first tracked down the cause of the strange sounds--as\r\nto its ultimate origin, that was still veiled in mystery.\r\n\r\nAt the end of the first day people had become nervous, at the end\r\nof the second many were on the point of breaking, and then mankind\r\nbegan to go insane. It was too much for their nervous systems and the\r\nvibration seemed to affect the inner ear. Suddenly a well ordered\r\nplanet became a center of bedlam and chaos. Order could not be restored\r\nbecause there was no one to handle affairs. 

If Dr. Hankins had not\r\ndiscovered that iron would shield a wearer from the vibrations, mankind\r\nwould have been doomed. As it was only a few of the earth\'s heavy\r\npopulation had been able to get the protecting helmets, and some had\r\nlived in metal lined rooms. This discovery of the shielding effect of\r\niron led to the discovery that an electro-magnetic radiation between\r\ninfra-red and the short radio waves was acting on the ozone molecules\r\nto set them into vibration. To cap it all the ionized Heavyside Layer\r\nthat protected the earth from the ultra-violet rays from the sun\r\nwas decomposing also. Thus to the plague of the Whispering Death was\r\nadded the threat of sun burn--a horrible burn that killed the skin and\r\nultimately the patient.\r\n\r\nSavagely John Cortland kicked at his chair as he paced across the\r\nroom. There was one slender hope, a tiny thread that might save them\r\nat last. Europe was prostrated, Asia in turmoil, and America in chaos.\r\nAll depended on the theory that the origin of the destructive vibration\r\nthat had set their ozone molecules into their dance of death had\r\nintelligence back of it. The source of the radiation could not be found\r\nat this time, but that was not needed. If they could use the incoming\r\nradiation field as a carrier and heterodyne on it a super-imposed\r\nvibration perhaps the source could be destroyed. Japan had furnished\r\nthe formula for the opposing field, and United Utilities Power the\r\nenergy. All the great power stations on the planet had been connected\r\nup into a unit, all the tremendous kilowatts of energy had been flowing\r\nfor hours into those great reservoirs of bound energy, the artificial\r\nspace field invented by Minski of Stalingrad; and the great glass\r\nglobes at Schenectady had taken this power and had built up a voltage\r\nunthinkable. The earth was going to hurl the thunderbolts of Jove.\r\n\r\nFor hours now he had restlessly awaited the signal to release this\r\nenergy in answer to the Whispering Death. For hours the stunned planet\r\nhad awaited the moment of decision. When he would release all this pent\r\nup energy that Niagara, Victoria, and countless other water falls and\r\nmany great steam power plants that had been harnessed for man\'s use,\r\nthe carefully pre-calculated voltage would hurl an electron stream\r\nat a target, the desired wave length would be omitted by the target,\r\nand would automatically heterodyne itself on the invading field. This\r\nfrightful stream of energy would blast its generators into atoms, but\r\nit must suffice. It was earth\'s dying stroke.\r\n\r\nA bell tinkled and eagerly John Cortland rushed to answer. A quiet\r\nvoice said.\r\n\r\n"We are ready. The potential has reached maximum.

"\r\n\r\nThe zero hour had arrived. Nervously John Cortland looked around the\r\nroom, at the familiar articles, and once out the window at the sunlight\r\nand then back in.\r\n\r\nHe threw the switch.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nPhor, great leader of the once powerful Murians, gazed through the\r\nmatter shield across space to the planet hanging in the heavens. A\r\ngreat green disk outlined in pearly light with green continents and\r\nbluish-green seas pointed clearly to its nearness. The artificial\r\nsatellite that housed the observatory was circling this planet with\r\nincredible velocity. This was just what they had been looking for, an\r\nhabitable planet with intelligent beings on it to aid them in their\r\nproblems. Long ages ago they had left their planet just before their\r\nsun had become a nova and had exploded. Only a few of their peoples\r\nhad been saved and at the thought the great goggle eyes filmed in\r\nsorrow. The great journey through space had tried them all, generations\r\nhad been born and some had died. 

By necessity they had kept their\r\npopulation down until they could come to a system which might support\r\nthem. They not only needed a habitable planet but an intelligent people\r\non this planet so that they could rebuild their civilization quickly.\r\nThey were friendly and had no wish to harm the dwellers on this planet.\r\n\r\nHe did not entirely agree with the council that they should get into\r\ncommunication with these peoples before landing. Phor thought they\r\nwere wasting time to encircle this beautiful world while attempting\r\nto communicate with them. Their atmosphere analysis had shown them\r\nsmall quantities of ozone and they were bombarding the ozone with\r\na controlled radiation. This caused them to act as receivers and\r\nconverters so that intelligent communication could be set up. It was\r\njust like a radio without a receiving set. The ozone molecules did\r\nit all just before decomposing. To one side he could see the huge\r\ntransformers and generators of the tiny moonlet\'s driving plant and\r\nray generators. The actual projector hung like a huge mushroom some\r\ndistance from the generating plant. The inclined buildings, due to the\r\nhigh radius of curvature of the moonlet, looked as if they were falling\r\ndown all the time. Tiny figures of Murians ceaselessly worked about the\r\ngreat machines that had cared for them for ages.\r\n\r\nFor days now they had been keeping up the barrage, hoping to get a\r\nresponse. Their electro-telescopes had shown them that this planet\r\nhoused a people as intelligent as their own. Their great cities,\r\nships, and power stations made them long to be with the planet\'s\r\npeoples. Together they could do wonders and here they were waiting\r\nin space. 

Why this waste of time? Of course the Council was right in\r\nbelieving that the sudden appearance of unfamiliar beings might start\r\nan interplanetary war, and they could not fight a war. Their resources\r\nwere practically exhausted, their peoples few, and they had no desire\r\nto cause trouble. 

They only wanted peace and a place to live. He\r\nshrugged his scaly shoulders and cocked his vertical eye at the meters\r\ncovering the walls. No response to their messages yet. 

What could be\r\nthe matter? Of course the planet had a denser atmosphere than that they\r\nhad been accustomed to, but no matter. They could adjust themselves to\r\nit. 

Strange about the messages though. They had been exactly within the\r\naudibility range of the Murians and their antennae had no difficulty in\r\nreading them. Of course the planet\'s men would receive them just the\r\nsame. Still the prediction of Tum-tak that the denser atmosphere would\r\nincrease the pitch of the ozone molecules had to be considered. However\r\nthis increased pitch should not harm the inhabitants. Their antennae\r\nreceived them very well tests demonstrated. They had not tested them\r\nfor an effect on an inner ear structure, for they had never possessed\r\nthem. Their sound transmission had been direct.\r\n\r\nIf they did not get a response within a few more revolutions about the\r\nplanet they would be compelled to go down into the atmosphere. Wonder\r\nwhat that unusual activity about the power plants and the great crystal\r\nglobes on one of the major continents meant anyway? Perhaps they were\r\npreparing to answer their calls. But why so much power as they seemed\r\nto be accumulating? What a peculiar field! That was unknown to them.\r\nWhy these peoples had pumped more power into that one field than the\r\nMurians had developed for ages. Great peoples these inhabitants of the\r\nthird planet. Well, he would take one more glance at the great crystal\r\nglobes before turning over his place to his aide. There it was now.\r\nThe crystal globes were surrounded in crimson flame, they disappeared\r\nin blinding incandescence, and horrors, simultaneously their projector\r\nhad been surrounded by a halo of radiation that arced across to the\r\ngenerators. These exploded showering molten metal on the frightened\r\nMurians. Phor did not see the full charge arrive, blasting the moonlet\r\ninto incandescence and destroying the last of the Murians.\r\n\r\n[Illustration: "_The generators exploded showering molten metal on the\r\nfrightened Murians._"]\r\n\r\nA great flare came into being in space between earth and moon. The\r\nearthlings were greatly mystified at it, but the Whispering Death had\r\nceased. They were satisfied.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


snapped Rogers. "It\'s bad enough without your moaning!"\r\n\r\nOblivious to the captain\'s words, Lejeune patted his bottle\r\naffectionately.\r\n\r\n"In the name of heaven!" growled Geitz, leaping to his feet. Think of that cylinder in the supply\r\nroom. It contains all the photographs we took of Mercurian plant and\r\nanimal life, and the photos of Vulcan. To say nothing of the data\r\nconcerning the sun\'s corona--why, our analysis would be of infinite\r\nvalue to earth scientists!"\r\n\r\n"Quite so," Rogers said crisply. 

"But while you\'re thinking about\r\nthat, don\'t forget the three men who would be left aboard this\r\nship--think of what would happen to them." He stopped his pacing and\r\nshook a finger under the doctor\'s imposing Van Dyke. "Do you know what\r\nwould happen to them, Geitz? They\'d burn alive--they\'d cook--while on\r\nearth your scientists would hop around in glee over a few photographs\r\nof Mercury!"\r\n\r\nGeitz sat down heavily, exhausted.\r\n\r\n"The doc\'s right, Rogers," Lane interposed. "There\'s no reason for all\r\nfour of us dying when it\'s possible for one to gain freedom. And for\r\nGod\'s sake if you\'re going to do something do it in a hurry! 

We\'ll burn\r\nbefore you make up your mind!"\r\n\r\n"My mind\'s made up," Rogers retorted. "I\'m staying. In case you\'ve\r\nforgotten, a captain is the last man to leave his ship. As for you\r\nthree, fight it out among yourselves. 

Draw straws--anything. The\r\nconsequences will be your worry."\r\n\r\n"I\'ll stay," murmured Lejeune, lifting his bottle to his lips.\r\n\r\n"You don\'t mean that," said the youthful Lane. "You want to go--we all\r\nwant to go--but it can only be one of us."\r\n\r\nHe fell silent, placing his head in his hands. Rogers resumed his\r\npacing.\r\n\r\nThe ship drifted on, slowly it seemed, ever nearing the solar furnace,\r\nfalling toward the flames that were eager to dissolve the tiny cruiser\r\nlocked in an unyielding gravitational pull.\r\n\r\n"Soon," mused Lejeune. "Soon we\'ll be too close for the rocket capsule\r\nto break free of the sun\'s drag. Then there will be no doubt as to what\r\nwill be done. 

Ha!"\r\n\r\n"Damnation!" yelled Lane, jerking erect. "How can you be so confounded\r\nhappy about it all? We\'re falling into the sun, man--doesn\'t that have\r\nany effect upon you?"\r\n\r\nLejeune shrugged. "Perhaps. We are falling into the sun, yes. We\'ll\r\ndie, no doubt, so my future is definite. I know what is coming. Soon I\r\nshall be but a tiny spark, drifting nowhere in a big sun. Do I regret\r\nbeing a tiny spark? Not when I have my scotch with me."\r\n\r\n"You\'re a smart guy," Lane thrust at him. "Maybe you can tell us how to\r\nchoose the rocket capsule\'s passenger."\r\n\r\n"Simple, my friend. The captain won\'t go--he must stay with the ship. I\r\nhave no relatives, only my scotch, so I am satisfied. The doctor must\r\nstay--he\'s too fat to get in the capsule. M\'sieu Lane, the honor is\r\nyours. 

Au revoir."\r\n\r\n"Don\'t be crazy--"\r\n\r\n"Do not worry about us, my friend. We will find something to do.\r\nPerhaps I can interest the doctor and the captain in three-handed\r\nbridge. If not, we\'ll wait. 

We\'ll go soon--sssss! 

Like that."\r\n\r\nLane buried his face in his hands again.\r\n\r\nFor a few moments there was an unbroken silence. From the\r\ndouble-insulated hulls emanated a dry hotness that scorched the already\r\nblistered air. The hotness increased, rising to a fierce, intolerable\r\ndegree. It grew, inexorably, pressing against their lungs--\r\n\r\nLane floundered crazily, leaped across the control room and plucked a\r\ngun from his locker. "This\'ll make it easier," he gasped, lifting the\r\nweapon to his head. "Somebody\'s got to fly that capsule--"\r\n\r\n[Illustration: _Lane plucked a gun from his locker. "This\'ll make it\r\neasier," he gasped, lifting the weapon to his head._]\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nFor ten minutes no one spoke. It was hard to speak--each breath was a\r\ntorture to the lungs.\r\n\r\n"Lejeune," said Geitz finally, in short gasps, "in God\'s name will you\r\nget into the capsule and take that cylinder to Mercury? One of us has\r\ngot to go--for Lane\'s sake!"\r\n\r\nLejeune, sprawled out on the pilot\'s bunk, made no reply. The captain\r\nstood before the dull gray view-screen, watched him a moment,\r\nthoughtfully. "Can\'t you reverse the field?" he asked at length. 

"I\'d\r\nlike to see the System just once more."\r\n\r\nRogers had already made a few deft motions on the instrument panel.\r\nPresently, the screen came to life. Its scope possessed a bright\r\nhalo--the sun\'s glow. In the center of the screen Mercury was visible,\r\na faint, receding globe. Rogers moved the scope slowly until he found\r\nthe feeble point of light that designated the earth. He watched it\r\ngrimly. 

"Satisfied, Geitz?"\r\n\r\n"Dr. Geitz is dead," came Lejeune\'s monotone.\r\n\r\nRogers turned. The doctor lay on his face, immobile and silent.\r\n\r\n"The heat," said Rogers, "and his age."\r\n\r\nThey carried him to the supply room, laid him beside the inert form of\r\nLane.\r\n\r\nThe two men stood watching earth\'s dull glimmer on the screen. The heat\r\npressed them relentlessly, always increasing--\r\n\r\n"Take the capsule, Lejeune. You\'ve no reason to remain."\r\n\r\n"I prefer to stay, Captain Rogers. You have relatives--it is only\r\nproper that you should fly the capsule."\r\n\r\n"Under any circumstances, Lejeune, the captain does not leave his ship\r\nin distress. Rogers, stripped to the waist,\r\nperspiring, his thick black hair hanging in his eyes; Lejeune, small,\r\nwiry, faint traces of a smile lurking on his lips.\r\n\r\nSuddenly the floor shook beneath them.
