The momentum of the sunward fall increased.\r\n\r\nRegaining his balance, Rogers gasped, "Good God--the capsule!"\r\n\r\nThey saw a flash of light on the screen, saw the tiny rocket streak\r\nfor Mercury in a flare of brilliance. It dwindled rapidly to a\r\nreceding speck that was swallowed in the depths of space.\r\n\r\nSpeechless, Rogers and Lejeune raced to the supply room. They found\r\nLane there, but no Geitz and no cylinder. Needles on the face of the\r\ncapsule compartment jutting out from the wall registered zero.\r\n\r\n"He was faking," said Rogers. "He wasn\'t dead--he merely pretended, the\r\ncoward!"\r\n\r\nLejeune took a quick drink, threw a sidelong glance at Lane\'s bloody\r\nform, and walked slowly back to the control room. Rogers followed. The\r\nclicking of their heels made a sullen echo upon the blistered walls.\r\n\r\nOn the screen, something dim and remote was moving, growing in size.\r\nRogers hastened forward in amazement.\r\n\r\n"It\'s Geitz!" he breathed. 

"Lord--he was too late--he\'s falling back!"\r\n\r\n"A pity," said Lejeune. "He has so much longer to wait now. It must be\r\nhorrible."\r\n\r\n"And the cylinder," Rogers sighed. "All that information will be lost."\r\nHis tired, bloodshot eyes followed the little capsule\'s course across\r\nthe screen, back toward the flaming sun.\r\n\r\n"Perhaps," remarked Lejeune, "there will be another expedition to\r\nMercury some day, another group of scientists, with a better ship and\r\nbetter equipment. And no meteorite will prevent their safe return to\r\nearth." He hesitated, took two tumblers from a nearby cabinet and\r\nfilled them with the remaining contents of his bottle. He handed one of\r\nthem to Rogers, took the other himself. "A final toast, Captain?"\r\n\r\nRogers accepted. "To the next Mercurian expedition, Lejeune."\r\n\r\n"The next expedition, Captain Rogers."\r\n\r\nThey drank, and Lejeune sucked in a breath. "I say--it\'s getting a bit\r\nwarm in here, isn\'t it?"\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


What did\r\nthey mean? He shifted uncomfortably in the tight yellow suit, searching\r\nthe near horizon for ...\r\n\r\n_Where is it?_\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nA vague calling came from beyond the black sea curtain. Objectively,\r\nbecause he could do nothing to stop them, he watched his feet pick up,\r\nmove forward, put down; pick up, move forward, put down. Funny. He had\r\nthe feeling, the concept, that this action held meaning. It was supposed\r\nto cause some reaction, accomplish an act. He wondered at the regular\r\nmovement of his legs. One of them hurt. A hurt is a sensation of pain,\r\ncaused by over-loading sensory-units in the body; a hurt is bad, because\r\nit indicates something is wrong.\r\n\r\nSomething certainly was wrong. Something stirred in Cully\'s mind. He\r\nstopped and sat down on the sandy sea bottom, gracefully, like a ballet\r\ndancer. He examined his foot. There was a tiny hole in the yellow\r\nplastic fabric, and a thin string of red-black was oozing out. Blood. He\r\nknew.\r\n\r\nHe was bleeding. He could do nothing about it. He got up and resumed\r\nwalking.\r\n\r\n_Where is it?_\r\n\r\nCully lifted his head in annoyance at the sharp thought.\r\n\r\n"Go away," he said in a low, pleading voice. The sound made him feel\r\nbetter. He began muttering to himself.\r\n\r\n"Water, black, s-sand, hurt. Pain. Radio tanks ..."\r\n\r\nIt didn\'t sound right. After a few minutes, he was quiet. 

The\r\nmanythoughts were calling him. He must go to the manythoughts.\r\n\r\nIf his foot was bleeding, then something had happened; if something had\r\nhappened, then his foot was bleeding.\r\n\r\n"No!"\r\n\r\nIf something had happened, then maybe other things had happened--before\r\nthat. But how could something happen in a world of flat gold sand and\r\nflaccid sea? Surely there was something wrong. 

Wrong: the state of being\r\nnot-right; something had happened that was not-right. Cully stared at\r\nthe edges of the unmoving curtain before him.\r\n\r\n_Where is it?_\r\n\r\nIt was a driving, promise-filled concept. No words; just the sense that\r\nsomething wonderful lay just beyond reach. 

But this voice was different\r\nfrom the manythoughts. It was directing his body; his mind was along for\r\nthe ride.\r\n\r\nThe sameness of the sea and sand became unbearable. It was too-right,\r\nsomehow. Cully felt anger, and kicked up eddies of dust. It changed the\r\nsameness a little. He kicked more up, until it swirled around him in a\r\nthick gold haze, blotting out the terrible emptiness of the sea.\r\n\r\nHe felt another weight at his side. He found a holster and gun. He\r\nrecognized neither. Again he watched objectively as his hand pulled the\r\nblack object out and handled it. His body was evidently familiar with\r\nit, though it was strange to his eyes. His finger slipped automatically\r\ninto the trigger sheaf. His legs were still working under two drives:\r\nthe manythoughts\' urging, and something else, buried in him. A longing.\r\nUp-and-down, back-and-forth.\r\n\r\n_Where is it?_\r\n\r\nAnger, frustration flared in him. His hand shot out, gun at ready. He\r\nturned around slowly. Through the settling trail of suspended sand,\r\nnothing was visible.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAgain he was moving. Something made his legs move. He walked on through\r\nthe shrouds of Death until he felt a taut singing in his nerves. An\r\nirrational fear sprang out in him, cascading down his spine, and Cully\r\nshuddered. Ahead there was some_thing_. Two motives: get there because\r\nit (they?) calls; get there because you must.\r\n\r\n_Where is it?_\r\n\r\nThe mind-voice was excited, demanding. Something was out there,\r\nbesides the sameness. Cully walked on, trailing gold. The death-curtain\r\nparted ...\r\n\r\nAn undulating garden of blue-and-gold streamers suddenly drifted toward\r\nhim on an unfelt current. Cully was held, entranced. They flowed before\r\nhim, their colors dazzling, hypnotic.\r\n\r\n_Come closer, Earthling_, the manythoughts spoke inside his head,\r\nsoothingly.\r\n\r\n_Here it is!_ Cully\'s mind shouted.\r\n\r\nCully\'s mind was held, hypnotized, but his body moved of its own\r\nvolition.\r\n\r\nHe moved again. His mind and the manythoughts\' spoke:\r\nfulfillment--almost. 

There was one action left that must be completed.\r\n\r\nCully\'s arms moved. They detached the small black box from his pack. He\r\nmoved on into the midst of the weaving, gold-laced plants. Little\r\nspicules licked out from their flexing stalks and jabbed, unsensed, into\r\nCully\'s body to draw nourishment. From the manythoughts came the sense\r\nof complete fulfillment.\r\n\r\nFrom Cully\'s mind came further orders.\r\n\r\n_Lie down._ It was a collective concept. _Lie still. We are friends._\r\n\r\nHe could not understand. They were speaking words; words were beyond\r\nhim. His head shook in despair. 

The voices were implanting an emotion of\r\nhorror at what his hands were doing, but he had no control over his\r\nbody. It was as if it were not his.\r\n\r\nThe black box was now lying in the sand among the streaming plants.\r\nCully\'s fingers reached out and caressed a small panel. A soundless\r\n\'click\' ran through the murkiness. The strangely beautiful, gold-laced\r\nblue plants began a writhing dance. Their spicules withdrew and jabbed,\r\nwithdrew and jabbed. A rending, silent scream tore the quiet waters.\r\n\r\n_NO!_ they cried. It was a negative command, mixed in with the terrible\r\nscreaming. _Turn it off!_\r\n\r\n"Stop it, stop it!" Cully tried to say, but there were no words. He\r\ntried to cover his ears within the helmet, but the cries went on.\r\nEmotions roiled the water: pain, hurt, reproach. Cully sobbed. Something\r\nwas wrong here; something was killing the plants--the beautiful blue\r\nthings! The plants were withering, dying. He looked up at them,\r\nstupefied, not understanding, tears streaming down his face. What did\r\nthey want from him? What had he done ...\r\n\r\n_Where is it?_\r\n\r\nA different direction materialized; a new concept of desire.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nCully\'s body turned and crawled away from the wonderful, dying garden,\r\noblivious to the pleadings floating, now weakly, in the torpid water. He\r\nscuffed up little motes of golden sand, leaving a low-lying scud along\r\nthe bottom, back to the little black box in the garden. The plants, the\r\nbox, all were forgotten by now. Cully crawled on, not knowing why. A\r\nrise appeared; surprise caught Cully unaware. A change in the sameness!\r\n\r\n_Where is it?_\r\n\r\nAgain the voice was insistent. His desire was close ahead; he did not\r\nlook back at the black churning on the sea bottom. His legs worked, his\r\nchest heaved, words swirled in his mind. He topped the rise.\r\n\r\nBelow him, in the center of a shallow golden bowl, floated a long, shiny\r\ncylinder. Even from here he knew it was huge. He knew other things about\r\nit: how heavy it was; how it was; that it carried others of his kind. He\r\nhad been in it before. 

And they were waiting for him. He lurched on.\r\n\r\n"Captain! Here comes Cully!" the midshipman shouted from the airlock.\r\n"Look what they\'ve done to him!"\r\n\r\nThe old man\'s grey eyes took in the spectacle without visible emotion.\r\nHe watched the pathetic, bleeding yellow plastic sack crawl up to the\r\nship and look up. His hands reached down and lifted Cully up into the\r\nlock.\r\n\r\nThey took his suit off and stared with loathing at what had once been a\r\nman. A white scar zig-zagged across his forehead. The Captain bent\r\nclose, in range of the dim blue eyes.\r\n\r\n"It was a brave thing you did, Cully. The whole system will be grateful.\r\nVenus could never be colonized as long as those cannibals were there to\r\neat men, and drive men mad." Cully fingered the scar on his forehead,\r\nand looked unseeing into the old man\'s compassionate eyes. 

"I\'m sorry\r\nCully. 

We all are. 

But there was no other way. Prefrontal lobotomy,\r\ndestruction of your speech center ... it was the only way you could get\r\npast the telepaths and destroy them. I\'m sorry, Cully. 

The race of Man\r\nshall long honor your name."\r\n\r\nCully smiled at the old man, the words churning in his brain; but he did\r\nnot understand.\r\n\r\n_Where is it?_\r\n\r\nThe emptiness was still there.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Amazing Stories_ January 1963.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. "\r\n\r\n"I consider that an honor!" Frank snapped back.\r\n\r\nThen the music on the radio was cut off and the announcement was\r\nmade--in the calm, impersonal voice of the announcer that gave it a\r\nflavor of grotesque unreality....\r\n\r\n"--and so, although the discovery of the celestial interloper was made\r\nby astronomers some time ago, the announcement was delayed until all\r\ndoubt as to its orbit had been dispelled. "That\'s\r\nexactly what they will have--very little time."\r\n\r\n"And your people--?"\r\n\r\n"We haven\'t told them. We thought it best."\r\n\r\nThe President sighed. "We stick to our ideologies to the very end,\r\ndon\'t we?"\r\n\r\n"Policy can\'t be changed overnight. Yet great strides can be made."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t think I understand you."\r\n\r\n"I\'ll try to clarify. A nice way to end a political career."\r\n\r\n"Why don\'t you call me back and read it to me when you\'ve finished?"\r\n\r\n"I\'ll do that. Goodbye Mr. 

President."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nFrank and Dee Allison walked hand in hand down the street. Dee had been\r\ncrying but now her tears had been dried and her expression was calm.\r\nThere was a wistful light in her eyes. "It could have been so much\r\ndifferent, Frank."\r\n\r\n"Yes darling. My fault. It was my damn temper."\r\n\r\n"But I was always ready to snarl back. A wife\'s job is to--"\r\n\r\nHe squeezed her hand. "Are you afraid, baby?"\r\n\r\n"No--no. 

I won\'t be afraid as long as you\'re there to hold my hand."\r\n\r\nHe put his arm around her shoulders and drew her close and they walked\r\nwith the other people toward the Church.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe President of the United States put through a call to the Premier\r\nof Russia. Connections clicked into place across half a world and the\r\nRussian operator\'s voice came through warm and cordial. "Of course, Mr.\r\nPresident. The Premier\'s wire is always open to you. I\'ll ring him."\r\n\r\nThe phone was lifted instantly. "Mr. 

President! How nice of you to\r\ncall!"\r\n\r\n"Our previous conversation set me thinking, Mr. Premier. I want to be a\r\npart of your inspiring idea. So I\'m rewriting our own statement and I\r\nsuggest we make a joint public release. I think it will help the people\r\nof the world to face the end with greater dignity. The _knowing_--I\r\nthink--will help.

"\r\n\r\n"I\'m sure it will. How soon will your draft be finished?"\r\n\r\n"Can you give me another two hours?"\r\n\r\n"Of course. Ring me when you\'re ready. Perhaps we can set up an\r\ninternational television hookup and appear together."\r\n\r\n"I\'m sure we can."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nFrank and Dee Allison came out of church bringing some of the peace\r\nand the strength with them. Heads up. 

Eyes bright."\r\n\r\nThey walked up the street, others around them going quietly about their\r\nbusiness. The people were very calm.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe conference of astronomers and scientists realized their ghastly\r\nblunder at 11:59 a.m. For a long moment, there was stunned silence in\r\nthe room. None of them could believe that such a progressive series of\r\nerrors could have been passed from man to man and been added to by\r\neach. Through every mind went the dread of what would come out of this.\r\nIn the future it would be called the greatest hoax of all time. There\r\nwould be gigantic investigations. Possibly a goat would have to be\r\nfound. The world would never believe the truth.\r\n\r\n"We might as well make the announcement," someone said.\r\n\r\n"You make it," another scientist said. "I\'m leaving for the North Pole."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nFrank Allison heard the announcement from a loudspeaker in a store\r\nwindow on his sixth trip around the block. He\'d been walking slowly,\r\ndeep in his own thoughts and regrets--giving Dee a little more time\r\nwith her mother. Then--\r\n\r\n"--so the great danger is passed, ladies and gentlemen. 

The why and\r\nthe wherefore of it is not known at this time. We are only sure of one\r\nthing: The comet will swing away into space. Rumor has it that the size\r\nof the invading body was what threw our scientists off. But whether\r\nthe earlier announcement was sincere or merely a cruel joke will not\r\nbe known immediately. The main thing is to be thankful that an error\r\nexisted--whatever its cause--"\r\n\r\nFrank straightened his shoulders, turned and started briskly up the\r\nstreet.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe President of the United States put a call through to the Russian\r\nPremier. He awaited expectantly with the phone in his hand. But the\r\nconnections slipped into place slowly and five minutes later a voice\r\ncame across half a world. "The Premier is busy. Please inform the\r\nPresident of the United States that the Premier is engaged. Inform the\r\nPresident that I am able to connect him with the Premier\'s secretary.\r\nAsk him if that will be satisfactory."\r\n\r\nThe frost in the voice seemed to chill the President\'s ear. "I will\r\ntalk to the Premier\'s secretary."\r\n\r\nThe Secretary\'s voice was careful, guarded. "May I help you, Mr.\r\nPresident?"\r\n\r\n"Perhaps you can. ]\r\n\r\n\r\n              Jack\'s blunder was disastrous, but what he\r\n           worried about was: would Einstein have approved?\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nDear Mr. Gretch:\r\n\r\nMrs. Burroughs and I are sending your son Jack to you because we do not\r\nknow what else to do with him. As you can see, we can\'t keep him with\r\nus in his present condition.\r\n\r\nAlso, Jack owes us two weeks rent and, since Mrs. Burroughs and I are\r\nretired, we would appreciate your sending the money. It has been a dry\r\nyear and our garden has done poorly.\r\n\r\nThe only reason we put up with your son in the first place was because\r\nwe are so hard-pressed.\r\n\r\nHe saw the sign on the porch, rang the bell and paid Mrs. Burroughs a\r\nmonth\'s rent without even looking at the room. Then he ran out to his\r\ncar and commenced pulling out suitcases and boxes and dragging them\r\nupstairs.\r\n\r\nAfter the third trip, Mrs. Burroughs saw he was having trouble with\r\nthe stuff and he looked kind of worn out, so she offered to help.\r\n\r\nHe gave her a hard look, as she described it to me when I got home. He\r\nsaid, "I don\'t want anyone touching anything. Please don\'t interfere."\r\n\r\n"I didn\'t mean to interfere," my wife told him. "I only wanted to help."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t want any help," he said quietly, but with a wild look in his\r\neye, and he staggered upstairs with the last of his baggage and locked\r\nthe door.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWhen I got home, Mrs. Burroughs told me she thought I ought to take\r\na look at the new boarder. I went up, thinking we\'d have a little\r\nchat and straighten things out. 

I could hear him inside, hammering on\r\nsomething.\r\n\r\nHe didn\'t hear my first knock or the second. I got sore and nearly\r\nbanged the door down, at which time he decided to open up.\r\n\r\nI charged in, ready to fight a bear. And there was this skinny\r\nred-headed son of yours glaring at me.\r\n\r\n"That\'s a lot of hammering you\'re doing, son," I said.\r\n\r\n"That\'s the only way I can get these boxes open, and don\'t call me son."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t like to disturb you, Mr. 

Gretch, but Mrs. Burroughs is a\r\nlittle upset over the way you acted today. I think you ought to come\r\ndown for a cup of tea and get acquainted."\r\n\r\n"I know I was rude," he said, looking a little ashamed, "but I have\r\nwaited for years for a chance to get to work on my own, with no\r\ninterference. I\'ll come down tomorrow, when I have got my equipment set\r\nup, and apologize to Mrs. Burroughs then."\r\n\r\nI asked him what he was working on, but he said he would explain later.\r\nBefore I got out of the door, he was hammering again. He worked till\r\nafter midnight.\r\n\r\nWe saw Jack at mealtimes for the next few days, but he didn\'t talk\r\nmuch. We learned that he was twenty-six, in spite of his looking like a\r\nboy in his teens, that he thought Prof. Einstein the greatest man ever,\r\nand that he disliked being called son. Of his experiment, he didn\'t\r\nhave much to say then. 

He saw Mrs. Burroughs was a little nervous about\r\nhis experimenting in the guest room and he assured her it was not\r\ndangerous.\r\n\r\nBefore the week was out, we started hearing the noises. The first one\r\nwas like a wire brush going around a barrel. It went _whisk, whisk_.\r\nThen he rigged up something that went _skaboom_ every few seconds, like\r\na loud heartbeat. Once in a while, he got in a sound like a creaky\r\nwell pump, but mostly it was _skaboom_ and _whisk_, which eventually\r\nsettled down to a steady rhythm, _whiskaboom, whiskaboom_.\r\n\r\nIt was kind of pleasant.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nNeither of us saw him for two days. The noises kept going on. Mrs.\r\nBurroughs was alarmed because he did not answer her knock at mealtimes,\r\nand one morning she charged upstairs and hollered at him through the\r\ndoor.\r\n\r\n"You stop your nonsense this minute and come down to breakfast!"\r\n\r\n"I\'m not hungry," he called back.\r\n\r\n"You open this door!" she ordered and, by George, he did. "Your\r\n_whiskaboom_ or whatever it is will keep till after breakfast."\r\n\r\nHe sat at the table, but he was a tired boy. He had a cold, his eyelids\r\nkept batting, and I don\'t believe he could have lifted his coffee cup.\r\nHe tried to look awake, and then over he went with his face in the\r\noatmeal.\r\n\r\nMrs. Burroughs ran for the ammonia, but he was out cold, so we wiped\r\nthe oatmeal off his face and carried him upstairs.\r\n\r\nMy wife rubbed Jack\'s wrists with garlic and put wet towels on his\r\nface, and presently he came to. He looked wildly about the room at his\r\nmachinery. 

It was all there, and strange-looking stuff, too.\r\n\r\n"Please go away," he begged. "I\'ve got work to do."\r\n\r\nMrs. Burroughs helped him blow his nose. "There\'ll be no work for you,\r\nsonny. Not until you\'re well. 

We\'ll take care of you." He didn\'t seem\r\nto mind being called sonny.\r\n\r\nHe was sick for a week and we tended him like one of our own. We got to\r\nknow him pretty well. 

And we also got to know you.\r\n\r\nNow, Mr. Gretch, whatever you are doing in your laboratory is your own\r\nbusiness. You could be making atomic disintegrators, for all Jack told\r\nus. But he does not like or approve of it and he told us about your\r\nrunning battle with him to keep him working on your project instead of\r\nhis own.\r\n\r\nJack tried to explain his ideas for harnessing time and what he called\r\n"the re-integration principle." It was all so much _whiskaboom_ to us,\r\nso to speak, but he claimed it was for the good of mankind, which was\r\nfine with us.\r\n\r\nBut he said you would not let him work it out because there was less\r\nmoney in it than in your project, and this is why he had to get away\r\nand work and worry himself into a collapse.\r\n\r\nWhen he got well, Mrs. Burroughs told him, "From now on, you\'re going\r\nto have three meals a day and eight hours sleep, and in between you can\r\nplay on your _whiskaboom_ all you please."\r\n\r\nThe _whiskabooming_ became as familiar to us as our own voices.\r\n\r\nLast Sunday, Mrs. Burroughs and I came home from church, about noon.\r\nShe went inside through the front door to fix dinner. I walked around\r\nthe house to look at the garden. And the moment I walked past the front\r\nof the house, I got the shock of my life.\r\n\r\nThe house disappeared!\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI was too surprised to stop walking, and a step later I was standing at\r\nthe back of the house, and it was all there. I took a step back and the\r\nwhole house vanished again. One more step and I was at the front.\r\n\r\nIt looked like a real house in front and in back, but there wasn\'t any\r\nin-between. It was like one of those false-front saloons on a movie\r\nlot, but thinner.\r\n\r\nI thought of my wife, who had gone into the kitchen and, for all I\r\nknew, was as thin as the house, and I went charging in the back door,\r\nyelling.\r\n\r\n"Are you all right?"\r\n\r\n"Of course I\'m all right," she said. 

"What\'s the matter with you?

"\r\n\r\nI grabbed her and she was all there, thank heavens. She giggled and\r\ncalled me an old fool, but I dragged her outside and showed her what\r\nhad happened to our house.\r\n\r\nShe saw it, too, so I knew I didn\'t have sunstroke, but she couldn\'t\r\nunderstand it any better than I.\r\n\r\nRight about then, I detected a prominent absence of _whiskabooming_.\r\n"Jack!" I hollered, and we hurried back into the house and upstairs.\r\n\r\nWell, Mr. Gretch, it was so pitiful, I can\'t describe it. He was there,\r\nbut I never saw a more miserable human being. He was not only thin but\r\nalso flat, like a cartoon of a man who had been steamrollered. He was\r\nlying on the bed, holding onto the covers, with no more substance to\r\nhim than a thin piece of paper. 

Less.\r\n\r\nMrs. Burroughs took one of his shoulders between her thumb and\r\nforefinger, and I took the other, and we held him up. There was a\r\nbreeze coming through the window and Jack--well, he waved in the breeze.\r\n\r\nWe closed the window and laid him down again and he tried to explain\r\nwhat had happened. "Professor Einstein wouldn\'t have liked this!" he\r\nmoaned. "Something went wrong," he cried, shuddering.\r\n\r\nHe went on gasping and mumbling, and we gathered that he had hooked up\r\na circuit the wrong way. "I didn\'t harness the fourth--I chopped off\r\nthe third dimension! Einstein wouldn\'t have approved!"\r\n\r\nHe was relieved to learn that the damage had been confined to himself\r\nand the house, so far as we knew. Like the house, Jack had insides, but\r\nwe don\'t know where they are. We poured tea down him, and he can eat,\r\nafter a fashion, but there never is a sign of a lump anywhere.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThat night, we pinned him to the bed with clothespins so he wouldn\'t\r\nblow off the bed. Next morning, we rigged a line and pinned him to it\r\nso he could sit up.\r\n\r\n"I know what to do," he said, "but I would have to go back to the lab.\r\nDad would have to let me have his staff and all sorts of equipment. And\r\nhe won\'t do it."\r\n\r\n"If he thinks more of his money than he does of his own son," Mrs.\r\nBurroughs said, "then he\'s an unnatural father."\r\n\r\nBut Jack made us promise not to get in touch with you.\r\n\r\nStill, people are beginning to talk. The man from the electric company\r\ncouldn\'t find the meter yesterday, because it is attached to the middle\r\nof the outside wall and has vanished.\r\n\r\nMr. Gretch, we are parents and we feel that you will not hesitate a\r\nmoment to do whatever is necessary to get Jack back into shape. So,\r\ndespite our promise, we are sending Jack to you by registered parcel\r\npost, air mail. He doesn\'t mind the cardboard mailing tube he is rolled\r\nup in as he has been sleeping in it, finding it more comfortable than\r\nbeing pinned to the sheets.\r\n\r\nJack is a fine boy, sir, and we hope to hear soon that he is back to\r\nnormal and doing the work he wants to do.\r\n\r\nVery truly yours,\r\n\r\nW. Burroughs\r\n\r\nP.S. When Jack figures out the re-integration principle, we would\r\nappreciate his fixing our house. We get along as usual, but it makes us\r\nnervous to live in a house that, strictly speaking, has no insides. W.B.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


Fellow IRE.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n_Jan. 

25._\r\n\r\nLast night, in my dreams, I was a monstrous ant, and had been digging\r\nmyself a burrow in the soft fresh earth. The dream was intensely real,\r\nand when I awoke, I felt as tired as if I had actually been digging. My\r\narms ached, and I was astonished, upon examining my hands, to find them\r\nraw.\r\n\r\nDressing hastily, I rushed to the back yard, and there, sure enough,\r\nnear the fence, was a large hole about two feet deep and three feet\r\nlong. Hurriedly, I filled it in and returned to the house.\r\n\r\nI must rest for a few days, as I feel that the intense excitement caused\r\nby my investigations, is preying too heavily upon my mind.\r\n\r\nAt this time, I feel that I should make a brief summary of my findings\r\nin respect to the ants, so that Barclay may go over these notes upon his\r\nreturn from his vacation.\r\n\r\n_First:_ The ant colony is the source of a powerful bell-like tone which\r\nis radiated continuously on two wave-lengths, .0018 meter, and .00176\r\nmeter. This tone acts as a radio-beacon, and directs the ants to the\r\ncolony, no matter where they may be located. 

The .0018 meter wave is\r\nused by the ants for their "clacking" conversations, by means of which\r\nthey communicate with each other and the colony, receiving orders from\r\nthe directing intelligence, reporting the location of food, and\r\nrequesting help, when needed.\r\n\r\nThe wave .00176 meter, is used for sending thought images or pictures\r\nwhich may be sent with the "clacking" code, or independently. I cannot\r\nconceive a more efficient or highly specialized communications system. 

I\r\n_must_ learn their secret, their methods.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n_Jan. 30._\r\n\r\nThis morning, while sitting at the receiver in a semi-doze, with the\r\nbell-tone ringing in my ears, I fell into that state known as\r\n"day-dreaming." Little "Nippy," my beloved fox terrier, and constant\r\ncompanion, rushed into the laboratory and ran up to me.\r\n\r\nFor a moment my mind went blank. My hands shot out. I grasped the dog\r\naround the throat and began to throttle him. I had risen from my chair,\r\nand the dog was nearly dead, when I slipped and fell, pulling the phone\r\nplug out of the receiver.\r\n\r\nInstantly, my mind cleared, and words cannot express the remorse I felt\r\nat my inhuman actions. Nippy would have nothing to do with me, and\r\ncrawled dejectedly from the room, a terrified look in his eyes.\r\n\r\nI have no explanation for my actions.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n_Feb. 3._\r\n\r\nThe transmitter is ready for operation. 

I have constructed a pair of\r\nmetal disc-electrodes which clamp tightly to my head and press upon my\r\ntemples. This device will pick up the thought impulses from my brain,\r\nfeed them directly into the radio-frequency amplifier, where they will\r\nbe amplified, and then radiated in a tight directed beam.\r\n\r\nMy two ants were in their little enclosure under the microscope when I\r\nthrew the switch to the "send" position. I pictured myself as I looked\r\nas a man, and sent the thought, "I am a man."\r\n\r\nHastily, I threw the switch to the "receive" position. I looked through\r\nthe microscope.\r\n\r\nThe ants were lying on their sides. Somehow, I felt that the power was\r\ntoo great, and had stunned them. Keeping my eye to the microscope, I\r\nagain threw the switch to "send," and cut the power to half.\r\n\r\n"Get up, friends ... get up," I thought, as I pictured them rising. Sure\r\nenough ... the ants slowly regained their feet. They looked about in\r\napparent bewilderment. Back again, in "receive" position, I was\r\nconscious of the thought image,\r\n\r\n"The man ... he is the man. The man holds us here. He is killing us. We\r\nmust kill the man."\r\n\r\nThey gnashed their fierce-looking mandibles. I snapped back to "send"\r\nand thought.\r\n\r\n"No ... you must not kill the man. The man will not harm you ... he is\r\nyour friend. 

He will help you."\r\n\r\nAs I watched, the ants seemed to become less excited. From the larger of\r\nthe two, I received the thought,\r\n\r\n"We are dying. The man is killing us with his strong vibrations. We\r\nmust kill the man."\r\n\r\nThen a very powerful thought impression burst upon my brain.\r\n\r\nIt seemed to come from the colony, three feet away.\r\n\r\n"Warning to the man. Stop your thought transmissions at once! Your\r\nvibrations are killing us. We want nothing from you. We have everything\r\nwe need. You will learn nothing from us. You will stop _at once_!"\r\n\r\nI threw the switch to "send." Viewed through the microscope, the two\r\nants were lying on their backs ... dead, to all appearances.\r\n\r\n"What if I don\'t stop?" I sent the thought question, "I want to learn\r\nthe secret of your communication. In return, I will teach you many\r\nthings. I can\'t stop now!"\r\n\r\nI changed to receive, and the answer came back,\r\n\r\n"If you do not stop ... we will kill you!"\r\n\r\nI turned off the apparatus, but the powerful bell tone continued to\r\npound incessantly into my brain.\r\n\r\nI laughed. They\'d kill me ... would they? Those tiny insects ... what\r\ncould they do? Well--let them try, but I\'d get what I was after. I would\r\nnot quit now, with success so near. What if my transmissions did kill a\r\nfew of them? Of what importance were the lives of a few ants as compared\r\nto the advancement of the science of Communication?\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n_Feb. 9._\r\n\r\nI found myself digging again in the back yard yesterday. As before, I\r\nhad been "day-dreaming," when an overwhelming desire to go outside and\r\nfeel the cool moist earth between my fingers and on my face took\r\npossession of me.\r\n\r\nI rushed out into the back yard, and began digging feverishly ... madly,\r\nuntil finally I fell, exhausted. Then my mind cleared and I filled in\r\nthe hole.\r\n\r\nAbout half the ants have died, due no doubt to the strength of my\r\nradiations. No matter how low I cut the power, they still cannot live\r\nbut a short time under the force of my transmissions. They have stopped\r\nsending thought impressions entirely, and are using only their\r\n"clacking" code signals, which they seem to realize I cannot understand.\r\n\r\nI feel that they are undertaking some sort of campaign against me. For\r\nhours they congregate, closely packed, their antennae stiffly pointed\r\nstraight up. Their thought currents seem to be flowing into and merging\r\nwith the bell tone, which grows stronger and more penetrating day by\r\nday.\r\n\r\nIn my back yard, there are four large ant hills, and at each hill,\r\ncuriously, there is no activity except the same mass concentration of\r\nthe ants. Have they, too, been affected by my radiations and joined\r\nforces with the original colony against myself?\r\n\r\nThe bell tone continues to grow stronger.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n_Feb. 11_\r\n\r\nMrs. 

Winslow, the middle-aged widow, who comes to clean my house and\r\nlaboratory twice a week, was here this morning.\r\n\r\nShe is short, dumpy, and inclined to be stout. As she went about her\r\nwork, I noticed particularly the fat firm flesh of her neck, just below\r\nthe jaw. I felt an uncontrollable desire to sink my teeth deep into that\r\nflesh, and enjoy the taste of the warm fresh blood.\r\n\r\nI had actually risen from my chair to accomplish my desire, when the\r\ntelephone rang ... and my mind cleared.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n_Feb. 14._\r\n\r\nI have decided to stop my experiments with the ants.\r\n\r\nAs they refuse to send any more thought impressions, there is nothing\r\nfurther I can learn from them. Somehow, I feel that they are gaining a\r\nhold upon my mind, and that every time I listen in on the receiver, that\r\nhold becomes stronger. I firmly believe that I would have attacked poor\r\nMrs. Winslow, had not the ringing of the \'phone so opportunely\r\ninterrupted me. I have sent word for her to stay away ... as I cannot\r\ntrust myself.\r\n\r\nI keep a box of fresh earth on the table in my laboratory. I often run\r\nmy hands through it, and taste it. 

It is remarkable how much this\r\nsoothes my nerves.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n_Feb. 16._\r\n\r\nIt is too late!\r\n\r\nFor two days, I have kept my apparatus shut off. I have not so much as\r\nlooked at the ants, but still that confounded bell tone rings in my ears\r\nwith all the insistence of African tom-toms. Hour by hour ... the tone\r\nbecomes more penetrating. I cannot sleep, and can eat but little.\r\n\r\nAs a last resort, I destroyed my ant colony. I even went so far as to\r\npour boiling water on the four ant hills in my yard.\r\n\r\nStill ... the bell tone persists. I can stand it no longer!\r\n\r\nPerhaps if I were to dig ... again in the yard ... in the soothing\r\nearth, I could forget....\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n(News Clipping: From Philadelphia Banner)\r\n\r\nRADIO COMMUNICATIONS ENGINEER DEAD\r\n\r\nHoward E. Edwards, Suicide\r\n\r\n_Philadelphia, Feb. 18._ The body of Howard E. Edwards, B.S., PhD.,\r\nMember I. R. E., eminent authority on Radio Communications, aged 56, was\r\nfound this morning in the back yard of his residence, 1427 Raines\r\nAvenue. The body was almost completely buried in a long narrow hole in\r\nthe ground.\r\n\r\nAt first, foul-play was suspected, but later it appeared that Edwards\r\nhad dug himself into the ground and died of suffocation, as his nostrils\r\nand mouth were filled with dirt.\r\n\r\nDr. P. A. Hofner, who examined the body, found no wounds, stated that\r\nEdwards had been dead for about two days, and pronounced the death as a\r\nclear case of suicide, the strange means employed probably due to an\r\nunbalanced mental condition.\r\n\r\nElaborate radio apparatus upon which Edwards had been working had been\r\nsmashed to bits.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\nThis etext was produced from _Comet_ July 1941.
