he complained,\r\ntugging at the extremely "historical" sword that completed the effect\r\nof his dazzling white and gold uniform.\r\n\r\nCommodore Miller, his aide, stiffened nervously.\r\n\r\n"Around to the right of it, sir," he gestured. "As you see, the local\r\nmilitary are already keeping the route clear of onlookers. We thought\r\nit would be most impressive if your party were to descend the outer\r\nstairway from the palace balcony here ... to heighten the importance\r\nof--"\r\n\r\n"To draw out the pomp and circumstance of opening the conference?"\r\n\r\n"Well, sir ... and then across the square to the conference hall of\r\nthe capitol, outside which you will pause for a few gracious words to\r\nthe crowd--"\r\n\r\n"And that will probably be my last opportunity to enjoy the morning\r\nsunlight. Oh, well, it seems much too bright here in any case."\r\n\r\nThe commodore absently reached out to adjust a fold of his chief\'s\r\nsky-blue sash, and the marshal as absently parried the gesture.\r\n\r\n"I shall be hardly less than half an hour crossing the square," he\r\npredicted sourly. "With the cheering throngs they have undoubtedly\r\narranged, and the sunlight reflecting from all that imitation marble,\r\nit will be no place to collect one\'s thoughts."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe turned back to the huge chamber constituting the "office" of the\r\nsuite supplied by his Polluxian hosts. The skeleton staff of men and\r\nwomen remaining occupied chairs and benches along only one wall, since\r\nthe bulk of the delegation had been sent out to make themselves\r\npopular with the local populace.\r\n\r\nHennings presumed the bulk of the local populace to consist of\r\nPolluxians assigned to making themselves popular with his Ursan\r\nFederation delegation. His people would be listening politely to\r\nmyriad reasons why the Polluxians had a natural right to occupy all\r\nthe star systems from here to Castor, a dozen light-years farther\r\nfrom Terra. No one would mention the true motive--their illogical\r\nchoice in naming themselves the Twin Empire.\r\n\r\n"Well, now!" he said crisply. 

"Once more over the main points of the\r\nsituation! No, commodore, not the schedule of experts that will\r\naccompany me to the table; I rely upon you to have perfected that. But\r\nhave there been any unforeseen developments in the actual fighting?"\r\n\r\nA cluster of aides, mostly in uniform but including a few in\r\ndiscreetly elegant civilian attire, moved forward. Each was somehow\r\nfollowed within arm\'s reach by an aide of his own, so that the advance\r\npresented overtones of a small sortie.\r\n\r\nHennings first nodded to the first, a youngish man whose air suggested\r\ntechnical competence more than the assurance of great authority. The\r\nofficer placed his brief case upon the glistening surface of a large\r\ntable and touched a switch on the flap.\r\n\r\n"It\'s as well to be sure, sir," the commodore approved. "Our men have\r\nbeen unable to detect any devices, but the walls may have ears."\r\n\r\n"They won\'t scan through this scrambler, sir," asserted the young\r\nofficer.\r\n\r\nHennings accepted a seat at the table and looked up to one of the\r\nothers.\r\n\r\n"Mirelli\'s Star," an older officer reported briskly. "The same\r\nsituation prevails, with both sides having landed surface troops in\r\nforce on Mirelli II, Mirelli III, and Mirelli V, the fourth planet\r\nbeing inhabited by a partly civilized, nonhuman race protected under\r\nthe Terran Convention."\r\n\r\n"Recent engagements?"\r\n\r\n"No, sir. Maneuvering continues, but actual encounters have declined\r\nin frequency. Casualties are modest and evenly matched. General\r\nNilssen on Mirelli III continues to receive Polluxian agents seeking\r\nhis defection."\r\n\r\n"I never thought to ask," murmured Hennings. "Is he really a distant\r\nconnection of the Polluxian Nilssen family?"\r\n\r\n"It is improbable, sir, but they are polite enough to accept the\r\npretense. Of course, he rejects every offer in a very high-minded\r\nmanner, and seems to be making an adequate impression of chivalry."\r\n\r\nHe stepped back at Henning\'s nod, to be replaced by another officer.\r\n\r\n"One minor space skirmish in the Agohki system to report, sir. The\r\nadmiral in command appears to have recouped after the error of two\r\ndays ago, when that Polluxian detachment was so badly mauled. He\r\narranged the capture of three of our cruisers."\r\n\r\n"Was that not a trifle rash?" demanded Hennings.\r\n\r\n"Intelligence is inclined to think not, sir. The ships were armed only\r\nwith weapons listed as general knowledge items. The crews were not\r\nonly trained in prisoner-of-war tactics, but also well supplied with\r\nsmall luxuries. The Polluxian fleet in that system is known to have\r\nbeen in space for several months, so a friendly effect is\r\nanticipated."\r\n\r\nHennings considered the condensed report proffered for his perusal. He\r\nnoted that the Polluxians had been quite gentlemanly about notifying\r\nUrsan headquarters of the capture and of the complete lack of\r\ncasualties. He also saw that while the message was ostensibly directed\r\nto the Federation flagship, it had been beamed in such fashion as to\r\nbe conveniently intercepted at the secret Ursan Federation\r\nheadquarters on Agohki VII.\r\n\r\n"That was a bit rude of them," he commented. "We have never dragged\r\ntheir secrets into the open."\r\n\r\n"On the other hand, sir," the commodore suggested, "it may be an\r\nalmost sophisticated method of permitting us to enjoy our superior\r\nfinesse."\r\n\r\n"I am just as pleased to have the reminder," said Hennings. 

"It will\r\nserve to alert us all the more when we sit down with them over there."\r\n\r\nAn elegant civilian, a large man with patient, drooping features,\r\nstated that nothing had occurred to change the economic situation.\r\nAnother reported that unofficial channels of information were holding\r\nup as well as could be expected. A uniformed officer summarized the\r\nbattle situation in two more star systems.\r\n\r\n"Those are positions we actually desire to hold, are they not?"\r\nHennings asked. 

"Is action to be taken there?"\r\n\r\n"Plans call for local civilian riots at the height of the conference,\r\nsir."\r\n\r\n"But ... can we lay no groundwork sooner than that? Sometime in the\r\nforeseeable future, at least! 

Take it up with Propaganda, Blauvelt! It\r\nseems to me that the briefing mentioned an indigenous race on one of\r\nthese planets--"\r\n\r\nBlauvelt dropped his eyes momentarily, equivalent in that gathering to\r\na blush of intense embarrassment. Hennings coughed apologetically.\r\n\r\n"Well, now, I should not pry into arrangements I must later be able to\r\ndeny convincingly with a clear conscience. 

I can only plead, my dear\r\nBlauvelt, the tenseness of the past several days."\r\n\r\nThe officer murmured inaudibly, fumbled with his papers, and edged to\r\nthe rear rank. Someone, at Commodore Miller\'s fluttering, obtained a\r\nvacuum jug of ice water and a glass for the marshal, but Hennings\r\nchose instead to produce a long cigar from a pocket concealed beneath\r\nhis resplendent collection of medals.\r\n\r\n"My apologies to all of you," he said thoughtfully. "I fear that any\r\nof you who may expect contact with the local population had better see\r\nDr. Ibn Talal about the hypnosis necessary to counteract my little\r\nindiscretion. And now--what remains?"\r\n\r\n"Nothing but the prisoner exchange, sir," Commodore Miller announced\r\nafter collecting the eyes of the principal officers.\r\n\r\nHennings got his cigar going. He listened to confirmation of a\r\nprevious report that a massive exchange of "sick and wounded"\r\nprisoners had been accomplished, and learned that the Ursans now\r\nsuspected that they had accepted unknowingly about as many secret\r\nagents as they had sent the Polluxians.\r\n\r\n"Oh, well!" he sighed. 

"As long as the amenities were preserved! We\r\nmust be as friendly as possible about that sort of thing, or run the\r\nrisk of antagonizing them."\r\n\r\nSeeing that the commodore was tense with impatience, the marshal rose\r\nto his feet. An aide deftly received the cigar for disposal, and the\r\nparty drifted expectantly toward the balcony doors.\r\n\r\nFrom among that part of the staff which would remain to man\r\nheadquarters, an officer was dispatched to alert the Polluxian honor\r\nguard.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n_One more touch before the die is cast_, thought the marshal, as two\r\nyoung officers opened the balcony doors to admit the blare of\r\ntrumpets.\r\n\r\nCheers rolled successively across the square, rising like distant\r\nwaves from somewhere beneath the gigantic banner that draped the\r\ncapitol opposite with fiery letters spelling out "PEACE CONFERENCE."\r\n\r\nWith a dramatic gesture, Hennings held up the sheaf of reports they\r\nhad just reviewed. Smiles disappeared in response to his own serious\r\nmien.\r\n\r\n"So much for the hostilities!" he snapped. 

He tossed the reports to\r\nthe officer who would remain in charge. "_Now for the actual war!_"\r\n\r\nPivoting on his heel, he led them smartly out to the ornate balcony\r\nstairway that curved down into the sea of cheering Polluxians.\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEnd of Project Gutenberg\'s The Outbreak of Peace, by Horace Brown Fyfe\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


Or the time he let a\r\nmouse loose among the female students to illustrate chain reaction. Or\r\nthe afternoon he played boogie-woogie on the Huyler Memorial Carillon.\r\n\r\n"The absorption of knowledge," he used to say, "increases in direct\r\nproportion to the sense of humor--the belly laugh, measured in decibels,\r\nbeing constant."\r\n\r\nHe could say a thing like that and make it sound funnier than anybody\r\nelse could. It was partly the way he looked--tall and mournful and sly,\r\nwith wispy hair that had once been blond, drooping like a tired willow\r\nover his forehead.\r\n\r\nBut for all his vaudeville tactics he was by no means a second-rate\r\nscientist. Which was why he had gained his position at Southwestern\r\nTech in the first place. He refused to work directly for the government\r\n(no sense of humor, just initials, he said) but this way he could at\r\nleast be called upon for consultation at the nearby Air Force\r\nDevelopment Center, just at the foot of the mountains to the west.\r\n\r\nNow the AFDC, as it was called, didn\'t advertise what sort of thing it\r\nwas developing--but everybody knew that Lyman Dane was an expert on\r\nreactive propulsion of rocket motors. He could tell you--and frequently\r\nwould without being asked--exactly what mass ratio, nozzle diameter and\r\npropulsive velocity would be needed for the first trip to the Moon. He\r\nknew how many hours a round trip would take, both for landing there or\r\nmerely circling the body of the satellite.\r\n\r\nHe had the courses to Mars and Venus thoroughly charted--but considered\r\na trip to Jupiter somewhat impractical. So, what with Dane\'s presence\r\nand the mysterious white streaks that so often shot up into the sky like\r\nfuzzy yarn from the AFDC base, it wasn\'t hard to guess what was going\r\non.\r\n\r\nNevertheless Professor Dane was surprised and somewhat offended when the\r\nyoung man from the Federal Bureau of Investigation came to call on him\r\none afternoon. And the worst part of it was that the young man didn\'t\r\nhave much sense of humor.\r\n\r\n"As you know, sir," the young man said, "we\'ve been sighting and\r\ntracking these unidentified objects in the sky. You must have read about\r\nthose they chased near Atlanta yesterday."\r\n\r\n"Ah," said Professor Dane. "Martian through Georgia, no doubt."\r\n\r\nThe young man stared at him blankly. He seemed to Professor Dane one of\r\nthe most nondescript young men his eyes had ever beheld. He had a\r\nclean-shaven, pleasant face without exactly being handsome and his eyes\r\nwere sincere and mild. He wore a neat gray tropical worsted suit and an\r\nunobtrusive tie. 

He was about thirty. Professor Dane supposed that all\r\nthis was an advantage in his profession.\r\n\r\nThe young man went on--earnestly. "Without forming any theories about\r\nthese things we\'ve been asked to take certain precautions. I don\'t know\r\nwhether they suspect a hostile power, or what. That\'s not my job. At any\r\nrate I\'ve been given the responsibility of instituting certain security\r\ntechniques. You do after all, sir, have access to and knowledge of\r\nconsiderable classified information."\r\n\r\nThis lad reminded him somewhat of his old friend and colleague, Dr.\r\nFincher, out in California. Wally Fincher was a well-known physicist\r\nnow, though how anyone ever managed to struggle through his dry\r\nponderous books Dane didn\'t know. Probably he had gained most of his\r\nfame through his part in those experiments where they bounced radar\r\nblips off the moon, Dane thought.\r\n\r\nWally always talked in long unnecessary words. He never merely "went"\r\nwhen he could "proceed," he never simply "used" when it was possible to\r\n"utilize," he didn\'t "get things done"--he "implemented" them. Professor\r\nDane made a mental note to put in a long distance call to Wally that\r\nevening and tweak his nose a bit. Maybe Dane could pretend he was the\r\nFBI--disguise his voice and interrogate Wally, as though he were\r\ninvestigating him. He chuckled a little at the idea. Then he realized\r\nthat the young man had been talking and he hadn\'t been listening.\r\n\r\n"... so among other things, sir, we thought it best to monitor your\r\nofficial mail and hope you won\'t mind."\r\n\r\n"What?" said Dane, raising his eyebrows.\r\n\r\n"_And_ your phone. You\'ll hear a couple of clicks whenever you use it.\r\nWe\'re recording what\'s said over it--though I assure you all records\r\nobtained will be kept in strictest confidence."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nDane acquiesced. The young man finally managed to make it clear that all\r\nthis surveillance would have to be with Dane\'s permission and the\r\nprofessor, annoyed though he was, didn\'t want to appear uncooperative.\r\nHe couldn\'t resist, however, giving the young man the wrong hat when he\r\nwent out and being delighted when the young man came back for the right\r\none five minutes later. He was glad to see that something could fluster\r\nhim.\r\n\r\nBut that wasn\'t really enough. Professor Dane had been annoyed, and he\r\nneeded to express himself further--by means of the joke, which was his\r\nart--in order to regain some measure of his equilibrium and\r\nself-respect.\r\n\r\nInspiration visited him as he was climbing the stairs to his bedroom at\r\nten-thirty that evening. He stopped short, thought a minute, then began\r\nto chuckle. He turned and went downstairs again, stepped to the phone.\r\nProfessor Dane lived alone and no one else would be able to share his\r\nplanned joke--but this didn\'t matter.\r\n\r\nHe had been privately enjoying his pranks ever since, as a frail boy\r\nwith an unreasonable and dominating male parent, he had discovered that\r\nthey were one way in which he could compete with hardier souls, at times\r\neven surpass them. Never mind the audience, he thought. 

The jest was the\r\nthing!\r\n\r\nIt was an hour earlier in Los Angeles and Dr. Wallace Fincher was at\r\nhome. Dane disguised his voice--he did a lot of University Theater work\r\nand this kind of thing came to him easily. He listened first to Dr.\r\nFincher\'s arid, humorless, "Hello. Dr. 

Fincher speaking." Then he heard\r\nthe preliminary clicking, just as the FBI man had predicted.\r\n\r\n"Thandor," said Professor Dane, "this is Klon calling."\r\n\r\n"I beg your pardon?" 

said Doctor Fincher.\r\n\r\n"The jig\'s up," said Professor Dane. "Captain Ixl in propul-cruiser\r\nnine-nine-seven-three will never be able to break through. The\r\nEarthlings have set up a close watch--they\'re suspicious.

"\r\n\r\n"Who is this?" Doctor Fincher sounded startled. "Who the devil is this\r\ncalling?"\r\n\r\nDane could barely keep his laughter from breaking into his voice.\r\n"Thandor, we can come to no conclusion but that the Terrestrials are\r\ndefinitely hostile. We should have expected that from their primitive\r\nstage of development. 

They have orders to shoot any of our\r\npropul-cruisers they can catch. I suggest that we withdraw all ships of\r\nthe Franistan class immediately from their free orbits and send them on\r\na standard Keplerian course to the home planet for further\r\nconsultation."\r\n\r\n"_Is this some kind of joke?_" Fincher sounded as if he were almost\r\npanicky.\r\n\r\n"Furthermore," said Dane, "I recommend that we withdraw all agents from\r\nEarth. We can\'t conceal our superior mental development and advanced\r\ntechnology much longer.\r\n\r\n"Someone\'s bound to catch on pretty soon. I was against this plan in the\r\nGalactic Council in the first place, you\'ll remember. Well, farewell,\r\nThandor! 

I\'ll be seeing you soon in space!"\r\n\r\nAnd Professor Dane hung up before he exploded with laughter.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe laughed until the tears came to his eyes. He held his stomach with\r\nboth hands. 

He was weak. He supported himself on the stair railing and\r\nfor minutes was unable to take the first tread. With his lively\r\nscientist\'s imagination he could picture the completely bewildered look\r\non the young FBI man\'s face when he listened to this conversation on the\r\ntape recorder or whatever it was they used.\r\n\r\nHe was certainly going to have to try to get that recording from them.\r\nPlay it back for Fincher some time--Lordy, Fincher would have apoplexy\r\nevery time he heard it!\r\n\r\nHe finally gained enough strength to climb the stairs. He went into his\r\nbedroom, still chuckling weakly, still wiping the tears from his eyes,\r\nstomach muscles still aching.\r\n\r\nDr. Wallace Fincher stood there by his bed. It _was_ Fincher--the same\r\nstocky round-faced man with the steel-rimmed glasses he had always\r\nknown. It was either Fincher or the darndest hallucination he had\r\never ...\r\n\r\n"I\'m sorry, Lyman," said Dr. Fincher in a kindly but impersonal voice.\r\n"You were getting a trifle too close. I\'m afraid you have left me no\r\nchoice."\r\n\r\nHe pointed a little silvery tube at Professor Dane and there was a soft\r\nbuzzing and the smell of ozone and Professor Dane was no longer in the\r\nroom--or anywhere else.\r\n\r\nDr. Fincher sighed, adjusted his glasses and faded into the dimension\r\nthat would take him back to Los Angeles and his interrupted work.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Fantastic Universe_ Aug-Sept 1953.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and\r\n    typographical errors have been corrected without note.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


Tau was\r\n           electrical. Yet Tau could face death like a man.\r\n\r\n           [Transcriber\'s Note: This etext was produced from\r\n                      Planet Stories Summer 1948.\r\n         Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that\r\n         the U.S. copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nA gleaming binary swung in the blue sky, sending a moist warmth\r\nacross the swaying fern-growths of the _Fourteenth Planet_. 

Feathered\r\ncreatures of bright colors flashed through the underbrush and made\r\nnoises there. A figure came stalking down through the shaded clearings,\r\nand small scaly bodies scurried out of sight, leaving ungainly tracks\r\nscrawled in the swamp mud.\r\n\r\nTau, the metal man, a mechanical half-sentient messenger from the\r\nfar distant past, strode impassively along, not heeding the smaller\r\ncreatures of the jungle. He had sighted the tiny habitable world from\r\nthe distant depths of an outer galaxy, and had moored his space-ship in\r\na clearing that was not distant.\r\n\r\nHe halted his berylite six-foot body in a leafy glade and let the wind\r\nplay about his cold outer surface. 

The lens-cased inscrutable orbs in\r\nhis head peered about, taking in the scene with photographic detail.\r\n\r\n"Life! This is life!" 

he thought to himself. 

"This is the life the\r\nMaster said I would find some day."\r\n\r\nThough his memories were of a distant past, of a remote planet, and\r\nof the Master whose atoms might lie even now in the etheric dust, Tau\r\nremembered with perfect clarity. He could recall the aged countenance\r\nof the Master, the broad forehead, the jutting chin, and the determined\r\nundertone of his deep voice.\r\n\r\n"Men may die," the Master had said, "but their deeds live after them."\r\nAnd Kendall Smith\'s face had lighted inwardly as though from some deep\r\ninspiration. Tau had said nothing in reply, but in the neurochemical\r\nmechanisms of his brain the words had been imprinted forever.\r\n\r\n"You\'re just a robot," the master had said, "with responses and\r\nreactions that are the involuntary activations of metal and\r\nchemical-change impulse, yet I believe that some day in the aeons which\r\nwill pass, you will learn to reason for yourself to some extent, and\r\nperhaps understand your mission. But you will never live, even though\r\nyou may carry the germs of life into the far distant future."\r\n\r\nAnd now Tau, standing in the mire of that world of the future he had\r\ntalked about, wondered at the mystery which was called Life, and\r\ndoubted if he clearly understood what the Master had meant. One thing\r\nhe knew certainly, that his metallic body was meant to bridge the\r\nepoch which yawned between the life-lines of the past and those of the\r\nfuture. Old Kendall Smith, stalking back and forth in his laboratory,\r\nhad explained as much, and Tau had never forgotten.\r\n\r\n"Our life-line is narrowing, the earth is dying," the Master had\r\nexplained. "That one-in-a-million chance of opportune conditions in\r\nwhich life may exist is vanishing. I doubt if the circumstances can be\r\nduplicated in the entire universe. 

But someday, by the very laws which\r\ngovern chance, they must return again. It is not within the powers\r\nof man to bridge the gap of space and time, but you, Tau, the robot,\r\nswinging in the non-conducting realms of the vacuum of space, will be\r\nnext to eternal."\r\n\r\nTau had learned the secrets of extracting radiant energy from the\r\natom, had become adept in applying the forces to the mechanisms that\r\npropelled the space-ship and supplied motivation for his own metal\r\nbody. Many other secrets the Master had taught him in the laboratories,\r\nand he had come to know the uses of the scientific paraphernalia that\r\nwas sealed in the inner heart of the space-craft. When the occasion\r\ncame for Tau to use the equipment, Kendall Smith had said, he would\r\nunderstand the true nature constituting life.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe binary descended, and night fell. Glittering shards of the stars\r\npierced the black firmament. Night creatures let out occasional shrieks\r\nand snarls. Once a six-legged catlike creature, half as tall as the\r\nmetal man, was attracted by Tau\'s movements, and sprang upon him. Tau\'s\r\nresponses were mechanical, and he knew no such thing as fear. He simply\r\nripped the creature apart with the tremendous strength that surged in\r\nhis metal arms.\r\n\r\n[Illustration: _Tau tore him to pieces._]\r\n\r\nLater that night he returned to the space-ship. As he approached the\r\ngleaming ovoid a circular door opened. Crossing its threshold, he\r\npassed into the interior, distorted by intricate mechanisms, and the\r\naperture closed behind him.\r\n\r\nSlowly Tau walked to the center of the room, his body reflected in\r\ngleaming surfaces of berylite stanchions and sheathings. In the center\r\nof the whorled contrivances a row of ingenious troughs lay exposed.\r\nEach of these troughs was centered by a molding that had the perfect\r\noutline of a man, empty in the crystalline interior.\r\n\r\nAll that night iridescent gleamings crawled along the monstrous\r\nglassite tubes, illuminating the busy robot with an eerie splendor.\r\nMiniature lightning shot and sparkled from insulated spheres high in\r\nthe nose of the craft. Pulsating, sluggish liquids gave off radiant\r\ncolors and seeped through tortuous channels along the tubes of\r\nglassite. The central troughs became opaque, and formed a webwork\r\nnow into which the throbbing aqueous masses were assembling. A chill\r\ncurrent of the outer atmosphere was forced by rotating blades along a\r\nchannel that whirled in a maelstrom around the central apparatus.\r\n\r\nTau worked swiftly, but days fled by as he watched the quiescent gauges\r\nand indicators, lengthened into months. Blinding storms raged unheeded\r\non the exterior of the ovoid craft. Winter came and fled.\r\n\r\nAt last David and his tribe came to life, all molded from a magnificent\r\nscale. During those long months of creation, Tau had imprinted\r\nknowledge and learning upon the brains of the dormant bodies. Each\r\nawoke with a full knowledge of what had transpired on the dying planet\r\nof earth, and each knew that a strange new-born world awaited them. The\r\nlargest and most magnificent man was named David. The Master had been\r\ncareful in instructing Tau about that. Kendall Smith had never had a\r\nson. And this synthetic offspring in a distant life-line of the cosmos\r\nwould be almost like a son for him.\r\n\r\nAll of Tau\'s knowledges were conveyed to David and his followers, and\r\nhe led them into the unknown dangers of the pristine jungled planet,\r\nguarding them from the ferocious animals while they learned the edible\r\nfruits from the poisonous ones. Gradually David\'s men came to recognize\r\nthe dangers and constructed weapons for their own defense.\r\n\r\nAnother winter descended upon the new world. Food had been stored in\r\nthe big compartment of the space vessel. Furs of slain animals had been\r\ncured to provide clothing and warmth.\r\n\r\nSpring thaws came and Tau led them again into the jungle, but now David\r\nwas big and strong and wary, quite able to defend himself against the\r\ndangers of the forest, and Tau\'s presence was hardly needed, though he\r\nalways hovered near.\r\n\r\nFive men and five women had been given life by Tau\'s instruments, and\r\nit was inevitable that a gradual pairing off would take place. Myri, a\r\nmodel of womanly perfection, had grown to adore the handsome leader of\r\nthe tribe, and Tau was one of the first to notice signs of fecundity.\r\n\r\nA terrific storm lashed the planet. Giant trees groaned and split\r\nacross the trunks. The raging downpour built up into outer floods that\r\nraged down the lowlands in mighty rivers, sweeping everything in its\r\npath to destruction. Of all this Tau was oblivious. The fury of the\r\ntempest was deadened by the berylite walls of the space-ship, and not\r\nas loud as the shrill cry of the new-born babe.\r\n\r\nThunder boomed outside. 

Lightning forked across the rent heavens,\r\nsending flickering flashes of illumination through the beating sheets\r\nof rain that poured across the glassite sheathing above the neglected\r\ncontrol mechanisms. David the second was born, and for a brief time was\r\ncuddled against the breast of the metal man, whose terribly strong arms\r\nof metal held him as lightly and delicately as could a bed of thistle\r\ndown. The imperturbable orbs of immobile transparency gazed downward,\r\nand suddenly Tau staggered.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nDavid took the child with a startled cry and stood eyeing the tottering\r\nrobot. Tau\'s consciousness was centered upon his dragging limbs and\r\nfor a moment his mentality flickered as though it were gone, then\r\nreturned. He saw that his metallic body was dark and stained with an\r\nodd encrustation, and he turned and made his way to the cubicle in\r\nwhich he had sat while an aeon of time slipped away in the depths of\r\ninterplanetary space, and the life-line of one aeon had merged with\r\nanother.\r\n\r\nThere was one hooded mechanism at which he always sat, and when he was\r\njust so, the mind of the Master would speak from down the ages, and the\r\nimage of Kendall Smith arose, as it had always done, in his mind. He\r\nthought he visualized the Master now, out of the dim consciousness of\r\nthe past. Tall and arresting with the vigorous personality of a dynamic\r\nintelligence, the keen grey eyes peered at him again, as they had done\r\nin the distant past.\r\n\r\n"You, Tau, are just a man of metal," the Master was saying "and yet\r\nI\'ve a feeling that part of myself is implanted within you just as part\r\nof my mind is implanted into the mechanisms of your consciousness. As\r\na thing of metal, floating in a non-conducting void, you are something\r\nthat is almost eternal. Yet if you succeed in finding a habitable\r\nworld, such as the earth has been in the past, the atmosphere of that\r\nplanet will suffuse about you, and in the triumph of my wishes will lie\r\nyour downfall. Oxides of the surrounding air will cause your gradual\r\ndeterioration, and the only one who could help you will be nothing\r\nmore than motes of cosmic dust in the unpredictable corners of the\r\nsurrounding universe."\r\n\r\nUnseen by David or any of the others, Tau slipped to the door and down\r\na corridorway. Through an aperture he could glimpse the inner room\r\nwhere Myri lay, nursing the infant at her breast. For just an instant\r\nhe paused, for the Master had never seemed closer than in that single\r\nmoment.\r\n\r\nTurning finally, the metal man walked impassionately through the\r\ndoorway and vanished into the driving blasts of the lashing storm.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


"\r\n\r\nThey glowered at each other. Then Les rubbed her cheek with the back of\r\nhis hand, and smiled.\r\n\r\n"Thanks, kid," he said. "You really had me going for a minute. 

Now I\r\nfeel better!"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nPleased with the compliment, Janet concocted an extra-fancy combination\r\nof films to spray on herself for the morning\'s wear. When it was\r\nin place, she ordered a large breakfast and arranged to have the\r\nwaiter-doll do a special dance-routine while serving.\r\n\r\nBut Les\'s smile had vanished with the whiskers he\'d rubbed off. He\r\npicked at his food, turned his back on the dancing, and afterward\r\nyawned away the few minutes they spent on their apartment\'s terrace,\r\nstared at by fifty thousand neighbors who lacked anything better to do.\r\nWhen Les wandered idly off, Janet followed.\r\n\r\nLes went to the living room, projected a book onto the ceiling,\r\nswitched it off without reading, played with the glowing phosphors\r\nthat lighted the room in colors he varied jarringly, fiddled with the\r\nconsole of the perfume aerosol and created a stink, and then, in sheer\r\ndespair, turned on the puppet-set.\r\n\r\nIts lighted screen listed the necessary dolls and props, so he laid\r\nthem out. Soon the three-foot stage reflected a broadcast picture of\r\nthe State Executive Office. A stringless, formally-dressed puppet sat\r\nat a desk, its blank face a transmitted facsimile of the Governor\'s.\r\n\r\n"... the last time I can make this announcement," the Governor was\r\nsaying into a hidden microphone. "The tests are to begin at noon. Jobs\r\nare now open! I repeat: jobs are now open! Men only, of course. But if\r\nany of you fellows out there suffer from boredom--and who doesn\'t in\r\nthis wonderful State of ours that by virtue of the New Energy-Sources\r\nguarantees leisured security to each citizen--if, I repeat, you suffer\r\nfrom ennui, then why not apply for a job?\r\n\r\n"Do it now--no further vacancies will occur for years, and we have some\r\nreally desirable positions open this morning. Appointments will be made\r\nstrictly on merit, as usual, with a job for every applicant and the\r\nbest job for the top man.\r\n\r\n"Though it\'s true that losers in this competition are required to\r\nassume for life the less desirable duties that our civilization\r\nimposes, I assure you that isn\'t as bad as it sounds. I was pretty far\r\ndown the list in my day, yet I only have to be Governor....\r\n\r\n"So won\'t you please apply? I want a _lot_ of competition!"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe stage darkened, and the puppet got up and walked to its box. Before\r\nthe lights could go up on the next program, Les switched the set off.\r\n\r\n"What do you think?" he asked Janet.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know," she said. "Nobody in _my_ family has ever worked."\r\n\r\n"Mine, either. But I once knew a fellow who\'d tried for a job. He\r\nseemed o.k. 

to me, but he sure didn\'t get a good one! Had a clerical\r\nposition, with business machines, and their output was geared down\r\nto spread the work. So he didn\'t have enough to do ... just stacked\r\npunched cards or something every day for eighty years!"\r\n\r\n"Oh, you\'d do better than that, dear!"\r\n\r\n"Maybe. Point is, there _are_ jobs worse than no job at all!"\r\n\r\n"I\'m not so sure!" Janet said, suddenly determined. "Only a few minutes\r\nago you weren\'t very happy about the idle days ahead. Why not take a\r\nchance?

"\r\n\r\n"Take a chance? What kind of language is that? Chance went out along\r\nwith disease and poverty and crime and accidents. You\'re way off base,\r\nJan!

"\r\n\r\n"But you have a chance--oh, all right!--an opportunity, then, if you\r\nlike that better, to get a _good_ job. Now, if I were a man--"\r\n\r\n"But you\'re not.... Still ... maybe I\'ll try it...."\r\n\r\nFor the first time in a month or two, Janet kissed him warmly. And\r\nafter she\'d helped him into his wings and seen him off from the\r\nterrace, she felt a strange warm glow of anticipation. Not since she\'d\r\nmarried had there been need for a decision that could bring change into\r\nher life. This was a Day!\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIt was a Day for a lot of others, too. She learned that from the noon\r\nbroadcast of the test ceremony.\r\n\r\n"In my time," the Governor said, speaking from the Capitol\'s rotunda,\r\n"in my time a hundred aspirants was considered a good turnout. Today\'s\r\napplicants total a thousand! We haven\'t actually got a thousand jobs\r\nlined up, but we\'ll get \'em! And I\'m privileged to announce, now that\r\nthe list of competitors has closed, that we do have the astoundingly\r\nlarge number of ten--repeat, ten--genuinely desirable appointments to\r\nmake."\r\n\r\nTen good jobs for a thousand applicants didn\'t sound to Janet\r\nlike an astoundingly large number. She\'d been sprawled on a\r\nmagnetically-positioned pad half-way between floor and ceiling, but\r\nshe sat up when the Governor stopped talking, and with a twinge of\r\ngenuine and unwonted anxiety watched the long file of applicants as\r\nthey approached in turn the brain-wave analyzer, the voice-operated\r\nsorter that would add their life-files to current test results, and the\r\nofficials who judged each man\'s configuration.\r\n\r\nShe wished they\'d announce the test results publicly, but knew they\r\nwouldn\'t. So, when Les had gone through--about twenty minutes after the\r\nstart--Janet shut off the broadcast, dissolved her dress-films, and\r\nhad herself rubbed by the massage machine. The morning\'s suspense was\r\nproving too much for her, and she didn\'t want to have a headache when\r\nLes came home.\r\n\r\nBut even the mechanical masseuse couldn\'t rub away her strange\r\nfeelings. Not since marriage had Janet felt curiosity as to the future.\r\n\r\nWhat if he got so dull they never even argued about anything? She\r\nshivered at the thought--but then she smiled. And for the next hour\r\nJanet lay under the soothing massage and gave herself up to the\r\ndelightful new pleasure of worrying.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWhen Les returned, shadowing the terrace in his descent like some\r\nportentous bird, Janet began to shake. Without even waiting to kiss\r\nhim, she said, "How was it? 

How did you do?

"\r\n\r\nLes grinned teasingly. "Help me moult, first," he said. "I\'m tired."\r\n\r\nUnable to get anything else out of him until it was done, she tore\r\nhis wings off damagingly, kissed him, and said, "_Now_ won\'t you say\r\nsomething?"\r\n\r\n"I\'m hungry!"\r\n\r\n"No!" She danced her impatience like a little girl. "Tell me!"\r\n\r\nBut even as she pouted, her eyes sparkled in anticipation.\r\n\r\n"I start tomorrow," he said.\r\n\r\n"Did you get the best job?"\r\n\r\n"Nope. No, I really didn\'t.

"\r\n\r\n"What, then?"\r\n\r\n"Second best!"\r\n\r\n"Oh, wonderful! 

What is it?"\r\n\r\n"Rigger and high-climber--topping trees, setting structural iron,\r\nfixing flag-poles--that sort of thing. Powderman was first."\r\n\r\n"Oh, rigger\'s wonderful!" Visions of his future work flashed across her\r\nmind, implanted there by childhood hours spent watching other members\r\nof this elite profession at their thrilling work. She knew there could\r\nbe broken cables, falling pulleys, snapped booms, dropped loads--every\r\nday would have its interesting possibilities!\r\n\r\n"My darling!" She threw her arms around him and was momentarily\r\nsilenced by his kiss.\r\n\r\nThen she stepped back, looked admiringly up at him, and said, "Oh, I\'m\r\nso happy for you! And so proud! 

I\'m going right in and order up a nice\r\nbig meal. 

I know you\'ll enjoy this one--it really _might_ be your last!"\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\n    _They say the Lion and the\r\n      Lizard keep\r\n    The Courts where Jamshyd\r\n      gloried and drank deep_--\r\n\r\n    --_The Rub\xc3\xa1iy\xc3\xa1t_\r\n\r\n\r\nThe dust-reddened sun was low in the west when the tribe filed down\r\nfrom the fissured foothills to the sea. The women spread out along the\r\nbeach to gather driftwood, while the men took over the task of setting\r\nup the rain-catch.\r\n\r\nRyan could tell from the haggard faces around him that there would\r\nbe a dance that night. He knew his own face must be haggard too,\r\nhaggard and grimed with dust, the cheeks caved in, the eyes dark with\r\nhunger-shadows. The dogless days had been many this time.\r\n\r\nThe rain-catch was a crazy quiltwork pattern of dogskins laboriously\r\nsewn together into a makeshift tarpaulin. Ryan and the other young men\r\nheld it aloft while the older men set up the poles and tied the dog-gut\r\nstrings, letting the tarp sag in the middle so that when it rained the\r\nprecious water would accumulate in the depression. When the job was\r\ndone, the men went down to the beach and stood around the big fire the\r\nwomen had built.\r\n\r\nRyan\'s legs ached from the long trek through the hill country and his\r\nshoulders were sore from packing the dogskin tarp over the last five\r\nmiles. Sometimes he wished he was the oldest man in the tribe instead\r\nof the youngest: then he would be free from the heavy work, free to\r\nshamble along in the rear on marches; free to sit on his haunches\r\nduring stopovers while the younger men took care of the hunting and the\r\nlove-making.\r\n\r\nHe stood with his back to the fire, letting the heat penetrate his\r\ndogskin clothing and warm his flesh. Nearby, the women were preparing\r\nthe evening meal, mashing the day\'s harvest of tubers into a thick\r\npulp, adding water sparingly from their dogskin waterbags. Ryan\r\nglimpsed Merium out of the corner of his eye, but the sight of her\r\nthin young face and shapely body did not stir his blood at all, and he\r\nturned his eyes miserably away.\r\n\r\nHe remembered how he had felt about her at the time of the last dog\r\nkill--how he had lain beside her before the roaring fire, the aroma\r\nof roasted dog flesh still lingering in the night air. His belly had\r\nbeen full and he had lain beside her half the night, and he had almost\r\nwanted her. She had seemed beautiful then, and for many days afterward;\r\nbut gradually her beauty had faded away and she had become just another\r\ndrab face, another listless figure stumbling along with the rest of the\r\ntribe, from oasis to oasis, from ruin to ruin, in the eternal search\r\nfor food.\r\n\r\nRyan shook his head. He could not understand it. 

But there were so\r\nmany things that he could not understand. The Dance, for instance. Why\r\nshould the mouthing of mere words to the accompaniment of rhythmic\r\nmovements give him pleasure? How could hatred make him strong?\r\n\r\nHe shook his head again. In a way, the Dance was the biggest mystery of\r\nall....\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nMerium brought him his supper, looking up at him shyly with her large\r\nbrown eyes. Illogically, Ryan was reminded of the last dog he had\r\nkilled and he jerked the earthen pot out of her hands and walked down\r\nto the water\'s edge to eat alone.\r\n\r\nThe sun had set. Streaks of gold and crimson quivered in the\r\nwind-creased water, slowly faded away. Darkness crept down from the\r\ngullied foothills to the beach, and with it came the first cold breath\r\nof night.\r\n\r\nRyan shivered. He tried to concentrate on his food, but the memory of\r\nthe dog would not go away.\r\n\r\nIt had been a small dog, but a very vicious one. It had bared its teeth\r\nwhen at last he had cornered it in the little rocky cul-de-sac in the\r\nmountains, and as further evidence of its viciousness, it had wagged\r\nits ridiculous tail. Ryan could still remember the high-pitched sound\r\nof its growl--or was it a whine?--when he advanced on it with his club;\r\nbut most of all he remembered the way its eyes had been when he brought\r\nthe club down on its head.\r\n\r\nHe tried to free himself from the memory, tried to enjoy his tasteless\r\nmeal. But he went right on remembering. He remembered all the other\r\ndogs he had killed and he wondered why killing them should bother him\r\nso. Once, he knew, dogs had run with the hunters, not from them; but\r\nthat was long before his time--when there had been something else\r\nbesides dogs to hunt.\r\n\r\nNow it was different. Now it was dogs--or death....\r\n\r\nHe finished his meatless stew, swallowing the last mouthful grimly. He\r\nheard a soft step behind him, but he did not turn around. Presently\r\nMerium sat down beside him.\r\n\r\nThe sea glinted palely in the light of the first stars.\r\n\r\n"It\'s beautiful tonight," Merium said.\r\n\r\nRyan was silent.\r\n\r\n"Will there be a dance?" she asked.\r\n\r\n"Maybe.

"\r\n\r\n"I hope there is."\r\n\r\n"Why?

"\r\n\r\n"I--I don\'t know. Because everyone\'s so different afterwards, I\r\nsuppose--so happy, almost."\r\n\r\nRyan looked at her. Starlight lay gently on her child-like face, hiding\r\nthe thinness of her cheeks, softening the hunger-shadows beneath her\r\neyes. Again he remembered the night he had almost wanted her and he\r\nwanted it to be the same again, only all the way this time. He wanted\r\nto want to take her in his arms and kiss her lips and hold her tightly\r\nto him, and when desire refused to rise in him, shame took its place,\r\nand because he couldn\'t understand the shame, he supplanted it with\r\nanger.\r\n\r\n"Men have no happiness!" he said savagely.\r\n\r\n"They did once--a long time ago.

"\r\n\r\n"You listen too much to the old women\'s tales."\r\n\r\n"I like to listen to them. I like to hear of the time when the ruins\r\nwere living cities and the earth was green--when there was an abundance\r\nof food and water for everyone.... Surely you believe there was such a\r\ntime. The words of the Dance--"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know," Ryan said. "Sometimes I think the words of the Dance\r\nare lies."\r\n\r\nMerium shook her head. "No. The words of the Dance are wisdom. Without\r\nthem we could not live."\r\n\r\n"You talk like an old woman yourself!" Ryan said. Abruptly he stood up.\r\n"You _are_ an old woman. 

An ugly old woman!" He strode across the sand\r\nto the fire, leaving her alone by the water.\r\n\r\nThe tribe had broken up into groups. The old men huddled together in\r\none group, the younger men in another. The women sat by themselves near\r\nthe wavering perimeter of the firelight, crooning an ancient melody,\r\nexchanging an occasional word in low tones.\r\n\r\nRyan stood by the fire alone. He was the youngest male of the tribe.\r\nHe and Merium had been the last children to be born. The tribe had\r\nnumbered in the hundreds then, and the hunting had been good, the dogs\r\nstill tame and easy to find. There had been other tribes too, wandering\r\nover the dust-veiled land. Ryan wondered what had become of them. 

But\r\nhe only pretended to wonder. In his heart, he knew.\r\n\r\nIt was growing colder. He added more driftwood to the fire and watched\r\nthe flames gorge themselves. Flames were like men, he thought. They ate\r\neverything there was in sight, and when there was nothing more to eat,\r\nthey died.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nSuddenly a drum throbbed out and a woman\'s voice chanted: "What is a\r\ntree?"\r\n\r\nA voice answered from the group of old men: "A tree is a green dream."\r\n\r\n"What has become of the living land?

"\r\n\r\n"The living land is dust!"\r\n\r\nThe drum beat grew louder. Ryan\'s throat tightened. He felt the\r\nrefreshing warmth of anger touch his face. The opening phase of the\r\nDance always affected him, even when he was expecting it.\r\n\r\nOne of the old men was moving out into the firelight, shuffling his\r\nfeet to the beat of the drum. The light reddened the wrinkles on his\r\nthirty-year-old face, made a crimson washboard of his forehead. His\r\nthin voice drifted on the cold night air:\r\n\r\n    "_The living land is dust, and those\r\n    who turned it into dust\r\n    are dust themselves_--"\r\n\r\nA woman\'s voice took up the chant:\r\n\r\n    "_Our ancestors are dust:\r\n    dust are our gorged ancestors_--"\r\n\r\nThere were other figures shuffling in the firelight now, and the\r\nbeat on the dogskin drum head was sharper, stronger. Ryan felt the\r\nquickening of his blood, the surge of new-born energy.\r\n\r\nVoices blended:\r\n\r\n    "_Dust are our gorged ancestors,\r\n    our ancestors who raped the\r\n      fields and ravished the hills,\r\n    who cut the forest chains and\r\n      set the rivers free;\r\n    our ancestors who drank deep\r\n      from the well of the world\r\n    and left the well dry_--"\r\n\r\nRyan could contain himself no longer. He felt his own feet moving with\r\nthe vindictive beat of the drum. He heard his own voice take up the\r\nchant:\r\n\r\n    "_Let us take the memory of our ancestors\r\n    and tear it open, rend its vitals,\r\n    throw its entrails on the fire:\r\n    our ancestors, the eaters,\r\n    the putrefiers of the lakes and the rivers;\r\n    the consumers, the destroyers, the murderers of the living land;\r\n    the selfish, the obese, the great collectors,\r\n    who tried to devour the world_--"\r\n\r\nHe joined the stomping mass of the tribe, his hands going through the\r\nmimic motions of killing, rending, throwing. Strength flowed into his\r\nemaciated limbs, pulsed through his undernourished body. He glimpsed\r\nMerium across the fire and he caught his breath at the beauty of her\r\nanimated face. Again he almost wanted her, and for a while he was able\r\nto convince himself that some day he _would_ want her; that this time\r\nthe effect of the Dance would not wear off the way it always had\r\nbefore and he would go on feeling strong and confident and unafraid and\r\nfind many dogs to feed the tribe; then, perhaps, the men would want the\r\nwomen the way they used to, and he would want Merium, and the tribe\r\nwould increase and become great and strong--\r\n\r\nHe raised his voice higher and stomped his feet as hard as he could.\r\nThe hatred was like wine now, gushing hotly through his body, throbbing\r\nwildly in his brain. The chant crescendoed into a huge hysterical wail,\r\na bitter accusation reverberating over the barren hills and the dead\r\nsea, riding the dust-laden wind--\r\n\r\n    "_Our ancestors were pigs!\r\n    Our ancestors were pigs!..._"\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


"\r\n\r\n"Thank you, Professor," Gloria simpered. "I made them myself."\r\n\r\n"You must give us the recipe," said one of the ladies--and the others\r\nmurmured agreement, glad to get their individualities on a plane they\r\ncould understand.\r\n\r\n"Since most decisions are hardly as momentous as the individual\r\nimagines," Professor Falabella continued, "and since the imagination of\r\nthe average individual is very limited, many of these different\r\nplanes--or, as they are colloquially known, space-time continuums--may\r\nexist in close, even tangential relationship."\r\n\r\nGloria rose unobtrusively and took the teapot to the kitchen for a\r\nrefill. "\r\n\r\n"Horses," he observed, "have sense."\r\n\r\nHe was being brutal, but he couldn\'t help it and didn\'t want to.\r\nProfessor Falabella was only the most long-winded of a long series of\r\nmystics Gloria was forever dragging into the house. _The trouble with\r\nthe half-educated_, he thought bitterly, _is that they seek culture in\r\nthe most peculiar places_.\r\n\r\n"I\'ll bet she would have let me have peace on Sunday," he said. She looked sexy, but how deceiving appearances could be!\r\n\r\nProfessor Falabella was still talking as Bill and Gloria emerged from\r\nthe kitchen. Gloria restrained tears with an\r\neffort.\r\n\r\n"Brute," someone muttered.\r\n\r\nBut ridicule apparently only stimulated the professor. He beamed. 

"You\r\ndon\'t believe me. Your imagination cannot extend to the comprehension of\r\nthe multifariousness of space."\r\n\r\n"Nonsense," Bill said again, but less confidently.\r\n\r\n"I believe that I have discovered the Doorway," Professor Falabella\r\ncontinued, "and the Way is Open. His teeth were very sharp and white. 

"Very\r\nwell, Mr. Hughes, since you are a skeptic, perhaps you will not object\r\nto being the subject of our experiment yourself?"\r\n\r\n"What kind of an experiment?" "\r\n\r\n"That is all. Of course, you go with the awareness that it is the\r\nthreshold of another plane and that you step voluntarily from this\r\nexistence to an adjacent one."\r\n\r\n"Sure," Bill said. He had just remembered there was a nearly full bottle\r\nof Calvert in the bottom drawer of the desk. "Sure. 

Anything to oblige."\r\n\r\n"Very well. Go to the door, and keep remembering that of your own free\r\nwill you are passing from this plane to the next."\r\n\r\n"Look out, everybody!" A\r\nwonderful excuse to get away from those blasted women. He\'d climb out of\r\nthe window as soon as he\'d collected the whiskey and give them a nervous\r\nmoment thinking he\'d really passed into another existence. It would\r\nserve Gloria right.\r\n\r\nFor a moment, as he crossed, he had a queer sensation. Maybe there was\r\nsomething in what Professor Falabella said. But no, there he was in the\r\nstudy. 

All that mumbo jumbo was getting him down, that was all. He was a\r\nnervous man--only nobody appreciated the fact.\r\n\r\nTaking a cigarette out of the pack in his pocket, he reached for the\r\nlighter on his desk. It wasn\'t there. Time and time again he\'d told\r\nGloria not to touch his things, and always she\'d disobeyed him. Company\r\nwas coming and she must tidy up. Cooking and cleaning--that was all she\r\nwas good for. But this was carrying tidiness too far; she\'d even removed\r\nthe ashtrays.\r\n\r\nAnd where did that glass block paperweight come from? He\'d had a penguin\r\nin a snowstorm and he\'d been happy with it. This was too much. 

He\'d tell\r\nGloria off. Stealing a man\'s penguin!\r\n\r\nHe opened the door into the living room and bumped into Lucy Allison.\r\n"Don\'t you think you\'ve been in there long enough, Bill?" she asked\r\nacridly. 

"I\'m sure your guests would appreciate catching a glimpse of\r\nyou."\r\n\r\n"Why, hello, Lucy," he said, surprised. "I didn\'t know Gloria had\r\ninvited you--"\r\n\r\n"Gloria, Gloria, Gloria!" The thick,\r\ntwo-foot-long pest lay very still on the ground, and she only got a\r\nglimpse of it before it jumped. 

Out it whipped to its full, slim,\r\nsix-foot length and wrapped around her throat. Fangs struck, and in\r\nthree seconds--with a loud _slurp_--it had withdrawn a quart of her\r\nblood. "I\'ve been slurped!"\r\n\r\n"Again?" her lanky husband asked, looking up from the reports on his\r\ndesk.\r\n\r\n"I\'m so sorry, Pole," she said contritely.\r\n\r\n"Well, sit down and start recovering, Bliss," he said in a kindly\r\nmanner. Darn that vacuum snake and his\r\nfast draft."\r\n\r\n"I just hope the neighborhood dragon doesn\'t come around while you\'re\r\nin that weakened condition, Bliss," Pole worried as he totaled up the\r\nmonth\'s production on his reports. He decided, "I had better take time\r\noff from pretzin hunting today so I can be handy to help you with your\r\ngetaway, if need arises."\r\n\r\n"Oh, the dragon never bothers us," Bliss said uneasily.\r\n\r\n"He has gotten close enough to burn up several of our pretzin patches,\r\nthough. He may get to this cabin some day."\r\n\r\n"He doesn\'t mean any harm," defended Bliss. "I\'m sure he wouldn\'t want\r\nto eat us. They are known to be strictly vegetarians."\r\n\r\n"No, he won\'t eat us. 

He\'ll cook us, unless we can run away fast\r\nenough--but he\'ll never eat us."\r\n\r\nThey heard a faraway sound.\r\n\r\n"What is that crisp crackling that sounds like a dank forest burning?"\r\nwondered Bliss.\r\n\r\nPole scrambled to the door. "The dragon is coming! He\'s headed straight\r\nfor this cabin!"\r\n\r\n"Shall we be going?" asked Bliss, grabbing her clothes.\r\n\r\nA few minutes later, at a distance of a thousand yards, Pole and Bliss,\r\nloaded with all their portable possessions, watched their cabin burst\r\ninto flames as a roaring, forty-foot lizard, with fifty-foot flames\r\ngouting from his mouth, ambled through their clearing.\r\n\r\n"There, he\'s gone," said Pole as the dragon passed on. "I\'d better put\r\nout the fire."\r\n\r\nDipping water from a nearby pond with a bucket, Pole had, after\r\nfifty-three fast buckets, a blackened ruin of what had formerly been\r\ntheir rude jungle cabin.\r\n\r\nPole moved a new, nearly finished split-pole settee he had been working\r\non back in the jungle to their front porch. As they seated themselves,\r\nhe complacently surveyed the slits burned between the charred boards of\r\nthe walls and roof. "The roof will leak a mite when it rains, but it\r\nwill let in lots of light," he observed optimistically.\r\n\r\n"There\'s nothing like lots of light," Bliss agreed.\r\n\r\n"Charcoal is healthful, too."\r\n\r\n"It absorbs poison like nobody\'s business!"\r\n\r\n"However, since it rains every day on Venus we will have to have a new\r\ncabin." He sighed resignedly. "And you know what that means: Lower\r\nproduction, fewer of the magical, antibiotic pretzins. I\'d better radio\r\nthe Division Chief."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAs the jet plane flashed across their vision, the Kentons saw a tiny\r\nbundle drop from it. Pole ran out into the jungle and was under the\r\nparachute when it landed. He came back into the clearing unwrapping a\r\npackage.\r\n\r\n"It sure was thoughtful of Mr. Wattles to answer so fast," said Pole,\r\nas he opened the little package. "And will you look here in the middle!\r\nHe even sent us a present!"\r\n\r\n"It\'s a beautiful, plain white, rectangular carton of approximately\r\nthree by seven inches," she said breathlessly.\r\n\r\n"But we mustn\'t be selfish," Pole reminded hastily. "Let\'s see what Mr.\r\nWattles has to say in his memorandum here first." They both read the\r\ngreen memorandum.\r\n\r\n    To: Napoleon B. Kenton, Special Agent, Pretzin Division, Venus\r\n\r\n    From: Chief, Pretzin Division, Venusport, Venus\r\n\r\n    Subject: Personal Problems of Special Agents\r\n\r\n    In a radio message dated January 25, 1982 you related certain\r\n    personal problems you were experiencing, and you stated that delays\r\n    might be encountered in your harvesting of pretzins. "\r\n\r\n"Isn\'t he the nicest man?"\r\n\r\nThey read on.\r\n\r\n    In your radio message you refer to difficulties you are having with\r\n    a snake and a lizard (which you colloquially refer to as a dragon).\r\n    It is believed that the enclosed package, serial number 93G-18,\r\n    will cope with the matter, and that no further report will be\r\n    necessary with respect to snakes and lizards.\r\n\r\n    Carl Wattles\r\n    Chief, Pretzin Division\r\n\r\nEagerly Bliss Kenton opened the plain white carton bearing the serial\r\nnumber 93G-18. "\r\n\r\n"As before?" Without waiting for an answer, he continued, the coin\r\nclutched tightly in one hand. "I\'m Charles J. Fisher, professor of\r\nPhilosophy at Reiser College."\r\n\r\nHe looked at me quickly. 

"Or at least I was until recently." For a\r\nsecond his face was boyish. "Professor of Philosophy, that is."\r\n\r\nI smiled and found that I was staring at the coin in his hand. He gave\r\nit to me. On one side I read the words: THE STATEMENT ON THE OTHER SIDE\r\nOF THIS COIN IS FALSE. The patient watched me with an expressionless\r\nface; I turned over the coin. It was engraved with the words: THE\r\nSTATEMENT ON THE OTHER SIDE OF THIS COIN IS FALSE.\r\n\r\n"That\'s not the problem," he said, "not _my_ problem. I had the coin\r\nmade when I was an undergraduate. I enjoyed reading one side, turning\r\nit over, reading the other side, and so on. A fiendish enjoyment like\r\nboys planning where to put the tipped-over outhouse."\r\n\r\nI looked at the patient. He was thirty-eight, single, medium build, had\r\nan M.A. and Ph.D. 

from an eastern university. I knew this and more from\r\nthe folder on my desk.\r\n\r\n"Eight months ago," he continued, "I read about the sphere found on\r\nPaney Island." He stopped, looking at me questioningly.\r\n\r\n"Yes, I know," I said. I opened my desk drawer, took out a clipping\r\nfrom the newspaper, and handed it to him.\r\n\r\n"That\'s it."\r\n\r\nI read the clipping before putting it back in the drawer.\r\n\r\n    Manila, Sept. 24 (INS) Archeologists from University of California\r\n    have discovered in earth fault of recent quake a sphere two feet in\r\n    diameter of an unidentifiable material.\r\n\r\n    Dr. Karl Schwartz, head of the group, said the sphere was returned\r\n    to the University for study. He declined to answer questions on the\r\n    cultural origin of the sphere.\r\n\r\n"There wasn\'t any more in the newspapers about it," he said. "I have a\r\nfriend in California who got me the photographs.

"\r\n\r\n_He looked at me intently. 

"You won\'t believe any of this." He pressed\r\nthe coin into the palm of his hand. "You won\'t be able to."_\r\n\r\n"The photographs," he continued, as if lecturing, "were of characters\r\nprojected by the sphere when placed before a focused light. The sphere\r\nwas transparent, you see, imbedded with dark microscopic specks. By\r\nmoving the sphere a certain distance each time, there was a total\r\nprojection of three hundred and sixty different characters in eighteen\r\ndifferent orderings. Or nineteen different orderings if you count one\r\nwhich was a list of all the characters."\r\n\r\nI made a mental note of the numbers. I felt they were significant.\r\n\r\n"As I said," he continued, "I obtained the photographs of the\r\ncharacters. Very strange shapes, totally unlike the characters of\r\nOriental languages, but yet that is the closest way to describe them."\r\nHe jerked forward in his chair, "Except, of course, ostensively.

"\r\n\r\n"Later," I said. 

I wanted to get through the preliminaries first. There\r\nwould be time later to see the photographs.\r\n\r\n                     *      *      *      *      *\r\n\r\n"The characters projected by the sphere," he said, "weren\'t like the\r\ncharacters of any known language." He paused dramatically. "There was\r\nreason to believe they had origin in an unknown culture. A culture more\r\nscientifically advanced than our own."\r\n\r\n"And the reasons for this supposition?" I asked.\r\n\r\n"The material ... the material of the sphere. It could only be roughly\r\nclassified as _ferro-plastic_. Totally unknown, amazing imperviousness.\r\nA synthetic material, hardly the product of a former culture."\r\n\r\n"From Mars?" I said, smiling.\r\n\r\n"There were all kinds of conjectures, but, of course, the important\r\nthing was to see if the projection of characters was a message. The\r\nmessage, if any, would mean more than any conjecture."\r\n\r\n"You translated it?"\r\n\r\n_He polished the coin on his jacket. "You won\'t dare believe it," he\r\nsaid sharply._\r\n\r\nHe cleared his throat and stiffened into a more rigid posture. "It\r\nwasn\'t exactly translation. You see, _to us_ none of the characters had\r\ndesignation. They were just characters."\r\n\r\n"So it was a problem of decoding?" I asked.\r\n\r\n"As it turned out, no. Decoding is dependent on knowledge of language\r\ncharacteristics--characteristics of known languages. Decoding was\r\ntried, but without success. No, what we had to find was a key to the\r\nlanguage."\r\n\r\n"You mean like the Rune Stone?"\r\n\r\n"More or less. No, I had\r\nto work on the assumption that the key to the sphere was implicit in\r\nthe sphere."\r\n\r\n"You hoped to find the key to the language in the language itself?"\r\n\r\n"Exactly. You know, of course, some languages do have an implicit key?\r\nFor example hieroglyphics or picture language. The word for _cow_ is a\r\npicture of a cow.

"\r\n\r\n_He looked at the toes of his shoes. "You won\'t be able to believe it.\r\nIt\'s impossible to believe. I use the word impossible in its logical\r\nsense._\r\n\r\n"In most languages," he continued, looking up from his shoes, "the\r\nsound of some words themselves indicates the meaning of the word.\r\nOnomatopoetic words like _bowwow, buzz_."\r\n\r\n"And the key to the unknown language?" I asked. 

"How did you find it?"\r\n\r\n                     *      *      *      *      *\r\n\r\nI watched him push the coin against the back of his arm, then lift it\r\nto read the backward letters pressed into his skin. He looked up at me\r\nand smiled.\r\n\r\n"I built models of the characters. Big material ones, exactly\r\nproportionate to the ones projected. No one can believe\r\nit."_\r\n\r\n"In addition to the visual response, the distortions gave me definite\r\nfeelings. "And the translation?"\r\n\r\n"Doctor, what would you say if I told you the translation was\r\nunbelievable; that it couldn\'t be seriously entertained by any man?\r\nWhat if I said that it would take the sanity of any man who believed\r\nit?"\r\n\r\n"I would say that it might well be incorrect."\r\n\r\nHe took some papers from his pocket and laughed excitedly, slumping\r\ndown in the chair. Moreover, keep in mind that physics accepts the\r\npath of a beam of light as its definition of a straight line. Yet, the\r\npath is a curve; if extended sufficiently it would be a circle, the\r\nsection of a sphere.

"\r\n\r\n"All right," I said. By now the patient was pounding the coin against\r\nthe sole of one shoe.\r\n\r\n"And," he said, "keep in mind that in some sense time can be thought of\r\nas another dimension."
