copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n     _Because this is a masculine world, the author of this fairytale is\r\n     usually identified as the wife of Poul Anderson. But a few more\r\n     incisive cameos of fantasy such as this, and Mr. Anderson may come\r\n     to be identified as Karen\'s husband._\r\n\r\n\r\nThe edge of the world is fenced off stoutly enough, but the fence isn\'t\r\nmade that will stop a boy. Johnny tossed his pack and coil of rope over\r\nit and started climbing. 

The top three strands were barbed wire. He\r\ncaught his shirt as he went over, and had to stop for a moment to ease\r\nhimself off. Then he dropped lightly to the grass on the other side.\r\n\r\nThe pack had landed in a clump of white clover. A cloud of disturbed\r\nbees hung above, and he snatched it away quickly lest they should notice\r\nthe honeycomb inside.\r\n\r\nFor a minute he stood still, looking out over the edge. This was\r\ndifferent from looking through the fence, and when he moved it was\r\nslowly. He eased himself to the ground where a corner of rock rose clear\r\nof the thick larkspur and lay on his belly, the stone hard and cool\r\nunder his chin, and looked down.\r\n\r\nThe granite cliff curved away out of sight, and he couldn\'t see if it\r\nhad a foot. He saw only endless blue, beyond, below, and on both sides.\r\nClouds passed slowly.\r\n\r\nDirectly beneath him there was a ledge covered with long grass where\r\nclusters of stars bloomed on tall, slender stalks.\r\n\r\nHe uncoiled his rope and found a stout beech tree not too close to the\r\nedge. Doubling the rope around the bole, he tied one end around his\r\nwaist, slung the pack on his back, and belayed himself down the cliff.\r\nPebbles clattered, saxifrage brushed his arms and tickled his ears; once\r\nhe groped for a hold with his face in a patch of rustling ferns.\r\n\r\nThe climb was hard, but not too much. Less than half an hour later he\r\nwas stretched out on the grass with stars nodding about him. They had a\r\nsharp, gingery smell. He lay in the cool shadow of the world\'s edge for\r\na while, eating apples and honeycomb from his pack. When he was finished\r\nhe licked the honey off his fingers and threw the apple cores over,\r\nwatching them fall into the blue.\r\n\r\nLittle islands floated along, rocking gently in air eddies. Sunlight\r\nflashed on glossy leaves of bushes growing there. 

When an island drifted\r\ninto the shadow of the cliff, the blossoming stars shone out. Beyond the\r\nshadows, deep in the light-filled gulf, he saw the hippogriffs at play.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThere were dozens of them, frisking and cavorting in the air. He gazed\r\nat them full of wonder. 

They pretended to fight, stooped at one another,\r\nsoared off in long spirals to stoop and soar and stoop again. One\r\nflashed by him, a golden palomino that shone like polished wood. The\r\nwind whistled in its wings.\r\n\r\nAway to the left, the cliff fell back in a wide crescent, and nearly\r\nopposite him a river tumbled over the edge. A pool on a ledge beneath\r\ncaught most of the water, and there were hippogriffs drinking. One side\r\nof the broad pool was notched. The overflow fell sheer in a white plume\r\nblown sideways by the wind.\r\n\r\nAs the sun grew hotter, the hippogriffs began to settle and browse on\r\nthe islands that floated past. Not far below, he noticed, a dozen or so\r\nstood drowsily on an island that was floating through the cliff\'s shadow\r\ntoward his ledge. It would pass directly below him.\r\n\r\nWith a sudden resolution, Johnny jerked his rope down from the tree\r\nabove and tied the end to a projecting knob on the cliff. Slinging on\r\nhis pack again, he slid over the edge and down the rope.\r\n\r\nThe island was already passing. The end of the rope trailed through the\r\ngrass. He slithered down and cut a piece off his line.\r\n\r\nIt was barely long enough after he had tied a noose in the end. He\r\nlooked around at the hippogriffs. They had shied away when he dropped\r\nonto the island, but now they stood still, watching him warily.\r\n\r\nJohnny started to take an apple out of his pack, then changed his mind\r\nand took a piece of honeycomb. He broke off one corner and tossed it\r\ntoward them. They fluttered their wings and backed off a few steps, then\r\nstood still again.\r\n\r\nJohnny sat down to wait. They were mostly chestnuts and blacks, and some\r\nhad white stockings. One was piebald. That was the one which, after a\r\nwhile, began edging closer to where the honeycomb had fallen. Johnny sat\r\nvery still.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe piebald sniffed at the honeycomb, then jerked up its head to watch\r\nhim suspiciously. He didn\'t move. After a moment it took the honeycomb.\r\n\r\nWhen he threw another bit, the piebald hippogriff wheeled away, but\r\nreturned almost at once and ate it. Johnny tossed a third piece only a\r\nfew yards from where he was sitting.\r\n\r\nIt was bigger than the others, and the hippogriff had to bite it in two.\r\nWhen the hippogriff bent its head to take the rest Johnny was on his\r\nfeet instantly, swinging his lariat. He dropped the noose over the\r\nhippogriff\'s head. For a moment the animal was too startled to do\r\nanything; then Johnny was on its back, clinging tight.\r\n\r\nThe piebald hippogriff leaped into the air, and Johnny clamped his legs\r\nabout convulsed muscles. Pinions whipped against his knees and wind\r\nblasted his eyes. The world tilted; they were rushing downward. His\r\nknees pressed the sockets of the enormous wings.\r\n\r\nThe distant ramparts of the world swung madly, and he seemed to fall\r\nupward, away from the sun that suddenly glared under the hippogriff\'s\r\ntalons. He forced his knees under the roots of the beating wings and dug\r\nheels into prickling hair. A sob caught his breath and he clenched his\r\nteeth.\r\n\r\nThe universe righted itself about him for a moment and he pulled breath\r\ninto his lungs. Then they plunged again. 

Wind searched under his shirt.\r\nOnce he looked down. After that he kept his eyes on the flutter of the\r\nfeather-mane.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nA jolt sent him sliding backward. He clutched the rope with slippery\r\nfingers. The wings missed a beat and the hippogriff shook its head as\r\nthe rope momentarily checked its breath. It tried to fly straight up,\r\nlost way, and fell stiff-winged. The long muscles stretched under him as\r\nit arched its back, then bunched when it kicked straight out behind. The\r\nviolence loosened his knees and he trembled with fatigue, but he wound\r\nthe rope around his wrists and pressed his forehead against whitened\r\nknuckles. Another kick, and another. Johnny dragged at the rope.\r\n\r\nThe tense wings flailed, caught air, and brought the hippogriff upright\r\nagain. The rope slackened and he heard huge gasps. Sunlight was hot on\r\nhim again and a drop of sweat crawled down his temple. It tickled. 

He\r\nloosened one hand to dab at the annoyance. A new twist sent him sliding\r\nand he grabbed the rope. The tickle continued until he nearly screamed.\r\nHe no longer dared let go. Another tickle developed beside the first. He\r\nscrubbed his face against the coarse fibre of the rope; the relief was\r\nlike a world conquered.\r\n\r\nThen they glided in a steady spiral that carried them upward with\r\nscarcely a feather\'s motion. When the next plunge came Johnny was ready\r\nfor it and leaned back until the hippogriff arched its neck, trying to\r\nfree itself from the pressure on its windpipe. Half choked, it glided\r\nagain, and Johnny gave it breath.\r\n\r\nThey landed on one of the little islands. The hippogriff drooped its\r\nhead and wings, trembling.\r\n\r\nHe took another piece of honeycomb from his pack and tossed it to the\r\nground where the hippogriff could reach it easily. While it ate he\r\nstroked it and talked to it. When he dismounted the hippogriff took\r\nhoneycomb from his hand. He stroked its neck, breathing the sweet warm\r\nfeathery smell, and laughed aloud when it snuffled the back of his neck.\r\n\r\nTying the rope into a sort of hackamore, he mounted again and rode the\r\nhippogriff to the pool below the thunder and cold spray of the\r\nwaterfall. He took care that it did not drink too much. When he ate some\r\napples for his lunch, the hippogriff ate the cores.\r\n\r\nAfterward he rode to one of the drifting islands and let his mount\r\ngraze. For a while he kept by its side, making much of it. 

With his\r\nfingers, he combed out the soft flowing plumes of its mane, and examined\r\nits hoofs and the sickle-like talons of the forelegs. He saw how the\r\nsmooth feathers on its forequarters became finer and finer until he\r\ncould scarcely see where the hair on the hindquarters began. Delicate\r\nfeathers covered its head.\r\n\r\nThe island glided further and further away from the cliffs, and he\r\nwatched the waterfall dwindle away to a streak and disappear. After a\r\nwhile he fell asleep.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe woke with a start, suddenly cold: the setting sun was below his\r\nisland. 

The feathery odor was still on his hands. He looked around for\r\nthe hippogriff and saw it sniffing at his pack.\r\n\r\nWhen it saw him move, it trotted up to him with an expectant air. He\r\nthrew his arms about the great flat-muscled neck and pressed his face\r\nagainst the warm feathers, with a faint sense of embarrassment at\r\nfeeling tears in his eyes.\r\n\r\n"Good old Patch," he said, and got his pack. He shared the last piece of\r\nhoneycomb with his hippogriff and watched the sun sink still further.\r\nThe clouds were turning red.\r\n\r\n"Let\'s go see those clouds," Johnny said. He mounted the piebald\r\nhippogriff and they flew off, up through the golden air to the sunset\r\nclouds. There they stopped and Johnny dismounted on the highest cloud of\r\nall, stood there as it turned slowly gray, and looked into dimming\r\ndepths. When he turned to look at the world, he saw only a wide smudge\r\nof darkness spread in the distance.\r\n\r\nThe cloud they were standing on turned silver. Johnny glanced up and saw\r\nthe moon, a crescent shore far above.\r\n\r\nHe ate an apple and gave one to his hippogriff. While he chewed he gazed\r\nback at the world. When he finished his apple, he was about to toss the\r\ncore to the hippogriff, but stopped himself and carefully took out the\r\nseeds first. With the seeds in his pocket, he mounted again.\r\n\r\nHe took a deep breath. "Come on, Patch," he said. 

"Let\'s homestead the\r\nmoon."\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEnd of Project Gutenberg\'s The Piebald Hippogriff, by Karen Anderson\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


"\r\n\r\n"Know what?" Eklund demanded. 

"What does it say? Does she accept?"\r\n\r\n"She accepts," Christianson said in a peculiar half-strangled tone as he\r\npassed the letter to Eklund. "See for yourself."\r\n\r\nEklund\'s reaction was different. His face was a mottled reddish white as\r\nhe finished the letter and handed it across the table to Carlstrom. "Why,"\r\nhe demanded of no one in particular, "did this have to happen to us?"\r\n\r\n"It was bound to happen sometime," Carlstrom said. "It\'s just our\r\nmisfortune that it happened to us." He chuckled as he passed the letter\r\nback to Christianson. "At least this year the presentation should be an\r\nevent worth remembering."\r\n\r\n"It seems that we have a little problem," Christianson said, making what\r\nwould probably be the understatement of the century. Possibly there would\r\nbe greater understatements in the remaining ninety-nine years of the\r\nTwenty-first Century, but Carlstrom doubted it. "We certainly have our\r\nnecks out," he agreed.\r\n\r\n"We can\'t do it!" Eklund exploded. "We simply can\'t award the Nobel Prize\r\nin medicine and physiology to that ... that _C. Edie_!" He sputtered into\r\nsilence.\r\n\r\n"We can hardly do anything else," Christianson said. "There\'s no\r\nquestion as to the identity of the winner. Dr. Hanson\'s letter makes\r\nthat unmistakably clear. And there\'s no question that the award is\r\ndeserved."\r\n\r\n"We still could award it to someone else," Eklund said.\r\n\r\n"Not a chance. We\'ve already said too much to the press. It\'s known all\r\nover the world that the medical award is going to the discoverer of the\r\nbasic cause of cancer, to the founder of modern neoplastic therapy."\r\nChristianson grimaced. "If we changed our decision now, there\'d be all\r\nsorts of embarrassing questions from the press."\r\n\r\n"I can see it now," Carlstrom said, "the banquet, the table, the flowers,\r\nand Professor Doctor Nels Christianson in formal dress with the Order\r\nof St. Olaf gleaming across his white shirtfront, standing before that\r\ndistinguished audience and announcing: \'The Nobel Prize in Medicine and\r\nPhysiology is awarded to--\' and then that deadly hush when the audience\r\nsees the winner."\r\n\r\n"You needn\'t rub it in," Christianson said unhappily. 

"I can see it, too."\r\n\r\n"These Americans!" Eklund said bitterly. He wiped his damp forehead. The\r\npicture Carlstrom had drawn was accurate but hardly appealing. "One simply\r\ncan\'t trust them. Publishing a report as important as that as a laboratory\r\nrelease. They should have given proper credit."\r\n\r\n"They did," Carlstrom said. "They did--precisely. But the world, including\r\nus, was too stupid to see it. We have only ourselves to blame."\r\n\r\n"If it weren\'t for the fact that the work was inspired and effective,"\r\nChristianson muttered, "we might have a chance of salvaging this situation.\r\nBut through its application ninety-five per cent of cancers are now\r\ncurable. It is obviously the outstanding contribution to medicine in the\r\npast five decades."\r\n\r\n"But we must consider the source," Eklund protested. "This award will make\r\nthe prize for medicine a laughingstock. No doctor will ever accept another.\r\nIf we go through with this, we might as well forget about the medical award\r\nfrom now on. This will be its swan song. 

It hits too close to home. Too\r\nmany people have been saying similar things about our profession and its\r\ntrend toward specialization. And to have the Nobel Prize confirm them\r\nwould alienate every doctor in the world. We simply can\'t do it."\r\n\r\n"Yet who else has made a comparable discovery? Or one that is even half as\r\nimportant?" 

Christianson asked.\r\n\r\n"That\'s a good question," Carlstrom said, "and a good answer to it\r\nisn\'t going to be easy to find. For my part, I can only wish that Alphax\r\nLaboratories had displayed an interest in literature rather than medicine.\r\nThen our colleagues at the Academy could have had the painful decision."\r\n\r\n"Their task would be easier than ours," Christianson said wearily. "After\r\nall, the criteria of art are more flexible. Medicine, unfortunately, is\r\nbased upon facts."\r\n\r\n"That\'s the hell of it," Carlstrom said.\r\n\r\n"There must be some way to solve this problem," Eklund said. "After all\r\nit was a perfectly natural mistake. We never suspected that Alphax was a\r\nphysical rather than a biological sciences laboratory. Perhaps that might\r\noffer grounds--"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t think so," Carlstrom interrupted. "The means in this case aren\'t\r\nas important as the results, and we can\'t deny that the cancer problem is\r\nvirtually solved."\r\n\r\n"Even though men have been saying for the past two generations that the\r\nanswer was probably in the literature and all that was needed was someone\r\nwith the intelligence and the time to put the facts together, the fact\r\nremains that it was C. Edie who did the job. And it required quite a bit\r\nmore than merely collecting facts. 

Intelligence and original thinking of\r\na high order was involved." Christianson sighed.\r\n\r\n"Some_one_," Eklund said bitterly. "Some _thing_ you mean. _C.\r\nEdie_--C.E.D.--Computer, Extrapolating, Discriminatory. Manufactured\r\nby Alphax Laboratories, Trenton, New Jersey, U.S.A. _C. 

Edie!_\r\nAmericans!!--always naming things. A machine wins the Nobel Prize.\r\nIt\'s fantastic!"\r\n\r\nChristianson shook his head. 

"It\'s not fantastic, unfortunately. 

And I\r\nsee no way out. We can\'t even award the prize to the team of engineers who\r\ndesigned and built Edie. Dr. Hanson is right when he says the discovery was\r\nEdie\'s and not the engineers\'. It would be like giving the prize to Albert\r\nEinstein\'s parents because they created him."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Is there any way we can keep the presentation secret?" Eklund asked.\r\n\r\n"I\'m afraid not. The presentations are public. We\'ve done too good a job\r\npublicizing the Nobel Prize. As a telecast item, it\'s almost the equal of\r\nthe motion picture Academy Award."\r\n\r\n"I can imagine the reaction when our candidate is revealed in all her\r\nmetallic glory. A two-meter cube of steel filled with microminiaturized\r\ncircuits, complete with flashing lights and cogwheels," Carlstrom chuckled.\r\n"And where are you going to hang the medal?"\r\n\r\nChristianson shivered. "I wish you wouldn\'t give that metal nightmare a\r\npersonality," he said. "It unnerves me. 

Personally, I wish that Dr. Hanson,\r\nAlphax Laboratories, and Edie were all at the bottom of the ocean--in some\r\nnice deep spot like the Mariannas Trench." He shrugged. 

"Of course, we\r\nwon\'t have that sort of luck, so we\'ll have to make the best of it."\r\n\r\n"It just goes to show that you can\'t trust Americans," Eklund said. "I\'ve\r\nalways thought we should keep our awards on this side of the Atlantic where\r\npeople are sane and civilized. Making a personality out of a computer--ugh!\r\nI suppose it\'s their idea of a joke."\r\n\r\n"I doubt it," Christianson said. "They just like to name things--preferably\r\nwith female names. It\'s a form of insecurity, the mother fixation. But\r\nthat\'s not important. I\'m afraid, gentlemen, that we shall have to make\r\nthe award as we have planned. I can see no way out. After all, there\'s no\r\nreason why the machine cannot receive the prize. The conditions merely\r\nstate that it is to be presented to the one, regardless of nationality,\r\nwho makes the greatest contribution to medicine or physiology."\r\n\r\n"I wonder how His Majesty will take it," Carlstrom said.\r\n\r\n"The king! I\'d forgotten that!" Eklund gasped.\r\n\r\n"I expect he\'ll have to take it," Christianson said. "He might even\r\nappreciate the humor in the situation."\r\n\r\n"Gustaf Adolf is a good king, but there are limits," Eklund observed.\r\n\r\n"There are other considerations," Christianson replied. "After all, Edie is\r\nthe reason the Crown Prince is still alive, and Gustaf is fond of his son."\r\n\r\n"After all these years?"\r\n\r\nChristianson smiled. Swedish royalty _was_ long-lived. It was something\r\nof a standing joke that King Gustaf would probably outlast the pyramids,\r\nproviding the pyramids lived in Sweden. "I\'m sure His Majesty will\r\ncooperate. He has a strong sense of duty and since the real problem is\r\nhis, not ours, I doubt if he will shirk it."\r\n\r\n"How do you figure that?" Eklund asked.\r\n\r\n"We merely select the candidates according to the rules, and according\r\nto the nature of their contribution. Edie is obviously the outstanding\r\ncandidate in medicine for this year. It deserves the prize. We would\r\nbe compromising with principle if we did not award it fairly."\r\n\r\n"I suppose you\'re right," Eklund said gloomily. "I can\'t think of any\r\nreasonable excuse to deny the award."\r\n\r\n"Nor I," Carlstrom said. "But what did you mean by that remark about\r\nthis being the king\'s problem?"\r\n\r\n"You forget," Christianson said mildly. "Of all of us, the king has the\r\nmost difficult part. As you know, the Nobel Prize is formally presented\r\nat a State banquet."\r\n\r\n"Well?"\r\n\r\n"His Majesty is the host," Christianson said. copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nThad Morgan looked around his little room. The two deactivated robots\r\nand the framework that suspended the limp suit hardly left room for him\r\nto move around. At the moment he felt mildly disgusted with this whole\r\nconvention.\r\n\r\nHe asked himself why engagements and marriages had to be surrounded\r\nwith tradition and ridiculous games. But, of course, he had to go\r\nthrough with it. Myrna seemed to have been filled with excitement when\r\nthey were discussing the final plans for the ceremony. He might as well\r\nget started. 

He glanced at the clock; it was almost eight. He picked up\r\nthe book of rules and looked at it again.\r\n\r\nHe re-read the instructions for operating the mechanism. First,\r\nit said, inspect the facsimile and see that it is well-groomed and\r\nentirely in order. He looked at the two lifeless twins of himself.\r\nYes, they looked all right. He decided which one he would use tonight.\r\nThen, he read, he was to get into the suit (the book called it a\r\nharness), activate the selected facsimile, and set the controls. It\r\nwent on to say that every movement he made would be duplicated by the\r\nrobot. Everything the facsimile experienced would be transmitted to the\r\nharness becoming his experiences. Well, he had practiced all that since\r\nrenting the thing three days ago. He turned towards the marriage game\r\nrules.\r\n\r\nThe rules dictated seven situations. That would mean, in his case,\r\nseven evenings for Myrna and him to decide whether they were meeting\r\neach other\'s robots or their real selves.\r\n\r\nThe book pointed out that the primary or real body had to be used\r\nat least once in the first five situations. The first contestant to\r\ncorrectly identify the other\'s real body won the game and the contest\r\nwas over. The winner received commendation and was supposed to be the\r\ndominant spouse. Of course, the last was mere convention. However,\r\nthe most important, the most rigid, and to Thad the most fantastic,\r\nrule in the whole contest was that if the girl won, the couple was\r\nrequired to wait a year before completing the marriage ceremony. That\r\nseemed a weightier matter to Morgan. He read on. The first contestant\r\nwho correctly identified the other as a facsimile won a point. If\r\nhe failed, the other contestant had the opportunity to make an\r\nidentification. The situation ended when one contestant made a correct\r\nidentification or when both failed. Laying the book down, he decided\r\nhe\'d better get started because it was getting late.\r\n\r\nHe climbed into the harness and hung in mid-air suspended by his belt.\r\nHe activated one of his facsimiles and turned his head so he could see\r\nhimself through the robot\'s eyes. Thumbing his nose, he watched the\r\ncreature hanging in the harness do likewise. It gave him an eerie\r\nfeeling. Even though he knew he was walking in thin air and getting\r\nnowhere, it really seemed as if he could feel the floor under his feet\r\nand see the room move around him in a very ordinary fashion. As soon as\r\nhis facsimile left the room, his mind made the adjustment and it was as\r\nif it were really he strolling nonchalantly down the corridor.\r\n\r\nHe drove to a florist\'s shop and started to purchase a corsage.\r\nAbashed, he caught himself. He rushed out of the shop and went home to\r\nput a wallet and handkerchief into his pockets. He would have to be\r\nmore careful, he realized. Slips like that might cost him the contest.\r\n\r\nWith corsage box in hand, he pressed the door bell and waited. He hoped\r\nhis plastic flesh was moulded perfectly. It looked all right to him,\r\nbut you never could tell what someone else might notice. Myrna opened\r\nthe door.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nShe was lovely and he took her in his arms. Drawing back, he looked at\r\nher dubiously. 

At least, he thought it was she. His family, her family,\r\nand two or three others, acting as judges and referees in the contest,\r\nstood in the living room watching them. They began to laugh as they saw\r\nhis questioning look. 

It really was rather funny, he decided. Myrna\r\nled him into the room and introduced him to the few he didn\'t know.\r\n\r\nHe watched her closely as she opened the box. He thought her fingers\r\nwere fumbling a bit. Everyone in the room watched the two of them\r\nintently. They didn\'t know whether the couple were real or robot\r\neither. At any moment, she might suddenly try to identify him. Maybe he\r\nshould take the first chance. She might be fumbling from nervousness,\r\nhe realized. If it were really she and he called her a robot, she might\r\nbe offended. Girls were like that, but of course, he would have to take\r\nthat chance.\r\n\r\n"You\'re a robot," he announced suddenly.\r\n\r\nMyrna looked surprised. "Oh, how did you know?" She was crestfallen.\r\nHe was congratulated as they all trooped upstairs to help Myrna out of\r\nher harness. Later it was nice to know for sure that it was really her\r\nliving flesh in his arms. Then he felt guilty as he realized she was\r\nnot in his living arms. He excused himself hurriedly and returned home.\r\n\r\nThe next evening he was invited to Myrna\'s home for dinner. He thought\r\nof actually going himself because he knew the food would be good. The\r\napparatus could transmit heat, cold, and pressure, but it didn\'t do\r\nmuch when it came to taste and it couldn\'t make any sensation in one\'s\r\ninterior.\r\n\r\nBut he decided it would be too risky. If she identified his facsimile\r\nshe would win a point to be sure, but if she identified his real self,\r\nwell, that would end the contest and he would have to wait a year to\r\nget married.\r\n\r\nHe would have to be careful of the food though. She might try to trick\r\nhim with something that looked good but tasted terrible, and his\r\nfacsimile would eat it just the same.\r\n\r\nThat night before sending his proxy to Myrna\'s dinner party, he had his\r\nfacsimile stick himself with a pin. The sharp pain made him wince. 

He\r\nwondered about the mechanics of the machine. He supposed that his pain\r\nwas caused by a tiny electrical shock that stimulated a pain nerve. He\r\nrealized that the more he could find out about his equipment the better\r\nhis chances were of winning.\r\n\r\nThat evening Myrna was very watchful and very cool. He wondered if she\r\nsuspected that she had been loved by a robot the evening before. He had\r\nhardly seated himself at the table when she called him a robot. The\r\nfamilies seemed uproariously amused. 

He wondered how she had known. He\r\ncongratulated her politely and she was allowed to go unidentified since\r\nit was her round.\r\n\r\nWhen his facsimile was brought back to the room, Thad climbed wearily\r\nout of his harness and made himself a cold, uninteresting supper. He\r\nfelt lonely. Was Myrna really sore at him? Damn this whole business! He\r\nwished he didn\'t have to go through all of this.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe next evening he had a plan worked out. He went himself and greeted\r\nher at the door, slammed it shut, and bent towards her to listen. It\r\nwould take a moment for the reverberation to reach her room. If she\r\nwere a robot, the sound would come through the primary microphone\r\nin the sender and he might be able to hear the faint echo from her\r\nlips. He did, and he immediately announced her as a facsimile. Her\r\ncongratulations were hardly more than civil.\r\n\r\nHe left with no great feeling of triumph.\r\n\r\nThe next three evenings, she was very distant. He understood why she\r\ndidn\'t meet him at the door anymore, but he couldn\'t tell why the rest\r\nof her behavior was so cold. She was very lucky, too. She identified\r\nhim correctly as a robot each time before he even had time to greet\r\nthe rest of the family. The day went very slowly. Thad left the office\r\nearly in his uneasiness. Tonight was the seventh and last situation.\r\nHe hoped it also wouldn\'t be their last evening together. At this\r\npoint, he hardly knew what to do. If she won the contest, it would be a\r\nwhole long year before they could marry. He knew that quite often that\r\nspelled the finish to a romance. On the other hand, if he won, it might\r\nestrange them immediately. She had such pride. What to do?\r\n\r\nHe decided to forget the robots and go as his real self again. Points\r\nwere in her favor anyway. He realized that if she were present by\r\nfacsimile, he couldn\'t possibly win. He might as well be the first\r\none to guess and be done with it. It wasn\'t the contest that mattered\r\nanyhow; it was Myrna and what she was feeling.\r\n\r\nWhen he rang the doorbell that evening, the corsage box under his arm\r\ncontained orchids. Unexpectedly, it was Myrna that opened the door.\r\n\r\n"Hello, _real_ Myrna."\r\n\r\nShe hesitated for a moment. "Good evening, Thad. Please come in."\r\n\r\nHe followed her in and greeted the family. She opened the box and for\r\na moment she seemed impressed. Then she regained her composure. He\r\naccepted her formal thanks as the families milled around admiring the\r\ngift. Everyone seemed slightly restrained. Thad finally phrased the\r\nquestion that they were all thinking.\r\n\r\n"Are you real?"\r\n\r\n"Perhaps you could tell if you kissed me," she said with mocking\r\nsweetness.\r\n\r\n"Myrna, I\'m sorry about that first evening, but I forgot that I wasn\'t\r\nreally there." He wished the family wasn\'t there so close. All of them\r\nwatching and listening made him feel an even greater uneasiness. Oh, he\r\nthought, the hell with this contest!\r\n\r\n"Myrna, honey, look, I don\'t care if it\'s really you or not. Well, that\r\nis, I mean--"\r\n\r\nHis voice faded out. He realized he was getting more confused. Someone\r\nsnickered. Myrna was watching him with a contemptuous smile curving her\r\nlips. The whole thing suddenly made him mad.\r\n\r\n"O.K.! I don\'t care who wins the contest! I don\'t care if we do have to\r\nwait a year. 

I don\'t even care at the moment if there\'s going to be a\r\nwedding or not.

"\r\n\r\nHe started out of the room dimly aware that he was angrier than he\r\nrealized. Myrna caught him in the vestibule.\r\n\r\n"Thad! Thad! 

Wait! 

Please, I know I was being spiteful. You won the\r\ncontest, I\'m really me. Please don\'t go like this. I\'d never forgive\r\nmyself."\r\n\r\nShe looked up at him tearfully. 

He felt himself relenting finally and\r\nsmiled. She threw her arms around his neck and he drew her close.\r\n\r\nAfter a very long kiss, she looked up at him and said softly, "Thad,\r\nlet\'s be sure the robots are all sent back to the agency before our\r\nhoneymoon."\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


And the awakening\r\nhad not brought the reassurance that it had all been a bad dream. That\r\nif it had happened in reality, the people of Earth would have been\r\ncapable of dealing with the terrible menace. 

It had been real. And they\r\nhad been no more capable of resisting the giant intelligences than a\r\nchild of killing the ogre in his favorite fairy story.\r\n\r\nIt was an ironic parallel, because that was what finally saved Earth for\r\nits own people. A fairy story.\r\n\r\nThe old fable of the lion and the mouse. When the lion had exhausted his\r\natomic armor and proud science against the invincible and immortal\r\ninvaders of Earth--for they could not be killed by any means--the mouse\r\nattacked and vanquished them.\r\n\r\nThe mouse, the lowest form of life: the fungoids, the air of Earth\r\nswarming with millions of their spores, attacked the monstrous bodies,\r\ngrew and entwined within the gray convolutions that were their brain\r\ncenters. And as the tiny thread-roots probed and tightened, the aliens\r\nscreamed soundlessly. The intelligences toppled and fell, and at last\r\nthat few among them who retained sanity gathered their lunatic brethren\r\nand fled as they had come.\r\n\r\nIf he had known the effect the fungoids would have on them, he would\r\nhave told them that too. He had told them everything else, when he had\r\nbeen snatched from a busy city street, a random specimen of humanity to\r\nbe probed and investigated.\r\n\r\nThey had chosen well. For the payment they offered him he was willing to\r\nbarter the whole human race. As far as it lay in his power he did just\r\nthat.\r\n\r\nHe was not an educated man, though he was intelligent. It was child\'s\r\nplay to them to strip his mind bare; but they had to know the\r\nintangibles too, the determined will of humanity to survive, the\r\nprobabilities of the pattern of human behavior in a situation which\r\nhumanity had never before faced. He told them all he could, gladly and\r\nwillingly. 

He would have descended to any treachery for the vast\r\nglittering reward they tempted him with.\r\n\r\nIt wasn\'t easy for the Yugoslavs to guard him and, anyway, their hearts\r\nweren\'t in the task. His treachery, the ultimate treason, the betrayal\r\nof the whole human race, was commonly known.\r\n\r\nInevitably the mob got him and killed three policemen in the process.\r\nWhen they had sated their anger a little and the traitor had lost most\r\nof his clothes and the thumb of his right hand, they dragged him to the\r\njunction where the Danube meets the Sava and held him under the gray\r\nwaters with long poles, as if he was some poisonous reptile.\r\n\r\nHe lay supinely on the bed of the river and smiled evilly while a\r\nhundred thousand people writhed in neural agony.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nTwenty-four hours later the neural plague had spread to Zagreb and into\r\nAlbania as far as Tirana. When it crossed to Leghorn in Italy the\r\nBalkans held twenty million lunatics and the Danube was an artificial\r\nlake a hundred miles wide.\r\n\r\nThey had used a "clean" bomb. So they were able to bring a loudspeaker\r\nvan to its edge and boom at him to come out. He allowed them to do that\r\nfor some inscrutable reason; perhaps to demonstrate that his powers were\r\nselective. Then it seemed he got tired of the farce, and cruel fingers\r\ntwined themselves into the nerve centers of the President of Italy and\r\nthe Prime Minister of the government of United Europe. He made them\r\ndance a horribly twisted _pas de deux_ on the banks of the Danube for\r\nhis perverted amusement.\r\n\r\nThen he released them, and released the millions of gibbering, twitching\r\nidiots that inhabited Southern Europe, and he came out of the river bed\r\nin which he had lain for forty-eight hours.\r\n\r\nHe walked alone through the deserted streets of Belgrade until he came\r\nto the United Nations building. There he told a very brave lieutenant\r\nthat he was willing to stand trial any place in the world they wished.\r\n\r\nFor three days nobody came to arrest him. He sat alone with the\r\nlieutenant in the peopleless city of Belgrade and waited for his\r\ncaptors. 

They came then, timidly reassured by his non-violence. 

While he\r\ntalked to them pleasantly the citizens of London and Paris suddenly\r\nbegan to dance jerky and grotesque jigs on the pavements of their\r\ncities. In the same moment the Chief Justice of the Court of the\r\nNations, at a cocktail party in Washington, writhed in the exquisite\r\npain of total muscle cramp, his august features twisted into a mask of\r\nabject fear.\r\n\r\nThe trial itself was a legal farce. The prisoner promptly pleaded guilty\r\nto the charge of betraying mankind to an alien race, but he didn\'t allow\r\nthem to question him. When one lawyer persisted in face of his pleasant\r\nrefusals, he died suddenly in a cramped ball of screaming agony.\r\n\r\nThe gray-faced Chief Justice inquired whether he wished to be sentenced\r\nand he answered yes, but not to death. They couldn\'t kill him, he\r\nexplained. 

That was part of the reward the aliens had given him. The\r\nother part was that _he_ could kill or immobilize anybody in the\r\nworld--or everybody--from any distance. He sat back and smiled at the\r\nstricken courtroom. Then he lost his composure and his mouth twitched.\r\nHe laughed uproariously and slapped his knees in ecstasy.\r\n\r\nIt was plain that he was fond of a joke.\r\n\r\nAn anonymous lawyer stood up and waited patiently for his merriment to\r\nsubside.\r\n\r\nIf this was true, he asked, why had not the aliens used this power? Why\r\nhad they not simply killed off the inhabitants and taken over the vacant\r\nplanet? 

The traitor gazed kindly at him; and a court stenographer who\r\nhad cautiously picked up a pencil returned agonizingly to her foetal\r\nposition and, that way, died.\r\n\r\nThe traitor looked at his fingers and shrugged. The thumb that had been\r\nsnapped off in the mob\'s frenzy was more than half grown again.\r\n\r\n"They needed slaves," he said simply.\r\n\r\n"And at the end, while some of them were still sane?"\r\n\r\nThe traitor raised his eyebrows, giving him his full courteous\r\nattention. The lawyer sat down abruptly, his question unfinished. The\r\ncreature who had betrayed his own race smiled at him and permitted him\r\nto live.\r\n\r\nHe even completed his question for him, and answered it. "Why did they\r\nnot kill then? They had something else on their minds--fungoids!" He\r\nlaughed uproariously at his macabre joke. 

"And in their minds too!"\r\n\r\nThe lawyer\'s blue eyes gazed at him steadily and he stopped laughing. In\r\nthe bated hush of the courtroom he said softly, "What a pity I\'m not an\r\nalien too. You could have the fungoids destroy me!"\r\n\r\nHe laughed again helplessly, the tears running down his cheeks.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe Chief Justice adjourned the Court then and the prisoner sauntered to\r\nhis comfortable quarters in front of his frightened guards.\r\n\r\nThat night, in his own living room, the Chief Justice danced an agonized\r\nfandango in front of his horror-stricken wife and the anonymous lawyer\r\nsat in his apartment, staring at the blank wall. He was glad the aliens\r\nhad not made the traitor telepathic too.\r\n\r\nHe had found the chink in his armor.\r\n\r\nThe neural paralysis, the murders by remote control, were acts of a\r\nconscious will. He had himself admitted that if his mind was destroyed\r\nhis powers would be destroyed with it. The aliens had not sought revenge\r\nbecause their minds were totally occupied with saving themselves. The\r\nstricken ones had simply lost the power.\r\n\r\nThe knowledge was useless to him. There was no way they could attack his\r\nmind without his knowing it.\r\n\r\nPossibly they could steal away his consciousness by drugging or\r\nbludgeoning, but it would be racial suicide to attempt it. In the split\r\nmoment of realization he would kill every human being on Earth. There\r\nwould be nobody left to operate on his brain, to make him a mindless,\r\npowerless idiot for the rest of time. For any period of time, he\r\ncorrected himself. His brain would heal again.\r\n\r\nIt was useless to think about it. There was nothing they could use\r\nagainst his invincibility. The only hope was to attack him unawares ...\r\nand if that hope was a fraction less than a certainty it could only mean\r\nfinal and absolute catastrophe.\r\n\r\nThe lawyer looked at his watch. It was four in the morning.\r\n\r\nHe went into the kitchenette and then shrugged himself into his coat. He\r\nwalked through the silent streets, past the city hospital where the\r\nChief Justice lay in agony while the motor impulses from his nerve\r\ncenters wrenched and twisted his body. He entered the foyer of the\r\nluxury hotel where the race betrayer was held prisoner and took the\r\nelevator to the sixth floor.\r\n\r\nTwo sleepy guards jerked erect outside the unlocked door. He put his\r\nfinger to his lips, enjoining them to silence. Then he entered the room\r\nand stood for a moment over the man who was invincible and immortal--and\r\nhuman. Human, and subject to the involuntary unconsciousness which\r\nnature demands from all men. He slept.\r\n\r\nThe eyelids fluttered. The lawyer took the steel meat skewer from his\r\npocket. He thrust it through a half-opened eye and rotated it,\r\nmethodically reducing the soft brain to formless mush.\r\n\r\nAfter that the trial proceeded normally.\r\n\r\nThe prisoner stared vacantly in front of him and all his movements had\r\nto be directed. But he was alive and his thumb was full grown again.\r\n\r\nIt was the lawyer that noticed this and pointed out the implications.\r\nThe thumb had grown to full size in less than six weeks. They must\r\nregard that as their maximum period of immunity.\r\n\r\nThey ruminated over it for another four days. The question was a tricky\r\none, for malignant immortality was beyond human solution. It was not\r\njust a matter of dealing out punishment. The problem now was the\r\nprotection of the race from sudden annihilation. An insolvable problem,\r\nbut one that must be solved. They could only do their best.\r\n\r\nHe was sentenced to life imprisonment, with a special feature.\r\n\r\nIt was decided he should be guillotined once a month as long as he\r\nlived.\r\n\r\n\r\nEND\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


]\r\n\r\n\r\nThey climbed the hill together, arm in arm. At the crest, they stopped\r\nand looked back into the moon-brightened valley where the thin needle\r\nof metal pointed skyward.\r\n\r\nThe night wind blew her dress tightly about her slim legs, and she\r\nreached a hand to her head to keep the blonde curls from whipping about\r\nher face.\r\n\r\nHe put his arm about her waist, squeezed her gently. "Only a few more\r\nhours to wait," he said, reassuringly.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe great ship from beyond the Galaxy drew alongside the tiny planet,\r\nmatched its orbit, cut its drive, and drifted slightly toward the lone\r\nmoon. The ship was nearly as large as the planet itself, but there was\r\nno interchange of gravity between the two bodies, for the ship was of a\r\nsubstance made beyond the stars.\r\n\r\nInspector Ryt looked at his sky chart. Yes, it was Sol III. Then he\r\nlooked through the port hole at his left and adjusted the lens. Then he\r\nswore by the Seven Sister Suns of Sagittarius.\r\n\r\nThe lens showed him the moonlit side of the planet. There were lights\r\nthere, little rows of lights forming checkered patterns in various\r\nareas. And there were other lights, greater lights which flickered\r\nviciously among the patterns, leaving squat, circular clouds above them.\r\n\r\nRyt\'s cheeks puffed out in uncontrollable wrath. "Contaminated!" he\r\nbellowed. "And they are warring on each other!"\r\n\r\nHe turned from the lens, his gross body glowing in red anger.\r\n"Krembyl!" he screamed. "Krembyl!"\r\n\r\nThe door at the far side of the room swung open, and the entity called\r\nKrembyl fluttered in. 

"Yes?" he asked, his body trembling at the manner\r\nin which his name had rung out.\r\n\r\n"Your records show Sol III as sterile. Decontaminated!"\r\n\r\n"Y-yes, sir," Krembyl stammered. "I--I took care of it myself. Just\r\na--a few days ago...."\r\n\r\n"Look!" shouted Inspector Ryt. "Look for yourself!"\r\n\r\nKrembyl went hesitantly to the lens and adjusted himself before it. He\r\nsaw the sparkling lights below, the flashes, the tiny clouds, and his\r\nbody went pale pink with the shame of defeat.\r\n\r\n"I--I am sorry, sir." He turned from the instrument, his pale pink\r\nfading to an ashen gray. 

"I just don\'t understand it. I have renovated\r\nthe planet several times...."\r\n\r\n"_Several times?_"\r\n\r\n"Why, y-yes." Krembyl hurried to a shelf of documents along one wall,\r\nscanned the titles briefly selected one, and returned to the desk.\r\n"Here it is, sir. You will find my reports quite in order, sir."\r\n\r\n"Damn the reports!" snapped the inspector. "I want to know why this\r\nplanet hasn\'t been cared for properly!" He darkened his body with a\r\nscowl.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nKrembyl fumbled the document open, flipped a few pages. "Here it is,\r\nsir. All written down, sir. All in correct order, sir.\r\n\r\n"_Cosmos 66, 9238_," he read. "_Malignant growth noted._\r\n\r\n"_Cosmos 67, 9238 Decontamination process begun._\r\n\r\n"_Method: Entire planet encircled with electrical impulses which caused\r\nhydrogen and oxygen to unite into a heavy liquid. Process continued for\r\na full 40 of planet revolutions._\r\n\r\n"_Result: Planet covered with the liquid to an average depth of 30\r\nfathoms. Contaminating element, being oxygen-breathing, could not\r\npossibly exist under such conditions._"\r\n\r\n"Fool!" barked Ryt. "Some of them probably floated to the surface on\r\nsome of the buoyant vegetation. They may even have made rafts of the\r\nvegetation. Or a boat!"\r\n\r\n"They are exceedingly persistent and adaptable, sir," Krembyl admitted.\r\n"And there were other times...." He broke off to fumble through the\r\ndocumented account. "Yes, here it is, all written down in correct\r\nform...."\r\n\r\n"Damn the reports!" snapped the inspector. "Tell me what happened!"\r\n\r\n"Well, sir," said Krembyl, scanning the pages carefully, "it was back\r\nin 9237. I noticed the malignancy and took proper measures. I took\r\nthe planet from its orbit and into an area remote from the Sol unit.\r\nThere, in the intense cold, the polar caps grew larger and larger until\r\nthey finally extended over the land portions. Even the middle belt\r\nbecame frigid. Then I swung the planet back near Sol and let it soak in\r\ntropical heat. I subjected the planet to this treatment three--or was\r\nit four?--times before placing it back permanently in its orbit."\r\n\r\n"Dolt!" said Ryt. 

"They probably hid away in deep crevices. Probably\r\nremained alive through the treatment by eating each other!" He looked\r\nat the unhappy Krembyl for a devastating minute. "You should have used\r\nfire. _Burned them out!_"\r\n\r\n"But I _did_, sir!" Krembyl said, hurriedly. "I _did_!" He fumbled\r\nrapidly through the pages. "Here it is, right here! All written out!\r\n\r\n"_Nebula 42, 9235. Persistence of malignant contamination noted...._"\r\n\r\nHe broke off abruptly as the inspector\'s body turned to brittle\r\nobsidion.\r\n\r\n"H-m-mm.... A-hh.... Well, sir, finding them confined in an area of\r\nparticularly lush vegetation, I burned them out, chased them with fire\r\ninto arid regions, and swept the garden of plant growth completely away\r\nwhere they could not find it again."\r\n\r\n"But it is obvious that you failed! 

Even if two of them succeeded in\r\nescaping...."\r\n\r\n"And before that, sir," Krembyl hurried on. "Before that, I shook the\r\nland masses violently, rent great fissures that permitted the gasses\r\nand flames to leap out from the central core and spread destruction. I\r\nsubmerged huge infected areas into the depths of the seas, and brought\r\nup new land masses, fresh and clean, into the light of Sol. I even...."\r\n\r\n"Enough! 

Enough!" Ryt hit the desk before him a ponderous blow.\r\n"Silence, fool, while I think!"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nKrembyl turned a sickly shade of green and let the document close in\r\nweary hands.\r\n\r\nSol III had been a particularly painful lancet in his side, even more\r\nso than had yet been guessed. He hoped the inspector would probe no\r\ndeeper. 

But even as his hopes kindled, they became but ashes.\r\n\r\n"There are a few more things I do not understand about this," Inspector\r\nRyt was saying. "When this planet was formed from the elements of\r\nspace, there was no contamination. It was virgin. 

And, yet, it is now\r\ncontaminated. 

Why?"\r\n\r\nKrembyl felt his inners churning fearfully. His whole body was so\r\nfilled with trembling that he could not bring himself to fashion words.\r\n\r\nRyt\'s body grew blacker in the silence. "_Why?_" The word was lightning\r\nfrom the Stygian depths. "WHY?"\r\n\r\nKrembyl\'s body rent asunder, and the effort of reknitting himself so\r\nweakened him that his voice was scarcely a whisper. "They--they came\r\nfrom Sol V, sir."\r\n\r\nThe thunderous blow upon the desk top mingled with Ryt\'s bellow of\r\nfury. Together, the sounds shook the room and nearly disintegrated\r\nKrembyl\'s hastily reassembled body.\r\n\r\n"Dolt! Ass!" screamed Ryt, his body assuming the blackness of the dust\r\ncloud of Orion. "You failed to stop them on Sol V! You not only let\r\nthem blow the planet into tiny bits, but you also let them escape to\r\nSol III! And here all your efforts of extermination have failed again\r\nand again!"\r\n\r\nHe wheeled to look through the lens again. Three brilliant flashes,\r\ngreater than the others, sparkled almost simultaneously upon the\r\nplanet\'s troubled surface, sent up mushrooms of dust and shattered\r\natoms. "And is this what happened on Sol V?"\r\n\r\n"Y-yes," stammered Krembyl. 

"The same thing. Just before ... just\r\nbefore...."\r\n\r\nHe could not bring himself to complete the statement.\r\n\r\nRyt leaped from the seat at the desk, his body black and bloated.\r\n"Then there is not a moment to lose! Exterminate before this planet is\r\ndestroyed! And let none escape!"\r\n\r\n"But, sir," pleaded Krembyl, "I have tried everything--fire, floods,\r\nice...."\r\n\r\n"Then try something else!" Ryt roared.\r\n\r\nKrembyl drifted slowly towards the door.\r\n\r\n"Wait!"\r\n\r\nKrembyl stopped obediently.\r\n\r\n"What about Sol IV?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, Sol IV is all right, sir." Krembyl brightened a shade as he\r\nturned. "There is not the slightest trace of contamination. That planet\r\nmust have been on the far side of Sol when--when they escaped Sol V.\r\nI am certain, sir, you will find the rest of the system quite in\r\norder...."\r\n\r\n"Enough! Begin the extermination! And this time employ drastic\r\nmeasures. Take the planet to the rim of Sol itself and bake it to a\r\ncrisp before they infest the entire galaxy."\r\n\r\n"Yes, sir. 

Immediately, sir." Krembyl turned again to the door,\r\nthankful his fate had not been worse.\r\n\r\n"And don\'t fail this time!" warned Ryt. "If you lose Sol III as you\r\nlost Sol V, I\'ll see to it that you put them both back together again,\r\npiece by piece, if it takes you six eons beyond your retirement age!"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe moon, with its strange accompanying cloud, had nearly set. The blue\r\nof the eastern sky was fading into apple-green. There was a roaring\r\nswish of sound, a shattering blast of energy, a whistling sigh, then\r\na remote whisper. The needle-like structure from the valley became a\r\nflickering pin point in the sky.\r\n\r\nThe girl leaned her blonde head against the shoulder of the man beside\r\nher. "We--we are free?" Her voice was but a whisper.\r\n\r\nHe adjusted the ra-vis to get a clearer view of Earth and its\r\nsurrounding space. The view was but slightly distorted by the hot gases\r\nof the stern tubes. "Yes," he said, struggling to keep his nervousness\r\nfrom playing havoc with his vocal cords. "Free. 

Free from a mad world!"\r\nHe squeezed her hand reassuringly, his eyes intent upon the screen.\r\n\r\nSomething had gone wrong. The earth had slid to one edge of the screen.\r\nHe readjusted the ra-vis. The space-cloud of black that had hovered\r\nnear the moon that night had also shifted its position. It was now\r\nbetween the earth and the sun, and the earth seemed to be following\r\nit.... The furrow between his dark brows deepened, but he said nothing.\r\n\r\n"Just think of it!" she said, her voice a song. "Mars! And a brave new\r\nworld!"\r\n\r\nHe put an arm about her shoulders and took his eyes from the screen.\r\nIt was absurd to think the earth was moving sunward. It was probably\r\nmerely due to some space aberration....\r\n\r\n"Yes," he said, picking up her enthusiasm. "And after that--the\r\n_stars_!"\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                This is how it all began--the terrible\r\n                civil strife that devastates our world!\r\n\r\n\r\n    Based in material in Ch. 

7--"First Clashes of the Wheeled and\r\n    Footed Sects"--of Vol. 3 of Burger\'s monumental _History of\r\n    Traffic_, published by the Foundation for Twenty-Second\r\n    Century Studies.\r\n\r\nThe raggedy little old lady with the big shopping bag was in the exact\r\ncenter of the crosswalk when she became aware of the big black car\r\nbearing down on her.\r\n\r\nBehind the thick bullet-proof glass its seven occupants had a misty\r\nlook, like men in a diving bell.\r\n\r\nShe saw there was no longer time to beat the car to either curb.\r\nVeering remorselessly, it would catch her in the gutter.\r\n\r\nUseless to attempt a feint and double-back, such as any venturesome\r\nchild executed a dozen times a day. Her reflexes were too slow.\r\n\r\nPolite vacuous laughter came from the car\'s loudspeaker over the\r\nengine\'s mounting roar.\r\n\r\nFrom her fellow pedestrians lining the curbs came a sigh of horror.\r\n\r\nThe little old lady dipped into her shopping bag and came up with a big\r\nblue-black automatic. She held it in both fists, riding the recoils\r\nlike a rodeo cowboy on a bucking bronco.\r\n\r\nAiming at the base of the windshield, just as a big-game hunter aims\r\nat the vulnerable spine of a charging water buffalo over the horny\r\narmor of its lowered head, the little old lady squeezed off three shots\r\nbefore the car chewed her down.\r\n\r\nFrom the right-hand curb a young woman in a wheelchair shrieked an\r\nobscenity at the car\'s occupants.\r\n\r\nSmythe-de Winter, the driver, wasn\'t happy. The little old lady\'s\r\nlast shot had taken two members of his car pool. Bursting through the\r\nlaminated glass, the steel-jacketed slug had traversed the neck of\r\nPhipps-McHeath and buried itself in the skull of Horvendile-Harker.\r\n\r\nBraking viciously, Smythe-de Winter rammed the car over the right-hand\r\ncurb. Pedestrians scattered into entries and narrow arcades, among them\r\na youth bounding high on crutches.\r\n\r\nBut Smythe-de Winter got the girl in the wheelchair.\r\n\r\nThen he drove rapidly out of the Slum Ring into the Suburbs, a shred\r\nof rattan swinging from the flange of his right fore mudguard for\r\na trophy. Despite the two-for-two casualty list, he felt angry and\r\ndepressed. The secure, predictable world around him seemed to be\r\ncrumbling.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWhile his companions softly keened a dirge to Horvy and Phipps and\r\nquietly mopped up their blood, he frowned and shook his head.\r\n\r\n"They oughtn\'t to let old ladies carry magnums," he murmured.\r\n\r\nWitherspoon-Hobbs nodded agreement across the front-seat corpse. "They\r\noughtn\'t to let \'em carry anything. 

God, how I hate Feet," he muttered,\r\nlooking down at his shrunken legs. "Wheels forever!" he softly cheered.\r\n\r\nThe incident had immediate repercussions throughout the city. At the\r\ncombined wake of the little old lady and the girl in the wheelchair,\r\na fiery-tongued speaker inveighed against the White-Walled Fascists\r\nof Suburbia, telling to his hearers, the fabled wonders of old Los\r\nAngeles, where pedestrians were sacrosanct, even outside crosswalks. He\r\ncalled for a hobnail march across the nearest lawn-bowling alleys and\r\nperambulator-traversed golf courses of the motorists.\r\n\r\nAt the Sunnyside Crematorium, to which the bodies of Phipps and Horvy\r\nhad been conveyed, an equally impassioned and rather more grammatical\r\norator reminded his listeners of the legendary justice of old Chicago,\r\nwhere pedestrians were forbidden to carry small arms and anyone with\r\none foot off the sidewalk was fair prey. He broadly hinted that a\r\nholocaust, primed if necessary with a few tankfuls of gasoline, was the\r\nonly cure for the Slums.\r\n\r\nBands of skinny youths came loping at dusk out of the Slum Ring into\r\nthe innermost sections of the larger doughnut of the Suburbs slashing\r\ndefenseless tires, shooting expensive watchdogs and scrawling filthy\r\nwords on the pristine panels of matrons\' runabouts which never ventured\r\nmore than six blocks from home.\r\n\r\nSimultaneously squadrons of young suburban motorcycles and scooterites\r\nroared through the outermost precincts of the Slum Ring, harrying\r\nchildren off sidewalks, tossing stink-bombs through second-story\r\ntenement windows and defacing hovel-fronts with sprays of black paint.\r\n\r\nIncident--a thrown brick, a cut corner, monster tacks in the portico\r\nof the Auto Club--were even reported from the center of the city,\r\ntraditionally neutral territory.\r\n\r\nThe Government hurriedly acted, suspending all traffic between the\r\nCenter and the Suburbs and establishing a 24-hour curfew in the Slum\r\nRing. Government agents moved only by centipede-car and pogo-hopper to\r\nunderline the point that they favored neither contending side.\r\n\r\nThe day of enforced non-movement for Feet and Wheels was spent in\r\nfurtive vengeful preparations. 

Behind locked garage doors, machine-guns\r\nthat fired through the nose ornament were mounted under hoods, illegal\r\nscythe blades were welded to oversize hubcaps and the stainless steel\r\nedges of flange fenders were honed to razor sharpness.\r\n\r\nWhile nervous National Guardsmen hopped about the deserted sidewalks of\r\nthe Slum Ring, grim-faced men and women wearing black armbands moved\r\nthrough the webwork of secret tunnels and hidden doors, distributing\r\nheavy-caliber small arms and spike-studded paving blocks, piling\r\ncobblestones on strategic roof-tops and sapping upward from the secret\r\ntunnels to create car-traps. Children got ready to soap intersections\r\nafter dark. The Committee of Pedestrian Safety, sometimes known as\r\nRobespierre\'s Rats, prepared to release its two carefully hoarded\r\nanti-tank guns.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAt nightfall, under the tireless urging of the Government,\r\nrepresentatives of the Pedestrians and the Motorists met on a huge\r\nsafety island at the boundary of the Slum Ring and the Suburbs.\r\n\r\nUnderlings began a noisy dispute as to whether Smythe-de Winter had\r\nfailed to give a courtesy honk before charging, whether the little old\r\nlady had opened fire before the car had come within honking distance,\r\nhow many wheels of Smythe-de\'s car had been on the sidewalk when he hit\r\nthe girl in the wheelchair and so on. After a little while the High\r\nPedestrian and the Chief Motorist exchanged cautious winks and drew\r\naside.\r\n\r\nThe red writhing of a hundred kerosene flares and the mystic yellow\r\npulsing of a thousand firefly lamps mounted on yellow sawhorses ranged\r\naround the safety island illumined two tragic, strained faces.\r\n\r\n"A word before we get down to business," the Chief Motorist whispered.\r\n"What\'s the current S.Q. of your adults?

"\r\n\r\n"Forty-one and dropping," the High Pedestrian replied, his eyes\r\nfearfully searching from side to side for eavesdroppers. "I can hardly\r\nget aides who are halfway _compos mentis_."\r\n\r\n"Our own Sanity Quotient is thirty-seven," the Chief Motorist revealed.\r\nHe shrugged helplessly.... "The wheels inside my people\'s heads are\r\nslowing down. I do not think they will be speeded up in my lifetime."\r\n\r\n"They say Government\'s only fifty-two," the other said with a matching\r\nshrug.\r\n\r\n"Well, I suppose we must scrape out one more compromise," the one\r\nsuggested hollowly, "though I must confess there are times when I think\r\nwe\'re all the figments of a paranoid\'s dream."\r\n\r\nTwo hours of concentrated deliberations produced the new Wheel-Foot\r\nArticles of Agreement. Among other points, pedestrian handguns were\r\nlimited to a slightly lower muzzle velocity and to .38 caliber and\r\nunder, while motorists were required to give three honks at one block\r\ndistance before charging a pedestrian in a crosswalk. Two wheels over\r\nthe curb changed a traffic kill from third-degree manslaughter to petty\r\nhomicide. Blind pedestrians were permitted to carry hand grenades.\r\n\r\nImmediately the Government went to work. The new Wheel-Foot Articles\r\nwere loudspeakered and posted. Detachments of police and psychiatric\r\nsocial hoppers centipedaled and pogoed through the Slum Ring, seizing\r\noutsize weapons and giving tranquilizing jet-injections to the unruly.\r\nTeams of hypnotherapists and mechanics scuttled from home to home\r\nin the Suburbs and from garage to garage, in-chanting a conformist\r\nserenity and stripping illegal armament from cars. On the advice of\r\na rogue psychiatrist, who said it would channel off aggressions, a\r\ndisplay of bull-fighting was announced, but this had to be canceled\r\nwhen a strong protest was lodged by the Decency League, which had a\r\nlarge mixed Wheel-Foot membership.\r\n\r\nAt dawn, curfew was lifted in the Slum Ring and traffic reopened\r\nbetween the Suburbs and the Center. After a few uneasy moments it\r\nbecame apparent that the _status quo_ had been restored.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nSmythe-de Winter tooled his gleaming black machine along the Ring. A\r\nthick steel bolt with a large steel washer on either side neatly filled\r\nthe hole the little old lady\'s slug had made in the windshield.\r\n\r\nA brick bounced off the roof. Bullets pattered against the side\r\nwindows.\r\n\r\nSmythe-de ran a handkerchief around his neck under his collar and\r\nsmiled.\r\n\r\nA block ahead children were darting into the street, cat-calling and\r\nthumbing their noses. Behind one of them limped a fat dog with a spiked\r\ncollar.\r\n\r\nSmythe-de suddenly gunned his motor. He didn\'t hit any of the children,\r\nbut he got the dog.\r\n\r\nA flashing light on the dash showed him the right front tire was losing\r\npressure. 

Must have hit the collar as well! He thumbed the matching\r\nemergency-air button and the flashing stopped.\r\n\r\nHe turned toward Witherspoon-Hobbs and said with thoughtful\r\nsatisfaction, "I like a normal orderly world, where you always have a\r\nlittle success, but not champagne-heady; a little failure, but just\r\nenough to brace you."\r\n\r\nWitherspoon-Hobbs was squinting at the next crosswalk. Its center was\r\ndiscolored by a brownish stain ribbon-tracked by tires.\r\n\r\n"That\'s where you bagged the little old lady, Smythe-de," he remarked.\r\n"I\'ll say this for her now: she had spirit."\r\n\r\n"Yes, that\'s where I bagged her," Smythe-de agreed flatly. He\r\nremembered wistfully the witchlike face growing rapidly larger, her\r\njerking shoulders in black bombazine, the wild white-circled eyes. He\r\nsuddenly found himself feeling that this was a very dull day.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


But could he smuggle himself aboard?\r\n\r\n\r\n            Illustrated by Lloyd Rognan\r\n\r\n\r\nDad had already gone when Bobby got up. This disappointed Bobby a little\r\nbut then he remembered--_this was the big day_. Naturally Dad would get\r\nover to the project early. And at four o\'clock-- Bobby shivered\r\ndeliciously at the thought of it.\r\n\r\nHe ate his breakfast in silence with Mom across the table drinking a cup\r\nof coffee and looking at a fashion catalogue. He was glad she was\r\noccupied because he didn\'t want to talk; not today he didn\'t. Might\r\nspill something secret. 

Might even let out the _big secret_. That would\r\nbe terrible.\r\n\r\nOf course, all things were secret at Buffalo Flats. So secret top\r\nscientists like Dad didn\'t even discuss them with wives like Mom. And\r\nwives like Mom never asked.\r\n\r\nSo it was really something to sit there eating breakfast knowing that,\r\ntoday, Dad was going to rocket to the Moon. And with Mom not even\r\nknowing the Lunar project was in the works, so naturally not dreaming\r\nthat he was going _with_ Dad! The thrill was overpowering.\r\n\r\nMaybe they would have radio communication after they got there and he\r\nwould call back and say, _Hello, Mom! Guess where I am? On the moon with\r\nDad!_ And Mom would say, _Why, Bobby! Scaring me to death like this! I\r\nwas looking all over for you._ Sounding very angry but not being really\r\nangry after all. Because maybe Dad would cut in and say, _Yeah, he\'s\r\nright here with me, dear. What do you think of this boy of ours?_\r\n\r\nBobby gulped the last of his cereal so he could go outside and wriggle\r\nfor joy. As he got up from his chair, Mom said, "And what\'s your plan\r\nfor today, young man? Davy Crockett or Buck Rogers?"\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\nBobby had a quick thought--a sudden temptation. Why not give Mom a hint?\r\nWhy he could even _tell_ her and she still wouldn\'t know. Then later,\r\nafter he was gone, she would remember back and say, _That boy! When he\r\ntells you something he really means it._\r\n\r\nBobby smiled and said, "I think I\'ll go to the moon today."\r\n\r\nMom smiled too and went back to her fashions. "Well, see to it your fuel\r\nmixture is correct."\r\n\r\n"I\'ll check it. And Mom--I might not be home for lunch."\r\n\r\n"Where will you be?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, I don\'t know.

"\r\n\r\n"Well, mind your manners and say thank you when you leave."\r\n\r\nMrs. Kendall, still smiling, watched Bobby dash out into the yard.\r\nLiving on a restricted government area had one compensation at least.\r\nYou didn\'t have to worry about your children. Four dozen families, all\r\nwith offspring, trapped behind ten-foot patrolled fence. Here, nobody\r\nworried about their children. They came and went and at noon a mother\r\nfed whatever number happened to be in the house at the time. Mrs.\r\nKendall usually drew six or seven. It would be a relief to dodge the\r\nchore for one Saturday....\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nOut in the backyard, Bobby fussed around his space rocket a little:\r\ntightening a screw here--hammering in a nail there. Just until he could\r\nslip away without Mom noticing his direction.\r\n\r\nIt wasn\'t a bad rocket at that, he thought. Six feet long with two seats\r\nand a keen instrument panel. But kid stuff of course. After he found the\r\nway in through the sewer he hadn\'t paid any more attention to his own\r\nship.\r\n\r\nHe could see Mom through the window, back in her book, so he went\r\ncasually out through the back gate and turned left, kicking at pebbles\r\nas he sauntered along and trying to look as though he had no place to\r\ngo. Had to be careful. Didn\'t want to bump into any of the other kids\r\ntoday, either.\r\n\r\nThe way in through the sewer was at a place behind Laboratory B. There\r\nwas a kind of an alley there that nobody ever walked through and then\r\nthis round lid you could lift up and look under. And a ladder you could\r\nclimb down.\r\n\r\nBobby hadn\'t dared go down at first. But, after thinking about it\r\novernight, his curiosity won out and he went back and ducked down\r\ninto the lower level. He called it a sewer because of sewers being\r\nunderground, but this place was clean and had bunches of wires strung\r\nin every direction and faint little lights you could see by.\r\n\r\nBobby went further and further every trip he took, never telling anybody\r\nbecause you weren\'t supposed to talk about things at Buffalo Flats--not\r\neven to the other kids.\r\n\r\nThen he found the big drome where they were building the rocket. It was\r\nso sleek and beautiful and shiny that he just stared at it--up through\r\nthe grating in the floor that was for air circulation or something.\r\n\r\nHe didn\'t know it was the moon rocket at first. Not until he\'d gone back\r\nseveral times to peek up at it and then one day two scientists came\r\nwalking along right in front of his nose.\r\n\r\nOne of them was Dad.\r\n\r\nBobby almost called out but he caught himself and just listened to them\r\ntalking. This was the first time his conscience bothered him about going\r\nunderneath the drome. He thought about it a lot--whether it was the\r\nright thing to do. And while he was never able to still his conscience\r\ncompletely, he quieted down by saying he really wasn\'t doing any harm\r\nbecause he\'d never told anybody what he saw.\r\n\r\nHe learned the rocket was going to the moon by listening to Dad and the\r\nother scientists talk when they thought they were alone. And it was\r\nfunny. Because even there, they spoke in low voices and didn\'t give too\r\nmuch away.\r\n\r\nHe had known now for three days that at four o\'clock the roof would open\r\nand the drome would be turned into a blast-pit and the rocket would\r\nshoot out through space to the moon.\r\n\r\nThat was all he _did_ know for sure. None of the men had said who was\r\ngoing on the first trip to the moon. Nothing had been said on that\r\nsubject at all, but Bobby knew Dad would go. He would have to. After\r\nall, Dad was the second biggest scientist at Buffalo Flats. Second only\r\nto Schleimmer himself and Professor Schleimmer was very old and\r\ncertainly wouldn\'t make the trip. That left Dad. Dad would just have to\r\ngo in order to run the rocket. There probably wasn\'t anybody else smart\r\nenough in the whole place.\r\n\r\nThe idea of going himself had been born the previous day--when he found\r\na larger grating in the floor near the rocket and realized if he was\r\nvery careful he could climb out of the sewer and duck into the rocket\r\nwhen nobody was looking. Once inside he was pretty sure he\'d find a\r\nplace to hide until blast-off.\r\n\r\nAll the men would probably be strapped in bunks but if he found a place\r\nhe could wedge himself in he didn\'t think he\'d get hurt. Then, halfway\r\nto the moon he would come out and find Dad and would he be surprised!\r\n\r\nAt first, thinking about it, he\'d been scared but after he realized how\r\nproud Dad and Mom would be, he made up his mind.\r\n\r\nNow, crouched beside the grating near the ship, he waited while two\r\nmen--technicians in white overalls--walked by.\r\n\r\nOne of them said, "Well, whatever happens, she\'ll make a big splash."\r\n\r\n"You said it. 

Hope the brains know what they\'re doing."\r\n\r\nThat made Bobby mad. Who said Dad didn\'t know what he was doing? Dad was\r\njust about the smartest scientist in the world.\r\n\r\nAfter the two men left he waited a long time. He heard voices but no one\r\ncame in sight. Taking a deep breath, he opened the grating and got out.\r\nIt was only four steps to the open port of the rocket. There was a\r\nlittle ramp they\'d used to roll things in and Bobby\'s feet touched it\r\nbut lightly as he jumped into the ship. He found himself in some kind of\r\na storeroom. It would be a good place to hide all right. It was full of\r\naluminum barrels all the same size. He found a space between two rows\r\nand sat down and got his breath back. 

It was very quiet around him.\r\nScary quiet. But he set his lips firmly.\r\n\r\nHe was going to the moon with Dad.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nJohn Kendall was a little late that night. He kissed his wife and said,\r\n"Well, did you see the big sky rocket?"\r\n\r\n"How could I miss it, darling? 

Your supper is in the oven."\r\n\r\n"I could use a Martini first."\r\n\r\n"Coming right up."\r\n\r\nWhile Myra fixed the drink John lay back in his easy chair and closed\r\nhis eyes. "We\'d hoped to stage a little ceremony at the launching but\r\nWashington said no."\r\n\r\n"The Russians?"\r\n\r\n"The Eastern Coalition. It was a race. 

That was why it had to be so\r\nsecret. Washington said, light the fuse and fire the thing."\r\n\r\n"Is it still hush-hush?"\r\n\r\n"No. Not between us at least. We fired an explosion rocket at the moon.\r\nIt will hit in about an hour and telescopes will show a big purple spot\r\nwhen our explosives go off and throw dye all over the place."\r\n\r\nMyra handed him a dry Martini. 

"I see. 

Lots of fun no doubt but what\'s\r\nthe purpose? Fourth of July on the moon?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, no. If the experiment is a success the next rocket will carry men\r\ninstead of a bomb."\r\n\r\nMyra went to the kitchen to see about supper. John called, "Where\'s\r\nBobby? In bed I suppose."\r\n\r\nMyra didn\'t hear and John set his drink down and moved toward the\r\nbedroom. Maybe he was still awake.\r\n\r\nBobby rolled over. His eyes popped open. 

"Dad! I thought you went to--"\r\n\r\nJohn Kendall sat down on the edge of the bed and tousled his son\'s hair.\r\n"No, son. It\'s the old _terra firma_ for me. Did you see the rocket\r\nblast?"\r\n\r\n"Uh-huh. It was really something. It went to the moon, didn\'t it?"\r\n\r\n"That\'s right." 

Kendall smiled and thought. Try to keep a secret from\r\nthe kids. It just can\'t be done. "How\'s _your_ moon rocket coming along,\r\nson?"\r\n\r\n"Pretty good. Gee, Dad! As long as you didn\'t go, I\'m glad I didn\'t go\r\neither."\r\n\r\n"You were planning to make the trip also?"\r\n\r\n"Uh-huh. I got into the rocket and was all set but I got to thinking\r\nabout Mom--how one of us should stay and take care of her in case\r\nanything happened."\r\n\r\n"Smart thinking, son. Now you get to sleep. I\'ll have a little time\r\ntomorrow. We\'ll play some ball."\r\n\r\n"That will be keen!"\r\n\r\nJohn Kendall smiled as he left the bedroom. Kids were wonderful! Give\r\nthem a few old boards and a steering wheel and they could build a ship\r\nto fly to the moon. What a wonderful dream world they lived in!\r\n\r\nToo bad they had to grow out of it.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Imagination_ April 1956.
