The Old One watched, squinting into the morning sun. He\r\nsighed, hitched up his saffron robes and started walking down toward\r\nthe strangers.\r\n\r\nGriffin turned, not trying to conceal his excitement. "You\'re the\r\nlinguist, see what you can get out of him."\r\n\r\n"I might," Kung Su ventured sourly, "if you\'d go weed the air machine\r\nor something. This is going to be hard enough without a lot of\r\nkibitzers cramping my style and scaring Old Pruneface here half to\r\ndeath."\r\n\r\n"I see your point," Griffin answered. He turned and started back toward\r\nthe diggings. "Let me know it you make any progress with the local\r\nlanguage." He stopped whistling and strove to control the jauntiness of\r\nhis gait. _Must be the lower gravity and extra oxygen_, he thought. _I\r\nhaven\'t bounced along like this for thirty years. Nice place to settle\r\ndown if some promoter doesn\'t turn it into an old folks home._ He sighed\r\nand glanced over the diggings. The rammed earth walls were nearly\r\nobliterated by now. 

_Nothing lost_, he reflected. _It\'s all on tape\r\nand they\'re no different from a thousand others at any rate._\r\n\r\n                     *      *      *      *      *\r\n\r\nGriffin opened a door in the transparent bubble from which Alba\xc3\xb1ez was\r\noperating the diggers. "Anything?" 

he inquired.\r\n\r\n"Nothing so far," Alba\xc3\xb1ez reported. "What\'s the score on this job? I\r\nmissed the briefing."\r\n\r\n"How\'d you make out on III, by the way?"\r\n\r\n"Same old stuff, pottery shards and the usual junk. See it once and\r\nyou\'ve seen it all."\r\n\r\n"Well," Griffin began, "it looks like the same thing here again. We\'ve\r\npretty well covered this system and you know how it is. Rammed earth\r\nwalls here and there, pottery shards, flint, bronze and iron artifacts\r\nand that\'s it. They got to the iron age on every planet and then\r\nblooey."\r\n\r\n"Artifacts all made for humanoid hands I suppose. I wonder if they were\r\nclose enough to have crossbred with humans."\r\n\r\n"I couldn\'t say," Griffin observed dryly. "From the looks of Old\r\nPruneface I doubt if we\'ll ever find a human female with sufficiently\r\ndetached attitude to find out."\r\n\r\n"Who\'s Pruneface?"\r\n\r\n"He came ambling down out of the hills this morning and walked into\r\ncamp."\r\n\r\n"You mean you\'ve actually found a live humanoid?"\r\n\r\n"There\'s got to be a first time for everything." Griffin opened the\r\ndoor and started climbing the hill toward Kung Su and Pruneface.\r\n\r\n                     *      *      *      *      *\r\n\r\n"Well, have you gotten beyond the \'me, Charlie\' stage yet?" Griffin\r\ninquired at breakfast two days later.\r\n\r\nKung Su gave an inscrutable East Los Angeles smile. "As a matter of\r\nfact, I\'m a little farther along. 

Joe is amazingly co\xc3\xb6perative."\r\n\r\n"Joe?"\r\n\r\n"Spell it Chou if you want to be exotic. It\'s still pronounced Joe and\r\nthat\'s his name. The language is monosyllabic and tonal. 

I happen to\r\nknow a similar language."\r\n\r\n"You mean this humanoid speaks Chinese?" Griffin was never sure whether\r\nKung was ribbing him or not.\r\n\r\n"Not Chinese. The vocabulary is different but the syntax and phonemes\r\nare nearly identical. 

I\'ll speak it perfectly in a week. 

It\'s just a\r\nquestion of memorizing two or three thousand new words. Incidentally,\r\nJoe wants to know why you\'re digging up his bottom land. He was all set\r\nto flood it today."\r\n\r\n"Don\'t tell me he plants rice!" Griffin exclaimed.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t imagine it\'s rice, but it needs flooding whatever it is."\r\n\r\n"Ask him how many humanoids there are on this planet."\r\n\r\n"I\'m way ahead of you, Griffin. He says there are only a few thousand\r\nleft. The rest were all destroyed in a war with the barbarians."\r\n\r\n"Barbarians?"\r\n\r\n"They\'re extinct."\r\n\r\n"How many races were there?"\r\n\r\n"I\'ll get to that if you\'ll stop interrupting," Kung rejoined testily.\r\n"Joe says there are only two kinds of people, his own dark,\r\nstraight-haired kind and the barbarians. They have curly hair, white\r\nskin and round eyes. You\'d pass for a barbarian, according to Joe, only\r\nyou don\'t have a faceful of hair. He wants to know how things are going\r\non the other planets."\r\n\r\n"I suppose that\'s my cue to break into a cold sweat and feel a\r\npremonition of disaster." Griffin tried to smile and almost made it.\r\n\r\n"Not necessarily, but it seems our iron-age man is fairly well informed\r\nin extraplanetary affairs."\r\n\r\n"I guess I\'d better start learning the language."\r\n\r\n                     *      *      *      *      *\r\n\r\nThanks to the spade work Kung Su had done in preparing hypno-recordings,\r\nGriffin had a working knowledge of the Rational People\'s language\r\neleven days later when he sat down to drink herb infused hot water with\r\nJoe and other Old Ones in the low-roofed wooden building around which\r\nclustered a village of two hundred humanoids. He fidgeted through\r\ninterminable ritualistic cups of hot water. Eventually Joe hid his\r\nhands in the sleeves of his robe and turned with an air of polite\r\ninquiry. _Now we get down to business_, Griffin thought.\r\n\r\n"Joe, you know by now why we\'re digging up your bottom land. We\'ll\r\nrecompense you in one way or another. 

Meanwhile, could you give me a\r\nlittle local history?"\r\n\r\nJoe smiled like a well nourished bodhisattva. "Approximately how far\r\nback would you like me to begin?"\r\n\r\n"At the beginning."\r\n\r\n"How long is a year on your planet?" Joe inquired.\r\n\r\n"Your year is eight and a half days longer. Our day is three hundred\r\nheartbeats longer than yours."\r\n\r\nJoe nodded his thanks. 

"More water?"\r\n\r\nGriffin declined, suppressing a shudder.\r\n\r\n"Five million years ago we were limited to one planet," Joe began. "The\r\ncourt astronomer had a vision of our planet in flames. I imagine you\'d\r\nsay our sun was about to nova. The empress was disturbed and ordered a\r\nconvocation of seers. One fasted overlong and saw an answer. As the\r\ndying seer predicted the Son of Heaven came with fire-breathing\r\ndragons. The fairest of maidens and the strongest of our young men were\r\ntaken to serve his warriors. We served them honestly and faithfully. A\r\nthousand years later their empire collapsed leaving us scattered across\r\nthe universe. Three thousand years later a new race of barbarians\r\nconquered our planets. We surrendered naturally and soon were serving\r\nour new masters. Five hundred years passed and they destroyed\r\nthemselves. This has been the pattern of our existence from that day to\r\nthis."\r\n\r\n"You mean you\'ve been slaves for five million years?" Griffin was\r\nincredulous.\r\n\r\n"Servitude has ever been a refuge for the scholar and the philosopher."\r\n\r\n"But what point is there in such a life? 

Why do you continue living\r\nthis way?"\r\n\r\n"What is the point in any way of life? Continued existence. Personal\r\nimmortality is neither desirable nor possible. We settled for\r\nperpetuation of the race."\r\n\r\n"But what about self-determination? You know enough astronomy to\r\nunderstand novae. Surely you realize it could happen again. What would\r\nyou do without a technology to build spaceships?"\r\n\r\n"Many stars have gone nova during our history. Usually the barbarians\r\ncame in time. When they didn\'t--"\r\n\r\n"You mean you don\'t really care?"\r\n\r\n"All barbarians ask that sooner or later," Joe smiled. "Sometimes\r\ntoward the end they even accuse us of destroying them. We don\'t. Every\r\ntechnology bears the seeds of its own destruction. The stars are older\r\nthan the machinery that explores them."\r\n\r\n"You used technology to get from one system to another."\r\n\r\n"We used it, but we were never part of it. When machines fail, their\r\npeople die. We have no machines."\r\n\r\n"What would you do if this sun were to nova?"\r\n\r\n"We can serve you. We are not unintelligent."\r\n\r\n"Willing to work your way around the galaxy, eh? But what if we refused\r\nto take you?"\r\n\r\n"The race would go on. Kung Su tells me there is no life on planets of\r\nthis system, but there are other systems."\r\n\r\n"You\'re whistling in the dark," Griffin scoffed. "How do you know if\r\nany of the Rational People survive?"\r\n\r\n"How far back does your history go?" Joe inquired.\r\n\r\n"It\'s hard to say exactly," Griffin replied. "Our earliest written\r\nrecords date back some seven thousand years."\r\n\r\n"You are all of one race?"\r\n\r\n"No, you may have noticed Kung Su is slightly different from the rest\r\nof us."\r\n\r\n"Yes, Griffin, I have noticed. When you return ask Kung Su for the\r\nlegend of creation. More hot water?" Joe stirred and Griffin guessed\r\nthe interview was over. He drank another ritual cup, made his farewells\r\nand walked thoughtfully back to camp.\r\n\r\n                     *      *      *      *      *\r\n\r\n"Kung," Griffin asked over coffee next afternoon, "how well up are you\r\non Chinese mythology?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, fair, I guess. 

It isn\'t my field but I remember some of the\r\nstories my grandfather used to tell me."\r\n\r\n"What is your legend of creation?" Griffin persisted.\r\n\r\n"It\'s pretty well garbled but I remember something about the Son of\r\nHeaven bringing the early settlers from a land of two moons on the back\r\nof his fire-breathing dragon. The dragon got sick and died so they\r\ncouldn\'t ever get back to heaven again. There\'s a lot of stuff about\r\ndevils, too."\r\n\r\n"What about devils?"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t remember too well, but they were supposed to do terrible\r\nthings to you and even to your unborn children if they ever caught you.\r\nThey must have been pretty stupid though; they couldn\'t turn corners.\r\nMy grandfather\'s store had devil screens at all the doors so you had to\r\nturn a corner to get in. The first time I saw the lead baffles at the\r\npile chamber doors on this ship it reminded me of home sweet home. By\r\nthe way, some young men from the village were around today. They want\r\nto work passage to the next planet. 

What do you think?"\r\n\r\nGriffin was silent for a long time.\r\n\r\n"Well, what do you say? We can use some hand labor for the delicate\r\ndigging. Want to put them on?"\r\n\r\n"Might as well." Griffin answered. "There\'s a streetcar every\r\nmillennium anyway."\r\n\r\n"What do you mean by that?

"\r\n\r\n"You wouldn\'t understand. You sold your birthright to the barbarians."\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


copyright on this publication was\r\n      renewed.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nSUMMIT\r\n\r\nby\r\n\r\nMACK REYNOLDS\r\n\r\nIllustrated by Freas\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\n_Almost anything, if it goes on long enough, can be reduced to, first a\r\nRoutine, and then, to a Tradition. And at the point it is, obviously,\r\nNecessary._\r\n\r\n\r\nTwo king-sized bands blared martial music, the "_Internationale_" and\r\nthe "Star-Spangled Banner," each seemingly trying to drown the other in\r\na _G\xc3\xb6tterd\xc3\xa4mmerung_ of acoustics.\r\n\r\nTwo lines of troops, surfacely differing in uniforms and in weapons, but\r\nbasically so very the same, so evenly matched, came to attention. A\r\nthousand hands slapped a thousand submachine gun stocks.\r\n\r\nMarshal Vladimir Ignatov strode stiff-kneed down the long march, the\r\nstride of a man for years used to cavalry boots. He was flanked by\r\nfrozen visaged subordinates, but none so cold of face as he himself.\r\n\r\nAt the entrance to the conference hall he stopped, turned and waited.\r\n\r\nAt the end of the corridor of troops a car stopped and several figures\r\nemerged, most of them in civilian dress, several bearing brief cases.\r\nThey in their turn ran the gantlet.\r\n\r\nAt their fore walked James Warren Donlevy, spritely, his eyes darting\r\nhere, there, politician-like. A half smile on his face, as though afraid\r\nhe might forget to greet a voter he knew, or was supposed to know.\r\n\r\nHis hand was out before that of Vladimir Ignatov\'s.\r\n\r\n"Your Excellency," he said.\r\n\r\nIgnatov shook hands stiffly. Dropped that of the other\'s as soon as\r\nprotocol would permit.\r\n\r\nThe field marshal indicated the door of the conference hall. "There is\r\nlittle reason to waste time, Mr. President."\r\n\r\n"Exactly," Donlevy snapped.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe door closed behind them and the two men, one uniformed and\r\nbemedaled, the other nattily attired in his business suit, turned to\r\neach other.\r\n\r\n"Nice to see you again, Vovo. How\'re Olga and the baby?"\r\n\r\nThe soldier grinned back in response. "Two babies now--you don\'t keep up\r\non the _real_ news, Jim. How\'s Martha?" They shook hands.\r\n\r\n"Not so good," Jim said, scowling. "I\'m worried. It\'s that new cancer.\r\nAs soon as we conquer one type two more rear up. How are you people\r\ndoing on cancer research?"\r\n\r\nVovo was stripping off his tunic. He hung it over the back of one of the\r\nchairs, began to unbutton his high, tight military collar. "I\'m not\r\nreally up on it, Jim, but I think that\'s one field where you can trust\r\nanything we know to be in the regular scientific journals our people\r\nexchange with yours. I\'ll make some inquiries when I get back home,\r\nthough. You never know, this new strain--I guess you\'d call it--might be\r\none that we\'re up on and you aren\'t."\r\n\r\n"Yeah," Jim said. 

"Thanks a lot." He crossed to the small portable bar.\r\n"How about a drink? Whisky, vodka, rum--there\'s ice."\r\n\r\nVovo slumped into one of the heavy chairs that were arranged around the\r\ntable. He grimaced, "No vodka, I don\'t feel patriotic today. How about\r\none of those long cold drinks, with the cola stuff?"\r\n\r\n"Cuba libra," Jim said. "Coming up. 

Look, would you rather speak\r\nRussian?"\r\n\r\n"No," Vovo said, "my English is getting rusty. I need the practice."\r\n\r\nJim brought the glasses over and put them on the table. He began\r\nstripping off his own coat, loosening his tie. "God, I\'m tired," he\r\nsaid. "This sort of thing wears me down."\r\n\r\nVovo sipped his drink. "Now there\'s as good a thing to discuss as any,\r\nin the way of killing time. The truth now, Jim, do you really believe in\r\na God? After all that\'s happened to this human race of ours, do you\r\nreally believe in divine guidance?" He twisted his mouth sarcastically.\r\n\r\nThe other relaxed. 

"I don\'t know," he said. 

"I suppose so. I was raised\r\nin a family that believed in God. Just as, I suppose, you were raised in\r\none that didn\'t." He lifted his shoulders slightly in a shrug. "Neither\r\nof us seems to be particularly brilliant in establishing a position of\r\nour own."\r\n\r\nVovo snorted. "Never thought of it that way," he admitted. "We\'re\r\nusually contemptuous of anyone still holding to the old beliefs. There\r\naren\'t many left."\r\n\r\n"More than you people admit, I understand."\r\n\r\nVovo shook his heavy head. "No, not really. Mostly crackpots. Have you\r\never noticed how it is that the nonconformists in any society are\r\nusually crackpots? The people on your side that admit belonging to our\r\norganizations, are usually on the wild eyed and uncombed hair side--I\r\nadmit it. On the other hand, the people in our citizenry who subscribe\r\nto your system, your religion, that sort of thing, are crackpots, too.\r\nApplies to religion as well as politics. An atheist in your country is a\r\nnonconformist--in mine, a Christian is. Both crackpots."\r\n\r\nJim laughed and took a sip of his drink.\r\n\r\nVovo yawned and said, "How long are we going to be in here?"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know. Up to us, I suppose."\r\n\r\n"Yes. How about another drink? I\'ll make it. How much of that cola stuff\r\ndo you put in?"\r\n\r\nJim told him, and while the other was on his feet mixing the drinks,\r\nsaid, "You figure on sticking to the same line this year?"\r\n\r\n"Have to," Vovo said over his shoulder. "What\'s the alternative?

"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know. We\'re building up to a whale of a depression as it is,\r\neven with half the economy running full blast producing defense\r\nmaterials."\r\n\r\nVovo chuckled, "Defense materials. I wonder if ever in the history of\r\nthe human race anyone ever admitted to producing _offense_ materials."\r\n\r\n"Well, you call it the same thing. All your military equipment is for\r\ndefense. And, of course, according to your press, all ours is for\r\noffense."\r\n\r\n"Of course," Vovo said.\r\n\r\nHe brought the glasses back and handed one to the other. He slumped back\r\ninto his chair again, loosened two buttons of his trousers.\r\n\r\n"Jim," Vovo said, "why don\'t you divert more of your economy to public\r\nworks, better roads, reforestation, dams--that sort of thing."\r\n\r\nJim said wearily, "You\'re a better economist than that. Didn\'t your boy\r\nMarx, or was it Engels, write a small book on the subject? We\'re already\r\noverproducing--turning out more products than we can sell."\r\n\r\n"I wasn\'t talking about your government building new steel mills. But\r\ndams, roads, that sort of thing. You could plow billions into such items\r\nand get some real use out of them. We both know that our weapons will\r\nnever be used--they can\'t be."\r\n\r\nJim ticked them off on his fingers. "We already are producing more farm\r\nproducts than we know what to do with; if we build more dams it\'ll open\r\nup new farm lands and increase the glut. If we build more and better\r\nroads, it will improve transportation, which will mean fewer men will be\r\nable to move greater tonnage--and throw transportation employees into\r\nthe unemployed. If we go all out for reforestation, it will eventually\r\nbring down the price of lumber and the lumber people are howling\r\nalready. No," he shook his head, "there\'s just one really foolproof way\r\nof disposing of surpluses and using up labor power and that\'s war--hot\r\nor cold."\r\n\r\nVovo shrugged, "I suppose so."\r\n\r\n"It amounts to building pyramids, of course." Jim twisted his mouth\r\nsourly. "And since we\'re asking questions about each other\'s way of\r\nlife, when is your State going to begin to _wither away_?

"\r\n\r\n"How was that?" Vovo asked.\r\n\r\n"According to your sainted founder, once you people came to power the\r\nState was going to wither away, class rule would be over, and Utopia be\r\non hand. That was a long time ago, and your State is stronger than\r\nours.

"\r\n\r\nVovo snorted. "How can we wither away the State as long as we are\r\nthreatened by capitalist aggression?"\r\n\r\nJim said, "Ha!

"\r\n\r\nVovo went on. "You know better than that, Jim. The only way my\r\norganization can keep in power is by continually beating the drums,\r\nkeeping our people stirred up to greater and greater sacrifices by using\r\nyou as a threat. Didn\'t the old Romans have some sort of maxim to the\r\neffect that when you\'re threatened with unease at home stir up trouble\r\nabroad?"\r\n\r\n"You\'re being even more frank than usual," Jim said. "But that\'s one of\r\nthe pleasures of these get-togethers, neither of us resorts to\r\nhypocrisy. But you can\'t keep up these tensions forever."\r\n\r\n"You mean _we_ can\'t keep up these tensions forever, Jim. And when they\r\nend? Well, personally I can\'t see my organization going out without a\r\nblood bath." He grimaced sourly, "And since I\'d probably be one of the\r\nfirst to be bathed, I\'d like to postpone the time. It\'s like having a\r\ntiger by the tail, Jim. 

We can\'t let go."\r\n\r\n"Happily, I don\'t feel in the same spot," Jim said. He got up and went\r\nto the picture window that took up one entire wall. It faced out over a\r\nmountain vista. He looked soberly into the sky.\r\n\r\nVovo joined him, glass in hand.\r\n\r\n"Possibly your position isn\'t exactly the same as ours but there\'ll be\r\nsome awfully great changes if that military based economy of yours\r\nsuddenly had peace thrust upon it. You\'d have a depression such as\r\nyou\'ve never dreamed of. Let\'s face reality, Jim, neither of us can\r\nafford peace."\r\n\r\n"Well, we\'ve both known that for a long time."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThey both considered somberly, the planet Earth blazing away, a small\r\nsun there in the sky.\r\n\r\nJim said, "I sometimes think that the race would have been better off,\r\nwhen man was colonizing Venus and Mars, if it had been a joint\r\nenterprise rather than you people doing one, and we the other. If it had\r\nall been in the hands of that organization ..."\r\n\r\n"The United Nations?" Vovo supplied.\r\n\r\n"... Then when Bomb Day hit, perhaps these new worlds could have gone on\r\nto, well, better things."\r\n\r\n"Perhaps," Vovo shrugged. "I\'ve often wondered how Bomb Day started. Who\r\nstruck the spark."\r\n\r\n"Happily there were enough colonists on both planets to start the race\r\nall over again," Jim said. "What difference does it make, who struck the\r\nspark?

"\r\n\r\n"None, I suppose." Vovo began to button his collar, readjust his\r\nclothes. "Well, shall we emerge and let the quaking multitudes know that\r\nonce again we have made a shaky agreement? 

One that will last until the\r\nnext summit meeting."\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note\r\n\r\nIn two places in the text the word "reforestration" was corrected to\r\n"reforestation."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


So I certainly could not be subtle, which requires\r\nboth cleverness and an ability to tell the truth and a lie in the same\r\nbreath.\r\n\r\nLet us turn back the clock a few ages. I was lying in the sun thinking\r\nof love. I understand that you human beings have an aversion to\r\nbiological discussion, so I will not go into detail. But I must remind\r\nyou that my love life is quite different from yours, for I am from\r\nanother planet. At the time under discussion, I was most deeply in love.\r\n\r\nMy heart\'s desire had no shape, the lovely creature. She had no\r\nintelligence, the divine soul. But she was the greatest bit of\r\nprotoplasm in any galaxy you could name. By our standards, I probably\r\nmight be called handsome. I was young and healthy. I had all of my genes\r\nand chromosomes. My color was the dirty green that is associated with\r\nbeauty.\r\n\r\nThe sun warmed my body and the tidal undulation of my planet\'s surface\r\nrocked me gently. And then she came into my life. She floated gently in\r\nthe breeze, her dainty figure held aloft by a mere hint of levitation.\r\nSparks of static electricity shot from her tender cilia so brightly that\r\nI was forced to exude a layer of protective fibre to protect my visual\r\nbuds. She sucked a deep breath of cyanic gas into her pulmonary pouch\r\nand spoke to me sweetly with a voice like distant thunder.\r\n\r\n"My dear Yljm, the world is coming to an end."\r\n\r\nI could not believe her, for she had no intelligence. 

She only loved to\r\ntalk. "Perhaps," I said, "but not today."\r\n\r\n"Very soon, then," said she. Her name was Mjly.\r\n\r\nI watched her with patronizing amusement. The static electricity showed\r\nthat she was nervous and upset, but people often get nervous and upset\r\nover trivial matters. "Now, how," I reasoned, "could our world come to\r\nan end? 

The other planet has gone on for thousands of years without\r\ncolliding with us. We circle it, in fact."\r\n\r\n"No," Mjly said, "that is not our doom. Actually our world will not\r\ncease to exist. Life will end here, that is all."\r\n\r\n"Ah," I said. "Our atmosphere is escaping into space." I sucked air,\r\nviciously. True, the air was thin. True, the atmosphere was escaping.\r\nBut there would be breathable amounts for many thousands of centuries\r\nyet to come.\r\n\r\n"Not the air. The food is all gone. Things we eat have ceased to exist."\r\n\r\nI levitated myself and looked out over the throbbing land. A few years\r\nago, this land had been covered with vegetation. I had come to take\r\nvegetation so much for granted that I\'d ceased to notice it. Now it was\r\ngone. There were no round fruits growing from tender grasses, no tubers\r\ndangling from the fungus trees, no legume vines sprawling over the\r\nrocks. Everywhere lay desert, barren dunes shaking their crests with\r\ntidal motion.\r\n\r\nI lowered myself to the ground and dug my big fibrosities into the sod.\r\nNo green leaves grew there beneath the surface. The soil was dead. "This\r\nwill seriously interfere with our future, Mjly," I said.\r\n\r\n"We might eat each other," she replied, "but then there would be no one\r\nleft."\r\n\r\n"No one? 

There are many others here."\r\n\r\n"The others are dying," said Mjly, blinking her otic nerves eerily. "We\r\nsoon will be the only ones left."\r\n\r\nIt was indeed a senseless thing to do, to die just because there was no\r\nmeans of going on living. But I must admit that I was tempted for a\r\nmoment. But I hung onto myself, for there was Mjly, and as long as she\r\nlived, there was a reason for me to live too.\r\n\r\n"It\'s not a cheerful prospect," I said, "but I suppose death by\r\nstarvation is the best way out. We will face death as we have lived,\r\ncheerfully and fortuitously."\r\n\r\n"And why should we die, when there is another world so close?" she\r\nasked.\r\n\r\n"Are you suggesting interplanetary flight, my dear?" I was amused again,\r\neven though there was little enough left to be amused at.\r\n\r\nShe crinkled her sense of smell in reply, and I realized I was not being\r\namused at the right time. Anchoring herself by magnetic processes, she\r\nbegan to weave the atmosphere delicately with her taste-bud tendrils.\r\nQuickly she hollowed the air molecules into a reflective mirror, and\r\nbrought it to focus on our neighboring world. I levitated myself into a\r\nposition so that I could look into the mirror.\r\n\r\nThe near planet was quite satisfactory. It was the one you know as the\r\nearth. 

It was young. It was green. Huge fern-like plants grew abundantly\r\non its surface. 

It was full of food. And near.\r\n\r\n"The trip could be made by levitation," Mjly said.\r\n\r\nI hung back. "Animals might live there. We\'d be devoured."\r\n\r\n"I am not afraid," she said.\r\n\r\n"We might not get hungry for a time. Let us linger here awhile. Later\r\nwhen we get desperate, there will be time enough for interplanetary\r\nflight." I hated the thought of stuffing myself full of air enough to\r\nlast for the long trip.\r\n\r\nMjly lowered her visual buds. "I am going to become a mother," she said.\r\n\r\n"Go then, and become a mother. I\'ll stay here till I get hungry and then\r\njoin you.

"\r\n\r\nMjly unflexed her sense of touch and I felt sorry for her. "If I could\r\nbe sure," I said, "that no wild animals live on the earth, I\'d go\r\nsooner."\r\n\r\nShe snapped her sense of balance in happiness. "I will go first," said\r\nshe. "If everything is pleasant and safe, I will return and let you\r\nknow."\r\n\r\nI nodded my otic nerves and off she went.\r\n\r\nAs you human beings are doubtless aware, space levitation is quite\r\ncomplicated, but not beyond accomplishment. Once you are able to reach\r\nthe speed of escape the rest is easy. But Mjly was young and strong and\r\nsoon she had disappeared from sight traveling at a tremendous velocity.\r\nI followed her as long as I could with the telescope and then I lowered\r\nmyself to the tidal crest of a nearby sand dune and lost myself in\r\nmetaphysical thoughts.\r\n\r\nAlmost half a year later I realized that Mjly had been gone longer than\r\nI expected. Either she had been eaten by wild animals on the earth, or\r\nshe had forgotten me.\r\n\r\nI was beginning to get lonesome and in a few more months I would get\r\nhungry. At the thought of enduring two such excruciating pains at a\r\nsingle time, I decided to risk my life. I would travel through space to\r\nthe earth and try to find my beloved.\r\n\r\nAs you may have guessed, the planet on which we had been living is the\r\none you now know as the Moon, and the distance to the earth is\r\ncomparatively small. The sand dunes now have hardened and the tidal sway\r\nof its surface can be felt only slightly. The moon no longer turns on\r\nits axis and it has no sweetly scented cyanide in its atmosphere. It has\r\nno atmosphere of any sort. But it stands now as it did when I left it,\r\nglorious in death. Since I departed, no living thing has trod its soil.\r\n\r\nMy scientific sense instinctively came to the rescue as I approached the\r\nearth. I felt a strong gravity wrenching at my vitals and so instead of\r\ntrying reverse levitation, I spread my processes so that the atmosphere\r\ncaught in the folds of my skin and I came floating gently down to the\r\nground without harm.\r\n\r\nThe earth was much as it had appeared through the molecule telescope. It\r\nwas covered with green vegetation, good, rich, nourishing stuff. And\r\nthere was enough to feed Mjly and me for a million years.\r\n\r\nThere were no animals of any sort. Again I went to my scientific sense\r\nfor the answer. I realized that while vegetable life was far advanced,\r\nanimal life had yet to appear. Mjly was the first of this type of life\r\never to set foot on terrestrial soil.\r\n\r\nBut where was she? On the moon, I could often locate her a thousand\r\nmiles away by a simple radio call. Although the earth was much larger\r\nthan the moon, I did not doubt that she was within a thousand miles. So\r\nI generated power and issued a call.\r\n\r\nI waited for the response. It came feebly to my antenna.\r\n\r\nUsing my sense of direction, I pushed through the vegetation in search\r\nof her. I did not levitate, because the feebleness of her call indicated\r\nshe might be hurt and on the ground. Besides, levitation is much more\r\ndifficult on the earth than on the moon.\r\n\r\nThe reply came stronger to my next call and I sensed through seven of my\r\nsenses that she was near. She was on the ground, probably injured, which\r\nexplained why she had not returned as she had promised.\r\n\r\nI came to a patch of wilderness, a great marshy plain. In the middle of\r\nthis swamp was a crater, like those caused by meteors, a deep, ugly scar\r\nin the mud. I shuddered at the thought that my darling Mjly might have\r\nlanded there. Her weaker scientific sense might not have given her the\r\ncue to use her skin as a parachute and she might have made the fatal\r\nmistake of trying to reverse-levitate.\r\n\r\n"Mjly!" I called, speaking aloud now. 

"Mjly! Where are you?"\r\n\r\n"Yljm! I am here!"\r\n\r\nYes, the voice came from the crater. Gliding to its rim, I looked down.\r\nA pool of water lay on the bottom. A greenish scum covered the surface.\r\nThe scum moved with a million tiny wriggles.\r\n\r\n"Yes, Yljm," came Mjly\'s voice. "It is I. But I am no longer one being."\r\nAnd her voice sounded like a million tiny chirps joined together. "I\r\nlanded with such force that I came apart. Now each of my body cells\r\nlives a life of its own. And now and then each cell grows fat and\r\nbecomes two. I am my sisters, I ..."\r\n\r\nLet\'s not be subtle about it. Mjly was a microbe, the beginning of\r\nanimal life on the earth. She lives today, she is and always will be her\r\nsisters, her mothers, herselves and her ancestors. But there are few\r\nancestors, for microbes do not die--just part of themselves die.\r\n\r\nAnd I do not die. For I crept away into a hole in the ground, where I\r\nwill live forever. 

I do not starve, for roots reach me here. But I miss\r\nmy love life with Mjly. I can never be a mother or a sister. I will\r\nalways be me, a lonesome old bem.\r\n\r\n\r\n                                                           \xc2\xb7\xc2\xb7\xc2\xb7 THE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _If Worlds of Science Fiction_ July\r\n    1954. She was not disappointed. "Is Terry really way up there all\r\nalone, Martha?" "Aren\'t you _scared_, Martha?" 

"I do hope they can get\r\nhim back down all right, Martha." She supposed it must have given them\r\nquite a turn to have their egg woman change into a star mother\r\novernight.\r\n\r\nShe hadn\'t expected the TV interview, though, and she would have avoided\r\nit if it had been politely possible. But what could she do when the line\r\nof cars and trucks pulled into the drive and the technicians got out and\r\nstarted setting up their equipment in the backyard? What could she say\r\nwhen the suave young man came up to her and said, "We want you to know\r\nthat we\'re all very proud of your boy up there, ma\'am, and we hope\r\nyou\'ll do us the honor of answering a few questions."\r\n\r\nMost of the questions concerned Terry, as was fitting. From the way the\r\nsuave young man asked them, though, she got the impression that he was\r\ntrying to prove that her son was just like any other average American\r\nboy, and such just didn\'t happen to be the case. But whenever she opened\r\nher mouth to mention, say, how he used to study till all hours of the\r\nnight, or how difficult it had been for him to make friends because of\r\nhis shyness, or the fact that he had never gone out for\r\nfootball--whenever she started to mention any of these things, the suave\r\nyoung man was in great haste to interrupt her and to twist her words, by\r\nrequestioning, into a different meaning altogether, till Terry\'s\r\nbehavior pattern seemed to coincide with the behavior pattern which the\r\nsuave young man apparently considered the norm, but which, if followed,\r\nMartha was sure, would produce not young men bent on exploring space but\r\nyoung men bent on exploring trivia.\r\n\r\nA few of the questions concerned herself: Was Terry her only child?\r\n("Yes.") What had happened to her husband? 

("He was killed in the Korean\r\nWar.") What did she think of the new law granting star mothers top\r\npriority on any and all information relating to their sons? ("I think\r\nit\'s a fine law ... It\'s too bad they couldn\'t have shown similar\r\nhumanity toward the war mothers of World War II.")\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIt was late in the afternoon by the time the TV crew got everything\r\nrepacked into their cars and trucks and made their departure. Martha\r\nfixed herself a light supper, then donned an old suede jacket of Terry\'s\r\nand went out into the garden to wait for the sun to go down. According\r\nto the time table the general had outlined in his first telegram,\r\nTerry\'s first Tuesday night passage wasn\'t due to occur till 9:05. But\r\nit seemed only right that she should be outside when the stars started\r\nto come out. Presently they did, and she watched them wink on, one by\r\none, in the deepening darkness of the sky. She\'d never been much of a\r\none for the stars; most of her life she\'d been much too busy on Earth to\r\nbother with things celestial. She could remember, when she was much\r\nyounger and Bill was courting her, looking up at the moon sometimes; and\r\nonce in a while, when a star fell, making a wish. But this was\r\ndifferent. It was different because now she had a personal interest in\r\nthe sky, a new affinity with its myriad inhabitants.\r\n\r\nAnd how bright they became when you kept looking at them! They seemed to\r\ncome alive, almost, pulsing brilliantly down out of the blackness of the\r\nnight ... And they were different colors, too, she noticed with a start.\r\nSome of them were blue and some were red, others were yellow ... green\r\n... orange ...\r\n\r\nIt grew cold in the April garden and she could see her breath. There was\r\na strange crispness, a strange clarity about the night, that she had\r\nnever known before ... She glanced at her watch, was astonished to see\r\nthat the hands indicated two minutes after nine. Where had the time\r\ngone? Tremulously she faced the southern horizon ... and saw her Terry\r\nappear in his shining chariot, riding up the star-pebbled path of his\r\norbit, a star in his own right, dropping swiftly now, down, down, and\r\nout of sight beyond the dark wheeling mass of the Earth ... She took a\r\ndeep, proud breath, realized that she was wildly waving her hand and let\r\nit fall slowly to her side. Make a wish! she thought, like a little\r\ngirl, and she wished him pleasant dreams and a safe return and wrapped\r\nthe wish in all her love and cast it starward.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nSometime tomorrow, the general\'s telegram had said--\r\n\r\nThat meant sometime today!\r\n\r\nShe rose with the sun and fed the chickens, fixed and ate her breakfast,\r\ncollected the eggs and put them in their cardboard boxes, then started\r\nout on her Wednesday morning run. "My land, Martha, I don\'t see how you\r\nstand it with him way up there! 

Doesn\'t it get on your _nerves_?" ("Yes\r\n... Yes, it does.") "Martha, when are they bringing him back down?"\r\n("Today ... 

_Today_!") "It must be wonderful being a star mother,\r\nMartha." ("Yes, it is--in a way.

")\r\n\r\nWonderful ... and terrible.\r\n\r\nIf only he can last it out for a few more hours, she thought. 

If only\r\nthey can bring him down safe and sound. Then the vigil will be over, and\r\nsome other mother can take over the awesome responsibility of having a\r\nson become a star--\r\n\r\nIf only ...\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe general\'s third telegram arrived that afternoon: _Regret to inform\r\nyou that meteorite impact on satellite hull severely damaged\r\ncapsule-detachment mechanism, making ejection impossible. Will make\r\nevery effort to find another means of accomplishing your son\'s return._\r\n\r\nTerry!--\r\n\r\nSee the little boy playing beneath the maple tree, moving his tiny cars\r\nup and down the tiny streets of his make-believe village; the little\r\nboy, his fuzz of hair gold in the sunlight, his cherub-cheeks pink in\r\nthe summer wind--\r\n\r\n_Terry!--_\r\n\r\nUp the lane the blue-denimed young man walks, swinging his thin tanned\r\narms, his long legs making near-grownup strides over the sun-seared\r\ngrass; the sky blue and bright behind him, the song of cicada rising and\r\nfalling in the hazy September air--\r\n\r\n_Terry ..._\r\n\r\n_--probably won\'t get a chance to write you again before take-off, but\r\ndon\'t worry, Ma. The _Explorer XII_ is the greatest bird they ever\r\nbuilt. Nothing short of a direct meteorite hit can hurt it, and the odds\r\nare a million to one ..._\r\n\r\n_Why don\'t they leave the stars alone? Why don\'t they leave the stars to\r\nGod?_\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe afternoon shadows lengthened on the lawn and the sun grew red and\r\nswollen over the western hills. Martha fixed supper, tried to eat, and\r\ncouldn\'t. After a while, when the light began to fade, she slipped into\r\nTerry\'s jacket and went outside.\r\n\r\nSlowly the sky darkened and the stars began to appear. At length _her_\r\nstar appeared, but its swift passage blurred before her eyes. Tires\r\ncrunched on the gravel then, and headlights washed the darkness from the\r\ndrive. A car door slammed.\r\n\r\nMartha did not move. _Please God_, she thought, _let it be Terry_, even\r\nthough she knew that it couldn\'t possibly be Terry. Footsteps sounded\r\nbehind her, paused. Someone coughed softly. She turned then--\r\n\r\n"Good evening, ma\'am."\r\n\r\nShe saw the circlet of stars on the gray epaulet; she saw the stern\r\nhandsome face; she saw the dark tired eyes. 

And she knew. Even before he\r\nspoke again, she knew--\r\n\r\n"The same meteorite that damaged the ejection mechanism, ma\'am. It\r\npenetrated the capsule, too. We didn\'t find out till just a while\r\nago--but there was nothing we could have done anyway ... Are you all\r\nright, ma\'am?"\r\n\r\n"Yes. I\'m all right."\r\n\r\n"I wanted to express my regrets personally. I know how you must feel.

"\r\n\r\n"It\'s all right."\r\n\r\n"We will, of course, make every effort to bring back his ... remains ...\r\nso that he can have a fitting burial on Earth."\r\n\r\n"No," she said.\r\n\r\n"I beg your pardon, ma\'am?"\r\n\r\nShe raised her eyes to the patch of sky where her son had passed in his\r\nshining metal sarcophagus. Sirius blossomed there, blue-white and\r\nbeautiful. She raised her eyes still higher--and beheld the vast\r\nparterre of Orion with its central motif of vivid forget-me-nots, its\r\nfar-flung blooms of Betelguese and Rigel, of Bellatrix and Saiph ... And\r\nhigher yet--and there flamed the exquisite flower beds of Taurus and\r\nGemini, there burgeoned the riotous wreath of the Crab; there lay the\r\npulsing petals of the Pleiades ... And down the ecliptic garden path,\r\nwafted by a stellar breeze, drifted the ocher rose of Mars ...\r\n\r\n"No," she said again.\r\n\r\nThe general had raised his eyes, too; now, slowly, he lowered them. "I\r\nthink I understand, ma\'am. And I\'m glad that\'s the way you want it ...\r\nThe stars _are_ beautiful tonight, aren\'t they."\r\n\r\n"More beautiful than they\'ve ever been," she said.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAfter the general had gone, she looked up once more at the vast and\r\nvariegated garden of the sky where her son lay buried, then she turned\r\nand walked slowly back to the memoried house.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Amazing Stories_ January 1959.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. ]\r\n\r\n\r\nDonnie clenched his small fists and tried not to cry, but two\r\nelliptical tears ran slowly down his cheeks. The sight of them made Mr.\r\nAmes even madder.\r\n\r\n"Look at him," he stormed, turning to Martha. "Just look at him. Every\r\ndamn time I try to reason with him, he starts to snivel like an animal,\r\ninstead of acting like a normal human being." Mr. Ames flicked his\r\ncigar ashes toward a vacuum cup on the wall and looked down at the boy.\r\n"Now stop that stupid crying and tell me what this is all about."\r\n\r\nDonnie sniffled a couple of times and wiped his nose on the back of one\r\nof his blue uniform sleeves.\r\n\r\n"Well," Mr. Ames said, coldly.\r\n\r\nThe boy took a deep breath and raised his head. "I want you to spend\r\nsome time with me," he said. "I want you to--" he searched the elusive\r\nshadows of memory until he found the word he wanted--"I want you to\r\n_play_ with me. That\'s it. I want you to play with me once in a while."\r\n\r\nMr. Ames blinked his eyes and stepped back. "Play," he repeated. "What\r\ndo you mean _play_?"\r\n\r\nDonnie hesitated. "You know," he said, finally, "take me on long walks\r\nand sit down and play games and tell me stories once in a while."\r\n\r\n"But you\'ve got all the stories you need," Mr. Ames said, waving his\r\nhand at the banks of audiotapes stacked neatly on the wall shelves.\r\n"And your audio-prompter can tell them better than I can."\r\n\r\n"Yes," Donnie said, "but that\'s a machine and I want--"\r\n\r\n"What\'s wrong with a machine," Mr. Ames said, his face getting red.\r\n"Some of our best things come from machines. Didn\'t they teach you that\r\nat the Incubator?"\r\n\r\n"Yes," the boy said, "but isn\'t there anything besides machines? I\r\ncan\'t play with machines, I want to play with you!" He began to sob\r\nagain.\r\n\r\nMr. Ames dashed his cigar to the floor. "I give up," he said. "By the\r\nRed Balls of Jupiter, I give up!"\r\n\r\n"Now, Henry," his wife said. "Remember, the boy\'s only seven."\r\n\r\n"Don\'t \'Henry\' me," Mr. Ames said, "And besides, what does being seven\r\nhave to do with it. When I was his age, I was an honor student in\r\nphysics. _He_ can\'t even pass algebra."\r\n\r\nDonnie stared at the toes of his boots.\r\n\r\n"I\'ve given this kid everything," Mr. Ames went on. "He\'s going to\r\nthe best pre-nuclear school in the whole hemisphere. He\'s got his own\r\nrocket kit. Why, he\'s even been on a study cruise to the moon! How\r\nmany kids his age have been to the moon already? I bet no other kid in\r\nour project has been there. And what do I get as a reward." 

Mr. Ames\r\ndidn\'t wait for an answer. "Trouble. 

That\'s what I get, trouble. Why in\r\nGalaxy he can\'t leave me alone like a normal child is more than I can\r\nunderstand." He stopped for breath and lit a fresh cigar.\r\n\r\n"Maybe the boy\'s sick," Martha said timidly.\r\n\r\nMr. Ames ignored her. "I\'ve tried to be a good father to him," he said,\r\nhis voice self-righteous. "I\'m giving him a chance to make something\r\nout of himself. All I ask is that he be of service to the world, and\r\nmake me proud of him some day. But what does he do? Does he concentrate\r\non his career, like the rest of the kids? Hell, no, he wants to hang\r\naround me, always underfoot, always asking stupid questions. Play!" Mr.\r\nAmes snorted.\r\n\r\n"It\'s not just play."\r\n\r\n"Heh, what\'s that?" Mr. Ames jumped.\r\n\r\n"I said it\'s not just play," Donnie repeated, bravely brushing away\r\nhis tears. "You don\'t give me any--" he searched again for the right\r\nword--"any _companionship_. A boy needs companionship. Don\'t you\r\nunderstand?"\r\n\r\n"No, I don\'t," Mr. Ames said. "And I\'m sure they didn\'t teach you\r\nthat in the Incubator either. Don\'t you realize you should be fully\r\ncoordinated by now. Instead, you want me to take time from my work--Why\r\nit\'s preposterous. It\'s, it\'s--unscientific!"\r\n\r\n"But, all I want--"\r\n\r\nMr. Ames held up his hand. "Enough of this," he said. "I refuse to\r\ndiscuss it anymore. Now go to your room and get ready for your study\r\nperiod."\r\n\r\nThe boy burst out crying again and ran out of the room.\r\n\r\nMr. Ames shook his head. "Definite neurotic tendencies," he muttered to\r\nhimself.\r\n\r\n"What dear?" his wife said.\r\n\r\n"Nothing, Martha," he answered. "Just talking to myself." He sat down\r\nheavily on the couch and sighed. What was wrong with Donnie, anyway?\r\nWhere did he get those archaic ideas from? Surely he had been taught\r\nthat the whole purpose of the incubator system was to speed up learning\r\nand growth processes so children wouldn\'t have to waste precious years\r\ngrowing up, like they did in the old days. Why their new technological\r\nage simply had no time to fool around with infantile desires. There\r\nwere too many things to do, too many knotty scientific problems to\r\nsolve. 

Emotions, Mr. Ames mumbled to himself, you never could trust\r\nyour damn emotions.\r\n\r\nThat night, after Donnie was in bed, Mr. Ames went to his study and\r\npulled out the boy\'s file. It explained what he was fitted for, what\r\nabilities he had inherited, and what his primary training included.\r\nMr. Ames noted sadly that the boy\'s Scientific Quotient was 142, well\r\nabove normal, and that he would stand six feet tall and weigh close to\r\n195 pounds when fully developed.\r\n\r\nMr. Ames, who was incubator-born himself, was completely sold on\r\nthe ingenious system the Federation of World Councils had devised.\r\nNo more hit-and-miss mass reproduction, where morons were gradually\r\nout-breeding intelligent beings, but instead, selective artificial\r\ninsemination through which only the best strains were permitted to\r\nreproduce. Each generation, the human race got healthier and smarter.\r\nInsanity and inherited diseases were a thing of the past and nature\'s\r\nprimitive law--only the fittest shall survive--was now a glittering\r\nreality. Why the Federated Incubators even took over the burden of\r\neducating the children for the first five years. Parents no longer\r\nhad to be bothered caring for helpless, bawling brats. By the time\r\nIncubates were placed on the available list, they were completely\r\nself-sufficient and emotionally conditioned to fit into any family\r\ngroup. Parents simply picked what they wanted. 

Mr. Ames, of course, had\r\nselected a future nuclear-chemist.\r\n\r\nIt was a beautiful system, Mr. Ames told himself, and even more\r\nimportant, it worked. But somehow, some way, there was something\r\nradically wrong with their child.\r\n\r\n"Definite neurotic symptoms," Mr. Ames murmured, half aloud. 

By\r\nJupiter, there was only one thing to do. He shut the folder firmly and\r\nspun around to the trans-audio. A green light appeared on the panel\r\nalmost immediately.\r\n\r\n"Your connection, please?" the automon said.\r\n\r\n"Give me the local Incubator."\r\n\r\nThere was a pause, then a click. "Federated Health and Service,\r\ncoordinator speaking. May I help you?"\r\n\r\n"Yes. 

This is Mr. Henry Ames, over at the Amarillo Group Project. I\r\nhave a complaint to make."\r\n\r\n"Yes?" The coordinator, a woman, was carefully polite.\r\n\r\n"It\'s about the child you sent us."\r\n\r\n"Specimen please?"\r\n\r\n"What? Oh, it\'s a boy, Class Triple A, breed, nuclear chemistry. We got\r\nhim about 18 months ago and--"\r\n\r\n"What is your number please?"\r\n\r\n"It\'s ... just a minute." 

Mr. Ames consulted the folder. "My number is\r\n34-72-oh-41. And we\'ve got a three-year guarantee," he added pointedly.\r\n\r\n"Yes, sir. Just a minute sir." There was a whirring sound at the other\r\nend of the circuit. After a short wait, the coordinator\'s voice came\r\nthrough again.\r\n\r\n"Well, sir," she said. "You have the select model in our scientific\r\nline of seven-year-olds. According to our records, he checked out\r\nperfectly on all phases of learning and aptitude. Have you tried memory\r\nteaching?"\r\n\r\n"Yes, I\'ve tried memory teaching. He learns fine." 

Mr. Ames stopped.\r\n"Look, you don\'t seem to understand. He\'s okay as far as performance\r\ngoes. He does everything we tell him and all that, but he\'s\r\nstill a real pain in the--I mean, he\'s developing very annoying\r\ncharacteristics."\r\n\r\n"Please go on, Mr. 

Ames." The coordinator\'s voice was warm and\r\nsympathetic. "How does he annoy you?"\r\n\r\n"Well, for one thing, he\'s getting pronounced possessive tendencies. He\r\nalmost seems to resent being left alone. Why, just this evening he told\r\nme he wants us to _play_ with him!"\r\n\r\n"Did you say _play_ with him?"\r\n\r\n"That\'s right," Mr. Ames said, triumphantly. "And he says he needs\r\ncompanionship, or something like that."\r\n\r\n"Companionship," the coordinator repeated. "Oh, dear. 

This is more\r\nserious than I thought. I\'m afraid you definitely have a reject,\r\nMr. Ames. If he shows these tendencies at this early age, then the\r\nsituation will be intolerable later on."\r\n\r\n"It\'s intolerable right now," Henry insisted. "Anyway, I thought you\r\npeople were supposed to clear up all this emotional unbalance in the\r\nprimary psych indoctrination."\r\n\r\n"We usually do," the coordinator agreed, "but every once in a while,\r\none slips through inspection with faulty communal-perception. The\r\none you\'ve got is obviously a throw-back." The coordinator coughed\r\napologetically. "It\'s really not the boy\'s fault, of course, but I\'m\r\nafraid we\'ll have to reclaim him."\r\n\r\n"The sooner the better," Mr. Ames said. "This mess is upsetting my work\r\nat the lab. When can I get a replacement?"\r\n\r\n"We\'ll send a new model over when we pick up the reject. Will tomorrow\r\nmorning be convenient?"\r\n\r\n"Sure. Fine. 

Just make sure this one is normal. You better check our\r\nphysio records too. I hear the people down the circle got one that\r\ndidn\'t look like them at all."\r\n\r\n"Don\'t worry," the coordinator assured him. "You\'ll get a boy you can\r\nbe proud of this time. Will there be anything more now?"\r\n\r\n"No, no, I guess not." An uneasy feeling slipped into Mr. Ames\'s\r\nconsciousness. "I just wondered," he said, suddenly. "What will happen\r\nto Don--I mean, the reject you sent us. Will he be--uh--destroyed?"\r\n\r\nThe coordinator laughed. 

"Heavens, no, Mr. Ames," she said, lightly.\r\n"He\'ll be sent to the Biological Reservation and allowed to live out\r\nhis life span with other rejects. He\'ll be much happier there. We\'re\r\nnot savages, you know."\r\n\r\n"That\'s right," Mr. Ames said, his tone matching her brightness. "We\'re\r\nnot savages. Well, we\'ll be expecting the new one tomorrow, and thanks\r\nfor all your trouble."\r\n\r\n"No trouble at all," the coordinator said, smoothly. 

"Feel free to call\r\non us any time."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


Well, not exactly, but that\'s\r\nwhat I call it. 

No, I don\'t know how it works. Too complicated for me.\r\nCarter could make it go, but after he made it he never used it. Too bad;\r\nhe thought he\'d make a lot of money with it there for awhile, while he\r\nwas working it out. Almost had me convinced, but I told him, "Get it to\r\nworking first, Carter, and then show me what you can do with it better\r\nthan I can do without it. I\'m doing pretty well as is ... pictures\r\nselling good, even if I do make \'em all by guesswork, as you call it."\r\nThat\'s what I told him.\r\n\r\nY\'see, Carter was one a them artists that think they can work everything\r\nout by formulas and stuff. Me, I just paint things as I see \'em. Never\r\nworry about perspective and all that kinda mechanical aids. Never even\r\nwent to Art School. 

But I do all right. Carter, now, was a different\r\nsorta artist. Well, he wasn\'t really an artist--more of a draftsman.\r\n\r\nI first got him in to help me with a series of real estate paintings I\'d\r\ngot an order for. Big aerial views of land developments, and drawings of\r\nbuildings, roads and causeways, that kinda stuff. Was a little too much\r\nfor me to handle alone, \'cause I never studied that kinda things, ya\r\nknow. I thought he\'d do the mechanical drawings, which shoulda been\r\nsimple for anybody trained that way, and I\'d throw in the colors,\r\nfigures and trees and so on. He did fine. Job came out good; client was\r\nreal happy. We made a pretty good amount on the job, enough to keep us\r\nfor a coupla months without working afterwards. I took it easy, fishing\r\nand so on, but Carter stayed here in the studio working on his own\r\nstuff. I let him keep an eye on things for me around the place, and just\r\ndropped in now and then to check up.\r\n\r\nThe guy was nuts on the subject of perspective. I thought he knew all\r\nthere was to know about it already, but he claimed _nobody_ knew\r\nanything about it, really. Said he\'d been studying it for years, and the\r\nmore he learned about it the more there was to learn. He used to cover\r\nbig sheets of paper with complicated diagrams trying to prove something\r\nor other to himself. I\'d come into the studio and find him with thumb\r\ntacks and strings and stuff all over the place. He\'d get big long rulers\r\nand draw lines to various points all over the room, and end up with a\r\nlittle drawing of a cube about an inch square that anybody coulda made\r\nin a half a minute without all the apparatus. Seemed pretty silly to me.\r\n\r\nThen he brought in some books on mathematics and physics and other\r\nthings, and a bunch of slide rules, calculators, and junk. He musta been\r\na pretty smart guy to know how to handle all those things, even if he\r\nwas kinda dopey about other things. You know ... women and fishing and\r\nsports and drinking; he was lousy at everything except working those\r\nperspective problems. Personally, I couldn\'t see much sense to what he\r\nwas doing. The guy could draw all right already, so I asked him what\r\nmore did he want? Lemme see if I can remember what he said.\r\n\r\n"I\'m trying to get at things as they really are, not as they appear," he\r\nsaid. I think those were his words. "Art is an illusion, a bag of\r\ntricks. Reality is something else, not what we _think_ it is. Drawings\r\nare two-dimensional projections of a world that is not merely three- but\r\nfour-dimensional, if not more," he said.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nYeh, kind of a crackpot, Carter was. Just on that one subject, though;\r\nnice enough guy otherwise. 

Here, look at some of the drawings he made,\r\nworking out his formulas. Nice designs, huh? Might make good wall paper\r\nor fabric patterns. Real abstract ... that\'s what people seem to like.\r\nSee all those little letters scattered around among the lines? Different\r\nkinds of vanishing points, they are. Carter claimed the whole world was\r\nfull of vanishing points. You don\'t know what a vanishing point is?\r\nLemme see if I can explain. Come over to the window here.\r\n\r\nYa see how that road out there gets smaller and smaller in the distance?\r\nOf course the road doesn\'t really get smaller--it just looks that way.\r\nThat\'s what we call a vanishing point in drawing. Simple, isn\'t it?\r\nNever could understand why Carter went to so much trouble working out\r\nall those ways to locate vanishing points. Me, I just throw \'em in\r\nwherever I need \'em. But Carter claimed that was wrong. Said they were\r\nall connected together some way, and he was gonna work out a method to\r\nprove it.\r\n\r\nHere ... here\'s a little gadget he made up to help his calculations.\r\nBunch of disks all pivoted together at the center; you\'re supposed to\r\nturn \'em around so the arrows point to the different figures and things.\r\nHere\'s the square root sign, I remember Carter telling me that. This one\r\nis the Tangent Function, whatever that means. Log, there, is short for\r\nlogarithm. Oh, he had a bunch of that scientific stuff in his head all\r\nthe time; dunno whether he understood it all himself. He built this\r\nthing just before he put together the perspective machine there.\r\n\r\nSilly-looking gadget, huh? All them pipes and wires and that little cube\r\nin the center ... don\'t try to touch it, it ain\'t really there. 

You just\r\nthink it is. It\'s what Carter called a teteract, or a cataract ... no,\r\nthat ain\'t the right word. Somepin\' like that--tesser something or\r\nother. 

There\'s a picture like it in one of Carter\'s books. Hurts your\r\neyes to look at it, don\'t it?\r\n\r\nThat\'s what Carter thought was going to make him a lot of fame and\r\nmoney, that perspective machine. I told him nobody\'d ever made a drawing\r\nmachine yet that worked, but he said it wasn\'t supposed to make\r\ndrawings. It was just supposed to give people a view of what reality\r\nreally is, instead of what they think it is. I dunno whether he expected\r\nto charge money to look through it, or whether he was gonna look through\r\nit himself and make some new kinda drawings and sell \'em.\r\n\r\nNo, I can\'t tell you how it works--I said before I don\'t know. Carter\r\nonly used it once himself. I came in here the day he finished it, just\r\nas he was ready to turn it on. He was just putting the finishing touches\r\non it.\r\n\r\n"In a few minutes," he told me, "I\'ll have the answer to a question that\r\nmay never have been answered before: what is reality? Is the world a\r\nthing by itself, and all we know illusion? Why do things grow smaller\r\nthe farther away from us they appear? Why can\'t we see more than one\r\nside of anything at a time? What happens to the far side of an object;\r\ndoes it cease to exist just because we can\'t see it? Are objects not\r\npresent nonexistent? Because artists draw things vanishing to points,\r\ndoes that mean that they really vanish?"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nA wack, that\'s what he was. 

Nice guy, but sorta screwy. He kept saying\r\nmore goofy things while he was finishing up the machine, about how he\'d\r\nfigured out that all we knew about vision and drawing and so on must be\r\nwrong, and that once he got a look at the real world he\'d prove it.\r\n\r\n"How about cameras?" I asked him. "Take a picture with a camera and it\r\nlooks just about the same as a drawing, don\'t it?"\r\n\r\n"That\'s because cameras are built to take pictures like we\'re used to\r\nseeing them," he said. "Flat, two-dimensional slices of reality, without\r\ndepth or motion."\r\n\r\n"Even 3-D moving pictures?" I asked.\r\n\r\n"They\'re closer to reality," he admitted. "But they are still only cross\r\nsections of it. The shutter of a movie camera is closed as much of the\r\ntime as it is open. What happens in between the times it\'s open?\r\n\r\n"You know," he went on, "people used to think matter and motion were\r\ncontinuous, but scientists have proved that they are discontinuous. Now\r\nsome of them think time may be, too. Maybe everything is just imaginary,\r\nand appears to our senses in whatever way we want it to appear. We are\r\nso well-trained that we see everything just as we are taught to see it\r\nby generations of artists, writers, and other symbol-makers. If we could\r\nsee things as they really are, what might happen?"\r\n\r\n"We\'d probably all go nuts!" I told him. 

He just smiled.\r\n\r\n"Well, here goes," he said. "It\'s finished. Now to find out who is\r\nright, the scientists and philosophers who say reality is forever\r\nunreachable, or the artists who say there isn\'t any reality--that we\r\nmake the whole thing up to suit ourselves."\r\n\r\nHe moved one of those pointers you see there, and squinted around at the\r\ndifferent scales and dials, and then stepped back. That little\r\ntessy-thing appeared, real small at first. Just a point; you could\r\nhardly see it. I couldn\'t see anything else happening, and thought he\r\nwas gonna do somepin\' else to the machine. I turned to look at Carter,\r\nand saw his face was white as a sheet.\r\n\r\n"Good Gawd!" he says, just like that: "Good Gawd!" That\'s all.\r\n\r\n"Well," I says to him, "who was right, the scientists or the artists?"\r\n\r\n"The artists!" he sorta screeches. "The artists were right all the time\r\n... there _is_ no reality! It\'s all a fabric of illusion we\'ve created\r\nourselves! 

And now I\'ve ripped a hole in that!

"\r\n\r\nHe gives a strangled hoot and goes hightailin\' outta here like somepin\'\r\nwas after him. Jumps in his car and roars off down the road and\r\ndisappears.\r\n\r\nNaw, I don\'t mean he really disappeared--are you nuts? Just roared on\r\ndown the road till he got so small I couldn\'t see him no more. 

You\r\nknow--the way things do when they go farther and farther away. Happens\r\nevery day; that\'s what us artists mean by perspective.\r\n\r\nThe machine? Well, I dunno what to do with it. If Carter ever comes back\r\nhe might not like my getting rid of it. I was thinking mebbe I\'d put it\r\nin the hobby show at the county fair next week, though. Ya notice how\r\nthat funny-looking cube inside there gets bigger every time you look at\r\nit? There ... it just doubled its size again, see? People at the fair\r\noughtta get a big kick outta that. No telling how big it\'ll get with all\r\nthose people looking at it.\r\n\r\nBut come on, let\'s go fishing. We\'d better hurry or it\'ll be too late.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Astounding Science Fiction_ July 1959.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Mattup\'s face was purple and his eyes looked\r\nlike wolves\' eyes. He glared at Danny, making a noise in his throat, and\r\nthen I saw his gaze leave Danny and go to something down by the reactor.\r\n\r\nIt was Uncle Pete, shuffling along toward the control room.\r\n\r\nMattup didn\'t say a word. He stood up and unholstered the thing the\r\nOutsiders had given him and pointed it at Uncle Pete. There was a\r\nringing in our ears and Uncle Pete began to twist. Something inside him\r\ntwisted him, twisting inside his arms, his legs, head, trunk, even his\r\nfingers. It was only for a few seconds. Then the ringing stopped, and\r\nUncle Pete sunk to the ground, and there was the silence and the smell.\r\n\r\nMattup made us leave the body there until we had played two more hands.\r\nDanny won one; he was a man with good nerves. When we were back in our\r\nroom he said, "That did it--I\'m going to get that guy."\r\n\r\n"I hate his big thick guts," I said, buttoning my pajama shirt, "but how\r\nare you going to get him?"\r\n\r\n"I\'ll get him," said Danny. 

"Meanwhile, we\'ll keep playing cards."\r\n\r\nThings went on almost normally at the Bayless reactor. It was a\r\nprivately-owned pool-type reactor, and we were sent samples of all sorts\r\nof material for irradiation from all over the country. Danny was one of\r\nthe irradiation men; I generally handled controlling. The Outsiders had\r\nfilled the place with telescreens and guards, and all mail was opened,\r\nbut there was no real interference with the work. I began to worry a\r\nlittle about Danny. Almost every afternoon he spent an hour alone in our\r\nroom, with the door closed.\r\n\r\nMattup kept getting worse; an animal with power. He used to go hunting\r\nwith the damnable Outsider weapon, although the meat killed with it\r\nwasn\'t fit to eat, and he used it on birds until there wasn\'t one left\r\nanywhere near the plant. He never killed a bluebird, though. He said it\r\nwas bad luck. Sometimes he drank moonshine corn liquor, usually alone,\r\nbecause the Outsiders wouldn\'t touch it, but sometimes he made some of\r\nus drink with him, watching sharply to see we didn\'t poison him and\r\ncraftily picking his nose. When he was drunk he was abusive.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nOne night we were in our room, dead for sleep after a long game, and\r\nDanny said, "Let me show you something."\r\n\r\nHe shuffled the cards, I cut, and he dealt me an ace, king, queen, jack,\r\nten and deuce of spades. He shuffled again and dealt me the same in\r\nhearts.\r\n\r\n"Watch as closely as you can," he grinned. "See if you can catch me."\r\n\r\nI couldn\'t.\r\n\r\n"I\'ve been practicing," he said. "I\'m going to get Mattup."\r\n\r\n"What good will it do to beat him in cards? You\'ll only make him sore."\r\nI was relieved to learn what Danny had been doing, alone in our room,\r\nbut this card-sharp angle didn\'t make much sense to me.\r\n\r\n"Who says I\'m going to beat him at cards?" smiled Danny. 

"By the way,\r\ndid you hear the rumor? They\'re going to break up the staff, Outsider\r\npolicy, send us to Oak Ridge, Argonne, Shippingport, send new people\r\ndown here."\r\n\r\n"That doesn\'t leave you much time," I said.\r\n\r\n"Time enough," said Danny.\r\n\r\nThe next night Mattup began a fantastic streak of luck. It seemed he\r\ncouldn\'t lose, and he was as unpleasant a winner as he was a loser.\r\n\r\n"You boys don\'t know what card-playin\' is," he\'d gloat. "Think you\'re\r\npretty smarty with all that science stuff but you can\'t win a plain old\r\ncard game. You know why you can\'t beat me, boys?"\r\n\r\n"Because you\'re too smart, I guess," said Danny.\r\n\r\n"Well, yeah, and somethin\' else. I dipped my hands in spunk water, up on\r\nthe mountain where you can never find it, and besides that I spit on\r\never\' card in this deck and wiped it off. Couldn\'t lose now to save my\r\nlife."\r\n\r\n"Maybe you\'re right," said Danny, and went on dealing.\r\n\r\nIn a few days the rumor of moving was confirmed; I was being sent to Oak\r\nRidge, Danny to Argonne. Mattup kept winning, and "suggested" that we\r\nraise the stakes. By the day that we were to leave we owed him every\r\ncent we had.\r\n\r\nI paid up soberly; I wouldn\'t give Mattup any satisfaction by\r\ncomplaining. It looked as though Danny wasn\'t going to "get" Mattup\r\nafter all. But Danny surprised me.\r\n\r\n"Look, buster," he wheedled. "If I pay you seventy-five bucks I won\'t\r\nhave a cent left. How about me paying half now and the rest later?"\r\n\r\n"No good," said Mattup. "You got it--pay me. If you can\'t pay cash gimme\r\nyour watch. I know you got one."\r\n\r\n"Look, buster--"\r\n\r\n"Quit callin\' me buster."\r\n\r\n"What am I going to live on until I get paid again?

"\r\n\r\n"What do I care?"\r\n\r\nIt went on like that until the busses for the airport were nearly ready\r\nto leave and both men seemed angry enough to kill each other.\r\n\r\n"Let\'s go," I begged Danny. "Pay him and leave."\r\n\r\n"All right then!" Danny snapped, and pulled out his wallet. He counted\r\nout all his bills into Mattup\'s hand.\r\n\r\n"You\'re a buck short," said Mattup.\r\n\r\n"Why not forget the buck?" said Danny. "You can spare it."\r\n\r\n"You\'re a buck short," repeated Mattup, scowling.\r\n\r\nDanny dashed his wallet to the ground. "You\'re even taking my change!"\r\nHe got his jacket from the back of a chair--it was a hot day--and\r\nemptied change from the side pocket.\r\n\r\nThere were two quarters and a half dollar, and he paid them over. "I\r\nhave eleven cents left," he said. "Hell, take that too. 

I don\'t give a\r\ndamn."\r\n\r\nMattup grinned. "Sure I\'ll take it--if you weren\'t lying when you said I\r\ncould have it."\r\n\r\n"It\'ll break me," said Danny.\r\n\r\n"I know it," said Mattup. "Gonna break your promise?"\r\n\r\nThe bus driver was honking. "The hell with you," Danny said to Mattup,\r\nand gave him a dime and a penny. He looked Mattup in the eye with a\r\nstrange expression. "Now, I gave you that and you didn\'t win it. You\r\ntook it of your own free will. I offered it to you and you took it.\r\nRight?"\r\n\r\n"Right," said Mattup. 

"Sucker."\r\n\r\nWe scrambled on the bus and as it pulled away Danny yelled "Hey, Buster,\r\nlook!" Mattup looked, and Danny stuck his right arm out the window,\r\npointing at Mattup with his right forefinger and his little finger stuck\r\nout straight and parallel, the thumb tucked under. A strange, disturbed\r\nlook came over Orley. He turned his back as the bus roared out of the\r\ndrive.\r\n\r\nAt the airport Danny popped into a phone-booth and got Orley on the\r\nline--nobody seemed to care, either Outsiders or guards--and he let me\r\nlisten.\r\n\r\n"Spent your money yet, dead man?" purred Danny.\r\n\r\n"Whacha mean, dead man?" gruffed Orley\'s voice. 

"You crazy or\r\nsomething?"\r\n\r\n"You know that eleven cents extra you took?" gloated Danny. "It\'s gonna\r\nkill you, Buster, for killing Uncle Pete, and for everything else you\'ve\r\ndone. I know. I\'ve been talking nights to Uncle Pete. You\'re a dead\r\nduck, Orley Mattup! Dead!"\r\n\r\n"That\'s--I don\'t believe it, it\'s baloney! I\'m going to spend that\r\neleven cents and get rid of it."\r\n\r\n"You do exactly that, Buster. I locked the curse on it, and I made the\r\nsign on you, and you have to keep that eleven cents the rest of your\r\nlife. If you spend it--or if you lose it, and you will lose it--that\'s\r\nthe end of you.

"\r\n\r\n"I\'ll come out there and pound the hell out of you!" yelled Mattup.\r\n\r\n"Too late, Buster, our planes are leaving. Goodbye, dead man!

"\r\n\r\nAnd we had to run for our planes. Danny\'s pitch sounded pretty weak to\r\nme, even though Orley was superstitious, but I didn\'t get to tell Danny\r\nthat until nearly five years later.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"I think I got him," said Danny. "You don\'t know the whole thing."\r\n\r\nA hotel clerk had been listening. "You mean Orley Mattup, the guard? He\r\ngot sick, and said he had a hex on him, and took off one day and a lot\r\nlater they found him up on the mountain. He was dead."\r\n\r\n"Any money on him?" asked Danny.\r\n\r\n"Jest some change. They buried it with him; they heard the hex was\r\nlocked onto that money."\r\n\r\n"Congratulations," I told Danny. 

"I didn\'t think it\'d work. You scared\r\nhim to death."\r\n\r\n"Not quite," said Danny. "I scared him into hanging onto the money. That\r\nmoney would have killed anybody that carried it much longer than the few\r\nminutes I handled it. I\'d been keeping the stuff in the reactor beam\r\ntubes. 

It was radioactive as hell."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Imagination Stories of Science and\r\n    Fantasy_ April 1958. Extensive research did not uncover any evidence\r\n    that the U.S.
