Garfield jammed down the\r\naccelerator, had a sense of sick helplessness at the complete lack of\r\nresponse from the motor. The Packard rolled on, getting rid of its\r\nmomentum, and came to a stop.\r\n\r\nPhil Garfield swore shakily. He checked his watch, switched off the\r\nheadlights and climbed out into the dark road. 

A delay of even half an\r\nhour here might be disastrous. It was past midnight, and he had another\r\nhundred and ten miles to cover to reach the small private airfield where\r\nMadge waited for him and the thirty thousand dollars in the suitcase on\r\nthe Packard's front seat.\r\n\r\nIf he didn't make it before daylight....\r\n\r\nHe thought of the bank guard. The man had made a clumsy play at being a\r\nhero, and that had set off the fool woman who'd run screaming into their\r\nline of fire. 

One dead. 

Perhaps two. Garfield hadn't stopped to look at\r\nan evening paper.\r\n\r\nBut he knew they were hunting for him.\r\n\r\nHe glanced up and down the road. No other headlights in sight at the\r\nmoment, no light from a building showing on the forested hills. He\r\nreached back into the car and brought out the suitcase, his gun, a big\r\nflashlight and the box of shells which had been standing beside the\r\nsuitcase. He broke the box open, shoved a handful of shells and the .38\r\ninto his coat pocket, then took suitcase and flashlight over to the\r\nshoulder of the road and set them down.\r\n\r\nThere was no point in groping about under the Packard's hood. When it\r\ncame to mechanics, Phil Garfield was a moron and well aware of it. The\r\ncar was useless to him now ... except as bait.\r\n\r\nBut as bait it might be very useful.\r\n\r\nShould he leave it standing where it was? No, Garfield decided. To\r\nanybody driving past it would merely suggest a necking party, or a drunk\r\nsleeping off his load before continuing home. He might have to wait an\r\nhour or more before someone decided to stop. 

He didn't have the time. He\r\nreached in through the window, hauled the top of the steering wheel\r\ntowards him and put his weight against the rear window frame.\r\n\r\nThe Packard began to move slowly backwards at a slant across the road.\r\nIn a minute or two he had it in position. Not blocking the road\r\nentirely, which would arouse immediate suspicion, but angled across it,\r\nlights out, empty, both front doors open and inviting a passerby's\r\ninvestigation.\r\n\r\nGarfield carried the suitcase and flashlight across the right-hand\r\nshoulder of the road and moved up among the trees and undergrowth of the\r\nslope above the shoulder. Placing the suitcase between the bushes, he\r\nbrought out the .38, clicked the safety off and stood waiting.\r\n\r\nSome ten minutes later, a set of headlights appeared speeding up Route\r\nTwelve from the direction of Redmon. Phil Garfield went down on one knee\r\nbefore he came within range of the lights. Now he was completely\r\nconcealed by the vegetation.\r\n\r\nThe car slowed as it approached, braking nearly to a stop sixty feet\r\nfrom the stalled Packard. There were several people inside it; Garfield\r\nheard voices, then a woman's loud laugh. The driver tapped his horn\r\ninquiringly twice, moved the car slowly forward. As the headlights went\r\npast him, Garfield got to his feet among the bushes, took a step down\r\ntowards the road, raising the gun.\r\n\r\nThen he caught the distant gleam of a second set of headlights\r\napproaching from Redmon. He swore under his breath and dropped back out\r\nof sight. The car below him reached the Packard, edged cautiously around\r\nit, rolled on with a sudden roar of acceleration.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe second car stopped when still a hundred yards away, the Packard\r\ncaught in the motionless glare of its lights. Garfield heard the steady\r\npurring of a powerful motor.\r\n\r\nFor almost a minute, nothing else happened. Then the car came gliding\r\nsmoothly on, stopped again no more than thirty feet to Garfield's left.\r\nHe could see it now through the screening bushes--a big job, a long, low\r\nfour-door sedan. The motor continued to purr. After a moment, a door on\r\nthe far side of the car opened and slammed shut.\r\n\r\nA man walked quickly out into the beam of the headlights and started\r\ntowards the Packard.\r\n\r\nPhil Garfield rose from his crouching position, the .38 in his right\r\nhand, flashlight in his left. If the driver was alone, the thing was now\r\ncinched! But if there was somebody else in the car, somebody capable of\r\nfast, decisive action, a slip in the next ten seconds might cost him the\r\nsedan, and quite probably his freedom and life. Garfield lined up the\r\n.38's sights steadily on the center of the approaching man's head. He\r\nlet his breath out slowly as the fellow came level with him in the road\r\nand squeezed off one shot.\r\n\r\nInstantly he went bounding down the slope to the road. The bullet had\r\nflung the man sideways to the pavement. Garfield darted past him to the\r\nleft, crossed the beam of the headlights, and was in darkness again on\r\nthe far side of the road, snapping on his flashlight as he sprinted up\r\nto the car.\r\n\r\nThe motor hummed quietly on. The flashlight showed the seats empty.\r\nGarfield dropped the light, jerked both doors open in turn, gun pointing\r\ninto the car's interior. Then he stood still for a moment, weak and\r\nalmost dizzy with relief.\r\n\r\nThere was no one inside. The sedan was his.\r\n\r\nThe man he had shot through the head lay face down on the road, his hat\r\nflung a dozen feet away from him. Route Twelve still stretched out in\r\ndark silence to east and west. 

There should be time enough to clean up\r\nthe job before anyone else came along. Garfield brought the suitcase\r\ndown and put it on the front seat of the sedan, then started back to get\r\nhis victim off the road and out of sight. He scaled the man's hat into\r\nthe bushes, bent down, grasped the ankles and started to haul him\r\ntowards the left side of the road where the ground dropped off sharply\r\nbeyond the shoulder.\r\n\r\nThe body made a high, squealing sound and began to writhe violently.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nShocked, Garfield dropped the legs and hurriedly took the gun from his\r\npocket, moving back a step. The squealing noise rose in intensity as the\r\nwounded man quickly flopped over twice like a struggling fish, arms and\r\nlegs sawing about with startling energy. Garfield clicked off the\r\nsafety, pumped three shots into his victim's back.\r\n\r\nThe grisly squeals ended abruptly. The body continued to jerk for\r\nanother second or two, then lay still.\r\n\r\nGarfield shoved the gun back into his pocket. 

The unexpected\r\ninterruption had unnerved him; his hands shook as he reached down again\r\nfor the stranger's ankles. Then he jerked his hands back, and\r\nstraightened up, staring.\r\n\r\nFrom the side of the man's chest, a few inches below the right arm,\r\nsomething like a thick black stick, three feet long, protruded now\r\nthrough the material of the coat.\r\n\r\nIt shone, gleaming wetly, in the light from the car. Even in that first\r\nuncomprehending instant, something in its appearance brought a surge of\r\nsick disgust to Garfield's throat. Then the stick bent slowly halfway\r\ndown its length, forming a sharp angle, and its tip opened into what\r\ncould have been three blunt, black claws which scrabbled clumsily\r\nagainst the pavement. Very faintly, the squealing began again, and the\r\nbody's back arched up as if another sticklike arm were pushing\r\ndesperately against the ground beneath it.\r\n\r\nGarfield acted in a blur of horror. He emptied the .38 into the thing at\r\nhis feet almost without realizing he was doing it. Then, dropping the\r\ngun, he seized one of the ankles, ran backwards to the shoulder of the\r\nroad, dragging the body behind him.\r\n\r\nIn the darkness at the edge of the shoulder, he let go of it, stepped\r\naround to the other side and with two frantically savage kicks sent the\r\nbody plunging over the shoulder and down the steep slope beyond. He\r\nheard it crash through the bushes for some seconds, then stop. He\r\nturned, and ran back to the sedan, scooping up his gun as he went past.\r\nHe scrambled into the driver's seat and slammed the door shut behind\r\nhim.\r\n\r\nHis hands shook violently on the steering wheel as he pressed down the\r\naccelerator. The motor roared into life and the big car surged forward.\r\nHe edged it past the Packard, cursing aloud in horrified shock, jammed\r\ndown the accelerator and went flashing up Route Twelve, darkness racing\r\nbeside and behind him.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n_What had it been?_ Something that wore what seemed to be a man's body\r\nlike a suit of clothes, moving the body as a man moves, driving a man's\r\ncar ... roach-armed, roach-legged itself!\r\n\r\nGarfield drew a long, shuddering breath. Then, as he slowed for a curve,\r\nthere was a spark of reddish light in the rear-view mirror.\r\n\r\nHe stared at the spark for an instant, braked the car to a stop, rolled\r\ndown the window and looked back.\r\n\r\nFar behind him along Route Twelve, a fire burned. Approximately at the\r\npoint where the Packard had stalled out, where something had gone\r\nrolling off the road into the bushes....\r\n\r\nSomething, Garfield added mentally, that found fiery automatic\r\ndestruction when death came to it, so that its secrets would remain\r\nunrevealed.\r\n\r\nBut for him the fire meant the end of a nightmare. He rolled the window\r\nup, took out a cigarette, lit it, and pressed the accelerator....\r\n\r\nIn incredulous fright, he felt the nose of the car tilt upwards,\r\nheadlights sweeping up from the road into the trees.\r\n\r\nThen the headlights winked out. Beyond the windshield, dark tree\r\nbranches floated down towards him, the night sky beyond. He reached\r\nfrantically for the door handle.\r\n\r\nA steel wrench clamped silently about each of his arms, drawing them in\r\nagainst his sides, immobilizing them there. Garfield gasped, looked up\r\nat the mirror and saw a pair of faintly gleaming red eyes watching him\r\nfrom the rear of the car. Two of the things ... the second one stood\r\nbehind him out of sight, holding him. They'd been in what had seemed to\r\nbe the trunk compartment. 

And they had come out.\r\n\r\nThe eyes in the mirror vanished. A moist, black roach-arm reached over\r\nthe back of the seat beside Garfield, picked up the cigarette he had\r\ndropped, extinguished it with rather horribly human motions, then took\r\nup Garfield's gun and drew back out of sight.\r\n\r\nHe expected a shot, but none came.\r\n\r\nOne doesn't fire a bullet through the suit one intends to wear....\r\n\r\nIt wasn't until that thought occurred to him that tough Phil Garfield\r\nbegan to scream. He was still screaming minutes later when, beyond the\r\nwindshield, the spaceship floated into view among the stars.\r\n\r\nEND\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber's Note:\r\n\r\nThis etext was produced from _Worlds of If_ January 1962. 

Extensive\r\nresearch did not uncover any evidence that the U.S. copyright on this\r\npublication was renewed.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


There was work to do. Wayne must be hidden. The next to\r\ncome must never know. And it should be done quickly. Time would fly and\r\nin the last hours the fear would return. He knew that. Right now his\r\ntriumph sustained him.\r\n\r\nThere was the broadcast to look forward to. A billion people waited for\r\nhis words. It was a sop to his ego, but it could not make him forget\r\nthat this was costing him his life. On occasion, Thurmon could be\r\nrealistic, and he knew that, when there was nothing left to do but sit\r\nand wait for the end, he would be afraid. Terribly, hideously afraid\r\nand alone. It was the only flaw in his plan for immortality. Yet, his\r\nlife had been a barren thing, devoid of love or any real success. It\r\nwas little enough to trade. And this was his only chance for lasting\r\nfame. He could not let it go.\r\n\r\nThe plan was working ... almost of its own inertia. He was alone.\r\nHe was on the Moon, where no man had ever been before him. Not even\r\nWayne. Wayne, who designed the rocket and guided it. Wayne, who had\r\nstolen every chance Thurmon had ever had for recognition! Well, Wayne\r\nwas dead now. He had never put a living foot on the soil of the Moon.\r\nOnly Thurmon had done that. And it was his passport to eternal glory!\r\nNo one, _no one_ could take that away from him! Weighed in the loaded\r\nbalance of his mind, it more than compensated for dying alone and on\r\nan alien world. In fact, even the dying would add to the legends, and\r\nThurmon would live forever. The first man on the Moon!\r\n\r\nHe ran his tongue over dry lips and stooped to pick up the thing at his\r\nfeet. Wayne\'s corpse was still bloated from internal pressures, and the\r\nnaked flesh was drying fast to a parchment-like consistency. Moisture\r\nwas still seeping in awful little globules from the shattered skull\r\nwhere Thurmon\'s unseen blow had landed.\r\n\r\nThurmon found himself shuddering. The murder had been the hardest\r\npart ... but now it was done ... and all that remained was to give his\r\ndead companion a secret resting-place somewhere in the vast expanse of\r\npumice that lay out there under the blistering sun....\r\n\r\nThurmon\'s unsteady mind swerved from high elation to sadness. Poor\r\nWayne! 

He felt he could afford to be generous now. 

So many years of\r\nwork so soon to be forgotten. Just one quick blow, and poor, poor Wayne\r\nslipped into the limbo of the Earth\'s forgotten....\r\n\r\nUnder the light gravity, he carried the naked, grisly bundle easily.\r\nAnd, as he walked out into the Mare Tranquilitatis, his spirits rose\r\nagain. How wonderful it was to be certain that no one could steal his\r\ntriumph! Not even Wayne. 

Particularly not Wayne. He looked down at the\r\nthing in his arms and chuckled. The sound was uncanny within the pyrex\r\nbubble of his helmet.\r\n\r\nAfter what seemed a long time, Thurmon stopped and set down his burden.\r\nWith his pack-spade he set to work digging a trench in the pumice. As\r\nhe dug, he found himself crooning happily to the corpse. His voice was\r\nhigh-pitched and hysterical, but of course he did not notice it.\r\n\r\n"There, there ... Wayne, old friend ... see? I am making a grave for\r\nyou. The very first grave, Wayne ... and you shall have it, old friend!\r\nYours the grave and mine the glory!" He laughed hilariously at the\r\nthought. "I\'ll say you didn\'t make it alive. You didn\'t, did you? But\r\n_I_ made it, Wayne. _Me!_ Alone ... all alone! With no help from you,\r\ndo you hear?"\r\n\r\nThurmon chattered on, the sound of his crazed voice dying within the\r\nconfines of his helmet, while all around him the eternal silence of the\r\nSea of Serenity continued unbroken. The stars shown steadily in the\r\nairless sky, and the sun flamed in impotent splendor, furiously silent.\r\n\r\nAt last the pit was done, and Thurmon lowered the nude corpse into\r\nthe shadows. "Goodbye, Wayne. 

You see, you shouldn\'t have come here\r\nwith me. You shouldn\'t have tried to steal my success. That was a\r\nwrong thing. But you\'re sorry now, aren\'t you, old friend? Don\'t feel\r\ntoo badly, Wayne. I\'ll join you soon. Goodbye, Wayne. Goodbye...."\r\nLaboriously, he shoveled pumice into the pit and tamped it down with\r\nhis leaded boots. Then he smoothed the surface of the dig until it was\r\nas smooth as the rest of the surrounding plain. Satisfied, he turned\r\nhis back on the grave and started for the rocket.\r\n\r\nHe sang on the way back, so happy was he to have done with his ghastly\r\ncompanion. Recklessly prodigal of his oxygen supply, he ran toward the\r\nopen valve of the ship. Breath coming hard, he stumbled into the rocket\r\nand across the buckled deck-plates to the radarphone. The tiny atomic\r\nbatteries hummed as he removed the cadmium dampers. Power flickered the\r\nneedles of the main set. Thurmon adjusted the selector to "relay" and\r\ntuned in his suit radio. Then he returned to sit in the open valve and\r\ncall the monitoring station.\r\n\r\nHe smiled with satisfaction as the response cut through the blanket of\r\nhissing solar static.\r\n\r\n"Hello! Hello, ES-1! 

This is White Sands! My Lord, we\'d given you up\r\nfor lost! 

Where are you?"\r\n\r\nThurmon took a steadier grip on his dancing mind and replied:\r\n\r\n"Listen carefully. Carefully, you understand? This is John Thurmon. I\r\nam on the westernmost edge of the Sea of Serenity on the Moon. Wayne\r\nis dead ... he didn\'t make it. Died during acceleration and I had to\r\ndispose of his body in space. Did you get that? 

I am alone here. The\r\nship crashed on landing. I can\'t get back ... but it\'s worth it! I\r\nhaven\'t much time left ... but I want everyone to know that I made it.\r\nIt will be easier now for others ... after I\'ve pointed the way. I\'m\r\nthe _first_ and it\'s worth it! Did you get that?

"\r\n\r\nThere was a long silence. Finally, the radarman spoke respectfully.\r\n"Yes, Thurmon, we got that. Your transmission is being shunted onto the\r\ncommercial bands. Can you tell us what you see up there? And ... and\r\nThurmon, we all want you to know that our prayers are with you." Tears\r\nwere flowing on Earth now, Thurmon knew. Tears for a martyr to science\r\ndoomed to death alone on an alien world. He smiled thinly. Even this\r\ntiny taste of deference and respect was heady wine to his frustrated\r\npsyche.\r\n\r\nThurmon stepped through the valve and lowered himself to the plain. His\r\nheart was pounding triumphantly. Carefully, painstakingly, he began\r\nto describe his surroundings, interspersing his words with scientific\r\ndata. He played the hero well. There was no hysteria recognizable in\r\nhis voice ... and, if it trembled slightly, there was reason enough for\r\nthat.\r\n\r\nHe rounded the bulge of the rocket\'s nose and looked for the first\r\ntime at the western edge of the Mare. In the near distance an\r\nirregularly-shaped outcropping of rock caught his eye. Transmitting as\r\nhe went, he made his way toward it.... He drew nearer. And as he did,\r\nfear began to stir within him. 

His steps faltered, but some awful\r\npower drew him on. His voice became a shrill rasp in his ears, and on\r\nEarth a billion people gasped with horror....\r\n\r\n"_Wayne!_"\r\n\r\nThurmon shouted the name in fear and threw his arm over his face. But\r\nthe thing remained. It was _real_!\r\n\r\n"_Wayne ... no!_ IT CAN\'T BE! NO...."\r\n\r\nBut the figure did not move. The vast colossus loomed stark white and\r\nnaked in the brilliant sunlight. Legs apart, arms folded on its breast,\r\nit stared with brooding eyes at the vast emptiness of the lunar plain.\r\n\r\nThurmon howled with terror and fury.\r\n\r\n"Damn you! _Damn you!_ Why don\'t you answer me? 

I killed you once ...\r\nI\'ll kill you again! I\'m the first one here! Do you hear me? I\'ll kill\r\nyou again!"\r\n\r\n[Illustration: "_Why don\'t you answer me? 

I killed you once!_"]\r\n\r\nHe lowered his head and charged. The last thing he remembered was the\r\nsoundless tinkle of his shattering helmet, and the terrible pain as his\r\nskull cracked under the suddenly shifting pressures....\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"... _And strangely enough, the story of the race\'s first conquest\r\nof space is the story of one man, Sargon, the Lemurian Immortal, who\r\nled his people to the Moon in the misty past of Earth\'s youth. The\r\nLemurians are gone now, but on the westernmost edge of the Sea of\r\nSerenity there stands a statue of Sargon. It stands in magnificent\r\nisolation, a monument to the first man on the Moon._"\r\n\r\n                     Essays on Tellurian History,\r\n                      Quintus Bland, Geneva Keep\r\n                           Press, 12.50 Cr.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


"Oh brother!"\r\n\r\nHe went to the control chamber of the _Lady Luna_ and ran through his\r\nchecklist almost mechanically. He waited almost breathlessly until the\r\nradio barked the word that told him to hit the ignition switch, and\r\nwhen it came he hit it with a vigor and enjoyed the crushing sensation\r\nthat followed. The thunder from below was music in his ears; now he was\r\non his way and they wouldn\'t call him back.\r\n\r\nHolt was no mere glory machine. Not for him was the simple honor. He\r\nhad it planned, had it planned from the moment he was selected.\r\n\r\nFor Holt, the honor of setting the first foot on another world was a\r\nflat and tasteless award. It would last only until someone else did\r\nsomething slightly better. What could he get out of driving a space\r\nrocket to Luna? Not a hell of a lot. He was not headed for an adventure\r\nand he knew it; with everything precalculated, including the risk, what\r\nadventure could he have? To land and collect a quart of pumice and a\r\npound of rock and maybe a shiny stone. Look for lichen or moss. Listen\r\nto the Geiger.\r\n\r\nThis sort of dry action would sell no books, collect no royalties,\r\nmake no moving pictures, bring in no dough.\r\n\r\nGordon took a deep breath as soon as the motor cut off. He was on his\r\nway and he knew how to handle everything from here on in.\r\n\r\nHe had seen enough of human nature to foresee it all. 

A slight mishap\r\nand a call for help would start it. A landing just hard enough to bend\r\nthe control vanes or to plug up the rocket exhaust. Maybe to dinge up\r\nthe spacecraft enough to make it unspaceworthy. Then--\r\n\r\nThe cry for help and the whole world crying in return that a Human\r\nBeing was marooned out there, helpless and alone.\r\n\r\nThey\'d come.\r\n\r\nThey\'d turn handsprings to get out there. Time and money would be\r\ntossed down the drain, and men would strive and women would cry, and\r\nthe news would be filled with daily columns of how the rescue was\r\nprogressing.\r\n\r\nDrop a man in the ocean and the navies of every country go out and comb\r\nthe sea to find him. Put a cat on the telephone pole and three hundred\r\npeople struggle to get the animal down. Drop a child in a well and the\r\ncountryside turns out en masse to help.\r\n\r\nWell, maroon a man on the moon and watch \'em struggle.\r\n\r\nHe had air for ninety days and food and water and just about anything\r\na man would need. He could sit it out and he knew it. And he knew that\r\nthere was a second rocket that could be put in space within a couple of\r\nmonths. Sixty days he\'d sit it out and then--\r\n\r\nIt would be the story of his life, the tale of his rescue, the bright\r\nlights and the personal appearances. Radio and television and endorsing\r\nthis junk and that googoo. Women and liquor and money.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe came down in the Crater Plato, tail first but far too fast. The\r\ntailfins crumpled and the sifting pumice drove up into the exhaust and\r\npacked like cement. A seam whistled far below to let out some air from\r\na sealed compartment, cracked in the bump.\r\n\r\nThe crash staggered him a bit, but all he suffered was a nosebleed and\r\na set of sprained chest muscles. He sat up and looked around.\r\n\r\nThe radio. He snapped it on and called: "_Lady Luna_ Gordon Holt\r\nreporting. Made a crash landing. May be dangerous. 

Will check and call\r\nat 0300."\r\n\r\nHe eyed the radio thoughtfully; it only took about three seconds for\r\nan answer, but in that time Gordon considered smashing the radio in\r\nthe middle of the next broadcast and then discarded the idea because\r\nit might lead people to think that he, too, had been smashed. Gordon\r\nwanted to be rescued, not given a hero\'s brief hail and farewell.\r\n\r\n"Calling _Lady Luna_. Holt! 

Are you all right? Explain!"\r\n\r\n"I am all right. I am not hurt. Crash landing rather rough but nothing\r\nbroken. No air leakage, nothing completely ruined that I can tell.\r\nLanded as per program in the dead center of Plato, but a little too\r\nhard."\r\n\r\nThat ought to do it. 

Let \'em get excited slowly. They\'ll forget me less\r\nslowly.\r\n\r\n"_Lady Luna_ what happened?" They were worried.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know. I have a hunch that the pumice does not provide a true\r\nground-plane for the radar. We landed as though the ground were about\r\nthirty feet below the surface."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThat sounds logical. Such things are entirely possible, I\'m told.\r\nPowdery, filmy stuff with no water shouldn\'t have a firm ground-plane.\r\n\r\n"_Lady Luna_ inspect your damage and report as planned at 0300."\r\n\r\nHolt checked his air first. 

Plenty of it. 

Not a bit gone. 

Water next\r\nand food next. He checked the hull as well as he could from the inside\r\nand then went out in his space suit to view the damage.\r\n\r\nHe had done an admirable job. The tail fins were bent messily and the\r\nhull was crumpled a bit just above the place where the rocket motor\r\nended. If this ship took off--\r\n\r\n"_Lady Luna_ calling home. Reporting as per plan. Hull bent, tail fins\r\nruined. Crater filled with powdery pumice and I feel that the exhaust\r\nis packed. Shall I try a blast to clear it?"\r\n\r\nWhile he waited for the answer Gordon found a bit of wire and shorted\r\nthe battery for a second. He had to fade out slowly enough to fool them\r\ncompletely.\r\n\r\n"_Lady Luna_, do not try a clearing blast. You\'ll explode. 

Wait for\r\ninstructions."\r\n\r\n"Will do. 

Will do."\r\n\r\nHe shorted the battery a couple more times and watched the voltmeter\r\ndrop.\r\n\r\n"_Lady Luna_ can you dig down to the exhaust port?"\r\n\r\n"Will try. Note battery dropping. Nothing else in danger. Food, water,\r\nair all okay. Hull sound but battery dropping."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nSeconds went on and Holt could see the resources of the entire world\r\ncollecting to prepare the First Spacewreck Rescue. Complete with\r\nvideo, reporters, clergymen, politicians, and humanity waiting.\r\n\r\n"_Lady Luna_ repeat. You are fading."\r\n\r\nHolt repeated, insisting that he was all right. "I can stick it out. 

I\r\ncan stick it out."\r\n\r\nHe watched the radio battery fade.\r\n\r\nLet it fade. He could stand the silence for two months until rescue\r\ncame.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nA billion people listened to his voice die away. And when their radio\r\nnetworks went dead, they raced to their telephones and clogged the land\r\nwires demanding that something had to be done.\r\n\r\nCongressmen gave speeches and clergymen spoke and doctors gave opinions\r\nand scientists differed. A government seldom known for its cooperation\r\nannounced that its new atomic-powered rocket was about to effect the\r\nrescue single-handedly. But the atomic part blew up in front of the\r\nvideo cameras and took some of the landscape with it. The Council\r\nof the United Nations called a meeting. The newspapers and networks\r\ncovered everything.\r\n\r\nA man known for his brilliance came on the air.\r\n\r\n"The batteries of the _Lady Luna_ have run down," he said. "We must\r\nget there in less than ten days."\r\n\r\nThey tried to do it.\r\n\r\nA second rocket exploded in France.\r\n\r\nA third blew up in Germany.\r\n\r\nThe fourth would not be ready for space for sixty days.\r\n\r\nThat was seventy long days after Holt\'s landing.\r\n\r\nWithout a miracle, Holt would be dead, even if the experts were wrong.\r\n\r\nProtestants prayed, Catholics crossed themselves, and Mohammedans\r\ncalled it _kismet_ and let it go at that. A scientist suggested that\r\nsince there was no habitable planet in the solar system and that\r\nmankind could never reach the stars, there was small point in this\r\neffort to make space travel pay off. An economist computed the sum of\r\nmoney shelled out already and called it damned foolishness. A Senator\r\nMaculay suggested that taxes could be lowered if such expenditures were\r\ncut out.\r\n\r\nAnd ten days after the accident there was a world-wide prayer said for\r\nGordon Holt.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe other rocket at White Sands grew cobwebs in its empty fuel tanks.\r\n\r\nAnd the _Lady Luna_ slipped into the dark of the moon. It grew colder\r\nand colder as time went on....\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n

]\r\n\r\n\r\n"Your Majesty!"\r\n\r\nD\'hai Merssu, Emperor of All the Suns, Protector of the Galaxy, looked\r\nup calmly as his prime minister burst into the room. His lean, brooding\r\nface did not change expression as he watched the pale and perspiring\r\nman cross the flagstoned floor with a sharp, nervous patter of leather.\r\n\r\n"Gently, Tors, gently," he said quietly, his eyes mocking under their\r\noverhang of dark eyebrow. "You\'re Prime Minister now--remember that.\r\nA prime minister doesn\'t come blundering into the palace looking as\r\nthough the sky was falling. It creates unrest in the population. Try to\r\nremember that we\'re no longer a pair of obscure rabblerousers, trying\r\nto overthrow the Crown. We _are_ the Crown now. Try to act like it.

"\r\n\r\n"D\'hai, the sky _is_ falling!" Tors burst out unheedingly, "I have word\r\nthat the Earthmen are driving beyond the Rim and into the heart of the\r\nEmpire itself! Their ships are irresistible. 

They\'re winning battle\r\nafter battle! And the people are restless! They say it\'s time the False\r\nEmperor\'s rule was overthrown. Some of the garrisons are rebelling!"\r\n\r\nStill the Emperor\'s expression did not change. "So," he said calmly,\r\n"the Earthmen were not bluffing when they said they\'d maintain the\r\nrights of the old Emperor."\r\n\r\n"Yes! You said they wouldn\'t, D\'hai. 

What are we going to do?"\r\n\r\n"I was wrong, Tors," Merssu said evenly. "No matter. 

As for what\r\nwe are going to do, why, I suppose you\'d better arrange for another\r\nbroadcast. Tell the people we have weapons ready if the situation\r\nbecomes serious, that they have nothing to fear."\r\n\r\n"But the situation _is_ serious! And what weapons?"\r\n\r\n"No weapons, Tors," Merssu explained patiently. "But the story will\r\nserve to keep the people calm--and, perhaps, make them think twice\r\nabout revolt. Now go. 

Hurry!"\r\n\r\nThe prime minister\'s feet pattered over the floor again. The door to\r\nthe room closed.\r\n\r\nMerssu smiled quietly. He rose, and opened the concealed door behind\r\nhis chair. Closing it behind him, he slipped into a passage of which\r\nno one knew, and ten minutes later he was in a private tubeway that\r\nled half-way across the continent into the heart of an old and barren\r\nmountain range.\r\n\r\nAs he sat comfortably in the padded upholstery of the tube car, Merssu\r\nsmiled again. Poor Tors! 

So excitable. Always the hysteric--a perfect\r\nrabblerouser, perhaps, but not a clever man. No, never a clever man. A\r\nclever man knew when the game was over. And Merssu laughed.\r\n\r\nThe game had been worth it. Five years ago, he had been a\r\nrevolutionary, slinking through the alleys at night, always in\r\ndanger--and always clever. Four years of that, and then--Empire.\r\nAbsolute rule over the entire Greater Magellanic Cloud. Now he was once\r\nagain in danger. 

But it was a danger he had long ago foreseen, and\r\nplanned for. And the past year had been worth it. He laughed again.\r\nPoor, addle-witted Tors! Left with the empty bag in his hands.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe spaceship rested like a crouching bullet in its chamber. As he slid\r\nthe tubeway door shut behind him, Merssu admired the savage sleekness\r\nof its lines once again. Even more, he admired his cleverness in having\r\nit built. A clever man always has a back door. He crossed the hangar\r\nfloor unhurriedly, and climbed into the ship.\r\n\r\nThe control room was small, but efficient. A hundred controls lay\r\nclosely around the padded chair, some of them for the standard drive,\r\nothers for the hyperspatial warp.\r\n\r\nThe hyperspatial warp! Merssu smiled. There was his escape--and more.\r\nHere were the means for his future rulership over nothing so small as\r\nthe Cloud--here were entire galaxies waiting for his hand.\r\n\r\nHyperspace! There was something to make a man think! Another universe,\r\nnot beyond, but _alongside_ his own, hidden in the complex byways\r\nof Reimannian geometry and the mathematics of Einstein. A universe\r\nwhere time itself ran slower, where a year of normal time encompassed\r\ncenturies. A ship could twist itself into that universe and travel just\r\nbelow the speed of light, the limit which, in normal space, was the\r\nbarrier no ship could cross. But, in hyperspace, while the same barrier\r\nexisted, a man from normal space could travel for centuries, covering\r\ngreat distances, while, for him, only a few months passed.\r\n\r\nMerssu chuckled. Behind him, stored in the great holds of the ship,\r\nwere working models of every machine and weapon the Cloud civilization\r\npossessed. There were plans, manuals, instructions, all translated into\r\nbasic symbology that any intelligent being could understand. Packed\r\ninto this ship was an entire civilization, ready to be brought to\r\nwhatever people Merssu chose. He had only to enter hyperspace and lose\r\nhimself where no Earthman or rebel could follow, and there he would\r\nfind a primitive race, barely beginning to rise out of the mud. He\r\nwould bring them civilization. In return, he would have--Godhood!\r\n\r\nThey would worship him, those primitive people. He would be Merssu\r\nthe Firegod, thundering out of the sky, bringing with him the gift of\r\ncivilization. And once the gift was given, he would climb back into the\r\nsky on a pillar of fire, promising to return when his people were ready.\r\n\r\nHe laughed aloud, the deep bass sound echoing through the control\r\nchamber. Why not? He could fly back into space and spend a year,\r\nwaiting, while centuries passed on the primitive world. When he\r\nreturned, that world would be his, and soon afterward the entire\r\nuniverse would bow before the name of Merssu, the immortal Firegod, for\r\nthere is no force so strong, no loyalty so great, as that of men for\r\ntheir gods.\r\n\r\nStill laughing, he blasted the ship out of its hangar into the darkness\r\nof space, and a little later, into hyperspace, while the big blue ships\r\nof Earth smashed his discarded Empire behind him.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIn a month, he had found his planet, and his people. They were almost\r\nhuman in appearance, but shorter. So much the better. He was like them,\r\nbut just different enough to be a god.\r\n\r\nHe brought his ship roaring down through the atmosphere, trailing a\r\nstreamer of flame. As he passed over the sea that covered most of the\r\nworld, the wash of his jets kicked the water into froth, and the sound\r\nof his passage echoed through the sky.\r\n\r\nThe village rested on the shore of the sea. The mud huts trembled as\r\nhis ship sank down, resting on its jetstream until it settled slowly to\r\nthe ground.\r\n\r\nSmiling faintly, Merssu put on his spacesuit, strapping his antigravity\r\nharness on over it. He flew out of his upper airlock, carrying a gun in\r\nhis hand.\r\n\r\nHe hovered in the air above the village. He pointed the gun into the\r\nair and fired. 

A cone of flame shot toward the sky. He pointed the\r\ngun at the sea, and towering curtains of steam rose to hang over the\r\nvillage.\r\n\r\nMerssu descended, and found his people groveling in the mud.\r\n\r\nWeeks passed. A stream of men carried the ship\'s cargo into a great\r\nsprawling building that Merssu carved out of a stone cliff with a\r\nsubatomic cutter. The lintels of the building were sanctified with\r\nthe blood of virgins. A new class of people arose in the village--the\r\nPriests of Merssu, the Firegod.\r\n\r\nAnd as the ship rose up into space again, on its journey back into the\r\nnormal space where Merssu would wait his year and the centuries would\r\npass for his people, the priests chanted over their altars.\r\n\r\n"He will return. Merssu goes to his kingdom in the sky, but he will\r\nreturn, bearing flame in his hands. Merssu the Firegod--Merssu, the\r\nimmortal Bringer of Fire--will return."\r\n\r\nAnd the centuries passed.\r\n\r\nMerssu brought his ship out of the sky, tearing the air as he came, the\r\ngrowl of his jets thundering over the mighty city on the sea. The sound\r\nechoed back from the carved face of the Temple of Merssu, and beat\r\nagainst the spreading buildings.\r\n\r\nThe ship settled to earth. Merssu strapped on his antigrav unit, and\r\nflashed out into the air above the city. He fired his gun into the sea,\r\nand the steam-curtain rose once more. He pointed the gun skyward, and\r\nthe heavens danced with flame.\r\n\r\nA low, snarling car bearing the sign of Merssu\'s priesthood drove up to\r\nhim as he touched the ground. Two men got out and walked toward him,\r\none of them dressed in the somber black of the priesthood. Merssu stood\r\nwaiting, his eyes lighting with triumphant fire.\r\n\r\n"Who are you?" the priest asked.\r\n\r\nMerssu stared, the pose broken. "Who am I? 

Kneel, fool! I am Merssu,\r\nthe Firegod."\r\n\r\nThe two men looked at him speechlessly for a moment, then burst into\r\nlaughter.\r\n\r\n"Merssu!" The priest wiped his eyes. The other man\'s laughter trailed\r\ninto anger.\r\n\r\n"Watch your tongue, blasphemer!" he said curtly, drawing a gun from his\r\nholster.\r\n\r\n"Merssu!" the priest repeated, "You\'re the fool, stranger. At least\r\nthe others who\'ve tried to claim his godhood had the sense to disguise\r\nthemselves to resemble his pictures."\r\n\r\n"Pictures change, rash priest!" Merssu thundered. "I am the Firegod!\r\nLook on my power!" Once more he fired into the sea, and once more the\r\nsteam pillars rose. "I am the God of Fire. I fly in the hands of flame.\r\nI walk on the air. I burn the land and the sea. I am Merssu!"\r\n\r\nThe priest\'s face lost its tolerant amusement. His mouth twisted in\r\nscorn.\r\n\r\n"Walk on the air, do you? In a Mark XI Antigrav belt, yes. Burn sea and\r\nland, eh? With a sungun, certainly. Fly in hands of flame? If you wish\r\nto be picturesque about it, yes--but so does every drunken fool of a\r\nspaceman."\r\n\r\n"_I tell you, I am Merssu!_" Merssu screamed. "_Bow down and worship!_"\r\n\r\n"_Silence!_" The priest\'s voice was dangerous, "You will come with us\r\nto the temple. There you\'ll see how we worship imposters!"\r\n\r\n"I\'ll kill you!" Merssu shouted, raising his gun.\r\n\r\nThe priest motioned with his hand. The man with him blew Merssu\'s head\r\noff.\r\n\r\n"Blasphemer!" the priest spat disdainfully, his voice filled with\r\ndisgust. He and his retainer turned back to the car, leaving the body\r\nto be carted away later.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nEvery evening at sunset, the priests of Merssu stand over their altars\r\nand intone the words.\r\n\r\n"He will return. Merssu the Firegod--Merssu, the immortal Bringer of\r\nFire--will return."\r\n\r\nAnd the people of Merssu\'s world intone in reply, "He will return."\r\nThroughout the galaxies of hyperspace, wherever the men of Merssu\'s\r\nworld may wander, there are other priests, and other races that\r\nrespond, but the ritual is always the same.\r\n\r\n"He will return."\r\n\r\nAnd the city waits. The planet waits, and the other planets about the\r\nother stars through all the galaxies of hyperspace wait.\r\n\r\nThey always will.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


It isn\'t comfortable; but of course they expect to\r\nmake me still more uncomfortable.\r\n\r\nThey expect to take me out of this precinct jail to the District prison\r\nand eventually to the death house.\r\n\r\nSure, there will be a trial first, but that is only a formality. Not\r\nonly did they catch me with the smoking gun in my hand and Connaught\r\nbubbling to death through the hole in his throat, but I admitted it.\r\n\r\nI--knowing what I was doing, with, as they say, malice\r\naforethought--deliberately shot to death Laurence Connaught.\r\n\r\nThey execute murderers. So they mean to execute me.\r\n\r\nEspecially because Laurence Connaught had saved my life.\r\n\r\nWell, there are extenuating circumstances. I do not think they would\r\nconvince a jury.\r\n\r\nConnaught and I were close friends for years. We lost touch during the\r\nwar. 

We met again in Washington, a few years after the war was over. We\r\nhad, to some extent, grown apart; he had become a man with a mission.\r\nHe was working very hard on something and he did not choose to discuss\r\nhis work and there was nothing else in his life on which to form a basis\r\nfor communication. And--well, I had my own life, too. It wasn\'t\r\nscientific research in my case--I flunked out of med school, while he\r\nwent on. I\'m not ashamed of it; it is nothing to be ashamed of. I simply\r\nwas not able to cope with the messy business of carving corpses. 

I\r\ndidn\'t like it, I didn\'t want to do it, and when I was forced to do it,\r\nI did it badly. So--I left.\r\n\r\nThus I have no string of degrees, but you don\'t need them in order to be\r\na Senate guard.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nDoes that sound like a terribly impressive career to you? Of course not;\r\nbut I liked it. The Senators are relaxed and friendly when the guards\r\nare around, and you learn wonderful things about what goes on behind the\r\nscenes of government. And a Senate guard is in a position to do\r\nfavors--for newspapermen, who find a lead to a story useful; for\r\ngovernment officials, who sometimes base a whole campaign on one\r\ncareless, repeated remark; and for just about anyone who would like to\r\nbe in the visitors\' gallery during a hot debate.\r\n\r\nLarry Connaught, for instance. I ran into him on the street one day, and\r\nwe chatted for a moment, and he asked if it was possible to get him in\r\nto see the upcoming foreign relations debate. 

It was; I called him the\r\nnext day and told him I had arranged for a pass. And he was there,\r\nwatching eagerly with his moist little eyes, when the Secretary got up\r\nto speak and there was that sudden unexpected yell, and the handful of\r\nCentral American fanatics dragged out their weapons and began trying to\r\nchange American policy with gunpowder.\r\n\r\nYou remember the story, I suppose. There were only three of them, two\r\nwith guns, one with a hand grenade. The pistol men managed to wound two\r\nSenators and a guard. I was right there, talking to Connaught. I spotted\r\nthe little fellow with the hand grenade and tackled him. I knocked him\r\ndown, but the grenade went flying, pin pulled, seconds ticking away. I\r\nlunged for it. Larry Connaught was ahead of me.\r\n\r\nThe newspaper stories made heroes out of both of us. They said it was\r\nmiraculous that Larry, who had fallen right on top of the grenade, had\r\nmanaged to get it away from himself and so placed that when it exploded\r\nno one was hurt.\r\n\r\nFor it did go off--and the flying steel touched nobody. The papers\r\nmentioned that Larry had been knocked unconscious by the blast. He was\r\nunconscious, all right.\r\n\r\nHe didn\'t come to for six hours and when he woke up, he spent the next\r\nwhole day in a stupor.\r\n\r\nI called on him the next night. He was glad to see me.\r\n\r\n"That was a close one, Dick," he said. "Take me back to Tarawa."\r\n\r\nI said, "I guess you saved my life, Larry."\r\n\r\n"Nonsense, Dick! I just jumped. Lucky, that\'s all."\r\n\r\n"The papers said you were terrific. They said you moved so fast, nobody\r\ncould see exactly what happened."\r\n\r\nHe made a deprecating gesture, but his wet little eyes were wary.\r\n"Nobody was really watching, I suppose."\r\n\r\n"I was watching," I told him flatly.\r\n\r\nHe looked at me silently for a moment.\r\n\r\n"I was between you and the grenade," I said. "You didn\'t go past me,\r\nover me, or through me. But you were on top of the grenade."\r\n\r\nHe started to shake his head.\r\n\r\nI said, "Also, Larry, you fell _on_ the grenade. It exploded underneath\r\nyou. I know, because I was almost on top of you, and it blew you clear\r\noff the floor of the gallery. Did you have a bulletproof vest on?"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe cleared his throat. "Well, as a matter of--"\r\n\r\n"Cut it out, Larry! What\'s the answer?"\r\n\r\nHe took off his glasses and rubbed his watery eyes. He grumbled, "Don\'t\r\nyou read the papers? It went off a yard away."\r\n\r\n"Larry," I said gently, "I was there."\r\n\r\nHe slumped back in his chair, staring at me. Larry Connaught was a small\r\nman, but he never looked smaller than he did in that big chair, looking\r\nat me as though I were Mr. Nemesis himself.\r\n\r\nThen he laughed. 

He surprised me; he sounded almost happy. He said,\r\n"Well, hell, Dick--I had to tell somebody about it sooner or later. Why\r\nnot you?"\r\n\r\nI can\'t tell you all of what he said. I\'ll tell most of it--but not the\r\npart that matters.\r\n\r\nI\'ll never tell _that_ part to _anybody_.\r\n\r\nLarry said, "I should have known you\'d remember." He smiled at me\r\nruefully, affectionately. "Those bull sessions in the cafeterias, eh?\r\nTalking all night about everything. 

But you remembered."\r\n\r\n"You claimed that the human mind possessed powers of psychokinesis," I\r\nsaid. "You argued that just by the mind, without moving a finger or\r\nusing a machine, a man could move his body anywhere, instantly. You said\r\nthat nothing was impossible to the mind."\r\n\r\nI felt like an absolute fool saying those things; they were ridiculous\r\nnotions. Imagine a man _thinking_ himself from one place to another!\r\nBut--I had been on that gallery.\r\n\r\nI licked my lips and looked to Larry Connaught for confirmation.\r\n\r\n"I was all wet," Larry laughed. "Imagine!"\r\n\r\nI suppose I showed surprise, because he patted my shoulder.\r\n\r\nHe said, becoming sober, "Sure, Dick, you\'re wrong, but you\'re right\r\nall the same. The mind alone can\'t do anything of the sort--that was\r\njust a silly kid notion. But," he went on, "_but_ there are--well,\r\ntechniques--linking the mind to physical forces--simple physical forces\r\nthat we all use every day--that can do it all. Everything! Everything I\r\never thought of and things I haven\'t found out yet.\r\n\r\n"Fly across the ocean? In a second, Dick! Wall off an exploding bomb?\r\nEasily! You saw me do it. 

Oh, it\'s work. It takes energy--you can\'t\r\nescape natural law. That was what knocked me out for a whole day. 

But\r\nthat was a hard one; it\'s a lot easier, for instance, to make a bullet\r\nmiss its target. It\'s even easier to lift the cartridge out of the\r\nchamber and put it in my pocket, so that the bullet can\'t even be fired.\r\nWant the Crown Jewels of England? I could get them, Dick!

"\r\n\r\nI asked, "Can you see the future?"\r\n\r\nHe frowned. "That\'s silly. This isn\'t supersti--"\r\n\r\n"How about reading minds?"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nLarry\'s expression cleared. "Oh, you\'re remembering some of the things I\r\nsaid years ago. No, I can\'t do that either, Dick. Maybe, some day, if I\r\nkeep working at this thing-- Well, I can\'t right now. There are things I\r\ncan do, though, that are just as good."\r\n\r\n"Show me something you can do," I asked.\r\n\r\nHe smiled. Larry was enjoying himself; I didn\'t begrudge it to him. He\r\nhad hugged this to himself for years, from the day he found his first\r\nclue, through the decade of proving and experimenting, almost always\r\nbeing wrong, but always getting closer.... He _needed_ to talk about it.\r\nI think he was really glad that, at last, someone had found him out.\r\n\r\nHe said, "Show you something? Why, let\'s see, Dick." He looked around\r\nthe room, then winked. "See that window?

"\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\nI looked. It opened with a slither of wood and a rumble of sash weights.\r\nIt closed again.\r\n\r\n"The radio," said Larry. There was a _click_ and his little set turned\r\nitself on. "Watch it."\r\n\r\nIt disappeared and reappeared.\r\n\r\n"It was on top of Mount Everest," Larry said, panting a little.\r\n\r\nThe plug on the radio\'s electric cord picked itself up and stretched\r\ntoward the baseboard socket, then dropped to the floor again.\r\n\r\n"No," said Larry, and his voice was trembling, "I\'ll show you a hard\r\none. Watch the radio, Dick. 

I\'ll run it without plugging it in! The\r\nelectrons themselves--"\r\n\r\nHe was staring intently at the little set. I saw the dial light go on,\r\nflicker, and hold steady; the speaker began to make scratching noises. I\r\nstood up, right behind Larry, right over him.\r\n\r\nI used the telephone on the table beside him. I caught him right beside\r\nthe ear and he folded over without a murmur. Methodically, I hit him\r\ntwice more, and then I was sure he wouldn\'t wake up for at least an\r\nhour. I rolled him over and put the telephone back in its cradle.\r\n\r\nI ransacked his apartment. I found it in his desk: All his notes. All\r\nthe information. The secret of how to do the things he could do.\r\n\r\nI picked up the telephone and called the Washington police. When I heard\r\nthe siren outside, I took out my service revolver and shot him in the\r\nthroat. He was dead before they came in.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nFor, you see, I knew Laurence Connaught. We were friends. I would have\r\ntrusted him with my life. But this was more than just a life.\r\n\r\nTwenty-three words told how to do the things that Laurence Connaught\r\ndid. Anyone who could read could do them. Criminals, traitors,\r\nlunatics--the formula would work for anyone.\r\n\r\nLaurence Connaught was an honest man and an idealist, I think. But what\r\nwould happen to any man when he became God? Suppose you were told\r\ntwenty-three words that would let you reach into any bank vault, peer\r\ninside any closed room, walk through any wall? Suppose pistols could not\r\nkill you?\r\n\r\nThey say power corrupts; and absolute power corrupts absolutely. And\r\nthere can be no more absolute power than the twenty-three words that can\r\nfree a man of any jail or give him anything he wants. Larry was my\r\nfriend. But I killed him in cold blood, knowing what I did, because he\r\ncould not be trusted with the secret that could make him king of the\r\nworld.\r\n\r\nBut I can.\r\n\r\n                                                       --FREDERIK POHL\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Galaxy Science Fiction_ February 1955.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and\r\n    typographical errors have been corrected without note.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


"\r\n\r\n"Got here as soon as I could. I wager half my time was taken up by the\r\nsecurity check points. You are certainly isolated in here."\r\n\r\n"All of that," agreed the general. "Have a seat, won\'t you?" he asked,\r\nindicating a chair.\r\n\r\nHis friend sank into it gratefully. "Now, what\'s this vital problem you\r\ncalled me about? 

You weren\'t too specific."\r\n\r\n"No," said Garvers, "I wasn\'t. This is a security matter, after a\r\nfashion. It\'s vitally important that we get technical help on this\r\nthing, and since you and I are friends, I was asked to call you in."\r\n\r\n"Well?"\r\n\r\n"I\'m afraid I\'ll have to make a story of it."\r\n\r\n"Quite all right by me, but don\'t mind if I interject a question now and\r\nthen. Mind if I smoke?"\r\n\r\n"Go right ahead," said Garvers, fumbling out a lighter. "Just don\'t\r\nspill ashes on the rug.\r\n\r\n"This all began on the Third of May. I was working here on some\r\ntop-security stuff. 

I had suddenly got the feeling of being watched. I\r\nknow it seems silly, what with all the check points that a potential spy\r\nwould have to go through to get here, but that\'s just how I felt.\r\n\r\n"Several times I glanced around the office, but of course it was empty.\r\nThen I began to think that it was my nerves."\r\n\r\n"You always were a bit of a hypochondriac," observed his friend.\r\n\r\n"Be that as it may," continued Garvers, "it was the only explanation I\r\nhad at the time. Either someone was watching me, which seemed\r\nimpossible, or I was beginning to crack under the strain.\r\n\r\n"Well, I put my papers away and tried to take a short break. I was\r\nreaching into my drawer where I keep magazines when, so help me, a man\r\nstepped out of the wall into my office."\r\n\r\n"What? It seems as if you just said a guy stepped out of the wall."\r\n\r\n"That\'s just what I did say. It sounds crazy, but let me finish, will\r\nyou? I\'m not kidding, and I\'ll show you proof later if necessary.\r\n\r\n"Anyway, this bird stepped straight out of the wall as if it had been a\r\nwaterfall or something, but the wall itself was undamaged. The only\r\nproof I had that he had actually done it was the fact that he was in my\r\noffice, but that was proof enough.\r\n\r\n"To put it mildly, I was thunderstruck. After jumping to my feet, I\r\ncould only stand there like an idiot. I was so shaken that I couldn\'t\r\nspeak a word. But he spoke first.\r\n\r\n"\'General Garvers?\' he asked, just as if he had run into me at a\r\ncocktail party or on the street.\r\n\r\n"I told him he was correct, and asked him who _he_ was and what he\r\nwanted. And how he got into my office.\r\n\r\n"He identified himself as a Henry Busch and explained that he was acting\r\nin behalf of a good friend of his, the late Dr. Hymann Duvall. Have you\r\never heard of Duvall, Max?"\r\n\r\nHis friend twisted his face in thought. 

"Can\'t say that I have,\r\noff-hand. 

But the name seems to ring a bell somewhere."\r\n\r\n"Well, anyway, he said that Duvall had perfected an invention of great\r\nnational importance shortly before his death and asked Busch to deliver\r\nit to the government if anything should happen to him. Then Duvall died\r\nsuddenly of a heart attack."\r\n\r\n"And what was this invention?"\r\n\r\n"Isn\'t it obvious? A machine that would enable a man to walk through\r\nwalls. And Busch has no idea how the thing works, other than the general\r\nexplanation that Duvall gave him. And Busch was poles apart from Duvall.\r\nThey were friends from college, but not because of professional\r\ninterests. It seems they were both doublecrossed by the same girl.\r\n\r\n"Duvall was a brilliant but obscure nuclear and radiation physicist. He\r\nwas one of those once-in-a-lifetime fellows like Tesla. He was so shy\r\nthat he didn\'t bring himself to anybody\'s attention, save for a few\r\npapers he published in the smaller physical societies\' magazines. It was\r\nonly because he had inherited a considerable amount of money that he\r\ncould do any research whatsoever."\r\n\r\n"Hm-m-m. I seem to remember a paper about wave propagation in one of the\r\nquarterlies. Quite unorthodox, as I recall," said Max.\r\n\r\n"Could be. But anyway, about Busch.\r\n\r\n"Busch majored in psychology at college, but took special courses after\r\nhe graduated and took a Master\'s in English. He has written two novels\r\nand three collections of poems under various pen names. At the time of\r\nDuvall\'s death, he was working on the libretto of an opera. He has had\r\nno technical training, unless you want to count a year of high school\r\ngeneral science. So he wasn\'t too much help in explaining how Duvall\'s\r\ninstrument works.\r\n\r\n"And, just to make matters more juicy, Duvall kept no notes. He had\r\ntotal recall and a childlike fear of putting anything into writing that\r\nhad not been experimentally verified."\r\n\r\n"And this machine, how is it supposed to work?"\r\n\r\n\r\nGarvers got up and began to pace. "According to Busch, Duvall devised\r\nthe instrument after stumbling into an entirely new branch of physics.\r\n\r\n"This device of Duvall\'s is a special case of a new theory of matter and\r\nenergy. Matter is made up of subnuclear particles--electrons, protons\r\nand the like. However, Duvall said that these particles are in turn made\r\nup of much smaller particles grouped together in aggregate clouds. The\r\nsize ratio of these particles to protons is somewhat like the ratio of\r\nan individual proton to a large star. They seem to be composed of tiny\r\nclots of energy from a fantastically complex energy system, in which\r\nelectromagnetism is but a small part. Each energy-segment is represented\r\nby a different facet of each particle, and the arrangement of the\r\nindividual particles to each other determines what super-particle they\r\nwill form, such as an electron. Duvall called these sub-particles\r\n\'lems\'.\r\n\r\n"Busch says he was told that a field of a special nature could be\r\ngenerated so as to make the individual lems in the particles of matter\r\nrotate in a special way that would introduce a \'polarization field\', as\r\nDuvall called it. This field seems to be connected somehow with gravity,\r\nbut Busch wasn\'t told how.\r\n\r\n"The upshot is that matter in the _initial_ presence of the field is\r\naffected so that it is able to pass through ordinary matter--"\r\n\r\n"Hold on," interrupted Max. "If a device can do that, then the user\r\nwould immediately fall towards the center of the Earth."\r\n\r\n"Just _you_ hold on. 

You didn\'t let me finish. A single plane of atoms,\r\nat the base of the treated object is the point of contact. It remains\r\npartially unaffected because it is closest to the \'gravetostatic field\r\ncenter\', which I guess is the Earth\'s center of attraction. This plane\r\nof \'semi-treated\' atoms can be forced through an object, if it is moved\r\nhorizontally, but its \'untreated\' aspect prevents the subject wearing\r\nthe device from falling through the floor.\r\n\r\n"Busch demonstrated this device to me, turning it on and strolling\r\nthrough various objects in this room. Think of it! 

No soldier could be\r\nkilled or held prisoner. And--"\r\n\r\n"Now hang on," objected Max. "Let\'s not run away with ourselves. He may\r\nhave perfected a device that would enable a soldier to avoid capture,\r\nbut there would certainly be other ways to kill him than by bullets.\r\nLet\'s see now: suppose that the enemy shot a flamethrower at him. The\r\nburning materials might pass through him, but he would be cooked anyway.\r\nOr poison gas--"\r\n\r\n"Hm-m-m. As far as gas goes, I suppose a gas mask would be necessary.\r\nBusch doesn\'t know about the breathing mechanism, except that he had to\r\ntake breaths. But as far as fire or radiation goes, the man\'s protected.\r\nIf the radiation is either harmful by nature or by amount, the field\r\nmerely reflects it. It is something called the \'lemic stress\' of the\r\nfield that causes the phenomenon.\r\n\r\n"That\'s why we need your help."\r\n\r\nMax scratched his head thoughtfully. 

"I don\'t understand.

"\r\n\r\nGarvers looked pained. "When Busch had finished his demonstration, he\r\ncarelessly tossed the device on my desk. The thing skidded and hit my\r\npaperweight so that the switch was thrown on again. So now the device\r\nand my desk are both untouchable.\r\n\r\n"Go over to the desk and try to touch it," said Garvers dryly.\r\n\r\nHis friend got up and ambled over to the desk. There he saw a small\r\nblack box resting near a paperweight. Its toggle switch was at the "on"\r\nposition, and it was lying on its side. He tried to pick the box up, but\r\nhis hand slid effortlessly through it as if it were so much air.\r\n\r\n"_Well_!" Max said. He passed his hand through the desk again. "Well,\r\nwell. Are you sure Busch told you everything?"\r\n\r\n"Busch! He honestly wants to help and we have taken him through the\r\nmill. Pentathol, scopolamine and the like; hypnotism and the polygraph.\r\nWe\'ve dug that man deeper than we have ever dug anybody before."\r\n\r\n"And have you conducted any experiments of your own?"\r\n\r\n"Certainly. That\'s what is so frustrating. We try to X ray the thing,\r\nand we don\'t get a thing. We bombarded it with every radiation we could\r\nthink of, from radio to gamma and it just reflected them. We can detect\r\nno radiation coming out of it. Magnetic fields don\'t effect it, nor do\r\nheat and cold. Nuclear particles are ignored by it; it just _sits_ there\r\nthumbing its nose at us. And we can\'t even wait for it to run down.\r\nAccording to Busch, the power requirements of the thing are funny and\r\nonce the field is established, it takes no additional energy to maintain\r\nit. And the collapsing power remains indefinitely until it is time to\r\nturn the machine off, but it\'s unreachable by any means we have.\r\n\r\n"It\'s pure frustration. There\'s no way we can analyze it until we can\r\nhandle it, and no way we can handle it until we can turn it off. 

And\r\nthere\'s no way we can turn it off until we have analyzed it. If it were\r\nalive, I\'d think that it was laughing at us.\r\n\r\n"Do _you_ have any ideas?" asked Garvers hopefully.\r\n\r\n"Nothing that would help a solution at present," said Max. "But do you\r\nremember the legend of King Tantalus?"\r\n\r\n"Slightly. What about it?

"\r\n\r\n"Well ... if _he_ were here," said Max thoughtfully, "he\'d ...\r\nsympathize."\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


Biff Hawton was too sophisticated to be awed. He stayed on\r\nbecause he wanted to find out what the trick was that made the gadget\r\nwork.\r\n\r\n"It\'s all explained right here in your instruction book," the\r\ndemonstrator said, holding up a garishly printed booklet opened to a\r\nfour-color diagram. "You all know how magnets pick up things and I bet\r\nyou even know that the earth itself is one great big magnet--that\'s why\r\ncompasses always point north. Well ... the Atomic Wonder Space Wave\r\nTapper hangs onto those space waves. Invisibly all about us, and even\r\ngoing right through us, are the magnetic waves of the earth. The Atomic\r\nWonder rides these waves just the way a ship rides the waves in the\r\nocean. Now watch...."\r\n\r\nEvery eye was on him as he put the gaudy model rocketship on top of the\r\ntable and stepped back. It was made of stamped metal and seemed as\r\nincapable of flying as a can of ham--which it very much resembled.\r\nNeither wings, propellors, nor jets broke through the painted surface.\r\nIt rested on three rubber wheels and coming out through the bottom was a\r\ndouble strand of thin insulated wire. This white wire ran across the top\r\nof the black table and terminated in a control box in the demonstrator\'s\r\nhand. An indicator light, a switch and a knob appeared to be the only\r\ncontrols.\r\n\r\n"I turn on the Power Switch, sending a surge of current to the Wave\r\nReceptors," he said. The switch clicked and the light blinked on and off\r\nwith a steady pulse. Then the man began to slowly turn the knob. "A\r\ncareful touch on the Wave Generator is necessary as we are dealing with\r\nthe powers of the whole world here...."\r\n\r\nA concerted _ahhhh_ swept through the crowd as the Space Wave Tapper\r\nshivered a bit, then rose slowly into the air. The demonstrator stepped\r\nback and the toy rose higher and higher, bobbing gently on the invisible\r\nwaves of magnetic force that supported it. Ever so slowly the power was\r\nreduced and it settled back to the table.\r\n\r\n"Only $17.95," the young man said, putting a large price sign on the\r\ntable. "For the complete set of the Atomic Wonder, the Space Tapper\r\ncontrol box, battery and instruction book ..."\r\n\r\nAt the appearance of the price card the crowd broke up noisily and the\r\nchildren rushed away towards the operating model trains. The\r\ndemonstrator\'s words were lost in their noisy passage, and after a\r\nmoment he sank into a gloomy silence. He put the control box down,\r\nyawned and sat on the edge of the table. Colonel Hawton was the only one\r\nleft after the crowd had moved on.\r\n\r\n"Could you tell me how this thing works?" the colonel asked, coming\r\nforward. The demonstrator brightened up and picked up one of the toys.\r\n\r\n"Well, if you will look here, sir...." He opened the hinged top. "You\r\nwill see the Space Wave coils at each end of the ship." With a pencil he\r\npointed out the odd shaped plastic forms about an inch in diameter that\r\nhad been wound--apparently at random--with a few turns of copper wire.\r\nExcept for these coils the interior of the model was empty. The coils\r\nwere wired together and other wires ran out through the hole in the\r\nbottom of the control box. Biff Hawton turned a very quizzical eye on\r\nthe gadget and upon the demonstrator who completely ignored this sign of\r\ndisbelief.\r\n\r\n"Inside the control box is the battery," the young man said, snapping it\r\nopen and pointing to an ordinary flashlight battery. "The current goes\r\nthrough the Power Switch and Power Light to the Wave Generator ..."\r\n\r\n"What you mean to say," Biff broke in, "is that the juice from this\r\nfifteen cent battery goes through this cheap rheostat to those\r\nmeaningless coils in the model and absolutely nothing happens. Now tell\r\nme what really flies the thing. 

If I\'m going to drop eighteen bucks for\r\nsix-bits worth of tin, I want to know what I\'m getting."\r\n\r\nThe demonstrator flushed. "I\'m sorry, sir," he stammered. "I wasn\'t\r\ntrying to hide anything. Like any magic trick this one can\'t be really\r\ndemonstrated until it has been purchased." He leaned forward and\r\nwhispered confidentially. "I\'ll tell you what I\'ll do though. This\r\nthing is way overpriced and hasn\'t been moving at all. The manager said\r\nI could let them go at three dollars if I could find any takers. If you\r\nwant to buy it for that price...."\r\n\r\n"Sold, my boy!" the colonel said, slamming three bills down on the\r\ntable. "I\'ll give that much for it no matter _how_ it works. The boys in\r\nthe shop will get a kick out of it," he tapped the winged rocket on his\r\nchest. "Now _really_--what holds it up?"\r\n\r\nThe demonstrator looked around carefully, then pointed. "Strings!" 

he\r\nsaid. "Or rather a black thread. It runs from the top of the model,\r\nthrough a tiny loop in the ceiling, and back down to my hand--tied to\r\nthis ring on my finger. When I back up--the model rises. 

It\'s as simple\r\nas that."\r\n\r\n"All good illusions are simple," the colonel grunted, tracing the black\r\nthread with his eye. "As long as there is plenty of flimflam to distract\r\nthe viewer."\r\n\r\n"If you don\'t have a black table, a black cloth will do," the young man\r\nsaid. "And the arch of a doorway is a good site, just see that the room\r\nin back is dark."\r\n\r\n"Wrap it up, my boy, I wasn\'t born yesterday. 

I\'m an old hand at this\r\nkind of thing."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBiff Hawton sprang it at the next Thursday-night poker party. The gang\r\nwere all missile men and they cheered and jeered as he hammed up the\r\nintroduction.\r\n\r\n"Let me copy the diagram, Biff, I could use some of those magnetic waves\r\nin the new bird!"\r\n\r\n"Those flashlight batteries are cheaper than lox, this is the thing of\r\nthe future!"\r\n\r\nOnly Teddy Kaner caught wise as the flight began. He was an amateur\r\nmagician and spotted the gimmick at once. He kept silent with\r\nprofessional courtesy, and smiled ironically as the rest of the bunch\r\ngrew silent one by one. The colonel was a good showman and he had set\r\nthe scene well. He almost had them believing in the Space Wave Tapper\r\nbefore he was through. When the model had landed and he had switched it\r\noff he couldn\'t stop them from crowding around the table.\r\n\r\n"A thread!" one of the engineers shouted, almost with relief, and they\r\nall laughed along with him.\r\n\r\n"Too bad," the head project physicist said, "I was hoping that a little\r\nSpace Wave Tapping could help us out. Let me try a flight with it."\r\n\r\n"Teddy Kaner first," Biff announced. "He spotted it while you were all\r\nwatching the flashing lights, only he didn\'t say anything."\r\n\r\nKaner slipped the ring with the black thread over his finger and started\r\nto step back.\r\n\r\n"You have to turn the switch on first," Biff said.\r\n\r\n"I know," Kaner smiled. "But that\'s part of illusion--the spiel and the\r\nmisdirection. I\'m going to try this cold first, so I can get it moving\r\nup and down smoothly, then go through it with the whole works.

"\r\n\r\n[Illustration: ILLUSTRATED BY BREY]\r\n\r\nHe moved his hand back smoothly, in a professional manner that drew no\r\nattention to it. The model lifted from the table--then crashed back\r\ndown.\r\n\r\n"The thread broke," Kaner said.\r\n\r\n"You jerked it, instead of pulling smoothly," Biff said and knotted the\r\nbroken thread. "Here let me show you how to do it.

"\r\n\r\nThe thread broke again when Biff tried it, which got a good laugh that\r\nmade his collar a little warm. Someone mentioned the poker game.\r\n\r\nThis was the only time that poker was mentioned or even remembered that\r\nnight. Because very soon after this they found that the thread would\r\nlift the model only when the switch was on and two and a half volts\r\nflowing through the joke coils. With the current turned off the model\r\nwas too heavy to lift. The thread broke every time.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"I still think it\'s a screwy idea," the young man said. "One week\r\ngetting fallen arches, demonstrating those toy ships for every brat\r\nwithin a thousand miles. Then selling the things for three bucks when\r\nthey must have cost at least a hundred dollars apiece to make."\r\n\r\n"But you _did_ sell the ten of them to people who would be interested?"\r\nthe older man asked.\r\n\r\n"I think so, I caught a few Air Force officers and a colonel in missiles\r\none day. Then there was one official I remembered from the Bureau of\r\nStandards. Luckily he didn\'t recognize me. Then those two professors you\r\nspotted from the university."\r\n\r\n"Then the problem is out of our hands and into theirs. All we have to do\r\nnow is sit back and wait for results."\r\n\r\n"_What_ results?! These people weren\'t interested when we were hammering\r\non their doors with the proof. We\'ve patented the coils and can prove to\r\nanyone that there is a reduction in weight around them when they are\r\noperating...."\r\n\r\n"But a small reduction. And we don\'t know what is causing it. No one can\r\nbe interested in a thing like that--a fractional weight decrease in a\r\nclumsy model, certainly not enough to lift the weight of the generator.\r\nNo one wrapped up in massive fuel consumption, tons of lift and such is\r\ngoing to have time to worry about a crackpot who thinks he has found a\r\nminor slip in Newton\'s laws."\r\n\r\n"You think they will now?" the young man asked, cracking his knuckles\r\nimpatiently.\r\n\r\n"I _know_ they will. The tensile strength of that thread is correctly\r\nadjusted to the weight of the model. The thread will break if you try to\r\nlift the model with it. Yet you can lift the model--after a small\r\nincrement of its weight has been removed by the coils. This is going to\r\nbug these men. 

Nobody is going to ask them to solve the problem or\r\nconcern themselves with it. But it will nag at them because they know\r\nthis effect can\'t possibly exist. They\'ll see at once that the\r\nmagnetic-wave theory is nonsense. Or perhaps true? 

We don\'t know. 

But\r\nthey will all be thinking about it and worrying about it. Someone is\r\ngoing to experiment in his basement--just as a hobby of course--to find\r\nthe cause of the error. And he or someone else is going to find out what\r\nmakes those coils work, or maybe a way to improve them!"\r\n\r\n"And we have the patents...."\r\n\r\n"Correct. They will be doing the research that will take them out of the\r\nmassive-lift-propulsion business and into the field of pure space\r\nflight."\r\n\r\n"And in doing so they will be making us rich--whenever the time comes to\r\nmanufacture," the young man said cynically.\r\n\r\n"We\'ll all be rich, son," the older man said, patting him on the\r\nshoulder. "Believe me, you\'re not going to recognize this old world ten\r\nyears from now."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Analog_ April 1962.
