I\'ll guarantee that it sells, though. 

There\'s nothing like it\r\non any midway."\r\n\r\n"I\'d like to try it out first, of course," Allenby said. "Star-Time uses\r\nonly the very best, you know."\r\n\r\n"Yes, I know," Jenkins said. He had heard the line before, from almost\r\nevery carnival buyer to whom he had sold. He did not do much business\r\nwith the carnivals; there weren\'t enough to keep him busy with large or\r\nworthwhile rides and features. The amusement parks of the big cities\r\nwere usually the best markets.\r\n\r\nAllenby warily eyed the entrance, a room fashioned from a side-show\r\nbooth. A rough red curtain concealed the inside. 

Over the doorway, in\r\ncrude dark blue paint, was lettered, "Journey Home." Behind the doorway\r\nwas a large barnlike structure, newly painted white, where Jenkins did\r\nhis planning, his building, and his finishing. When he sold a new ride\r\nit was either transported from inside the building through the large,\r\npull-away doors in back or taken apart piece by piece and shipped to the\r\npark or carny that bought it.\r\n\r\n"Six thousand\'s a lot of money," the buyer said.\r\n\r\n"Just try it," Jenkins told him.\r\n\r\nThe buyer shrugged. "O.K.," he said. 

"Let\'s go in." They walked through\r\nthe red curtain. Inside the booth-entrance was a soft-cushioned\r\neasy-chair, also red, secured firmly in place. It was a piece of salvage\r\nfrom a two-engine commercial airplane. A helmet looking like a Flash\r\nGordon accessory-hair drier combination was set over it. Jenkins flipped\r\na switch and the room became bright with light. "I thought you said this\r\nwasn\'t a thrill ride," Allenby said, looking at the helmetlike structure\r\nominously hanging over the chair.\r\n\r\n"It isn\'t," Jenkins said, smiling. "Sit down." He strapped the buyer\r\ninto place in the chair.\r\n\r\n"Hey, wait a minute," Allenby protested. "Why the straps?"\r\n\r\n"Leave everything to me and don\'t worry," Jenkins said, fitting the\r\nheadgear into place over the buyer\'s head. The back of it fitted easily\r\nover the entire rear of the skull, down to his neck. The front came just\r\nbelow the eyes. After turning the light off, Jenkins pulled the curtain\r\nclosed. It was completely black inside.\r\n\r\n"Have a nice trip," Jenkins said, pulling a switch on the wall and\r\npushing a button on the back of the chair at the same time.\r\n\r\nCurrents shifted and repatterned themselves inside the helmet and were\r\nfed into Allenby at the base of his skull, at the medulla. The currents\r\nof alternating ions mixed with the currents of his varied and random\r\nbrain waves, and the impulses of one became the impulses of the other.\r\nAllenby jerked once with the initial shock and was then still, his mind\r\nand body fused with the pulsating currents of the chair.\r\n\r\nSuddenly, Roger Allenby was almost blinded by bright, naked light.\r\nAllenby\'s first impression was one of disappointment at the failure of\r\nthe device. Jenkins was reliable, usually, and hadn\'t come up with a\r\nfluke yet.\r\n\r\nAllenby got out of the chair and called for Jenkins, holding on to the\r\narm of the chair to keep his bearings. 

"Hey! Where are you? Jenkins!" He\r\ntried to look around him but the bright, intense light revealed nothing.\r\nHe swore to himself, extending his arms in front of him for something to\r\ngrasp. As he groped for a solid, the light became more subdued and\r\nshifted from white into a light, pleasant blue.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nShapes and forms rearranged themselves in front of him and gradually\r\nbecame distinguishable. He was in a city, or on top of a city. A\r\npanoramic view was before him and he saw the creations of human beings,\r\nobviously, but a culture far removed from his. A slight path of white\r\nbegan at his feet and expanded as it fell slightly, ramplike, over and\r\ninto the city. The buildings were whiter than the gate of false dreams\r\nthat Penelope sung of and the streets and avenues were blue, not gray.\r\nThe people wore white and milled about in the streets below him. They\r\nshouted as one; their voices were not cries but songs and they sang his\r\nname.\r\n\r\nHe started walking on the white strip. It was flexible and supported his\r\nweight easily. Then he was running, finding his breath coming in sharp\r\ngasps and he was among the crowds. They smiled at him as he passed by\r\nand held out their hands to him. Their faces shone with a brilliance of\r\nawareness and he knew that they loved him. Troubled, frightened, he kept\r\nrunning, blindly, and, abruptly, there were no people, no buildings.\r\n\r\nHe was walking now, at the left side of a modern super-highway, against\r\nthe traffic. Autos sped by him, too quickly for him to determine the\r\nyear of model. Across the divider the traffic was heavier, autos\r\nspeeding crazily ahead in the direction he was walking; none stopped. He\r\nhalted for a moment and looked around him. There was nothing on the\r\nsides of the road: no people, no fields, no farms, no cities, no\r\nblackness. There was nothing. But far ahead there was green etched\r\naround the horizon as the road dipped and the cars sped over it. He\r\nwalked more quickly, catching his breath, and came closer and closer to\r\nthe green.\r\n\r\nAllenby stopped momentarily and turned around, looking at the highway\r\nthat was behind him. It was gone. Only bleak, black and gray hills of\r\nrock and rubble were there, no cars, no life. He shuddered and continued\r\non toward the end of the highway. The green blended in with the blue of\r\nthe sky now. Closer he came, until just over the next rise in the road\r\nthe green was bright. Not knowing or caring why, he was filled with\r\nexpectation and he ran again and was in the meadow.\r\n\r\nAll around him were the greens of the grasses and leaves and the yellows\r\nand blues of the field flowers. It was warm, a spring day, with none of\r\nthe discomfort of summer heat. Jubilant, Roger spun around in circles,\r\ninhaling the fragrance of the field, listening to the hum of insect life\r\nstirring back to awareness after a season of inactivity. Then he was\r\nrunning and tumbling, barefoot, his shirt open, feeling the soft grass\r\ngive way underfoot and the soil was good and rich beneath him.\r\n\r\nHe saw a stream ahead, with clear water melodiously flowing by him. He\r\nwent to it and drank, the cold, good water quenching all his thirst,\r\nclearing all the stickiness of his throat and mind. He dashed the water\r\non his face and was happy and felt the coolness of it as the breeze\r\npicked up and swept his hair over his forehead. With a shake of his head\r\nhe tossed it back in place and ran again, feeling the air rush into his\r\nlungs with coolness and vibrance unknown since adolescence. No nicotine\r\nspasms choked him and the air was refreshing.\r\n\r\nThen up the hill he sped, pushing hard, as the marigolds and dandelions\r\nparted before him. At the top he stopped and looked and smiled\r\necstatically as he saw the green rolling land and the stream, curving\r\naround from behind the house, his house, the oaks forming a secret lair\r\nbehind it, and he felt the youth of the world in his lungs and under his\r\nfeet. He heard the voice calling from that house, his house, calling him\r\nto Saturday lunch.\r\n\r\n"I\'m coming!" he cried happily and was tumbling down the hill, rolling\r\nover and over, the hill and ground and sky blending blues and greens and\r\nnothing had perspective. The world was spinning and everything was black\r\nagain. He shook his head to clear the dizziness.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Well?" Jenkins said. 

"How was it?"\r\n\r\nAllenby looked up at him as Jenkins swung the helmet back and unhooked\r\nthe seatbelt. He squinted as Jenkins flipped the light switch and the\r\nbrightness hit him.\r\n\r\nHis surroundings became distinguishable again very slowly and he knew he\r\nwas back in the room. "Where was I?" he asked.\r\n\r\nJenkins shrugged. "I don\'t know. It was all yours. You went wherever you\r\nwanted to go, wherever home is." Jenkins smiled down at him. "Did you\r\nvisit more than one place?" he asked. The buyer nodded. "I thought so.\r\nIt seems that a person tries a few before finally deciding where to go."\r\n\r\nThe buyer stood up and stretched. "Could I please see the barn?" he\r\nasked, meaning the huge workshop where Jenkins did the construction\r\nwork.\r\n\r\n"Sure," Jenkins said and opened the door opposite the red curtain into\r\nthe workshop. It was empty.\r\n\r\n"You mean it was all up here? I didn\'t move at all?" He tapped his\r\ncranium with his index finger.\r\n\r\n"That\'s right," Jenkins said anxiously. "Do you want it or not?"\r\n\r\nAllenby stood looking into the empty room. "Yes ... yes, of course," he\r\nsaid. "How long did the whole thing last?"\r\n\r\n"About ten seconds," Jenkins said, looking at his watch. "It seems much\r\nlonger to the traveler. I\'m not sure, but I think the imagined time\r\nvaries with each person. It\'s always around ten seconds of actual time,\r\nthough, so you can make a lot of money on it, even if you only have one\r\nmachine."\r\n\r\n"Money?" Allenby said. 

"Money, yes, of course." He took a checkbook from\r\nhis inside pocket and hurriedly wrote a check for six thousand dollars.\r\n"When can we have it delivered?" he asked.\r\n\r\n"You want it shipped the usual way?"\r\n\r\n"No," Allenby said, staring at the red-cushioned chair. "Send it air\r\nfreight. 

Then bill us for the expense."\r\n\r\n"Whatever you say," Jenkins said, smiling, taking the check. "You\'ll\r\nhave it by the first of the week, probably. I\'ll put a complete parts\r\nand assembly manual inside the crate."\r\n\r\n"Good, good. 

But maybe I should test it again, you know. Star-Time can\'t\r\nreally afford to make a mistake as expensive as this."\r\n\r\n"No," Jenkins said quickly. Then, "I\'ll guarantee it, of course. If it\r\ndoesn\'t work out, I\'ll give you a full refund. But don\'t try it again,\r\ntoday. 

Don\'t let anyone have it more than once in one day. Stamp them on\r\nthe hand or something when they take the trip."\r\n\r\n"Why?"\r\n\r\nJenkins looked troubled. "I\'m not sure, but people might not want to\r\ncome back. Too many times in a row and they might be able to stay\r\nthere ... in their minds of course."\r\n\r\n"Of course, of course. Well, it\'s been a pleasure doing business with\r\nyou, Mr. Jenkins. 

I hope to see you again soon." They walked back to\r\nAllenby\'s not-very-late model car and shook hands. Allenby drove away.\r\n\r\nOn the way back to the hotel, and as he lay for a long time in the\r\nbathtub, letting the warmness drift away from the water, the thought ran\r\nover and over in his mind. They might be able to stay there, Allenby\r\nsaid to himself. They might be able to stay there. He smiled warmly at a\r\ncrack in the plaster as he thought of the first of the week and the\r\nfragrant meadow.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Analog Science Fact & Fiction_\r\n    November 1963. Several of the town\'s\r\nministers who had been with him on other issues had balked on this one,\r\nbut he had three of them present, as well as heads of several women\'s\r\nclubs.\r\n\r\nAs he had anticipated, the irresponsible liberals were present to do\r\nbattle, headed by red-haired Patrick Levitt.\r\n\r\n"This board," said Levitt in his strong, sarcastic voice, "has gone too\r\nfar. It was all right to get rid of the actual filth ... and everyone\r\nwill agree there was some. But when you banned the sale of some\r\nmagazines and books because they had racy covers or because the contents\r\nwere a little too sophisticated to suit the taste of members of this\r\nboard ... well, you can carry protection of our youth to the point of\r\ninsulting the intelligence of adults who have a right to read what they\r\nwant to."\r\n\r\n"You\'re talking about something that\'s already in the past, Mr. 

Levitt,"\r\nsaid Montcalm mildly. 

"Let\'s keep to the issue at hand. You won\'t deny\r\nthat children see this indecent statue every day?"\r\n\r\n"No, I won\'t deny it!" snapped Levitt. 

"Why shouldn\'t they see it? They\r\ncan see the plate of the original in the encyclopaedia. It\'s a fine copy\r\nof a work of art."\r\n\r\nMontcalm waited for some rebuttal from his supporters, but none was\r\nforthcoming. On this matter, they apparently were unwilling to go\r\nfarther than the moral backing of their presence.\r\n\r\n"I do not consider the statue of a naked woman art, even if it is called\r\n\'Dawn,\'" he said bitingly. He looked at his two colleagues and received\r\ntheir nods of acquiescence. He ruled: "The statue must be removed from\r\nthe park and from public view."\r\n\r\nLevitt had one parting shot.\r\n\r\n"Would it solve the board\'s problem if we put a brassiere and panties on\r\nthe statue?" he demanded.\r\n\r\n"Mr. 

Levitt\'s levity is not amusing. The board has ruled," said Montcalm\r\ncoldly, arising to signify the end of the meeting.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThat night Montcalm slept the satisfied sleep of the just.\r\n\r\nHe awoke shortly after dawn to find a strange, utterly beautiful naked\r\nwoman in his bedroom. For a bemused instant Montcalm thought the statue\r\nof Dawn in the park had come to haunt him. His mouth fell open but he\r\nwas unable to speak.\r\n\r\n"Take me to your President," said the naked woman musically, with an\r\naccent that could have been Martian.\r\n\r\nMrs. Montcalm awoke.\r\n\r\n"What\'s that? 

What is it, Richard?" she asked sleepily.\r\n\r\n"Don\'t look, Millie!" exclaimed Montcalm, clapping a hand over her eyes.\r\n\r\n"Nonsense!" she snapped, pushing his hand aside and sitting up. She\r\ngasped and her eyes went wide, and in an instinctive, unreasonable\r\nreaction she clutched the covers up around her own nightgowned bosom.\r\n\r\n"Who are you, young woman?" demanded Montcalm indignantly. 

"How did you\r\nget in here?"\r\n\r\n"I am a visitor from what you would call an alien planet," she said. "Of\r\ncourse," she added thoughtfully, "it isn\'t alien to me."\r\n\r\n"The woman\'s mad," said Montcalm to his wife. A warning noise sounded in\r\nthe adjoining bedroom. Alarmed, he instructed: "Go and keep the children\r\nout of here until I can get her to put on some clothes. They mustn\'t see\r\nher like this."\r\n\r\nMrs. Montcalm got out of bed, but she gave her husband a searching\r\nglance.\r\n\r\n"Are you sure I can trust you in here with her?" she asked.\r\n\r\n"Millie!" exclaimed Montcalm sternly, shocked. She dropped her eyes and\r\nleft the room. When the door closed behind her, he turned to the strange\r\nwoman and said:\r\n\r\n"Now, look, young lady, I\'ll get you one of Millie\'s dresses. You\'ll\r\nhave to get some clothes on and leave."\r\n\r\n"Aren\'t you going to ask me my name?" asked the woman. "Of course, it\'s\r\nunpronounceable to you, but I thought that was the first thing all Earth\r\npeople asked of visitors from other planets."\r\n\r\n"All right," he said in exasperation. "What\'s your name?"\r\n\r\nShe said an unpronounceable word and added: "You may call me Liz."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nMontcalm went to the closet and found one of Millie\'s house dresses. He\r\nheld it out to her beseechingly.\r\n\r\nAs he did so, he was stricken with a sudden sharp feeling of regret that\r\nshe must don it. Her figure ... why Millie had never had a figure like\r\nthat! At once, he felt ashamed and disloyal and sterner than ever.\r\n\r\nLiz rejected the proffered garment.\r\n\r\n"I wouldn\'t think of adopting your alien custom of wearing clothing,"\r\nshe said sweetly.\r\n\r\n"Now look," said Montcalm, "I don\'t know whether you\'re drunk or crazy,\r\nbut you\'re going to have to put something on and get out of here before\r\nI call the police."\r\n\r\n"I anticipated doubt," said Liz. 

"I\'m prepared to prove my identity."\r\n\r\nWith the words, the two of them were no longer standing in the Montcalm\r\nbedroom, but in a broad expanse of green fields and woodland, unmarred\r\nby any habitation. Montcalm didn\'t recognize the spot, but it looked\r\nvaguely like it might be somewhere in the northern part of the state.\r\n\r\nMontcalm was dismayed to find that he was as naked as his companion!\r\n\r\n"Oh, my Lord!" he exclaimed, trying to cover himself with a September\r\nMorn pose.\r\n\r\n"Oh, I\'m sorry," apologized Liz, and instantly Montcalm\'s pajamas were\r\nlying at his feet. He got into them hurriedly.\r\n\r\n"How did we get here?" he asked, his astonished curiosity overcoming his\r\ndisapproval of this immodest woman.\r\n\r\n"By a mode of transportation common to my people in planetary\r\natmospheres," she answered. "It\'s one of the things I propose to teach\r\nyour people."\r\n\r\nShe sat down cross-legged on the grass. Montcalm averted his eyes, like\r\nthe gentleman he was.\r\n\r\n"You see," said Liz, "the people of your world are on the verge of going\r\nto space and joining the community of worlds. It\'s only natural the rest\r\nof us should wish to help you. We have a good many things to give you,\r\nto help you control the elements and natural conditions of your world.\r\nThe weather, for example ..."\r\n\r\nSuddenly, out of nowhere, a small cloud appeared above them and spread,\r\nblocking out the early sun. It began to rain, hard.\r\n\r\nThe rain stopped as suddenly as it had begun and the cloud dissipated.\r\nMontcalm stood shivering in his soaked pajamas and Liz got to her feet,\r\nher skin glistening with moisture.\r\n\r\n"You have a problem raising food for your population in some areas," she\r\nsaid....\r\n\r\nA small haw-apple tree near them suddenly began to grow at an amazing\r\nrate of speed. It doubled its size in three minutes, put forth fruit\r\nand dropped it to the ground.\r\n\r\n"These are only a few of the things I\'ll give to your planet," she said.\r\n\r\nAt her words, they were back in the bedroom. This time she had been\r\nthoughtful. Montcalm was still clad in wet pajamas.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know what sort of hypnosis this is," he began aggressively,\r\n"but you can\'t fool me, young lady, into believing ..."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nMillie came into the room. She had donned a robe over her nightgown.\r\n\r\n"Richard, where have you been with this woman?" she demanded.\r\n\r\n"Why, my dear ..."\r\n\r\n"You\'ve been roaming around the house somewhere with her. I came in here\r\na moment ago and you were gone. Now, Richard, I want you to do something\r\nabout her and stop fooling around. I can\'t keep the children in their\r\nroom all day."\r\n\r\nIt hadn\'t been hypnosis then! Liz was for real. A vision rose before\r\nMontcalm of mankind given wonders, powers, benefits representing\r\nadvances of thousands of years. The world could become a paradise with\r\nthe things she offered to teach.\r\n\r\n"Millie, this woman _is_ from another planet!" he exclaimed excitedly,\r\nand turned to Liz. "Why did you choose me to contact on Earth?"\r\n\r\n"Why, I happened to land near your house," she answered. "I know how\r\nyour primitive social organization is set up, but isn\'t one human being\r\njust as good as another to lead me to the proper authorities?"\r\n\r\n"Yes," he said joyfully, visualizing black headlines and his picture in\r\nthe papers.\r\n\r\nMillie stood to one side, puzzled and grim at once. Montcalm picked up\r\nthe house dress he had taken from the closet earlier.\r\n\r\n"Now, Miss," he said, "if you\'ll just put this on, I\'ll take you to the\r\nmayor and he can get in touch with Washington at once."\r\n\r\n"I told you," said Liz, "I don\'t want to adopt your custom of wearing\r\nclothing."\r\n\r\n"But you can\'t go out in public like that!" said the dismayed Montcalm.\r\n"If you\'re going to move among Earth people, you must dress as we do."\r\n\r\n"My people wouldn\'t demand that Earth people disrobe to associate with\r\nus," she countered reasonably.\r\n\r\nMillie had had enough. She went into action.\r\n\r\n"You can argue with this hussy all you like, Richard, but I\'m going to\r\ncall the police," she said, and left the room with determination in her\r\neye.\r\n\r\nThe next fifteen minutes were agonizing for Montcalm as he tried\r\nfutilely to get Liz to dress like a decent person. He was torn between\r\nrealization of what the things she offered would mean to the world and\r\nhis own sense of the fitness of things. His children, the children of\r\nTraskmore, the children of the world ... what would be the effect on\r\ntheir tender morals to realize that a sane adult was willing to walk\r\naround in brazen nakedness?\r\n\r\nThere was a pounding on the front door, and the voice of Millie inviting\r\nthe law into the house.\r\n\r\n"Now I\'m afraid you\'re due to go to jail," said Montcalm mournfully.\r\n"But when they get some clothes on you, I\'ll try to explain it and get\r\nyou an audience with the mayor."\r\n\r\nTwo blue-clad policemen entered the room.\r\n\r\nOne policeman took the house dress from Montcalm\'s lax fingers and\r\ntossed it over Liz\' head without further ado.\r\n\r\nLiz did not struggle. She looked at Montcalm with a quizzical\r\nexpression.\r\n\r\n"I\'m sorry," she said. "My people made a mistake. If you Earth people\r\naren\'t tolerant enough to accept a difference in customs of dress, I\'m\r\nafraid you\'re too immature.

"\r\n\r\nWith that, she was gone like a puff of air. The astonished policemen\r\nheld an empty dress.\r\n\r\nMontcalm didn\'t see the flying saucer that whizzed over Traskmore that\r\nmorning and disappeared into the sky, but he didn\'t doubt the reports.\r\nHe debated with himself for a long time whether he had taken the right\r\nattitude, but decided he had.\r\n\r\nAfter all, there were the children to consider.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Amazing Science Fiction Stories_\r\n    September 1958. No power."\r\nEndicott beat his old blue-veined hands together.\r\n\r\nAllison\'s frost-numbed fingers picked at the straps on his reclining\r\ngeeseat, and he stepped to the light metal deck. He shivered and\r\npunched the button on the control board again. He was seized by a spasm\r\nof uncontrollable shaking. "No power means--no heat!" Panic crept into\r\nhis voice.\r\n\r\nEndicott said nothing but looked at the tier upon tier of buttons,\r\nfunctionless now.\r\n\r\nAllison looked at the board, too, his narrow shoulders hunched.\r\n"They\'ve never failed before," he muttered through chattering teeth.\r\n\r\n"What?" Endicott seemed bemused.\r\n\r\n"The buttons. Punch \'em, and you always get what you want--except now!"\r\n\r\n"Now, now," Endicott said soothingly. "Panic isn\'t going to help us\r\nany. All we have to do is sit tight--and wait. They\'ll send a relief\r\nship out--"\r\n\r\n"When?"\r\n\r\n"In the morning. Morning, sure. They had us on the \'viewer, don\'t\r\nforget. They\'ll know exactly where to look."\r\n\r\n"They won\'t be able to locate us in this white stuff."\r\n\r\n"I tell you they know precisely where we are. And anyway the scanviewer\r\nwill pick us up."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t think they\'ll ever find us." Allison slumped down on his\r\ntransverse geeseat, stared wide-eyed at the drift forming slowly inside\r\nthe torn metal of the windward side of the control room. "This white\r\nstuff scares me." He shivered, then got up hastily, his boots slipping\r\nslightly on the snow-slick decking, and punched the button again. "It\'s\r\ngot to work!" 

he cried and beat on the board with his fist.\r\n\r\n"Stop that!" Endicott said sharply.\r\n\r\nThere was a crack of a slap in the control room, then silence.\r\n\r\nIn a moment Endicott said in his soothing voice, "Sorry, Allison.\r\nEverything\'ll be all right. Don\'t you worry."\r\n\r\n"If you say so, Chief." Allison stood in the center of the control\r\nroom, his arms slack by his sides.\r\n\r\n"We\'ll be all right," Endicott said. "We have food capsules--"\r\n\r\n"Sure, Chief."\r\n\r\n"We\'ll be all right, except--" Endicott peered through the rents in the\r\nhull into the storm outside. "All we have to do is sit tight," he added\r\nhastily.\r\n\r\n"We\'ll freeze tonight without heat." Allison\'s voice was still\r\nbreathless with panic.\r\n\r\n"Yeah. 

Yeah, I\'ve been thinking about that. There\'s some thing\r\n\'way down deep in my mind--something I can\'t quite get--" Endicott\r\nstill looked out at the storm-thrashed trees, a puzzled expression\r\nwrinkling his face. "Something from my childhood--I was born a long\r\ntime before you, you know, before they set up state conditioning homes\r\nfor children. Long before they set up this \'everything-from-buttons\'\r\nbusiness. Lived with my own people, I did, and I seem to remember--seem\r\nto remember--" The puzzled expression became a frown of concentration.\r\n"Or maybe it was something I read a long time ago," he mused.\r\n\r\n"Did what?" Allison perked up.\r\n\r\n"Read. 

You wouldn\'t know what that was. Everything comes from buttons\r\nnow, entertainment, food, light, heat--everything.... No, it was from\r\nmy childhood, I\'m sure. I remember my people used to take me out in\r\nthe country--" Endicott mused on while a cloak of snow grew on the\r\nshoulders of his jacket, and the light began to fade.\r\n\r\n"Out in the country? What for? 

Nobody goes out there." Allison\'s eyes\r\ngleamed slightly in the growing dusk.\r\n\r\n"--for picnics. And--" Endicott\'s eyes brightened, and one hand\r\nclenched.\r\n\r\n"For what?" Allison\'s head thrust forward.\r\n\r\n"What?" Endicott snapped, irritated at having his train of thought\r\nbroken.\r\n\r\n"What did your people take you in the country for?"\r\n\r\n"A picnic.... Yes, yes, that\'s it! I remember now!" Endicott\'s words\r\npoured out.\r\n\r\n"You know it is forbidden to think of the old days."\r\n\r\n"Shut up! 

Let me think. You want heat, don\'t you?"\r\n\r\n"It\'s forbidden to think of the old days," Allison repeated stubbornly.\r\n"You\'ll get heat when I report this--in a different way."\r\n\r\n"Shut up! 

Look, you want to keep from freezing tonight?" Endicott\r\nglared. 

"All right. Come with me and do as I say." Without a backward\r\nglance Endicott crossed the slippery deck and entered the passageway.\r\nAt the midship cargo natch he stopped.\r\n\r\n"How are you going to open it without power?" Allison\'s breath-plume\r\nshot over Endicott\'s shoulder. "It\'s locked and unlocked by a button on\r\nthe control board. Remember Chief?"\r\n\r\n"Stop gloating, Allison. This is for your benefit as well as mine.\r\nThere\'s an escape hatch in the control room."\r\n\r\n"That\'s controlled by power, too."\r\n\r\n"Yes, but in these older models the hatch also has a manual control, as\r\nI remember." Endicott moved off toward the control room.\r\n\r\nAllison hesitated, then followed, and joined Endicott as he began to\r\nsearch the control board. Endicott found the emergency lever for the\r\nescape hatch and tugged on it, turning his head to watch the hatch\r\nin the side of the hull, back of his seat. The hatch, big enough for\r\none man to pass through at a time, popped, crackling with frost, and\r\nstirred slightly.\r\n\r\n"Now, Allison, my boy, let\'s put our shoulders to it." Endicott was in\r\nhigh spirits again.\r\n\r\nAs soon as the hatch swung open, Endicott put his head and shoulders\r\nthrough the opening, squinting his eyes against the icy snow which\r\nswirled past him. He grabbed a handhold on the outside of the hull and\r\npulled his legs through, and dropped into the snow alongside the ship.\r\n\r\nAllison\'s head and shoulders appeared in the opening, and in a moment\r\nhe was beside Endicott. "Now what?" Allison yelled above the wind.\r\n\r\nEndicott looked toward the clearing in which they had landed, then\r\nturned to face the trees around the disabled ship. He waded through the\r\nsnow to the nearest one and reflectively took hold of a dry branch over\r\nhis head, tugged it several times as though judging its resiliency,\r\nbefore snapping it off.\r\n\r\n"Now, Allison, you see what I did? Well, you do the same, only gather\r\nan armload of branches. When you have them, bring them to me at the\r\nship. 

And keep on gathering them until I tell you to stop."\r\n\r\nAllison stood still in the deep snow, peering suspiciously at Endicott\r\nthrough the snow-swirl. "Is this something from the old--?"\r\n\r\n"Never mind that now, Allison," Endicott said patiently. "Let\'s not\r\nworry about all that twaddle. You want to be warm, don\'t you? So, just\r\ndo as I say."\r\n\r\nAllison\'s eyebrows shot up and lowered instantly, and his face set in\r\nstubborn planes. "If this is from the old days I\'m not sure I want any\r\npart of it." He looked furtively over his shoulders at the gloomy woods.\r\n\r\n"There are no Conditioning Committees here, Allison," Endicott said\r\ntestily. "Get on with it."\r\n\r\nAllison took a few reluctant steps toward the nearest tree. Endicott\r\nstarted back to the ship with his branch, looking back over his\r\nshoulder.\r\n\r\n"No, no, Allison. See those green needles? It won\'t do at all.\r\nDry branches, Allison, _dry_ branches." The whipping wind carried\r\nEndicott\'s words over the few yards.\r\n\r\n"I can\'t see how these--branches?--are going to keep us warm. It seems\r\nlike a lot of useless trouble getting them," Allison said sulkily,\r\nsuspicion and fear unabated.\r\n\r\nEndicott didn\'t answer. Instead, he went to the side of the ship away\r\nfrom the wind and began tramping the snow down into a flat, hard\r\nfloor. He broke his branch into short lengths over his knee, then, in\r\na nearly forgotten gesture, slapped at his uniform until he remembered\r\nthat he had no pockets. For a moment he stood still, his eyes roving\r\nover the side of the ship until it came to one of the jagged tears.\r\nWith a little self-congratulatory chuckle, he began scraping one of\r\nthe lengths of wood over the torn metal, catching the splinters and\r\nshavings in the palm of one hand.\r\n\r\nAllison dropped his armload of branches by the ship, waged an inner\r\nbattle between fear of the unknown and curiosity in which curiosity\r\nwon, and stood watching Endicott arrange the branches in a crib around\r\nthe neatly piled shavings. Endicott, on one knee by the crib, worked\r\nsteadily, laying the pieces of wood with care and a returning sense\r\nof sureness, with only brief pauses to flex his freezing fingers.\r\nFinally, with a smile of satisfaction on his face, Endicott got to his\r\nfeet, and the nearly forgotten gesture at the pocketless uniform was\r\nrepeated.\r\n\r\nSlowly, Endicott\'s lined face altered. He looked hastily at the\r\nwatchful Allison and hastily looked away; he looked at the completed\r\ncrib, and his tongue licked his lips; he looked along the side of the\r\ndamaged ship, and his eyes narrowed thoughtfully; finally, he looked\r\ninto the swirl of the icy snow, and he shivered. 

His hands ceased their\r\npawing, fell slowly, to hang slack by his sides. 

He was not smiling as\r\nhe turned away.\r\n\r\n"What were you looking for?" Allison asked curiously.\r\n\r\n"I just remembered something else," said Endicott, his voice was very\r\nsoft in the stillness, "we used to have something called a match to\r\nstart those picnic fires."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


When does--"\r\n\r\n"Oh! At 1900 hours," she gushed.\r\n\r\n"The ship splits in half," she added helpfully, and dimpled in that\r\nwinning way of little girls who will never grow up.\r\n\r\n"Remarkable. They tell me some sort of cable will tie us together."\r\n\r\n"Yes sir, when we are far enough out in space so there isn\'t any air\r\nfriction, Mr. Webley, the pilot, pulls a little lever and the nose\r\nflies off. He\'ll be all alone out there for forty-two days."\r\n\r\n"And only a thin cable connects our passenger section to his control\r\nsection?" He was quite familiar with the details since he had lobbied\r\nfor the initial appropriation. Her forearm had a nice warm smooth\r\nfeeling.\r\n\r\n"Oh, you understand it perfectly, sir. When we\'re a mile apart a little\r\nrocket in the side makes us spin round and round. Then I can take off\r\nthese old iron shoes." She followed his gaze to her legs and tittered.\r\n\r\nHe speculated that similar magnets must be holding down the hem of her\r\nnylon skirt.\r\n\r\n"And does this spinning about a common axis continue until we near\r\nMars?"\r\n\r\n"Yes sir, for forty-two days. Excuse me sir, I think null gravity is\r\nmaking that lady ill."\r\n\r\nAfter carefully wiping his palm on his coatsleeve he replaced his unlit\r\ncigar in his broad, gleaming face. He was in the smiling sensuality of\r\na daydream when the powder-room door clicked.\r\n\r\nHis wife was beautiful.\r\n\r\nUptilting his cigar he watched her drift down the aisle. With one\r\nscarlet-tipped finger she prevented her diaphanous skirt from floating\r\nvery high above her knees. A lovely lady. 

He champed on the cigar. It\'s\r\nnot every man whose wife is a natural blonde ex-starlet young enough to\r\nbe his daughter.\r\n\r\nBut a little discipline was in order.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Landa, I wish you had remembered to have Hykato pack my golf things."\r\n\r\n"Edwin please, this null gravity is upsetting my tummy.

"\r\n\r\n"Well, it\'s the least you could have done."\r\n\r\n"And how would we have gotten it on the ship?" her voice shrilled\r\nunexpectedly. "You embarrassed me enough as it was."\r\n\r\n"Listen, I\'m the Commissioner. No two-bit pilot is going to tell me\r\nwhat I can\'t take. The luggage limit is ridiculous!"\r\n\r\n"What are you complaining about? He let you take everything, didn\'t he?"\r\n\r\n"After you smiled at him."\r\n\r\n"I was only trying to be pleasant."\r\n\r\n"Pleasant is it? Last time you said it was to influence him to take all\r\nmy luggage."\r\n\r\n"Yeah and you got sore because you weren\'t a big enough shot to swing\r\nthe deal alone," her voice rasped through its lady-like veneer.\r\n\r\n"That\'s a lie. Furthermore I don\'t want to catch you smiling at him\r\nagain."\r\n\r\n"I give up," she exclaimed and reached for a telemag.\r\n\r\nBut he wouldn\'t drop it there. "I didn\'t like that fellow\'s looks.\r\nPads in his shoulders, little waxed mustache. Who does he think he is,\r\nCaptain Future?

"\r\n\r\n"Oh, don\'t be funny. Just think what he thinks of you after what you\r\nsaid to him in front of all the other passengers and crew."\r\n\r\n"Taking his side now?

"\r\n\r\n"I am not." She gave a little sniff and fumbled for her handkerchief.\r\n"You\'re so mean and masterful I\'m surprised you don\'t make me go up\r\nfront and tell him what a sap he is."\r\n\r\n"He was a sap smiling at my wife all right." He uplifted his cigar with\r\na mollified grin. "He wasted a smile there. Two-bit pilot, who does he\r\nthink he is?"\r\n\r\n"He did smile at me though," she appended in a small voice.\r\n\r\nHis voice snapped out again: "And you smiled back!" He ground his unlit\r\ncigar into the ash tray. "I think you were just now trying to flatter\r\nme; I think you were trying to turn me off the track when you said\r\nyou\'d go up and tell him what a sap he is."\r\n\r\n"I was not."\r\n\r\n"Don\'t try to wiggle out of it. That\'s what you said.

"\r\n\r\n"All right, if you think I should, I will."\r\n\r\n"Well now--" He paused smiling and carefully trimmed the crushed end of\r\nhis cigar with a gold plated cigar cutter before he continued: "If you\r\ninsist, go ahead."\r\n\r\n"There\'s not much time left," she said, pointing at the neon-dialed\r\nclock above the powder-room door. Beneath it hung an orange luminescent\r\nsign: U. S. Eastern Standard Earth Time Equivalent.\r\n\r\n"1850 hours," he snorted. "Don\'t try to wiggle out on that account. 

You\r\nhave a half hour."\r\n\r\n"O.K., if you say so," she shrugged and chewed the inside of her\r\ncheek. "This isn\'t very nice."\r\n\r\n"Let\'s not get that way. You coolly slip the shaft in me enough. And\r\nstop powdering your nose."\r\n\r\nWithout another word she rose and floated down the aisle, taking little\r\ncare to suppress her skirt. Somebody whistled and the Commissioner\r\nangrily craned his thick neck around. He couldn\'t see who had done it.\r\nBut he suspected the three grinning Cadet Astronauts in the last row of\r\nseats.\r\n\r\n[Illustration: _She rose and floated down the aisle, taking little care\r\nto suppress her rising, diaphanous skirt._]\r\n\r\nAs the door to the control room clanged shut, the powder-room door\r\nclicked open and the rockette tapped out on her iron shoe-soles.\r\nCommissioner Elbert rolled his eyes and smiled, but she seemed\r\npreoccupied with a smaller female with pigtails and the hiccups.\r\n\r\nGuess I\'ll have a look forward myself, he thought. Just like a woman to\r\ngo up there, wait in the hall a minute and come back.\r\n\r\nRising, he floated past the rockette toward the control room door.\r\n\r\n"Don\'t open that, sir. The ship\'s about to separate."\r\n\r\n"What? It\'s only 1855 hours."\r\n\r\n"That is Eastern Standard Time, sir. The clock at the other end of\r\nthe aisle, over the men\'s room, gives the Standard Star Time our ship\r\nschedule operates on."\r\n\r\nThose neon hands pointed at 1900.\r\n\r\nWith a strangled yell he lunged for the door, but as his hand closed\r\nabout the handle something clicked and it resisted his straining and\r\nthen his pounding fists.\r\n\r\nA buzzer sounded and a cheery masculine voice spoke over the intercom.\r\n"Hello again passengers, this is your pilot Hugh Webley wishing you a\r\npleasant crossing. Please re-enter your safticorsettes. The Bolo II\r\nwill now separate."\r\n\r\n"Intercom," the Commissioner shouted. Shoving past the slack-jawed\r\nrockette, he literally swam down the gravityless aisle to the\r\nengineering hatchway. It opened to his shouts.\r\n\r\n"Yeah?" A giant with a handlebar mustache peered up at him.\r\n\r\n"I\'m Commissioner Elbert. Call your pilot at once. I order the ship not\r\nto separate."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHastily the giant lifted the phone. Commissioner Elbert could hear the\r\nsteady buzz.\r\n\r\n"Sorry sir, Webley\'s cut us off. He does that so no one will interrupt\r\nhim while he\'s setting the auto controls.

"\r\n\r\n"Get him somehow. 

My wife\'s up there."\r\n\r\nThe giant coughed and strangled and turned his face away. "I\'ll keep\r\ntrying sir," he gasped. "But sometimes he cuts us off for days. He\r\nsleeps a lot."\r\n\r\n"Forehatch," the Commissioner shouted suddenly. "Unlock the forehatch."\r\n\r\nWearily the giant clambered up. He towered above Elbert.\r\n\r\n"Didn\'t you hear what I said," the Commissioner yelled. "Unlock the\r\ndoor to the control room."\r\n\r\n"Sorry sir, the lock\'s automatic."\r\n\r\n"Well dammit, blast it down."\r\n\r\nNoisily the giant scratched his crewcut. "Maybe I could crowbar it."\r\n\r\n"Quick, you fool."\r\n\r\n"No, I can\'t. 

I can\'t sir. The ship might separate while the hatch was\r\nopen and our own air pressure would blow us all into the vacuum. I\r\ncan\'t risk the lives of our passengers, sir."\r\n\r\n"I\'m Commissioner Elbert. Give me that crowbar."\r\n\r\nThe giant held it behind him.\r\n\r\n"That\'s an order."\r\n\r\n"Sorry sir, better reclaim your seat before the jolt." The giant\r\nsignalled with his fingers at the rockette.\r\n\r\nElbert snatched at the crowbar. As the two men grappled for it,\r\nwhirling like fighting cocks in the air, a tremendous surge hurled them\r\nthe length of the aisle. Another slammed them against the powder-room\r\ndoor. When the giant helped the bleeding Commissioner to his feet,\r\nartificial gravity held them down.\r\n\r\nEmitting motherly sounds, the rockette tried to wipe the blood from his\r\nforehead. But he shoved her aside.\r\n\r\n"I\'ll sue. I\'ll have your transport license revoked."\r\n\r\n"Please sir," the rockette squeaked, "I\'ll bring you a sedative."\r\n\r\n"Hugens will hear about this," he shouted, writhing in the engineer\'s\r\nbrawny arms. But then he sobbed: "I sent her up there. My fault, my\r\nidea, she didn\'t want to go. She was worried about the time and I told\r\nher there was plenty of time."\r\n\r\nAs he gulped the sedative he looked like a punctured balloon.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t want a sedative," he shouted. But he had just swallowed it.\r\nHe sagged again. 

"My fault. I told her there was plenty of time." He\r\nrubbed his sleeve across his nose.\r\n\r\nAfter they had settled him groggily in his seat, the rockette drew the\r\nengineer aside. Her pretty little brow wrinkled.\r\n\r\n"Dan, I can\'t figure it. Why does he think it\'s his fault? Gee, when\r\nwe were in the powder-room together she asked me about why the clocks\r\ntold different times, and I explained how we figure time by positions\r\nof stars instead of the earth and sun and all that stuff. You\'d think\r\nshe\'d understood. 

She talked bright enough."\r\n\r\nThe giant squeezed her arm affectionately. Lucky Webley, sap Commish,\r\nbright dame. Forty-two days and an alibi.\r\n\r\nHe chuckled and walked his fingers up her arm.\r\n\r\n"Carol, you can\'t ever tell. All dames don\'t have the same amount of\r\nbrightness you do."\r\n\r\nShe giggled and shivered a little at his hand. "We learned all about\r\ntime in rockette school."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


"\r\n             He smiled grimly. Yes, he knew what to do....\r\n\r\n           [Transcriber\'s Note: This etext was produced from\r\n                      Planet Stories Winter 1946.\r\n         Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that\r\n         the U.S. copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nThe Fifth Sector Commander was known as a rigid man, that was true, and\r\nyet no one could say exactly how rigid.\r\n\r\nHis office, aboard the _Polaris_, was a rather grim place. All command\r\noffices were, essentially, being limited pretty much to regulation\r\nfurnishings, but rare was the Commander who did not manage to plant\r\nsome of his personality there. It was perhaps characteristic of\r\nCommander Gray that there was only one item in his office which could\r\nbe said to reveal anything about him.\r\n\r\nHe sat now behind the cubical steel desk and looked down at the glowing\r\nscreen of the television set. The face in it was not at ease. Far from\r\nit.\r\n\r\nOrdinarily, John Brullar, the Commissioner over Gray, was a\r\nself-important, unconsciously comical person. Now he looked neither\r\ncomical nor important. He just looked very, very frightened.\r\n\r\nHe licked his trembling lips and said, in a voice hoarse with fear,\r\n"Of _course_ there is something you can do, Commander! After all,"\r\nhe brightened faintly, "there are important people on the _Stella_.\r\nImportant people." He emphasized "important."\r\n\r\n"I am aware of that, Commissioner Brullar," said the Commander. "Yet,\r\nwhat can I do?"\r\n\r\n"You have authority!" sputtered Brullar. "And you know what you can\r\n_do_! Get through to Interstellar Command on Sirius VII and tell them\r\njust exactly what these Beolins are up to!" He glared, a fat man in\r\nmortal fear for his life. "And you can do it quickly, Commander!\r\nQuickly, do you understand?"\r\n\r\n"I understand," the Commander said.\r\n\r\n"Good." Brullar started to speak again, gulped, hesitated, and finally\r\nrepeated, "Good." He switched off.\r\n\r\nThe Commander gazed reflectively down the catwalk, through the ship,\r\nat the faint glimmer of green outside of an open lock. There was a\r\nturbulence deep in his steel-colored eyes. He tapped a small stud with\r\na slim, tapering forefinger.\r\n\r\nKina Staun came in.\r\n\r\nKina wasn\'t all Solarian. He had enough Sol blood in him to make him\r\none in almost every respect, but there were differences, if you looked\r\nclosely. He was the Commander\'s personal aide. 

There was actually\r\nmore than that between them. The tremendousness of all the Commander\r\ngoverned--and which Kina helped him run--made for a rather involved\r\nrelationship.\r\n\r\nWhen people saw the Commander, they looked for Kina Staun. The two\r\nhad not been a hundred yards apart since they had first met as\r\nnewly-appointed official and aide. It was said that Kina knew every\r\nbit as much about the Fifth Sector and the Commander\'s work as the\r\nCommander knew himself.\r\n\r\nFor that reason, if Kina ever left his post, he would certainly die\r\nwithin an hour.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe Commander said, "Kina, call Hauns." The Secretary showed no\r\nsurprise, but somehow managed to give that impression.\r\n\r\n"The city of Hauns, capitol of Beolin III, the ruling planet of the\r\nBeolin system?" he asked very respectfully.\r\n\r\n"Yes. 

I want to talk to their Commissioner-in-Chief. And also find the\r\npresent location of the _Stella_."\r\n\r\n"Yes, sir," said Kina.\r\n\r\nHe came back within ten seconds. "The _Stella_," he said, "is now at\r\n3rd Quadrant 3521 NA, W-88236. Speed, one light-year per hour. Heading,\r\n338 Degrees NA of nearest sun, Beolin. And I have Beolin Command for\r\nyou."\r\n\r\nThe Commander touched a switch and the screen flicked on again. "Thank\r\nyou, Kina," he said.\r\n\r\nThe face in the screen was definitely not human. Its structure, and\r\neven more, its expression was alien. It was distinctly unpleasant.\r\n\r\nIt belonged to Krraula, who was Commander-in-Chief, and the foremost\r\nmurderer of the Beolin System. He smiled, a smile that was not a smile.\r\nHe said, "Ah, Commander." And he saluted, sneering slightly.\r\n\r\nThe Commander said, "Greetings, Krraula. I would like to inquire the\r\nreason for your fleet being in its present position."\r\n\r\nKrraula smiled again. "The fleet, Commander? Merely maneuvers," he said\r\nslyly. 

"Why do you ask?"\r\n\r\n"There is a liner transiting through the outer fringes of your\r\nterritory in--" he looked at a paper Kina had slipped before him\r\n"--about four hours. I would appreciate it if your fleet is withdrawn\r\nin time. It would not go well, Krraula, if an ... accident ... were to\r\nhappen to this liner of which I speak. I think you understand."\r\n\r\nHe gave Krraula no time to answer, but switched off. He sat back, and\r\nlooked aimlessly at Kina.\r\n\r\n"Kina," he said, after a few moments of thought.\r\n\r\n"Yes, Commander."\r\n\r\n"Do you get the framework of this problem?"\r\n\r\n"I do, sir," answered the aide.\r\n\r\n"Good. Let me hear it."\r\n\r\n"The question is one of Command," said Kina Staun quietly. "Out here in\r\nthe stars, power--the authority to command--goes not to men\'s heads but\r\nto their souls. Krraula of Beolin is an example, and, in a different\r\nway--"\r\n\r\n"Myself?"\r\n\r\n"No, Commander Brullar. He is the brass-hat type, while Krraula is\r\nsimply a tyrannical madman."\r\n\r\n"So far, you\'re right. 

But what of _this_ particular problem?

"\r\n\r\n"Yes, sir," the aide said. "Krraula, and the Beolin rulers, have power\r\nin and about their system to the extent that their depredations go\r\nunchallenged there. And an apathetic Interstellar Command--"\r\n\r\n"Does not act," finished the Commander. "You are entirely correct,\r\nKina." He touched studs on the desk and reports slid through the viewer\r\non the wall. He said quietly, "We have lost a score of ships--ships\r\nthat we are sure the Beolins could tell us about. And yet the Command\r\ndoes not act." He looked reflectively at the slim, impassive man, and\r\nthen spoke swiftly.\r\n\r\n"Kina, I want you to get me two more connections ... Sirius VII, and\r\nthe Command Cruiser nearest to Beolin. Hurry! 

The cruiser first."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nA minute or so later, Kina slipped a sheet of paper onto the desk, and\r\ntouched a switch. The screen glittered into life, showing the face of\r\na man who wore a captain\'s shoulder bars. Glancing at the paper, which\r\ngave the name of the officer and the ship, the Commander said, "Captain\r\nStang, how far are you from Beolin?"\r\n\r\n"Roughly twenty light years, sir," was the immediate answer.\r\n\r\n"Do you think that you can make a speed of--say--five light-years per\r\nhour, or perhaps more?"\r\n\r\nThe captain frowned slightly. 

"I\'m not sure, Commander. Perhaps we can."\r\n\r\n"Good! Stand by, at your present position in space." Gray switched off.\r\n\r\nKina spoke softly at his side. "That one cruiser, Commander, is more\r\nthan a match for the entire Beolin fleet." He paused. "Here is your\r\ncall to Sirius Headquarters, sir."\r\n\r\n[Illustration: "That one cruiser, Commander, is more than a match for\r\nthe entire Beolin fleet."]\r\n\r\nThe Commander turned back to the screen. "Over-Commissioner Branu, are\r\nyou aware of the present stage of relations with Beolin?"\r\n\r\nThe Over-Commissioner frowned at him. "Certainly! Why are you asking,\r\nCommander?" There was an imperious sharpness in his voice.\r\n\r\n"What are they?"\r\n\r\nBranu hesitated, said, "Relations are somewhat strained at present, of\r\ncourse, but not seriously. I--"\r\n\r\n"Suppose proof was given that Beolin was back of the recent\r\ndisappearances of spacecraft?"\r\n\r\n"My dear Commander Gray! You--you must not say that! Such an intimation\r\nmight _easily_ cost you your post! Why--"\r\n\r\nThe Commissioner cut him off.\r\n\r\n"You see, Commander," said Kina, "the Command simply cannot think of\r\nsuch a thing."\r\n\r\n"Yes ... but they could be made--forced--to think of it."\r\n\r\n"There is only one way to do _that_," said Kina. "Only one way."\r\n\r\n"Yes." Commander Gray fell silent for a minute, and then said quietly,\r\n"Kina."\r\n\r\n"I am listening, sir."\r\n\r\n"The hands of one man," said the Commander, "were never meant to hold\r\npersonal power such as this. We can do only the best we can ... and it\r\nwill never be perfect. We must be prepared to--" he hesitated slightly\r\nbefore going on "--to set aside all personal things, and substitute the\r\nstars for them. Because only in that way can we approach perfection."\r\n\r\nKina was silent and attentive, but his eyes flickered for a second\r\nacross the one personal item in the office.\r\n\r\n"I am not a god, Kina. And yet I must be. Because there are men--such\r\nas Krraula--who think they are." He fell silent.\r\n\r\nThen he said, "A god _must_ have power of life ... and death."\r\n\r\nThe screen was on again and, once more, it was Commissioner Brullar. He\r\nwas almost frantic.\r\n\r\n"Commander Gray! Have you acted yet? 

The captain says that we are being\r\nscreened out. Only this special set can get through--and only to you!"\r\nHe gulped, mopping at his forehead. "Commander, I have my entire family\r\naboard this ship! I--I know that you...." His voice faltered for an\r\ninstant. "Can\'t _you_ get through to the Command?

"\r\n\r\nThen, nervously, without waiting for a reply, he plunged on. "The\r\nCaptain of the _Stella_ says he believes there is an Interstellar\r\nCommand cruiser within four hours or so. Can\'t you get it here? It\r\ncould escort us through the edge of the Beolin system in safety!\r\nCommander Gray, I in--"\r\n\r\nThe Commander cut Brullar off.\r\n\r\n"Kina," he asked, "what do you think the effect of a Beolin massacre\r\nwould be on the Command?"\r\n\r\n"Roughly estimating, Commander, considerably more than the effect of an\r\nunleashed power beam on inert matter."\r\n\r\n"Yes," said the Commander. 

"Yes. Kina, at least ten thousand human\r\nlives have been lost on ships that I _know_ have been captured by the\r\nBeolins. Unless the Command takes action--now--there will never be a\r\ncheck on Krraula and his successors. And only a shocking catastrophe\r\nwould stir up the Sirius Command Headquarter. A certain kind of\r\ncatastrophe."\r\n\r\n"The sacrifice justifies itself," said Kina Staun. "The moral laws, the\r\nvery framework of civilization itself, is now of a shape incredible to\r\nthe person of two or three hundred years ago."\r\n\r\n"My orders, then, should be...?"\r\n\r\nKina stood up, stiffly. "It would be presumptuous of me, Commander."\r\n\r\nThe silence did not last very long.\r\n\r\nAt last the Commander said, "Kina, order Captain Stang to resume\r\nhis usual patrol activities. Arrange to follow the _Stella_ with a\r\nlong-range recording beam. Prepare for the Interstellar Command\'s\r\norder ... to proceed with a punitive expedition against the Beolin\r\nsystem." He looked long down the catwalk, and his fingers slowly closed\r\nabout the one personal touch to his office.\r\n\r\nHis voice was very low. 

"No more messages are to be received from the\r\n_Stella_."\r\n\r\nAnd he opened his hand.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nLater, after the Commander had gone down the catwalk to walk about for\r\na while on the soft, Earthlike greenness of this world\'s vegetation,\r\nKina bent to pick up that which had fallen to the floor.\r\n\r\nIt was a color photograph, and the cold plastic sheen of the film\r\nsomehow managed to convey the impression of the blonde, young woman\'s\r\nsoft, warm loveliness.\r\n\r\nIt was inscribed, "_With all my love, John. Myra._" Kina had often seen\r\nCommissioner Brullar\'s daughter.\r\n\r\nHe dropped the photograph in to a disposal chute, and turned to some\r\npapers that had to be filed.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


As\r\na result of them the permanent population includes smugglers and\r\nblack-marketeers, fugitives from justice and international con men,\r\nespionage and counter-espionage agents, homosexuals, nymphomaniacs,\r\nalcoholics, drug addicts, displaced persons, ex-royalty, and subversives\r\nof every flavor. Local law limits the activities of few of these.\r\n\r\nLike I said, it\'s quite a town.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI looked up from my _Herald Tribune_ and said, "Hello, Paul. Anything\r\nnew cooking?"\r\n\r\nHe sank into the chair opposite me and looked around for the waiter. The\r\ntables were all crowded and since mine was a face he recognized, he\r\nassumed he was welcome to intrude. It was more or less standard\r\nprocedure at the Cafe de Paris. It wasn\'t a place to go if you wanted to\r\nbe alone.\r\n\r\nPaul said, "How are you, Rupert? Haven\'t seen you for donkey\'s years."\r\n\r\nThe waiter came along and Paul ordered a glass of beer. Paul was an\r\neasy-going, sallow-faced little man. I vaguely remembered somebody\r\nsaying he was from Liverpool and in exports.\r\n\r\n"What\'s in the newspaper?" he said, disinterestedly.\r\n\r\n"Pogo and Albert are going to fight a duel," I told him, "and Lil Abner\r\nis becoming a rock\'n\'roll singer."\r\n\r\nHe grunted.\r\n\r\n"Oh," I said, "the intellectual type." 

I scanned the front page. "The\r\nRusskies have put up another manned satellite."\r\n\r\n"They have, eh? How big?"\r\n\r\n"Several times bigger than anything we Americans have."\r\n\r\nThe beer came and looked good, so I ordered a glass too.\r\n\r\nPaul said, "What ever happened to those poxy flying saucers?"\r\n\r\n"What flying saucers?"\r\n\r\nA French girl went by with a poodle so finely clipped as to look as\r\nthough it\'d been shaven. The girl was in the latest from Paris. Every\r\npore in place. We both looked after her.\r\n\r\n"You know, what everybody was seeing a few years ago. It\'s too bad one\r\nof these bloody manned satellites wasn\'t up then. Maybe they would\'ve\r\nseen one."\r\n\r\n"That\'s an idea," I said.\r\n\r\nWe didn\'t say anything else for a while and I began to wonder if I could\r\ngo back to my paper without rubbing him the wrong way. I didn\'t know\r\nPaul very well, but, for that matter, it\'s comparatively seldom you ever\r\nget to know anybody very well in Tangier. Largely, cards are played\r\nclose to the chest.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nMy beer came and a plate of tapas for us both. Tapas at the Cafe de\r\nParis are apt to be potato salad, a few anchovies, olives, and possibly\r\nsome cheese. Free lunch, they used to call it in the States.\r\n\r\nJust to say something, I said, "Where do you think they came from?" And\r\nwhen he looked blank, I added, "The Flying Saucers."\r\n\r\nHe grinned. "From Mars or Venus, or someplace."\r\n\r\n"Ummmm," I said. "Too bad none of them ever crashed, or landed on the\r\nYale football field and said _Take me to your cheerleader_, or\r\nsomething."\r\n\r\nPaul yawned and said, "That was always the trouble with those crackpot\r\nblokes\' explanations of them. If they were aliens from space, then why\r\nnot show themselves?"\r\n\r\nI ate one of the potato chips. It\'d been cooked in rancid olive oil.\r\n\r\nI said, "Oh, there are various answers to that one. We could probably\r\nsit around here and think of two or three that made sense.

"\r\n\r\nPaul was mildly interested. "Like what?"\r\n\r\n"Well, hell, suppose for instance there\'s this big Galactic League of\r\ncivilized planets. But it\'s restricted, see. You\'re not eligible for\r\nmembership until you, well, say until you\'ve developed space flight.\r\nThen you\'re invited into the club. Meanwhile, they send secret missions\r\ndown from time to time to keep an eye on your progress."\r\n\r\nPaul grinned at me. 

"I see you read the same poxy stuff I do."\r\n\r\nA Moorish girl went by dressed in a neatly tailored gray jellaba,\r\nEuropean style high-heeled shoes, and a pinkish silk veil so transparent\r\nthat you could see she wore lipstick. Very provocative, dark eyes can be\r\nover a veil. We both looked after her.\r\n\r\nI said, "Or, here\'s another one. Suppose you have a very advanced\r\ncivilization on, say, Mars."\r\n\r\n"Not Mars. No air, and too bloody dry to support life."\r\n\r\n"Don\'t interrupt, please," I said with mock severity. "This is a very\r\nold civilization and as the planet began to lose its water and air, it\r\nwithdrew underground. Uses hydroponics and so forth, husbands its water\r\nand air. Isn\'t that what we\'d do, in a few million years, if Earth lost\r\nits water and air?"\r\n\r\n"I suppose so," he said. 

"Anyway, what about them?"\r\n\r\n"Well, they observe how man is going through a scientific boom, an\r\nindustrial boom, a population boom. A boom, period. Any day now he\'s\r\ngoing to have practical space ships. Meanwhile, he\'s also got the H-Bomb\r\nand the way he beats the drums on both sides of the Curtain, he\'s not\r\nagainst using it, if he could get away with it."\r\n\r\nPaul said, "I got it. So they\'re scared and are keeping an eye on us.\r\nThat\'s an old one. I\'ve read that a dozen times, dished up different."\r\n\r\nI shifted my shoulders. "Well, it\'s one possibility."\r\n\r\n"I got a better one. How\'s this. 

There\'s this alien life form that\'s way\r\nahead of us. Their civilization is so old that they don\'t have any\r\nrecords of when it began and how it was in the early days. They\'ve gone\r\nbeyond things like wars and depressions and revolutions, and greed for\r\npower or any of these things giving us a bad time here on Earth. They\'re\r\nall like scholars, get it? And some of them are pretty jolly well taken\r\nby Earth, especially the way we are right now, with all the problems,\r\nget it? 

Things developing so fast we don\'t know where we\'re going or how\r\nwe\'re going to get there."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI finished my beer and clapped my hands for Mouley. "How do you mean,\r\n_where we\'re going_?"\r\n\r\n"Well, take half the countries in the world today. They\'re trying to\r\nindustrialize, modernize, catch up with the advanced countries. Look at\r\nEgypt, and Israel, and India and China, and Yugoslavia and Brazil, and\r\nall the rest. Trying to drag themselves up to the level of the advanced\r\ncountries, and all using different methods of doing it. But look at the\r\nso-called advanced countries. Up to their bottoms in problems. Juvenile\r\ndelinquents, climbing crime and suicide rates, the loony-bins full of\r\nthe balmy, unemployed, threat of war, spending all their money on\r\narmaments instead of things like schools. All the bloody mess of it.\r\nWhy, a man from Mars would be fascinated, like."\r\n\r\nMouley came shuffling up in his babouche slippers and we both ordered\r\nanother schooner of beer.\r\n\r\nPaul said seriously, "You know, there\'s only one big snag in this sort\r\nof talk. I\'ve sorted the whole thing out before, and you always come up\r\nagainst this brick wall. Where are they, these observers, or scholars,\r\nor spies or whatever they are? Sooner or later we\'d nab one of them.\r\nYou know, Scotland Yard, or the F.B.I., or Russia\'s secret police, or\r\nthe French S\xc3\xbbret\xc3\xa9, or Interpol. This world is so deep in police,\r\ncounter-espionage outfits and security agents that an alien would slip\r\nup in time, no matter how much he\'d been trained. Sooner or later, he\'d\r\nslip up, and they\'d nab him.

"\r\n\r\nI shook my head. 

"Not necessarily. The first time I ever considered this\r\npossibility, it seemed to me that such an alien would base himself in\r\nLondon or New York. Somewhere where he could use the libraries for\r\nresearch, get the daily newspapers and the magazines. Be right in the\r\ncenter of things. 

But now I don\'t think so. I think he\'d be right here\r\nin Tangier."\r\n\r\n"Why Tangier?"\r\n\r\n"It\'s the one town in the world where anything goes. Nobody gives a damn\r\nabout you or your affairs. For instance, I\'ve known you a year or more\r\nnow, and I haven\'t the slightest idea of how you make your living."\r\n\r\n"That\'s right," Paul admitted. "In this town you seldom even ask a man\r\nwhere\'s he\'s from. He can be British, a White Russian, a Basque or a\r\nSikh and nobody could care less. Where are _you_ from, Rupert?"\r\n\r\n"California," I told him.\r\n\r\n"No, you\'re not," he grinned.\r\n\r\nI was taken aback. "What do you mean?"\r\n\r\n"I felt your mind probe back a few minutes ago when I was talking about\r\nScotland Yard or the F.B.I. possibly flushing an alien. Telepathy is a\r\nsense not trained by the humanoids. If they had it, your job--and\r\nmine--would be considerably more difficult. Let\'s face it, in spite of\r\nthese human bodies we\'re disguised in, neither of us is humanoid. Where\r\nare you really from, Rupert?"\r\n\r\n"Aldebaran," I said. 

"How about you?"\r\n\r\n"Deneb," he told me, shaking.\r\n\r\nWe had a laugh and ordered another beer.\r\n\r\n"What\'re you doing here on Earth?" I asked him.\r\n\r\n"Researching for one of our meat trusts. We\'re protein eaters. Humanoid\r\nflesh is considered quite a delicacy. How about you?"\r\n\r\n"Scouting the place for thrill tourists. My job is to go around to these\r\nbackward cultures and help stir up inter-tribal, or international,\r\nconflicts--all according to how advanced they are. Then our tourists\r\ncome in--well shielded, of course--and get their kicks watching it."\r\n\r\nPaul frowned. 

"That sort of practice could spoil an awful lot of good\r\nmeat."\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Amazing Stories_ December 1960.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed.
