]\r\n\r\n\r\nIt happened just before he reached the zero point, the no-man's land\r\nin space where the attenuated gravity fields of two planets meet and\r\ncancel out.\r\n\r\nMaynard was dividing his attention equally between the transparent\r\nbubble that housed the Meinz pendulum and the two ports, forward\r\nand aft, that broke the steel panelling of the control cubicle. He\r\nlistened critically to the measured clicking of the Geiger counters\r\nand the quiet sibilance of the air purifiers, and in spite of his\r\nweightlessness and his total loss of equilibrium he was quite calm.\r\n\r\nBut deep inside him, under his trained calmness, Maynard felt a\r\nsteadily growing triumph, a swelling exultation that was a thing quite\r\napart from scientific pride. The feeling that he was a pioneer, an\r\nadvance guard for a conquering people, elated him and multiplied the\r\neagerness in him when he turned his eyes to the forward port where\r\nMars hung, full and ruddy, a spotted enigmatic disc of promise.\r\n\r\nEarth hung in the after port behind and below him, a soft emerald\r\ncrescent in its first thin quarter. A warm green sickle that was home,\r\na hustling verdant young world impatient to push its way across black\r\nempty space and satisfy its lusty curiosity about its cosmic neighbors.\r\n\r\nHe was at the end of his second day out, and he had covered roughly\r\nhalf of the distance he must travel. The atomic jets had cut off long\r\nago, at escape velocity, and would not come on again until they were\r\nneeded to slow his approach. The midpoint lay just ahead; in a matter\r\nof minutes now he would leave Earth's waning field and fall free into\r\nthe grasp of the red planet.\r\n\r\nHe was watching the cobalt ball of the Meinz pendulum quiver on its\r\nthin quartz thread with the first fluttering release of Earth's gravity\r\nwhen the fear came.\r\n\r\nTerror struck him suddenly, galvanically, blanking out all reason and\r\nall sensation. The control cubicle whirled giddily before his eyes, and\r\nthe abysmal panic that gripped his mind was a monstrous thing boiling\r\nup out of unguessed subconscious depths. It froze him, breathing, like\r\na man paralyzed under an overwhelming electric shock.\r\n\r\n[Illustration: _Then terror struck!_]\r\n\r\nIt was not fear of death. It was not even his own fear.\r\n\r\nIt was the blind panic of Something inside him whose existence he\r\nhad never remotely suspected, Something that shrieked soundlessly in\r\nsenseless maniac terror and fought to tear Itself free of him.\r\n\r\nHe was torn by the struggle for an interminable instant, and then it\r\nwas over. He felt it writhe loose from the encumbrance of his mind,\r\nlike a madman writhing out of a strait-jacket, and then It was falling\r\nback toward Earth, away from him. He could sense It plainly, once It\r\nwas outside him--a malevolent, intangible Thing that fell back swiftly\r\ntoward the emerald crescent of Earth.\r\n\r\nHe sat for a moment dazed while breath came back into his lungs and the\r\nsteel-panelled cubicle grew steady again before his starting eyes.\r\nAnd, when It had gone in the distance and he could no longer feel\r\nthe frenzy of Its terror, he felt the swift unbounded freedom that a\r\nspirited horse feels when it has, unexpectedly, lost its rider.\r\n\r\nHe was still Robert Maynard, but with a difference.\r\n\r\n_He was free._\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe feeling of utter freedom staggered him. For the first time in his\r\nlife he possessed himself entirely, without doubt or reservation, a\r\ncomplete and serene entity. He could feel his consciousness still\r\nexpanding, reaching into every hidden corner of his mind and taking\r\ncontrol of functions he had not dreamed of before.\r\n\r\nAn analogy occurred to him in perfect exactness of detail: he was like\r\na man waking from a vague world of sleep to find that what he had\r\nthought a single small room was in reality a spacious house. There\r\nwere other rooms than the cramped chamber he had lived in all his\r\nlife--rooms that had been tenanted a moment before by Something else,\r\nbut which lay open and ready for his own use now that their Tenant was\r\ngone. A moment before his ego had occupied a meager one-twelfth of his\r\nbrain; with Its departure the whole of his mind was his.\r\n\r\nAs suddenly as that he knew what had happened to him and why, and his\r\nincredibly-multiplied intelligence arranged the details of it precisely\r\nfor his consideration.\r\n\r\nHe had been host to a parasitic intelligence, without knowing it, all\r\nhis life. He had moved at Its dictates, following his own will only\r\nwhen It slept or tired or was distracted, never succeeding fully in any\r\nendeavor of his own because It was in control and must be obeyed. He\r\nknew when he had explored the vacated premises of his newly freed mind\r\nthat It was only one of many, that all earthmen had Tenants like It,\r\nintangible parasitic entities subsisting upon and controlling the human\r\nlife force.\r\n\r\nHe thought: _No wonder we have wars on Earth! We have no common ground\r\nfor agreement because we are under Their compulsion. 

They know our\r\ninherent abilities and keep us at each others' throats lest we learn\r\nof and destroy them. Everything that man has accomplished has been done\r\nin spite of Them._\r\n\r\nHe looked with new eyes at the instrument panel under the forward port\r\nand was astonished at the crudity of the engines it controlled. He was\r\nprimarily an astrophysicist, and his understanding of atomic propulsion\r\nhad been negligible; now its every function was clear to him at a\r\nglance. Experimentally he drew a graph of the arc he described through\r\nspace, and knew to a minute how long it would be before the braking\r\njets slowed his speed for landing.\r\n\r\nHe raised his eyes to the forward port where the ruddy disc of Mars\r\nhung framed against the black velvet backdrop of space like a red jewel\r\nburning dully among a random display of lesser brilliants, beckoning\r\nhim on with the future's illimitable promise.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe sat quite still for a time on the padded control couch, thinking\r\nintently, testing the new powers of his mind as he might have flexed a\r\nnewly discovered limb.\r\n\r\nHis first conclusion was inescapable: his Tenant had left him because\r\nIt could not exist outside Earth's gravity. It had been forced to quit\r\nhim or perish, and Its departure had made him the first really free man.\r\n\r\nThey were not invincible. 

They were not even particularly intelligent,\r\nin spite of Their gift of parasitic control, or his own Tenant would\r\nhave known Its danger. The fact that They were gravity-bound entities\r\ngave him the first vulnerable chink in Their armor, an Achilles heel\r\nthat offered eventual salvation for men. There would be other ways to\r\nbe rid of Them, and it was his responsibility as the first free man to\r\nsee that others of his kind were freed as he had been.\r\n\r\nHe pictured the harmonious integration of an Earth peopled by free\r\nmen and saw clearly the heights men might reach unhampered by their\r\nTenants. His own possibilities, when he had summed them up, awed him in\r\ntheir extent. There were no limits to what he could do, no bounds to\r\nthe knowledge he could accumulate and use.\r\n\r\n_This is what being a man is really like. I can liberate a world. Like\r\nMoses, I can set my people free._\r\n\r\nThe thought set his face shining, suffused him with a glow of\r\nanticipated triumph. It was all so simple, now that he was free....\r\n\r\nIn a few hours he would land on Mars, and in a matter of minutes he\r\ncould set up a beam transmitter to report back to the scientific\r\nfoundation that had sent him out. He could not tell his fellows the\r\ntruth because they were still captive, and their Tenants must not\r\nbe warned; but he could invent a plausible story of easily acquired\r\nwealth on Mars that would bring other and larger commercial expeditions\r\nswarming after him. With the help of other freed men he could found a\r\nnew civilization on the red planet, develop means to carry the fight\r\nback to Earth and exterminate the Tenants utterly. It would take time,\r\nbut in the end men would be free.\r\n\r\nThe Meinz centrifuge spun slowly, and with the swing of its cobalt ball\r\nMaynard felt the shift from terrestrial to Martian gravity. He felt the\r\nfirst tiny tug of weight and the slow returning of equilibrium as his\r\nbody oriented itself to the growing pull of the new attraction.\r\n\r\nWith the return of equilibrium he suddenly realized that he was upside\r\ndown and turned to the control board for correction. The cubicle\r\nrighted itself, rotating gently until the ruddy expanding disc of Mars\r\nhung below and ahead of the forward port. The Meinz pendulum ceased to\r\noscillate, the little cobalt ball hanging stiffly at the end of its\r\ntaut quartz filament.\r\n\r\nHe was well into the Martian attraction field by now. He made a quick\r\ncalculation (which once would have taken painstaking hours) and knew\r\nthat he would release the first braking blast from his forward jets\r\nin precisely ten hours. The little ship would nose into a slowly\r\ntightening spiral, avoiding the odd-planed orbits of the two tiny moons\r\nand, within minutes of establishing his declaration track, he would be\r\nready to land.\r\n\r\nHe watched eagerly as the red disc of Mars swelled to a mottled globe,\r\nblurred already at the edges by atmospheric refraction. Down there on\r\nthe dead ground of that ancient world he would set up his equipment and\r\nflash back his triumphant message to Earth, a fabulous exultant lie\r\nthat would bring other men like him swarming to the red planet.\r\n\r\n_Free men! Supermen, really, in a new free world. Nothing impossible,\r\nthen!_\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nLater, he shut off the braking blast of the forward jets and felt\r\nthe soft rubber-foam padding of the couch rise gently under him as\r\ndeceleration ceased. He was well into his landing spiral, eating up the\r\npaltry thousands of miles that lay between him and the shining future.\r\n\r\nHe lay back on the couch, smiling, his mind busy with the message he\r\nwould beam back to Earth, planning already the campaign he would carry\r\nout. Years must pass before men were freed completely of their Tenants,\r\nperhaps decades, but time did not matter. It was essentially a simple\r\ntask because he and those to come after him would be free of Their\r\ncompulsion--serene unhampered supermen to whom time was nothing.\r\n\r\nIn the end they could not fail....\r\n\r\nSomething impinged sharply upon his new perception, a chill groping\r\ntentacle of questioning intelligence. The smile froze on his face;\r\nhe sat up stiffly, numbled with the unforeseen horror of what was\r\nhappening to him. The groping ceased, and the hungry Intelligence from\r\noutside poured into his mind like smoke into an empty room, smothering\r\nhis feeble attempt at resistance.\r\n\r\nHe rose and went to the forward port, staring dully down at the\r\nuprushing sandy wastes and trying to recall what glorious thing it\r\nwas that he had been thinking. Or had it been only a dream? 

Somewhere\r\nin the farthest recess of his blunted consciousness a thought formed\r\nand floated like a bubble up into his awareness; but like a bubble it\r\nburst, and its meaning was lost on him.\r\n\r\n_There were Tenants on Earth_, it said. _Why not on Mars, too?_\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nThe missionaries came out of the planetary system of a star they didn\'t\r\ncall Antares. They called it, naturally enough, The Sun--just as home\r\nwas Earth, Terra, or simply The World. And naturally enough, being the\r\nascendant animal on Earth, they called themselves human beings. They\r\nwere looking for extraterrestrial souls to save.\r\n\r\nThey had no real hope of finding humans like themselves in this\r\nwonderously diversified universe. But it wasn\'t against all probability\r\nthat, in their rumaging, there might not be a humanoid species to whom\r\nthey could reach down a helping paw; some emergent cousin with at least\r\na rudimentary symmetry from snout to tail, and hence a rudimentary soul.\r\n\r\nThe ship they chose was a compact scout, vaguely resembling the outside\r\nof an orange crate--except that they had no concept of an orange crate\r\nand, being a tesseract, it had no particular outside. It was simply an\r\nexpanding cube (and as such, quite roomy) whose "interior" was always\r\nparalleling its "exterior" (or attempting to), in accordance with all\r\nthe well-known, basic and irrefutable laws on the subject.\r\n\r\nA number of its sides occupied the same place at the same time, giving\r\na hypothetical spectator the illusion of looking down merging sets of\r\nrailway tracks. This, in fact, was its precise method of locomotion.\r\nThe inner cube was always having to catch up, caboose-fashion, with\r\nthe outer one in time (or space, depending on one\'s perspective).\r\nAnd whenever it had done so, it would have arrived with itself--at\r\napproximately wherever in the space-time continuum it had been pointed.\r\n\r\nWhen they felt the jar of the settling geodesics, the crew crowded at\r\nthe forward visiplate to see where they were. It was the outskirts of\r\na G type star system. Silently they watched the innermost planet float\r\npast, scorched and craggy, its sunward side seeming about to relapse to\r\na molten state.\r\n\r\nThe Bosun-Colonel turned to the Conductor. "A bit of a disappointment\r\nI\'m afraid, sir. 

Surely with all that heat...?"\r\n\r\n"Steady, lad. The last wicket\'s not been bowled." The Conductor\'s\r\nwhiskers quivered in amusement at his next-in-command\'s impetuosity.\r\n"You\'ll notice that we\'re dropping downward. If the temperature\r\naccordingly continues dropping--"\r\n\r\nHe couldn\'t shrug, he wasn\'t physiologically capable of it, but it was\r\napparent that he felt they\'d soon reach a planet whose climate could\r\nsupport intelligent life.\r\n\r\nIf the Bosun-Colonel had any ideas that such directions as up and\r\ndown were meaningless in space, he kept them to himself. As the second\r\nplanet from its sun hove into view, he switched on the magniscan\r\neagerly.\r\n\r\n"I say, this is more like it. 

Clouds and all that sort of thing. 

Should\r\nwe have a go at it, sir?"\r\n\r\nThe Conductor yawned. "Too bloody cloudy for my taste. 

Too equivocal.\r\nLet\'s push on," he said languidly. "I have a hunch the third planet\r\nmight be just our dish of tea."\r\n\r\nQuelling his disappointment, the Bosun-Colonel waited for the third\r\nplanet to swim into being. And when it did, blooming like an orchid\r\nin all its greens and moistnesses, he could scarcely contain his\r\nexcitement.\r\n\r\n"Why, it looks just like Earth," he marveled. "Gad, sir, what a master\r\nstroke of navigation. 

How did you realize this would be it?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, I don\'t know," the Conductor said modestly. "Things usually have\r\na habit of occurring in threes. I\'m quite a student of numerology, you\r\nknow." Then he remembered the Mission and drew himself erect on all his\r\nlegs. "You may prepare for landing, Mister," he ordered crisply.\r\n\r\nThe Bosun-Colonel shifted over to manual and busied himself at the\r\nhelm, luffing the square craft down the troughs of air. Gliding over\r\nthe vast tropical oceans, he put down at a large land mass above a\r\nshallow warm sea, twenty-five degrees below the northern pole.\r\n\r\nToo numbed for comment, the crew stared out at the alien vista. They\'d\r\nheard of retarded life forms from other Missionary expeditions--of\r\nplanets where the inhabitants, in extreme emergency, had been known\r\nto commit murder. But this was surely the worst, the most vicious\r\nimaginable in the galaxy.\r\n\r\nHere, with life freshly up from the sea, freshly launched on the long\r\nclimb to maturity and self-realization--was nothing but horror. With so\r\nlush a vegetation, so easily capable of supporting them side by side\r\nin abundance, the monsters were actually feeding on each other. Great\r\nlumbering beasts they were with their bristling hides and huge tails,\r\ncharging between the giant tree ferns; gouging living chunks from one\r\nanother while razor-toothed birds with scaly wings flapped overhead,\r\nscreaming for the remnants. As the sounds of carnage came through the\r\naudio ports, the youngest Oarsman keeled over in a faint.\r\n\r\nEven the Conductor was visibly shaken. The Bosun-Colonel turned to him\r\nwith a sick expression.\r\n\r\n"Surely it\'s a lost cause, Skipper. Life like this will never have a\r\nsoul worth saving.

"\r\n\r\n"Not in its present stage," the Old Man was forced to agree. "Still,\r\none never knows the devious paths that evolution takes." He considered\r\nthe scene for a thoughtful, shuddering interval. "Perhaps in several\r\nthousand millenniums...."\r\n\r\nThe Bosun-Colonel tried to visualize the possibility of Ethical Life\r\never materializing through these swamp mists, but the logic against it\r\nwas too insurmountable for the imagination.\r\n\r\n"Even so," he conceded, "granting the impossible--whatever shape it\r\ntook, the only worthwhile species would still be...." He couldn\'t bring\r\nhimself to say it.\r\n\r\n"Meat-eaters," the Conductor supplied grimly.\r\n\r\nOn hearing this, the Oarsman who had just revived promptly fainted\r\nagain.\r\n\r\n"It\'s too deep in the genes," the Conductor continued, "too far\r\nadvanced for us to tamper with. All we can hope to do is modify their\r\nmoral outlook. 

So that by the time they achieve star travel, they\'ll at\r\nleast have a basic sense of Fair Play."\r\n\r\nSighing, bowed by responsibilities incommensurate with his\r\nchronological youth, he gave the order wearily. It was snapped down the\r\nchain of command to the Senior Yardbird:\r\n\r\n"All paws stand by to lower the Ethics Ray! Step lively, lads--bugger\r\noff, now...."\r\n\r\nThere was a din of activity as the outer locks were opened and the\r\nbulky mechanism was shipped over the side. It squatted on a cleared\r\nrise of ground in all its complex, softly ticking majesty, waiting for\r\nthe First Human to pad within range of its shedding Grace and Uplift.\r\nThe work party scrambled back to the ship, anxious to be off this\r\nsinister terrain. Once more the crew gathered at the visiplate as the\r\nplanet fell away beneath them, the Ethics Ray winking in the day\'s last\r\nlight like a cornerstone. Or perhaps a tambourine....\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nNight closed down on the raw chaotic world, huge beasts closed in on\r\nthe strange star-fallen souvenir. They snuffled over it; then enraged\r\nat discovering it was nothing they could fill their clamoring mindless\r\nstomachs with, attempted to wreck it. They were unsuccessful, for\r\nthe Machine had been given an extra heavy coat of shellac and things\r\nto withstand such monkeyshines. And the Machine, in its own finely\r\ncalibrated way, ignored its harassers, for they had no resemblance to\r\nthe Life it had been tuned to influence.\r\n\r\nDays lengthened into decades, eons. The seas came shouldering in to\r\nstand towers tall above the Ethics Ray, lost in the far ooze below.\r\nThen even the seas receded, and the mountains buckled upward in their\r\nplace, their arrogant stone faces staring changelessly across the\r\nepochs. Until they too were whittled down by erosion. The ice caps\r\ncrept down, crackling and grinding the valleys. The ground stretched\r\nand tossed like a restless sleeper, settled, and the Ethics Ray was\r\nbrought to light once more.\r\n\r\nAs it always had, it continued beaming its particular signal, on\r\na cosmic ray carrier modulated by a pulse a particular number of\r\nangstroms below infrared. The beasts that blundered within its field\r\nwere entirely different now, but they still weren\'t the Right Ones.\r\nAmong them were some shambling pale bipeds, dressed in skins of other\r\nbeasts, who clucked over its gleaming exterior and tried to chip it\r\naway for spearheads. In this of course they were unsuccessful.\r\n\r\nAnd then one day the First Human wandered by, paused square in the\r\npath of the beam. His physiology was only approximate, his I.Q. was\r\nregrettably low--but he was Pre-Moral Life, such as it was, on this\r\nplanet.\r\n\r\nThe Ethics Ray made the necessary frequency adjustments, tripped on\r\nfull force. The Primitive froze under the bombardment, its germ plasm\r\nshifting in the most minute and subtle dimensions. Then, its mission\r\nfulfilled, the Ethics Ray collapsed into heavy molecules and sank into\r\nthe ground. The first convert raced away in fright, having no idea what\r\nhad happened. Neither did his billion sons and daughters....\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBack on the home base, the Conductor reported in at the Ethication of\r\nPrimitive Planets office. It was a magnificently imposing building,\r\nas befitting the moral seat of the universe. And the Overseer was an\r\nequally imposing human with ears greyed by service. His congratulations\r\nwere unreserved.\r\n\r\n"A splendid mission, lad," he said, "and I don\'t mind\r\nsuggesting--strictly entre nous--that it could jolly well result in a\r\nFleet Conductorship for you."\r\n\r\nThe Conductor was overwhelmed.\r\n\r\n"Now just let me jot down the essentials while they\'re still fresh in\r\nmind," he continued, pawing through a desk drawer. "Botheration! 

I seem\r\nto have traded the last of my styluses. Do you happen to have one on\r\nyou?"\r\n\r\n"With pleasure." The Conductor handed over his monogrammed gold stylus,\r\nreceiving in exchange a toy silencemaker.\r\n\r\n"My youngster traded it to me this morning," the Overseer chuckled.\r\n\r\nHe wrote rapidly for several moments, then gave the stylus back. The\r\nConductor found a weathered paper-weight in his rear pocket, which he\r\ntraded him for it. It looked like it might have come from this very\r\ndesk at one time. Then with a smart salute, he about-faced.\r\n\r\nOn the way out, a pair of secretaries paused in their trading of a pelt\r\nbrush for a tail-curler to watch him admiringly. As well they might.\r\nFleet Conductor!\r\n\r\nThe future Fleet Conductor of a solar system he would never think of\r\ncalling Antares paused at the door. In its polished panel he regarded\r\nhimself with due appreciation. He had sown the seeds of civilization on\r\na far-flung planet where, countless light years from now, they would\r\nflower to maturity. Not among the strongest or cleverest species, to\r\nbe sure, but among those most worthy of applying First Principles, the\r\nmoral law of give and take.\r\n\r\nAmong those remote cousins of the Conductor himself--who under no\r\ncircumstances would ever think of himself as resembling a rather\r\noversized trader rat.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


"\r\n\r\nDarquelnoy clicked his eyes in despair. "Those _things_!" he cried.\r\n"Those annoying little creatures on that blasted planet up there!"\r\n\r\nEbor repressed an amused ripple. He knew Darquelnoy well enough to\r\nknow that the commander invariably overstated things. "What\'ve they\r\nbeen up to, Dar?" 

he asked. "Come on, you can tell me over a hot cup\r\nof restno."\r\n\r\n"I\'ve been practically living on the stuff for the last two dren,"\r\nsaid Darquelnoy hopelessly. "Well, I suppose another cup won\'t kill\r\nme. 

Come on to my quarters."\r\n\r\n"I\'ve worked up a fine thirst on the trip," Ebor told him.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe two walked down the long corridor together and Ebor said, "Well?\r\nWhat happened?"\r\n\r\n"They came here," Darquelnoy told him simply. At Ebor\'s shocked look,\r\nhe rippled in wan amusement and said, "Oh, it wasn\'t as bad as it\r\nmight have been, I suppose. It was just that we had to rush around so\r\nfrantically, unloading and dismantling the dome, getting this place\r\nready--"\r\n\r\n"What do you mean, they _came_ here?" demanded Ebor.\r\n\r\n"They are absolutely the worst creatures for secrecy in the entire\r\ngalaxy!" exclaimed Darquelnoy in irritation. "Absolutely the worst."\r\n\r\n"Then you\'ve picked up at least one of their habits," Ebor told him.\r\n"Now stop talking in circles and tell me what happened."\r\n\r\n"They built a spaceship, is the long and the short of it," Darquelnoy\r\nanswered.\r\n\r\nEbor stopped in astonishment. "No!"\r\n\r\n"Don\'t tell me no!" cried Darquelnoy. "I _saw_ it!" He was obviously\r\nat his wit\'s end.\r\n\r\n"It\'s unbelievable," said Ebor.\r\n\r\n"I know," said Darquelnoy. He led the way into his quarters, motioned\r\nEbor to a perch, and rang for his orderly. "It was just a little\r\nremote-controlled apparatus, of course," he said. 

"The fledgling\r\nattempt, you know. But it circled this Moon here, busily taking\r\npictures, and went right back to the planet again, giving us all a\r\nterrible fright. There hadn\'t been the slightest indication they were\r\nplanning anything _that_ spectacular."\r\n\r\n"None?" asked Ebor. "Not a hint?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, they\'ve been boasting about doing some such thing for ages,"\r\nDarquelnoy told him. "But there was never any indication that they\r\nwere finally serious about it. They have all sorts of military\r\nsecrecy, of course, and so you never know a thing is going to happen\r\nuntil it does."\r\n\r\n"Did they get a picture of the dome?"\r\n\r\n"Thankfully, no. 

And before they had a chance to try again, I whipped\r\neverything underground."\r\n\r\n"It must have been hectic," Ebor said sympathetically.\r\n\r\n"It was," said Darquelnoy simply.\r\n\r\nThe orderly entered. Darquelnoy told him, "Two restno," and he left\r\nagain.\r\n\r\n"I can\'t imagine them making a spaceship," said Ebor thoughtfully. "I\r\nwould have thought they\'d have blown themselves up long before\r\nreaching that stage."\r\n\r\n"I would have thought so, too," said Darquelnoy. "But there it is. At\r\nthe moment, they\'ve divided themselves into two camps--generally\r\nspeaking, that is--and the two sides are trying like mad to outdo each\r\nother in everything. As a part of it, they\'re shooting all sorts of\r\nrubbish into space and crowing every time a piece of the other side\'s\r\nrubbish malfunctions."\r\n\r\n"They could go on that way indefinitely," said Ebor.\r\n\r\n"I know," said Darquelnoy gloomily. "And here we sit."\r\n\r\nEbor nodded, studying his friend. "You don\'t suppose this is all a\r\nwaste of time, do you?" he asked, after a minute.\r\n\r\nDarquelnoy shook a tentacle in negation. "Not at all, not at all.\r\nThey\'ll get around to it, sooner or later. They\'re still boasting\r\nthemselves into the proper frame of mind, that\'s all."\r\n\r\nEbor rippled in sympathetic amusement. "\r\n\r\n"A relief for you, eh?" said Ebor.\r\n\r\n"You know," said Darquelnoy thoughtfully, "I can\'t help thinking I was\r\nborn in the wrong age. All this scrabbling around, searching\r\neverywhere for suitable planets.

(The relatives\r\nusually take care of all that.) He made a lovely corpse--considering everything.\r\n\r\nIt was the day following the funeral when there came a gentle tapping\r\nat my office door.\r\n\r\n"Come in," I said, tossing the half-finished bottle of gin back into\r\nthe lower drawer.\r\n\r\nThey didn\'t bother about opening the door; they just crawled under it.\r\nA moment later, they had slithered across the floor, had wiggled their\r\nway up to the top on my desk, and had flattened out upon its polished\r\nsurface in complete pseudopod relaxation. Gyf and Gyl. My two very good\r\nfriends.\r\n\r\n"Sorry, boys," I said, after we had exchanged the usual amenities,\r\n"that I had to get rid of your symbiotics in such a messy fashion. "It upsets me frightfully."\r\n\r\n"Time and the rising tide of accidents will tell," I soothed.\r\n\r\n"I\'m cold," trembled Gyf, "since I ain\'t got no body to keep me warm."\r\n\r\n"You might try my secretary," I offered, playfully. "\r\n\r\nHe instantly became all ears.

]\r\n\r\n\r\nColen Shratt studied his image in the silver-framed mirror. he\r\nsaid.\r\n\r\nBarnes sat down, gulped noisily. "I\'m listening."\r\n\r\n"We\'re going to have a visitor from the planet Mars. Now supposedly,\r\nthey will be on a friendly mission. We were behind the times, our scientists were incredibly\r\nstupid, our military men were old ladies and our industry was only fit\r\nto make children\'s toys.\r\n\r\nHidden microphones revealed all this.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Everything has gone according to plan," Captain Shratt told Barnes the\r\nday the Martians blasted off for their home planet. "We\'ve nothing to\r\nworry about.

"\r\n\r\n"I\'m glad. I\'ve been on edge the whole time they were here."\r\n\r\n"I\'ve got reports to make out so I\'ll have to leave now. 

But we\'ll get\r\ntogether again sometime."\r\n\r\n"Certainly." Barnes shook hands and Shratt left the playwright\'s\r\napartment.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Hello, General," Captain Shratt said, entering his office. He took off\r\nhis cap, tossed it on a leather chair, and went behind his desk.\r\n\r\n"I\'ve come from the president," the general said. "He says the time has\r\ncome."\r\n\r\n"Good." Shratt sat down. "I wish I was coming along."\r\n\r\n"You\'re needed here. What about this fellow Barnes? He knows an awful\r\nlot."\r\n\r\n"We\'ve nothing to worry from him. Besides, once we\'ve started there\'s\r\nnothing anyone can do."\r\n\r\n"Our fleet of Space ships is ready to take off within hours."\r\n\r\n"It\'s best to wait till the Martian ship is well on its way. Thanks to a playwright and his sense of\r\ndevotion to earth."\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\n"Good morning, madam," Ira said. "I represent...."\r\n\r\n"We don\'t want any," said the women, easing the door shut.\r\n\r\nWith the time tested finesse of door-to-door salesmen, Ira slipped his\r\nsize twelve shoe between the swinging door and the jamb. "Whatever it is, we don\'t want\r\nany.

"\r\n\r\n"I represent U.S. Robot Company," Ira persisted. He smiled pleasantly.\r\nHis unyielding foot maintained a six inch wide avenue of communication\r\nbetween himself and the woman in the house. She was\r\npretty and petite and very young; and, from her appearance, had never\r\ndone a day\'s work in her life. 

A typical newlywed, Ira thought. A\r\nperfect prospect, he decided.\r\n\r\n"As you undoubtedly know, the outstanding characteristics of U.S.\r\nRobot mechanicals have always been ability, durability and reliability.\r\nTheir performance in industry has earned for the United States Robot\r\nCompany the enviable reputation it is proud to possess: \'Leader in the\r\nart, artist of the trade--if it\'s U.S. Robot, it\'s perfect!\'"\r\n\r\nThe woman smiled and allowed the door to swing open slightly. Why...."\r\n\r\n"I think," the woman tried to interrupt, "that some of...."\r\n\r\n"How can you compare them to U.S. Robot?" 

Ira ran on. "We have had\r\nforty-seven years of experience in producing mechanicals for the most\r\ndifficult jobs imaginable. Amalgamated Androids while producing an\r\nadequate household model, does not have the valuable know-how to build\r\ninto their mechanicals the strength and quality that is taken for\r\ngranted in every machine bearing the U.S. Robot label."\r\n\r\nThe woman was skeptical. And Amalgamated Androids are specialists in building humanoid\r\nrobots, while your company...."\r\n\r\n"But, madam," Ira said, grinning. "Our household models are perfectly\r\nhuman in appearance--I should say, _im_perfectly human because we even\r\ngive them tiny blemishes to make them seem more natural."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe woman was obviously unconvinced. Ira applied the clincher. "What\r\ngreater proof could you want than this?" He held up his left hand,\r\nbaring his wrist so that she could read his identification stamp.\r\n\r\n    _Model I (Masc.)_\r\n    _Serial No. 27146 12V_\r\n    _U.S. ROBOT CO., INC._\r\n\r\nThe woman\'s eyes widened. Her face took on an expression of delighted\r\nsurprise.\r\n\r\n"What better proof could you want?" Ira repeated. "Do I look like a\r\nrobot? 

Am I not a perfect humanoid? Here," he said, extending his hand,\r\n"feel my skin and see if it isn\'t just like a man\'s."\r\n\r\nThe woman gingerly touched his hand. 

Her eyes mirrored her\r\nsatisfaction.\r\n\r\nIra pressed his advantage. "Model I robots come in both masculine and\r\nfeminine designs, built to your individual specifications as to size,\r\ncoloring, strength, personality traits, apparent age, and so forth. For\r\nexample, lonely people can have companionship built in, if they like.\r\nYou can have an Ira or Inez possessing an almost human intelligence and\r\nfree choice, or you can get one that is blindly servile and which will\r\nnever volunteer advice or information. She was looking at him in a\r\npeculiar way. Knowing that he was a robot, she seemed to be appraising\r\nhim as she would a man. Ira noted her odd reaction and puzzled over it.\r\nIt usually went the other way--women lost interest in him when they\r\nlearned that he was not a man.\r\n\r\n"Why don\'t you come inside," the woman suggested suddenly, opening the\r\ndoor for him.\r\n\r\nIra smiled at her graciously and went into the house. It was conceivably dangerous to be alone in the\r\nhouse with a handsome man. But, if he\'s a robot, she has nothing to\r\nfear--from him or herself.\r\n\r\n"Sit down," the woman said, "and rest a while."\r\n\r\n"Thank you, madam." 

He sat. "But, of course, I don\'t need the rest.\r\nModel I\'s can do strenuous work for twenty-three out of every\r\ntwenty-four hours. In fact, in laboratory tests, they\'ve been run for\r\none hundred and eighty-six hours continuously, without a breakdown."\r\n\r\nHe was back in his sales pitch. "Work is the basic function of all\r\nU.S. Robot Company robots. With all their esthetic perfection, the\r\nhousehold models are no exception to this rule. They are unequaled in\r\nefficient performance. Power is the keynote of the Model I."\r\n\r\nHe opened his demonstration case and removed a steel bar, three inches\r\nin diameter. Placing one hand on each end, he bent the metal into a V.\r\n\r\n"The heart of the mechanism," he went on, "is a powerful twelve volt\r\nA-battery, perfectly shielded and guaranteed to give trouble-free\r\nservice for at least forty years. Sixteen motor centers are fed by\r\nthe central power plant, all coordinated and synchronized by the best\r\nflui-electronic brain ever devised. Sturdy TS steel alloy construction\r\nover all gives the Model I its phenomenal strength and durability. Lips slightly parted, she watched\r\nIra attentively and listened breathlessly to everything he said.\r\nInstinctively, he felt that he had made a sale. But the woman said\r\nnothing; only gazed at him in a way that might have been covetous,\r\nmight have been adoring or might have been merely symptomatic of\r\nhypnosis.\r\n\r\n"May I demonstrate the I\'s power and versatility in practical\r\nperformance?" Ira asked. Taking her silence to be consent, he swung\r\ninto his demonstration.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nSwiftly, surely, he went about the room, cleaning. "\r\n\r\nThe woman cocked her head to a side. "I don\'t hear _anything_," she\r\nsaid.\r\n\r\nIra smiled triumphantly. "Of course, you don\'t! Come here," he said.\r\n"Put your ear to my chest and you\'ll just be able to make it out."\r\n\r\nShe rested her head on his chest and listened. The delicate fragrance\r\nof her perfume mingled with that sweet human scent that not even\r\nthe Model I robots could imitate. Ira bent his head and brushed his\r\nsensitized cheek against her hair. He felt emotions that no robot\r\nshould feel.\r\n\r\nHe silently cursed his makers and the wonderfully human brain they had\r\ngiven him. Their theory was that a salesman, to be effective, should\r\nthink exactly like a human being. To better satisfy the customers, he\r\nshould appreciate every human drive and desire. But it was wrong to\r\nfeel like a man, to desire like a man, to hurt like a man and be unable\r\nto ease the pain because he was not a man! For once, U.S. Robot had\r\ngone too far!\r\n\r\nThe woman looked up at him with the eyes that broadcast adoration.\r\n"You\'re wonderful!" she repeated. 

"Do you think...?" She hesitated,\r\nlooked away. "Could I be in love with you?" she asked with child-like\r\ninnocence. I only work here.

"\r\n\r\nGone was his exultant feeling, gone the light-headedness. Only the\r\nmisery and weakness remained in the realization that his yearning was\r\nimpossible of fulfillment and that, to top it off, he had wasted his\r\ntime trying to sell himself to a servant.\r\n\r\n"Do you think I could?" the maid repeated.\r\n\r\n"Could what?"\r\n\r\n"Be in love with you."\r\n\r\n"But, miss don\'t you understand? Then, she held up her right hand,\r\nrevealing the identification stamp on her wrist.\r\n\r\n    _Model M (fem.)_\r\n    _Serial No. 6139 12V_\r\n    _AMALGAMATED ANDROIDS, INC._\r\n\r\nA moment later the android was in his arms. "When our companies built us they made\r\nus as near human as possible--perhaps too much so. If we can work\r\nfor humans we can also live like them. U.S. Robots and Amalgamated\r\nAndroids have just lost two employees. Your bag."\r\n\r\nBeing an android she could work faster than any human counter-part; her\r\nbag was packed in nothing flat.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nWhy me? Why, out of 300 billion people on earth, why did they have to\r\npick on _me_?\r\n\r\nAnd if it had to happen, why couldn\'t it have happened before I met\r\nBetty and fell in love with her? You see, Betty and I were to be\r\nmarried tomorrow. We _were_ to have been married. Tomorrow.\r\n\r\nTomorrow, indeed! What a ghastly thought that is! How can I explain\r\nto Betty--to anyone! I can\'t face her, and what could I say on the\r\ntelephone? "Sorry, Betty, I can\'t marry you. I\'m no longer--quite\r\nhuman."\r\n\r\nQuit joking, Kelley! This is for real. 

You\'re sober and awake and it\r\ndid happen. Marrying Betty is out of the question even if she\'d have\r\nyou the way you are. You\'re not _that_ two-faced!\r\n\r\nQuit standing in front of the mirror, naked and shaking, looking\r\nfor scars, counting your fingers and toes. You\'ve taken a hundred\r\ninventories, and it always comes out wrong. And it always will,\r\nunless ... unless _they_ come back. But that\'s hopeless. They\'d never\r\nfind me again. Not out of all the people on earth. 

Besides, they\r\ndidn\'t seem to give a damn. No more than a kid gives a damn what\r\nhappens to a lump of modelling clay when he gets bored squeezing it\r\ninto this shape and that.\r\n\r\nWhere did they come from? Or, judging from their "talk," _when_ did\r\nthey come from? And would it do me any good if I knew?\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI was sitting there in my bachelor apartment, drinking a can of\r\nbeer and trying to work a crossword puzzle to get sleepy. I wasn\'t\r\nespecially jittery like the groom is always supposed to be on the eve\r\nof his wedding. Just wide awake at midnight, wanting to get sleepy so I\r\ncould get some real rest when I went to bed.\r\n\r\nJust sitting there trying to think of a two-letter word for "sun-god."\r\nAnd that made me think of the gold in Betty\'s hair when the sun was on\r\nit at the beach. And pretty soon I was just staring into space, aching\r\nfor Betty, wishing the next twelve hours of my life would vanish and we\r\ncould be together, heading for our little cottage at the lake.\r\n\r\nStaring into space.... Then it wasn\'t just space. There were these two\r\nbig ball bearings in front of me, about three feet in diameter, if you\r\ncould say they had a diameter. They looked like ball bearings because\r\ntheir surfaces were shiny, mirrorlike steel. But they had unevenly\r\nspaced, smooth bumps. Something like the random knobs on a potato, so\r\nthey weren\'t really round at all.\r\n\r\nThe light from my lamp reflected crazily, and my own image gaped back\r\nat me from their distorted, reflecting curves. Like the fun-mirrors at\r\nthe crazy-house, only crazier ... and not funny at all. Fear is never\r\nfunny. And I was afraid. I\'ll swear I could _taste_ the terror. It was\r\nsalty on my tongue. When I tried to cry out, the roof of my mouth felt\r\nlike old concrete.\r\n\r\nThen one of them spoke. "It\'s alive! Intelligent! It senses our\r\npresence!"\r\n\r\nI was receiving pure thought, not words. But man thinks only in words.\r\nAnd their thoughts fished suitable words from my subconscious to frame\r\nthem for my assimilation.\r\n\r\nTelepathy? Impossible! What common points of reference could I have\r\nwith these two unthinkably alien life-forms?\r\n\r\nThe answer whipped back at me on an intuitive, sub-vocal level: Thought\r\nis a universal energy manifestation. _Language is only the clumsy\r\nvehicle for thought._\r\n\r\nBetween me and the aliens lay no such barrier.\r\n\r\n"Obviously intelligent," the other agreed. "Feel those gamma\r\nradiations? Too bad they\'re so weak. It would be interesting if he\r\ncould communicate with us."\r\n\r\nI stammered aloud, "But--but I _can_ communicate with you. I understand\r\nevery--"\r\n\r\nThey were paying no attention to my raspy words. "Yes, that\'s typical\r\nof these ancient, organic life-forms. As I recall, they use some form\r\nof physical vibration of their gaseous medium for communicating among\r\nthemselves--"\r\n\r\n"Speaking of which," the other interrupted, "this particular gaseous\r\nmedium seems to contain oxygen. We\'d best not remain overlong or we\'ll\r\ncorrode and catch hell when we return.

"\r\n\r\n"Exude a little nickel if it irritates you. We\'ll catch hell anyway\r\nwhen mother--"\r\n\r\nYes, that\'s the word that came to me!\r\n\r\n"--discovers _when_ we\'ve been. I\'m curious about these flesh and blood\r\ncreatures. I wonder who invented this clumsy monstrosity."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe meant me. 

He rolled a foot nearer, and the other followed with an\r\nuncertain wobble. "I turned out better in the third grade."\r\n\r\n"Liar! You nearly flunked meta-plastics."\r\n\r\n"Well, you did flunk it, so who are you to--?"\r\n\r\n"Just don\'t be over-critical. I think this one looks fairly practical.\r\nWell-balanced--"\r\n\r\n"That\'s just what I mean. Observe the unimaginative bisymmetry. Two\r\narms, two legs, two eyes, five fingers on each hand, five toes on each\r\nfoot. Surely, the inventor was a mechanic and no artist. In this light\r\ngravity there was no need for--"\r\n\r\n"And how would you improve the design, your high-and-mightiness?

"\r\n\r\n"First let\'s remove the covering."\r\n\r\nMy clothes left my body gently, but with the sound of violent tearing.\r\nIn two seconds I sat naked, my garments laid back like split bandages.\r\n\r\nI shouted, "See here, for God\'s sakes!"\r\n\r\nThe aliens had made no visible move, yet they had wielded powerful\r\nforces to strip everything I wore from my body, shirt, slacks,\r\nunderwear and even my shoes ... without so much as pinching my flesh.\r\n\r\nI leaped to my feet naked as a straw. They were between me and the\r\ndoor, but they seemed so clumsy.\r\n\r\n"Watch it! 

He\'s alarmed. Don\'t let him escape!"\r\n\r\n"Try and stop me!" I screamed, tensing my muscles for a leap over the\r\npair of intruders. Suddenly the air about my sweating body seemed to\r\nthicken to the viscosity of molasses. I could breathe it all right, but\r\nquick motion was denied me. My grand leap died before my right foot\r\nleft the floor. I retreated to my chair in slow-motion panic, sinking\r\nslowly through the clabbered atmosphere, to a sitting position on my\r\ntorn clothing.\r\n\r\n"Yes, a very clumsy, unesthetic life-form. In fact the bisymmetry\r\nfairly nauseates me. Granted that the two arms are practical, doubtless\r\none or the other does 90% of all work. So why have them of equal\r\nimportance? See here, I\'ll demonstrate...."\r\n\r\n"Wait!" 

the other cautioned. "This is a sentient creature. You can\'t\r\noperate without...."\r\n\r\n"Of course not!"\r\n\r\nSomething buzzed in my spine, and I blanked out. For the space of one\r\nbreath, it seemed.\r\n\r\n"There, that\'s better."\r\n\r\n"I guess I must agree with you."\r\n\r\nA faint tingle in my left arm caused me to stare at it. Unbelievingly!\r\nIts length was the same, but its diameter was reduced to two-thirds,\r\nand there were two fingers missing on the hand. The opposable thumb\r\nremained, but it now had more the appearance of a claw than a human\r\nhand. I tried to scream, but the sound was a glutinous bubble of air\r\nthat never reached my lips.\r\n\r\n"How about the pedal appendages?"\r\n\r\n"Well--" there was some hesitation. "Considering the method of\r\nlocomotion, bisymmetry seems more justified there. However, why\r\nbilateral? Why not quadrilateral?"\r\n\r\n"Because the organs of sight face only one way.

"\r\n\r\n"I can fix that, too."\r\n\r\nMy spine buzzed, and when I looked down again a flood of peculiar\r\nchanges had taken place. My ankles terminated in the middle of my feet,\r\nand my heels had disappeared. In their place were toes.\r\n\r\n"You see, with the double-hinged knee-joint, he can travel forward or\r\nbackward now without pivoting...."\r\n\r\nThen I became aware that I could _look_ forward and backward at the\r\nsame time.\r\n\r\n"That thing in the middle is certainly superfluous."\r\n\r\n"Yes."\r\n\r\nBuzz!\r\n\r\nIt was gone.\r\n\r\n"A tentacle fastened, say, to the right hip-bone could be very useful."\r\n\r\nBuzz!\r\n\r\nMy right hip tingled. From it protruded a whip-like appendage some\r\neight feet long, brown and leathery, tapering to the diameter of a\r\npencil and terminating in a pink flesh-pad richly supplied with sensory\r\nbuds. I could feel every hair in the nap of the carpet on which it\r\nrested--feel, taste, smell and hear! Four sense organs in one!\r\n\r\n"Now we are making progress!" came the exclamation.\r\n\r\nBuzz! 

Buzz! Buzz!\r\n\r\nThe instant-seeming anesthetic moments came upon me in quick\r\nsuccession, and each left me bereft of some standard, human equipment\r\nor in the possession of some extra-normal addition to my anatomy--with\r\nno more sensation than the slight tingle I have mentioned.\r\n\r\nFrom their mental remarks I conclude that I lost my vermiform appendix,\r\ntonsils and a mole on my left shoulder blade. Most of the other items\r\nwhich I acquired were too grotesque to describe further.\r\n\r\n"The two additional cardiac structures and the adrenal adjustments\r\nshould assure some likelihood of immortality," one of the intruders was\r\nexplaining.\r\n\r\n"Which would probably bring about over-population in ten generations,"\r\nthe other reminded him.\r\n\r\n"Ah, yes. I should compensate for that.

"\r\n\r\nBuzz, and he did!\r\n\r\n"I\'m corroding."\r\n\r\n"Exude some chrome as I told you."\r\n\r\n"I think I hear mother calling, anyway. Let\'s go before she--"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThey were too late. A third bumpy ball-bearing materialized behind the\r\ntwo aliens, and instantly a barrage of maternal scolding dominated the\r\nether. "I\'ve been searching the whole continuum for you two! What are\r\nyou doing back here?"\r\n\r\n"We were just about to return, Mother."\r\n\r\n"That\'s the truth, Mother. We just broke through here so we could\r\npractice our advanced--"\r\n\r\n"Practice!" Mother exclaimed. "Practice on this poor, primitive,\r\norganic creature?"\r\n\r\nI felt poor and primitive indeed. My hand dropped\r\nto my right hip.\r\n\r\nThe tentacle was gone.\r\n\r\n"Thank God!" I breathed, and for an instant my common sense tried to\r\ninsist that I had merely fallen asleep for a few minutes and dreamed\r\nthe whole fantastic sequence.\r\n\r\nBut no! Why would I be stark naked? And why were my clothes lying\r\nruined in my chair like bandages split with a huge razor?\r\n\r\nI clenched my left fist and gained comfort from the reassuring pressure\r\nof four fingers and a thumb in my palm. But then I stepped into my\r\nbedroom and stood before my full-length mirror--where I have stood\r\nrooted ever since.\r\n\r\nAnd the question revolves in my brain, punctuated only by my profanity\r\nand sobs of despair. How can I marry Betty now? How can I face her, let\r\nalone marry her?\r\n\r\nWhat woman on earth could bring herself to marry a man with no\r\nnavel ... and two heads?\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


"\r\n\r\n"You mean, you cook?" He stared in awe.\r\n\r\n"I\'m making a cake," she breathed, inching closer.\r\n\r\nHe backed out of the doorway and she entered. Without giving him\r\nanother glance, she went to the pneumatic, cut in the phone and ordered\r\na pound of sugar. She turned back to him.\r\n\r\n"It shouldn\'t be a minute. I\'ll wait--if you don\'t mind."\r\n\r\nHe had tried to keep himself from studying her. Despite this, his\r\neyes told him that her figure was just about perfect and as both a\r\ncounteraction and a stimulant to the mounting tension in him, her smile\r\nwas surprisingly bright and full. There was little danger of the flavor\r\nof her warpaint confusing a man. She wore little, if any. Her bright\r\nlips and cheeks seemed to need no added color.\r\n\r\n"Don\'t bother to stand," she said considerately. She waited until he\r\nhad lowered himself to the couch, then dropped down beside him, a\r\ntrifle too close to allow him to put his mind on other things.\r\n\r\n"I hope I haven\'t troubled you." Her hand brushed his.\r\n\r\n"Not at all." He drew his hand away.\r\n\r\n"From the looks of your side-board," she went on cheerily, "you were\r\njust getting ready to mix a drink. I\'m an expert. Shall I mix a couple?"\r\n\r\nHe resisted the inclination to rise when she did, and deliberately kept\r\nhis eyes from following her. He snatched up the paper, rustled it\r\nnoisily and tried to concentrate on the headlines.\r\n\r\nTwo things distracted him. One was the faint scent of perfume and the\r\nother was the chinking of ice and glasses. He put the paper aside,\r\ntried to put his mind on distant things. 

This soon palled. He was about\r\nto get up and pace the floor when she returned and handed him a cool\r\nglass.\r\n\r\n"Thanks," he said and leaned back.\r\n\r\nShe sat down again, so close that her shoulder brushed his. He\r\nedged over against the arm of the couch, putting an inch of space\r\nbetween them, glanced sidelong at her, and drank. He rolled his eyes\r\nceiling-ward, smacked his lips and drank again.\r\n\r\n"What did you put in it?"\r\n\r\n"About a spoonful of creme de menthe, a couple drops of bitters and\r\nabout two ounces of rye. Like it?"\r\n\r\nHe scowled deliberately, armoring himself against his feelings. "It\'s\r\nfair--for a woman\'s mixings. You should have put in more liquor."\r\n\r\n"Of course. 

I\'ll learn."\r\n\r\n"Not from me," he snapped. "I\'m a woman-hater."\r\n\r\nShe leaned toward him. 

"Why?"\r\n\r\nHe tossed off the balance of the drink, set the glass on the table and\r\nmade a sweeping gesture. "They\'re all alike," he said brutally. "Fickle\r\nand treacherous. Deceivers. Always flinging their sex around."\r\n\r\n"Not all women," she countered. "Take this Professor Madigan who\r\ndiscovered that new adhesion force."\r\n\r\n"A woman?"\r\n\r\n"Of course. Professor Madigan is a scholarly young woman. Her sex\r\nappeal might not win a beauty contest, but she discovered a perfectly\r\nwonderful man-catcher."\r\n\r\n"What?"\r\n\r\n"A new force. Works like gravity--only it\'s different. Its strength\r\nincreases in ratio to the square of the distance."\r\n\r\n"What are you talking about? Women don\'t understand things like that."\r\n\r\n"No?"\r\n\r\n"No! Need I spell it out for you? Your delivery should be in the\r\npneumatic by now. Why don\'t you pick it up and go home and make your\r\ncake?"\r\n\r\n"I shall. I had no idea I was living next door to a misogynist, and a\r\nbrutal one at that."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t like women," Kerran said emphatically. "They\'re all alike.\r\nFickle. Deceivers. Everything about them artificial. Lips, color,\r\nshape."\r\n\r\nThe girl rose and stood over him. "I\'m not wearing make-up," she\r\nasserted. "You flatter yourself in thinking I would put on my face to\r\ncome across the hall."\r\n\r\n"Your shape! Your hips aren\'t that neat!"\r\n\r\nThe color rose in her cheeks. She lifted a hand as though to strike\r\nhim. The hand trembled. She lowered it to her side. "I do not wear a\r\ngirdle. Want to feel?"\r\n\r\n"No," he said, his own color rising. 

"Go on home."\r\n\r\nIgnoring the pneumatic, she crossed to the door, snatched it open,\r\nmarched into the corridor. Through the open doorway he heard the knob\r\nturn on her door. He went to the pneumatic, picked up the sugar, strode\r\nacross the corridor and knocked. In a moment her head appeared, then\r\nthe door swung wide.\r\n\r\n"You forgot something," he said contritely. "Sorry I was rude. I\'m\r\na natural woman-hater, and a moment before you came in some wench\r\non television triggered my feelings on the subject.... Just keep on\r\nyour own side of the fence and I\'ll stay on mine. I\'ll even speak\r\nto you occasionally, if you wish, but that\'s as far as I\'ll go in\r\nneighborliness."\r\n\r\n"Thanks," she said. "You\'re more than kind. But I shan\'t trouble you.\r\nI\'ve just become a man-hater."\r\n\r\nKerran turned to go. Halfway across the corridor he felt something tug\r\nat him. It was a steady and increasingly powerful pull, forcing him\r\ninto the girl\'s apartment. He lost his balance, reeled through the\r\ndoorway, came to a halt against the table, noticed that the force still\r\ndrew him toward the girl on the far side of the table.\r\n\r\n"Well?" she said.\r\n\r\n"Er-uh, just dropped in. 

Going right back out."\r\n\r\nHe got halfway to the door before it again took effect. He leaned\r\nagainst it, dug his feet into the carpet, pushed. He almost reached the\r\ndoor. He could go no farther, knew he was going to be snatched back to\r\nthe table.\r\n\r\nHe turned, dug in his heels, braced himself, and then the girl came\r\nflying over the table and directly into his arms. Instantly the force\r\nreleased him and he fell with the girl on top.\r\n\r\nThe platinum hair was in his eyes, against his face, the scent of\r\nperfume all about, the full weight of the soft warm flesh pressing him\r\ndown. Then she struggled up, stood erect.\r\n\r\nGetting his feet under him, he said, "I want to apologize. Your shape\r\nis natural. You don\'t wear a girdle. And now I\'ll be going.

"\r\n\r\nHe had scarcely turned before he felt it again. He swung back quickly,\r\nsaw that the girl was hanging on the sofa. He lost his balance, went\r\nstaggering toward her, flung out his arms, and the next thing he knew\r\nshe was pressing against him, standing on her toes, and her lips were\r\nbrushing his cheek, and they were moist and warm and soft.\r\n\r\nShe drew back and said, belligerently, "I wish you\'d get out of here."\r\n\r\nHe started again, hesitated when he felt the force, turned back. "I\'ve\r\nheard of magnetic women," he said with restraint. "I never believed in\r\nit. But now--" He gestured vaguely. "Please turn off your charms."\r\n\r\nShe lowered her eyes. "I thought it was you. I\'ve been drawn to you\r\nfrom the first and I thought you\'d suddenly become irresistible. Do you\r\nmean you feel it too?"\r\n\r\nHe nodded. "I\'ve read about magnetic women in the best books. Now, dash\r\nit, turn it off! I\'m getting tired of hanging around here."\r\n\r\n"It\'s you," she insisted. "You turn it off."\r\n\r\nHe shook his head. "I\'m plain as an old shoe. 

Everybody knows. But you!\r\nOne look at you and anybody\'d know you\'ve got this magnetism. That\'s\r\nwhy I had to be so brutal. It was the only way I could resist and keep\r\nmy woman-hating integrity. I can feel your magnetism now. It\'s getting\r\nstronger."\r\n\r\n"And I feel yours. It\'s pulling me right into your arms."\r\n\r\n"Stay back. I can\'t stand much more. I\'m a confirmed misogynist, and if\r\nyou keep on I\'ll have to go against my principles, and that wouldn\'t be\r\nhonest."\r\n\r\n"I can\'t help it," she murmured from two feet away. "I can\'t resist\r\nyou."\r\n\r\nKerran puzzled briefly. "Maybe that\'s it. I remember when I was\r\noverseas. 

But no! All they wanted was chewing gum and cigarets. Still,\r\nyou never can tell. 

Maybe it came on me suddenly. Maybe looking at you\r\nsort of triggered my magnetism."\r\n\r\nShe smiled. "If you\'ll quit looking at me maybe we can stop it. Look\r\nthe other way and I\'ll try to stop thinking about you because you do\r\nsomething to me."\r\n\r\nKerran nodded. "That\'s it. 

Beat it! 

I\'ll put my mind on something else."\r\n\r\nVisualizing a horse race in which he had his money on the bang-tail\r\njust ready to break the tape, he didn\'t feel the tug for several\r\nseconds. He struggled mightily but futilely to resist. He wound up in\r\nthe kitchen where the girl was holding onto the electric range.\r\n\r\n"You didn\'t play fair," he said accusingly. "Treacherous. 

Just like\r\nall your sex. You thought about me."\r\n\r\nShe lowered her eyes. "I--I just couldn\'t help it."\r\n\r\nKerran felt his chest expand involuntarily. "One of us is\r\nirresistible," he said. "It isn\'t you because I positively was not\r\nthinking about you. So it must be me." His chest expanded another inch.\r\n"I guess a girl who can\'t resist me would be true. And since we can\'t\r\nbeat this force, the only solution is to get married."\r\n\r\nShe nodded. "That\'s the only solution. But maybe I don\'t want to solve\r\nthe problem. 

You\'ll have to persuade me."\r\n\r\nThe voice from the television in the living room was barely audible in\r\nthe kitchen: "The new force was originally developed for the purpose\r\nof drawing troops into a compact group so they could be atom-bombed.\r\nProfessor Madigan refused to disclose its secret to be used for that\r\npurpose. She pointed out that it had a far more useful potential. A\r\nfield of it, built into a woman\'s garments, enables her to attract at\r\na distance the man of her choice. She can control this with a switch\r\nconveniently located in a pocket. 

Her own charms do the rest."\r\n\r\nKerran ignored the telecast. She was in his arms and he had his face\r\nhalf-buried in her silken hair. "I don\'t even know your name ..." he\r\nlaughed embarrassedly.\r\n\r\nHer voice was low and soft as she murmured, "Madigan--Joyce Madigan."\r\n\r\nHe stiffened suddenly. "You mean you\'re _Professor_ Madigan--"\r\n\r\nShe snuggled closer against him and somehow it didn\'t really seem to\r\nmatter now what her name was. "Let\'s say I _was_ Professor Madigan--a\r\nwoman\'s place is in the home, don\'t you agree?"\r\n\r\nAfter a few emphatic kisses he did.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


Something was haywire in the fuel system of his\r\nInterstar Runabout. 

He was losing altitude fast, so fast that all five\r\npairs of his eyes couldn\'t focus on a place to land.\r\n\r\nFive pairs of arms, each pair about three feet apart on the loglike\r\nbody, pushed buttons and rotated controls frantically, but to no avail.\r\nIn a few short minutes it would all be over for Probos Five. Even if by\r\nsome miracle he remained unhurt after crashing, he would die shortly\r\nthereafter. The frigid climatic conditions of the third planet were\r\ndeadly to a Mercurian. He thought once of donning his space suit but\r\ndecided against it. 

That would merely prolong the agony. From Planet\r\nThree, when one has a smashed space cruiser, there is no return. Probos\r\nFive knew that death was riding with him in the helpless ship. The\r\nsituation did not unnecessarily dismay him; Mercurians are philosophers.\r\n\r\nProbos Five ceased to manipulate the unresponding controls. Stretching\r\nhis trunklike torso to its full twenty feet, four heads gazed through\r\nobservation ports at the four points of the compass while the remaining\r\nhead desultorily watched the instrument panel.\r\n\r\nSince die he must, Probos Five would meet his end stoically, and five\r\npairs of stumpy arms folded over five chests in a coordinated gesture of\r\nresignation.\r\n\r\nProbos Five thought fleetingly of his wife Lingua Four and remembered\r\nwith some annoyance that she was the author of his present predicament.\r\nA social climber, Probos Five thought to himself, but aside from that a\r\ngood wife and mother in addition to being a reigning beauty. Lingua Four\r\nwas tall even for a Mercurian. Already she scaled seven dergs, or in\r\nEarth terms, fourteen feet and was beginning to show evidences of a\r\nfifth head. Five heads were rarely found on females and Probos Five was\r\njustly proud of his good fortune. In all Mercury at the present time, he\r\nknew of but two females possessing five heads and soon Lingua Four would\r\nbe the third of her sex to be thus endowed.\r\n\r\nYes, thought Probos Five, a woman to be proud of; for today after three\r\nvargs of marriage the memory of her trim trunk with four pairs of eyes\r\nlaughing mischievously, filled his five brains with flame. Slim as a\r\nbirch she stood in his memory, and eight eyes whispered lovers\' thoughts\r\nacross space and time.\r\n\r\nProbos Five recalled his five minds from their nostalgic reverie and\r\ngazed at the contour of the Earth that was rushing up to meet him.\r\nWhite, blazing white reflecting the rays of the midnight sun covered the\r\nregion as far as the eye could reach.\r\n\r\n"Good," thought Probos Five, "the Polar regions. That means the end will\r\ncome quickly. One or two seconds at the most of that bitter cold would\r\nbe enough."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nTurning away from the windows Probos Five let his thoughts return to\r\nLingua Four, to Probos Two, his son, and his home on the first planet\r\nfrom the sun. Ah, that is the place to live, thought Probos, the\r\ntemperature an unchanging 327\xc2\xb0; just comfortably warm, where one could\r\nenjoy a life of warmth and ease. Too bad that he would not live to see\r\nit again. 

Thirty vargs, he reflected, is such a short time. With luck,\r\nperhaps he may have lived to see a hundred vargs slip by. And perhaps in\r\ntime he may have added three more heads and five dergs in length to his\r\ntowering trunk.\r\n\r\nHe thought of Probos Two and wondered idly if his son would also visit\r\nthe barbarian worlds to collect data for Lingua Four.\r\n\r\nHe wished that he could have seen more of Probos Two. There\'s an\r\nup-and-coming lad, he thought, not quite two vargs old and two heads\r\nalready. Yes, indeed, he\'s quite a boy, Probos Five remembered proudly;\r\nmaybe his mother will keep him at home instead of running him all over\r\nthe universe to get material for her committees.\r\n\r\nHe wished that Lingua Four would settle down and be content as a\r\nhousewife, but he doubted that she would. Social ambition was boring\r\nlike a termite under her bark.\r\n\r\nLingua Four was determined to be the first lady of Arbor, the capital\r\ncity of Mercury. To this end Lingua Four had labored unceasingly. She\r\nwas president of half the women\'s clubs of Arbor. She could always be\r\ndepended upon to furnish the best in new and diverting subjects.\r\n\r\nShe headed almost all committees for aid or research on any type of\r\nproblem. It was owing to Lingua Four being president of the Committee\r\nfor Undernourished Arborians that Probos Five was making this\r\nill-starred trip. His purpose was to capture a few of the upright,\r\ndivided trunk animals that inhabited the third planet.\r\n\r\nThey were to be transported to Mercury and given over to scientific\r\nstudy as to their edible qualities. If it were found that the divided\r\ntrunk creatures were fit for Mercurian consumption, the problem of\r\nundernourishment would no longer exist since the supply of divided\r\ntrunks was seemingly inexhaustible. Mercurians had made expeditions to\r\nthe third planet before and every report concluded with--"Divided trunk\r\ncreatures increasing in number."\r\n\r\nPrivately Probos Five doubted the possibility of using the divided\r\ntrunks for food, since the last expedition once again reported a\r\ncomplete lack of captives due to the frail and tenuous bodies of the\r\ndivided trunks. Then, too, transportation and preservation posed a\r\ntremendous problem, not to mention the difficulty of trying to eat\r\nsomething that might vaporize on your fork. But then these questions may\r\nnever arise, he decided, for of all the reports perused by Probos Five\r\nnot one expedition had succeeded in bringing a divided trunk to Mercury.\r\n\r\nAll reports were read to the last letter by Probos Five before\r\nassembling equipment for his own trip. In the reports he had noted many\r\nof the difficulties of the earlier missions. Planet Three was impossible\r\nfor a Mercurian without a heated space suit. The temperature of Planet\r\nThree was so low that it would literally freeze a Mercurian stiff in a\r\nmatter of seconds.\r\n\r\nThe casualties of the early expeditions had been numerous. Many\r\nMercurians had succumbed to the bitter cold due to flaws in space suits\r\nand other accidents. A break in the suit meant instant death. The\r\nvictims of such mishaps were invariably buried in the isolated, sparsely\r\ninhabited Polar regions to avoid alarming the divided trunk creatures.\r\n\r\nIt was strange, mused Probos Five, that the divided trunks were\r\nseemingly unable to bear the slightest increase in temperature. Their\r\nbodies disintegrated upon contact with a Mercurian. Some were roped and\r\ndragged from a distance up to the doors of the space ships, but no\r\ninhabitant of Planet Three had been closer to Mercury than the air lock\r\nof the space cruisers. As the divided trunk people were dragged into the\r\nair lock, warm air from the ship would be pumped into the lock to dispel\r\nthe frigid air of Planet Three. As the warmth of Mercury enveloped the\r\ndivided trunks they became quite red, began to melt and finally\r\ndissolved into a gaseous state, leaving a small pile of ashes and a\r\ndisagreeable odor in the air lock that sometimes lingered for days.\r\n\r\nProbos Five believed he had the solution for these obstacles in the path\r\nof scientific study of the divided trunks. He had decided to use guile\r\nin place of strength. 

For this reason he had come alone and in a small\r\nspace runabout to put his solution to the test. But his solution now\r\ncould never be tried, he remembered morosely.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIn the aft compartment Probos Five had constructed a refrigeration\r\nplant. By maintaining a constant degree of frigidity he hoped to deliver\r\na pair of each species of divided trunks to Mercury. He hoped especially\r\nto capture a complete set and perhaps a few over to make up for breakage\r\nand losses. As to what form of sustenance the divided trunks were\r\naccustomed to, he had no idea whatsoever. He had intended to bring\r\nsamples of earth, vegetation and anything else that may have suggested a\r\nsource of food for the divided trunks.\r\n\r\nThe thought too had occurred to him that possibly the divided trunk\r\ncreatures ate one another. On the possibility of this Probos Five had\r\ndetermined to capture three black ones, three white ones, three yellows,\r\nthree browns and three reds, and three of any other color that he might\r\nfind. He rather doubted that more colors or combination of colors\r\nexisted. All previous expedition reports had mentioned only the five\r\ncolors. However, Probos Five had determined to keep several eyes open on\r\nthe off chance that he might find a new and different species.\r\n\r\nHis refrigerator was modeled along the architectural lines of the dens\r\nof the divided trunks. The main room of the refrigerator opened to the\r\noutside of the ship by means of a small air lock. A Mercurian size air\r\nlock was not needed for the divided trunks, as few had been found to be\r\nmuch over three dergs in height.\r\n\r\nWinches and cables to pull the divided trunks into the refrigerator were\r\ninstalled in the refrigerator room itself to avoid burning the divided\r\ntrunks with hot cables from other parts of the ship.\r\n\r\nIn addition, Probos Five had cunningly devised a refrigerated trap. This\r\ntoo was designed to simulate the caves of the divided trunk creatures\r\nbut was smaller. It was constructed with entrances readily seen and\r\nexits well hidden. 

Probos Five had expected great things of his trap. He\r\nhad conceived the idea after reading the report of a Mercurian\r\nexpedition that explored the dens of the divided trunks at some place\r\nmarked "Coney Island." According to the reports the divided trunks\r\nshowed no hesitancy in entering these types of dens. In fact, the writer\r\nof the report gave it as his opinion that the divided ones perhaps\r\nplayed games in these types of caves. It also mentioned that some of the\r\ndens were equipped with flat shiny surfaces that cast reflections or\r\nimages. Probos Five had incorporated the image-making surfaces into his\r\ntrap design. A pity that all this effort must be wasted, thought Probos\r\nas he once more turned to the observation ports to check his remaining\r\ndistance from the planet\'s surface. Seeing that his time was short,\r\nProbos Five turned all five faces forward in the Mercurian gesture of\r\ndisdain for death. A moment later came the shock.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nA week later the proprietor of a novelty shop in Fairbanks watched two\r\nnatives with their dog team pulling something loglike through the snow\r\ntoward the trading post. Turning to a customer he remarked,\r\n\r\n"Here comes Ketch and Ah Koo dragging in another Totem Pole. Guess that\r\nKetch must be the biggest liar ever produced by the Eskimos. He tried to\r\ntell me that Totem Poles fall from the sky. Says he can always find one\r\nif he sees it fall because it\'s so hot it melts the snow around it.\r\nPersonally I think he should be elected president of the Liars\' Club,\r\nbut I\'ll buy the Totem Pole anyway. Those pesky tourists always whittle\r\na chunk out of my Totem Pole for a souvenir.\r\n\r\n"I\'m glad he\'s bringing me another one," the storekeeper concluded, "the\r\none he sold me last year is about whittled away."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Planet Stories_ January 1954.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Got \'em right here." I unfolded them and handed them\r\nover to him.\r\n\r\nHe ran his eyes over them quizzically. "Hokay," he said. "I guess we go\r\nto Aldebaran, huh?"\r\n\r\nOur instructions came in detail a little while later. I didn\'t\r\nknow anything particular about the planet or its people--there are\r\nenough worlds in the galaxy so you don\'t get to know each type of\r\nalien there is.
