The Aldebaran system is a huge one--31 planets spread out over\r\nsix or seven billion miles of space.\r\n\r\nMost of them were dead worlds, though. It was only Aldebaran VII that\r\nhad any sort of intelligent life, or so our survey teams reported.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIt took three days more to get within hailing distance of the seventh\r\nplanet. It spun beneath us, a pretty blue-green ball about the size of\r\nEarth.\r\n\r\nWe came within about a million miles and set up an orbit as per\r\ninstructions. No sooner had we done that than we found ourselves\r\nsurrounded by a flock of alien warships.\r\n\r\nI went to the radio room and made contact.\r\n\r\n"State name and object here," I was ordered in a crisp, business-like\r\nvoice.\r\n\r\n"I\'m Johnny Martin, Captain of the Terran vessel 13-XV-1, with no\r\nhostile intent. We\'re here to pick up an ambassador from Aldebaran to\r\nEarth, along with his pet."\r\n\r\nI heard some hasty conferring going on and then someone said, "Hold on,\r\nTerran ship. 

We\'ll check with the home planet."\r\n\r\nFive tense minutes passed--minutes in which I half expected to be\r\nblown out of the sky by a sudden attack. You never can tell with\r\naliens. They\'re likely to do almost anything; their psychologies are\r\nunpredictable in Terran terms--as, I guess, ours are in theirs.\r\n\r\nBut finally my receiver crackled and the alien voice said, "Everything\r\nis clear, 13-XV-1. Remain in orbit and ambassador will be transferred\r\nto your ship. Any suspicious move on your part will bring immediate\r\nattack by our defense fleet."\r\n\r\n"Don\'t worry. I\'m not going any place. 

I\'ll wait right here."\r\n\r\nI watched in the viewscope as a small ship bellied upward from the\r\nblue-green world below and approached us. They matched velocities with\r\nus, airlock to airlock.\r\n\r\n"Get that fluorine room ready," I ordered my men. "The Ambassador\'s\r\ncoming aboard."\r\n\r\nThe two ships hung side by side in space. Of course, there was no\r\napparent relative motion since we had the same velocity. It was\r\npossible to walk back and forth from their ship to ours.\r\n\r\n"Prepare to receive Ambassador," came the message from the other ship.\r\n"His excellency, Quelf Tharkol, Minister Plenipotenitiary--and his pet."\r\n\r\n"I\'m ready," I said. "Our airlock\'s open."\r\n\r\nSlowly the lock of the other ship slid back and two space-suited\r\nfigures appeared--the Ambassador, Quelf Tharkol, and his pet. The\r\nAmbassador was invisible within his spacesuit but he stood upright and\r\nlooked to be about the size of a man. I was happy about that; it\'s\r\nalways a lot easier to negotiate with a humanoids-type alien than with\r\nsomething totally bizarre.\r\n\r\nI chuckled when I saw the space-suited cat--for so I thought of it.\r\nIt was cat-size, in a little form-fitting spacesuit, and it scampered\r\nafter its master on four legs, space-suited tail wagging behind. It was\r\nsort of a cute little thing, I thought; no wonder its master didn\'t\r\ncare to leave it behind.\r\n\r\n"Everything all set?" I asked.\r\n\r\n"Transfer is completed," said the captain of the other ship. He closed\r\nhis lock, and pulled away from us.\r\n\r\n"Close the lock!" 

I ordered.\r\n\r\nI gestured to a crewman standing by. "Show the Ambassador to his room,"\r\nI said.\r\n\r\nWhen the Ambassador and his pet were in their special fluorinated\r\nstateroom I called them on the special television hookup I had set up\r\nbetween them.\r\n\r\nThey had taken their spacesuits off and were lying sprawled out in\r\ntheir green murky atmosphere, the Ambassador in his bunk and the pet\r\nin his. I could hardly see into the room over my circuit but I could\r\nsee that the Ambassador was very human and that the pet was pretty much\r\nlike a cat, except that he had sharp-clawed fingers instead of the soft\r\nlittle pads a cat has.\r\n\r\n"Everything all right in there?" I asked.\r\n\r\n"Fine, just fine. How long will it take to get to Earth?"\r\n\r\n"About three weeks," I said. 

"We\'ll be going into warp any minute."\r\n\r\n"Very well," came the reply.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI didn\'t expect to have many dealings with the Ambassador. I had\r\nbeen told that he would have his own food supply and naturally he was\r\nconfined to his fluorinated stateroom. So we settled down to a pleasant\r\nreturn trip.\r\n\r\nBut on the second day of warp I was awakened from sweet dreams by\r\nWhitey Durbin, the Night Engineer. He shoved me around in my bunk until\r\nI opened one eye and said "Whatsamatter?"\r\n\r\n"It\'s the cat, Chief!"\r\n\r\n"Cat? What cat? You crazy, Whitey? 

Lemme go back to sleep."\r\n\r\nBut he was obstinate. "The Ambassador\'s pet. It\'s out of its room."\r\n\r\n"Huh? But it can\'t breathe--"\r\n\r\n"It\'s wearing a spacesuit. And it\'s wandering all over the ship,\r\nsnooping around. I caught it in the drive section and up front with the\r\ncharts. I don\'t like it, Chief."\r\n\r\n"No. Neither do I." 

I was wide awake all at once. There had been\r\nsomething fishy about this pet business all along and now I was\r\nsuspicious. Suppose the pet were a little smarter than a cat? Suppose\r\nit was snooping around innocently enough--and actually soaking up vital\r\nsecret information about the workings of a Terran spaceship?\r\n\r\nBut I didn\'t know what to do. My orders stressed the fact that I had to\r\nhandle the Ambassador with kid gloves--but on the other hand, was I\r\nsupposed to let that creature roam all over the ship?\r\n\r\n"Get me a hookup with Home Base," I said. "And in the meantime keep an\r\neye on that cat. Don\'t let it catch wise but try to follow it around.\r\nAnd _don\'t_ stop it from roaming. These aliens may be touchy about the\r\nfunniest things."\r\n\r\nI got in touch with Home Base in jig time. Commander Mahoney was the\r\nman I spoke to.\r\n\r\n"How\'s that Ambassador, Martin?"\r\n\r\n"That\'s why I\'m calling, sir. You see--the Ambassador\'s pet is creeping\r\nall around the ship. It\'s sort of a cat but I wonder whether maybe it\'s\r\ndoing a very neat job of spying on us."\r\n\r\n"Have you taken any action yet?"\r\n\r\n"No. I wanted to check with Home Base."\r\n\r\nMahoney thought for a moment. "I suppose it would be all right to\r\nspeak to the Ambassador about this and tactfully request that he keep\r\nthe creature in his own quarters. But be _tactful_ about it, Martin.\r\nRemember, we don\'t want to offend these aliens."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIt was the middle of the "night" aboard ship, so I didn\'t think it\r\nwould be particularly tactful to call the Ambassador just then.\r\n\r\nI waited until morning, by which time my men reported that the cat had\r\ncompleted its survey and had promptly returned to the Ambassador\'s room.\r\n\r\nWhen the television came on, the Ambassador and his pet were again\r\nreclining leisurely on their bunks.\r\n\r\n"Sorry if I\'m disturbing you," I said hesitantly.\r\n\r\n"That\'s quite all right. What can I do for you?"\r\n\r\n"A matter of shipboard procedure I\'d like to point out. It seems last\r\nnight your pet left your cabin and explored the ship, or so some of\r\nmy men reported. I\'d appreciate it if you\'d restrain the animal to\r\nquarters from now on. It upsets shipboard routine--and, besides, my\r\ninstructions request that I keep the operating sections of the ship\r\nunder security wrap."\r\n\r\nThere was silence for a moment. I held my breath, hoping I hadn\'t\r\nsaid something wrong, some thing that might foul up the delicate\r\nEarth-Aldebaran negotiations in progress.\r\n\r\nFinally came the reply. "I understand fully. I\'m sorry about the\r\nexploration trip--it was mere curiosity. It won\'t be repeated. 

But\r\nyou\'re mistaken about one thing.

"\r\n\r\n"What\'s that?" I asked somewhat puzzledly.\r\n\r\n"My pet remained in the cabin all night. _I_ was the one who explored\r\nthe ship." There was a sneer in his voice.\r\n\r\n"You? But--"\r\n\r\nMy mouth clammed shut. And then I understood. I couldn\'t keep the flush\r\nof embarrassment from my face and he saw it over the screen. It seemed\r\nto please him. 

Pretty damned clever, I thought. Smart psychology for\r\nthe aliens to bring a "human" as a pet, putting our diplomats on the\r\ndefensive right from the start. The Ambassador must have known what I\r\nwas thinking for the sneer grew on his face.\r\n\r\nThen suddenly I grinned. It seemed to surprise him. This, he hadn\'t\r\nexpected.\r\n\r\n"Captain, something strikes you as humorous?" There was uncertainty in\r\nhis tone. Plus a little annoyance.\r\n\r\nMy grin widened. "Just a little private joke, Ambassador," I said. I\r\nwas thinking that this joker was in for a shock. Two planets could play\r\nat this game and I would have plenty of time to tip off Home Base.\r\n\r\nAfter all, we have pets too....\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nThe sign said: RIDE THE ROCKET! TWICE AROUND THE UNIVERSE FOR 25\xc2\xa2!\r\nWhich was cheap enough, Pete Moore thought. Cheap enough at twice the\r\nfare.\r\n\r\nGlory giggled and pulled at his arm. "Let\'s ride, Pete. 

Let\'s see what\r\nyou\'re in for."\r\n\r\nHe smiled down at her thinly, because it wasn\'t really anything for\r\nher to giggle about, but that was Glory for you. She was young enough,\r\ngay enough, to be able to make a joke of it, and that was good and he\r\nshouldn\'t spoil it. Not many other wives would feel like that. Not many\r\nother wives would want to spend his last night home on the midway, for\r\nthat matter. But then again, that was Glory.\r\n\r\nHe listened to the tinny carousel music and the babble of the crowd,\r\nthe laughter and the mingled drone of barkers. He smelled the tang\r\nof roasting popcorn and the hot-doggy stink of the lunchcounters. He\r\nlooked at the ferris wheel and the crazy swoop of lights that was the\r\nscenic railway and the people crowding along the boardwalk with kewpie\r\ndolls and spun-sugar candy cones in their hands.\r\n\r\nQuestion! his mind demanded: Is this reality?\r\n\r\nAnswer: Of course. What else?\r\n\r\nI\'ve been too long away from cities, he thought. Too many silent nights\r\nin the desert, too many high flights in cold blue air. Too long away\r\nfrom Glory?\r\n\r\nHe felt guilty and depressed at the thought. It wasn\'t the way for a\r\nman to feel. Not before the great adventure. Still, he couldn\'t avoid\r\nan almost homesick longing for the deep darkness of the desert and the\r\nsilver ship waiting there.\r\n\r\nSoon, he thought. Three days; three days and a few hours.\r\n\r\nHe felt a tug at his arm.\r\n\r\n"Pete!" Glory was smiling up at him, half-aggrieved, half-loving. He\r\nlooked again at the garishly painted sign.\r\n\r\nRIDE THE ROCKET!\r\n\r\n"Let\'s ride it, Pete," Glory said. "Let\'s!"\r\n\r\nThere was something in her smile that touched him. Pride? That, and\r\nlove and youth. To her, he was _the_ man. For her, and for all the\r\nworld. The one who was going to reach out beyond the far horizon and\r\ntouch the sky and bring back a pot of gold for everyone.\r\n\r\nShe thinks no one else could do it, he told himself. That\'s love. There\r\nwere a dozen qualified men, and yet--\r\n\r\nThe moonshot was his.\r\n\r\nRIDE THE ROCKET!\r\n\r\n"All right, baby," he said.\r\n\r\nAs he paid their fare for the rocket-ride, Pete found himself looking\r\nat the girl in the booth. Tired eyes and stringy hennaed hair. 

No\r\ndreams there. He had an impulse to tell her that soon he\'d really be\r\nriding the rocket and that from then on things would be different.\r\n\r\nNew frontiers and new dreams for everybody. Up and up.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe girl\'s eyes met his, and it was Pete who looked away. You don\'t\r\ntalk frontiers to pale, worn faces and eyes bleached of color by tinny\r\nmusic and stinks and men.\r\n\r\nThey walked up a wooden ramp to where a little metal bullet on rails\r\nwaited. The paint, once bright, was all scuffy. A sour-faced attendant\r\nin grayish coveralls stood by a large lever.\r\n\r\n"Fasten ya seat belts, Mac."\r\n\r\n"We\'re off to the sky," Glory said.\r\n\r\nSomewhere old machinery wheezed.\r\n\r\nThe little bullet began to move along the rails toward a hinged\r\ntrap-door in a wall painted to look like clouds.\r\n\r\n"Hold my hand, Pete," Glory said breathlessly.\r\n\r\nGlory, Glory, he thought. Young and simple and in love with life. 

Any\r\nkind of life. Real or unreal. Glory with a bubbling laughter, a zest, a\r\nfaith. Maybe it was really for her that he was taking the big flight.\r\nIf only he could bring back the pot of gold. If only he could tell\r\nweary Man that the sky was all his. 

He thought of the strained, unhappy\r\nfaces in the streets, the fear-filled eyes. If he could return and say\r\nto them: "Here\'s your new frontier!" Yes, by God, it was worth the\r\nwork, and the risk. 

Glory was right. It was something to be proud of.\r\n\r\nI\'m going to the moon!\r\n\r\nMe, Pete Moore, to the _moon_!\r\n\r\n"There it is, Pete!"\r\n\r\nThey had bumped through the painted door into a musty semi-darkness.\r\nThe walls were perforated with holes for stars, and from somewhere\r\nbelow a huge yellowish moon was rising.\r\n\r\nOff a short way to the right was a glowing papier-m\xc3\xa2ch\xc3\xa9 globe painted\r\nwith broad bands slightly askew, and behind that was another with rings.\r\n\r\nA loudspeaker whistled tinnily and overhead, on wire runners, an\r\nelectric globe crossed the dim chamber, pieces of yellow and white\r\ncrepe paper fluttering feebly behind.\r\n\r\n"Oh, Pete! A comet?"\r\n\r\n"Sure enough, Glory," he said.\r\n\r\nThe rumbling little bullet skirted the walls and Pete could see the\r\nelectric lights behind the holes. Stars, he thought sardonically. Close\r\nenough to touch. Lucky us.\r\n\r\n"There\'s Mars, Pete," Glory said, squeezing his hand.\r\n\r\nI\'m getting disenchanted, he thought.\r\n\r\nA red ball, all painted with canals and white polar caps far too big.\r\n\r\nThey should have had a technical advisor on this project, he thought.\r\nPaging Palomar.\r\n\r\nThe bullet began its second circuit of the papier-m\xc3\xa2ch\xc3\xa9 universe,\r\nand the moon was high now, projected on the wall by some kind of\r\nlantern-slide lamp. There was a face on the moon.\r\n\r\nIt began then--just a tiny bead of fear way down inside his belly. But\r\nit grew. He felt suffocated, claustrophobic, oppressed by fakery and\r\ncheapness.\r\n\r\nGlory was laughing with delight. "Oh, it\'s wonderful!"\r\n\r\nShut up! 

Pete thought savagely. Shut up, _shut up_!\r\n\r\nWith an effort, he got hold of himself.\r\n\r\nI\'ve been working too hard. I\'m jittery thinking about the moonshot,\r\nand all this seedy burlesque just irritates me. There\'s nothing to get\r\nheated up about. 

Calm down.\r\n\r\nBut why am I suddenly afraid?\r\n\r\nHe looked again at the ridiculous moon with its smirking face. He saw\r\nthat plaster had fallen from the wall in places, peeling away, leaving\r\nthe bare hexagons of wire and laths.\r\n\r\nMy God, he thought. A chickenwire sky.\r\n\r\nHe thought again of the girl in the ticket booth, and of the tired,\r\nfrightened people all laughing too much and shoving and running outside.\r\n\r\nThe bullet started down at last, toward the hinged door. On this side\r\nit was painted to look like Earth, with a distorted map of North\r\nAmerica. All wrong, somehow.\r\n\r\nPete felt ill. It was as though someone were making ill-tempered fun\r\nof the dreams and the tall silver ship waiting out on the desert.\r\nCheapening it. Laughing nastily.\r\n\r\nThe little bullet bumped through the seedy, scruffy Earth and out\r\ninto the night of the midway, out into the crowd-sounds and music and\r\nhot-doggy smells.\r\n\r\n"It was fun, Pete," Glory said.\r\n\r\nHe helped her out onto the rickety platform. He had the insane notion\r\nthat the girl in the ticket booth and the lounging attendant were\r\nlaughing at him.\r\n\r\n"It sure was, honey," he said wearily, still feeling the illogical fear\r\nof he-knew-not-what inside himself. "Real fun."\r\n\r\nGlory looked up at him, eyes alight and almost feverishly gay. "I did\r\nwhat you are going to do. I touched the sky!"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nNew frontiers. New lands in the sky. New hope.\r\n\r\nIt was quiet. The jet was still and no sound was anywhere in the ship.\r\nNow a soft tick from the timer. A whisper from the questing radarscope.\r\nAnd again, the stillness.\r\n\r\nWe\'ve done it, Pete thought. We\'ve really done it. The hard part is\r\nover.\r\n\r\nRide the rocket!\r\n\r\nHe remembered the pain of the takeoff and the absolute panic that had\r\nwelled up in him when the irrevocability of his action came home. He\r\nremembered riding a tail of red fire up out of the hot desert air of\r\nNew Mexico into the still blue, and then the silence and the almost\r\nunnerving thrill of the realization that the moonshot was going to\r\nsucceed.\r\n\r\nThe radio hissed at him with the voice of the desert base half around\r\nthe world.\r\n\r\n"Hello moonshot. This is Base. 

All\'s okay. Stage one landed in the\r\nGulf. Stage two just reported floating off the Azores. Good show."\r\n\r\nPete lifted himself from the acceleration couch and felt a moment of\r\nnausea and panic as he floated toward the ceiling of the tiny cell.\r\nFree flight. He steadied himself and checked the flow of telemetered\r\ninformation binding the ship to the glowing curve far below. All okay.\r\nExcept that--\r\n\r\nExcept that you\'re still afraid, he told himself. Not just the normal\r\nfear-of-falling-afraid that the psychs told you about. Afraid like\r\nbefore--in that silly damn carnival ride thing.\r\n\r\nAfraid of the dark?\r\n\r\nNo, not quite that. More a closed in, cheated feeling.\r\n\r\nPremonition? Nonsense.\r\n\r\nHe clung to the radarscope, trembling. With every rushing mile upward,\r\noutward, his fear was growing. It wasn\'t right, it didn\'t make sense.\r\nBut he felt as though he were rushing straight at a brick wall, head\r\ndown, eyes closed.\r\n\r\nHe lit the telescreens.\r\n\r\nThe stars look funny, he thought uneasily.\r\n\r\nThe timer ticked. The radar whispered, searching. Time passed and his\r\nfear grew thicker, less reasonable.\r\n\r\nHis fingers dug hard at the metal of the instrument panel as the night\r\nslipped by outside the hull. The ship\'s orbital ellipse, Kepler\'s\r\ncontribution to the new frontier, was established.\r\n\r\nPete thought, something\'s wrong. Very wrong. The stars look queer.\r\n\r\nThe constellations in the telescreens were distorting, and there\r\nwas something ahead of the ship where there should be nothing but\r\nemptiness. It showed in the screen for just an instant and was lost. A\r\nringed sphere.\r\n\r\nI must be dreaming, Pete thought. But then, what is reality? That\r\nsphere was Saturn. And it was a hundred yards across.\r\n\r\nReality? _Insanity!_\r\n\r\nI\'d better check with Base, Pete thought, and tell them I\'ve gone off\r\nmy rocker, that I\'m suffering hallucinations.\r\n\r\nBut he did nothing except cling shaking to the panel, watching the\r\ndistorted stars in the screen. And _small_. Very small and very close.\r\n\r\nPete felt closed in, suffocated. The radar alarm was screaming at him\r\nthat something was near, too near.\r\n\r\nHe clamped down savagely on himself. There was an explanation\r\nsomewhere. He had to find it! He had to think!\r\n\r\nItem. The stars. Distorted. Blurred.\r\n\r\nItem. Saturn. A hundred yards across.\r\n\r\nItem. A tiny replica of the moon, like a pimple on the inside of an egg.\r\n\r\nReplica? No. _The_ moon. The only moon. Reality.\r\n\r\nHypothesis. Say that space is not as men imagined it. Say that it is an\r\nillusion, without lightyears, without great suns, without huge planets.\r\nSay for the sake of argument that it is a shell with holes in it, and\r\nlight outside, and the Sun itself an illusion of heat and power, and--\r\n\r\nSay that this hollow shell is man\'s new frontier; a fraud, a toy for\r\nthings outside--\r\n\r\nThe alarm screamed at him. The ship was plunging toward the blurry\r\nlight of the stars.\r\n\r\nWith an icy hand on his heart, Pete Moore turned to look at the\r\ntelescreen behind him. A misty blue ball swam in musty darkness. 

The\r\noceans gleamed in the light of the sun, cloud masses whitened it, the\r\nwrinkled face of the land looked unreal--\r\n\r\nHe began to laugh. Tears streaked his cheeks as he pounded his bloody\r\nfists against the instrument panel in time to the clanging of the alarm.\r\n\r\nThe Earth, the Earth--\r\n\r\nIt _did_ rather look like papier-m\xc3\xa2ch\xc3\xa9.\r\n\r\nHe touched the sky.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


His\r\nvision went beyond the Congress of the United States, past the balmy\r\nJune day to another day that was coming. A day when the Army would have\r\nits destined place of authority.\r\n\r\nHe drew a deep breath and delivered what was perhaps the shortest speech\r\never heard in the hallowed halls of Congress:\r\n\r\n"The General Staff of the U.S. Army requests Congress to abolish the\r\narchaic branch of the armed forces known as the U.S. Navy."\r\n\r\nThe aging Senator from Georgia checked his hearing aid to see if it was\r\nin operating order, while the press box emptied itself in one concerted\r\nrush and a clatter of running feet that died off in the direction of the\r\ntelephone room. A buzz of excited comment ran through the giant chamber.\r\nOne by one the heads turned to face the Naval section where rows of blue\r\nfigures stirred and buzzed like smoked-out bees. The knot of men around\r\na paunchy figure heavy with gold braid broke up and Admiral Fitzjames\r\nclimbed slowly to his feet.\r\n\r\nLesser men have quailed before that piercing stare, but General Wingrove\r\nwas never the lesser man. The admiral tossed his head with disgust,\r\nevery line of his body denoting outraged dignity. He turned to his\r\naudience, a small pulse beating in his forehead.\r\n\r\n"I cannot comprehend the general\'s attitude, nor can I understand why he\r\nhas attacked the Navy in this unwarranted fashion. The Navy has existed\r\nand will always exist as the first barrier of American defense. I ask\r\nyou, gentlemen, to ignore this request as you would ignore the\r\nstatements of any person ... er, slightly demented. I should like to\r\noffer a recommendation that the general\'s sanity be investigated, and an\r\ninquiry be made as to the mental health of anyone else connected with\r\nthis preposterous proposal!"\r\n\r\nThe general smiled calmly. "I understand, Admiral, and really don\'t\r\nblame you for being slightly annoyed. But, please let us not bring this\r\nissue of national importance down to a shallow personal level. The Army\r\nhas facts to back up this request--facts that shall be demonstrated\r\ntomorrow morning."\r\n\r\nTurning his back on the raging admiral, General Wingrove included all\r\nthe assembled solons in one sweeping gesture.\r\n\r\n"Reserve your judgment until that time, gentlemen, make no hasty\r\njudgments until you have seen the force of argument with which we back\r\nup our request. It is the end of an era. In the morning the Navy joins\r\nits fellow fossils, the dodo and the brontosaurus."\r\n\r\nThe admiral\'s blood pressure mounted to a new record and the gentle thud\r\nof his unconscious body striking the floor was the only sound to break\r\nthe shocked silence of the giant hall.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe early morning sun warmed the white marble of the Jefferson Memorial\r\nand glinted from the soldiers\' helmets and the roofs of the packed cars\r\nthat crowded forward in a slow-moving stream. All the gentlemen of\r\nCongress were there, the passage of their cars cleared by the screaming\r\nsirens of motorcycle policemen. 

Around and under the wheels of the\r\nofficial cars pressed a solid wave of government workers and common\r\ncitizens of the capital city. The trucks of the radio and television\r\nservices pressed close, microphones and cameras extended.\r\n\r\nThe stage was set for a great day. Neat rows of olive drab vehicles\r\ncurved along the water\'s edge. Jeeps and half-tracks shouldered close by\r\nweapons carriers and six-bys, all of them shrinking to insignificance\r\nbeside the looming Patton tanks. A speakers\' platform was set up in the\r\ncenter of the line, near the audience.\r\n\r\nAt precisely 10 a.m., General Wingrove stepped forward and scowled at\r\nthe crowd until they settled into an uncomfortable silence. His speech\r\nwas short and consisted of nothing more than amplifications of his\r\nopening statement that actions speak louder than words. He pointed to\r\nthe first truck in line, a 2\xc2\xbd-ton filled with an infantry squad sitting\r\nstiffly at attention.\r\n\r\nThe driver caught the signal and kicked the engine into life; with a\r\ngrind of gears it moved forward toward the river\'s edge. There was an\r\nindrawn gasp from the crowd as the front wheels ground over the marble\r\nparapet--then the truck was plunging down toward the muddy waters of the\r\nPotomac.\r\n\r\nThe wheels touched the water and the surface seemed to sink while taking\r\non a strange glassy character. The truck roared into high gear and rode\r\nforward on the surface of the water surrounded by a saucer-shaped\r\ndepression. It parked two hundred yards off shore and the soldiers,\r\ngoaded by the sergeant\'s bark, leapt out and lined up with a showy\r\n_present arms_.\r\n\r\nThe general returned the salute and waved to the remaining vehicles.\r\nThey moved forward in a series of maneuvers that indicated a great\r\nnumber of rehearsal hours on some hidden pond. The tanks rumbled slowly\r\nover the water while the jeeps cut back and forth through their lines in\r\nintricate patterns. The trucks backed and turned like puffing\r\nballerinas.\r\n\r\nThe audience was rooted in a hushed silence, their eyeballs bulging.\r\nThey continued to watch the amazing display as General Wingrove spoke\r\nagain:\r\n\r\n"You see before you a typical example of Army ingenuity, developed in\r\nArmy laboratories. These motor units are supported on the surface of the\r\nwater by an intensifying of the surface tension in their immediate area.\r\nTheir weight is evenly distributed over the surface, causing the shallow\r\ndepressions you see around them.\r\n\r\n"This remarkable feat has been accomplished by the use of the\r\n_Dornifier_. A remarkable invention that is named after that brilliant\r\nscientist, Colonel Robert A. Dorn, Commander of the Brooke Point\r\nExperimental Laboratory. It was there that one of the civilian employees\r\ndiscovered the Dorn effect--under the Colonel\'s constant guidance, of\r\ncourse.\r\n\r\n"Utilizing this invention the Army now becomes master of the sea as well\r\nas the land. Army convoys of trucks and tanks can blanket the world. 

The\r\nsurface of the water is our highway, our motor park, our\r\nbattleground--the airfield and runway for our planes."\r\n\r\nMechanics were pushing a Shooting Star onto the water. They stepped\r\nclear as flame gushed from the tail pipe; with the familiar whooshing\r\nrumble it sped down the Potomac and hurled itself into the air.\r\n\r\n"When this cheap and simple method of crossing oceans is adopted, it\r\nwill of course mean the end of that fantastic medieval anachronism, the\r\nNavy. No need for billion-dollar aircraft carriers, battleships,\r\ndrydocks and all the other cumbersome junk that keeps those boats and\r\nthings afloat. Give the taxpayer back his hard-earned dollar!"\r\n\r\nTeeth grated in the Naval section as carriers and battleships were\r\ncalled "boats" and the rest of America\'s sea might lumped under the\r\ncasual heading of "things." Lips were curled at the transparent appeal\r\nto the taxpayer\'s pocketbook. 

But with leaden hearts they knew that all\r\nthis justified wrath and contempt would avail them nothing. This was\r\nArmy Day with a vengeance, and the doom of the Navy seemed inescapable.\r\n\r\nThe Army had made elaborate plans for what they called "Operation\r\nSinker." Even as the general spoke the publicity mills ground into high\r\ngear. From coast to coast the citizens absorbed the news with their\r\nmorning nourishment.\r\n\r\n"... Agnes, you hear what the radio said! The Army\'s gonna give a trip\r\naround the world in a B-36 as first prize in this limerick contest. All\r\nyou have to do is fill in the last line, and mail one copy to the\r\nPentagon and the other to the Navy ..."\r\n\r\nThe Naval mail room had standing orders to burn all the limericks when\r\nthey came in, but some of the newer men seemed to think the entire thing\r\nwas a big joke. Commander Bullman found one in the mess hall:\r\n\r\n    _The Army will always be there,\r\n    On the land, on the sea, in the air.\r\n    So why should the Navy\r\n    Take all of the gravy ..._\r\n\r\nto which a seagoing scribe had added:\r\n\r\n    _And not give us ensigns our share?_\r\n\r\nThe newspapers were filled daily with photographs of mighty B-36\'s\r\nlanding on Lake Erie, and grinning soldiers making mock beachhead\r\nattacks on Coney Island. Each man wore a buzzing black box at his waist\r\nand walked on the bosom of the now quiet Atlantic like a biblical\r\nprophet.\r\n\r\nRadio and television also carried the thousands of news releases that\r\npoured in an unending flow from the Pentagon Building. 

Cards, letters,\r\ntelegrams and packages descended on Washington in an overwhelming\r\ntorrent. The Navy Department was the unhappy recipient of deprecatory\r\nletters and a vast quantity of little cardboard battleships.\r\n\r\nThe people spoke and their representatives listened closely. This was an\r\nelection year. There didn\'t seem to be much doubt as to the decision,\r\nparticularly when the reduction in the budget was considered.\r\n\r\nIt took Congress only two months to make up its collective mind. The\r\npeople were all pro-Army. The novelty of the idea had fired their\r\nimaginations.\r\n\r\nThey were about to take the final vote in the lower house. If the\r\namendment passed it would go to the states for ratification, and their\r\nvotes were certain to follow that of Congress. The Navy had fought a\r\nlast-ditch battle to no avail. The balloting was going to be pretty much\r\nof a sure thing--the wet water Navy would soon become ancient history.\r\n\r\nFor some reason the admirals didn\'t look as unhappy as they should.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe Naval Department had requested one last opportunity to address the\r\nCongress. Congress had patronizingly granted permission, for even the\r\ndoomed man is allowed one last speech. Admiral Fitzjames, who had\r\nrecovered from his choleric attack, was the appointed speaker.\r\n\r\n"Gentlemen of the Congress of the United States. We in the Navy have a\r\nfighting tradition. 

We \'damn the torpedoes\' and sail straight ahead into\r\nthe enemy\'s fire if that is necessary. We have been stabbed in the\r\nback--we have suffered a second Pearl Harbor sneak attack! The Army\r\nrelinquished its rights to fair treatment with this attack. 

Therefore we\r\nare _counter-attacking_!" Worn out by his attacking and mixed metaphors,\r\nthe Admiral mopped his brow.\r\n\r\n"Our laboratories have been working night and day on the perfection of a\r\ndevice we hoped we would never be forced to use. It is now in operation,\r\nhaving passed the final trials a few days ago.\r\n\r\n"The significance of this device _cannot_ be underestimated. We are so\r\npositive of its importance that--we are _demanding_ that the _Army_ be\r\nabolished!"\r\n\r\nHe waved his hand toward the window and bellowed one word.\r\n\r\n"LOOK!"\r\n\r\nEveryone looked. 

They blinked and looked again. They rubbed their eyes\r\nand kept looking.\r\n\r\nSailing majestically up the middle of Constitution Avenue was the\r\nbattleship Missouri.\r\n\r\nThe Admiral\'s voice rang through the room like a trumpet of victory.\r\n\r\n"The Mark-1 Debinder, as you see, temporarily lessens the binding\r\nenergies that hold molecules of solid matter together. Solids become\r\nliquids, and a ship equipped with this device can sail anywhere in the\r\nworld--on sea _or_ land. 

Take your vote, gentlemen; the world awaits\r\nyour decision."\r\n\r\n                                                           ... THE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _If Worlds of Science Fiction_ January\r\n    1954. He was going to refuse to die._\r\n\r\n\r\nBart Neely was fighting the hypo. They\'d slipped that over on him. 

Now\r\nhe had to struggle to keep his brain ready for plan B. The alternate\r\nplan. He nodded feebly at his reflection in the mirror over the white\r\nenamel dresser. This throat-trouble wasn\'t going to lick him. He lay\r\nback on the cool white pillow. Medical men always thought theirs was the\r\nfinal answer; well, psychologists like himself knew there was a broader\r\nview of man than the anatomical. There was a vast region of energy at\r\nman\'s disposal; the switch to turn it on, located in the brain.\r\n\r\nRubber-soled shoes squished across the bare floor as Dr. Jonas Morton\r\ncame into Bart\'s room. His hair was hidden by a sterile cap, his arms\r\nbare to well above the elbows.\r\n\r\nLooks like a damned butcher, thought Bart.\r\n\r\n"Bart, I want you to reconsider the anesthetic. I think you ought to be\r\nout for this one, completely out." The doctor\'s voice became a shade\r\nless professional. "I don\'t tell you how to run your perception\r\nexperiments, I think you ought to let me judge what\'s best in the\r\nsurgical area."\r\n\r\n"No," Bart whispered hoarsely. It was hell squeezing the words out.\r\nLifting his voice these days was harder than lifting a half-ton truck.\r\n"Must be conscious, able to decide." Jonas had to lean down to catch all\r\nthe words. "Not going to let you take my voice while I\'m unconscious ...\r\nhelpless ..."\r\n\r\nDr. Morton shook his head. "You\'re the boss."\r\n\r\n"How soon?"\r\n\r\n"Twenty minutes." The professional tone became pronounced again. "Your\r\nwife\'s outside waiting to see you. Don\'t get emotional, I don\'t want\r\nyour endocrine system in an uproar." The doctor stepped out into the\r\ncorridor.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nEmotional. He mustn\'t think about it. He might weaken, consent to linger\r\non, an invalid, just to be with Vivian a few extra years. Extra years of\r\nindignities calculated to twist the man-woman relationship into an ugly\r\ndistortion. How romantic it would be, he and Vivian locked in an\r\nembrace, the silky softness of her hair falling across his arm, the\r\npressure of her fingers on his back. And then, instead of placing his\r\nmouth against her ear and whispering the familiar intimacies, he would\r\nswitch on the light, disengage himself so that he could whip out a pad\r\nand pencil and ...\r\n\r\nHis heart skipped at the sound pattern of high heels on the corridor.\r\nVivian, Vivian. Her perfume pricked his senses and it took effort to\r\nshut out the emotional response. "Remember the need for an alternate\r\nplan," he reminded himself fiercely and then looked up into his wife\'s\r\nclear green eyes. Without a word she bent down and lay her face next to\r\nhis. He was struck with the warmth of her. He gently pushed her head\r\naway. "Vi." (My Lord, his eyes were wet ... what a schoolboy\r\nperformance!) "Vi, you know I don\'t want to go on here ... if radical\r\nsurgery is necessary. I want you to remember me as a whole man, not\r\na ... 

dummy.

"\r\n\r\n"Bart, oh Bart." There was a frown of apprehension on her forehead. She\r\nsighed heavily and whispered, "Can it make so much difference when I\r\nlove you Bart?"\r\n\r\n"But don\'t you see, Vi? It may not be Bart Neely they wheel back here\r\nafter the operation." He motioned for her to bend closer for the sound\r\nof his voice was becoming weaker. "In my field I\'ve seen a lot of crazy\r\nreactions to loss of basic ability. Personality reversals brought about\r\nby loss of hearing, impotency, or even the inability to bear a child."\r\nHe stroked the back of her hand with his finger. "Bart Neely without a\r\nvoice-box might be a stranger. I\'m not sure you\'d like him. 

I don\'t\r\nthink I\'d even like him."\r\n\r\nAn intern backed into the room followed by a gurney. Bart shot a look at\r\nVi. "This is plan A."\r\n\r\nVi\'s eyebrows arched in a question.\r\n\r\n"Exploration and ..." he paused; the nurse tucked a dark gray blanket\r\nall around him. He raised his thin white hand and crossed two fingers ...\r\n"and we hope, a negative biopsy."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThere was no pain. Whatever the anesthetist had worked out was doing\r\nnicely. The overhead light, however, was giving him a headache and the\r\noperating room was damned cold. Jonas and Holsclaw weren\'t talking\r\nmuch, and what they did say wasn\'t loud enough for Bart to get. He\r\nstudied their faces. "I\'ll know by their faces," he assured himself,\r\n"and if it\'s widespread malignancy I\'ll proceed with plan B."\r\n\r\nThe sweat was heavy on Jonas\' forehead. The sterile mask hid his nose\r\nand mouth, but his eyes, behind the lenses of his glasses, looked moist\r\nand tired. The surgeon\'s gloved fingers manipulated, probed, cut.\r\nFinally, he turned to a waiting nurse.\r\n\r\n"Get this analyzed right away." That was it, the tissue ... was it\r\ncancerous or not? 

The atmosphere grew heavy. Bart watched the second\r\nhand on the large wall-clock swing slowly around its perimeter, and then\r\naround again and again. The nurse reentered and spoke softly to the\r\ndoctor. The two doctors whispered, explaining to each other with hand\r\nmotions what they were going to do.\r\n\r\nThis is it. Bart was certain. Well, he\'d fool the hell out of the\r\nknow-it-all doctors. He closed his eyes and thought. The years he had\r\nspent sharpening his perception, his ability to transfer his thoughts,\r\nwere just the groundwork for this greatest experiment of all. He had\r\ntransferred thought waves in all forms to all corners of this world with\r\nthe highest percentage of accuracy. Now Plan B, the alternate plan, was\r\nto transfer himself! He was willing himself out of his own body. He\r\ncould feel the perspiration trickle down his arms with the effort. It\r\nhad to work. He had to cheat them out of their mutilation. No, he\r\ncouldn\'t fail. He strained against the confines of his body, burdening\r\nhis brain with thought, and suddenly he was free. Bart wanted to shriek\r\nwith laughter. He\'d outwitted them. There stood gray-faced Jonas working\r\nover that shell, not even realizing that it was an empty body. It was\r\nlike a television play or something; everyone clustered around a poor\r\nstiff on the operating table, repeating the litany of the saw-bones.\r\n"Scalpel ... sponge ... clamps ..."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBart mentally chuckled and fluttered himself upwards; above the\r\nsquare-shaped hospital with its rows of tiny windows. Beyond the\r\npolluted air of the city. 

Up and up, until there was nothing to look\r\nback on. Nothing.\r\n\r\nNow Bart perceived something ahead. It appeared to be a body of land. It\r\nlooked marvelously appealing, dark greens, bright yellows, and all the\r\nshades in between. He hurried forward, eager to explore what lay ahead.\r\nBut as he drew closer, becoming more excited over its possibilities, he\r\nstruck a cold hard surface which repelled him. It was like glass and\r\nthrough it Bart could see a poorly defined figure some distance away.\r\nBart was intrigued. This was a mental barrier thrown up by the fellow on\r\nthe other side. Well, he\'d give the guy some competition. Bart\r\nconcentrated on cracking the wall, building a visual picture of the\r\nbreak-through in his mind.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"It\'s useless. You can\'t enter here."\r\n\r\n"Why do you oppose me?" Bart tested the unseen wall, but found no\r\nweakness in its structure.\r\n\r\n"We don\'t care for your sort."\r\n\r\n"Is that so. 

And how have you classified me?"\r\n\r\n"As a coward. A suicide. A man of meager resources."\r\n\r\n"I\'m nothing of the kind. In the first place, I did not commit suicide."\r\nBart wished he could kick at the invisible wall. "I willed myself away\r\nfrom an imperfect shell. I severed the mind from the body."\r\n\r\n"Why?"\r\n\r\n"Because I had cancer of the larynx, and I\'d never have been able to\r\ntalk again. I\'d be less than a man."\r\n\r\n"You are less than a man now." There was a long period of no exchange.\r\nBart decided he had not made himself clear. "I didn\'t want to live\r\nwithout being able to communicate with other men and women."\r\n\r\n"Communicate. Communicate. There are a million ways to communicate.\r\nMichelangelo communicated, Bach, Beethoven, yes, Elvis Presley\r\ncommunicates. Hemingway, Martha Graham, actors, dancers, even a baby\r\ncommunicates!"\r\n\r\n"But speech ..."\r\n\r\n"Speech is the least dependable method of all. Few people can explain\r\ntheir love, their pain, their innermost feelings in words. And often a\r\nman speaks his thoughts, and having spoken them, finds he really thinks\r\nthe opposite. No, this is second-rate expression and my opinion of you\r\nhas not been altered by your feeble argument."\r\n\r\nThe other fellow\'s thoughts came over the wall, pounding against Bart\'s\r\nsub-conscious. "You consider yourself a man of great intelligence," it\r\nwent on, "but your lack of imagination makes you less than mediocre. And\r\nas for your mind-power, well, you see you cannot cross my mental\r\nbarrier."\r\n\r\n"That\'s not entirely conclusive. There may be a catalyst here in this\r\narea which works in conjunction with your thought-processes and not\r\nmine. You\'re familiar with conditions here, while I only know the\r\nearth.

"\r\n\r\n"You are hardly a challenge to me. However, to satisfy you that you have\r\npractically no control, let us make a test on your home ground."\r\n\r\n"All right. 

You propose the test."\r\n\r\n"Let us see ... if you can re-enter your former body while I am willing\r\nyou to stay here, on the other side of that wall."\r\n\r\n"Ahah. You\'re trying to trick me."\r\n\r\n"I knew before I proposed my plan you would make exactly that excuse in\r\norder to escape my challenge. Even in excuses you lacked imagination."\r\n\r\n"Okay, it\'s a deal." Bart was mad. "Start concentrating. I\'ll show you\r\nthe power of my mind, both now and after I resume that shell." Bart was\r\nfurious. He tried to leave the place by the wall. He seemed stuck. There\r\nwere waves like laughter vibrating against the glass. Bart strained and\r\nsaw that he had come away a little. He tried again and again. 

There was\r\na little more distance gained. He tried to build the picture of the\r\noperating-room in his mind and while he was doing this a flash of Vivian\r\nexploded his mind. With that quick image, he felt himself free to drift\r\ndownward.\r\n\r\nThere indeed was the hospital. Bart hurried to the operating-room,\r\nhovering near the ceiling light, watching the operating team below.\r\n\r\n"He\'s gone, doctor." The anesthetist looked at Jonas. "Respiration\'s\r\nstopped altogether."\r\n\r\n_No_, thought Bart. _Don\'t close me out now._\r\n\r\n"Let\'s open the chest and massage the heart."\r\n\r\n_Yes. Yes._\r\n\r\n"I think it\'s futile, doctor.

"\r\n\r\n"We can try."\r\n\r\n_Good old Jonas._ Bart floated to the table and forced himself into the\r\nshell which lay white and unmoving under the penetrating light from\r\nabove. It wasn\'t easy, Bart tried to move the heavy hand, but it was\r\nquite numb.\r\n\r\n"Not a thing. Might as well quit."\r\n\r\n_Holsclaw\'s in a hurry. Damn him._\r\n\r\n"I\'ll massage a little longer."\r\n\r\nBart pushed at the leaden eyelid. No go. _Come on, come on._ He felt a\r\nconvulsive chill, a throbbing in his head.\r\n\r\n"I\'m getting a pulse." Jonas\' voice was excited.\r\n\r\nBart knew there was a searing pain in his throat, but shutting it out of\r\nhis consciousness was the steady, thumping beat of his own heart.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Amazing Science Fiction Stories_\r\n    September 1958.
