]\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was a perfectly conventional tour, once around the Milky Way with\r\nstops at several of the major stars. It was supposed to take about\r\neighty-eight million years so they planned to be back for supper.\r\n\r\nIn the beginning the students had remained in a fairly close knot\r\naround mundo Karftahiti, their instructor, but as the tour progressed\r\nsome of the more venturesome strayed further and further from the rest\r\nof the class.\r\n\r\nDro Orena and Dro Xeluchli had wandered a greater distance than usual\r\nfrom the crowd and were jamming experimental thought webs into a large\r\nspace vortex when Xeluchli signalled to Orena to tune her mind off the\r\nlecture frequency. It was against the rules, of course, but then Orena\r\nsupposed Xeluchli would take the blame for her if they were caught, so\r\nshe switched over to the conversational band.\r\n\r\n"Want to have some fun?" asked Xeluchli.\r\n\r\nOrena continued to stare into the space vortex. "How?" she asked.\r\n\r\nXeluchli waved a visible thought fragment in a circle about him. "The\r\nstars," he said. 

"Let\'s explore a little on our own. 

They never hit the\r\nreally good spots on these tours."\r\n\r\nOrena had been thinking for a long time of doing that very thing so she\r\nhardly argued at all before letting Xeluchli convince her.\r\n\r\n"We\'ll be gone only a little while and they\'ll never miss us," said\r\nXeluchli as they headed for a nearby star-cluster.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nEverything would have been all right if they had obeyed the rules.\r\n"Hands off the planets," the rules said, and that was really a\r\nreasonable and intelligent demand. In all fairness to them, it must be\r\nadmitted that Orena and Xeluchli had no intention of breaking that rule\r\nwhen they strayed away from the rest of the crowd.\r\n\r\nThey found this little planet which was listed in the textbook as\r\n"BuP"; an .02F star with nine planets. By a lucky chance they were just\r\nin time to see a transient little civilization spring into being on its\r\nthird planet. This was too wonderful a chance to miss so they decided\r\nto stay a few hundred thousand years and see how it would end. They\r\nwould catch up with the rest of the tour afterward.\r\n\r\nThe creatures entering into civilization were bipeds and of a physical\r\nappearance rather low on the aesthetic scale but Orena and Xeluchli\r\nsoon discovered that they were bi-sexual. This pleased them very much\r\nand made them feel that they had something in common with this little\r\ncivilization, for Orena and Xeluchli were bi-sexuals too, and bi-sexual\r\ncivilizations were rare. Orena and Xeluchli had, in fact, been the\r\nonly bi-sexuals in the touring group, which had been composed mostly\r\nof the slow-moving amoeboids from Procyon and the emotionally unstable\r\npenta-sexuals from Antares.\r\n\r\nIt was a land civilization which they had found and, just as the\r\ntextbooks said, it was having its beginning in the river deltas of\r\nthe continents. The bipeds were both herbivorous and carnivorous and\r\nthe duration and bloodiness of their early wars was almost exactly as\r\npredicted by Globnung\'s food-war formula. The speed of advance of the\r\ncivilization was a little slow, but still comfortably within the lower\r\nlimits of the Atati equation.\r\n\r\nEverything went well for the first five thousand years, but then Orena\r\nand Xeluchli began to catch signs of Gibrait\'s anachronism. 

They\r\nwatched anxiously for a while, and soon they saw that their fears\r\nhad been justified. Sociological advance had fallen so far behind\r\ntechnological advance that the Law of Socio-Martial Flux had been\r\nbrought into play. The little civilization would almost certainly die a\r\npremature death.\r\n\r\nOrena and Xeluchli watched the invention of greater and greater weapons\r\nand the hopeless retardation of the social system and were saddened.\r\nThey had hoped to watch a real civilization and this one was not even\r\ngoing to go past the one-planet stage. They did not see how it could\r\nlast half a century more.\r\n\r\n"And they\'re bi-sexuals, too," said Xeluchli. "It\'s a shame. 

I wish we\r\ncould do something."\r\n\r\n"Yes, but you know what the rules are," reminded Orena. "We can only\r\nwatch. We can\'t help them."\r\n\r\n"I know," said Xeluchli a little crossly. "A bunch of poly-sexuals and\r\nsixth-degree intellectuals make rules and we\'re supposed to obey them.\r\nYou know, I\'m tempted to interfere. No one would know."\r\n\r\nOrena objected, but she was really in favor of violating the rule, too,\r\nand after a while she let Xeluchli have his way.\r\n\r\n"We\'ll start the civilization over," he suggested. Soon her senses and thoughts were operating on a level hardly\r\nabove that of the creatures themselves.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nShe often found herself wishing that she had paid more attention to\r\nher classes in the lower civilizations so she could better understand\r\nthe things she was seeing. We must pay more attention to the _spiritual_." He adjusted\r\nhis eyelenses. 

"I believe that that is one of the major troubles of\r\ncivilization." He tapped the ashes from his cigarette and looked at her\r\nfor confirmation.\r\n\r\n"Hell, yes!" she agreed heartily. "\r\n\r\nThis bit of conversation was enough to convince the somewhat satiated\r\nOrena. His face had a\r\nglisten of sweat under the lowered lights.\r\n\r\nThe lead psych man chose a hypodermic needle, looked to Erwin and\r\nCostain for authority, and administered a second injection.\r\n\r\n"You gave up searching," he said. "What then, Lieutenant?"\r\n\r\n"We waited," Walraven said.\r\n\r\nHe relaxed, his face smoothing to impersonal detachment as his mind\r\nslipped back to the ship and its crew. Watching, Costain felt a sudden\r\ndeep unease as if the man\'s mind had really winged back through time\r\nand space and carried a part of his own with it.\r\n\r\n"There was only one more possible check," Walraven said. "We had to\r\nwait two days for that."\r\n\r\nThe check was Maxon\'s idea, simple of execution and unarguable of\r\nresult. At halfway point acceleration must cease, the ship rotate on\r\nits gyros and deceleration set in. There would be a period of waiting\r\nwhen the power plant must be shut off completely.\r\n\r\nIf the Feeling stemmed from the psi-drive, it would lift then.\r\n\r\nIt did not lift. They sat weightless and disoriented while the gyros\r\nprecessed and the ship swung end by end and the steady pressure of the\r\nFeeling mounted up and up without relief.\r\n\r\n"It gets worse every hour," Vaughn said raggedly.\r\n\r\n"It\'s not a matter of time," Maxon said. "It\'s the distance. The\r\nFeeling grows stronger as we get farther from home."\r\n\r\nThey sat for another time without talk, feeling the distance build up\r\nbehind them and sensing through the unwindowed hull of the ship what\r\nthe emptiness outside must be like. The ship was no longer an armored\r\nprojectile bearing them snugly and swiftly to a first planetfall. It\r\nwas a walnut shell without strength or direction.\r\n\r\nIn the end they talked out their problem because there was nothing else\r\nthey could do.\r\n\r\n"We\'re men," Maxon said, not as if he must convince himself but as if\r\nit were a premise that had to be made, a starting point for all logic.\r\n"We\'re reasoning creatures. If the trouble lies in ourselves we can\r\nfind its source and its reason for being."\r\n\r\nHe picked Vaughn first because Vaughn had been first to sense the\r\nwrongness and because the most sensitive link in a chain is also\r\npredictably its weakest.\r\n\r\n"Try," Maxon said. "I know there are no words to describe this thing,\r\nbut get as close as you can.

"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nVaughn tried. "It isn\'t home-sickness. It\'s a different thing\r\naltogether from nostalgia. It\'s not just fear. I\'m afraid--not of any\r\n_thing_, just afraid in the way a child is afraid of falling in his\r\ndreams, when he\'s really had no experience with falling because he\'s\r\nnever fallen more than a few inches in his life.... When I think of my\r\nwife, it\'s not the same at all as if I were just in some far corner of\r\nthe Earth with only land and water between us. Even if I were marooned\r\non an uncharted island somewhere with no hope of seeing home again, I\r\nwouldn\'t feel this way. 

There wouldn\'t be this awful _pulling_."\r\n\r\nRagan agreed with Vaughn that the Feeling was essentially a _pull_, but\r\nbeyond agreement could add nothing. Ragan had covered the world without\r\nforming a tie to hold him; one place was as good as another and he\r\nfelt no loss for any particular spot on Earth.\r\n\r\n"I only want to be back there," he said simply. "Anywhere but here."\r\n\r\n"I was born on a farm in New England," Walraven said. "Out of the land,\r\nlike my father and his people before him. I\'m part of that land, no\r\nmatter how far from it I go, because everything I am came from it. I\r\nfeel uprooted. 

I don\'t belong here."\r\n\r\n_Uprooted_ was the key for which they had hunted.\r\n\r\nMaxon said slowly, "There are wild animals on Earth that can\'t live\r\naway from their natural homes. Insects--how does a termite feel, cut\r\noff from its hive? Maybe that\'s our trouble. 

Something bigger than\r\nindividual men made the human race what it is. Maybe we\'ve been a sort\r\nof composite being all along, without knowing it, tied together by the\r\nneed of each other and not able to exist apart. Maybe no one knew it\r\nbefore because no one was ever isolated in the way we are."\r\n\r\nWalraven had more to say, almost defiant in his earnestness. "This is\r\ngoing to sound wild, but I\'ve been fighting inside myself ever since\r\nVaughn mentioned being pulled toward home. I have the feeling that if\r\nI\'d only let go, I\'d be back where I belong." He snapped his fingers,\r\nthe sound loud in the room. 

"Like that."\r\n\r\nNo one laughed because each found in himself the same conviction\r\nwaiting to be recognized. Ragan said, "Walraven\'s right. There\'s no\r\nplace on Earth I care for more than another, but I feel I could be back\r\nthere in any one of them"--he snapped his fingers, as Walraven had\r\ndone--"as quickly as that."\r\n\r\n"I know," Maxon said. 

"But we can\'t let go. We were sent out to put\r\nthis ship into orbit around Mars. We\'ve got to take her there."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWalraven said, "It wasn\'t easy. The Feeling got worse as we went out\r\nand out. Knowing what it was helped a little, but not enough. We held\r\nonto each other, the four of us, to keep the group together. We _knew_\r\nwhat would happen if we let go."\r\n\r\nThe head psych man looked to Costain and put his needle away when\r\nCostain shook his head.\r\n\r\n"The ship," Coordinator Erwin said sharply. "Walraven, you did put her\r\ninto orbit?"\r\n\r\n"Yes," Walraven said. "We put her into orbit and turned on the\r\ntelemetering equipment--they\'ll be picking up her signals by now--and\r\nthen we turned our backs on each other and we let go. There wasn\'t any\r\nfeeling of motion or speed, but I felt a fresh breeze on my face and\r\nwhen I opened my eyes I was standing beside a familiar stone fence on\r\na hill above the house where I was born. You haven\'t told me, but the\r\nothers came back, too, didn\'t they?

"\r\n\r\n"All but Ragan," Erwin said. His tone made Costain think wryly, _Even\r\nthe military can snatch at straws_. "Maxon and Vaughn called in. But we\r\nhaven\'t heard from Ragan."\r\n\r\n"He wasn\'t left behind," Walraven said with certainty. "Ragan has no\r\nfamily, but he has a home. We\'re standing on it."\r\n\r\nAn orderly came in with an envelope for Costain, who opened it and\r\nhanded the paper to Erwin. To Walraven, Costain said, "It\'s a cablegram\r\nfrom North Ireland. Ragan is back."\r\n\r\nErwin was still gripping the paper in his hand when he walked with\r\nCostain out of the hospital into the bright airiness of a spring day.\r\nHe glared at the warm, blue sky.\r\n\r\n"We\'ll find a way," Erwin said. "We\'ve proved that we can put men on\r\nMars. With the right conditioning, we can keep them there."\r\n\r\n"You\'re a dedicated and resolute man, Coordinator," Costain said. 

"Do\r\nyou really suppose that any amount of conditioning could fit you to do\r\nwhat those boys failed at?"\r\n\r\nThe long moment of considering that passed before Erwin answered left a\r\nfine sheen of sweat on his face.\r\n\r\n"No," Erwin said.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


All the\r\nwrecks nest there while waiting hopefully for a payload or a\r\ngrubstake. 

They have all of Solis Lacus for a landing field, and if\r\nthey spill it doesn\'t matter much. The drifting red sands soon cover\r\nup the scattered shards of dural and the slow, lonely life of Yakki\r\ngoes on like before.\r\n\r\nThe Patrol was on Kane\'s trail and the blaster in his hand was still\r\nwarm when he shoved it up against Pop Ganlon\'s ribs and made his\r\nproposition.\r\n\r\nHe wanted to get off Mars--out to Callisto. To Blackwater, to Ley\'s\r\nLanding, it didn\'t matter too much. Just off Mars, and quickly. 

His\r\neyes had a metallic glitter and his hand was rock-steady. Pop knew he\r\nmeant what he said when he told him life was cheap. Someone else\'s\r\nlife, not Kane\'s.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThat\'s how it happened that _The Luck_ lifted that night from Yakki,\r\noutward bound for Ley\'s Landing, with Pop and Kane aboard her alone.\r\n\r\nSitting at the battered console of _The Luck_, Pop watched his\r\npassenger. He knew Kane, of course. Or rather, he knew of him. 

A\r\nkiller. The kind that thrives and grows fat on the frontiers. The\r\nbulky frame, the cropped black hair, the predatory eyes that looked\r\nlike two blaster muzzles. They were all familiar to Pop. Kane was all\r\nsteel and meanness. The kind of carrion bird that took what others had\r\nworked for. 

Not big time, you understand. In another age he\'d have\r\nbeen a torpedo--a hireling killer. But out among the stars he was\r\nworking for himself. And doing well.\r\n\r\nPop didn\'t care. His loyalty to the Patrol had stopped quite suddenly\r\nnot long before--in a dark alley in Lower Marsport. This was only a\r\njob, he told himself now. A job for coffee and cakes, and maybe a\r\ngrubstake to work a few more lonely rocks. Life had become a habit for\r\nPop, even if living had ended.\r\n\r\n"What are you staring at, Pop?" Kane\'s voice was like the rest of him.\r\nHarsh and cold as space itself.\r\n\r\n"At you, I guess," Pop said, "I was wondering what you\'d done--and\r\nwhere--and to whom."\r\n\r\n"You\'re a nosey old man," Kane said. "Just get me to Ley\'s Landing.\r\nThat\'s what I\'m paying for, not a thing more."\r\n\r\nPop nodded slowly and turned back to the control board. They were\r\nabove the Belt by now, and a few short hours from turnover point. The\r\ncranky drives of _The Luck_ needed all his attention.\r\n\r\nPresently he said, "We\'ll be turning over soon. Want to get some\r\nrest?"\r\n\r\nKane laughed. "No thanks, old man. I\'ll stay here and watch you."\r\n\r\nPop eyed the ready blaster and nodded again. He wondered vaguely how\r\nit would feel to die under the blast of such a weapon. It couldn\'t be\r\nvery painful. He hoped it wasn\'t painful. Perhaps the boy hadn\'t\r\nsuffered. It would be nice to be sure, he thought.\r\n\r\nThere wasn\'t much for Pop to remember about the boy. He\'d never been\r\none for writing many letters. But the District Patrolman had come down\r\nto Yakki and looked Pop up--afterward. He\'d said the boy was a good\r\nofficer. A good cop. Died doing his job, and all that sort of thing.\r\nPop swallowed hard. His job. What had \'his job\' been that night in\r\nLower Marsport, he wondered. Had someone else finished it for him?\r\n\r\nHe remembered about that time hearing on the Mars Radio that a\r\nTriangle Post Office had been knocked over by a gunman. That might\r\nhave been it. The Patrol would be after anyone knocking over EMV\r\nTriangle property. The Earth-Mars-Venus Government supported the\r\nPatrol for things like that.\r\n\r\nPop guided _The Luck_ skillfully above the Belt, avoiding with\r\npracticed ease the few errant chunks of rock that hurtled up out of\r\nthe swarms. He talked to Kane because he was starved for\r\ntalk--certainly not because he was trying to play Sherlock. Pop had\r\nlong ago realized that he was no mental giant. Besides, he owed the\r\nPatrol nothing. Not a damned thing.\r\n\r\n"Made this trip often?" Pop tried to strike up a conversation with\r\nKane. His long loneliness seemed sharper, somehow, more poignant,\r\nwhen he actually had someone to talk to.\r\n\r\n"Not often. I\'m no space pig." It was said with scorn.\r\n\r\n"There\'s a lot to spacing, you know," Pop urged.\r\n\r\nKane shrugged. "I know easier ways to make a buck, old timer.

"\r\n\r\n"Like how?"\r\n\r\n"A nosey old man, like I said," Kane smiled. Somehow, the smile wasn\'t\r\nfriendly. "Okay, Pop, since you ask. Like knocking off wacky old\r\nprospectors for their dust. Or sticking up sandcar caravans out in\r\nSyrtis. Who\'s the wiser? The red dust takes care of the leftovers."\r\n\r\nPop shook his head. 

"Not for me. There\'s the Patrol to think of."\r\n\r\nKane laughed. "Punks. Bell-boys. They\'d better learn to shoot before\r\nthey leave their school-books."\r\n\r\nPop Ganlon frowned slightly. 

"You talk big, mister."\r\n\r\nKane\'s eyes took on that metallic glitter again. He leaned forward and\r\nthrew a canvas packet on the console. It spilled crisp new EMV\r\ncertificates. Large ones. "I take big, too," he said.\r\n\r\nPop stared. Not at the money. It was more than he had ever seen in one\r\npile before, but it wasn\'t that that shook him. It was the canvas\r\npacket. It was marked: _Postal Service, EMV_. Pop suddenly felt cold,\r\nas though an icy wind had touched him.\r\n\r\n"You ... you killed a Patrolman for this," he said slowly.\r\n\r\n"That\'s right, Pop," grinned Kane easily. "Burned him down in an alley\r\nin Lower Marsport. It was like taking candy from a baby...."\r\n\r\nPop Ganlon swallowed hard. "Like taking candy from a ... baby. As easy\r\nas that...."\r\n\r\n"As easy as that, old man," Kane said.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nPop knew he was going to die then. He knew Kane would blast him right\r\nafter turnover point, and he knew fear. He felt something else, too.\r\nSomething that was new to him. Hate. An icy hate that left him shaken\r\nand weak.\r\n\r\nSo the boy\'s job hadn\'t been finished. It was still to do.\r\n\r\nThere was no use in dreaming of killing Kane. Pop was old. Kane was\r\nyoung--and a killer. Pop was alone and without weapons--save _The\r\nLuck_....\r\n\r\nTime passed slowly. Outside, the night of deep space keened\r\nsoundlessly. The stars burned bright, alien and strange. 

It was time,\r\nthought Pop bleakly. Time to turn _The Luck_.\r\n\r\n"Turnover point," he said softly.\r\n\r\nKane motioned with his blaster. "Get at it."\r\n\r\nPop began winding the flywheel. It made a whirring sound in the\r\nconfined space of the tiny control room. Outside, the night began to\r\npivot slowly.\r\n\r\n"We have to turn end-for-end," Pop said. "That way we can decelerate\r\non the drop into Callisto. But, of course, you know all about that,\r\nMr. 

Kane."\r\n\r\n"I told you I\'m no space pig," Kane said brusquely. "I can handle a\r\nlanding and maybe a takeoff, but the rest of it I leave for the\r\nboatmen. 

Like you, Pop."\r\n\r\nPop spun the flywheel in silence, listening to the soft whir.\r\nPresently, he let the wheel slow and then stop. He straightened and\r\nlooked up at Kane. The blaster muzzle was six inches from his belly.\r\nHe swallowed against the dryness in his throat.\r\n\r\n"You ... you\'re going to kill me," Pop said. It wasn\'t a question.\r\nKane smiled, showing white teeth.\r\n\r\n"I ... I know you are," Pop said unsteadily. "But first, I want to say\r\nsomething to you."\r\n\r\n"Talk, old timer," Kane said. "But not too much."\r\n\r\n"That boy--that boy you killed in Marsport. He was my son," Pop said.\r\n\r\nKane\'s face did not change expression. "Okay. 

So what?"\r\n\r\nPop\'s lips twitched. "I just wanted to hear you say it." He looked at\r\nthe impassive face of the killer. "You made a mistake, Mr. Kane. You\r\nshouldn\'t have done that to my boy."\r\n\r\n"Is that all?"\r\n\r\nPop nodded slowly. "I guess that\'s all."\r\n\r\nKane grinned. "Afraid, old man?"\r\n\r\n"I\'m a space pig," Pop said. "Space takes care of its own."\r\n\r\n"You\'re in a bad way, old timer," Kane said, "and you haven\'t much\r\nsense. I\'m doing you a favor."\r\n\r\nPop lifted his hands in an instinctive gesture of futile protection as\r\nthe blaster erupted flame.\r\n\r\nThere was a smell in the control room like burnt meat as Kane\r\nholstered his weapon and turned the old man over with a foot. Pop was\r\na blackened mass. Kane dragged him to the valve and jettisoned the\r\nbody into space.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAlone among the stars, _The Luck_ moved across the velvet night. The\r\nsteady beat of flame from her tubes was a tiny spark of man-made\r\nvengeance on the face of the deeps.\r\n\r\nFrom her turnover point, she drove outward toward the spinning Jovian\r\nmoons. For a short while she could be seen from the EMV Observatory on\r\nCallisto, but very soon she faded into the outer darkness.\r\n\r\nMuch later, the Observatory at Land\'s End on Triton watched her\r\nheading past the gibbous mass of Pluto--out into the interstellar\r\nfastnesses.\r\n\r\nThe thrumming of the jets was still at last. A wild-eyed thing that\r\nmay once have been a man stared in horror at the fading light of the\r\nyellow star far astern.\r\n\r\nIt had taken Kane time to understand what had happened to him, and now\r\nit was too late. Space had taken care of its own. 

The air in _The\r\nLuck_ was growing foul and the food was gone. Death hung in the fetid\r\natmosphere of the tiny control room.\r\n\r\nThe old man--the boy--the money. They all seemed to spin in a\r\nnarrowing circle. Kane wanted suddenly to shriek with laughter. A\r\ncircle. 

The turnover circle. The full circle that the old man had made\r\ninstead of the proper half-turn of a turnover. Three hundred sixty\r\ndegrees instead of one hundred eighty. Three hundred sixty degrees to\r\nleave the nose of _The Luck_ pointing outward toward the stars,\r\ninstead of properly toward the Sun. A full circle to pile G on G until\r\nthe Jovian moons were missed, and the Uranian moons and Triton, too.\r\n_Ad Astra per Ardua...._\r\n\r\nWith the last fragment of his failing sanity, Kane thought of how Pop\r\nGanlon and the boy must be laughing. He was still thinking that as the\r\nlong night closed in around him.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


He\r\ncontinued, however, to slump loosely against the curving, pearly plastic\r\nof the wall, and took care not to glance toward the translucent ovals he\r\nknew to be observation panels.\r\n\r\nHe was a large man, but thin and bony-faced. His dirty gray coverall\r\nbore the name "Barnsley" upon grimy white tape over the heart. Except at\r\nthe shoulders, it looked too big for him. His hair was dark brown, but\r\nthe sandy ginger of his two-week beard seemed a better match for his\r\nblue eyes.\r\n\r\nFinally, he satisfied the softly insistent gong by standing up and\r\ngazing in turn at each of the three doors spaced around the cylindrical\r\nchamber. He deliberately adopted an expression of simple-minded\r\nanticipation as he ambled over to the nearest one.\r\n\r\nThe door was round, about four feet in diameter, and set in a flattened\r\npart of the wall with its lower edge tangent with the floor. Rods about\r\ntwo inches thick projected a hand\'s breadth at four, eight, and twelve\r\no\'clock. The markings around them suggested that each could be rotated\r\nto three different positions. Barnsley squatted on his heels to study\r\nthese.\r\n\r\nNoting that all the rods were set at the position he had learned to\r\nthink of as "one," he reached out to touch the door. It felt slightly\r\nwarm, so he allowed his fingertips to slide over the upper handle. A\r\ntentative tug produced no movement of the door.\r\n\r\n"That\'s it, though," he mumbled quietly. "Well, now to do our little act\r\nwith the others!"\r\n\r\nHe moved to the second door, where all the rods were set at "two." Here\r\nhe fell to manipulating the rod handles, pausing now and then to shove\r\nhopefully against the door. Some twenty minutes later, he tried the same\r\nroutine at the third door.\r\n\r\nEventually, he returned to his starting point and rotated the rods there\r\nat random for a few minutes. Having, apparently by accident, arranged\r\nthem in a sequence of one-two-three, he contrived to lean against the\r\ndoor at the crucial instant. As it gave beneath his weight, he grabbed\r\nthe two lower handles and pushed until the door rose to a horizontal\r\nposition level with its hinged top. It settled there with a loud click.\r\n\r\n                 *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBarnsley stooped to crawl through into an arched passage of the same\r\npearly plastic. He straightened up and walked along for about twenty\r\nfeet, flashing a white-toothed grin through his beard while muttering\r\ncurses behind it. Presently, he arrived at a small, round bay, to be\r\nconfronted by three more doors.\r\n\r\n"Bet there\'s a dozen of you three-eyed clods peeping at me," he growled.\r\n"How\'d you like me to poke a boot through the panel in front of you and\r\nkick you blubber-balls in all directions? Do you have a page in your\r\ndata books for that?

"\r\n\r\nHe forced himself to _feel_ sufficiently dull-witted to waste ten\r\nminutes opening one of the doors. The walls of the succeeding passage\r\nwere greenish, and the tunnel curved gently downward to the left.\r\nBesides being somewhat warmer, the air exuded a faint blend of heated\r\nmachine oil and something like ripe fish. The next time Barnsley came to\r\na set of doors, he found also a black plastic cube about two feet high.\r\nHe squatted on his heels to examine it.\r\n\r\n_I\'d better look inside or they\'ll be disappointed_, he told himself.\r\n\r\nFrom the corner of his eye, he watched the movement of shadows behind\r\nthe translucent panels in the walls. He could picture the observers\r\nthere: blubbery bipeds with three-jointed arms and legs ending in\r\nclusters of stubby but flexible tentacles. Their broad, spine-crested\r\nheads would be thrust forward and each would have two of his three\r\nprotruding eyes directed at Barnsley\'s slightest move. They had probably\r\nbeen staring at him in relays every second since picking up his scout\r\nship in the neighboring star system.\r\n\r\nThat is, Barnsley thought, it must have been the next system whose\r\nfourth planet he had been photo-mapping for the Terran Colonial Service.\r\nHe hoped he had not been wrong about that.\r\n\r\n_Doesn\'t matter_, he consoled himself, _as long as the Service can trace\r\nme. These slobs certainly aren\'t friendly._\r\n\r\nHe reconsidered the scanty evidence of previous contact in this volume\r\nof space, light-years from Terra\'s nearest colony. Two exploratory ships\r\nhad disappeared. There had been a garbled, fragmentary message picked up\r\nby the recorders of the colony\'s satellite beacon, which some experts\r\ninterpreted as a hasty warning. As far as he knew, Barnsley was the only\r\nTerran to reach this planet alive.\r\n\r\nTo judge from his peculiar imprisonment, his captors had recovered from\r\ntheir initial dismay at encountering another intelligent race--at least\r\nto the extent of desiring a specimen for study. In Barnsley\'s opinion,\r\nthat put him more or less ahead of the game.\r\n\r\n"They\'re gonna learn a lot!" he muttered, grinning vindictively.\r\n\r\nHe finished worrying the cover off the black box. Inside was a plastic\r\nsphere of water and several varieties of food his captors probably\r\nconsidered edible. The latter ranged from a leafy stalk bearing a number\r\nof small pods to a crumbling mass resembling moldy cheese. Barnsley\r\nhesitated.\r\n\r\n"I haven\'t had the guts to try this one yet," he reminded himself,\r\npicking out what looked like a cluster of long, white roots.\r\n\r\nThe roots squirmed feebly in his grasp. Barnsley returned them to the\r\nbox instantly.\r\n\r\nHaving selected, instead, a fruit that could have been a purple\r\ncucumber, he put it with the water container into a pocket of his\r\ncoverall and closed the box.\r\n\r\n_Maybe they won\'t remember that I took the same thing once before_, he\r\nthought. _Oh, hell, of course they will! But why be too consistent?_\r\n\r\nHe opened one of the doors and walked along a bluish passage that\r\ntwisted to the left, chewing on the purple fruit as he went. It was\r\ntougher than it looked and nearly tasteless. 

At the next junction, he\r\nunscrewed the cap of the water sphere, drained it slowly, and flipped\r\nthe empty container at one of the oval panels. A dim shadow blurred out\r\nof sight, as if someone had stepped hastily backward.\r\n\r\n"Why not?" 

growled Barnsley. "It\'s time they were shaken up a little!"\r\n\r\n                 *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nPretending to have seen something where the container had struck the\r\nwall, he ran over and began to feel along the edge of the panel. When\r\nhis fingertips encountered only the slightest of seams, he doubled his\r\nfists and pounded. He thought he could detect a faint scurrying on the\r\nother side of the wall.\r\n\r\nBarnsley laughed aloud. He raised one foot almost waist-high and drove\r\nthe heel of his boot through the translucent observation panel. Seizing\r\nthe splintered edges of the hole, he tugged and heaved until he had torn\r\nout enough of the thin wall to step through to the other side. He found\r\nhimself entering a room not much larger than the passage behind him.\r\n\r\nTo his left, there was a flicker of blue from a crack in the wall. The\r\ncrack widened momentarily, emitting a gabble of mushy voices. The blue\r\ncloth was twitched away by a cluster of stubby tentacles, whereupon the\r\ncrack closed to an almost imperceptible line. Barnsley fingered his\r\nbeard to hide a grin and turned the other way.\r\n\r\nHe stumbled into a number of low stools surmounted by spongy, spherical\r\ncushions. One of these he tore off for a pillow before going on. At the\r\nend of the little room, he sought for another crack, kicked the panel\r\na bit to loosen it, and succeeded in sliding back a section of wall.\r\nThe passage revealed was about the size of those he had been forced\r\nto explore during the past two weeks, but it had an unfinished,\r\nbehind-the-scenes crudeness in appearance. Barnsley pottered along\r\nfor about fifteen minutes, during which time the walls resounded with\r\ndistant running and he encountered several obviously improvised\r\nbarriers.\r\n\r\nHe kicked his way through one, squeezed through an opening that had not\r\nbeen closed quite in time, restrained a wicked impulse to cross some\r\nwiring that must have been electrical, and at last allowed himself to be\r\ndiverted into a passage leading back to his original cell. He amused\r\nhimself by trying to picture the disruption he had caused to the\r\nhoneycomb of passageways.\r\n\r\n"There!" he grinned to himself. "That should keep them from bothering me\r\nfor a few hours. 

Maybe one or two of them will get in trouble over it--I\r\nhope!"\r\n\r\nHe arranged his stolen cushion where the wall met the floor and lay\r\ndown.\r\n\r\nA thought struck him. He sat up to examine the cushion suspiciously.\r\nIt appeared to be an equivalent to foam rubber. He prodded and twisted\r\nuntil convinced that no wires or other unexpected objects were concealed\r\ninside. Not till then did he resume his relaxed position.\r\n\r\nPresently one of his hands located and pinched a tiny switch buried\r\nin the lobe of his left ear. Barnsley concentrated upon keeping his\r\nfeatures blank as a rushing sound seemed to grow in his ear. He yawned\r\ncasually, moving one hand from behind his head to cover his mouth.\r\n\r\nHaving practiced many times before a mirror, he did not think that any\r\npossible watcher would have noticed how his thumb slipped briefly inside\r\nhis mouth to give one eyetooth a slight twist.\r\n\r\nA strong humming inundated his hearing. It continued for perhaps two\r\nminutes, paused, and began again. Barnsley waited through two repetitions\r\nbefore he "yawned" again and sleepily rolled over to hide his face in his\r\nfolded arms.\r\n\r\n"Did you get it all?" he murmured.\r\n\r\n"Clear as a bell," replied a tiny voice in his left ear. "Was that your\r\nwhole day\'s recording?"\r\n\r\n"I guess so," said Barnsley. "To tell the truth, I lose track a bit\r\nafter two weeks without a watch. Who\'s this? 

Sanchez?"\r\n\r\n"That\'s right. You seem to come in on my watch pretty nearly every\r\ntwenty-four hours. Okay, I\'ll tape a slowed-down version of your blast\r\nfor the boys in the back room. You\'re doing fine."\r\n\r\n                 *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Not for much longer," Barnsley told him. "When do I get out of here?"\r\n\r\n"Any day," Sanchez reassured him. "It was some job to learn an alien\r\nlanguage with just your recordings and some of your educated guesses to\r\ngo on. We\'ve had a regular mob sweating on it night and day.

"\r\n\r\n"How is it coming?

"\r\n\r\n"It turns out they\'re nothing to worry about. The fleet is close enough\r\nnow to pick up their surface broadcasting. Believe me, your stupid act\r\nhas them thoroughly confused. They hold debates over whether you could\r\npossibly be intelligent enough to belong in a spaceship."\r\n\r\n"Meanwhile, I\'m slowly starving," said Barnsley.\r\n\r\n"Just hang on for a couple of days. Now that we know where they are,\r\nthey\'re in for a shock. 

One of these mornings, they\'re going to hear\r\nvoices from all over their skies, demanding to know what kind of savages\r\nthey are to have kidnapped you--and in their own language!"\r\n\r\nBarnsley grinned into his improvised pillow as Sanchez signed off.\r\nThings would really work out after all. He was set for an immensely\r\nlucrative position; whether as ambassador, trade consultant, or colonial\r\ngovernor depended upon how well the experts bluffed the blubber-heads.\r\nWell, it seemed only his due for the risks he had taken.\r\n\r\n"Omigosh!" he grunted, sitting up as he pictured the horde of Terran\r\nColonial experts descending upon the planet.

"\r\n\r\nThe old lady poured the glass full again. And then she sprinkled sugar\r\ndown among the apple cubes in the casserole and covered them with a\r\nblanket of dough. "\r\n\r\n"Well, it isn\'t so, is it, Aunt Twylee?"\r\n\r\nThe room was filled with blinding blue-white light, and the walls quaked\r\nat the sound of a monstrous thunderclap.\r\n\r\nThe old Martian glanced nervously at the clock on the wall. In great\r\nvolumes of water, it fell, as though the heavens were attempting to wash\r\nthe sins of man from the universe and into non-existence in the void\r\nbeyond the void.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nMarilou lay beside the other children. What water fell was a monotonous trickle from the\r\neaves of the lime-washed stone house. Aunt Twylee washed the blood from\r\nthe knife and wiped it dry on her apron. She opened the oven and took\r\nout the browned cobbler. Sweet apple juice bubbled to the surface\r\nthrough the half moons and burst in delights of sugary aroma. The sun\r\nbroke through the thinning edge of the thunderhead.\r\n\r\nAunt Twylee brushed a lock of her feathery white hair from her moist\r\ncheek. "Gracious," she said, "I must tidy up a bit before the others\r\ncome."\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _If Worlds of Science Fiction_ July\r\n    1953. ]\r\n\r\n\r\nKlon fled from fern to fern like a drifting shadow, circling the new\r\nclearing that had been torn in the steamy jungle by the gleaming\r\nmonster that had come from the eternal fog that clothed his world. He\r\nhalted now and then, slipped into the stagnant water that covered nine\r\ntenths of the planet, and listened for the slightest sound that would\r\nwarn him of a hidden watcher spying on his movements.\r\n\r\nSatisfied that he was alone in the jungle swamp, he edged closer to the\r\nclearing whose edge was a charred and ragged circle. His lidless eye\r\ngleamed phosphorescently in the darkness that never changed, bringing\r\ninto sharp detail the shadows that were two shades of blackness for\r\nthere were no colors on his earth.\r\n\r\nHe slipped over the burned ground, wincing at the bruises given him by\r\nthe unaccustomed hardness beneath his body. He hissed a bit in anger\r\nthat he should suffer so, then went rigid as the thing happened again.\r\n\r\nAn amazingly light shadow had suddenly come into being on the roundness\r\nof the gleaming visitor from somewhere above.\r\n\r\nKlon wanted that shadow, wanted that thing that was brighter than\r\nanything he had ever seen--and his purpose was to gain it in any way\r\npossible. For possession of that light shadow would make him greater\r\nthan anyone else on the planet. Mightier even than Valok.\r\n\r\nKlon knew that his time was growing short; the nation would declare\r\ntheir new leader within a very short while, and he knew that possession\r\nof that light shadow was the one thing that would assure him of victory\r\nover his rival for leadership.\r\n\r\nHis gills opened and closed automatically, involuntary muscles working\r\neven when his lungs worked on the damp air. He winced a bit from the\r\nlightness of the shadow, for never had his eye seen one that was so\r\nwithout blackness.\r\n\r\nAnd then Klon was at the roundness of the thing, the touch of its\r\ncoolness sending a thrill of dread through his heart. He moved slowly\r\nuntil he was just below the circle of lightness, then climbed upwards\r\nwith his sucker-discs.\r\n\r\nSlowly, carefully, instantly ready for flight to safety, he lifted his\r\nhead until his eye was pressed against the light shadow. He felt tiny\r\npains running through his eye, back into his head, and down into his\r\nbody, but he gave it no heed.\r\n\r\nFor he was seeing something that none other of his race had had the\r\ncourage to face. He saw things but dimly, and the hideousness of the\r\nscene almost made him lose his hold.\r\n\r\nFor nightmarish creatures moved within the gleaming thing, moving on\r\nstiff tentacles, gesturing with others, while above, on a thin neck,\r\nfanged mouths opened and closed in sickening motions. And the shadows\r\nof their skins were of shades of lightness and darkness that were\r\nterrifying to Klon\'s senses that had never met the like before.\r\n\r\nHe gasped audibly, swung back from the circle of lightness, shaking\r\nwith horror at what he had seen.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nInside the gleaming space ship, three men were seated on the\r\ncollapsible bunks. Kurt Overland, his muscular body unclad except for\r\nshorts, was speaking in his even tone.\r\n\r\n"Well," he said cheerfully, even his steady voice failing to conceal\r\nthe burning eagerness within him, "we\'re finally ready. 

I\'ve just made\r\nthe last repair on the things broken by landing."\r\n\r\nFrank Barker grinned at him from across the cell-like room, stretched\r\nhis six feet of blond-topped, lanky strength happily.\r\n\r\n"Suits me," he said, "I\'m tired of being cooped in this animated bullet\r\nthat\'s been home for so long."\r\n\r\n"We had to wait," gray-haired Professor Kent said mildly, "After all,\r\nif we are met by hostile beings, we want to be able to escape."\r\n\r\nKurt Overland grinned. "Maybe you\'re right, Professor," he said. "But\r\nI\'d hate to return to Earth and say that we\'d been run off before we\r\nhad a chance to bring back proof of our expedition\'s success."\r\n\r\n"That would be a calamity," Barker broke in. "Remember what a devil of\r\na time we had getting permission to make this flight through space.\r\nThe President told me, just before we took off, that because of the\r\nmany deaths in faulty rockets a law was being passed to forbid any more\r\nflights. He said that it was only his influence that made it possible\r\nfor us to leave Earth on a trip to Venus, and that if we failed to make\r\ngood there would probably be no more flights for, possibly, hundreds of\r\nyears."\r\n\r\n"So!" Professor Kent nodded his head. "Then I am glad that we did not\r\nfail; for it is apparent that we are the vanguard of a new phase of our\r\ncivilization."\r\n\r\nKurt Overland stood, flexed his arms. "Well, come on, let\'s go," he\r\nsaid. 

"It\'s time we took a look around."\r\n\r\nThe three of them slipped into their space suits, each of them\r\ntight-breathed with eagerness to explore the second of the planets.\r\nThey were strangely silent as they dressed.\r\n\r\n"Better slip the cover over that radi-light," Professor Kent tried to\r\nkeep his tone even. "There may be poisonous insects outside that would\r\nbe attracted by it. 

We will go outside without lights, then switch them\r\non when the port is closed."\r\n\r\nFrank Barker moved toward the radi-light, slipped the cover over its\r\neternal brightness with a gloved hand. Then he joined the other two\r\nat the port. For a long second the three of them stood shoulder to\r\nshoulder.\r\n\r\n"Professor Kent," Kurt Overland said softly, "please go first. It is\r\nyour right that you should be the first to step onto a world made\r\naccessible only by your genius."\r\n\r\nProfessor Albert Kent\'s shoulders shook silently for a moment in great\r\nemotion, then straightened with pride. He nodded, swung shut his visor\r\nplate, dogged it securely.\r\n\r\nBarker and Overland followed suit, clicked on their radio receivers.\r\nThey waited patiently for their leader, knowing the feelings that must\r\nhave been his at the moment.\r\n\r\nAnd then, unsealing the port, clutching the American flag gently in\r\nhis left hand ready for its planting on Venus, Professor Kent stepped\r\nthrough the port, the first human to land on the veiled planet. Behind\r\nhim, following with a clumsy speed, came Frank Barker and Kurt Overland.\r\n\r\n"We three--" Professor Albert Kent began.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nKlon dropped from the side of the ship.\r\n\r\nHe paused for a moment over the lifeless bodies of the three intrepid\r\nexplorers, then moved away, disgusted by his closeness to the horrible\r\ncreatures he had slain so swiftly and casually.\r\n\r\nHis every sense was alert for the slightest movement on the long\r\ngleaming thing beside him to retaliate in quick vengeance for the\r\nslaying of the things that lived within its belly.\r\n\r\nKlon crouched there for moments, then moved toward the ship. He climbed\r\ninto the port entrance, leaving a thick trail of slime in his wake. He\r\nmoved eagerly toward the small hole in the opposite wall, his heart\r\nthudding with bursting eagerness.\r\n\r\nHe had seen Frank Barker slip the shield over the shadow that was so\r\nunlike anything on his earth. And now he moved through the darkness of\r\nthe space ship, slipping surely through a darkness that was natural to\r\nhim and his fellow creatures.\r\n\r\nHe lifted the small box from its recess, turned and sped from the ship,\r\nvague terror and superstition overcoming the courage that had taken\r\nso long to build to a white heat. He rushed past the men who slept\r\nthe eternal sleep before the port of their ship, slipped into the\r\nwarm water at the edge of the clearing, began his long journey to the\r\nmeeting place at which a leader would be chosen.\r\n\r\nHe clasped the box close to him as he raced through the swampy jungle,\r\nafraid that it might disappear before he could reach his destination.\r\nHe did not pause to examine his prize, knowing that the time was\r\ngrowing short, feeling certain a longer wait would only make the globe\r\nof lightness more thrilling.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe people of Klon\'s nation were gathered in the Council Clearing,\r\nsilent as each of the candidates for leader extolled his own virtues\r\nand explained his qualification for the position as their leader.\r\n\r\nHisses of approval and sounds of disapproval greeted each candidate as\r\nhe placed himself on the stone at the clearing\'s center.\r\n\r\nAnd then Klon slipped into the clearing. He hissed greetings as he made\r\nhis way to the central stone. Still clutching the box tightly to his\r\nbody, he climbed to the top of the stone, faced his nation.\r\n\r\nA respectful silence fell as his powerful body loomed high in the air\r\nover the heads of his people.\r\n\r\nKlon stood for a moment, silently considering the short speech he\r\nintended to make. He caught the glance of Valok\'s eye, looked away.\r\nHis gaze travelled over the clearing, making out familiar features of\r\nhis people.\r\n\r\nThe crowd was not large, for Klon\'s nation was a small one. It was\r\nlarge in the sense that no other group on the planet was as large. And\r\nit was the only race with useful intelligence.\r\n\r\nKlon looked at his people, and pride made his heart beat even faster.\r\n\r\n"I am here to prove to you that I am the mightiest among you," he\r\nhissed. "I have here the thing that will prove what I say." 

He lifted\r\nthe small box so that everyone could see.\r\n\r\nA wave of interested hissing grew in sudden applause, then a respectful\r\nsilence fell again. Klon hesitated for a moment longer, then continued:\r\n\r\n"I got this thing from the belly of the thing that came from the\r\nclouds, killing three horrible creatures single-handedly. Thus I have\r\nproved that I am clever, brave and strong."\r\n\r\n"What is this thing you have brought us, Brave Klon?" Valok\'s sneering\r\nhiss broke in upon Klon\'s words.\r\n\r\n"A thing that is like nothing any of you have ever seen; it is a shadow\r\nlighter than anything on this world," Klon said proudly, and placed the\r\nsmall box on the rock beside himself.\r\n\r\nHe paused again, knowing the effect his wait would have on his\r\naudience. And then he whisked the cover from the radi-light, slid from\r\nthe central stone.\r\n\r\nThe radi-light flared with a dazzling, gleaming whiteness on the\r\nstone, bringing with it a light such as had never penetrated the\r\nalways-present clouds that veiled Venus. Klon stood proudly to one\r\nside, drinking in the hissing applause and hisses of surprise and awe\r\nthat greeted his showing of the globe of light shadow. He knew then\r\nthat he had won the coveted leadership of his nation.\r\n\r\n"This," he hissed over the uproar of his people, "is the--"\r\n\r\nKlon gasped in sudden intolerable agony, fiery fingers of pain tearing\r\nat every bit of his body, cutting off his speech almost at its very\r\ninception. He crumpled slowly to the ground, dimly conscious that other\r\ncries were echoing his own.\r\n\r\nHe died then, hearing the agonized hisses of his friends, his last\r\nsight of life being that of the globe that burned with a white-hot\r\nlight on the top of the central stone.\r\n\r\nAnd slowly, but with increasing speed, his people died too. They fell\r\nlike tiny trees before a huge storm, falling even as they tried to find\r\na reason for the death around them. 

Like a wave eddying out from the\r\ncentral stone, death cut its merciless sweep.\r\n\r\nAnd within seconds there was no life in the clearing. Within seconds\r\nan entire nation, every intelligent being on Venus, was dead of the\r\nunleashed light rays, the like of which had never penetrated the miles\r\nof fog that lay between earth and the sun.\r\n\r\nThe radi-light gleamed brightly on the central stone, shedding radiance\r\nover the last beings of intelligence ever to be on Venus--perhaps\r\nforever!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEnd of Project Gutenberg\'s The Victory of Klon, by Wilbur S. Peacock\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


You don\'t miss\r\na thing."\r\n\r\n_I can\'t afford to_, the alien\'s telepathic voice said. _The first rule\r\nin thievery is never to trust an accomplice._\r\n\r\n"That makes sense," Kiley admitted. "Only there\'s no way I can escape\r\nyou--not when you can telepath anywhere in the galaxy. How do I get to\r\nyour planet?"\r\n\r\n_Don\'t trouble yourself. Simply blast off and I\'ll assume mental\r\ncontrol of your ship once you\'re out in space. I\'d prefer that the\r\nlocation of my world remain a secret even to you._\r\n\r\nKiley shrugged. "Okay. 

I won\'t argue. 

I\'m blasting off now."\r\n\r\nHe jabbed down on the firing stud.\r\n\r\nThe stolen spaceship sprang up into the void, and Kiley felt the\r\nalien\'s mental emanations enfolding him, seizing control of the ship,\r\nguiding it--just as, a month before, similar emanations had come to\r\nhim in the darkness of a jail cell in the Under-Dungeon of Alpheraz VII.\r\n\r\nThey had nailed him for a bungled burglary--he\'d have made it, all\r\nright, except that he hadn\'t foreseen one of the new-model psionic\r\nalarms--and, since he was a four-timer, they\'d stuck him in solitary\r\ndeep in the dank heart of the planet.\r\n\r\nThe guard, a thick-muscled Alpherazian with three cold, slitted eyes,\r\nhad hurled him into the cell, thrown him sprawling against the slimy\r\nstone.\r\n\r\n"That ought to hold you, Kiley!" the Alpherazian growled. 

"You\'ve\r\nstolen your last jewel, Earthman."\r\n\r\n"Get out of here!" Kiley said thinly. "Don\'t stand here and gloat. I\'d\r\nbe free and out of here if that crazy alarm hadn\'t popped off."\r\n\r\nThe guard chuckled. "Relax and cool off, Kiley. You\'ve got plenty of\r\ntime to get used to your new home."\r\n\r\nThe door clanged shut. Kiley spat in the darkness as he heard the bolt\r\nslipping home--the unbreakable, foolproof bolt of the escape proof\r\nAlpheraz jail. And then--\r\n\r\n_How would you like to be free in five minutes?_ a voice asked.\r\n\r\n"Huh? Who\'s there?" Kiley looked around, narrowing his eyes to see in\r\nthe foggy blackness, but there was no one within sight.\r\n\r\n_Don\'t strain your eyes_, the voice said--and Kiley realized it was an\r\nunspoken voice in his mind. _I\'m a thousand light-years away. The name\r\nis Thaklaru._\r\n\r\n"Who are you? _What_ are you?

"\r\n\r\n_That doesn\'t concern you. I need your professional services, and I\r\nhave a proposition to make._\r\n\r\n"Go ahead," Kiley said, mystified.\r\n\r\n_You\'re a jewel-thief--and a good one. I can aid you in such a way that\r\nyou\'ll be a perfect one._\r\n\r\n"What do you mean?"\r\n\r\n_How would you like the power of instant hypnosis?_ the alien asked.\r\n_You could go anywhere you liked--simply by convincing people you\r\nbelonged there. My mind, projected out through the focus of yours,\r\ncould do this thing. We could work as partners, and divide fifty-fifty._\r\n\r\n"Hold on," said Kiley suspiciously. "What do you need _me_ for, then?\r\nIf you\'ve got this power, why not just rob whatever you want yourself?"\r\n\r\nThere was the voiceless equivalent of a chuckle. _I do not like to\r\nleave my home world. You will act as my travelling--ah--agent._\r\n\r\n"Sounds good to me," Kiley said. "I\'ve got nothing to lose, anyway. 

But\r\nhow do I get out of here?"\r\n\r\n_A simple matter. 

Just be patient._\r\n\r\nKiley waited. A few minutes later, the Alpherazian jailer showed\r\nup--but the look of scorn was gone from his eyes.\r\n\r\n"Dreadfully sorry, Mr. Smith," the guard said humbly. "There\'s been\r\nsome mistake here--we thought you were someone else. Naturally, we\'ll\r\nindemnify you for this inconvenience."\r\n\r\n"That\'s all right," Kiley said casually. "Mistakes _do_ happen, you\r\nknow."\r\n\r\n"This way, please. 

We\'re terribly sorry about the whole affair."\r\n\r\nKiley smiled as the guard led him out of the cell-block to freedom.\r\n_You\'re a man of your word, Thaklaru_, he thought. _It\'s a deal._\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nOnce free, Kiley had spent a very pleasant three weeks on Alpheraz\r\nVII. Thaklaru\'s mind was with him at all times--and with his power of\r\ninstant hypnosis, all doors were open to him. It was a simple matter.\r\n\r\nThe big coup came when Kiley grew tired of the planet\'s pleasures. He\r\ntravelled to the Emperor\'s palace.\r\n\r\nThe guards bowed to him as he approached. "Good afternoon, your\r\nmajesty!"\r\n\r\nKiley smiled politely and kept on going. He walked quickly through the\r\npalace, stopping only to ask a butler where the jewel-room was.\r\n\r\nAs it turned out, the Emperor himself was in the jewel-room. "Pardon\r\nme, your majesty," Kiley said. "I\'ll have to have some of these, I\'m\r\nafraid."\r\n\r\nThe monarch looked up, met Kiley\'s eye, and froze. "Of course," he\r\nsaid politely. 

"Go right ahead." And he stood to one side while Kiley\r\nplundered the crown jewels.\r\n\r\nFrom there, he travelled to the spaceport outside the city, where he\r\ncommandeered a small one-man ship by asking its pilot to leave. Guided\r\nby Thaklaru, he arranged for clearance and blasted off.\r\n\r\nIt had been simple. Terribly, terribly simple--almost dull, Kiley\r\nreflected, as his ship sped through space toward Thaklaru\'s home world.\r\nHe wondered idly what his partner-in-crime looked like. A grotesque\r\npulsating slug floating in a bath of some slimy fluid, perhaps? It\r\nwould have to be something along those lines, Kiley thought--something\r\nthat would keep Thaklaru from entering the worlds of the galaxy by\r\nhimself and taking whatever he pleased.\r\n\r\n"We make a good team, Thaklaru," Kiley said aloud.\r\n\r\n_True_, the alien said. _With my power and your agility, we could steal\r\nanything the galaxy contained._\r\n\r\nKiley turned and looked at the heap of jewels again. Two million\r\nstellors! Quickly, he computed the value in Earth currency, and gasped.\r\nThe haul was worth nearly ten billion dollars!\r\n\r\nPerspiration broke out all over him. He tried frantically not to think\r\nwhat he was thinking, but there was no way to keep the thoughts from\r\nflooding into his mind.\r\n\r\nHe heard Thaklaru chuckling. _No, Kiley. There\'s no way you can cheat\r\nme of my share of the wealth._\r\n\r\n"Dammit, Thaklaru, do you have to keep listening to my mind? Can\'t I\r\nhave a _little_ privacy?"\r\n\r\n_Don\'t fear, Kiley. Your reaction is a perfectly understandable one,\r\nand I hold no rancor against you for desiring great wealth. I expect\r\nyou to think that way--which is why I keep listening to you. I never\r\ntrust an accomplice, remember._\r\n\r\nA new thought entered Kiley\'s mind. "Say--what do you _need_ these\r\njewels for? Seems to me you could have anything you wanted, money no\r\nobject--so why do you want to be rich?"\r\n\r\n_Rich? I do not want to be rich. The jewels are pretty, though--and I\r\nlike beautiful things. I covet them for purely esthetic reasons._\r\n\r\n"Okay with me," Kiley said. "I have more practical ends in mind.

"\r\n\r\n_It is understandable. Ah--you are approaching my home world now.\r\nPlease prepare for deceleration._\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAn hour later, Kiley stood on the soil of Thaklaru\'s planet and looked\r\naround.\r\n\r\n_Welcome_, the alien\'s voice said.\r\n\r\nKiley stood by the side of his spaceship and stared at the awesome\r\nsight. A vast chain of naked mountains sprang up like a row of\r\ngigantic teeth to the east--bare, jagged peaks stretching up into dim\r\nimmensity, twenty and thirty and forty thousand feet in air. 

Wild\r\nsavage-looking vegetation swept fiercely around him, trees well over a\r\nthousand feet high and looking to be a block wide at their base. Just\r\nat a distance of a few feet, a monstrous cliff reared straight upward\r\ntoward the swirling black-and-gold clouds. It was a strange and utterly\r\nprimitive world.\r\n\r\n"Okay, I\'m here!" Kiley shouted. "Where are you?"\r\n\r\n_I will be with you soon_, the alien responded. _Take the jewels from\r\nthe ship._\r\n\r\n"How do I decide which are yours and which are mine?"\r\n\r\n_Take them all. We will decide once they are out of the ship._\r\n\r\nA sudden ripple of terror ran through Kiley, turning the little\r\njewel-thief cold. He felt dwarfed by the sheer magnitude of Thaklaru\'s\r\nworld. He wondered where the alien was, what sort of creature he might\r\nbe.\r\n\r\n_Your curiosity will soon be ended_, Thaklaru said. _When you have\r\nbrought the jewels out, I will appear._\r\n\r\nKiley shrugged and started to climb the catwalk that led into the ship.\r\nThere was little sense in trying to argue with Thaklaru\'s abilities;\r\nif he didn\'t go willingly, the alien would only force him. He gathered\r\nthe jewels into a double handful and brought them back outside,\r\ndropping them onto a bare patch of reddish-green soil. Returning, he\r\nbrought the rest of them out.\r\n\r\n"Okay," he said. "They\'re all there."\r\n\r\n_Good. They are lovely._\r\n\r\n"Suppose you show up and let\'s divide these things," Kiley said. "I\'m\r\ntired of your mental voice--let\'s hear the real thing."\r\n\r\n_Very well._\r\n\r\nA clap of thunder seemed to split the sky--a deafening, booming noise\r\nthat made the ground quiver. Kiley cowered in fright as the sound was\r\nrepeated--and this time, he was able to detect words.\r\n\r\n"I am Thaklaru!"\r\n\r\n"Where are you?"\r\n\r\n"Look upward!" the booming voice cried.\r\n\r\nHesitantly, Kiley turned his gaze upward--and gasped. The "cliff" he\r\nhad thought stood next to him was no cliff at all. It was a vast alien\r\ncreature, stony and terrifying, whose head vanished in the fuzzy clouds\r\nfar overhead.\r\n\r\nAgain came the booming noise: "I am Thaklaru!"\r\n\r\n"I see why you needed an accomplice," Kiley said in a weak voice.\r\n"Something--someone of your size--"\r\n\r\n"Yes. I could never venture into anything as tiny as one of your\r\ncities.

"\r\n\r\nKiley licked his lips nervously. "Well--here are the jewels.\r\nLet\'s--let\'s divide them!"\r\n\r\n"One bit of business first," the alien\'s thunderous boom came. "You\r\nhave served well--but you cannot live."\r\n\r\n"_What?_"\r\n\r\n"It is necessary, Kiley. There are ways of extracting information from\r\na man\'s subconscious--and I would not have my existence known."\r\n\r\nSuddenly the sky was black. Kiley looked up and saw what could only be\r\na foot--a monstrous, horrible foot--blotting out the sunlight overhead.\r\n\r\n"I warned you, Kiley--never trust an accomplice.
