It\'s--"\r\n\r\n"Sorry, Kiley."\r\n\r\n_Like an ant_, the thief thought bitterly. _I\'m dying like an ant._\r\n\r\nAnd then the great foot came down.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was three in the afternoon and quitting time at Utopian Appliances,\r\nInc. Bertram J. Bernard, the firm\'s stocky, thick-jawed president,\r\nwaited discreetly at his desk for a few minutes, then closed the file\r\nhe had been studying, bid his secretary a pleasant evening, and strode\r\ncalmly out of the office.\r\n\r\nHe did not want to appear eager, and succeeded superbly in that.\r\nJoining several junior executives, he conversed genially with them\r\nas they descended to the rapid-transit floor. Three of the bright,\r\nconfident young men decided to stop for a quick one at the building\'s\r\nplush saloon. Well, that was okay--Bernard had been a late-runner in\r\nhis youth. But now, well into middle age, he had learned that life had\r\nother demands and pleasures.\r\n\r\n"Have a good run, B. B.," said Watkins, the treasurer, at the rap-tran\r\ngate. "Gloria\'s coming in on the three-thirty and we\'re going to dinner\r\nand then some musical or other she\'s been dying to see."\r\n\r\nSo Bernard entered the rap-tran alone, though surrounded by scores of\r\npushing, jabbering strangers. Finding a seat on the aisle, next to a\r\nelectronics company vice-president whom he knew slightly, he engaged\r\nin trade conversation during the five minutes it took the monorail to\r\nreach his stop. He and the electronics executive got off, as did about\r\nhalf of the rap-trans passengers, mostly middle-aged men like himself.\r\nEarly-runners.\r\n\r\nThe escalator from the monorail stop descended directly into the\r\nJungle Station beneath. In the large lobby the crowd dispersed and\r\nBernard was again alone when he reached the dressing rooms. This was\r\nnot surprising, he reflected; not many members of his Jungle Station\r\ncould afford the elaborate private locker unique to this wing of the\r\nbuilding. He pressed his thumbprint to the lock and the door slid back.\r\n\r\nInside, he undressed completely, noting with critical satisfaction the\r\nstrength and color of his body in the full-length mirror at one end of\r\nthe locker. He quickly packed his clothes, shoes, and briefcase into a\r\nsmall suitcase, with delivery instructions on the top. Then he climbed\r\ninto his jungle suit--knee-length shorts, sweat shirt, rubber-soled\r\nshoes, and hip holster.\r\n\r\nHe checked the frequency setting on the sonic pistol, adjusting it to\r\nthe panthers who were reported in ascendancy. As a last thought, merely\r\na whim, he glanced down at the station emblem on his sweat shirt, just\r\nto enjoy the sense of pride he derived from the large red "U-F" above\r\nit.\r\n\r\nOf course there were getting to be more and more ulcer-frees these\r\ndays, but that did not make it any less a matter for pride. And anyway\r\nseveral factions were pressing determinedly for a neurosis-free\r\ninsignia. 

Though there were complications there. Oh, well, the\r\nimportant thing\'s the run, he remembered.\r\n\r\nIn the lobby again he deposited his suitcase at the delivery window.\r\nThen he stopped at the bulletin board to read the ascendancy ratings\r\nfor the day. These were official, therefore several days outdated, but\r\none could extrapolate. Panthers were dropping into third position,\r\nbehind polar bears, with giraffes at the top by a good margin.\r\n\r\nOutside the building he ran into a tipster and decided he had best buy\r\na dope sheet. He gave the seedy little man a dollar bill and looked\r\nover the page.\r\n\r\n"Keep it right where you got it, Mac," the man whispered hoarsely,\r\nnodding toward the pistol at Bernard\'s side. "I got it straight, dem\r\npant\'ers is all over de place. 

Watch out at de water hole, specially."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nGlancing swiftly over the page, Bernard saw that fifty panthers had\r\nentered this sector of the jungle overnight, with a herd of fifteen\r\ngiraffes headed well toward the south. But he also noted that there\r\nhad been three deaths from polar bears in the past week in his sector\r\nalone. Fortunately, the frequency readjustment from panthers to polar\r\nbears was an easy one, three clicks clockwise with the thumb. He would\r\nhave to remember about the water hole, though it was either that or\r\ngoing above the rapids. The sharks below the rapids were pretty thick\r\nduring the summer.\r\n\r\n"Thanks, bud," he told the tipster. Then he strode, still calm, to\r\nthe wall. Expertly he clambered up its handholds, till he reached the\r\ntop, thirty feet from the ground. On the other side lay the jungle,\r\nits lush tropical growth hiding from his alert eyes the danger that\r\nlurked within. He popped a Verve pill into his mouth and chewed on it\r\nthoughtfully.\r\n\r\nFar in the distance, some five miles at the narrowest point, rose the\r\nouter wall. Between the two prowled a variety of ambivalent robot\r\nbeasts, now ready to dismember him, but on weekends adjusted to\r\ntake small boys and girls for short rides or simply to stalk about\r\npicturesquely.\r\n\r\nDrawing his pistol and placing it between his teeth, Bernard leaped to\r\nthe ground between the wall and a large low palm. At once the pistol\r\nwas again in his hand. 

But nothing moved. Now he could see clearly the\r\npath he must take.\r\n\r\nBending low, he trotted along through the undergrowth. It soon began\r\nto clear, and still no danger in sight. He holstered the pistol and\r\nadvanced, half-walking, half-running, till he could hear the hiss of\r\nthe rapids. Enough noise to mask the sounds of a dozen panthers, he\r\nthought. But it covered his own footsteps, too, and panthers were more\r\nphonotropic than polar bears, the latter having a preference for radar\r\nspotting.\r\n\r\nCoyotes were the worst, of course, with their damned infrared\r\nthermo-sensors. They could spot a runner even when he was in cover.\r\nFortunately they were scarce and getting more so. Bernard had only\r\nencountered a coyote twice, deactivating it both times. But he had been\r\nlucky. He recalled the story about that city councilman....\r\n\r\nAn hour later he arrived at the river, a half-mile above the rapids\r\nand well away from the water hole. He had seen only one beast in the\r\nfirst three miles of his trek, a giraffe hobbling along in olfactory\r\npursuit of another runner far to the right. Giraffes were mainly a\r\nnuisance, though they could kick and trample a man. Bernard had heard\r\nof such a thing happening, but it was a rarity. They were too easy to\r\nelude.\r\n\r\nHe crossed the river on a log raft he found, which had evidently been\r\nrigged to dump him in about halfway across. At least he had got that\r\nfar on it he told himself, as he struck out for the shore. For one\r\nhorrible moment he thought he detected a shark upstream, but it was\r\nmerely the shadow of a large palm leaf. He had a strong and sensible\r\nfear of sharks.\r\n\r\nA mile farther found him crawling over the rocky ground as the growls\r\nof panthers reached his acute ears from behind a ridge of brush. If\r\nthey heard him, they ignored him, perhaps more interested in other\r\nquarry. His knees and arms were scraped but not bleeding, and at last\r\nhe was able to get to his feet to make better time.\r\n\r\nIt was then that he heard the girl\'s scream.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nNo regulation in the rule book discriminated against women becoming\r\nrunners, but only a few of the millions who worked at offices and\r\nplants in the city did so. Also there was nothing in the code about\r\nhelping other runners. Each was entirely on his own, free to help or\r\nbe helped, or not helped, if he chose.\r\n\r\nBernard would never have called for help for himself. But the sound of\r\nthe woman\'s cry appealed to another side of his nature. 

He changed his\r\ndirection, but moved with great caution now. Soon he saw her, and froze.\r\n\r\nShe was clad as he, different sector emblem, but the same proudly borne\r\n"U-F" on her sweater. Her face and body were young and attractive, but\r\nher long dark hair was tangled and wet, and her limbs mud-spattered.\r\nShe had screamed only once, and now her small lipsticked mouth hung\r\nopen with terror.\r\n\r\nBacked against a tree, she gaped in horror, waiting, as three panthers\r\napproached from as many directions. Her sonic lay on the ground outside\r\nthe circle. It was obvious that she was finished if Bernard did not\r\nassist her.\r\n\r\nRaising his hand till the pistol sight was where he wanted it, he\r\nmodified the angle adjustment till all of the animals were within\r\nits range. Then he depressed the trigger several times. Two fell and\r\nthe third animal leaped at the girl. But she twisted around the tree\r\nand Bernard picked off the panther as it readied itself for a second\r\nspring. At once the girl dived for her pistol. Proper response, Bernard\r\nthought approvingly. Then she ran toward him and threw herself against\r\nhim, breathing deeply in that position for several moments.\r\n\r\nBernard felt strongly the strength and zest of youth as he held the\r\ngirl in his arms. Then they turned and walked together to the outer\r\nwall, which was less than half a mile away. There was no danger from\r\nthe deactivated panthers, which would remain out of commission for half\r\nan hour. So they had no reason to hurry.\r\n\r\nBernard helped her climb the wall, though she seemed quite adept at it\r\nherself. On the other side they emerged upon the street. Across the\r\nstreet lay the acres and acres of homes which were the city\'s eastern\r\nsuburbia.\r\n\r\n"Oh, it was just horrible!" the girl finally cried. "All at once they\r\nsprang. 

From nowhere. I tripped and my sonic fell out of the holster.\r\nI\'d be _dead_ if it weren\'t for you!"\r\n\r\n"Very true," Bernard agreed. "You\'ll be more careful in the future, I\r\nhope."\r\n\r\n"If only I could thank you in some way. I owe you so much. My apartment\r\nis just up the next street. Only a few blocks. Wouldn\'t you like to\r\nstop in for a drink? I\'m sure you\'re as tired as I."\r\n\r\nBut Bernard declined. He walked her home, then continued on, unaware of\r\nthe envious glances of young children as he passed. Unaware of other\r\nrunners, early-runners, middle-aged men like himself, also walking the\r\nstreets, wearily but not stooping, not frowning.\r\n\r\nHow good a warm shower would be, thought Bernard, as he entered the\r\nlast mile. His wife would probably want a drink, so there would be that\r\ntoo. 

And dinner. He was _hungry_.\r\n\r\nUlcer-free and happy, he walked the last mile in contentment. The\r\noffice was something that had happened long ago, would happen again\r\ntomorrow, but could never invade his thoughts that night. And he knew\r\nexactly how his wife would greet him at the door.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Hello, darling. How was the run?" she asked, kissing him as he came\r\ninto the house. "You only made fair time this evening. 

Something\r\nhappen?

"\r\n\r\n"No, pretty routine. Panthers are on the increase. I came across\r\nthree of them attacking a girl runner. Works as a copy writer in the\r\ncity. She claims that the jungle cured her ulcers completely. Really\r\nremarkable.

"\r\n\r\n"Mmm-hmm," said Virginia, taking his holster. "Attractive, no doubt. I\r\nsuppose she tried to seduce you. I\'ve heard stories about those jungle\r\nwomen."\r\n\r\n"Nothing of the sort. Just suggested I drop in for a drink. 

After all,\r\nshe was grateful."\r\n\r\nWhat nonsense, he told himself as he showered, Virginia suggesting that\r\nthe girl had intended to seduce him. Oh, well, what difference did it\r\nmake?\r\n\r\nMan, that hot water felt good! Even on his scratched legs and arms.\r\n\r\nHow many years had he been making the run now? Twenty-three, almost. In\r\na way he could consider himself a sort of a pioneer. And to think that\r\nthe only reason he had started jungle running in the first place was to\r\nplease a supervisor! Those days everyone did it.\r\n\r\nAs he dried himself off, hearing the tinkle of cocktails in the living\r\nroom, he wondered if the panthers would move south, away from the water\r\nhole, before tomorrow\'s run.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


And the faint lines\r\naround his dark, deep-set eyes were accentuated when he smiled at his\r\nwife.\r\n\r\n"All set, honey. How do I look in my monkey suit?"\r\n\r\nHis wife was sitting stiffly on the flowered couch that was still not\r\ntheirs completely. In her fingers she held a cigarette burned down too\r\nfar. She said, "You look fine, Phil. You look just right." 

She managed a\r\nsmile. Then she leaned forward and crushed the cigarette in the ash\r\ntray on the maple coffee table and took another from the pack.\r\n\r\nHe came to her and touched his hands to her soft blond hair, raising her\r\nface until she was looking into his eyes. "You\'re the most beautiful\r\ngirl I know. Did I ever tell you that?

"\r\n\r\n"Yes, I think so. Yes, I\'m sure you did," she said, finishing the\r\nritual; but her voice broke, and she turned her head away. Phil sat\r\nbeside her and put his arm around her small shoulders. He had stopped\r\nsmiling.\r\n\r\n"Honey, look at me," he said. "It isn\'t going to be bad. 

Honestly it\r\nisn\'t. We know exactly how it will be. If anything could go wrong, they\r\nwouldn\'t be sending me; you know that. I told you that we\'ve sent five\r\nun-manned ships up and everyone came back without a hitch."\r\n\r\nShe turned, facing him. There were tears starting in the corners of her\r\nwide, brown eyes, and she brushed them away with her hand.\r\n\r\n"Phil, don\'t go. Please don\'t. They can send Sammy. Sammy doesn\'t have a\r\nwife. Can\'t he go? They\'d understand, Phil. Please!" She was holding his\r\narms tightly with her hands, and the color had drained from her cheeks.\r\n\r\n"Mary, you know I can\'t back out now. How could I? 

It\'s been three\r\nyears. You know how much I\'ve wanted to be the first man to go. Nothing\r\nwould ever be right with me again if I didn\'t go. 

Please don\'t make it\r\nhard." He stopped talking and held her to him and stroked the back of\r\nher head. He could feel her shoulders shaking with quiet sobs. He\r\nreleased her and stood up.\r\n\r\n"I\'ve got to get started, Mary. Will you come to the field with me?"\r\n\r\n"Yes, I\'ll come to say good-by." She paused and dropped her eyes. "Phil,\r\nif you go, I won\'t be here when you get back--if you get back. I won\'t\r\nbe here because I won\'t be the wife of a space pilot for the rest of my\r\nlife. It isn\'t the kind of life I bargained for. No matter how much I\r\nlove you, I just couldn\'t take that, Phil. I\'m sorry. 

I guess I\'m not\r\nthe noble sort of wife."\r\n\r\nShe finished and took another cigarette from the pack on the coffee\r\ntable and put it to her lips. Her hand was trembling as she touched the\r\nlighter to the end of the cigarette and drew deeply. Phil stood watching\r\nher, the excitement completely gone from his eyes.\r\n\r\n"I wish you had told me this a long time ago, Mary," Phil said. His\r\nvoice was dry and low. "I didn\'t know you felt this way about it."\r\n\r\n"Yes, you did. I told you how I felt. I told you I could never be the\r\nwife of a space pilot. But I don\'t think I ever really believed it was\r\npossible--not until this morning when you said tonight was the take-off.\r\nIt\'s so stupid to jeopardize everything we\'ve got for a ridiculous\r\ndream!"\r\n\r\nHe sat down on the edge of the couch and took her hands between his.\r\n"Mary, listen to me," he said. "It isn\'t a dream. It\'s real. There\'s\r\nnothing means anything more to me than you do--you know that. But no\r\nman ever had the chance to do what I\'m going to do tonight--no man ever.\r\nIf I backed out now for any reason, I\'d never be able to look at the sky\r\nagain. I\'d be through."\r\n\r\nShe looked at him without seeing him, and there was nothing at all in\r\nher eyes.\r\n\r\n"Let\'s go, if you\'re still going," she finally said.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThey drove through the streets of the small town with its small\r\nbungalows, each alike. There were no trees and very little grass. It was\r\na new town, a government built town, and it had no personality yet. It\r\nexisted only because of the huge ship standing poised in the take-off\r\nzone five miles away in the desert. Its future as a town rested with the\r\nship, and the town seemed to feel the uncertainty of its future, seemed\r\nready to stop existing as a town and to give itself back to the desert,\r\nif such was its destiny.\r\n\r\nPhil turned the car off the highway onto the rutted dirt road that led\r\nacross the sand to the field where the ship waited. In the distance they\r\ncould see the beams of the searchlights as they played across the\r\ntake-off zone and swept along the top of the high wire fence stretching\r\nout of sight to right and left. 

At the gate they were stopped by the\r\nguard. He read Phil\'s pass, shined his flashlight in their faces, and\r\nthen saluted. "Good luck, colonel," he said, and shook Phil\'s hand.\r\n\r\n"Thanks, sergeant. I\'ll be seeing you next week," Phil said, and smiled.\r\nThey drove between the rows of wooden buildings that lined the field,\r\nand he parked near the low barbed fence ringing the take-off zone. He\r\nturned off the ignition, and sat quietly for a moment before lighting a\r\ncigarette. Then he looked at his wife. She was staring through the\r\nwindshield at the rocket two hundred yards away. Its smooth polished\r\nsurface gleamed in the spotlight glare, and it sloped up and up until\r\nthe eye lost the tip against the stars.\r\n\r\n"She\'s beautiful, Mary. You\'ve never seen her before, have you?"\r\n\r\n"No, I\'ve never seen her before," she said. "Hadn\'t you better go?" Her\r\nvoice was strained and she held her hands closed tightly in her lap.\r\n"Please go now, Phil," she said.\r\n\r\nHe leaned toward her and touched her cheek. Then she was in his arms,\r\nher head buried against his shoulder.\r\n\r\n"Good-by, darling," she said.\r\n\r\n"Wish me luck, Mary?" he asked.\r\n\r\n"Yes, good luck, Phil," she said. He opened the car door and got out.\r\nThe noise of men and machines scurrying around the ship broke the spell\r\nof the rocket waiting silently for flight.\r\n\r\n"Mary, I--" he began, and then turned and strode toward the\r\nadministration building without looking back.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nInside the building it was like a locker room before the big game. The\r\ntension stood alone, and each man had the same happy, excited look that\r\nPhil had worn earlier. 

When he came into the room, the noise and bustle\r\nstopped. They turned as one man toward him, and General Small came up to\r\nhim and took his hand.\r\n\r\n"Hello, Phil. We were beginning to think you weren\'t coming. You all\r\nset, son?"\r\n\r\n"Yes, sir, I\'m all set, I guess," Phil said.\r\n\r\n"I\'d like you to meet the Secretary of Defense, Phil. He\'s over here by\r\nthe radar."\r\n\r\nAs they crossed the room, familiar faces smiled, and each man shook his\r\nhand or touched his arm. He saw Sammy, alone, by the coffee urn. Sammy\r\nwaved to him, but he didn\'t smile. Phil wanted to talk to him, to say\r\nsomething; but there was nothing to be said now. Sammy\'s turn would come\r\nlater.\r\n\r\n"Mr. Secretary," the general said, "this is Colonel Conover. He\'ll be\r\nthe first man in history to see the other side of the Moon. Colonel--the\r\nSecretary of Defense."\r\n\r\n"How do you do, sir. I\'m very proud to meet you," Phil said.\r\n\r\n"On the contrary, colonel. I\'m very proud to meet you. I\'ve been looking\r\nat that ship out there and wondering. I almost wish I were a young man\r\nagain. I\'d like to be going. It\'s a thrilling thought--man\'s first\r\nadventure into the universe. You\'re lighting a new dawn of history,\r\ncolonel. It\'s a privilege few men have ever had; and those who have had\r\nit didn\'t realize it at the time. Good luck, and God be with you."\r\n\r\n"Thank you, sir. I\'m aware of all you say. 

It frightens me a little."\r\n\r\nThe general took Phil\'s arm and they walked to the briefing room. There\r\nwere chairs set up for the scientists and Air Force officers directly\r\nconnected with the take-off. They were seated now in a semicircle in\r\nfront of a huge chart of the solar system. Phil took his seat, and the\r\nlast minute briefing began. It was a routine he knew by heart. He had\r\ngone over and over it a thousand times, and he only half listened now.\r\nHe kept thinking of Mary outside, alone by the fence.\r\n\r\nThe voice of the briefing officer was a dull hum in his ears.\r\n\r\n"... And orbit at 18,000-mph. You will then accelerate for the breakaway\r\nto 24,900-mph for five minutes and then free-coast for 116 hours\r\nuntil--"\r\n\r\nPhil asked a few questions about weather and solar conditions. And then\r\nthe session was done. They rose and looked at each other, the same\r\nunanswered questions on each man\'s face. There were forced smiles and\r\nhandshakes. They were ready now.\r\n\r\n"Phil," the general said, and took him aside.\r\n\r\n"Sir?"\r\n\r\n"Phil, you\'re ... you feel all right, don\'t you, son?"\r\n\r\n"Yes, sir. I feel fine. Why?"\r\n\r\n"Phil, I\'ve spent nearly every day with you for three years. I know you\r\nbetter than I know myself in many ways. 

And I\'ve studied the\r\npsychologist\'s reports on you carefully. Maybe it\'s just nervousness,\r\nPhil, but I think there\'s something wrong. Is there?"\r\n\r\n"No, sir. There\'s nothing wrong," Phil said, but his voice didn\'t carry\r\nconviction. He reached for a cigarette.\r\n\r\n"Phil, if there is anything--anything at all--you know what it might\r\nmean. You\'ve got to be in the best mental and physical condition of your\r\nlife tonight. You know better than any man here what that means to our\r\nsuccess. I think there is something more than just natural apprehension\r\nwrong with you. Want to tell me?"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nOutside, the take-off zone crawled with men and machines at the base of\r\nthe rocket. For ten hours, the final check-outs had been in progress;\r\nand now the men were checking again, on their own time. The thing they\r\nhad worked toward for six years was ready to happen, and each one felt\r\nthat he was sending just a little bit of himself into the sky. Beyond\r\nthe ring of lights and moving men, on the edge of the field, Mary stood.\r\nHer hands moved slowly over the top of the fence, twisting the barbs of\r\nwire. But her eyes were on the ship.\r\n\r\nAnd then they were ready. A small group of excited men came out from the\r\nadministration building and moved forward. His face was drawn tight, and there were tears on his\r\ncheeks. "Thank, God," she said. "It doesn\'t matter, darling. The only\r\nthing that matters is you didn\'t go."\r\n\r\n"You\'re right, Mary," he said. His voice was low--so low she could\r\nhardly hear him. "It doesn\'t matter. Nothing matters now." 

He stood with\r\nhis hands at his sides, watching her. And then turned away and walked\r\ntoward the car.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


"\r\n\r\n"Where\'d you get it?"\r\n\r\n"Mom gave it to me."\r\n\r\n"If you give it to me, I\'ll tell you what I\'m doing."\r\n\r\n"It\'s not worth it."\r\n\r\n"I\'ll let you be my assistant, too."\r\n\r\n"Still not worth it."\r\n\r\n"For ten cents?

"What\r\nshould I do now, Bob?"\r\n\r\n"Get the salt," Bob instructed.\r\n\r\nHe poured sardine oil from the can into the juicer, being very careful\r\nnot to let the sardines fall in. "Where is it?

"\r\n\r\n"Behind the salt."\r\n\r\n"What did you find there?"\r\n\r\n"Two chocolate grahams."\r\n\r\nBobby held out his hand, accepted one of the crackers without thanks\r\nand proceeded to crumble the whole thing into his concoction, not even\r\nstopping to lick the chocolate off his hands.\r\n\r\nBonnie frowned in disbelief. "\r\n\r\n"I give up."\r\n\r\n"It\'s animal serum," Bob said, sliced his thumb on the sardine can,\r\nglanced unemotionally at the cut, ignored it.\r\n\r\n"What\'s animal serum, Bob?"\r\n\r\n"It\'s certain properties without which the universe in eternity regards\r\nfor human beings."\r\n\r\n"Oh," Bonnie said. 

She took off her apron and sat down at the other end\r\nof the kitchen. The smell from the juicer was beginning to reach her\r\nstomach.\r\n\r\nBobby combed the kitchen for something else to throw into his\r\nconcoction and came up with some oregano and liquid garlic.\r\n\r\n"I guess this is about it," he said.\r\n\r\nHe poured the garlic and oregano into his juicer, put the lid on, shook\r\nit furiously for a minute and then emptied the contents into a deep pot.\r\n\r\n"What are you doing now, Bob?" Bonnie asked.\r\n\r\n"You have to cook it for seven minutes."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBobby lit the stove, put a cover on the pot, set the timer for ten\r\nminutes and left the room. Bonnie tagged after him and the two of them\r\ngot involved in a rough game of basketball in the living room.\r\n\r\n"BING!" said the timer.\r\n\r\nBob dropped the basketball on Bonnie\'s head and ran back into the\r\nkitchen.\r\n\r\n"It\'s all done," he said, and took the cover off the pot. Only his\r\ndedication to his work kept him from showing the discomfort he felt\r\nwith the smell that the pot gave forth.\r\n\r\n"Fyew!" said Bonnie. 

"What do we do with it now? Throw it out?"\r\n\r\n"No, stupid. We have to stir it till it cools and then drink it."\r\n\r\n"Drink it?" Bonnie wrinkled her nose. "How come we have to drink it?"\r\n\r\nBobby said, "Because that\'s what you do with experiments, stupid."\r\n\r\n"But, Bob, it smells like garbage."\r\n\r\n"Medicine smells worse and it makes you healthy," Bob said, while\r\nstirring the pot with an old wooden spoon.\r\n\r\nBonnie held her nose, stood on tiptoe and looked in at the cooking\r\nsolution. "Will this make us healthy?"\r\n\r\n"Maybe." Bob kept stirring.\r\n\r\n"What will it do?"\r\n\r\n"You\'ll see." Bob took two clean dish towels, draped them around the\r\npot and carried it over to the formica kitchen table. In the process,\r\nhe managed to dip both towels in the mixture and burn his already\r\nsliced thumb. One plastic handle of the pot was still smoldering, from\r\nbeing too near the fire, but none of these things seemed to have the\r\nslightest effect on him. He put the pot down in the middle of the table\r\nand stared at it, chin in hand.\r\n\r\nBonnie plopped down opposite him, put her chin in her hands and asked,\r\n"We _have_ to drink that stuff?"\r\n\r\n"Yup."\r\n\r\n"Who has to drink it first?" Bob made no sign of having heard. 

"I\r\nthought so," said Bonnie. Still no comment. "What if it kills me?"\r\n\r\nBobby spoke by raising his whole head and keeping his jaw stationary\r\nin his hands. "How can it hurt you? There\'s nothing but pure food in\r\nthere."\r\n\r\nBonnie also sat and stared. "How much of that stuff do I have to drink?"\r\n\r\n"Just a little bit. Stick one finger in it and lick it off."\r\n\r\nBonnie pointed a cautious finger at the tarry-looking brew and slowly\r\nimmersed it, until it barely covered the nail. "Is that enough?"\r\n\r\n"Plenty," said Bob in a judicious tone.\r\n\r\nBonnie took her finger out of the pot and stared at it for a moment.\r\n"What if I get sick?"\r\n\r\n"You can\'t get sick. There\'s aspirin and vitamins in it, too."\r\n\r\nBonnie sighed and wrinkled her nose. 

"Well, here goes," she said. She\r\nlicked off a little bit.\r\n\r\nBob watched her with his television version of a scientific look. "How\r\ndo you feel?" he inquired.\r\n\r\nBonnie answered, "It\'s not so bad, once it goes down. You can taste the\r\nchocolate graham cracker." Bonnie was really enjoying the attention.\r\n"Hey," she said, "I\'m starting to get a funny feeling in my--" and,\r\nbefore she could finish the sentence, there was a loud _pop_.\r\n\r\nBob\'s face registered extreme disappointment.\r\n\r\nShe sat quite still for a moment and then said, "What happened?"\r\n\r\n"You\'ve turned into a chicken."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe little bird lifted its wings and looked down at itself. "How come\r\nI\'m a chicken, Bob?" it said, cocking its head to one side and staring\r\nat him with its left eye.\r\n\r\n"Ah, nuts," he explained. "I expected you to be more of a pigeon\r\nthing." Bob mulled over the ingredients of his stew to see what went\r\nwrong.\r\n\r\nThe chicken hopped around the chair on one leg, flapped its wings\r\nexperimentally and found itself on the kitchen table. It walked to the\r\nfar corner and peered into a small mirror that hung on the side of the\r\nsink cabinet.\r\n\r\n"I\'m a pretty ugly chicken, boy," it said.\r\n\r\nIt inspected itself with its other eye and, finding no improvement,\r\nwalked back to Bobby.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t like to be a chicken, Bob," it said.\r\n\r\n"Why not? What does it feel like?

"\r\n\r\n"It feels skinny and I can\'t see so good."\r\n\r\n"How else does it feel?"\r\n\r\n"That\'s all how it feels. Make me stop being it."\r\n\r\n"First tell me better what it\'s like."\r\n\r\n"I told you already. Make me stop being it."\r\n\r\n"What are you afraid of? Why don\'t you see what it\'s like first, before\r\nyou change back? 

This is a valuable experience."\r\n\r\nThe chicken tried to put its hands on its hips, but could find neither\r\nhips nor hands. "You better change me back, boy," it said, and gave Bob\r\nthe left-eye glare.\r\n\r\n"Will you stop being stupid and just see what it\'s like first?" Bob was\r\nfinding it difficult to understand her lack of curiosity.\r\n\r\n"Wait till Mom sees what an ugly mess I am, boy. Will you ever get it!"\r\nBonnie was trying very hard to see Bob with both eyes at once, which\r\nwas impossible.\r\n\r\n"You\'re a sissy, Bonnie. You ruined the opportunity of a lifetime. 

I\'m\r\ndisgusted with you." Bob dipped his forefinger in the serum and held it\r\ntoward the chicken. It pecked what it could from the finger and tilted\r\nits head back.\r\n\r\nIn an instant, the chicken was gone and Bonnie was back. She climbed\r\ndown from the table, wiped her eyes and said, "It\'s a good thing you\r\nfixed me, boy. 

Would you ever have got it."\r\n\r\n"Ah, you\'re nothing but a sissy," Bob said, and licked off a whole\r\nfingerful of his formula. "If I change into a horse, I won\'t let you\r\nride me, and if I change into a leopard, I\'ll bite your head off." Once\r\nagain, the loud _pop_ was heard.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBonnie stood up, wide-eyed. "Oh, Bob," she said, "you\'re beautiful!"\r\n\r\n"What am I?" Bob asked.\r\n\r\n"You\'re a bee-yoo-tee-full St. Bernard, Bob! Let\'s go show Melissa and\r\nChuck."\r\n\r\n"A St. Bernard?" The animal looked disgusted. "I don\'t want to be no\r\ndog. I want to be a leopard."\r\n\r\n"But you\'re _beautiful_, Bob! 

Go look in the mirror."\r\n\r\n"Naah." The dog paddled over to the table.\r\n\r\n"What are you going to do, Bob?"\r\n\r\n"I\'m going to try it again."\r\n\r\nThe dog put its front paws on the table, knocked over the serum and\r\nlapped up some as it dripped on the floor. _Pop_ went the serum, taking\r\neffect. Bobby remained on all fours and kept on lapping. _Pop_ went the\r\nserum again.\r\n\r\n"What am I now?" he asked.\r\n\r\n"You\'re still a St. Bernard," said Bonnie.\r\n\r\n"The devil with it then," said the dog. "Let\'s forget all about it."\r\n\r\nThe dog took one last lap of serum. _Pop!_ Bobby got up from the floor\r\nand dejectedly started out the back door. Bonnie skipped after him.\r\n\r\n"What\'ll we do now, Bob?" she asked.\r\n\r\n"We\'ll go down to Thrifty\'s and get some ice cream."\r\n\r\nThey walked down the hill silently, Bobby brooding over not having\r\nbeen a leopard and Bonnie wishing he had stayed a St. Bernard. As they\r\napproached the main street of the small town, Bonnie turned to her\r\nbrother.\r\n\r\n"You want to make some more of that stuff tomorrow?"\r\n\r\n"Not the same stuff," said Bob.\r\n\r\n"What\'ll we make instead?"\r\n\r\n"I ain\'t decided yet."\r\n\r\n"You want to make an atomic bomb?"\r\n\r\n"Maybe."\r\n\r\n"Can we do it in the juicer?"\r\n\r\n"Sure," Bob said, "only we\'ll have to get a couple of onions."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n

copyright on this publication was renewed.              |\r\n    |                                                              |\r\n    +--------------------------------------------------------------+\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nBy EDGAR PANGBORN\r\n\r\nThe Good Neighbors\r\n\r\n\r\n  You can\'t blame an alien for\r\n  a little inconvenience--as\r\n  long as he makes up for it!\r\n\r\nIllustrated by WOOD\r\n\r\n\r\nThe ship was sighted a few times, briefly and without a good fix. It was\r\nspherical, the estimated diameter about twenty-seven miles, and was in\r\nan orbit approximately 3400 miles from the surface of the Earth. No one\r\nobserved the escape from it.\r\n\r\nThe ship itself occasioned some excitement, but back there at the\r\ntattered end of the 20th century, what was one visiting spaceship more\r\nor less? Others had appeared before, and gone away discouraged--or just\r\nnot bothering. 

3-dimensional TV was coming out of the experimental\r\nstage. Soon anyone could have Dora the Doll or the Grandson of Tarzan\r\nsmack in his own living-room. Besides, it was a hot summer.\r\n\r\nThe first knowledge of the escape came when the region of Seattle\r\nsuffered an eclipse of the sun, which was not an eclipse but a near\r\nshadow, which was not a shadow but a thing. The darkness drifted out of\r\nthe northern Pacific. It generated thunder without lightning and without\r\nrain. 

When it had moved eastward and the hot sun reappeared, wind\r\nfollowed, a moderate gale. The coast was battered by sudden high waves,\r\nthen hushed in a bewilderment of fog.\r\n\r\nBefore that appearance, radar had gone crazy for an hour.\r\n\r\nThe atmosphere buzzed with aircraft. They went up in readiness to shoot,\r\nbut after the first sighting reports only a few miles offshore, that\r\norder was vehemently canceled--someone in charge must have had a grain\r\nof sense. 

The thing was not a plane, rocket or missile. It was an\r\nanimal.\r\n\r\nIf you shoot an animal that resembles an inflated gas-bag with wings,\r\nand the wingspread happens to be something over four miles tip to tip,\r\nand the carcass drops on a city--it\'s not nice for the city.\r\n\r\nThe Office of Continental Defense deplored the lack of precedent. But\r\nactually none was needed. You just don\'t drop four miles of dead or\r\ndying alien flesh on Seattle or any other part of a swarming homeland.\r\nYou wait till it flies out over the ocean, if it will--the most\r\ncommodious ocean in reach.\r\n\r\n\r\nIt, or rather she, didn\'t go back over the Pacific, perhaps because of\r\nthe prevailing westerlies. After the Seattle incident she climbed to a\r\ngreat altitude above the Rockies, apparently using an updraft with very\r\nlittle wing-motion. There was no means of calculating her weight, or\r\nmass, or buoyancy. Dead or injured, drift might have carried her\r\nanywhere within one or two hundred miles. Then she seemed to be\r\nfollowing the line of the Platte and the Missouri. By the end of the day\r\nshe was circling interminably over the huge complex of St. Louis,\r\nhopelessly crying.\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\nShe had a head, drawn back most of the time into the bloated mass of the\r\nbody but thrusting forward now and then on a short neck not more than\r\nthree hundred feet in length. When she did that the blunt turtle-like\r\nhead could be observed, the gaping, toothless, suffering mouth from\r\nwhich the thunder came, and the soft-shining purple eyes that searched\r\nthe ground but found nothing answering her need. The skin-color was\r\nmud-brown with some dull iridescence and many peculiar marks resembling\r\nweals or blisters. Along the belly some observers saw half a mile of\r\npaired protuberances that looked like teats.\r\n\r\nShe was unquestionably the equivalent of a vertebrate. Two web-footed\r\nlegs were drawn up close against the cigar-shaped body. The vast, rather\r\nnarrow, inflated wings could not have been held or moved in flight\r\nwithout a strong internal skeleton and musculature. Theorists later\r\nargued that she must have come from a planet with a high proportion of\r\nwater surface, a planet possibly larger than Earth though of about the\r\nsame mass and with a similar atmosphere. She could rise in Earth\'s air.\r\nAnd before each thunderous lament she was seen to breathe.\r\n\r\nIt was assumed that immense air sacs within her body were inflated or\r\npartly inflated when she left the ship, possibly with some gas lighter\r\nthan nitrogen. Since it was inconceivable that a vertebrate organism\r\ncould have survived entry into atmosphere from an orbit 3400 miles up,\r\nit was necessary to believe that the ship had briefly descended,\r\nunobserved and by unknown means, probably on Earth\'s night-side. Later\r\non the ship did descend as far as atmosphere, for a moment ...\r\n\r\nSt. Louis was partly evacuated. There is no reliable estimate of the\r\nloss of life and property from panic and accident on the jammed roads\r\nand rail lines. 1500 dead, 7400 injured is the conservative figure.\r\n\r\n\r\nAfter a night and a day she abandoned that area, flying heavily\r\neastward. The droning and swooping gnats of aircraft plainly distressed\r\nher. At first she had only tried to avoid them, but now and then during\r\nher eastward flight from St. Louis she made short desperate rushes\r\nagainst them, without skill or much sign of intelligence, screaming from\r\na wide-open mouth that could have swallowed a four-engine bomber. Two\r\naircraft were lost over Cincinnati, by collision with each other in\r\ntrying to get out of her way. Pilots were then ordered to keep a\r\ndistance of not less than ten miles until such time as she reached the\r\nAtlantic--if she did--when she could safely be shot down.\r\n\r\nShe studied Chicago for a day.\r\n\r\nBy that time Civil Defense was better prepared. About a million\r\nresidents had already fled to open country before she came, and the loss\r\nof life was proportionately smaller. 

She moved on. We have no clue to\r\nthe reason why great cities should have attracted her, though\r\napparently they did. She was hungry perhaps, or seeking help, or merely\r\ndrawn in animal curiosity by the endless motion of the cities and the\r\nstrangeness. It has even been suggested that the life forms of her\r\nhomeland--her masters--resembled humanity. She moved eastward, and\r\nreligious organizations united to pray that she would come down on one\r\nof the lakes where she could safely be destroyed. She didn\'t.\r\n\r\nShe approached Pittsburgh, choked and screamed and flew high, and soared\r\nin weary circles over Buffalo for a day and a night. Some pilots who had\r\nfollowed the flight from the West Coast claimed that the vast\r\nlamentation of her voice was growing fainter and hoarser while she was\r\ndrifting along the line of the Mohawk Valley. She turned south,\r\nfollowing the Hudson at no great height. Sometimes she appeared to be\r\nchoking, the labored inhalations harsh and prolonged, like a cloud in\r\nagony.\r\n\r\nWhen she was over Westchester, headquarters tripled the swarm of\r\ninterceptors and observation planes. Squadrons from Connecticut and\r\nsouthern New Jersey deployed to form a monstrous funnel, the small end\r\nbefore her, the large end pointing out to open sea. Heavy bombers closed\r\nin above, laying a smoke screen at 10,000 feet to discourage her from\r\nrising. The ground shook with the drone of jets, and with her crying.\r\n\r\nMultitudes had abandoned the metropolitan area. Other multitudes trusted\r\nto the subways, to the narrow street canyons and to the strength of\r\nconcrete and steel. Others climbed to a thousand high places and\r\nwatched, trusting the laws of chance.\r\n\r\nShe passed over Manhattan in the evening--between 8:14 and 8:27 P.M.,\r\nJuly 16, 1976--at an altitude of about 2000 feet. She swerved away from\r\nthe aircraft that blanketed Long Island and the Sound, swerved again as\r\nthe southern group buzzed her instead of giving way. She made no attempt\r\nto rise into the sun-crimsoned terror of drifting smoke.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe plan was intelligent. It should have worked, but for one fighter\r\npilot who jumped the gun.\r\n\r\nHe said later that he himself couldn\'t understand what happened. It was\r\ncourt-martial testimony, but his reputation had been good. He was Bill\r\nGreen--William Hammond Green--of New London, Connecticut, flying a\r\none-man jet fighter, well aware of the strictest orders not to attack\r\nuntil the target had moved at least ten miles east of Sandy Hook. He\r\nsaid he certainly had no previous intention to violate orders. It was\r\nsomething that just happened in his mind. A sort of mental sneeze.\r\n\r\nHis squadron was approaching Rockaway, the flying creature about three\r\nmiles ahead of him and half a mile down. He was aware of saying out loud\r\nto nobody: "Well, she\'s too big." Then he was darting out of formation,\r\ndiving on her, giving her one rocket-burst and reeling off to the south\r\nat 840 MPH.\r\n\r\nHe never did locate or rejoin his squadron, but he made it somehow back\r\nto his home field. He climbed out of the cockpit, they say, and fell\r\nflat on his face.\r\n\r\nIt seems likely that his shot missed the animal\'s head and tore through\r\nsome part of her left wing. She spun to the left, rose perhaps a\r\nthousand feet, facing the city, sideslipped, recovered herself and\r\nfought for altitude. She could not gain it. In the effort she collided\r\nwith two of the following planes. One of them smashed into her right\r\nside behind the wing, the other flipped end over end across her back,\r\nlike a swatted dragonfly. It dropped clear and made a mess on Bedloe\'s\r\nIsland.\r\n\r\nShe too was falling, in a long slant, silent now but still living. After\r\nthe impact her body thrashed desolately on the wreckage between\r\nLexington and Seventh Avenues, her right wing churning, then only\r\ntrailing, in the East River, her left wing a crumpled slowly deflating\r\nmass concealing Times Square, Herald Square and the garment district.\r\n\r\nAt the close of the struggle her neck extended, her turtle beak grasping\r\nthe top of Radio City. She was still trying to pull herself up, as the\r\nbuoyant gasses hissed and bubbled away through the gushing holes in her\r\nside. Radio City collapsed with her.\r\n\r\nFor a long while after the roar of descending rubble and her own roaring\r\nhad ceased, there was no human noise except a melancholy thunder of the\r\nplanes.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe apology came early next morning.\r\n\r\nThe spaceship was observed to descend to the outer limits of atmosphere,\r\nvery briefly. A capsule was released, with a parachute timed to open at\r\n40,000 feet and come down quite neatly in Scarsdale. Parachute, capsule\r\nand timing device were of good workmanship.\r\n\r\nThe communication engraved on a plaque of metal (which still defies\r\nanalysis) was a hasty job, the English slightly odd, with some evidence\r\nof an incomplete understanding of the situation. That the visitors were\r\nthemselves aware of these deficiencies is indicated by the text of the\r\nmessage itself.\r\n\r\n      Most sadly regret inexcusable escape of livestock. 

While\r\n      petting same, one of our children monkied (sp?) with airlock.\r\n      Will not happen again. Regret also imperfect grasp of\r\n      language, learned through what you term Television etc.\r\n      Animal not dangerous, but observe some accidental damage\r\n      caused, therefore hasten to enclose reimbursement, having\r\n      taken liberty of studying your highly ingenious methods of\r\n      exchange. Hope same will be adequate, having estimated\r\n      deplorable inconvenience to best of ability. 

Regret\r\n      exceedingly impossibility of communicating further, as\r\n      pressure of time and prior obligations forbids. Please accept\r\n      heartfelt apologies and assurances of continuing esteem.\r\n\r\nThe reimbursement was in fact properly enclosed with the plaque, and may\r\nbe seen by the public in the rotunda of the restoration of Radio City.\r\nThough technically counterfeit, it looks like perfectly good money,\r\nexcept that Mr. Lincoln is missing one of his wrinkles and the words\r\n"FIVE DOLLARS" are upside down.\r\n\r\n\r\n  --EDGAR PANGBORN\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nThree paths led through the woods away from the resort hotel, and of\r\nthe three two were clearly marked: one with a sign that said it led to\r\nthe lake, the other pointing toward the golf links. The third pathway\r\nwas unmarked, and this was the one that inevitably the lovers and the\r\nhoneymooners took--the path that Alice and Fred Daniels followed today.\r\n\r\nThe sun was unusually warm for this time of year, but only a few\r\nyards along the pathway Fred and Alice were swallowed up by the great\r\nand near-great trees of the forest. The sunlight was, except for an\r\noccasional patch of light here and there, warded away by the foliage\r\nabove. The forest was very quiet. The pathway bridged a silent brook,\r\nand then, perhaps a third of a mile into the woods, turned abruptly to\r\nthe left and the woods became even more dense, the pathway narrow.\r\n\r\nThrough the trees to the right at this point was a clearing, an unusual\r\ngrassy circle perhaps sixty yards in diameter. It was not the clearing\r\nitself, however, but, instead, the glint of color in the sunlight that\r\ncaused Fred and Alice to stop and look.\r\n\r\nAlice said, "Fred, what is that?"\r\n\r\n"Don\'t know," he said. "Something red. Let\'s look."\r\n\r\nThe two of them turned off the path and made their way through a\r\ndismal barrage of thicket to the clearing that lay beyond. When they\r\ngot there, they saw the circular object--_vehicle_ might be a better\r\nword. It was possibly fifteen yards in diameter. It seemed to be made\r\nof three rings, smaller ones bottom and top and the larger one ribbing\r\nthe center, and to be constructed of some kind of plastic. Between the\r\ncentral and upper rings were set a series of small windows. The entire\r\nthing was painted a gaudy red.\r\n\r\n"What do you think it is?" Fred said.\r\n\r\n"A flying saucer," Alice said promptly. She laughed a little, but\r\nclutched at her husband\'s arm. "Isn\'t it?

"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know."\r\n\r\n"But what else would it be?"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know," Fred said again. "Let\'s look inside."\r\n\r\n"Fred," Alice said, "You\'d better not--"\r\n\r\n"Don\'t be silly," he said, and walked resolutely up to the object and,\r\nstanding on tiptoe, peered through one of the windows.\r\n\r\n"What is it?" Alice called from the edge of the clearing. "What do you\r\nsee?"\r\n\r\n"It\'s empty," he called back.\r\n\r\n"What\'s inside?"\r\n\r\nFred shook his head. "You won\'t believe it."\r\n\r\n"What?"\r\n\r\n"It\'s got a steering wheel," he called out hollowly. "And some dials."\r\n\r\n"My goodness," Alice said. "Is it a real one?"\r\n\r\n"How do I know?" he said, and rejoined her, casting a series of glances\r\nuncertainly over his shoulder at the bright red saucer behind him.\r\n"What do you suppose we ought to do?"\r\n\r\n"Tell somebody," Alice said. "I suppose."\r\n\r\n"Who do we tell?"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know. There must be _somebody_--"\r\n\r\nThey looked almost guiltily at each other. "Nobody\'ll believe us," Fred\r\nsaid.\r\n\r\n"Why not?" Alice said. "It\'s _here_, isn\'t it?"\r\n\r\nFred stopped and thought. "Who knows how long it\'ll stay?"\r\n\r\nThey looked at each other again. Then Alice said slowly, "If we went\r\nback and got the camera--"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nSwiftly, they made their way back toward the hotel through the quiet\r\nforest. When they got there, they found Mr. Mason, the manager of the\r\nhotel, adjusting the badminton net in front of the main porch. Mr.\r\nMason loosed a ready smile. "How\'s everything?" 

he said. "Find enough\r\nto do?"\r\n\r\n"Yes, thank you," Fred said to him. "We were just walking through the\r\nwoods. We came back for our camera. Then we\'re off again."\r\n\r\nMr. Mason nodded. "Find the saucer?"\r\n\r\nFred looked at him. "You mean the flying saucer?"\r\n\r\nThe manager nodded again. "I see you did find it. 

Good. Take a picture\r\nof it, by all means. I\'ve already taken a whole batch myself."\r\n\r\n"You have?" Fred said, frowning. "What\'s it all about?"\r\n\r\n"It\'s a flying saucer," Mr. Mason said. "From Venus. Mr. Steariot, who\r\npiloted it, is a guest here. I can introduce you to him if you like. 

He\r\nspeaks excellent English."\r\n\r\nFred Daniels said, "Wait a minute. You--"\r\n\r\n"Oh, there\'s no point in it," Mr. Mason said in a weary tone of voice.\r\n"No point in it at all. I took pictures. I tried to get the Army up\r\nhere. I wrote letters." He shrugged expressively. "It\'s a cynical age\r\nwe live in, I guess. Everybody\'s very polite, but they make it clear\r\nthey think it\'s just a gimmick I worked up to get the hotel publicity."\r\nHe nodded seriously. 

"The whole trouble\'s with Mr. Steariot. If he had\r\na light bulb for a head, or seven legs, or talked funny, why, it\'d be\r\na different thing entirely. But he looks and acts just like you or I.\r\nHere I\'ve got a legitimate flying saucer sitting on my property and you\r\nmight as well try to tell them it\'s a--well, a flying saucer! For all\r\nthey\'ll believe me. 

Now you two have seen it with your own eyes and you\r\ndon\'t believe it either."\r\n\r\nFred swallowed and looked at Alice for a moment. Then he said, "What\r\ndid you say his name was?"\r\n\r\n"Mr. Steariot," Mr. 

Mason said. "Actually, he\'s just as happy nobody\r\nbelieves he\'s from Venus. If they believed it, they\'d probably lock him\r\nup in jail somewhere or impound his saucer. As it is, he says this is\r\nthe first vacation he\'s had in years." Mr. Mason looked unhappily about\r\nhim. "He\'s probably in the lounge now. Want to meet him?"\r\n\r\nFred said dazedly, "I--"\r\n\r\n"Ah, come on," Mr. Mason said. "He won\'t bite you." He led the way up\r\nthe steps of the porch and into the lounge and over to where a small,\r\nmustachioed man, wearing eyeglasses and appearing to be in his late\r\nforties, was working a crossword puzzle in the morning paper.\r\n\r\n"Mr. Steariot," Mr. 

Mason said, "I should like you to meet Mr. and Mrs.\r\nDaniels, also guests here. They have just seen your saucer."\r\n\r\n"Charmed," Mr. Steariot said, and got to his feet. He shook hands with\r\nFred Daniels. "Are you here for a long stay, Mr. Daniels?"\r\n\r\n"I\'m not sure," Fred said, a little unhappily. "Mr. Mason told us you\r\nwere from Venus."\r\n\r\n"I told them about you, Mr. Steariot," Mr. Mason said. "Naturally, they\r\ndon\'t believe it any more than anybody else."\r\n\r\n"No reason why they should," Mr. Steariot said amiably. "No reason in\r\nthe world, if I may coin a phrase. Dr. Phelps at the Institute didn\'t\r\nbelieve it either."\r\n\r\nMr. Mason said, "Mr. Steariot here had a long interview with Dr. Phelps\r\nof the Geophysical Institute at Princeton when he first arrived here on\r\nEarth with us."\r\n\r\n"Oh," Fred said. He gazed uncomfortably at Mr. Steariot. "We didn\'t\r\nmean to interrupt you."\r\n\r\n"I was only doing the crossword puzzle," Mr. 

Steariot said. "Do you\r\nknow a two-letter word for sun-god?"\r\n\r\nAlice said, "Is this your first trip here?"\r\n\r\n"You mean here to the hotel," Mr. Steariot said, "or to Earth?"\r\n\r\n"Earth," Fred said, dismally.\r\n\r\n"My second," Mr. Steariot said. "First trip I wound up near Leningrad.\r\nTerrible time. I thought they\'d talk English, but they don\'t, and they\r\nthought I was an American, and two of their officials got into the\r\nsaucer with me, and the only way I could save myself was to take off\r\nwith them. They\'re on Venus now."\r\n\r\n"This accounts," Mr. Mason broke in, "for the way those two high\r\nRussian officials suddenly disappeared from sight three years ago. You\r\nremember? Everybody thought they\'d been liquidated."\r\n\r\nFred Daniels looked around the room. A hollow, frightening feeling had\r\ncome upon him. There were hundreds of questions he could have asked,\r\nand yet he wanted nothing so much as to be away from there.\r\n\r\nHis wife Alice, though, was constrained to learn more about Mr.\r\nSteariot. She said, "Mr. Steariot, may I ask you something?"\r\n\r\n"By all means," Mr. Steariot said, and blinked owlishly at her.\r\n\r\n"Do you," Alice said to him, "carry any money?"\r\n\r\nIt was, Fred Daniels realized, a marvelous question. If there were sham\r\nhere, this would be the quickest way to--\r\n\r\n"Why, of course." 

Mr. Steariot said, and reached for his wallet.\r\n"Let\'s see--health insurance--saucer driver\'s license--here, my dear.\r\nA five-djino bill." He extracted a yellow banknote and handed it to\r\nAlice. The banknote, slightly larger than an American dollar bill, was\r\nremarkably similar in other particulars. It had upon it a picture of a\r\nflying saucer, the figure 5, and, spelled out, "FIVE DJINOS".\r\n\r\n"Let me sign it for you," Mr. Steariot said, taking out a pen. "You can\r\nhave it for a souvenier."\r\n\r\n"Like the short snorters in the war," Mr. Mason, the hotel manager,\r\nsaid. "You remember them, Mr. 

Daniels? Where people got famous\r\nsignatures on five and ten and twenty-dollar bills and exchanged them\r\nand what not, and they called them short snorters?"\r\n\r\n"I remember," Fred Daniels said. 

"Something like that."\r\n\r\n"Five djinos on Venus," Mr. Steariot said, signing his name with a\r\nflourish, "is worth about twenty dollars here on Earth. No official\r\nrate of exchange, of course, but from what I\'ve seen, that\'s about what\r\nI\'d judge. 

Here you go." He handed the bill over.\r\n\r\n"Well, wait, then," Fred Daniels said. "I ought to sign one of _our_\r\nbills for _you_."\r\n\r\n"Ah, no need for that," Mr. 

Steariot said. "No doubt you need twenty\r\ndollars worse than I need five djinos."\r\n\r\n"Don\'t be ridiculous," Fred said, a little stiffly; and, by now\r\ncommitted, he went into his wallet and came out with a twenty dollar\r\nbill. He signed his name to it, using Mr. Steariot\'s fountain pen.\r\n\r\n"Wonderful," Mr. Steariot said. "How nice to have met you both."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"I feel very badly about this," Mr. Mason, the hotel manager, said to\r\nFred and Alice. The three of them were on the porch outside. "This\r\nshort snorter business always seems to happen whenever I introduce Mr.\r\nSteariot to anyone. Dr. Phelps at the Institute gave him fifty dollars.\r\nCan you imagine that?"\r\n\r\n"It\'s interesting in its way," Fred said. "It just occurred to me: Mr.\r\nSteariot can spend Earth money here, but we can\'t spend Venus money."\r\n\r\n"That\'s true," Mr. Mason said. 

"On the other hand, Mr. Steariot has\r\nnever once, to my knowledge, been the one to bring up the subject. I\r\nthink it\'s quite painful to him, really. But the same thing inevitably\r\noccurs to everybody he meets. You know, let\'s see the color of your\r\nmoney. I guess people are pretty much the same everywhere--that\r\nis, everywhere on _Earth_. They judge everything in terms of money,\r\nincluding whether you\'ve even been born on Earth! \'Let\'s see your\r\nmoney,\' they say to Mr. Steariot, and out he comes with one of those\r\ndamn five-djino bills, and we\'re off."\r\n\r\n"You know," Alice Daniels said thoughtfully, "in a way it\'s a lesson.\r\nIsn\'t it, Fred? "After\r\nall, for you it\'s just a vacation. For me, I\'ve got this man sitting in\r\nmy lounge day in and day out doing crossword puzzles and trading short\r\nsnorters with my guests. Nobody really believes he\'s from Venus--nobody\r\nimportant, anyway. It\'s a little frightening, when you\'re trying to run\r\na happy hotel. Sometimes I wish he\'d go back to wherever he came from."\r\n\r\n"Well," Fred said, "he\'s bound to leave one of these days."\r\n\r\n"Maybe," Mr. Mason said doubtfully. "Offhand, though, I\'d say the way\r\nhe\'s taking it in, he can\'t afford to."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


No, he wasn't the Agent just before you. He was here in\r\n2180--oh, a good thirty years back, Earth-time. The natives say\r\nhundreds of years, but they're a short-lived lot. The way they cut\r\neach other's throats, it's a wonder any of them live out the life span\r\nthey've got, anyway.\r\n\r\nI came out when Duncan did--knew him pretty well, as well as anybody\r\ncould. A perfect fool. Knowing him was a real education. Do anything\r\nthe other way from the way Duncan did it, and you'd be all right.\r\n\r\nYou wouldn't think it to look at him. Well set-up man, around thirty\r\nwhen he got here, intelligent face, good talker, had a degree--but\r\na fool. 

Seemed as if he couldn't do anything right. He told me once\r\nthat he'd been married, and that it had broken up. He more or less\r\nimplied that his wife had gotten sick of little things--broken dishes,\r\ntactless remarks, carelessness. You wouldn't think that would be\r\nenough to break up a marriage, but you've got no idea how that sort of\r\nthing can add up.\r\n\r\nI was clerking for him then. I swear I did all the work. 

I had to. He\r\ncouldn't add, couldn't file a record, and couldn't have found one if\r\nhe'd managed somehow to put it away. I took Agent's inventories, I did\r\nmost of the trading with the native chiefs, I did everything. Duncan\r\njust bumbled around the post, or listened to records, or wrote those\r\nsilly, hopeless, letters to his ex-wife. He was trying to get her to\r\ncome back to him. 

How do I know? Well, who do you think worked the\r\nsubspace transmitter, as well as doing everything else?\r\n\r\nThe native thing really annoyed me, though, because it was dangerous.\r\nYou know the Tarchiki. They look human enough, except for minor\r\ndetails. When it comes to a Tarchik female I'll overlook the green skin\r\nand the pointed ears every time. But they aren't entirely like us. 

They\r\nhave a liking for war and torture that's really sickening.\r\n\r\nOur ancestors? Oh, now, really ... you're talking just like Duncan.\r\nThat was always his apology for them. He said our own ancestors were\r\npretty bad, too. Certainly they were, but I can't see any ancestor of\r\nmine acting the way a Tarchik does with a captured enemy. And they\r\nhaven't the slightest sense of sportsmanship, either. They'd rather\r\njump you from ambush than fight in the open, and they won't fight at\r\nall if the enemy's stronger than they are. That's why they've never\r\nmade any serious attempt to do in all the Earthmen on their world.\r\nThat, and greed; they get very good deals from us, and they know it.\r\n\r\nAnyway, I'm sure none of my ancestors ever acted like that.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBut Duncan was always ready to forgive a Tarchik anything. That used\r\nto upset the hell out of them, too, because they expect to be punished\r\nwhen they're caught at anything. They don't understand our reluctance\r\nto kill, but they respect a Patrolman's shock gun, and when they get\r\ncaught stealing or taking each other's tails they know they're going\r\nto get a few months in quod, or what they hate much worse, a public\r\nflogging. If they didn't get punished, they'd assume it was weakness on\r\nour part. Just like kids.\r\n\r\nAnyway, there was Duncan, holding long confabs with the Tarchiki,\r\ntrying to teach them some sort of elementary ethics. Naturally, it\r\ndidn't take at all. They listened, because they love long speeches, but\r\nthey never acted on what he said.\r\n\r\nHe used to tell them that if they stopped chopping each other up and\r\nhanging up the rows of tails as war trophies, their lives would be a\r\nlot pleasanter. They used to nod and applaud, but Duncan never caught\r\non to the simple fact that they thought this was meant to be a joke.\r\n_They_ didn't think their lives weren't pleasant enough. After all,\r\nlook at their situation. They've got plenty to eat, without working\r\nhard for it, plenty of time on their hands--why shouldn't they keep\r\ndown their surplus population? They don't know any other way, except\r\nbreaking up their eggs, and they only do that to enemy tribes.\r\n\r\nWhile he was at it, Duncan tried to tell them all about love and things\r\nlike that. Oh, no, not sex. If there's anything a Tarchik doesn't\r\nknow about _that_, there's no Earthman going to teach him. I mean the\r\nway they treat their women. A Tarchik woman's nothing but a piece of\r\nproperty as far as sex goes, but there's some kind of curious maternal\r\ninheritance thing--anyway, it's as funny as hell to see a big Tarchik\r\nbuck get down and bump his head in front of his mother, and his aunts,\r\nand all his other female ancestors. That's the one thing he's really\r\nafraid of. But, till she gets to be a mother, a woman leads a fairly\r\nrough life, getting passed around as a kind of prize of war, working\r\nharder than the men, all that.\r\n\r\nSo Duncan wanted them to be a bit chivalrous to their women. Share the\r\nwork, all kinds of things like that. You know what they thought of that\r\nidea--another Earthman's joke.\r\n\r\nBut the funniest thing of all, to them, was his idea about the kids.\r\nNaturally, a Tarchik pup's no use to its father till it's a bit grown.\r\nThen, if it's a boy, the old man teaches it to drink _smassi_ and file\r\nits teeth, and go out ambushing and cutting tails with the other noble\r\nsavages. If it's a girl, the father looks around for a suitable buyer\r\nas soon as its breasts are grown, and hopes for the best price possible.\r\n\r\nTo the mothers, though, the kids represent a kind of investment, since\r\ncustom directs the first loyalties to the mother's clan. So they treat\r\nthem pretty well, although a bit casually, since they litter by twos\r\nand at least once a year.\r\n\r\nAnyway, Duncan seemed to think highly of kids. Can't imagine why, since\r\nhe never had any of his own. 

He used to run a kind of school for them.\r\nTaught them all kinds of things a Tarchik's got no use for at all, made\r\ntoys for them--badly, naturally; he couldn't have cut his initials in\r\na tree without slicing his thumb. But what he couldn't make in the way\r\nof school stuff, he imported from Earth. Cost him his entire salary,\r\nexcept for what he spent on those futile letters to his wife.\r\n\r\nThose kids were fond of him, I suppose--as fond of him as a Tarchik\r\never gets of anything. They even kept the school foolishness going\r\nawhile afterward, but I think it's gone now.\r\n\r\nAnything that fool Duncan said, the Tarchiki thought was a great joke.\r\nThey wouldn't have hurt his feelings for anything, for fear he'd quit\r\ntelling them tall stories. They told him quite a few things, too. 

He\r\nwrote it all down, in dead earnest, as if their fairy tales and drum\r\npoems had any value. I sent the whole lot off to his wife, after it\r\nhappened. I think it got lost in transit--I never heard from her,\r\nanyway. 

Or she may have thrown it all away. I can't imagine what else\r\nyou could do with such a pile of nonsense.\r\n\r\nAs a matter of fact, that's what led up to it--those damned legends.\r\nDuncan got interested in their religion. Never do that, boy. Let 'em\r\nall have their ghost stories and wooden gods, and never fool around\r\nwith their idea of what makes the planet go round.\r\n\r\nThe Tarchiks have a lot of small time fetishes, but they also have\r\none big god, a fat one made out of stone, out in the jungle over near\r\nMount Clarke. Every so often they all go up in a body and pay him a\r\nvisit, and they take along any spare pups, usually extra girl children\r\nor prisoners from other tribes. This god--Kachan, his name is, I\r\nthink--likes children too. He likes them best roasted, like birds on a\r\nspit. Charming deity.\r\n\r\nAnyway, when Duncan found out about Kachan, he got very upset. He went\r\nblazing out there to Mount Clarke, and he blew Kachan all to bits with\r\na grenade. The Tarchiki didn't care for that, naturally.\r\n\r\nAbout a week later, Duncan was on his way over to the big village near\r\nhere, to give his Tarchik kids another arithmetic lesson, I suppose.\r\nOld Stancha--he was the local religious big shot, a kind of High\r\nPriest--threw a spear from the bushes, Tarchik fashion, and nailed\r\nDuncan very neatly. Nailed, yes. That's the way we found him, with his\r\nback against a tree.\r\n\r\nJust another case of a man's foolishness catching up with him. But\r\nDuncan hasn't stopped giving us trouble yet, dead or not. First thing\r\nthat happened was that old Stancha came in to the post, demanding to\r\nbe executed. He claimed he'd made a big mistake killing Duncan, the\r\nbiggest mistake of his life. I never could figure out what he meant--it\r\nseemed to have something to do with what Duncan said to him just before\r\nhe died.\r\n\r\nWell, if Stancha had kept his mouth shut, we'd have had no case at\r\nall, which would have been just fine with me. I was Agent, in Duncan's\r\nplace, and I was out to see to it that business stayed good and got\r\nbetter. Can't annoy the natives by executing their high priest and\r\nexpect good trade. But I couldn't very well let Stancha go, either,\r\nonce he'd confessed. So I had him tried, all proper and correct, and\r\nexecuted him in due form.\r\n\r\nNext thing I knew, the Tarchiks were putting Kachan back together\r\nagain. They were all up there, building a great big new version, and\r\nhaving a first class party at the same time. 

These parties generally\r\nlead to a tail-hunting expedition, so I expected some trouble. But it\r\ndidn't, this time.\r\n\r\nThere was plenty of noise, though. The Tarchiki never do anything\r\nquietly, and this seemed to be an occasion. What with drums, bagpipes,\r\nwailing and howling, there wasn't a bird would roost for twenty miles\r\naround.\r\n\r\nWhen they got all through, I went up to look over the new statue, out\r\nof curiosity, and because I'd heard that they hadn't sacrificed a\r\nsingle pup. I thought there must be something queer about Kachan Number\r\nTwo. There was.\r\n\r\nIt was Duncan. They'd given him a tail, and he looked more like a\r\nTarchik than an Earthman, but the face was unmistakable. They aren't\r\nhalf bad carvers, you know; and they'd really spread themselves this\r\ntime. The thing was forty feet tall, and it stood on a rock platform,\r\nwith some words carved in that lettering Duncan had taught them to use.\r\nThe words were something Duncan was supposed to have said as he was\r\ndying.\r\n\r\nI never could read that stuff really well; all I got out of the thing\r\nwas that Duncan was forgiving the old murderer, because he didn't know\r\nwhat he was doing. Pure nonsense, of course, but you don't expect a\r\ndying man to make sense, and particularly not Duncan. But it seems\r\nthose words were what had caused all the to-do.\r\n\r\nI found the story in one of those ballads Duncan had collected. Seems\r\nthat the Tarchiki had been expecting a great teacher to show up,\r\nwho'd do all sorts of wonderful things for them. Nothing unusual; all\r\nprimitives have some story like that. But there was something else.\r\n\r\nThe idea was that if the Tarchiki listened to this teacher, he'd make\r\nthem the most important people in the whole world; in the universe,\r\nin fact, from the way the thing sounded. Just how, wasn't specified.\r\nBut if they should let him be killed, they would know who he had been\r\nbecause of his last words, forgiving them. Naturally, they fitted\r\nDuncan right in; forgiving anybody would be the least likely idea in\r\nany Tarchik's mind if he were being speared.\r\n\r\nSo the Tarchiki think they've made a terrible mistake, and they seem\r\nbent on spending the rest of time making up for it. It's the leading\r\nreligion now, and it's the biggest joke I've ever come across. 

Poor\r\nDuncan, wrong-headed as he was about nearly everything else, had a bit\r\nof sense in that department; he never had any religious nonsense in him.\r\n\r\nAnyway, it shows you, doesn't it? I've always said you can learn a\r\nlittle from practically anything. You keep Duncan in mind, any time you\r\nget to feeling too soft on these natives. He might be a god to these\r\nTarchiki, but I'll tell you the real test of whether a man's got any\r\nsense; he's dead, I'm alive, and you're alive. That's enough proof for\r\nme.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n

]\r\n\r\n\r\nN\'Zik was a forlorn and weary figure at the forward port. He balanced\r\nhis frail, bulbous body on four of his eight limbs, while the other\r\nfour moved listlessly over the etheroscope, adjusting sights and\r\nlenses. N\'Zik wondered dully why he bothered. Even from here he could\r\nsee that the system looking ahead, the dull reddish Sun with its wild\r\nand darksome planets, was not for them.\r\n\r\nBitterness flooded his soul. To have come so far and searched so\r\nlong, only to find this! In all this Galaxy here was the one Sun that\r\nsustained a planetary system, and that Sun was dying! The irony was\r\nmore than he could bear.\r\n\r\nShi-Zik came to stand beside him. Only she and N\'Zik were left, of all\r\nthe thousands; two alone on this driving colossus which was the only\r\nworld they had ever known. She sensed his bitterness now and tried to\r\nspeak words of hope.\r\n\r\n"See, N\'Zik, there are inner planets! How close their orbits are! There\r\nmay still be warmth and life-sustaining rays."\r\n\r\nN\'Zik\'s limbs sprawled outward in despair.\r\n\r\n"This dying system is not for us, Shi-Zik. The five largest and\r\noutermost planets are but barren, frigid rock. But if you wish, we\r\nshall go inward."\r\n\r\nHis limbs flashed over the huge control-console. Gradually the ship\r\nslowed in its headlong pace. Nearly the size of a small planet, was\r\nthis ship; entire generations had been born and died aboard it, during\r\nthe trip between Galaxies. Somewhere deep inside, perpetual generators\r\npounded out the power that had driven them through space faster than\r\nlight.\r\n\r\nN\'Zik and Shi-Zik had never seen those generators, nor were they\r\nconscious now of the smooth threnody. They had known it always. Miles\r\nof inter-locking corridors extended behind them too, a veritable city\r\nwith vast rooms of wonderful machinery--but none of this had they ever\r\nseen. For DEATH had struck suddenly there, was lurking there still.\r\n\r\nThe huge metal tomes told of it. N\'Zik and Shi-Zik had read that\r\nhistory so often that they knew it now by heart. They knew how and why\r\nthe last generations had been wiped out.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe first scientists had planned well for the safety and well-being\r\nof the generations to come, but they had overlooked one thing. Within\r\ntheir own Galaxy they had been cognizant of certain cosmic rays, which\r\nwere harmless insofar as they had no apparent effect on living tissues.\r\nHowever, in that utter vacuity between Galaxies _no such rays existed_!\r\nAnd there between Galaxies new generations were born. Five, ten, a\r\ndozen generations. And at last--they had reached the new Galaxy....\r\n\r\nWhether the cosmic rays here differed, or whether the new generations\r\nhad simply lost all resistance to them, was never fully known. The\r\nrace had died by thousands as the hard rays penetrated the ship. The\r\nscientists worked feverishly to build up a section with layers of\r\ntheir heaviest metals; but by the time they had achieved a sufficient\r\nthickness, a few dozen had survived.\r\n\r\nN\'Zik and Shi-Zik were the last of that final group.\r\n\r\nNow, under N\'Zik\'s sure guidance, the ship crossed the orbits of the\r\nouter planets. He had thrown over the deceleration control, but their\r\nspeed was still tremendous.\r\n\r\nIn a few minutes craggy fragments of rock were skimming past their\r\nhull. The larger ones were deflected by automatic repulsion plates and\r\nthe few that drifted through became molten upon contact. Such was their\r\nspeed.\r\n\r\nThen they were through the swarm, and N\'Zik remarked, "This is an old\r\nsystem indeed. At one time a planet must have occupied that orbit."\r\n\r\n"Look." Shi-Zik\'s spider-like body was taut with eagerness as she\r\npointed to a planet far ahead, swinging away from their trajectory.\r\n"Shall we follow it?"\r\n\r\n"There is no purpose. 

We can pick it up in the etheroscope." 

N\'Zik\r\nadjusted the sights. The planet together with its two moons leaped into\r\nview on the screen. N\'Zik manipulated the magnilens and it was brought\r\nstill nearer.\r\n\r\nVast icy caps encompassed most of this world. The rest was frozen\r\ndesert, slightly reddish, with a few peculiar straight-line markings\r\nthat might have been man-made. But that didn\'t interest them now.\r\nIt was all too apparent that this planet had been uninhabitable for\r\nmillennia.\r\n\r\n"Dead. A frozen, dead world," Shi-Zik intoned. "Let us go on to the\r\nnext one."\r\n\r\nThey moved ever inward. The next planet with its single satellite\r\noffered no more promise. Here they saw stark mountain ranges in\r\ncontrast to vast hollows that might have been dead ocean bottoms. The\r\nmagnilens picked out several cities, tottering, crumbling in ruin.\r\n\r\n"Cities," N\'Zik muttered. "Cities still standing on this airless world.\r\nA civilization once existed here, and it cannot have been so long ago.\r\nShall we go on, Shi-Zik? There are two or three other planets but I\r\nfear they will offer no more than this."\r\n\r\nNow something of N\'Zik\'s despair came upon Shi-Zik. "No, we need not\r\ngo on. I feel weary of it all. I care not if we ever find the place we\r\nseek."\r\n\r\n"I too, have had this feeling," N\'Zik waved his limbs in agreement.\r\n"Shi-Zik, we have searched this Galaxy through. There may yet be\r\nlife-giving Suns with planets, but we have not much time. Of late I\r\nhave felt the engines becoming sluggish of power...."\r\n\r\n"True. The way has been long." 

She gestured hopelessly. "Do you suggest\r\nthen, that we put an end to the mission?"\r\n\r\n"Not without your consent, Shi-Zik."\r\n\r\n"I have wanted to end it!" Shi-Zik cried. "For a very long time I have\r\nthought of it, but dared not speak."\r\n\r\n"And yet," N\'Zik mused, "perhaps we should search further. Search until\r\nthe end. It was the will of our forebears that the race be continued.\r\nShould we end so ingloriously what they set out to achieve?"\r\n\r\n"The will of our forebears is as nothing to the will of Praav," Shi-Zik\r\nspoke softly, gazing out to the stars. "Praav has watched safely over\r\nus all this time. If He had wanted us to find a place, we should have\r\nfound it. 

And we need not end ingloriously. Observe, N\'Zik, that we,\r\nthe last of our kind, have ended here, at what is probably the last\r\nplanetary system. Its sun is dying as our race is dying. Let us all go\r\nout in a final flame together, a blaze of glory!"\r\n\r\nThe bitterness had left N\'Zik now. "You are right, my dear. It was\r\nmeant that we should end here. I believe Praav has willed it so!"\r\n\r\nHe threw the controls over to full acceleration and locked them\r\ninto place. The colossus of all spaceships piled acceleration upon\r\nacceleration with the speed of light, plunging on its unerring course\r\ntoward the dying Sun. The two beings from another Galaxy stood at the\r\nforward port, proudly side by side. Space-suited and helmeted, he emerged from the low line of\r\ncliffs and looked out upon the desolate surface of Mercury.\r\n\r\nFor the past week he had worked hard in the underground laboratories.\r\nOccasionally he came to the surface where he could see the dark sky,\r\nand the pin-points of stars, and the dying Sun once more. That alone\r\ngave him incentive to go on. 

He, with the several thousand others,\r\nwere working out the problem which might save them from extinction. It\r\nwas slow work, damnably slow and hard, and Curt knew in his heart they\r\nwould not be in time.\r\n\r\nHe raised his face to the red orb whose heat scarcely touched\r\nhere. Again he marvelled that disaster had come so suddenly. Solar\r\nradiation was not supposed to end like that! It should have gone on\r\nfor millennia. That\'s what the scientists had preached. But it had\r\nended--scarcely five hundred years ago. Curt had never known Earth,\r\nonly the city here far within Mercury, where there was meager warmth\r\nand light. And now even the internal heat of Mercury was fast cooling.\r\n\r\nCurt turned at the sound of footsteps behind him. That would be Olana.\r\nShe, too, came here each week.\r\n\r\nShe stopped beside him, raised her helmeted face to Sun and stars\r\nwith infinite longing. For a moment neither of them spoke. Then Olana\r\nclicked on her helmet radio.\r\n\r\n"Each time, Curt ... each time I come here I imagine the Sun has grown\r\ndimmer. Is it really only my imagination?"\r\n\r\n"Yes. It becomes dimmer, but not perceptibly. Solar radiation is\r\nelectronic, and the theory is that our Sun has merely exhausted an\r\nouter sheath of electrons. Lord knows what internal condition caused\r\nit! If it\'s a solid body, it may be due to certain peculiarities of\r\nthe strata. The sun spots of hundreds of years ago must have been the\r\nbeginning of the end."\r\n\r\nShe nodded. "How is the work coming?"\r\n\r\n"The Traction Rays? Slowly, Olana--too slowly." Curt shook his head\r\nin weariness. "We\'re in the process of testing, but they are still\r\nnot strong enough. It means months more of work, and we shall need\r\nhundreds! You know, if we fail on the first attempt we shall not have\r\nanother chance."\r\n\r\n"I--I still don\'t quite understand it," Olana was puzzled. "I know it\r\nhas something to do with the orbit of Vulcan. But how can it save us?"\r\n\r\n"It may not. 

It\'s a forlorn chance. You know of course that Vulcan\'s a\r\nvery small planet, scarcely larger than Earth\'s moon. And it pursues\r\nan orbit much closer to the Sun than Mercury. If we can drive it out of\r\nits orbit with the Traction Rays, it may fall into the Sun!"\r\n\r\n"But suppose," Olana pointed out, "it only takes up a closer orbit?"\r\n\r\n"Exactly why we\'re taking no chances. "\r\n\r\nCurt shrugged. 

"After that it\'s anybody\'s guess. Professor Marston\r\nbelieves that such a collision will set up a combustion sufficient to\r\nrelease internal electronic action from the Sun\'s depths. And, once\r\nthat is started, the Sun will blaze again."\r\n\r\n"I see," Olana exclaimed. "Something like stirring up dying embers!"\r\n\r\n"Yes." There was no eagerness in Curt\'s voice. "\r\n\r\nThis was more like it. If Brigadier General Straut could have this\r\nthing wrapped up by the time Washington awoke to the fact that it was\r\nsomething big--well, he\'d been waiting a long time for that second\r\nstar.
