He might spot something the\r\nothers were missing. It might blow them all to kingdom come any second;\r\nbut what the hell, he had earned his star on sheer guts in Normandy. He\r\nstill had \'em.\r\n\r\nHe keyed the phone. "I\'m coming down, Bill," he told the Major.\r\nOn impulse, he strapped a pistol belt on. copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nThe sun had not yet taken the chill out of the early April morning that\r\nbroke on the foothills of the Rocky Mountains, when the ship settled to\r\nthe ground. It was surprisingly large compared to the aircraft native\r\nto this planet, and yet ridiculously small to have brought enough men\r\nand material to launch an invasion across light years of space.\r\n\r\nThe landing went unobserved in this fearful year of 1955. The world\r\nfaced too many crucial crises of their own making to consider the\r\nnecessity to be watchful for an extra-terrestrial invasion.\r\n\r\nHardly had the craft come to rest, when the outer lock slid noiselessly\r\nopen and a small ladder-like stairway came down until it too had\r\ntouched earth.\r\n\r\nA man appeared in the doorway, pausing to study the landscape which\r\nlay before him. His features, his body, were human. Despite his being\r\ntoo well muscled, and his face unusually handsome, he would never have\r\naroused suspicion of being from another planet.\r\n\r\nGrunting in satisfaction, he permitted himself the pleasure of being\r\nproud at having landed so near the cabin chosen as his goal. It had\r\nbeen a wise choice, this picking of so well isolated a place as a\r\ntesting ground for the weapon. A wisp of smoke, a dark smudge against\r\nthe rich blueness of the sky, attested to the cabin\'s occupancy. What\r\nhe was about to do seemed fitting, for even the scientists of this\r\nplanet had used animal life to test their own puny weapons. Now he,\r\nman, would be the guinea pig to prove the devastation to be wrought\r\nagainst all mankind native to this world.\r\n\r\nHe turned and spoke to someone within the lock. His language, while\r\nresembling no earthly tongue, was not much different than perhaps\r\nEnglish to Chinese. It was foreign but not completely alien.\r\n\r\nWith the ease of a man accustomed to heavier gravity he went down the\r\nladder easily, turning when he reached the ground to look up at the\r\nlock.\r\n\r\nAnd then to the edge of the air lock, she came--the weapon! There had\r\nbeen no doubt in the minds of her creators as to her effectiveness--she\r\nwould conquer this planet. The armed might of Earth would vanish\r\nbefore her. Before the year had ended the invasion would have been\r\naccomplished. As a weapon, the Earth\'s H-Bomb might well be a mere\r\nfirecracker. She had been tested against the men of her own planet and\r\nfound to be irresistible, but now would come the final test against the\r\nenemy without laboratory-controlled conditions.\r\n\r\nThe planet she had come from is unimportant, suffice to say their\r\ntechnology had conquered space over a thousand years ago. For over\r\nhalf that time they had subjugated neighboring worlds until their rule\r\nhad spread to the borders of Earth. Scouting ships had been spying on\r\nEarth for the past two centuries and had brought back alarming reports\r\nconcerning the rapidly expanding technology of this planet.\r\n\r\nSoon after the aliens had discovered the secret of space flight had\r\ncome the added knowledge planets could be conquered by other than the\r\nforce of arms. Psychological warfare had been developed to a fantastic\r\ndegree, making weapons more potent than any bombs of fissionable\r\nmaterial.\r\n\r\nThere she stood, a monument to her creators. Eve, soon to be conqueror\r\nof the planet Earth.\r\n\r\nTo attempt description of her beauty would be an impossibility, for the\r\nlanguages of man do not contain the necessary word-symbols to express\r\nthe utter perfection of her face and form. To each man she would appear\r\ndifferent, for he would see in her the substance of his unconscious\r\ndesires for the woman he had never dreamed might exist. For this\r\npurpose the scientists had labored in their laboratories for nearly a\r\nhalf century, and now she would justify the time and effort spent in\r\nher creation.\r\n\r\nGently, she smiled at the man waiting below, and despite the special\r\nconditioning he had undergone, and the drugs he took with careful\r\nregularity for added protection, he almost surrendered to the impulse\r\nto throw himself at her feet; to beg for only the privilege to serve\r\nher, to obey her, and to worship her.\r\n\r\nOut of the entire space fleet, he, Commander Ydnas, after extensive\r\npsychological testing, had been selected for this task. The three\r\nmonths of conditioning had passed rapidly, his response to the\r\ntreatments had been better than they had dared to hope. 

In the two\r\nweeks of their flight he had been unaffected by her presence, and now\r\nupon landing he was beginning to feel the strain he was under. He\r\nwondered what would have happened had it not been for the added help of\r\nthe drugs?\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHis face betrayed none of the anxiety he now felt. It was an impassive\r\nmask, his body was ramrod tense and erect.\r\n\r\nShe came down the steps gracefully, her litheness would have made the\r\nmovements of a cat seem awkward and clumsy.\r\n\r\nBoth had been thoroughly trained in the languages needed to carry out\r\nthe plan of invasion, English and Russian. First, the large continent\r\nof North America would be disarmed at her command; and then they would\r\nmove across the large body of water to Europe. Russia would be their\r\ninitial target there. The invasion timetable called for a three month\r\ncampaign, and then Eve would be removed from the planet before the\r\noccupation fleet from the mother world would land. Not a man would be\r\nlost, nor a space ship damaged, and yet the planet\'s rich potential\r\nwould be theirs for the taking.\r\n\r\nAnd what of Eve? She was too dangerous to be permitted to return to her\r\ncreators. Commander Ydnas had his instructions covering the final phase\r\nof the invasion plan. When her task of disarming Earth was completed,\r\nand the planet lay helpless to defend itself, they would blast off into\r\nspace together. Soon as Earth\'s atmosphere was left behind, she would\r\nbe slain, her body incinerated through the rocket tubes.\r\n\r\nIt seemed such a dreadful waste to destroy such beauty of perfection,\r\nbut the Commander, raised from infancy to be a space officer, realized\r\nthe need for her disposal. After the need for a weapon has passed, it\r\nis safer to destroy it then risk the danger of trying to store it. Even\r\non this world they dumped their poison gases into the seas and did the\r\nsame with the more volatile explosives.\r\n\r\n"Come," he said, starting toward the cabin. When she would have taken\r\nhis hand, he brushed it aside angrily. 

Even the work the psychologists\r\nhad done to condition him, and the strength of the drugs, could be\r\ntrusted only up to a point. He feared what her touch might do to the\r\niron discipline with which he kept himself in check.\r\n\r\nThe only response to his rebuff, was a shrug of those magnificently\r\nrounded shoulders, and a lazy half-smile of amusement.\r\n\r\nHer creators had considered it a bit of ironic humor to name her so\r\noutlandish and yet befitting a name as Eve. For her namesake too had\r\nbeen a temptress bringing about the calamities of mankind, and now eons\r\nlater another Eve would end the supremacy of man.\r\n\r\nAt the door of the cabin the commander paused. His eyes sought those of\r\nthe woman. She stood regarding him strangely, and for the first time he\r\nfound himself wondering what she must feel about her part in bringing\r\nabout the defeat of a world? She had no control over her actions. She\r\nwas conditioned to follow the tenets of the master plan. He wished he\r\nhad not held himself so aloof from her during the flight. Now there was\r\nno time to question what she felt. And after the invasion for her there\r\nwould be only destruction.\r\n\r\nAnnoyed with himself, he turned back to the door, his knuckles sounded\r\ndully against the thickness of the wood. 

He waited impatiently,\r\nreceiving no answer to his knocking. With one hand near the weapon in\r\nhis belt, he reached out and lifted the latch.\r\n\r\nGesturing for Eve to remain outside, he stepped over the threshold.\r\n\r\nA man dozed in the large chair before the still smouldering fireplace.\r\nWhen the cool air reached him he shivered and opened his eyes.\r\n\r\n"I am Commander Ydnas."\r\n\r\nThe man gazed at him blankly, his sleep-stained face bewildered at the\r\nrude awakening. He seemed unimpressed by the military splendor of the\r\ncommander\'s uniform.\r\n\r\nThe commander eyed the man with mild contempt. This would do as a\r\nguinea pig to prove the effectiveness of Eve. Here too would be an\r\nexcellent base of operations. The man could supply many useful details\r\nneeded before the invasion could begin.\r\n\r\n"Eve," he called. "Come in!"\r\n\r\nShe entered the room reluctantly, her gaze pitying the man seated so\r\nstrangely still in his chair. She waited for his expression to change\r\nwhen he saw her. 

In a moment he would be grovelling at her feet. Eve\r\nhated what she was doing, but the patterns implanted in her brain by\r\nthe creators made it impossible for her to resist.\r\n\r\nThe Commander\'s stern jaw relaxed, his mouth fell open in shock.\r\nImpossible! Incredible! The man continued to remain motionless,\r\nregarding them with annoyed perplexity.\r\n\r\nThe scientists had blundered; earth beings were not creatures governed\r\nby their emotions. The data collected by the spy ships had been\r\nerroneous, the invasion would fail.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nInstinctively he looked to the woman. Eve watched him in open\r\namusement, and he wondered if he had not caught a glimpse of sympathy\r\nin her eyes. She knew what this meant to him. No man returned to the\r\nmother planet in defeat. If he did not follow the time-honored custom\r\nof self-destruction to atone for his failure, he would face a quick\r\ndeath when he returned.\r\n\r\n"What--what did you want?" asked the man, annoyance making his voice a\r\npetulant whine.\r\n\r\n"Nothing, sir. We made a mistake. 

I\'m afraid we came to the wrong\r\nplace."\r\n\r\nThe Commander turned to Eve, his face transformed by a smile for the\r\nfirst time since they had been together.\r\n\r\n"I know of an asteroid that is pretty well out of the space lanes. It\r\nhas an atmosphere and can support life without a great struggle on our\r\npart. 

Do you think you could like it there? Of course, it wouldn\'t be\r\nmuch of a world for you to conquer, and I would be the only man to\r\nserve you ... but...."\r\n\r\nShe studied him thoughtfully, and then in answer to what he had asked,\r\nshe took his arm. They left the cabin together, walking very closely.\r\n\r\nIt must have seemed a cosmic joke to the gods of the universe to see\r\nthe invader and the woman, who was to have been his weapon, pause and\r\nwave a casual farewell to the planet they had come to conquer.\r\n\r\n"Asteroid," the man mused aloud. "What kind of crazy gibberish had they\r\nbeen talking? 

Must be honeymooners from one of the nearby resorts."\r\n\r\nHe shrugged in an attempt to dismiss it from his mind, maybe he ought\r\nto ask Helen about it when she got back. Come to think of it she should\r\nbe back with the supplies any minute now.\r\n\r\nThere was a strange roar from outside, and the sound of some great\r\nobject hurtling through the air, but strangely enough the man did\r\nnot leap from his chair and rush to the door to see what created the\r\ndisturbance.\r\n\r\nHe did not move from the fireplace until the chill had begun to fill\r\nthe cabin, and then reluctantly he stood up fumbling along the side of\r\nthe chair for some object leaning against it.\r\n\r\nWhen he located it, he grasped it tightly, and then made his way\r\ncautiously to the door. He shifted the stick to his left hand fumbling\r\nfor the latch. Locating it he closed the door.\r\n\r\nThe invaders had come ... and left in defeat. But the victor would\r\nnever know he had beaten off the first invasion of Earth, saving\r\nmankind from slavery and civilization from destruction. To him they\r\nwere mere voices babbling meaningless words. The splendor of their\r\nspace ship, the wondrous fatal beauty of the woman never would be known\r\nto him ... for he was totally blind!\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


But as a newspaper\r\n           reporter, Bennet had the job of keeping facts and\r\n           fancies separate. He was good at that--too good!\r\n\r\n           [Transcriber\'s Note: This etext was produced from\r\n          Science Fiction Adventures Magazine, February 1953.\r\n         Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that\r\n         the U.S. copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nI found Johnny a few blocks from our hotel in a little bar that was\r\nnearly deserted. He was sitting alone at a table in a dark corner,\r\nstaring morosely at nothing in particular, his hand limp around an\r\nalmost-empty glass. He seemed perfectly sober, though his eyes stared\r\nglassily ahead.\r\n\r\nI sat down beside him. "What do you say we go back to the hotel,\r\nJohnny? Tomorrow\'s another slave day."\r\n\r\nHis eyes shifted to me and then back to nothing. I wondered if he had\r\nactually seen me.\r\n\r\n"We can talk about it over some coffee and a bit to eat."\r\n\r\nI suggested, placing my hand on his arm.\r\n\r\n"Go to hell," he said quietly and shook me loose. He lifted his glass,\r\ndrained the last few drops. He held the empty glass to the light, then\r\nset it down, regretfully. "But first buy me a drink."\r\n\r\n"You\'d better go home," I said. "You\'ve had enough."\r\n\r\nHe laughed harshly. "Look who\'s giving me orders. I know things about\r\nthis cock-eyed old world you never had nightmares about, and you\'re\r\nordering me around! Bossy newspapermen! Go to hell, then; I\'ll get my\r\nown drink."\r\n\r\nHe rose unsteadily and managed his way to the bar. He came back with\r\nthe glass full.\r\n\r\n"You still here. I thought I told you--"\r\n\r\n"You\'d better lay off that stuff," I said quietly. "You\'re not used to\r\nit."\r\n\r\n"Boy, oh boy, you\'re just full of orders today, aren\'t you? Charlie\r\nBennet, boy crusader! Well, I\'ve got something you can crusade about.\r\nAnything else you\'d like?"\r\n\r\n"That\'s enough for now."\r\n\r\n"You\'re damn right it is. Now get the hell out of here and leave me\r\nalone. Can\'t you see I\'m brooding over the fate of the world?"\r\n\r\n"What are you so mad about?"\r\n\r\nHe looked annoyed, and a little startled. "Brother, if you only knew--"\r\nHe raised his glass, and then stopped and set it on the table. "Wait a\r\nminute. 

Maybe I ought to tell you. Maybe I ought to let the two of us\r\nworry about it, instead of just me. Maybe you should print it in that\r\nnewspaper of yours."\r\n\r\n"I\'m willing to listen, anyway."\r\n\r\n"Sure! Why not? I\'m just beginning to experience that rosy sensation,\r\nthat warm feeling of camaraderie they keep stoppered up in bottles.\r\nIt\'s the only place on this planet you can find it."\r\n\r\n"Don\'t be cynical."\r\n\r\n"Maybe I should bust out laughing. The whole thing\'s really funny; it\'s\r\nthe funniest thing I\'ve ever heard."\r\n\r\n"We\'d better go."\r\n\r\n"Sure, let\'s go. But first--you want to see something really funny?\r\nHere."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe took a pair of glasses from his pocket and handed them to me. They\r\nseemed like ordinary shell-rimmed glasses, though the lenses were\r\ntinted a slight blue.\r\n\r\n"Put them on," he prompted. "Go ahead."\r\n\r\n"Where\'d you get these?"\r\n\r\n"Made \'em," he said. "My job is optical research, remember. I was\r\nfooling around in the lab with some invisible light experiments. The\r\nright combination of lenses and coatings--and whammo! This." 

He took\r\na drink. "I should have been a lawyer or a plumber or something." He\r\ngrunted. 

"Or even a newspaperman!"\r\n\r\n"What are they supposed to do--see in the dark?"\r\n\r\nHe laughed humorlessly. "That\'d be a boon for a reporter, wouldn\'t it?\r\nNo, my friend, much worse than that. Try them on. 

Go ahead."\r\n\r\nI did. "Well?

"\r\n\r\n"Notice anything peculiar?"\r\n\r\n"The coating makes everything here seem bluish--maybe even unearthly,\r\nif that\'s what you want--but--"\r\n\r\n"C\'mon outside, then," he said. This time he took my arm and steered me\r\nfrom the bar. I was glad of the opportunity to get him into the night\r\nair.\r\n\r\n"Look at the sky," he directed. "See anything unusual?" He stood\r\nwaiting, expectant.\r\n\r\n"I see stars," I said. "Nothing unusual about that, is there?"\r\n\r\n"Stars! Only stars?" His voice had lost its tinge of sarcasm. His\r\nfingers were tight on my arm. "Look, across the sky, see those luminous\r\nbands? All across the sky. Like a giant spider web."\r\n\r\nI looked again. After awhile, I said, "Sorry, Johnny, but there aren\'t\r\nany luminous bands, spider webs or otherwise. I think we\'d better get\r\nto the room. A good night\'s rest--"\r\n\r\n"Wait a minute," he cried suddenly, his face pale. "You think I\'m\r\ndrunk--or worse. I tell you there _is_ something up there. Shining\r\nstreamers crisscrossing the sky, like--like--"\r\n\r\n"There\'s nothing, Johnny. Only stars."\r\n\r\nI took the glasses off. He made a quick grab for them and somehow they\r\nfell to the pavement and shattered.\r\n\r\nFor a moment, Johnny stared at the glittering fragments, his jaws\r\nworking. "You\'ve broken them," he accused finally, his eyes filled more\r\nwith sudden despair than hatred. "It took weeks to build them."\r\n\r\n"It was an accident," I told him. "But it\'s just as well they are\r\nbroken. I tell you, Johnny, there\'s nothing unusual in the sky. Nothing\r\nat all. Spider webs! Next you\'ll be seeing pink elephants."\r\n\r\nJohnny stood in the cool night and stared at the sky. "They\'re up\r\nthere, I tell you. They\'re up there, and I want to know why. And\r\nthere\'s one thing I want to know more than anything else; suppose\r\nthey\'re really spider webs--" His face was deathly white. "Are there\r\nspiders?"\r\n\r\nHe stared at me insanely in the darkness. "Do you realize what that\r\nwould mean, Charlie? Giant spiders, invisible, roaming across the\r\nEarth!" His fingers were digging into my arm again.\r\n\r\n"Johnny, come out of it," I snapped, shaking him. "There is no web in\r\nthe sky, you hear me? And there aren\'t any spiders, either. It\'s just\r\nsome crazy figment of your imagination. 

That\'s all."\r\n\r\n"But just suppose there are," he persisted, a little wildly.\r\n"Maybe--maybe it\'s not just the glasses. Maybe it\'s partly me, too;\r\nmaybe I\'m the only one who can see them; maybe that\'s why you didn\'t\r\nsee the web. Maybe--"\r\n\r\n"Johnny, be sensible! If there were such monsters roaming around, don\'t\r\nyou think they\'d have been discovered by now?"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know," he said, helplessly. "I don\'t know, and it\'s driving\r\nme crazy. You\'ve probably wondered why I haven\'t slept very well for\r\nthe past couple of weeks; well, that\'s the reason. I didn\'t want to say\r\nanything. I hardly dared put the glasses on, I was so afraid. Not of\r\nbeing thought crazy, but--but afraid of what _they_ might do if they\r\nknew they were discovered."\r\n\r\n"Look, Johnny. Even supposing you might be right, why wouldn\'t they\r\nshow themselves? Why just stay up in the sky in a large web?"\r\n\r\n"Maybe they\'re sizing us up," Johnny said, trembling but not with cold.\r\n"After all, we\'ve got a few weapons, too. Maybe a machine gun or an\r\natomic bomb can hurt them, as well as humans."\r\n\r\n"Unless they\'re here for some good?" I suggested.\r\n\r\nJohnny laughed. "Spiders? Maybe they\'re hungry--and they think we\'re a\r\nbunch of flies down here. That\'s more likely.

"\r\n\r\n"Isn\'t this--rather fantastic?"\r\n\r\n"Of course it is. Why do you suppose I\'ve been keeping quiet about\r\nit for the past two weeks? Why do you suppose I\'m out trying to get\r\ndrunk?" He added disgustedly: "I can\'t even do that."\r\n\r\n"C\'mon," I said, "let\'s go to the room and we\'ll have some coffee. We\r\ncan talk about it there."\r\n\r\n"Sure," he said, and his voice was suddenly subdued. 

"Sure, why not?"\r\n\r\nWe went to the hotel room and I made some coffee, being careful to\r\nslip enough sleeping tablets in Johnny\'s cup. In a few minutes he was\r\nsprawled across the bed.\r\n\r\nI went to the window and looked at the glowing beads of traffic below.\r\nI looked at the sky--at the stars. Spiders in the sky; what a story\r\nthat would make. The editor\'d slap me in the booby hatch if I ever\r\nhanded in a who-what-when-where like that.\r\n\r\nWhen I left for work the next morning, Johnny was still snoozing. Let\r\nhim sleep it off. Do him good. He\'d been working too hard at the lab,\r\nanyhow.\r\n\r\nI couldn\'t get back to the hotel room that morning, though I wanted to\r\nsee if Johnny was okay. I was pretty busy writing a human interest yarn\r\nkidding the pants off some astronomer\'s notion that light waves coming\r\nfrom certain portions of the sky were being deflected or refracted\r\nslightly for no discernible reason.\r\n\r\nThe amount of difference was microscopic, and I wrote it up to\r\nemphasize its ridiculous splitting of hairs and the fact that you can\'t\r\ntake some of these crackpots seriously. Here the world is on the verge\r\nof coming apart at the seams, and they worry about wayward light rays.\r\n\r\nDuring the afternoon, I managed to drop into the hotel to see if Johnny\r\nhad slept off the liquor and the sleeping tablets. He had, and he was\r\nsitting on the edge of the bed, looking grim--and a little perplexed.\r\n\r\n"How ya feeling, Johnny?" I said.\r\n\r\n"Great," he said, though he didn\'t sound it. "Things seem a lot clearer\r\nthis morning."\r\n\r\n"Good. I thought they would. You know, you really had me going last\r\nnight. I thought you meant all that stuff, but I guess imagination and\r\na few beers can do a lot."\r\n\r\n"Cut the kidding," he said grimly.\r\n\r\n"What?"\r\n\r\n"I said, cut it. I\'m not in the mood."\r\n\r\n"Now what\'s the matter?

"\r\n\r\n"This," he said. He held up a pair of glasses, twins to those destroyed.\r\n\r\n"But--how could you have made another set? You haven\'t been near the\r\nlab today."\r\n\r\n"When I first discovered this web business, I made two pair of glasses.\r\nI figured two people could do something about it a whole lot easier\r\nthan just one. But I was afraid to let anyone in on it. I thought maybe\r\nI _was_ batty."\r\n\r\n"So?"\r\n\r\n"I made this pair for you. For you, Charlie, so you could write the\r\nstuff up in your paper to let people know. That\'s a laugh, isn\'t it?"\r\n\r\n"Say--that\'s swell. 

But--"\r\n\r\n"Stand back!" Johnny cried suddenly, as I started to move toward him.\r\nHe snatched a gun from beneath a pillow and waved it threateningly.\r\n"Know what I was doing this afternoon before you came in?"\r\n\r\n"Johnny, this is crazy! Put down that gun and listen to reason."\r\n\r\n"I had the glasses on," he continued, "and I was looking out the window\r\nhere. I\'m getting real brave--even in broad daylight--but there comes\r\na time when you just don\'t care. I saw _spiders_ in the streets. Huge\r\nspiders walking along the streets, mingling with human beings. And\r\nget this, Charlie--when I took the glasses off, they were like human\r\nbeings. Like humans, you understand. 

You know what that means? They\'re\r\nin disguise all around us!"\r\n\r\n"That\'s not true, Johnny," I insisted. "There are no webs in the sky.\r\nThere are _no_ spiders. It\'s your imagination. 

The strain. Working in\r\nthe lab--"\r\n\r\n"No," he cried, and the gun never wavered. "You know what else I saw? 

A\r\nfew minutes ago. I was looking down into the street, and a spider got\r\nout of a car just in front of the hotel here and started coming in. I\r\ntook off the glasses to see if it might be someone I knew.

"\r\n\r\nHe began to laugh hysterically. "You know who it was, Charlie--"\r\n\r\nI leaped forward, trying to knock the gun down. But Johnny\'s hand came\r\nup, and the gun jumped, spurting noise and flame. The bullet slammed\r\ninto my body.\r\n\r\nDesperately, I drove forward. My arms went around him. The gun went\r\noff again, before I could prevent it. A furrow of pain shot across my\r\nstomach, and I shrieked out in sudden anguish.\r\n\r\n"Johnny, Johnny. Stop it. Stop!"\r\n\r\nI struck his hand. The gun clattered to the floor. He was struggling\r\nfrantically, striking out against me with doubled fists. His shirt was\r\nsplattered with my blood. He gasped, clearing his lungs for a scream.\r\n\r\nThere was nothing else I could do. The life was draining from me.\r\n\r\nI held his arms and legs together and tried not to look into the\r\nterrified expression crossing his face. I held him tightly while he\r\nsquirmed in helpless frustration.\r\n\r\nAnd with my two remaining arms I strangled him!\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nIt\'s had it. Finished. 

Done. My wonderful red Thunderflash, I thought\r\nto myself, isn\'t worth the electricity to atomize it to Kingdom Come.\r\n\r\nEver since that drunk in his two-seat Charioteer plowed into the rear\r\nend with such force that even my radar repellant couldn\'t stop it,\r\nmy Thunderflash had been out of kilter. The specialists my garage\r\nrecommended worked over it for two days, but couldn\'t get it to\r\nrunning the way it did new.\r\n\r\nAnd what was I supposed to do for an automobile now? I had signed the\r\ncustomary 40-year pact for half my salary to pay for it. That meant I\r\nwould still be shelling out by 2117.\r\n\r\nWeeping over it wasn\'t going to do any good. It was stuck on the fifth\r\nlevel expressway and that was that. I levered myself out (at least\r\nthe ejector still worked) then got behind the car and gave it a good\r\nold-fashioned push to get it on an off-ramp, out of the stream of\r\ntraffic.\r\n\r\nAfter I parked I remembered I was heading for a date with Jenny. I\r\nchecked my wallet. No, not enough for a taxi there. I would just have\r\nto phone her to cancel the date.\r\n\r\nReluctantly I pushed the tip of my tongue against my tooth telephone.\r\n\r\n"Operator," said the operator.\r\n\r\n"Poplar 3104, please."\r\n\r\n"Thank you. 

One moment. 

I\'ll ache it for you."\r\n\r\nShe dialed the number of the tooth telephone in Jenny\'s mouth, so the\r\ntwo fine wires sent gentle electric currents into the nerve. On the\r\nthird ache Jenny clicked the receiver open with the tip of her tongue.\r\n\r\n"Hello?"\r\n\r\n"Jenny, this is Arnold. I won\'t be able to come over this evening."\r\n\r\n"But we had a date," Jenny said in a petulant voice.\r\n\r\n"I know, but my car broke down."\r\n\r\n"Again?"\r\n\r\n"Yes, honey."\r\n\r\n"Why don\'t you do something about it?" Jenny complained.\r\n\r\n"But baby, what can I do? I\'ve been to the garage. 

I\'ve been to the\r\nspecialists. I\'m so broke on account of these repair bills I\'ve been\r\nliving on macaroni concentrate for the last couple of weeks."\r\n\r\nJenny, my beautiful sweetheart, was distinctly unhappy. "Don\'t come to\r\nme with your troubles," she replied. "In fact, you don\'t have to come\r\nto me at all until you can come like a gentleman."\r\n\r\n"Aw, listen just a minute, Jenny," I started to plead. But it was too\r\nlate. Jenny had clicked off.\r\n\r\nA fine thermokettle of fish! A month ago I had a shiny lifetime car and\r\nwas romancing the best looking girl in town. Then one drunk comes along\r\nand my car is next to useless and my girl is mad at me.\r\n\r\nFeeling in a distinctly blue mood I moved my tongue to the other side\r\nof my mouth and shoved on my tooth radio. I rolled the tongue over the\r\nbottom of the tooth until I got a program with some blues music. Just\r\nthe way I felt. The blues. I sat in the front seat of my Thunderflash\r\nand listened to the music echoing against my tonsils.\r\n\r\nAfter the song came the inevitable commercial. Only this was a new one.\r\nThe announcer said:\r\n\r\n"Here\'s some big, big, big news from Grinning Gregory, your largest\r\nvolume dealer in lifetime cars. Gregory announced today that his used\r\npeople lots are nearly empty. Yes, Grinning Gregory\'s used people lots\r\nare nearly empty. And that means good, good, good news for you car\r\nowners with lifetime contracts who would like new cars.\r\n\r\n"Grinning Gregory has added to his stocks of new Orions,\r\nThunderflashes, Galaxies, Solars, Charioteers, Protons and Fords. For\r\nthe first time in two years, yes, the first time in two years, he has\r\nmore new cars than new people to sell them to.\r\n\r\n"So he is offering a limited number of them to used people, you folks\r\nwho have had cars, on his conveniently located used people lots. Come\r\non down and let some of Grinning Gregory\'s new cars look you over.\r\nBe sure and bring photostats of your credit ratings and official car\r\nhistories. Hurry, hurry, hurry and avoid the rush to Grinning Gregory\'s\r\nused people lots."\r\n\r\nThe commercial ended and was replaced by music.\r\n\r\nGosh, that was exciting news. Ever since the accident I had given up\r\nhope of ever owning a decent running car again, automobile prices and\r\ngovernment restrictions being what they were.\r\n\r\nI clicked on my tooth telephone and ached my garage mechanic to come\r\nby and pick up my car. Then I took my credit rating and official car\r\nhistory from the glove compartment and caught a helibus to the nearest\r\nof Grinning Gregory\'s used people lots.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nA lot of guys were already there before me, most of them in the same\r\nfix I was. They had been in accidents or they were divorced and their\r\nwives got custody of the car, although they still had to pay for it.\r\n\r\nSome of them had been on the lot for some time and looked a little\r\nshopworn under the lights and fluttering pennants, but they hadn\'t\r\nfound a car yet that would take them. We were all classified as used\r\npeople, a lot less desirable than people who hadn\'t signed for cars yet.\r\n\r\nOne of Grinning Gregory\'s contract brokers lined us up in a row facing\r\nthe path the cars would come by robot direction. The fellow to my right\r\nslicked his hair down neatly and began shining his shoe-tops on the\r\nbacks of his trouser legs.\r\n\r\n"Sure hope I get selected," he whispered nervously to me. "Boy, don\'t\r\nyou sometimes wish you were living a couple of hundred years ago when\r\ncars were cheap enough so that people were doing the picking?

"\r\n\r\n"Not me," I told him. "Drive that junk? I\'ll admit you didn\'t have to\r\nswear but a couple of years of your life away. But look at all you get\r\nnow in a car.

"\r\n\r\n"Mmm, I suppose you\'re right," he said. "My Orion was stolen a year ago\r\nwhen I accidentally cut off the burglar photocell. The police never did\r\nfind it and I\'ve been trying ever since to get another one.

"\r\n\r\n"This is the first time I\'ve tried," I said. "My car...."\r\n\r\n"Ssh," he interrupted. "Here they come."\r\n\r\nA procession of new cars, led by a beautiful green Solar convertible,\r\ninched its way along the row of hopeful buyers, all of us with our\r\ncredit ratings and car histories pinned to our lapels.\r\n\r\nEach car\'s robot mechanism recorded our statistics, took our pictures,\r\nnoted our heights, weights and appearances, then began to correlate the\r\ndata.\r\n\r\nBy government order the robot mechanism was directed to select its\r\nmost promising future owner. A sobersides bank president, for example,\r\nmight dearly love to change his big black Galaxy sedan for a low-slung\r\nCharioteer sports car, but sports cars were planned with crew-cutted\r\ncollege boys in mind, so the bank president would be likely to end up\r\nwith another big Galaxy. Of course, the payment rate was fixed and the\r\ncontracts were almost always for 40 years. A tie salesman might want a\r\nGalaxy to make an impression on his neighbors, but he\'d probably wind\r\nup with a Proton or a Thunderflash like I had. I was a tie salesman.\r\n\r\nThe Solar came abreast of me. I stood straight and smiling as it began\r\nto note my statistics. It flashed a 23 when it was done.\r\n\r\nNot so good. That put me in the 23 percentile rank of its desirability.\r\nThe next car, a rhinestone Ford, gave me a 28. I was rated 22, 31, 14\r\n(by a Galaxy), 27, 35 and 30 by the next six cars. That was the way it\r\nwent for the whole procession. I received the highest rating, 58, from\r\nan experimental model Proton that was no longer in production, but I\r\nknew it was rating everybody higher and I was pretty gloomy.\r\n\r\nImagine my surprise when my name was called out as one of the possible\r\nchoices. I went into the broker\'s office and was told the Proton would\r\nselect me if I would get rid of all but ten years of my Thunderflash\r\ncontract. That meant I had to find someone to take my car and 27 years\r\nof my contract, since I had been paying for three years of the 40. The\r\nprice of the Proton, the broker told me, was scaled down to a 30-year\r\ncontract because it was an off-model.\r\n\r\nBut who would take my heap with a 27-year contract attached to it? The\r\nbroker said Grinning Gregory might go for five years, just out of the\r\ngoodness of his big, big, big heart. I wouldn\'t get that kind of a deal\r\nanywhere else, the broker said.\r\n\r\nMaybe I wouldn\'t, but that didn\'t do me much good. I needed someone to\r\ntake 27 years.\r\n\r\nHarry! Why didn\'t I think of Harry before? He didn\'t have a car yet.\r\nSkinflint Harry didn\'t want to sign the standard 40-year contract for a\r\ncar and he had been shopping around for second-hand cars. Besides, good\r\nold Harry knew how crazy I was about Jenny. He had even taken her out a\r\ncouple of times.\r\n\r\nI gave Harry an ache on the telephone and told him I\'d be right over.\r\nThen I ached the garage and the mechanic told me he could get my\r\nThunderflash in pretty good running condition again, even though he\r\ncouldn\'t promise anything permanent. I caught a helibus to my friend\'s\r\napartment.\r\n\r\n"Harry, old pal, I\'ve got the chance of a lifetime for both of us."\r\n\r\nHarry eyed me suspiciously. "How\'s that?" 

he asked.\r\n\r\n"Well, here\'s the deal. You know my real fine Thunderflash? You said\r\nit was a sharp car. It is. It\'s a first class car. But ever since that\r\nslight accident, I\'ve had just a wee bit of trouble with it. Not much,\r\nyou understand, but it\'s niggling enough to annoy my girl, Jenny. You\r\nremember Jenny, the girl you used to go with before I cut you out? Ha!\r\nHa! Anyhow, Jenny wants me to get another car. A newer one.

"\r\n\r\n"But how can you?" Harry asked. "You already have one."\r\n\r\n"That\'s just it, old buddy," I replied. "Grinning Gregory has one of\r\nthose experimental model Protons. It\'s a beauty, shimmering orange with\r\npurple wheels and bearskin upholstery. 

You\'d love it. They\'ll let me\r\nhave it on a 30-year contract if I can sell 27 years of my Thunderflash\r\ncontract. So here\'s what I\'m going to do for you, pal. I\'ll keep ten\r\nyears of the contract and let you have the Thunderflash for the rest.\r\nYou\'ll be getting a three-year-old car with 13 years of the contract\r\ntaken care of. Now is that a deal or is that a deal!"\r\n\r\nHarry wasn\'t convinced. "What\'s wrong with your car?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, hardly anything."\r\n\r\n"What\'s hardly anything?"\r\n\r\n"Not even worth mentioning."\r\n\r\n"What\'s not worth mentioning?"\r\n\r\n"To tell the truth, the frame is just the least trifle out of line and\r\nevery once in a great while it makes the rear wheel twist sideways."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know," said Harry.\r\n\r\n"Good old cautious, hard-headed Harry," I told him. "You are getting\r\nthe deal of a lifetime and doing a good, loyal friend a big favor\r\nbesides."\r\n\r\n"I still don\'t know, Arnold," said Harry.\r\n\r\n"All right. When will you know?"\r\n\r\n"Let me sleep on it tonight."\r\n\r\n"OK, Harry."\r\n\r\nI went home in high spirits. I knew Harry would come through for me and\r\ntake that wreck off my hands. He always was a man with an eye out for a\r\ndeal.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI slept late the next morning, but by afternoon I was over to the used\r\npeople lot to tell them to hold the Proton for me for another day.\r\nInstead, they tapped me over the head with the news that someone came\r\nin that morning and bought it. And they didn\'t have another one like it\r\nthat would accept me.\r\n\r\nAnother hope gone astray! I caught a helibus to the garage and picked\r\nup my Thunderflash after paying a whopping repair bill. I drove to\r\nJenny\'s house to convince her it was just as good as new.\r\n\r\nJenny\'s mother met me at the door.\r\n\r\n"Hello, Arnold," she said with the big smile of greeting she always\r\ngave me. "I\'m glad to see you and I hope you\'ll keep dropping over to\r\nsee me, but Jenny isn\'t here any more."\r\n\r\n"Not here?"\r\n\r\n"I\'m afraid not."\r\n\r\n"Where is she?"\r\n\r\n"She eloped less than an hour ago. You remember the boy she used to\r\ngo with, Harry? 

He came by in a beautiful new car. It was shimmering\r\norange with purple wheels and bearskin upholstery and...."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


Manners."\r\n\r\n"Now it\'s perfectly natural, darling, that the boy should notice and be\r\nexcited. Yes, Son, the Martian\'s not so very different from us."\r\n\r\n"Oh, certainly," the Professor\'s Wife said with a trace of bitterness.\r\n"I don\'t imagine his turquoise complexion will cause any comment at all\r\nwhen you bring him to a faculty reception. They\'ll just figure he\'s had\r\na hard night--and that he got that baby-elephant nose sniffing around\r\nfor assistant professorships."\r\n\r\n"Really, darling! He probably thinks of our noses as disagreeably\r\namputated and paralyzed."\r\n\r\n"Well, anyway, Pop, he\'s in the bathroom. I followed him when he\r\nsquiggled upstairs."\r\n\r\n"Now, Son, you shouldn\'t have done that. He\'s on a strange planet and it\r\nmight make him nervous if he thought he was being spied on. We must show\r\nhim every courtesy. 

By George, I can\'t wait to discuss these things with\r\nAckerly-Ramsbottom! When I think of how much more this encounter has to\r\ngive the anthropologist than even the physicist or astronomer ..."\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\nHe was still going strong on his second rhapsody when he was interrupted\r\nby another high-speed entrance. It was the Professor\'s Coltish Daughter.\r\n\r\n"Mom, Pop, the Martian\'s--"\r\n\r\n"Hush, dear. We know."\r\n\r\nThe Professor\'s Coltish Daughter regained her adolescent poise, which\r\nwas considerable. "Well, he\'s still in there," she said. "I just tried\r\nthe door and it was locked."\r\n\r\n"I\'m glad it was!" the Professor said while his wife added, "Yes, you\r\ncan\'t be sure what--" and caught herself. "Really, dear, that was very\r\nbad manners."\r\n\r\n"I thought he\'d come downstairs long ago," her daughter explained. "He\'s\r\nbeen in there an awfully long time. It must have been a half hour ago\r\nthat I saw him gyre and gimbal upstairs in that real gone way he has,\r\nwith Nosy here following him." The Professor\'s Coltish Daughter was\r\ncurrently soaking up both jive and _Alice_.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWhen the Professor checked his wristwatch, his expression grew troubled.\r\n"By George, he is taking his time! Though, of course, we don\'t know how\r\nmuch time Martians ... I wonder."\r\n\r\n"I listened for a while, Pop," his son volunteered. 

"He was running the\r\nwater a lot."\r\n\r\n"Running the water, eh? We know Mars is a water-starved planet. I\r\nsuppose that in the presence of unlimited water, he might be seized by a\r\nkind of madness and ... But he seemed so well adjusted."\r\n\r\nThen his wife spoke, voicing all their thoughts. Her outlook on life\r\ngave her a naturally sepulchral voice.\r\n\r\n"_What\'s he doing in there?_"\r\n\r\nTwenty minutes and at least as many fantastic suggestions later, the\r\nProfessor glanced again at his watch and nerved himself for action.\r\nMotioning his family aside, he mounted the stairs and tiptoed down the\r\nhall.\r\n\r\nHe paused only once to shake his head and mutter under his breath, "By\r\nGeorge, I wish I had Fenchurch or von Gottschalk here. They\'re a shade\r\nbetter than I am on intercultural contracts, especially taboo-breakings\r\nand affronts ..."\r\n\r\nHis family followed him at a short distance.\r\n\r\nThe Professor stopped in front of the bathroom door. Everything was\r\nquiet as death.\r\n\r\nHe listened for a minute and then rapped measuredly, steadying his hand\r\nby clutching its wrist with the other. There was a faint splashing, but\r\nno other sound.\r\n\r\nAnother minute passed. The Professor rapped again. Now there was no\r\nresponse at all. He very gingerly tried the knob. The door was still\r\nlocked.\r\n\r\nWhen they had retreated to the stairs, it was the Professor\'s Wife who\r\nonce more voiced their thoughts. This time her voice carried overtones\r\nof supernatural horror.\r\n\r\n"_What\'s he doing in there?_"\r\n\r\n"He may be dead or dying," the Professor\'s Coltish Daughter suggested\r\nbriskly. "Maybe we ought to call the Fire Department, like they did for\r\nold Mrs. Frisbee."\r\n\r\nThe Professor winced. "I\'m afraid you haven\'t visualized the\r\ncomplications, dear," he said gently. "No one but ourselves knows that\r\nthe Martian is on Earth, or has even the slightest inkling that\r\ninterplanetary travel has been achieved. Whatever we do, it will have to\r\nbe on our own. 

But to break in on a creature engaged in--well, we don\'t\r\nknow what primal private activity--is against all anthropological\r\npractice. Still--"\r\n\r\n"Dying\'s a primal activity," his daughter said crisply.\r\n\r\n"So\'s ritual bathing before mass murder," his wife added.\r\n\r\n"Please! Still, as I was about to say, we do have the moral duty to\r\nsuccor him if, as you all too reasonably suggest, he has been\r\nincapacitated by a germ or virus or, more likely, by some simple\r\nenvironmental factor such as Earth\'s greater gravity."\r\n\r\n"Tell you what, Pop--I can look in the bathroom window and see what he\'s\r\ndoing. 

All I have to do is crawl out my bedroom window and along the\r\ngutter a little ways. 

It\'s safe as houses."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe Professor\'s question beginning with, "Son, how do you know--" died\r\nunuttered and he refused to notice the words his daughter was voicing\r\nsilently at her brother. He glanced at his wife\'s sardonically composed\r\nface, thought once more of the Fire Department and of other and larger\r\nand even more jealous--or would it be skeptical?--government agencies,\r\nand clutched at the straw offered him.\r\n\r\nTen minutes later, he was quite unnecessarily assisting his son back\r\nthrough the bedroom window.\r\n\r\n"Gee, Pop, I couldn\'t see a sign of him. That\'s why I took so long. 

Hey,\r\nPop, don\'t look so scared. He\'s in there, sure enough. It\'s just that\r\nthe bathtub\'s under the window and you have to get real close up to see\r\ninto it."\r\n\r\n"The Martian\'s taking a bath?"\r\n\r\n"Yep. Got it full up and just the end of his little old schnozzle\r\nsticking out. Your suit, Pop, was hanging on the door."\r\n\r\nThe one word the Professor\'s Wife spoke was like a death knell.\r\n\r\n"_Drowned!_"\r\n\r\n"No, Ma, I don\'t think so. His schnozzle was opening and closing regular\r\nlike."\r\n\r\n"Maybe he\'s a shape-changer," the Professor\'s Coltish Daughter said in a\r\nburst of evil fantasy. "Maybe he softens in water and thins out after a\r\nwhile until he\'s like an eel and then he\'ll go exploring through the\r\nsewer pipes. Wouldn\'t it be funny if he went under the street and\r\nknocked on the stopper from underneath and crawled into the bathtub with\r\nPresident Rexford, or Mrs. President Rexford, or maybe right into the\r\nmiddle of one of Janey Rexford\'s Oh-I\'m-so-sexy bubble baths?"\r\n\r\n"Please!" The Professor put his hand to his eyebrows and kept it there,\r\ncuddling the elbow in his other hand.\r\n\r\n"Well, have you thought of something?" the Professor\'s Wife asked him\r\nafter a bit. "What are you going to do?"\r\n\r\nThe Professor dropped his hand and blinked his eyes hard and took a deep\r\nbreath.\r\n\r\n"Telegraph Fenchurch and Ackerly-Ramsbottom and then break in," he said\r\nin a resigned voice, into which, nevertheless, a note of hope seemed\r\nalso to have come. "First, however, I\'m going to wait until morning."\r\n\r\nAnd he sat down cross-legged in the hall a few yards from the bathroom\r\ndoor and folded his arms.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nSo the long vigil commenced.\r\n\r\nThe Professor\'s family shared it and he offered no objection. Other and\r\nsterner men, he told himself, might claim to be able successfully to\r\norder their children to go to bed when there was a Martian locked in the\r\nbathroom, but he would like to see them faced with the situation.\r\n\r\nFinally dawn began to seep from the bedrooms. When the bulb in the hall\r\nhad grown quite dim, the Professor unfolded his arms.\r\n\r\nJust then, there was a loud splashing in the bathroom. The Professor\'s\r\nfamily looked toward the door. The splashing stopped and they heard the\r\nMartian moving around. Then the door opened and the Martian appeared in\r\nthe Professor\'s gray pin-stripe suit. His mouth curled sharply downward\r\nin a broad alien smile as he saw the Professor.\r\n\r\n"Good morning!" the Martian said happily. "I never slept better in my\r\nlife, even in my own little wet bed back on Mars."\r\n\r\nHe looked around more closely and his mouth straightened. "But where did\r\nyou all sleep?" he asked. "Don\'t tell me you stayed dry all night! You\r\n_didn\'t_ give up your only bed to me?"\r\n\r\nHis mouth curled upward in misery. "Oh, dear," he said, "I\'m afraid I\'ve\r\nmade a mistake somehow. 

Yet I don\'t understand how. Before I studied\r\nyou, I didn\'t know what your sleeping habits would be, but that question\r\nwas answered for me--in fact, it looked so reassuringly homelike--when I\r\nsaw those brief TV scenes of your females ready for sleep in their\r\nlittle tubs. Of course, on Mars, only the fortunate can always be sure\r\nof sleeping wet, but here, with your abundance of water, I thought there\r\nwould be wet beds for all."\r\n\r\nHe paused. "It\'s true I had some doubts last night, wondering if I\'d\r\nused the right words and all, but then when you rapped \'Good night\' to\r\nme, I splashed the sentiment back at you and went to sleep in a wink.\r\nBut I\'m afraid that somewhere I\'ve blundered and--"\r\n\r\n"No, no, dear chap," the Professor managed to say. He had been waving\r\nhis hand in a gentle circle for some time in token that he wanted to\r\ninterrupt. 

"Everything is quite all right. 

It\'s true we stayed up all\r\nnight, but please consider that as a watch--an honor guard, by\r\nGeorge!--which we kept to indicate our esteem."\r\n\r\n                                                        --FRITZ LEIBER\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Galaxy Science Fiction_ December 1957.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and\r\n    typographical errors have been corrected without note.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEnd of Project Gutenberg\'s What\'s He Doing in There?, by Fritz Reuter Leiber\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


It was all like a\r\nmasquerade, with odd costumes and funny masks.\r\n\r\nI know that the masks are their faces, but I argue with them and find I\r\nthink as if I am arguing with humans behind the masks. They are people.\r\nI recognize people and whether I am going to like this person or that\r\nperson by something in the way they move and how they get excited when\r\nthey talk; and I know that I like these people in a motherly sort of\r\nway. You have to feel motherly toward them, I guess.\r\n\r\nThey all remind me of Ronny, a medical student I knew once. He was small\r\nand round and eager. 

You had to like him, but you couldn\'t take him very\r\nseriously. He was a pacifist; he wrote poetry and pulled it out to read\r\naloud at ill-timed moments; and he stuttered when he talked too fast.\r\n\r\nThey are like that, all fright and gentleness.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI am not the only survivor--they have explained that--but I am the first\r\nthey found, and the least damaged, the one they have chosen to represent\r\nthe human race to them. They stand around my bed and answer questions,\r\nand are nice to me when I argue with them.\r\n\r\nAll in a group they look half-way between a delegation of nations and an\r\nark, one of each, big and small, thick and thin, four arms or wings, all\r\nshapes and colors in fur and skin and feathers.\r\n\r\nI can picture them in their UN of the Universe, making speeches in their\r\ndifferent languages, listening patiently without understanding each\r\nother\'s different problems, boring each other and being too polite to\r\nyawn.\r\n\r\nThey are polite, so polite I almost feel they are afraid of me, and I\r\nwant to reassure them.\r\n\r\nBut I talk as if I were angry. I can\'t help it, because if things had\r\nonly been a little different ... "Why couldn\'t you have come sooner? 

Why\r\ncouldn\'t you have tried to stop it before it happened, or at least come\r\nsooner, afterward...?"\r\n\r\nIf they had come sooner to where the workers of the Nevada power pile\r\nstarved slowly behind their protecting walls of lead--if they had looked\r\nsooner for survivors of the dust with which the nations of the world had\r\nslain each other--George Craig would be alive. He died before they came.\r\nHe was my co-worker, and I loved him.\r\n\r\nWe had gone down together, passing door by door the automatic safeguards\r\nof the plant, which were supposed to protect the people on the outside\r\nfrom the radioactive danger from the inside--but the danger of a failure\r\nof politics was far more real than the danger of failure in the science\r\nof the power pile, and that had not been calculated by the builders. We\r\nwere far underground when the first radioactivity in the air outside had\r\nshut all the heavy, lead-shielded automatic doors between us and the\r\noutside.\r\n\r\nWe were safe. And we starved there.\r\n\r\n"Why didn\'t you come sooner?" I wonder if they know or guess how I feel.\r\nMy questions are not questions, but I have to ask them. He is dead. I\r\ndon\'t mean to reproach them--they look well meaning and kindly--but I\r\nfeel as if, somehow, knowing why it happened could make it stop, could\r\nlet me turn the clock back and make it happen differently. If I could\r\nhave signaled them, so they would have come just a little sooner.\r\n\r\nThey look at one another, turning their funny-face heads uneasily,\r\nmoving back and forth, but no one will answer.\r\n\r\nThe world is dead.... George is dead, that thin, pathetic creature with\r\nthe bones showing through his skin that he was when we sat still at the\r\nlast with our hands touching, thinking there were people outside who had\r\nforgotten us, hoping they would remember. We didn\'t guess that the world\r\nwas dead, blanketed in radiating dust outside. Politics had killed it.\r\n\r\nThese beings around me, they had been watching, seeing what was going to\r\nhappen to our world, listening to our radios from their small\r\nsettlements on the other planets of the Solar System. They had seen the\r\ndoom of war coming. They represented stellar civilizations of great\r\npower and technology, and with populations that would have made ours\r\nseem a small village; they were stronger than we were, and yet they had\r\ndone nothing.\r\n\r\n"Why didn\'t you stop us? You could have stopped us."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nA rabbity one who is closer than the others backs away, gesturing\r\npolitely that he is giving room for someone else to speak, but he looks\r\nguilty and will not look at me with his big round eyes. I still feel\r\nweak and dizzy. It is hard to think, but I feel as if they are hiding a\r\nsecret.\r\n\r\nA doelike one hesitates and comes closer to my bed. "We discussed it ...\r\nwe voted...." It talks through a microphone in its helmet with a soft\r\nlisping accent that I think comes from the shape of its mouth. It has a\r\nmuzzle and very soft, dainty, long nibbling lips like a deer that\r\nnibbles on twigs and buds.\r\n\r\n"We were afraid," adds one who looks like a bear.\r\n\r\n"To us the future was very terrible," says one who looks as if it\r\nmight have descended from some sort of large bird like a penguin. "So\r\nmuch-- Your weapons were very terrible."\r\n\r\nNow they all talk at once, crowding about my bed, apologizing. "So much\r\nkilling. 

It hurt to know about. But your people didn\'t seem to mind.

"\r\n\r\n"We were afraid."\r\n\r\n"And in your fiction," the doelike one lisped, "I saw plays from your\r\namusement machines which said that the discovery of beings in space\r\nwould save you from war, not because you would let us bring friendship\r\nand teach peace, but because the human race would unite in _hatred_ of\r\nthe outsiders. They would forget their hatred of each other only in a\r\nnew and more terrible war with us." Its voice breaks in a squeak and it\r\nturns its face away from me.\r\n\r\n"You were about to come out into space. We were wondering how to hide!"\r\nThat is a quick-talking one, as small as a child. He looks as if he\r\nmight have descended from a bat--gray silken fur on his pointed face,\r\nbig night-seeing eyes, and big sensitive ears, with a humped shape on\r\nthe back of his air suit which might be folded wings. "We were trying to\r\nconceal where we had built, so that humans would not guess we were near\r\nand look for us."\r\n\r\nThey are ashamed of their fear, for because of it they broke all the\r\nkindly laws of their civilizations, restrained all the pity and\r\ngentleness I see in them, and let us destroy ourselves.\r\n\r\nI am beginning to feel more awake and to see more clearly. And I am\r\nbeginning to feel sorry for them, for I can see why they are afraid.\r\n\r\nThey are herbivores. I remember the meaning of shapes. In the paths\r\nof evolution there are grass eaters and berry eaters and root diggers.\r\nEach has its functional shape of face and neck--and its wide,\r\nstartled-looking eyes to see and run away from the hunters. In all their\r\nracial history they have never killed to eat. They have been killed and\r\neaten, or run away, and they evolved to intelligence by selection. Those\r\nlived who succeeded in running away from carnivores like lions, hawks,\r\nand men.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI look up, and they turn their eyes and heads in quick embarrassed\r\nmotion, not meeting my eye. The rabbity one is nearest and I reach out\r\nto touch him, pleased because I am growing strong enough now to move my\r\narms. He looks at me and I ask the question: "Are there any\r\ncarnivores--flesh eaters--among you?"\r\n\r\nHe hesitates, moving his lips as if searching for tactful words. "We\r\nhave never found any that were civilized. We have frequently found them\r\nin caves and tents fighting each other. 

Sometimes we find them fighting\r\neach other with the ruins of cities around them, but they are always\r\nsavages."\r\n\r\nThe bearlike one said heavily, "It might be that carnivores evolve more\r\nrapidly and tend toward intelligence more often, for we find radioactive\r\nplanets without life, and places like the place you call your asteroid\r\nbelt, where a planet should be--but there are only scattered fragments\r\nof planet, pieces that look as if a planet had been blown apart. We\r\nthink that usually ..." He looked at me uncertainly, beginning to\r\nfumble his words. "We think ..."\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\n"Yours is the only carnivorous race we have found that was--civilized,\r\nthat had a science and was going to come out into space," the doelike\r\none interrupted softly. "We were afraid."\r\n\r\nThey seem to be apologizing.\r\n\r\nThe rabbity one, who seems to be chosen as the leader in speaking to me,\r\nsays, "We will give you anything you want. Anything we are able to give\r\nyou.

"\r\n\r\nThey mean it. We survivors will be privileged people, with a key to all\r\nthe cities, everything free. Their sincerity is wonderful, but puzzling.\r\nAre they trying to atone for the thing they feel was a crime; that they\r\nallowed humanity to murder itself, and lost to the Galaxy the richness\r\nof a race? Is this why they are so generous?\r\n\r\nPerhaps then they will help the race to get started again. The records\r\nare not lost. The few survivors can eventually repopulate Earth. Under\r\nthe tutelage of these peaceable races, without the stress of division\r\ninto nations, we will flower as a race. No children of mine to the\r\nfurthest descendant will ever make war again. This much of a lesson we\r\nhave learned.\r\n\r\nThese timid beings do not realize how much humanity has wanted peace.\r\nThey do not know how reluctantly we were forced and trapped by old\r\ninstitutions and warped tangles of politics to which we could see no\r\nanswer. We are not naturally savage. We are not savage when approached\r\nas individuals. Perhaps they know this, but are afraid anyhow,\r\ninstinctive fear rising up from the blood of their hunted, frightened\r\nforebears.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe human race will be a good partner to these races. Even recovering\r\nfrom starvation as I am, I can feel in myself an energy they do not\r\nhave. The savage in me and my race is a creative thing, for in those who\r\nhave been educated as I was it is a controlled savagery which attacks\r\nand destroys only problems and obstacles, never people. Any human raised\r\noutside of the political traditions that the race inherited from its\r\nbloodstained childhood would be as friendly and ready for friendship as\r\nI am toward these beings. I could never hurt these pleasant, overgrown\r\nbunnies and squirrels.\r\n\r\n"We will do everything we can to make up for ... we will try to help,"\r\nsays the bunny, stumbling over the English, but civilized and cordial\r\nand kind.\r\n\r\nI sit up suddenly, reaching out impulsively to shake his hand. Suddenly\r\nfrightened he leaps back. 

All of them step back, glancing behind them as\r\nthough making sure of the avenue of escape. Their big luminous eyes\r\nwiden and glance rapidly from me to the doors, frightened.\r\n\r\nThey must think I am about to leap out of bed and pounce on them and eat\r\nthem. I am about to laugh and reassure them, about to say that all I\r\nwant from them is friendship, when I feel a twinge in my abdomen from\r\nthe sudden motion. I touch it with one hand under the bedclothes.\r\n\r\nThere is the scar of an incision there, almost healed. 

An operation. The\r\nweakness I am recovering from is more than the weakness of starvation.\r\n\r\nFor only half a second I do not understand; then I see why they looked\r\nashamed.\r\n\r\nThey voted the murder of a race.\r\n\r\nAll the human survivors found have been made sterile. There will be no\r\nmore humans after we die.\r\n\r\nI am frozen, one hand still extended to grasp the hand of the rabbity\r\none, my eyes still searching his expression, reassuring words still half\r\nformed.\r\n\r\nThere will be time for anger or grief later, for now, in this instant, I\r\ncan understand. They are probably quite right.\r\n\r\nWe were carnivores.\r\n\r\nI know, because, at this moment of hatred, I could kill them all.\r\n\r\n                                                        --G. A. MORRIS\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Galaxy Science Fiction_ October 1953.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and\r\n    typographical errors have been corrected without note.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


We knew he\'d been close, but not _how_ close.\r\n\r\nMy nickname\'s Monk. I\'ve fought it, certainly, but what can you do\r\nwhen a well-wishing mother names you after a wealthy uncle and your\r\nbirth certificate says Neander Thalberg? As early as high school some\r\nbright pundit noted the name\'s similarity to that of a certain\r\nprehistoric man. Unfortunately the similarity is not in name alone:\r\nI\'m muscular, stooped, and, I must admit, not handsome hero model\r\nmaterial.\r\n\r\nWell, maybe the nickname\'s justified, but still, Al Benson didn\'t have\r\nto give the crowning insult. And yet, if he hadn\'t, there probably\r\nwouldn\'t be a torchship stern-ending on Mars just about now.\r\n\r\nC. 

I. (Central Intelligence, that is) at the Sands figured Benson\r\nwould head for New York. Which is why the boss sent me here. I\r\nregistered in a hotel in the 50\'s and, figuring that whatever Benson\r\nintended to do would have spectacular results, I kept the stereo on\r\nNews.\r\n\r\nBenson\'s wife hadn\'t yielded much info. Sure she described the clothes\r\nhe was wearing and said he\'d taken nothing else except an artist\'s\r\ncase. What was in that was anybody\'s guess; his private lab is such a\r\njumble nobody could tell what, if anything, was missing.\r\n\r\nC. I. knew his political feelings. Seems he\'d been talking wild about\r\nthe upcoming presidential election and had sworn he\'d nip the\r\ndraft-Cadigan movement in the bud. Cadigan\'s Mayor of New York City.\r\nHe\'s anti-space. In fact, Cadigan\'s anti just about everything in\r\nscience except intercontinental missiles. Strictly for defense, of\r\ncourse. Cadigan says.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nA weathercaster was making rash promises on the stereo when the potray\r\ndinged. The potray? I certainly wasn\'t expecting mail. Only C. I. knew\r\nwhere I was and they\'d have closed-circuited me on visio if they\r\nwanted contact.\r\n\r\nThe potray dinged and there was a package in it.\r\n\r\nNow matter transference I knew. It put mailmen out of business.\r\nThere\'s a potray in every domicile and you can put things in it, dial\r\nthe destination and they come out there. They come out the same size\r\nand weight and in the same condition as they went in, provided they\r\ndidn\'t go in alive. Life loses, as many a shade of a hopeful guinea\r\npig could relate.\r\n\r\nSo the potray dinged and here was this package. At first glance it\r\nlooked like one of those cereal samples manufacturers have been\r\neverlastingly sending through since postal rates dropped after cost of\r\nthe potrays had been amortized. But cereal samples don\'t come through\r\nat midday; they\'re night traffic stuff.\r\n\r\nThe package was light, its wrapping curiously smooth. There was an\r\nenvelope attached with my correct name and potray number. Whoever had\r\nmailed it must be in C. I. or must know someone in C. I. who knew\r\nwhere I was.\r\n\r\nThe postmark was blurred but I could make out that it had been cast\r\nfrom Grand Central. Time didn\'t matter. It couldn\'t have been cast\r\nmore than a microsecond earlier.\r\n\r\nThe envelope contained a card upon which was typed:\r\n\r\n"Caution! Site on cylinder of 2 ft. 

radius and 6 ft. 

height. Unwrap at\r\narmslength."\r\n\r\nNow what? A practical joke? If so, it must be Benson\'s work. He\'s\r\nplayed plenty, from pumping hydrogen sulphide (that\'s rotten egg gas,\r\nas you know) into the air-conditioning system at high school to\r\ncalling a gynecologist to the launching stage at the Sands to sever an\r\numbilical cord which he neglected to say was on a Viking rocket.\r\n\r\nI followed the instructions. As I bent back the first fold of the\r\nstrange wrapping it came alive, unfolding itself with incredible\r\nswiftness.\r\n\r\nSomething burst forth like a freed djinn--almost instantaneously\r\nlengthening, spreading--a thing with beetling brows, low, broad\r\nforehead, prognathous jaw, and a hunched, brutally muscular body, with\r\na great club over its swollen shoulder.\r\n\r\nI went precipitously backward over a coffee table.\r\n\r\nIt stabilized, a dead mockery, replica of a Neanderthal.\r\n\r\nA placard hung on its chest. I read this:\r\n\r\n"Even some of the early huntsmen weren\'t successful. Abandon the\r\nchase, Monk. 

I\'ve things to do and this--your blood brother, no\r\ndoubt--couldn\'t catch me any more than you can!"\r\n\r\nWhich positively infuriated me.\r\n\r\nDo you blame me?\r\n\r\nA few cussing, cussed minutes later I realized what Al Benson had\r\napparently done: solved the torchship\'s fuel problem.\r\n\r\nOh, I\'d seen Klein bottles and Mobius strips and other things that\r\ntwist in on themselves and into other dimensions, twisting into\r\nmicrocosms and macrocosms--into elsewhere, in any event. And here I\r\nhad visual evidence that Benson had had something nearly six feet tall\r\nand certainly two feet in breadth enclosed in a nearly weightless\r\ncarton less than eight inches on the side!\r\n\r\nSufficient fuel for a Marstrip? Just wrap it up!\r\n\r\nThe stereo\'s audio was saying: "... from the Museum of Natural\r\nHistory. Curators are compiling a list of the missing exhibits which\r\nwe will reveal to you on this channel as soon as it\'s available. Now\r\nwe switch to Dick Joy at City Hall with news of the latest exhibit\r\nfound. Come in, Dick!"\r\n\r\nOn the steps of City Hall was a full size replica of a mastodon over\r\nwhose massive back was draped a banner bearing the slogan: "The\r\nUniversal Party is for you! Don\'t return to prehistory with Cadigan!\r\nRe-elect President Ollie James and go to the stars!"\r\n\r\nAnd there was a closeup of Mayor Cadigan standing pompous and\r\nwrathful--and looking very diminutive--behind the emblem of his\r\nopposition party.\r\n\r\nDick Joy was saying, "Eyewitnesses claim that this replica--obviously\r\none of the items stolen from the Museum of Natural History--suddenly\r\nmaterialized here. Immediately prior to the alleged materialization a\r\nman--whose photograph we show now--ostensibly bent down to tie a\r\nshoelace, setting a shoebox beside him. He left the box, walking off\r\ninto the gathering crowd, and this mastodon _seemed_ to spring into\r\nbeing where the shoebox had been.\r\n\r\n"The mastodon replica has been examined. A report just handed me says\r\nit is definitely that from the Museum and that it could not\r\nconceivably have been contained in a shoebox. It\'s obviously a case of\r\nmass hypnotism. The replica must have been trucked here. There\'s no\r\nother possible explanation. 

Excuse me!"\r\n\r\nDick Joy turned away, then back.\r\n\r\n"I have just been handed a notice that Mayor Cadigan wishes to say a\r\nfew words and I hereby introduce him, His Honor the Mayor, Joseph F.\r\nCadigan!"\r\n\r\nHis balding, fragmentarily curly-haired Honor glared.\r\n\r\n"Friends," he said chokingly, "whatever madman is responsible for this\r\noutrageous act will not go unpunished. I call upon the City\'s Finest\r\nto track him down and bring him to justice.\r\n\r\n"I am for justice, for equality and peace. I--"\r\n\r\nHis Honor was apparently determined to use all the time he could.\r\nBeing a newscast, it was for free.\r\n\r\nI killed the stereo. And the visio rang. It was Phil Pollini, the C.\r\nI. Chief.\r\n\r\n"Monk," he said, "guess you\'ve seen the stereo. Al\'s out to fix the\r\nMayor\'s wagon."\r\n\r\n"Say that again," I said, having a brainstorm.\r\n\r\n"Now, look--" he started.\r\n\r\n"Maybe you\'ve got something there, Chief," I cut in. "Cadigan\'s got\r\nthe superduper of all wagons--a seven passenger luxury limousine with\r\nbulletproof glass, stereo, a bar, venetian blinds and heaven knows\r\nwhat else. Hot and cold running androids, maybe. 

He prowls the\r\nelevated highways with an \'In Conference\' sign flashing over the\r\nwindshield. So\'s he can\'t be wire-tapped or miked, I guess. It\'d be a\r\nnatch for Al Benson to go for."\r\n\r\nPollini grinned.\r\n\r\n"So if you were Benson what\'d you do to fix the Mayor\'s wagon?"\r\n\r\n"Hitch it to a star," I said, "and the closest spot to a star would be\r\nthe observation platform of the Greater Empire State."\r\n\r\n"You\'re probably right," the Chief said. "Get going!"\r\n\r\nI got.\r\n\r\nTen minutes later I walked out onto the observation platform on the\r\n150th floor of the Greater Empire State Building--and found an\r\nincredulous crowd gathered around the mayor\'s limousine. I felt good.\r\nI\'d predicted.\r\n\r\nI asked a guard, "How\'d it get here?"\r\n\r\nHis eyebrows were threatening a back somersault.\r\n\r\n"Don\'t know," he said. "I was looking over the side; then turned\r\naround and here it was! 

You have any ideas?"\r\n\r\nWhich is when I spotted Al Benson.\r\n\r\nI settled for shoving Benson toward the elevator, being careful since\r\nhe had a box under each arm. We made the elevator and went down and it\r\nstopped on the 120th floor and the operator said, "Change here for all\r\nlower floors and the street--"\r\n\r\nAs we waited on the 120th for the down elevator, the P. A. system\r\nbarked:\r\n\r\n"Attention all building occupants. By order of the Mayor no one will\r\nbe permitted to leave the building until further notice. Please remain\r\nwhere you are. 

We will try not to inconvenience you for any great\r\ntime."\r\n\r\nThere was no one close to us.\r\n\r\n"Al," I said, "look, stinker, you\'ve had your fun but this is it. I\r\ndon\'t know what you\'ve got in those boxes but you\'ve got to turn them\r\nover--and yourself--to the next copper who shows. This is a civil\r\nmatter, strictly local, and not C. I.

"\r\n\r\nBenson grinned. "Got to make a delivery first, Monk. Look, there\'s a\r\npotray over there. Can I use it?"\r\n\r\nHis grin was infectious. 

"So what are you going to send where?" I\r\nasked as sternly as I could.\r\n\r\n"The Mayor\'s personal files," he said. "I managed to carry them out of\r\nCity Hall--once they\'d been suitably wrapped, of course! I\'m sending\r\nthem to the Senate Investigation Committee. Don\'t worry, Monk, His\r\nHonor won\'t be President this or any year!"\r\n\r\nI helped him dial the SIC number.\r\n\r\n"What about the other package?" I asked him then.\r\n\r\n"Insurance," he said. "Come out on the setback."\r\n\r\nHe placed the last package on the mosaic tile of the terrace, untied\r\nits string, flipped open the edge of the Benson wrapping and jumped\r\nback.\r\n\r\nIt was an NYC police helicopter.\r\n\r\nWe potrayed it back from the Sands. Suitably wrapped, of course.\r\n\r\nThat was a month ago. Most of it never came out in the papers. Nothing\r\nof Benson\'s invention. C. I. thought it should be squelched, at least\r\nuntil Benson and the boys get back from Mars.\r\n\r\nWhich would be the end except for the packages. Yes, Benson left a\r\ngross of them with me and I\'ve been mailing them one a day to the\r\nleaders of the opposition party. I don\'t truly know what\'s in them, of\r\ncourse. But it\'s very curious that the day before the torchship left\r\nexactly one hundred and forty-four cylinders of hydrogen sulphide were\r\nmissing from quartermaster stores. Coincidentally one of my C. I.\r\nfriends tells me Benson had him rig up a gross of automatic releases\r\nfor gas cylinders.\r\n\r\nAdding it up, it could be a good lesson for politicians to keep their\r\nnoses out of science.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEnd of Project Gutenberg\'s Political Application, by John Victor Peterson\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


"What are you doing in here? You know it\'s\r\na Federal Offense for anybody to come into this room without I say so?"\r\n\r\n"Momma and Hilda come in all the time, and you don\'t say so." 

Oley stood\r\nfirm on what he figured were legal grounds. "What makes shorts?

"\r\n\r\nSven relented a little. This brother had been something of a surprise to\r\nhim, coming along when Sven was a full ten years old. But, he reflected,\r\nafter a few years maybe I should get used to the idea. Actually, he sort\r\nof liked the youngster.\r\n\r\n"Shorts," he said, speaking from the superior eminence of his fourteen\r\nyears to the four-year-old, "is when electricity finds a way to get back\r\nwhere it came from without doing a lot of hard work getting there. But\r\nyou see, electricity like to work; so, even when it has an easy way, it\r\njust works harder and uses itself up."\r\n\r\nThis confused explanation of shorts was, of course, taken verbatim,\r\ndespite the fact that Oley couldn\'t define half the words and probably\r\ncouldn\'t even pronounce them.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t like shorts. I don\'t like these pink shorts Momma put on me\r\nthis morning. Is they electrics, Sven?"\r\n\r\nSven glanced around at the accidentally-dyed-in-the-laundry, formerly\r\nwhite shorts.\r\n\r\n"Um-m-m. Yeah. You could call \'em electric."\r\n\r\nWith this Oley let out whoop and dashed out of the room, trailing a\r\nsmall voice behind him. "Momma, Momma. Sven says my shorts is electric!"\r\n\r\n"I\'ll short Sven\'s electrics for him, if he makes fun of your shorts!"\r\nOley heard his mother\'s comforting reply.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIn the adult world days passed before Oley\'s accidentally acquired\r\npattern of nubilous information on the subject of shorts was enlarged.\r\nIt was only days in the adult world, but in Oley\'s world each day was a\r\nmountainous fraction of an entire lifetime, into which came tumbling and\r\njumbling--or were pulled--bits, pieces, oddments, landslides and\r\nacquisitions of information on every subject that he ran into, or that\r\nran into him. Nobody had told Oley that acquiring information was his\r\njob at the moment; the acquisition was partly accidental, mostly\r\ninstinctive, and spurred by an intense curiosity and an even more\r\nintense determination to master the world as he saw it.\r\n\r\nThere was the taste of the sick green flowers that Momma kept in the\r\nwindow box and, just for a side course, a little bit of the dirt, too.\r\nThere were the patterns of the rain on the window, and the reactions of\r\na cat to having its tail pulled. The fact that you touch a stove one\r\ntime, and it\'s cool and comfortable to lay your head against, and\r\nanother time it hurts. 

Things like that. 

And other things--towering\r\nadults who sometimes swoop down on you and throw you high into the air;\r\nand most times walk over you, around you, and ignore you completely. The\r\njumble of assorted and unsorted information that is the heritage of\r\nevery growing young inquiring brain.\r\n\r\nIn terms of time, it was only a couple of weeks, if you were looking at\r\nit as an adult, until the next "shorts" incident.\r\n\r\nOley was sitting peacefully at the breakfast table, doing his level best\r\nto control the manipulation of the huge knife-fork-and-spoon,\r\nplate-bowl-and-glass, from which he was expected to eat a meal. Things\r\nsmelled good. 

Momma was cooking doste, and that to Oley smelled best of\r\nall. The doster ticked quietly to itself, then gave a loud pop, and up\r\ncame two golden-brown slices of doste. Dostes? Oley wasn\'t sure. But he\r\nhadn\'t really begun paying too much attention to whether one doste was\r\nthe same as two doste or what, though he could quite proudly tell you\r\nthe difference between one and two.\r\n\r\nOut it came, and fresh butter was spread on it, and in went two shiny\r\nwhite beds, for some more doste.\r\n\r\nLittle Oley watched in fascination. And now he reached for the\r\ntremendous glass sitting on the table in front of him. But his fingers\r\ndidn\'t quite make it. Somehow, the glass was heavy and slippery, and it\r\neluded him, rolled over on its side, and spilled the bright purple juicy\r\ncontents out across the table in a huge swish.\r\n\r\nOley wasn\'t dismayed, but watched with a researcher\'s interest as the\r\nbright purple juice swept across the table towards the busily ticking\r\ndoster. Momma, of course, wasn\'t here, or she would have been gruff\r\nabout it. She\'d just gone into the other room.\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\nThe juice spread rapidly at first, and then more and more slowly, making\r\na huge, circuitous river spreading across the table, first towards the\r\ndoster and then away from it towards the frayed power-cord lying on the\r\ntable. It touched and began to run along the cord. Not a very eventful\r\nrecording so far, but Oley watched, charmed.\r\n\r\nAs he watched, a few bubbles began to appear near the frayed spot. A few\r\nwisps of steam. And then, suddenly, there was a loud, snarling\r\nsplat--and Momma screamed from the doorway. "That juice is making a\r\nshort!"\r\n\r\nThe information, of course, was duly recorded. Juice makes shorts.\r\n\r\nIt was a minor item of information, mixed into a jumble of others, and\r\nnothing else was added to this particular file for nearly another week.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nOley was playing happily on the living room floor that night. Here there\r\nwas much to explore, though an adult might not have thought twice about\r\nit. Back in the corner behind Momma\'s doing bachine a bright, slender\r\npiece of metal caught Oley\'s attention. Bigger on one end than the\r\nother, but not really very big anywhere, the sewing machine needle\r\nproved fascinating. As a first experiment, Oley determined that it\r\nworked like a tooth by biting himself with it. After that he went around\r\nthe room, biting other things with it. Information, of course, is\r\ninformation, and to be obtained any way one can.\r\n\r\nThe brown, snaky lamp cord was the end of this experiment. Oley bit it,\r\nviciously, with his new tooth, and had only barely observed that it had\r\npenetrated completely through when there was a loud splat, and all the\r\nlights in the room went out.\r\n\r\nIn the darkness and confusion, of course, Oley moved away, seeking other\r\nnew experiences. So the cause of the short that Momma and Poppa yakked\r\nso loudly about was never attributed to Oley\'s actions, but only to "How\r\ncould a needle have gotten from your sewing machine into this lamp cord,\r\nAlice?"\r\n\r\nBut the sum of information had increased. Neatles stuck into lamp cords\r\nhad something to do with shorts.\r\n\r\nMore time passed. And this time the file on shorts was stimulated by\r\nPoppa. The big, rough, booming voice had always scared Oley a bit when\r\nit sounded mad, like now.\r\n\r\n"Alice, I\'ve just got to have some more shorts!"\r\n\r\nPoppa was rummaging in a drawer far above Oley\'s head, so he couldn\'t\r\nsee the object under discussion. But all he already knew about\r\nshorts--the information passed in review before him.\r\n\r\nShorts are useful.
