They help electrics to work harder.\r\n\r\nShorts you wear, and they are electrics.\r\n\r\nWires are electrics.\r\n\r\nShorts can be made by juice.\r\n\r\nShorts can be made by neatles, that bite like teeth.\r\n\r\nPoppa needs more shorts.\r\n\r\nBut Oley wasn\'t motivated to act at the moment. Just sorting out\r\ninformation and connecting it with other information files in the\r\nnecessarily haphazard manner that might eventually result in something\r\ncalled intelligence, although he didn\'t know that yet.\r\n\r\nIt was a week later in the kitchen, when Momma dropped a giant version\r\nof the neatle on the floor, that his information file in this area\r\nincreased again.\r\n\r\n"Is that a neatle?" Oley asked.\r\n\r\nHis mother laughed quietly and looked fondly at her son as she put the\r\nice pick back on the table.\r\n\r\n"I guess you could call it a needle, Oley," she told him. "An ice\r\nneedle."\r\n\r\nOley instinctively waited until Momma\'s back was turned before taking\r\nthe nice neatle to try its biting powers; and instinctively took it out\r\nof the kitchen before starting his experiments.\r\n\r\nAs he passed the cellar door he heard a soft gurgling and promptly\r\nchanged course. Pulling open the door with difficulty, he seated himself\r\non the cellar stairs to watch a delightful new spectacle--frothing,\r\ngurgling water making its way across the floor towards the stairs. It\r\nlooked wonderfully dirty and brown, and to Oley it was an absorbing\r\nphenomenon. It never occurred to him to tell Momma.\r\n\r\nSuddenly above him the cellar door slammed open, and Poppa came charging\r\ndown the stairs, narrowly missing the small figure, straight into the\r\nrising waters, intent, though Oley couldn\'t know it, on reaching the\r\ndrain pipe in the far corner of the cellar to plug it before water from\r\nthe spring rains could back up farther and really flood the cellar out.\r\n\r\nHalfway across the cellar, Poppa reached up and grasped the dangling\r\noverhead light to turn it on, in order to see his way to the drain--and\r\nsuddenly came to frozen, rigid, gasping stop as his hand clamped firmly\r\nover the socket.\r\n\r\nLittle Oley watched. There was juice in the cellar. Poppa had hold of an\r\nelectric. Was Poppa trying to make the shorts he needed?\r\n\r\nOley wasn\'t sure. He thought it probable. And from the superior\r\nknowledge of his four years, Oley already knew a better way to make\r\nshorts. Neatles make good shorts. Juice don\'t do so well.\r\n\r\nSuddenly, Oley decided to prove his point: Nice neatles probably made\r\neven better shorts than other neatles--and there was a big electric\r\nrunning up the side of the stairs--an electric fat enough to make a real\r\ngood shorts. Maybe lots of shorts.\r\n\r\nRaising his nice neatle, Oley took careful aim and plunged it through\r\nthe 220-volt stove feeder cable.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nOley woke up. The strange pretty lady in white was a new experience.\r\nSomebody he hadn\'t seen before. And there seemed to be something wrong\r\nwith his hand, but Oley hadn\'t noticed it very much, yet.\r\n\r\n"Well, my little Hero\'s awake! And how are you this morning? Your Momma\r\nand Poppa will be in to see you in just a minute."\r\n\r\nThe pretty lady in white went away, and Oley gazed around the white room\r\nwith its funny shape, happily recorded the experience, and dozed off\r\nagain.\r\n\r\nThen suddenly he was awakened again. Momma was there; and Poppa. 

And\r\nSven. But they all seemed different somehow this morning. Momma had been\r\ncrying, even though she was smiling bravely now. And Poppa seemed to\r\nhave a new softness that he\'d seldom seen before. Sven was looking\r\npuzzled.\r\n\r\n"I still say, Pop, that he\'s a genius. He _must_ have known what he was\r\ndoing."\r\n\r\n"Oley," Poppa\'s voice was husky--gruff, but kinder and softer than\r\nusual. "I want you to answer me carefully. 

But understand that it\'s all\r\nright either way. 

I just want you to tell me. Why did you put the ice\r\npick through the stove cable? You saved my life, you know. 

But I\'d like\r\nto know how you knew how."\r\n\r\nLittle Oley grinned. His world was peaceful and wonderful now. And all\r\nthe big adults were bending and leaning down and talking to him.\r\n\r\n"Nice neatle," he said. "Big electric. Poppa needed shorts."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Analog Science Fact & Fiction_ January\r\n    1964. "Soon we come to\r\nwaterhole."\r\n\r\nI didn\'t ask him how he knew. Andromedans have a knack for geography.\r\nIn many ways, they\'re almost as good as an Earthman. "Good," was all I\r\nanswered. It was short, to the point, and showed who was boss.\r\n\r\nOnward we trekked, a sunburnt duo casting long bronze shadows across\r\nthe burning sands of K\'niik K\'naak. A thin plume of Yekkweed fumes\r\nmarked our passage. It was nearly sunset when we spotted the pink\r\nglitter of that sickening slop that is the Polaris III excuse for\r\nwater. I stood watching the sunset, while Mimp unloaded all the gear\r\nand began to set up camp. As the last rays faded in the sky, I turned\r\nand entered the pseudolog hut Mimp had inflated. Hard on his lungs, of\r\ncourse, but I hadn\'t wanted to burden him with the extra weight of a\r\nhand-pump. I\'m a stern man, but I\'m fair.\r\n\r\nHe had my slippers laid out beside the armchair by the fire and a cool\r\nmint julep awaiting me on the small teakwood taboret. He was busying\r\nhimself in the kitchenette, whipping up a quick souffle with one hand\r\nand tossing a small salad with the other.\r\n\r\n"Hurry it up there," I growled jovially. "Time is money, time is\r\nmoney!" A bit of friendly joshing is good for the relationship; shows\r\nMimp I\'m tolerant of him sharing the same quarters, without actually\r\nmaking me act like an equal, if you know what I mean.\r\n\r\n"I hurry, Sahib," said Mimp. "Coming up." 

(He always called me Sahib.)\r\nHe rushed across the room and began setting the table, with my\r\npearl-handled silverware.\r\n\r\n"No, not there," I yawned, picking up my julep and settling back into\r\nthe armchair. "I think I\'d like the table nearer the piano, so you can\r\nplay Chopin Nocturnes while I dine." I added, as a kindly afterthought,\r\n"You can reheat your share of the souffle later, after I\'ve gone to\r\nbed." Personally, I hate cold souffle.\r\n\r\n"Yes, Effendi," said Mimp. (He always called me Effendi.) Rapidly, he\r\nmoved the table over to the Steinway, set out the finished souffle\r\nand salad and then hurried to the piano and began laboriously plunking\r\nout glorious melody. I took a sip of my julep, then spat it out on the\r\ncarpet.\r\n\r\n"Mimp!" I roared, incensed. "Did you make this drink with Polaris III\r\nwater?"\r\n\r\nCraven and cowering, he fell at my feet, whining for mercy. 

But I was\r\nadamant. You let an alien take an inch, and the next thing, he\'s swiped\r\na parsec. "The knout," I said, keeping my voice emotionless and holding\r\nout my hand.\r\n\r\n"Please, Kimosabe," whimpered Mimp, "I dared not use the water in\r\nthe canteens. You know that Polaris III water is poisonous to us\r\nAndromedans, while you Earthmen can tolerate it."\r\n\r\n"I can _not_!" 

I raged.\r\n\r\n"I was speaking medically," he mewed piteously.\r\n\r\n"And I, esthetically," I snarled. "The knout, now, and be quick about\r\nit."\r\n\r\nHe scurried on all fours to the bureau where I kept my odds and ends,\r\nand came crawling back with the brutal leather whip. I weighed the\r\ninfraction, decided that three stripes should be lesson enough and I\r\nlaid them onto his bare back with a steady hand. "Now," I said, wearied\r\nby the effort, "play something gay and lilting."\r\n\r\nHastily, he dragged himself to the Steinway and complied. Dinner was\r\nreally delicious.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nNext morning, before sun-up, we lay in wait for the herd behind a\r\nrock beside the waterhole. The sky was growing pale saffron near the\r\nhorizon, then light yellow, and finally glaring brass as the sun arose.\r\n(By "sun," I mean the star Polaris, of course. Our sun is a star, you\r\nknow. Or did you? 

_I_ knew, naturally.) Then, afar off, I espied the\r\nbulky blobs in the sky that were the flying tuskers of K\'niik-K\'naak.\r\nNo man had ever hunted one before. I felt pretty proud, let me tell you.\r\n\r\nOnward they came through the air, their large skin-type gray wings\r\nflapping stolidly up and down, about three strokes to the mile.\r\nEnormous creatures they were, with fiery little eyes, and long trailing\r\ntrunks that had a wicked little hook at the tip. But the thing that\r\nreally caught one\'s eye was their tusks. Ten of them. Eight originating\r\nin the mouth, and one in either fore-knee. Each tusk was seven feet\r\nin length, long, white, straight-tapered and flawless. But not ivory,\r\nnot on these babies. Pure pearl. 

That lovely lustrous calcareous\r\nconcretion! Each tusk would bring fifty thousand interplanetary credits\r\non the open market. And there were ten per elephantine beast, and at\r\nleast sixty of them in the herd.\r\n\r\n"Look at that, will you!" I cried to Mimp. "Look, feast your ugly eyes\r\non that gleaming fortune swooping down upon us, Mimp!"\r\n\r\n"I look, I feast," he murmured servilely, huddled behind me behind the\r\nrock behind the tree. Aliens tend to be cowardly when their lives are\r\nin danger.\r\n\r\nCarefully, I raised the rifle and took a bead on the youngest beast in\r\nthat descending herd. It\'s slightly illegal to shoot the fledglings,\r\nbut after all, I wasn\'t going to bring him _back_ with me, so no one\r\nwould know. It\'s just that I find that when I shoot the eldest in a\r\nherd of wildlife, the others miss their protector and flee. But if I\r\nshoot one of the babies, the elder ones stay around to protect it, and\r\nI get to kill lots more. Nasty, perhaps, but that\'s the hunting game\r\nfor you.\r\n\r\nAnyhow, I took this bead on the beast. I was just in the act of\r\ndepressing the firing stud when an unwonted lightness in the weapon\r\ncaught my attention. Irritated, I cracked open the firing chamber.\r\n"_Mimp!_" I growled, in one of my rare real wraths. "You didn\'t _load_\r\nthe ray-rifle! Even a Moxley .55 is no damned good without cartridges!"\r\n\r\n"A thousand pardons, boss," muttered Mimp, inclining his loathsome\r\nlavender face in a subservient bow. 

"I go get."\r\n\r\nHe wriggled away across the sand and into the hut, fortunately not\r\ndisturbing the herd, which was now kneeling on the slope above\r\nthe waterhole and inhaling that putrid pink liquid through their\r\ntrunks. I drooled a bit, seeing the rainbow glint of sunlight on\r\nthose magnificent tusks. Seconds passed, then minutes. The herd was\r\npractically slaked, and still no crawling Mimp reappeared from the hut.\r\n\r\nSoon they\'d fly off, and cost me a fortune.\r\n\r\nI was already pretty much in hock after paying the fare to Polaris\r\nIII from Earth. (I\'d been able to save a little by listing Mimp as\r\nbaggage, and storing him in the hold for the flight.) Angry, irked, and\r\npretty well enraged, I moved swiftly toward the hut on hands and knees,\r\nscuttling in the doorway as fast as I could, lest the herd see me and\r\nflee, or attack.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIn the parlor, I stood erect, and glanced about. There was no one in\r\nsight, but the back door was open. "_Mimp!_" I bellowed, stamping\r\nacross the carpet. "Where are you, you off-color blemish!?" No reply.\r\n"This means six stripes with the knout!" I warned him.\r\n\r\nThen I heard a faint sound, not unlike that of a fourteen-inch bolo\r\nknife being brought down hard upon the inflating-valve of a pseudolog\r\nhut. I felt at my belt. My bolo was missing. 

"Mimp!" I hollered, much\r\ntoo late.\r\n\r\nThen the whole damned room, piano, fireplace, carpet, armchair and all,\r\nsnapped in upon me, and I was wound up with those rubberized walls\r\ntighter than the center of a golfball. I think I must have swooned,\r\nthen.\r\n\r\nMuch, much later, by dint of tooth, fingernail and sheer grit, I\r\nhad gnawed, clawed and wrenched my way free of the collapsed hut. A\r\nstunning sight met my eyes. All about the waterhole, the flying tuskers\r\nwere still kneeling. Every one of them was dead and already beginning\r\nto rot. But the infuriating thing was that not one of them had so much\r\nas an inch of tusk any more.\r\n\r\nEvery beast had been detusked, the priceless pearl shafts lopped off\r\nflush with the thick gray hides. _Mimp!_ And with _my_ bolo knife,\r\nalready!\r\n\r\nAt least he\'d left me a canteen. I tasted it. _Pffaugh!_ Pink Polaris\r\nIII slop! The dirty little--! 

But I saved it anyhow. I had a long\r\nlonely walk back to town ahead of me.\r\n\r\nAnd there it was that I learned even worse news.\r\n\r\nMimp had already sold the tusks and was on his way back to Andromeda,\r\nwith a fortune in his breechclout. I swore revenge, then and there,\r\nbut was unable to carry it out, since I was short the rocketfare back\r\nto Earth and the authorities. (It seems that Polaris III is a neutral\r\nplanet. Even the mighty word "Earthman" carries no weight there.) So\r\nI had to hock the piano, my precious Moxley .55 and what could be\r\nsalvaged of the souffle, and even then I was only able to book passage\r\nas near Earth as Sirius II.\r\n\r\nLuckily, they had a consulate there. I was able to secure a ride home,\r\nafter some weeks\' wait. By then, however, it was too late to avenge\r\nmyself.\r\n\r\nMimp, with his stolen fortune, had paid off his planet\'s debt to Earth.\r\nAndromeda IV (his home planet) declared its independence, and the\r\nEarth authorities throw up their hands and shrug whenever I hint at\r\nextraditing him. Seems he\'s the new emperor there, or something. 

They\r\ncan\'t afford to antagonize him. Damn!\r\n\r\nHowever, I suppose you\'re wondering just why I get goosebumps when I\r\nrecall the flying tuskers of K\'niik-K\'naak. Well, it wasn\'t so much the\r\ndanger from the beasts, nor the hideous heat of that desert, nor my\r\nlong, painful sojourn beneath the Steinway in the shrunken hut that was\r\nso bad.\r\n\r\nIt was those tuskers. Know how they died? Mimp had poisoned the\r\nwaterhole. Unsporting, and all that, but the thing that nags my brain\r\nis: Why didn\'t _I_ think of that?\r\n\r\nMe! Bested by a lousy purple alien!\r\n\r\nWhat\'s the universe coming to?\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nGeorge Main lay dying in the wreckage of the space-ship. Dying--and\r\ncursing the deadly wind of Venus. It had killed his mates. It would\r\nsoon have him.\r\n\r\nThe wind was trying to finish him off right now. It shrieked, moaned,\r\nwhispered and shouted through the smashed hull where he sprawled in his\r\nspace-suit. Laughed, too. The wind was a murderer--and was glad.\r\n\r\nAll but he were dead. Soon the grit-laden wind would bury them and\r\ntheir ship. Then all the effort, the skill, the faith--all the\r\ningenuity and labor expended on the expedition--would be wiped away, as\r\ninvisible as the wind that buried them.\r\n\r\nThinking of that, thinking back over each agonizing hour since his\r\nlanding on Venus, George Main wondered what he should have done, what\r\nhe could now do, to prevent the utter waste of their efforts and their\r\nlives.\r\n\r\nThe wind was his enemy--and the wind couldn't even be seen. Only the\r\ndust it carried was visible. 

Too visible. Dust was so thick in the\r\nupper atmosphere that the scope-readers had mistaken dust-clouds for\r\nsolid ground.\r\n\r\nWith ports blinded by dust, the possibility of that error had been\r\nobvious enough. The navigator knew the risk. He chanced it--and lost\r\nthe toss.\r\n\r\nGeorge knew he was still alive only because he'd acted like a childish\r\neager-beaver. And had been tolerated by the others because he was the\r\ncrew's youngest member.\r\n\r\nEver since he could read and dream, he'd wanted to be the first man\r\never to touch the soil of Venus. So, having no duties connected\r\nwith setting down the ship, he'd gotten into his space-suit and had\r\nwaited by a hatch. He was standing there when the ship went into the\r\ntwenty-mile free fall that smashed it.\r\n\r\nGeorge didn't know who opened the escape hatch and shoved him out. That\r\nman was dead, along with the rest of the crew. Unlike George's suit,\r\nthe space-ship had no parachute.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe'd landed blind, in dust so thick he didn't know he was down till he\r\ngot there. For forty-eight hours he'd lain where he fell, waiting for a\r\nlull in the storm so he could see the ship.\r\n\r\nWhen the wind finally quit, the ship was already half buried. Thirsty,\r\nhungry, stinking in the hot suit, George had staggered over windrow\r\nafter windrow of dust to reach it.\r\n\r\nHe'd broken out an emergency-jug of water, found some uncontaminated\r\nfood, erected within the hull a small gas-proof tent, and then passed\r\nout before he could crawl in the tent to eat and drink.\r\n\r\nLater he'd gone out while the lull continued, to search for bodies.\r\nLike the hull itself, they were scattered over a wide area. Some were\r\nalready buried in dust. The wind had buried them.\r\n\r\nThe wind--the murdering wind. The wind of formaldehyde that poisoned\r\nevery drop of water it touched, every bit of food. The wind that\r\nlimited George's supplies to unbroken containers--of which there were\r\ntragically few.\r\n\r\nThe wind mocked him, then and thereafter. It mocked his efforts to find\r\nthe ship's log and continue it. 

It mocked his efforts to live.\r\n\r\nHe tried to fight back. He lay prone and relaxed because that took less\r\noxygen. He lay in the suit and not in the tent because that took less\r\noxygen. He ate and drank but once a day because that took less oxygen.\r\n\r\nSo he had run out of water while there were still some potassium oxides\r\nleft to refresh his thrice-breathed air, some oxygen for the tent.\r\n\r\nGeorge Main wanted to live, knew he would die. And was enraged at the\r\nthought that he would die without having accomplished anything. He and\r\nhis friends, and the pioneering scientists back of them, had put too\r\nmuch effort into trans-System travel to have it all come to nothing\r\nlike this.\r\n\r\nStubbornly he noted in the log that he was now dehydrated to the point\r\nof occasional delirium. And that he hated the wind.\r\n\r\nAs if that wind had not already done enough, it now sought to destroy\r\nhis last remaining moments of sanity. It brought a horde of odd shapes\r\nto haunt him.\r\n\r\nThe shapes literally rolled into the dust-filled metal cavity where he\r\nlay writing. The wind rolled them. But when they got into shelter--had\r\nrolled to one side or the other of the holes through which they'd\r\ncome--the shapes began to move, slowly, under their own power.\r\n\r\nThey all looked alike. There were a couple of dozen, maybe--George\r\ncounted ten and gave up because counting was too much like work. They\r\nwere teardrops--eight-inch yellow teardrops with the point down.\r\nAnd each point rested on an extensible foot that looked like a blue\r\nstarfish, about four inches across its seven points.\r\n\r\nThey came in, rolling along the ground as the wind took them, and then\r\nextended their stars from some hidden place and moved on them when out\r\nof the wind.\r\n\r\nThat is, they seemed to. But whether they were in the hull or in his\r\nmind, George was by no means sure.\r\n\r\nNothing could live in this wind. Nothing could live on a planet with\r\nno water, where the air was full of formaldehyde ready to react with\r\nproteins, the basis of life.\r\n\r\nHe lay motionless, watching idly. There was no sound but the wind. 

The\r\nyellow teardrops scattered out. They could have been exploring--or\r\nseeking shelter--or nonexistent.\r\n\r\nWhen he got tired of watching them, George put the log aside and slept.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe awoke to find a small congregation of teardrops surrounding the\r\nwatch strapped outside the suit on his left wrist. The watch was\r\ngoing--wound through habit every twenty-four hours, though that was but\r\na third of a day, here on Venus. The teardrops were curious about it.\r\n\r\nHow he got the idea they were curious, George didn't quite know. They\r\nseemed attracted to it, was all. There were no eyes, so far as he\r\ncould tell--no ears. If these things had senses, they were not like\r\nterrestrial senses. But the teardrops did have an attitude of attention.\r\n\r\nGeorge removed his watch, laid it before them. Two teardrops detached\r\nthemselves from the group to examine his right hand, with which he'd\r\nslipped off the wrist-band. Three others perched on the dust-covered\r\ndeck, the watch between them and him.\r\n\r\nGeorge flexed his right hand, twiddled his fingers. The teardrops\r\nseemed unafraid. He chose one and lifted it. It seemed light in weight.\r\nIts star-foot was slightly prehensile, and grasped his glove with tiny\r\nclaws arranged in rows on its bottom surface.\r\n\r\nThe claws seemed for clinging, not for seizing. George put down the\r\nteardrop, turned it over, and found no opening anywhere on the surface.\r\nIf these things lived, he decided, they must be plants, synthesizing\r\ntheir food--they had no way to eat as animals do.\r\n\r\nVaguely, George made up his wavering mind that the things existed\r\noutside his imagination. They were alive. 

They felt curiosity about\r\nhim. Leathery, he found them--hard and smooth, except for the foot.\r\n\r\nWhen he set down the teardrop he'd been examining, the three by his\r\nwatch took up a rhythmic motion. The center one stood in place,\r\nswaying slowly above the watch like a bit of seaweed in a quiet lagoon.\r\n\r\nEach of the other two had somehow obtained a pebble. They set their\r\npebbles down near the watch. Each then tapped with a star-point, first\r\nat the pebble, then at the watch. Back and forth they swayed, their\r\nmotions synchronized--perhaps directed by the center one.\r\n\r\nInteresting--but meaningless. It was equally meaningless when the two\r\nteardrops at his right began to dance. They found an empty food-can\r\nlid, pushed it near his hand, and began a concerted swaying and\r\npointing that took them between hand and can.\r\n\r\nIdly, George led the dance with a waggled forefinger. The teardrops\r\npromptly changed their motion. They stood in place, no longer pointing\r\nalternately at lid and finger, but swaying between them in time with\r\nGeorge.\r\n\r\n[Illustration: _Idly, George led the dance with a waggled\r\nforefinger...._]\r\n\r\nThey were slow, though--he could easily have left them behind. But if\r\nhe moved his finger slowly enough, they kept perfect time.\r\n\r\nThe dance at the watch had stopped. Many teardrops gathered around the\r\npair that followed the beat of his right index finger.\r\n\r\nIt must have amused them. But it soon tired George. He stopped.\r\n\r\nHe needed all his remaining energy to think with. He knew these\r\nteardrops were sentient. They were curious, they communicated with each\r\nother, and they danced. They had minds, therefore.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nGeorge remembered hearing that Man had danced even before he learned\r\nto speak, in a primitive effort to express his feelings. He knew some\r\nbirds dance, too--as a courtship procedure. Insects, even.\r\n\r\nBut why did the teardrops dance?\r\n\r\nWhat was the significance of rhythmic motion between a pebble and a\r\nwatch? A tin lid and a man's hand? What did the pebbles mean?\r\n\r\nThe pebble was a native object, known to be lifeless, inanimate. The\r\nwatch was a strange something that moved. 

The can-lid did not move.\r\nThe hand--gloved, though they could not know that--was an object that\r\nmoved.\r\n\r\nThe dance was a question, therefore. Alive, or dead? 

The teardrops\r\nwanted to know. Is the watch that moves by itself alive? The strangely\r\nsymmetrical lid of a can, is it alive? The oddshaped hand?\r\n\r\nThese teardrops had good minds--could grasp abstractions. In a sense,\r\nGeorge felt, the difference between animate and inanimate objects is an\r\nabstraction. In his dying state, the notion amused him.\r\n\r\nSmiling, he placed a pebble on the watch, another on the lid. He sat\r\nup, moved his weakened body so they could perhaps tell it was a unit.\r\nHe picked up a teardrop in each hand, held them at his visor, rolled\r\nhis eyes, and opened and shut his mouth. He spoke to them. 

He sang to\r\nthem. He swayed with them to show he too could dance.\r\n\r\nThey made no sign of reply. None that he could recognize, at any rate.\r\n\r\nCarefully he felt and looked at the entire surface of a teardrop,\r\nputting one down to devote both hands to the other. He thought perhaps\r\nthe lack of organs and openings might simply mean they were clothed or\r\narmored in some way. But the thing was apparently naked. The surfaces\r\nhe touched were probably skin. He didn't know.\r\n\r\nAnd they, would they know what a man was? Were they even certain he was\r\nalive?\r\n\r\nOne of them was behind him, dancing before the tent. Seeing that, he\r\nwas certain the teardrops hadn't yet distinguished the animate from the\r\ninanimate in the objects around them here.\r\n\r\nAnd George had little time to teach them. Already he was dull and\r\nlistless. His vision was playing tricks on him.\r\n\r\nLike as not he'd be dead before they knew for certain he'd been alive.\r\nDead in the grotesque space-suit. Preserved in an atmosphere of\r\nformaldehyde. His body would seem like a machine that had run down.\r\nThere would be no discernable difference between himself and his watch.\r\n\r\nBut if they knew he'd been alive? They might remember, then. 

They were\r\nintelligent, could communicate with one another. By rights they should\r\nhave some kind of legends or traditions or history. If they did, if\r\nthey knew they'd seen alien life, they'd keep the memory alive.\r\n\r\nThey'd recognize the next man to land on Venus, might find means\r\nto tell of this first expedition. Might lead a man to the buried\r\nspace-ship, the bodies, the ship's log.\r\n\r\nAt least they could defeat the wind. The teardrops could keep his life\r\nand the lives of his mates from going utterly to waste. Whether men\r\never found out or not, the teardrops themselves would know that the\r\nexpedition had reached Venus.\r\n\r\nBut first, George had to prove he was alive, like them--not some\r\nstrangely mobile meteorite, nor oddly contrived machine.\r\n\r\nHis very lack of strength, his real nearness to death, provided George\r\nwith the means he sought. Already he was half anesthetized by weakness\r\nand shock. 

He didn't have to worry about pain.\r\n\r\nHolding his breath, he took off his helmet. He picked up a teardrop\r\nwith each hand, held them to his hot cheeks. Then he let himself\r\nbreathe.\r\n\r\nHe knew the physical changes to follow would be obvious to the\r\nintelligent little dancers he held in his hands. He hoped they wouldn't\r\nget hurt, when they fell.\r\n\r\nHurt or not, they'd soon figure out he'd been alive--once he was\r\ndead....\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


"\r\n\r\nStanley Rapp blinked, considering the matter. He always thought over\r\neverything very carefully. Of course, some questions were easier to\r\nanswer than others. This one, for instance. He had very few doubts about\r\nhis name.\r\n\r\n"Uh," Stanley Rapp said. "Yes. 

Yes."\r\n\r\nHe stared at the bearded young man. Living in the Village, even on the\r\nbetter side of it, one saw beards every day, all shapes and sizes of\r\nbeard. This one was not a psychoanalyst beard, or a folk singer beard;\r\nnot even an actor beard. This was the scraggly variety, almost certainly\r\na poet beard. 

Mr. Rapp, while holding no particular prejudice against\r\npoets, had not sent for one, he was sure of that.\r\n\r\nThen he noticed the toolcase in the bearded young man\'s hand, lettered\r\nlarge LIGHTNING SERVICE, TV, HI-FI.\r\n\r\n"Oh," Stanley said, nodding. "You\'re the man to fix the TV set."\r\n\r\n"You know it, Dad," the young man said, coming in. He shut the door\r\nbehind him, and stared around the apartment. "What a wild pad. Where the\r\nidiot box, hey?"\r\n\r\nThe pleasantly furnished, neat little apartment was not what Mr. Rapp\r\nhad ever thought of as a "wild pad." But the Village had odd standards,\r\nMr. Rapp knew. Chacun a son gout, he had said, on moving into the\r\napartment ten years ago. Not aloud, of course, because he had only taken\r\none year of French, and would never have trusted his accent. But chacun\r\na son gout, anyway.\r\n\r\n"The television set," Mr. Rapp said, translating. 

"Oh, yes." 

He went to\r\nthe closet door and opened it. Reaching inside, he brought out an\r\nimposingly large TV set, mounted on a wheeled table. The bearded\r\nrepairman whistled.\r\n\r\n"In the closet," the repairman said, admiringly. "Crazy. 

You go in there\r\nto watch it, or you let it talk to itself?"\r\n\r\n"Oh. Well, I don\'t exactly watch it at all," Mr. Rapp said, a little\r\nsadly. "I mean, I can\'t. That\'s why I called you."\r\n\r\n"Lightning\'s here, have no fear," the bearded one said, approaching the\r\nset with a professional air. "Like, in the closet, hey." He bent over\r\nthe set, appraisingly. "I thought you were a square, Pops, but I can see\r\nyou\'re.... Hey, this is like too much. Man, I don\'t want to pry, but why\r\nis this box upside down?"\r\n\r\n"I wish I knew," Mr. Rapp said. He sat down, and leaned back, sighing.\r\nThis was going to be difficult, he knew. He had already had to explain\r\nit to the last three repairmen, and he was getting tired of explaining.\r\nAlthough he thought, somehow, that this young man might understand it a\r\nlittle more quickly than the others had.\r\n\r\n"I\'ve had a couple of other repairmen look it over," Mr. Rapp told the\r\nbearded one. 

"They ... well, they gave up."\r\n\r\n"Dilettantes," commented the beard.\r\n\r\n"Oh, no," Mr. Rapp said. 

"One of them was from the company that made it.\r\nBut they couldn\'t do anything."\r\n\r\n"Let\'s try it," the repairman said, plugging the cord into a wall\r\nsocket. He returned to the set, and switched it on, without changing\r\nits upside down position. Immediate relief from headache," a bland voice said, as the\r\npictured face broke into a broad smile. The set is upside down, right?"\r\n\r\n"Right," said Mr. Rapp.\r\n\r\n"Only the picture--" the repairman paused, trying to find the right\r\nphrase. "I mean, the picture\'s flipped. Like, it\'s wrong side up, too.\r\nOnly, right side up, now."\r\n\r\n"Exactly," said Mr. Rapp. "You see, that\'s the trouble. I put the set\r\nupside down because of that."\r\n\r\n"Cool," the repairman said, watching the picture. "I mean, so why worry?\r\nYou got a picture, right? You want me to turn the picture around? I can\r\ndo that with a little fiddling around inside the set ... uh-oh. Dad,\r\nsomething\'s happening."\r\n\r\n          *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe repairman bent closer, staring at the picture. It was now showing a\r\nbusty young woman singer, her mouth opened, but silent, since the sound\r\nwas turned down. She was slowly rotating as Rapp and the bearded\r\nrepairman watched, turning until her face, still mouthing silent song,\r\nhung upside down on the screen.\r\n\r\n"It always does that," Rapp said. "No matter which way I put the set,\r\nthe picture\'s always upside down."\r\n\r\n"No, man," the repairman said, pleadingly. "Look, I took a course. I\r\nmean, the best school, you dig? It don\'t work that way. 

It just can\'t."\r\n\r\n"It does, though," Rapp pointed out. "And that\'s what the other repair\r\npeople said, too. They took it out, and brought it back, and it still\r\ndid it. Over she goes." He set it down again, right side up. The\r\npicture, still the singer\'s face, remained in a relatively upright\r\nposition for another moment, and then slowly rolled over, upside down\r\nagain.\r\n\r\n"You see," Mr. Rapp said, shrugging. "I guess I\'ll have to buy another\r\nset. Except I\'d hate to have it happen again, and this one did cost\r\nquite a lot."\r\n\r\n"You couldn\'t trade it in, either," the repairman agreed. "Not to me,\r\nanyway." Suddenly he snapped his fingers. "Hey now. Sideways?"\r\n\r\n"You mean on its side?"\r\n\r\n"Just for kicks...." the repairman gripped the set again. "On the\r\nside...." Did you cross up any\r\nwitches lately, Pops?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, dear," Mr. Rapp said sadly. He shook his head. "No, I haven\'t ...\r\ner, offended any witches. Not that I know of." 

He regarded the inverted\r\npicture for a moment. Then, as the repairman\'s words began to sink in,\r\nMr. Rapp looked at him apprehensively.\r\n\r\n"Witches?" Mr. Rapp asked. "But ... I mean, that\'s all superstition,\r\nisn\'t it? And anyway ... well, television sets!"\r\n\r\n"They used to dry up cows, but who keeps cows?" the bearded one said\r\nominously. "Why not television sets? Like, I happen to be personally\r\nacquainted with several witches and like that. The Village is full of\r\nthem. However--" He rose, and stalked toward the set, his eyes\r\nglittering in a peculiar way. "You\'re a lucky one, Daddyo. Back in my\r\nsquare days, I did some reading up on the hookups between poetry and\r\nmagic. Now, I\'m a poet. Therefore, and to wit, I\'m also a magician. On\r\nthis hangup, I\'m going to try magic. Electronics won\'t work, that\'s for\r\nsure."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"But...." Mr. Rapp was not quite sure why he disapproved, but he did. "Don\'t worry, though. 

I got the touch, like with\r\npoetry. Same thing, in fact. All magic spells rhyme, see? Well, I used\r\nto rhyme, back before I really started swinging. Anybody can rhyme. Now he bent\r\ndown, to take another look at the back of the set, and nodded with an\r\nair of assurance.\r\n\r\n"The tube layout," the repairman told Mr. Rapp, exhibiting his notebook.\r\n"That, and Ohm\'s Law, and a couple of Hindu bits I picked up listening\r\nto the UN on the radio ... makes a first-class spell."\r\n\r\nMr. Rapp backed away, nervously. "I mean, it\'s\r\nworking. I ought to pay...."\r\n\r\n"I goofed," the repairman said. He picked up his tools, and moved toward\r\nthe door. "Like, I won\'t mention it to anybody if you won\'t. But I\r\ngoofed, all right.

That\'s all."\r\n\r\nIt took a few minutes for Ferris to recover. Replacement! After six\r\nyears of service at the number one fuel station between the Earth\r\nand Moon. Why, he was the only man who could handle Station 12! And\r\nGalsworth was sending Brooks, a green kid barely out of SM school. What\r\nwas the guy thinking of?\r\n\r\nAngered, Ferris got up from his stool and paced the floor. It was easy\r\nto picture Galsworth sitting at his desk. He\'d be chewing a big cigar,\r\npounding a pudgy fist into his palm, telling young Brooks that Station\r\n12 needed a stalwart lad willing to face numerous cosmic dangers in\r\norder that commerce between the Earth and Moon would not fall below its\r\npresent status. Only Galsworth would say it like that.\r\n\r\nWell, what was wrong with the present status? Ferris had kept the\r\ncompany heads above water; he hadn\'t fallen down on the job. But they\r\napparently weren\'t satisfied. Something was wrong, and it seemed that\r\nGalsworth was taking it out on Ferris.\r\n\r\nStill perplexed, Ferris entered his living quarters and began packing.\r\nHe dismissed Galsworth from his mind, wondered whether or not Brooks\r\ncould meet the task of operating the station. It was a lonely job,\r\nsitting there in the cylindrical island of space, watching ships\r\napproach and pass in the cold void that housed him. Brooks would grow\r\nweary of it, just as Ferris had at first. There wasn\'t a more dismal\r\nexistence in the solar system, but to Ferris it was home, and even the\r\nthought of that was comforting.\r\n\r\nThe sound of a hissing airlock brought Ferris to his senses. Brooks was\r\nahead of schedule--\r\n\r\nFerris went back to the control room. A tall fellow stood there, his\r\nhair drooping, his space tunic ripped open at the collar. His face was\r\nstone-like.\r\n\r\n"You aren\'t Brooks," said Ferris. "What do you want?"\r\n\r\n"Fuel," the other dropped a hand to a belt holster. "I need fuel for\r\nmy ship--a lot of it. And you\'re the only fellow in my path who\'s got\r\nit. 

Let\'s not waste time.

"\r\n\r\n"You\'ve come to the wrong place," said Ferris, starting forward. "The\r\nbarrels here are under government combination seal, and can\'t be opened\r\nby anyone other than the inspectors who accompany our regular ships."\r\n\r\n"Nevertheless," the tall fellow drew his beam gun, "you have fuel in\r\nyour repulsion tanks, and that\'s as good as any."\r\n\r\nFor a moment Ferris stood there, undetermined. 

Then he remembered a\r\npolice bulletin not so long ago. A convict had escaped from one of\r\nEarth\'s interplanetary prisons. He understood now.\r\n\r\n"You\'re Siegal," he said.\r\n\r\nThe other nodded. "My ship hasn\'t the fuel to carry me to the Moon. I\r\ndon\'t like to insist, but I\'m going to drain your tanks."\r\n\r\n"The station will fall," Ferris warned. "If the repulsion tanks are\r\ndrained, gravity will take hold."\r\n\r\n"Unfortunate," said Siegal, "but it\'s me or the station. I\'ve brought a\r\nhose along--also a container. I\'ll give you the pleasure of filling it\r\nfor me. 

Hurry.

"\r\n\r\nFerris had no choice, so he did as directed. Siegal had the drop on\r\nhim, and it was best to play safe. Perhaps he could talk the fellow out\r\nof his wild plan. There was a chance.\r\n\r\n"Think you\'ll make it to the Moon?" queried Ferris as he loosened a\r\nvalve and inserted the hose. "It\'s a long trek for such a small amount\r\nof fuel. Besides, you\'ll burn up half the stuff getting started.\r\nThere\'s no launch here, you know."\r\n\r\n"I left Earth without a launch," said Siegal crisply. "I can do it\r\nagain."\r\n\r\nThe syphon began a steady flow.\r\n\r\n"You won\'t make it," remarked Ferris. "And if you do get there, what\r\nthen? There\'s no place for you on the Moon. They\'ll track you down in a\r\nfew days."\r\n\r\nSiegal laughed. "You seem quite certain of all this."\r\n\r\n"Besides," went on Ferris, "I\'ll tell them all about you. They\'ll know\r\njust where you are, and they\'ll be waiting for you when you reach the\r\nMoon."\r\n\r\n"Not if I destroy your radio," said Siegal, "and not if you ride the\r\nstation back to Earth."\r\n\r\nFor a long minute there was silence. The only sound was the trickling\r\nof the liquid fuel. Ferris became uneasy.\r\n\r\n"That\'s murder," he said at length.\r\n\r\n"True," agreed Siegal. "That is murder, isn\'t it?"\r\n\r\nThe container was full. At the point of Siegal\'s gun, Ferris carried\r\nthe fuel to the airlock, where he was forced to don a space tunic and\r\ntransport the container to the lone ship that was anchored outside.\r\nHe made several trips, until the station\'s tanks were nearly empty.\r\nThrough vision screens, the glow of the repulsion jets could be seen,\r\nreceding gradually.\r\n\r\n"The station will move in a matter of hours," said Ferris. "It\'s a\r\ndevilish trick, Siegal, and I hope they get you for it.

"\r\n\r\n"Never mind. 

Just fill the container again. I want to be sure the tank\r\nis empty."\r\n\r\nFerris set to work again. As he bent over the tanks, the floor gave a\r\nsudden lurch and threw him against the wall. Siegal clutched a door\r\nframe and steadied himself.\r\n\r\n"No tricks, Ferris."\r\n\r\n"But the station\'s moving. 

Can\'t you see?"\r\n\r\n"Sooner than you expected. Perhaps you can tell me why."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know, Siegal. Something\'s happened."\r\n\r\n"It\'s all right, finish your work."\r\n\r\nFerris complied. Once more the precious liquid trickled into the\r\ncontainer. Minutes passed.\r\n\r\n"Brooks reporting, sir."\r\n\r\nSiegal turned, astounded. 

The red-headed youngster stood there, a\r\nlook of bewilderment on his face. Then Ferris leaped, caught Siegal\r\nabout the hips and sent him sprawling over the station floor. But the\r\nconvict was elusive. He twisted free, somewhat dazed, and stood erect.\r\nHe fired a beam at Ferris, who rolled across the floor in pain. Brooks,\r\nrealization having dawned upon him, started forward. Siegal emitted a\r\nshrill noise, grabbed the container and ran for the airlock. Brooks\r\nblocked his way, and went down as the gun struck his skull. Siegal\r\nleaped over him, vanishing a moment later beyond the airlock.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHis brain in a turmoil, Ferris got slowly to his feet and looked about.\r\nThe room was empty. No Siegal, no Brooks. The station was tilted at\r\nan angle, swaying slightly. It was falling, due to the excess weight\r\napplied when Brooks anchored his cruiser.\r\n\r\nFerris nursed his aching head. The beam had shaved his neck just below\r\nthe ear, breaking his space tunic\'s glass helmet, otherwise doing no\r\nharm.\r\n\r\nFerris made his way to the airlock. He dropped flat and crawled to the supply lock, through\r\nwhich a ship\'s food bundles were loaded. He grasped the latch firmly,\r\nand waited.\r\n\r\nA minute later the little cruiser moved into space. Behind, Fuel\r\nStation 12 continued its Earthward fall. Ferris watched it go, his\r\nheart heavy. All his belongings went with Station 12, all the things he\r\nhad called his home for six long years. He wondered about Brooks. The\r\nfellow\'s cruiser was drifting lifelessly to one side, no doubt having\r\nbeen cut free by Siegal. There was no evidence of Brooks\' whereabouts.\r\n\r\nFerris clung to the heavy latch as Siegal\'s cruiser slipped away in\r\nspace. To the\r\nleft was the Moon, drifting aimlessly along the great star-curtain.\r\n\r\nFerris tugged at the latch. It moved a little. 

He tugged again and it\r\nsprang free. Ferris stood up, straddled the circular lock, and pulled\r\nback the cover. Air rushed out. Through the narrow hole he saw the tiny\r\nstorage compartment. Satisfied, he let himself through and dropped to\r\nthe floor, pulling the cover back in place as he did so.\r\n\r\nThe room was small--only a few feet higher than Ferris, not much\r\nlonger. Finding the\r\nair suitable, he stepped to the compartment door, opened it a crack,\r\nand peered out.\r\n\r\nSteps led downward to a brief corridor. Beyond the corridor, a portion\r\nof the control room was visible.\r\n\r\nFerris moved out, went down the steps and proceeded cautiously along\r\nthe corridor.\r\n\r\nHe put a hand to his forehead; a sudden dizziness swept through him.\r\nHe leaned against the wall, rubbing his eyes. There was blood on his\r\nsleeve.\r\n\r\nHe couldn\'t remember how long he waited there; it may have been a\r\nnumber of minutes. He could feel his sickness overcoming him. He was\r\nweakening.\r\n\r\nA footstep sounded, and Ferris tried to open his eyes. Then he turned\r\nto go back, but a voice stopped him. It was Siegal\'s.\r\n\r\nThere was no use resisting. Siegal still had the drop on him. The\r\nconvict led him into the control cabin, forced him into a seat.\r\n\r\n"You\'re a good man, Ferris," Siegal said, "but not good enough. Soon it would strike, and then Galsworth\r\nwould be notified. Things would begin to happen.\r\n\r\n"Brooks reporting.

"\r\n\r\nSiegal swung, shouting angrily. But the youth was on him, knocking\r\nthe beam gun away, pinning him against the wall of the cabin. Willing?"\r\n\r\nTo Ferris, it was overwhelming--more so than it had been aboard\r\nSiegal\'s cruiser. It was all right--after six years!\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


Phui!"\r\n\r\nSimone was washing the dishes, gazing out across the windowsill where\r\ntwo pink and white Murex shells stood, to the tidy garden beyond where\r\nNina was engaged in her private games.\r\n\r\nShe dried the dishes by passing her hand once above each plate or glass,\r\nbringing it to a dry sparkle. It saved wear on the dishtowels, and it\r\namused her.\r\n\r\n"Sam\'s not home very much," she said in a placating voice. She herself\r\nhad grown terrified, since her marriage, that she wouldn\'t be able to\r\nbear the weight of her past. She felt its power on her and couldn\'t\r\ncarry it. Cecily had brought her up, after her father had disappeared\r\nand her mother had died in an unexplained accident. Daily she saw the\r\nreflection of her failure in the face of her grandmother, who seemed\r\nbuilt of the same seasoned and secure wood as the old Putnam house.\r\nSimone looked at her grandmother, whom she loved, and became a mere\r\nvapor.\r\n\r\n"He\'s not home so much," Simone said.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHer face was small, with a pointed chin, and she had golden-red hair\r\nwhich she wore loose on her shoulders. Nina, too, had a small face, but\r\nit was neither so pale nor so delicate as her mother\'s, as if Sam\'s\r\ntougher substance had filled her out and strengthened her bone\r\nstructure. If it was true that she, Simone, was a weak link, then Sam\'s\r\nstrength might have poured into the child, and there would be no more\r\nPutnam family and tradition.\r\n\r\n"People don\'t change that easily," the old woman said.\r\n\r\n"But things--" Simone began. The china which had a history of five\r\ngenerations slipped out of her hands and smashed; Sam\'s toaster wouldn\'t\r\ntoast or pop up; Simone couldn\'t even use the telephone for fear of\r\ngetting a wrong number, or no number at all.\r\n\r\n"Things, things!" her grandmother cried. "It\'s blood that counts. If the\r\nblood is strong enough, things dissolve. They\'re just garbage, all those\r\nthings, floating on the surface of our history. It\'s our history that\'s\r\ndeep. 

That\'s what counts."\r\n\r\n"You\'re afraid of Sam," the young woman accused.\r\n\r\n"Not afraid of any man!" Cecily said, straightening her back. "But I\'m\r\nafraid for the child. Sam has no family tradition, no depth, no talent\r\nhanded down and perfected. A man with his head full of wheels and\r\nwires."\r\n\r\nSimone loved him. She leaned on him and grew about him, and he supported\r\nher tenderly. She wasn\'t going to give him up for the sake of some\r\nabstract tradition--\r\n\r\n"--it\'s not abstract," her grandmother said with spirit. "It\'s in your\r\nblood. Or why don\'t you sweep the floors the way other women do? The way\r\nSam\'s mother must?"\r\n\r\nSimone had begun to clean the house while she was thinking, moving her\r\nhand horizontally across the floor, at the height of her hip, and the\r\ndust was following the motion of her hand and moving in a small,\r\nsun-brightened river toward the trash basket in the kitchen corner. Now\r\nSimone raised her hand to her face to look at it, and the river of dust\r\nrose like a serpent and hung a foot below her hand.\r\n\r\n"Yes," she agreed, "at least I can clean the house. If I don\'t touch the\r\ngood china, and look where I\'m going."\r\n\r\n"Phui," the old woman said again, angrily. 

"Don\'t feel so sorry for\r\nyourself."\r\n\r\n"Not for myself," Simone mumbled, and looked again toward the garden\r\nwhere her daughter was doing something with three stones and a pie plate\r\nfull of spring water.\r\n\r\n"I do despair of Nina," Cecily said, as she had said before. "She\'s\r\nfour, and has no appearance. Not even balance. She fell out of the\r\napplerose tree, and couldn\'t even help herself." Suddenly the old woman\r\nthrust her face close to her granddaughter. It was smooth, round, and\r\nsweet as a young kernel of corn. The eyes, sunk down under the bushy\r\ngrey brows, were cold and clear grey.\r\n\r\n"Simone," the old woman said. "You didn\'t lie to me? You did know she\r\nwas falling, and couldn\'t get back in time to catch her?"\r\n\r\nA shudder passed through Simone\'s body. There was no blood in her veins,\r\nonly water; no marrow in her bones, they were empty, and porous as a\r\nbird\'s. Even the roots of her hair were weak, and now the sweat was\r\nstarting out on her scalp as she faced her grandmother and saw the\r\nbristling shapes of seven generations of Putnam women behind her.\r\n\r\n"You lied," the old woman said. "You didn\'t know she was falling."\r\n\r\nSimone was a vapor, a mere froth blowing away on the first breeze.\r\n\r\n"My poor dear," the old woman said in a gentle voice. "But how could you\r\nmarry someone like Sam? Don\'t you know what will happen? 

He\'ll dissolve\r\nus, our history, our talents, our pride. Nina is nothing but an ordinary\r\nlittle child."\r\n\r\n"She\'s a good child," Simone said, trying not to be angry. She wanted\r\nher child to be loved, to be strong. "Nina isn\'t a common child," she\r\nsaid, with her head bent. "She\'s very bright."\r\n\r\n"A man with his head full of wheels, who\'s at home with electricity and\r\nwires," the old woman went on. "We\'ve had them before, but never allowed\r\nthem to dominate us. My own husband was such a man, but he was only\r\nallowed to make token gestures, such as having the power lines put in.\r\nHe never understood how they worked." She lowered her voice to a\r\nwhisper, "Your Sam understands. I\'ve heard him talk to the water pump."\r\n\r\n"That\'s why you\'re afraid of him," Simone said. "Not because I\'m weak,\r\nand he might take something away from me, but because he\'s strong, and\r\nhe might give us something. Then everything would change, and you\'re\r\nafraid of that. 

Nina might be our change." She pointed toward the\r\ngarden.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nFollowing the white line of her granddaughter\'s finger, Cecily looked\r\nout into the garden and saw Nina turn toward them as though she knew\r\nthey were angry. The child pointed with one finger directly at them in\r\nthe house. There was a sharp crackle, and something of a brilliant and\r\nvibrating blue leaped between the out-stretched fingers of mother and\r\ndaughter, and flew up like a bird to the power lines above.\r\n\r\n"Mommy," Nina called.\r\n\r\nSimone\'s heart nearly broke with wonder and fright. Her grandmother\r\ncontemptuously passed through the kitchen door and emerged on the step\r\noutside, but Simone opened the door and left it open behind her. "What\r\nwas that?" 

she asked Nina. "Was it a bluebird?"\r\n\r\n"Don\'t be silly," Nina said. She picked up the pie plate and brought it\r\ntoward them. Cecily\'s face was white and translucent, one hand went to\r\nher throat as the child approached.\r\n\r\nBrimfull of crackling blue fire with a fluctuating heart of yellow, the\r\npie plate came toward them, held between Nina\'s small, dusty hands. Nina\r\ngrinned at them. "I stole it out of the wires," she said.\r\n\r\nSimone thought she would faint with a mixture of joy and fear. "Put it\r\nback," she whispered. 

"Please put it back."\r\n\r\n"Oh Mommy," Nina said, beginning to whine. "Not now. 

Not right away. I\r\njust got it. 

I\'ve done it lots of times." The pie plate crackled and\r\nhissed in the steady, small hands.\r\n\r\nSimone could feel the old woman\'s shocked silence behind her. "You\r\nmustn\'t carry it in a pie plate, it\'s dangerous," Simone said to her\r\nchild, but she could see Nina was in no danger. "How often have you done\r\nthis?" She could feel her skirt and her hair billow with electricity.\r\n\r\n"Lots of times. You don\'t like it, do you?" She became teasing and\r\nroguish, when she looked most like Sam. Suddenly she threw back her head\r\nand opened her mouth, and tilting up the pie plate she drank it empty.\r\nHer reddish gold hair sprang out in crackling rays around her face, her\r\neyes flashed and sparks flew out between her teeth before she closed her\r\nmouth.\r\n\r\n"Nina!" the old woman cried, and began to crumple, falling slowly\r\nagainst Simone in a complete faint. Simone caught her in trembling hands\r\nand lowered her gently. She said to her daughter, "You mustn\'t do that\r\nin front of Grandy. You\'re a bad girl, you knew it would scare her," and\r\nto herself she said: I must stop babbling, the child knows I\'m being\r\nsilly. O isn\'t it wonderful, isn\'t it awful, O Sam, how I love you.\r\n\r\n"Daddy said it would scare you," Nina admitted. "That\'s why I never\r\nshowed you before." Her hair was softly falling into place again, and\r\nshe was gazing curiously at her great-grandmother lying on the doorstep.\r\n\r\n"It did scare me," Simone said. "I\'m not used to it, darling. 

But don\'t\r\nkeep it secret any more."\r\n\r\n"Is Grandy asleep?"\r\n\r\nSimone said hastily, "Oh yes, she\'s taking a nap. She is old, you know,\r\nand likes to take naps."\r\n\r\n"That\'s not a nap," Nina said, leaning over and patting the old woman\'s\r\ncheek, "I think she\'s having a bad dream."\r\n\r\nSimone carried her grandmother into the house. If that old, tired heart\r\nhad jumped and floundered like her own, there must be some damage done\r\nto it. If anything happened to her grandmother, the world would end,\r\nSimone thought, and was furious with Nina, and at the same time, full of\r\njoy for her.\r\n\r\nCecily Putnam opened her eyes widely, and Simone said, "It does change,\r\nyou see. But it\'s in the family, after all.

"\r\n\r\nThe old woman sat upright quickly. "That wicked child!" she exclaimed.\r\n"To come and frighten us like that. She ought to be spanked." She got up\r\nwith great strength and rushed out to the garden.\r\n\r\n"Nina!" she called imperiously. The child picked up one of the small\r\nstones from the pie plate now full of spring water, and came to her\r\ngreat-grandmother.\r\n\r\n"I\'ll make something for you, Grandy," she said seriously. She put the\r\nstone in the palm of her hand, and breathed on it, and then held out her\r\nhand and offered the diamond.\r\n\r\n"It\'s lovely. Thank you," the old woman said with dignity, and put her\r\nhand on the child\'s head. "Let\'s go for a walk and I\'ll show you how to\r\ngrow rose-apples. That\'s more becoming to a young lady."\r\n\r\n"You slept on the step."\r\n\r\n"Ah! I\'m old and I like to take little naps," Cecily answered.\r\n\r\nSimone saw them disappear among the applerose trees side by side. She\r\nwas still trembling, but gradually, as she passed her hand back and\r\nforth, and the dust followed, moving in a sparkling river toward the\r\ntrash basket, Simone stopped trembling and began to smile with the\r\nnatural pride of a Putnam woman.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Amazing Stories_ January 1963.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Edwardson asked, standing at the port,\r\nlooking at the stars.\r\n\r\n"No," Morse said. He had been staring fixedly at the Attison Detector\r\nfor over an hour. Now he blinked three times rapidly, and looked again.\r\n"Not a millimeter."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t think it moved either," Cassel added, from behind the gunfire\r\npanel. And that was that. The slender black hand of the indicator rested\r\nunwaveringly on zero. The ship\'s guns were ready, their black mouths\r\nopen to the stars. A steady hum filled the room. It came from the\r\nAttison Detector, and the sound was reassuring. It reinforced the fact\r\nthat the Detector was attached to all the other Detectors, forming a\r\ngigantic network around Earth.\r\n\r\n"Why in hell don\'t they come?" Edwardson asked, still looking at the\r\nstars. "Why don\'t they hit?"\r\n\r\n"Aah, shut up," Morse said. He had a tired, glum look. High on his right\r\ntemple was an old radiation burn, a sunburst of pink scar tissue. From a\r\ndistance it looked like a decoration.\r\n\r\n"I just wish they\'d come," Edwardson said. He returned from the port to\r\nhis chair, bending to clear the low metal ceiling. "Don\'t you wish\r\nthey\'d come?" Edwardson had the narrow, timid face of a mouse; but a\r\nhighly intelligent mouse. One that cats did well to avoid.\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\n"Don\'t you?" he repeated.\r\n\r\nThe other men didn\'t answer. They had settled back to their dreams,\r\nstaring hypnotically at the Detector face.\r\n\r\n"They\'ve had enough time," Edwardson said, half to himself.\r\n\r\nCassel yawned and licked his lips. "Anyone want to play some gin?" 

he\r\nasked, stroking his beard. The beard was a memento of his undergraduate\r\ndays. Cassel maintained he could store almost fifteen minutes worth of\r\noxygen in its follicles. He had never stepped into space unhelmeted to\r\nprove it.\r\n\r\nMorse looked away, and Edwardson automatically watched the indicator.\r\nThis routine had been drilled into them, branded into their\r\nsubconscious. They would as soon have cut their throats as leave the\r\nindicator unguarded.\r\n\r\n"Do you think they\'ll come soon?" Edwardson asked, his brown rodent\'s\r\neyes on the indicator. The men didn\'t answer him. After two months\r\ntogether in space their conversational powers were exhausted. They\r\nweren\'t interested in Cassel\'s undergraduate days, or in Morse\'s\r\nconquests.\r\n\r\nThey were bored to death even with their own thoughts and dreams, bored\r\nwith the attack they expected momentarily.\r\n\r\n"Just one thing _I\'d_ like to know," Edwardson said, slipping with ease\r\ninto an old conversational gambit. "How far can they do it?"\r\n\r\nThey had talked for weeks about the enemy\'s telepathic range, but they\r\nalways returned to it.\r\n\r\nAs professional soldiers, they couldn\'t help but speculate on the enemy\r\nand his weapons. It was their shop talk.\r\n\r\n"Well," Morse said wearily, "Our Detector network covers the system out\r\nbeyond Mars\' orbit."\r\n\r\n"Where we sit," Cassel said, watching the indicators now that the others\r\nwere talking.\r\n\r\n"They might not even know we have a detection unit working," Morse said,\r\nas he had said a thousand times.\r\n\r\n"Oh, stop," Edwardson said, his thin face twisted in scorn. "They\'re\r\ntelepathic. They must have read every bit of stuff in Everset\'s mind."\r\n\r\n"Everset didn\'t know we had a detection unit," Morse said, his eyes\r\nreturning to the dial. "He was captured before we had it."\r\n\r\n"Look," Edwardson said, "They ask him, \'Boy, what would you do if you\r\nknew a telepathic race was coming to take over Earth? How would you\r\nguard the planet?\'"\r\n\r\n"Idle speculation," Cassel said. "Maybe Everset didn\'t think of this.

"\r\n\r\n"He thinks like a man, doesn\'t he? Everyone agreed on this defense.\r\nEverset would, too."\r\n\r\n"Syllogistic," Cassel murmured. 

"Very shaky."\r\n\r\n"I sure wish he hadn\'t been captured," Edwardson said.\r\n\r\n"It could have been worse," Morse put in, his face sadder than ever.\r\n"What if they\'d captured _both_ of them?"\r\n\r\n"I wish they\'d come," Edwardson said.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nRichard Everset and C. R. Jones had gone on the first interstellar\r\nflight. They had found an inhabited planet in the region of Vega. The\r\nrest was standard procedure.\r\n\r\nA flip of the coin had decided it. Everset went down in the scouter,\r\nmaintaining radio contact with Jones, in the ship.\r\n\r\nThe recording of that contact was preserved for all Earth to hear.\r\n\r\n"Just met the natives," Everset said. "Funny-looking bunch. 

Give you the\r\nphysical description later.

"\r\n\r\n"Are they trying to talk to you?" Jones asked, guiding the ship in a\r\nslow spiral over the planet.\r\n\r\n"No. Hold it. 

Well I\'m damned! They\'re telepathic! How do you like\r\nthat?"\r\n\r\n"Great," Jones said. "Go on.

"\r\n\r\n"Hold it. Say, Jonesy, I don\'t know as I like these boys. They haven\'t\r\ngot nice minds. 

Brother!

"\r\n\r\n"What is it?" Jones asked, lifting the ship a little higher.\r\n\r\n"Minds! These bastards are power-crazy. Seems they\'ve hit all the\r\nsystems around here, looking for someone to--"\r\n\r\n"Yeh?"\r\n\r\n"I\'ve got that a bit wrong," Everset said pleasantly. "They are not so\r\nbad."\r\n\r\nJones had a quick mind, a suspicious nature and good reflexes. He set\r\nthe accelerator for all the G\'s he could take, lay down on the floor and\r\nsaid, "Tell me more."\r\n\r\n"Come on down," Everset said, in violation of every law of spaceflight.\r\n"These guys are all right. As a matter of fact, they\'re the most\r\nmarvelous--"\r\n\r\nThat was where the recording ended, because Jones was pinned to the\r\nfloor by twenty G\'s acceleration as he boosted the ship to the level\r\nneeded for the C-jump.\r\n\r\nHe broke three ribs getting home, but he got there.\r\n\r\nA telepathic species was on the march. What was Earth going to do about\r\nit?\r\n\r\nA lot of speculation necessarily clothed the bare bones of Jones\'\r\ninformation. Evidently the species could take over a mind with ease.\r\nWith Everset, it seemed that they had insinuated their thoughts into\r\nhis, delicately altering his previous convictions. They had possessed\r\nhim with remarkable ease.\r\n\r\nHow about Jones? Why hadn\'t they taken him? Was distance a factor? Or\r\nhadn\'t they been prepared for the suddenness of his departure?\r\n\r\nOne thing was certain. Everything Everset knew, the enemy knew. That\r\nmeant they knew where Earth was, and how defenseless the planet was to\r\ntheir form of attack.\r\n\r\nIt could be expected that they were on their way.\r\n\r\nSomething was needed to nullify their tremendous advantage. But what\r\nsort of something? 

What armor is there against thought? How do you dodge\r\na wavelength?\r\n\r\nPouch-eyed scientists gravely consulted their periodic tables.\r\n\r\nAnd how do you know when a man has been possessed? Although the enemy\r\nwas clumsy with Everset, would they continue to be clumsy? Wouldn\'t they\r\nlearn?\r\n\r\nPsychologists tore their hair and bewailed the absence of an absolute\r\nscale for humanity.\r\n\r\nOf course, something had to be done at once. The answer, from a\r\ntechnological planet, was a technological one. Build a space fleet and\r\nequip it with some sort of a detection-fire network.\r\n\r\nThis was done in record time. The Attison Detector was developed, a\r\ncross between radar and the electroencephalograph. Any alteration from\r\nthe typical human brain wave pattern of the occupants of a\r\nDetector-equipped ship would boost the indicator around the dial. Even a\r\nbad dream or a case of indigestion would jar it.\r\n\r\nIt seemed probable that any attempt to take over a human mind would\r\ndisturb something. There had to be a point of interaction, somewhere.\r\n\r\nThat was what the Attison Detector was supposed to detect. Maybe it\r\nwould.\r\n\r\nThe spaceships, three men to a ship, dotted space between Earth and\r\nMars, forming a gigantic sphere with Earth in the center.\r\n\r\nTens of thousands of men crouched behind gunfire panels, watching the\r\ndials on the Attison Detector.\r\n\r\nThe unmoving dials.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Do you think I could fire a couple of bursts?" Edwardson asked, his\r\nfingers on the gunfire button. "Just to limber the guns?"\r\n\r\n"Those guns don\'t need limbering," Cassel said, stroking his beard.\r\n"Besides, you\'d throw the whole fleet into a panic."\r\n\r\n"Cassel," Morse said, very quietly. "Get your hand off your beard."\r\n\r\n"Why should I?" Cassel asked.\r\n\r\n"Because," Morse answered, almost in a whisper, "I am about to ram it\r\nright down your fat throat."\r\n\r\nCassel grinned and tightened his fists. 

"Pleasure," he said. "I\'m tired\r\nof looking at that scar of yours." He stood up.\r\n\r\n"Cut it," Edwardson said wearily. "Watch the birdie."\r\n\r\n"No reason to, really," Morse said, leaning back. "There\'s an alarm bell\r\nattached." But he looked at the dial.\r\n\r\n"What if the bell doesn\'t work?" Edwardson asked. "What if the dial is\r\njammed? How would you like something cold slithering into your mind?"\r\n\r\n"The dial\'ll work," Cassel said. His eyes shifted from Edwardson\'s face\r\nto the motionless indicator.\r\n\r\n"I think I\'ll sack in," Edwardson said.\r\n\r\n"Stick around," Cassel said. "Play you some gin."\r\n\r\n"All right." Edwardson found and shuffled the greasy cards, while Morse\r\ntook a turn glaring at the dial.\r\n\r\n"I sure wish they\'d come," he said.\r\n\r\n"Cut," Edwardson said, handing the pack to Cassel.\r\n\r\n"I wonder what our friends look like," Morse said, watching the dial.\r\n\r\n"Probably remarkably like us," Edwardson said, dealing the cards. Cassel\r\npicked them up one by one, slowly, as if he hoped something interesting\r\nwould be under them.\r\n\r\n"They should have given us another man," Cassel said. "We could play\r\nbridge."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t play bridge," Edwardson said.\r\n\r\n"You could learn."\r\n\r\n"Why didn\'t we send a task force?" Morse asked. "Why didn\'t we bomb\r\ntheir planet?"\r\n\r\n"Don\'t be dumb," Edwardson said. "We\'d lose any ship we sent. Probably\r\nget them back at us, possessed and firing."\r\n\r\n"Knock with nine," Cassel said.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t give a good damn if you knock with a thousand," Edwardson said\r\ngaily. "How much do I owe you now?"\r\n\r\n"Three million five hundred and eight thousand and ten. Dollars."\r\n\r\n"I sure wish they\'d come," Morse said.\r\n\r\n"Want me to write a check?"\r\n\r\n"Take your time. Take until next week."\r\n\r\n"Someone should reason with the bastards," Morse said, looking out the\r\nport. Cassel immediately looked at the dial.\r\n\r\n"I just thought of something," Edwardson said.\r\n\r\n"Yeh?"\r\n\r\n"I bet it feels horrible to have your mind grabbed," Edwardson said. "I\r\nbet it\'s awful."\r\n\r\n"You\'ll know when it happens," Cassel said.\r\n\r\n"Did Everset?"\r\n\r\n"Probably. He just couldn\'t do anything about it."\r\n\r\n"My mind feels fine," Cassel said. "But the first one of you guys starts\r\nacting queer--watch out."\r\n\r\nThey all laughed.\r\n\r\n"Well," Edwardson said, "I\'d sure like a chance to reason with them.\r\nThis is stupid."\r\n\r\n"Why not?" Cassel asked.\r\n\r\n"You mean go out and meet _them_?"\r\n\r\n"Sure," Cassel said. "We\'re doing no good sitting here."\r\n\r\n"I should think we could do something," Edwardson said slowly. "After\r\nall, they\'re not invincible. They\'re reasoning beings."\r\n\r\nMorse punched a course on the ship\'s tape, then looked up.\r\n\r\n"You think we should contact the command? Tell them what we\'re doing?"\r\n\r\n"No!" Cassel said, and Edwardson nodded in agreement. "Red tape. We\'ll\r\njust go out and see what we can do. 

If they won\'t talk, we\'ll blast \'em\r\nout of space."\r\n\r\n"Look!"\r\n\r\nOut of the port they could see the red flare of a reaction engine; the\r\nnext ship in their sector, speeding forward.\r\n\r\n"They must have got the same idea," Edwardson said.\r\n\r\n"Let\'s get there first," Cassel said. Morse shoved the accelerator in\r\nand they were thrown back in their seats.\r\n\r\n"That dial hasn\'t moved yet, has it?" Edwardson asked, over the clamor\r\nof the Detector alarm bell.\r\n\r\n"Not a move out of it," Cassel said, looking at the dial with its\r\nindicator slammed all the way over to the highest notch.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Space Science Fiction_ September 1953.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed.
