]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n            They awoke after ages of hiding--to emerge into\r\n            a world richer than they had dared to dream of!\r\n\r\n\r\nRik\'s first impressions were an uncomfortable chill creeping along his\r\nbare flesh, and a bright milky swirling of light that encompassed his\r\nentire vision. He shivered and blinked his eyes a few times, and then\r\nthe swirling settled down and became the vault. The chill, he realized,\r\nwas due to the body warmth being methodically sucked away by the cold\r\nslab on which he lay. Another shiver brought a gasp of breath into his\r\nlungs, and then he was wide awake.\r\n\r\nWhen he sat up and swung his legs over the side, the interior of the\r\nvault began swirling again. He had to grip the edge of the slab to keep\r\nfrom falling. The air was humid, much too humid, and he could taste the\r\nprickly presence of carbon dioxide when he breathed. "The pump," he\r\nmumbled, dropping to the floor on feet that he could barely control.\r\n"Something\'s happened to the pump."\r\n\r\nHe pushed himself determinedly erect, then stumbled down the long\r\ncorridor between the other slabs, hardly glancing at their silent\r\ntenants, until he got to Zina\'s. She lay still as death, not flicking\r\nso much as an eyelid, and her flesh was like frozen wax beneath his\r\nexploring fingers.\r\n\r\nThere was nothing he could do for her until he got the pump working\r\nagain....\r\n\r\nRik pushed away from the slab on which Zina lay, and went through the\r\narchway into the next chamber. Here another fifty of the group lay on\r\ntheir slabs, not so much as a muscle twitch betraying the fact that\r\nthey were all quite alive. It seemed only a few hours since he had lain\r\ndown on his slab in the other room and gotten his injection, but he\r\ncould not, for a dizzy moment, recall in which direction the pump lay.\r\nHis mind seemed to be plumbing dust-covered depths to dredge out his\r\nmemories, one by one.\r\n\r\nHe suddenly remembered the War. The war that had driven the group to\r\nbuild this place, to try and safeguard a handful from the holocaust\r\nthat would set fire to the surface of the world and turn the seas to\r\nsteam. Was it possible the war had passed? Or had it ever come!\r\n\r\nThere was no way to know without going outside--Wait! 

There was!\r\nRik thought hard, trying to get his sense of direction back. The\r\natom-powered clock that marked off months instead of minutes was in the\r\ncentral vault, where the elders slept. The other nine vaults ringed\r\nthat one, he recalled, veering at right angles to his first direction,\r\nwhich would have taken him on a circular tour of the nine vaults and\r\nback to his starting place again.\r\n\r\nThe archway to the vault of the elders was unaccountably blocked,\r\nand Rik realized suddenly that part of the ceiling there had fallen,\r\ncarried by some fault in the granite of the mountain itself. But that\r\nwas impossible! 

The elders had selected this site on the basis of the\r\nrigidity of the rocky strata that made it up. A fault could not have\r\noccurred for more years than Rik\'s own lifetime--\r\n\r\nOr had that many years passed already?\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThere was no way of knowing; not until he had examined the clock. Rik\r\nmoved away from the blockade and made his way into the next vault, and\r\nthe next, finally finding an archway in the sixth vault from his own\r\nwhere the rock had not completely sealed the way into the elders\' vault.\r\n\r\nHere he had expected to find the air fresher, already having theorized\r\nthat the staleness elsewhere was due to the poor circulation occasioned\r\nby the blockaded central vault. But in fact the air there was even\r\nworse, and laden with an odor that made Rik suddenly afraid to see its\r\nsource.\r\n\r\nStill, he was the first to awake. It was up to him to try and save\r\nhimself and the others. Rik made an effort of will, and then squeezed\r\nthrough the narrow orifice into the main chamber. He looked once toward\r\nthe slabs holding the bodies of the elders, then quickly away. It was\r\ntrue. All were in advanced stages of corruption already.\r\n\r\nChoking, Rik went to the center of the high room and looked into the\r\nhorizontal face of the clock. The broad indicator arm was at its\r\nutmost numeral, and was pocked with rust. They\'d lain here beyond the\r\ntime-of-awakening by at least four times the years they\'d planned!\r\n\r\n"It can\'t be right," Rik gasped, his brain reeling for want of clean,\r\ncool air. "The mechanism has failed somehow." Afraid to think about it,\r\nhe tilted the clock up on its base until the pedestal which supported\r\nit lay on its side upon the floor. The square block of metal that\r\nbased the pedestal was now uptilted beyond the vertical, exposing a\r\ngaping trap in the floor. Rik did not like the tarnished look of the\r\nmetal underside of the pedestal-base, forged of an alloy supposed\r\nto be incorruptible. A sick thought took hold of his insides then,\r\nas he placed one foot upon the rocky staircase under the floor. The\r\nclock-indicator had halted at its utmost numeral.\r\n\r\nBut what if they\'d lain here even longer than that? There would be no\r\nway of knowing. No way at all.\r\n\r\nHe descended the staircase swiftly then, glad at least that the air\r\nwas better down in the pump chamber. "It would be, of course," he\r\nreminded himself, "if the pump went off, even. This air would never\r\nbe circulated, never have its chance to become corrupt with our\r\nexhalations." And then his musing was halted in midthought as he came\r\nupon the pump. Or upon what had been the pump.\r\n\r\nWhere rigid cylinders of gleaming metal had been, a few jagged teeth of\r\nbrown corruption lay in a circle. The pistons were no better, though\r\ntheir thickness had preserved more of their original shape despite the\r\ninroads of age, so they could be recognized for what they were--had\r\nbeen. The central shaft was a long mound of flaking dust on the floor\r\nbetween the path of the pistons, and the wall-sized mass of the\r\nfilters--woven of metal and powerful synthetic fibers--crumbled beneath\r\nthe pressure of his finger.\r\n\r\nHe sought and found the ponderous casing in which the engine-empowering\r\nradioactive element had lain, and its thick walls tore away like wood\r\npulp in his hands. The element, when he found it, was already become\r\ncold grey lead. And it had had a half-life of centuries....\r\n\r\nRik crumpled slowly to the floor, shutting his eyes, trying not to\r\nthink of the eons which must have passed while they all lay sleeping\r\nthe pseudodeath in the vaults. What might the world have become in the\r\ninterim!\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nA current of cool air suddenly touched his face. His head came up\r\ninstantly, his eyes seeking the source.\r\n\r\nA feathery motion of torn edges in the filter showed him that it came\r\nthrough the gap he had torn there. Rik sprang to his feet then, leaped\r\nat the filter and tore out chunks by the armful, letting the pulverized\r\nmaterial float in spinning clouds of dust motes behind him. The air\r\ngrew stronger, came faster, as he ripped away the corruption, and then\r\nhe could see the tunnel beyond.\r\n\r\nGasping at the effort--how long since he had eaten?--he staggered\r\nback from the opening then back up the stairs into the chamber of the\r\nelders. Now that his nostrils had been stimulated by the clean air the\r\nsmell of corruption was violently repelling; but he held his breath and\r\nran to the gap in the tumbled rock about the archway, and squeezed his\r\nway into the area of subsidiary vaults.\r\n\r\nWithout the pump in operation, the air could not circulate to this\r\npoint, but he hoped to drag some of his companions down to the torn\r\nfilter and revive them--then, with their help, bring the others.\r\n\r\nIt would be all right. They would be saved, as planned. He regretted\r\nthe loss of the elders. But no matter. 

They were but the rulers. He\r\nand the others were the chemists, the scientists, the engineers. New\r\nelderships could be created when they had become settled again, and\r\ncould rebuild their civilization.\r\n\r\nHe went to Zina\'s slab first. She would not be as much help as some of\r\nthe others, but Zina and he were too close for him to delay her revival\r\nany longer. Life was not worth having without Zina. He carried her out\r\nof the vault, through the gap and thick miasma of corruption, then down\r\ninto the pump chamber. Leaving her lying on her back, with the breeze\r\nruffling her hair about her face, Rik went back up for the next person.\r\n\r\nThree exhausting trips later, he sat among the bodies of his friends,\r\nlistening with joy to their returning quiver of breath and life. Zina\r\nwas the first to open her eyes. She seemed startled to find she was no\r\nlonger on the slab, and then joyous when her glance fell upon his eager\r\nface.\r\n\r\n"We\'ve done it!" she sighed. "We came through!" She tried to sit up,\r\nthen lay down heavily. "Rik--I\'m so weak...."\r\n\r\n"We need food, all of us," he said. "I\'m weak myself." He arose from\r\nhis crouch at her side and stared down the tunnel to the outer world.\r\n"I don\'t know what it\'s like out there," he said. "There may be no food\r\nat all. If the War was as devastating as predicted, it may be barren\r\nrock, burning sun and overall death.

"\r\n\r\n"How long--?" Zina began, and then her eyes fell upon the time-rotted\r\nhulk of the pump and she stopped, her face going pale. "As long as\r\nthat!" 

she whispered. "Oh, Rik! Do you think--?

"\r\n\r\n"I\'ll know when I\'ve looked," he said. Their eyes met for a long,\r\nsilent moment, then he turned and started up the tunnel.\r\n\r\nThree hundred strides brought him to the barrier, the thinly\r\nperforated shield of rock that had been left intact to hide the\r\nlocation of the vaults from their enemies. Rik put his shoulder to the\r\nshell. It cracked and fell away as he\'d thought it would, with weather\r\nand erosion having weakened it for centuries. Bright yellow moonlight\r\nlay all about the land outside. Incredibly fine sand was everywhere,\r\nbut a smell of fresh water and green growing things was mingled with\r\nthe night air. The region had not been desert when the vaults were\r\nconstructed. The War had left its mark of devastation here, Rik saw,\r\nlooking in vain for a trace of the magnificent towered city that had\r\nonce been just beyond this spot.\r\n\r\nHe shook off his dismay and set himself to the task for which he\'d\r\nemerged.\r\n\r\nThe animals had to be alive, yet, or they were doomed. He\'d always\r\nregretted the haste in their preparations that had precluded preparing\r\nsurvival vaults for the food animals. The best they\'d been able to do,\r\nbefore the Day of Devastation, was herd the stupid beasts into caves\r\nand pile the entrances with loose rock, hoping the animals would dig\r\nthemselves out only after the worst fury of the War had passed.... Rik\r\nthrew off the bitter memory, abruptly, as his ears detected a tiny buzz\r\nof sound.\r\n\r\nHe dropped to the ground and lay still, watching to see what sort of\r\nbeast would appear. It sounded larger than the animals he remembered.\r\n"I must be near a waterhole," he reasoned. "There\'s a pathway here,\r\nmade by many animals passing this way...." he mused, studying the\r\nnarrow, flattened track that he\'d spotted in the night-chilled sand.\r\n\r\nThen he saw something coming slowly up the trail, a thing much larger\r\nthan the animals he remembered.\r\n\r\nIt was a long moment before he realized what it was, and smiled. Then\r\nhe reached out his hands and had it. 

It buzzed loudly in his grip until\r\nhe pounded it to silence on a rock. By the time he\'d returned to the\r\npump chamber, he\'d managed to prise it open, but its contents--mangled\r\nby the smashing upon the rock--were barely fit to eat.\r\n\r\n"It\'s better than I could have hoped," he said to Zina, when they and\r\nthe others had picked the thing clean. "Life promises to be much more\r\nexciting, infinitely more sporting in this new age outside the vaults.\r\nWith care, we can survive until our engineers rig up some whip-rays and\r\nherding-claws again."\r\n\r\n"It _will_ be fun," Zina agreed, smiling with grim anticipation. "I\r\nenjoy a challenge in the hunt. 

Who\'d have thought the animals would\r\nhave come so _far_ from the caves!"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIt was hours later that the bus company grew worried about their\r\nmissing vehicle, and started an investigation. But they could find no\r\ntrace of the bus, anywhere, and it remained a mystery until the day\r\neverybody suddenly knew what had happened.\r\n\r\nBut that was far too late.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


He waved at the bystanders. "Clear a path through here; I\'m\r\ntakin\' my prisoner over to the jail."\r\n\r\n"Jest a dad-blamed minute, Sheriff." Stump\'s face was pale, his\r\nglasses were gone and one khaki shoulder strap dangled--but what was\r\nalmost a grin twisted one meaty cheek. He hid his hands behind his\r\nback, leaned away from the cuffs. "I don\'t like that word \'prisoner\'.\r\nI ast you fer pertection. And better look out who you go throwin\' that\r\nword \'murder\' off at, too. 

I ain\'t murdered nobody."\r\n\r\nThe sheriff blinked, turned to roar, "How\'s the victim, Doc?"\r\n\r\nA small gray head rose from bending over the limp form of the Fianna.\r\n"Deader\'n a mackerel, Sheriff."\r\n\r\n"I guess that\'s it. 

Let\'s go, Cecil."\r\n\r\n"What\'s the charge?"\r\n\r\n"First degree murder."\r\n\r\n"Who\'d I murder?"\r\n\r\n"Why, you killed this here ... this stranger."\r\n\r\n"That ain\'t no stranger. That\'s a varmint. Murder\'s got to do with\r\nkillin\' humerns, way I understand it. "Well, let\'s see," he began.\r\n"Technically--"\r\n\r\n"Good Lord!" 

someone blurted. "You mean the laws on murder don\'t define\r\nwhat constitutes--I mean, what--"\r\n\r\n"What a humern is?" Stump snorted. Ain\'t no\r\ndifferent killin\' it than any other critter."\r\n\r\n"Then, by God, we\'ll get him for malicious damage," a man called. "Or\r\nhunting without a license--out of season!"\r\n\r\n"--carrying concealed weapons!"\r\n\r\nStump went for his hip pocket, fumbled out a fat, shapeless wallet,\r\nextracted a thumbed rectangle of folded paper, offered it.\r\n\r\n"I\'m a licensed exterminator. And at no charge to the county."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nA smaller man with bristly red hair flared his nostrils at Stump.\r\n"You blood-thirsty idiot!" "Let\'s not go gettin\'\r\nno lynch talk started."\r\n\r\n"Lynch, is it!" Cecil Stump bellowed, his face suddenly red. "Why, I\r\ndone a favor for every man here! Now you listen to me! 

What is that\r\nthing over there?" He jerked a blunt thumb toward the judicial bench.\r\n"It\'s some kind of critter from Mars or someplace--you know that as\r\nwell as me! And what\'s it here for? 

It ain\'t for the good of the likes\r\nof you and me, I can tell you that. It\'s them or us. And this time, by\r\nGod, we got in the first lick!"\r\n\r\n"Why you ... you ... hate-monger!

"\r\n\r\n"Now, hold on right there. I\'m as liberal-minded as the next feller.\r\nHell, I like a nigger--and I can\'t hardly tell a Jew from a white man.\r\nBut when it comes to takin\' in a damned purple worm and callin\' it\r\nhumern--that\'s where I draw the line."\r\n\r\nSheriff Hoskins pushed between Stump and the surging front rank of the\r\ncrowd. 

"Stay back there! Send it around to my\r\nplace when you\'re done with it." "Quiet, everybody. There\'ll be reporters\r\nhere in a matter of minutes. Maybe our ordinance won\'t hold water. "He\'s vermin."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nOn the courthouse steps Cecil Stump stood, hands in hip pockets,\r\ntalking to a reporter from the big-town paper in Mattoon, surrounded\r\nby a crowd of late-comers who had missed the excitement inside. "Who\'re\r\nyou?"\r\n\r\nThe man reached the foot of the steps, raised the revolver and cocked\r\nit with a thumb.\r\n\r\n"I\'m the new exterminator," he said.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


I don\'t\r\nwant to give you the impression that peanuts are in short supply here,\r\nor that our economy is in the fix of having to import them sidewise.\r\nWhat I\'m trying to convey is that, if you\'re one of the rare ones\r\nfunctionally equipped to do the side-shuffle, you ought to be well\r\npaid for it--in any coin.\r\n\r\nThat\'s what I told Krasnow. And he wasn\'t after peanuts. "I\'ll do it,"\r\nI said, "if you\'ll make it worth my while."\r\n\r\n"I\'d hardly expect you to do it for nothing," he replied\r\nreproachfully. "How much do you want?"\r\n\r\nI told him. The amount shook him up, but only briefly.\r\n\r\n"Okay," he said grudgingly. "I suppose I\'ll have to give it to you.\r\nBut the stuff had better be good."\r\n\r\n"Oh, it is," I assured him. "And you don\'t have to be afraid, because\r\nI couldn\'t possibly skip with the loot. I\'ll have to travel naked. I\r\ncan\'t get there with so much as a sandal on one foot or a filling in a\r\nsingle tooth. 

Fortunately, my teeth are perfect."\r\n\r\nSweat poured off Krasnow\'s florid face as he worked the combination of\r\nhis office safe. His fat jowls quivered unhappily around his cigar\r\nwhile he counted out the bills. Ten per cent was cash in advance, and\r\nthe rest went into a bank account in my name. I paid off a batch of\r\nbills, then stripped and did my off-to-Buffalo.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Honest" John Krasnow was a crooked District Attorney who wanted to be\r\nGovernor and then President. He had the Machine, but he didn\'t have\r\nthe People. 

And, because he needed the People, he needed me. I had\r\nbeen to this other dimension--the one on the farthest branch of the\r\ntime-tree--and I could give him what he wanted.\r\n\r\nKrasnow found out about it after I was hauled up in front of him on a\r\ncheck-kiting charge. I\'d had something of a reputation before I got\r\ninto difficulties and, in trying to live up to the reputation, I had\r\ndone some plain and fancy financing. Nothing that fifteen to twenty\r\ngrand wouldn\'t have fixed--but while I scrounged around, trying to get\r\ncash, I kited a few checks. They pyramided me right into the D.A.\'s\r\noffice, where Krasnow was properly sympathetic.\r\n\r\n"How," he asked, "could a man of your standing in the scientific world\r\nstoop so low?" It developed into quite a lecture and, even coming from\r\nKrasnow, it made me feel pretty low.\r\n\r\nSo I began explaining. I told him where I was born, and where I went\r\nto school, and where I had taken my sabbaticals--including this other\r\ndimension. And Krasnow believed me. I can\'t account for it, except\r\npossibly because he knew he was a crook and knew I wasn\'t\r\none--exactly. Anyway, he believed me, and we made the deal and I did\r\nthe side-shuffle, as agreed.\r\n\r\nThe journey to that other dimension is not a pleasant one. It does\r\ndisturbing things to the stomach, and you see everything thin and\r\nelongated, as if you\'re sitting too far to the side in a movie\r\ntheater.\r\n\r\nI got there, however, and waited for the hiccups to subside. _Hiccupi\r\nlaterali_, I had called them when I considered writing an article for\r\nthe _Medical Journal_ after my first trip. With the hiccupi gone, I\r\nstole some clothing--which was one of the riskiest parts of the\r\nprogram--and waited for morning. I didn\'t have any money, of course,\r\nso I had to hitchhike into town.\r\n\r\nI could have stolen myself a better fit, but people aren\'t\r\nclothes-conscious in that dimension. They\'re more interested in what\r\nyou are and what you can do. 

The driver of the car that gave me a lift\r\nasked, "And what is your field of endeavor?"\r\n\r\nI told him, "I am able to eliminate the long wait in ivory production\r\nby accelerating the growth cycle of elephants."\r\n\r\nHe was deeply impressed and tipped me handsomely. I was less impressed\r\nwith his talent for growing cobless corn, and therefore had to return\r\nonly a small part of the sum he gave me.\r\n\r\nThe world of this dimension had developed some remarkable parallels to\r\nEarth. I mean our Earth, which falls into what I have designated\r\nTimeline One Point One, since it\'s the Earth with which I am most\r\nfamiliar. Every other world that has a language calls itself Earth,\r\ntoo. I had to visit briefly hundreds of the lateral worlds, hovering\r\nover primordial swamps, limitless oceans, insect kingdoms and\r\nradioactive planetoids, before I found the one that was truly\r\nparallel.\r\n\r\nIt existed in Timeline Seventeen Point Zero Eight, and it had\r\nrefrigerators, platinum blondes, automobiles, airplanes, apple pie,\r\ntabloids, television, scotch and soda--just about everything we think\r\nmakes life worthwhile. But it had its little differences, which was\r\nonly to be expected in a timeline where the bionomics could create a\r\nnew world each time someone changed his mind.\r\n\r\nThus, the cobless-corn man was driving what looked to me like a\r\nChevrolet, but which was a Morton in his world. He let me off near a\r\ndowntown restaurant where, thanks to our little exchange of talent\r\ntalk, I had enough money for breakfast. It was considered unethical to\r\nswap talent talk outside the limits of certain rigidly defined groups,\r\nso I didn\'t try to out-impress the waitress.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nFed, and filling my stolen clothes a bit better, I walked to the\r\nrecorder\'s office and spent the rest of the morning looking up old\r\ndocuments. There was nothing there for Krasnow, as I had expected. But\r\nfor me there was a very pretty file clerk. Talking to her, I verified\r\nmy impression that human instincts and relationships were much the\r\nsame in this dimension as in my own--except in the one basic respect\r\nthat interested Krasnow, of course.\r\n\r\nThe file clerk and I lunched together and then I spent the afternoon\r\nin the library. But I didn\'t find anything there, either, and then I\r\nhad dinner with her. She said her name was Julie. I told her mine was\r\nHeck, for Hector, which it is. She thought this was "awfully cute" and\r\nwe got along fine.\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\nJulie had a delightful apartment and a matching sense of hospitality.\r\nThe following day, when she went to work, I stayed home and washed the\r\ndishes and made the bed and used the telephone.\r\n\r\nI ran up quite a bill with my long-distance calls, but I found out\r\nwhat I needed to know. I impressed a lot of people with my elephant\r\nstory and pretended to be impressed hardly at all with what they told\r\nme they did--although often I was, very much.\r\n\r\nThe trouble with these people is that they no longer know how to lie,\r\nif that can be listed as trouble. I don\'t think it can. 

Neither did\r\nKrasnow, obviously. He\'d never have sent me off on my expensive\r\nside-trip if he had.\r\n\r\nOf course, Krasnow looked at it objectively. What he wanted from\r\nTimeline Seventeen Point Zero Eight was not for himself. 

It was for\r\neverybody else. He wanted the formula for the truth gas these people\r\nhad developed long ago and loosed upon their world to put a stop to\r\nwars.\r\n\r\nThey had been in a bad way, although no worse than the sort of problem\r\nwe were up against. Their trans-ocean squabbles and power politics\r\nseemed to have settled into a pattern of a war or two per generation.\r\nJust like us. Hence, the man who invented the truth gas became a\r\nglobal hero, after a certain amount of cynicism and skepticism. All\r\nthe doubts vanished, naturally, once the gas got to working. And so\r\ndid war.\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\nYou can\'t do much plotting and scheming if, every time you open your\r\nmouth to tell a lie, you stammer, sweat, turn red and gasp for breath.\r\nIt\'s a dead giveaway. Nobody tries it more than once.\r\n\r\nOne or two men had tried to nullify the gas or work out a local\r\nantidote, either as a pure research project or through power-madness.\r\nBut, because they had had to state their purposes as soon as they\r\nthought of them, they were put away. Neat. Very neat.\r\n\r\nWhat I wanted was the formula for the truth gas. Its location wasn\'t\r\nexactly a secret in this land of complete candor, but it wasn\'t writ\r\nlarge on any wall for all to see, either. They kept it in their\r\ncapital--located about where our Omaha is--on file among the Vital\r\nStatistics.\r\n\r\nI took a superjet out there.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI had no trouble posing as a historian entitled to the facts. The gas\r\ndidn\'t work on me, you see, because it was adjusted to the physiology\r\nof that timeline. There was just enough difference between us for it\r\nnot to make me stick to the truth.\r\n\r\n"We\'ll write out the formula for you," I was told obligingly. "But\r\nyou\'ll have to sign the usual statement."\r\n\r\n"Of course," I said. 

"Which one is that?"\r\n\r\n"The one that says you won\'t publish it, and will destroy your copy\r\nwhen it has served your research purpose, without letting anyone else\r\nsee it."\r\n\r\n"Oh, _that_ statement," I said.\r\n\r\nI signed freely, told my elephant story and departed in an aura of\r\ngood will.\r\n\r\nThe jet got me back that same evening. Julie fixed me up a snack, and\r\nwe discussed how pretty she was and how nice I was.\r\n\r\nI had everything Krasnow wanted now. I felt pretty good about it,\r\nbecause there was nobody else who could have done the job for him, and\r\nbecause it wasn\'t spying, really. Earth One Point One on the Timeline\r\nis world enough for Krasnow, I\'m sure. Besides, dimensions don\'t have\r\nwars with one another. Too many things can go wrong.\r\n\r\nJulie was lovely and I hated to leave the next morning, but it was my\r\njob. I told her, "I\'m afraid I have to leave town for a bit, dear, but\r\nI\'ll be back very soon. 

Business, you know."\r\n\r\nBeing a Seventeen Point Zero Eight girl, Julie had no reason to doubt\r\nme. "Make it _very_ soon," she whispered, her lips close to my ear.\r\n\r\nSo I came back, and now Krasnow has what he wants. He\'s delighted, as\r\nhe should be. 

I\'ve made up the gas for him and adjusted the formula so\r\nthat it will work on people of our timeline. It\'s high-power stuff and\r\na little will go a long way. I also made up an antidote for him. This\r\nwas easy, since I could work on it without feeling any compulsion to\r\ntell everybody what I was doing and why.\r\n\r\nKrasnow plans to release the truth gas just before the state\r\nconvention. He\'ll be nominated, of course, and after November he\'ll\r\nbe Governor. With everyone else compelled to tell the truth, it should\r\nbe a cinch for him. He\'s a patient man, Honest John Krasnow is, and\r\nhe\'s willing to wait four years for the Presidency.\r\n\r\nI ought to be happy too. With the money Krasnow gave me, I\'ve been\r\nliving in the style to which I\'ve always wanted to be accustomed. He\r\nhas offered me a place on his staff and, somewhat superfluously, the\r\nuse of his antidote. Naturally, the reason he was so magnanimous was\r\nthat he doesn\'t want anyone else around who knows his gimmick and\r\nmight have to tell the truth about it.\r\n\r\nBut I have had enough of this dimension now--now that Krasnow has what\r\nI promised him. He\'s going to use it tomorrow. And if I know Honest\r\nJohn--and I do--not even the Presidency will be big enough for him.\r\n\r\nSo I\'m going back to Julie.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThere are some obvious questions in your mind, I know, such as: Why\r\ndid I get the formula for Krasnow, knowing there was no way for him to\r\nprosecute me while I was in Julie\'s dimension? And what made me come\r\nback?\r\n\r\nIn short--what was in it for me?\r\n\r\nLet\'s call it research. Krasnow is a big-time operator; I\'ve always\r\nbeen, you might say, in the peanut end of the game. He had a great\r\ndeal to teach me and I, I\'m happy to say, was an apt pupil. You might\r\nspeculate on what\'s in it for you, because, if you ask me, anybody who\r\ncan do the side-shuffle should do it before Krasnow becomes President.\r\n\r\nHowever, don\'t go to Seventeen Point Zero Eight unless you want to\r\nswap one Krasnow for another. The fact is that I\'ve learned I can be\r\none in Julie\'s dimension. After all, their formula doesn\'t work on\r\nme--but I can assure you that it will work on you.\r\n\r\nAnd that elephant story I told on my last visit is, as I\'ve indicated,\r\nin the peanut category. All Krasnow has is a country. I\'ll have a\r\nwhole world.\r\n\r\nThere\'s nothing like study under a master, is there?\r\n\r\nI should be back to Julie by midnight if I start now.\r\n\r\n--RICHARD WILSON\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


"More than a\r\nmile long, and wider than hell." 

He waved his hands expansively. "She\'s\r\nnever touched down on Earth, you know. Never will. Too big for that.\r\nThey built her on the moon. 

The cost? Well ..."\r\n\r\nSwiveling his chair around, Heselton slowly surveyed the ship\'s control\r\nroom with a small, satisfied smile. The two pilots sitting far forward,\r\nalmost hidden by their banks of instruments, the radar operators idly\r\nwatching their scopes, the three flight engineers sitting intently at\r\ntheir enormous control consoles, and, just behind, the radio shack--its\r\nclosed door undoubtedly hiding a game of cards. For weeks now, as Big\r\nJoe moved across the galaxy\'s uncharted fringe, the radio bands had been\r\ncompletely dead, except, of course, for the usual star static hissing\r\nand burbling in the background.\r\n\r\nTurning back again to his navigator, Heselton smiled modestly and noted\r\nthat Big Joe was undisputedly the largest, most powerful, most feared,\r\nand most effective spaceship in the known universe.\r\n\r\nAs always, Rogers nodded agreement. The fact that he\'d heard it a\r\nhundred times didn\'t make it any less true. Big Joe, armed with every\r\nweapon known to Terran technology, was literally the battleship to end\r\nall battleships. Ending battleships--and battles--was, in fact, her job.\r\nAnd she did it well. For the first time, the galaxy was at peace.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWith a relaxed sigh, Heselton leaned back to gaze at the stars and\r\ncontemplate the vastness of the universe, compared to which even Big Joe\r\nwas an insignificant dot.\r\n\r\n"Well," said Rogers, "time for another course check. I\'ll ..." He jumped\r\nback, barely avoiding the worried lieutenant who exploded upon them from\r\nthe radio shack.\r\n\r\n"A signal, sir! Damn close, on the VHF band, their transmission is\r\ncompletely overriding the background noise." He waved excitedly to\r\nsomeone in the radio shack and an overhead speaker came to life emitting\r\na distinct clacking-grunting sound. 

"It\'s audio of some sort, sir, but\r\nthere\'s lots more to the signal than that."\r\n\r\nIn one motion Heselton\'s chair snapped forward, his right fist hit the\r\nred emergency alert button on his desk, and his left snapped on the\r\nship\'s intercom. Lights dimmed momentarily as powerful emergency drive\r\nunits snapped into action, and the ship echoed with the sound of two\r\nthousand men running to battle stations.\r\n\r\n"Bridge to radar! Report."\r\n\r\n"Radar to bridge. All clear."\r\n\r\nHeselton stared incredulously at the intercom. "What?"\r\n\r\n"Radar to bridge, repeating. All clear. Admiral, we\'ve got two men on\r\nevery scope, there\'s nothing anywhere."\r\n\r\nA new voice cut in on the speaker. 

"Radio track to bridge."\r\n\r\nFrowning, Heselton answered. "Bridge. Come in radio track. We\'re\r\nlistening."\r\n\r\n"Sir," the crisp voice of the radio track section\'s commander had an\r\nexcited tinge. "Sir, Doppler calculations show that the source of those\r\nsignals is slowing down somewhere to our right. It\'s acting like a\r\nspaceship, sir, that\'s coming to a halt."\r\n\r\nThe admiral locked eyes with Rogers for a second, then shrugged. "Slow\r\nthe ship, and circle right. Radio track, can you keep me posted on the\r\nobject\'s position?"\r\n\r\n"No can do, sir. Doppler effect can\'t be used on a slow moving source.\r\nIt\'s still off to our right, but that\'s the best I can say."\r\n\r\n"Sir," another voice chimed in, "this is fire control. We\'ve got our\r\ndirectional antennas on the thing. It\'s either directly right or\r\ndirectly left of the ship, matching speed with us exactly."\r\n\r\n"_Either_ to our right or left?"\r\n\r\n"That\'s the best we can do, sir, without radar help."\r\n\r\n"Admiral, sir," the lieutenant who had first reported the signal came\r\nrunning back. "Judging from the frequency and strength, we think it\'s\r\nprobably less than a hundred miles away."\r\n\r\n"_Less_ than a hundr ..."\r\n\r\n"Of course, we can\'t be positive, sir."\r\n\r\nHeselton whirled back to the intercom. "Radar! That thing is practically\r\non our necks. What the hell\'s the matter with that equipment...?"\r\n\r\nThe radar commander\'s voice showed distinct signs of strain. "Can\'t help\r\nit, Admiral. The equipment is working perfectly. We\'ve tried the\r\ncomplete range of frequencies, twenty-five different sets are in\r\noperation, we\'re going blind looking. There is absolutely nothing,\r\nnothing at all."\r\n\r\nFor a moment the bridge was silent, except for the clacking-grunting\r\nfrom the overhead speaker which, if anything, sounded louder than\r\nbefore.\r\n\r\n"It\'s tv, sir!" The radio lieutenant came running in again. "We\'ve\r\nunscrambled the image. 

Here!" The communications screen on Heselton\'s\r\ndesk glowed for a moment, then flashed into life.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe figure was clearly alien, though startlingly humanoid--at least from\r\nthe waist up, which was all that showed in the screen. A large mouth and\r\nslightly bulging eyes gave it a somewhat jovial, frog-like demeanor.\r\nSeated at a desk similar to Heselton\'s, wearing a gaudy uniform\r\nprofusely strewn with a variety of insignia, it was obviously Heselton\'s\r\ncounterpart, the commander of an alien vessel.\r\n\r\n"Hmmm, looks like we\'ve contacted a new race. Let\'s return the call,\r\nLieutenant." A tiny red light glowed beneath a miniature camera on\r\nHeselton\'s desk and almost at once the alien\'s face registered obvious\r\nsatisfaction. It waved a six-fingered hand in an unorthodox, but\r\nfriendly, greeting.\r\n\r\nHeselton waved back.\r\n\r\nThe alien then pointed to his mouth, made several clacking-grunting\r\nsounds, and moved a hand on his desk. The scene switched to another\r\nalien standing in front of what looked like a blackboard, with a piece\r\nof chalk in his hand. The meaning was clear.\r\n\r\n"Lieutenant, have this transmission switched to the linguistics section.\r\nMaybe those guys can work some sort of language." The screen blanked\r\nout. Heselton leaned back, tense, obviously worried. Hesitantly, he\r\nreached out and touched a button on the intercom.\r\n\r\n"Astronomy."\r\n\r\n"Professor, there\'s a ship right next door somewhere that should stand\r\nout like King Kong in a kindergarten."\r\n\r\n"I know, Admiral. 

I\'ve been listening to the intercom. Our optical\r\nequipment isn\'t designed for close range work, but we\'ve been doing the\r\nbest we can, tried everything from infra-red through ultra-violet. If\r\nthere is a ship out there I\'m afraid it\'s invisible."\r\n\r\nBeads of sweat sprinkled Heselton\'s forehead. "This is bad, Rogers.\r\nMighty bad." Nervously, he walked across to the right of the bridge and\r\nstood, hands clasped behind his back, staring blankly out at blackness\r\nand the scattered stars. "I know there is a ship out there, and I know\r\nthat a ship simply can\'t be invisible, not to radar _and_ optics."\r\n\r\n"What makes you sure there is only one, sir?"\r\n\r\nHeselton cracked his fists together. "My God, Rogers, you\'re right!\r\nThere might be ..."\r\n\r\nThe intercom clacked. "This is fire control again, sir. I think we\'ve\r\ngot something on the radiation detectors."\r\n\r\n"Good work, what did you find?"\r\n\r\n"Slight radioactivity, typical of interstellar drive mechanisms,\r\nsomewhere off to our right. Can\'t tell exactly where, though."\r\n\r\n"How far away is it?"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know, sir."\r\n\r\nHeselton\'s hands dropped to his sides. 

"Thanks," he said, "for the\r\nhelp."\r\n\r\nHis desk tv flashed into life with a picture of the smiling alien\r\ncommander. "This is the linguistics section, Admiral. The aliens\r\nunderstand a fairly common galactic symbology, I believe we can\r\ntranslate simple messages for you now."\r\n\r\n"Ask him where the hell he is," Heselton snapped without thinking, then\r\ninstantly regretted it as the alien\'s face showed unmistakable surprise.\r\n\r\nThe alien\'s smile grew into an almost unbelievable grin. He turned\r\nsideways to speak to someone out of sight of the camera and suddenly\r\nburst into a series of roaring cackles. "He\'s laughing, sir." The\r\ntranslator commented unnecessarily.\r\n\r\nThe joke was strictly with the aliens. Heselton\'s face whitened in quick\r\nrealization. "Rogers! They _didn\'t know_ that we can\'t see them!

"\r\n\r\n"Look, sir." The navigator pointed to the tv screen and a brilliantly\r\nclear image of Big Joe shimmering against the galaxy, lit by millions of\r\nstars. Every missile port, even the military numerals along her nose\r\nwere clearly visible.\r\n\r\n"They\'re rubbing it in, Rogers. Showing us what we look like to them.

"\r\nHeselton\'s face was chalk. "They could blast Big Joe apart, piece by\r\npiece--the most powerful ship in the galaxy."\r\n\r\n"Maybe," said Rogers, "the second most powerful."\r\n\r\nWithout answering, Heselton turned and looked out again at empty space\r\nand millions of steady, unwinking stars. His mind formed an image of a\r\nhuge, ethereal spaceship, missile ports open, weapons aimed directly at\r\nBig Joe.\r\n\r\nThe speaker interrupted his nightmare. "This is fire control, Admiral.\r\nWith your permission I\'ll scatter a few C-bombs ..."\r\n\r\nHeselton leaped for the microphone. "Are you out of your mind? We\r\nhaven\'t the slightest idea of the forces that guy has. We might be in\r\nthe center of a whole blooming fleet. 

Ever think of that?"\r\n\r\nThe alien\'s face, still smirking, appeared again on the screen. "He\r\nsays," said the interpreter, "that he finds the presence of our armed\r\nship very annoying."\r\n\r\nHeselton knew what he had to do. "Tell him," he said, swallowing hard,\r\n"that we apologize. This part of the galaxy is strange to us."\r\n\r\n"He says he is contemplating blasting us out of the sky."\r\n\r\nHeselton said nothing, but he longed to reach out and throttle the\r\ngrinning, alien face.\r\n\r\n"However," the interpreter continued, "he will let us go safely if we\r\nleave immediately. He says to send an unarmed, diplomatic vessel next\r\ntime and maybe his people will talk to us."\r\n\r\n"Thank him for his kindness." Heselton\'s jaws clenched so tightly they\r\nached.\r\n\r\n"He says," said the interpreter, "to get the hell out."\r\n\r\nThe grinning face snapped off the screen, but the cackling laughter\r\ncontinued to reverberate in the control room until the radio shack\r\nfinally turned off the receiver.\r\n\r\n"Reverse course," the admiral ordered quietly. "Maximum drive."\r\n\r\nA thousand missile launchers, designed to disintegrate solar systems,\r\nwere deactivated, hundreds of gyros swung the mile-long ship end for end\r\nand stabilized her on a reverse course, drive units big enough to power\r\nseveral major cities whined into operation, anti-grav generators with\r\nthe strength to shift small planets counterbalanced the external\r\nacceleration, and the ship moved, away, with a speed approaching that of\r\nlight.\r\n\r\n"Well," muttered Heselton, "that\'s the very first time Big Joe has ever\r\nhad to retreat." As if it were his own personal failure, he walked\r\nslowly across the control room and down the corridor towards his cabin.\r\n\r\n"Admiral!" Lost in thought, Heselton barely heard the call.\r\n\r\n"Admiral, look!" Pausing at the door to his cabin, Heselton turned to\r\nface the ship\'s chief astronomer running up waving two large\r\nphotographs.\r\n\r\n"Look, sir," the professor gasped for breath. "We thought this was a\r\nspot on the negative, but one of the men got curious and enlarged it\r\nabout a hundred times." He held up one of the photos. It showed a small,\r\nfuzzy, but unmistakable spaceship. "No wonder we couldn\'t spot it with\r\nour instruments."\r\n\r\nHeselton snatched it out of his hand. 

"I see what you mean. This ship\r\nmust have been thousands of miles ..."\r\n\r\nThe professor shook his head. "No, sir. As a matter of fact, it was\r\nquite close by."\r\n\r\n"But ..."\r\n\r\n"We figure that the total length of the alien ship was roughly an inch\r\nand a half."\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Amazing Science Fiction Stories_\r\n    January 1960. copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nAfter her husband left her, Marigold filed a protection-request form\r\nand an availability form.\r\n\r\nShe did not do this immediately. She stayed up for the better part of\r\nthe night, hoping that he would come back. She could not bring herself\r\nto believe that he would really walk out on her and leave her available\r\nfor confiscation, or for the slavery pool. She also thought for quite a\r\nwhile about the possibility of somehow getting back to Earth, where she\r\nwould not be available for either.\r\n\r\nShe even went to the fantastic expense of televiewing there to talk\r\nwith her father and mother. They had been shocked and unfriendly. They\r\nhad said good-by with a finality which left little room for doubt as\r\nto what they thought of an Abandoned. They had never had one in their\r\nfamily, they had pointed out, neither of them, and they did not intend\r\nto have one in their family now. They had warned her that they intended\r\nto report the call to the Beta III Protection People.\r\n\r\nThis did not worry her much. The call almost certainly had been\r\nmonitored anyway. If they wanted to go to the considerable extra\r\nexpense of reporting it, in order to impress the Protection People with\r\ntheir loyalty, that was their own lookout. She understood that, now,\r\nshe had no family. She thought for a moment of going up-ramp to say\r\ngood-by to the children, but she knew that this would not help.\r\n\r\nBesides, it was illegal. They were no longer hers. She was an Abandoned.\r\n\r\nShe had never known what a tremendously harrowing experience\r\nfilling out an availability form could be. Name, age, Sector, race,\r\nsize-classification, beauty-index, fertility tests, personality scores,\r\naptitudes, psyche-rating and so on, and so on and so on. It was like\r\nundressing for an auction. The protection-request form was much\r\nsimpler, except for that one question: STATUS? Her hand shook almost\r\nuncontrollably as she wrote. _Abandoned._\r\n\r\nAfter that she did not know what to do. She had stood for nearly twenty\r\nminutes before the document file, listening, thinking desperately that\r\nhe would come back; that if she only waited a few minutes more he would\r\ncome back. She had made herself refreshment. She had sat with the\r\nfilled-out documents on her lap looking, from time to time, longingly\r\nat the entrance-ramp. But he had not come back. Finally, with a low\r\nmoaning sound, she had pushed the papers through the document file\r\nslot. She made the deadline by a scant three minutes.\r\n\r\nNow she knew that whatever else happened, the Protection People would\r\nbe there in the morning to pick up the children. She knew that it could\r\nshow in her favor if she were to get together the things they would\r\nneed to take with them. She could do this without seeing them and\r\nwithout talking to them, which was forbidden, but she could not bring\r\nherself to move.\r\n\r\nThe red light on the atmosphere control blinked warningly. Soon it\r\nwould let out a piercing scream. She was tempted to just let it.\r\nAnother of Clytia\'s suns must have set. She found that she had no sense\r\nof time. She had only the conviction that this would be her last night.\r\nThe last night that mattered to her at all. She wanted it to be a long\r\none. She had adjusted the atmoset. She had done this every night for\r\nthe seven years of their marriage. She began to sob uncontrollably. She\r\ntook her Status Married card and tore it in half. Then she held the\r\nhalves to her cheeks, her face wet and wretched between them.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAfter a while she dialed the credit balance at her account. The figures\r\ncame back indicating a balance of 1300. He had left her quite a lot,\r\nwhen you considered that she had televiewed to Earth. She cried hard\r\nagain because she knew that he had not had to leave her anything at\r\nall. This made her certain (although she had known it already) that he\r\nwas not coming back.\r\n\r\nShe sat for quite a while studying the 1300 credit indicator.\r\nShe thought about using the money to buy a "pick-up-immediately\r\nadvertisement" on the omnivision. She was not sure of the rates, but\r\nshe thought the amount might even stretch to include a picture of\r\nher. 

She did not know. She did not even know if she would be expected\r\nto be nude or dressed for the picture. In the end, she decided not to\r\ntry an advertisement because there would not be time enough to employ\r\na reply-receiving address. All that would be accomplished would be to\r\nput every predator within miles in possession of the address of an\r\nAbandoned.\r\n\r\nShe took a dictator and said into it: "Dear children, I am leaving you\r\n1300 credit." She stopped then and shook her head. 

The tears made it\r\nso that she could not see, and she did not seem to be able to think.\r\n"Correction," she sobbed "Erase preceding. Dear Children of Yan, I make\r\nyou this gift of 1300. I am sure that your excellence will continue to\r\ndeserve much more than so small a gift. I send love with this small\r\ngift."\r\n\r\nThere could, of course, be no signature. An Abandoned had none.\r\n\r\nShe wished that she had not made the Earth call. There would have been\r\nmuch more to leave them then. He had left an astonishing amount in her\r\naccount. It was almost as though he had expected her to try to get\r\naway. She wished now that she had thought before taking action. There\r\nmight have been some way out.\r\n\r\nShe must have fallen asleep. The morning announcements came on as\r\nusual, waking her. She listened to the instructions for that day, and\r\nthe areas announced as forbidden. She made no effort, however, to\r\nindicate them on the day-map. She knew that, now, none of this applied\r\nto her.\r\n\r\nWith a very great effort she got up and shut off the children\'s ramp,\r\nso that they could not come down. She knew how much this would count in\r\nher favor. Then she began, as hurriedly as she could, to collect the\r\nthings they would need. She knew that she could not possibly get the\r\nthings together in time, and that so late an effort was more likely\r\nto count against her. She was not even close to finished when the\r\nannouncer flashed on.\r\n\r\nWithout asking who it was, she pressed the admitter. She was glad that\r\nthey had troubled to announce themselves.\r\n\r\nShe offered to go into another room while they removed the children.\r\nThey did not answer. One of them threw a sack over her. After a\r\nmoment, they took it off again and, rather apologetically, asked her\r\nto indicate where the child-ramp control was. She showed them. Their\r\nleader said that perhaps it would be all right for her to go into\r\nanother room if one of them went with her. When she saw the one chosen,\r\nshe put the sack back on herself. They laughed so hard at this that she\r\ndid not hear the children leave.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWhen the children had been taken out, the leader came back and removed\r\nthe sack from around her. He asked if she had applied for protection.\r\nShe showed her card.\r\n\r\n"Well, that\'s too bad," he said. "Do you have any refreshment left?"\r\n\r\nShe did not dare to lie to him. She showed him. He helped himself.\r\n\r\n"How about credits?" he asked.\r\n\r\n"I gave it all to the ones who were here," she answered carefully. She\r\nfelt quick panic because she remembered that she had not so instructed\r\nher account. She had merely dictated it to the children. If he didn\'t\r\nfind out, though, that would be all right. The dictation was proof\r\nenough. But while she was still in this house, the credits were still\r\nin her control.\r\n\r\n"My credit indicator is here," she said, holding it out. He didn\'t take\r\nit.\r\n\r\n"Thanks for the refreshment," he said, getting up. 

"Make yourself\r\ncomfortable. 

The others will be here shortly."\r\n\r\nShe had nothing to do to make herself ready. She could not take\r\nanything from this house. Sometimes they let you wear what you were\r\nwearing, if it did not look as though you had put on your best things.\r\nThey did not always allow it, but they did sometimes. She remembered\r\nthat she had expressed strong disapproval of that to Yan, when they\r\nwere newly married. Then they both felt the same way about Abandoneds.\r\n\r\nShe indicated to her account how she wanted the 1300 disposed. Then she\r\nwaited. After a while, the Protection People came and led her out of\r\nthe house. They did not touch her or speak to her, they merely formed\r\na square in the center of which she walked. They led her to a records\r\nroom where an interview apparatus prepared a report on her.\r\n\r\n"You have filed availability papers?" it asked.\r\n\r\n"Yes," she said, and gave the file number.\r\n\r\n"This is being checked," the apparatus said. "Have you any claims upon\r\nthe State?"\r\n\r\nShe came very close to mentioning the children. "None," she said in\r\na very small voice. It was difficult to remember that the interview\r\napparatus was not at all sensitive.\r\n\r\n"Have you credits in your possession?" the machine asked.\r\n\r\n"None," she said.\r\n\r\n"You are eligible for exclusion from the slave classification in what\r\nway?" That part of the recording seemed a bit worn. At least she did\r\nnot hear it very well.\r\n\r\n"In no way," she replied.\r\n\r\n"You will wait," said the machine, "until we have a report on the\r\navailability petition which you have filed. Please take a seat."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThere were no seats. This was an older machine which they had not\r\nbothered to replace, or even to correct. She stood in horror as the\r\nlong minutes passed.\r\n\r\nHer number was finally called.\r\n\r\n"I am here," she said as the machine hummed, and she gave her number.\r\n\r\n"Your availability petition has been taken up," said the machine. "You\r\nare however to receive twenty-eight demerits for disposing of 6300\r\ncredit after having been abandoned. Do you accept?

"\r\n\r\n"I accept," she said. She was so dizzy that she could hardly stand. The\r\nmachine whirred and produced a reception-area card. She read it, and\r\nwalked as in a daze to the indicated reception area. Yan waited for her\r\nthere.\r\n\r\n"You look terrible," he said as he put his arm around her. "I\'m sorry.\r\nYou made me do this to you. 

I didn\'t want to. 

It\'s all over now, don\'t\r\ncry."\r\n\r\nShe thought that she was going to faint.\r\n\r\n"Thank you for receiving me," she said, according to the formula. "I am\r\nthe Abandoned of Yan, of the Estate...."\r\n\r\n"Stop it!" he said. "I know who you are! Stop it!"\r\n\r\n"Do you have children at your estate?" She asked it as one asks a\r\npolite, social question.\r\n\r\n"They\'ll be there when we get home," he said. "Don\'t do this. 

I didn\'t\r\nknow it would hurt that much. I wouldn\'t have done it if I had. They\'re\r\nyour children again now." He held her shoulders as he looked at her.\r\n\r\n"I came to you with twenty-eight demerits," she said. "Shall I work\r\nthem off before I come to your estate?"\r\n\r\n"Please, stop it!" 

he said. "They were paid when you accepted. I waited\r\nhere all night. No one else could have claimed you. 

Please, come on\r\nhome now?" He handed her a brand-new wife-status card.\r\n\r\n"Thank you," she said. "I shall try to deserve the opportunity which\r\nyou restore to me." He smiled as she recited the formula and took his\r\narm. Yet he did not look as if he felt like smiling.\r\n\r\n"Come home," he said. "Come home now.

Self-conscious, none of them said\r\nanything.\r\n\r\n"Okay," said Murph, "Out we go."\r\n\r\nThe precision door swung open quietly and the three descended to the\r\nstill-smoking ground. Each set up his rapid fire electro-gun, covering\r\nthe entrance and then they sat back, waiting. Nothing happened, and\r\nMurph broke the tense silence.\r\n\r\n"Turn on the radio," he looked at Forsyth. "We can hear it from here.\r\nI\'ll man both guns."\r\n\r\nForsyth grunted and vanished into the ship. Murph heard the crackle\r\nas equipment warmed up, and listened to the voice of Sitra. Oddly\r\nenough, Jamison tensed as he heard the voice of the present champion,\r\nand Forsyth nearly cried as his son\'s tones came through the metallic\r\nspeaker. But all the voices said the same thing.\r\n\r\n"... subject to unprincipled attack to resist invasion of our homeland.\r\nThis is the last time this warning will be broadcast." The receiver\r\nclicked, then dropped into the monotonous hum of a radio on an unused\r\nbut still alert wavelength.\r\n\r\nForsyth returned and the three men sat, each back of an electro-gun,\r\nalert eyes scanning the alien landscape. From over a slight rise a mile\r\noff, a figure approached the ship. Murph blinked, doubting his senses,\r\nconfused, then his roar broke the silence of the strange world.\r\n\r\n"Sitra!" Just one word, but that\'s all he could do. She looked as she\r\nhad when he\'d left on this expedition, when they had said goodbye.\r\nSparkling with sequins in her dressing room, undulating with feathers\r\nin the right places, she walked toward him with the feline grace he\'d\r\nlearned to love.\r\n\r\n"Sitra!" he shouted again. Astonished, he deserted his position behind\r\nthe gun and started running across the plain. Gracefully, daintily,\r\nencountering difficulties because of her spiked heels on the rough\r\nterrain, she smiled bravely and hurried toward him.\r\n\r\nForsyth saw the approaching figure too. He tensed with disbelief and\r\nsurprise and then his voice rose excitedly.\r\n\r\n"Jimmy, _Jimmy!_" What was his boy doing _here_? Reason faded as he\r\nwatched his nine-year-old son stumbling toward the ship. He unfastened\r\nhis harness and slipped from behind the gun: _his_ boy on an alien\r\nplanet, confronting unknown dangers! He must--_must_--get him back to\r\nthe ship and the little ring of certainty behind the guns. Forsyth\r\nstarted across the level space, grateful that the towering hulk of\r\nMurph had recognized his boy and would, on this unknown world, help\r\nbring the kid back to comparative safety. In six hours, now, the\r\nfleet would be here. The boy could be sent home on one of the capital\r\nships....\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBehind him Jamison watched the two figures running away. His face froze\r\ninto granite. 

Rage and resentment surged within him. Across the plain\r\nhe saw the man who had stolen, yes, _stolen_, the championship from\r\nhim. The fighter loped toward him casually, sneering and confident.\r\nJamison felt a surge like an electric shock across his shoulders. His\r\nteeth ground together and he could hear their roaring within his ears.\r\nDeliberately he moved from behind his gun, started at a fighter\'s dog\r\ntrot toward his opponent. It occurred to him that Murph and Forsyth\r\nwould beat him there. He was glad they were willing to help, but for\r\nthe sake of his own integrity he considered this _his_ fight.\r\n\r\nJamison ran swiftly then. He passed Forsyth and Murph, determined to be\r\nthe first to reach the one man he hated. He sprinted eagerly, sucking\r\nthe strange air chemicals of this world into his lungs. He was short\r\nof breath. Behind him he heard the heavy thudding of Murph plunging\r\nand plowing toward him, and in addition, the light but rapid steps of\r\nForsyth. By now he didn\'t care. He was confronting his opponent.\r\n\r\nDropping into a crouch, Jamison moved in. Feet wide, tense; there\r\nwould be no mistake, no error, this time. His fist lashed out and\r\nhis opponent fell on the strange and powdery dust of a strange world\r\nmillions of miles from their first fight.\r\n\r\nThe man started struggling up--and again flat-footed, tense, fists like\r\ncrunching sledge hammers, Jamison dove at him.\r\n\r\nAnd then it happened. Murph hit Jamison from the side. Raw and choking\r\nwith rage, Murph clubbed, groped, kicked, fouled, until the ex-fighter\r\nfell in the pale and strange dust. Murph\'s voice was hoarse and shaking:\r\n\r\n"Hit my woman, will you!" he screamed in rage.\r\n\r\nJamison tried to rally, but each time he moved Murph\'s fists slammed\r\nagainst his face and head.\r\n\r\nThere was a final crash as the back of his head struck against the\r\nrocks on the ground. Jamison lay in the dust on an alien planet and\r\nfrom behind his right ear gray and reddish matter oozed. He didn\'t move.\r\n\r\nMurph stood up. 

He looked again at Sitra. He was choked and tired,\r\nstanding there, and as he grasped for breath, Forsyth ran by him, ran\r\nup to her. Angrily he watched. Forsyth running up to _his_ woman! What\r\nwas wrong with these men? Murph saw Forsyth put his arms around Sitra,\r\nand say--meaninglessly to Murph--"Jimmy, Jimmy!"\r\n\r\nAgain a red rage filled Murph. He dove forward, smashed into Forsyth,\r\nand the navigator reeled backwards. As he fell back, his feet tangled\r\nin the scrubby vegetation of the planet, he reached toward his belt and\r\nhis electro-gun jerked free from the holster. He saw the bull shape of\r\nMurph over him, an enraged beast, and as he fell, the twin electrodes\r\nshot out an energy stream. Fear and hatred tensed his nerves, but\r\ndespite the emotion, he set the range right. The sparks arced together\r\njust in front of the great bulk of Murph. There was a crackling and\r\nthe smell of burning flesh, then a surprised look upon Murph\'s face.\r\nThe surprise turned to rage and the last thing Forsyth saw was Murph\r\nfalling down on him, his clothes and his chest burned away until the\r\nribs showed, animal rage welling from his lips.\r\n\r\nA figure stood fifty feet away and watched this drama. Murph, blood\r\ncoughing from his mouth and nose, the great muscles of his chest\r\nnothing but crisp burned meat, reached for Forsyth, picked him up,\r\nholding him over his head as an ape would a man, and slammed him again\r\nand again to the ground.\r\n\r\nThe final time Murph tried to lift Forsyth, his strength gave out. He\r\ndropped Forsyth\'s limp form, coughed in a final paroxysm, and fell\r\nbeside Forsyth and Jamison.\r\n\r\nThe figure which stood fifty feet away turned and walked leisurely\r\nback over the rise.\r\n\r\nNow, it was not a fighter, and it was not Jimmy, and it was not Sitra.\r\nIt was a denizen of the planet and it looked like no human.\r\n\r\nShortly thereafter the all-wave radio in the deadly, powerful silvery\r\nneedle standing serenely on the strange world blared again.\r\n\r\n"... in accordance with Interstellar Code we have asked that we not be\r\ninvaded and are warning you that according to Article 19, Section 3,\r\nfleets which invade a peaceful people become subject to unprincipled\r\nattack, even to the use of psychological weapons."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nFive hours away the main fleet streaked toward the planet. 

The Admiral\r\nlooked at the tape reports from the scout ship and at transcripts of\r\nthe recorded warning.\r\n\r\n"Nuts!" he said. 

"We go in."\r\n\r\nHe felt an odd, intuitive twinge. The voice was so much like his\r\nmother\'s--and she hadn\'t been well when he\'d last seen her. Beside\r\nhim the Radioman busily, tersely, sent out landing instructions. 

He\r\nfelt irritable: the voice had sounded just like Peggy--that no-good,\r\ncheating!... He shrugged: just imagination.\r\n\r\nIn a diminishing spiral, the fleet swung around the planet while the\r\nAdmiral scanned the screen for a free landing site.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


Increased atmospheric pressure did funny things to his chest and\r\nstomach. And quick and sure-footed on Mars, he struggled constantly\r\nagainst the heavy gravity that made all his movements clumsy and\r\nuncoordinated.\r\n\r\nThe endless canyons of towering buildings, with their connecting\r\nSkywalks, oppressed and smothered him. Remembering the endless vistas of\r\n_rabbara_ fields beside a canal that was like an inland sea,\r\nhomesickness flooded over him.\r\n\r\nHe hated the people who stared at him with either open or hidden\r\namusement. His Aunt Bee, for instance, who looked him up and down with\r\nfrank disapproval and said loudly, "For Heavens sake, Helen! Take him to\r\na _good_ tailor and get those bones covered up!"\r\n\r\nWas it his fault he was six inches taller than Terran boys his age, and\r\nhad long, thin arms and legs? Or that his chest was abnormally developed\r\nto compensate for an oxygen-thin atmosphere? I\'d like to see _her_, he\r\nthought fiercely, out on the Flatlands; she\'d be gasping like a\r\ncanal-fish out of water.\r\n\r\nEven his parents, happily riding the social merry-go-round of Terra,\r\nafter eleven years in the Martian flatlands, didn\'t seem to understand\r\nhow he felt.\r\n\r\n"Don\'t you _like_ Earth, Tommy?" queried his mother anxiously.\r\n\r\n"Oh ... it\'s all right, I guess."\r\n\r\n"... \'A nice place to visit\' ..." said his father sardonically.\r\n\r\n"... \'but I wouldn\'t live here if they gave me the place!\' ..." said his\r\nmother, and they both burst out laughing for no reason that Tommy could\r\nsee. Of course, they did that lots of times at home and Tommy laughed\r\nwith them just for the warm, secure feeling of belonging. This time he\r\ndidn\'t feel like laughing.\r\n\r\n"When _are_ we going home?" he repeated stubbornly.\r\n\r\nHis father pulled Tommy over in the crook of his arm and said gently,\r\n"Well, not right away, son. As a matter of fact, how would you like to\r\nstay here and go to school?"\r\n\r\nTommy pulled away and looked at him incredulously.\r\n\r\n"I\'ve _been_ to school!"\r\n\r\n"Well, yes," admitted his father. "But only to the colony schools. You\r\ndon\'t want to grow up and be an ignorant Martian sandfoot all your life,\r\ndo you?"\r\n\r\n"Yes, I do! I _want_ to be a Martian sandfoot. And I want to go home\r\nwhere people don\'t _look_ at me and say, \'So this is your little\r\nMartian!\'"\r\n\r\nBenton, Sr., put his arm around Tommy\'s stiffly resistant shoulders.\r\n"Look here, old man," he said persuasively. "I thought you wanted to be\r\na space engineer. You can\'t do that without an education you know. And\r\nyour Aunt Bee will take good care of you."\r\n\r\nTommy faced him stubbornly. "I don\'t want to be any old spaceman. I want\r\nto be a sandfoot like old Pete. And I want to go home.

"\r\n\r\nHelen bit back a smile at the two earnest, stubborn faces so\r\nridiculously alike, and hastened to avert the gathering storm.\r\n\r\n"Now look, fellows. Tommy\'s career doesn\'t have to be decided in the\r\nnext five minutes ... after all, he\'s only ten. He can make up his mind\r\nlater on if he wants to be an engineer or a _rabbara_ farmer. 

Right now,\r\nhe\'s going to stay here and go to school ... _and_ I\'m staying with\r\nhim."\r\n\r\nResolutely avoiding both crestfallen faces, Helen, having shepherded\r\nTommy to bed, returned to the living room acutely conscious of Big Tom\'s\r\nbleak, hurt gaze at her back.\r\n\r\n"Helen, you\'re going to make a sissy out of the boy," he said at last.\r\n"There isn\'t any reason why he can\'t stay here at home with Bee."\r\n\r\nHelen turned to face him.\r\n\r\n"Earth _isn\'t_ home to Tommy. And your sister Bee told him he ought to\r\nbe out playing football with the boys instead of hanging around the\r\nhouse."\r\n\r\n"But she knows the doctor said he\'d have to take it easy for a year till\r\nhe was accustomed to the change in gravity and air-pressure," he\r\nanswered incredulously.\r\n\r\n"Exactly. She also asked me," Helen went on grimly, "if I thought he\'d\r\nbe less of a freak as he got older."\r\n\r\nTom Benton swore. "Bee always did have less sense than the average hen,"\r\nhe gritted. "My son a freak! Hell\'s-bells!"\r\n\r\nTommy, arriving at the hall door in time to hear the tail-end of the\r\nsentence, crept back to bed feeling numb and dazed. So even his father\r\nthought he was a freak.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe last few days before parting was one of strain for all of them. If\r\nTommy was unnaturally subdued, no one noticed it; his parents were not\r\nfeeling any great impulse toward gaiety either.\r\n\r\nThey all went dutifully sight-seeing as before; they saw the Zoo, and\r\nwent shopping on the Skywalks, and on the last day wound up at the great\r\nshowrooms of "Androids, Inc."\r\n\r\nTommy had hated them on sight; they were at once too human and too\r\ninhuman for comfort. 

The hotel was full of them, and most private homes\r\nhad at least one. Now they saw the great incubating vats, and the\r\nprocessing and finally the showroom where one of the finished products\r\nwas on display as a maid, sweeping and dusting.\r\n\r\n"There\'s one that\'s a dead-ringer for you, Helen. If you were a little\r\nbetter looking, that is." Tommy\'s dad pretended to compare them\r\njudicially. Helen laughed, but Tommy looked at him with a resentfulness.\r\nComparing his mother to an Android....\r\n\r\n"They say for a little extra you can get an exact resemblance. Maybe I\'d\r\nbetter have one fixed up like you to take back with me," Big Tom added\r\nteasingly. Then as Helen\'s face clouded over, "Oh, hon, you know I was\r\nonly kidding. Let\'s get out of here; this place gives me the\r\ncollywobbles. 

Besides, I\'ve got to pick up my watch."\r\n\r\nBut his mother\'s face was still unhappy and Tommy glowered sullenly at\r\nhis father\'s back all the way to the watch-shop.\r\n\r\nIt was a small shop, with an inconspicuous sign down in one corner of\r\nthe window that said only, "KRUMBEIN--watches," and was probably the\r\nmost famous shop of its kind in the world. Every spaceman landing on\r\nTerra left his watch to be checked by the dusty, little old man who was\r\nthe genius of the place. Tommy ranged wide-eyed about the clock and\r\nchronometer crammed interior. He stopped fascinated before the last\r\ncase. In it was a watch ... but, _what_ a watch! Besides the regulation\r\nTerran dial, it had a second smaller dial that registered the\r\ncorresponding time on Mars. Tommy\'s whole heart went out to it in an\r\necstasy of longing. 

He thought wistfully that if you could know what\r\ntime it was there, you could imagine what everyone was doing and it\r\nwouldn\'t seem so far away. 

Haltingly, he tried to explain.\r\n\r\n"Look, Mom," he said breathlessly. "It\'s almost five o\'clock at home.\r\nDouwie will be coming up to the barn to be fed. Gosh, do you suppose old\r\nPete will remember about her?"\r\n\r\nHis mother smiled at him reassuringly. "Of course he will, silly. Don\'t\r\nforget he was the one who caught and tamed her for you."\r\n\r\nTommy gulped as he thought of Douwie. Scarcely as tall as himself; the\r\nbig, rounded, mouselike ears, and the flat, cloven pads that could carry\r\nher so swiftly over the sandy Martian flatlands. One of the last\r\ndwindling herds of native Martian douwies, burden-carriers of a vanished\r\nrace, she had been Tommy\'s particular pride and joy for the last three\r\nyears.\r\n\r\nBehind him, Tommy heard his mother murmur under her breath, "Tom ... the\r\nwatch; _could_ we?"\r\n\r\nAnd his Dad regretfully, "It\'s a pretty expensive toy for a youngster,\r\nHelen. And even a _rabbara_ raiser\'s bank account has limits."\r\n\r\n"Of course, dear; it was silly of me." 

Helen smiled a little ruefully.\r\n"And if Mr. Krumbein has your watch ready, we _must_ go. Bee and some of\r\nher friends are coming over, and it\'s only a few hours \'till you ...\r\nleave."\r\n\r\nBig Tom squeezed her elbow gently, understandingly, as she blinked back\r\nquick tears. Trailing after them, Tommy saw the little by-play and his\r\nheart ached. The guilt-complex building up in him grew and deepened.\r\n\r\nHe knew he had only to say, "Look, I don\'t mind staying. Aunt Bee and I\r\nwill get along swell," and everything would be all right again. Then the\r\nterror of this new and complex world--as it would be without a familiar\r\nface--swept over him and kept him silent.\r\n\r\nHis overwrought feelings expressed themselves in a nervously rebelling\r\nstomach, culminating in a disgraceful moment over the nearest gutter.\r\nThe rest of the afternoon he spent in bed recuperating.\r\n\r\nIn the living room Aunt Bee spoke her mind in her usual, high-pitched\r\nvoice.\r\n\r\n"It\'s disgraceful, Helen. A boy his age.... None of the _Bentons_ ever\r\nhad nerves."\r\n\r\nHis mother\'s reply was inaudible, but on the heels of his father\'s\r\ndeeper tones, Aunt Bee\'s voice rose in rasping indignation.\r\n\r\n"_Well!_ I never! And from my own brother, too. From now on don\'t come\r\nto me for help with your spoiled brat. Good-_bye_!"\r\n\r\nThe door slammed indignantly, his mother chuckled, and there was a\r\nspontaneous burst of laughter. Tommy relaxed and lay back happily.\r\nAnyway, that was the last of Aunt Bee!\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe next hour or two passed in a flurry of ringing phones, people coming\r\nand going, and last-minute words and reminders. Then suddenly it was\r\ntime to leave. Dad burst in for a last quick hug and a promise to send\r\nhim pictures of Douwie and her foal, due next month; Mother dropped a\r\nhasty kiss on his hair and promised to hurry back from the Spaceport.\r\nThen Tommy was alone, with a large, painful lump where his heart ought\r\nto be.\r\n\r\nThe only activity was the almost noiseless buzzing as the hotel android\r\nran the cleaner over the living room. Presently even that ceased, and\r\nTommy lay relaxed and inert, sleepily watching the curtains blow in and\r\nout at the open window. Thirty stories above the street the noises were\r\npleasantly muffled and remote, and his senses drifted aimlessly to and\r\nfro on the tides of half-sleep.\r\n\r\nDrowsily his mind wandered from the hotel\'s android servants ... to\r\nthe strictly utilitarian mechanical monstrosity at home, known\r\naffectionately as "Old John" ... to the android showroom where they\r\nhad seen the one that Dad said looked like Mother....\r\n\r\nHe jolted suddenly, sickeningly awake. Suppose, his mind whispered\r\ntreacherously, suppose that Dad _had_ ordered one to take Mom\'s\r\nplace ... not on Mars, but _here_ while she returned to Mars with him.\r\nSuppose that instead of Mom he discovered one of those _Things_ ... or\r\neven worse, suppose he went on from day to day not even knowing....\r\n\r\nIt was a bad five minutes; he was wet with perspiration when he lay back\r\non his pillows, a shaky smile tugging at the corners of his mouth. He\r\nhad a secret defense against the Terror. He giggled a little at the\r\nthought of what Aunt Bee would say if she knew.\r\n\r\nAnd what had brought him back from the edge of hysteria was the\r\ntriumphant knowledge that with the abnormally acute hearing bred in the\r\nthin atmosphere of Mars, no robot ever created could hide from him the\r\ninfinitesimal ticking of the electronic relays that gave it life. Secure\r\nat last, his overstrung nerves relaxed and he slid gratefully over the\r\nedge of sleep.\r\n\r\nHe woke abruptly, groping after some vaguely remembered sound. A soft\r\nclicking of heels down the hall.... Of course, his mother back from the\r\nSpaceport! Now she would be stopping at his door to see if he were\r\nasleep. He lay silently; through his eyelashes he could see her outlined\r\nin the soft light from the hall. She was coming in to see if he was\r\ntucked in. In a moment he would jump up and startle her with a hug, as\r\nshe leaned over him. 

In a moment....\r\n\r\nScreaming desperately, he was out of bed, backing heedlessly across the\r\nroom. He was still screaming as the low sill of the open window caught\r\nhim behind the knees and toppled him thirty stories to the street.\r\n\r\nAlone in the silent room, Helen Benton stood dazed, staring blindly at\r\nthe empty window.\r\n\r\nTommy\'s parting gift from his father slid from her hand and lay on the\r\ncarpet, still ticking gently.\r\n\r\nIt was 9:23 on Mars.\r\n\r\n\r\nThe End\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Imagination Stories of Science and\r\n    Fantasy_ July 1953.
