copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nPilot Officer Roy Vanjan happened to be spaceborne when the Earth\r\nexploded. In that way he escaped the annihilation along with one other\r\nman, revered old Dr. Garfield Gar, who was in the space station.\r\n\r\nRoy had backed well off in preparation for a mach ten dive on Kabul,\r\nwhich the enemy had lately taken over. He had one small omnibomb left\r\nin his racks and Kabul had seemed to be about the right size. But then\r\nthe destruction of Earth changed his plans.\r\n\r\nHe watched, expressionless, as the planet exploded. He shrugged. There\r\nwas nothing to do now but go see Dr. Gar.\r\n\r\nRoy\'s foescope clamored insistently and he tensed, thinking a\r\nspaceborne enemy was on him, but it was only a piece of exploding Earth\r\nstumbling by.\r\n\r\nDr. Gar was alone in the space station because all able-bodied men had\r\nbeen called to fight World War V. The governments of Earth, in a rare\r\nmoment of conscience during the Short Truce, had agreed that Dr. Gar,\r\nas the embodiment of all Earthly knowledge, should be protected from\r\nharm.\r\n\r\nPilot Officer Roy Vanjan didn\'t receive as warm a reception from old\r\nDr. Gar as he might have, considering that they were the only two\r\npeople left. The old man was combing his white beard with his fingers\r\nand didn\'t offer to shake hands.\r\n\r\n"Well," said Roy as he defused his bomb and secured his single-seater\r\nin the spacelock, "I guess it\'s all over."\r\n\r\n"Scarcely a historic statement," Dr. 

Gar said, "but it describes the\r\nsituation."\r\n\r\n"If you don\'t have anything for me to do I\'d just as soon have a drink.\r\nThey usually let me have a stiff one after I complete a mission."\r\n\r\nDr. Gar examined the hard young pilot from under shaggy white eyebrows.\r\n"I do have another mission for you but you can have a drink first.\r\nPeach brandy is all that\'s left."\r\n\r\n"That\'ll be fine," Roy said. 

"I was never particular."\r\n\r\n"Then you\'re my man," Dr. Gar said, giving him a deep look, "because I\r\nwant you to go back in time and destroy humanity."\r\n\r\n"Whatever you say." 

Roy\'s training showed. "But if I may comment,\r\nwouldn\'t that be superfluous? Except for you and me the human race is\r\nfinished. We\'ve achieved our objective." He spoke without irony.\r\n\r\n"Never _my_ objective."\r\n\r\n"I\'m not a scholar and I mean no offense," Roy said, "but I believe it\r\nwas the co-ordinated spatial theory you announced back in \'06 that made\r\nit possible."\r\n\r\n"Misapplication," Dr. Gar said wearily, not wanting to go into it\r\nfurther for such an audience. Though, he thought, he\'d never have\r\nanother. "Come into my study and have your brandy."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"I still don\'t understand," Roy said later. He reached tentatively for\r\nthe bottle. When the old man made no objection he poured a second stiff\r\none.\r\n\r\n"You want me to go back in time and wipe out all human life," Roy said.\r\n"I assume you\'ll tell me when and where. All right. 

That would destroy\r\nour ancestors and so we\'d cease to exist, too. Wouldn\'t it be simpler\r\nto kill ourselves now? That is, if you see no point to our further\r\nexistence.

"\r\n\r\nOld Dr. Gar watched the other remnant of Earthly life twirl the brandy\r\nin the goblet. He looked at the viewscreen. It showed a panorama of\r\nrock dust and steam where Earth had been.\r\n\r\n"You forget that we have annihilated everything," Dr. Gar said, gazing\r\npensively at the screen. "Mankind, the animals, plant life and the tiny\r\nthings that creep the earth or swim the waters. Your mission will be\r\nmore selective."\r\n\r\n"Selective? How?"\r\n\r\n"You\'ll destroy man, but the rest will live. They may evolve into\r\nsomething better."\r\n\r\n"If you say so, Doctor." Roy\'s devotion to duty was a well-worn path.\r\n"Assuming you have the machine and I can operate it."\r\n\r\n"The machine is merely an attachment. It will plug into the instrument\r\npanel of your spacecraft. It operates automatically."\r\n\r\n"Good enough. You always were a whiz at these things. How far back do I\r\ngo? And who do I kill?"\r\n\r\n"I want you to strafe the Ark, exercising care not to hurt any of the\r\nanimals," said old Dr. Garfield Gar.\r\n\r\n"Noah\'s Ark?" Pilot Officer Roy Vanjan asked. "You mean during the\r\nFlood?"\r\n\r\n"Yes, I\'ve computed it exactly. You won\'t have to worry about getting\r\nthere at the wrong time."\r\n\r\n"You mean after the forty days\' rain, so I\'ll have good visibility.\r\nGood-o." He agreed readily and he\'d do as the doctor said, of course,\r\nbut he permitted a trace of skepticism in his inflection and a\r\nsearching look into his goblet.\r\n\r\n"No, not the fortieth day," Dr. Gar said, "but in what we are told was\r\nthe six hundred and first year, in the first month, the first day of\r\nthe month. The animals need dry land. I have it all figured out.

"\r\n\r\n"I hope so. I mean I\'m sure you have. You\'re the doctor, of course, but\r\nwasn\'t there some doubt about the accuracy of the old Book? I didn\'t\r\nknow you were a fundamentalist."\r\n\r\n"Am I not the repository of all human knowledge?" Dr. 

Gar asked. He was\r\nnot a bit angry with Roy Vanjan. "Am I not the last best hope? 

Has not\r\nall else failed us?"\r\n\r\n"Well, sure--"\r\n\r\n"Did not the Noahic Covenant, under which human government was\r\nestablished, fail? Has not Japhetic science been our undoing?"\r\n\r\nRoy looked lost. "I\'m no scholar, Doctor."\r\n\r\n"Agreed. But perhaps you\'ll grant that I am?" He looked with supreme\r\ncalm at the young pilot. "I\'m your new intelligence officer and you\'re\r\nmerely my striking arm. Help yourself to another brandy, son."\r\n\r\n"Maybe I\'d better not. I don\'t want to goof the mission."\r\n\r\n"There\'s time. You\'ll want some sleep first."\r\n\r\n"All right. I suppose I\'ll need a steady hand to murder Noah and the\r\nrest."\r\n\r\n"And Shem, and Ham, and Japheth, and Noah\'s wife," said Dr. Gar, "and\r\nthe three wives of his sons with them, as it was written. Especially\r\nJapheth. 

But not the animals, remember."\r\n\r\n"I understand that. If you think the Ten Commandments don\'t apply.\r\nWhichever one of them it was."\r\n\r\n"They were an element of the Mosaic Covenant. It, too, failed. Perhaps\r\nthe Garic Covenant, if I may be so vain, will endure."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe waters covered the Earth.\r\n\r\nA moment ago, before he activated the attachment, Pilot Officer Roy\r\nVanjan\'s spacecraft had been plunging towards the vortex of a ragged\r\nball of dust and vapor, the destroyed Earth of World War V. Now, in the\r\nAdamic Year 601 (or was it the Edenic?--he couldn\'t remember, though\r\nDr. Gar had let him study the Book), the waters stretched everywhere.\r\nAhead the sun glinted in reflection from something rising above the\r\nsurface. Ararat?\r\n\r\nHe made out the twin peaks. He throttled back to scarcely more than\r\nmach one and flew over them, high. His second pass took him back along\r\nhis own vapor trail. This time he spotted the tiny surface craft making\r\nfor the solitary bit of land. He had to hand it to Dr. 

Gar. The old\r\nboy\'s space-time grid had hit it right on the button.\r\n\r\nRoy was too high to distinguish details but he imagined that Noah and\r\nhis family would be on deck, full of the wonder of Mount Ararat rising,\r\nas promised, from the sea.\r\n\r\nBut there was another wonder--the vapor trails that stretched for miles\r\nacross the upper air. They were a sign of the lord\r\nGar and of his servant, Pilot Officer Vanjan, come to blast them into\r\neternity and change the future, to give the animals a chance.\r\n\r\nWho would chronicle his role as the re-arranging angel, the unheavenly\r\nhost about to gather up in violence the drifting souls below? These questions and more had been anticipated by Dr. Gar.\r\nSoon now, at the end of Roy\'s strafing run, it would be up to History\r\nto begin assembling the answers.\r\n\r\nHe slowed to mach minus and sent out wings. He would have to dip close\r\nto see if the entire Ark\'s complement was on deck. 

The job had to be\r\ndone right or Earth was kaput. Nothing personal, Noah, old boy.\r\n\r\nThere they were, on the starboard side of the top deck, well out from\r\nunder the pitch of the roof, craning their necks for a look at this\r\nmiracle in the sky where they had expected to see only a returning dove.\r\n\r\n"Behold!" My tidings\r\nare of the new future which your descendants will not know and so will\r\nnot doom."\r\n\r\nThe frightened upturned faces were far behind and he was talking to\r\nhimself.\r\n\r\n"Hear me, Noah, for I am come to destroy you, and with you your seeds\r\nof self-destruction. These are the tidings I bring from the future that\r\nhas ceased to exist because you existed--the future that will exist\r\nonce more when you cease to."\r\n\r\nHe heeled the spacecraft over and back. No more speeches, he told\r\nhimself, though he had studied the Book in fascination. He was a\r\nkiller, not a philosopher.\r\n\r\nHe would have to make his strafing run low. He roared at\r\nthe Ark a few feet above the waves.\r\n\r\nThey were all together in a clump, the eight of them.\r\n\r\nFarewell, Noah! he thought as his thumbs pressed on the death-dealing\r\nbutton. Farewell, Noah and Noah\'s wife!\r\n\r\nFarewell, Ham, and Ham\'s wife and unborn sons--farewell, Canaan, and\r\nCush, and Mizraim, and Phut!\r\n\r\nFarewell, Shem! Make way for the animal kingdom in the Garic\r\nCovenant.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe had made three passes and now he zoomed into the sky. He had\r\ndestroyed humanity and changed the future.\r\n\r\nOr had he? He\'d be dead, too, if he had, gone like the snap of a finger\r\nwith the last gasp from the Ark. He had killed his ancestors. _It\'s a flop. But he felt so damn silly!\r\n\r\nWell, he couldn\'t stand there all day. It was Monday and they would\r\nexpect him at the office.\r\n\r\nHe squared his shoulders and walked into the hall.\r\n\r\n    "Lung Cancer, Heart Attacks!\r\n    Heart Attacks, Lung Cancer!\r\n    Beware, old man, Be ... ware!

"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe tinkly message followed him up the hall. The toast!"\r\n\r\nShe scooted off his lap and ran into the kitchen. How she managed to\r\nburn toast in an electronic toaster beat him. By sending it down twice,\r\nhe suspected.\r\n\r\nHe picked up the paper by his plate and unfolded it. 

The first page, as\r\nusual, was devoted to the Propagandists. Headlines proclaimed: "375\r\ndied this weekend doing _you know what_." The second line asked: "Will\r\nyou be next?"\r\n\r\nIt made a good story because only three hundred deaths had been\r\npredicted. Here was\r\nan editorial by the Department of Health. He scanned it. 

Same old\r\nthing. Sex to be avoided like poison by all persons, male and female,\r\nover thirty-five years.\r\n\r\nChuck forked a piece of soya bread, and swabbed the last of ham grease\r\nand egg from his plate. He sat drinking his soya hot chocolate, and\r\nwanting a cigarette.\r\n\r\nSally finished eating, stretched, and the nylon threatened to rip. She\r\nwent and got his suit coat and hat. I\'ll call and tell them you\r\ncaught a virus!"\r\n\r\nHe almost took off his hat. Then he said, "You know it would show up\r\nin my weekly S-Count!" He shuddered just saying the words. God! 

how he\r\nhated that! He continued, "And if I slip once or twice on that, you\r\nknow what they do."\r\n\r\nFeeling sorry for her, he added half-heartedly, "But you\'re only\r\nthirty. But\r\nit was only a Catholic priest pedalling furiously along on a girl\'s\r\nbicycle. Then there had been another clash! He climbed out of the\r\nditch, and walked a ways down the highway. 

There it was. The priest was\r\njust climbing off the bike, and there was a motorcycle cop.\r\n\r\nChuck Dane walked up the highway to the scene and stood watching. Even in this cotton\r\nbatting, vacuum world of 1990 the Teenagers could find ways to kill\r\neach other off! This was damn\r\nundignified! He hated the kid, wanted to kill him with his bare hands.\r\n\r\nHe walked along, thinking how it had all come about. First it had been\r\nthe highway death toll. When it had reached over two thousand on week\r\ndays, and ten thousand on weekends, the government had stepped in.\r\nTheir solution had been simple and foolproof. They simply taxed gas out\r\nof sight. Now the oil companies exported their total output, and were\r\nmaking more money than ever.\r\n\r\nThen some fool in the A.M.A. had pointed out that almost as many people\r\nwere dying of lung cancer as had previously fallen on the ribbons of\r\ndeath.\r\n\r\nAt first Congress had passed a bill to ban the manufacture of all\r\ncigarettes. But the black market flourished and the psychiatrists\r\nyelped. They yelped that the approach to the problem was all wrong,\r\ndue to the fact that they hadn\'t been consulted. This was warping\r\npersonalities and making martyrs out of cigarette users. The way to do\r\nit, they said, was to have tobacco products available, but to shame\r\npeople into giving them up of their own free wills.\r\n\r\nThey theorized that a cigarette smoker is really a frustrated person\r\nunable to cope with the adult world. When he puts a cig between his\r\nlips he is really searching for his mother\'s nipple. Therefore, the\r\nthing to do is to force him to out-grow this, rather than take it\r\nforcibly away from him. Same way with a cigar smoker or pipe smoker.\r\n\r\nThe psychiatric lobby prevailed and the government repealed the\r\ntobacco bill. And replaced it with another. Now it was the law for all\r\ncigarettes, cigars and pipe tobacco to have an hallucination inducing\r\ndrug, Xlene 91, in them. And taken away the only\r\npleasure a guy had left!\r\n\r\nHe was in sight of his place of work now. A huge half-circle of\r\nplexiglass that was Airex Roller Skating Factory. He hoped the\r\nbill to change working hours to three hours would pass soon....\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAt two o\'clock in the afternoon, Chuck lined up with the rest of the\r\noffice force to walk single file past the hidden electronic camera. Chuck tried to\r\nlook into the green eyes, so calm and assured, but he had to look away.\r\n\r\n"You okay, Dane?"\r\n\r\n"Sure! Tired, that\'s all. 

Helluva long day!"\r\n\r\n"Yes. Well, you come in and see me tomorrow. 

We\'ll have us a little\r\ntalk."\r\n\r\nRapidly, Chuck left the building. He muttered, "Like hell we will,\r\nHeadshrinker!"\r\n\r\nFurtively, he left the usual road home, and walked into a corner\r\ndrugstore. Then he set fire to them,\r\nnot minding the acrid smoke.\r\n\r\nHe put a cigarette to his lips. Still he hesitated, fearing the\r\nhallucinations, about which he had heard but never experienced.\r\n\r\nSuddenly he grinned and leaned back, lit up and closed his eyes. The\r\nparade of pictures began in front of his eyeballs. First a picture of\r\nhuman lungs, and slowly the cancer virus invades them and eats them\r\naway. Then the parade of men and women clutching their chests, writhing\r\nin death throes. Chuck Dane smiled, enjoying each hallucination.\r\nPretending that the unlucky victims were the Propagandists.\r\n\r\nHe lit another cigarette from the butt of the first one, and leaned\r\nback, feeling his lungs pleasantly saturated with smoke.\r\n\r\nWhen ten cigarettes were snubbed in a row on the glass top of the desk,\r\nhe stopped and mused. He got up. 

Left the den. Went to the kitchen\r\nand leaned in the door watching her.\r\n\r\nTomorrow was Tuesday. His day for S-Count. But he wouldn\'t submit to\r\nthat again. Or have that little talk with Doctor Benton. Tomorrow,\r\ngoing to work, when he crossed U.S. 75 he would give some Teenager a\r\nhell of a thrill! 

But tonight ... tonight....\r\n\r\n"Come here, baby!" he whispered harshly.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEnd of Project Gutenberg\'s The Downhill Side of Thirty, by Virgil F. Shockley\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


A Viking? A pyramid builder? One of Xenophon\'s Ten\r\nThousand? Or was he, perhaps (for it is always possible), Alexander the\r\nGreat?\r\n\r\nThatcher Blitt had a product to sell. And sell he did, for other\r\nreasons that he alone had noted at the beginning. The races of mankind\r\nhave twisted and turned with incredible complexity over the years; the\r\nnumbers of people have been enormous.\r\n\r\nWith thirty thousand years in which to work, it was impossible that\r\nthere was not, somewhere along the line, a famous ancestor for\r\neverybody. A minor king would often suffice, or even a general in some\r\nforgotten army. And if these direct ancestors were not enough, it was\r\nfairly simple to establish close blood kinship with famous men. The\r\nblood lines of Man, you see, begin with a very few people. In all of\r\nancient Greece, in the time of Pericles, there were only a few thousand\r\nfamilies.\r\n\r\nSeeing all this, Thatcher Blitt became a busy man. It was necessary not\r\nonly to patent his idea, but to produce the enormous capital needed\r\nto found a large organization. The cost of the time scanner was at\r\nfirst prohibitive, but gradually that obstacle was overcome, only for\r\nThatcher to find that the government for many years prevented him from\r\nusing it. Yet Blitt was indomitable. And eventually, after years of\r\nheart-rending waiting, Genealogy, Inc., began operations.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIt was a tremendous success. Within months, the very name of the\r\ncompany and its taut slogan, "An Ancestor for Everybody," became\r\nhousehold words. There was but one immediate drawback. It soon became\r\napparent that, without going back very far into the past, it was\r\nsometimes impossible to tell who was really the next father in line.\r\nThe mothers were certain, but the fathers were something else again.\r\nThis was a ponderable point.\r\n\r\nBut Blitt refused to be discouraged. He set various electronic\r\nengineers to work on the impasse and a solution was found. An ingenious\r\ndevice which tested blood electronically through the scanner--based\r\non the different sine waves of the blood groups--saved the day. That\r\ninvention was the last push Genealogy, Inc., was ever to need. It\r\nrolled on to become one of the richest and, for a long while, most\r\nexclusive corporations in the world.\r\n\r\nYet it was still many years before Thatcher Blitt himself had time to\r\nrest. There were patent infringements to be fought, new developments\r\nin the labs to be watched, new ways to be found to make the long and\r\narduous task of father-tracing easier and more economical. Hence he was\r\nwell past sixty when he at last had time to begin considering himself.\r\n\r\nHe had become by this time a moderately offensive man. Surrounded as\r\nhe had been all these years by pomp and luxury, by impressive names\r\nand extraordinary family trees, he had succumbed at last. He became\r\nunbearably name-conscious.\r\n\r\nHe began by regrouping his friends according to their ancestries. His\r\ninfrequent parties were characterized by his almost Parliamentarian\r\nsystem of seating. No doubt, all this had been in Thatcher Blitt to\r\nbegin with--it may well be, in perhaps varying quantities, in all of\r\nus--but it grew with him, prospered with him. Yet in all those years he\r\nnever once inspected his own forebears.\r\n\r\nYou may well ask, was he afraid? One answers, one does not know. But at\r\nany rate, the fact remains that Thatcher Blitt, at the age of 67, was\r\none of the few rich men in the world who did not know who exactly their\r\nancestors had been.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAnd so, at last, we come to the day when Thatcher Blitt was sitting\r\nalone in his office, one languid hand draped vacantly over his brow,\r\nlistening with deep satisfaction to the hum and click of the enormous\r\noperations which were going on in the building around him.\r\n\r\nWhat moved him that day remains uncertain. Perhaps it was that, from\r\nwhere he was sitting, he could see row upon row of action pictures of\r\nfamous men which had been taken from his time scanners. 

Or perhaps it\r\nwas simply that this profound question had been gnawing at him all\r\nthese years, deeper and deeper, and on this day broke out into the\r\nlight.\r\n\r\nBut whatever the reason, at 11:02 that morning, he leaped vitally from\r\nhis chair. He summoned Cathcart, his chief assistant, and gave him the\r\nimmortal command.\r\n\r\n"Cathcart!" he grated, stung to the core of his being. 

"Who am I?"\r\n\r\nCathcart rushed off to find out.\r\n\r\nThere followed some of the most taut and fateful days in the brilliant\r\nhistory of Genealogy, Inc. Father-tracing is, of course, a painstaking\r\nbusiness. But it was not long before word had begun to filter out to\r\ninterested people.\r\n\r\nThe first interesting discovery made was a man called Blott, in\r\neighteenth century England. (No explanation was ever given for the\r\nname\'s alteration from Blott to Blitt. Certain snide individuals\r\ntook this to mean that the name had been changed as a means to avoid\r\nprosecution, or some such, and immediately began making light remarks\r\nabout the Blotts on old Blitt\'s escutcheon.) This Blott had the\r\ndistinction of having been a wineseller of considerable funds.\r\n\r\nThis reputedly did not sit well with Thatcher Blitt. Merchants, he\r\nsnapped, however successful, are not worthy of note. 

He wanted empire\r\nbuilders. He wanted, at the very least, a name he had heard about. 

A\r\nname that appeared in the histories.\r\n\r\nHis workers furiously scanned back into the past.\r\n\r\nMonths went by before the next name appeared. In 9th century England,\r\nthere was a wandering minstrel named John (last name unprintable) who\r\nachieved considerable notoriety as a ballad singer, before dying an\r\nunnatural death in the boudoir of a lady of high fashion. Although\r\nthe details of this man\'s life were of extreme interest, they did\r\nnot impress the old man. 

He was, on the contrary, rather shaken. 

A\r\nminstrel. And a rogue to boot.\r\n\r\nThere were shakeups in Genealogy, Inc. Cathcart was replaced by a man\r\nnamed Jukes, a highly competent man despite his interesting family\r\nname. Jukes forged ahead full steam past the birth of Christ (no\r\nrelation). But he was well into ancient Egypt before the search began\r\nto take on the nature of a crisis.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nUp until then, there was simply nobody. Or to be more precise, nobody\r\nbut _nobodies_. It was incredible, all the laws of chance were against\r\nit, but there was, actually, not a single ancestor of note. And no\r\nway of faking one, for Thatcher Blitt couldn\'t be fooled by his own\r\nmethods. What there was was simply an unending line of peasants,\r\nserfs, an occasional foot soldier or leather worker. Past John the\r\nballad-singer, there was no one at all worth reporting to the old man.\r\n\r\nThis situation would not continue, of course. There were so few\r\nfamilies for men to spring from. The entire Gallic nation, for example,\r\na great section of present-day France, sprang from the family of one\r\nlone man in the north of France in the days before Christ. Every native\r\nFrenchman, therefore, was at least the son of a king. It was impossible\r\nfor Thatcher Blitt to be less.\r\n\r\nSo the hunt went on from day to day, past ancient Greece, past\r\nJarmo, past the wheel and metals and farming and on even past all\r\ncivilization, outward and backward into the cold primordial wastes of\r\nnorthern Germany.\r\n\r\nAnd still there was nothing. Though Jukes lived in daily fear of losing\r\nhis job, there was nothing to do but press on. In Germany, he reduced\r\nBlitt\'s ancestor to a slovenly little man who was one of only three\r\nmen in the entire tribe, or family, one of three in an area which now\r\ncontains millions. But Blitt\'s ancestor, true to form, was simply a\r\nmember of the tribe. As was his father before him.\r\n\r\nYet onward it went. Westward back into the French caves, southward\r\ninto Spain and across the unrecognizable Mediterranean into a verdant\r\nNorth Africa, backward in time past even the Cro-Magnons, and yet ever\r\nbackward, 30,000 years, 35,000, with old Blitt reduced now practically\r\nto gibbering and still never an exceptional forebear.\r\n\r\nThere came a time when Jukes had at last, inevitably, to face the old\r\nman. He had scanned back as far as he could. 

The latest ancestor he had\r\nunearthed for Blitt was a hairy creature who did not walk erect. And\r\nyet, even here, Blitt refused to concede.\r\n\r\n"It may be," he howled, "it _must_ be that my ancestor _was_ the first\r\nman to walk erect or light a fire--to do _something_."\r\n\r\nIt was not until Jukes pointed out that all those things had been\r\nalready examined and found hopeless that Blitt finally gave in. Blitt\r\nwas a relative, of course, of the first man to stand erect, the man\r\nwith the first human brain. But so was everybody else on the face of\r\nthe Earth. 

There was truly nowhere else to explore. What would be found\r\nnow would be only the common history of mankind.\r\n\r\nBlitt retired to his chambers and refused to be seen.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe story went the rounds, as such stories will. And it was then\r\nat last, after 40,000 years of insignificance, that the name of\r\nBlitt found everlasting distinction. The story was picked up, fully\r\ndocumented, by psychologists and geneticists of the time, and inserted\r\ninto textbooks as a profound commentary on the forces of heredity. The\r\nname of Thatcher Blitt in particular has become famous, has persisted\r\nuntil this day. For he is the only man yet discovered, or ever likely\r\nto be discovered, with this particular distinction.\r\n\r\nIn 40,000 years of scanner-recorded history, the blood line of Blitt\r\n(or Blott) never once produced an exceptional man.\r\n\r\nThat record is unsurpassed.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


But he hadn\'t been able to pin\r\nthe feeling down.\r\n\r\n    _... Our civilization predates that of Earth\'s by millions of years.\r\n    We are an advanced, peaceful race. Yet, since Earth\'s first rocket\r\n    landed here thirteen years ago, we have been looked upon as freaks\r\n    and contemptuously called \'bug-men\' behind our backs! This is our\r\n    planet. We gave of our far-advanced knowledge and science freely, so\r\n    that Earth would be a better place. We asked nothing in return, but\r\n    we were rewarded by having forced upon us foreign ideas of\r\n    government, religion, and behavior. Our protests have been silenced\r\n    by an armed-police and punitive system we\'ve never before needed.\r\n    Someday you will awaken to this injustice. On that day in your life,\r\n    you have my sympathy and pity!_\r\n\r\nStark knew that the Settlement\'s Investigations Lab could readily\r\ndetermine the identity of the Martian who had written the note. But he\r\nhesitated to send it over. Under the New System, such troublemakers were\r\nbanished to the slave-labor details of the precious-earth mines to the\r\nNorth.\r\n\r\nCrumpling the note in sudden decision, Stark dropped it into the office\r\nincendiary tube. The morning visi-report had shown that there were more\r\nthan 17,000 workers at the mines. Only five had been Earthlings. Let the\r\narmed-police system find the Martian through their own channels. It\r\nwasn\'t his job.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nA glance at the solar clock on the far wall reminded him there was still\r\ntime for one more interview before the last bell, so he impatiently\r\nsignaled his secretary to send in the waiting couple.\r\n\r\nOrdinarily, he liked his work and time meant little to him. He had\r\njumped from interpreter to director in the ten years since the\r\ndepartment had been created. But this day was different.\r\n\r\nStark was to announce his engagement at the Chief\'s monthly dinner party\r\nthat evening and time had seemed to drag since his lunch with Carol.\r\n\r\nWhen the door opened, he rose and nodded to the plump, freckle-faced\r\ngirl who entered. The girl topped five feet by one or two inches, but\r\nshe was no taller than the Martian man who followed her at the\r\nprescribed four feet.\r\n\r\nAfter the girl had seated herself, Stark and the Martian sat down. Stark\r\nopened the folder, which his secretary had placed on his desk earlier.\r\n\r\n"Your names are Ruth and Ralph Gilraut? And you want permission to move\r\ninto Housing Perimeter D?" It was merely a formality, since the\r\ninformation was in the folder.\r\n\r\nWhen the girl nodded, Stark placed a small check mark in the space\r\nbeside her name. Then he turned to the Martian.\r\n\r\nThe large, single red eye set deep in the Martian\'s smooth, green\r\nforehead above the two brown ones blinked twice before he answered.\r\n\r\nHe spoke deliberately. "As is required of all Martians under the New\r\nSystem, I have taken the name of one of the early Earthlings to write\r\nand pronounce." The large red eye blinked again. "My wife would like\r\nto move into Housing Perimeter D. By regulation, I respect her wish."\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\nStark placed a check mark by the Martian\'s name. He wiped the smudge of\r\nink off his hand and said, "You both know, of course, that Perimeter D\r\nis reserved for couples who have intermarried and are about to have\r\noffspring?"\r\n\r\nThe girl and the Martian nodded, and the girl passed Stark a medical\r\nreport. Stark looked over the report and then made a notation on a small\r\npink slip.\r\n\r\nHe said, "This permit certifies that you are eligible to move from\r\nPerimeter E to Housing Perimeter D. It also certifies that your husband\r\nhas no record as a troublemaker." Stark looked at the girl. "You\r\nunderstand that you may visit your friends in Perimeter E, but, by law,\r\nthey will not be allowed to enter Perimeter D to visit you. And, of\r\ncourse, the new law clearly states that neither of you may visit\r\nEarthlings in Housing Perimeter A, B or C."\r\n\r\nThe girl looked down at her hands. Her voice was almost inaudible. "My\r\nhusband and I are familiar with the advantages and disadvantages listed\r\nunder the section pertaining to intermarriage in the new law, Mr. Stark.\r\nThank you.

"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nStark rose as they left. For a brief moment, he thought he had detected\r\na sense of rebellion in their attitude. But that was not possible.\r\n\r\nThe new law provided equality for all. And his department had been\r\ncreated to iron out relations between the two races--excepting\r\ncomplaints originated by troublemakers for the purpose of weakening the\r\nNew System. In such cases, Investigations had stepped in and the Martian\r\nor Earthling troublemaker had been sent to the rare-earth mines.\r\n\r\nThe reddish light filtering in through the quartz and lead wall of his\r\noffice showed that it was almost time for the last bell.\r\n\r\nOn the street below, shoppers were streaming out of the stores on their\r\nway to the various housing perimeters.\r\n\r\nEarthlings were climbing into their speedy little jet cars for the short\r\ntrip to the recently modernized inner perimeters. Martians were waiting\r\nfor the slower auto buses. The traffic problem had been solved, under\r\nthe New System, by restricting the use of the Martian-built jet cars to\r\npersons living in the inner perimeters.\r\n\r\nAs Stark watched, a black jet car impatiently hurtled out of the line of\r\ntraffic, bowled through a crowd of Martians waiting for an auto bus, and\r\nskidded to a stop at the curb in front of the building.\r\n\r\nA tall girl got out. The red evening glow reflecting from her golden\r\nhair, made her breathing globe almost amber. Male Martians and\r\nEarthlings alike turned to stare in appreciation as she pushed her way\r\nthrough the crowd to the building\'s compressor lock. Carol was that kind\r\nof girl.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAlmost at the exact moment that Carol opened the door into Stark\'s\r\noffice, the yellow visi-screen of the vocal box upon Stark\'s desk\r\nflashed on brilliantly and the Chief\'s booming voice filled the office.\r\nThe light from the screen picked up the highlights on the furniture and\r\ngave a sallow, greenish cast to Stark\'s features. Carol stepped back\r\ninto the doorway to stay out of range of the two-way unit.\r\n\r\n"Stark!" The automatic tuner on the box corrected to bring the Chief\'s\r\nimage in wire-sharp focus.\r\n\r\n"Yes, sir?"\r\n\r\n"About the dinner tonight. 

Just checking to make sure you\'re planning to\r\nbe there. 

We want a full turnout. An inspection team has come up from\r\nEarth and we have two visiting dignitaries from Venus."\r\n\r\nStark nodded and waited for the Chief to say something else, but the\r\nvisi-screen blanked out.\r\n\r\nCarol said, "That was Dad, wasn\'t it?"\r\n\r\nStark felt very depressed suddenly. "Haven\'t you told him yet?"\r\n\r\n"No. He\'s been tied up with those inspectors all afternoon. And you know\r\nhow Dad is, Johnny. There\'s a right and a wrong time to tell him things.\r\nRight now, he\'s only interested in hearing about Earth."\r\n\r\n"But we\'re supposed to announce our engagement tonight at the dinner."\r\nHe shook his head. 

"We can\'t go on forever with just a few stolen\r\nmoments here and there, eating an occasional lunch or third meal\r\ntogether in little out-of-the-way places."\r\n\r\nCarol laughed, the youthful swell of her breasts against the soft,\r\nspun-glass material of her blouse. "Don\'t worry so, Johnny! I\'m a big\r\ngirl now. This is my eighteenth birthday. Dad\'s bark is much worse than\r\nhis bite. I\'ll tell him about us on the way home.

"\r\n\r\nShe moved closer to him, until he could feel the warmth of her body. He\r\ncould see the warm, damp indentation where her breathing globe had\r\nrested against her shoulders and chest.\r\n\r\nShe asked teasingly, "What did you get me for my birthday, Johnny?\r\nSomething real nice?"\r\n\r\n"What did you want?" Johnny asked her gently.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAnd suddenly she wasn\'t teasing any more. She put her arms around him.\r\n"Dad and my brother would say I\'m crazy. But all I want, Johnny, is you.\r\nJust you! 

You know that."\r\n\r\nStark had picked out her birthday present, but he wanted it to be a\r\nsurprise for that night. He said, "I already saw one of your presents. A\r\nblack jet car!"\r\n\r\n"How did you know that?"\r\n\r\n"I saw you drive up in it a few minutes ago."\r\n\r\nCarol giggled. "Dad gave it to me. Did you see me plow through that\r\ncrowd waiting for the auto bus?"\r\n\r\n"Did your brother send you anything?"\r\n\r\nShe nodded. "Three new outfits from Earth. They were on the same liner\r\nthat brought the inspection team to the Settlement this morning. Oh,\r\nyes, and the captain of the liner brought me this."\r\n\r\nShe showed him the tiny pin she wore attached to her collar. The pin\r\nitself was a carefully wrought but cruel caricature of an awkward\r\nbuglike creature. A small ruby set in the center of its face served as\r\nits eye.\r\n\r\nStark frowned. "Carol, you shouldn\'t be wearing that." He reached up and\r\nunpinned it. "That\'s the sort of thing our department is fighting."\r\n\r\n"But the captain said it was the latest rage back on Earth. They\'re even\r\nmaking toys like it. I\'m sure they\'re not designed to ... to poke fun at\r\nanyone."\r\n\r\nStark started to say something, but the last bell interrupted him. He\r\nsaid, "If you\'re going to take your father home and tell him about us\r\nbefore the dinner, you\'d better hurry. I\'ll come early.

"\r\n\r\nCarol kissed him and said good-by. She left the pin on Stark\'s desk and\r\nwas smiling at him as she closed the door.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAfter waiting until the first rush of workers had gone and the building\r\nwas quiet, Stark caught the elevator down. The overhead lights in the\r\ncompressor lock were reflected in the twin rows of breathing globes. The\r\ngreen-tinted ones had to be used by Martians in the building, and the\r\nclear ones were used by Earthmen when they were outside in the Martian\r\natmosphere. Stark stopped in at a little open shop down one of the many\r\nside streets. The sign said "Closed," but he rang the bell until a\r\nlittle, dried-up Martian appeared.\r\n\r\nThe storekeeper handed him a small box. Stark opened it to examine the\r\nring--Carol\'s birthday present. The single, large diamond set in the\r\nthin precious-metal band dated back to an all-but-forgotten custom\r\npracticed on Earth. Stark thought the engagement ring would please\r\nCarol, though.\r\n\r\nStanding in the compressor lock at the Chief\'s home later, Stark rubbed\r\nthe diamond against the sleeve of his tunic. He fumbled with his\r\nbreathing globe and then pushed the button that activated the door. The\r\ntele-guard beyond the opening door scanned him rapidly. As he stepped\r\nforward, a red light above the tele-guard flashed on and the door began\r\nto close again.\r\n\r\nStark threw all his strength against the door and squeezed through into\r\nthe house.\r\n\r\nThroughout the house, Stark could hear the alarm bell. A taped voice,\r\nactivated by the tele-guard, said, "Do not enter! 

Do not enter!"\r\n\r\nHe found Carol and the Chief in the library alone. Nearly purple with\r\nrage, the Chief drew himself up to his full six feet.\r\n\r\nThe Chief bellowed, "Stark! Are you crazy?"\r\n\r\nThe growing feeling of sickness spread through Stark.\r\n\r\n"Who do you think you are?" the Chief yelled. "Get back to your office\r\nand consider yourself under arrest as a troublemaker. Give you people an\r\ninch and you try to walk away with everything. Why, I wouldn\'t let you\r\ntouch my daughter if you were the last living being in the Universe!"\r\n\r\nCarol didn\'t look up. 

She stood through it all, silently, without\r\nmoving. Stark knew now where his blind spot had been. He turned and left\r\nthem.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBack at his office, he waited for the police. Stark stared down at his\r\nreflection in the polished top of the desk. A yellow, moist film of\r\nsweat covered his face. 

The red eye set in his forehead blinked. But the\r\npain visible just behind the surface of that eye was not over Carol or\r\nhimself.\r\n\r\nThe pain was for what he was seeing for the first time ... now.\r\n\r\n                                                   --BASCOM JONES, JR.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Galaxy Science Fiction_ February 1955.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. "\r\n\r\nAgain Kroll shrugged. "The Inquisitor would like Miss Horniman first,\r\nMr. Leslie. 

This is the preferred order, and this is the order that\r\nwill be."\r\n\r\nA guard stepped forward and shoved the sobbing girl up and ahead,\r\ntoward the door. The man named Leslie clashed his manacles impotently\r\ntogether and spat. "Butchers! Torturers!"\r\n\r\n"Please, Mr. Leslie," Kroll said gently, a pained expression on his\r\nface. "You make our job even harder than it is."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe followed the girl into the adjoining room, where the Inquisitor was\r\nwaiting. The Interrogation Chamber was an immense rectangular room with\r\nconcrete floor and bleak white walls, in the center of which stood the\r\nInquisitor.\r\n\r\n"Good morning, Kroll," the Inquisitor said. Its metallic voice rattled\r\nand boomed in the big room. In the depths of the machine, relays\r\nclicked and hummed. Kroll bowed to it, and the Inquisitor responded\r\nwith a gesture of a prolonged metal arm. "The first prisoner, Kroll."\r\n\r\n"Miss Florence Horniman," Kroll said. "Accused of treason against the\r\nState. Denies charge.

"\r\n\r\n"How do you plead?" the machine asked coldly.\r\n\r\n"Not guilty," stammered the girl.\r\n\r\nTwo huge metal arms extended from the Inquisitor\'s sides and folded\r\naround her. They drew her across the room to the bosom of the robot.\r\n"Feed in the data, Kroll."\r\n\r\nAt the signal, Kroll slipped in the tape on the girl. A moment passed\r\nwhile the Inquisitor digested the data, and then: "The plea of not\r\nguilty is rejected as invalid."\r\n\r\n"You can\'t just do that!" 

the girl said. 

"That\'s my plea!"\r\n\r\n"Not valid in view of the evidence," said the Inquisitor. Kroll smiled\r\ndistantly. He had seen this scene repeated, over and over, almost\r\nevery day for the ten years he had held the post. He wrapped his\r\nblue-and-gold Interrogator\'s cloak around himself impressively and\r\nstepped forward.\r\n\r\n"You are accused of treason against the State," Kroll said sonorously.\r\n"But it is my duty to inform you that your sentence may be mitigated\r\nupon your delivering us certain information--about leaders of your\r\nmovement, future plans, location of your party cell, and so forth."\r\n\r\nFlorence Horniman\'s eyes flashed brightly. "I won\'t tell you anything!"\r\n\r\n"Perhaps I did not make myself clear," Kroll said. He repeated his\r\noffer.\r\n\r\n"The answer is still no!"\r\n\r\nKroll sighed. 

"Very well," he said. A third hand slid from the\r\nInquisitor\'s body and a needle-thin finger traced a line down the\r\ngirl\'s bare arm. A bloody trickle appeared.\r\n\r\nShe began to sob again. Kroll stepped closer and lifted her head. "Why\r\nmust you hold out?" he asked. "Why don\'t you speak?

"\r\n\r\nStill silence. The finger rose again and sliced lightly across her\r\ncheek.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"All right, take her away," Kroll said when twenty minutes had passed.\r\nThe Inquisitor was humming merrily, busily taping the data that had\r\nbeen extracted from the girl and feeding it to the main computers\r\ndownstairs. They would integrate it and notify the State Police. It was\r\na smooth-functioning system.\r\n\r\nThe bloody thing that had been Florence Horniman was led away by\r\na guard, and the next prisoner led in. It was the middle-aged man,\r\nChester Wengrove.\r\n\r\n"Get your hands off me," he snapped to the guard as he was shoved into\r\nthe room. "You have no right to--"\r\n\r\n"Unfortunately, as a representative of the State he has every right,"\r\nKroll said calmly. He fed Wengrove\'s tape to the Inquisitor. The trial\r\nproceeded.\r\n\r\nWengrove was stubborn; it took half an hour to break him down at all,\r\nbut when he did speak he sang freely, giving data on his cell of the\r\nMovement.\r\n\r\n"Very good," the Inquisitor said when Wengrove finally coughed and said\r\nhe knew no more. "You are completely exonerated from the charge of\r\ntreason, in view of the information you have given."\r\n\r\nThe eyes in the bloody face lit up. "I\'m free, you mean?"\r\n\r\n"Unfortunately, no," the Inquisitor said. "Because of your danger\r\nto the State, you must be kept in Quarantine Camp, along with other\r\ndiseased former members of society, until such time as we are able to\r\nclear your mind of its confusion. But you will not be punished."\r\n\r\n"I won\'t be punished?" Wengrove repeated mindlessly.\r\n\r\n"When the Inquisitor says something, it means it," Kroll said. "Take\r\nhim away."\r\n\r\nThe next prisoner was Neil Leslie. He strode into the Inquisitor\'s\r\nChamber without having to be pushed, and confronted Kroll defiantly.\r\n"My turn, eh?"\r\n\r\nKroll nodded. "Your companions have both been removed." He nodded\r\nmeaningful toward the Inquisitor, whose claws were red with the blood\r\nof Florence Horniman and Chester Wengrove. "They both spoke most\r\nsatisfactorily----after some persuasion.

"\r\n\r\n"Torture, you mean."\r\n\r\n"We\'ve been through this already," Kroll said. "Since you\'re going to\r\ntalk anyway, I don\'t understand why you can\'t save yourself a great\r\ndeal of pain by talking now, before I hand you to the Inquisitor."\r\n\r\n"Because I don\'t mean to talk at all," Leslie said. He ran a hand\r\nthrough his shock of blonde hair and glared fiercely at Kroll.\r\n\r\n"Very well," the Interrogator said. He stepped to the robot and slipped\r\nin Neil Leslie\'s tape.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"I don\'t understand you at all," Kroll admitted, looking down at the\r\npain-racked body before him. "Why don\'t you talk? 

I don\'t _want_ to\r\nkeep you in here, you know."\r\n\r\nBloodshot eyes looked back at him, eyes clouded with pain and hatred.\r\n"I\'m not saying anything," Leslie murmured. "Oil up your robot and\r\nlet\'s try again."\r\n\r\nFor the hundredth time the Inquisitor\'s talons descended, raked a red\r\nline across the man\'s body. He shuddered, but did not speak. Kroll\r\nshook his head impatiently. No prisoner had ever held out against the\r\nInquisitor this long before. He found himself perspiring.\r\n\r\nThe Inquisitor said, "The name of your leader is David Cosbro. Is this\r\ntrue?"\r\n\r\nNo answer.\r\n\r\nA needle descended.\r\n\r\nStill no answer.\r\n\r\n"Your Cell was located in East Appalachia. Upper Quadrant. 

Is this\r\ntrue?"\r\n\r\nNo answer again.\r\n\r\nMinutes passed, minutes in which Leslie continued to stare defiantly\r\noutward, continued to clench his fists and remain silent.\r\n\r\nFinally the Inquisitor opened its tightly-clamped arms and let Leslie\r\nstagger out. He slumped to the ground at the feet of the robot and\r\nleaned dazedly against the Inquisitor\'s gleaming base.\r\n\r\n"Prisoner is on the verge of death," the Inquisitor said. "Further\r\nquestioning is pointless."\r\n\r\nKroll looked down in surprise and chagrin. In ten years, this was the\r\nfirst time a prisoner had not broken under Interrogation. He scowled\r\nangrily; it was his first failure.\r\n\r\n"You\'re a stubborn man, Leslie. But it\'s killed you."\r\n\r\n"I\'m not dead yet," the prisoner said brokenly. Suddenly he mustered\r\nsome strength and managed to look up. "Tell me something, Kroll. I want\r\nto know something."\r\n\r\n"Yes?"\r\n\r\n"Why do you do what you do?"\r\n\r\n"You mean--Interrogate?"\r\n\r\n"I mean torture," Leslie said.\r\n\r\n"I am an Interrogator because it is my duty to the State. Treason must\r\nbe unmasked, the enemies of the State destroyed. It is necessary."\r\n\r\nLeslie looked up, and there seemed to be pity in his eyes. "Just one\r\nquestion, Kroll. 

Doesn\'t it bother you, when you go home? _How do you\r\nknow you\'re right and we\'re wrong?_"\r\n\r\nKroll started to say something, then saw there was no point in\r\nbothering.\r\n\r\n"Prisoner is dead," said the Inquisitor.\r\n\r\n"Take him away," ordered Kroll. The day was over.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWhat Leslie had said preyed on Kroll\'s mind all the way home. He got\r\nout of the tube and made his way to his austere room with his mind\r\nfixed on one question--the snarling words the dying prisoner had\r\nhurled at him: _How do you know you\'re right and we\'re wrong?_\r\n\r\nThey _had_ to be wrong, Kroll told himself firmly. The State had to\r\nbe right. It was necessary; it was logical; it was the way things had\r\nalways been.\r\n\r\nBut the thought obsessed him, and the image of Neil Leslie\'s face,\r\nbloody but undefeated, hung before him as he went about his evening\'s\r\nactivities. The face was still in his mind as he prepared to go to bed.\r\n\r\nOdd, Kroll thought. This was the first time he had been disturbed after\r\na torture session. He had seen hundreds--no, thousands--pass through\r\nthe Inquisitor, come out shambling rags of bone and flesh, and it had\r\nnever bothered him, because they were enemies of the State and deserved\r\nno more.\r\n\r\nHe dropped off into an uneasy sleep. But suddenly, in the small hours\r\nof the night, he sat bolt upright in bed, a cold, clammy perspiration\r\nbreaking out on him.\r\n\r\nLeslie had just asked the question for the hundredth time. And Kroll\r\nhad had no answer. He _didn\'t_ know who was right. He just didn\'t know.\r\nHis mind, unswervingly loyal for so many years, swayed in an agony of\r\ndoubt.\r\n\r\nHe got out of bed and paced back and forth across the floor of his room.\r\n\r\n"The State is wrong!" he said aloud. 

But it didn\'t sound right. It\r\ncouldn\'t be true. It wasn\'t true. "Stupid!" he told himself. It\r\nwas stupid to distrust the State--and wrong. "Wrong! Criminally,\r\ndisgustingly wrong!"\r\n\r\nThere! He felt better. He had rid himself of his foolish doubts. "How\r\ncould I have been so foolish?" he said aloud. His nerves felt better\r\nnow. Once again he was ready to do his duty as a loyal officer of the\r\nState.\r\n\r\nSmiling to himself for being so easily disturbed by the remarks of\r\ndisloyal traitors, he climbed back into bed and closed his eyes. A few\r\nmoments later, he was asleep.\r\n\r\nIn the morning, everything seemed to be all right; the terrors of the\r\nlast twelve hours were pale things of the past, no longer exerting\r\npressure on him. He caught the tube and headed to the Ministry.\r\n\r\nHe donned his uniform in the locker room and took the elevator to the\r\nInterrogation Floor. He stepped into his office. It was empty. 

No\r\nprisoners this morning? It didn\'t seem likely.\r\n\r\nHe pushed open the inner door and entered the Interrogation Chamber.\r\nTo his surprise, he saw Matthews, one of his assistants, wearing the\r\nuniform of an Interrogator and standing near the robot, arms folded.\r\n\r\n"What are you doing in here dressed that way?" Kroll snapped.\r\n\r\n"I am the new Interrogator," Matthews told him.\r\n\r\n"Since when?"\r\n\r\n"The appointment was made very early this morning," the Inquisitor\r\nsaid. "We have all the evidence we need to brand you as a traitor to\r\nthe State."\r\n\r\nThe new Interrogator turned a switch, and Kroll heard his own voice\r\ncome from a speaker. "_The State is wrong! Stupid! Wrong! Criminally,\r\ndisgustingly wrong! How could I have been so foolish?_"\r\n\r\n"There is no need to deny these words," said the Interrogator. "It is\r\nonly necessary that you tell us with whom you have been working."\r\n\r\n"But there\'s no one!" Kroll shouted. "You don\'t understand! 

I\'m loyal!\r\nI can explain!"\r\n\r\nBut the new Interrogator merely looked cold as the long, chilling metal\r\narms of the Inquisitor reached out and gathered Kroll to its steel\r\nbosom.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


exclaimed DeCrabbe haughtily. "Always dislike long\r\nconversations you know. Supposing you tell me what you know so can\r\nexterminate them without further delay. No doubt solution before dusk."\r\n\r\n"Before dusk?" asked the mayor, dumfounded. "Oh, no, not today, I\'m\r\nafraid. 

They\'ve been around too many years to whip in one day."\r\n\r\n"Perhaps shall require two days then," said Five-gun Charles DeCrabbe\r\ngraciously. "But doubt it. 

Tell me what you know of them."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Very well," assented the older man. "Perhaps the best place to\r\nbegin is with their name. When we first occupied this planet, a\r\nbare twenty years ago, we called them wolfhawk-whirlybirds and\r\ntigerhawk-whirlybirds because they preyed on vicious animals. The\r\nwhirlybirds were our best friends in those days. The only trouble is\r\nthat they ran out of tigers and wolves to eat."\r\n\r\n"Presumed they are now called peoplehawk-whirlybirds?" "Although that isn\'t their full\r\nname. From the way they attack--"\r\n\r\n"Most important," interrupted Five-gun. They fly with amazing speed,\r\nconsidering they are an untidy ball forty feet in diameter, and they\r\nare on top of their victims before the unlucky ones are aware of the\r\nmenace. Blowing their victims down with a rush of air from their\r\nfeathers, they grab them up by the heels, carry them high aloft and\r\ndrop them on piles of rock outside of town."\r\n\r\n"They are _downdraft_-peoplehawk-whirlybirds then?" asked DeCrabbe.\r\n\r\n"That\'s almost it," agreed the mayor. As they rise in the air with the victim\r\ndangling from their talons by his heels, they utter a pleased\r\n\'Coo! Coo!\' like a gentle dove. That is why they are called\r\nCoocoo-downdraft-peoplehawk-whirlybirds."\r\n\r\n"Approve of adequate names," nodded Five-gun, unbending a trifle.\r\n"First step toward efficiency. Only one thing haven\'t made clear.\r\nPresumably have shotguns and rifles. 

Why unable drive off these\r\npredators yourselves?"\r\n\r\nThe mayor laughed bitterly. "It would be easy to tell you\'d just\r\narrived on this planet--although the birds are not well known in the\r\nother cities either; they are all concentrated in this area. Yes, our\r\nsportsmen tried to shoot down the whirlybirds. No luck, of course.\r\nImagine the problems you have when one of these forty-foot balls of\r\ncommotion comes at you: You try to aim but you can\'t hold your arm\r\nstill because of the swirling wind they raise; and then the dust clouds\r\nthicken and you\'re firing wildly, and you can\'t begin to tell which is\r\nbody and which is feathers anyway."\r\n\r\n"Very well," accepted Charles DeCrabbe mercifully. 

"You\'ve made\r\nattempt. My first step therefore the attachment of high explosives to\r\nboobytrapped mannequins. Brought these with me."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Great winds of catastrophe. I\'m glad you mentioned it before you did\r\nit!" exclaimed the mayor. 

"We tried that once. The city was six weeks\r\ndigging out from under the feathers--and it didn\'t kill the whirlybird!"\r\n\r\n"Aren\'t you exaggerating difficulties encountered in picking up few\r\nfeathers?" loftily inquired DeCrabbe.\r\n\r\n"How do you think we got the name of Featherton? Before the deluge we\r\nwere called West Applebury!"\r\n\r\n"Then why haven\'t you attempted lure them into boobytraps outside town?\r\nCould detonate them there without even slight inconvenience of picking\r\nup feathers."\r\n\r\n"Believe me, if there were only a _few_ feathers," insisted Mayor\r\nPrince, "few enough for you to pick up by yourself, we wouldn\'t mind\r\nyou blowing up a whirlybird."\r\n\r\n"Wasn\'t considering picking up _any_ feathers," replied Five-gun with\r\ndignity. "Had supposed a menial or two could be supplied for that."\r\n\r\nThe mayor shook his head. "It would take everybody in town to clean\r\nup. And as for blowing one up outside the city, one of our orchardists\r\ntried it. admired the mayor\'s son. "Only two days!"\r\n\r\n"If you will now lead me to your city park will begin campaign of\r\nextermination at once."\r\n\r\n"It\'s down that way," said the mayor, pointing. Plainly he had no\r\nintention of leaving the shelter of the marquee. "Am armed, young man," he retorted severely.\r\n\r\n"Yeah, but those whirlybirds don\'t pay any attention to guns."\r\n\r\n"Soon will," DeCrabbe replied, unruffled.\r\n\r\nSlowly he drove down the center of the empty street, receiving more\r\ncheers from heads thrust out of windows. He arrived at the city park\r\nand turned in. He unloaded most of his equipment under the roof of the\r\nbandstand.\r\n\r\nA few minutes later one of his robot mannequins moved slowly around\r\nthe clearing before the bandstand, its control set for slow walking to\r\nconserve its atomic battery. The predator hunter unlimbered all his\r\nguns as he sat under the bandstand roof waiting.\r\n\r\nIt was an hour before the first whirlybird attacked.\r\n\r\nHis first warning was the rising wind. His gaze moved around the sky\r\nuntil he found the rapidly growing black spot. A few seconds later\r\nit became a universe-engulfing blackness as it spotted the mannequin\r\nand came down for it. As soon as the wind-screaming blackness reached\r\nthe mannequin, the needle guns in his hands emptied their hundreds of\r\nanesthetizing needles into the turbulence. But it was as the mayor had\r\nsaid. Where did the bird\'s body end and the feathers begin? When the\r\nneedle pistols were empty he dropped them and snatched up the rocket\r\npowered stun-gas weapon; its immense flare poured into the blackness\r\nwithout visible result. He dropped it and grabbed the N-ray flashburn\r\ngun. The forty-foot ball of fury was beginning to rise high with its\r\nprey now, as the gun stuttered fifty bolts of burning lethal radiation\r\ninto it. He smelled feathers that time. Finally as the giant bird,\r\nwithout faltering, rose above the range of the N-ray gun, he took to\r\nthe explosive pellet rifle. It had only ten shots; all of these went\r\ninto the center of the blackness well before the whirlybird had flown\r\nbeyond range. And as it neared the horizon with its mannequin prey, he\r\nheard its sweet song:\r\n\r\n"Coo! Coo!"\r\n\r\n"How _dare_ it coo after all I did to it?" muttered DeCrabbe grimly.\r\n"Shall not coo next time!"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHalf an hour later a new mannequin stood out in front of the bandstand.\r\nIts arms waved ceaselessly but it stood still. Nestled against its\r\nback was a ten gallon drum of gas, which would be exploded--blanketing\r\nmost of the park in fumes--as soon as the mannequin was moved. Charles\r\nDeCrabbe waited, his mask ready, his potent weapons all reloaded.\r\n\r\nNinety minutes later the huge black menace arrived--either the first\r\nwhirlybird or another forty-foot wind-screaming fury. Slipping his\r\ngas mask on, the man waited for the right moment to begin firing. The\r\nwhirlybird swooped down, the tank exploded in a fog, and the giant\r\nwobbled!\r\n\r\nDeCrabbe emptied all his weapons again. The bird arose, wobbling, its\r\nspeed greatly impaired, but making its getaway despite all he could do.\r\n\r\n"Damn well didn\'t coo that time," he said when the monster had reached\r\nthe horizon. "Next time won\'t fly either."\r\n\r\nBut just then the monstrous bird mocked him in the distance with a\r\nloud, sweet, "Coo! Coo!

"\r\n\r\nShortly after lunch he had it all set up. A new mannequin stood out in\r\nfront of the bandstand, its arms waving and a pair of slim, gleaming,\r\nten-gallon drums of stun gas nearby.\r\n\r\nIt was one o\'clock before the third whirlybird struck.\r\n\r\nDown it sank until it became a huge, ebony blot in the afternoon sky.\r\nUnderneath the bandstand roof DeCrabbe got ready for his supreme\r\neffort. He slipped on his gas mask and made sure his N-ray flashburn\r\ngun was ready for instant action, its safety off. He was determined\r\nthat if he got the bird prostrate he would climb aboard and fire N-ray\r\nbolts into it until something _gave_!\r\n\r\nThe huge black, wind-screaming monster plummeted the last few yards\r\ndown and grabbed the mannequin. The\r\ngiant whirlybird slumped unconscious--and DeCrabbe scrambled aboard!\r\n\r\nThe feverishly hurrying hunter was not long discovering why he had\r\nnot--and never would--penetrate the bird\'s feathers with any of his\r\nweapons: He burrowed down into the feathers the length of his arm and\r\nthere were yet more feathers beyond! A feather pillow would stop a\r\nrifle bullet, he knew, and this monster had the probable equivalent of\r\na thousand feather pillows protecting it, invulnerable as a battleship.\r\n\r\nAnd just then the maneater awoke, wobbled into the air, and flew away\r\nbefore DeCrabbe could get off!\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe following afternoon, as Five-gun Charles DeCrabbe made his farewell\r\nof the city of Featherton, he once more drove down the center of the\r\nstreet with the bubble of his space convertible slid back.\r\n\r\nYet there was a difference this time. The mayor and his son rode beside\r\nhim on the seat, and all of the people were now out of doors standing\r\nalong the curb, cheering their deliverer wildly as he passed.\r\n\r\n"I can\'t tell you how much I personally appreciate what you\'ve done for\r\nus," said the mayor humbly.\r\n\r\n"Quite quite quite!" returned Five-gun haughtily in his clipped speech,\r\nhoping to shut off the man\'s tendency toward windyness.\r\n\r\nWith awe in his voice the mayor\'s son admired, "So instead of being\r\nscared to death you were all ready for action when you and the\r\nwhirlybird landed at their rocky, mountain lair?"\r\n\r\n"Yes yes yes! 

Slid off its back, hid between two boulders, waited\r\nfor the appropriate moment. After bagging that one, waited for other\r\nmonsters as they landed, one by one. We girls have made up our minds."\r\n\r\nHugh Farrel, Chief Medical Officer of the Exodus VII, sighed and leaned\r\nback in his chair. He looked at Mary\'s husband. "And you, Ralph," he\r\nsaid. "How do you feel?"\r\n\r\nRalph Pornsen looked at Mary uncomfortably, started to speak and then\r\nhesitated.\r\n\r\nHugh Farrel sighed again and closed his eyes. It was that way with all\r\nthe boys. The wives had the whip hand. If the husbands put up an\r\nargument, they\'d simply get turned down flat: no sex at all, children or\r\notherwise. The threat, Farrel thought wryly, made the boys softer than\r\nwatered putty. His own wife, Alice, was one of the ringleaders of the\r\n"no babies" movement, and since he had openly declared warfare on the\r\nidea, she wouldn\'t even let him kiss her good-night. (For fear of losing\r\nher determination, Farrel liked to think.)\r\n\r\nHe opened his eyes again to look past the Pornsens, out of the curving\r\nport of his office-lab in the Exodus VII\'s flank, at the scene outside\r\nthe ship.\r\n\r\nAt the edge of the clearing he could see Danny Stern and his crew, tiny\r\nbeneath the cavernous sunbeam-shot overhang of giant leaves. Danny was\r\nstanding up at the controls of the \'dozer, waving his arms. His crew was\r\nstruggling to get a log set so he could shove it into place with the\r\n\'dozer. They were repairing a break in the barricade--the place where\r\none of New Earth\'s giant saurians had come stamping and whistling\r\nthrough last night to kill three colonists before it could be blasted\r\nout of existence.\r\n\r\nIt was difficult. Damned difficult. A brand-new world here, all ready\r\nto receive the refugees from dying Earth. Or rather, all ready to be\r\n_made_ ready, which was the task ahead of the Exodus VII\'s personnel.\r\n\r\nAn Earth-like world. Green, warm, fertile--and crawling, leaping,\r\nhooting and snarling with ferocious beasts of every variety. Farrel\r\ncould certainly see the women\'s point in banding together and refusing\r\nto produce children. Something inside a woman keeps her from wanting to\r\nbring life into peril--at least, when the peril seems temporary, and\r\nsecurity is both remembered and anticipated.\r\n\r\nPornsen said, "I guess I feel just about like Mary does. I--I don\'t see\r\nany reason for having a kid until we get this place ironed out and safe\r\nto live in."\r\n\r\n"That\'s going to take time, Ralph." Farrel clasped his hands in front of\r\nhim and delivered the speech he had delivered so often in the past few\r\nweeks. "Ten or twelve years before we really get set up here. We\'ve got\r\nto build from the ground up, you know. We\'ll have to find and mine our\r\nmetals. Build our machines to build shops to build more machines.\r\nThere\'ll be resources that we _won\'t_ find, and we\'ll have to learn what\r\nthis planet has to offer in their stead. Colonizing New Earth isn\'t\r\nsimply a matter of landing and throwing together a shining city. I only\r\nwish it were.\r\n\r\n"Six weeks ago we landed. We haven\'t yet dared to venture more than a\r\nmile from this spot. We\'ve cut down trees and built the barricade and\r\nour houses. After protecting ourselves we have to eat. We\'ve planted\r\ngardens. We\'ve produced test-tube calves and piglets. The calves are\r\ndoing fine, but the piglets are dying one by one. We\'ve got to find out\r\nwhy.\r\n\r\n"It\'s going to be a long, long time before we have even a minimum of\r\nsecurity, much less luxury. Longer than you think.... So much longer\r\nthat waiting until the security arrives before having children is out of\r\nthe question. There are critters out there--" he nodded toward the port\r\nand the busy clearing beyond--"that we haven\'t been able to kill. We\'ve\r\nthrown everything we have at them, and they come back for more. We\'ll\r\nhave to find out what _will_ kill them--how they differ from those we\r\n_are_ able to kill. We are six hundred people and a spaceship, Ralph. We\r\nhave techniques. That\'s _all_. Everything else we\'ve got to dig up out\r\nof this planet. We\'ll need people, Mary; we\'ll need the children. We\'re\r\ncounting on them. 

They\'re vital to the plans we\'ve made."\r\n\r\nMary Pornsen said, "Damn the plans. I won\'t have one. 

Not now. You\'ve\r\njust done a nice job of describing all my reasons. And all the other\r\ngirls feel the same way."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nShe looked out the window at the \'dozer and crew. I\'ve a few left." Thousands of\r\npeople from Earth, coming here to the new world we\'re supposed to get\r\nbusy and carve out for them. "\r\n\r\n"It won\'t work that way," Farrel said. "We\'re none of us kids any\r\nlonger. I\'m fifty-five. Ralph, you\'re forty-three. I realize that I must\r\nbe getting old to think of you as young. Mary, you\'re thirty-seven. We\r\ntook a long time getting here. 

Fourteen years. We left an Earth that\'s\r\ndying of radioactive poisoning, and we all got a mild dose of that. The\r\nradiation we absorbed in space, little as it was, didn\'t help any. "But we\'ve given it some thought."\r\n\r\nMacGuire had installed the button convenient to Farrel\'s right hand,\r\njust below the level of the desk-top. Farrel pressed it. 

Ralph and Mary\r\nPornsen slumped in their chairs. The door opened, and Doctor John J.\r\nMacGuire and Ted Harris, the Exodus VII\'s chief psychologist, came in.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWhen it was over, and the after-play had been allowed to run its course,\r\nFarrel told the Pornsens to go into the next room and shower. They came\r\nback soon, looking refreshed. 

Farrel ordered them to get back into their\r\nclothes. Under the power of the hypnotic drug which their chairs had\r\ninjected into them at the touch of the button, they did so. Then he told\r\nthem to sit down in the chairs again.\r\n\r\nMacGuire and Harris had gathered up their equipment, piling it on top of\r\nthe operating table.\r\n\r\nMacGuire smiled. "I\'ll bet that\'s the best-monitored, most hygienic sex\r\nact ever committed. I think I\'ve about got the space radiations effect\r\nlicked."\r\n\r\nFarrel nodded. "If anything goes wrong, it certainly won\'t be our fault.\r\nBut let\'s face it--the chances are a thousand to one that something\r\n_will_ go wrong. We\'ll just have to wait. 

And work." 

He looked at the\r\nPornsens. "They\'re very much in love, aren\'t they? And she was receptive\r\nto the suggestion--beneath it all, she was burning to have a child, just\r\nlike the others."\r\n\r\nMacGuire wheeled out the operating table, with its load of serums,\r\npressure-hypos and jury-rigged thingamabobs which he was testing on\r\nalternate couples. Ted Harris stopped at the door a moment. He said, "I\r\nthink the suggestions I planted will turn the trick when they find out\r\nshe\'s pregnant. They\'ll come through okay--won\'t even be too angry.

"\r\n\r\nFarrel sighed. They\'d been over it in detail several times, of course,\r\nbut apparently Harris needed the reassurance as much as he did. He said:\r\n"Sure. Now scram so I can go back into my act."\r\n\r\nHarris closed the door. Farrel sat down at his desk and studied the pair\r\nbefore him. They looked back contentedly, holding hands, their eyes\r\ndull.\r\n\r\nFarrel said, "How do you feel?"\r\n\r\nRalph Pornsen said, "I feel fine."\r\n\r\nMary Pornsen said, "Oh, I feel _wonderful_!"\r\n\r\nDeliberately Farrel pressed another button below his desk-top.\r\n\r\nThe dull eyes cleared instantly.\r\n\r\n"Oh, you\'ve given it some thought, Doc?" Mary said sweetly. "And what\r\nhave you decided?"\r\n\r\n"You\'ll see," Farrel said. "Eventually."\r\n\r\nHe rose. "That\'s all for now, kids. I\'d like to see you again in one\r\nmonth--for a routine check-up."\r\n\r\nMary nodded and got up. "You\'ll still have to wait, Doc. Why not admit\r\nyou\'re licked?"\r\n\r\nRalph got up too, and looked puzzled.\r\n\r\n"Wow," he said. "I\'m tired."\r\n\r\n"Perhaps just coming here," Farrel said, "discharged some of the tension\r\nyou\'ve been carrying around."\r\n\r\nThe Pornsens left.\r\n\r\nFarrel brought out some papers from his desk and studied them. Then,\r\nfrom the file drawer, he selected the record of Hugh and Alice Farrel.\r\nAlice would be at the perfect time of her menstrual cycle tomorrow....\r\n\r\nFarrel flipped his communicator.\r\n\r\n"MacGuire," he said. "Tomorrow it\'s me."\r\n\r\nMacGuire chuckled. Farrel could have kicked him. He put his chin in his\r\nhands and stared out the port. Danny Stern had the log in place in the\r\nbarricade. The bulldozer was moving on to a new task. His momentary\r\ndoubt stilled, Farrel went back to work.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nTwenty-one years later, when the ships from Earth began arriving, the\r\nlog had been replaced by a stone monument erected to the memory of the\r\nExodus VII, which had been cut apart for its valuable steel. Around the\r\nmonument was a park, and on three sides of the park was a shining\r\ntown--not really large enough to be called a city--of plastic and stone,\r\nfor New Earth had no iron ore, only zinc and a little copper. This was\r\noften cause for regret.\r\n\r\nStill it was a pretty good world. The monster problem had been licked by\r\nhigh-voltage cannon. Now in their third generation since the landing,\r\nthe monsters kept their distance. And things grew--things good to eat.\r\n\r\nAnd even without steel, the graceful, smoothly-functioning town looked\r\nimpressive--quite a thing to have been built by a handful of beings with\r\ntwo arms and two legs each.\r\n\r\nIt hadn\'t been, entirely. But nobody thought much about that any more.\r\nEven the newcomers got used to it. Things change.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _If Worlds of Science Fiction_ November\r\n    1953.
