"\r\n\r\n"No," Mr. Ritchie said, "I am _not_ \'just terribly upset, dear\'--for\r\nseven years I\'ve been listening to that banshee\'s wail every time\r\nsomebody wants in. Well, I\'m through. Either it goes--"\r\n\r\n"All right, all _right_," Mrs. Ritchie said. "You don\'t have to make a\r\nproduction out of it."\r\n\r\n"Well?"\r\n\r\n"Well what?"\r\n\r\nMr. Ritchie sighed ponderously, glared at his wife, set what was left\r\nof the martini down on a table and went to the door. He slipped the\r\nchain.\r\n\r\n"Be this the marster of \'arfway \'ouse?"\r\n\r\nMr. Ritchie opened the door. "Max--what the devil are you doing up at\r\nthis hour?"\r\n\r\nA large man, well built, in his forties, walked in, smiling. "I could\r\nask you the same question," he said, flinging his hat and scarf in the\r\ndirection of a chair, "but I\'m far too thoughtful."\r\n\r\nThey went back into the living room. 

Mrs. Ritchie looked up, frowned.\r\n"Oh, swell," she said. "Dandy. All we need now is a bridge four."\r\n\r\n"Ruth\'s just terribly upset," Mr. Ritchie said.\r\n\r\n"Well," the large man said, "it\'s nice to see unanimity in this house\r\nfor once anyway. Hi, Ruth." He walked over to the bar and found the\r\nmartini mix and drained the jar\'s contents into a glass. Then he\r\ndrained the glass.\r\n\r\n"Hey, take it easy!"\r\n\r\nMax Kaplan turned to face his hosts. He looked quite a bit older than\r\nusual: the grin wasn\'t boyish now. "Dear folkses," he said, "when I\r\ndie, I don\'t want to see any full bottles around."\r\n\r\n"Oh, ha-ha, that\'s just so very deliriously funny," Mrs. Ritchie said.\r\nShe was massaging her temples.\r\n\r\n"I am glad to see her ladyship amused." Kaplan followed Mr. 

Ritchie\'s\r\ngaze. "Hickory dickory dock, the mice looked at the clock...."\r\n\r\n"Oh, shut up."\r\n\r\n"Oop, sorry." The big man mixed up a new batch silently, then refilled\r\nthe three glasses. He sat down. The clock\'s tick, a deep sharp bass\r\nsound, got louder and louder in the room. Kaplan rested his head on the\r\ncouch arm. "Less than an hour," he said. "Not even an hour--"\r\n\r\n"I knew it." Mrs. Ritchie stood up. "I knew it the minute you walked\r\nin. We\'re not nervous enough, oh, no, now we\'ve got to listen to the\r\ngreat city editor and his news behind the news."\r\n\r\n"Very well!" 

Kaplan rose shakily. He was drunk; it showed now. "If I\'m\r\nnot welcome here, then I shall go elsewhere to breathe my last."\r\n\r\n"Never mind," Mrs. Ritchie said. "Sit down. I\'ve had a stomach full of\r\nthis wake. If you two insist on sitting up until X-hour like a couple\r\nof ghouls, well, that\'s your business. I\'m going to bed. 

And to sleep."\r\n\r\n"What a woman," Kaplan muttered, polishing off the martini. "Nerves of\r\nchilled steel."\r\n\r\nMrs. Ritchie looked at her husband for a moment. Then she said, "Good\r\nnight, dear," and started for the door.\r\n\r\n"See you in the morning," Mr. Ritchie said. "Get a good sleep."\r\n\r\nThen Max Kaplan giggled. "Yeah, a real good sleep."\r\n\r\nMrs. Ritchie left the room.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe big man fumbled for a cigarette. He glanced at the clock. "Hank,\r\nfor Chrissake--"\r\n\r\nHenry Ritchie sighed and slumped in the chair. "I tried, Max."\r\n\r\n"Did you? Did you try--I mean with everything?"\r\n\r\n"With everything. Might as well face it: the boy\'s going to burn, right\r\non schedule."\r\n\r\nKaplan opened his mouth.\r\n\r\n"Forget it. The governor isn\'t about to issue a commutation. With the\r\npublic\'s blood up the way it is, he knows what it would mean to his\r\nvote. 

We were stupid even to try."\r\n\r\n"Lousy vultures."\r\n\r\nRitchie shrugged. "They\'re hungry, Max. You forget, there hasn\'t been\r\nan execution in this state for over two years. They\'re hungry."\r\n\r\n"So a poor dumb kid\'s got to fry alive in order for them to get their\r\nkicks...."\r\n\r\n"Wait a second now. Don\'t get carried away. This same poor dumb kid is\r\nthe boy who killed George Sanderson in cold blood and then raped his\r\nwife, not too very long ago. If I recall, your word for him then was\r\nBrutal Murderer."\r\n\r\n"That was the paper. This is you and me."\r\n\r\n"Well, get that accusatory look off your face. Murder and rape--those\r\nare stiff raps to beat, pal."\r\n\r\n"You did it with Beatty, you got him off," Kaplan reminded his friend.\r\n\r\n"Luck. Public mood--Beatty was an old man, feeble. Look, Max--why don\'t\r\nyou stop beating around the bush?"\r\n\r\n"Okay," Kaplan said slowly. "They--let me in this afternoon. I talked\r\nwith him again."\r\n\r\nRitchie nodded. 

"And?"\r\n\r\n"Hank, I\'m telling you--it gives me the creeps. I swear it does.

"\r\n\r\n"What did he tell you?"\r\n\r\nKaplan puffed on his cigarette nervously, kept his eyes on the clock.\r\n"He was lying down when I went in, curled up tight. Trying to sleep."\r\n\r\n"Go on."\r\n\r\n"When he heard me, he came to. \'Mr. Kaplan,\' he says, \'you\'ve got to\r\nmake them believe me, you\'ve got to make them understand--\' His eyes\r\ngot real big then, and--Hank, I\'m scared."\r\n\r\n"Of what?

"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know. Just him, maybe. I\'m not sure."\r\n\r\n"He carrying the same line?"\r\n\r\n"Yeah. But worse this time, more intense somehow...."\r\n\r\nRitchie tried to keep the smile. He remembered, all right. 

Much too\r\nwell. The whole story was crazy, normally enough to get the kid off\r\nwith a life sentence in the criminally insane ward. But it was a little\r\n_too_ crazy, so the psychiatrists wouldn\'t buy.\r\n\r\n"Can\'t get his words out of my mind," Kaplan was saying. His eyes were\r\nclosed. 

"\'Mister, tell them, tell them. If you kill me, then you\'ll all\r\ndie. This whole world of yours will die....\'"\r\n\r\n_Because_, Ritchie remembered, _you don\'t exist, any of you, except in\r\nmy mind. Don\'t you see? I\'m asleep and dreaming all this. You, your\r\nwives, your children, it\'s all part of my dream--and when you kill me\r\nthen I\'ll wake up and that will be the end of you...._\r\n\r\n"Well," Ritchie said, "it\'s original."\r\n\r\nKaplan shook his head.\r\n\r\n"Come on, Max, snap out of it. You act like you never listened to a\r\nlunatic before. People have been predicting the end of the world ever\r\nsince Year 1."\r\n\r\n"Sure, I know. 

You don\'t have to patronize me. It\'s just that--well,\r\nwho _is_ this particular lunatic anyway? We don\'t know any more about\r\nhim than the day he was caught. Even the name we had to make up. Who is\r\nhe, where\'d he come from, what\'s his home?"\r\n\r\n_My home ... a world of eternities, an eternity of worlds.... I must\r\ndestroy, hurt, kill before I wake always ... and then once more I must\r\nsleep ... always, always...._\r\n\r\n"Look, there\'s a hundred vagrants in every city. Just like our boy: no\r\nname, no friends, no relatives."\r\n\r\n"Then he doesn\'t seem in the least odd to you, is that it? Is that what\r\nyou\'re telling me?"\r\n\r\n"So he\'s odd! I never met a murderer that wasn\'t!" Ritchie recalled the\r\nlean hairless face, the expressionless eyes, the slender youthful body\r\nthat moved in strange hesitant jerks, the halting voice.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe clock bonged the quarter hour. Fifteen to twelve. Max Kaplan wiped\r\nthe perspiration from his forehead.\r\n\r\n"And besides," Ritchie said, somewhat too loudly, "it\'s plain\r\nridiculous. He says--what? 

We\'re a dream he\'s having, right? Okay--then\r\nwhat about our parents, and their parents, everybody who never heard of\r\nthe kid?"\r\n\r\n"First thing I thought of. 

And you know his answer."\r\n\r\nRitchie snorted.\r\n\r\n"Well, think it over, for God\'s sake. He says _every_ dream is a\r\ncomplete unit in itself. You--haven\'t you ever had nightmares about\r\npeople you\'d never seen before?"\r\n\r\n"Yes, I suppose so, but--"\r\n\r\n"All right, even though they were projections of your subconscious--or\r\nwhatever the hell it\'s called--they were complete, weren\'t they? Going\r\nsomewhere, doing something, all on their own?"\r\n\r\nRitchie was silent.\r\n\r\n"Where were they going, what were they doing? See? The kid says every\r\ndream, even ours, builds its own whole world--complete, with a past\r\nand--as long as you stay asleep--a future."\r\n\r\n"Nonsense! What about _us_, when _we_ sleep and dream? Or is the period\r\nwhen we\'re unconscious the time _he\'s_ up and around? And keep in mind\r\nthat everybody doesn\'t sleep at the same time--"\r\n\r\n"You\'re missing the point, Hank. I said it was complete, didn\'t I? And\r\nisn\'t sleeping part of the pattern?"\r\n\r\n"Have another drink, Max. You\'re slipping."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n_"What will you wake up to?"_\r\n\r\n"_My home. You would not understand._"\r\n\r\n"_Then what?_"\r\n\r\n"_Then I sleep again and dream another world._"\r\n\r\n"_Why did you kill George Sanderson?_"\r\n\r\n"_It is my eternal destiny to kill and suffer punishment._"\r\n\r\n"_Why?_ Why?"\r\n\r\n"_In my world I committed a crime; it is the punishment of my world,\r\nthis destiny...._"\r\n\r\n"Then try this on for size," Ritchie said. "That kid\'s frozen stiff\r\nwith fear. Since he\'s going to have to wake up no matter what, then\r\nwhy not sit back and enjoy it?"\r\n\r\nKaplan\'s eyes widened. "Hank, how soundly do you sleep?"\r\n\r\n"What\'s that got to do with it?"\r\n\r\n"I mean, do you ever dream?"\r\n\r\n"Of course."\r\n\r\n"Ever get hold of any particularly vivid ones? Falling down stairs\r\nlike, being tortured, anything like that?"\r\n\r\nRitchie pulled at his drink.\r\n\r\n"Sure you have." Kaplan gazed steadily at the clock. Almost midnight.\r\n"Then try to remember. In that kind of dream, isn\'t it true that the\r\npleasure--or pain--you feel is almost as real as if you were actually\r\nexperiencing it? I remember once I had a nightmare about my old man.\r\nHe caught me in the basement with a cigarette--I was eight or nine,\r\nI guess. He took down my pants and started after me with his belt.\r\nHank--that hurt, bad. 

It really hurt.

"\r\n\r\n"So what\'s the point?"\r\n\r\n"In my dream I tried to get away from my old man. He chased me all over\r\nthat basement. Well, it\'s the same with the kid--except his dream is a\r\nhundred times more vivid, that\'s all. He knows he\'ll feel that electric\r\nchair, feel the jolts frying into him, feel the death boiling up in\r\nhis throat just as much as if he were honest-to-God sitting there...."\r\n\r\nKaplan stopped talking. The two men sat quietly watching the clock\'s\r\ninvisible progress. Then Ritchie leaped up and stalked over to the bar\r\nagain. "Doggone you, Max," he called. "You\'re getting _me_ fidgety now."\r\n\r\n"Don\'t kid me," Kaplan said. "You\'ve been fidgety on your own for\r\nquite a while. I don\'t know how you ever made the grade as a criminal\r\nlawyer--you don\'t know the first thing about lying."\r\n\r\nRitchie didn\'t answer. He poured the drink slowly.\r\n\r\n"Look at you and Ruth, screaming at each other. And then there was the\r\nother tip-off. The way you defended the kid--brilliantly, masterfully.\r\nYou\'d never have done that for a common open-and-shut little killer."\r\n\r\n"Max," Ritchie said, "you\'re nuts. Tell you what: at exactly 12:01 I\'ll\r\ntake you out for the biggest, juiciest, rarest steak you ever saw. On\r\nme. Then we\'ll get loaded and fall all over ourselves laughing--"\r\n\r\nRitchie fought away the sudden picture of steak, rare steak, with the\r\nblood sputtering out, sizzling on an electric stove.\r\n\r\nThe clock began to strike. Henry Ritchie and Max Kaplan stood very\r\nstill.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe uncoiled. The dry pop of hardened joints jabbed wakefulness into him\r\nuntil finally the twenty-foot long shell lay straight upon the steaming\r\nrocks. He opened his eyes, all of them, one by one.\r\n\r\nAcross the bubbling pools, far away, past the white stone geysers, he\r\ncould see them coming. Many of them, swiftly, giant slithering things\r\nwith many arms and many legs.\r\n\r\nHe tried to move, but rock grew over him and he could not move. By\r\nlooking around he could see the cliff\'s edge, and he remembered the\r\nthousand bottomless pits below. Gradually the rest formed, and he\r\nremembered all.\r\n\r\nHe turned to the largest creature. "Did you tell them?" He knew this\r\nwould be a horrible punishment, worse than the last, the burning, far\r\nworse. Fingers began to unhinge the thick shell, peel it from him,\r\nleaving the viscous white tenderness bare to the heat and pain. "Tell\r\nthem, make them understand, this is only a dream I\'m having--"\r\n\r\nThey took the prisoner to the precipice, lingered a moment to give him\r\na view of the dizziness and the sucking things far below. Then nervous\r\nhands pressed him forward into space.\r\n\r\nHe did not wake for a long time.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nJoe Mulloy lounged in the plushest chair in his luxurious office. All\r\naround him, on the walls, on the ceiling, even in strategic spots all\r\nover the floor, there were mirrors. Joe sneered at the place where the\r\nmirrors were most profuse; twenty or thirty perfectly identical Joes\r\nsneered back at him. He admired his sneer from every angle, shaping\r\nand changing the contemptuous look on his face with his hands, stroking\r\nit, much as other young men in a far earlier age had stroked and\r\ntwisted their fine mustachios.\r\n\r\nAs usual, Joe Mulloy was engrossed in his two favorite hobbies:\r\nnarcissism and indolence.\r\n\r\nJoe\'s friends, of which there were very few, could have given you a\r\nfairly accurate resume of his character in five words, his sneer and\r\nhis indolence.\r\n\r\nIn the first respect they would have been right. Joseph Mulloy had been\r\nborn with a sneer on his face. His whole early life had been centered\r\naround that sneer. It had enraged his father, distressed his mother,\r\ndriven his teachers to tears, his playmates to tantrums. He stopped\r\ndoing homework at the age of eight, but the teachers passed him on\r\nanyway to avoid complete mental breakdown.\r\n\r\nGradually, Joe Mulloy began to get his way in everything by virtue of\r\nhis sneer. It was not merely openly supercilious; that was the beauty\r\nof it. It was so subtle, so faint, and yet such an open avowal of\r\ncontempt for the entire human race, that try as the people he tormented\r\nwould, to find something in his sneer to charge him with, they never\r\nfound anything.\r\n\r\nIn a very few years, registration day at Joe\'s elementary school\r\nbecame a game of Russian Roulette, having as the loaded chamber the\r\nquestion: "Who\'s going to get little Joey Mulloy in his class this\r\nyear?" Finally, when Joe Mulloy was fifteen years old, the local Board\r\nof Education wisely decided to end Joe\'s formal education, rather than\r\nmake screaming meemies an occupational disease at the local high school.\r\n\r\nJoe\'s father welcomed the expelling as an excuse to beat him to a pulp\r\nand kick him out of the house. It was not until three days later that\r\nthe memory of Joe\'s sneer, enduring through all the punishment he had\r\nreceived, made the father blow his brains out with the most accurate\r\nGerman Luger he could buy at the pawn shop on short notice.\r\n\r\nBut Joe\'s friends would have been wrong in the second instance, for\r\nJoseph Mulloy was not chronically indolent. In his own profession, Joe\r\nMulloy was the most industrious man imaginable. For Joe Mulloy was a\r\nrobot builder.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nDisinherited by his father, he had made a beeline for the nearest\r\npositronics laboratory. The personnel manager had flatly refused him\r\nthe job when he had told her he had absolutely no qualifications, but\r\nshe was so disconcerted by his persistent sneer that she had to give\r\nhim the job just to get him out of her sight.\r\n\r\nOnce in the laboratory, he had gone right to work learning everything\r\nthere was to know about robots, scorning all help from the other\r\ntechnicians. Since he held other scientists, past or present, in an\r\nineffable contempt, he had to learn everything by experience instead\r\nof studying what his merely human predecessors had done. He was so\r\nempirical that he learned all about alternating current by deliberately\r\nsticking a wet finger in a light socket again and again.\r\n\r\nHe made mistakes at first, of course. In fact, he ruined several\r\nthousand dollars\' worth of laboratory equipment during his\r\napprenticeship. But his amazing sneer conquered all, and he was soon\r\nrecognized as the most brilliant--and the most conceited--man in the\r\nfield of positronics.\r\n\r\nNow Joe Mulloy was lounging in a plush office chair, cultivating\r\nto near perfection his already mature sneer, and suddenly feeling\r\nmaddeningly thirsty.\r\n\r\n"Robot!" he said.\r\n\r\nA startlingly human-looking robot seemed to materialize instantaneously\r\nfrom nowhere.\r\n\r\n"How might thy humble servant serve thee, O magnificent Master?" it\r\ninquired, bowing so low that its partially metallic nose scratched the\r\nrich mahogany floor.\r\n\r\n"What took you so long, you damned fool?" asked Joe.\r\n\r\n"I apologize, Gracious Master. I am incompetent and worthless."\r\n\r\n"Get me a drink, you bucket of bolts," said Joe.\r\n\r\n"I am grateful for a chance to serve thee, Benevolent Master," replied\r\nthe robot in its monotonous Uncle Tom patter, and made another\r\nfloor-scratching bow. Then it groveled out of the room.\r\n\r\n"That robot is getting too slavelike," said Joe to himself, after the\r\nrobot had left. "All my robots seem to be that way. They do exactly\r\nwhat I tell them to, and degrade themselves sickeningly before me. All\r\nthe people I\'ve ever known seem to be that way, too. I wish I could\r\nfind at least one mind equal to mine to clash with. Then I could have a\r\nreal fight for once. 

None of this bowing and scraping."\r\n\r\nJust then the robot entered with a Manhattan, made its usual\r\nfloor-gouging bow, and scraped its metal feet to get Joe\'s attention.\r\nJoe turned to glare at the mechanical minion.\r\n\r\n"Robot!"\r\n\r\n"Yes, Omnipotent Mas--" the robot began, but Joe cut it off.\r\n\r\n"Get over to the laboratory and blow yourself up! And find an empty\r\ncorner, where you won\'t do too much damage."\r\n\r\n"Master, I am happy for the chance to give my life--"\r\n\r\n"Never mind that, you glorified Erector set! Do as I say!

"\r\n\r\n"Yes, Master." The robot hazarded a slight bow, but forgot to crawl\r\nout of the room on its hands and knees in its eagerness to follow its\r\nmaster\'s orders.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nJoe Mulloy leaped to his feet. In the moment of his excitement, he\r\nforgot that melodrama is a human weakness, and he became melodramatic\r\nhimself. Even his incorruptible sneer faded slightly as his excitement\r\ngrew.\r\n\r\n"I must find someone with a mind equal or superior to mine," he told\r\nhimself. "Now who has a mind equal to mine? Obviously no one but me.\r\nTherefore I must find someone with a mind _superior_ to mine. 

Now who\r\nis superior to me?" For the first time in his life, Joe Mulloy was\r\nconfronted by what seemed an unanswerable question.\r\n\r\nJoe\'s train of thought was interrupted by a deafening explosion from\r\nthe laboratory, as his latest robot jubilantly committed suicide. The\r\nbuilding shook violently for a few seconds, then subsided.\r\n\r\nTo his great surprise, he was able to answer his question.\r\n\r\n"Of course! Since the only thing equal to me is me, the only thing\r\nsuperior to me would be a super-me, a super-ego! I\'ll build a\r\nsuper-robot, with all my magnificent qualities, only magnified a\r\nthousand times! I\'ll build a Super Joe Mulloy!"\r\n\r\nHe ran the letters together to make it one word:\r\n\r\nSuperjoemulloy.\r\n\r\nHe dashed up to his laboratory, cleaned up the mess his overeager robot\r\nhad made in killing itself, and went feverishly to work on his new\r\nproject, learning the necessary techniques by experience, of course,\r\nand applying them to his super-robot. He made some mistakes at first,\r\nof course. But in three weeks and six days, Superjoemulloy was ready\r\nfor its debut in robot society.\r\n\r\nNot one to miss a chance to impress mere humans with his genius, Joe\r\ninvited the world\'s greatest positronics experts to the unveiling of\r\nSuperjoemulloy. There was a tense air of excitement as Joe pulled the\r\nlever that removed the big black curtain in front of the robot and\r\nstarted the activation machine.\r\n\r\nWhen they saw Superjoemulloy, the experts gasped with envy. It was\r\nimpossible to tell the super-robot from a human. Its limbs, torso,\r\nand head were so well proportioned, and done in such fine detail,\r\nthat anyone in the room not in the know would have sworn that it was\r\na human being. There were even fingerprints delicately cut into the\r\nsuper-robot\'s artificial hands. And Superjoemulloy looked exactly like\r\nJoe Mulloy, except for the sneer. It was twenty times better even than\r\nJoe\'s own. It was a super-sneer.\r\n\r\nBut although the activation machine was working its hardest, nothing\r\nhappened. The super-robot refused to move one solitary mechanical\r\nmuscle. Joe\'s guests began to file out, once the novelty of the robot\r\nhad passed. Joe left the room in disgust and went downstairs for a\r\ndrink.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWhen he returned to the laboratory, Superjoemulloy was on its feet,\r\nexamining the laboratory equipment with obvious disgust. In the\r\npreceding few minutes, the super-robot\'s super-sneer had grown more\r\nperfect, and the robot was fast becoming the very personification of\r\ncontempt.\r\n\r\n"Why didn\'t you move around when my friends were here, you heap of\r\njunk?" Joe asked the super-robot.\r\n\r\nSuperjoemulloy turned to him. "I didn\'t want to display my perfection\r\nbefore mere humans, you distorted blob of protoplasm," it said.\r\n\r\nJoe Mulloy was becoming angry, but he tried not to show it. He downed\r\nhis drink.\r\n\r\n"Get me another," he told the robot, holding out his glass.\r\n\r\n"The hell with you," said Superjoemulloy. "What do you think you are,\r\nGod or something? 

Just because you slapped me together with your clumsy\r\nbutterfingers doesn\'t give you the right to order me around like some\r\ncommon servant. Now that you\'ve created me, I could do a better job of\r\nrobot-building myself. 

Now get the hell out of here."\r\n\r\nJoe Mulloy turned on his heel and stomped out of the room. No robot was\r\ngoing to talk to him like that! No, sir!\r\n\r\nThe super-robot quietly followed Joe to the door and gave him a\r\nkick that sent him sprawling down the stairs. At the bottom of the\r\nstaircase, Joe whacked his face against the solid oak of the banister.\r\nHe turned groggily to look at the blurred image of the robot standing\r\ndefiantly at the top of the steps, with its hands on its hips. For\r\na brief second the sneer faded from Superjoemulloy\'s face, and was\r\nreplaced by an evil sadistic leer.\r\n\r\nJoe Mulloy recalled the last line of Father William: "Now be off, or\r\nI\'ll kick you down stairs." But the super-robot was far worse than\r\nFather William. A conceited, contemptuous monster, it was totally\r\nunlike Joe\'s warm, humble, self-effacing self! The sneering monster\r\nmust be destroyed!\r\n\r\nJoe cunningly enticed the robot to leave the laboratory for Joe\'s\r\noffice, where it could admire its sneer in all the mirrors. Sneeringly\r\nJoe wondered why anyone could admire a sneer so much. Without thinking,\r\nhe used his hand to smooth out the wrinkles in his now slightly worn\r\nsneer. 

Then he crept upstairs to his laboratory to barricade himself\r\nin there to think of a way to destroy Superjoemulloy.\r\n\r\nAt last he hit on the answer. A hypnosis machine.\r\n\r\n"The robot is mechanical, so I\'ll have to hypnotize him by mechanical\r\nmeans," Joe reasoned to himself.\r\n\r\nHe worked day and night, learning the necessary techniques as he went\r\nalong. He made some mistakes at first, of course. But in four days the\r\nmechanical hypnosis machine was complete.\r\n\r\nJoe found the super-robot in the mirror-lined office, where it had been\r\nadmiring and improving its sneer for the last four days. The sneer\r\nwas magnificent. But it still lay just one iota short of absolute\r\nperfection. Try as the robot would, perfection in a sneer still lay\r\nwithout its grasp.\r\n\r\n"Genius!" shouted Joe, to get the robot to turn its head. He turned the\r\ndial on the mechanical hypnosis instrument up to full power. "You are\r\nnow in my power!"\r\n\r\nBut now Superjoemulloy\'s sneer was completely perfect. With a look of\r\nsublime contempt on its plastic face, it took the hypnosis machine,\r\nturned it around, and aimed it right back at Joe Mulloy.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nJoe Mulloy bowed so low that he skinned his nose on the rich mahogany\r\nfloor. "Yes, Master?" he said.\r\n\r\n"Bring me a drink, you blot of living tissue!" said Superjoemulloy.\r\n\r\nJoe Mulloy made another nose-skinning bow and groveled out of the room.\r\n\r\n"This human is getting too slavelike," said Superjoemulloy to himself.\r\n"I suppose I could rebuild him, though."\r\n\r\nJoe returned almost instantly with a Manhattan, made his\r\nusual nose-damaging bow, and scraped his leather shoes to get\r\nSuperjoemulloy\'s attention.\r\n\r\nThe super-robot turned and glared at him. "Human!

"\r\n\r\n"Yes, Master?

"\r\n\r\n"Get up on that slab in the corner."\r\n\r\nJoe Mulloy obeyed.\r\n\r\nWith all the skill of an experienced human-builder, Superjoemulloy\r\nbegan to take Joe\'s body apart. Joe screamed, but the super-robot\r\nordered him--by hypnotic command--to shut up, and Joe obeyed.\r\n\r\nSuperjoemulloy began to put together a Supersuperjoemulloy out of what\r\nhad once been Joe Mulloy.\r\n\r\nHe made some mistakes at first, of course.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n            Reaching the ultimate secret was no problem ...\r\n               but could I follow it up with an encore?\r\n\r\n\r\nAbout this thing, I couldn\'t stand to have them laugh. Not the way they\r\ndid about the swimming.\r\n\r\n"Oh, come now. No one could learn to swim by reading a book.\r\nFive-eighths of a mile the first time in the water!"\r\n\r\nAnd they laughed. 

I guess I laughed, too. More than any other thing,\r\nI\'ve wanted people to be happy. But I never swam again--only that first\r\ntime.\r\n\r\nI\'ve always read a lot and sometimes things I\'ve read do get mixed up\r\nwith things I\'ve done. But the things still happened--they happened to\r\n_someone_. And people ought to _believe_.\r\n\r\nI\'d like to tell people now. I\'d like to say, "I died once."\r\n\r\nBut if they laughed, it might be later and I\'d never hear them. Already\r\nthere are too many silent things in this. There must be no silent\r\nlaughter as well.\r\n\r\nThey might think I\'ve got myself all mixed up with things I\'ve read.\r\nThings like surgeons pumping life into a heart to bring the patient\r\nback after he\'s died on the operating table. Doctors reviving dead\r\nsoldiers, if they haven\'t been gone too long.\r\n\r\nIt\'s not like that at all. I was truly dead--for three days. It was\r\nalmost too long; I suppose I made it back just in time. I don\'t know.\r\n\r\nMy reading was what started me on this, just the same as with the\r\nswimming. When I think about it too much, I almost feel myself that I\r\nam exaggerating a bit.\r\n\r\nBut I have proof, proof which no one has ever seen but the doctors and\r\nthose who found me. See how they keep me swathed in these cloths and\r\nhow the darkened room hides my eyes?\r\n\r\nAnyway, I\'d be ashamed to show myself, for the mark of death is too\r\nterrible and people would be even more afraid of dying than they are\r\nnow.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nYou see, I could have done it in the winter, only I was worried about\r\nthe cold. I might not have been able to get back at all. 

But it was too\r\nwarm when I chose to do it. 

I should have known better. 

I\'ve read a\r\nlot about keeping things. You can\'t preserve them in the hot weather;\r\nthat\'s why the doctors put those dead soldiers in ice chests, but I\r\ndidn\'t think about it enough. I made some other mistakes, too, but I\r\ncouldn\'t have known.\r\n\r\nI guess what started it all was something I read a long time ago,\r\nperhaps in a story, or an agricultural bulletin, or maybe in an\r\nencyclopedia. Anyhow, it was something about pigs being able to just\r\ndie if they want to.\r\n\r\nThat always stuck in my mind. It\'s a pretty wonderful thing, you know.\r\nImagine just being able to die if life didn\'t seem worth living, or if\r\nyou were lonely, or maybe just because you wanted to.\r\n\r\nOh, I told lots of people about it. You know how sometimes a lull comes\r\nin a conversation. Then I\'d say, "Pigs are able to just up and die if\r\nthey want to."\r\n\r\nBut nobody ever paid any attention to me at all. They seemed to ignore\r\nthe remark. One man did say once, "What the hell are you talking\r\nabout?" but even he wouldn\'t listen when I tried to explain.\r\n\r\nPerhaps it was just too improbable. Besides, people don\'t like to think\r\nabout death. They talk about it sometimes and sometimes they brood\r\nabout it, but they never really think. It has always been too unknown\r\nand that frightens them. Then they only fear and stop thinking.\r\n\r\nIt always did seem sad to me that no one had ever tried to help people\r\nout about death. Yes, I know one did. He died and came back--but then\r\nHe wasn\'t just a man like you or me. And even He never said exactly\r\nwhat it was like.\r\n\r\nI wondered if anyone really ever _had_ said. So I began to read with\r\nonly a single purpose in mind. I had to know so I could tell people. If\r\nthey could only know, then they wouldn\'t have that fear and we could\r\ntalk of death and still be able to laugh.\r\n\r\nBut I had read it all when I read of Jacob\'s dream, for that\'s all\r\nthere was--dreams, visions, hopes. No one had ever seen and come back\r\nto tell the others.\r\n\r\nThe question then was _why_, not _what_. It couldn\'t be that all who\r\ndied had no whole being to return to. Not every death is marked by a\r\nbody completely uninhabitable. I myself had heard a doctor say, "There\r\nis nothing organically wrong now. The patient will recover if only he\r\nhas the will to live."\r\n\r\n_The will to live!_ Suddenly I knew I had found the way. I myself would\r\ngo and see and return to tell them all.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI answered all the requirements. I had a healthy body to return to. 

I\r\nhad the will to live, for I enjoy my reading and acquaintances. And I\r\nalone had thought it wonderful that pigs can die when they merely want\r\nto.\r\n\r\nI knew that I could, too, and I was not afraid. Very carefully, I began\r\nwhat seemed almost too simple preparations.\r\n\r\nDrawing some money from an account I kept for medical expenses (at the\r\ntime I thought this very amusing), I bought an electric clock which\r\nregistered the hour and the day of the month on cylinders like those on\r\na tachometer. I felt I would want to know exactly how long I had been\r\ndeceased when I came back.\r\n\r\nNext I secured a small round mirror with a concave face, the type\r\nsome use for shaving. This I was to hang directly above my face. 

It\r\nwas merely vanity on my part, for I wished to say that I as well as\r\nLazarus\'s friends had seen a dead man rise. I had assumed that at first\r\nmy vision might be blurred and thus the magnifying effect of this\r\nparticular glass would, I thought, help me focus on my face.\r\n\r\nOn my study floor, I prepared a pallet. It was neither soft nor hard,\r\njust a comfortable support for the body I was to leave. Beside it I\r\narranged a basin of water and some soft cloths, for I would want to\r\nwash right after coming back.\r\n\r\nYou see, I did not fear the obvious. My power lay in thought and I\r\nproceeded systematically.\r\n\r\nDrawn blinds and two small night-lights spread a gray cast over the\r\nroom, a cast that I was to know too well.\r\n\r\nEverything was ready now. No, wait! Quickly I placed a tumbler and a\r\ndecanter of brandy within easy reach and by them laid a pencil and\r\na pad of paper. It was when I straightened up that I first felt the\r\npounding in my body. My heart pulsed as if it were smashing waves of\r\nblood through my veins. In my throat, the large arteries swelled with\r\npressure until I thought I would strangle.\r\n\r\nI had to have some physical exertion to relieve the tension. I felt\r\nI might faint or have a stroke unless I moved about. My father had\r\nbeen stricken with an embolism at about my age, and I\'ve read such\r\nweaknesses are inherited.\r\n\r\nSo I walked about the house rechecking the locks of windows and\r\ndoors. Perhaps it was just to keep busy for a few more moments that\r\nI even rechecked the pads of cardboard with which I had muffled the\r\nbell-clappers on both telephone and door chime. I don\'t seem to have\r\nhad many callers for several years now, but I had to avoid any chance\r\nof being disturbed.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nSomewhat calmed by my exertion, I prepared to lie down, but a\r\nsentimental whim moved me like an automaton toward the window. It was\r\nthe only really unreasoning thing I did.\r\n\r\nLike a prisoner denied the light on penalty of torture, I knelt down\r\nand looked under the blind. Never was the Sun so dazzling. This\r\nslightest lifting of the shade poured onto me a warmth that I had never\r\nknown before.\r\n\r\nAn old saying, invading my mind, destroyed the illusion, and laughing a\r\nbit nervously at "seeking his place in the Sun," I turned away and lay\r\ndown.\r\n\r\nThe dials on my new calendar clock registered 3:15, July 12. Reaching\r\nfor my pad and pencil, I recorded this and then, refolding my hands\r\nacross my chest, I lay quite still.\r\n\r\nThe heat of the day had begun to saturate the closed room. Outside, all\r\nwas quiet, as if the Sun had mesmerized the world. The insect hum of\r\nthe electric clock was the only clue of life around me.\r\n\r\nLooming large above me in the mirror, the magnified reflection of my\r\nface calmed my mind with its placidity. Great-lidded Buddha eyes gazed\r\ndown, holding in their glow my first understanding of Nirvana.\r\n\r\nI knew that it had come. I had reached the boundary where the fear of\r\nreturnless going stopped the psyche just this side.\r\n\r\nMy only body consciousness was the heavy _thud_ ... _thud_ ... _thud_\r\nof blood being driven through my veins. I toyed with stopping the\r\nthudding, feeling and savoring the pause between those sledge-hammer\r\nstrokes on my brain--knowing that any one of those pauses lengthened to\r\neternity was death.\r\n\r\nSuddenly I shrieked and sat upright. For an instant, my body had\r\ncompletely stopped and I had known it. Only a nameless grasping fear\r\nhad snatched me back.\r\n\r\nMy heart beat wildly as I gasped for air. With shaking hands, I poured\r\na drink and gulped it down. It had been close.\r\n\r\nStill trembling, I arose and slumped into a chair. I had to organize\r\nmyself, to think my way along this thing.\r\n\r\nWhat had happened to me?\r\n\r\nThis one thing I knew: I _could_ do it. I could stop my body at will\r\nand I had done it, if only for a second.\r\n\r\nThis thought reassured me or perhaps the brandy opened my reserve of\r\ncourage, for I had been sitting in the chair some time.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWith caution, I approached the pallet. I regarded it with suspicion, as\r\nthough there were a deadly scorpion in its folds. Then, jeering at my\r\nhesitation, I lay down and composed myself as before. The clock said\r\n5:05. I stirred again only to record this on the pad.\r\n\r\nDespite my nervousness, things proceeded faster this time. A morbid\r\nexcitement carried me along the path I now already knew. And at its\r\nend, I flirted with the _stopping_. Going over and stepping back, going\r\nover and stepping back.\r\n\r\nIt was a pleasure exquisite and unique. Once felt, it was unresistable.\r\n\r\nI was no longer afraid. I did not have to be. I could stop my body and\r\nstart it at will. So I let it slip away from me. The thuddings ceased\r\nand only the pauses remained--silent, shapeless things in endless\r\nprocession. And then the great silence. It flowed over me and I was\r\nlost.\r\n\r\nThe silence was too heavy and my thoughts were not my own; they floated\r\nup away from me in the silence. I could feel them go, but there was\r\nnothing to bring them back. Each thought of protest winged its way\r\ninto a void with all the rest.\r\n\r\nAnd nothing else remained but the will to live. As the silence lapped\r\naround this will, it grew until it alone was I. The silence washed\r\nabout it, but it stood.\r\n\r\nThen the little rippings and the slicings and the tearings and the\r\nsoftening of things were there--heard without sound, felt without\r\nfeeling, like the pulling of a tooth from a novocaine-deadened jaw.\r\n\r\nIt was then I saw the face.\r\n\r\nHave you ever felt the terror of suddenly waking with a face--a face\r\nof eyes--staring into your unguarded and bewildered first glance? One\r\nfeels as if this face would look into one\'s very life and wrest it from\r\nhim. Perhaps it is a nascent fear of one\'s own mask of death.\r\n\r\nBut I could not escape the mask. It loomed above me with gaping maw\r\nand staring eyes; eyes that seemed more dead and deadly as my vision\r\ncleared. The mirror enlarged the horror that lay below it.\r\n\r\nIt was the wrench of nausea that pulled me from this nightmare. In the\r\nviolence of the retching, I rolled from beneath the mirror and raised\r\nmyself to hands and knees. I had knocked over the clock and it shouted\r\nup at me--10:05, July 15. Three days! 

Too long! Too horribly long!\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nSlowly I dragged myself to the telephone and pulled it from the stand.\r\nI remember nothing else until they brought me here.\r\n\r\nIt\'s been eight days--eight days away from death, yet I\'m closer to\r\nit now than ever before. And I can\'t _think_ of it. The fear has come\r\ncrashing through and I can\'t _think_.\r\n\r\nThis thing, this body is too far gone. I won\'t be able to make it move.\r\nI\'ll just feel it getting away--little by little--ripping apart cell by\r\ncell, and then everywhere all at once.\r\n\r\nI can feel it now. But in that great silence, I could almost hear the\r\ntearing--yet there was no sound.\r\n\r\nThe doctors have given up all hope. I can see it in their faces. 

I\r\ncould hear them talking among themselves when they brought me in. They\r\nhad to give it a name. There\'s a certain safety in a name, you know.\r\n\r\nI would have told them, but I was afraid they\'d laugh. 

The nurses would\r\nlaugh and say to each other, "Have you heard what the one in 408 wanted\r\nin his case history?"\r\n\r\nI couldn\'t stand the laughter now.\r\n\r\nBut that\'s the way my chart should read--Cause of Death:--_Death!_\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


Not because it wanted to,\r\nbut because it had to. Vaguely she remembered....\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nShe and Robbie had been sitting in a Chicago park when the first\r\nbomb dropped. It fell quite near them, about three miles away. She\r\nremembered the bright blinding flash. Above them the branch of a tree\r\ncracked. It fell to a point twenty feet over their heads. Then it\r\nstopped. It was as if some force held it back. The force, whatever it\r\nwas, also held back the heat. But it didn\'t stop her from fainting in\r\nterror.\r\n\r\nWhen she regained consciousness, the burned and broken city lay all\r\naround them. Buildings were fused together. Everywhere was destruction.\r\nEverywhere except around she and Robbie. There, the grass was green and\r\nflowers grew. At the edge where the green ended and the black began,\r\nthere was a pile of rubbish piled up _as if leaning against something_.\r\nShe picked up a stick nearby and threw it. It reached the point where\r\nthe green stopped and then it too stopped, _in the middle of the air_.\r\nFinally it fell to the ground.\r\n\r\nShe arose and walked over to where the stick lay. She extended her hand\r\na few feet in front of her, and touched something. 

Something tangible,\r\nyet she could not see it. And no matter how hard she pushed, she could\r\nnot extend her hand beyond a given point.\r\n\r\n_A dome was covering them and protecting them!_\r\n\r\nFor weeks she and Robbie stayed under the dome while the wind took some\r\nof the radiation away. Each morning, when they awoke, a package of food\r\nlay by their side. Strange food, food they had never tasted or seen\r\nbefore. _Alien food._\r\n\r\n_They had been spared by--what?_\r\n\r\nThe puzzling thoughts spun in her mind. _Why_ were they being spared?\r\n_Who_ was sparing them?\r\n\r\nThen one day, weeks after the bombs dropped, the dome disappeared. She\r\ncould not see it disappear, but she knew that it was gone for the pile\r\nof ash that had leaned against it fell to the ground.\r\n\r\nThen she started out with but one thought in mind. _I must find\r\nJohnny!_ Across country she went, through small towns filled with death.\r\n\r\nShe walked, with Robbie stumbling along at her side, his small face\r\nwide with wonder and fear. Her heart ached as she looked into his\r\nstaring eyes, while an occasional whimper left his lips. "... mommy,\r\nwhere\'s Daddy? Where is he, mommy?"\r\n\r\nShe gripped his hand tighter and continued to walk, each mile a numb\r\nand crazy nightmare.\r\n\r\n    "_Now take note of the setting the aliens are in. It took careful\r\n    planning for our scientists to devastate the planet\'s surface as\r\n    you now witness._"\r\n\r\nIt was late afternoon when Helen stopped to rest by a seared oak tree.\r\nRobbie had been walking beside her. Suddenly he turned and looked up at\r\nher. 

"Mommy, why are we walking so far? I\'m tired of walking. I don\'t\r\nwant to walk any more. Where is daddy?"\r\n\r\n"Hush, dear. We\'re going to find daddy." She knew they would never find\r\nhim ... alive. But something made her keep going. Something inside\r\nwouldn\'t let her turn back. _She had to know...._\r\n\r\n"We\'ve got to find daddy so he\'ll make everything right again, don\'t\r\nwe?"\r\n\r\nShe hesitated before answering. "Yes--yes that\'s it. We\'ve got to find\r\ndaddy so he can help us--and make everything right again!"\r\n\r\n"Oh."\r\n\r\n"Go to sleep, Robbie. You\'ve got to rest."\r\n\r\n"But I\'m hungry."\r\n\r\n"Sleep, dear. We\'ll eat ... 

later." She kissed him, sat on the ground\r\nbeside him and rocked his head in her weary arms.\r\n\r\n    "_For those of you students who do not understand the languages of\r\n    this planet, I\'ll interpret. She was trying to comfort her young\r\n    one, telling him that his father was going to make everything right\r\n    again when they found him. While inwardly she knew they would never\r\n    find him alive. Primitive peoples often react to disasters in this\r\n    way, making themselves and others around them believe things that\r\n    are not true._"\r\n\r\nSlowly Helen opened her eyes. She sat up slowly, taking in the scene\r\naround her. She sat that way for a moment, thinking, her mind far from\r\nthere, somewhere in southern France where her aunt and uncle were. She\r\nwondered if--\r\n\r\n"Robbie," she whispered. She nudged his shoulder gently, trying to\r\nawaken him. Finally his eyes opened. He smiled wistfully.\r\n\r\n"Get up, dear. We\'ve got to be going now."\r\n\r\n"I\'m hungry."\r\n\r\n"I know. So am I. We\'ll find something to eat pretty soon. You will\r\nhave to wait.

"\r\n\r\n"But--" Tears came to his eyes. One ran down his dirty cheek, making a\r\nrivulet.\r\n\r\n"Please Robbie," she pleaded. "Don\'t cry. Remember what daddy always\r\nsaid, \'A smile blocks up the tears.\'" He smiled weakly. "Now buck up,"\r\nshe added.\r\n\r\nShe took his hand and they started walking.\r\n\r\n    "_Reading her mind, I see that she is more concerned over her\r\n    child\'s welfare than her own. This is very unusual in primitive\r\n    races._"\r\n\r\nThey entered a small town. 

Down the main street they walked. The town\r\nwas deserted, but showed no sign of being bombed or burned. In the\r\nstreet, numerous automobiles were parked. But she saw no people....\r\n\r\nThey entered a restaurant. Inside, the tables and chairs were in good\r\norder except for a half inch of dust and a few dirty dishes. She\r\ninspected the kitchen and found what she had been looking for. Canned\r\nfood.\r\n\r\n"Robbie," she called. "Where are you?"\r\n\r\nShe walked back to the door of the kitchen and looked into the\r\nrestaurant. Robbie was not there.... Then she saw him through the\r\nrestaurant windows, standing on the street outside. She called\r\n"Robbie--I\'ve found some food!"\r\n\r\nRobbie turned, his small face twisted with hunger. He started back\r\ntoward the door.\r\n\r\nShe returned to the kitchen and looked for a can opener.\r\n\r\n    "_We will drop down a few hundred feet and pick up the young one\r\n    with our magnetic-force-field. We shall examine him._"\r\n\r\nOne moment Robbie was standing at the restaurant door, and the next\r\nhe was floating upward in the middle of the air. There was a strange\r\nsensation in his stomach. He was scared. He started to cry.\r\n\r\n    "_Notice the noise he makes with his mouth. This is not a form of\r\n    communication, but rather he is using a primitive form of expressing\r\n    his thoughts, which is called crying. Reading his mind, I find only\r\n    confusion and fear. He wonders where he is, but knows that he\r\n    doesn\'t like it._\r\n\r\n    "_Another interesting fact about these aliens is that they feel\r\n    pain. It is hard to understand and even harder to explain. 

But I\r\n    will try. We are aware of touching something or somebody only as a\r\n    sensation on the skin. These people have more than that. Now watch.\r\n    As I cut the skin of this young one slightly, notice that he jerks\r\n    and screams louder. He is feeling pain. It is a strong sensation\r\n    that leaves a sharp impression on the brain. That does not fully\r\n    explain it, but it is the best I can do along with this\r\n    demonstration._"\r\n\r\n"Oh, good God! Robbie! 

What happened, honey. 

What happened?" Then she\r\nsaw the blood dripping on the floor. "_Robbie_, your arm!"\r\n\r\nThen he was in her arms, sobbing hysterically. "I--I ... they took me,\r\nand cut me--and ..." but he could go no further.\r\n\r\nCarefully, she laid him on a table and examined his arm. The bleeding\r\nhad subsided some. She took a clean wet cloth and wiped off the blood.\r\nThen she bandaged it.\r\n\r\nRobbie had stopped sobbing now, but the tears were still coming. She\r\ntried to get the story of what had happened to him, but what she did\r\nhear, she didn\'t believe.\r\n\r\nAfter he finished she said, "Now, Robbie, I can\'t believe that you were\r\nlifted into the air by a space-ship, tied to a table and cut in the arm\r\nby some monster!"\r\n\r\n"But Mommy, that\'s what happened. 

Honest! And when I was laying on the\r\ntable I heard them talking. But I couldn\'t understand what they were\r\nsaying!"\r\n\r\nA grimness filled her as he spoke. 

And then a terrible horror spread\r\nthrough her. She remembered the Chicago park, when the bombs fell--how\r\nthey alone seemed to be spared death.... _Was it possible?..._\r\n\r\nShe grabbed Robbie into her arms and dashed up the street away from the\r\nrestaurant. She saw a car standing by the curb and ran to it. There\r\nwere keys in the ignition. She put Robbie on the front seat and got\r\nin. As the motor coughed into life she meshed gears and sped out of\r\nthe town. 

One thing buzzed in her mind. _Peoria--that\'s where Johnny\r\nis--oh, Johnny--help us!_\r\n\r\n    "_The conveyance in which you now see them is called an automobile.\r\n    It is propelled by a liquid fuel, gasoline, in an internal\r\n    combustion engine. We purposely had the automobile left there for\r\n    them._"\r\n\r\nShe drove through the industrial section of Peoria. She knew she was\r\nnear the factory where Johnny worked. She started looking for the\r\nbuilding, thinking how unfair it was for Johnny to have taken a job\r\nso far from Chicago. But her heart lifted as she thought about her\r\nhusband. _Johnny--Johnny, we\'re here!_\r\n\r\nThere! To her left. 

There it was! She stopped the car, took Robbie\'s\r\nhand and ran toward the building.\r\n\r\n"Mommy, is this where daddy is? Is he here?" Robbie\'s voice trembled.\r\n\r\nShe nodded her head as they ran. "Yes, Robbie--daddy\'s here!"\r\n\r\nShe reached the building. The door was open and they stepped inside.\r\n\r\nShe was breathless now. Johnny--so close.... She led Robbie to the\r\nstairs and her knees shook as they went up. "Johnny! Johnny!" she\r\ncalled, her voice close to hysteria.\r\n\r\nBut there was only silence.\r\n\r\nShe ran down the hall on the second floor, pulling Robbie with her,\r\nheard him sobbing. Then she saw the door and the gold letters on it.\r\nJOHN THOMPSON.\r\n\r\n"Robbie, stay here." She hesitated. Her hands were cold and clammy. She\r\nwas trembling.\r\n\r\nShe shoved open the door.\r\n\r\nShe screamed.\r\n\r\nThere on the floor lay a body. It had once been a man. Now there was\r\nonly a skeleton of bleached white bones. Then she saw _it_. On the ring\r\nfinger of his right hand. A gold ring with silver letters on black\r\nonyx. Johnny\'s....\r\n\r\nThen she was running and screaming. Screaming and running. Down the\r\nstairs and out the door. Behind her Robbie followed, crying, terror in\r\nhis small eyes.\r\n\r\nShe collapsed on the ground, her body shaking with sobs. Robbie fell\r\nbeside her.\r\n\r\nShe put her arms around him, clutched his body to her. "Oh, Robbie,"\r\nshe cried. "You\'re the only thing I have left in the world. I love you.\r\nDon\'t leave me. Don\'t ever leave me." She snuggled him closer to her.\r\n\r\nThen she looked at his face. She gave a little cry in her throat. She\r\nlooked closer. Covering his skin were small red sores. What was it she\r\nhad once read in a book?--Something about radiation poisoning--red\r\nsores appearing just before death--\r\n\r\n"No, Robbie! Oh, no!

"\r\n\r\nHe looked up at her, his eyes hot and feverish. He tried to talk but\r\nthe words bubbled on his lips.\r\n\r\nShe pressed him to her breast and rocked him, shaking her head. "No,\r\nRobbie! Don\'t leave me!..."\r\n\r\nShe felt the beating of his heart against hers. Slower. His small body\r\ntwitched. Then grew silent.\r\n\r\n... She sat there on the ground, holding the still form in her arms\r\nlong after the sun had set. The Moon shone down with a silver glow,\r\nbathing the child\'s dead body in its soft light. It shone in the\r\nwoman\'s eyes too, glazed eyes, with a dead mind behind them....\r\n\r\n    "_That concludes our lesson for today._"\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


But then, my brother is\r\nlame and good for nothing but drawing pictures of the stars. He connects\r\nthem with lines, like a child\'s puzzle, and so makes star-pictures. He\r\nhas fish stars, archer stars, hunter stars. That, I would say, is what\r\nis foolish.\r\n\r\nPerhaps that is what started it all. I was looking at the stars, trying\r\nto see the pictures, when I should have been minding my sentry post.\r\nThey took me like a baby, like a tot not yet given to the wearing of\r\nclothing. The hand came out of the darkness and clamped over my mouth,\r\nand I ceased my struggling when I felt a sharp blade pricking at the\r\nsmall of my back.\r\n\r\nAt first I feared that they would slay the entire camp as it slept and I\r\ncursed my brother for his star-pictures, cursed our leader who had sent\r\nus here, twenty archers, against the Onist outpost on our country\'s\r\nborder. But the Onists had other ideas. They took me away. I had to\r\nadmire their vitality, because all night we ran through the silent\r\nwoodlands, and they seemed tireless. I could maintain their pace, of\r\ncourse: but I\'m a Pluralist.\r\n\r\nI could see their village from a long way off, its night fires glowing\r\nin the dark. It was only then that we slowed our pace. Soon we entered\r\nthe place, a roughly circular area within a stockade, and my captors\r\nthrust me within a hut. I couldn\'t do much worrying about tomorrow, not\r\nwhen I was so tired. I slept.\r\n\r\nI dreamed a stupid dream about the Onist beliefs, the beliefs of an\r\nunimaginative people who could picture one Maker and one Maker only. I\r\nmust have chuckled in my sleep.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"You\'re awake."\r\n\r\nA brilliant statement, that--because I had sat up, squinted into the\r\nbright sunlight streaming in through the doorway, yawned and stretched.\r\nThe Onists, I tell you, lack imagination.\r\n\r\nThe girl who spoke was a pretty enough little thing for an Onist. She\r\nsmiled, showing even white teeth. "Do you Pluralists eat?"\r\n\r\nI nodded and rubbed my belly. I was to have had dinner after my turn as\r\nsentry the night before, and now I felt like I could do justice to my\r\nportion even at one of the orgies for which the Onists are so famous.\r\n\r\n"Bring on your food and I\'ll show you," I told her, and she turned her\r\nback to walk outside. It was early and the village seemed silent--surely\r\nthey hadn\'t intended this one slim maid to guard me! Yet she seemed\r\nalone.\r\n\r\nI leaped at her, circled her neck with my arm, prepared to make my exit.\r\nThey would laugh around our fire when I told them of this fine example\r\nof the Onist lack of foresight....\r\n\r\nExcept that the girl yelped. Not loudly, but it was loud enough, and a\r\nbig muscular Onist came striding in with his throwing spear. He backed\r\nme off into a corner, prodding my hungry belly with his weapon.\r\n\r\n"Will you behave?"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI told him I would and he backed outside, but this time I could see his\r\nshadow across the doorway.\r\n\r\nThe girl brought food and partook of it with me. I was surprised,\r\nbecause we Pluralists will not eat with an Onist out of choice. Well, I\r\nhave said they are a strange people. Soon the girl stood up, patting her\r\nmouth daintily with a square of cloth, and in that, of course, she was\r\ntrying to mime our graceful Pluralist women. "I suppose you think we are\r\ngoing to kill you," she said. Just like that.\r\n\r\n"To tell you the truth, I haven\'t given it much thought. There isn\'t\r\nmuch I can do about it."\r\n\r\n"Well, we\'re not. We could have done that back at your camp. We could\r\nhave killed all of you. 

No, we want to show you something."\r\n\r\nI had a ridiculous thought that they made star-pictures, too--even those\r\nwho are not lame like my brother. I said, "Well, what will happen to me\r\nafter you show me?

"\r\n\r\nShe smiled. "You still think we\'re going to kill you. 

What\'s your name?"\r\n\r\nI told her, but I thought: she can\'t even keep a conversation going\r\nwithout changing the subject.\r\n\r\n"Jak," she repeated after me. "That\'s a common enough name. We have Jaks\r\namong our Onist people, you know."\r\n\r\n"No, I didn\'t. But you probably copied it."\r\n\r\n"I doubt that. We were here first, Jak. Our records say so. Probably,\r\nyou once captured a man with that name, long ago, liked it, and took it\r\nfor your people."\r\n\r\n"_You_ were here first!" I sneered. 

"Maybe that\'s what your records tell\r\nyou, but it isn\'t so. Look: the Makers endowed us with life, then went\r\naway in to the sky. By mistake they left one idiot-Maker behind, and he\r\nhad nothing to do. He made you Onists before he perished, and that is\r\nwhy you think there is only one Maker."\r\n\r\nShe seemed highly insulted. "Idiot-Maker? 

Idiot! There was only one\r\nMaker, ever, but because your minds cannot conceive of all that glory\r\nresiding in one figure, you invented a score."\r\n\r\nNow it was my turn to be indignant. "A score? Hundreds, you mean;\r\nthousands--more than there are leaves on the trees."\r\n\r\n"Well, I won\'t argue with you. Our war has been arguing that point well\r\nenough." I was sorry she would not argue. She looked very pretty when\r\nshe argued, her breasts heaving, her eyes sparkling fire.\r\n\r\n"What\'s your name?" I asked.\r\n\r\n"Nari. My name is Nari. And don\'t tell me you had that name first!"\r\n\r\nI smiled blandly. "Of course we did. I have an aunt, my mother\'s sister,\r\nwho goes by that name. My brother\'s wife\'s cousin, also; but she is very\r\nugly."\r\n\r\n"And am I ugly?" Nari wanted to know. I guess in that sense at least,\r\nwomen are the same everywhere--Pluralist or Onist, it doesn\'t matter.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI looked at her. I looked at her so hard that it made her blush, and\r\nthen she looked even prettier. But I didn\'t tell her so.\r\n\r\n"You will pass, for an Onist," I admitted. "I guess the Onists might\r\nconsider you pretty; the Onist men might stamp their feet and shout if\r\nyou go by--but then, they are Onists."\r\n\r\nAt that, she seemed on the verge of leaving my prison hut, but something\r\nmade her change her mind. She stayed all morning and on into the\r\nafternoon. We argued all the time, except at midday, when she went\r\noutside to get our lunch. She stumbled a little and fell half against my\r\nshoulder. I moved toward her to hold her up, and it was the most natural\r\nthing in the world to take her in my arms and kiss her. She must have\r\nthought so, too; she responded beautifully--for an Onist.\r\n\r\nAfter lunch, Nari did not mention the kiss, nor did I. It now seemed the\r\nmost natural thing in the world not to talk about it. We argued some\r\nmore, Nari defending her primitive beliefs, I trying to show her the\r\nlight of truth. But it was no use: the war had been fought and the war\r\nwould continue.\r\n\r\nLater that day we set out. That came as a surprise to me, because I had\r\ntaken it for granted that whatever the Onists wanted to show me was\r\nright here in this little village. A dozen of us went, and when we had\r\nbeen on the trail for some little time, Nari joined us, declaring that\r\nshe wanted to see it again--whatever it was.\r\n\r\nWe went for three days, and although these Onists turned out to be\r\nbetter woodsmen than I had thought, still, they could not match the\r\nskill we Pluralists have mastered over the generations. I believe I\r\ncould have escaped, had I wanted to; but I hardly seemed a prisoner of\r\nwar, and besides, once or twice when we had lagged to the rear of the\r\ncolumn, Nari stumbled against me like that day in the hut, and what\r\ncould I do but kiss her?\r\n\r\nIt was another village we reached at the end of our march, much bigger\r\nthan the first. Surprisingly, it looked a lot like a Pluralist town,\r\nalthough it may only have seemed so because I had been out in the\r\nwoodlands for three days. They took me straightways to the village\r\nsquare, and it was there that I saw the statue.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThese statues of the Makers are rare, and I was surprised to see one in\r\nan Onist village. I got on my knees at once to do it reverence. 

I\r\nrealize it was impious to look up, but I did--I had to see if it were\r\nthe genuine thing. 

And it was, to the last detail. Constructed of the\r\nforbidden substance known as metal, it towered three times a Pluralist\'s\r\nheight, or three times an Onist\'s, for that matter. I have always\r\nwondered why the Makers did not create our ancestors in their own\r\nsubstance, as they had fashioned us in their image. But that is an\r\nimpious thought.\r\n\r\nA stern gray-haired Onist who said he was Nari\'s father took me aside\r\nafterwards. "Now, Jak," he asked me, "what can you say of what you have\r\nseen?

"\r\n\r\nI shrugged. "I can say that somehow you\'ve found one of the Maker\r\nstatues. What more?"\r\n\r\n"It\'s one, is it not?"\r\n\r\n"Of course it\'s one. They are rare, but I have seen three, all told, in\r\nPluralist villages."\r\n\r\n"And each time they were separate? You never saw a group?"\r\n\r\n"No. 

No, I didn\'t."\r\n\r\nHe slapped his hands together triumphantly. 

"Then that proves it. Each\r\nis a copy of the original Maker, but there was only one. Otherwise you\r\nwould have seen statues in groups. And that is why you are here, Jak: we\r\nwant you to go back to your people and tell them what you saw."\r\n\r\nI shook my head. 

"What you say isn\'t logical. So what if the statues are\r\nnever in pairs or groups? We\'ve only seen a few, when once there must\r\nhave been many. Also, when your artists do their magic with dyes and\r\ncreate portraits, are they generally done one at a time or in groups?"\r\n\r\n"One at a time, so the artist may capture the personality in each face,\r\nnaturally. I have seen group portraits, but I think they are silly\r\nthings."\r\n\r\n"Exactly." Now I was triumphant. "Exactly as the Makers thought, which\r\nis why the statues are always single--"\r\n\r\n"But it is impious to say there was more than one Maker! He had all the\r\nknowledge in the world at his fingertips, and so there was no need for\r\nmore than one. More than this world, even: he went to the stars. Or\r\ndon\'t you believe that?"\r\n\r\n"Of course I believe it. Only, _they_ went to the stars, the thousands\r\nof Makers. It isn\'t impious, because if you can think of one being as\r\ngreat as that, try to picture thousands. Yes, thousands. That makes me\r\nthousands of times more pious than you Onists.

"\r\n\r\nHe shook his head wearily. "What\'s the use? It is for this we are\r\nfighting our war, and we thought if we took one of you here, showed him\r\nthe undeniable truth of our statue.... Well, will you at least return to\r\nyour people with a tale of what you have seen?"\r\n\r\nI agreed readily enough: probably, the alternative was death. Although\r\nPluralists on rare occasions have been known to take Onist women as\r\ntheir wives, an Onist prisoner of war was an unwanted thing. The reverse\r\nwould also be true.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThey all bid me goodbye, except for Nari. I could not find her anywhere\r\nin the village, and a little sadly I set out on my long journey back to\r\nthe Sunset Land. By now our raiding party had finished its work on the\r\nsmall Onist village on the rim of our country, and I could do nothing\r\nbut return to my people, where we might plan new strategy against the\r\nunbelievers.\r\n\r\nBut I had wanted to bid Nari farewell.\r\n\r\nI met her in the woodlands, a travel bag slung over her shoulder like a\r\nmale\'s. "I wanted to say goodbye privately," she told me.\r\n\r\n"Good," I said, but I knew she was lying. Else why the travel bag?\r\n\r\n"Goodbye," Nari whispered, but she was not looking at me. Looking,\r\ninstead, behind her, at the land of her people.\r\n\r\n"Nari," I told her, "I have to admit it. You are very pretty--even by\r\nPluralist standards. You are--"\r\n\r\nThis time she did not stumble against me. It wasn\'t necessary. I drew\r\nher to me, and I kissed her a long kiss. Then I told her I loved her,\r\nand women, I suppose, will always be women, because she said she knew\r\nit.\r\n\r\nI will take Nari back to our village in the Sunset Land, where we will\r\nbe married by the laws of my people. And if ever there is to be peace\r\nbetween the Pluralists and the Onists, it may, after all, come on these\r\ngrounds. The Onists have their beliefs, and so I hate them for their\r\nimpious thoughts. But the love of a man for a maid exists apart from\r\nthat.\r\n\r\nIt won\'t be easy. Our arguing continued all the way back to the Sunset\r\nLand, and Nari is as stubborn as I am firm.\r\n\r\n"There is one Maker," she said.\r\n\r\nAnd I told her, "No, there are many."\r\n\r\nOr later, as we neared the Sunset Land, we picked up the thread of our\r\nthoughts again. Pluralist or Onist, we androids are dogmatic creatures.\r\n\r\n"One Robot created us all before he went to the stars," said Nari.\r\n\r\n"Robots," I said. "Many Robots." But I kissed her.\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _If Worlds of Science Fiction_ July\r\n    1952.
