I love him better than anyone else in the whole\r\nworld. Whenever the other kids tease me and call me Crazy Joe I go to\r\nGramp and he tells me funny stories and makes me laugh.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI remember the first time he told me about people hating other people\r\nwho are different.\r\n\r\n"Why do the kids call me Crazy Joe and laugh at me?" I asked him.\r\n\r\n"Well, you see," Gramp said slowly, "your Daddy worked for Uncle Sam\r\nin a big place where they make things that the government won\'t tell\r\nanybody about. Then your Daddy got sick from something in the big\r\nplace. After a long time he went up to stay with God. Then God took\r\nMommy too, when He gave you to her. And now you\'re our little boy,\r\nmine and Gramma\'s. And because you\'re a very special kind of little\r\nboy, the other children are jealous. So I wouldn\'t play with them any\r\nmore if they tease you. Just don\'t let them see you\'re afraid of them.\r\nYou\'ll always be Gramp\'s Little Joe."\r\n\r\nI love Gramp very much....\r\n\r\nWe kept walking until we came to Fayette. We went into Carl Van\r\nRemortal\'s store. Gramp sat on a chair by the big iron stove and I sat\r\non his knee on his good leg. The stove must be real old, because it\'s\r\ngot 1926 on its door in big iron letters.\r\n\r\n"Tell me the pictures you see in Mr. Van\'s mind," Gramp whispered in my\r\near, "but don\'t let him hear you."\r\n\r\n"He\'s making pictures of the fishing boats coming in," I said. "In the\r\npictures he\'s talking to Jack La Salle and giving him some money for\r\nhis fish.... The pictures are getting all mixed up now. He\'s putting\r\nthe fish in ice in boxes, but other pictures show him in church. Jack\r\nLa Salle is in the church too, and Mr. Van\'s sister Margaret is dressed\r\nin a long white dress and standing alongside him."\r\n\r\n"He\'s thinking that Jack La Salle will be marrying Margaret pretty\r\nsoon," Gramp said. "What else is he thinking?"\r\n\r\n"The pictures are coming so fast now that I can\'t name them all," I\r\nsaid.\r\n\r\nMr. Lawrence St. Ours came into the store, and Gramp told me to read\r\nwhat he was thinking. I looked inside his head.\r\n\r\n"He\'s making pictures of himself driving a car, and buying bread, and\r\nbacon, and piling hay on his farm, and ..." I said, but then I had to\r\nstop. "All the pictures come so fast that I can\'t read them," I told\r\nGramp. "Everybody makes blurry pictures like that most of the time."\r\n\r\n"Instead of trying to tell me what the pictures are, see if you can\r\nunderstand what they mean," Gramp said.\r\n\r\nI tried but it was awful hard and pretty soon I got tired and Gramp and\r\nI left the store and went back home.\r\n\r\nThe next morning Gramp and I went out in the barn and Gramp said, "Now\r\nlet\'s see what we got here." He had me try to do a lot of things, like\r\nlifting something without touching it, and trying to make chickens run\r\nby making a picture of them doing that and putting it in their minds.\r\nBut I couldn\'t do any of them.\r\n\r\nAfter a while he said, "Let\'s go down to the store again."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWe went to the store almost every day after that. Then sometimes we\r\njust walked around Fayette, and Gramp had me practice reading what the\r\npictures in people\'s minds meant instead of just what they looked like.\r\nSometimes I did it real good. Then Gramp would buy me some candy or ice\r\ncream.\r\n\r\nOne day we were following Mr. Mears and I was telling Gramp what I saw\r\nin Mr. Mears\' mind when Mr. 

St. Ours drove by in his car. 

"Mr. Mears is\r\nmaking pictures about feeding meat to Mr. St. Ours\'s dog and the dog is\r\ncrawling away and dying," I said to Gramp.\r\n\r\nGramp was real interested. He said, "Watch close and read everything\r\nyou can about that." I did. After, Gramp seemed very happy. He bought\r\nme a big chocolate bar that time. Chocolate is my best kind of candy.\r\n\r\nI read lots of things in other people\'s minds that made Gramp feel good\r\ntoo, and he bought me candy just about every day.\r\n\r\nGramp seemed to have money all the time now instead of having to ask\r\nGramma for any. She wanted to know where he got all the money. But he\r\njust smiled with his right cheek like he does and wouldn\'t tell her.\r\nMost of the people in town didn\'t seem to like Gramp any more. They\r\nmade mad pictures about him whenever we met them.\r\n\r\nSometimes when we were in the store Mrs. Van would come in and she\r\nwould talk to me. She was awful nice. But she always had sad pictures\r\nin her mind and sometimes she would cough real hard and hold a\r\nhandkerchief up in front of her mouth.\r\n\r\nWhen she did that Mr. Van used to get sad too. In his pictures Mrs. Van\r\nwould be dead and laying in a coffin and they would be burying her in\r\na big hole in the ground. Mr. 

Van was nice too. He gave me crackers and\r\ncookies, or sometimes a big thin slice of cheese.\r\n\r\nOne night Gramp was holding me and buying some groceries and Mr. Van\r\nwas putting them in a cardboard box, and he was thinking about going to\r\nthe bank in Escanaba and cashing a check. And the man gave him a big\r\nhandful of money.\r\n\r\nI told Gramp, but then Mr. Van came close. I didn\'t say anymore, like\r\nGramp had told me. Mr. 

Van was whistling now. He made pictures of\r\ngiving the money to Mrs. Van. She was getting on a train and going to\r\na place where it was sunny all the time, and her cough went away and\r\nshe wasn\'t skinny any more. In his mind Mrs. Van was real pretty. She\r\ndidn\'t have the long nose like she really has.\r\n\r\nWhen we got in our car Gramp was excited. He asked me where Mr. Van had\r\nput the money he brought back from Escanaba.\r\n\r\nHe had bad pictures in his mind about taking Mr. Van\'s money and I\r\ndidn\'t want to tell him. But he grabbed my arm so hard it hurt and I\r\nbegan to cry. Gramp never hurt me before.\r\n\r\n"What are you crying for?" he asked me, cranky.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t want you to take Mr. Van\'s money," I told him.\r\n\r\nGramp let go of my arm and didn\'t say anything for a while.\r\n\r\n"Sometimes the pictures you see aren\'t true," he said. "You know that."\r\nHe took out his blue handkerchief and made me blow my nose. "Like when\r\nyou see pictures in Gramma\'s mind about her hurting me," he said. "She\r\nnever does, you know. 

So the pictures aren\'t true. It\'s just what we\r\ncall imagination."\r\n\r\n"But your pictures are bad! They make me scared," I said.\r\n\r\n"We all make bad pictures like that, but we don\'t mean them," Gramp\r\nsaid. "Remember how you said that you\'d like to eat the whole apple pie\r\nlast Sunday? You probably made pictures of doing that. 

But you never\r\ndid, because you know that Gramma and me should have some of it too." I\r\nguess Gramp can explain just about everything.\r\n\r\nSo I told him where Mr. Van had hid the money under a box of brown\r\nsugar. Gramp smiled and started the car.\r\n\r\nHe let me steer while it was going slow. "Who\'s my Chum?" he asked.\r\n\r\n"I am," I said, and I laughed real happy.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe next day when I got up Gramp was gone.\r\n\r\nI went back of the barn and played. I got a bunch of tin cans and\r\npunched holes in them with a nail like Gramp showed me, and I made\r\nsteps out of rocks and put a can on each step. I poured water in the\r\ntop can. It ran through the holes from each can to the other all the\r\nway down the steps.\r\n\r\nI heard our car come in the front yard.\r\n\r\nI went around the barn, and Gramp was just going up the steps to the\r\nhouse. He had been to Fairport where the big store is, and he had\r\nbought a lot of things that he was carrying in his arms. At first I was\r\nglad because he had bought something that was for me too.\r\n\r\nBut then I saw some bad pictures mixed with the happy ones--of Gramp\r\nbreaking a window in Mr. Van\'s store when it was dark and going in and\r\ntaking something from underneath the brown sugar box.\r\n\r\n"You told me you wouldn\'t take Mr. Van\'s money. 

And you did!" I said.\r\n\r\n"Ssh," Gramp said. He put his packages on the porch and sat down and\r\ntook me on his lap. He took a deep breath. "Remember what I told you\r\nabout imagination, Chum?" he asked me. "So you know you\'re not supposed\r\nto believe all the pictures you see. Now you\'re Gramp\'s Chum. And I\r\nwant you to promise me again not to tell anyone but me what you see,\r\nand I\'ll tell you if the pictures are real or not. Promise?"\r\n\r\nI promised, and Gramp opened one of the packages. He took out two new\r\npistols and a belt with double holsters to carry them in. He bent over\r\nand buckled them on me.\r\n\r\n"You look just like Hoppy now," he said.\r\n\r\nI gave him a big kiss, and ran back of the barn to shoot robbers.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIn the afternoon Gramp was playing he was a bad Indian and trying to\r\nscalp me when a strange car drove in our yard.\r\n\r\nMr. Van and two men with badges got out.\r\n\r\nMr. 

Van was real mad. "We\'ve come after the money, Bill," he said.\r\n\r\nGramp got white. He was scared, but he said, loud, "What the hell are\r\nyou talking about?"\r\n\r\n"You know what, Bill," Mr. 

Van said. "Someone saw you break into the\r\nstore. It will go easier on you if you admit it."\r\n\r\n"I told you I don\'t know what you\'re talking about," Gramp said. His\r\neyes moved kind of quick. 

Then he noticed me and he walked over to\r\nme. "That\'s a fine way to talk in front of the boy," he said over his\r\nshoulder. He took my hand. "Come on, Chum. 

We\'re going in the house."\r\n\r\n"Just a minute," the biggest policeman said. "We\'ve got a few questions\r\nthat we have to ask you."\r\n\r\nGramp made believe he was brushing some dirt from my pants. "Did anyone\r\nsee me take the money, Chum?" he whispered to me.\r\n\r\n"No," I said, even though I didn\'t understand exactly. "Mr. Van is just\r\npretending he knows you took it but he doesn\'t."\r\n\r\n"Good boy." Gramp patted me on the head. "Go into the house now."\r\n\r\nHe turned and walked back to the three men, pushing his wooden leg into\r\nthe ground hard. I didn\'t go in the house, though.\r\n\r\n"Now I\'ve had just about enough of this," Gramp said, with a big frown\r\non his face. "You can\'t bluff me, Van. Say what you got to say, and\r\nget off my property."\r\n\r\nMr. Van\'s shoulders seemed to sag and he got sad. He made the pictures\r\nin his mind of Mrs. Van being dead and being put in a big hole.\r\n\r\nIt made me so sorry I couldn\'t stand it, and I cried, "Tell him you got\r\nhis money under the seat in our car! Please, Gramp! 

Give it back to\r\nhim."\r\n\r\nNobody said anything, but everybody turned and looked at me.\r\n\r\nThey stood real still. I saw in Gramp\'s mind that I had been bad, bad.\r\nI ran to him and put my face in his coat and began to cry. I couldn\'t\r\nhelp it.\r\n\r\nAfter a minute Gramp knelt on his good knee in front of me and took my\r\ncheeks in both his hands.\r\n\r\n"I\'ve let you down, Chum," he said. He wasn\'t mad any more.\r\n\r\nHe picked me up in his arms. "You needed me, Little Joe," he said. "You\r\nneeded me." 

His eyes were all smudgy. He squeezed me so hard I couldn\'t\r\nbreathe, almost.\r\n\r\nThen he put me down and said, "Come on," to the two policemen. He\r\nwalked away between them.\r\n\r\nGramp!\r\n\r\nThe pictures in his mind were awful. I could hardly bear to look at\r\nthem.\r\n\r\nThe worst picture was--me.\r\n\r\nI cried and cried.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nThe Security Council was in emergency session. The four delegates would\r\nhave had easier consciences had more nations been represented, but it\r\nwas hard to travel now. Only Russia, England and France were able to\r\nsend their men to New York.\r\n\r\nSergei Moskov, USSR, presided unofficially. He wore a harried look, and\r\naddressed them wearily.\r\n\r\n"To think, gentlemen, that it has taken circumstances like these to\r\nbring us into accord!"\r\n\r\nThe others said nothing. Overhead, above New York\'s stone and glass UN\r\nbuilding that had been conceived in hope and wrought with faith, they\r\ncould hear the whine of the patrolling ships. The delegates stared at\r\nthe table in front of them.\r\n\r\n"Your country, Mr. Conrad," Moskov said to the American\r\nrepresentative, "is the mother of our last hope." He looked around the\r\ntable for concurrence. 

Sir Manly straightened a bit, and M. Tourneau\'s\r\nmustache twitched, but they all nodded. What use national pride now?\r\nThere was not much time, anyway. Tonight....\r\n\r\n"He will be here?" 

Moskov asked.\r\n\r\nConrad cleared his throat. He reached into his coat pocket and pulled\r\nout a slip of paper.\r\n\r\n"Joe--I mean, Dr. Waters--sent an answer to our request." He read:\r\n\r\n    "\'I take my vorpal sword in hand. Beware, Jabberwock--I come. Joe\r\n    Waters.\'"\r\n\r\n"The courage of youth," Sir Manly said, but he smiled.\r\n\r\nMoskov looked at his watch. "He should be here, then."\r\n\r\n"I am."\r\n\r\nThey all turned at the sound of that voice, and rose as Joe Waters\r\nstrode in. Just thirty years old, athletic, brilliant. He was\r\naccompanied by a wizened character in a baggy brown suit and crumpled\r\nfelt hat.\r\n\r\n"Gentlemen." Joe said, and bowed. They all sat down.\r\n\r\n"A friend," he explained, indicating his companion. "Name of Mike."\r\n\r\n"Friend _and_ buddy," Mike said in a whiskey-hoarse voice.\r\n\r\n"We thought you understood, Dr. Waters," Moskov said, eyeing Mike\r\ndistastefully, "that this was to be a secret conference."\r\n\r\nM. Tourneau, who had a sensitive nose, shifted his chair slightly away\r\nfrom the bum.\r\n\r\nJoe said, "I met Mike in a bar last night and he\'s been with me since.\r\nI like his unsophisticated point of view."\r\n\r\n"Bar!" Sir Manly exclaimed, visibly shaken.\r\n\r\n"Bar." Joe answered. 

"For the same reason I\'m here now." He leaned\r\nforward.\r\n\r\n"I happened to be looking at the moon with my girl when they blew it\r\nup." His eyes narrowed at the memory. "She started to cry, and was\r\nstill at it when we got back to her apartment. That\'s when I went to\r\na bar to get drunk. It\'s also one reason I\'m here. When they take the\r\nmoon away from lovers, it\'s the last straw!"\r\n\r\n"Give \'em hell, kid!" Mike rasped. Joe silenced him with a wave of his\r\nhand, and Mike slouched down in his chair looking hurt.\r\n\r\n"Mr. Conrad," Moskov said, "will you be good enough to give Dr. Waters\r\nthe latest developments?

"\r\n\r\n"All right. 

Joe, you know what\'s happened this past week."\r\n\r\nJoe nodded.\r\n\r\n"In case you didn\'t get the overall picture--their ships," he jerked\r\na thumb at the whine passing back and forth above, "have completely\r\nblanketed the world. They have destroyed every means of defense we\'ve\r\nused against them. 

Atomic anti-aircraft, even, hasn\'t fazed them in the\r\nleast.\r\n\r\n"Yesterday they sent for us. The head of their expedition told us who\r\nthey are, and it accounts, perhaps, for their anthropoidal appearance.\r\nThey are from Jupiter, so it\'s not inconceivable after all that similar\r\nforms of life should become dominant in the same solar system.\r\n\r\n"They are easily twice our size--and if ability to learn and speak\r\nfluently in a half hour, each of the three languages represented here\r\nmeans anything, they have a proportionate I.Q.\r\n\r\n"Their leader, Slan, says his title means he is the crown prince\r\nof the royal Jovian family. Slan was nothing if not courteous and\r\nchivalrous. He told us yesterday he would give us a sporting chance for\r\nsurvival--why, I can\'t imagine. Apparently this expedition is like a\r\nglorified fox hunt to them.\r\n\r\n"We are to choose a person to represent the world in an intellectual\r\nduel with him. If we win, they withdraw completely, never to bother us\r\nagain. If we lose, then, he said, we\'re not worth saving and we\'ll be\r\ncompletely destroyed--hunted individually, which to them is great sport.\r\n\r\n"To prove they could do it, he had his ship\'s guns turn on the moon.\r\nYou saw what happened--disintegrated completely."\r\n\r\n"Them crumbs!" Mike grated. "We\'ll murder \'em, Joe!"\r\n\r\n"Quiet, Mike."\r\n\r\nMike grumbled, pulled out a cigarette paper and tobacco and rolled his\r\nown.\r\n\r\n"That\'s why we\'ve called on you," Conrad said.\r\n\r\n"Waters," Sir Manly said, "the world rests on your shoulders."\r\n\r\n"You have every qualification," M. Tourneau put in.\r\n\r\n"Your brilliant theories in symbolic logic and theoretical\r\nmathematics," said Sir Manly.\r\n\r\n"Chess champion of the world," Moskov added respectfully.\r\n\r\n"Your contributions to astrophysics," Conrad said.\r\n\r\n"And don\'t you guys ferget--he won the decathlon when he was just a\r\nhigh school kid. He\'ll murder them bums!

"\r\n\r\nJoe smiled. 

"Don\'t mind my pugnacious friend."\r\n\r\n"You are, so far as we know, the finest representative the world\r\ncould have." Moskov looked serious, and Joe became aware suddenly of\r\nthe awful burden involved. What use intellectual ability or athletic\r\nprowess, compared to Jovian standards? Wasn\'t there someone--even a\r\nscience-fiction writer, perhaps--better qualified to handle a situation\r\nas fantastic as this? Apparently not.\r\n\r\n"When\'s the funeral?" Joe asked drily.\r\n\r\n"Please, m\'sieu, a little respect for the situation!" M. Tourneau\r\nlooked pained.\r\n\r\n"The contest is to be in Slan\'s ship at eight o\'clock tonight," Moskov\r\nanswered. "They will pick you up here in five hours."\r\n\r\n"You and me both, Joe," Mike said.\r\n\r\n"Yeah," Joe answered, and now he was mentally reeling under the impact\r\nof his responsibility. "Let\'s have a drink first. I think we\'ll need\r\none.

"\r\n\r\nSir Manly paled. "I say...."\r\n\r\n"We\'ll murder them damn Greeks," Mike chortled.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Shay, I\'m not goin\' in that thing," Mike protested.\r\n\r\n"Can\'t fight \'em if we don\'t," Joe answered mournfully.\r\n\r\n"They\'re big enough, all right," Mike admitted respectfully. "Wouldn\'t\r\nsome football coach like to have one o\' _them_ on his squad!"\r\n\r\n"C\'mon, le\'s go." Joe shoved Mike toward the waiting ship, at the door\r\nof which a behemoth of a figure waited patiently, watching with some\r\napparent disdain as the two, arms around each other\'s shoulders, weaved\r\nunsteadily inside.\r\n\r\nInside the ship, Joe took a long pull at the bottle Mike passed him.\r\nStrange, he thought, how an unforseeable factor, upsetting life\'s\r\nroutine equations, produces unguessed mental reactions. Until last\r\nnight he\'d never had a drink in his life. 

Then a little thing like the\r\nmoon being blown up. Aloud he quoted,\r\n\r\n    "\'Yet what are all such mysteries to me\r\n    Whose life is full of indices and surds?\r\n    x^2 + 7x + 53 - 11/3\'"\r\n\r\n"Whassat?"\r\n\r\n"Lewish Carroll," Joe answered, and wondered greatly at the vast\r\namounts of liquor he had consumed in a short space of time.\r\n\r\n    "\'Beware the Jabberwock, my son....\'"\r\n\r\nAnd Joe Waters, the world\'s most brilliant human, passed out.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThey left Joe in the ship and dragged Mike before Slan. That gigantic\r\nfigure sat in regal splendor at the end of a long corridor that ran the\r\nlength of the vessel. On either side of Mike, as he stumbled toward the\r\nthrone which seemed miles away, uniformed giants stood at attention.\r\nHad he stretched his arm he might have been able to rap a belt buckle.\r\nThe sensation of being a pygmy increased as he approached Slan.\r\n\r\nGrouped around Slan, whose throne was on a platform several feet\r\nhigh, stood members of what seemed to be a retinue. They sneered and\r\nsnickered as Mike drew near, and Mike had to strain his neck and\r\nblurred eyes to see them.\r\n\r\n"Are you ready to begin?" Slan asked in a voice that nearly deafened\r\nMike.\r\n\r\n"We\'ll murder ya, ya bums," Mike answered belligerently. His\r\nwhiskey-fogged mind somehow assumed Joe was still by his side.\r\n\r\n"Very well, then." And Slan extended an arm toward Mike, thumb pointed\r\nup.\r\n\r\nMike promptly repeated the gesture, except that he pointed _his_ thumb\r\ndown.\r\n\r\nSlan reached for a huge flagon of red liquid, which he poured slowly\r\nonto the floor. Mike stared, then reached into a hip pocket and\r\nproduced a bottle of whiskey, swallowed some and vigorously smacked his\r\nlips. Then he held the bottle out to Slan, grinning broadly.\r\n\r\nSlan reached into a bag at his side, took out a handful of colored\r\npebbles, and scattered them on the floor. Mike scrambled after them and\r\nstuffed them into his pocket, then struggled erect, panting with the\r\nexertion.\r\n\r\nSlan arose from his throne, stepped off the platform, and towered over\r\nMike.\r\n\r\n"You surprise me," he boomed. "You and your little planet are smarter\r\nthan I expected. Go, and tell your people that they could not have\r\nchosen a worthier representative."\r\n\r\nIt was a dazed and confused Mike who was led stumbling, and clutching\r\nhis bottle, back to the ship which was to take him to a free world.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nSlan, meanwhile, found himself besieged by annoyed and puzzled\r\nfollowers. He held up his hand for silence, and relapsed into native\r\nJovian.\r\n\r\n"That earthling," he said sarcastically, "seems to have fared better\r\nthan you who are so proud of your intellects.\r\n\r\n"When I held my thumb up, indicating our superiority in size and\r\nstrength, he pointed his thumb down, to show that physical power is\r\nreally of minor importance.\r\n\r\n"I poured a red liquid onto the floor, dramatizing the effect of\r\nconflict on them, if that should be my wish. He demonstrated his\r\nfearlessness by producing a light-colored liquid and sampling it with\r\nenjoyment--as his kind would react to such an encounter.\r\n\r\n"Finally I flung out a handful of colored pebbles, displaying the\r\nconfusing array of languages, races, and ideas their world contains. He\r\nscooped them into his pocket, showing that their diversity could still\r\nbe united into single purpose."\r\n\r\nSlan looked contemptuously at the crestfallen faces of his men.\r\n\r\n"It would be to our benefit if we had half their spirit in proportion\r\nto our size," he said. Then he bellowed,\r\n\r\n"Order all ships to withdraw at once!" To an aide he muttered, "We\'ll\r\nleave this planet to those worthy of it."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nMike and Joe were hiding from a world delirious with joy and anxious to\r\nheap glory upon its saviour--whom they thought was Joe Waters. Joe had\r\nno intention of deluding the world in this regard, but right now he was\r\nplying Mike with whiskey to get from him the story of what happened.\r\n\r\nThey were in the rear booth of a bar, and Mike kept insisting that Joe\r\nknew perfectly well what had happened because he\'d been right there.\r\n\r\n"All right," Joe said coaxingly, "I know what happened. Joe pleaded. Mike, who apparently had no saturation\r\npoint, gulped some more whiskey.\r\n\r\n"First thing," he said, "the guy sticks his thumb up in the air, like\r\nhe\'s gonna give me the bum\'s rush. So I point mine down--if he tries to\r\nkick me outa there before we even get a chance to talk business, I\'ll\r\nfloor \'im."\r\n\r\n"Yeah, you would."\r\n\r\nMike ignored this comment, took yet another drink and wiped his lips on\r\nthe back of his hand. Joe watched this display of alcoholic immunity\r\nwith admiration, and Mike continued.\r\n\r\n"Then he takes a bottle of this awful-looking wine and pours it out on\r\nthe floor.\r\n\r\n"No wonder they been raising such a rumpus, Joe. With nothing but that\r\nstuff to drink, I would too! So I pulled out my flask and took a swig,\r\nto show what we\'ve got, and I offer him some. You know something, Joe,"\r\nand Mike leaned forward earnestly, "when that guy saw the kind of stuff\r\nwe drink he got a new respect, \'cause he takes a handful of jewels and\r\nrolls \'em at me. Now, I don\'t look no gift horse in the teeth--I pocket\r\n\'em as fast as I get my hands on \'em. ]\r\n\r\n\r\n    _That first trip to the moon has been the subject of many stories.\r\n    Mr. Vandenburg has come up with as novel a twist as we\'ve ever read._\r\n\r\n    _And it could happen._\r\n\r\n\r\nThe Ajax XX was the first American space craft to make a successful\r\nlanding on the moon. She had orbited the Earth\'s natural satellite for a\r\nday and a half before making history. 

The reason for orbiting was\r\nimportant. The Russians had been boasting for a number of years that\r\nthey would be first. Captain Junius Robb, U.S.A.F., had orders to\r\ninvestigate before and after landing.\r\n\r\nThe moon\'s dark side was explored, due to the unknown hazards involved,\r\nduring the orbiting process. More thorough investigation was possible on\r\nthe moon\'s familiar side. The results seemed to be incontrovertible.\r\nCaptain Junius Robb and his crew of four were the first humans to tread\r\nthe ashes of the long dead heavenly body. The Russians, for all their\r\nboasts, had never come near the place.\r\n\r\nThe Ajax XX stood tall and gaunt and mighty, framed against the\r\nforbidding blackness of space. Captain Robb had maneuvered her down to\r\nthe middle of an immense crater, which the crew came to nickname "the\r\ncoliseum without seats."\r\n\r\nRobb had orders not to leave the ship. Consequently, the crew of four\r\nscrupulously chosen, well-integrated men split into two groups of two.\r\nFor three days they labored at gathering specimens, conducting countless\r\ntests and piling up as much data as time and weight would allow. Captain\r\nRobb kept them well reminded of the weight problem attached to the\r\nreturn trip.\r\n\r\nNear the end of the third day Captain Robb contacted his far flung crew\r\nmembers over helmet intercom. He ordered them back to the Ajax XX for a\r\nbriefing session.\r\n\r\nSoon the men entered the ship. They were hot, uncomfortable and\r\nexhausted. Once back on Earth they could testify that there was nothing\r\nromantic about a thirty-five-pound pressure suit.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHamston, the rocket expert, summed it up: "With that damn bulb over his\r\nskull a man is helpless to remove a single bead of perspiration. He\r\ncould easily develop into a raving maniac.

"\r\n\r\nRobb held his meeting in the control room. "You have eight hours to\r\nfinish your work, gentlemen. We\'re blasting off at 0900."\r\n\r\n"I beg your pardon, Captain," said Kingsley, the young man in charge of\r\nradio operation, "but what about Washington? They haven\'t made contact\r\nyet and I thought--"\r\n\r\n"I talked with Washington an hour ago!"\r\n\r\nA modest cheer of approval went up from the crew members.\r\n\r\n"Well, why didn\'t you say so before!" said Anderson, the first officer.\r\n\r\nRobb explained. "It seems _their_ equipment has been haywire for two\r\ndays, they haven\'t been able to get through.

"\r\n\r\n"How do you like that!" cracked Farnsworth, the astrogator. "We\'re two\r\nhundred and forty thousand miles off the Earth and our equipment works\r\nfine. They have all the comforts of Earth down at headquarters and they\r\ncan\'t repair radio transmission for two days!"\r\n\r\nThe men laughed.\r\n\r\n"Gentlemen," Robb continued, "every radio and TV network in the country\r\nwas hooked up to the chief\'s office in Washington. I not only talked to\r\nGeneral Lovett, I spoke to the whole damn country.

"\r\n\r\nThe men could not contain their excitement. The captain received a\r\nverbal pelting of stored-up questions.\r\n\r\n"Did you get word to my family, Captain?" asked Kingsley.\r\n\r\n"I hope you told them we\'re physically sound, Captain," said Farnsworth.\r\n"I have a fianc\xc3\xa9e that\'ll never forgive me if anything happens to me--"\r\n\r\n"What\'s the reaction like around the country--"\r\n\r\n"Have the Russians had anything to say yet--"\r\n\r\n"Ha! I\'ll bet they\'re sore as hell--"\r\n\r\n"Do you think the army would mind if I hand in my resignation?"\r\nKingsley\'s remark brought vigorous applause from the others.\r\n\r\nCaptain Robb held up his hand for silence. "Hold on! 

Hold on! First of\r\nall, General Lovett has personally contacted relatives and told them\r\nwe\'re all physically and mentally sound. Secondly, you\'d better get set\r\nto receive the biggest damn welcome in history. The general says half\r\nthe nation has invaded Florida for the occasion."\r\n\r\n"Tell them we\'re not coming back," snapped Kingsley, "until the Florida\r\nTourist Bureau gives us a cut."\r\n\r\n"Kingsley, the President has declared a national holiday. We\'ll all be\r\nable to write our own ticket."\r\n\r\n"Yes," Anderson put in, "to hell with the Florida Tourist Bureau!"\r\n\r\nCaptain Robb said, "We\'ll be so sick of parades we\'ll wish we\'d stayed\r\nin this God forsaken place."\r\n\r\n"Not me," boasted Farnsworth. "I\'m ready for a parade in my honor any\r\nold time. 

The sooner the better."\r\n\r\n"Oh, and about the Russians," said Captain Robb, smiling. "There\'s been\r\nnothing but a steady stream of \'no comment\' out of the Kremlin since we\r\nlanded here."\r\n\r\n"Right now," said Hamston, "it\'s probably high noon for every scientist\r\nbehind the iron curtain."\r\n\r\n"I wonder how they plan to talk their way out of this one?" asked\r\nFarnsworth.\r\n\r\n"Gentlemen, I\'d like to go on talking about the welcome we\'re going to\r\nreceive, but I think we\'d better take first things first. Before there\r\ncan be a welcome we have to get back. And we still have work to do\r\nbefore we start."\r\n\r\n"What about souvenirs, Captain?" asked Farnsworth.\r\n\r\nRobb pursed his lips thoughtfully, "Yes, I guess there is a matter of\r\nsouvenirs, isn\'t there."\r\n\r\nThe others detected a note of disturbance in the way the captain spoke.\r\n\r\nKingsley asked, "Is anything wrong, Captain?"\r\n\r\nRobb laughed with a noticeable lack of enthusiasm. "Nothing is wrong,\r\nKingsley. The fact is we\'ve taken on enough additional weight here to\r\ngive us some concern on the return trip." He paused to study the faces\r\nof his men. They were disappointed. "But," he added emphatically, "I\r\nseem to remember promising something about souvenirs--and I guess a man\r\ncan\'t travel five hundred thousand miles without something to show for\r\nit. I\'ll get together with Hamston and work out something. But remember\r\nthat weight problem. First trouble we encounter on the return trip and a\r\nsouvenir will be our number one expendable."\r\n\r\nThe crew was more than happy with Robb\'s compromise. Robb went into a\r\nhuddle with Hamston, the rocket expert. When he emerged he informed the\r\ncrew that each man would be permitted one souvenir which must not exceed\r\ntwo pounds. He allowed them four hours to find whatever they wanted. The\r\nmen got back into their pressure suits and left the ship.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nCaptain Junius Robb stood outside the Ajax XX. His eyes scanned the\r\ngreat circular plain that stretched for fifty miles in all directions.\r\nThe distant jagged rises of the crater\'s rim resembled the lower half of\r\na gigantic bear trap.\r\n\r\nThe moon in all its splendor--wasn\'t there a song that went something\r\nlike that?--the moon in all its splendor, or lack of it was Robb\'s mute\r\nopinion. The scientists, as usual, were right about the place. To all\r\nintents and purposes the moon was as dead as The Roman Empire. True they\r\nhad found scattered vegetation; there were even two or three volcanoes\r\nspewing carbonic acid, but they spewed it as though it were life\'s last\r\nbreath.\r\n\r\nNothing more. The fires of the moon had given way to soft lifeless\r\nashes.\r\n\r\nRobb was glad he had allowed the men to look for souvenirs. After all,\r\nit wasn\'t a hell of a lot to ask for. A man could cut press clippings\r\nand collect medals and frame citations; and probably these things would\r\nimpress grandchildren someday. But it seemed that nothing would be quite\r\nas effective as for a man to be able to produce something tangible, an\r\nauthentic piece of the moon itself.\r\n\r\nCaptain Robb had always tried to be a humble man. He recalled an\r\ninterview held by the three wire services a week before take-off. One of\r\nthe reporters had asked the obvious question, "Why do you want to go to\r\nthe moon?" He could have given all of the high sounding, aesthetic\r\nreasons, but instead his answer was indirect, given with a modest smile.\r\n"To get to the other side, I guess," he had told them.\r\n\r\nLike the chicken crossing the road, that was how simple and\r\nuncomplicated Robb\'s life had been. But now he stood, his feet spread\r\napart, beside his mighty ship, a quarter of a million miles away from\r\nhome. He was the first! And he could not fight back the feeling of pride\r\nand accomplishment that welled in him. The word "first" in this instance\r\nconjured up names like Balboa, Columbus, Peary, Magellan--and Junius\r\nRobb.\r\n\r\nThe crew members deserved the hero\'s welcome they would receive. They\r\ncould have the banquets, parades and honorary degrees. But it was Junius\r\nRobb who had commanded the flight. It would be Junius Robb\'s name for\r\nthe history books.\r\n\r\nHe wouldn\'t be needing any souvenirs.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nKingsley and Anderson were the first to return. They both carried small\r\nleather bags. Inside the ship they revealed the contents to Robb. He\r\nexamined them carefully.\r\n\r\nKingsley had found an uncommonly large patch of brownish vegetation. He\r\nhad torn away a sizeable chunk and placed it in the bag. "Who knows?" 

he\r\nshrugged. 

"I might be able to cultivate it."\r\n\r\n"Or let it play the lead in a science fiction movie," snapped Anderson.\r\n\r\nThe first officer\'s bag contained a piece of one of the smaller craters.\r\nIt had no immediately discernable value. It was Anderson\'s intention to\r\npolish it up and put some kind of a metal plaque on it.\r\n\r\nFour more hours went by and there was no sign of Farnsworth or Hamston.\r\nRobb began to worry. He\'d never forgive himself if anything happened to\r\neither of the two men. He waited another half hour, then ordered Kinsley\r\nand Anderson to put on their pressure suits and go look for the two\r\nmissing crew members.\r\n\r\nThe search was avoided as Farnsworth entered the ship dragging Hamston\r\nbehind him.\r\n\r\n"What happened!" yelled Robb.\r\n\r\nFarnsworth began the job of getting out of his pressure suit. "I don\'t\r\nknow. Hamston\'s sick as a dog. I checked every inch of his suit and\r\ncouldn\'t find anything out of order."\r\n\r\nRobb bent over the prone rocket expert. Hamston looked up at him with\r\nhalf-opened eyes and an insipid grin on his face. He mumbled something\r\nabout "a fine state of affairs."\r\n\r\nThey removed Hamston\'s suit and placed his limp frame on a bunk. Robb\r\nexamined him for forty minutes.\r\n\r\nHe reached the curious conclusion that Hamston was as fit as a fiddle.\r\n\r\nThe rocket expert fell asleep. Robb and the rest of the crew prepared to\r\nblast off.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe Ajax XX thrust itself through space, halfway back to its home\r\nplanet.\r\n\r\nThe excitement of her crew members grew with every passing second. In\r\nhis concern over Hamston, Farnsworth had forgotten about his souvenir.\r\nHe now opened his bag and displayed it before the others.\r\n\r\n"What is it?" asked Kingsley.\r\n\r\n"Dust!" was Farnsworth\'s proud reply.\r\n\r\n"What the hell you going to do with dust?"\r\n\r\n"Maybe you don\'t know it but this is going to be the most valuable dust\r\non the face of the Earth! Do you realize what I can get for an ounce of\r\nthis stuff?"\r\n\r\n"What\'s anybody want to buy dust for?"\r\n\r\n"Souvenirs, man, souvenirs!"\r\n\r\nFarnsworth asked to see what Kingsley and Anderson had picked up. The\r\ntwo men obliged. For the next hour the three men and Robb discussed the\r\nmementoes and their possible uses on Earth.\r\n\r\nThen Anderson said, "I sure wouldn\'t turn down about a gallon of good\r\nKentucky whiskey right now!"\r\n\r\nRobb laughed. 

"We did enough sweating on the way. You wouldn\'t want to\r\nsweat out the trip back on a belly full of booze.

"\r\n\r\n"That may be a better idea than you think it is, Captain."\r\n\r\nThe four men turned to find Hamston sitting up on his bunk.\r\n\r\n"Hamston!" Robb exclaimed, "how do you feel?"\r\n\r\n"Terrible."\r\n\r\n"What happened to you?" asked Kingsley.\r\n\r\nHamston stared at each man individually. He took a deep breath and his\r\ncheeks puffed up as he let it out slowly. "Well, I guess you\'d better\r\nknow now."\r\n\r\nRobb frowned. 

"What do you mean?"\r\n\r\n"Farnsworth and I separated after we got about four miles from the ship.\r\nI thought I saw something that looked like a cave. I figured I might\r\nfind something interesting there to take back with me. So I told\r\nFarnsworth I\'d keep radio contact with him and off I went."\r\n\r\n"Did you find a cave?" Robb wanted to know.\r\n\r\n"No, it was just a big indentation in the wall of the crater. I threw\r\nsome light on it and found it to be ten or fifteen feet deep." He paused\r\nas though not sure of what to say next.\r\n\r\n"So?"\r\n\r\n"So that\'s where I found my souvenir."\r\n\r\n"Well, let\'s see it!" said Anderson.\r\n\r\nHamston opened his leather bag. The object he removed rendered the crew\r\nweak in the knees. He said, "We can have that drink, Anderson, but I\r\ndon\'t think we\'ll enjoy it."\r\n\r\nHe poured them each a shot from a half-filled bottle of Vodka.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


I know what I wanted to\r\nthink, but that\'s different from actually knowing.\r\n\r\nThere was the usual news just after Labor Day. The Dodgers were winning\r\nor losing, I forget which, and UCLA was strong and was going to beat\r\neverybody they met that fall. An H-bomb had been tested in the\r\nPacific, blowing another island off the map, just as if we had islands\r\nto spare. Ordinarily this was important, but now it wasn\'t. They put\r\nstuff like this in the back pages and hardly anybody reads it. There\r\nwas only one thing on the front pages and it was all people talked\r\nabout. All I talked about, anyway.\r\n\r\nIt began long before. I don\'t know how long because they didn\'t print\r\nthat. But it began and there it was, right upon us that day. It\r\nwas Saturday. Big things always seem to happen on Saturdays. I ate\r\nbreakfast and got out early. I had the usual things to do, mowing the\r\nlawn, for instance. I didn\'t do it nor anything else and nobody said\r\nanything. There wasn\'t any use in mowing the lawn on a day like that.\r\n\r\nI went out, remembering not to slam the door. It wasn\'t much, but it\r\nshowed thoughtfulness. I went past the church and looked at the sign\r\nthat was set diagonally at the corner so that it could be read from\r\nboth streets. There it was in big letters, quoting from the papers:\r\nTHIS IS THE DAY THE WORLD ENDS! Some smart reporter had thought it up\r\nand it seemed so true that that was the only way it was ever said. Me?\r\nI didn\'t know.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIt was a bright day. People were out walking or just standing and\r\nlooking at the sky. It was too early to look up. 

I went on. Paul\r\nEberhard was sitting on the lawn when I came along. He tossed me the\r\nfootball and I caught it and tried to spin it on my finger. It didn\'t\r\nspin. It fell and flopped out with crazy bounces into the street.\r\nThe milk truck stopped, while I got it out of the way. I tossed the\r\nfootball back to Paul. He put his hand on it and sat there.\r\n\r\n"What\'ll we do?" he said.\r\n\r\nI made a motion with my hands. "We can throw the ball around," I said.\r\n\r\n"Naw," he said. "Maybe you\'ve got some comic books."\r\n\r\n"You\'ve seen them all," I said. "You got some?"\r\n\r\n"I gave them to Howie," he said, thoughtfully screwing the point of the\r\nball into the center of a dandelion. "He said he was going to get some\r\nnew ones though. 

Let\'s go see." He got up and tossed the ball toward\r\nthe porch. It hit the railing and bounced back into the bushes. That\'s\r\nwhere he usually kept it.\r\n\r\n"Paul," called his mother as we started out.\r\n\r\n"Yeah?"\r\n\r\n"Don\'t go far. I\'ve got some things I want you to do."\r\n\r\n"What?" he said patiently.\r\n\r\n"Hauling trash out of the basement. Helping me move some of the potted\r\nplants around in front."\r\n\r\n"Sure," he said. 

"I\'ll be back."\r\n\r\nWe went past another church on the way to Howie\'s. The sign was the\r\nsame there. THIS IS THE DAY THE WORLD ENDS! They never said more than\r\nthat. They wanted it to hang in our minds, something we couldn\'t quite\r\ntouch, but we knew was there.\r\n\r\nPaul jerked his head at the sign. "What do you think of it?

"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know." I broke off a twig as we passed a tree. "What about\r\nyou?

"\r\n\r\n"We got it coming." He looked at the sky.\r\n\r\n"Yeah, but will we get it?"\r\n\r\nHe didn\'t answer that. "I wonder if it will be bright?"\r\n\r\n"It is now."\r\n\r\n"It might cloud over."\r\n\r\n"It won\'t matter. It\'ll split the sky." That was one thing sure. Clouds\r\nor anything weren\'t going to stand in the way.\r\n\r\nWe went on and found Howie. Howie is a Negro, smaller than we are and\r\ntwice as fast. He can throw a football farther and straighter than\r\nanyone else on the team. We pal around quite a bit, especially in the\r\nfootball season.\r\n\r\nHe came out of the house like he was walking on whipped cream. I didn\'t\r\nlet that fool me. More than once I\'ve tried to tackle him during a\r\npractice game. Howie was carrying a model of a rocket ship, CO_2\r\npowered. It didn\'t work. 

We said hi all around and then he suggested a\r\ngame of keep-away. We\'d left the football at Paul\'s and we couldn\'t so\r\nwe walked over to the park.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWe sat down and began talking about it. "I\'m wondering if it will\r\nreally come," said Paul. We all squinted up.\r\n\r\n"Where\'ll the President watch it from?" I said. "He should have a good\r\nview from the White House."\r\n\r\n"No better than us right here," said Howie.\r\n\r\n"What about Australia? Will they see it there?" I said.\r\n\r\n"They\'ll see it all over."\r\n\r\n"Africa, too? And what about the Eskimos?"\r\n\r\n"It doesn\'t matter whether they actually see it or not. It will come to\r\neveryone at the same time."\r\n\r\nI didn\'t see how it could, but I didn\'t feel like an argument. That\'s\r\nwhat they were saying on TV and you can\'t talk back to that.\r\n\r\n"Everybody," said Howie. "Not just in this town, but all over. Wherever\r\nthere are people. Even where they\'re not."\r\n\r\n"You read that," said Paul.\r\n\r\n"Sure," said Howie. "You lent me the comic books. It\'s even in them.

"\r\n\r\nWe didn\'t say much after that. I kept thinking of the man who made\r\nthe H-bomb. I bet he felt silly and spiteful, blowing up an island.\r\nSomebody might have wanted to live on it, if he\'d just left it there.\r\nHe must have felt mean and low when something really big like this came\r\nalong.\r\n\r\nWe talked on for a while, but we\'d talked it out long ago. There was\r\nreally nothing new we could say. 

Every so often we\'d look up at the\r\nsky, but it wasn\'t going to come until it got here.\r\n\r\nFinally we drifted apart. There wasn\'t anything left to do. We walked\r\nhome with Howie and then I went with Paul, leaving him to come back to\r\nmy house. I looked at the lawn and without thinking about it got busy\r\nand mowed it. I surprised myself.\r\n\r\nIt was hot, or it seemed to me it was. I went in to eat. Ma came by and\r\nshut off the sound of TV. I could still see the picture in the other\r\nroom. The announcer was making faces, but, of course, I didn\'t hear\r\nwhat he said. He looked pretty funny, I thought. I thought we were all\r\nprobably pretty funny, moving our mouths and blinking our eyes and\r\nwaving our hands. Only nothing real was coming out. Not yet, anyway.\r\n\r\n"Sit still," said Ma. "It will happen without your help. It\'s going to\r\nbe all right."\r\n\r\n"Think so?" 

I said. She would have told me anything to keep me quiet.\r\nShe gets nervous when I fidget.\r\n\r\n"I think so," she said, giving me my allowance. It was early for that.\r\nUsually I didn\'t get it until after supper. "Why don\'t you run uptown\r\nand watch it from there?"\r\n\r\n"Maybe I will," I said, dabbling my hands in the water at the sink.\r\n"Are you going to go?"\r\n\r\n"Of course I\'m not. Why should I get into that mob? I can watch it just\r\nas well from here.

"\r\n\r\nSure she could. But it was not the same. Everybody I knew was going\r\nto be there. I changed shirts before I left. I took a rag and wiped\r\nthe dust from my shoes. I wasn\'t trying to be fussy or dressed up or\r\nanything. I just thought I should do it.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThere was shade and sun on the streets and a few big clouds in the sky.\r\n\r\nA car slowed up and stopped beside me. The window rolled down and Jack\r\nGoodwin leaned toward me. "Going uptown?"\r\n\r\n"Yeah."\r\n\r\n"Want a lift?"\r\n\r\n"Sure." Actually I didn\'t. I\'d rather have walked, looking around as I\r\nwent.\r\n\r\nJack Goodwin grinned as I got in. He\'s got gray hair, where he has\r\nhair. The rest is bald. 

He looked me over. "I don\'t see any comets on\r\nyour shoulders," he said gravely.\r\n\r\n"I never had any," I said. Some people seem to think everyone under\r\nseventeen is a kid.\r\n\r\n"You\'ll be needing them," he said.\r\n\r\n"Maybe," I said. I ought to have walked.\r\n\r\nI never knew how slow a day could pass. I suppose I should have slept\r\nlate and kept busy doing something. This was worse than putting on a\r\nuniform and waiting until gametime. At least there was a coach on the\r\nfield to tell you what to do as you ran through the drill.\r\n\r\nJack Goodwin stopped at a light. I had a notion to get out. 

But I\r\ndidn\'t. Goodwin grinned again as the light changed and we started up.\r\n"I don\'t blame you for being edgy," he said. "It\'s the suspense. If we\r\nonly had some way of knowing for sure, radio maybe."\r\n\r\n"There\'s no radio," I said. "The calculations have been checked."\r\n\r\n"Sure, but maybe there\'s something we forgot. Or don\'t know. All sorts\r\nof things can go wrong."\r\n\r\nHe must have talked on and on, but I didn\'t listen. Howie and me and\r\nPaul had gone over everything he was saying.\r\n\r\n"Thanks," I said as he stopped and I got out.\r\n\r\n"Don\'t mention it," he said. He nearly scraped the rear fender of the\r\ncar as he drove off. It was a new car, too. 

He wasn\'t so bad. Maybe he\r\nwas just worried.\r\n\r\nI wandered to the newsstand and looked at magazines and pocketbooks.\r\nOld lady Simpson didn\'t ask me if I was going to buy and didn\'t chase\r\nme away. She was busy arguing with some customers. Even so it was the\r\nfirst time she didn\'t pay attention to me when I came in. I had a\r\ngood chance to look at things I never buy. There was nothing in them\r\nI wanted to see. I was thirsty. I had a coke and was still thirsty. I\r\nasked for a glass of water, drank half of it and went out.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nDown the street there was a TV set in a store window. I watched it.\r\nThey were showing a street in India, people looking up. They flashed\r\nall around, to Italy, China, Brazil. Except for their clothes, it\r\nwasn\'t much different from here. They were all looking up.\r\n\r\nI did the same. For the first time I noticed there was a slight\r\novercast. Big billowing clouds had passed, but this was worse. I hoped\r\nit would clear away in time. Not that it really mattered.\r\n\r\nIt was more crowded than usual for Saturday, but at the same time it\r\nwas quiet. People were shopping, but they weren\'t really buying much or\r\nelse they bought it faster. Nobody wanted to miss it. They all seemed\r\nto have one eye on their lists and another on the clock.\r\n\r\nHowie and Paul came up the street and we nodded and said something. A\r\nfew other boys from the school passed by and we stopped. We gathered\r\ntogether. It was getting closer--and the space between the minutes was\r\ngrowing longer and longer.\r\n\r\nI looked at Paul\'s watch. He said it was on the minute. I decided there\r\nwas time to go in and get a candy bar. All of a sudden I was hungry. I\r\ndidn\'t know where it came from. I\'d had to stuff down lunch not long\r\nago. And now I was hungry.\r\n\r\nI went to a store and had to fight my way in. People were coming out.\r\nNot just customers, but the clerks and owner, too. There was a big\r\ntelevision screen inside, but nobody wanted to see it on that. They\r\nwanted to be outside where it would happen to them. Not just see it,\r\nhave it happen. The store was empty. Not closed--empty.\r\n\r\nI turned and rushed out to join the others. I couldn\'t miss it.\r\nThere were still minutes to go, but suppose there _had_ been a\r\nmiscalculation. I knew what that would mean, but even so I had to be\r\nthere. I would almost die, too.\r\n\r\nNow we were all looking up--all over the world people were, I suppose.\r\nIt was quiet. You could hear them breathing.\r\n\r\nAnd then it came, a flash across the sky, a silver streak, the biggest\r\nvapor trail there ever was. It went from this side to that side in no\r\ntime. It split the sky and was gone before the shock blast hit us.\r\nNobody said anything. We stood there and shivered and straightened up\r\nafter the rumbling sound passed.\r\n\r\nBut there was the vapor trail that stretched farther than anyone could\r\nsee. It would go around the world at least once before it came to an\r\nend somewhere in the desert. I saw my science teacher--he was trying to\r\nsmile, but couldn\'t. And then there was the pharmacist who had wanted\r\nto be a research chemist, but wasn\'t good enough.\r\n\r\nIn front of me, old Fred Butler who drives the bus to Orange Point and\r\nKing City cracked his knuckles. "He did it," he whispered. 

"All the way\r\nto Mars and back. Safe and right on schedule." He jumped up in the air\r\nand kept jumping up. He hadn\'t been that high off the ground in several\r\nyears. He never would be again unless he took an elevator. And I knew\r\nhe hated elevators.\r\n\r\nFactory whistles started blowing. They sounded louder than Gabriel.\r\nI wonder if he heard them. I grabbed hold of the nearest person and\r\nstarted hugging. I didn\'t know it was the snooty girl from the next\r\nblock until she hugged back and began kissing me. 

We yelled louder than\r\nthe factory whistles. We had a right.\r\n\r\nIt was just like the papers said: This was the day the world ended--\r\n\r\nAnd the Universe began.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nBallard was quite dead. 

There could be no doubt of it. He lay sprawled\r\nin front of Edith, with his head very messily bashed in and with one\r\nhand still extended toward her. A long shimmering stream of blood\r\nran half-way across the large room. Dr. Dudley Ballard had been as\r\ninconsiderate in his dying as he had been in his living.\r\n\r\nArt MacKinney and I stood in the doorway and stared. We were shocked\r\nnot so much by the fact that Ballard was dead as by the fact that he\r\nlay in this most secret room, this holy of holies. Ours was the most\r\nsecurity conscious project in the whole country; and this was where he\r\nhad picked to get himself killed.\r\n\r\n"God! There\'ll really be a stink about this," MacKinney breathed.\r\n\r\n"Well, I can\'t think of anyone who had it coming more than he did,"\r\nI said. I hated Ballard\'s guts and everyone knew it, so there was no\r\npoint in being hypocritical now.\r\n\r\nEdith stood silently. She didn\'t seem to be interested in the fact\r\nthat the man who had run her life, who had spent hours shouting\r\nquestions at her and criticizing her slightest error with burning\r\nsarcasm was now dead. No, Edith wasn\'t interested, but you couldn\'t\r\nreally expect her to be--she was only a computing machine, a mechanical\r\nbrain, the final result of years of work by the best cybernetics\r\nexperts in the world. Edith was silent, and would be, until we turned\r\nher on and fed the tapes into her.\r\n\r\n"It looks as though this is what did it," MacKinney said, indicating a\r\nlarge spanner lying on the floor beside Ballard. He touched it gingerly\r\nwith his foot. 

His face was white and strained and it occurred to me\r\nthat he was more upset than I thought he should be. After all, he had\r\nas much reason to hate the dead man as the rest of us. Ballard had\r\ntaken advantage of his position as head of the research project to make\r\npasses at Jane Currey and MacKinney wasn\'t at all a cool scientist when\r\nit came to Jane. He was engaged to her and quite naturally resented\r\nBallard\'s attentions to her.\r\n\r\n"You\'d better not touch that until the police get here," I said as he\r\nbent over to pick up the spanner.\r\n\r\n"Yeah, I guess you\'re right--I forgot. How do you suppose this got in\r\nhere anyway?"\r\n\r\n"One of the workmen making adjustments on Edith\'s outer casing must\r\nhave left it. I saw it sitting up there on top of her late yesterday\r\nafternoon," I told him. 

"You\'d better go call Mr. Thompson and--the\r\nFBI."\r\n\r\nWith Ballard gone, I was in charge. Maybe someone would think that was\r\nreason enough for me to kill him. 

I didn\'t care, I was just glad he was\r\ngone. Now he couldn\'t mistreat Edith anymore.\r\n\r\nI turned Edith on just as MacKinney returned. "What are you doing?" he\r\nasked.\r\n\r\n"Why I\'m going to wake Edith up and feed these tapes into her. After\r\nall these are more important than any one man\'s life."\r\n\r\n"You didn\'t care much for Ballard, did you Bill?"\r\n\r\nI gave him look for look as I replied. "Can you name anyone around here\r\nthat did?"\r\n\r\nHe shook his head. "No--I guess not. 

But maybe it wasn\'t one of us. It\r\nmight have been an outside job, you know. Edith was working on that\r\nspace station stuff and the iron curtain people would give a lot to\r\nknow about it."\r\n\r\n"Hell," I said pressing the studs and levers that would arouse Edith\r\nand put her to work. "You don\'t really think anyone could get past\r\nthose security guards, do you?"\r\n\r\nHappily I went about the business of waking Edith, my sleeping beauty,\r\nfrom her slumbers. In a very few seconds, her hundreds of tiny red eyes\r\nwere gleaming with intelligence.\r\n\r\n_Good morning, Edith_, I punched out the tape and fed it into her.\r\n\r\nThere was the faintest pause, while Edith\'s photo-electric cells\r\nsurveyed the room, pausing for a moment on the sprawled body of Ballard.\r\n\r\n_Good morning, Bill Green_, she typed back. I knew she was happy to\r\nsee me by the cheerful little clicks she emitted.\r\n\r\n_I have some interesting work for you this morning, Edith. And I think\r\nyou\'ll be glad to know that we will be working together from now on\r\ninstead of...._\r\n\r\n"Hey! 

What\'s the idea of starting that machine?" a gray haired, gray\r\nsuited security agent demanded, striding into the room with MacKinney,\r\nMr. Thompson and several other officers at his heels. 

"Don\'t you know\r\nenough not to touch anything in here?"\r\n\r\n"This work is too important to be stopped--even for a murder," I said,\r\nand Mr. Thompson nodded in agreement.\r\n\r\n"That\'s right," he said mopping his perpetually perspiring forehead,\r\n"this work has top priority from Washington." He looked nervous and I\r\ncouldn\'t help wondering what he was thinking. There had been stories\r\ncirculating about Ballard and Thompson\'s wife and the dome-headed\r\nlittle man must have heard them too. Ballard just couldn\'t keep his\r\nhands off any female within reach. That was one of the reasons he was\r\nso thoroughly hated.\r\n\r\nThe youngest of the security agents rose from where he had been\r\nkneeling beside Ballard and crossed to me.\r\n\r\n"You\'re Green, aren\'t you?" I nodded and he continued, "How did you\r\nknow it was murder?"\r\n\r\nI laughed at him. "How the hell could a man bash in his own brains that\r\nway?"\r\n\r\nThe gray haired man stepped into the breach. He gave us all a thorough\r\ngoing over, but concentrated on MacKinney and me. He seemed to think it\r\npeculiar that neither of us could give any reason for Ballard\'s being\r\nalone with Edith. I was sure I knew, but no one would have believed me\r\nso I made no attempt to enlighten him.\r\n\r\n"Well, I guess that\'s all we can do now," he said at last. "Someone\r\nfrom the local police will have to be notified and brought in after\r\nthey get security clearance." He turned to go.\r\n\r\n"Wait a minute," MacKinney said, "we\'re all overlooking one thing."\r\n\r\n"What\'s that?"\r\n\r\n"There was an eye witness to this crime," he said, and I stared at him\r\nin consternation. I didn\'t know he knew. I thought I was the only one\r\nwho knew.\r\n\r\n"What do you mean," the agent demanded angrily.\r\n\r\n"Edith saw it. Edith, the computer."\r\n\r\n"Are you nuts?" the agent demanded.\r\n\r\n"You forget that Edith was turned off," Thompson said.\r\n\r\n"But Mr. Thompson, Edith\'s not like most cybernetic machines. She\'s\r\nso far advanced, that I\'m not sure we understand her completely. She\r\ncan\'t really be turned off. She has a distinct personality and that new\r\ncircuit--"\r\n\r\nOf course Edith had a personality of her own! She had more charm, more\r\nintelligence, more understanding than most women.\r\n\r\n"--well--she\'d be able to tell us who killed Ballard."\r\n\r\n"That\'s ridiculous," I said, badly frightened. "A machine can\'t be a\r\nwitness to murder."\r\n\r\nThe security officer looked dubious and shook his head. "I guess we\'ll\r\nhave to leave that up to the coroner at the inquest."\r\n\r\n"But they can\'t ask questions like that of Edith," I protested.\r\n"She\'s--she\'s too important to the national defense to have some\r\ncountry coroner asking her silly questions about the murder of a man\r\nwho deserved to die anyway." I had to prevent this. 

I had to get around\r\nthis eye witness business.\r\n\r\nThompson looked at me levelly. "MacKinney may be right, Green. The\r\ncoroner may very well want to talk to Edith and there\'s no reason we\r\nshould object if Security gives him clearance."\r\n\r\n"But Mr. Thompson, our work--it\'ll be interrupted."\r\n\r\n"We\'ll have to take that chance. And I think Washington will agree."\r\n\r\n"But--" Couldn\'t they see that there wasn\'t any question of spying\r\nhere. Couldn\'t they understand that Ballard had just gotten what he had\r\ncoming. I couldn\'t let them question Edith. At least not until I had a\r\nchance to talk to her alone.\r\n\r\n"And Green--because of your rather strange behaviour, I\'m afraid I\'ll\r\nhave to ask you to stay in your quarters until the inquest. MacKinney\r\nwill handle your work with Edith until then."\r\n\r\nI was shocked and really frightened now. 

I wouldn\'t get to talk to\r\nher, wouldn\'t get a chance to tell her what to say. I protested, but\r\nThompson was firm, so firm that he placed a guard outside my door to\r\nmake sure I didn\'t leave.\r\n\r\nWashington rushed through clearance for the local officers and the\r\ninquest was held three days later. The coroner proved to be a shrewd\r\ncountry doctor, who had the inquest adjourned to the computer room as\r\nsoon as he heard MacKinney\'s ideas about Edith.\r\n\r\nThe security guards on duty the night of the murder testified that only\r\nMacKinney, Thompson, Ballard and I had had access to the computer room;\r\nand it had already been established that it would have been impossible\r\nfor a spy or foreign agent to have slipped into the heavily guarded\r\nroom. It was clearly an inside job.\r\n\r\nWith all of us at the scene of the crime, the coroner summed it up\r\nfor us. "--and since it could not have been the work of an outsider,\r\nit must have been a crime of a private nature." He looked closely at\r\nThompson, MacKinney and me. "A crime of a private nature with the\r\nmotive either revenge, jealousy or ambition. We know that the victim\r\nwas an over-bearing man with a good many unpleasant traits. We know he\r\nwas a man who forced his attentions on women, who was ill-tempered and\r\nabusive to those who worked with him. A man who had many enemies--but\r\nthere were only three people who had the chance to attack him on this\r\nparticular night.\r\n\r\n"I am going to attempt to establish the identity of the killer by the\r\nunusual procedure of questioning a machine. It will be for later courts\r\nto establish the validity of such testimony. Because of the nature\r\nof this case and because of the urgent need to get this computer back\r\nto its proper work, I am going to ask the questions in a more direct\r\nmanner than I would ordinarily employ."\r\n\r\nMacKinney took his place before Edith. They didn\'t even trust me to\r\nfeed the tapes into her under their very eyes.\r\n\r\n"Mr. Thompson, I object to the use of this delicate piece of equipment\r\nin--"\r\n\r\nThey ignored me, and MacKinney punched out the questions the coroner\r\nasked:\r\n\r\n"Do you know who murdered Dr. Ballard?

"\r\n\r\nThere was a pause. Edith blinked several times. I was shaking with\r\napprehension for her. A mind so delicate and noble should not be faced\r\nwith such a dilemma.\r\n\r\n_Yes, she typed back._\r\n\r\n"Did you witness the murder?"\r\n\r\nThere was a longer pause this time. "You must answer the question,"\r\nMacKinney reminded her.\r\n\r\n_I was here._\r\n\r\n"Is it true that you do not lose your perceptive qualities when we turn\r\nyou off?" MacKinney asked this on his own.\r\n\r\n_It is true._\r\n\r\n"We might as well get to the heart of the matter," the coroner said.\r\n"Did Mr. Thompson kill Ballard?"\r\n\r\nEdith clicked and her eyes glowed. _No._\r\n\r\n"Did Mr. MacKinney kill Ballard?"\r\n\r\n_No._\r\n\r\nEdith had to tell the truth ... it was an innate part of her\r\npersonality. I tensed in my seat. I wanted to scream, to leap at\r\nMacKinney and prevent, somehow, the asking of the next question. But\r\nthere wasn\'t a chance.\r\n\r\n"Did Mr. Green kill Dr. Ballard?"\r\n\r\nEdith\'s beautiful electric eyes flashed and her clicks pulsed twice as\r\nrapidly as before. There was such a roaring and wrenching within her\r\nI was afraid for her--she was being torn apart in her struggle not to\r\nanswer. I couldn\'t stand listening to her desperate efforts any longer.\r\n\r\n"Yes!" I leapt to my feet. "Yes, I did it. Leave her alone. Can\'t you\r\nsee what you\'re doing to her? That swine was always mistreating her. He\r\ndidn\'t understand her--no one understands her as I do!"\r\n\r\nThe coroner looked at me closely. "Is that really why you killed him,\r\nMr. Green?"\r\n\r\n"No! You were wondering why he was here by himself while no work was\r\ngoing on. He--he had begun to feel about Edith as he did about all\r\nwomen. 

He sneaked back here to be alone with her. He wanted to--he\r\nwanted to--" My voice broke and they stared at me in shocked amazement.\r\n\r\nInto the silence MacKinney read what Edith had slowly typed out: "Mr.\r\nGreen did not kill Dr. Ballard."\r\n\r\n"Yes--yes I did," I screamed. "Don\'t Edith--"\r\n\r\n"Who did kill him?" the coroner asked, quietly.\r\n\r\nThis was the question I had wanted to avoid. I sank down my hands\r\ncradling my aching head. Edith must have expected the question. She\r\nhad her answer ready.\r\n\r\n_I refuse to state on the grounds that it may tend to incriminate me._\r\n\r\nMy poor, sweet, adorable Edith. If only I had had a chance to talk to\r\nher, to tell her what to say. I had known ... ever since I had seen the\r\nspanner and remembered where it had been before. I could have warned\r\nher to say that Ballard had attacked her, threatened her, to say\r\nanything ... but not to attempt to hide behind a Fifth Amendment that\r\ndidn\'t exist anymore. My darling, never had kept up with current events.\r\n\r\nNow they\'ll disconnect her, they\'ll rewire her, they\'ll destroy her\r\nunderstanding, her warmth, her whole personality ... and I ... I love\r\nher, I love her....\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


"You\'re\r\nvery sweet or very clever. Now if you\'ll coax Howard off my stomach--"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t have to be coaxed," Howard announced, sliding to the floor\r\nwith all the covers. "From now on, you just order me, Daddy. Because\r\nyou\'ll be a Senior Citizen tomorrow."\r\n\r\nBozzy didn\'t want to think of that just then. "Tell your mother I\'m\r\nup," he said. "And get out so I can bathe and dress."\r\n\r\nSophie minced, Howard ran, Ralph toddled.\r\n\r\nBozzy rose, a pudgy man slightly under average height at six feet two,\r\nwith blue eyes and thinning brown hair. He was exactly thirty-nine\r\nyears, eleven months, and twenty-nine days old.\r\n\r\nAnd that was the point. At forty, he would have to go to work. This\r\nwas his day for job-taking.\r\n\r\nHe dreaded it.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe put the coming ceremonies out of his mind and concentrated on his\r\nsupersonic bath, the depilatory cream, the color of his outer\r\nclothing. It took time to achieve the right shade of purple in the\r\nbathroom plastic-dispenser, but no time at all to pour, solidify, and\r\ncut the sheet-like robe required for the occasion.\r\n\r\nIn it, he was the sensation of the breakfast room, handsome as a male\r\nbird in spring plumage. Kate, his slender wife, who had been up and at\r\nwork for an hour, looked moth-eaten by comparison, as if their nest\r\nhad been lined with her plucked-out down.\r\n\r\n"You look very attractive this morning, Kate," Bozzy told her. He gave\r\nher an extra-warm kiss.\r\n\r\n"Well!" 

she said. "Quite the gallant today, aren\'t we? Just be sure\r\nyou\'re on time today, darling. Remember what Mr. Frewne had to say\r\nabout promptness."\r\n\r\nFrewne. That overinflated windbag. The obesity who was about to become\r\nhis boss. Without having worked a day in his life, Bozzy found he\r\nhated the idea of having a boss.\r\n\r\n"Let\'s think of something pleasant," he grunted, and thought of\r\nbreakfast.\r\n\r\nHe took his place at the table. Kate and the kids had already eaten,\r\nso Kate served, while the kids, attracted by his finery, stood off and\r\nwatched him swallow a vitamin pill, a thyroid pill, and a Dexedrine\r\npill.\r\n\r\nSolemnly, he opened the three eggs Kate brought. Each was guaranteed\r\nby her to have been irradiated for exactly two minutes and fifty-five\r\nseconds, and guaranteed by the grocer to have been enriched by\r\nfeeding the hens three kinds of mold.\r\n\r\nHis mouth was full of the third and last one when Sophie asked, "Why\r\ndo you have to go to work, Daddy?"\r\n\r\nThe reminder choked him. Gulping, he said, "To support us all, honey.\r\nMy pension stops tomorrow."\r\n\r\n"Yes, but I read in a book where people used to go to work when they\r\nwere young."\r\n\r\nHe was tempted to say, "I _am_ young!" but thought better of it. 

"That\r\nwas long ago, dear."\r\n\r\n"Were people different then?"\r\n\r\n"No, but society was. Our Senior Citizens used to be pensioned off,\r\nwhile younger people worked. But when science improved the Seniors\'\r\nhealth, they got tired of sitting in corners on pensions and, besides,\r\na lot of them died soon after they stopped working. When it got so\r\nthat more than half of all voters were between forty and seventy years\r\nold, the Seniors voted their pensions to the young, to get educated\r\nand raise families on, and nobody\'s allowed to work till he\'s forty.\r\nNow do you see?"\r\n\r\n"Forty is awful old," said Sophie.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHoward had meanwhile taken his mother\'s hand. "_You\'re_ not going to\r\nwork, are you, Mommy?" he asked.\r\n\r\n"Not for ten years, dear. I\'ll be here when you want me, so why don\'t\r\nyou go play on the balcony? I\'ve got to get Daddy off and give Ralph\r\nhis bath."\r\n\r\n"I\'ll bathe him," Sophie volunteered. "You help, Howie. We can make\r\nlike we\'re young."\r\n\r\n"Don\'t drop him," Kate warned.\r\n\r\n"Clean up the bathroom afterward," added Bozzy.\r\n\r\n"Yes, sir," said Howard, for the first time in his life.\r\n\r\nThe children left, and Kate came close to pour Bozzy his cup of\r\nDaystart. He slipped an arm around her waist and squeezed\r\nconvulsively.\r\n\r\n"Darling!" 

she said, stroking his bald spot. "You\'re positively\r\ntrembling!"\r\n\r\n"Wouldn\'t you be, if you had to take over from somebody you like as\r\nwell as I like Mr. Kojac? And for no good reason, except he\'s\r\nseventy-five and I\'ll soon be forty."\r\n\r\nKate pushed away from him, frowning. "Sometimes you\'re so silly, it\r\nscares me. You know perfectly well that if you don\'t take Mr. Kojac\'s\r\njob, someone else will. He\'d rather have it in your hands than in a\r\nstranger\'s, and I\'d rather live on his income than on a laborer\'s. So\r\nstop moping and drink your Daystart, while I call a cab."\r\n\r\nNo help in that quarter, Bozzy decided as she left. All Kate could\r\nthink of was that she\'d soon be the wife of a big-shot: the\r\nmanager--that is, controls setter--of a furniture factory.\r\n\r\nBozzy had never told her how simple the job really was, though he\r\nsupposed she knew.\r\n\r\nYou first ordered designs, and then you ordered a poll taken on the\r\ndesigns. A computer tabulated the poll\'s results and pointed out the\r\ndesign most likely to sell.\r\n\r\nYou then fed economic data into the same computer, and found out how\r\nmany units the market could take. You called in the engineers to set\r\nup the machines, and the maintenance men to keep them running. In\r\nbrief, you were errand boy to a bunch of gadgets, with nothing to do\r\nbut look important.\r\n\r\nHe was practicing his important look when Kate bustled in and spoiled\r\nit by sitting on his lap.\r\n\r\n"You\'re going to do fine today," she said, "and you\'re going to get\r\noff to a good start. I made them show me your cab. It\'s one of their\r\nbrand-new battery-electric ones, a sort of mauve that will go with\r\nyour purple robe. You\'ll look swell in it."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBozzy was kissing her when the lobby buzzer sounded three long rings.\r\n\r\n"There\'s your cab," Kate said, rising.\r\n\r\nHe followed her to the living room. Projected on one wall was a\r\npicture of the cabman facing the lobby annunciator, fifty-three\r\nstories down. The man was tall, fat, and in need of a shave, yet he\r\nwore purple tights with pink and green trim.\r\n\r\nBozzy shuddered. "Who in the world concocted that rig?"\r\n\r\n"Your wife, sir," the cabman answered.\r\n\r\n"It\'s beautiful," said Bozzy. "I\'ll be right down.

"\r\n\r\nHe wasn\'t, though. Kate told the kids he was leaving, and they trooped\r\nout of the bathroom to say good-by.\r\n\r\nBozzy could tell Ralph was the one being bathed only because he was\r\nnaked--all three were equally wet, and equally anxious to embrace\r\ntheir Daddy. He had to make himself a new robe while the cab meter\r\nticked and Kate jittered.\r\n\r\nBut once started, the drive between balconied buildings and\r\nintervening plazas went fast enough. 

Bozzy wasn\'t over half an hour\r\nlate in reaching Mr. Kojac\'s apartment building.\r\n\r\nThe old man waited in the street, looking spare, spruce, and\r\nimpatient.\r\n\r\n"I do wish," he said, easing himself into the cab, "that you had a\r\nless anti-social attitude. Now you\'ll have to claim I delayed you.

"\r\n\r\n"I\'m sorry, sir," Bozzy mumbled. "It\'s kind of you to take the blame."\r\n\r\nHe thought it was also typical. 

He had understudied Mr. Kojac for the\r\npreceding two years, and felt there was no one else in the world for\r\nwhom he could have as much respect.\r\n\r\n"Actually, sir," he explained, "I was delayed by the children."\r\n\r\n"An excuse, Boswell! Whether conscious or subconscious, nothing more\r\nthan an excuse! Distaste for today\'s ceremonial is smeared over your\r\nface like so much bread-and-jelly."\r\n\r\nUnconsciously, Bozzy wiped his cheeks.\r\n\r\nMr. Kojac laughed. "You\'re guilt-ridden and that\'s plain absurd. All\r\nyoung men in your position have to go through exactly the same thing.\r\nYou must simply make up your mind to do what society requires."\r\n\r\n"All I can think of is your kindness," Bozzy blurted. "People should\r\nreplace those they hate!"\r\n\r\n"But the understudy system wouldn\'t work, then," Mr. Kojac pointed\r\nout. "You can\'t learn from a man who upsets you."\r\n\r\nBozzy nodded miserably.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIn silence, he let himself be carried toward the furniture factory,\r\ntill Mr. Kojac asked, "Did you bring the stimulants?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, yes, sir. 

Excuse me. I should have offered them sooner." With\r\nembarrassed clumsiness, he fished from a pocket in his under-wear the\r\npills required by custom. "Here you are, sir," he said in ritual form.\r\n"Big pills make troubles little."\r\n\r\nMr. Kojac smiled. "I don\'t need any," he said gently. "You do. Take\r\none."\r\n\r\n"That isn\'t proper!"\r\n\r\n"No one will know. 

Go ahead."\r\n\r\nHe would feel like a fool to take a pill brought only for Mr. Kojac\'s\r\nuse. He would feel much more like a fool if he broke down during the\r\nceremony--might even lose his job.\r\n\r\nHe took the pill, finally, and immediately felt sorry. He was still\r\ntense and twitchy when they reached the factory.\r\n\r\nAs custom demanded, everyone was out of sight. Nobody met them at the\r\ngate, or observed their silent progress up the escalator to the\r\npersonnel office. Noiselessly, through empty soundproof offices, they\r\nwalked together to the ceremonial chamber.\r\n\r\nThe door they used was the room\'s only entrance. It was hooked open\r\ninvitingly. Within was a small conference table of imitation oak, and\r\nsix chairs of imitation leather. Ceiling, walls, and floor were\r\nplastic sheets in soft, sandy shades that harmonized with the\r\nfurniture\'s rich browns.\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\nOn the table were four wristlets, four anklets, and two belts, all\r\nmade of iron links and stamped with either Bozzy\'s or Mr. Kojac\'s\r\nname. As he had been told to do, Bozzy picked out and put on his own\r\nset while Mr. Kojac rested in the armchair at the head of the table.\r\nThen, breathing noisily, he knelt before Mr. Kojac and fastened the\r\nold man\'s anklets.\r\n\r\nHe rose, grunting. Mr. Kojac held out first the left hand, then the\r\nright, while Bozzy put the wristlets on him. Their cheeks accidentally\r\ntouched while Bozzy fastened the belt. He thought of his father and\r\nwas irrationally tempted to plant a kiss, as if he were four instead\r\nof forty.\r\n\r\nHe stifled the impulse and shook hands instead.\r\n\r\n"Good luck," Mr. Kojac said.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe procedure did not call for that remark, and so, for a second,\r\nBozzy forgot what came next. Then, helped by the stimulant pill, he\r\nfocused his thoughts, crossed the room, and turned a lighted red\r\nswitch that glowed by the door.\r\n\r\nHe heard a muffled clank as iron links froze to the magnetized\r\narmchair, sounding the signal for his speech.\r\n\r\n"Sir," he intoned, "the Company takes this opportunity to express its\r\ndeep and heart-felt appreciation of the thirty-five years you have\r\ndevoted to serving the Company, the furniture industry generally, and\r\nthat great public, our customers."\r\n\r\nWithout looking at Mr. Kojac, he bowed, turned, went out, and released\r\nthe catch holding the door open. It closed automatically, and\r\nautomatically set in motion the rest of the ceremony.\r\n\r\nFrom somewhere out of sight, fat Mr. Frewne waddled over and briefly\r\nshook Bozzy\'s hand.\r\n\r\n"You\'ve done fine," he wheezed. "A little late getting started, but\r\nthat\'s to be expected. 

Every-thing\'s fine--just fine!

"\r\n\r\nPraise seemed a miscue. Bozzy didn\'t quite know how to answer.\r\n\r\n"Sir," he asked, mopping his forehead, "what about Mr. Kojac?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, he\'s all right," Mr. Frewne said. "Those fumes are fast. We can\r\nleave the rest to the undertaker."\r\n\r\nHe slapped Bozzy on the back and pushed him down the corridor. "Come\r\non into my office, boy. I\'ll pour you a drink--pour us each one, as a\r\nmatter of fact. And hand over your iron jewelry, son. You won\'t need\r\nthat stuff again for thirty-five years."\r\n\r\n                                                          --DAVE DRYFOOS\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


I\'ve got to, I tell you! 

And I\'m going to make\r\nit!"\r\n\r\nDifferent members of the group regarded him variously, some with\r\namusement, some with contempt, others with frank curiosity.\r\n\r\n"You\'re plain nuts, Joe. What do you want to go to the Moon for?"\r\n\r\n"Sure, why you wanna go? What they got on the Moon we ain\'t got right\r\nhere?"\r\n\r\nThere was general laughter from the dozen or so who sat eating their\r\nlunch in the shade of Building B. They all thought that was a pretty\r\ngood one. Good enough to repeat. "Sure, what they got on the Moon we\r\nain\'t got here?"\r\n\r\nBut Joe Spain wasn\'t in the mood for jokes. He burned with even greater\r\nconviction and stood up as though to harangue the workers. "You wanta\r\nknow why I got to go to the Moon? Why I\'ve got to get on that ship? Then\r\nI\'ll tell you. 

It\'s \'cause I\'m a little guy--that\'s why! Joe\r\nSpain--working stiff--one of the great inarticulate masses."\r\n\r\nMore laughter. "Where\'d you get those big words, Joey? 

Out of a book?\r\nCome on--talk English!"\r\n\r\nJoe Spain pointed to the huge, tubelike Building A, off across the\r\ndesert; the building you had to have two different passes and a written\r\npermit to enter. The mystery building where even newspaper reporters\r\nwere barred. "It\'s only the big shots they let in there ain\'t it? 

Only\r\nthem that\'s got a drag or went to college or something. Us little guys\r\nthey tell go to blow--ain\'t that right?"\r\n\r\n"Who the hell cares? Maybe it\'s a damn good place to stay away from.\r\nMaybe it\'ll explode or something. Who wants to die and collect his\r\ninsurance?"\r\n\r\n"I got to get on that ship when it blasts off because they can\'t push\r\nthe masses around! We got a right to be represented even if we got to\r\nsneak in!"\r\n\r\n"Me--I\'ll stay on the ground."\r\n\r\n"And besides there\'s the glory! You guys are too stupid to see that but\r\nit\'s there. The glory of being on the first rocket ship to the Moon. The\r\nname of Joe Spain written down in the history books and said over by\r\npeople and school kids for thousands of years! Immortality! That\'s the\r\nword!
