"\r\n\r\n"Well, just forget about it, Joe, \'cause you ain\'t going."\r\n\r\nJoe Spain\'s eyes burned brighter. "Joe Spain, coming down the ramp with\r\nthe big shots when it\'s all over. News cameras snapping! People asking\r\nfor interviews!"\r\n\r\n"But you ain\'t going \'cause--"\r\n\r\nJoe shouted the man down. 

"And another thing. Us little people are\r\nentitled to a representative aboard that ship. We got a right to know\r\nwhat\'s going on. How come there\'s nothing about it in the papers? Only\r\nthe big shots knowing about it and whispering among themselves? It\'s\r\nbecause they\'re trying to snag it all and freeze us out!"\r\n\r\n"You\'re crazy. It\'s for security reasons. It\'s all hush-hush so it won\'t\r\nleak out like the atom bomb did. 

The big boys are being smart this\r\ntime."\r\n\r\n"And you ain\'t getting on," the interrupted man repeated doggedly,\r\n"because there ain\'t a way in God\'s world to _get_ on. With triple\r\nsecurity all around the building, just tell me a way to get in. Just\r\ntell me one."\r\n\r\n"I\'m going to get on that ship," Joe Spain said. Then he clammed up\r\nsuddenly. Joe Spain wasn\'t stupid. He was a talker, but he knew when to\r\nstop sounding off.\r\n\r\nThe men went back to work shifting the big aluminum barrels from trucks\r\ninto Building B. Carrying the wooden crates and the paper-wrapped\r\nparcels up the ramps and to the side of the building facing the big\r\nsecret structure labeled A. They worked until five o\'clock. Then they\r\nfiled out and got into the waiting trucks and were hauled back to town;\r\nthe boom town that had mushroomed up in the desert overnight and would\r\ndie with the same swiftness when the project was completed.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nJoe went straight to his rooming house, washed up, put on his good\r\nclothes, and found a stool in a nearby restaurant. He ate a leisurely\r\nsupper, glancing now and again at the clock. When the clock read eight,\r\nhe went out into the neon-stained darkness and walked three blocks to\r\nthe Black Cat, one of the three night clubs the desert town boasted. He\r\nwent to the bar and ordered a drink. He downed it slowly, carefully,\r\nafter the manner of a man who wanted to stay sober.\r\n\r\nA half-hour passed before a thin, nervous individual elbowed to the bar\r\nand stood beside him. Joe said. 

"Hello, Nick. You been thinking it\r\nover?"\r\n\r\n"I need a drink."\r\n\r\n"Sure, Nick. Then we\'ll go some place and talk." But Nick got rid of\r\nfive drinks while Joe protected his own glass from the barkeep. After a\r\nwhile, Joe said, "I\'m willing to up the price, Nick. Two thousand--cash.\r\nAll I got."\r\n\r\n"Le\'s get out o\' here," Nick mumbled.\r\n\r\nThey walked out of the town and into the desert, Nick stumbling now and\r\nagain, to be supported by the tense, sober Joe. "Two thousand, Nick. You\r\nneed the dough."\r\n\r\n"Sure. Need the dough. But it wouldn\'t work. Couldn\'t get you into one\r\no\' them barrels."\r\n\r\n"You wouldn\'t have to. All I ask is that you come along in the morning\r\nand seal me up in one. All you\'ll have to do is lock on the lid."\r\n\r\n"How you know the barrels are going on the ship?"\r\n\r\n"Never mind about that. 

I just know. I paid to find out."\r\n\r\n"Okay--suppose you do get on the ship in a barrel. Maybe it\'ll be stored\r\nin a hold somewhere. Maybe they wouldn\'t open it very soon. You\'d die."\r\n\r\n"I got a way to get out. One of them special torches. The little ones.\r\nAluminum isn\'t very strong. I can cut it like butter."\r\n\r\n"It\'d be hot. You\'d burn yourself."\r\n\r\n"Let me worry about that," Joe said fiercely. "You want the two grand or\r\nnot?"\r\n\r\nNick wanted the two thousand and he was against the wall for excuses.\r\nThen he had a happy thought. "Barrels is air-tight. You\'d smother.\r\nThing\'s im--impracac\'l. We\'ll forget it."\r\n\r\n"I won\'t smother. I\'m taking my own oxygen. Enough to last me clear to\r\nthe Moon if it has to. Come on. Break down!"\r\n\r\n"Okay. For two grand. Got to have the dough now though."\r\n\r\nHis heart singing, Joe Spain counted out two thousand in cash. When he\'d\r\nfinished he had exactly nine dollars left. He was a pauper. But the\r\nhappiest pauper who ever bought with his whole fortune the thing he\r\ncraved most.\r\n\r\n"You won\'t double-cross me now, will you? If you\'ve got any ideas like\r\nthat--"\r\n\r\n"I\'ll do like we said. Nick Sparks never went back on his word--never.\r\nBut how you going to stay hid when it\'s time to leave work?"\r\n\r\n"Leave that to me. 

It\'ll be easy. They don\'t check Building B too close.\r\nNo double check \'cause it\'s over a mile from Building A--outside the\r\nsafety perimeter. I\'ll stay in tomorrow night and I\'ll put a little\r\nchalk-mark on the barrel I\'m in--right near the top rim. First thing you\r\ndo when you come to work the next morning is seal it and line it up with\r\nthe filled ones."\r\n\r\n"Okay, but I gotta go home now. 

I got a head. I gotta get some sleep."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"What\'s in the duffel bag?"\r\n\r\n"Clean overalls--towel." Joe pulled the zipper down halfway. The guard\r\nfingered the blue denim but didn\'t dig deeper to find the towel. He\r\nchecked Joe\'s badge number, made a note on his pad, and motioned to the\r\nnext worker. Joe let tight breath slowly out of his lungs as he walked\r\ntoward Building B. Getting past the guard was a load off his mind. He\'d\r\nexpected to get by, but it was one of the calculated risks that could\r\nhave stopped him cold.\r\n\r\nOnce inside the building, he put the bag into his locker and went to\r\nwork. He labored briskly and carried more than his share of the load.\r\nBut now and again he stopped to look over at the outline of Building A,\r\nlimned hard against hot blazing sky. And each time it was with a sense\r\nof heady exhilaration that he thought of his destiny--his hard-earned,\r\ndearly bought destiny. To be among that select group who would first set\r\nfoot upon the surface of the Moon!\r\n\r\nHe had no worries about not being allowed to do so. Once he showed\r\nhimself--with the ship far out in space--they\'d have to accept him. Not\r\ngraciously of course, but they\'d have to admire his courage and\r\ntenacity. They could not, in all humanity, deny him a share of the\r\nvictory.\r\n\r\nThe day wore on and as quitting time approached, he became more\r\ntense--more alert. Five minutes before the whistle, he faded back into\r\nthe building and hurried to the lavatory. He went into the booth\r\nfurthest from the entrance and locked the door. Now there was nothing to\r\ndo but wait. Another of the calculated risks.\r\n\r\nThe whistle blew. Almost immediately, the sound of footsteps broke the\r\nsilence and the lavatory was filled with hurrying men. Their stay in the\r\nroom was short, however, as Joe had known it would be. Men leaving for\r\nhome do not dawdle on the premises.\r\n\r\nThe lavatory was empty again. A period of silence while Joe raised his\r\nfeet from the floor and braced them on the toilet seat. The entrance\r\ndoor opened. A guard making the departure checkup.\r\n\r\nJoe held his breath. If the guard came down the line and tried the door,\r\nhe was finished. But Joe had banked upon human nature. The guard\r\nstopped. For a long moment there was no sound and Joe knew the man was\r\nbending over to run his eyes down the line of toilets close to the\r\nfloor. In this manner he could see the floor of every booth. The guard\r\nstraightened, turned, walked out. The door closed. 

Silence. Joe\'s heart\r\nswelled with gratitude. He grinned, looking forward with joy to the long\r\nnight ahead.\r\n\r\nHe found a spot over behind the barrels where the night watchman would\r\nhave to climb over a lot of equipment in order to find him. He made\r\nhimself comfortable, practically certain the guard would not do this. He\r\nstretched out on the hard floor and recorded the passing of the hours by\r\nthe number of times the watchman went through.\r\n\r\nAnd he was surprised at how fast the time passed. Finally, checking his\r\ncount carefully, he left his hiding place and tiptoed to the line of\r\nlockers. He took the oxygen equipment from the duffel bag after which he\r\nhid the bag and the clothing therein behind a wall flange in a far\r\ncorner. Then he climbed into the barrel at the front end of the packing\r\nline. He checked the barrel with a small X, and jockeyed the lid into\r\nplace.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nTime passed. Nothing happened. 

He wondered, if he\'d missed on the time\r\nelement. The men should certainly have come to work now. More than once\r\nhe was tempted to push the barrel lid aside and check the situation.\r\nWhen footsteps sounded, close by, and the lid snapped firmly into place,\r\nhe was glad he hadn\'t done so. Good old Nick! When he got back from the\r\nMoon, he\'d see to it that Nick got credit for his courageous act.\r\n\r\nSoon the barrel began to move. Joe felt it rise into the air and settle\r\nwith a thump. Then the motor of a truck roared and Joe knew where he was\r\ngoing. Straight toward Building A and the Moon rocket. There was more\r\nmovement until finally the barrel was set down for what appeared to be\r\nthe last time. Joe put the nose-piece of the oxygen tube into place and\r\nvisualized himself safe and snug in a storage room of the rocket.\r\n\r\nHe closed his eyes and went peacefully to sleep.\r\n\r\nHe slept a long time, to be awakened by a crushing--a wrenching--that\r\nall but drove his head down into his spine. The pain brought him sharply\r\nalert. He knew instantly what had happened.\r\n\r\n_Blast-off._\r\n\r\nHe braced himself against the sides of the barrel, and gritted his\r\nteeth.\r\n\r\nSoon it was better. Then no pressure at all. Only the fierce happiness\r\non his heart. He\'d set a course and won through! He was on the way to\r\nthe Moon!\r\n\r\nJoe let plenty of time elapse. He knew it was well over an hour later\r\nwhen he unlimbered the torch to cut an escape-hole in the barrel. This,\r\nhe knew, would be tricky. He could easily burn himself. The heat would\r\nbe intense.\r\n\r\nBut it wasn\'t too bad. The aluminum cut quickly, and in a matter of\r\nminutes he was standing beside his barrel. As he\'d suspected, it was a\r\nstorage hold. 

The pitch-darkness did not bother him. He\'d come prepared\r\nwith a small pencil flash that threw an adequate beam.\r\n\r\nHe found the door, opened it and went out into a long passageway....\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nNow he\'d covered the length and breadth of the ship. He\'d found a lot of\r\nrooms--all in pitch-darkness. No observation ports.\r\n\r\n_And no living thing._\r\n\r\nHe stood frozen in one of the rooms while the beam of his flash picked\r\nout a code stenciled on a steel plate over some piece of machinery.\r\nX59-306MY--Experimental--Explosion Rocket--Moon.\r\n\r\nThe flash dropped from Joe Spain\'s fingers. He stood in the\r\npitch-darkness while the jets vibrated through the rocket.\r\n\r\nBut there was no fear in him. Only the great pain of futility. Only his\r\ntears, and his whispered words:\r\n\r\n"They\'ll never know. Nobody won\'t ever know!"\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _If Worlds of Science Fiction_ March\r\n    1952. Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and\r\n    typographical errors have been corrected without note.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nJon ran down the long corridor and into the Old Man\'s room. He was\r\nbreathless as he threw himself on his face beneath the Old Man\'s chair\r\nmade from gypsum. A kind of savage eagerness lighted his face, but the\r\nOld Man\'s face, a frozen pallid ball crinkled into a million lines, was\r\nsad and hopelessly resigned.\r\n\r\n"I seen \'em," Jon cried. "I seen \'em." His unhealthily pallid body,\r\nthough big and rawboned, was slender and writhed with a leathery\r\nstrength that comes with constant effort and exercise rather than diet\r\nand sun.\r\n\r\nThe Old Man shrugged. His voice was a hoarse whisper in that one cavern\r\namong the hundred and fifty miles of corridors, interlocking levels and\r\nrivers that made up the underground hideaway.\r\n\r\n"So you seen \'em, Jon. Many have seen the Mechs. The Mechs might have\r\nseen you too. If they ever find us here--well, they\'d probe us out,\r\nlike we were grubs. And they\'d burn us with those red-ray eyes. Why\'d\r\nyou go up on top? You know it\'s against the rules."\r\n\r\nJon got up. 

His chest heaved. His eyes were polished beads in a thick\r\nnest of reddish beard.\r\n\r\n"\'Cause I don\'t like livin\' in this cave like a grub. I been up twice,\r\nand now I can\'t stay down here anymore. 

Nobody else\'s got guts enough\r\nto go up. So let \'em stay down here and rot! But I\'m going back up on\r\ntop, Chief. And I\'m staying up there."\r\n\r\nThe Old Man leaned back. He couldn\'t hide the gleam of gruff respect in\r\nhis eyes. "Go ahead, Jon, but don\'t come back down. Once they get on\r\nyour tail, you can\'t shake \'em and you\'d lead \'em right back here, and\r\nthen they\'d get the rest of us. As far as I know, Jon, we\'re the only\r\nhumans left."\r\n\r\nJon\'s hands clenched. "And so might all of us be dead too. Livin\' down\r\nhere in this cave where they ain\'t never no sun, eatin\' lizards and\r\nsnakes, and dyin\' off one by one anyway. We\'re all gonna be dead in\r\nanother year. What\'s so great about spendin\' that year crawlin\' and\r\ngrubbin\' down here? Scared to even take one last look at the sun? It\'s\r\nnot for me, Chief. 

I\'m leavin\'."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe Old Man shrugged again. "Go ahead, I said. Just promise not to ever\r\ncome back and lead them down here. You\'ll promise that, Jon?"\r\n\r\nSomething thickened in his throat, but he managed to say yes. 

He\r\nturned, then twisted back toward the Old Man. "You\'re smart," he said.\r\n"You\'re supposed to know about when they took over. I\'ve asked others.\r\nNo one seems to know, and they care less. Would you tell me, Chief.\r\nWhat are _they_--the Mechs?"\r\n\r\nThe Old Man\'s voice echoed strangely against the surrounding grotesque\r\nbars of limestone stalactites and stalagmites in multicolored hues of\r\nfusing reds and orange, purple and browns. A pinched face peered at\r\nthem from between the ancient bars, then withdrew its tired eyes.\r\n\r\n"Maybe there\'s fifty humans left down here in Mammoth Hole," the Old\r\nMan said softly. "Maybe there ain\'t nobody else left in the world. Just\r\nthem with their silent machinery drivin\' over the wastes, and their\r\nred death eyes sweeping the dark, grubbin\' for us. The big war went\r\non and on, nobody knows how long. But humans couldn\'t fight it. Too\r\nmuch deadly radiation, so they made machines to fight for \'em. The sky\r\nand the land were just masses of machines, throwing out clouds and\r\nstreamers and explosions. The land became nothing but pools and seas\r\nof deadly dust, and fire. The sky was clouded with it. And people went\r\nunderground. They had to go down deep, and they couldn\'t come back up,\r\nwhat was left of \'em, for hundreds of years and more."\r\n\r\nThe Old Man was gazing with a distant, haunted expression at the small\r\nblind lizard crawling up the painted wall. Jon listened, his skin was\r\ncold. A shiver ran down his back.\r\n\r\n"Then _they_ started grubbing the humans out, and killing \'em. I don\'t\r\nsuppose anyone knows how long it\'s been since _they_ took over. That\'s\r\nwrong. 

I wasn\'t around then. Nor my father, nor my father\'s father\'s\r\nfather. It was long, long before that. It was so long ago that--"\r\nThe Old Man\'s eyes widened. His voice choked off with a cloud of\r\nunconscious fear that had slipped through.\r\n\r\n"They\'re godly," he whispered. "You seen \'em. They\'re all shapes and\r\nangles, cubes, and small smooth running things. They all shine like\r\nmetal. And I guess they are metal. Nobody knows what they are. I heard\r\ntell when I was a boy that they were just machines. Machines built by\r\nhumans a long time before. And that somehow or other the hard radiation\r\nhad put a spark in \'em that made \'em able to think, and move around and\r\norganize like humans used to do. But I reckon they\'re more intelligent\r\nthan any humans ever were."\r\n\r\nJon backed away. Sweat popped out coldly on his face and chest. "I\r\nseen \'em," he choked. "I sneaked on top. I went down to the river. It\r\ntook me hours to get used to the sun. I waited until the sun started\r\ngoing down, then I sneaked out and looked down the big hill that goes\r\ninto the valley. I seen two of \'em. 

They must have been a hundred foot\r\nhigh. They was smooth. They had long snaking arms and single eyes that\r\nshot out red beams like fire. They stood on top of the hill against\r\nthe sun. The sun was red all around \'em. They looked like they were\r\nmade of metal, all right, Chief. But how can they move by themselves,\r\nand--and _think_, if they\'re metal?"\r\n\r\nThe Old Man sighed. 

"How?" He peered at Jon with tired retreating\r\neyes. "What is thought," he said then. "What was life, ever? Floods of\r\ngamma rays bathed them for centuries, and then they were living, and\r\nthey had thoughts of their own. Humans never got a chance to find out\r\nwhat life was before he took it away from himself. He took it and gave\r\nit--to _them_."\r\n\r\nThe Old Man dropped his face in his shaking hands. Jon had never heard\r\na man crying before. He backed away slowly, then turned and ran out of\r\nthe great cavern.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nA grey dusky afternoon was dying when Jon crawled out of the small hall\r\nbetween rocks and started writhing down the hill. His eyes stayed open\r\nin fearful wonderment until tears rolled down his cheeks. The soft\r\ngreens and browns of the great forest that thinned up into the hills.\r\nThere was not the slightest hint that beneath this vast silent beauty,\r\nstretched the enormous grotesque underworld of Mammoth Hole.\r\n\r\nNor that in those nameless caverns and corridors along the cold and\r\nrushing and naked rivers a few unkempt savages clung to dim memories of\r\ncenturies-lost power and surface civilization.\r\n\r\nJon stopped. An intangible yet powerful emotion surged in him. 

"I\'m\r\ncrawlin\'," he gritted as he sat up. "I said I was sick a\' crawlin.\' I\r\nain\'t a grub. I\'m not crawlin\' anymore. Not for them damn machines, not\r\nfor anything. They can\'t do nothing but kill me, an\' what\'s life down\r\nin that hole?"\r\n\r\nHe stood up. He stood up straight and started walking down the rocky\r\ntrail, and finally along the smooth greenness beside the river. His\r\nstrides were long and unhesitating, but inside him was a deep growing\r\nhorror, as he remembered those shiny silver giants that had stood so\r\nsilently on the hill against the red sunset. The huge attentive waiting\r\nstillness, and the sudden terrible sweep of the red beamed eye and the\r\nreaching of the metal arms.\r\n\r\nHe stopped and looked down at his thin white legs, starved of the sun,\r\nknotted and scarred from crawling over the harsh underground paths. He\r\nlooked at his gnarled pallid fingers quivering in the cold.\r\n\r\nHe looked up at the sky. A few stars were showing dimly, palely. "Oh\r\nGod, give me a quick ending when my time comes, that\'s all I ask. Don\'t\r\nlet me crawl anymore on my belly. Give me the guts to keep walkin\',\r\nstraight up, like I\'m walkin\' now."\r\n\r\nThere was no answer. There was no sound except the cry of birds in the\r\nforest, the drone of insects and other louder noises from the river. He\r\nwas alone. He walked faster.\r\n\r\nBut he soon tired, because he had never walked far at a time.\r\nUnderground, people crawled a lot of the time through narrow holes. And\r\nunder there no one could walk far unless they went in circles.\r\n\r\nHe sat down to rest beneath the canopy of stars. He lay back and looked\r\nup at them, a feeling of frightful awe pressing down upon him. The\r\nnight around him was colder now, and the sounds of the night had risen\r\nto a hungry song. And then he rolled over with a quick, terrible cry,\r\nleaped crouching to his feet.\r\n\r\nThere were at least a dozen of them. Great shiny angular and\r\ncubed monsters sliding noiseless down the hill. A peculiar bluish\r\nradiance pushed out around them, bathing the surrounding night in a\r\ndeadly-seeming pall.\r\n\r\nWith a pathetic defiance, Jon picked up the heavy stone, stood with\r\nlegs wide apart, holding the rock in front of him. Every nerve in him\r\nshrieked, pulling his muscles away. 

But he couldn\'t run. He couldn\'t\r\nrun, nor crawl anymore. A kind of dark resigned courage replaced the\r\nfirst impulses of flight, and he hurled the rock. There was a futile\r\nthud, and the rock bounded from the great unruffled wall of metal.\r\n\r\nThen--for an instant he didn\'t think the thoughts, the voices, were\r\nanything but his own, strange, alien, terrifying, inspired by his own\r\nfears.\r\n\r\nAnd then he realized it was the _Mechs_!\r\n\r\n"_A grub!_"\r\n\r\n"_Yes. I thought they were all gone._"\r\n\r\n"_No. There are some remaining, deep in the soil. Central File says\r\nthey are no longer of any danger. But File also retains orders to kill\r\nall organic things._"\r\n\r\nJon moved toward them. He moved stiffly, a strange and intangible\r\nbulwark of purpose shielding him from the screaming horror.\r\n\r\nSomething of the awful indignity of his position shook him, sent a hot\r\nrage throbbing blindly past his temples. He heard his breath coming\r\nhard from tightened throat. These great nameless things--machines,\r\nintelligent metal, it didn\'t matter what. They had no idea of what he\r\nwas, that he had a brain, that he could think. And yet, their gigantic\r\nthoughts were plain to him.\r\n\r\nSome time, some time so very long ago, he--his kind--humans--had made\r\nthese things. Had built them up from molten stuff, had put intricate\r\ninterlocking machinery within them so that they could move, think for\r\nthemselves, repair themselves. And then--humans had launched the Big\r\nWar, had released seething seas of basic energy, and somehow these\r\ngigantic shiny silvery things had begun to--_live_.\r\n\r\nBut to them, Jon, a human, a descendant of the humans that had made\r\nthem and had given them life, was less than the dirt under their\r\ntowering, invulnerable radiance. Less than the dust beneath their\r\nsweeping red-death eyes. They had no conception that he was anything\r\nbut a pale, crawling, cave-worm.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nJon walked closer. He was not so much afraid for himself now. There was\r\nmore of a sweeping terror of the whole situation, the terrible futility\r\nand irony. He wasn\'t afraid to die, and he knew that he had to die now,\r\nthat there was no escape, no defiance.\r\n\r\nHe shook his fist at the silent, towering forms. "Damn you! 

It\'s me.\r\nMan. Man. I\'m human. I\'m not crawlin\'. See, I\'m not crawlin\', I\'m\r\ntalkin\' to you. I\'m talkin\' and I\'m thinkin\', too. See."\r\n\r\n"_It\'s making noises._"\r\n\r\n"_Yes. All the various species of organic life make noises peculiar to\r\ntheir type. Have you not seen a grub before?_"\r\n\r\n"_No. Let us kill it now. 

We must report back to Central File. How long\r\nwill it take to kill all organic life?_"\r\n\r\n"_Central File says it will take many more years, even though now\r\nmost organic life has been destroyed. We must complete the task soon,\r\nyou know. 

Man will return. Glorious Mangod. Mighty Mangod. Mangod the\r\nCreator. Mangod the Eternal!_"\r\n\r\n"_Ah yes. Mighty Mangod. How long will it be before the Mangod\'s\r\ncoming?_"\r\n\r\nJon shivered, reached out a shaking hand as though to support himself\r\nagainst the air. He tried to speak, but his facial muscles seemed\r\nfrozen. He wanted to say, "I\'m Man. I\'m your Creator. I made you, long\r\nago." But he could say nothing. 

Nothing at all.\r\n\r\n"_That is not known. Mangod made us in his own image, then departed,\r\npromising to return. Return to bring us glory and eternity._"\r\n\r\n"_May the Great Mangod who created us from the lifeless stuff of the\r\ndirt return soon, for only then may our destiny be fulfilled._"\r\n\r\n"_Yes. May Mangod return soon. Meanwhile, Central File demands\r\nimmediate action in preparation for that Day. Kill this grub. Soon all\r\norganic life that stands in the way of the Mangod\'s coming will be\r\neradicated._"\r\n\r\nThe thunderous impact of telepathic power roared in Jon\'s head as he\r\nstaggered forward, fists clenched.\r\n\r\n"FOR THEE, GREAT MANGOD. FOR WHOM WE WAIT."\r\n\r\n[Illustration: "_Return, oh Mangod, to bring us glory._"]\r\n\r\nJon laughed. Hot tears scalded his face as he laughed. He was still\r\nlaughing as the red-death eye brightened, leaped out, and silently\r\nswept him away.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nSnow had fallen in the morning but now the sky was clear and Ruy, with\r\na glance at the frosty stars and a sharp twist of his foot as he ground\r\nout a cigarette, stepped out quickly. It was axiomatic. 

What had to be\r\ndone, had to be done. A forged pass, with 48 hours of alleged validity\r\ngleaming brightly in red letters under the plastic overlaminate was\r\nbetter than no pass. And an outdated pass would wipe away a week\'s work\r\nin the underground.\r\n\r\nThe sharp, massive gray outline of the Pentagon loomed before him, dark\r\nand foreboding against the sky. The brightly lighted entrance through\r\nwhich he must gain admittance resembled the glowing peep-hole into the\r\ninferno of an atomic drive.\r\n\r\nRuy\'s stomach hardened, then exploded in a surge of bitter, stringent\r\ngastric juices as the MP glanced at his pass, scrutinized his face, and\r\nthen turned his attention toward others coming through the entrance.\r\n\r\nRuy wanted to run and hide. His dark blue uniform seemed to shrink\r\ntighter and tighter. 

The misfit must be apparent from the back. The\r\nsilvery commander\'s insignia on his jacket weighed heavily at his\r\nchest and at his heart. He wished desperately for one fleeting, but\r\nexcruciating, moment that he were back on his ship, in his own uniform,\r\nat the control panel of his computer.\r\n\r\nHe started off to the right in a seeming trance. The first step had\r\nbeen taken. His many hours of thought, study and planning would carry\r\nhim from here.\r\n\r\nThis was the only way. He had repeated the fact over and over. 

It was\r\nan ugly business, but had to be done. Five years of war was enough.\r\nMan was on his knees before the invaders from outer space; but they in\r\nturn had been too long from home and were near the breaking point. A\r\ncontinued drain would mean defeat for both sides. Ruy could turn the\r\ntide, but very probably his life would be the minimum sacrifice.\r\n\r\nHe had decided his fate long before he left the decks of his ship.\r\nOnly the belligerent pride of statesmen, and the steadfast belief in\r\nthe infallability of their computers, kept the two great battle fleets\r\ndrawn in null position against each other. The computers, perhaps,\r\ndeserved such ultimate confidence--in theory. They always predicted\r\noptimum maneuver envelopes, always predicted mobilization rates to\r\ndevelop force fields designed to offset those of the enemy. And they\r\nalways kept battle losses to a minimum--merely dribbling away the\r\nresources of the solar system. Yet in five years of such optimum\r\nmaneuvering, not a single battle had been won.\r\n\r\nTwo doors gave way before Ruy\'s pocket vibrator, the lock tumblers\r\nslipping and turning freely in a mad frenzy to escape the resonating\r\nhum. A short, windowless corridor lay before him, broken only by a\r\nmassive door at the other end. Beyond that door lay Ruy\'s objective.\r\n\r\nThe guard never had time to do more than note Ruy\'s presence in this\r\nsanctum sanctorum. The needle thin spray of a paralyzing drug made his\r\nbody feel stiff, unmanageable, and peculiarly buoyant, as though he\r\nwere being hurled through space. His thoughts became blurred and then\r\nafter a blinding flash, complete oblivion set in.\r\n\r\nThe two officers seated at the control panels of the master computer\r\nexperienced similar depression of their cardiovascular systems and\r\nmedullae.\r\n\r\nSmall thermite igniters pressed against the door lock and hinges fused\r\nthe steel door to its frame.\r\n\r\nWith the smell of scorched paint still stinging his nostrils, Ruy\r\nseated himself at the control panel, dabbed his left wrist with\r\nstringent antiseptic, gripped his hand into a fist, and plunged the\r\nsilver probes deep into the nerves of his wrist.\r\n\r\nGlancing through the observation window into the battle plotting room\r\nbelow, he studied the positions of the fleets as they appeared on the\r\nlarge wall diagram of the solar system.\r\n\r\nDisregarding the distraction offered by the moving figures of the few\r\nofficers and technicians on duty by the map, he fixed the positions of\r\nthe fleets into his mind. He would have need for a clear visual picture\r\nuntil he adapted to the mental images the computer would feed into his\r\nbrain. He worked with furious haste, yet each step was meticulously\r\nprecise--everything depended on his grasping the reins of battle\r\nfrom the computer and successfully twisting its authority to his own\r\npurposes.\r\n\r\nGrasping the viewing switch, he threw it on. Pinpoints of light flared\r\ndeep within his brain and seemed to blot his vision. Closing his eyes,\r\nhis brain fought for perspective. Gradually, it focused and perceived\r\nthe solar system, resplendent with sun, planets, moons, and men of war.\r\nEnveloping each ship were lines of force, scintillating sharp and hard;\r\nforming cosmic vortexes as the lesser computers on board followed the\r\nmaster\'s directives and distorted the ether around the ships, seeking\r\nto build a pattern to penetrate the opposing fields and engulf the\r\nenemy men of war.\r\n\r\nA moment, and the game was on. Ruy grasped the "Manual" switch before\r\nhim, pulled hard, and dropped his hands to the keyboard before him.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe General, who was known in military circles as a good Joe, but a\r\nstickler for the theory of war, relaxed languidly at his desk in the\r\nsmall office off the Battle Room. The other officers on duty milled\r\naround the plotting board within his eyesight awaiting the end of the\r\nevening shift.\r\n\r\nIt was strange and new to relax on the job after so many years of fleet\r\nduty. But staff duty to the master computer was good, politically. He\r\nwas getting along in years, and a few more contacts here might mean a\r\nseparate fleet command of his own, perhaps in pursuit of the invader,\r\nif the computers could ever break the deadlock.\r\n\r\nSuddenly, the sweet reverie of the General was snapped like a tight\r\ntension cable. A gong on the wall clanged rapidly three times and a\r\nred flashing light next to the gong told him what his ears refused to\r\nbelieve. The computer had been switched to manual. 

He had received no\r\nsuch instructions. In fact, the computer hadn\'t been on manual since\r\nthe war started.\r\n\r\n"Captain, who ordered manual control?" he barked as he sprang to the\r\ndoorway of the Battle Room.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know, Sir," stammered the Captain. His manner and bearing were\r\nthose of a man who had just been faced with a problem of cataclysmic\r\nproportions.\r\n\r\n"Well check with the control room--on the double--before our fleet gets\r\nout of defensive position." His parade ground roar snapped the Captain\r\nout of the catelepsy which had enveloped him and sent him scurrying\r\ninto the corridor.\r\n\r\nAn almost hysterical shout whirled the General back to the plotting\r\nboard.\r\n\r\n"Sir, our fleet is attacking--_attacking!_"\r\n\r\n"What? Where?" 

asked the General, his eyes darting over the board in a\r\nfrantic effort to orient himself.\r\n\r\n"Here, Sir, see. The positions are changing gradually in an unusual\r\npattern. A patrol ship, a destroyer, and a cruiser have all gone right\r\ninto the enemy vortex field," analyzed the Major.\r\n\r\n"Yes, I see--But with the enemy concentrating his ships\r\northogonally--he\'ll build a vortex that will disintegrate each and\r\nevery ship of ours near the vortex," said the General, his mind coming\r\nup to full battle speed as it grasped the situation. "My God! 

Can\'t\r\nthey see that they\'re going to certain death?"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nA gong sounded in a muffled sort of way in the plotting room below Ruy,\r\nas a gentle buzz told him that the computer had relinquished control.\r\n\r\nHis fingers began to play rapidly over the keys. Swift orders of\r\nstrategy were transmitted through steel conduits deep into the computer\r\nvaults of the building. There, the orders were transposed into detailed\r\ntactics and beamed throughout the solar system. And as his fingers\r\nlimbered to the keys, he played a deadly tune, a concerto of death.\r\n\r\nThe fleet grew alive with a sudden awareness; it seemed to be a thing\r\nalive, straining at its bonds in response to the music played into its\r\ncomputers and controls. Suddenly, the fleet sprang forward. A destroyer\r\nshot out into the midst of the enemy fleet, launching all of its energy\r\nin one tremendous lurch--only to go down in a flaming wreck as the\r\nenemy ships swerved and concentrated on it. And a second ship, and then\r\na third ship repeated the frightful maneuver, until the whole heavens\r\nwere lighted with the flaming novae of berserk atomic drives.\r\n\r\n"General, sir," said the Lieutenant, with sweat rolling from his brow\r\nas he saluted.\r\n\r\n"Yes, Lieutenant," said the General looking away from the battle map of\r\nthe solar system.\r\n\r\n"We can\'t make any headway against the control room door. Must be solid\r\nsteel. Whoever got in there must have fused it shut."\r\n\r\n"Well, get a welding torch," said the General, his eyes going back to\r\nwatch the devastation of the fleet. "But\r\nwe\'re losing our fleet this way."\r\n\r\nSeven, eight, nine great men of war went down before the blazing force\r\nfields of the enemy, who pounced on every sacrifice offered to it by\r\nthe computer.\r\n\r\nThe Lieutenant turned his eyes from the incandescent glare of the thick\r\nsteel conduit glowing red under the finger of the acetylene torch.\r\n"General, its extremely resistant to cutting. "\r\n\r\n"Keep at it, boy. We\'ve got to get through at the saboteur one way or\r\nanother. Do the best you can. The boys in the fleet are counting on\r\nyou. 

They\'re going down to certain death while we delay."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWith the last terms of the new equations of strategy played into the\r\ncomputer, Ruy sat back, gave a sigh, opened his eyes, and slipped the\r\nelectrodes from his wrist. His job was almost done. If he could keep\r\nthe others from this control panel for another half hour, the computer\r\ncould operate on his equations fully, and the battle would be won.\r\n\r\nThe first ships from Earth had already gone down in flames, expendable\r\nsacrifices to his purpose. He believed it deeply, deeply enough to\r\nthrow aside his career as a rising young theoretical mathematics\r\nofficer of the fleet and to go over the heads of his unconvinced\r\nsuperiors, with all their unread reports and unanswered recommendations\r\nfrom subordinates, in the only way a man of action could--by taking\r\nthings into his own hands, and staking his life on the gamble.\r\n\r\nThe General, eyes riveted to the board, winced with pain as ship after\r\nship roiled the heavens with flaming death. And as he watched, a\r\ngradual subtle design became apparent. For every ship he had lost, his\r\nships had taken a similar tally--for each sacrifice, a trap was sprung\r\nand a similar toll taken. Computers did not sacrifice, did not send men\r\nout to certain death. Therefore a sacrifice was greedily snapped up\r\nas a mistake of the enemy. And such greed snapped the trap. One move\r\nforced the next, once the bait was taken.\r\n\r\nAs the theme of the theory formed in the General\'s mind, he suddenly\r\nmuttered: "Even exchange will balance a computer\'s potential--but a\r\nseries of forced, even-exchanges can distort a fleet\'s position from\r\noptimum.... I never realized it before--an optimum move is not an\r\noptimum move--if it\'s a forced move."\r\n\r\nHe turned from the board and spoke quietly to the men who stood in\r\nhushed groups watching the flaming battle.\r\n\r\n"Gentlemen, we are winning a great victory; the war will soon be over."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe door to the computer room toppled outward, frame and all, after\r\nseveral ceaseless hours of cutting. "Place to get good\r\nmeals? Decent room for the night? The latest edition still gives Hotel Eros two asterisks.\r\n\r\nNow, two asterisks (**) is supposed to mean "Plain but fairly\r\ncomfortable".\r\n\r\n"Sure," says Brack, "the hotel may lack an up-to-date Dreamawake or a\r\nTime-conditioner, but at least you expect your room to have a Vibrobath\r\nand controllable gravity."\r\n\r\nNone of this at the Hotel Eros. Brack shakes his head complainingly.\r\n"You sleep in a primitive 7/8G-bed. You wash yourself with\r\nold-fashioned magnetic water. "\r\n\r\n"Boy, this sure is ancient!"\r\n\r\nEsther\'s eyes betrayed deep torment. "I know. I would do anything to\r\nget away from this place."\r\n\r\nShe put the towels in a rack. She sighed.\r\n\r\n"No, my only chance is to get away from the Dryodean System altogether.\r\nIf I go to another star--where the Pledge Act wasn\'t even heard of--"\r\n\r\nShe brushed back her long blond hair with an unconscious gesture, like\r\na maiden getting out of a degravity pool.\r\n\r\nBrack said thoughtfully: "Esther, if you\'re really determined to get\r\naway from here, maybe I can help you. I\'m taking a cargo to Hesdin.\r\nYour old man couldn\'t reach you there, or prove anything against me,\r\neither."\r\n\r\nThe girl\'s moonstone eyes flared up in hope, but she hesitated. "I\r\ndon\'t have very much money. I couldn\'t make it worth your while,\r\nfinancially."\r\n\r\n"That part is unimportant. The thing for you to consider is the\r\nsituation on Hesdin-2. It\'s a new colony; life there is pretty\r\nprimitive."\r\n\r\nEsther waved at the room. "Any more so than here?"\r\n\r\nBrack grinned. "Not much more. But then also, you\'ve got to remember\r\nthat it\'s a three-week trip. Pretty monotonous. 

Just the two of us."\r\n\r\nShe looked him in the eyes with understanding.\r\n\r\n"I\'d try not to get in the way."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThey met in the middle of the night at Brack\'s ship. Working slowly,\r\nsoundlessly, they opened a cargo case and removed enough unit boxes to\r\nmake room for the girl.\r\n\r\nEsther settled down in the container.\r\n\r\n"I\'m afraid that isn\'t too comfortable," Brack apologized, "but you\'ll\r\nonly have to put up with it four hours. I take off at seven.

"\r\n\r\n"That\'s all right, Bill. Just so there\'s no delay. My father expects me\r\nto open the dining room at seven."\r\n\r\n"We\'ll be ten million miles away before he misses you," said Brack. He\r\nput the top on loosely, faking the straps across the cover, so the\r\ngirl could breathe.\r\n\r\nIn his room again, Brack lay with arms folded under his head, thinking\r\nhoneyed thoughts. He would have Esther\'s pleasant company. 

His cargo\r\nwas a valuable one. Two-thirds of the receipts on Hesdin-2 would\r\nrepresent sheer profit. Perhaps it would be enough to establish him\r\nin some kind of a local freight business. Esther could make a man a\r\nwonderful partner. Lovely, delectable girl!\r\n\r\nHe reminded himself that they were not safely away from Corbie yet, and\r\nhe passed the remaining hours in the Hotel Eros sleeplessly anxious.\r\n\r\nBrack delayed going to his ship until the last minute before takeoff\r\ntime. Then, as he half-feared, he saw a customs officer standing beside\r\nthe airlock.\r\n\r\nThe trucker tried taking the offensive. "Gosh, I\'ll be late for my\r\nconvoy if I don\'t leave right away."\r\n\r\n"Sorry, sir, but I\'ll have to inspect your ship." He was a burly,\r\ntough-looking character in pale green uniform, blocking the doorway\r\nwith a flatfooted, wrestling stance.\r\n\r\nBrack sensed that a contest of fists might not end in his favor. He\r\nunlocked the entrance and waved the official in with reluctance. "Take\r\na look, but I\'ve already gone through customs on Dryod-7. I can show\r\nyou my clearance."\r\n\r\n"This isn\'t customs exactly," said the man. "We\'re searching for a\r\nperson."\r\n\r\n"A person?" (The old man sure kept a close watch on his daughter.) "I\'m\r\nthe only person aboard this ship."\r\n\r\nThe customs official remained polite. "Yes, I understand that, sir. 

But\r\nMr. Eros\' daughter is missing. He thinks she may have stowed away on\r\nyour ship."\r\n\r\n"Impossible! I had the ship locked."\r\n\r\nThey stepped into the pilot\'s cabin, a tetrahexahedron-shaped room\r\ncrowded with multiple-monitor screens of an astrogation-computer. Brack\r\nthrew the ignition switch to start the buildup in the ship\'s nuclear\r\nengine.\r\n\r\n"What is your cargo?" the customs man demanded.\r\n\r\n"Fifteen cases of deluplasm," said Brack with unfeigned anxiety.\r\n\r\nThe official debated with himself. "I believe it would be best if I\r\nopened the cases.

"\r\n\r\nBrack looked at his watch with desperation. "But we don\'t have time!\r\nThat would take at least a half-hour! I\'d miss the other ships! And\r\nyou know what that would mean. I couldn\'t navigate interstellar space\r\nalone, not at a hundred times the speed of light. I\'d be stuck here in\r\nthe Dryodean System until the next fleet left. That might be months!"\r\n\r\nHe grabbed the official\'s arm. "Please, fellow, give me a break!

"\r\n\r\nThe customs man considered. "Well, since the ship was locked, it\r\ndoes seem unlikely that the girl has hidden herself here. I certainly\r\nwouldn\'t want you to lose your convoy."\r\n\r\nBrack smiled in relief and started the rocket engine secondaries.\r\n\r\n"Thanks a million."\r\n\r\n"But just to protect me in case the girl has run off somewhere--I want\r\nyou to sign this form."\r\n\r\nBrack felt a twinge of suspicion, but more of a twinge of haste. "Sure.\r\nWhat kind of a form is this?"\r\n\r\n"It simply says that I inspected each case in your presence and found\r\nthe contents identical with your bill of lading. This girl has made\r\nseveral attempts to leave Corbie in the past. This is my protection in\r\ncase she\'s finally succeeded."\r\n\r\nThe customs officer made the slightest perceptible wink. Brack signed.\r\n\r\nHe took off immediately. He was already ten minutes late. He had to\r\nblast at top speed for the next hour, continually correcting his\r\nnavigation. There was no time to go back and let Esther out of the\r\ncargo room. He had to remain at the controls, feeding data into the\r\ncomputer, modifying course as solutions flashed on the screens.\r\n\r\nFinally, Brack sighted the convoy and maneuvered into pattern just as\r\nthe fleet was dematerializing into supra-space. He set his ship on\r\npantagraph-automatic with the lead navigator, then hastened to the\r\ncargo hold.\r\n\r\nEsther was not there. Neither were ten of the fifteen cases of\r\ndeluplasm. Two-thirds of his cargo had been hijacked.\r\n\r\nIt was of course pointless for Brack to turn around and raise hell on\r\nCorbie. With the waiver he\'d signed for the customs officer, he\'d only\r\nlook ridiculous. All he could do was continue to Hesdin-2 with his\r\none-third cargo. At least he\'d break even on the trip; Esther and her\r\nco-workers had been that considerate.\r\n\r\nNo, sex and space don\'t mix.\r\n\r\nAnd it\'s high time that Mr. Mattapenny deleted the Hotel Eros (**) from\r\nhis little red guidebook.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nThe land was dark in the softly falling rain, and the smell of green\r\nthings was in the air. The crew huddled in their cloaks and peered into\r\nthe approaching dusk as they unloaded the great silver space ship.\r\nThey were apprehensive of the stark ruins that began barely a mile from\r\nthe ship, the ruins that seemed to sprawl interminably across the flat\r\nland beside the broad river.\r\n\r\nIn the metal headquarters hut, the commander glanced nervously at his\r\nchronometer. The astrogator looked up from his interminable reckonings\r\nand smiled.\r\n\r\n"Don\'t worry, captain," he said. "They\'ll be all right. After all, we\r\nhaven\'t seen any life but a few small animals. And they ran from us."\r\n\r\nThe commander nodded absently, but went to the open door and stared out\r\ninto the rain. It made a musical tinkling on the thin metallic dome of\r\nthe hut.\r\n\r\n"I know," he said. "Perhaps that\'s why I\'m worried. It\'s the feeling of\r\ndeath here, as though it might spring at us from some corner in those\r\nruins.... I should have sent out a stronger scout party."\r\n\r\nThe astrogator shrugged and returned to his log. "If anything had gone\r\nwrong, they would have messaged us."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe commander smiled an unwilling agreement, but he stayed in the open\r\ndoor, searching the gathering darkness toward the city. He could not\r\nshake loose from the feeling of doom that had settled on him as soon\r\nas they had made their landfall and clambered from the airlocks of the\r\nspaceship. This was a strange world, the commander thought to himself.\r\nIt seemed to have everything--everything but intelligent inhabitants.\r\nThey had circled it for two days before they had chosen this wide green\r\nvalley for their landfall. They had seen cities, many of them, great\r\ncities along seacoasts and in rich plains, cities in mountains and in\r\nvalleys, but nowhere had they seen life.\r\n\r\nThe first cautious explorations after the landing that morning had\r\nshown that there was plenty of good water. The soil seemed rich, and\r\nvegetation grew in profusion, even among the ruins they had warily\r\nskirted. The atmosphere was perfect ... it was what they had searched\r\nfor through the long bitter years ... this stable atmosphere with\r\nits abundance of life-giving oxygen. And minerals aplenty ... the\r\nburned and blasted metal skeletons of the ruined city showed that. The\r\ncommander told himself that he was a fool for worrying, when he should\r\nbe shouting with joy at his luck.\r\n\r\nThere was a shout from the outpost, a laugh, and then his\r\nsecond-in-command loped through the rain, smiling broadly. Behind him\r\nwere the others, laughing and joking, shrugging their packs to the\r\nground. Gladness and wonder were in their faces and their voices, and\r\nthe commander knew that this was the world they had sought for so long.\r\n\r\nThe lieutenant ducked into the doorway and paused to warm himself at\r\nthe little thermal unit. He wiped the rain from his face, reached for\r\nthe wine bottle beside the astrogator\'s work board, and tilted it.\r\n\r\n"This is it, sir," he said. He was young, and Fate had been good to\r\nhim, and he was exulting in it. "It\'s everything we ever dared dream\r\nabout. It will support the whole race, every one of us, I think, if the\r\nrest of this world is anything like what we\'ve seen this day."\r\n\r\nThe commander grinned back at him, relief plain in his face. He was\r\nphrasing the message that he would send home across the void, the\r\nmessage they had waited for down through the weary years, the years\r\nthat had rolled by while the land burned up under a blazing sun, while\r\nthe water disappeared and the atmosphere became thin.... But there was\r\nstill in him the doubt, the remnant of fear....\r\n\r\n"Did you," he spaced the words carefully, "find any sign\r\nof--intelligent life?"\r\n\r\nThe lieutenant\'s smile faded. He glanced quickly out at the men,\r\nbreaking out their rations, resting from the labor, and looked back at\r\nhis captain. He nodded.\r\n\r\n"Tracks," he said. "We came across them leading out of the deserted\r\ncity."\r\n\r\n"Many?"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t think so. Five or six, perhaps. And we found where they had\r\nkilled one of the small animals and eaten it."\r\n\r\n"Did they seem--intelligent? 

Really, I mean?"\r\n\r\nThe lieutenant shrugged. "Who knows? 

They\'re bipeds, at any rate. We\r\nfollowed the tracks, but they had taken to a small stream bed, and we\r\nlost them.

"\r\n\r\nThe commander pondered. Then he made his decision.\r\n\r\n"In a country as large as this," he said, "five or six can\'t make any\r\ndifference to us, not even to a small party like our own. And certainly\r\nnot when the ships begin arriving from home.

"\r\n\r\nThe lieutenant leaned back on his pack, his face content. The commander\r\nsat at a field desk and started writing, carefully, knowing that\r\nwhat he wrote would someday be in every textbook. The message was not\r\ndifficult, really. Thousands of space captains had phrased the message\r\nin their minds down through, the years of The Search. So had he, time\r\nand again, as he lay in his bunk or watched the wheeling stars from\r\nthe bridge. In the glow of the thermal unit his stern face glowed with\r\npride and the certainty that it was his ship that had saved a world....\r\n\r\nIn another hut the scholar stared thoughtfully at the thing he had\r\nfound in the old house where they had discovered the tracks. There had\r\nbeen a language on this dead world, and in his hand he held some of the\r\nbrown mouldering pages upon which the language had been written. He\r\napplied his scholar\'s mind to the puzzle....\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe city crouched grimly about them. Even though they had neither seen\r\nnor heard any life in these streets save a few small animals who had\r\nfled their coming, they gripped their projectors at the ready.\r\n\r\nAlmost every structure had been damaged. Many were mere twisted heaps\r\nof debris, timbers and girders thrusting insanely at a sky that today\r\nwas blue and benign. The taller, sturdier buildings still stood, but\r\ntheir walls were cracked and their windows gaping hollow eyes in the\r\nblank faces. Rubble clogged the streets, and grass had split the\r\npavements. Here and there among the ruins a sapling stood bravely, its\r\nroots grasping in the shattered masonry.\r\n\r\nIn the streets, rusting and ancient, were objects which they surmised\r\nmust have been vehicles. In some of them they found fragments of bone\r\nand shreds of clothing. They had seen other bones; in doorways, on the\r\nground floors of the few buildings they had penetrated.\r\n\r\n"Whatever it was," the second-in-command said, "it struck them swiftly."\r\n\r\n"Some sickness, a virus, perhaps?" the astrogator suggested.\r\n\r\nThe commander shook his head. "War," he said. 

"Only war could do this\r\nto a city."\r\n\r\nThe lieutenant said admiringly, "Whoever they were, they certainly\r\ndeveloped some pretty terrific weapons."\r\n\r\nThe commander had smiled, and patted his projector. "No more terrific\r\nthan these," he said. "Our own people developed weapons, too. Thank the\r\nstars that we have learned not to use them on each other."\r\n\r\nThe scholar looked up from the inscription he had found on the side of\r\na building.\r\n\r\n"And thank the stars," he said, "that we learned in time. The people of\r\nthis world apparently did not."\r\n\r\nIt was then, while they spoke, that from somewhere in the ruins there\r\nwas a sharp crack, and one of the crew spun around and fell in the\r\nstreet. In the shattered silence of the city the sound echoed crazily.\r\n\r\n"Take cover!" the captain shouted, and he plunged into a huge doorway,\r\npeering around the protecting portal. There was another crack, and\r\nsomething whined by him.\r\n\r\n"Projectile weapon!" 

whispered the lieutenant behind him. He was prone,\r\nsighting his projector at a half-ruined four-story house at the corner.\r\nHe pressed the control switch, once, and a section of the second floor\r\nseemed to explode into hurtling gray dust and shrieking steel.\r\n\r\nOther projectors were spitting from doorways and from behind piles of\r\nbrick and debris in the streets. The captain, watching the building\r\nfrom which the answering fire seemed to come, thought he saw movement\r\nbehind one of the blank windows. Before he could take aim, there was a\r\nripping series of shots and the masonry of the portal flew into dust.\r\nHe heard the low flat whine of ricochets, and he withdrew deeper into\r\nthe dimness of the great entranceway. Up the street he heard a crew\r\nmember cry out in pain.\r\n\r\n"The second floor!" he cried, and a hurricane of electron bolts ripped\r\ninto the building at the corner. The building seemed to rip apart\r\nunder the impact and there was the roar of falling bricks and timber\r\nas a floor gave way with a crash. They dashed out of cover, crouching,\r\nfiring as they went.\r\n\r\nThey found three bodies in the ruins. Bipeds. Pale pasty flesh, faces\r\nhalf-hidden by tangled hair. The bodies were only partially clad in\r\nfaded tattered clothes, and the feet were encased in what appeared\r\nto be the tanned hide of an animal. The flesh and the clothing were\r\nfilthy, and they stank. The bodies were huddled around their weapon, a\r\nmetallic-looking projectile-thrower mounted on three legs. Its barrel\r\nwas still hot.\r\n\r\nA little later they flushed another of the creatures in a narrow\r\nstreet. It howled gibberish at them and fled, but they cornered the\r\nthing against a heap of rubble. It mouthed things at them, and hurled\r\nbits of brick. Its eyes were wild and staring, and spittle trickled\r\ndown the face into the sodden filthy rags it wore. They had to kill it,\r\nfinally.\r\n\r\n[Illustration: _They had to kill it, finally._]\r\n\r\nThe commander turned the dead thing over with his projector stock, and\r\nstared at it.\r\n\r\n"Mad," he said. "There are only a few of them, and they are mad.

"\r\n\r\nThe scholar nodded. He had found many of the writings, and they were\r\nstuffed in his pack and in his pockets, and he held one while he talked.\r\n\r\n"They are mad," he said, "and there cannot be many of them. Certainly\r\nnot enough to halt the advance of civilization."\r\n\r\nIt was as if he saw, already, the soaring towers of the cities they\r\nwould build here over the pitiful ruins, as though the busy highways\r\nalready spanned this rich new world.\r\n\r\n"We have won our bridgehead here," he said. "Soon we will have won the\r\nworld. The world," he looked down at the carcass at his feet, "that\r\nthese poor fools threw away."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe scholar made his greatest find late that afternoon, on the\r\nstreet-level floor of an almost-intact building. It must have been\r\na place where writings had been stored, or perhaps sold. The brown\r\nrotting pages were everywhere, and the mouldering covers in which the\r\nwritings had been bound. The scholar cried out with pleasure, and the\r\ncommander was forced to delay their return to the ship so that the crew\r\ncould carry part of the loot with them, for further study.\r\n\r\nThe scholar was squatting in a corner of the room, poring over one of\r\nthe ancient records, when he looked up and shouted, "I think I\'ve got\r\nit! I think I\'ve got it! I think I\'ve found the key to their language!"\r\n\r\nThe commander had smiled indulgently, for though he believed in\r\naction, he had respect for the scholar, and knew that the things the\r\nscholar might discover in the old writings might help him in his own\r\ntask as leader of the expedition.\r\n\r\nIt was then that the creatures attacked for the last time. They must\r\nhave crept into the building and gathered there in the dimness, waiting\r\ntheir opportunity. 

There were six of them. They poured through a rear\r\ndoor into the room of writings, howling, their projectile-throwers\r\nbarking. Their wild ululations were the screams of the demented. The\r\ncommander could see the madness in their eyes and he knew why he had\r\nbeen afraid.\r\n\r\nThe astrogator was down before they could return the fire, and then the\r\nprojectors cracked out their blue-flamed doom.\r\n\r\nThe lieutenant cursed as he was hit; he dropped to one knee, firing\r\nswiftly, and then the creatures were down and it was over. The wild\r\nbearded faces were charred and blackened, and in the sudden silence was\r\nthe crackle of the little blue flames as they danced over the filthy\r\nragged clothing of the dead. The commander let his breath go, at last,\r\nin a long gasping sigh.\r\n\r\nHe started to walk toward the bodies, knowing that they were the\r\nlast, knowing that if there had been any more they would have waited,\r\ngathering strength, and they would not have made the crazy suicidal\r\nattack. The fighting was over. The savage creatures, unbalanced by\r\ntheir miserable existence among the ruins of the glory that had been\r\ntheirs, would never again threaten the bridgehead he had carved on this\r\nworld. It was his world now.\r\n\r\nThere was a frantic tugging at his sleeve, and he shook the battle fog\r\nfrom his eyes and grinned at the scholar. The commander remembered\r\nthat even while the fight had roared hot and sharp, the scholar had\r\nnot moved from his corner, nor taken his eyes from the pages he was\r\nstudying. And now the scholar was fairly dancing with excitement.\r\n\r\n"I\'ve got it!" he said, almost chortling. 

"It wasn\'t hard with the\r\nkey--and I found the key!"\r\n\r\nHe gestured toward the little tangle of bodies, silent in the room of\r\nwritings.\r\n\r\n"They called themselves \'Men,\'" he said.\r\n\r\nThe commander shrugged.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


"This is ridiculous," he said.\r\n\r\nThe light chatter ceased. Cocktail glasses were set down on various\r\nhandy tables and ledges; and all faces in the room turned toward a man\r\nin his late fifties who sat propped up invalid-wise on pillows in a\r\nchair in a corner of the room.\r\n\r\n"The Comptroller is perspicacious," said the old man, agreeably,\r\nwaving one hand in a casual manner. "On your way, children.

"\r\n\r\nAnd the people present smiled and nodded. Quite as if it were an\r\nordinary leave-taking, they pushed past Terri Mac and filed out the\r\ndoor. Even the blonde, Terri had picked up at the embassy ball and who\r\nhad brought him here, strolled off casually, but in a decidedly less\r\ndrunken fashion than she had exhibited earlier in the evening.\r\n\r\n"Sit down," said the old man. Terri Mac did so, gazing searchingly at\r\nthe skinny frame and white eyebrows in an unsuccessful effort to\r\nconnect him with something in memory. "This is ridiculous," he\r\nrepeated.\r\n\r\n"Really?" The old man smiled benignly. "And why so?"\r\n\r\n"Why--" the situation was so obvious that Terri fumbled--a little at a\r\nloss for words. "Obviously you intend some form of coercion, or else\r\nyou would have come to me along recognized channels. And any thought\r\nof coercion is obviously--well, ridiculous."\r\n\r\n"Why?"\r\n\r\n"Why? You senile old fool, don\'t you know that I\'m shielded? Don\'t you\r\nknow all government officials from the fifth class up wear complete\r\npersonal shields that are not only crack-proof but contain all the\r\nnecessary elements to support life independently within the shield\r\nfor more than twenty hours? Don\'t you know that I\'ll be missed in two\r\nhours at the most and tracked down in less than sixty minutes more?\r\nAre you crazy?"\r\n\r\nThe old man chuckled, rubbing dry hands together. He said, "I\'m\r\nshielded too. You can\'t get at me. And now the room\'s shielded. You\r\ncan\'t get out of it."\r\n\r\nTerri stared at him. The initial shock was passing. His own statements\r\nanent the completeness of his protection had brought back confidence,\r\nand his natural coolness was returning. We must get to know\r\neach other personally."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIt occurred to Terri that he had misinterpreted the situation. "I\'m not an\r\nordinary politician. No man who works his way up to the fifth level of\r\nthe government is. I didn\'t get to where I am today by pussy-footing\r\naround and I haven\'t the leisure to spend on people who do. Now _what_\r\ndo you want?

"\r\n\r\nThe other cackled. 

"Now, what do you think?" he said, putting one\r\nfinger to his nose cunningly.\r\n\r\n"You are old," Terri said. "And therefore cautious. Consequently you\r\nwould not risk trying to force something from me, but are almost\r\ncertainly trying to sell me something. Now what do I want? 

Not the\r\nusual things, certainly. Within my position I have all the material\r\nthings a man could want; and within my shield I enjoy complete\r\nimmunity. No one but the Central Bureau, itself, can crack this\r\nshield. And no one but they can prevent the conditioned reflex that\r\nstops my heart if for some reason the shield should be broached. I\r\nhave a hold on every man beneath me that prevents him from knifing me\r\nin the back. "I am interested. I\'ll buy.\r\nWhat do you want. Money? A favor? Protection?"\r\n\r\n"No."\r\n\r\n"No?" Terri shouted, starting up from his chair. "What do you mean by\r\nno?
