I\'ll be missed. They\'ll be here in a few\r\nminutes--the Bureau Guards. They\'ll crack the room shield. They\'ll\r\nrescue me. And they\'ll take you into custody. To be questioned. To be\r\nexecuted. At my order. 

Do you understand? 

Your life depends on me."\r\n\r\nAfter a little, the old man chuckled again. "Yes," he muttered, in a\r\nhigh-pitched old voice. "That\'s the way it\'ll be."\r\n\r\nTerri stared at him. "You don\'t seem to understand. 

You\'re going to\r\ndie."\r\n\r\n"Oh yes," said the old man, nodding his head indulgently. "I\'ll die.\r\nBut I\'m an old man. I\'d die anyway in a year or so--maybe in a day or\r\nso. But for you--for a young man like you--the up and coming young\r\ngovernmental with everything to lose--" he leered slyly at Terri.\r\n"Your death won\'t be so easy for you to take."\r\n\r\n"I die?" echoed Terri, stupefied. "But I\'m not going to die. They\'re\r\ncoming to _rescue_ me."\r\n\r\n"Oh, are they?" said the old man, ironically.\r\n\r\n"Of course!" said Terri. "Of course, why shouldn\'t they?"\r\n\r\nThe old man winked one faded eye portentously.\r\n\r\n"Fine young man," he said. "Up and coming young man. Brilliant. Never\r\na thought for the people he trampled on the way up the ladder. Dear\r\nme, no.

"\r\n\r\n"What do you mean?" said Terri.\r\n\r\nThe old eyes, looking up suddenly, pierced him.\r\n\r\n"Do you remember Kilaren?"\r\n\r\n"K-Kilaren?"\r\n\r\n"Kilaren," recited the old man as if quoting from a newspaper. "The\r\nbeautiful young secretary of a provincial governor whose lecherous and\r\nunnatural pursuit drove her to suicide. So that one day to escape the\r\ngovernor, she jumped or fell from a high window. And the people of the\r\nprovince, who had for a long time heard ugly stories and rumors,\r\nfinally mobbed the office and lynched the governor, hanging him from\r\nthe same window from which the girl had jumped. They said that even\r\nthe fall had not spoiled her beauty, but that was probably false." The\r\nold man\'s words dwindled away into silence.\r\n\r\n"If so what of it?" said Terri. "What\'s that to do with me?

"\r\n\r\n"Why, you were there. You were the governor\'s aide, and when the mob\r\nhad gone home and feeling had slackened off, you stepped into the gap\r\nand seized up the reins of government, handling matters so skillfully\r\nthat you were immediately promoted to an under-post at Government\r\nCity."\r\n\r\n"What of it?"\r\n\r\n"Why it was all your doing," replied the other, in a mildly reproving\r\nvoice, "the rumors, the stories, the mob, even the suicide. Poor\r\nKilaren--a pitiful pawn in your ruthless game to eliminate the\r\ngovernor in your mad dash up the ladder."\r\n\r\n"I never touched her!" cried Terri, his voice cracking. "I swear it."\r\n\r\n"Who said you did? The type of mind that stoops to murder would never\r\nhave gotten you this far. But you were the one who hired her, knowing\r\nthe governor\'s tendencies. You were the one that gave her work that\r\nkept her, night after night, alone with the man. You preyed upon her\r\nfear of losing her job. You threw the sin in her face after she had\r\ncommitted it. You told her what she might have been, and what she was,\r\nand what she would be. You broke her, day after day. In the sterile\r\nprivacy of the office you reviled her, scorned her, brought her to\r\nbelieve that she was what she was not, a creature of filth and\r\ndishonor. You blocked off all avenues of escape but the one that led\r\nthrough one high window. _You killed her!_"\r\n\r\n"No!"\r\n\r\n"Yes!"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nTerri brought his quivering hands together and clenched them in his\r\nlap. He stared at the old man. "Who are you?"\r\n\r\n"I was a friend of hers. We lived in the same hotel-apartment. She had\r\nno family. I believe you knew that when you hired her."\r\n\r\n"I see," said Terri. He drew a long, deep, shuddering breath, and\r\nleaned back in the chair. "So that\'s the story," he said, his voice\r\nstrengthening, "I might have known it. Blackmail. There are always\r\nfools that want to try blackmail."\r\n\r\n"No," said the old man. "Not Blackmail, Comptroller. I want your\r\nlife."\r\n\r\nTerri laughed shortly, contemptuously. "No knowledge that you have can\r\nthreaten my life."\r\n\r\n"They will come," said the old man, leaning wearily back against his\r\ncushions. "As you said, the Bureau Guards will come; and I think I\r\nshall kill myself when I hear them starting to crack the shield around\r\nthis room. They will come in and find you with a dead man. What will\r\nyou tell them, Terri?"\r\n\r\n"Tell them? Anything I choose. They won\'t question _me_."\r\n\r\n"No. The guards won\'t. But the Bureau will. How can they raise a man\r\nto the fourth level when there is a two-hour mystery in his\r\nbackground? They will want to know what you were doing here."\r\n\r\n"I was kidnapped," said Terri.\r\n\r\n"By whom? Can you prove it? And why?"\r\n\r\n"I\'ve been held a prisoner here."\r\n\r\n"By a dead man? No, no, Terri. 

The circumstances are suspicious. You\r\nwalk away from the embassy under your own power. You disappear and are\r\nfound in a shielded room with a man who has committed suicide. This\r\nmust be explained, and in the end you will have to tell them the\r\ntruth.

"\r\n\r\n"And what if I do?" said Terri, truculently.\r\n\r\n"But the truth is so fantastic, Terri. So uncheckable. I am dead, and\r\nI am the only one who could have supported your story. These people\r\nwho were here when you came in are common actors. They have no idea\r\nwhy I wanted you decoyed here. These are my rooms. And there is no\r\nobvious connection between me and the dead Kilaren. And perhaps I will\r\ndecide to live just long enough to denounce you as a traitor when they\r\nenter."\r\n\r\nAshen-faced, Terri stared.\r\n\r\n"The Bureau will have to question you. They will clamp a block on your\r\nmind so that you can\'t operate the reflex that stops your heart. And\r\nthey will question you over and over again, because the Bureau cannot\r\nafford to take chances. You will go into a private hell of your own,\r\nTerri Mac. You will tell the story of your own evil to that girl over\r\nand over again, pleading to be believed. And they will not believe\r\nyou. And in the end they will kill you, just to be on the safe side.\r\nBecause, you see, you _might_ have been doing something traitorous in\r\nthese two shielded hours."\r\n\r\nTerri\'s head bobbed limply, like a drunken man\'s. 

He made one last\r\neffort. "Why?" he said. "Why do you do this? Your life. 

For a girl who\r\nwas no connection to you?"\r\n\r\nThe old man folded his hands.\r\n\r\n"I was a little like your governor," he said. "We all have our sins. I\r\nloved Kilaren and the shock of her death wrecked my health." He cocked\r\nhis head suddenly on one side. "Listen," he said.\r\n\r\nFrom beyond the closed door of the room, a high-pitched humming was\r\nbarely audible. It grew in volume, going up the scale. Terri leaped to\r\nhis feet; and for the space of a couple of seconds, he lunged first\r\nthis way then that, like a wild animal beating against its trap. Then,\r\nas if all will had at last gone out of him, he stopped in the middle\r\nof the room and closed his eyes. For a fraction of a moment he stood\r\nthere, before a faint convulsion seized him and he fell.\r\n\r\nWith a faint smile on his face, the old man reached out to a hidden\r\nswitch and cut the shield about the room. Uniformed guards tumbled\r\nthrough the door, to pull up in dismay at the sight of the body on the\r\nfloor.\r\n\r\n"I\'m sorry," said the old man, "I must have turned the shield on by\r\nmistake. I was trying to signal someone. 

The Comptroller seems to have\r\nhad a heart attack."\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEnd of Project Gutenberg\'s No Shield from the Dead, by Gordon Rupert Dickson\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


]\r\n\r\n\r\nThe sun was a shrunken red disk against the starfields, a distant\r\npale luminosity surrendering to the encroachment of the falling night.\r\nHoarfrost crunched under Marley\'s feet as he walked by the still black\r\nwaters of the canal, and then thin wind whispered over the sand and\r\nacross the breasts of the ancient hills. Starlight gleamed in the dark\r\nwater as the day faded. Earth hung low in the sky, like an emerald\r\npendant over the bosom of a sleeping woman.\r\n\r\nMarley pulled his silks and furs closer about his shoulders. The air\r\nwas sharp and cold. His breath froze wraithlike in the icy evening as\r\nhe hurried down the path toward Tydore\'s tower.\r\n\r\nThe green planet shone like a beacon in his eyes. Home. The thought\r\nbrought impatience and a longing to walk again under a pale sky and a\r\nwarm sun. He looked about him with faint distaste. This peace--this\r\nsolitude of low red hills and blue-black nights--was alien to Marley.\r\nIt was unreal. Mars was a dream. An ancient wasted slumbering dream.\r\n\r\nMarley\'s lips compressed as he thought of Tydore and their last\r\nmeeting. It seemed that Tydore laughed at him. Tydore withheld too\r\nmuch, and there was so little time left. There was an acrid core\r\nof decadence in the old Martian, Marley thought. A consciousness\r\nof too many millenia of civilization and decay. Devious was the\r\nword, perhaps, though it seemed a pallid one for the reality of the\r\nMartian\'s intricate mind. It was always impossible to know what he was\r\nthinking--how much he knew. About Marley being a spy. About the war on\r\nEarth. In spite of himself, Marley smiled. It sounded so melodramatic\r\nthat way, but it was the way it really was. The Martians held the\r\nperfect weapon. Marley needed that weapon, and his nation had put forth\r\na gigantic effort to get him to Mars so that he might steal it.\r\n\r\nTydore\'s tower loomed up before him in the fading light, a fey\r\nfilligree of minarettes and graceful flying buttresses too delicate\r\nfor a grosser world than Mars. The tower\'s reflection shimmered in the\r\nstill dark waters of the canal like an alter ego extending deep into\r\nthe liquid depths.\r\n\r\nMarley descended the steps of delicately wrought stone that led to the\r\ntower\'s underground entrance with care, for the drifted ferric sand\r\nmade them treacherous. How like the Martians, he thought with some\r\nirritation, to make it necessary to travel down in order to enter a\r\ntower. Everything the long way, the hard and devious way.\r\n\r\nThe outer doorway was shaped like a fleur-de-lis and it opened from the\r\ntop down, sliding into a recess of ancient, oily machinery. It would\r\nbe far too simple to make a door that looked and worked like a door.\r\nEverything Marley had seen during his months on Mars served only to\r\nincrease his sense of alienage. He had seen only Tydore, of course, of\r\nthe living Martians. There were only a handful left and they lived\r\nin their isolated towers along the still canals surrounded by their\r\ntissue-thin manuscripts and ancient, reedlike music spools that filled\r\nthe air of their retreats with skeins of weird and enharmonic melody.\r\n\r\nThe weapon was Tydore\'s. He had rebuilt it from plans drawn by some\r\nensorcelled armorer dead over five thousand years. Rebuilt it in the\r\nparadoxical way that Martians seemed to do everything, for if there was\r\none thing that no Martian needed it was a weapon. No strife had marred\r\nthe planet\'s peace for millenia. But build it he had, and Marley\'s\r\nhands itched for the sleek deadliness of it--the smooth grained stock,\r\nthe oddly wrought, ornate muzzle. There was a vicious, tangy violence\r\nfrozen into every line of the weapon. And it was the only hand gun\r\nMarley had ever seen that chained the forces of the atom. With such\r\nweapons an army could be invincible.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nTydore stood to greet him. With the elaborate courtesy of his kind, he\r\nperformed the ritual gestures of welcome, his slender, finely veined\r\nhands tracing the ancient symbols in the air.\r\n\r\n"The gods of sand and wind have brought you safely to my house, man\r\nof Earth. I give thanks and pray you find peace and wisdom within my\r\nwalls."\r\n\r\nThe old Martian\'s chanting voice was like the fluting grace of a\r\nScarlatti choral. It was one with the miniscule paintings that covered\r\nthe walls, the finely wrought carvings on the antique flagstones under\r\nhis feet. Marley was not at home in the fluid Martian tongue, but the\r\nvery sound of the words conjured for him the serried ranks of spectral\r\ngenerations that had reached their culmination in this one robed\r\nancient.\r\n\r\nAnd yet, he thought with irritation, Tydore\'s words mean not at all\r\nwhat they said. Through the finely polished phrases of welcome ran\r\na thread of hidden mockery--even hate--for Marley and everything he\r\nrepresented. Never once had Tydore, by word or deed, indicated that he\r\nfelt anything but friendship for his visitor from the silvery ship out\r\non the desert, and yet there was no mistaking the nuance of contempt.\r\nTydore despised Marley as an outworld savage. One with the despoilers\r\nof the holy places of Mars.\r\n\r\nNot that the Martians had gods. 

They had lived too long for that, and\r\ntheir deities existed only in their beautifully turned phrases and\r\ntheir hyper-cultured ritual. But the first men from Earth had looted\r\nthe libraries and shattered the soaring towers. It was a thing no\r\nMartian would ever forget--or forgive. It marked Earthmen for what\r\nthey were. In Martian eyes--precocious barbarians. Targets for Martian\r\nsubtlety.\r\n\r\n"I give thanks for your welcome," Marley said slowly, his tongue clumsy\r\non the singing syllables.\r\n\r\nTydore inclined his head slightly and indicated that Marley should\r\nfollow him up the winding ramp that pierced the core of the tower. Each\r\ntime Marley came, the ritual was the same, as unchanging as the still\r\nwaters of the dark canals or the frozen loneliness of the red hills\r\nbeyond. They would pass the first level, where the old engines supplied\r\nTydore with what little heat and sustenance he needed. 

They would go on\r\nto the second level, where the music spools lay in ordered confusion\r\namid the sonic transcribers that Tydore used to weave the sounds of the\r\nMartian night into atonal poems of melody. And then they would reach\r\nthe level of the weapon.\r\n\r\nIt would still be in its crystal case, guarded by a lock of bronze. A\r\nlock to which there was one key, and that one key on a silver chain\r\naround Tydore\'s neck. They would pass the weapon by and seek the top\r\nlevel, a platform shielded against the frigid night by a crystal\r\ncanopy. And there they would begin their nightly fencing with words and\r\nideas under the guise of friendship.\r\n\r\nMarley\'s heart was pounding suddenly as he drew near to the weapon. His\r\npatience was failing him at long last, he knew. He was sick of Mars,\r\nsick of Tydore. Sick of posing as a humble seeker after knowledge. If\r\nhe could not trick the Martian into parting with the weapon soon, he\r\nknew that he must chance violence. He had not dared it before, because\r\nhe could never be sure that Tydore and his kind were as defenseless as\r\nthey seemed. It was paradoxical that they should possess a weapon such\r\nas _the_ weapon and yet be unwilling or unable to use it.\r\n\r\nStill it seemed to Marley that such must be the case. He could only\r\nexplain it to himself by saying that they had lived too long, amid\r\ntoo much deviousness and inverted purpose to be quite virile. They\r\nwere--the word came readily to mind from the days of his training on\r\nEarth--decadent. And the meek did not inherit the earth or anything\r\nelse, he told himself with satisfaction. Only the militant, the\r\nruthless.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe time had come, Marley thought, for the calculated risk. Direct\r\naction. He could scarcely contain himself as they passed the weapon and\r\nclimbed to the top level.\r\n\r\n"You seem preoccupied tonight, Marley," Tydore said, pouring two tiny\r\ngoblets of wine, "Can it be that you grow tired of Mars?"\r\n\r\nMarley sipped the wine thoughtfully. 

To him it seemed completely\r\ninsipid and without flavor. Subtlety again? 

He doubted it. 

"I mean to\r\nask a favor of you, Tydore," he said, "And I but ponder how I should\r\nbegin."\r\n\r\n"My house is yours," the Martian replied softly, "And all that it\r\ncontains."\r\n\r\nMarley\'s eyes narrowed. Did he imagine the accent on the last phrase,\r\nor was it actually there? He decided to be very cautious. "I came here,\r\nas you know," he said, "To learn everything I might about your kind. As\r\nyou know, we of Earth are a young race, still much in need of guidance\r\nand knowledge."\r\n\r\n"You have learned much," Tydore said.\r\n\r\nMarley\'s tone grew harder. "But not enough."\r\n\r\nTydore\'s eyebrows arched delicately. 

"So? You have read my books,\r\nlistened to my music. You have tasted the wines and eaten the fruits of\r\nMars. 

You have seen the stars and the sand, the waters and the lichens.\r\nHave you not known my world?"\r\n\r\n"I want more," Marley said flatly.\r\n\r\nTydore smiled. In that smile Marley saw a flash of more distilled\r\nvenom and ancient hatred that he could have imagined existed. The utter\r\nvirulence of it left him shaken and his illogical fear brought anger.\r\n\r\nHe got to his feet, the tiny goblet in his hand. It was old and\r\ndelicate, a tiny gem of carved jade and ivory. To one such as\r\nTydore--priceless. Brutally, Marley crushed it to shards in his hands\r\nand dropped it to the flagstones. The fragments tinkled as they fell.\r\n\r\n"So it must always be," said Tydore in a soft voice.\r\n\r\n"I have not come here to listen to music, Tydore," Marley said, "Nor to\r\nread your books or to know your world. You have one thing that I want.\r\nYou will give it to me, or I will take it from you." He ground his heel\r\nonto the remains of the goblet with a grating sound.\r\n\r\n"The weapon," the Martian said, "You want the weapon. You may have it.\r\nYou need not have broken my goblet...."\r\n\r\nMarley was almost sorry that he had won so easily. He suddenly wanted\r\nto crush the old Martian as he had crushed the goblet. In both there\r\nwas a quality that eluded him, and it was maddening.\r\n\r\nTydore handed him the key. "Come, we will get it together."\r\n\r\nMarley followed him cautiously, alert for any trickery. Presently they\r\nstood before the case and Marley unlocked it, reaching greedily for\r\nthe polished stock. He cradled the gun in his arms lovingly, savoring\r\ntriumph. With this in his hands, he could defy a world.\r\n\r\n"There is no other like it, nor any but I to make one," Tydore said\r\nwith a strange smile.\r\n\r\n"Why did you make it?" asked Marley.\r\n\r\n"I made it for you."\r\n\r\n[Illustration: "_I made it for you...._"]\r\n\r\nMarley laughed aloud. It was an alien sound in the thin, cold air of\r\nthe tower. "You\'re a liar, Tydore. You built this weapon long before I\r\never left Earth and you know it."\r\n\r\n"By you, I meant simply men like you," Tydore said. "When the first\r\nEarthmen came and befouled Mars with their presence, I knew that I\r\nmust make the weapon." He smiled, showing even white teeth. "A small\r\ntriumph, but things are not to be measured by whether they are great\r\nor small. 

Rather by their flavor, their grace, and their neatness,\r\nMarley."\r\n\r\n"You speak of triumph, old man," snorted Marley derisively, "while your\r\nprecious weapon is in my hands."\r\n\r\nTydore shrugged. "As I knew it would be one day when I spread the tales\r\nof what the weapon would do. It drew you as a lodestone draws a sliver\r\nof iron."\r\n\r\nMarley felt a pang of panic. "You mean this thing is a fake?"\r\n\r\nTydore shook his head. "No counterfeit. It will do what I said it would\r\ndo. 

Kill. 

What more can one ask of a weapon?"\r\n\r\nIt was Marley\'s turn to smile. "Nothing. And there is only this one.\r\nAnd if you were to die...."\r\n\r\nTydore smiled a veiled smile. "It is as the gods of sand and wind\r\ndecree."\r\n\r\nMarley pointed the weapon at Tydore. He had only to kill the old\r\nMartian and return to his ship. The mission was over. 

Completed. He was\r\ndone with Mars and with Tydore and his subtle scorn.\r\n\r\nHe cradled the weapon lovingly, laying his cheek to the carven stock.\r\nOld Tydore had built well. There was perfect balance in the feel of\r\nit. His finger curled around the trigger and he sighted carefully down\r\nthe long barrel at the robed figure of the Martian. Tydore was smiling\r\nin the face of death, and Marley wanted to laugh out loud. This is the\r\nway the world ends, he was thinking. Not with a bang but a whimper. He\r\nsqueezed the trigger....\r\n\r\nThe universe exploded in Marley\'s face. There was a streak of searing\r\npain that carried away half his face, and as he fell he could hear a\r\nstrange sound. For the first time, Tydore was laughing aloud. It was a\r\nhideous sound. A voice for the torment and hatred of a race that had\r\nlived too long, planned too much. Marley felt the tower pinwheel around\r\nhim, the flagstones leapt up to meet him, greeting the searing agony of\r\nhis face with the soundless laughter of a million intricate patterns of\r\nlonely death. And blackness welled up out of the stones to engulf him,\r\nbut not before he knew--\r\n\r\nTydore had made the weapon with the muzzle resembling the stock. It was\r\nas simple as that.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\n"Is there anything you want to make disappear?" Clarence Willoughby\r\nasked his mother.\r\n\r\n"A sink full of dishes is all I can think of. How will you do it?

"\r\n\r\n"I just built a disappearer. All you do is cut the other end out of a\r\nbeer can. Then you take two pieces of red cardboard with peepholes in\r\nthe middle and fit them in the ends. You look through the peepholes and\r\nblink. Whatever you look at will disappear."\r\n\r\n"Oh."\r\n\r\n"But I don\'t know if I can make them come back. We\'d better try it on\r\nsomething else. 

Dishes cost money."\r\n\r\nAs always, Myra Willoughby had to admire the wisdom of her\r\nnine-year-old son. She would not have had such foresight herself. He\r\nalways did.\r\n\r\n"You can try it on Blanche Manners\' cat outside there. Nobody will care\r\nif it disappears except Blanche Manners."\r\n\r\n"All right."\r\n\r\nHe put the disappearer to his eye and blinked. The cat disappeared from\r\nthe sidewalk outside.\r\n\r\nHis mother was interested. "I wonder how it works. 

Do you know how it\r\nworks?"\r\n\r\n"Yes. You take a beer can with both ends cut out and put in two pieces\r\nof cardboard. Then you blink."\r\n\r\n"Never mind. Take it outside and play with it. 

You hadn\'t better make\r\nanything disappear in here till I think about this."\r\n\r\nBut when he had gone his mother was oddly disturbed.\r\n\r\n"I wonder if I have a precocious child. Why, there\'s lots of grown\r\npeople who wouldn\'t know how to make a disappearer that would work. I\r\nwonder if Blanche Manners will miss her cat very much?"\r\n\r\nClarence went down to the Plugged Nickel, a pot house on the corner.\r\n\r\n"Do you have anything you want to make disappear, Nokomis?"\r\n\r\n"Only my paunch."\r\n\r\n"If I make it disappear it\'ll leave a hole in you and you\'ll bleed to\r\ndeath."\r\n\r\n"That\'s right, I would. Why don\'t you try it on the fire plug outside?"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThis in a way was one of the happiest afternoons ever in the\r\nneighborhood. The children came from blocks around to play in the\r\nflooded streets and gutters, and if some of them drowned (and we don\'t\r\nsay that they _did_ drown) in the flood (and brother! it was a flood),\r\nwhy, you have to expect things like that. The fire engines (whoever\r\nheard of calling fire engines to put out a flood?) were apparatus-deep\r\nin the water. The policemen and ambulance men wandered around wet and\r\nbewildered.\r\n\r\n"Resuscitator, resuscitator, anybody wanna resuscitator," chanted\r\nClarissa Willoughby.\r\n\r\n"Oh, shut up," said the ambulance attendants.\r\n\r\nNokomis, the bar man in the Plugged Nickel, called Clarence aside.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t believe, just for the moment, I\'d tell anyone what happened to\r\nthat fire plug," he said.\r\n\r\n"I won\'t tell if you won\'t tell," said Clarence.\r\n\r\nOfficer Comstock was suspicious. "There\'s only seven possible\r\nexplanations. One of the seven Willoughby kids did it. I dunno how.\r\nIt\'d take a bulldozer to do it, and then there\'d be something left of\r\nthe plug. But however they did it, one of them did it."\r\n\r\nOfficer Comstock had a talent for getting near the truth of dark\r\nmatters. This is why he was walking a beat out here in the boondocks\r\ninstead of sitting in a chair downtown.\r\n\r\n"Clarissa!" said Officer Comstock in a voice like thunder.\r\n\r\n"Resuscitator, resuscitator, anybody wanna resuscitator?" chanted\r\nClarissa.\r\n\r\n"Do you know what happened to that fire plug?" asked officer C.\r\n\r\n"I have an uncanny suspicion. As yet it is no more than that. 

When I am\r\nbetter informed I will advise you."\r\n\r\nClarissa was eight years old and much given to uncanny suspicions.\r\n\r\n"Clementine, Harold, Corinne, Jimmy, Cyril," he asked the five younger\r\nWilloughby children. "Do you know what happened to that fire plug?"\r\n\r\n"There was a man around yesterday. I bet he took it," said Clementine.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t even remember a fire plug there. I think you\'re making a lot\r\nof fuss about nothing," said Harold.\r\n\r\n"City hall\'s going to hear about this," said Corinne.\r\n\r\n"Pretty dommed sure," said Jimmy, "but I wont tell."\r\n\r\n"Cyril!" cried Officer Comstock in a terrible voice. Not a terrifying\r\nvoice, a terrible voice. He felt terrible now.\r\n\r\n"Great green bananas," said Cyril, "I\'m only three years old. I don\'t\r\nsee how it\'s even my responsibility."\r\n\r\n"Clarence," said Officer Comstock.\r\n\r\nClarence gulped.\r\n\r\n"Do you know where that fire plug went?"\r\n\r\nClarence brightened. 

"No, sir. 

I don\'t know where it went."\r\n\r\nA bunch of smart alecs from the water department came out and shut off\r\nthe water for a few blocks around and put some kind of cap on in place\r\nof the fire plug. "This sure is going to be a funny-sounding report,"\r\nsaid one of them.\r\n\r\nOfficer Comstock walked away discouraged. "Don\'t bother me, Miss\r\nManners," he said. "I don\'t know where to look for your cat. I don\'t\r\neven know where to look for a fire plug."\r\n\r\n"I have an idea," said Clarissa, "that when you find the cat you will\r\nfind the fire plug the same place. As yet it is only an idea."\r\n\r\nOzzie Murphy wore a little hat on top of his head. Clarence pointed\r\nhis weapon and winked. The hat was no longer there, but a little\r\ntrickle of blood was running down the pate.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t believe I\'d play with that any more," said Nokomis.\r\n\r\n"Who\'s playing?" said Clarence. 

"This is for real."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThis was the beginning of the seven-day terror in the heretofore\r\nobscure neighborhood. Trees disappeared from the parkings; lamp posts\r\nwere as though they had never been; Wally Waldorf drove home, got out,\r\nslammed the door of his car, and there was no car. As George Mullendorf\r\ncame up the walk to his house his dog Pete ran to meet him and took\r\na flying leap to his arms. The dog left the sidewalk but something\r\nhappened; the dog was gone and only a bark lingered for a moment in the\r\npuzzled air.\r\n\r\nBut the worst were the fire plugs. The second plug was installed the\r\nmorning after the disappearance of the first. In eight minutes it\r\nwas gone and the flood waters returned. Another one was in by twelve\r\no\'clock. Within three minutes it had vanished. The next morning fire\r\nplug number four was installed.\r\n\r\nThe water commissioner was there, the city engineer was there, the\r\nchief of police was there with a riot squad, the president of the\r\nparent-teachers association was there, the president of the University\r\nwas there, the mayor was there, three gentlemen of the F.B.I., a\r\nnewsreel photographer, eminent scientists and a crowd of honest\r\ncitizens.\r\n\r\n"Let\'s see it disappear now," said the city engineer.\r\n\r\n"Let\'s see it disappear now," said the police chief.\r\n\r\n"Let\'s see it disa--it did, didn\'t it?" said one of the eminent\r\nscientists.\r\n\r\nAnd it was gone and everybody was very wet.\r\n\r\n"At least I have the picture sequence of the year," said the\r\nphotographer. But his camera and apparatus disappeared from the midst\r\nof them.\r\n\r\n"Shut off the water and cap it," said the commissioner. "And don\'t put\r\nin another plug yet. That was the last plug in the warehouse."\r\n\r\n"This is too big for me," said the mayor. "I wonder that Tass doesn\'t\r\nhave it yet."\r\n\r\n"Tass has it," said a little round man. "I am Tass."\r\n\r\n"If all of you gentlemen will come into the Plugged Nickel," said\r\nNokomis, "and try one of our new Fire Hydrant Highballs you will all be\r\nhappier. These are made of good corn whisky, brown sugar and hydrant\r\nwater from this very gutter. You can be the first to drink them."\r\n\r\nBusiness was phenomenal at the Plugged Nickel, for it was in front of\r\nits very doors that the fire plugs disappeared in floods of gushing\r\nwater.\r\n\r\n"I know a way we can get rich," said Clarissa several days later to her\r\nfather, Tom Willoughby. "Everybody says they\'re going to sell their\r\nhouses for nothing and move out of the neighborhood. Go get a lot of\r\nmoney and buy them all. Then you can sell them again and get rich."\r\n\r\n"I wouldn\'t buy them for a dollar each. Three of them have disappeared\r\nalready, and all the families but us have their furniture moved out\r\nin their front yards. There might be nothing but vacant lots in the\r\nmorning."\r\n\r\n"Good, then buy the vacant lots. And you can be ready when the houses\r\ncome back."\r\n\r\n"Come back? Are the houses going to come back? Do you know anything\r\nabout this, young lady?"\r\n\r\n"I have a suspicion verging on a certainty. 

As of now I can say no\r\nmore."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThree eminent scientists were gathered in an untidy suite that looked\r\nas though it belonged to a drunken sultan.\r\n\r\n"This transcends the meta-physical. It impinges on the quantum\r\ncontinuum. In some ways it obsoletes Boff," said Dr. Velikof Vonk.\r\n\r\n"The contingence on the intransigence is the most mystifying aspect,"\r\nsaid Arpad Arkabaranan.\r\n\r\n"Yes," said Willy McGilly. "Who would have thought that you could do it\r\nwith a beer can and two pieces of cardboard? When I was a boy I used\r\nan oatmeal box and red crayola."\r\n\r\n"I do not always follow you," said Dr. Vonk. "I wish you would speak\r\nplainer."\r\n\r\nSo far no human had been injured or disappeared--except for a little\r\nblood on the pate of Ozzie Murphy, on the lobes of Conchita when her\r\ngaudy earrings disappeared from her very ears, a clipped finger or so\r\nwhen a house vanished as the front door knob was touched, a lost toe\r\nwhen a neighborhood boy kicked at a can and the can was not; probably\r\nnot more than a pint of blood and three or four ounces of flesh all\r\ntogether.\r\n\r\nNow, however, Mr. Buckle the grocery man disappeared before witnesses.\r\nThis was serious.\r\n\r\nSome mean-looking investigators from downtown came out to the\r\nWilloughbys. The meanest-looking one was the mayor. In happier days he\r\nhad not been a mean man, but the terror had now reigned for seven days.\r\n\r\n"There have been ugly rumors," said one of the mean investigators,\r\n"that link certain events to this household. Do any of you know\r\nanything about them?

"\r\n\r\n"I started most of them," said Clarissa. "But I didn\'t consider them\r\nugly. Cryptic, rather. But if you want to get to the bottom of this\r\njust ask me a question."\r\n\r\n"Did you make those things disappear?" asked the investigator.\r\n\r\n"That isn\'t the question," said Clarissa.\r\n\r\n"Do you know where they have gone?" asked the investigator.\r\n\r\n"That isn\'t the question either," said Clarissa.\r\n\r\n"Can you make them come back?"\r\n\r\n"Why, of course I can. 

Anybody can. Can\'t you?"\r\n\r\n"I cannot. If you can, please do so at once."\r\n\r\n"I need some stuff. Get me a gold watch and a hammer. Then go down to\r\nthe drug store and get me this list of chemicals. And I need a yard of\r\nblack velvet and a pound of rock candy."\r\n\r\n"Shall we?" asked one of the investigators.\r\n\r\n"Yes," said the mayor, "it\'s our only hope. Get her anything she wants."\r\n\r\nAnd it was all assembled.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Why does she get all the attention?" asked Clarence. "I was the one\r\nthat made all the things disappear. How does she know how to get them\r\nback?"\r\n\r\n"I knew it!" cried Clarissa with hate. "I knew he was the one that did\r\nit. He read in my diary how to make a disappearer. If I was his mother\r\nI\'d whip him for reading his little sister\'s diary. That\'s what happens\r\nwhen things like that fall into irresponsible hands."\r\n\r\nShe poised the hammer over the gold watch of the mayor on the floor.\r\n\r\n"I have to wait a few seconds. This can\'t be hurried. 

It\'ll be only a\r\nlittle while."\r\n\r\nThe second hand swept around to the point that was preordained for it\r\nbefore the world began. Clarissa suddenly brought down the hammer with\r\nall her force on the beautiful gold watch.\r\n\r\n"That\'s all," she said. "Your troubles are over. See, there is Blanche\r\nManners\' cat on the sidewalk just where she was seven days ago."\r\n\r\nAnd the cat was back.\r\n\r\n"Now let\'s go down to the Plugged Nickel and watch the fire plug come\r\nback."\r\n\r\nThey had only a few minutes to wait. It came from nowhere and clanged\r\ninto the street like a sign and a witness.\r\n\r\n"Now I predict," said Clarissa, "that every single object will return\r\nexactly seven days from the time of its disappearance."\r\n\r\nThe seven-day terror had ended. The objects began to reappear.\r\n\r\n"How," asked the mayor, "did you know they would come back in seven\r\ndays?"\r\n\r\n"Because it was a seven-day disappearer that Clarence made. I also know\r\nhow to make a nine-day, a thirteen-day, a twenty-seven-day, and an\r\neleven-year disappearer. I was going to make a thirteen-day one, but\r\nfor that you have to color the ends with the blood from a little boy\'s\r\nheart, and Cyril cried every time I tried to make a good cut."\r\n\r\n"You really know how to make all of these?"\r\n\r\n"Yes. 

But I shudder if the knowledge should ever come into unauthorized\r\nhands."\r\n\r\n"I shudder too, Clarissa. But tell me, why did you want the chemicals?"\r\n\r\n"For my chemistry set."\r\n\r\n"And the black velvet?"\r\n\r\n"For doll dresses."\r\n\r\n"And the pound of rock candy?"\r\n\r\n"How did you ever get to be mayor of this town if you have to ask\r\nquestions like that? What do you think I wanted the rock candy for?"\r\n\r\n"One last question," said the mayor. "Why did you smash my gold watch\r\nwith the hammer?"\r\n\r\n"Oh," said Clarissa, "that was for dramatic effect."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


Not\r\njust the title or the preface, or a page somewhere in the middle. He\r\nwanted to read the whole thing, all the way through from beginning to\r\nend. A simple ambition perhaps, but in the cluttered life of Henry\r\nBemis, an impossibility.\r\n\r\nHenry had no time of his own. There was his wife, Agnes who owned that\r\npart of it that his employer, Mr. Carsville, did not buy. Henry was\r\nallowed enough to get to and from work--that in itself being quite a\r\nconcession on Agnes\' part.\r\n\r\nAlso, nature had conspired against Henry by handing him with a pair of\r\nhopelessly myopic eyes. Poor Henry literally couldn\'t see his hand in\r\nfront of his face. For a while, when he was very young, his parents\r\nhad thought him an idiot. When they realized it was his eyes, they got\r\nglasses for him. He was never quite able to catch up. 

There was never\r\nenough time. It looked as though Henry\'s ambition would never be\r\nrealized. Then something happened which changed all that.\r\n\r\nHenry was down in the vault of the Eastside Bank & Trust when it\r\nhappened. He had stolen a few moments from the duties of his teller\'s\r\ncage to try to read a few pages of the magazine he had bought that\r\nmorning. He\'d made an excuse to Mr. Carsville about needing bills in\r\nlarge denominations for a certain customer, and then, safe inside the\r\ndim recesses of the vault he had pulled from inside his coat the\r\npocket size magazine.\r\n\r\nHe had just started a picture article cheerfully entitled "The New\r\nWeapons and What They\'ll Do To YOU", when all the noise in the world\r\ncrashed in upon his ear-drums. It seemed to be inside of him and\r\noutside of him all at once. Then the concrete floor was rising up at\r\nhim and the ceiling came slanting down toward him, and for a fleeting\r\nsecond Henry thought of a story he had started to read once called\r\n"The Pit and The Pendulum". He regretted in that insane moment that he\r\nhad never had time to finish that story to see how it came out. Then\r\nall was darkness and quiet and unconsciousness.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWhen Henry came to, he knew that something was desperately wrong with\r\nthe Eastside Bank & Trust. The heavy steel door of the vault was\r\nbuckled and twisted and the floor tilted up at a dizzy angle, while\r\nthe ceiling dipped crazily toward it. Henry gingerly got to his feet,\r\nmoving arms and legs experimentally. Assured that nothing was broken,\r\nhe tenderly raised a hand to his eyes. His precious glasses were\r\nintact, thank God! He would never have been able to find his way out\r\nof the shattered vault without them.\r\n\r\nHe made a mental note to write Dr. Torrance to have a spare pair made\r\nand mailed to him. Blasted nuisance not having his prescription on\r\nfile locally, but Henry trusted no-one but Dr. Torrance to grind those\r\nthick lenses into his own complicated prescription. Henry removed the\r\nheavy glasses from his face. Instantly the room dissolved into a\r\nneutral blur. Henry saw a pink splash that he knew was his hand, and a\r\nwhite blob come up to meet the pink as he withdrew his pocket\r\nhandkerchief and carefully dusted the lenses. As he replaced the\r\nglasses, they slipped down on the bridge of his nose a little. He had\r\nbeen meaning to have them tightened for some time.\r\n\r\nHe suddenly realized, without the realization actually entering his\r\nconscious thoughts, that something momentous had happened, something\r\nworse than the boiler blowing up, something worse than a gas main\r\nexploding, something worse than anything that had ever happened\r\nbefore. He felt that way because it was so quiet. There was no whine\r\nof sirens, no shouting, no running, just an ominous and all pervading\r\nsilence.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHenry walked across the slanting floor. Slipping and stumbling on the\r\nuneven surface, he made his way to the elevator. The car lay crumpled\r\nat the foot of the shaft like a discarded accordian. There was\r\nsomething inside of it that Henry could not look at, something that\r\nhad once been a person, or perhaps several people, it was impossible\r\nto tell now.\r\n\r\nFeeling sick, Henry staggered toward the stairway. The steps were\r\nstill there, but so jumbled and piled back upon one another that it\r\nwas more like climbing the side of a mountain than mounting a\r\nstairway. It was quiet in the huge chamber that had been the lobby of\r\nthe bank. It looked strangely cheerful with the sunlight shining\r\nthrough the girders where the ceiling had fallen. The dappled sunlight\r\nglinted across the silent lobby, and everywhere there were huddled\r\nlumps of unpleasantness that made Henry sick as he tried not to look\r\nat them.\r\n\r\n"Mr. Carsville," he called. It was very quiet. 

Something had to be\r\ndone, of course. This was terrible, right in the middle of a Monday,\r\ntoo. Mr. Carsville would know what to do. He called again, more\r\nloudly, and his voice cracked hoarsely, "Mr. Carrrrsville!" And then\r\nhe saw an arm and shoulder extending out from under a huge fallen\r\nblock of marble ceiling. In the buttonhole was the white carnation Mr.\r\nCarsville had worn to work that morning, and on the third finger of\r\nthat hand was a massive signet ring, also belonging to Mr. Carsville.\r\nNumbly, Henry realized that the rest of Mr. Carsville was under that\r\nblock of marble.\r\n\r\nHenry felt a pang of real sorrow. Mr. Carsville was gone, and so was\r\nthe rest of the staff--Mr. Wilkinson and Mr. 

Emory and Mr. 

Prithard,\r\nand the same with Pete and Ralph and Jenkins and Hunter and Pat the\r\nguard and Willie the doorman. There was no one to say what was to be\r\ndone about the Eastside Bank & Trust except Henry Bemis, and Henry\r\nwasn\'t worried about the bank, there was something he wanted to do.\r\n\r\nHe climbed carefully over piles of fallen masonry. Once he stepped\r\ndown into something that crunched and squashed beneath his feet and he\r\nset his teeth on edge to keep from retching. The street was not much\r\ndifferent from the inside, bright sunlight and so much concrete to\r\ncrawl over, but the unpleasantness was much, much worse. Everywhere\r\nthere were strange, motionless lumps that Henry could not look at.\r\n\r\nSuddenly, he remembered Agnes. He should be trying to get to Agnes,\r\nshouldn\'t he? He remembered a poster he had seen that said, "In event\r\nof emergency do not use the telephone, your loved ones are as safe as\r\nyou." He wondered about Agnes. He looked at the smashed automobiles,\r\nsome with their four wheels pointing skyward like the stiffened legs\r\nof dead animals. He couldn\'t get to Agnes now anyway, if she was safe,\r\nthen, she was safe, otherwise ... of course, Henry knew Agnes wasn\'t\r\nsafe. He had a feeling that there wasn\'t anyone safe for a long, long\r\nway, maybe not in the whole state or the whole country, or the whole\r\nworld. No, that was a thought Henry didn\'t want to think, he forced it\r\nfrom his mind and turned his thoughts back to Agnes.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nShe had been a pretty good wife, now that it was all said and done. It\r\nwasn\'t exactly her fault if people didn\'t have time to read nowadays.\r\nIt was just that there was the house, and the bank, and the yard.\r\nThere were the Jones\' for bridge and the Graysons\' for canasta and\r\ncharades with the Bryants. And the television, the television Agnes\r\nloved to watch, but would never watch alone. He never had time to read\r\neven a newspaper. He started thinking about last night, that business\r\nabout the newspaper.\r\n\r\nHenry had settled into his chair, quietly, afraid that a creaking\r\nspring might call to Agnes\' attention the fact that he was momentarily\r\nunoccupied. He had unfolded the newspaper slowly and carefully, the\r\nsharp crackle of the paper would have been a clarion call to Agnes. He\r\nhad glanced at the headlines of the first page. "Collapse Of\r\nConference Imminent." He didn\'t have time to read the article. He\r\nturned to the second page. "Solon Predicts War Only Days Away." He\r\nflipped through the pages faster, reading brief snatches here and\r\nthere, afraid to spend too much time on any one item. On a back page\r\nwas a brief article entitled, "Prehistoric Artifacts Unearthed In\r\nYucatan". Henry smiled to himself and carefully folded the sheet of\r\npaper into fourths. 

That would be interesting, he would read all of\r\nit. Then it came, Agnes\' voice. "Henrrreee!" 

And then she was upon\r\nhim. She lightly flicked the paper out of his hands and into the\r\nfireplace. He saw the flames lick up and curl possessively around the\r\nunread article. Agnes continued, "Henry, tonight is the Jones\' bridge\r\nnight. They\'ll be here in thirty minutes and I\'m not dressed yet, and\r\nhere you are ... 

_reading_." She had emphasized the last word as\r\nthough it were an unclean act. "Hurry and shave, you know how smooth\r\nJasper Jones\' chin always looks, and then straighten up this room."\r\nShe glanced regretfully toward the fireplace. "Oh dear, that paper,\r\nthe television schedule ... oh well, after the Jones leave there won\'t\r\nbe time for anything but the late-late movie and.... Don\'t just sit\r\nthere, Henry, hurrreeee!"\r\n\r\nHenry was hurrying now, but hurrying too much. He cut his leg on a\r\ntwisted piece of metal that had once been an automobile fender. He\r\nthought about things like lock-jaw and gangrene and his hand trembled\r\nas he tied his pocket-handkerchief around the wound. In his mind, he\r\nsaw the fire again, licking across the face of last night\'s newspaper.\r\nHe thought that now he would have time to read all the newspapers he\r\nwanted to, only now there wouldn\'t be any more. That heap of rubble\r\nacross the street had been the Gazette Building. It was terrible to\r\nthink there would never be another up to date newspaper. Agnes would\r\nhave been very upset, no television schedule. But then, of course, no\r\ntelevision. 

He wanted to laugh but he didn\'t. That wouldn\'t have been\r\nfitting, not at all.\r\n\r\nHe could see the building he was looking for now, but the silhouette\r\nwas strangely changed. The great circular dome was now a ragged\r\nsemi-circle, half of it gone, and one of the great wings of the\r\nbuilding had fallen in upon itself. A sudden panic gripped Henry\r\nBemis. What if they were all ruined, destroyed, every one of them?\r\nWhat if there wasn\'t a single one left? Tears of helplessness welled\r\nin his eyes as he painfully fought his way over and through the\r\ntwisted fragments of the city.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe thought of the building when it had been whole. He remembered the\r\nmany nights he had paused outside its wide and welcoming doors. He\r\nthought of the warm nights when the doors had been thrown open and he\r\ncould see the people inside, see them sitting at the plain wooden\r\ntables with the stacks of books beside them. He used to think then,\r\nwhat a wonderful thing a public library was, a place where anybody,\r\nanybody at all could go in and read.\r\n\r\nHe had been tempted to enter many times. He had watched the people\r\nthrough the open doors, the man in greasy work clothes who sat near\r\nthe door, night after night, laboriously studying, a technical journal\r\nperhaps, difficult for him, but promising a brighter future. There had\r\nbeen an aged, scholarly gentleman who sat on the other side of the\r\ndoor, leisurely paging, moving his lips a little as he did so, a man\r\nhaving little time left, but rich in time because he could do with it\r\nas he chose.\r\n\r\nHenry had never gone in. He had started up the steps once, got almost\r\nto the door, but then he remembered Agnes, her questions and shouting,\r\nand he had turned away.\r\n\r\nHe was going in now though, almost crawling, his breath coming in\r\nstabbing gasps, his hands torn and bleeding. His trouser leg was\r\nsticky red where the wound in his leg had soaked through the\r\nhandkerchief. It was throbbing badly but Henry didn\'t care. He had\r\nreached his destination.\r\n\r\nPart of the inscription was still there, over the now doorless\r\nentrance. P-U-B--C L-I-B-R---. The rest had been torn away. The place\r\nwas in shambles. The shelves were overturned, broken, smashed, tilted,\r\ntheir precious contents spilled in disorder upon the floor. A lot of\r\nthe books, Henry noted gleefully, were still intact, still whole,\r\nstill readable. He was literally knee deep in them, he wallowed in\r\nbooks. He picked one up. The title was "Collected Works of William\r\nShakespeare." Yes, he must read that, sometime. He laid it aside\r\ncarefully. He picked up another. Spinoza. He tossed it away, seized\r\nanother, and another, and still another. 

Which to read first ... there\r\nwere so many.\r\n\r\nHe had been conducting himself a little like a starving man in a\r\ndelicatessen--grabbing a little of this and a little of that in a\r\nfrenzy of enjoyment.\r\n\r\nBut now he steadied away. From the pile about him, he selected one\r\nvolume, sat comfortably down on an overturned shelf, and opened the\r\nbook.\r\n\r\nHenry Bemis smiled.\r\n\r\nThere was the rumble of complaining stone. Minute in comparison with\r\nthe epic complaints following the fall of the bomb. This one occurred\r\nunder one corner of the shelf upon which Henry sat. 

The shelf moved;\r\nthrew him off balance. The glasses slipped from his nose and fell with\r\na tinkle.\r\n\r\nHe bent down, clawing blindly and found, finally, their smashed\r\nremains. A minor, indirect destruction stemming from the sudden,\r\nwholesale smashing of a city. But the only one that greatly interested\r\nHenry Bemis.\r\n\r\nHe stared down at the blurred page before him.\r\n\r\nHe began to cry.\r\n\r\n\r\n                    THE END\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\n_You better take your money back, mister. Thanks a lot but--no thanks.\r\nI wasn\'t panhandling, my hat fell off and I was trying to find it on\r\nthe sidewalk. Thanks again for finding it for me but I think I could\r\nhave managed. 

And, no offense, but I can find my way all right without\r\nbeing led._\r\n\r\n_You\'re surprised that I\'m rather young, huh? Well, youth isn\'t a\r\ncrime and anyways, twenty-four can be either young or old, depending on\r\nwho you\'re talking to. But I know what you mean. I\'m rather young for\r\nbeing blind, isn\'t that it? Most blind people you see on the streets\r\nare the old ones, the shabby ones with the pleading faces and the hat\r\nwith the lead pencils in it or maybe a tin cup and a violin. Sorry to\r\ndisappoint you but I guess I\'m not the type._\r\n\r\n_Sure, I know--you were only trying to help. You probably think I\'m\r\nbitter because I can\'t see your world and all the wonderful things in\r\nit. Well, it\'s a long story but that\'s not the punch line. I might be\r\nbitter but not for the reasons you might think. Up until two weeks\r\nago I could see as well as you. And you couldn\'t call what happened\r\n"losing" my sight. Not exactly._\r\n\r\n_So you\'re curious. 

You want to hear the rest of it. And you\'re sure\r\nit\'s not just out of sympathy. 

Well, all right. There\'s a bar in the\r\nnext block where we can get a booth and a couple of beers._\r\n\r\n_Now look, I don\'t need to be led! You don\'t need eyes to find your\r\nway to a bar on a hot summer day like this. It\'s toward the end of the\r\nblock, just a few steps further.... Right here. There\'s a booth in the\r\nback where nobody will bother us for a while._\r\n\r\n_Okay, make mine the same and here\'s half a dollar to pay for them.\r\nDon\'t worry, I\'ve got money enough to keep me in beer and pretzels for\r\na long time. Nobody could accuse the professor of being stingy with the\r\nuniversity funds when he paid me off._\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIt began about six months ago. I was in my third year at college,\r\nstudying physics under Professor Martin. Maybe you\'ve seen Martin\r\naround the campus--a rather thin guy with a face like the Rock of\r\nGibraltar. One of the few profs who can still sound enthusiastic about\r\ntheir subject after twenty years of teaching it.\r\n\r\nThe unit we were studying at the time was the one on light and physical\r\noptics, primarily a study of the spectrum stretching from x-rays beyond\r\nthe ultra-violet to the visible spectrum, down to the infra-red and\r\nradio waves and the short waves used in television and radar. I had\r\nbeen absent from class a week and on my return the professor invited me\r\nto dinner. After the dishes had been cleared away he leaned back in his\r\nchair and lit what I took to be his usual after dinner cigar.\r\n\r\n"I like to meet my students informally, Charles," he began. "Sorry that\r\nyour wife couldn\'t come but I understand she\'s ... well...." He let the\r\nsentence trail off.\r\n\r\nI sat there feeling rather sick. It\'s one of those things you hope\r\neverybody has heard about so you don\'t have to explain, to sit and\r\ntake their looks of pity and sympathy. Apparently the professor hadn\'t\r\nheard. "I\'m sorry," I said. 

"I thought you knew. Both Alice and the\r\nbaby died."\r\n\r\nThe hand he held his cigar in quivered a little. 

"I\'m sorry," he said,\r\nand mercifully dropped it there. Then he changed the subject to the one\r\nhe had in mind when he had asked me to dinner.\r\n\r\n"Light, Charles, is such a large subject--and, comparatively speaking,\r\nso little is known about it. But perhaps--perhaps I know more than\r\nmost. And if you wish, you can too. Would you like to see the world you\r\nlive in, Charles? Not just the one tenth of one percent that they call\r\nthe visible spectrum, but all of it, the whole glorious universe of\r\nlight?"\r\n\r\nHe took me into his confidence on his favorite research project, an\r\nattempt to see wavelengths other than those in the visible spectrum.\r\nHis enthusiasm was catching and there wasn\'t much hesitation. I signed\r\nthe paper releasing the university from all responsibility in case\r\nof an "accident." So easy to sign one\'s life away--though it wasn\'t\r\nactually my life, only my eyesight.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe treatments began immediately. First, adaptation of vision to a\r\ndark room, like those used for flyers during the war. Then the drops\r\nof black liquid that the professor had invented, slowly spreading over\r\nthe eyes, subtly altering the rods and cones of the retina, the nerve\r\nendings sensitive to light.\r\n\r\nAnd I began to live in a gradually fading world. Have you ever wondered\r\nwhat it\'s like to go blind? The increasing dusk and darkness around the\r\nedges of your vision, the little errors and mistakes that begin to crop\r\nup in everyday life. Your blunder over a stool that you didn\'t quite\r\nsee, your snubbing someone on the street whom you didn\'t recognize in\r\ntime, the gradual awareness among your friends that something was\r\nwrong with your eyes and their crude attempts to make it "easier" for\r\nyou.\r\n\r\nFor to all intents and purposes I was going blind. My "range" of vision\r\nremained the same but it was shifting down the scale. The first colors\r\nto fade out of my vision were violet and blue and their tints. The sky\r\noverhead gradually became colorless, magazine covers began to lose\r\ntheir appeal and slip into a bleak blending of yellows and reds. Then\r\nslowly, the other colors began to grow dim and less distinct until\r\nfinally even red had faded from my sight.\r\n\r\nBut there were other colors that replaced them. Brilliant,\r\nscintillating colors that made seeing an adventure.\r\n\r\nDescribe them to you? How could you describe "red" and "green" to a\r\nperson who was blind from birth? How can I describe iridescent and\r\nvliosheen to you? Do you think you could understand? Do you think you\r\ncould "see" what I mean?\r\n\r\nOh, I could still get around in your world. I could still "see" people.\r\nAll objects radiate heat, even ice. As an object\'s temperature goes up,\r\nthe wavelength of the radiation given off goes up to the infra-red,\r\nthen into the visible. I could tell how hot water was by looking at it.\r\nI could see people by the heat they gave off, glowing figures moving\r\ndown the street and around the lab!\r\n\r\nAnd still my range of vision shifted. Down to short waves and radio\r\nwaves, the language of international communication, the wavelengths\r\nthat continents and countries speak to each other in. Do you know how\r\nbeautiful the aerial of your radio is, the different waves running down\r\nit like ripples across a pond? Have you ever seen the glorious pool\r\nof light around a radio broadcasting station? Have you ever marveled\r\nat the thin, trailing filaments of color tangling in the nest of\r\ntelevision antennas that the city carries on its rooftops?\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe professor was worried, for along with losing my sight of this\r\nworld, I began to lose interest in it. A truly blind man wouldn\'t\r\nfor he has nothing to replace vision with, he\'s still bound to the\r\ncommonplace globe. He can improve his hearing or his sense of touch,\r\nbut nothing replaces his sight. It was different with me. I was seeing\r\nsomething far more interesting than the dull, mundane world.\r\n\r\nThey fixed a cot up for me in the laboratory; an experiment like myself\r\nwas far too important to risk on the streets. Even then, I\'d bump into\r\ntables or smash lab apparatus. I suppose an important experiment like I\r\nwas should have taken care of itself, sort of like a self-lubricating\r\nmotor. I\'d cost the university lots of money and I suppose I should\r\nhave watched out for their investment--though I was probably the only\r\none who _didn\'t_ care what happened to me.\r\n\r\nThere finally came a day when my eyes didn\'t change. I had reached a\r\nsticking point. The end of the spectrum? The professor said he didn\'t\r\nthink so.\r\n\r\nI didn\'t think so either for just beyond my range of vision seemed a\r\nhint of something else. I caught "glimpses" of something--I couldn\'t\r\nmake out exactly what. There seemed to be vague suggestions of form\r\nand color and life, indistinct figures that capered and grimaced just\r\nbeyond my view. There was nothing definite, nothing that I could draw\r\na picture of and describe like you could an automobile or a building.\r\nThere were just suggestions, a feeling of something more. There was a\r\nhint of life in the masses of winking light that beckoned and burned.\r\n\r\nThe next day the professor brought my eyes back to normal. Familiar\r\nobjects had a sudden fascination that quickly faded when I had regained\r\nnormal vision for an hour or so. It was a prosaic world once again.\r\nRadios and aerials were just--cabinets of wood and plastic and glass\r\ntubes and strips of rusty wire and metal.\r\n\r\nI wasn\'t sure the experiment was over. I asked the professor if there\r\nwas anything that would take me further along the scale, beyond,\r\nperhaps, even the spectrum as we knew it.\r\n\r\nHe twisted his hands nervously behind his back and walked over and\r\nlooked out the laboratory window. "I could do it for you, Charles, but\r\nI\'m not sure that I could bring you back. Your eyes would be stranded\r\nin that world of yours. 

You could never look at ours again."\r\n\r\nHe turned from the window and faced me.\r\n\r\n"Why don\'t you forget it for a few weeks and then come back here and if\r\nyou still want to, we\'ll continue the experiment."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI agreed and left. I spent the next two weeks doing nothing but looking\r\nat our world. Do you think you really appreciate your sight? If you\r\nknew you had but a few weeks of sight left, what would you do with it?\r\nVisit famous landmarks? See the country? 

If you thought about it, I\r\nthink you\'d do the same as I did. I began to enjoy what was close at\r\nhand, the surroundings I had lived in. Everyday sights held a certain\r\nfascination for me. The stark black and white mosaic of a city at the\r\ntag end of winter; the sheer, raucous color of the magazines at your\r\nlocal newsstand; the smooth patterns of hues and tints in a department\r\nstore window display.\r\n\r\nAnd how much do you appreciate springtime? The few weeks of the year\r\nwhen the city loses its look of drabness and little plots of grass and\r\nflowers add color to it--like brilliant strips of cloth in a dirty\r\npatchwork quilt. Then there were the kids roller skating down the\r\nsidewalks, the girls\' pigtails flying and the boys\' knickers flapping\r\nin the breeze. And later on, in the business blocks, the soft glow of\r\nneon against the swirling fog of a warm spring night.\r\n\r\nThat was the last spring I\'ll ever see. I\'ll be able to smell the\r\nflowers and feel the warmth of the sun and run my fingers through the\r\ngreen grass. But I\'ll never see it again.\r\n\r\nAfter the few weeks were up I returned to the professor--still curious\r\nabout what lay beyond the spectrum limits. There were the eye washes\r\nand the drops and then the heavy strips of white cloth wrapped around\r\nmy head, keeping your world out and bounding mine with a rim of black.\r\nMy last look at the world was of some kids playing in the city streets,\r\nand some bread crumbs spread out on the window sill for the birds.\r\nAfter that a quick view of the lab--a jungle of glass retorts and vats\r\nfilled with oily chemicals--and a closeup of Professor Martin\'s gnarled\r\nhands holding the bandages for my eyes.\r\n\r\nI lay on the cot in the lab for the next few days, listening to your\r\nworld and feeling it and remembering it; the good and the bad, the\r\nadventuresome and the dull. I could hear the newsboy hawking his papers\r\nand the shouts of the kids and the clatter of the main street trolley.\r\nI could smell the factory smoke and the heavy, animal odor drifting up\r\nfrom the stockyards. I could hear the people in the lab and Professor\r\nMartin scurrying about, asking me how I felt, and toward the end,\r\ntelling me that in a few hours the bandages would come off.\r\n\r\nTwo weeks ago the professor came into the lab and started tearing at\r\nthe adhesive, stripping away the layers of white cloth. Even when he\r\nhad the bandages all the way off, I kept my eyes closed, almost afraid\r\nto open them.\r\n\r\nMy eyes had to focus first. Everything was so damned brilliant and\r\nindistinct. Then my sight cleared and suddenly everything was very\r\nplain.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n_Well, that\'s about it. There isn\'t much more to tell. 

It hasn\'t been\r\ntoo boring to listen to me for fifteen minutes, has it? I can tell you\r\nhaven\'t been too bored because you haven\'t touched your beer, have you?\r\nIt\'s getting warm--and you know what they say about warm beer...._\r\n\r\n_What did I see? You really want to know, don\'t you?_\r\n\r\n_Well, I\'ve tried to rationalize it and explain it and I suppose I\r\ncan, in a dim way. 

Put it this way: I\'m totally blind now. What\'s\r\nbright to you is black to me. But I\'m not bitter because I can\'t see_\r\nyour _world. And I can\'t describe to you what I saw because, you see, I\r\ndon\'t remember. 

Perhaps it\'s merciful, I don\'t know. I can only guess\r\nfrom what the professor told me._\r\n\r\n_Professor Martin had stripped the bandages from my eyes and he and a\r\nfew assistants saw my eyes blur and finally focus on something in a\r\ndifferent world from theirs. And then, before I fainted, I screamed the\r\none word that none of them would ever forget._\r\n\r\n"_ALICE!_"\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nGeorge Washington was the father of his country.\r\n\r\nI am not George Washington. My name is Andrew Jones, and it is because\r\nof me there will be no more Joneses in the world. There will be, in\r\nfact, no more anybody.\r\n\r\nThis is the end of the world.\r\n\r\nIt did not come through fire or ice, with a bang or a whimper, from\r\nsolar catastrophe or man\'s suicidal mis-use of atomic power or any\r\nof the other fearful possibilities with which the Sunday-supplement\r\nwriters once terrified us. It came through the exposure of an age-old\r\nconspiracy.\r\n\r\nI did it. My excuse is the eternal excuse of the scientist: I sought\r\nthe truth. How it was used was not my concern.\r\n\r\nBut that it should have led to the depopulation of the Earth concerns\r\nme, as it must concern every man, and I have an unshakable feeling of\r\nguilt.\r\n\r\nPerhaps I write this now in the hope that I may somehow purge myself. I\r\nknow that it will never be read.\r\n\r\nThe linen wick gutters in the saucer of melted tallow. 

It casts strange\r\nshadows on the cellar wall. Sometimes I think that they are the ghosts\r\nof children come to haunt me, the ghosts of all the little children who\r\nwill never be born.\r\n\r\nBut this is not what I sat down to write while I waited for Lindsay to\r\nreturn. What is keeping Lindsay? He should be back by now.\r\n\r\nI will begin again.\r\n\r\nMy name is Andrew Jones, and today, by my figures, is October 3, 1969.\r\nThe weather is turning cold here, and soon we must go looking for\r\nanother hiding place. My joints are getting old; the damp has seeped\r\ninto them. I long for the year-long warmth of California or Florida,\r\nbut those areas are still crowded and deadly.\r\n\r\nSomeone would recognize me.\r\n\r\nI think we will try a powerhouse again this winter. Often they have\r\nsupplies of coal large enough to last us through the cold weather\r\nwithout extra foraging.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nCataclysm began in 1954, June 13 to be exact. That was the day my\r\nsecond child was born, a boy we named Kevin.\r\n\r\nIt is surprising that a man who was the father of two children should\r\naccuse himself of depopulating the Earth. And yet it is because I was\r\nthe father of two children that it happened.\r\n\r\nPre-natal care of mothers and post-natal care of infants were\r\nsubjects of compelling interest in those days, arriving monthly in\r\nthe burgeoning women\'s magazines and annually in the proliferous\r\nchild-care manuals. Pediatricians and mothers besieged parents with\r\nadvice, and we consumed everything with catholic appetite: logical,\r\nillogical, sensible, insensible, nonsensical, self-contradictory.\r\n\r\nThey kept us on our toes, strung as taut as Stradivarius violins,\r\nafraid to act for fear we would do the wrong thing, afraid not to act\r\nfor fear inaction would be disastrous. Pediatricians and mothers,\r\nalways the same authors. Never were there any articles on the care of\r\nmother and child by a father, only by what I came to think of as the\r\nvested interests.\r\n\r\nI was slow, I admit; but what father has not been slow? Who, if he had\r\nnot been slow, would be a father?\r\n\r\nThe books and the articles would have been troublesome enough if the\r\ninformation they imparted had been accurate. But slowly I became aware\r\nthat they were subtly interwoven with mis-statements.\r\n\r\nI raveled them out, I categorized them. I counted five different kinds\r\nbefore I convinced myself.\r\n\r\nA mother published this: "One baby takes up all your time--two can\'t\r\ntake any more."\r\n\r\nThe fallacy was obvious. A certain amount of housework was inescapable.\r\nIf the mother was unable to do the work, what happened to it?\r\n\r\nAnswer: somebody else did it.\r\n\r\nWho? Even in the abundance of those days, most of us couldn\'t afford\r\nnurses, maids, cooks, laundresses, or cleaning women. The era of the\r\npoor relation who came to help out for a few months was long past.\r\n\r\nWho did the work, then? The father, that\'s who.\r\n\r\nI stared deep into the shocking chasm between the mental processes of\r\nmen and women.\r\n\r\nI studied the statement again. There was no mis-statement at all--if\r\nyou granted the hidden premise and didn\'t boggle on the implication. It\r\nwas perfectly valid.\r\n\r\nThe hidden premise was that women did all the housework. But that\r\nhadn\'t been true for a generation. The husband-father had been drafted\r\ninto home service, and there was no discharge for him short of death or\r\ntotal disability.\r\n\r\nThe latter was hard to prove.\r\n\r\nBut the implication was the deadly thing: in the consideration of\r\nsecond child, a father\'s time and labor counted for nothing.\r\n\r\nI remembered a shaggy little story about a farmer who held up his hog\r\nto let it eat the corn off the stalk. "Doesn\'t it take a long time to\r\nfatten up a hog that way?" exclaimed the efficiency expert.\r\n\r\n"Shore," said the farmer, "but what\'s time to a hog?"\r\n\r\nAnd what, in a woman\'s eyes, was time to a father?\r\n\r\nThe second type of mis-statement was a pure omission. The thing\r\nthe baby books didn\'t mention was that most women felt ten times\r\nworse during their second pregnancies.[1] At this time life became\r\nalmost unbearable for them--and it was, as a consequence, completely\r\nunbearable for their husbands.\r\n\r\n    [Footnote 1: Editor\'s note: This may help explain the size of the\r\n    average American family: 1.6 children.--W. M.

]\r\n\r\nNot one baby book or article mentioned that fact. That it was a fact I\r\nproved by a personal survey. Every mother questioned revealed that she\r\nfelt horrible during her second pregnancy. She was surprised that my\r\nwife and I didn\'t know this.\r\n\r\nI was not surprised. 

Nobody ever mentioned it, that is why we didn\'t\r\nknow. I think it was at this time I first asked myself: _Is there a\r\nsubconscious conspiracy to keep this kind of information from leaking\r\nout?_\r\n\r\nIt wasn\'t important that women didn\'t know this. They had selective\r\nmemories (proof of this was that mankind lasted as long as it did).\r\nIf they were maternally inclined (as most of them were at one time or\r\nanother), the disadvantages of pregnancy faded into a sort of merciful\r\nblur.\r\n\r\nIf there was a conspiracy, it was aimed at fathers. It was intended to\r\nlull them into the logical supposition that conditions usually improve\r\nand that experience is the great teacher. 

Pure delusion! With women,\r\nthings are always worse, and they are born with all the knowledge they\r\nwill ever need.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBabies could be divided into two kinds: "most" and "occasional."\r\nConsider, for instance, the following quotation: "Most babies in the\r\nearly months sleep from feeding to feeding; an occasional baby won\'t\r\nfall into this pattern but insists on being sociable after his meals."\r\n\r\nThe first time I read that I supposed that this business of "most" and\r\n"occasional" was a statistical matter. That was my fatal mistake. If\r\nthere was any statistical backing for that statement, I never found it.\r\n\r\nIn my experience, the chances were nine out of ten that--try as you\r\nwould--you would have an "occasional" baby.\r\n\r\nWe did. We had two of them.\r\n\r\nThe fourth type of mis-statement was the false generalization. It was\r\nsaid, much too often: "A full baby is a sleepy baby."\r\n\r\nThat is a re-statement of the quotation above.\r\n\r\nI sat down with a pencil and paper and figured it out. A small infant\r\ntook half an hour to finish a bottle. If he ate five times a day, he\r\nwould have spent 21-1/2 hours asleep out of every 24.\r\n\r\nA little farther on I would read something like: "If a baby wakes up\r\nearly, he is not getting enough to eat." I drew up a schedule:\r\n\r\n    _Baby wakes up (being hungry)._\r\n\r\n    _Baby gets fed (all he can hold)._\r\n\r\n    _Baby is sleepy (being fed)._\r\n\r\n    _Baby goes to sleep (being sleepy)._\r\n\r\n    _Baby sleeps until next feeding (being full)._\r\n\r\nI didn\'t recognize the baby. Who could? 

He wasn\'t my child or anybody\r\nelse\'s. He was the pediatrician\'s pipe-dream child.\r\n\r\nI looked at it another way: if the baby slept except when being\r\nfed, when did it get the baths, orange juice, vitamins, cereal, and\r\neverything else the pediatricians prescribed?\r\n\r\nHoist by their own petards!\r\n\r\nThe fifth type of mis-statement was the impossible ideal. I tried this\r\none for logic: "Babies should not be allowed to cry before feeding."[2]\r\n\r\n    [Footnote 2: Editor\'s note: This led to swallowing air which made\r\n    gas bubbles; gas bubbles caused colic.--W. M.]\r\n\r\nHad those doctors ever tried to keep a hungry child from crying?\r\n\r\nHungry children cried. It was their nature. Some of them--my kind for\r\ninstance--cried very hard. And children--even pipe-dream children--woke\r\nup hungry.\r\n\r\nWarming a bottle to drinkable temperature took time, at least five\r\nminutes and sometimes ten. Meanwhile, in spite of everything that\r\nanyone could do, the baby was crying. He would not he cajoled, walked,\r\nteased, patted, jollied, scolded, or argued into accepting any\r\nsubstitute for his formula. With him, it was food or nothing.\r\n\r\nFor horror, I had a favorite scene: the mother alone, rushing from\r\nbaby to bottle, from bottle to baby, one screaming, the other cold,\r\nfrantic with the pediatrician\'s admonitions, and then both too hot....\r\n\r\nI would not have had it on my conscience for all the royalties in\r\nAmerica! At least I have saved the world that.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThere were more mis-statements, but those were enough. 

I did what any\r\nman, any scientist, would have done. I gave my findings to the world.\r\nThey were published under the title: "What the Baby Books Won\'t Tell\r\nYou." The article stirred up immediate controversy.\r\n\r\nIt is not enough to uncover a conspiracy; you must find a motive. I had\r\ndiscovered the motive behind the Great Conspiracy.\r\n\r\nBaby books were not written to teach parents how to care for their\r\nchildren; baby books were written to sell baby books. And magazines\r\npublished articles about babies to sell magazines to mothers.\r\n\r\nValid reasons. If they had not existed, there would have been no baby\r\nbooks, no women\'s magazines. But this had far-reaching consequences:\r\nthe market for baby books and women\'s magazines was the great,\r\nproliferating population of new parents. If the awful truth about\r\nparenthood were published, if these hardy, ingenuous souls were\r\ndiscouraged, something quite startling would happen to the market: it\r\nwould disappear.\r\n\r\nThere were attempts at suppression on all levels, but the truth was out\r\nand nothing could stop its spread. Secret printing presses turned out\r\nreprints by the millions; they were passed from hand to hand. Fathers\r\nwhispered the word to husbands; husbands passed it on to bachelor\r\nfriends.\r\n\r\nThe word raced around the world.\r\n\r\nIt would not have been so disastrous if Lindsay McPherson had not\r\nsimultaneously perfected his contraceptive pill out of a Southwestern\r\nplant named _Lithospermum ruderale_. For the first time, a\r\ncontraceptive was safe, cheap, and convenient--and 100% effective in\r\nreducing _male_ fertility.\r\n\r\nBirth control was in the hands of the men.\r\n\r\nBillions of the tiny pills were turned out. Enemy nations sowed them\r\nover each other\'s territory in boxes containing translations of my\r\narticle. Men cached them away, carried them in money belts, hollowed\r\nout hiding places in the heels of shoes....\r\n\r\nBirths dropped suddenly. Almost overnight, the maternity wards were\r\ndepopulated. Hospitals went broke, or began advertising for patrons,\r\nsick or well.\r\n\r\nThe makers of baby foods, baby apparel, and baby accessories went next,\r\nthen the women\'s magazines when they lost their advertising. In a few\r\nyears, the condition hit the schools; one by one they closed their\r\ndoors.\r\n\r\nIt was a creeping paralysis. The toy makers and sellers collapsed. The\r\nclothing industry couldn\'t survive longer. The shoe-makers were hardest\r\nhit. Food consumption dropped. All over the country, farmers went\r\nbroke....\r\n\r\nBy comparison, the Great Depression seemed like a boom.\r\n\r\nBy 1965 the end was in sight. Society disintegrated. 

The cities were\r\ndeserted; they burned for years. From a mechanical-agricultural\r\ncivilization, the world returned to the stone age in one decade.\r\n\r\nPeople went in packs for protection. There were two kinds of them:\r\npacks of men hunting for food and packs of women hunting for men.\r\n\r\nSoon, as the women grow too old for child-bearing, the race of Man will\r\nbe doomed.\r\n\r\nI did it. I am guilty. 

Lindsay helped, but I am the one. But how was I\r\nto know that society--that human life itself--was founded on a basic\r\ndeception?\r\n\r\nI wonder what is keeping Lindsay. He should be back by now.\r\n\r\n    _Editor\'s note: This manuscript was found in a cellar of a house in\r\n    a Midwestern city; it is presented here partly for its historical\r\n    interest, but chiefly for your amusement._\r\n\r\n    _Mr. Wilma Masters (the former Andrew Jones) was found in the same\r\n    cellar. Our hunting party had taken Lindsay McPherson some time\r\n    before, and he had directed us promptly to the cellar.
