copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nThe man who discovered that the world was flat, after all, was an\r\nAustralian hermit named Herbert Fitzgrone. He was a thoughtful man with\r\na glass eye and a metal plate in his head, both obtained during the\r\nBoer War. In the bush shanty where he had lived for forty years, he\r\nstudied the riddle of the universe.\r\n\r\nOne day, shortly after he had turned sixty, he made his astonishing\r\ndiscovery. He went to Sydney, and found his way to the office of the\r\neditor of the _Sydney Sun_. He opened the door and went in. "The world,\r\nsir," he said simply, "is flat."\r\n\r\nThose historic words were the first inkling of the scientific storm\r\nthat was to burst without warning on a complacently globular world.\r\nUnfortunately, the editor was not there to hear them. It was 11:00\r\nA.M., Pacific time, and the Sydney pubs were open. Herbert Fitzgrone, a\r\npatient man to whom years were as seconds, sat down in the empty office\r\nto wait.\r\n\r\nWhen the editor showed up at 4:35 P.M., he seemed a trifle confused.\r\nHe hung his hat on Fitzgrone\'s head, and sat down in the waste paper\r\nbasket. The man of science then stood erect and said it again. "The\r\nworld, sir, is flat."\r\n\r\n"That so?" 

said the editor. "You know, I always had a secret hunch it\r\nwas." He was an amiable man, with four children and a glass fountain\r\npen that flashed a light in the top when he used it. At that moment he\r\nwasn\'t quite sure whether Herbert Fitzgrone was alone or at the head of\r\na delegation.\r\n\r\n"I expected you to scoff," Herbert Fitzgrone said, a shade of\r\ndisappointment in his tone. "After all, when Columbus and Magellan said\r\nthe world was round, everybody scoffed. I came here prepared to be\r\nscoffed at."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t like to scoff at anybody," the editor said. "I once scoffed at\r\na man in a pub, and he hit me in the eye."\r\n\r\n"Well, if you won\'t," the scientist said, vexed, "you won\'t. Anyhow,\r\nI want to show you my proof that the earth as a globe is a monstrous\r\nimpossibility. Look here." 

He spread out some sheets of paper on the\r\neditor\'s desk.\r\n\r\n"My," said the editor. "Impressive, all right. What is it?"\r\n\r\n"Trigonometry. Do you understand it?"\r\n\r\n"No, but I\'m very fond of it. All those big numbers and everything.\r\nVery impressive."\r\n\r\n"Well, my calculations prove that the earth couldn\'t be a globe,\r\nbecause two lines of latitude can\'t possibly be at the same level. Do\r\nyou realize what that means?"\r\n\r\n"My God," said the editor in awe.\r\n\r\n"Exactly! Suppose you had two ships in Sydney Harbor, one seven miles\r\nnorth of the other. According to the globular theory, the northern ship\r\nwould also be four miles higher!"\r\n\r\nThe editor lurched in his swivel chair. 

"Stop the presses!" he yelled\r\ninto the phone, as he had seen editors do in American films. "And get\r\nme the Hatson Line quickly!"\r\n\r\nHe waited for his connection. Then he said, "This is the editor of the\r\n_Sun_. Listen and listen carefully. 

Hold all sailings until further\r\nnotice! I\'ve just learned that the earth is flat! _Flat_, do you\r\nunderstand? God help the ships at sea!"\r\n\r\nHe hung up, wan and shaken. Then he rushed for the door to get the\r\nstory on the presses. 

He was already through the door when he made the\r\nodd discovery that it wasn\'t the door. It was the window, it was open,\r\nand his office was on the ninth floor.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nNothing more was heard of Herbert Fitzgrone after this tragedy.\r\nPresumably frightened that he might be held responsible for the\r\neditor\'s death, the scientist disappeared. Fortunately for posterity,\r\nhowever, he neglected to pick up the calculations he had spread out on\r\nthe editor\'s desk.\r\n\r\nThey were discovered by a vice-president of the Hatson Line, who came\r\nto the editor\'s office for further enlightenment. This gentleman made\r\na prolonged study of the papers--he was quick on the trig and a fast\r\nman with a digit. He came to the terrifying conclusion that Christopher\r\nColumbus had made a terrible mistake.\r\n\r\nHe immediately cabled the New York office, forwarding all figures\r\ndown to the last spherical triangle. The head of the New York office,\r\na patriotic man, promptly dispatched the whole thing to the State\r\nDepartment in Washington, marked "Top Secret." Five minutes later Drew\r\nPearson predicted darkly that the whole world would shortly find itself\r\nflat on its back.\r\n\r\nThe nation\'s top scientists were summoned to a secret and speedy\r\nconclave at the White House. The President put it squarely up to the\r\nscientists--was the world round, or wasn\'t it? And if it wasn\'t, what\r\neffect would a flat world have on the nation\'s defenses? Was this a\r\nboost for communism or democracy?\r\n\r\n"Speak up, boys," he said. "I haven\'t got all day."\r\n\r\n"Ridiculous, Mr. 

President," one scientist sneered. "If the world is\r\nflat, how do you explain that when you approach a mountain or ship at\r\nsea, you see first the summit or funnels?"\r\n\r\n"What you see depends upon the weather," a young scientist insisted.\r\n"If there are low clouds, you don\'t see the top first. Then again,\r\nwhat you see first often depends on what you _want_ to see first! 

It\'s\r\nconditioning. Have you ever made a conscious effort to see the bottoms\r\nfirst?"\r\n\r\nA little scientist with a high neck and a squint jumped up. "When a\r\npartial eclipse of the moon takes place, the shadow of the earth on\r\nthe moon is a circle. Only a ball-shaped object can throw a circular\r\nshadow, gentlemen!"\r\n\r\n"Poppycock!" scoffed a scientist next to him. "So can a flat disk.\r\nFurthermore, who is an authority here on what happens on the moon?\r\nMoon-gazing is guesswork, gentlemen--sheer guesswork!"\r\n\r\nA worried little bald man pleaded, "Why can\'t we reconcile these\r\nhostile theories of apple-shape and saucer-shape into a compromise\r\nconcept which will satisfy everybody?"\r\n\r\n"Exactly!" a ribald voice shouted. "Apple-saucer!"\r\n\r\n"Mr. Einstein?" said the President hopefully.\r\n\r\nThe great man rose wistfully. "I am sorry, Mr. President," he said\r\nmeekly. 

"But it is all over my head."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Flash," said Walter Winchell on Sunday night. "Attention, Mr. and Mrs.\r\nAmerica and all the ships at sea. I, Walter Winchell, want to tell you,\r\nwhoever you are, that I, Walter Winchell, am the first as usual to\r\nbreak the most sensational scoop of the century! I, Walter Winchell,\r\nnow tell you, whoever you are, that the world is no longer round, but\r\nflat. Flat, ladies and gentlemen ... F-L-A-T. 

Geography marches on! And\r\nthe very first baby to be born into this new flat world...."\r\n\r\nHearst papers promptly informed their readers that: REDS SABOTAGE\r\nGLOBE! The _New York Times_, with eminent fairness, editorialized:\r\n"It would seem that there is a great deal of justification for the\r\nnew theory that the world is flat, while on the other hand, it seems\r\nequally dubious that there is sufficient evidence for discarding the\r\nglobular theory which has had, we cannot afford to overlook, the\r\ndistinguished test of time."\r\n\r\nReaders of the _Daily Worker_ turned for the facts, as usual, to the\r\n_Herald Tribune_. The Communist Party suffered its usual crisis. One\r\ngroup contended that accepting the new theory would split the unity\r\nof the working class, diverting attention from the class struggle.\r\nThe other group bitterly maintained that to adhere to the discredited\r\nglobular theory would be a betrayal of Marx.\r\n\r\nThe latter lost. The result was a new splinter party called the True\r\nMarxists, which called a world rally to form the new popular front,\r\nthe Flat World Workers Party. On the other side of the barricades, the\r\nN.A.M. and American Legion denounced flat-worldism as an attack on the\r\nvery principles on which our great nation of free enterprise is founded.\r\n\r\nGabriel Heatter cried, "Ah, my friends, let\'s not be deceived! Let\'s\r\nnot be duped by this subtle attack on all that we hold dear, all that\r\nwe have learned in the little red schoolhouse, in cherished days gone\r\nby!"\r\n\r\n"This," Henry J. Taylor declared scathingly, "is the sort of thing we\r\nmight have expected in the worst days of the New Deal. What actually\r\nlies behind this subversive campaign to convince Americans that the\r\nworld is actually flat? Just this. Certain interests want you to\r\nbelieve that Columbus was wrong, that he made a mistake, when he\r\nsaid the world was round. If you swallow this, then you must believe\r\nhis discovery of America was also a fantastic mistake. Is any decent\r\nAmerican willing to concede that the founding of our great nation was\r\nnothing but a blunder?"\r\n\r\nThe Un-American Activities Committee immediately held hearings in\r\nWashington. Witnesses on all sides of the question were summoned.\r\nAmong those who testified were Herbert Hoover, Gabriel Heatter, Henry\r\nJ. Taylor, Thomas Dewey, Robert Taft, John Foster Dulles, Henry Luce,\r\nGerald K. Smith, Representative Rankin, Louis Budenz, Whittaker\r\nChambers, Elizabeth Dilling and Westbrook Pegler, who revealed that\r\nthe whole thing was a plot by Mrs. Roosevelt. Henry Wallace was also\r\ncalled, cited for contempt in the first five minutes, and thereafter\r\nthe proceedings went smoothly.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe C.I.O. and the A.F. 

of L. held special conventions to consider\r\nwhat stand labor should take on the issue. Since they felt it had\r\nlittle bearing on wages, hours or the Taft-Hartley Act, they passed a\r\nresolution to remain neutral. Or, as one delegate put it, to live in a\r\nworld without shape.\r\n\r\nA wave of unrest swept over the country. Teachers went on record in\r\nfavor of a flat world, out of sheer boredom with trying to cram the\r\nopposite concept into the thick skulls of small fry. Shipping companies\r\nand airlines spent millions in paid advertising to fight the flat world\r\nidea. They feared that business would fall off if people got scared\r\nabout doing the same.\r\n\r\nThose who accepted the theory were stigmatized as "flatheads," and were\r\nexhorted in black ad headlines: "DON\'T BE A FLATHEAD!" This led to the\r\ncoining of the counter-epithet, "globephobe."\r\n\r\nM.G.M. announced it would produce "The Flat Earth," made by the same\r\nhands who turned out "The Good Earth." Warner Brothers promptly\r\npurchased a vehicle called "One Globe" to star Humphrey Bogart as\r\nColumbus, Lauren Bacall as Queen Isabella, and Paul Muni as the _Santa\r\nMaria_.\r\n\r\nThe controversy spilled over into the United Nations. Russia, which\r\ndiscovered that it looked more imposing on flat maps, demanded that\r\nall globe maps be destroyed under a death penalty for non-compliance.\r\nThe United States, out of habit, opposed this idea. Despite\r\n$3,567,219,483,128.50 rushed as a loan to Albania, Iceland and 72\r\nother nations, the U.N. vote went with the Soviet. As one Albanian\r\ngrumbled, "They didn\'t send Chesterfields--just Wings."\r\n\r\nRussia\'s victory had reverberations heard around the world ... or\r\nrather, along the sides of the world. Old geographies were burned.\r\nGlobe maps were broken in half and used for ashtrays. The flat map won\r\nthe international distinction of being referred to as the Moscow map.\r\nGlobetrotters were laid off by the lecture bureaus in droves. Universal\r\nPictures had the plane in its trademark sky-write the company\'s name\r\naround a terrestrial saucer.\r\n\r\nThe world could not exist half round, half flat, the President of the\r\nUnited States told Congress sadly. And since the rest of the world was\r\nflat, there was no help for it--America would have to flatten out, too.\r\nDespite globephobe cries of "Shame!" the famous 22nd Amendment was\r\nadded to the Constitution:--\r\n\r\n"The world shall, for all purposes of this Republic, be considered\r\nas flat. The Congress shall have power to enforce this article by\r\nappropriate legislation. Any article or any amendment which may contain\r\nany implication that the world is round is hereby nullified and\r\nrepealed."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nNow that the world is once more flat, unified and serene, I do not\r\nthink that there can be any serious consequences if I reveal the\r\nsequel to this historic development. It came about when the editor\r\nof a national magazine, at his wit\'s end for a strong piece to follow\r\nhis usual lead article of "Is Sex Here To Stay" or "How Sexy Are You\r\nSexually?", hit upon the notion of sending me to Australia to find the\r\nman who had discovered the earth was flat.\r\n\r\nIt took me months of searching through the outback to locate Herbert\r\nFitzgrone. He was still living in his bush shanty, and had just turned\r\neighty when I found him. I had great difficulty in persuading him to\r\ntell me the whole story, as he was totally absorbed in a new scientific\r\nstudy. He was on the verge, he told me jubilantly, of proving that\r\nthere is no such thing as gravity, and that Newton was an ass.\r\n\r\nWhen I persisted in knowing more about his original research that had\r\nexploded the globular theory, he smiled dryly.\r\n\r\n"Oh, _that_! Well, you probably know that I left all my calculations\r\nbehind in that editor\'s office. When I came back here, I decided to\r\nwork out a duplicate set. Well, sir, do you know what I discovered?\r\nThat old Columbus had been right all along! I\'d put the decimal point\r\nfor the algebraic equation of one plane triangle in the wrong place."\r\n\r\n"But that\'s impossible!" I burst out in horror. "Why, the whole world\r\nis flat now as a result of your calculations!"\r\n\r\n"You don\'t say," Herbert Fitzgrone chuckled. 

"Well, now!"\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


"\r\n\r\nFord, the physicist, glanced at General LeRoy. The general had that\r\nquizzical expression on his face, the look that meant he was about to do\r\nsomething decisive.\r\n\r\n"Would you like to see the problem first-hand?" the general asked,\r\ninnocently.\r\n\r\nThe CIA man took a quick look at his wristwatch. "O.K., if it doesn\'t\r\ntake too long. 

It\'s late enough already."\r\n\r\n"It won\'t take very long, will it, Ford?" the general said, getting out\r\nof his chair.\r\n\r\n"Not very long," Ford agreed. "Only a lifetime."\r\n\r\nThe CIA man grunted as they went to the doorway and left the general\'s\r\noffice. Going down the dark, deserted hallway, their footsteps echoed\r\nhollowly.\r\n\r\n"I can\'t overemphasize the seriousness of the problem," General LeRoy\r\nsaid to the CIA man. "Eight ranking members of the General Staff have\r\neither resigned their commissions or gone straight to the violent ward\r\nafter just one session with the computer."\r\n\r\nThe CIA man scowled. "Is this area Secure?"\r\n\r\nGeneral LeRoy\'s face turned red. "This entire building is as Secure as\r\nany edifice in the Free World, mister. And it\'s empty. We\'re the only\r\nliving people inside here at this hour. I\'m not taking any chances.

"\r\n\r\n"Just want to be sure."\r\n\r\n"Perhaps if I explain the computer a little more," Ford said, changing\r\nthe subject, "you\'ll know what to expect."\r\n\r\n"Good idea," said the man from CIA.\r\n\r\n"We told you that this is the most modern, most complex and delicate\r\ncomputer in the world ... nothing like it has ever been attempted\r\nbefore--anywhere."\r\n\r\n"I know that They don\'t have anything like it," the CIA man agreed.\r\n\r\n"And you also know, I suppose, that it was built to simulate actual war\r\nsituations. We fight wars in this computer ... wars with missiles and\r\nbombs and gas. Real wars, complete down to the tiniest detail. The\r\ncomputer tells us what will actually happen to every missile, every city,\r\nevery man ... who dies, how many planes are lost, how many trucks will\r\nfail to start on a cold morning, whether a battle is won or lost ..."\r\n\r\nGeneral LeRoy interrupted. "The computer runs these analyses for both\r\nsides, so we can see what\'s happening to Them, too."\r\n\r\nThe CIA man gestured impatiently. "War games simulations aren\'t new.\r\nYou\'ve been doing them for years."\r\n\r\n"Yes, but this machine is different," Ford pointed out. "It not only\r\ngives a much more detailed war game. It\'s the next logical step in the\r\ndevelopment of machine-simulated war games." 

He hesitated dramatically.\r\n\r\n"Well, what is it?"\r\n\r\n"We\'ve added a variation of the electro-encephalograph ..."\r\n\r\nThe CIA man stopped walking. "The electro-what?"\r\n\r\n"Electro-encephalograph. You know, a recording device that reads the\r\nelectrical patterns of your brain. Like the electro-cardiograph."\r\n\r\n"Oh."\r\n\r\n"But you see, we\'ve given the EEG a reverse twist. Instead of using a\r\nmachine that makes a recording of the brain\'s electrical wave output,\r\nwe\'ve developed a device that will take the computer\'s readout tapes,\r\nand turn them into electrical patterns that are put _into_ your brain!"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t get it.

"\r\n\r\nGeneral LeRoy took over. "You sit at the machine\'s control console. A\r\nhelmet is placed over your head. You set the machine in operation. You\r\n_see_ the results."\r\n\r\n"Yes," Ford went on. "Instead of reading rows of figures from the\r\ncomputer\'s printer ... you actually see the war being fought. Complete\r\nvisual and auditory hallucinations. You can watch the progress of the\r\nbattles, and as you change strategy and tactics you can see the results\r\nbefore your eyes."\r\n\r\n"The idea, originally, was to make it easier for the General Staff to\r\nvisualize strategic situations," General LeRoy said.\r\n\r\n"But every one who\'s used the machine has either resigned his commission\r\nor gone insane," Ford added.\r\n\r\nThe CIA man cocked an eye at LeRoy. "You\'ve used the computer."\r\n\r\n"Correct."\r\n\r\n"And you have neither resigned nor cracked up."\r\n\r\nGeneral LeRoy nodded. 

"I called you in."\r\n\r\nBefore the CIA man could comment, Ford said, "The computer\'s right\r\ninside this doorway. Let\'s get this over with while the building is\r\nstill empty."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThey stepped in. The physicist and the general showed the CIA man\r\nthrough the room-filling rows of massive consoles.\r\n\r\n"It\'s all transistorized and subminiaturized, of course," Ford\r\nexplained. "That\'s the only way we could build so much detail into the\r\nmachine and still have it small enough to fit inside a single building."\r\n\r\n"A single building?"\r\n\r\n"Oh yes; this is only the control section. Most of this building is\r\ntaken up by the circuits, the memory banks, and the rest of it."\r\n\r\n"Hm-m-m."\r\n\r\n[Illustration: ILLUSTRATED BY SCHELLING]\r\n\r\nThey showed him finally to a small desk, studded with control buttons\r\nand dials. The single spotlight above the desk lit it brilliantly, in\r\nharsh contrast to the semidarkness of the rest of the room.\r\n\r\n"Since you\'ve never run the computer before," Ford said, "General LeRoy\r\nwill do the controlling. You just sit and watch what happens."\r\n\r\nThe general sat in one of the well-padded chairs and donned a grotesque\r\nheadgear that was connected to the desk by a half-dozen wires. The CIA\r\nman took his chair slowly.\r\n\r\nWhen they put one of the bulky helmets on him, he looked up at them,\r\nsquinting a little in the bright light. "This ... this isn\'t going\r\nto ... well, do me any damage, is it?

"\r\n\r\n"My goodness, no," Ford said. "You mean mentally? No, of course not.\r\nYou\'re not on the General Staff, so it shouldn\'t ... it won\'t ... affect\r\nyou the way it did the others. Their reaction had nothing to do with the\r\ncomputer _per se_ ..."\r\n\r\n"Several civilians have used the computer with no ill effects," General\r\nLeRoy said. "Ford has used it many times."\r\n\r\nThe CIA man nodded, and they closed the transparent visor over his face.\r\nHe sat there and watched General LeRoy press a series of buttons, then\r\nturn a dial.\r\n\r\n"Can you hear me?" The general\'s voice came muffled through the helmet.\r\n\r\n"Yes," he said.\r\n\r\n"All right. Here we go. 

You\'re familiar with Situation One-Two-One?\r\nThat\'s what we\'re going to be seeing."\r\n\r\nSituation One-Two-One was a standard war game. The CIA man was well\r\nacquainted with it. 

He watched the general flip a switch, then sit back\r\nand fold his arms over his chest. A row of lights on the desk console\r\nbegan blinking on and off, one, two, three ... down to the end of the\r\nrow, then back to the beginning again, on and off, on and off ...\r\n\r\nAnd then, somehow, he could see it!\r\n\r\nHe was poised incredibly somewhere in space, and he could see it all in\r\na funny, blurry-double-sighted, dream-like way. He seemed to be seeing\r\nseveral pictures and hearing many voices, all at once. It was all mixed\r\nup, and yet it made a weird kind of sense.\r\n\r\nFor a panicked instant he wanted to rip the helmet off his head. _It\'s\r\nonly an illusion_, he told himself, forcing calm on his unwilling\r\nnerves. _Only an illusion._\r\n\r\nBut it seemed strangely real.\r\n\r\nHe was watching the Gulf of Mexico. He could see Florida off to his\r\nright, and the arching coast of the southeastern United States. He could\r\neven make out the Rio Grande River.\r\n\r\nSituation One-Two-One started, he remembered, with the discovery of\r\nmissile-bearing Enemy submarines in the Gulf. Even as he watched the\r\nwhole area--as though perched on a satellite--he could see, underwater\r\nand close-up, the menacing shadowy figure of a submarine gliding through\r\nthe crystal blue sea.\r\n\r\nHe saw, too, a patrol plane as it spotted the submarine and sent an\r\nurgent radio warning.\r\n\r\nThe underwater picture dissolved in a bewildering burst of bubbles. A\r\nmissile had been launched. Within seconds, another burst--this time a\r\nnuclear depth charge--utterly destroyed the submarine.\r\n\r\nIt was confusing. He was everyplace at once. The details were\r\noverpowering, but the total picture was agonizingly clear.\r\n\r\nSix submarines fired missiles from the Gulf of Mexico. Four were\r\nimmediately sunk, but too late. New Orleans, St. Louis and three Air\r\nForce bases were obliterated by hydrogen-fusion warheads.\r\n\r\nThe CIA man was familiar with the opening stages of the war. The first\r\nmissile fired at the United States was the signal for whole fleets of\r\nmissiles and bombers to launch themselves at the Enemy. It was confusing\r\nto see the world at once; at times he could not tell if the fireball and\r\nmushroom cloud was over Chicago or Shanghai, New York or Novosibirsk,\r\nBaltimore or Budapest.\r\n\r\nIt did not make much difference, really. They all got it in the first\r\nfew hours of the war; as did London and Moscow, Washington and Peking,\r\nDetroit and Delhi, and many, many more.\r\n\r\nThe defensive systems on all sides seemed to operate well, except that\r\nthere were never enough anti-missiles. Defensive systems were expensive\r\ncompared to attack rockets. It was cheaper to build a deterrent than to\r\ndefend against it.\r\n\r\nThe missiles flashed up from submarines and railway cars, from\r\nunderground silos and stratospheric jets; secret ones fired off\r\nautomatically when a certain airbase command post ceased beaming out a\r\nrestraining radio signal. The defensive systems were simply overloaded.\r\nAnd when the bombs ran out, the missiles carried dust and germs and gas.\r\nOn and on. For six days and six firelit nights. Launch, boost, coast,\r\nre-enter, death.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAnd now it was over, the CIA man thought. The missiles were all gone.\r\nThe airplanes were exhausted. The nations that had built the weapons no\r\nlonger existed. By all the rules he knew of, the war should have been\r\nended.\r\n\r\nYet the fighting did not end. The machine knew better. There were still\r\nmany ways to kill an enemy. Time-tested ways. There were armies fighting\r\nin four continents, armies that had marched overland, or splashed ashore\r\nfrom the sea, or dropped out of the skies.\r\n\r\nIncredibly, the war went on. When the tanks ran out of gas, and the\r\nflame throwers became useless, and even the prosaic artillery pieces had\r\nno more rounds to fire, there were still simple guns and even simpler\r\nbayonets and swords.\r\n\r\nThe proud armies, the descendents of the Alexanders and Caesars and\r\nTemujins and Wellingtons and Grants and Rommels, relived their evolution\r\nin reverse.\r\n\r\nThe war went on. Slowly, inevitably, the armies split apart into smaller\r\nand smaller units, until the tortured countryside that so recently had\r\nfelt the impact of nuclear war once again knew the tread of bands of\r\narmed marauders. The tiny savage groups, stranded in alien lands, far\r\nfrom the homes and families that they knew to be destroyed, carried on a\r\nmockery of war, lived off the land, fought their own countrymen if the\r\noccasion suited, and revived the ancient terror of hand-wielded,\r\npersonal, one-head-at-a-time killing.\r\n\r\nThe CIA man watched the world disintegrate. Death was an individual\r\nbusiness now, and none the better for no longer being mass-produced. In\r\nagonized fascination he saw the myriad ways in which a man might die.\r\nMurder was only one of them. Radiation, disease, toxic gases that\r\nlingered and drifted on the once-innocent winds, and--finally--the most\r\nefficient destroyer of them all: starvation.\r\n\r\nThree billion people (give or take a meaningless hundred million) lived\r\non the planet Earth when the war began. Now, with the tenuous thread of\r\ncivilization burned away, most of those who were not killed by the\r\nfighting itself succumbed inexorably to starvation.\r\n\r\nNot everyone died, of course. Life went on. Some were lucky.\r\n\r\nA long darkness settled on the world. Life went on for a few, a pitiful\r\nfew, a bitter, hateful, suspicious, savage few. Cities became pestholes.\r\nBooks became fuel. Knowledge died. Civilization was completely gone from\r\nthe planet Earth.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe helmet was lifted slowly off his head. The CIA man found that he was\r\ntoo weak to raise his arms and help. He was shivering and damp with\r\nperspiration.\r\n\r\n"Now you see," Ford said quietly, "why the military men cracked up when\r\nthey used the computer."\r\n\r\nGeneral LeRoy, even, was pale. "How can a man with any conscience at all\r\ndirect a military operation when he knows that _that_ will be the\r\nconsequence?"\r\n\r\nThe CIA man struck up a cigarette and pulled hard on it. He exhaled\r\nsharply. "Are all the war games ... like that? Every plan?"\r\n\r\n"Some are worse," Ford said. "We picked an average one for you. Even\r\nsome of the \'brushfire\' games get out of hand and end up like that."\r\n\r\n"So ... what do you intend to do? Why did you call me in? 

What can _I_\r\ndo?"\r\n\r\n"You\'re with CIA," the general said. "Don\'t you handle espionage?"\r\n\r\n"Yes, but what\'s that got to do with it?

"\r\n\r\nThe general looked at him. "It seems to me that the next logical step is\r\nto make damned certain that _They_ get the plans to this computer ...\r\nand fast!"\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Analog Science Fact & Fiction_ May\r\n    1962.

The quiet. 

And the solitude. But there was\r\nalways Suzy, linking him to the earth so many miles away.\r\n\r\n"One hundred and forty-three days out, four hundred and seven to go."\r\nThe ritual of the report, designed to keep him thinking, day after day.\r\n\r\n"Nothing to report, sir, all equipment functioning. All graphs tracking.\r\nNo abnormality of any kind. My health is good...."\r\n\r\nIn four hundred and seven days they would bring him down, nearly mad,\r\nnearly dead, but his records well made on earth, and the record was what\r\ncounted.\r\n\r\nFive hundred and fifty days in an observation capsule, the economical\r\nhuman machine that did the work of fifty tons of unprojectable\r\nelectronic equipment. Five hundred and fifty days of cold and quiet and\r\nsolitude. The first eight men had died in the cold and loneliness of\r\nspace, until they thought of Suzy, there in the WAC manned offices at\r\nPoint Magu.\r\n\r\n"Suzy! My God, Suzy, where are you?" Whit could stand the waiting until\r\nthe time came close, then his mind would give away until her voice,\r\nbridging the space void came to him and brought him peace.\r\n\r\n"Whit? Whit, wake up, in case you\'re asleep. It\'s me, it\'s Suzy."\r\n\r\n"Asleep! You know I\'m not asleep! You know I stay awake for you! I\'ll\r\nalways be awake, Suzy. I wouldn\'t miss a minute with you, not a second."\r\n\r\n"Gee, Whit, you\'re nice. You\'re awful nice."\r\n\r\n"Suzy, for the hundredth time, will you marry me?"\r\n\r\n"Aw, Whit, you know I can\'t. You know they made me promise that before I\r\ntook the job."\r\n\r\n"Promise to be a talking floozy to fifty men in space, to hold \'em all\r\nat arm\'s length, let \'em love you, then leave \'em in the cold when they\r\ncame back down to earth. They made you promise to keep us stringing\r\nalong, until we got back home safe and sound, then turn us loose with\r\nour love for you burning a hole in our hearts! They made you promise a\r\nthing like that, Suzy?\r\n\r\n"You can\'t handle the merchandise, Whit. When you come down, then we\'ll\r\ntalk over things together."\r\n\r\n"Suzy, I love you, I love you!"\r\n\r\n"I mustn\'t say that I love you too, Whit. They made me promise that I\r\nwouldn\'t say that. But Whit, you\'re awful nice."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWhit sat silent, and Suzy kept on talking. She could always talk. No\r\nmatter what you said to her, no matter how you felt, no matter where you\r\nwere, Suzy could always talk to you and make your life seem brighter,\r\nand the trip back home again worth fighting to make. You fell in love\r\nwith Suzy, they all did, but as she always said, they made her promise\r\nnot to say she loved you back. Not until you got back home, safe and\r\nsound and sane.\r\n\r\nThat was Suzy\'s job on earth, in a drab little office with an engineer\r\nwho controlled her channels, and sometimes blushed at what he heard go\r\nout over them. She spoke, sometimes gaily, sometimes gently, sometimes\r\nwith all the frail strength of her body, into a microphone beamed to\r\neach capsule in turn, and in those capsules were men, who, but for her,\r\nwould go mad before their time was up.\r\n\r\nAnd Suzy never cheated, and she never lied, and she never changed. She\r\nwas the love light of outer space, she and a dozen others at Point Magu.\r\nShe kept men sane, and she brought them home, and she kept her promise\r\nnever to love and never to marry until they came back again.\r\n\r\n"Whit? What we were talking about yesterday. 

Did you think about that?"\r\n\r\n"You mean about the gardenias?"\r\n\r\n"Umhummm. My gardenias, to pin on my blouse."\r\n\r\n"Suzy, I\'ll bring you a thousand, one each day, until you say you love\r\nme. I\'m drawing them now, on paper, one every day, for you."\r\n\r\n"Aw, Whit, you\'re awful nice."\r\n\r\nThen, after frantic good-byes, shouting, screaming, pounding on the\r\nmicrophone, hoping that the dead metal would somehow speak once more,\r\nWhit would settle back for another day\'s dreaming of Suzy, while he kept\r\nhis tiny house-in-space, read his little gauges, and kept his dreams\r\nalive. It was only in the afternoon that madness came too close, and in\r\nthe power-saving darkness he raged and cursed and pled and begged, until\r\nSuzy\'s voice came winging out of space to comfort him for another day,\r\nwhen they talked of all the beautiful things that people talk about when\r\nthere is love between them.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nFor Suzy loved her men, all seven of them. To know them well, to listen\r\ntime and again to their recorded conversations, to pick out points that\r\nwere worth repeating, to avoid the subjects that depressed them, to say\r\nwhat would bring them home in love with her was a pleasure to her, and\r\nshe worked hard at the job. All alone, late into the night, Suzy would\r\nsit in her little office, listening to her records, and planning the\r\nnext day\'s battle for the sanity of her men.\r\n\r\n"Now Al," she\'d muse, "he\'ll want to know how that recipe came out, the\r\none with the mushrooms. Poor guy, he does like to eat. I\'ll tell him\r\nabout the party I went to with Sheila, and how she ate up all the rum\r\ncakes and could hardly find her way home again. He\'ll like that.

"\r\n\r\n"And Jim. He\'d like to have another problem, like the twelve coin one. I\r\nwish I had a mind like his. Maybe Miss Graham can find me a book on math\r\nproblems that a man can do in his head. And I\'ll tell him how nice it\r\nwould be to be a professor\'s wife, and a little college in the north.\r\nHe doesn\'t want _me_ yet, but he wants somebody...."\r\n\r\n"I guess I\'ll have to talk sex to Crazy Cat, too. It\'s about the only\r\nthing he likes to think about, and that\'s my job. I hope he doesn\'t\r\nrealize I\'m not the hellcat he seems to think I am. Maybe some of the\r\ngirls could give me some ideas he\'d like to think about; my dates are\r\npretty dull. They really should have given Crazy Cat to somebody else.\r\nSome psychiatrist slipped up there, I guess. But I\'ll bring him down!\r\nI\'ll bring him down sane if I have to wade in filth up to my eyeballs!\r\nThat\'s a joke."\r\n\r\n"Whit\'s hopeless, he loves me so. I hope he doesn\'t go off the deep end,\r\nand end up whacky. Maybe we\'ll have to relay him some instrument checks,\r\nto keep him busy. Or maybe, if I told him I\'d marry him it would keep\r\nhim leveled for a while. Can\'t say that too soon, though, or he\'d go\r\nnuts from jealousy. 

I guess I\'ll just have to keep on letting him love\r\nme, just being me, just showing him I care about him as much as I can.\r\nHe\'s a dear, really."\r\n\r\nThat was the way Suzy mused, in her drab little office, after hours,\r\ndoing her job for her men, her hopes up in the sky where only her voice\r\nand her love could reach them.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nMiss Graham was stiff, and stood tall in her prim tailored suit. Her\r\ndark man\'s necktie clashed with her hair and her complexion, but her\r\nface was kind and her voice, although firm, was soft and understanding.\r\n\r\n"Suzy, I want to talk to you. Don\'t get up.

"\r\n\r\n"Yes, Miss Graham?"\r\n\r\n"I\'ve been listening to some of your records. Some of this stuff you\'ve\r\nbeen putting out is going to make us trouble, you know."\r\n\r\n"I\'m sorry, Miss Graham. 

I try to do what I think is best, and you know\r\nI spend a lot of time planning. It\'s too late to shift poor Crazy Cat to\r\nanybody else, and it\'s the only thing that seems...."\r\n\r\n"I\'m not talking about Crazy Cat Tompkins, Suzy," interrupted Miss\r\nGraham. "I\'m talking about Whit Clayborne.

"\r\n\r\n"I see. I know I shouldn\'t have said that I\'d marry him, but gosh, he\r\nwas just about to go to pieces, right while I was talking to him. I\r\ncould hear him grit his teeth, and I could hear the mike squeak with the\r\ngrip he had on it. It was awful, Miss Graham."\r\n\r\n"Couldn\'t you have waited? You could have asked me what to do, you\r\nknow. Men ask our girls to marry them every day; it isn\'t as if it was a\r\nnew problem that we hadn\'t handled before."\r\n\r\n"But he needed me, right then. I didn\'t think he could wait. I _had_ to\r\nsay I\'d marry him, or he\'d have been biting pieces out of his mattress."\r\n\r\n"I know you did your best, Suzy. Those rules, well, they\'re not only for\r\nhis protection, you know. What are you going to do when Whit Clayborne\r\nlands, and comes in here to claim his bride? Had you thought of that?"\r\n\r\n"Honestly, Miss Graham, I didn\'t think of anything, except that he\r\nneeded me at the time. But of course I\'ll let him go. I\'d let him go\r\neven if the rules didn\'t say I had to."\r\n\r\nMiss Graham\'s voice was unexpectedly gentle. "You want to get married,\r\ndon\'t you? We _could_ break a rule, just this once."\r\n\r\n"Not like that, Miss Graham. Not like that. It wouldn\'t be fair to hold\r\nhim to a promise that he made in space. Even if you\'d let me do it, I\r\nwouldn\'t marry him. I couldn\'t live with myself. He doesn\'t know, well,\r\nabout me. He wouldn\'t have loved me if I\'d told him. He\'s never seen me;\r\nall he\'s in love with is a voice that understands how to keep him sane.\r\nI wouldn\'t hold him to that promise, Miss Graham, if he was the last\r\nchance to marry that I\'d ever have."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nMiss Graham was silent for a few moments, then turned to the door.\r\n\r\n"You\'ve figured out how to let him know that you won\'t marry him?"\r\n\r\n"I\'ll tell him when he comes down."\r\n\r\n"And you think that just telling him will do the trick, Suzy?"\r\n\r\n"The way I\'ll tell him, it\'ll stick, oh it\'ll stick all right." Suzy\r\nchoked off the last words, and blinked back the tears that seemed to\r\ncome into her eyes.\r\n\r\n"I\'m glad you\'ve got it figured out, dear." Miss Graham said\r\napprovingly. "His orbit got knocked loose somehow, and he\'ll be in this\r\nevening, to talk things over."\r\n\r\nSuzy gasped. "So soon? I mean, well, I\'ve got it sort of figured, but,\r\nwell," she paused, collecting her thoughts. "As well now as ever, I\r\nguess. 

I\'ll wait for him."\r\n\r\n"Do you think he\'d get violent? I could leave a couple of engineers in\r\nthe closet, or maybe you\'d like to have Sheila...."\r\n\r\n"No, I can handle him, and I\'d rather not have Sheila here when he comes\r\nin. I\'ll handle him. 

And thank you, Miss Graham."\r\n\r\nThe door closed on Miss Graham\'s back, and Suzy began to think of Whit\r\nClayborne.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe door opened slowly, and the pale young airman came into the office\r\non unsteady feet, his hat in his left hand, and a small package tucked\r\nunder his arm.\r\n\r\n"Is this Suzy\'s office? I mean, will she be in soon? 

Where can I find\r\nher?" The questions came eagerly.\r\n\r\n"I\'m Suzy."\r\n\r\nFor a minute the words meant nothing to him. He looked, blankly, round\r\nthe office, then back to the seated figure.\r\n\r\n"You recognize the voice, don\'t you, Whit?"\r\n\r\nHe gulped, and the expression drained from his face, leaving it blank,\r\nand helpless. Suzy\'s heart went out to him, as her voice had gone to him\r\nthrough space.\r\n\r\n"I know, the wheel chair, the rug to cover my knees, the brace on my\r\narm. There wasn\'t any other way, Whit. 

I couldn\'t tell you. My voice,\r\nWhit, was all that counted, up there. Down on earth, other things count,\r\ntoo. Forgive me, Whit."\r\n\r\nHis head seemed to swim, and his unsteady feet fumbled with the floor as\r\nhe came to her.\r\n\r\n"You could have told me. I\'d have loved you, I\'d have loved you anyway."\r\n\r\n"Would you?" Her face turned away from him as he came to her. "Would\r\nyou, Whit? Would you have stayed alive for a broken girl like me? Would\r\nyou have waited out your trip for the sake of a cripple in a wheel\r\nchair? I know you, Whit, I know your heart and your soul, and I know\r\nyou\'d have never loved me if I had told you what I was from the\r\nbeginning."\r\n\r\nWhit didn\'t speak, and Suzy continued.\r\n\r\n"It was a job for me, Whit. I had to bring you down. I lied to you and I\r\ndeceived you, and now you\'re free, and you can go away, to live a better\r\nlife than I can give you."\r\n\r\n"Suzy, you\'re saying that. You\'ve thought it out, and you\'ve written it\r\ndown, and it\'s what you planned to say to me. Is it the truth, Suzy?"\r\n\r\n"Whit, go away. I\'ve said my piece. I\'ve turned you loose. Now go! 

Go\r\naway, and don\'t ever come back to me again."\r\n\r\nWhit\'s body seemed to straighten up, and he put his little green package\r\ndown on the desk in front of her, then moved away.\r\n\r\n"Open it up, Suzy. It\'s a gardenia that I brought you. Sick or well,\r\ncrippled or sound, I\'ll bring you another every day, until you say you\r\nlove me."\r\n\r\nThen he went away.\r\n\r\nSuzy rose slowly, kicking the rug from her knees. She folded the wheel\r\nchair into a compact bundle, and stretching up on her toes, put it back\r\non the highest shelf in the closet. Quietly, she put her hat and coat\r\non, and went out of the office, locking the door behind her. The click\r\nof her high heels echoed bravely in the silence as she felt her way\r\nalong the vacant hallway.\r\n\r\n"Sheila, Sheila, come to me, girl," she called.\r\n\r\nThe big German shepherd shook herself as she rose from her bed beside\r\nthe doorway, and with the practiced skill of years brought the handle of\r\nher harness beneath her mistress\'s groping hand.\r\n\r\nSuzy knelt beside the big dog, and put her arms around her furry neck,\r\nweeping softly into the thick fur.\r\n\r\n"Sheila, Sheila, I think he\'s going to marry me!" she said.\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


For one\r\n             day that brain would crack. When it did, the\r\n              World would dissolve in cataclysmic Chaos.\r\n\r\n           [Transcriber\'s Note: This etext was produced from\r\n                      Planet Stories Spring 1940.\r\n         Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that\r\n         the U.S. copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nIn his little tower, perched at the very peak of the great terraced\r\npile of buildings which was his home and his citadel, Peter Groff sat\r\nbrooding with hatred. The city, its factories, its vast plowed fields,\r\nlay stretched below him. Millions of humans, at play in little games.\r\nHow he hated them! And they hated him--hated and feared him. It made\r\nhim chuckle. For all his life he had worked and schemed and fought to\r\nmake himself a power. The richest, most powerful man in the world--he\r\nhad attained it. They had called him cruel, in his youth, with his\r\nruthless business methods. He had laughed. Then they had no longer\r\ndared call him anything which would anger him. And he had laughed at\r\nthat, while he had bought their governments and their armies with his\r\nmoney.\r\n\r\nHe was laughing now as he thought of it. In seventy years he had made\r\nthe name Peter Groff a thing at which to tremble. Over all the earth,\r\nfrom the heads of his groveling puppet governments down to the lowliest\r\nchild driving a plow in the fields, there was no one who did not\r\nsecretly fear Groff, the power of his money, the sound of anger in his\r\nvoice. Here in his citadel his servants trembled--and hated him. It was\r\nfunny, because by their methods they had gotten nothing; and he had\r\ngotten everything.\r\n\r\nAlone in his little tower, he sat and brooded. There was little else\r\nto do now, and he enjoyed it--this contemplation of himself and his\r\nachievements. The mirror beside which he sat reflected his image. He\r\nstared at himself. His trusted companion. His face, thin-lipped, was\r\ngrim with its power. His eyes gleamed with it--eyes at which everyone\r\nshivered with fear. The banked rows of his television tuning knobs were\r\nwithin reach of his hand. And he decided that it would be amusing to\r\nlook and to listen from some of the newscasters\' vantage points at what\r\nwas transpiring down in the city streets. He chose one in the factory\r\ndistrict, over by the river. They were the people who had least.\r\n\r\nThe little cathode mirror presently was glowing with the scene he\r\nhad selected. It was a tube-lit city arcade, far down by the lowest\r\nlevel of the Inter-urban railway. Subterranean shops were along its\r\nsides--places where people with the tiniest fraction of money might\r\nspend it for something which wasn\'t worth having.\r\n\r\nAnd as he stared, from one of the shops a young couple came--a\r\ndark-haired, slender young man and a girl who was pretty, and who was\r\nlaughing. They were poorly dressed. They had nothing. But they were\r\nlaughing; and suddenly they were struggling as the young man fastened\r\nupon the girl\'s dress the bauble he had bought, and then was trying to\r\nkiss her for his payment. The scuffle was over in a moment; and Groff\r\nheard from his microphone the girl\'s gasping, murmured words:\r\n\r\n"Oh, Jac--I\'m so happy--"\r\n\r\nGroff stiffened. His thin, lined face was grim as he reached and cut\r\noff the image and the murmuring voice....\r\n\r\nSomething happened to Peter Groff that summer night. He wasn\'t\r\nconscious of it; he only knew that he was enraged as though an attack\r\nhad been made upon him. 

Atrocious things which menaced him needed\r\ncrushing. He pondered it, grim with his planning....\r\n\r\nNear dawn, some of his servants knew that something had happened. They\r\nheard him, with his wild laughter coming in an eerie muffled blur from\r\nhis little tower. Then young Peller dared go up to see what might be\r\nthe matter.\r\n\r\n"Is there anything you need of me, Master?" he asked.\r\n\r\nGroff was staring from his great armchair. "Not now, Peller. But I\'ve\r\njust discovered how to solve the situation very quickly. The Master has\r\njust made up his mind, Peller."\r\n\r\nIt was gratifying to see the terror and confusion on Peller\'s face.\r\nGroff\'s gesture drove the servant away, so that he would go down into\r\nthe corridors of the citadel and whisper with all the other servants as\r\nthey trembled, thinking the Master might be displeased with them.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe thing took Groff more than a year. The thousands of men whom he\r\nsent secretly throughout the world did as he commanded, and did not\r\nknow why they were doing it. Poor fools. The great scientist who for so\r\nmany years had been in Groff\'s employ gave him the technical knowledge\r\nhe sought. Fools. 

All fools. They could not guess what he was really\r\nafter. The lies he told them which awakened their cupidity were so easy\r\nfor them to believe. No servant could know what any other servant was\r\ndoing. No one could piece it together. There was only the masterful\r\nGroff in his tower weaving the poisonous threads of his gigantic\r\nenterprise into a pattern which only himself could see.\r\n\r\nThen at last he was ready. He had tracked down the identity of the\r\ndark-haired, slender young worker whom the laughing girl had called\r\nJac. And there came the momentous night when he sent for the young man\r\nand the girl, and white-faced, frightened, they stood before him in his\r\nlittle tower.\r\n\r\nGroff lolled back in his big chair as he quietly regarded them. "Quite\r\nan honor for you, isn\'t it?" 

he said. 

"Seeing me in person."\r\n\r\n"What do you want of us?" the young man murmured.\r\n\r\nIt was pleasing to Groff, to see his terror. "I wanted to thank you,"\r\nGroff said ironically. "It happened that I saw you two, one night about\r\na year ago. You made me realize what I must do. 

So I thought I would\r\ntell you about it."\r\n\r\nThey could only stand wordless, frightened. Groff sucked in his breath\r\nwith anticipatory pleasure. In a moment now they would be more than\r\nfrightened; they would be utterly terrified--and their terror would\r\nspread like a wave around the world.\r\n\r\nGroff was lashing himself into grim anger. "You are going to die," he\r\nsaid. At the girl\'s sudden little whimpering gasp he raised his hand.\r\n"That sort of think won\'t help you any. You and everyone on earth--this\r\nis your last night of health. Tomorrow, at dawn, you will all start\r\nswiftly to sicken. In a week, a month--you will be dead."\r\n\r\nHow well they knew that his threats were never empty. They were huddled\r\ntogether now, with trembling arms around each other as they stared\r\nat him. He lashed himself further into anger as he told them that he\r\nrealized how millions of people were conspiring to the end that Groff\r\nmight suffer misfortune. A menace which he could no longer tolerate....\r\nHow those millions would squirm as they saw death coming upon them! The\r\nsupreme power of Groff at last demonstrated to its ultimate. Queer that\r\nhe had never thought of this logical climax to his great career--not\r\nuntil that little incident a year ago when this young couple had caused\r\nhim to envisage it.\r\n\r\nHe was telling them now what he had done.... The little depots all\r\nover the earth, compressed with caged bacteria. Little time-bombs--all\r\nto explode within thirty minutes of this present instant. The women\r\nand children, the aged, would die first. But the polluted air, the\r\ncontagion spreading everywhere--in a week, a month, the swift and\r\ndeadly bacteria would leave no one alive.\r\n\r\n"You--are going to do this to us?" young Jac murmured at last.\r\n\r\n"Why not? 

It is my destiny." Never had Groff felt so quiet and\r\ncomfortable a thrill as now; and this was only the beginning. "Others\r\nbefore me have tried their little conquests," he said with his grim\r\nsmile. "Men who wanted power, and got it, just in a small way and for\r\na little while. There was one--I recall reading about him--one who was\r\nso foolish to disclose all his plans by writing them in a book, years\r\nbefore he had a chance to accomplish them. I am not like him. 

I tell\r\nyou now, when there is a scant thirty minutes before your inevitable\r\nannihilation begins."\r\n\r\n"You hate your fellow men so much," Jac murmured impulsively, "you\r\nwould kill yourself, just for the pleasure of killing the rest of us?"\r\n\r\nTo die. It sent so strangely a queer little shiver over Groff. He had\r\nalways felt it; but no one could ever know it, save himself. How many\r\ntimes his vaunted reckless bravery had awed his fellow man! He sat very\r\nstraight now, and his eyes flashed.\r\n\r\n"I have never been one to fear death," he said.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBut, as always before, he knew now that he was safe enough. His armed\r\ncitadel here was wholly safe from outside attack, even if the stricken\r\nmultitudes should find brief strength to try and assail him. His\r\nretainers, thinking they were safe, would remain at their posts. Poor\r\nfools. 

At the last, even they would be stricken and Groff would retreat\r\nup here. Impregnable, here in the tower and its neighbor little rooms,\r\nhe could maintain his unpolluted air, and eat the food and drink the\r\nwater which he had stored here in such abundance. Perhaps even, nature\r\nwould let him live the longer for his isolation.\r\n\r\nMaster of the earth. The man who owned everything. Pride swelled him\r\nagain as he thought of that poor little fool who had only wanted to\r\nmake himself the titular leader of the earth, and in his own fatuous\r\nconceit had written it all down in his little book.\r\n\r\n"You have good reason to fear me," Groff said. "You realize it now?

"\r\n\r\nThe young couple were white-faced and trembling as they clung to each\r\nother. And suddenly the girl murmured,\r\n\r\n"I--I pity you."\r\n\r\nGroff caught at it, with his sudden wild rage flooding him. "You lie!"\r\nhe rasped. "You are frightened. You are terrified of me and my revenge."\r\n\r\n"Revenge?" young Jac muttered. "I wonder what we have done to\r\nyou--except that we live and breathe and try to be happy." His arm held\r\nthe trembling girl closer; and he turned and gazed into her face, her\r\nmoist red lips quivering, her eyes like misted stars as she regarded\r\nhim. "If we are both to die," he murmured, "still we will have each\r\nother, Manya."\r\n\r\n"Yes," she whispered.\r\n\r\nThen it seemed that the youth was not quite so afraid as he\r\nstraightened and fronted Groff. "Your revenge, when you kill us both,\r\nis not quite complete," he said with a twisted smile.\r\n\r\nThey turned at Groff\'s gesture of dismissal. At the head of the great\r\nstaircase which went down from the tower, dominant with his power,\r\nGroff stood with his heavy ornamented robe tossed over one shoulder and\r\nall his emblazoned insignia dangling on his chest. The young couple\r\nwere still clinging to each other as they descended. Then they were a\r\nlittle blob, dwarfed by distance, dwindling into total insignificance.\r\nIt was only a trick of lighting of the great staircase, of course;\r\nbut suddenly, just before they vanished, it seemed that the light had\r\nmagnified them into something gigantic....\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe thing was over at last. It was a week? 

Two weeks? Three weeks?\r\nGroff had kept no track of the time. Exhausted with exulting he lay\r\nback in his chair with his instruments around him. How wonderful it\r\nhad been. The ultimate conquest. The power of Groff and Groff alone.\r\nSo many times it had made him think of those other conquerors--those\r\nlittle men of history who had been thrilled by their trips of triumph\r\ninto some petty land their armies had devastated. That little man in\r\nhis aircar, gazing in triumph, swelling himself with his pride as he\r\ngazed at the death and destruction he had brought to just one petty\r\nnation in three weeks....\r\n\r\nGroff\'s triumph was over now. He had seen much of it, with his\r\ntelescopes ranging the city, and on his television mirrors before the\r\ntelevision went blank. It had been queer, how people, stricken so that\r\nthey knew they had only a few days to live, had rushed around bringing\r\ntheir families together. Queer that then they had not really seemed\r\nafraid. Queer how the churches had been crowded, with doomed people who\r\nclung together and had a strange look on their faces as though they\r\nwere not afraid to die....\r\n\r\nThen it was over. From the immense height and safety of his little\r\ntower Groff sat surveying his conquered world. The man who had\r\neverything. The ultimate of personal power. And what would he do with\r\nit now? Queer thought! It was so queer, so whimsical a thought that he\r\nchuckled, and then was laughing at it--laughing for so long that it\r\nleft him breathless. There was nobody here to hate. That was another\r\nqueer thought.\r\n\r\nWas it days, or weeks or years, that now he sat alone in his little\r\ntower, surveying his empty world? There was nothing to do but\r\ngloat with pride at the greatness of himself; and to laugh at the\r\nwhimsicality of his hungry need to be angry at his enemies who now did\r\nnot exist. He had tired of that. Then there were times when he thought\r\nit would be satisfying if he killed himself, like the man who had\r\nwritten the book and who could not live when he realized that the time\r\nhad come when no one feared him. But Groff found that he had not the\r\ncourage to do that.\r\n\r\nIt tired him to laugh so much, so that often now he sat, just anguished\r\nwith emptiness. It was queer how that vision of the young couple\r\ngoing down his staircase seemed always here to haunt and to puzzle\r\nhim. 

What had been about them that was so gigantic? The thought\r\nenraged him, because he knew now that it was something he might have\r\nwanted--something he had failed to get.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEnd of Project Gutenberg\'s The Man Who Killed the Earth, by Ray King\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nHe knew that there had been trouble, and he had been told what he had\r\nto do. 

The trouble was he had forgotten. He didn\'t remember where it\r\nwas.\r\n\r\nHe had been speeding past an off-color white dwarf when it happened.\r\nIf he had taken the trouble to look around, he would have seen that\r\nthe white star was going to explode. He knew a potential nova when he\r\ntook a good look at one. But after all these centuries he had grown\r\ncareless, and when the blast had come--the small star suddenly blazing\r\ninto a billion-fold brilliance--the penetrating radiation had hit him\r\nwith full intensity. There had been no ship to protect him, no clothing\r\nthat might serve as a shield. His kind had done away with such things\r\neons before, as they had learned to move through space by using some\r\nof the radiant energy that filled it.\r\n\r\nHe had blacked out completely.\r\n\r\nWhen he came to again, he was far past the nova, in the dazzling\r\nbrightness of a rarefied cloud of radiant hydrogen atoms. The nova\r\nitself had lost so much of its momentary brilliance that it was now\r\nindistinguishable from the myriads of other stars. He himself was\r\nspeeding on with feverish haste toward a nebular cluster a thousand\r\nlight years away.\r\n\r\nHe slowed down. He had the feeling that the distant cluster was not his\r\nproper destination. But what was? What star, what planet was the spot\r\nin space he had to find? And what was he supposed to do once he got\r\nthere?\r\n\r\nAnd who had given him the instructions? Where, in the vast immensity\r\nof the universe was the place called "home", the place where he could\r\nreturn for the information he had forgotten?\r\n\r\nHe didn\'t recall. He knew only, with that same distressing vagueness,\r\nthat somewhere there was something he had been ordered to do. And that\r\nonce given, the order had to be carried out.\r\n\r\nHe traveled aimlessly, by feeling alone. Time meant nothing to him as\r\nan individual, for his kind had long mastered the problems of age. But\r\ntime meant much to those he had been sent to--to do what? Was it to\r\nhelp? They must be waiting for him now. They must be wondering why he\r\ndidn\'t come.\r\n\r\nHe would have to hurry. Hurry to do something he didn\'t yet suspect,\r\nbut would sooner or later remember.\r\n\r\nAfter a few centuries, he began, in his anxiety, to talk to himself,\r\nas is the way of individuals too long alone. "That star cluster there\r\ncould be it," he said to himself hopefully, and veered toward the right.\r\n\r\n"Doesn\'t look familiar, though," he muttered. "Maybe if I would get\r\ncloser--"\r\n\r\nHe came close enough to see the thousands of stars as individuals, to\r\npick out the satellites circling the bright discs of light, to study\r\nthe pale planets themselves and their tiny subsatellites. As he turned\r\nhis attention from one to another, disappointment slowly filled him.\r\nNo, this was not the place. There was nothing in the configuration of\r\nthe stars, nothing in the size or position of the planets that sounded\r\na familiar chord in his consciousness. He would have to go further--or\r\nturn back.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe left the place behind him. The next time the same thing happened he\r\ndidn\'t have quite so much hope, and his disappointment was less keen.\r\nBut it was disappointment none the less. Time was passing, and they\r\nmust be waiting for him impatiently.\r\n\r\nAfter a while the hope and the disappointment both died away almost\r\ncompletely. The former shrank to a tiny spark that grew dimmer and\r\ndimmer as the centuries passed. He wondered if it would ever wink out\r\nentirely.\r\n\r\nIt was characteristic of him that the anxiety this caused was only\r\nfor those who were waiting, expecting him hourly, and wondering why\r\nhe didn\'t come. He had no sense of fear for himself, no feeling of\r\ndespairing loneliness that might be expected to arise from being so\r\nlong isolated in space. It was only that he would have liked some one\r\nto talk to, besides himself.\r\n\r\nOn a fair number of planets he found animal-like creatures in\r\ndifferent stages of development, and on a few he discovered life that\r\nwas intelligent. It was with these that he had a renewed feeling of\r\nanticipation, the spark of hope glowing momentarily before it faded\r\nagain.\r\n\r\n"It\'s intelligent life I\'ve got to find," he told himself. "But where?"\r\n\r\nHis astronomical memory, insofar as it covered the post-nova\r\nperiod, was perfect, and he paid more attention to the details of\r\nstar-and-planet configuration than he had ever done before. Gradually\r\na star-map formed in his mind, a map that covered enormous distances\r\nof space. Those places he had investigated and eliminated from\r\nconsideration were slowly crossed off. It was a large needle he had to\r\nfind, and his own powers were considerable, but the haystack he had to\r\nsearch was infinite. There was no telling how many more centuries would\r\npass before he found it.\r\n\r\nAnd then another thought struck him. They\'d know back home that\r\nsomething had gone wrong. Would they send someone else to do the job in\r\nhis place?\r\n\r\nHe rather doubted it. He had a vague feeling that there weren\'t many\r\nwith his own peculiar talents. 

What had to be done had to be done by\r\nhim, or left undone altogether.\r\n\r\nMore time passed. And one day, when the space charted on his brain-map\r\nhad grown to vast dimensions, and the spark of hope had become so tiny\r\nthat he was not quite sure any longer that it was there at all, he\r\nnoted from a distance a galaxy that seemed familiar.\r\n\r\n"That\'s it!" he cried. "That\'s it!"\r\n\r\nThe spark flared, and as he sped toward the galaxy it became a flame.\r\nIt was a lens-shaped assemblage of stars, with two small spiral arms\r\ncomposed of a few million stars each, and it was seemingly not too\r\ndifferent from millions of other galaxies he had passed in the course\r\nof all those centuries. The third planet, the one with a single subsatellite, was\r\nthe one he had been sent to find. To find, and perhaps to help. But how?\r\n\r\nThe finding of the planet had solved one problem. So far it had given\r\nhim not a hint toward the solution of the second--the reason why he had\r\nbeen sent here.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThere was life on this ball of mud and water, a great deal of life,\r\nboth vegetable and animal. And some of the latter could, without too\r\ngreat a distortion of the truth, be called intelligent. 

It had raised\r\ncities, tunneled into mountains, changed the appearance of sections of\r\nthe planet itself. It was to this intelligent life that he had been\r\nsent.\r\n\r\nA dim memory of the need for caution kept him from letting himself be\r\nseen. "I\'d only frighten them," he thought. "I\'ll have to investigate\r\nthoroughly before I reveal myself. And maybe the investigation will\r\nremind me of what I have to do.

"\r\n\r\nThe first thing was to come down to earth. Choosing the dark side of\r\nthe planet, shaded from the central sun by its own bulk, he shrank his\r\nbody and let himself drop in the gravitational field. From time to time\r\nhe slowed his fall in order to keep from flaming through the atmosphere\r\nand attracting their attention. He\r\nhad to do some simple thing, something--\r\n\r\nThe two men were lying in wait, either for him or for some other\r\npedestrian they judged sufficiently unwary. He sensed them long before\r\nthe first one stepped out toward him, a cigarette in one hand and what\r\nwas supposed to be an ingratiating look on the brutal face.\r\n\r\n"Got a match, bud?"\r\n\r\nThe other man suddenly plunged at him from the side, an arm wrapping\r\nitself around his neck. He wasn\'t here to punish\r\neither.\r\n\r\nHe walked along, and soon he found himself entering the city. Many of those\r\nwho saw him seemed to sense his strangeness, and moved toward him with\r\na single impulse--to take advantage of his ignorance. Just came off a truck_--"\r\n\r\n"_Wanta look at some nice pictures, Mister?_"\r\n\r\n"_I can give you a good address, Bud._"\r\n\r\n"_Out for a good time, Jack?_"\r\n\r\nThe planet was sick. Had he been sent to cure it?\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe came to an area of broad lighted streets. Lights glittered\r\neverywhere, attracting the attention of those around him by going on\r\nand off. Great posters advertised the attractions inside places of\r\namusement.\r\n\r\nHe entered one of them, an astonished ticket-collector calling after\r\nhim, "Hey, where\'s your ticket, Bud?" But there was something about him\r\nthat prevented the man from pursuing.\r\n\r\nHe lost himself in the darkness and watched the screen. 

Here, in\r\nbrief and vivid form, was pictured the life of the planet. Women in\r\nbathing suits plunged into a pool and formed a pattern which imitated\r\nsensuously the petals of an unfolding rose. A small animal leaped\r\nthrough hoops and climbed a ladder. Groups of men drove against each\r\nother for possession of an object which they kicked occasionally\r\ninto the air. An elderly man looked grim and made a speech into a\r\nmicrophone. And then a film showed the main business of the planet,\r\nwhich seemed to be the killing of its supposedly intelligent\r\ninhabitants. Bombs exploded, planes crashed, desperate lines of men ran\r\nforward to meet their deaths.\r\n\r\nSomething quickened in his mind. He almost remembered now. This was\r\nwhat he had come here about.\r\n\r\nHis will moved, and the theatre vanished behind him. Now he was on the\r\nbattlefield itself.\r\n\r\nThe reality was worse than the image, far worse. Here were not only the\r\nroars of the great guns, but the curses and screams of the wounded, the\r\ngasps of the dying. Here were not only horrible sights and sounds, but\r\nthe odors of death--the sharp nitrogenous fragrance of explosives, the\r\nheavy sulfurous smoke of burning oil, the sickening smell of sweating\r\nor decaying flesh.\r\n\r\nA cloud came into being from the explosion of a mortar shell, and two\r\nmen dropped to the ground. In answer to the mortar, the flaring barrel\r\nof a tank gun spoke hoarsely, and half the crew of the mortar fell in\r\nturn. 

But there seemed no end to this deadly dialogue. The next moment\r\nthere came the burst of a bomb from a low-flying plane, and the tank\r\nhalf turned over on its side, a heap of smoking steel.\r\n\r\nHe knew at last why he had been sent here. He knew now what he had to\r\ndo.\r\n\r\nHe ripped the flaring-mouthed gun from the tank. His hands twisted the\r\nthick metal into a shape it had never known before, bent it into a\r\nstrange curve, fashioned it so that it would emit overtones to chill\r\nthe souls of those who heard it. His brain charged the instrument with\r\nthe energy of his own mind, energy that would send its voice to the far\r\ncorners of this diseased planet, and leave not a single individual deaf\r\nto its dreaded tones.\r\n\r\nPutting the improvised horn to his lips, Gabriel blew the call for\r\nwhich the planet had so long been waiting.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n

"\r\n\r\nThe relieving pair fell to. Mike stepped out of range of the flying\r\nchips to sit at the edge of the soft grass which was attempting another\r\ninvasion of the gravel shoulder. "You want the busted spot on the tree to\r\nshow?"\r\n\r\n"Aw, _they_ ain\'t got the brains to notice."\r\n\r\n"The hell they ain\'t! It stands out like one o\' them old street signs.\r\nD\'ya think they can tell, Blackie?"\r\n\r\n"I dunno. 

Maybe." Blackie rose cautiously to peer over a bed of\r\nblackberry bushes. "Guess I\'ll skin up a tree an\' see if anything\'s in\r\nsight."\r\n\r\nHe hitched up his pants, looking for an easy place to climb. They jounced in\r\nturn across a patch laid over a previous, unsuccessful patch, and halted\r\nbefore the felled tree. 

Two were bulldozers; the third was a light truck\r\nwith compartments for tools. No human figures were visible.\r\n\r\nA moment later, the working force appeared--a column of eight robots.\r\nThese deployed as they reached the obstacle, and explored like colossal\r\nants along its length.\r\n\r\n"What\'re they after?" asked Mike, whispering although he lay fifty yards\r\naway.\r\n\r\n"They\'re lookin\' over the job for whatever sends them out," Blackie\r\nwhispered back. "See those little lights stickin\' out the tops o\' their\r\nheads? 

I heard tell, once, that\'s how they\'re run."\r\n\r\nSome of the robots took saws from the truck and began to cut through the\r\ntree trunk. Others produced cables and huge hooks to attach the obstacle\r\nto the bulldozers.\r\n\r\n"Look at \'em go!" sighed Sid, hunching his stiff shoulders jealously.\r\n"Took us hours, an\' they\'re half done already."\r\n\r\nThey watched as the robots precisely severed the part of the tree that\r\nblocked the highway, going not one inch beyond the gravel shoulder, and\r\nhelped the bulldozers to tug it aside. On the opposite side of the\r\nconcrete, the shoulder tapered off into a six-foot drop. The log was\r\njockeyed around parallel to this ditch and rolled into it, amid a\r\nthrashing of branches and a spurting of small pebbles.\r\n\r\n"Glad we\'re on the high side," whispered Mike. "That thing \'ud squash a\r\nguy\'s guts right out!

"\r\n\r\n"Keep listenin\' to me," Blackie said, "an\' you\'ll keep on bein\' in the\r\nright place at the right time."\r\n\r\nMike raised his eyebrows at Vito, who thrust out his lower lip and\r\nnodded sagely. Sid grinned, but no one contradicted the boast.\r\n\r\n"They\'re linin\' up," Blackie warned tensely. "You guys ready? 

Where\'s\r\nthat rope?"\r\n\r\nSomeone thrust it into his hands. Still squinting at the scene on the\r\nhighway, he fumbled for the ends and held one out to Mike. The others\r\ngripped their clubs.\r\n\r\n"Now, remember!" ordered Blackie. "Me an\' Mike will trip up the last one\r\nin line. You two get in there quick an\' wallop him over the head--but\r\ngood!"\r\n\r\n"Don\'t go away while we\'re doin\' it," said big Sid. "They won\'t chase\r\nya, but they look out fer themselves. I don\'t wanna get tossed twenty\r\nfeet again!"\r\n\r\nThe eyes of the others flicked toward the jagged white scar running down\r\nbehind Sid\'s right ear and under the collar of his jacket. Then they\r\nswung back to the road.\r\n\r\n"Good!" 

breathed Blackie. "The rollin\' stuff\'s goin\' first."\r\n\r\nThe truck and bulldozers set out toward the city, with the column of\r\nrobots marching a fair distance behind. The latter approached the\r\nambush--drew abreast--began to pass.\r\n\r\nBlackie raised himself to a crouch with just the tips of his fingers\r\nsteadying him.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAs the last robot plodded by, he surged out of the brush, joined to Red\r\nMike by their grips on the twenty feet of rope. They ran up behind the\r\nmarching machine, trailed by the others.\r\n\r\nIn his right hand, Blackie twirled the part of the rope hanging between\r\nhim and Mike. On the second swing, he got it over the head of the robot.\r\nHe saw Mike brace himself.\r\n\r\nThe robot staggered. It pivoted clumsily to its left, groping vaguely\r\nfor the hindrance. Mike and Blackie tugged again, and the machine wound\r\nup facing them in its efforts to maintain balance. Its companions\r\nmarched steadily along the road.\r\n\r\n"Switch ends!" barked Blackie.\r\n\r\nAlert, Mike tossed him the other end of the rope and caught Blackie\'s.\r\nThey ran past the robot on either side, looping it in. Blackie kept\r\ngoing until he was above the ditch. He wound a turn of rope about his\r\nforearm and plunged down the bank.\r\n\r\n[Illustration: _With skill of long practice, they brought the robot\r\ndown._]\r\n\r\nA shower of gravel spattered after him as Mike jammed his heels into the\r\nshoulder of the highway to anchor the other end. Then he heard the\r\nbooming sound of the robot\'s fall.\r\n\r\nBlackie clawed his way up the bank. Vito and Sid were smashing furiously\r\nat the floundering machine. Mike danced about the melee with bared\r\nteeth, charging in once as if to leap upon the quarry with both feet.\r\nFrustrated by the peril of the whirling two-by-fours, he swept up\r\nhandfuls of gravel to hurl.\r\n\r\nBlackie turned to run for one of the axes. Just then, Sid struck home to\r\nthe head of the robot.\r\n\r\nSparks spat out amid a tinkle of glass. The machine ceased all motion.\r\n\r\n"All right!" panted Blackie. "All _right_! That\'s enough!"\r\n\r\nThey stepped back, snarls fading. 

A handful of gravel trickled through\r\nMike\'s fingers and pattered loudly on the concrete. Gradually, the men\r\nbegan to straighten up, seeing the robot as an inert heap of metal\r\nrather than as a weird beast in its death throes.\r\n\r\n"We better load up an\' get," said Blackie. "We wanna be over on the\r\ntrail if they send somethin\' up the road to look for _this_."\r\n\r\nVito dragged the robot off the highway by the head, and they began the\r\ntask of lashing it to the two-by-fours.\r\n\r\nIt was about two hours later when they plodded around a street corner\r\namong the ruins and stopped before a fairly intact building. By that\r\ntime, they had picked up an escort of dirty, half-clad children who ran\r\nahead to spread the news.\r\n\r\nTwo other men and a handful of women gathered around with eager\r\nexclamations. The hunters dropped their catch.\r\n\r\n"Better get to work on him," said Blackie, glancing at the sky. "Be dark\r\nsoon."\r\n\r\nThe men who had remained as guards ran inside the entrance of polished\r\ngranite and brought out tools: hammers, crowbars, hatchets. Behind them\r\nhurried women with basins and large cans. The original four, weary from\r\nthe weight of the robot despite frequent pauses on the trail, stepped\r\nback.\r\n\r\n"Where first, Blackie?" asked one of the men, waiting for the women to\r\nuntangle the rope and timbers.\r\n\r\n"Try all the joints. After that, we\'ll crack him open down the middle\r\nfor the main supply tank.

"\r\n\r\nHe watched the metal give way under the blows. As the robot was\r\ndismembered, the fluid that had lubricated the complex mechanism flowed\r\nfrom its wounds and was poured by the women into a five-gallon can.\r\n\r\n"Bring a cupful, Judy," Blackie told his woman, a wiry blond girl. "I\r\nwanna see if it\'s as good as the last.

"\r\n\r\nHe lit a stick at the fire as they crossed the littered, once-ornate\r\nlobby, and she followed him down a dim hall. He pulled aside the skins\r\nthat covered their doorway, then stumbled his way to the table. The\r\nwindow was still uncovered against the night chill, but it looked out on\r\na courtyard shadowed by towering walls. To eyes adjusted to the sunny\r\nstreet, the room was dark.\r\n\r\nJudy poured the oil into the makeshift lamp, waited for the rag wick to\r\nsoak, and held it out to Blackie. He lit the wick from his stick.\r\n\r\n"It burns real good, Blackie," the girl said, wrinkling her nose against\r\nthe first oily smoke. "Gee, you\'re smart to catch one the first day\r\nout."\r\n\r\n"Tell them other dames to watch how they use it!" he warned. 

"This\r\noughta last a month or more when we get him all emptied."\r\n\r\nHe blew out the dying flame on the stick and dropped the charred wood\r\nthoughtfully to the floor.\r\n\r\n"Naw, I ain\'t so smart," he admitted, "or I\'d figure a way to make one\r\nof them work the garden for us. Maybe someday--but _this_ kind won\'t do\r\nnothin\' but fix that goddam road, an\' what good\'s that to anybody?"\r\n\r\nHis woman moved the burning lamp carefully to the center of the table.\r\n\r\n"Anyway, it\'s gonna be better\'n last winter," she said. "We\'ll have\r\nlights now."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


"The rich get richer and the poor stay\r\npoor."\r\n\r\n"The wallpaper," Stahl smoothly proceeded, "is a replica of Italian\r\nmurals. If you adjust your focus properly the flat columns become\r\nsolids through the art of vanishing-point perspective."\r\n\r\n"Excellent period distortion of Greek styles," said Tinker, studying\r\nthe columns. "Genuine old copies are\r\neven scarcer than their originals. And originals, of course, can never\r\nbe quite as good."\r\n\r\n"Sometimes I don\'t see why," Smith muttered.\r\n\r\nThey all looked shocked. "\r\n\r\n"A little rundown," Smith admitted, "but.... Oh, let\'s forget it."\r\n\r\n"Let\'s," Stahl nodded, striving to recapture the pair\'s attention as\r\nthey went on through the Suite. She looked back, mildly interested. "We\'ll get there\r\neventually."\r\n\r\nHappily oblivious to everything but his collections, Stahl led them\r\ninto the library.
