Mrs. 

Stahl laughed. "But this must be a special occasion for\r\nyou."\r\n\r\nEyes bulging nervously, Smith ran his fingers through his luxuriant\r\nhair and sighed, "Special it is. All right."\r\n\r\nStahl casually mixed drinks for them all and sipped an Old Fashioned.\r\n"I\'ve concentrated somewhat more on the twentieth century of the Old\r\nTimes than any other," he said. "A particularly intriguing century, I\r\nfind, although not crucial like the twenty-first, of course."\r\n\r\n"_The_ crucial one," Tinker protested.\r\n\r\n"As a fellow antiquarian, I must beg to differ, sir."\r\n\r\n"What about rocket travel, Mr. Stahl? When did that begin?"\r\n\r\n"Old hat," he yawned.\r\n\r\n"And atomic energy?"\r\n\r\n"Same applies there. 

Look, Tinker, don\'t get me wrong. I love the\r\nperiod. But, objectively viewed, the twenty-first makes the great\r\ndifference."\r\n\r\n"And what about duplication of life functions, like the mechanical\r\nheart? That really got started in the twentieth."\r\n\r\n"Absolutely right," Smith nodded vigorously.\r\n\r\n"All strictly mechanical," Stahl sighed. "But the twenty-first turned\r\nthe study of pain and pleasure itself from an art into a true science."\r\n\r\n"No, no," scoffed the cyberneticist.\r\n\r\nStahl pounded the bar. "All right, I\'m going to prove it by putting on\r\nan All-Sense Feeliescope of Thomas Dyall. It\'s fully sense-adapted, so\r\nit should pick up perfectly."\r\n\r\n"Hope it isn\'t noisy," said Smith.\r\n\r\n"It\'s _beautiful_," answered Mary Stahl. "I could listen to it all day."\r\n\r\nThe odor of damp, new-mown grass filled the room and another more\r\nelusive scent mingled with it. _Entry of June 3rd, 2068_, said an\r\nimpersonal, mechanical voice, _from the journal of Thomas Dyall,\r\nelected World\'s First Poet Laureate in 2089_. A warm rich bass took\r\nover:\r\n\r\n    This morning I rode far out to reach open countryside in the\r\n    preserved areas to replenish my stock of sensory experiences. As\r\n    I was walking along through the woods, the most delicious scent\r\n    struck my nostrils. I immediately recognized new-mown grass in\r\n    it but the factor making the true difference escaped me until I\r\n    realized the faint odor belonged to roses. At that point, my\r\n    senses reeling with delight, I composed in my mind most of my\r\n    long poem, _The Nature of Nature_, grasping intuitively an\r\n    experience more intense, more valuable, than any "real" one. I\r\n    say _intuitively_ because I still thought the odor was merely\r\n    that of grass and roses. A minute afterwards, though, I came\r\n    into a clearing, spotted a forest ranger\'s cottage there and\r\n    discovered that the scent was from a recently-improved insecticide\r\n    that the ranger\'s wife was using in the living room. There was\r\n    little grass in the area and not a single rose!\r\n\r\n_The following note_, interrupted the monotone voice, _was added by\r\nthe author in the year 2116_:\r\n\r\n    Here in "real" life the great guiding principle of my future was\r\n    brought home to me. The well-done imitation of a thing was better\r\n    than the thing itself! This was the lesson I had to disseminate for\r\n    all humanity.\r\n\r\n"Interesting," Tinker said, "although we all know now that one thing\r\ncannot be substituted for. Also--"\r\n\r\n"No discussion now," pleaded Smith. 

"You need a while to consider all\r\nthat. Anyway, I\'ve been thinking about your bill, Stahl. That wasn\'t a\r\nfold on Washington\'s eyelid, just a tiny inkstain. It\'s _genuine_."\r\n\r\n"It can\'t be," Stahl snapped and angrily led them back to the first\r\nroom. "Tinker, I want you as my witness."\r\n\r\nHe handed the bill around and Smith had to concede it was really\r\ncounterfeit. "What\'s that next one?" 

he asked.\r\n\r\n"A ten." Stahl hesitated, then took it off the pile along with three\r\nothers and passed them to the visitors, showing off fine points of\r\nimitation. When he collected the bills he carefully made certain there\r\nwere still five and locked them up again.\r\n\r\n"What about another drink?" Smith asked hastily.\r\n\r\n"No." Tinker sat down in a large chair. "Let\'s straighten out\r\nsomething right now, Stahl. Dyall was making the first crude statement\r\nof an obvious truth. If we have a pleasant sensation it doesn\'t matter\r\nwhether it\'s caused by a rose or a chemical imitation of a rose or by\r\nmaking a brain imagine a rose--doesn\'t matter except that the real rose\r\nitself is the hardest thing to control. So it can\'t be as intensely\r\nreal as its imitations."\r\n\r\n"Mr. Tinker, isn\'t that crucial enough for you?" Mrs. 

Stahl asked. Her\r\nvoice was so rich and warmly rounded that Smith stared wonderingly at\r\nher, as if trying to fathom an alien tongue.\r\n\r\n"Not quite," Tinker shrugged. "Stahl, you\'re discussing the smallest\r\naspect of the three-part equation, Stimulus + Stimulated Body =\r\nExperience. Your poet was saying certain changes in Stimulus would\r\nstill give a Stimulated Body the same Experience as the original. But\r\nthe philosophers and cyberneticists, they already suspected something\r\nmore radical. If the Stimulated Body was properly changed, the same\r\nStimulus could give different Bodies the same Experience. In other\r\nwords, a properly-arranged process would have the same Experience as\r\nthe life function for which it was substituted."\r\n\r\n"Now then," he went on, "all life reproduces itself, right? Well,\r\nthey finally figured the most important thing to reproduce was a\r\nman\'s Experience itself, not any particular form of Stimulated Body.\r\nOf course we have higher ideals. We want the Stimulated Body to be as\r\nnearly like what it was as possible--then we can have the best of _all_\r\npossible worlds."\r\n\r\n"Some people," Smith grumbled, "don\'t get their fair share of that\r\nbest.

"\r\n\r\n"Anyway I hate _all_ theories," said Mrs. Stahl.\r\n\r\nStahl disregarded them as he stared at his cashbox. "My money," he said\r\nominously, "has been changed!"\r\n\r\nThe two visitors exchanged nervous glances. "That\'s not possible," said\r\nTinker.\r\n\r\n"It _is_. Somebody\'s palmed a real one as a substitute!"\r\n\r\n"That\'s very unfair," Smith protested. "We came here as guests,\r\nstrangers to you and to each other. "\r\n\r\nThey stopped a few feet away and waited. For, when their brilliant\r\nlabors had dehumanized them, the humans had possessed sufficient\r\nunderstanding to pass the dead world on to the superior wisdom of their\r\ncreations. If _they_ had been unable to foresee what would eventually\r\nhappen, Stahl and his fellow robots could. Some day the supreme\r\nknowledge and the supreme feeling would be perfectly wedded, the day\r\nthey became truly humanoid copies of their makers.\r\n\r\nHe moved forward, Tinker following him, to help his fellow creature\r\ncloser to that common final destiny.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n

"Maybe\r\nwe can pin something down a little better. You say your name is\r\nParks--right?"\r\n\r\nThe man nodded. "Jefferson Haldeman Parks, if that helps any. Haldeman\r\nwas my mother\'s maiden name."\r\n\r\n"All right. 

And you got into town on Friday--right?"\r\n\r\nParks nodded.\r\n\r\n"Fine. Now go through the whole story again. What happened first?"\r\n\r\nThe man thought for a minute. "As I said, first there was a fall. About\r\ntwenty feet. I didn\'t break any bones, but I was shaken up and limping.\r\nThe fall was near the highway going to the George Washington Bridge. I\r\ngot over to the highway and tried to flag down a ride."\r\n\r\n"How did you feel? 

I mean, was there anything strange that you noticed?"\r\n\r\n"_Strange!_" Parks\' eyes widened. "I--I was speechless. At first I\r\nhadn\'t noticed too much--I was concerned with the fall, and whether I\r\nwas hurt or not. But a car stopped and asked me\r\nif I was going into the city, and I knew I wasn\'t crazy."\r\n\r\nMorgan\'s mouth took a grim line. "You understood the language?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, yes. "I know, I noticed. What did you do when you got to New\r\nYork?"\r\n\r\n"Well, obviously, I needed money. I had gold coin. There\r\nwas no design on them, and no printing. Morgan looked up at the man\r\nsharply. "What did you get for these?"\r\n\r\nParks shrugged. "Too little, I suspect. Two dollars for the small one,\r\nfive for the larger."\r\n\r\n"You should have gone to a bank."\r\n\r\n"I know that now. I didn\'t then. Naturally, I assumed that with\r\neverything else so similar, principles of business would also be\r\nsimilar."\r\n\r\nMorgan sighed and leaned back in his chair. 

"Well, then what?"\r\n\r\nParks poured some more coffee. His face was very pale, Morgan thought,\r\nand his hands trembled as he raised the cup to his lips. Fright? Maybe.\r\nHard to tell. The man put down the cup and rubbed his forehead with the\r\nback of his hand. "First, I went to the mayor\'s office," he said. "I\r\nkept trying to think what anyone at home would do in my place. That\r\nseemed a good bet. I asked a policeman where it was, and then I went\r\nthere."\r\n\r\n"But you didn\'t get to see him."\r\n\r\n"No. I saw a secretary. She said the mayor was in conference, and that I\r\nwould have to have an appointment. She let me speak to another man, one\r\nof the mayor\'s assistants."\r\n\r\n"And you told him?"\r\n\r\n"No. I wanted to see the mayor himself. I thought that was the best\r\nthing to do. I waited for a couple of hours, until another assistant\r\ncame along and told me flatly that the mayor wouldn\'t see me unless I\r\nstated my business first." He drew in a deep breath. 

"So I stated it.\r\nAnd then I was gently but firmly ushered back into the street again."\r\n\r\n"They didn\'t believe you," said Morgan.\r\n\r\n"Not for a minute. They laughed in my face."\r\n\r\nMorgan nodded. "I\'m beginning to get the pattern. 

So what did you do\r\nnext?"\r\n\r\n"Next I tried the police. I got the same treatment there, only they\r\nweren\'t so gentle. 

They wouldn\'t listen either. They muttered something\r\nabout cranks and their crazy notions, and when they asked me where I\r\nlived, they thought I was--what did they call it?--a wise guy! Told me\r\nto get out and not come back with any more wild stories."\r\n\r\n"I see," said Morgan.\r\n\r\nJefferson Parks finished his last bite of pie and pushed the plate away.\r\n"By then I didn\'t know quite what to do. I\'d been prepared for almost\r\nanything excepting this. 

It was frightening. I tried to rationalize it,\r\nand then I quit trying. It wasn\'t that I attracted attention, or\r\nanything like that, quite the contrary. Nobody even looked at me, unless\r\nI said something to them. I began to look for things that were\r\n_different_, things that I could show them, and say, see, this proves\r\nthat I\'m telling the truth, look at it--" He looked up helplessly.\r\n\r\n"And what did you find?"\r\n\r\n"Nothing. Oh, little things, insignificant little things. Your\r\ncalendars, for instance. Naturally, I couldn\'t understand your frame of\r\nreference. And the coinage, you stamp your coins; we don\'t. And\r\ncigarettes. We don\'t have any such thing as tobacco." The man gave a\r\nshort laugh. "And your house dogs! We have little animals that look more\r\nlike rabbits than poodles. But there was nothing any more significant\r\nthan that. 

Absolutely nothing."\r\n\r\n"Except yourself," Morgan said.\r\n\r\n"Ah, yes. I thought that over carefully. I looked for differences,\r\nobvious ones. I couldn\'t find any. You can see that, just looking at me.\r\nSo I searched for more subtle things. Skin texture, fingerprints, bone\r\nstructure, body proportion. I still couldn\'t find anything. 

Then I went\r\nto a doctor."\r\n\r\nMorgan\'s eyebrows lifted. "Good," he said.\r\n\r\nParks shrugged tiredly. "Not really. He examined me. He practically took\r\nme apart. I carefully refrained from saying anything about who I was or\r\nwhere I came from; just said I wanted a complete physical examination,\r\nand let him go to it. He was thorough, and when he finished he patted me\r\non the back and said, \'Parks, you\'ve got nothing to worry about. You\'re\r\nas fine, strapping a specimen of a healthy human being as I\'ve ever\r\nseen.\' And that was that." Parks laughed bitterly. "I guess I was\r\nsupposed to be happy with the verdict, and instead I was ready to knock\r\nhim down. It was idiotic, it defied reason, it was infuriating."\r\n\r\nMorgan nodded sourly. "Because you\'re not a human being," he said.\r\n\r\n"That\'s right. I\'m not a human being at all."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"How did you happen to pick this planet, or this sun?" Morgan asked\r\ncuriously. "There must have been a million others to choose from."\r\n\r\nParks unbuttoned his collar and rubbed his stubbled chin unhappily. "I\r\ndidn\'t make the choice. 

Neither did anyone else. Travel by warp is a\r\nlittle different from travel by the rocket you fiction writers make so\r\nmuch of. With a rocket vehicle you pick your destination, make your\r\ncalculations, and off you go. The warp is blind flying, strictly blind.\r\nWe send an unmanned scanner ahead. It probes around more or less\r\nhit-or-miss until it locates something, somewhere, that looks habitable.\r\nWhen it spots a likely looking place, we keep a tight beam on it and\r\nsend through a manned scout." He grinned sourly. "Like me. If it looks\r\ngood to the scout, he signals back, and they leave the warp anchored for\r\na sort of permanent gateway until we can get a transport beam built. But\r\nwe can\'t control the directional and dimensional scope of the warp.\r\nThere are an infinity of ways it can go, until we have a guide beam\r\ntransmitting from the other side. Then we can just scan a segment of\r\nspace with the warp, and the scanner picks up the beam."\r\n\r\nHe shook his head wearily. 

"We\'re new at it, Morgan. We\'ve only tried a\r\nfew dozen runs. We\'re not too far ahead of you in technology. We\'ve been\r\nusing rocket vehicles just like yours for over a century. That\'s fine\r\nfor a solar system, but it\'s not much good for the stars. When the warp\r\nprinciple was discovered, it looked like the answer. asked Morgan. "You look like a human being. You talk\r\nlike one. You eat like one. You act like one. What you\'re asking them to\r\nbelieve is utterly incredible."\r\n\r\n"_But it\'s true._"\r\n\r\nMorgan shrugged. "So it\'s true. I won\'t argue with you. Combine our knowledges, our technologies,\r\nand we could explore the galaxy!"\r\n\r\nHe leaned forward, his thin face intense. "I need money and I need help.\r\nI know some of the mathematics of the warp principle, know some of the\r\ndesign, some of the power and wiring principles. You have engineers\r\nhere, technologists, physicists. They could fill in what I don\'t know\r\nand build a guide beam. But they won\'t do it if they don\'t believe me.\r\nYour government won\'t listen to me, they won\'t appropriate any money."\r\n\r\n"Of course they won\'t. They\'ve got a war or two on their hands, they\r\nhave public welfare, and atomic bombs, and rockets to the moon to sink\r\ntheir money into." Morgan stared at the man. 

"But what can _I_ do?"\r\n\r\n"You can _write_! That\'s what you can do. You can tell the world about\r\nme, you can tell exactly what has happened. I know how public interest\r\ncan be aroused in my world. It must be the same in yours."\r\n\r\nMorgan didn\'t move. He just stared. "And I\'m the one man who couldn\'t help you if my life depended\r\non it," he gasped.\r\n\r\n"You believe me?"\r\n\r\nMorgan nodded sadly. "I believe you. 

Yes. I think your warp brought you\r\nthrough to a parallel universe of your own planet, not to another star,\r\nbut I think you\'re telling the truth."\r\n\r\n"Then you _can_ help me.

"\r\n\r\n"I\'m afraid not."\r\n\r\n"Why not?"\r\n\r\n"Because I\'d be worse than no help at all."\r\n\r\nJefferson Parks gripped the table, his knuckles white. "Why?" 

he cried\r\nhoarsely. "If you believe me, why can\'t you help me?"\r\n\r\nMorgan pointed to the magazine lying on the table. "I write, yes," he\r\nsaid sadly. ]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n                   It was the awfullest dream in the\r\n                 world, no doubt about it. In fact, it\r\n                seemed to be the only dream there was!\r\n\r\n\r\nHe was a morning type, so it was unusual that he should feel depressed\r\nin the morning. Often she ate at Cahill\'s in the mornings with her\r\ngirl friend.\r\n\r\nGrape juice, pineapple juice, orange juice, apple juice ... why did\r\npeople look at him suspiciously just because he took four or five sorts\r\nof juice for breakfast?\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Agnes, it was ghastly. And yet she\r\nwas still recognizable. How could my mother look like a wart-hog and\r\nstill look like my mother? Mama\'s pretty!"\r\n\r\n"Teresa, it was only a dream. 

Forget it."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe stares a man must suffer just to get a dozen pancakes on his plate!\r\nWhat was the matter with people who called four pancakes a tall stack?\r\nAnd what was odd about ordering a quarter of a pound of butter? It was\r\nbetter than having twenty of those little pats each on its coaster.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Agnes, we all of us had eyes that bugged out. 

And we stank! We were\r\nbloated, and all the time it rained a dirty green rain that smelled\r\nlike a four letter word. Good grief, girl! We had hair all over us\r\nwhere we weren\'t warts. And we talked like cracked crows. We had\r\ncrawlers. I itch just from thinking about it. And the dirty parts of\r\nthe dream I won\'t even tell you. I\'ve never felt so blue in my life. I\r\njust don\'t know how I\'ll make the day through."\r\n\r\n"Teresa, doll, how could a dream upset you so much?"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThere isn\'t a thing wrong with ordering three eggs sunny-side up, and\r\nthree over easy, and three poached ever so soft, and six of them\r\nscrambled. What law says a man should have all of his eggs fixed alike?\r\nNor is there anything wrong with ordering five cups of coffee. That way\r\nthe girl doesn\'t have to keep running over with refills.\r\n\r\nBascomb Swicegood liked to have bacon and waffles after the egg\r\ninterlude and the earlier courses. But he was nearly at the end of his\r\nbreakfast when he jumped up.\r\n\r\n"What did she say?"\r\n\r\nHe was surprised at the violence of his own voice.\r\n\r\n"What did who say, Mr. Swicegood?"\r\n\r\n"The girl that was just here, that just left with the other girl."\r\n\r\n"That was Teresa, and the other girl was Agnes. Or else that was Agnes\r\nand the other girl was Teresa. It depends on which girl you mean. 

I\r\ndon\'t know what either of them said."\r\n\r\nBascomb ran out into the street.\r\n\r\n"Girl, the girl who said it rained dirty green all the time, what\'s\r\nyour name?"\r\n\r\n"My name is Teresa. You\'ve met me four times. 

Every morning you look\r\nlike you never saw me before."\r\n\r\n"I\'m Agnes," said Agnes.\r\n\r\n"What did you mean it rained dirty green all the time? Tell me all\r\nabout it.

"\r\n\r\n"I will not, Mr. Swicegood. I was just telling a dream I had to Agnes.\r\nIt isn\'t any of your business."\r\n\r\n"Well, I have to hear all of it. Tell me everything you dreamed."\r\n\r\n"I will not. It was a dirty dream. It isn\'t any of your business. If\r\nyou weren\'t a friend of my Uncle Ed Kelly, I\'d call a policeman for\r\nyour bothering me."\r\n\r\n"Did you have things like live rats in your stomach to digest for you?\r\nDid they--"\r\n\r\n"Oh! How did you know? 

Get away from me. I _will_ call a policeman. Mr.\r\nMcCarty, this man is annoying me."\r\n\r\n"The devil he is, Miss Ananias. Old Bascomb just doesn\'t have it in him\r\nany more. There\'s no more harm in him than a lamp post."\r\n\r\n"Did the lamp posts have hair on them, Miss Teresa? Did they pant and\r\nswell and smell green--"\r\n\r\n"Oh! You couldn\'t know! 

You awful man!"\r\n\r\n"I\'m Agnes," said Agnes; but Teresa dragged Agnes away with her.\r\n\r\n"What is the lamp-post jag, Bascomb?" asked Officer Mossback McCarty.\r\n\r\n"Ah--I know what it is like to be in hell, Mossback. I dreamed of it\r\nlast night."\r\n\r\n"And well you should, a man who neglects his Easter duty year after\r\nyear. But the lamp-post jag? If it concerns anything on my beat, I have\r\nto know about it."\r\n\r\n"It seems that I had the same depressing dream as the young lady,\r\nidentical in every detail."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nNot knowing what dreams are (and we do not know) we should not find\r\nit strange that two people might have the same dream. There may not\r\nbe enough of them to go around, and most dreams are forgotten in the\r\nmorning.\r\n\r\nBascomb Swicegood had forgotten his dismal dream. He could not account\r\nfor his state of depression until he heard Teresa Ananias telling\r\npieces of her own dream to Agnes Schoenapfel. Even then it came back to\r\nhim slowly at first, but afterwards with a rush.\r\n\r\nThe oddity wasn\'t that two people should have the same dream, but that\r\nthey should discover the coincidence, what with the thousands of people\r\nrunning around and most of the dreams forgotten.\r\n\r\nYet, if it were a coincidence, it was a multiplex one. On the night\r\nwhen it was first made manifest it must have been dreamed by quite a\r\nnumber of people in one medium-large city. There was a small piece in\r\nan afternoon paper. One doctor had five different worried patients\r\nwho had had dreams of rats in their stomachs, and hair growing on\r\nthe insides of their mouths. This was the first publication of the\r\nshared-dream phenomenon.\r\n\r\nThe squib did not mention the foul-green-rain background, but later\r\ninvestigation uncovered that this and other details were common to the\r\ndreams.\r\n\r\nBut it was a reporter named Willy Wagoner who really put the town on\r\nthe map. Until he did the job, the incidents and notices had been\r\nisolated. Doctor Herome Judas had been putting together some notes on\r\nthe Green-Rain Syndrome. Doctor Florenz Appian had been working up\r\nhis evidence on the Surex Ventriculus Trauma, and Professor Gideon\r\nGreathouse had come to some learned conclusions on the inner meaning of\r\nwarts. But it was Willy Wagoner who went to the people for it, and then\r\ngave his conclusions back to the people.\r\n\r\nWilly said that he had interviewed a thousand people at random. (He\r\nhadn\'t really; he had talked to about twenty. It takes longer than you\r\nmight think to interview a thousand people.) He reported that slightly\r\nmore than sixty-seven per cent had had a dream of the same repulsive\r\nworld. He reported that more than forty-four per cent had had the dream\r\nmore than once, thirty-two per cent more than twice, twenty-seven per\r\ncent more than three times. Many had had it every damned night. And\r\nmany refused frostily to answer questions on the subject at all.\r\n\r\nThis was ten days after Bascomb Swicegood had heard Teresa Ananias tell\r\nher dream to Agnes.\r\n\r\nWilly published the opinions of the three learned gentlemen above, and\r\nthe theories and comments of many more. He also appended a hatful of\r\nanswers he had received that were sheer levity.\r\n\r\nBut the phenomenon was not local. Wagoner\'s article was the first\r\ncomprehensive (or at least wordy) treatment of it, but only by hours.\r\nSimilar things were in other papers that very afternoon, and the next\r\nday.\r\n\r\nIt was more than a fad. Those who called it a fad fell silent after\r\nthey themselves experienced the dream. The suicide index arose\r\naround the country and the world. The thing was now international.\r\nThe cacophonous ditty _Green Rain_ was on all the jukes, as was _The\r\nWart-Hog Song_. People began to loathe themselves and each other.\r\nWomen feared that they would give birth to monsters. 

There were\r\nnew perversions committed in the name of the thing, and several\r\norgiastic societies were formed with the stomach rat as a symbol. All\r\nentertainment was forgotten, and this was the only topic.\r\n\r\nNervous disorders took a fearful rise as people tried to stay awake\r\nto avoid the abomination, and as they slept in spite of themselves and\r\nsuffered the degradation.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIt is no joke to experience the same loathsome dream all night every\r\nnight. It had actually come to that. _All_ the people were dreaming it\r\n_all_ night _every_ night. It had passed from being a joke to being a\r\nuniversal menace. Even the sudden new millionaires who rushed their\r\ncures to the market were not happy. They also suffered whenever they\r\nslept, and they knew that their cures were not cures.\r\n\r\nThere were large amounts posted for anyone who could cure the populace\r\nof the wart-hog-people dreams. There was presidential edict and\r\ndictator decree, and military teams attacked the thing as a military\r\nproblem, but they were not able to subdue it.\r\n\r\nThen one night a nervous lady heard a voice in her noisome dream.\r\nIt was one of the repulsive cracked wart-hog voices. "You are not\r\ndreaming," said the voice. "This is the real world. But when you wake\r\nyou will be dreaming. That barefaced world is not a world at all. It is\r\nonly a dream. 

This is the real world." The lady awoke howling. And she\r\nhad not howled before, for she was a demure lady.\r\n\r\nNor was she the only one who awoke howling. There were hundreds,\r\nthen thousands, then millions. The voice spoke to all and engendered\r\na doubt. 

Which was the real world? Almost equal time was now spent in\r\neach, for the people had come to need more sleep and most of them had\r\narrived at spending a full twelve hours or more in the nightmarish\r\nworld.\r\n\r\n"It could be" was the title of a headlined article on the subject by\r\nthe same Professor Greathouse mentioned above. It could be, he said,\r\nthat the world on which the green rain fell incessantly was the real\r\nworld. It could be that the wart-hogs were real and the people a dream.\r\nIt could be that rats in the stomach were normal, and other methods of\r\ndigestion were chimerical.\r\n\r\nAnd then a very great man went on the air in worldwide broadcast with a\r\nspeech that was a ringing call for collective sanity. It was the hour\r\nof decision, he said. 

The decision would be made. Things were at an\r\nexact balance, and the balance would be tipped.\r\n\r\n"But we can decide. One way or the other, we _will_ decide. I implore\r\nyou all in the name of sanity that you decide right. One world or the\r\nother will be the world of tomorrow. One of them is real and one of\r\nthem is a dream. Both are with us now, and the favor can go to either.\r\nBut listen to me here: whichever one wins, the other _will have always\r\nbeen_ a dream, a momentary madness soon forgotten. I urge you to the\r\nsanity which in a measure I have lost myself. Yet in our darkened\r\ndilemma I feel that we yet have a choice. Choose!"\r\n\r\nAnd perhaps that was the turning point.\r\n\r\nThe mad dream disappeared as suddenly as it had appeared. The world\r\ncame back to normal with an embarrassed laugh. 

It was all over. It had\r\nlasted from its inception six weeks.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBascomb Swicegood, a morning type, felt excellent this morning. The loneliness!"\r\n\r\n"Yes, we hadn\'t even pediculi to curry our body hair. We almost hadn\'t\r\nany body hair."\r\n\r\nTeresa was an attractive girl. She had a cute trick of popping the\r\nsmallest rat out of her mouth so it could see what was coming into\r\nher stomach. She was bulbous and beautiful. And outside the\r\npungent green rain fell incessantly.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n

She turned the clock over and over. "Just like my mother had, when\r\nPete was still alive." Her eyes sparkled with tears.\r\n\r\n"It\'s made in Germany," Larry said. After a moment he added, "Carl got\r\nit for me wholesale. 

He knows some guy in the clock business. Otherwise\r\nI wouldn\'t have--" He stopped.\r\n\r\nDoris made a funny little sound.\r\n\r\n"I mean, otherwise I wouldn\'t have been able to afford it." He scowled.\r\n"What\'s the matter with you? You\'ve got your clock, haven\'t you? Isn\'t\r\nthat what you want?"\r\n\r\nDoris sat holding onto the clock, her fingers pressed against the brown\r\nwood.\r\n\r\n"Well," Larry said, "what\'s the matter?"\r\n\r\nHe watched in amazement as she leaped up and ran from the room, still\r\nclutching the clock. He shook his head. 

"Never satisfied. They\'re all\r\nthat way. 

Never get enough."\r\n\r\nHe sat down at the table and finished his meal.\r\n\r\nThe cuckoo clock was not very large. It was hand-made, however, and\r\nthere were countless frets on it, little indentations and ornaments\r\nscored in the soft wood. Doris sat on the bed drying her eyes and\r\nwinding the clock. She set the hands by her wristwatch. Presently she\r\ncarefully moved the hands to two minutes of ten. She carried the clock\r\nover to the dresser and propped it up.\r\n\r\nThen she sat waiting, her hands twisted together in her lap--waiting for\r\nthe cuckoo to come out, for the hour to strike.\r\n\r\nAs she sat she thought about Larry and what he had said. And what she\r\nhad said, too, for that matter--not that she could be blamed for any of\r\nit. After all, she couldn\'t keep listening to him forever without\r\ndefending herself; you had to blow your own trumpet in the world.\r\n\r\nShe touched her handkerchief to her eyes suddenly. Why did he have to\r\nsay that, about getting it wholesale? Why did he have to spoil it all?\r\nIf he felt that way he needn\'t have got it in the first place. She\r\nclenched her fists. He was so mean, so damn mean.\r\n\r\nBut she was glad of the little clock sitting there ticking to itself,\r\nwith its funny grilled edges and the door. Inside the door was the\r\ncuckoo, waiting to come out. Was he listening, his head cocked on one\r\nside, listening to hear the clock strike so that he would know to come\r\nout?\r\n\r\nDid he sleep between hours? Well, she would soon see him: she could ask\r\nhim. And she would show the clock to Bob. He would love it; Bob loved\r\nold things, even old stamps and buttons. He liked to go with her to the\r\nstores. Of course, it was a little _awkward_, but Larry had been staying\r\nat the office so much, and that helped. If only Larry didn\'t call up\r\nsometimes to--\r\n\r\nThere was a whirr. The clock shuddered and all at once the door opened.\r\nThe cuckoo came out, sliding swiftly. He paused and looked around\r\nsolemnly, scrutinizing her, the room, the furniture.\r\n\r\nIt was the first time he had seen her, she realized, smiling to herself\r\nin pleasure. She stood up, coming toward him shyly. "Go on," she said.\r\n"I\'m waiting."\r\n\r\nThe cuckoo opened his bill. He whirred and chirped, quickly,\r\nrhythmically. Then, after a moment of contemplation, he retired. And the\r\ndoor snapped shut.\r\n\r\nShe was delighted. She clapped her hands and spun in a little circle. He\r\nwas marvelous, perfect! And the way he had looked around, studying her,\r\nsizing her up. He liked her; she was certain of it. And she, of course,\r\nloved him at once, completely. He was just what she had hoped would come\r\nout of the little door.\r\n\r\nDoris went to the clock. She bent over the little door, her lips close\r\nto the wood. "Do you hear me?" 

she whispered. "I think you\'re the most\r\nwonderful cuckoo in the world." She paused, embarrassed. "I hope you\'ll\r\nlike it here."\r\n\r\nThen she went downstairs again, slowly, her head high.\r\n\r\nLarry and the cuckoo clock really never got along well from the start.\r\nDoris said it was because he didn\'t wind it right, and it didn\'t like\r\nbeing only half-wound all the time. Larry turned the job of winding over\r\nto her; the cuckoo came out every quarter hour and ran the spring down\r\nwithout remorse, and someone had to be ever after it, winding it up\r\nagain.\r\n\r\nDoris did her best, but she forgot a good deal of the time. Then Larry\r\nwould throw his newspaper down with an elaborate weary motion and stand\r\nup. He would go into the dining-room where the clock was mounted on the\r\nwall over the fireplace. He would take the clock down and making sure\r\nthat he had his thumb over the little door, he would wind it up.\r\n\r\n"Why do you put your thumb over the door?" Doris asked once.\r\n\r\n"You\'re supposed to."\r\n\r\nShe raised an eyebrow. 

"Are you sure? I wonder if it isn\'t that you\r\ndon\'t want him to come out while you\'re standing so close."\r\n\r\n"Why not?"\r\n\r\n"Maybe you\'re afraid of him."\r\n\r\nLarry laughed. He put the clock back on the wall and gingerly removed\r\nhis thumb. When Doris wasn\'t looking he examined his thumb.\r\n\r\nThere was still a trace of the nick cut out of the soft part of it.\r\nWho--or what--had pecked at him?\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nOne Saturday morning, when Larry was down at the office working over\r\nsome important special accounts, Bob Chambers came to the front porch\r\nand rang the bell.\r\n\r\nDoris was taking a quick shower. She dried herself and slipped into her\r\nrobe. When she opened the door Bob stepped inside, grinning.\r\n\r\n"Hi," he said, looking around.\r\n\r\n"It\'s all right. Larry\'s at the office."\r\n\r\n"Fine." Bob gazed at her slim legs below the hem of the robe. "How nice\r\nyou look today."\r\n\r\nShe laughed. "Be careful! Maybe I shouldn\'t let you in after all."\r\n\r\nThey looked at one another, half amused half frightened. Presently Bob\r\nsaid, "If you want, I\'ll--"\r\n\r\n"No, for God\'s sake." She caught hold of his sleeve. "Just get out of\r\nthe doorway so I can close it. Mrs. Peters across the street, you\r\nknow."\r\n\r\nShe closed the door. "And I want to show you something," she said. "You\r\nhaven\'t seen it."\r\n\r\nHe was interested. "An antique? Or what?"\r\n\r\nShe took his arm, leading him toward the dining-room. "You\'ll love it,\r\nBobby." She stopped, wide-eyed. "I hope you will. 

You must; you must\r\nlove it. It means so much to me--_he_ means so much."\r\n\r\n"He?" Bob frowned. "Who is he?"\r\n\r\nDoris laughed. "You\'re jealous! 

Come on." A moment later they stood\r\nbefore the clock, looking up at it. "He\'ll come out in a few minutes.\r\nWait until you see him. I know you two will get along just fine."\r\n\r\n"What does Larry think of him?"\r\n\r\n"They don\'t like each other. Sometimes when Larry\'s here he won\'t come\r\nout. Larry gets mad if he doesn\'t come out on time. He says--"\r\n\r\n"Says what?"\r\n\r\nDoris looked down. "He always says he\'s been robbed, even if he did get\r\nit wholesale." She brightened. "But I know he won\'t come out because he\r\ndoesn\'t like Larry. When I\'m here alone he comes right out for me, every\r\nfifteen minutes, even though he really only has to come out on the\r\nhour."\r\n\r\nShe gazed up at the clock. "He comes out for me because he wants to. We\r\ntalk; I tell him things. Of course, I\'d like to have him upstairs in my\r\nroom, but it wouldn\'t be right."\r\n\r\nThere was the sound of footsteps on the front porch. They looked at each\r\nother, horrified.\r\n\r\nLarry pushed the front door open, grunting. He set his briefcase down\r\nand took off his hat. Then he saw Bob for the first time.\r\n\r\n"Chambers. I\'ll be damned." His eyes narrowed. "What are you doing\r\nhere?" 

He came into the dining-room. Doris drew her robe about her\r\nhelplessly, backing away.\r\n\r\n"I--" Bob began. "That is, we--" He broke off, glancing at Doris.\r\nSuddenly the clock began to whirr. The cuckoo came rushing out, bursting\r\ninto sound. Larry moved toward him.\r\n\r\n"Shut that din off," he said. He raised his fist toward the clock. The\r\ncuckoo snapped into silence and retreated. The door closed. "That\'s\r\nbetter." Larry studied Doris and Bob, standing mutely together.\r\n\r\n"I came over to look at the clock," Bob said. "Doris told me that it\'s a\r\nrare antique and that--"\r\n\r\n"Nuts. I bought it myself." Larry walked up to him. "Get out of here."\r\nHe turned to Doris. "You too. And take that damn clock with you."\r\n\r\nHe paused, rubbing his chin. "No. Leave the clock here. It\'s mine; I\r\nbought it and paid for it."\r\n\r\nIn the weeks that followed after Doris left, Larry and the cuckoo clock\r\ngot along even worse than before. For one thing, the cuckoo stayed\r\ninside most of the time, sometimes even at twelve o\'clock when he should\r\nhave been busiest. And if he did come out at all he usually spoke only\r\nonce or twice, never the correct number of times. And there was a\r\nsullen, uncooperative note in his voice, a jarring sound that made Larry\r\nuneasy and a little angry.\r\n\r\nBut he kept the clock wound, because the house was very still and quiet\r\nand it got on his nerves not to hear someone running around, talking and\r\ndropping things. And even the whirring of a clock sounded good to him.\r\n\r\nBut he didn\'t like the cuckoo at all. And sometimes he spoke to him.\r\n\r\n"Listen," he said late one night to the closed little door. 

"I know you\r\ncan hear me. I ought to give you back to the Germans--back to the Black\r\nForest." He paced back and forth. 

"I wonder what they\'re doing now, the\r\ntwo of them. That young punk with his books and his antiques. A man\r\nshouldn\'t be interested in antiques; that\'s for women."\r\n\r\nHe set his jaw. 

"Isn\'t that right?"\r\n\r\nThe clock said nothing. Larry walked up in front of it. "Isn\'t that\r\nright?" he demanded. "Don\'t you have anything to say?"\r\n\r\nHe looked at the face of the clock. It was almost eleven, just a few\r\nseconds before the hour. "All right. I\'ll wait until eleven. Then I want\r\nto hear what you have to say. You\'ve been pretty quiet the last few\r\nweeks since she left."\r\n\r\nHe grinned wryly. "Maybe you don\'t like it here since she\'s gone." He\r\nscowled. "Well, I paid for you, and you\'re coming out whether you like\r\nit or not. You hear me?

"\r\n\r\nEleven o\'clock came. Far off, at the end of town, the great tower clock\r\nboomed sleepily to itself. But the little door remained shut. Nothing\r\nmoved. The minute hand passed on and the cuckoo did not stir. He was\r\nsomeplace inside the clock, beyond the door, silent and remote.\r\n\r\n"All right, if that\'s the way you feel," Larry murmured, his lips\r\ntwisting. "But it isn\'t fair. 

It\'s your job to come out. We all have to\r\ndo things we don\'t like."\r\n\r\nHe went unhappily into the kitchen and opened the great gleaming\r\nrefrigerator. As he poured himself a drink he thought about the clock.\r\n\r\nThere was no doubt about it--the cuckoo should come out, Doris or no\r\nDoris. He had always liked her, from the very start. 

They had got along\r\nwell, the two of them. Probably he liked Bob too--probably he had seen\r\nenough of Bob to get to know him. They would be quite happy together,\r\nBob and Doris and the cuckoo.\r\n\r\nLarry finished his drink. He opened the drawer at the sink and took out\r\nthe hammer. He carried it carefully into the dining-room. The clock was\r\nticking gently to itself on the wall.\r\n\r\n"Look," he said, waving the hammer. "You know what I have here? 

You know\r\nwhat I\'m going to do with it? I\'m going to start on you--first." 

He\r\nsmiled. "Birds of a feather, that\'s what you are--the three of you."\r\n\r\nThe room was silent.\r\n\r\n"Are you coming out? Or do I have to come in and get you?"\r\n\r\nThe clock whirred a little.\r\n\r\n"I hear you in there. You\'ve got a lot of talking to do, enough for the\r\nlast three weeks. As I figure it, you owe me--"\r\n\r\nThe door opened. The cuckoo came out fast, straight at him. Larry was\r\nlooking down, his brow wrinkled in thought. He glanced up, and the\r\ncuckoo caught him squarely in the eye.\r\n\r\nDown he went, hammer and chair and everything, hitting the floor with a\r\ntremendous crash. For a moment the cuckoo paused, its small body poised\r\nrigidly. Then it went back inside its house. The door snapped tight-shut\r\nafter it.\r\n\r\nThe man lay on the floor, stretched out grotesquely, his head bent over\r\nto one side. Nothing moved or stirred. The room was completely silent,\r\nexcept, of course, for the ticking of the clock.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"I see," Doris said, her face tight. Bob put his arm around her,\r\nsteadying her.\r\n\r\n"Doctor," Bob said, "can I ask you something?"\r\n\r\n"Of course," the doctor said.\r\n\r\n"Is it very easy to break your neck, falling from so low a chair? It\r\nwasn\'t very far to fall. I wonder if it might not have been an accident.\r\nIs there any chance it might have been--"\r\n\r\n"Suicide?" the doctor rubbed his jaw. "I never heard of anyone\r\ncommitting suicide that way. It was an accident; I\'m positive."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t mean suicide," Bob murmured under his breath, looking up at the\r\nclock on the wall. "I meant _something else_."\r\n\r\nBut no one heard him.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Fantastic Universe_ January 1954.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and\r\n    typographical errors have been corrected without note.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nAs Computerman, I was the first to come out of deep freeze after we\r\nkicked clear of the Time-Warp. So I left the needles in my wrists--the\r\ntubes let me reach Brain One--and started punching data from the\r\ninstruments while my fingers were still half stiff. Finally, stiff\r\nfingers or not, I had all the data racked into the primary feed and\r\ndecided to check on the passengers. It amused me somewhat to note that\r\neven Brain One was strictly stalling for time when it came to figuring\r\nout where we were, and why. There was much buzzing and clicking but no\r\ntape feeding out, yet. 

Well, let the Brain figure it out. I had other\r\nthings to do.\r\n\r\nI strolled back to secondary freeze unit and checked Combatman. He\r\nwas on top of the heap, of course--as stiff as a fresh steak, so I\r\nstuck the needles in his wrists and switched to defrost. Automatic\r\nlift pulled him out and beneath him was the male Homonorm and the two\r\nfemale Homonorms. They came out, too, as the lifts worked, and pretty\r\nsoon the cabin looked like a morgue--or a cannibal\'s shop, if you\r\nprefer. Anyway, they were defrosting, so I left \'em to make a check\r\non Brain One and see what brilliant, if mechanical conclusion it had\r\nreached. Should be at least an hour before Combatman thawed--even with\r\nthe needles pumping.\r\n\r\nBrain One was feeding out tape now, slow as a snail considering its\r\ncycling rate, so I figured we were a long way from home. Okay with\r\nme--I\'d been around and knew that if we could get somewhere we could\r\nget back. But I wanted, and wanted bad, the data from Time-Warp gauges.\r\nSo I watched the tape, decoding mentally as it fed out and feeling, for\r\na Computerman, an emotion similar to impatience.\r\n\r\nWe were approaching--the Brain told me--a type three planet,\r\nradiations okay, atmosphere higher in oxygen than home, gravity\r\nslightly lighter in pull than normal--the same junk I\'d been picking\r\nup since we started colonizing. Land masses stable, water in the air,\r\nsemi-condensed. Good place for colonizing, and this pleased me. We were\r\nout to establish and leave the Homonorms for a generation, and Brain\r\nOne had figured all the details out while I was sitting in freeze like\r\na hamburger. So far, so good.\r\n\r\nOne thing annoyed, or puzzled me. I kept throwing data from TV and\r\nRadar into Feed-back and asking about population, life forms, land\r\ndenizens. All Brain One came up with was Insufficient Data. All right.\r\nIt would be just another routine landing on another distant planet.\r\nThen I heard the noise behind me and turned. Combatman stood in the\r\ndoorway, his skin still bluish from the freeze, his eyes just clearing\r\nand working into focus.\r\n\r\nI looked him over while he stood there, somewhat surprised--if one can\r\never be surprised at what his race did. He was hung with enough weapons\r\nto stop a division of Homonorms and I wondered, as I always did, at the\r\norigin of his race. His type always came drifting down from somewhere\r\nnorth, back home, and all our radar and planes had never found their\r\nhomeland. None of them ever talked with humans except to nose in on our\r\nexpeditions or break up our wars. This one was quite a specimen, maybe\r\nsix feet, about 180 pounds, with the quiet and arrogant strength of his\r\nrace. He took a deep breath, still leaning on the door frame.\r\n\r\n"Get me some whiskey," his voice was hoarse from disuse and the\r\nTime-Warp, "and get it now."\r\n\r\n"Now, see here," I began, "I\'m Computerman and in charge of this ship\r\nand...."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI didn\'t finish. With the quiet sureness of a jungle cat he had crossed\r\nthe room, taken a handful of my tunic and lifted me from the chair--in\r\nspite of the fact that gravity was nearly normal now because of the\r\nlanding jets. His voice was almost velvety.\r\n\r\n"Perhaps you didn\'t hear me. I will repeat once more." He paused while\r\nI considered striking him and then, sensibly, changed my mind. "Get me\r\nsome whiskey." Then he dropped me back into the chair.\r\n\r\nI\'m not Computerman for nothing, so I computed the situation in maybe\r\na thousandth of a second. No one could push me around, so to prevent\r\nbeing pushed around I got him his whiskey. He knocked off about a half\r\npint at a swallow and in a few minutes his skin lost its bluish tinge.\r\nHe was awake, and his quick eyes swept the gauges and the TV-Radar\r\nimage.\r\n\r\n"When do we land?" He made no attempt to be courteous.\r\n\r\nI checked Brain One\'s tape, somewhat rattled. "Twenty-one minutes, four\r\nseconds," I started, resisting a strange impulse to say \'sir\', "Near\r\nwater, fresh, altitude under one mile from...."\r\n\r\n"That\'s all," he said. "Thanks." He left the room like a cat, crouching\r\nslightly as he went through the door, leaping through and backing\r\nagainst the wall, but fast, once he cleared. His weapons, all of them,\r\nwere so skillfully hung that he didn\'t make a sound. Somehow, I enjoyed\r\nwatching the play of those muscles and felt rather glad to have him\r\nalong, rough as he was. Outlying planets often have warlike combat\r\norganizations of their own, and Combatmen have saved many expeditions\r\nlike this. Something in their nature, or training--or both--seems to\r\nmake them invincible.\r\n\r\nI turned back to Brain One, checked the wiring on the denizen circuit\r\nand tried to get more information about possible inhabitants. No luck.\r\nEither there were none or they were so highly civilized they could\r\nblock off our probing rays. That had happened before, and it usually\r\nmeant a minor war. We always won, though we sometimes had to dig in and\r\nsend for the Control Fleet from home. The Fleet was run by Combatmen,\r\nthough no Homonorm had ever figured out how they eased into all the key\r\npositions. They were quite a race, all right.\r\n\r\nSo I sat watching the Radarscreen and the planet, enlarging rapidly.\r\nIt looked pretty good--about a quarter to a third land mass, I\r\nguessed--just like home. Combatman came back in the room, quietly.\r\n\r\n"Your pap-fed colonists are waking," he grunted. "Better go and\r\nwet-nurse them. 

They might catch cold." He sat down in the pilot\'s\r\nchair, much to my annoyance, and swilled away at his bottle. I noticed\r\nhe\'d replaced the original crock, and felt a moment\'s concern. After\r\nall, we depended for basic safety on his training, in the event of\r\nencountering hostility. He seemed utterly unconcerned as he lazily\r\nwatched the screen.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe Homonorms were doing all right, complaining as usual about the cold\r\nand asking silly questions about where we were and what year it was--or\r\nwould be at home. I ducked the questions, gave them their hypos and\r\nwent back to Brain One and the control panel. One look at controls and\r\nI started boiling; this was the last straw.\r\n\r\n"Now, goddamit," I started, "you can boss me around, but when it comes\r\nto...."\r\n\r\n"Shut up!"\r\n\r\n"I will not shut up...."\r\n\r\n"Okay." He was calm, leisurely, even--but before I realized it he was\r\nrising, crossed the room and I had an arm behind me. It didn\'t hurt but\r\nI felt pretty helpless. Completely helpless, to be truthful.\r\n\r\n"Could it be," he appeared to be bored, "that you are tired of having\r\ntwo arms?" He twisted slightly and I got the idea so I shut up, for\r\nthe second time. 

After a few seconds he sat down in my chair and had\r\nanother drink. When I could talk without sputtering I worked up my\r\nmildest voice.\r\n\r\n"Would you tell me," I almost choked on the next word, "_Please_, what\r\nin hell is the idea of circling at twenty miles, then dropping to ten\r\nand circling some more? We\'re wasting tons of fuel which we may need\r\nfor--"\r\n\r\n"Sure, brainy one, I\'ll tell you. I want to see what this place looks\r\nlike and _I\'m_ picking the landing site. Not you or that pile of\r\nrattling tin there." He gestured contemptuously at Brain One.\r\n\r\n"Pile of tin!" I couldn\'t say more so I went back to the rear and\r\nhelped the Homonorms find food and the simple plasticlothes they\'d be\r\nwearing. The ship lurched suddenly as it changed course at twenty miles\r\nand started circling. Even back here I could hear Brain One clacking in\r\nprotest over the conflicting instructions. That big lunk of a fighting\r\nman, of course, hadn\'t had sense enough to punch Clear and Recompute\r\nwhen he changed course and I could see the tape in my mind\'s eye\r\npouring frantically out with Data Please, Data Please....\r\n\r\nOh, well.\r\n\r\nHomonorms were thawing okay but crying like babies from Time-Warp\r\nsickness and space fright. I expected this and let them cry it out.\r\nMeanwhile I got busy with Sensory Receptors to see if anything we knew\r\nof could be blocking Brain One\'s circuits. This lack of info about\r\nthe denizens had me a little worried: it wasn\'t often Brain One came\r\nup with a blank, on any subject. It made me furious to be working\r\nlike mad here while that big oaf lounged in _my_ chair slopping up a\r\nyear\'s supply of stimulant. Defending the ship was his job; he should\r\nbe trying to find out what was doing below us. Instead, he sat around\r\nwatching Radarscreen just like he was watching the fights his race\r\nstaged back home for amusement.\r\n\r\nThe ship lurched violently. Then it lurched again. I started forward,\r\nworried, but the tailjets blasted and I slammed against a wall, pinned\r\ntight. The pressure cut my wind and I fainted. My last recollection was\r\nthe smell of scorching duralumin. We\'d been hit, by something.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWhen I revived, we were back at Gravnorm and I staggered, literally,\r\nback to control. My nose was still bleeding, and the Homonorms, of\r\ncourse, were still unconscious. Combatman sat comfortably in my padded\r\nchair, almost dreamily watching the screen. I felt a surge of anger,\r\nthen realized I was too feeble to support such an emotion. Remembering\r\nmy Psycho training I redirected to curiosity.\r\n\r\n"What...." my voice sounded pretty shaky and Combatman handed me the\r\nbottle, grinning.\r\n\r\n"Quite a race down there," he seemed pleased. Then he spat, expertly,\r\nthe result landing on the Radarscreen. "Can you work that thing?

"\r\n\r\n"Of course," I muttered, half-insulted.\r\n\r\n"Okay. We\'re at a hundred miles. Get that in focus as of two miles,\r\nslow the ship and prepare to hold stationary when I see what I want to\r\nknow."\r\n\r\nWeakly I fumbled with the controls, sniffling back the blood from my\r\nnose.\r\n\r\n"And turn off this tin god of yours," he continued. "That clacking\r\nracket annoys me." Casually, he kicked the part of Brain One nearest\r\nhim, which was the back of Wiring Panel Six.\r\n\r\n"Oh, _no_...." I began. But I did as I was told and ran Brain One\r\nthrough three clearing cycles, just to make sure. There was no telling\r\nwhat this lummox may have done in my absence. Now I\'d have to check\r\neverything and feed in the information all over again.\r\n\r\nCombatman leaned back in the chair like he expected dental work, and\r\nyawned luxuriously. He watched as the screen blurred and focused,\r\nblurred and focused. It was sweeping at two miles and the ship was\r\nslowing. We dropped tail down and Grav changed faster than the interior\r\nhull moved. Finally we settled, and coasted above this planet.\r\n\r\nThe ship lurched, twice this time almost simultaneously. Then it\r\nlurched steadily. Combatman threw the All Screens switch and watched\r\nthe Radar. By now, he was tense.\r\n\r\n"At a hundred miles...." he muttered. "What a race this is!"\r\n\r\nHe watched the screen with eyes that reminded me more of a cat\'s than a\r\nhuman\'s.\r\n\r\n"Stop!"\r\n\r\nFrom habit I threw the master Out Switch and everything stopped--our\r\nmotion coordinated precisely with the planet\'s, the Radar focused where\r\nit had been--and I got slammed against a wall again, of course. Well--I\r\nmight as well get used to it. 

When my eyes cleared I studied the\r\nimage. It was a rather crude city of considerable size, though poorly,\r\ndesigned from the light, ventilation and transport angle. There was\r\nconsiderable movement, apparently ground vehicles of some sort. 

Then I\r\nlooked at Combatman. His face was registering disbelief and something\r\nresembling alarm--though I\'d never heard of any of his race being\r\nreally frightened.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe missile warning light blinked frantically and the ship started\r\nlurching and pitching again. Combatman turned toward me and his face\r\nwas taut and urgent.\r\n\r\n"How soon can you get into Time-Warp?"\r\n\r\n"And--and _leave_?

"\r\n\r\n"Right, and the sooner the better." He flipped the height control\r\nand we moved, smoothly this time, up away from the missiles blasting\r\noutside our protective screen. "There\'ll be no colonizing done here.

"\r\n\r\n"But--but our orders were to...."\r\n\r\n"No colonizing here. Put your Homonorms back in the freezer and set up\r\nfor return. Do it now.

"\r\n\r\nStunned, I went rearward and told the people. They didn\'t like the\r\nidea very much, but regulations said that when the ship was attacked,\r\nCombatman was absolute boss. Then I returned. Combatman shot a glance\r\nat me and I nodded, then went to work on the Control panel, reversing\r\nthe whole set up.\r\n\r\n"When you finish I\'ll get in your ice box," Combatman said. "And when\r\nyou get out of Time-Warp destroy that wiring. None of your ships is to\r\ncome back here."\r\n\r\nI digested this slowly, wondering how to report to the council. "Why\r\nnot?" 

I ventured. "Perhaps with part of the Control Fleet...."\r\n\r\n"The whole Control Fleet wouldn\'t last two days on a desert of that\r\nworld, Brainboy," he said. His eyes misted faintly for a fraction of a\r\nsecond. "Those denizens, as you call them, are all members of my race,\r\nand this planet was my home--we called it Earth."\r\n\r\nHe yawned and strode to the rear and the freezer. At the portal he\r\nturned and grinned. "And don\'t ask me how we get back and forth. 

I\r\nmight get mad and have my whole family drop over--in-laws and all."\r\n\r\nI didn\'t really understand him, so went on with my wiring.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


There goes that old discourtesy again, eh?" the\r\nlittle man, Pettigill, said with a dry laugh. He scurried about the room\r\nlike a confused squirrel until he spotted a chair behind his desk. "My\r\nchair. My chair for you, Mr. Bartle!" Again the dry laugh.\r\n\r\n"Thanks, Mr. Pettigill."\r\n\r\n"Arthur. Call me Arthur. Formality really isn\'t necessary among Mid\r\nEchelon, do you think? Section Secretary Andrews has often requested I\r\ncall him Morton, but I just can\'t seem to bring myself to such\r\ninformality. After all, he is Sub-Prime Echelon. 

It makes one\r\nuncomfortable, shall we say, to step out of one\'s class?" He stopped\r\ntalking and the corners of his mouth dropped quickly as if he had just\r\nbeen given one minute to live. "You--you _are_ only Mid Echelon, aren\'t\r\nyou? I mean, if you are Sub-Prime, I shouldn\'t be--"\r\n\r\n"Relax, Mr. Pettigill--\'Arthur\'--I _am_ Mid Echelon. And I\'m only that\r\nbecause my father was a man of far more industry than I; I inherited my\r\nclassification."\r\n\r\n"So? Well, now. 

Interesting--very. He must have been a great man, a\r\ngreat man, Mr. Bartle."\r\n\r\n"So I am told, Arthur. But let\'s get on with it," Bartle said, taking\r\nsome scrap paper and a pencil stub from his tunic pocket. "Now, tell me\r\nabout yourself and the Melopsych Center."\r\n\r\n"Well," the little man began with a sigh and blinked his eyes peculiarly\r\nas though he were mentally shuffling events and facts like a deck of\r\ncards. "Well, I--my life would be of little interest, but the Center is\r\nof the utmost importance. That\'s it--I am no more than a physical\r\nextremity that functions in accord with the vital life that courses\r\nthrough the great physique of the Center! No more--I ask no more than to\r\nserve the Center and in turn, my fellow citizens, whether they be Prime,\r\nSub-Prime, Mid, or even Sub-Lower!

"\r\n\r\nHe stopped speaking, affecting a martyr-like pose. Bartle covered a\r\nsmile with his hand.\r\n\r\n"Well, Bartle, as you know, the Center--the Melopsych Center, a\r\nthoroughly inadequate name for the installation I might say--is the\r\npoint of broadcast for these many taped musical selections contrived by\r\nMass Psych as a therapeutic treatment for the various Echelon levels. It\r\nis the Great Psychiatrist--the Father Confessor. For where can one bare\r\none\'s soul, or soothe one\'s nerves and disposition frayed by a day\'s\r\nendeavor, better than in the tender yet firm embrace of music?"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBartle was straining to follow the train of thought that was lost in the\r\ncamouflage of Pettigill\'s flowery phraseology.\r\n\r\n"You see all about you these many recorders, Mr. Bartle?"\r\n\r\nBartle nodded.\r\n\r\n"On those machines, sir, are spools of tape. Music tapes, all music. My\r\nheavens, every kind: classical music, jazz, western, all kinds of music.\r\nSome tapes are no more than a single melodious note, sustained for\r\nwhatever length of time necessary to relax and please the Echelon level\r\nhome it is being beamed to. Oh, I tell you, Mr. Bartle, when the last\r\ntape has expended itself for the day, as our service code suggests, I\r\nleave this great edifice with a feeling of profound pride in the fact\r\nthat I have so served my fellow man. You share that feeling too, don\'t\r\nyou Mr. Bartle?

"\r\n\r\nBartle shrugged. Pettigill paused and looked at the watch he carried on\r\na long chain attached to a clasp on his tunic.\r\n\r\n"A Benz chronometer, given to me by Section Secretary Andrews on the\r\ncompletion of my twenty-five years of service. It\'s radio-synchronized\r\nwith the master timepiece in Greenland. It gives me a feeling of close\r\ncommunion with my superiors, if you understand what I mean.

"\r\n\r\nBartle did not. He said, "Am I keeping you from your work? If I am, I\r\nbelieve I can fill in on most of this back at the paper; we have files\r\non the Center\'s operation."\r\n\r\nThe little man hurriedly put out a hand to restrain Bartle who was\r\neasing out of the chair.\r\n\r\n"Not yet, Mr. Bartle," he said, suddenly much more sober. Then his\r\nincongruous pomposity appeared again. "My gracious, no, you aren\'t\r\nkeeping me from my work. I just must start the Mid-Lower Echelon tape.\r\nIt won\'t take a moment. Bartle. Don\'t you\r\nknow Amendment 34206-B specifically states that all Echelon homes must\r\nreceive music therapy at 2300 hours every night? Of course, different\r\ntapes to different homes.

"\r\n\r\n"That\'s what I mean."\r\n\r\n"Haven\'t you been abiding by the directive, Mr. Bartle?"\r\n\r\n"I told you I owed my classification to my father\'s industry. And yet, this\r\nPettigill had disturbed him. ]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n              Don\'t wait to "Get \'em while they\'re hot."\r\n              By then, it is too late to get them of all!\r\n\r\n\r\nThe big bright doors of the office building parted with a pneumatic\r\n_whoosh_ and Robie glided onto Times Square. The crowd that had been\r\nwatching the fifty-foot-tall girl on the clothing billboard get\r\ndressed, or reading the latest news about the Hot Truce scrawl itself\r\nin yard-high script, hurried to look.\r\n\r\nRobie was still a novelty. Robie was fun. For a little while yet, he\r\ncould steal the show. But the attention did not make Robie proud. He\r\nhad no more emotions than the pink plastic giantess, who dressed and\r\nundressed endlessly whether there was a crowd or the street was empty,\r\nand who never once blinked her blue mechanical eyes. But she merely\r\ndrew business while Robie went out after it.\r\n\r\nFor Robie was the logical conclusion of the development of vending\r\nmachines. All the earlier ones had stood in one place, on a floor or\r\nhanging on a wall, and blankly delivered merchandise in return for\r\ncoins, whereas Robie searched for customers. He was the demonstration\r\nmodel of a line of sales robots to be manufactured by Shuler Vending\r\nMachines, provided the public invested enough in stocks to give the\r\ncompany capital to go into mass production.\r\n\r\nThe publicity Robie drew stimulated investments handsomely. It was\r\namusing to see the TV and newspaper coverage of Robie selling, but not\r\na fraction as much fun as being approached personally by him. Those\r\nwho were usually bought anywhere from one to five hundred shares, if\r\nthey had any money and foresight enough to see that sales robots would\r\neventually be on every street and highway in the country.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nRobie radared the crowd, found that it surrounded him solidly, and\r\nstopped. With a carefully built-in sense of timing, he waited for the\r\ntension and expectation to mount before he began talking.\r\n\r\n"Say, Ma, he doesn\'t look like a robot at all," a child said. "He looks\r\nlike a turtle."\r\n\r\nWhich was not completely inaccurate. The lower part of Robie\'s body was\r\na metal hemisphere hemmed with sponge rubber and not quite touching the\r\nsidewalk. The upper was a metal box with black holes in it. The box\r\ncould swivel and duck.\r\n\r\nA chromium-bright hoopskirt with a turret on top.\r\n\r\n"Reminds me too much of the Little Joe Paratanks," a legless veteran\r\nof the Persian War muttered, and rapidly rolled himself away on wheels\r\nrather like Robie\'s.\r\n\r\nHis departure made it easier for some of those who knew about Robie to\r\nopen a path in the crowd. Robie headed straight for the gap. The crowd\r\nwhooped.\r\n\r\nRobie glided very slowly down the path, deftly jogging aside whenever\r\nhe got too close to ankles in skylon or sockassins. The rubber buffer\r\non his hoopskirt was merely an added safeguard.\r\n\r\nThe boy who had called Robie a turtle jumped in the middle of the path\r\nand stood his ground, grinning foxily.\r\n\r\nRobie stopped two feet short of him. The turret ducked. The crowd got\r\nquiet.\r\n\r\n"Hello, youngster," Robie said in a voice that was smooth as that of a\r\nTV star, and was, in fact, a recording of one.\r\n\r\nThe boy stopped smiling. "Hello," he whispered.\r\n\r\n"How old are you?" Robie asked.\r\n\r\n"Nine. No, eight."\r\n\r\n"That\'s nice," Robie observed. A metal arm shot down from his neck,\r\nstopped just short of the boy.\r\n\r\nThe boy jerked back.\r\n\r\n"For you," Robie said.\r\n\r\nThe boy gingerly took the red polly-lop from the neatly fashioned blunt\r\nmetal claws, and began to unwrap it.\r\n\r\n"Nothing to say?" asked Robie.\r\n\r\n"Uh--thank you."\r\n\r\nAfter a suitable pause, Robie continued. "And how about a nice\r\nrefreshing drink of Poppy Pop to go with your polly-lop?" The boy\r\nlifted his eyes, but didn\'t stop licking the candy. Robie waggled his\r\nclaws slightly. "Just give me a quarter and within five seconds--"\r\n\r\nA little girl wriggled out of the forest of legs. "Give me a polly-lop,\r\ntoo, Robie," she demanded.\r\n\r\n"Rita, come back here!" a woman in the third rank of the crowd called\r\nangrily.\r\n\r\nRobie scanned the newcomer gravely. His reference silhouettes were not\r\ngood enough to let him distinguish the sex of children, so he merely\r\nrepeated, "Hello, youngster."\r\n\r\n"Rita!"\r\n\r\n"Give me a polly-lop!"\r\n\r\nDisregarding both remarks, for a good salesman is single-minded and\r\ndoes not waste bait, Robie said winningly, "I\'ll bet you read _Junior\r\nSpace Killers_. Now I have here--"\r\n\r\n"Uh-uh, I\'m a girl. _He_ got a polly-lop."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAt the word "girl," Robie broke off. I\'m her mother."\r\n\r\nA young woman in the front rank drawled over her powder-sprayed\r\nshoulder, "I\'ll get her for you," and slithered out on six-inch\r\nplatform shoes. "Run away, children," she said nonchalantly. Lifting\r\nher arms behind her head, she pirouetted slowly before Robie to show\r\nhow much she did for her bolero half-jacket and her form-fitting slacks\r\nthat melted into skylon just above the knees. The little girl glared at\r\nher. She ended the pirouette in profile.\r\n\r\nAt this age-level, Robie\'s reference silhouettes permitted him to\r\ndistinguish sex, though with occasional amusing and embarrassing\r\nmiscalls. "\r\n\r\nThe friend shook his head. "This way it\'s subtler."\r\n\r\nNo one in the crowd was watching the newscript overhead as it\r\nscribbled, "Ice Pack for Hot Truce? "\r\n\r\nRobie scanned the crowd resourcefully. "Is there any gentleman\r\nhere ..." he began just as a woman elbowed her way through the front\r\nrank.\r\n\r\n"I told you to come back!" she snapped at the little girl.\r\n\r\n"But I didn\'t get my polly-lop!"\r\n\r\n"... who would care to...."\r\n\r\n"Rita!"\r\n\r\n"Robie cheated. Ow!"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nMeanwhile, the young woman in the half bolero had scanned the nearby\r\ngentlemen on her own.
