Alive and amused in the fresh, weather-controlled air between the\r\nlines of bright skyscrapers with their winking windows and under a sky\r\nso blue you could almost call it dark.\r\n\r\n(But way, way up, where the crowd could not see, the sky was darker\r\nstill. Purple-dark, with stars showing. And in that purple-dark, a\r\nsilver-green something, the color of a bud, plunged down at better than\r\nthree miles a second. The silver-green was a newly developed paint that\r\nfoiled radar.)\r\n\r\nRobie was saying, "While we wait for the light, there\'s time for\r\nyou youngsters to enjoy a nice refreshing Poppy Pop. Or for you\r\nadults--only those over five feet tall are eligible to buy--to enjoy\r\nan exciting Poppy Pop fizz. Just give me a quarter or--in the case of\r\nadults, one dollar and a quarter; I\'m licensed to dispense intoxicating\r\nliquors--and within five seconds...."\r\n\r\nBut that was not cutting it quite fine enough. Just three seconds\r\nlater, the silver-green bud bloomed above Manhattan into a globular\r\norange flower. The skyscrapers grew brighter and brighter still, the\r\nbrightness of the inside of the Sun. The windows winked blossoming\r\nwhite fire-flowers.\r\n\r\nThe crowd around Robie bloomed, too. Their clothes puffed into petals\r\nof flame. Their heads of hair were torches.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe orange flower grew, stem and blossom. The blast came. The winking\r\nwindows shattered tier by tier, became black holes. The walls bent,\r\nrocked, cracked. A stony dandruff flaked from their cornices. The\r\nflaming flowers on the sidewalk were all leveled at once. Robie was\r\nshoved ten feet. His metal hoopskirt dimpled, regained its shape.\r\n\r\nThe blast ended. The orange flower, grown vast, vanished overhead\r\non its huge, magic beanstalk. It grew dark and very still. 

The\r\ncornice-dandruff pattered down. A few small fragments rebounded from\r\nthe metal hoopskirt.\r\n\r\nRobie made some small, uncertain movements, as if feeling for broken\r\nbones. He was hunting for the traffic light, but it no longer shone\r\neither red or green.\r\n\r\nHe slowly scanned a full circle. There was nothing anywhere to\r\ninterest his reference silhouettes. 

Yet whenever he tried to move, his\r\nunder-scanners warned him of low obstructions. It was very puzzling.\r\n\r\nThe silence was disturbed by moans and a crackling sound, as faint at\r\nfirst as the scampering of distant rats.\r\n\r\nA seared man, his charred clothes fuming where the blast had blown out\r\nthe fire, rose from the curb. Robie scanned him.\r\n\r\n"Good day, sir," Robie said. "Would you care for a smoke? A truly cool\r\nsmoke? Now I have here a yet-unmarketed brand...."\r\n\r\nBut the customer had run away, screaming, and Robie never ran after\r\ncustomers, though he could follow them at a medium brisk roll. He\r\nworked his way along the curb where the man had sprawled, carefully\r\nkeeping his distance from the low obstructions, some of which writhed\r\nnow and then, forcing him to jog. Shortly he reached a fire hydrant.\r\nHe scanned it. His electronic vision, though it still worked, had been\r\nsomewhat blurred by the blast.\r\n\r\n"Hello, youngster," Robie said. Then, after a long pause, "Cat got your\r\ntongue? Well, I have a little present for you. A nice, lovely polly-lop.\r\n\r\n"Take it, youngster," he said after another pause. "It\'s for you. 

Don\'t\r\nbe afraid."\r\n\r\nHis attention was distracted by other customers, who began to rise\r\nup oddly here and there, twisting forms that confused his reference\r\nsilhouettes and would not stay to be scanned properly. One cried,\r\n"Water," but no quarter clinked in Robie\'s claws when he caught the\r\nword and suggested, "How about a nice refreshing drink of Poppy Pop?"\r\n\r\nThe rat-crackling of the flames had become a jungle muttering. The\r\nblind windows began to wink fire again.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nA little girl marched, stepping neatly over arms and legs she did\r\nnot look at. A white dress and the once taller bodies around her had\r\nshielded her from the brilliance and the blast. Her eyes were fixed on\r\nRobie. In them was the same imperious confidence, though none of the\r\ndelight, with which she had watched him earlier.\r\n\r\n"Help me, Robie," she said. "I want my mother."\r\n\r\n"Hello, youngster," Robie said. "What would you like? Comics? 

Candy?"\r\n\r\n"Where is she, Robie? Take me to her."\r\n\r\n"Balloons? Would you like to watch me blow up a balloon?"\r\n\r\nThe little girl began to cry. The sound triggered off another of\r\nRobie\'s novelty circuits, a service feature that had brought in a lot\r\nof favorable publicity.\r\n\r\n"Is something wrong?" he asked. 

"Are you in trouble? Are you lost?"\r\n\r\n"Yes, Robie. Take me to my mother."\r\n\r\n"Stay right here," Robie said reassuringly, "and don\'t be frightened.\r\nI will call a policeman." He whistled shrilly, twice.\r\n\r\nTime passed. Robie whistled again. 

The windows flared and roared. The\r\nlittle girl begged, "Take me away, Robie," and jumped onto a little\r\nstep in his hoopskirt.\r\n\r\n"Give me a dime," Robie said.\r\n\r\nThe little girl found one in her pocket and put it in his claws.\r\n\r\n"Your weight," Robie said, "is fifty-four and one-half pounds."\r\n\r\n"Have you seen my daughter, have you seen her?" a woman was\r\ncrying somewhere. "I left her watching that thing while I stepped\r\ninside--_Rita!_"\r\n\r\n"Robie helped me," the little girl began babbling at her. "He knew I\r\nwas lost. 

He even called the police, but they didn\'t come. He weighed\r\nme, too. 

Didn\'t you, Robie?"\r\n\r\nBut Robie had gone off to peddle Poppy Pop to the members of a rescue\r\nsquad which had just come around the corner, more robotlike in their\r\nasbestos suits than he in his metal skin.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nAcross the blazing face of the sun moved a round dark speck, a tiny,\r\none-man space ship. It was very small, very close, and utterly\r\nhelpless. The side facing the sun glowed dull red.\r\n\r\nInside, Jim MacDonald stood glumly regarding the thermometer on the\r\npilot compartment bulkhead. Sweat made dark patches on the light blue\r\nof his uniform and ran in beads down his forehead. He rubbed his arm\r\nacross his face. The thermometer read over two hundred. He shook his\r\nhead slowly. It couldn\'t be that hot, heat must be conducting along the\r\nmagnesium bulkhead to the instrument.\r\n\r\nJim ran his fingers through his hair to brush back the damp strands\r\nthat clung to his forehead. The hand came away with little droplets\r\nclinging to his fingertips. 

He wiped it across his pants, and tapped\r\nthe thermometer again. The pointer stayed where it was, stuck against\r\nthe peg.\r\n\r\n"About one forty-five," he guessed aloud, and turned to walk with a\r\nslow, dragging step across to the pilot\'s seat. Weakly he slumped down\r\nwith his arms dangling loose over the chair arms, knuckles almost\r\ntouching the deck. He sat very still trying to ignore the temperature\r\nin the compartment, but the hot stifle wrapped around him and his\r\nchest heaved in a sigh.\r\n\r\nJim MacDonald was done for and he knew it. The thermo-couple to the\r\noutside skin showed three thousand degrees. The inside cooling system\r\nhad not been built for this and had long since ceased to cope with the\r\nheat. There seemed to be no use continuing his grim little existence,\r\nor facing the worse smother of heat to come.\r\n\r\nYet, driven by the dull automatism of training and habit, he listlessly\r\nswung the stand with the ship\'s log over before him and noted his\r\ntemperature readings. Then he critically reread what he had already\r\nwritten.\r\n\r\nA few days ago, he had been using the gravitational field of the sun\r\nas a booster to help fling the little ship from Earth to Venus. In the\r\nmighty field, a space warp had funneled out, caught him, and sucked the\r\nship toward the blazing maw.\r\n\r\nThe struggle to escape was a masterpiece of calculation. He had figured\r\nwith such a nicety that his fuel had run out just at the moment the\r\njet tubes at the rear became molten lumps on the ship\'s skin. He had\r\nescaped the warp. But it was a futile thing now, for the ship swung\r\naround the sun fuelless, inoperative, in a tight orbit that had a\r\nlittle initial inward momentum.\r\n\r\nHe had tried to radio for help, but radioing from where he was, was\r\nlike trying to signal from the heart of an atomic bomb; if a signal got\r\nthrough, it would be only a part of the meaningless jabber of static\r\nthat always came from here. And if the little black speck were seen,\r\nit would only be taken for a stray meteorite moving across the sun\'s\r\nincandescent face.\r\n\r\nThe ship was a little spherical world. It turned on its own axis once\r\nin an hour and twenty minutes. 

That was its little day. The orbit\r\nspiralled now a mere quarter million miles from the sun, one little\r\nyear to two earth days. It moved closer at a rate that accelerated a\r\nfew feet per second every second.\r\n\r\nEventually, said the impassive rows of equations in the log, the inward\r\nmovement would stop, as keeping the same speed in a smaller circle, the\r\nship\'s centrifugal force increased to set up an equilibrium. But that\r\npoint would be three thousand miles below the sun\'s surface. 

The ship\r\nwould never reach it. Jim MacDonald inhabited a doomed little world.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe chuckled. He even had a moon. The natural physical function of a few\r\nminutes before had left a jagged little chunk of ice swinging around\r\nthe ship, outside the waste lock on the side away from the sun. 

But\r\nthat wouldn\'t last long. It would pass into the hot light, and vanish\r\nin a puff of steam.\r\n\r\nNow the plastic fittings of the compartment began to send up a\r\nnostril stinging stench. Jim leafed over a few pages in the log to\r\nthe page printed at the top: ... SUGGESTIONS FOR REDESIGN OF\r\nSPACE-SHIPS.\r\n\r\nUnder his note, _Enlarge cooling systems_, he wrote, _Replace\r\nurea formaldehyde plastics with metals, and insulate compartment\r\nthermometers from bulkheads._\r\n\r\nFeeling foolish at the useless act of writing that which no one would\r\never read, Jim swung the log away. His tongue peeled from the roof\r\nof his mouth like a strip of adhesive tape and he dragged across the\r\ncompartment for a drink. 

Glancing toward the sun, he held his aluminum\r\ncup under the spout and pressed the hot button gingerly. Although the\r\nwindows on that side were blanked out almost purple, the sun\'s horizon\r\nglared through in a heaving mass of leaping gassy prominences.\r\n\r\nJim turned away, his face wrinkling into a grimace. Across the\r\ncompartment a little cabinet held a pistol. It would be a simple sane\r\nthing to walk across there, take out the pistol and bring this to a\r\nsudden stop. He stepped toward it, then turned away ashamed. Spacemen\r\ndidn\'t think like that.\r\n\r\nAhead of the ship something flared into incandescent brilliance. Waves\r\nof force pounded on the front, the deck heaved. Jim sprawled on his\r\nface and skidded over under the instrument panel, his cup clattering\r\nalong beside him.\r\n\r\nThe deck scorched his hands and face. He wriggled out and dragged\r\nhimself up to the chair, clinging tightly. 

But it was all over. He\r\nstood for a moment, waiting, then sat down.\r\n\r\nExperimentally he caressed his burned face. Looking out the windows\r\nhe tried to see some cause for the shock. Then he realized his moon\r\nwas gone. It had passed out of the deep shadow into the penumbra of\r\nthe ship and had been instantly vaporized. The shock had been its\r\ndissociated molecules pummeling the front of the ship.\r\n\r\nHe would have to be careful. If that could have passed directly into\r\nthe full light instead of through the half shadow of the penumbra,\r\nthe front of the ship might have caved in, softened as it was to near\r\nplasticity. Jim reached for the log again, but his hand stopped in\r\nmid air. With the spaceman\'s sensitivity to changes of state, he knew\r\nsomething was wrong. Something had changed in the shock of the moon\'s\r\nexplosion.\r\n\r\nHe puzzled it over, but his heat befuddled brain refused to grasp\r\nthings. He scanned all the instruments on the panel, but saw nothing\r\nunusual. At one side, he had a little tracer going, little drum turning\r\nwith a needle scribing a red line. On it he had set the increase in\r\nthe sun\'s pull against time to describe a curve. He examined this\r\ncurve. The red line had changed direction suddenly; the sun\'s pull was\r\nincreasing faster.\r\n\r\n"Dammit!" he said. 

The force of the explosion in front had slowed him\r\nand shorn off some protective centrifugal force. Now he picked up\r\npoints on the new curve, set down equations, and found he would die\r\nsome twenty hours sooner than he had expected.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHis mind began to revolt at the training that made him go on like this.\r\nThe turning of the ship now showed him only the face of the sun. He\r\nlooked at it a while, then shrugged his shoulders in disgust. 

Slowly he\r\ngot up and walked toward the gun cabinet. The little door swung open as\r\nhe pressed the button and he stared at the holstered weapon.\r\n\r\nLeaving the door open, he walked away, looking back toward it. He\r\nretrieved his cup and filled it with tepid water. Throwing his head\r\nback he drained it at a gulp; then refilled it. He walked to the engine\r\ncompartment door. It swung open at his touch, and he stepped into\r\nthe tiny gangway. Here a tiny porthole looked out into the infinite\r\nblue-black deeps of space. Jim leaned against a bulkhead and wiped\r\nsweat from his eyes.\r\n\r\nHe tried to think. Not of escape, but of the frigid emptiness of\r\nspace, the cool earth he had left behind. Into his mind came a\r\nfleeting glimpse of a lake back home on earth, a cold lake ringed with\r\nblue-green pines, jade waters where he had dived deep with the iciness\r\nstinging his skin. Against the metal bulkhead, his back began to burn.\r\nThe vision faded. He realized he was thirsty all over.\r\n\r\nHe gulped his cup of water and went back to the pilot\'s compartment.\r\nAt the open door of the gun cabinet, he stopped and sent his empty\r\ncup clattering against the sunward windows. He took the gun from the\r\ncabinet.\r\n\r\nBack to the pilot\'s chair again. He toyed with the gun. The ship had\r\nturned now so that the other vast heaving horizon cut across the view.\r\n"Oh, hell!" Jim said, and brought the gun\'s muzzle to his mouth.\r\n\r\n[Illustration: _"Oh, hell!" Jim said and brought the gun\'s muzzle to\r\nhis mouth._]\r\n\r\nThen he lowered it, sweat poured down into his eyes as his forehead\r\nwrinkled in dull puzzlement. He should be thinking about something,\r\nhe was forgetting something. Jim tried to cudgel his heat-beclouded\r\nbrain into some semblance of order.... Water, explosion, change of\r\nvelocity.... Where was the drain outlet for the water supply located?\r\n\r\nHe laid the gun aside and riffled through a drawer of blueprints, until\r\nhe found the piping layout. Now he explored the maze of piping along\r\nthe ship\'s sunward side. There it was, a little brass valve with a pipe\r\nleading to the outside skin.\r\n\r\nThe valve was hot enough to sear his hand. Jim carefully wrapped his\r\nhandkerchief around the handle and twisted gently. Inside pressure\r\nsquirted a thin stream of water from the supply tank into the hot\r\nvacuum of space. As it vaporized and dissociated into its atoms, Jim\r\nfelt a mighty surge of expansion against the ship. The blows of a soft\r\nfist pummeled the side.\r\n\r\nJim groaned as the softened plates of the hull creaked and buckled,\r\nbut he held the valve as it was. An inside panel split and let a thin\r\nsifting of insulation drift to the deck. His knee was against the deck\r\nplates and he became conscious of the burning through the cloth of his\r\nuniform. But he stayed there, until through the windows he saw nothing\r\nbut the speckled black of space turn slowly up. Then he shut the valve\r\noff and, rubbing his burned knee, anxiously hobbled to the tracer.\r\n\r\nThe red line had not so much swoop to it now. "Ya!" 

he shouted\r\nexultantly. The centrifugal force from his forward velocity needed just\r\na little help to begin pushing him away from the sun. Jim read the\r\nwater tank gauge; about twenty gallons left.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nFidgeting, he waited another hour. The sun\'s horizon swung up into\r\nview, the blazing plain filled the windows and at last he saw again the\r\nother horizon. It would not do to twist the valve too soon; he had to\r\nwait until the outlet was directly toward the sun so he wouldn\'t lose\r\nany precious forward velocity.\r\n\r\nThe sun\'s horizon bisected the windows. Now! Encouraged by his other\r\nsuccess, Jim twisted the valve hard. He stepped back so his sore knee\r\nwould not rest against the plates.\r\n\r\nThe ship bounced like a beachball in the tremendous upshoot of the\r\ngases outside. Jim clung to a stanchion to keep from being knocked off\r\nhis feet.\r\n\r\nLike a rubber ball dimpled by a thumb, the ship\'s skin began to bulge\r\ninward. Jim tried to let go his hold to get the valve.\r\n\r\nThe bounce of the ship knocked him to his knees. A little steel desk\r\ncame sliding across the compartment, banging him on the shoulder. He\r\nlet go with one hand and shoved the desk between the bulging wall and\r\na cross bulkhead. A white line appeared across the desk, and the paint\r\ncrackled as it began to fold in the middle.\r\n\r\nJim let go and dived for the valve. A panel split wide and insulation\r\npoured out. A scream bubbled from his throat as radiation cut a line\r\nacross his face.\r\n\r\nHe rolled away, then struggled to get to the valve again. But the push\r\nstopped. The tank was empty.\r\n\r\nGroaning with the pain of his face, Jim went to his tracer. He forgot\r\nthe burn as he saw the curve now paralleled zero. No ... it went up a\r\nlittle. Jim whooped for joy.\r\n\r\nNow he scurried about the ship gathering together all the liquids he\r\ncould find. Soup, fruit juice, medicines. He piled them beside the\r\nwater tank and unscrewed the cap. Air whooshed in.\r\n\r\nAt the sound, Jim grinned. He left his pile of cans and bottles as they\r\nwere, and unscrewed the cap to a spare oxygen tank. The compartment\r\nair pressure went up to about twenty five pounds. The excess of oxygen\r\nexhilarated him.\r\n\r\nHe looked over his pile of cans and bottles. He didn\'t like consomme,\r\nit went into the tank. Chicken broth followed. Everything he didn\'t\r\nlike went into the tank, everything else stayed out. Then he patched\r\nthe rip in the panel.\r\n\r\nIt was time. Jim crouched carefully beside the valve, opening it\r\nslowly. The mess inside the tank squirted out. Again the surge beat\r\nagainst the ship, but with the first groan of the hull, Jim throttled\r\nthe valve down a little. His eyes were on the compartment pressure\r\ngauge. The consomme went and inside air began to hiss out. As it too\r\nexpanded, the push on the hull continued.\r\n\r\nWhen the sun\'s horizon was out of sight, the inside pressure registered\r\nonly twelve pounds. Jim shut the valve off.\r\n\r\nNow the tracer line was a nice curve upward.\r\n\r\nJim swung into the pilot\'s chair. He was a little oxygen drunk, but he\r\nmade calculations grow on the page until he had his result. Then he\r\nleaned back and gave the universe a beatific smile.\r\n\r\nHis spiral now outward, would stop as soon as his orbit expanded and\r\ncentrifugal force became less. As the forces came into balance, he\r\nwould take up a permanent orbit around the sun. 

But that orbit lay well\r\noutside the region of heavy static, and he could radio for help. In his\r\nmind he already heard the sweet clang of magnetic grapples against the\r\nhull.\r\n\r\nJim reached for the log and began to letter neatly at the top of a new\r\npage:\r\n\r\nSUGGESTIONS FOR SPACEMEN CAUGHT IN THE SUN.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


"\r\n\r\n"Hardly," I said, rather flippantly. "Once the bug has bitten you--"\r\n\r\n"Have you had anything accepted?"\r\n\r\nI stared at the rug, hating the man for asking. But in this game,\r\nyou\'ve--well, you\'ve got to learn to take criticism. If your work\'s\r\nbad, admit it and throw in the towel."\r\n\r\n"And mine\'s bad?"\r\n\r\nHe shrugged, avoiding my eyes. 

"I\'m afraid so."\r\n\r\nBut the steam had been released and the period of mourning had ended,\r\nso "I\'ll improve," I told him.\r\n\r\n"You\'re wasting your time."\r\n\r\n"Possibly. "\r\n\r\n"Wait a minute. 

Just what did you mean by that other remark?"\r\n\r\nDonald MacDonald glanced around him as though he were afraid invisible\r\nbeings might be eavesdropping. "You really want to know the reason why?"\r\n\r\nI nodded.\r\n\r\n"Your work is good," he said seriously. "Too good. Not up to par on\r\nsome points, but in a few years you\'ll be going places. That\'s why I\r\nsneaked away from them and came here--to beg you to reconsider, to stop\r\nthis writing now, before it\'s too late."\r\n\r\n"You mean--you _can\'t_ mean--you\'re not--afraid of competition?"\r\n\r\nHe waved an annoyed hand. "Competition, hell! There\'s always room for\r\nmore. You don\'t understand," he went on, screwing his face into a look\r\nof determination. The mind is a great and powerful thing, sometimes dangerous.\r\nAll these things--these alien creatures that a science-fiction author\r\ncreates--"\r\n\r\n"Yes?"\r\n\r\nBut he had straightened suddenly, a look of terror on a face gone\r\nashen. 

He went to the door like a man being pushed, fumbled for the\r\nknob. "I beg of you, for your sake, forget it," he called back. Then he\r\nwas gone.\r\n\r\nI went out on the porch but MacDonald was not in sight. I heard a\r\nstrange noise as of the flapping of great leathery wings. A shadow\r\npassed across the lawn. I looked up.\r\n\r\nNothing.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe next morning I got a small envelope in the mail. The letter inside\r\nread, "Enclosed is a check for your story THE MONBEAST...." I sank into\r\nthe softest chair in the world and read those wonderful, wonderful\r\nwords, and held the check in my hand and read those wonderful,\r\nwonderful figures. I was so in a trance I hardly noticed the tiny\r\ndecimal point that scampered on tiny legs across the check. I hardly\r\nfelt the small, sharp bite--but....\r\n\r\nMy first acceptance! It was incredible the exhilaration that flowed\r\nthrough me in that instant. It was like a much-needed shot of\r\nadrenaline, like cool springwater to a thirsty man. I had a check for\r\na story someone thought enough of to publish. I was an author. 

A real,\r\nlive, honest-to-goodness author with a check in my hand to prove to a\r\ncritical world that I wasn\'t a bum after all. Suddenly the world was a\r\nbig, wide, wonderful place to live in, and I loved everyone in it--even\r\nthe poor, disillusioned Donald MacDonald.\r\n\r\nBut why stop here? I thought. 

There were more checks where that came\r\nfrom. If I could sell one story, I could sell two, and then three, and\r\nfour. So I did. In a way, it was something like digging my own grave.\r\nYou don\'t understand that now, but in a little while you\'ll see the\r\nreason why.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAfter I had haunted the newsstand for about three months, the great day\r\ncame. THE MONBEAST was the last story in the magazine (at the time I\r\nthought they really should have featured it) and my name was misspelled\r\non the contents page, but it was a great day just the same. A day of\r\ntriumph. A day for rejoicing. I\'d had several stories accepted during\r\nthe several months\' interval, but this was the day that the fruits of\r\nmy labor became evident to the world.\r\n\r\nI walked home with a proud, firm step, casually displaying the magazine\r\nto the vast public eye, to friend and foe alike. I tried to act\r\nnonchalant, as though this were old stuff to an established writer like\r\nme. It was a day of glory, of triumph, rivaling Caesar\'s victorious\r\nmarch into Rome.\r\n\r\nThat evening I read the story over and over again, marveling at the\r\nperfection of its form, savoring the exquisite flavor of each delicate,\r\nrichly-hued, word, the uniqueness of each choice, well-turned phrase. I\r\nfell asleep with the magazine in my hand.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe next morning the monbeast was sitting at the foot of my bed.\r\n\r\n"Okay, okay," it said, blinking its bug-eyes at me, "don\'t act so\r\nsurprised. MacDonald warned you, didn\'t he?"\r\n\r\n"But--but--"\r\n\r\n"Sure, I\'m real," the monbeast volunteered, scratching its scaly head\r\nwith a long-nailed finger. "That\'s the trouble with you guys. You\'re\r\nfull of imagination, but you can\'t face reality."\r\n\r\n"Where--where\'d you come from?"\r\n\r\nThe monbeast shrugged massive green shoulders. "The whole thing\'s much\r\ntoo technical for me to worry about. All I know is us BEMs exist, and\r\nwe get to your dimension via science-fiction."\r\n\r\n"That \'power of mind\' MacDonald was talking about?" I said, shuddering\r\na bit.\r\n\r\n"Something like that. Other forms of fiction deal with things native to\r\nyour world. Science-fiction regards us BEMs as real, so while we don\'t\r\nordinarily exist here, there\'s a stress created in the barrier between\r\nus, and we come through."\r\n\r\n"Then you\'re really real?"\r\n\r\n"Practically. Right now, though, you\'re the only one who can see and\r\nhear me. You haven\'t characterized me sufficiently so that the readers\r\nwill be convinced that I\'m real. But that\'s okay. 

You\'ll improve."\r\n\r\n"Thanks. But now what about you?" 

I said, trying to not appear\r\noveranxious. "Are you returning to your own dimension or are you\r\nstaying here for awhile?"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe monbeast grinned, showing the eighty sharp-pointed teeth I knew it\r\npossessed. "Sorry, I\'m here to stay. I\'m your brainchild, you know, so\r\nI\'ll have to stick to you."\r\n\r\nI gulped. "Stick to me?"\r\n\r\n"Only figuratively," the monbeast said. "But I\'ll be around." He\r\ncocked a bug-eye at me and said gravely, "We\'d better get a few things\r\nstraight right from the start. One of them is that as far as you\'re\r\nconcerned, I\'m as real as that bedpost."\r\n\r\n"Real?" I tried to laugh that off, but the sound came out a little\r\nweakly. "That\'s silly. You\'re just a product of my imagination."\r\n\r\n"Am I?" the monbeast said.\r\n\r\nHe thrust the scaly face close to mine and yawned. Suddenly the room\r\nbecame a turkish bath.\r\n\r\n"Okay, okay," I said hastily, "turn it off."\r\n\r\nCoolness came, and I breathed easier as the steam dissipated.\r\n\r\n"Secondly, you\'re going to create bigger and better BEMs and make them\r\nmore convincing," the monbeast continued. "With all you writers turning\r\nus loose, we can have a swell time in this world.

"\r\n\r\n"But how can you?" I protested. "You said the readers wouldn\'t believe\r\nin you, so you don\'t exist for them."\r\n\r\n"Science-fiction is growing," the monbeast said. "Everyday more people\r\nare getting to realize that there is more to the world than those\r\nthings they see around them. They believe what they read in love\r\nstories and detective stories. Science-fiction is next."\r\n\r\n"Suppose I don\'t want to create more BEMs?" I said. "Suppose I take up\r\nsaxophone playing or something and leave science-fiction alone."\r\n\r\n"You can\'t stop writing it now, any more than a true fan can stop\r\nreading it. The bug has bitten you." He smiled a piano keyboard of\r\nteeth and continued, "Besides, I could be obliged to--er--inspire you\r\njust a bit. But you just work along with me, and we\'ll both do fine."\r\n\r\nSo we did.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe monbeast isn\'t such a bad fellow after all, once you get to know\r\nhim. Neither are the other BEMs hanging around my house. 

Oh, yes, there\r\nare others, lots of them. Hanging from the rafters. Under chairs. In\r\ncoffee cups. Everywhere. It\'s an occupational hazard, you know.\r\n\r\nChances are, though, you wouldn\'t be able to see them--unless you\'re a\r\nreal gone science-fiction fan, and even then maybe not. But someday you\r\nwill.\r\n\r\nSomeday you\'ll be sitting in your favorite chair reading your favorite\r\nscience-fiction magazine, and you\'ll look up....\r\n\r\nMaybe it\'ll be sitting on the desk beside you, running one of four\r\nhands through a nest of snakes on its scaly head. Maybe it\'ll be only\r\nan inch tall and perched on the piano watching you. Maybe at first\r\nit\'ll be just a warm, dank breath on the back of your neck.\r\n\r\nNo telling _when_ it\'ll be either. Maybe next year, next month;\r\ntomorrow. 

Who knows--perhaps even now.\r\n\r\nHere\'s a little tip. When you lay down this magazine, turn around\r\nslowly. Have you ever had the feeling that something was going on\r\nbehind your back but when you turned around you saw nothing? What\'s\r\nthat? You think maybe you\'ve got that feeling right now?\r\n\r\nListen, on second thought, now that you know, maybe you better not turn\r\naround. Take this as a gag. 

A nice big laugh. You\'ll be a lot better\r\noff that way.\r\n\r\nWhat you don\'t know can\'t hurt you....\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


I\r\nasked him. Rusty and Doc laughed. It was a good joke because we rode out\r\nto the job in my jeep, and so we\'d naturally get there at the same time.\r\n\r\nThen Rusty sat up straighter and looked over at the bar. "Hey," he said,\r\n"Pop\'s talking to Burt Holden." Pop Johnson owns our outfit. He\'s one of\r\nthe small operators that guys like Burt are trying to squeeze out.\r\n\r\n"Hope he don\'t try to rook Pop into no deals," said Lew.\r\n\r\nDoc tipped up his bottle of beer. In Oregon they don\'t sell anything but\r\nbeer in the taverns. 

"Times change," he said. "Back in 1900 all they\r\nwanted was gold. Now they\'re trying to take all the trees."\r\n\r\n"It\'s the big operators like Burt," I said. "Little guys like Pop can\'t\r\ncut \'em as fast as they grow. The companies don\'t have to reseed,\r\neither, except on National Forest land."\r\n\r\n"That Burt Holden was up to my place couple weeks ago," said Doc. "Darn\r\nnear caught me skinning out a deer."\r\n\r\n"He better not yap to the game warden," said Rusty. "Them laws is for\r\nsports and Outsiders, not us guys who need the meat."\r\n\r\n"He wanted to buy all my timber," said Doc. "Offered me ten dollars a\r\nthousand board feet, on the stump."\r\n\r\n"Don\'t sell," I advised him. "If Burt offers that much, almost anyone\r\nelse will pay twelve."\r\n\r\nDoc looked at me. "I\'d never sell my trees. Not at any price. I got a\r\nhundred and sixty acres of virgin stand, and that\'s the way it\'s gonna\r\nstay. I cut up the windfalls and snags for firewood, and that\'s all."\r\n\r\n"Here comes Pop," said Lew.\r\n\r\nPop sat down with us and had a beer. He looked worried. 

We didn\'t ask\r\nhim any questions, because we figure a man will talk if he wants to, and\r\nif he doesn\'t it\'s his own business.\r\n\r\nHe finally unlimbered. "Burt Holden wants to buy the mill," he said,\r\nwiping his mouth on the back of his hand.\r\n\r\n"Buy _your_ mill?" said Lew. "Hell, his mill is five times as big, and\r\nhe\'s even got a burner to take care of slashings, so he don\'t have to\r\nshut down in the fire season."\r\n\r\n"He just wants the land," said Pop, "because it\'s near the highway. He\r\nwants to tear down my setup and build a pulp mill."\r\n\r\n"A _pulp_ mill!" If we could have seen Doc\'s eyes through the glasses I\r\nimagine they\'d have been popped open a full half inch. "Why, then\r\nthey\'ll be cutting down everything but the brush!"\r\n\r\nPop nodded. 

"Yeah. Size of a log don\'t matter when you make paper--just\r\nso it\'s wood."\r\n\r\nIt seemed as though Doc was talking to himself. 

"They\'ll strip the land\r\ndown bare," he mumbled. "And the hills will wash away, and the chemicals\r\nthey use in the mill will kill the fish in the creeks and the Illinois\r\nRiver."\r\n\r\n"That\'s why they won\'t let anyone start a pulp mill near Grants Pass,"\r\nsaid Pop. "Most of the town\'s money comes from sports who come up to the\r\nRogue River to fish."\r\n\r\nRusty set his jaw. "In the winter we _need_ them fish," he said. He was\r\nright, too. The woods close down in the winter, on account of the snow,\r\nand if a man can\'t hunt and fish he\'s liable to get kind of hungry. That\r\nrocking chair money doesn\'t stretch very far.\r\n\r\n"I ain\'t gonna sell," said Pop. "But that won\'t stop Burt Holden, and\r\nany place he builds the mill around here will drain into the Illinois."\r\n\r\nDoc pushed back his chair and stood up to his full height of five foot\r\nfour. "I\'m gonna talk to Burt Holden," he said.\r\n\r\nRusty stood up to his six foot three. "I\'ll bring him over here, Doc,"\r\nhe said. "We\'re handy to the cue rack here, and Lew and Simmons can keep\r\nthem guys he\'s with off my back."\r\n\r\nI stood up and shoved Rusty back down. I\'m no taller than he is, but I\r\noutweigh him about twenty pounds. I started working in the woods when we\r\nstill felled trees with axes and misery whips--crosscut saws to the\r\nOutsiders. "I\'ll go get him," I said. "You\'re still mad about the show,\r\nand you wouldn\'t be able to get him this far without mussing him up."\r\n\r\n"There won\'t be no trouble," said Doc. "I just want to make him an\r\noffer."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI went over and told Burt that Doc wanted to talk to him. The three guys\r\nwith him followed us back to the table.\r\n\r\nBurt figured he knew what it was all about, and he just stood over Doc\r\nand looked down on him. "If it\'s about your timber, Yoris," he said,\r\n"I\'ll take it, but I can\'t pay you more than nine dollars now. Lumber\'s\r\ncoming down, and I\'m taking a chance even at that." He rocked back and\r\nforth on his heels and looked at Pop as though daring him to say\r\ndifferent.\r\n\r\n"I still don\'t want to sell, Mr. Holden," said Doc. "But I\'ve got better\r\nthan three million feet on my place, and I\'ll _give_ it to you if you\r\nwon\'t put a pulp mill anywhere in the Illinois Valley."\r\n\r\nWe were all floored at that, but Burt recovered first. He gave a nasty\r\nlaugh. 

"Not interested, Yoris. If you want to sell, look me up."\r\n\r\n"Wait!" 

said Doc. "A pulp mill will take every tree in the Valley. In a\r\nfew years--"\r\n\r\n"It\'ll make money, too," said Burt flatly.\r\n\r\n"Money ain\'t everything by a long shot. It won\'t buy trees and creeks\r\nand rain."\r\n\r\n"It\'ll buy trees to make lumber." Burt was getting mad. "I don\'t want\r\nany opposition from you, Yoris. I\'ve had enough trouble from people who\r\ntry to hold back progress. If you don\'t like the way we run things here,\r\nyou can--hell, you can go back to Mars!

"\r\n\r\nIt seemed to me that it was just about time to start in. I could have\r\ntaken Burt easiest, but I knew Rusty would probably swing on him first\r\nand get in my way, so I planned to work on the two guys on Burt\'s right,\r\nleaving the one on his left for Lew. I didn\'t want Pop to get tangled up\r\nin it.\r\n\r\nI don\'t generally wait too long after I make up my mind, but then I\r\nnoticed Rusty reaching out slowly for a cue stick, and I thought maybe\r\nI\'d better take Burt first, while Rusty got set. I never did see a guy\r\nso one way about having something in his hands.\r\n\r\nBut Doc didn\'t drop out. "There ain\'t nothing but a few scrub trees on\r\nMars," he said to Burt, looking him square in the eye. "And no creeks\r\nand no rain."\r\n\r\nBurt curled his lip sarcastically. 

"The hell you say! 

Is that why you\r\ndidn\'t like it there?" You could see he was just trying to egg Doc into\r\nsaying he\'d come from Mars, so he could give him the horse laugh. The\r\nguys he was with were getting set for a fracas, but they were waiting\r\nfor Burt to lead off.\r\n\r\nDoc didn\'t get caught. "But there\'s gold," he said, like he hadn\'t heard\r\nBurt at all. "Tons of it--laying all over the ground."\r\n\r\nI guess Burt decided to ride along. "Okay, Yoris," he said. 

"Tell you\r\nwhat I\'ll do. For only one ton of Martian gold I\'ll agree to drop all\r\nplans for a pulp mill, here or anywhere else. In fact, I\'ll get out of\r\nbusiness altogether."\r\n\r\nDoc moved in like a log falling out of the loading tongs. "That\'s a\r\ndeal," he said. "You ready to go?"\r\n\r\nBurt started to look disgusted, then he smiled. 

"Sure. Mars must be\r\nquite a place if you came from there."\r\n\r\n"Okay," said Doc. "You just stand up against the wall, Mr. Holden."\r\nBurt\'s smile faded. He figured Doc was trying to maneuver him into a\r\nlikely position for us. But Doc cleared that up quick. "You boys get up\r\nand stand aside," he ordered. "Get back a ways and give Mr. Holden\r\nplenty of room." We didn\'t like it, but we cleared out from around the\r\ntable. A bunch from the bar and pool tables, sensing something was up,\r\ncame drifting over to watch. I could feel tension building up. "Now,"\r\nsaid Doc, pointing, "you just stand right over there, Mr. Holden, and\r\nfold your arms."\r\n\r\nBurt didn\'t like the audience, and I guess he figured his plans were\r\nbackfiring when Doc didn\'t bluff. "You hill-happy old coot," he\r\nsnarled. "You\'d better go home and sleep it off!" I grabbed hold of\r\nLew\'s arm and shook my head at Rusty. I wasn\'t going to interfere with\r\nDoc now.\r\n\r\n"You\'re not scared, are you, Mr. Holden?" said Doc quietly. "Just you\r\nstand against the wall and take it easy. It won\'t hurt a bit."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBurt Holden was plenty tough for an Outsider, and a hard-headed\r\nbusinessman to boot, but he\'d never run into a customer like Doc before.\r\nYou could see him trying to make up his mind on how to handle this\r\nthing. He glanced around quick at the crowd, and I could tell he decided\r\nto play it out to where Doc would have to draw in his horns. He actually\r\ngrinned, for the effect it would have on everybody watching. 

"All right,\r\nYoris," he said. He backed against the wall and folded his arms. "But\r\nhadn\'t you better stand up here with me?"\r\n\r\n"I ain\'t going," said Doc. "I don\'t like Mars. But you won\'t have no\r\ntrouble getting your gold. There\'s nuggets the size of your fist laying\r\nall over the dry river beds."\r\n\r\n"I hate to be nosey," said Burt, playing to the crowd, "but how are you\r\ngoing to get me there?"\r\n\r\n"With his head, o\'course!" 

blurted Rusty before I could stop him. "Just\r\nlike he cures you when you\'re sick!" Doc had pulled Rusty through two or\r\nthree bad kid sicknesses--and a lot of the rest of us, too.\r\n\r\n"Yep," said Doc. "A man don\'t need one of them rocket things to get\r\nbetween here and Mars. Fact is, I never seen one."\r\n\r\nBurt looked at the ceiling like he was a martyr, then back at Doc.\r\n"Well, Yoris," he said in a tone that meant he was just about through\r\nhumoring him, "I\'m waiting. Can you send me there or can\'t you?" The\r\nstart of a nasty smile was beginning to show at the corners of his\r\nmouth.\r\n\r\n"Sure," said Doc. He slumped down in his chair and cupped his hands\r\nlightly around his dark glasses. I noticed his fingers trembling a\r\nlittle against his forehead.\r\n\r\nThe lights dimmed, flickered and went out, and we waited for the\r\nbartender to put in a new fuse. The power around here doesn\'t go haywire\r\nexcept in the winter, when trees fall across the lines. A small fight\r\nstarted over in a corner.\r\n\r\nWhen the lights came back on, Doc and Pop started for the door, and Lew\r\nand Rusty and I followed. Burt\'s buddies were looking kind of puzzled,\r\nand a few old-timers were moving over to watch the fight. The rest were\r\nheading back to the bar.\r\n\r\nRusty piled into the jeep with Doc and me. "When you going to bring him\r\nback, Doc?" he asked when we started moving.\r\n\r\n"Dunno," said Doc. He took off his glasses to watch me shift gears. He\'s\r\nbeen after me for a long time to teach him how to drive. "It only works\r\non a man once."\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _If Worlds of Science Fiction_ November\r\n    1953. Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and\r\n    typographical errors have been corrected without note.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


Talking\r\nto Barbara, your fianc\xc3\xa9e. Looking at Barbara--Barbara in a swim\r\nsuit--her skin golden tan in the brilliant sunshine, beautiful.\r\n\r\nYou wore swimming trunks. Now you do not feel them on you; the slight\r\npressure of the elastic waistband is no longer there against your waist.\r\nYou touch your hands to your hips. 

You are naked. And standing.\r\n\r\nWhatever has happened to you is more than a change to sudden darkness or\r\nto sudden blindness.\r\n\r\nYou raise your hands gropingly before you. They touch a plain smooth\r\nsurface, a wall. You spread them apart and each hand reaches a corner.\r\nYou pivot slowly. A second wall, then a third, then a door. You are in a\r\ncloset about four feet square.\r\n\r\nYour hand finds the knob of the door. It turns and you push the door\r\nopen.\r\n\r\nThere is light now. The door has opened to a lighted room ... a room\r\nthat you have never seen before.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIt is not large, but it is pleasantly furnished--although the furniture\r\nis of a style that is strange to you. Modesty makes you open the door\r\ncautiously the rest of the way. But the room is empty of people.\r\n\r\nYou step into the room, turning to look behind you into the closet,\r\nwhich is now illuminated by light from the room. The closet is and is\r\nnot a closet; it is the size and shape of one, but it contains nothing,\r\nnot a single hook, no rod for hanging clothes, no shelf. It is an empty,\r\nblank-walled, four-by-four-foot space.\r\n\r\nYou close the door to it and stand looking around the room. It is about\r\ntwelve by sixteen feet. There is one door, but it is closed. There are\r\nno windows. Five pieces of furniture. Four of them you recognize--more\r\nor less. One looks like a very functional desk. One is obviously a\r\nchair ... a comfortable-looking one. There is a table, although its top\r\nis on several levels instead of only one. Another is a bed, or couch.\r\nSomething shimmering is lying across it and you walk over and pick the\r\nshimmering something up and examine it. It is a garment.\r\n\r\nYou are naked, so you put it on. Slippers are part way under the bed (or\r\ncouch) and you slide your feet into them. They fit, and they feel warm\r\nand comfortable as nothing you have ever worn on your feet has felt.\r\nLike lamb\'s wool, but softer.\r\n\r\nYou are dressed now. You look at the door--the only door of the room\r\nexcept that of the closet (closet?) 

from which you entered it. You walk\r\nto the door and before you try the knob, you see the small typewritten\r\nsign pasted just above it that reads:\r\n\r\n    This door has a time lock set to open in one hour. For reasons you\r\n    will soon understand, it is better that you do not leave this room\r\n    before then. There is a letter for you on the desk. Please read it.\r\n\r\nIt is not signed. You look at the desk and see that there is an envelope\r\nlying on it.\r\n\r\nYou do not yet go to take that envelope from the desk and read the\r\nletter that must be in it.\r\n\r\nWhy not? Because you are frightened.\r\n\r\nYou see other things about the room. The lighting has no source that you\r\ncan discover. It comes from nowhere. It is not indirect lighting; the\r\nceiling and the walls are not reflecting it at all.\r\n\r\n[Illustration: Illustrated by VIDMER]\r\n\r\nThey didn\'t have lighting like that, back where you came from. What did\r\nyou mean by _back where you came from_?\r\n\r\nYou close your eyes. You tell yourself: _I am Norman Hastings. I am an\r\nassociate professor of mathematics at the University of Southern\r\nCalifornia. I am twenty-five years old, and this is the year nineteen\r\nhundred and fifty-four._\r\n\r\nYou open your eyes and look again.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThey didn\'t use that style of furniture in Los Angeles--or anywhere else\r\nthat you know of--in 1954. That thing over in the corner--you can\'t even\r\nguess what it is. So might your grandfather, at your age, have looked at\r\na television set.\r\n\r\nYou look down at yourself, at the shimmering garment that you found\r\nwaiting for you. With thumb and forefinger you feel its texture.\r\n\r\nIt\'s like nothing you\'ve ever touched before.\r\n\r\n_I am Norman Hastings. This is nineteen hundred and fifty-four._\r\n\r\nSuddenly you must know, and at once.\r\n\r\nYou go to the desk and pick up the envelope that lies upon it. Your name\r\nis typed on the outside: _Norman Hastings_.\r\n\r\nYour hands shake a little as you open it. Do you blame them?\r\n\r\nThere are several pages, typewritten. Dear Norman, it starts. You turn\r\nquickly to the end to look for the signature. It is unsigned.\r\n\r\nYou turn back and start reading.\r\n\r\n"Do not be afraid. There is nothing to fear, but much to explain. Much\r\nthat you must understand before the time lock opens that door. Much that\r\nyou must accept and--obey.\r\n\r\n"You have already guessed that you are in the future--in what, to you,\r\nseems to be the future. The clothes and the room must have told you\r\nthat. I planned it that way so the shock would not be too sudden, so you\r\nwould realize it over the course of several minutes rather than read it\r\nhere--and quite probably disbelieve what you read.\r\n\r\n"The \'closet\' from which you have just stepped is, as you have by now\r\nrealized, a time machine. From it you stepped into the world of 2004.\r\nThe date is April 7th, just fifty years from the time you last remember.\r\n\r\n"You cannot return.\r\n\r\n"I did this to you and you may hate me for it; I do not know. That is up\r\nto you to decide, but it does not matter. 

What does matter, and not to\r\nyou alone, is another decision which you must make. I am incapable of\r\nmaking it.\r\n\r\n"Who is writing this to you? 

I would rather not tell you just yet. By\r\nthe time you have finished reading this, even though it is not signed\r\n(for I knew you would look first for a signature), I will not need to\r\ntell you who I am. You will know.\r\n\r\n"I am seventy-five years of age. I have, in this year 2004, been\r\nstudying \'time\' for thirty of those years. I have completed the first\r\ntime machine ever built--and thus far, its construction, even the fact\r\nthat it has been constructed, is my own secret.\r\n\r\n"You have just participated in the first major experiment. It will be\r\nyour responsibility to decide whether there shall ever be any more\r\nexperiments with it, whether it should be given to the world, or whether\r\nit should be destroyed and never used again."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nEnd of the first page. 

You look up for a moment, hesitating to turn the\r\nnext page. Already you suspect what is coming.\r\n\r\nYou turn the page.\r\n\r\n"I constructed the first time machine a week ago. My calculations had\r\ntold me that it would work, but not how it would work. I had expected it\r\nto send an object back in time--it works backward in time only, not\r\nforward--physically unchanged and intact.\r\n\r\n"My first experiment showed me my error. I placed a cube of metal in the\r\nmachine--it was a miniature of the one you just walked out of--and set\r\nthe machine to go backward ten years. I flicked the switch and opened\r\nthe door, expecting to find the cube vanished. Instead I found it had\r\ncrumbled to powder.\r\n\r\n"I put in another cube and sent it two years back. The second cube came\r\nback unchanged, except that it was newer, shinier.\r\n\r\n"That gave me the answer. I had been expecting the cubes to go back in\r\ntime, and they had done so, but not in the sense I had expected them to.\r\nThose metal cubes had been fabricated about three years previously. I\r\nhad sent the first one back years before it had existed in its\r\nfabricated form. Ten years ago it had been ore. The machine returned it\r\nto that state.\r\n\r\n"Do you see how our previous theories of time travel have been wrong? We\r\nexpected to be able to step into a time machine in, say, 2004, set it\r\nfor fifty years back, and then step out in the year 1954 ... but it does\r\nnot work that way. The machine does not move in time. Only whatever is\r\nwithin the machine is affected, and then just with relation to itself\r\nand not to the rest of the Universe.\r\n\r\n"I confirmed this with guinea pigs by sending one six weeks old five\r\nweeks back and it came out a baby.\r\n\r\n"I need not outline all my experiments here. You will find a record of\r\nthem in the desk and you can study it later.\r\n\r\n"Do you understand now what has happened to you, Norman?

"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nYou begin to understand. And you begin to sweat.\r\n\r\nThe _I_ who wrote that letter you are now reading is _you_, yourself at\r\nthe age of seventy-five, in this year of 2004. You are that\r\nseventy-five-year-old man, with your body returned to what it had been\r\nfifty years ago, with all the memories of fifty years of living wiped\r\nout.\r\n\r\n_You_ invented the time machine.\r\n\r\nAnd before you used it on yourself, you made these arrangements to help\r\nyou orient yourself. You wrote yourself the letter which you are now\r\nreading.\r\n\r\nBut if those fifty years are--to you--gone, what of all your friends,\r\nthose you loved? What of your parents? What of the girl you are\r\ngoing--were going--to marry?\r\n\r\nYou read on:\r\n\r\n"Yes, you will want to know what has happened. Mom died in 1963, Dad in\r\n1968. You married Barbara in 1956. I am sorry to tell you that she died\r\nonly three years later, in a plane crash. You have one son. He is still\r\nliving; his name is Walter; he is now forty-six years old and is an\r\naccountant in Kansas City."\r\n\r\nTears come into your eyes and for a moment you can no longer read.\r\nBarbara dead--dead for forty-five years. And only minutes ago, in\r\nsubjective time, you were sitting next to her, sitting in the bright sun\r\nin a Beverly Hills patio ...\r\n\r\nYou force yourself to read again.\r\n\r\n"But back to the discovery. You begin to see some of its implications.\r\nYou will need time to think to see all of them.\r\n\r\n"It does not permit time travel as we have thought of time travel, but\r\nit gives us immortality of a sort. Immortality of the kind I have\r\ntemporarily given us.\r\n\r\n"_Is it good?_ Is it worth while to lose the memory of fifty years of\r\none\'s life in order to return one\'s body to relative youth? The only way\r\nI can find out is to try, as soon as I have finished writing this and\r\nmade my other preparations.\r\n\r\n"You will know the answer.\r\n\r\n"But before you decide, remember that there is another problem, more\r\nimportant than the psychological one. I mean overpopulation.\r\n\r\n"If our discovery is given to the world, if all who are old or dying\r\ncan make themselves young again, the population will almost double every\r\ngeneration. Nor would the world--not even our own relatively enlightened\r\ncountry--be willing to accept compulsory birth control as a solution.\r\n\r\n"Give this to the world, as the world is today in 2004, and within a\r\ngeneration there will be famine, suffering, war. Perhaps a complete\r\ncollapse of civilization.\r\n\r\n"Yes, we have reached other planets, but they are not suitable for\r\ncolonizing. The stars may be our answer, but we are a long way from\r\nreaching them. When we do, someday, the billions of habitable planets\r\nthat must be out there will be our answer ... our living room. But until\r\nthen, what is the answer?\r\n\r\n"Destroy the machine? But think of the countless lives it can save, the\r\nsuffering it can prevent. Think of what it would mean to a man dying of\r\ncancer. 

Think ..."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThink. You finish the letter and put it down.\r\n\r\nYou think of Barbara dead for forty-five years. And of the fact that you\r\nwere married to her for three years and that those years are lost to\r\nyou.\r\n\r\nFifty years lost. You damn the old man of seventy-five whom you became\r\nand who has done this to you ... who has given you this decision to\r\nmake.\r\n\r\nBitterly, you know what the decision must be. You think that _he_ knew,\r\ntoo, and realize that he could safely leave it in your hands. Damn him,\r\nhe _should_ have known.\r\n\r\nToo valuable to destroy, too dangerous to give.\r\n\r\nThe other answer is painfully obvious.\r\n\r\nYou must be custodian of this discovery and keep it secret until it is\r\nsafe to give, until mankind has expanded to the stars and has new worlds\r\nto populate, or until, even without that, he has reached a state of\r\ncivilization where he can avoid overpopulation by rationing births to\r\nthe number of accidental--or voluntary--deaths.\r\n\r\nIf neither of those things has happened in another fifty years (and are\r\nthey likely so soon?), then you, at seventy-five, will be writing\r\nanother letter like this one. 

You will be undergoing another experience\r\nsimilar to the one you\'re going through now. 

And making the same\r\ndecision, of course.\r\n\r\nWhy not? You\'ll be the same person again.\r\n\r\nTime and again, to preserve this secret until Man is ready for it.\r\n\r\nHow often will you again sit at a desk like this one, thinking the\r\nthoughts you are thinking now, feeling the grief you now feel?\r\n\r\nThere is a click at the door and you know that the time lock has opened,\r\nthat you are now free to leave this room, free to start a new life for\r\nyourself in place of the one you have already lived and lost.\r\n\r\nBut you are in no hurry now to walk directly through that door.\r\n\r\nYou sit there, staring straight ahead of you blindly, seeing in your\r\nmind\'s eye the vista of a set of facing mirrors, like those in an\r\nold-fashioned barber shop, reflecting the same thing over and over\r\nagain, diminishing into far distance.\r\n\r\n                                                       --FREDRIC BROWN\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Galaxy Science Fiction_ December 1953.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and\r\n    typographical errors have been corrected without note.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


"Dr. Seaward, will\r\nyou please take the observer\'s place and check."\r\n\r\nSeaward dropped the calculations in hand, walked across the control\r\nroom of the great interstellar explorer, up to the very tip. Kendall\r\nstood aside while the doctor applied his eye to the lens.\r\n\r\n"It\'s there all right, Broster. A little red disk exactly where he\r\ncalled it off; the chart\'s wrong."\r\n\r\nBroster ran a hand through his chestnut hair, a puzzled look in his\r\neyes. He glared at the space-chart for a moment, as if loath to believe\r\nthat that faithful instrument could have gone haywire. Then he picked\r\nhis way over to the electro-telescope to verify the sighting personally.\r\n\r\nA moment later, the three were looking at each other wonderingly.\r\nAll realized what this might mean: if that space-chart failed them,\r\nit might be all over with any possibility ever of returning home.\r\nSpace-navigating in the bounds of the solar system was one thing; there\r\nit didn\'t matter whether you ran by chart or by observation. But here\r\nin the bounds of cosmic space, thousands of light-years from the sun,\r\nwhere they had to navigate in the blackness of interstellar distances,\r\nthe space-chart was all-important. Bodies out here were dark; there\r\nwere no stars nearby from which they could reflect light....\r\n\r\n"That chart will have to be overhauled," murmured the captain. "If it\'s\r\ngone wrong...."\r\n\r\n"What about this planet? It\'s the only one around this star," put in\r\nKendall, jerking a thumb in its general direction.\r\n\r\n"Head toward it; we may as well give it the once-over."\r\n\r\nThe huge ship pursued its unvarying course toward the approaching star.\r\nAt a single light-year away, they decelerated, slowed down. Riding the\r\nstrange eka-gravity waves, the little-known carrier-waves for light and\r\ngravity which seemed to travel as fast in relation to light as light\r\nin relation to sound, this craft of the Thirtieth Century was able to\r\naccomplish what had for centuries been believed unachievable.\r\n\r\nThey approached until at last the gravital drag clutched the ship,\r\nstarted to draw it in toward that vast, fiery globe spurting forth\r\ncountless tons of disintegrated matter per second, emanating energy\r\ninconceivable. Yet, withal, a small star, smaller than Sol and quite\r\ninconspicuous as stars go.\r\n\r\nAs they drifted, Broster and Seaward examined the space-chart\r\nthoroughly. But in vain; nothing could be found out of order: no\r\nshort circuits, no tubes needing replacement. It was in perfect shape,\r\nbut ... it refused to light a white speck in its black field for the\r\nnear planet.\r\n\r\nThey watched the planet grow larger, slowly made out surface details.\r\nA ruddy world, bathed entirely in red light, although the star around\r\nwhich it circled was white. Crimson clouds floated in masses of carmine\r\nseas and necine land-masses. The glow of the red world shone in\r\nthrough the stella-quartzite ports, throwing a weird, bloody glare on\r\neverything.\r\n\r\n"This is a helluva world," growled Kendall. "You\'d go nuts there after\r\nawhile.

"\r\n\r\nSeaward nodded. 

"Quite so. Red is a color that acts to irritate those\r\nwho look at it overlong. I wouldn\'t advise staying on this world for\r\nmore than a few minutes. We could easily go mad were we forced to\r\nremain here so much as a day.

"\r\n\r\n"We\'ll land, anyway, and look around. If--" Broster was cut off\r\nabruptly as the shrill scream of the alarm pierced his line of thought.\r\n"What the devil is that?"\r\n\r\nThe sound of running feet from the far back of the ship came to their\r\nears, then the fourth member of the crew streaked into the control\r\nroom. "Space-ships approaching us!" Arundell shouted. "Didn\'t you spot\r\nthem?"\r\n\r\nBroster wheeled around to the chart. Nothing indicated; according to\r\nit, there was no planet ahead of them, no space-ships behind them. He\r\nmuttered something then hurried across to the side ports, swung out the\r\nperiscopic plates, stared anxiously to their rear.\r\n\r\nThere were at least a dozen of the red bodies moving along in their\r\nwake. Large, all of them, and near. Ships almost as great as the\r\n_Astralite_, ships that looked dangerous.\r\n\r\n"They\'re close," he grated, "too damn close. I don\'t like it."\r\n\r\n"Neither did I. I was wondering why you didn\'t do something when I saw\r\nthem in the port," Arundell exclaimed.\r\n\r\nBroster jumped to the controls, pulled the lever that should shunt\r\nthe ship to one side. But as the nose turned away, and the great mass\r\nof her began slowly to describe a long arc in relation to her former\r\ncourse, another exclamation came from Kendall: "They\'re spreading out\r\nto stop us!"\r\n\r\nBroster cursed, reset the course. The planet was dead ahead now.\r\n\r\n"Trapped!" he fumed. "The red planet ahead of us, and those ships\r\nbehind us. What do they want?"\r\n\r\n"It might be well to stop," Dr. Seaward put in. "They may want to look\r\nus over and nothing more. Unless we arouse suspicion by resisting now."\r\n\r\n"And they might steal the ship under our noses, too," protested\r\nArundell.\r\n\r\nBroster shook his head. "There cannot be a question of letting unknown\r\nintelligences enter this craft or hold it. We can\'t afford to take\r\nchances, even if the notion that other world dwellers are necessarily\r\nenemies is silly. We\'ve got to assume that everything we see is\r\ndangerous until proven harmless or friendly. Those are our first\r\norders: do not surrender the ship."\r\n\r\n"Then we run for it?" asked Seaward.\r\n\r\n"We do. Our offensive weapons may be better than theirs but it\'s\r\nanother chance we\'re not taking. The very fact that we\'re outnumbered\r\nmakes retreat the order of the day."\r\n\r\n"Look there!" 

exclaimed Arundell. "They\'re beaming past us!"\r\n\r\nOne of the strange oval, multi-ported, oddly-ornamented, crimson craft\r\nhad just shot a red beam alongside of the _Astralite_. Not touching it,\r\nbut passing by, as if to show that, whenever they cared, this fleet\r\ncould annihilate the intruder. Then, all the other ships surrounding\r\nthem began to flash beams. Crossing and criss-crossing all about them\r\nsave in front.\r\n\r\n"Look," exclaimed Kendall. "You can see those beams as if they were in\r\nair."\r\n\r\n"Marvellous and impossible," groaned Seaward. "We\'ve run into a\r\nswarm of impossibilities today. Some philosopher once remarked that\r\nin eternity everything was possible--in fact, everything that could\r\npossibly happen has happened. It looks as if we\'re running into bits of\r\nthat now. 

I should have taken my daughter\'s advice and let a younger\r\nman come this trip."\r\n\r\n"It may be impossible, but it\'s so," broke in Broster. 

"And deadly.\r\nWe\'re getting out of here fast."\r\n\r\nHe turned to the controls and a moment later the _Astralite_ began to\r\naccelerate. There was a limit to the speed they could reach as they\r\nwould have to shunt again soon to keep from smashing against the red\r\nplanet. Unless--\r\n\r\n"Why not?" asked Arundell, following Broster\'s evident thoughts.\r\n\r\n"They apparently want us to land on the planet. So we do go for it,\r\nthen shunt aside at the last minute."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAt first, it seemed as if the _Astralite_ would leave the others\r\nbehind, but it was soon apparent that the unknown ships could keep up\r\nwith her. In fact were closing in.\r\n\r\nThere was one pursuer behind them that seemed to Kendall, as he\r\nwatched through the lens, almost to be upon them. It was, he knew,\r\nsome half-mile away in reality. He could see the curiously pitted nose\r\nof the craft, note the weirdly-streamlined mass. He observed, with\r\nastonishment, a little piece of wire seemingly flying loose from a\r\nbearing on one of the strange ships, which was streaming off behind as\r\nif in a stiff breeze. Yet space about them was empty!\r\n\r\n"Look out!" called Seaward from the forward scope. 

"Here\'s more of\r\nthem."\r\n\r\nComing around the planet from behind, spreading out along the side as\r\nif to form a welcoming arch were more of the weird ships.\r\n\r\n"That ties it," exclaimed Broster. "We\'ll never be able to pass the\r\nplanet. It\'s either land or crash."\r\n\r\n[Illustration: "_We\'ll never be able to pass the planet. It\'s either\r\nland or crash._"]\r\n\r\n"Then we crash," came the response.\r\n\r\n"Man the guns!" yelled Broster. 

"Let\'s see how many we can take with us\r\nbefore we go."\r\n\r\nThe three others swung in the various weapons and trained them on the\r\nsurrounding ships. Explosion-torpedo cannon, twin-rays for electric\r\njolting comprised the types of offensive guns. They were getting\r\nvery close to the planet, now. And it seemed as if the red ships\r\nwere expecting the _Astralite_ to slow down, for their beams shot\r\noccasionally in front of the earth-ship. The carmine bulk of the\r\nplanet loomed up over most of the view now. It was too late to shunt\r\naside.\r\n\r\n"Fire!"\r\n\r\nNo sound, no roar of explosions. They watched eagerly for results. 

But\r\nthere were none. Not a single torpedo appeared to have hit its mark,\r\nnot a single twin-ray seemed to bathe the surrounding ovoids. They\r\nfired again.\r\n\r\nKendall swore. The course of one torpedo was the stimulus; he watched\r\nit, saw its dark mass approach the nose of one of the vessels behind.\r\nThen he swears he saw it strike--and disappear.\r\n\r\nFiring was useless. These ships were invulnerable to their weapons.\r\n\r\nBroster looked up, bracing himself.\r\n\r\n"Stand by to crash!"\r\n\r\nThe four stopped everything, turned to look at each other for a moment\r\nin silence. In a few seconds more they would simply cease to exist. 

No\r\npain, no hours of lingering agony trapped in the wreckage. At the speed\r\nthey were going, the entire ship would be volatilized, would fuse into\r\na molten, glowing mass.\r\n\r\nThey turned again to the plates to look for a last time at the universe\r\naround them.\r\n\r\nFor six years they had traveled away from earth, far, far beyond any\r\npoint man had ever dreamed of reaching. They were almost to the point\r\nwhere the order to turn back would have been given. Much had been\r\nlearned; now it would be lost.\r\n\r\nBroster gave her full acceleration.\r\n\r\nThey saw the planet seemingly leap toward them, saw cloudbanks flick\r\npast them. A great flat plain of ruddy rock, a dread expanse of barren\r\ngranite. This in the veriest fragment of a second, then--\r\n\r\nA momentary shock, as if each man had received an electrical jolt; a\r\nsudden flash of intolerable red. Darkness.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe earthmen blinked their eyes.\r\n\r\nThey were in the ship, unharmed. They stood at their posts in the same\r\nposition as before. And about them the black of far space and the\r\nshining points of the star-studded Milky Way.\r\n\r\nKendall gazed into the lens of the rear port, beckoned to the others.\r\nThe red planet was already a small, crimson disk behind them, passing\r\ninto oblivion as they accelerated onward, outward.\r\n\r\nBroster laughed. "It\'s all clear now. Why the space-chart seemingly did\r\nnot function, why our weapons were useless."\r\n\r\n"And why we were not killed, and why their beams could be seen in\r\nspace," added Seaward.\r\n\r\n"Because they weren\'t in space; they were in air. In the air of another\r\nuniverse."\r\n\r\n"It was all an illusion," explained Seaward. "The ships, the planet,\r\neverything. That is why none of these things registered on the space\r\nchart; there were no gravity waves emanating from them because they\r\nwere not there."\r\n\r\nBroster leaned back in his chair. "We\'ve all known that there are many\r\nuniverses beside ours, separated from us by the fourth-dimensional\r\nspace-time sheet. That was demonstrated by Marilus centuries ago.\r\nLaboratory experiments have produced images of other planets. All this\r\nwas just such an image.\r\n\r\n"The space-time envelope must have been a little warped at this point.\r\nEnough so as to let part of the waves emanating from the atoms of that\r\nsection to pass through to our universe--and permit waves emanating\r\nfrom the atoms of our universe to pass through to them. We were able\r\nto see the red rays of their spectrum, nothing else. They saw us as a\r\nviolet ship. But that was all."\r\n\r\n"Then," put in Kendall, "that\'s why they seemed to be shooting rays at\r\nus."\r\n\r\n"Right. We appeared to them, in their world, as suddenly as they\r\nappeared to us in space; it was a double mirage. At one end of the\r\nwarp, they and their planet suddenly appear in what the instruments\r\nshow to be empty space; at the other end, we appear out of nowhere, a\r\nstrange ship headed for their planet. And, it must have seemed to them,\r\nthat we went right through their planet, too. That planet of theirs, by\r\nthe way, must be a tremendous one. Many times the mass and density of\r\nJupiter. It\'s probably what causes the space-warp."\r\n\r\n"What!" exclaimed Kendall. "You mean that thing\'s a permanent\r\ninstitution in space?"\r\n\r\n"Certainly.

"\r\n\r\n"Then let\'s go back and have a good look."\r\n\r\n"Check," agreed Broster.\r\n\r\n"We\'ll give their fleet and their planet the jitters again," laughed\r\nSeaward as he prepared the plates for special photos.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nThis section of New Sante Fe was off my beaten track. I\'ve been on Mars\r\na long time and am more than usually familiar with the various centers\r\nwhere we Terrans do our congregating. However, it\'d been years since\r\nI\'d come through here.\r\n\r\nI was sitting in an obscure tavern, called, with commendable restraint,\r\nsimply Sam\'s Bar, lapping up Martian brandy and facing the prospect of\r\nreturning to the spaceport in a few hours with no particular enthusiasm.\r\n\r\nI only half-noticed the old man who got up on the stool next to me. Sam\r\ncame over and asked him what he\'d have.\r\n\r\nThe oldster carefully counted out some coins on the bar and said,\r\n"Wine, Sam; a glass of Martian wine."\r\n\r\n"You know I don\'t want your money, Joseph," Sam told him.\r\n\r\nThe old man answered reproachfully, "The wine would taste that much the\r\nless, my friend, if I had not earned it by the sweat of my...."\r\n\r\n"Okay," Sam sighed. He poured the wine and rang up the money and went\r\noff to wait on someone else.\r\n\r\nA halftripper sidled up to me. "How about a drink, spaceman?" 

he\r\nwhined. "I\'m a graduate of the academy myself, class of \'72." He must\r\nhave noted my United Space Lines uniform.\r\n\r\n"Sorry," I said gruffly, keeping my back to him. Any spaceman can tell\r\nyou that if you talk to a halftripper for long you\'ll soon be showing\r\nsymptoms of space cafard yourself. The underlying terror in him; the\r\nmind shattering fear of space; the way he stares at you, thinking that\r\nyou can go home, while he is afraid to risk the trip. There are few of\r\nthem that can hide their disease.\r\n\r\n"I need a shot bad," he whispered urgently. He probably did, too. Few\r\nhalftrippers are able to secure jobs on the planets of their exile.\r\nMost of them become beachcombers of space. Of course, there are some\r\nexceptions, especially if they have money and connections.\r\n\r\nI shuddered. "Beat it," I grated, hating myself and him.\r\n\r\nThe fear of space cafard must be somewhat similar to that of\r\nseasickness every new sailor had back in ancient days when man sailed\r\nthe oceans of Terra. He never knew until he made his first voyage if he\r\nwas going to be susceptible; and, if he turned out to be, it meant the\r\nsea wasn\'t for him.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nOf course, space cafard goes tragically further. A new man usually\r\nsuccumbs his first few hours in space, if he is going to get it at\r\nall. He probably makes it to the next planet, sometimes not; sometimes\r\nhe goes incurably mad, right off the bat. But even if he does make\r\nit, wild horses could never get him on another rocketship. He becomes\r\na halftripper, marooned on an alien world. Usually, although I have\r\nknown of several exceptions, if you don\'t get it on your first trip, it\r\nseldom bothers you; you\'re immune for the rest of your life.\r\n\r\nHe repeated, "How about it, spaceman?"\r\n\r\nSam began to approach threateningly. 

He couldn\'t afford to have\r\nhalftrippers hang out in his place. For one thing, the shipping lines\r\nwould soon declare him out of bounds for their crews. You just can\'t\r\nlet good men come in contact with obvious victims of space cafard.\r\n\r\nThe old-timer Sam had called Joseph was distressed. "You know not what\r\nyou say," he told me gently.\r\n\r\nI managed a sneer. "Am I supposed to buy a drink for every spacebum\r\nthat comes along?"\r\n\r\nThe halftripper\'s eyes lit up and he came closer to the old man. "How\r\nabout it, pop? Could you loan me the price of a nip of woji?"\r\n\r\nJoseph\'s face was compassionate. "I am sorry, brother, I myself have\r\nnothing, but I commend you to the generosity of the tavern keeper."\r\n\r\nI snorted at that. I could imagine how much generosity the space leper\r\nwould get from the bartender.\r\n\r\nThat\'s where the surprise came. Sam sighed. "Okay, halftripper, what\'ll\r\nit be?"\r\n\r\nThe spacebum ordered a double woji, got it down quickly, as though he\r\nwas afraid Sam might change his mind, and then beat it to find a place\r\nto have his dreams when the full force of the also-narcotic drink hit\r\nhim.\r\n\r\nI finished my brandy, ordered another, and grinned wryly at the\r\nold-timer. "You give me kert for telling him to beat it, but you give\r\nSam the high sign to let him have woji with which to rot out his\r\nbrains. 

I\'d think I was being the kinder of the two of us."\r\n\r\n"Each man\'s salvation is within himself," Joseph said softly. "You\r\nwon\'t redeem him by attempting to keep him from his weaknesses."\r\n\r\n"You talk like a saint but I notice you\'re sitting here at a bar."\r\n\r\nHe looked at me penetratingly, and there was vast emptiness behind\r\nhis eyes. "There is little to enjoy in life," he said softly, "but\r\nI have had ample time to investigate all of the supposed pleasures.\r\nAt one time I drank greatly and kept myself in a state of continual\r\nintoxication for a period longer than you could believe. Then I went\r\nthrough a state when I let nothing pass my lips but water. Now I see\r\nthe mistake of both extremes and can enjoy an occasional glass without\r\nfeeling the need of swilling it down until intoxication dulls me."\r\n\r\nHe had me interested now. I said, "You sound as though you\'ve found the\r\nway in which to get the greatest satisfaction from everything in life\r\nbut I notice that you don\'t appear particularly happy."\r\n\r\nHe was silent for a long time. Finally he sighed and answered,\r\n"Happiness is not to be found in wine, nor in food, nor in beautiful\r\nwomen, nor even in wealth and power. It is from within, what you have\r\ndone, what you are in the eyes of your fellow man."\r\n\r\nHe looked as though he was about to say more, but he fell silent, his\r\neyes on something far away, although he seemed to be looking directly\r\ninto my face. Then a light returned to them and he came back to our\r\nconversation. "I am sorry," he said. "For a moment you reminded me of\r\nsomeone I knew long and long ago. But now I must be on my way." He left\r\nhis drink half-finished on the bar and walked wearily to the door.\r\n\r\nSam took his glass away and wiped the bar reflectively. "Whenever\r\nhe\'s here, I can\'t turn down any halftrippers or other spacebums," he\r\ncomplained. "I tried it once, and the old boy looked so pathetic that I\r\ndamn near cried myself."\r\n\r\n"He seems to be quite a character," I said, only half-interested.\r\n\r\n"Sure," Sam said. "Haven\'t you heard about Joseph? He\'s immortal."\r\n\r\n"What?" I said, startled.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Immortal. You know, he lives forever." He poured me another brandy and\r\nleaned on the bar. His other customers had left and he was obviously in\r\nthe mood for talking.\r\n\r\n"I thought everybody knew about Joseph," he went on. "He was one of the\r\nfirst spacebarons, a real bigshot, controlled the whole of Calypso; him\r\nand his brother. They not only personally owned all of the satellite,\r\nbut even all of the space lines that served it. When it came to law\r\nthere, he was judge, jury, and owner of the courthouse and jail.\r\nBrother, that was one monopoly."\r\n\r\n"You mean that old man that was just here?" 

I said in amazement.\r\n\r\n"That\'s right. Joseph, we call him now. He probably had a longer name\r\nthen. It was a long time ago.\r\n\r\n"Anyway, to get back to the story, one day a space liner radios in\r\nthat it wants to make an emergency landing on Calypso for medical\r\nassistance. They had some virulent disease on board and the passengers\r\nand crew were dying like flies.\r\n\r\n"Well, this brother of Joseph, Micheal, or something like that his name\r\nwas, advises Joseph not to give them permission to land. The captain of\r\nthe liner pleads with him, but Joseph tells him to move on, he doesn\'t\r\nwant to take any chances. The ship tried to make the next port, I\r\nforget just what it was, but, anyway, to cut it short, they all died.\r\nThat\'s what started things churning in Joseph\'s bailiwick; a full-scale\r\nrevolution, no less."\r\n\r\n"You missed something there," I said. 

"The people wouldn\'t have been\r\nexpected to be so upset. After all, no matter how mistaken, he must\r\nhave thought he was acting in the interests of everyone on Calypso."\r\n\r\n"Yeah," Sam pointed out, "but the thing is that among the passengers\r\nwas Joseph\'s own boy, the most popular person on the satellite and\r\nthe apple of his old man\'s eye. Nobody had known it, but the kid was\r\nplaying hookey from his school on Terra and was making a cruise of the\r\nJupiter moons.\r\n\r\n"Joseph himself had never been very popular with his people, neither\r\nhad this younger brother of his, Micheal. Too strict, see. 

But\r\neverybody liked the boy and were looking forward to the day when he\'d\r\ntake over the reins of government. When it came out what happened,\r\nthey went berserk. They cornered Joseph and Micheal and a dozen or so\r\nof their close associates in the palace, which was actually more of a\r\nfortress than anything else."\r\n\r\nSam wiped the bar again without need, and said reflectively, "It\r\nmust\'ve been quite a fight. Not that Joseph himself participated. The\r\nboy had been his whole life, and he just moved around like he was in a\r\ntrance.\r\n\r\n"They threw everything at that palace. Every weapon, every device, that\r\nhad been thought up for centuries; but it didn\'t crack. Finally, the\r\nfight was ended by a fleet of battle cruisers from Terra. Joseph and\r\nMicheal and the rest were removed and brought here to Mars. None of\r\nthem dared to remain on Calypso."\r\n\r\nI poured myself another brandy from the bottle that Sam had left on the\r\nbar. "You make quite a story of it," I told him, "but you didn\'t tell\r\nme what you\'d started to--about the immortality."\r\n\r\n"Yeah," he said, "that\'s right. Well, it seems that in the atomic\r\nbombardment of the palace something happened that wound up with Joseph\r\nand his friends all immortal. Don\'t ask me what; I don\'t know and\r\nneither did these scientist guys when they tried to figure it out. Of\r\ncourse, it didn\'t become known for years; not until it became obvious\r\nthey weren\'t dying, or even aging. They continued to appear as they had\r\nat the time of the fight. I don\'t mean they couldn\'t die at all; one by\r\none they dropped away. Two were lost in space; one was blown up in an\r\nexplosion on Terra; another was burned to death; but the only way they\r\ncould die was through accident--or suicide.
