After a few hundred years\r\nthey were all gone but Joseph, and, of course, he\'d gone batty."\r\n\r\nI interrupted. 

"You mean he\'s insane?"\r\n\r\nThe bartender grinned. "Crazy as a makron."\r\n\r\nI said slowly, "He seemed normal enough to me. Uh ... perhaps a bit\r\neccentric."\r\n\r\nSam said, "Brother, he\'s as far around the corner as you can get. You\r\nknow what he thinks? He thinks that he\'s wandering through space, going\r\nfrom planet to planet, trying to find a situation similar to that in\r\nwhich he sent away the person he loved most to his death. He thinks\r\nthat if he ever finds that similar situation, he\'ll be able to make the\r\nopposite decision from the one he made before and that will redeem him."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI frowned. "Where does he get the money for his wandering around the\r\nplanets?"\r\n\r\n"He don\'t need no money. He\'s good luck. There\'s not a captain in the\r\nsystem that would refuse free passage to old Joseph." Sam shrugged his\r\nbeefy shoulders. 

"And who am I to say otherwise? That\'s why I give the\r\nbums free drinks when he\'s around; so does every other bartender."\r\n\r\nTwo customers had entered and Sam made his way down to them, leaving me\r\nalone.\r\n\r\nA halftripper scurried through the door and cringed up to me. He\r\nwhimpered, "How about a drink, spaceman? I...."\r\n\r\nI flipped him a coin. "Sure, buddy," I said, repressing my usual nausea\r\nat the sight of him. 

I got down from my stool and made my way out. It\r\nwas time for me to return to the spaceport and my job.\r\n\r\nI suppose that I forgot to tell the cabbie to take me to the\r\nadministration building entrance--the first time I\'d made that mistake\r\nin years. I was preoccupied with thoughts of Joseph and the story Sam\r\nhad told of him. The guards at the main gate must have let us through\r\nwithout question when they saw my United Space Lines uniform. At any\r\nrate, when I looked up, it was too late. Not only was I on the landing\r\nfield and in full view of the concrete take-off aprons, but one\r\ngigantic freighter was in the process of blasting off.\r\n\r\nAll the horror of it flowed over me with a rush. The careful training\r\nof years; the work of the doctors who had treated me; all my own\r\nself-discipline--were gone. I shook with terrified frenzy. The depths\r\nof space! The free fall! 

The black emptiness! The utter, uncontrollable\r\nterror!\r\n\r\nI screamed shrilly and the cabbie turned, wide-eyed, to stare at me.\r\n\r\nHe knew the symptoms. "Space cafard! A halftripper!" he gasped, and\r\nspun the cab about to get me to a hospital. He must have realized then\r\nthat my uniform didn\'t necessarily mean that I worked on the liners\r\nthemselves, but that I could be an office employee who only on rare\r\noccasions went near the ships.\r\n\r\nHe knew too, that the very sight of a spacecraft blasting off was\r\nenough to put me in bed for a week; and that I was uncommonly lucky to\r\nhave the funds for the hospitalization. Mars was strewn with the human\r\nwrecks of halftrippers who hadn\'t.\r\n\r\nAs we whirled from the yard, we passed the bent figure of Joseph\r\nwalking unhurriedly toward a liner which was loading for the Venus run.\r\n\r\nMy heart cried out, even through my terror, my sickness:\r\n\r\n_Joseph, Joseph.... So you too are still alive; and still seeking\r\nforgiveness. I had thought I was the last._\r\n\r\n_But you are by far the better off of we two, Joseph. For at least you\r\nhave been free to wander while I have stayed on this one hated spot\r\nsince all those centuries ago when we fled from Calypso and the wrath\r\nof the people who had loved the boy so. As though we hadn\'t loved him\r\nourselves, Joseph._\r\n\r\n_Yes, you are the better off, you can seek throughout the stars for\r\nforgiveness. Then, too, your mind is forever dulled with your madness,\r\nwhile mine is horribly aware, always, of what we\'ve been through and of\r\nthe centuries ahead; it is only blurred when the space cafard comes._\r\n\r\n_Joseph, Joseph ... you didn\'t even recognize your brother Micheal, nor\r\nI you, when we met._\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\n[Sidenote: The biggest job in history and it had to be done with\r\ncomplete secrecy. It was--which was just the trouble!]\r\n\r\n\r\nI guess I\'m just a stickler, a perfectionist, but if you do a thing, I\r\nalways say, you might as well do it right. Everything satisfied me about\r\nthe security measures on our assignment except one--the official Army\r\ndesignation.\r\n\r\nProject Hush.\r\n\r\nI don\'t know who thought it up, and I certainly would never ask, but\r\nwhoever it was, he should have known better. Damn it, when you want a\r\nproject kept secret, you _don\'t_ give it a designation like that! You\r\ngive it something neutral, some name like the Manhattan and Overlord\r\nthey used in World War II, which won\'t excite anybody\'s curiosity.\r\n\r\nBut we were stuck with Project Hush and we had to take extra measures to\r\nensure secrecy. A couple of times a week, everyone on the project had to\r\nreport to Psycho for DD & HA--dream detailing and hypnoanalysis--instead\r\nof the usual monthly visit. Naturally, the commanding general of the\r\nheavily fortified research post to which we were attached could not ask\r\nwhat we were doing, under penalty of court-martial, but he had to be\r\ngiven further instructions to shut off his imagination like a faucet\r\nevery time he heard an explosion. Some idiot in Washington was actually\r\ngoing to list Project Hush in the military budget by name! It took fast\r\naction, I can tell you, to have it entered under Miscellaneous "X"\r\nResearch.\r\n\r\nWell, we\'d covered the unforgivable blunder, though not easily, and now\r\nwe could get down to the real business of the project. You know, of\r\ncourse, about the A-bomb, H-bomb and C-bomb because information that\r\nthey existed had been declassified. You don\'t know about the other\r\nweapons being devised--and neither did we, reasonably enough, since they\r\nweren\'t our business--but we had been given properly guarded\r\nnotification that they were in the works. Project Hush was set up to\r\ncounter the new weapons.\r\n\r\nOur goal was not just to reach the Moon. We had done that on 24 June\r\n1967 with an unmanned ship that carried instruments to report back data\r\non soil, temperature, cosmic rays and so on. Unfortunately, it was put\r\nout of commission by a rock slide.\r\n\r\nAn unmanned rocket would be useless against the new weapons. We had to\r\nget to the Moon before any other country did and set up a permanent\r\nstation--an armed one--and do it without anybody else knowing about it.\r\n\r\nI guess you see now why we on (_damn_ the name!) Project Hush were so\r\nconcerned about security. But we felt pretty sure, before we took off,\r\nthat we had plugged every possible leak.\r\n\r\nWe had, all right. Nobody even knew we had raised ship.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWe landed at the northern tip of Mare Nubium, just off Regiomontanus,\r\nand, after planting a flag with appropriate throat-catching ceremony,\r\nhad swung into the realities of the tasks we had practiced on so many\r\ndry runs back on Earth. Major Monroe Gridley prepared the big rocket,\r\nwith its tiny cubicle of living space, for the return journey to Earth\r\nwhich he alone would make.\r\n\r\nLieutenant-colonel Thomas Hawthorne painstakingly examined our\r\nprovisions and portable quarters for any damage that might have been\r\nincurred in landing.\r\n\r\nAnd I, Colonel Benjamin Rice, first commanding officer of Army Base No.\r\n1 on the Moon, dragged crate after enormous crate out of the ship on my\r\naching academic back, and piled them in the spot two hundred feet away\r\nwhere the plastic dome would be built.\r\n\r\nWe all finished at just about the same time, as per schedule, and went\r\ninto Phase Two.\r\n\r\nMonroe and I started work on building the dome. It was a simple pre-fab\r\naffair, but big enough to require an awful lot of assembling. Then,\r\nafter it was built, we faced the real problem--getting all the complex\r\ninternal machinery in place and in operating order.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile, Tom Hawthorne took his plump self off in the single-seater\r\nrocket which, up to then, had doubled as a lifeboat.\r\n\r\nThe schedule called for him to make a rough three-hour scouting survey\r\nin an ever-widening spiral from our dome. This had been regarded as a\r\nprobable waste of time, rocket fuel and manpower--but a necessary\r\nprecaution. He was supposed to watch for such things as bug-eyed\r\nmonsters out for a stroll on the Lunar landscape. Basically, however,\r\nTom\'s survey was intended to supply extra geological and astronomical\r\nmeat for the report which Monroe was to carry back to Army HQ on Earth.\r\n\r\nTom was back in forty minutes. His round face, inside its transparent\r\nbubble helmet, was fish-belly white. And so were ours, once he told us\r\nwhat he\'d seen.\r\n\r\nHe had seen another dome.\r\n\r\n"The other side of Mare Nubium--in the Riphaen Mountains," he babbled\r\nexcitedly. "It\'s a little bigger than ours, and it\'s a little flatter on\r\ntop. And it\'s not translucent, either, with splotches of different\r\ncolors here and there--it\'s a dull, dark, heavy gray. But that\'s all\r\nthere is to see."\r\n\r\n"No markings on the dome?" I asked worriedly. "No signs of anyone--or\r\nanything--around it?"\r\n\r\n"Neither, Colonel." I noticed he was calling me by my rank for the first\r\ntime since the trip started, which meant he was saying in effect, "Man,\r\nhave you got a decision to make!"\r\n\r\n"Hey, Tom," Monroe put in. "Couldn\'t be just a regularly shaped bump in\r\nthe ground, could it?"\r\n\r\n"I\'m a geologist, Monroe. I can distinguish artificial from natural\r\ntopography. Besides--" he looked up--"I just remembered something I left\r\nout. There\'s a brand-new tiny crater near the dome--the kind usually\r\nleft by a rocket exhaust."\r\n\r\n"Rocket exhaust?" I seized on that. "_Rockets_, eh?"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nTom grinned a little sympathetically. "Spaceship exhaust, I should have\r\nsaid. You can\'t tell from the crater what kind of propulsive device\r\nthese characters are using. It\'s not the same kind of crater our\r\nrear-jets leave, if that helps any.

"\r\n\r\nOf course it didn\'t. So we went into our ship and had a council of war.\r\nAnd I do mean war. Both Tom and Monroe were calling me Colonel in every\r\nother sentence. I used their first names every chance I got.\r\n\r\nStill, no one but me could reach a decision. 

About what to do, I mean.\r\n\r\n"Look," I said at last, "here are the possibilities. They know we are\r\nhere--either from watching us land a couple of hours ago or from\r\nobserving Tom\'s scout-ship--or they do not know we are here. They are\r\neither humans from Earth--in which case they are in all probability\r\nenemy nationals--or they are alien creatures from another planet--in\r\nwhich case they may be friends, enemies or what-have-you. I think common\r\nsense and standard military procedure demand that we consider them\r\nhostile until we have evidence to the contrary. Meanwhile, we proceed\r\nwith extreme caution, so as not to precipitate an interplanetary war\r\nwith potentially friendly Martians, or whatever they are.\r\n\r\n"All right. It\'s vitally important that Army Headquarters be informed of\r\nthis immediately. But since Moon-to-Earth radio is still on the drawing\r\nboards, the only way we can get through is to send Monroe back with the\r\nship. If we do, we run the risk of having our garrison force, Tom and\r\nme, captured while he\'s making the return trip. In that case, their side\r\nwinds up in possession of important information concerning our personnel\r\nand equipment, while our side has only the bare knowledge that somebody\r\nor something else has a base on the Moon. So our primary need is more\r\ninformation.\r\n\r\n"Therefore, I suggest that I sit in the dome on one end of a telephone\r\nhookup with Tom, who will sit in the ship, his hand over the firing\r\nbutton, ready to blast off for Earth the moment he gets the order from\r\nme. Monroe will take the single-seater down to the Riphaen Mountains,\r\nlanding as close to the other dome as he thinks safe. He will then\r\nproceed the rest of the way on foot, doing the best scouting job he can\r\nin a spacesuit.\r\n\r\n"He will not use his radio, except for agreed-upon nonsense syllables to\r\ndesignate landing the single-seater, coming upon the dome by foot, and\r\nwarning me to tell Tom to take off. If he\'s captured, remembering that\r\nthe first purpose of a scout is acquiring and transmitting knowledge of\r\nthe enemy, he will snap his suit radio on full volume and pass on as\r\nmuch data as time and the enemy\'s reflexes permit. How does that sound\r\nto you?

"\r\n\r\nThey both nodded. As far as they were concerned, the command decision\r\nhad been made. But I was sitting under two inches of sweat.\r\n\r\n"One question," Tom said. "Why did you pick Monroe for the scout?"\r\n\r\n"I was afraid you\'d ask that," I told him. "We\'re three extremely\r\nunathletic Ph.D.s who have been in the Army since we finished our\r\nschooling. There isn\'t too much choice. But I remembered that Monroe is\r\nhalf Indian--Arapahoe, isn\'t it, Monroe?--and I\'m hoping blood will\r\ntell."\r\n\r\n"Only trouble, Colonel," Monroe said slowly as he rose, "is that I\'m\r\none-_fourth_ Indian and even that.... Didn\'t I ever tell you that my\r\ngreat-grandfather was the only Arapahoe scout who was with Custer at the\r\nLittle Big Horn? He\'d been positive Sitting Bull was miles away.\r\nHowever, I\'ll do my best. And if I heroically don\'t come back, would you\r\nplease persuade the Security Officer of our section to clear my name for\r\nuse in the history books? Under the circumstances, I think it\'s the\r\nleast he could do."\r\n\r\nI promised to do my best, of course.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAfter he took off, I sat in the dome over the telephone connection to\r\nTom and hated myself for picking Monroe to do the job. But I\'d have\r\nhated myself just as much for picking Tom. And if anything happened and\r\nI had to tell Tom to blast off, I\'d probably be sitting here in the dome\r\nall by myself after that, waiting....\r\n\r\n"_Broz neggle!_" came over the radio in Monroe\'s resonant voice. He had\r\nlanded the single-seater.\r\n\r\nI didn\'t dare use the telephone to chat with Tom in the ship, for fear I\r\nmight miss an important word or phrase from our scout. So I sat and sat\r\nand strained my ears. After a while, I heard "_Mishgashu!_" which told\r\nme that Monroe was in the neighborhood of the other dome and was\r\ncreeping toward it under cover of whatever boulders were around.\r\n\r\n[Illustration]\r\n\r\nAnd then, abruptly, I heard Monroe yell my name and there was a terrific\r\nclattering in my headphones. Radio interference! He\'d been caught, and\r\nwhoever had caught him had simultaneously jammed his suit transmitter\r\nwith a larger transmitter from the alien dome.\r\n\r\nThen there was silence.\r\n\r\nAfter a while, I told Tom what had happened. He just said, "Poor\r\nMonroe." I had a good idea of what his expression was like.\r\n\r\n"Look, Tom," I said, "if you take off now, you still won\'t have anything\r\nimportant to tell. After capturing Monroe, whatever\'s in that other dome\r\nwill come looking for us, I think. I\'ll let them get close enough for us\r\nto learn something of their appearance--at least if they\'re human or\r\nnon-human. Any bit of information about them is important. I\'ll shout it\r\nup to you and you\'ll still be able to take off in plenty of time. 

All\r\nright?"\r\n\r\n"You\'re the boss, Colonel," he said in a mournful voice. "Lots of luck.

"\r\n\r\nAnd then there was nothing to do but wait. There was no oxygen system in\r\nthe dome yet, so I had to squeeze up a sandwich from the food\r\ncompartment in my suit. I sat there, thinking about the expedition. Nine\r\nyears, and all that careful secrecy, all that expenditure of money and\r\nmind-cracking research--and it had come to this. Waiting to be wiped\r\nout, in a blast from some unimaginable weapon. I understood Monroe\'s\r\nlast request. We often felt we were so secret that our immediate\r\nsuperiors didn\'t even want us to know what we we were working on.\r\nScientists are people--they wish for recognition, too. I was hoping the\r\nwhole expedition would be written up in the history books, but it looked\r\nunpromising.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nTwo hours later, the scout ship landed near the dome. The lock opened\r\nand, from where I stood in the open door of our dome, I saw Monroe come\r\nout and walk toward me.\r\n\r\nI alerted Tom and told him to listen carefully. "It may be a trick--he\r\nmight be drugged...."\r\n\r\nHe didn\'t act drugged, though--not exactly. He pushed his way past me\r\nand sat down on a box to one side of the dome. He put his booted feet up\r\non another, smaller box.\r\n\r\n"How are you, Ben?" he asked. 

"How\'s every little thing?"\r\n\r\nI grunted. "_Well?_" I know my voice skittered a bit.\r\n\r\nHe pretended puzzlement. "Well _what_? 

Oh, I see what you mean. The\r\nother dome--you want to know who\'s in it. You have a right to be\r\ncurious, Ben. Certainly. The leader of a top-secret expedition like\r\nthis--Project Hush they call us, huh, Ben--finds another dome on the\r\nMoon. He thinks he\'s been the first to land on it, so naturally he wants\r\nto--"\r\n\r\n"Major Monroe Gridley!" I rapped out. 

"You will come to attention and\r\ndeliver your report. 

Now!" Honestly, I felt my neck swelling up inside\r\nmy helmet.\r\n\r\nMonroe just leaned back against the side of the dome. "That\'s the _Army_\r\nway of doing things," he commented admiringly. "Like the recruits say,\r\nthere\'s a right way, a wrong way and an Army way. Only there are other\r\nways, too." He chuckled. "Lots of other ways."\r\n\r\n"He\'s off," I heard Tom whisper over the telephone. "Ben, Monroe has\r\ngone and blown his stack."\r\n\r\n"They aren\'t extraterrestrials in the other dome, Ben," Monroe\r\nvolunteered in a sudden burst of sanity. "No, they\'re human, all right,\r\nand from Earth. 

Guess _where_."\r\n\r\n"I\'ll kill you," I warned him. "I swear I\'ll kill you, Monroe. Where are\r\nthey from--Russia, China, Argentina?"\r\n\r\nHe grimaced. "What\'s so secret about those places? Go on!--guess again."\r\n\r\nI stared at him long and hard. "The only place else--"\r\n\r\n"Sure," he said. 

"You got it, Colonel. The other dome is owned and\r\noperated by the Navy. The goddam United States Navy!"\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


Gregory, across\r\nthe room, flicked rapidly through the pages of a magazine, too rapidly\r\nto be reading anything, or even looking at the pictures. Ross lay\r\nquietly on his bunk, staring out of the viewport.\r\n\r\nThe four were strangely alike in appearance, nearly the same age, the\r\nage where gray hairs finally outnumber black, or baldness takes over.\r\nThe age when the expanding waistline has begun to sag tiredly, when\r\nrobust middle age begins the slow accelerating decline toward senility.\r\n\r\nA strange group to find aboard a spaceship, but then _The Columbus_ was\r\na very strange ship. Bolted to its outer hull, just under the viewports,\r\nwere wooden boxes full of red geraniums, and ivy wound tenuous green\r\nfronds over the gleaming hull that had withstood the bombardment of\r\npinpoint meteors and turned away the deadly power of naked cosmic rays.\r\n\r\nFrankston glanced at his wristchrono. It was one minute to six.\r\n\r\n"In about a minute," he thought, "Ross will say something about going\r\nout to water his geraniums." The wristchrono ticked fifty-nine times.\r\n\r\n"I think I\'ll go out and water my geraniums," said Ross.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nNo one glanced up. Then Gregory threw his magazine on the floor. Ross\r\ngot up and walked, limping slightly, to a wall locker. He pulled out the\r\nheavy, ungainly spacesuit and the big metal bulb of a headpiece. He\r\ncarried them to his bunk and laid them carefully down.\r\n\r\n"Will somebody please help me on with my suit?" he asked.\r\n\r\nFor one more long moment, no one moved. Then James got up and began to\r\nhelp Ross fit his legs into the suit. Ross had arthritis, not badly, but\r\nenough so that he needed a little help climbing into a spacesuit.\r\n\r\nJames pulled the heavy folds of the suit up around Ross\'s body and held\r\nit while Ross extended his arms into the sleeve sections. His hands, in\r\nthe heavy gauntlets, were too unwieldy to do the front fastenings, and\r\nhe stood silently while James did it for him.\r\n\r\nRoss lifted the helmet, staring at it as a cripple might regard a\r\nwheelchair which he loathed but was wholly dependent upon. Then he\r\nfitted the helmet over his head and James fastened it down and lifted\r\nthe oxygen tank to his back.\r\n\r\n"Ready?" asked James.\r\n\r\nThe bulbous headpiece inclined in a nod. James walked to a panel and\r\nthrew a switch marked INNER LOCK. A round aperture slid silently open.\r\nRoss stepped through it and the door shut behind him as James threw the\r\nswitch back to its original position. Opposite the switch marked OUTER\r\nLOCK a signal glowed redly and James threw another switch. A moment\r\nlater the signal flickered out.\r\n\r\nFrankston, with a violent gesture, swept the checker board clean. Red\r\nand black men clattered to the floor, rolling and spinning. Nobody\r\npicked them up.\r\n\r\n"What does he do it for?" 

demanded Frankston in a tight voice. "What\r\ndoes he get out of those stinking geraniums he can\'t touch or smell?"\r\n\r\n"Shut up," said Gregory.\r\n\r\nJames looked up sharply. Curtness was unusual for Gregory, a bad sign.\r\nFrankston was the one he\'d been watching, the one who\'d shown signs of\r\ncracking, but after so long, even a psycho-expert\'s opinion might be\r\nhaywire. Who was a yardstick? Who was normal?\r\n\r\n"Geraniums don\'t smell much anyway," added Gregory in a more\r\nconciliatory tone.\r\n\r\n"Yeah," agreed Frankston, "I\'d forgotten that. But why does he torture\r\nhimself like this, and us, too?"\r\n\r\n"Because that\'s what he wanted to do," answered James.\r\n\r\n"Sure," agreed Gregory, "the whole trip--the last twenty years of it,\r\nanyhow--all he could talk about was how, when he got back to Earth, he\r\nwas going to buy a little place in the country and raise flowers."\r\n\r\n"Well, we\'re back," muttered Frankston, with a terrible bitterness.\r\n"He\'s raising flowers, but not in any little place in the country."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nGregory continued almost dreamily, "Remember the last night out? We were\r\nall gathered around the viewscreen. And there was Earth, getting bigger\r\nand greener and closer all the time. Remember what it felt like to be\r\ngoing back, after thirty years?"\r\n\r\n"Thirty years cooped up in this ship," grumbled Frankston. "All our\r\ntwenties and thirties and forties ..."\r\n\r\n"But we were coming home." There was a rapt expression on Gregory\'s\r\nlined and weathered face. "We were looking forward to the twenty or\r\nmaybe thirty good years we had left, talking about what we\'d do, where\r\nwe\'d live, wondering what had changed on Earth. At least we had that\r\nlast night out. All the data was stashed away in the microfiles, all the\r\ndata about planets with air we couldn\'t breathe and food we couldn\'t\r\neat. 

We were going home, home to big, friendly, green Earth."\r\n\r\nFrankston\'s face suddenly crumpled as though he were about to weep and\r\nhe cradled his head against his arms. "God, do we have to go over it all\r\nagain? 

Not again tonight!"\r\n\r\n"Leave him alone," ordered James with an inflection of command in his\r\nvoice. "Go to the other section of the ship if you don\'t want to listen.\r\nHe has to keep going over it, just like Ross has to keep watering his\r\ngeraniums."\r\n\r\nFrankston remained motionless and Gregory looked gratefully at James.\r\nJames was the steady one. It was easier for him because he understood.\r\n\r\nGregory\'s face became more and more animated as he lost himself, living\r\nagain his recollections: "The day we blasted in. The crowds. 

Thousands\r\nof people, all there to see us come in. We were proud. Of course, we\r\nthought we were the first to land, just like we\'d been the first to go\r\nout. Those cheers, coming from thousands of people at once. For us.\r\nRoss-- Lt. Ross--was the first one out of the lock. We\'d decided on\r\nthat; he\'d been in command for almost ten years, ever since Commander\r\nStevens died. You remember Stevens, don\'t you? He took over when we lost\r\nCaptain Willers. Well, anyway, Ross out first, and then you, James, and\r\nyou, Frankston, and then Trippitt, and me last, because you were all\r\nspecialists and I was just a crewman. _The_ crewman, I should say, the\r\nonly one left.\r\n\r\n"Ross hesitated and almost stumbled when he stepped out, and tears began\r\npouring from his eyes, but I thought--well, you know, coming home after\r\nthirty years and all that. But when I stepped out of the lock, my eyes\r\nstung like fire and a thousand needles seemed to jab at my skin.\r\n\r\n"And then the President himself stepped forward with the flowers. That\'s\r\nwhere the real trouble began, with the flowers. I remember Ross\r\nstretching out his arms to take the bouquet, like a mother reaching for\r\na baby. Then suddenly he dropped them, sneezing and coughing and sobbing\r\nfor breath, and the President reached out to help him, asking him over\r\nand over what was wrong.\r\n\r\n"It was the same with all of us, and we turned and staggered back to the\r\nship, closing the lock behind us. It was bad then. 

God, I\'ll never\r\nforget it! The five of us, moaning in agony, gasping for breath, our\r\neyes all swollen shut, and the itching ... that itching." Gregory\r\nshuddered.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nEven the emotionally disciplined James set his teeth and felt his scalp\r\ncrawl at the memory of that horror. He glanced toward the viewport, as\r\nthough to cleanse his mind of the memory. He could see Ross out there,\r\namong the geraniums, moving slowly and painfully in his heavy spacesuit.\r\nOccupational therapy. Ross watered flowers and Gregory talked and\r\nFrankston was bitter and ... himself? Observation, maybe.\r\n\r\nGregory\'s voice began again, "And then they were pounding on the lock,\r\nbegging us to let the doctor in, but we were all rolling and thrashing\r\nwith the itching, burning, sneezing, and finally James got himself under\r\ncontrol enough to open the locks and let them in.\r\n\r\n"Then came the tests, allergy tests. Remember those? They\'d cut a little\r\nrow of scratches in your arm ..." Each man instinctively glanced at his\r\nforearm, saw neat rows of tiny pink scars, row on row. "Then they\'d put\r\na little powder in each cut and each kind of powder was an extract of\r\nsome common substance we might be allergic to. The charts they made were\r\nfull of \'P\'s, P for positive, long columns of big, red \'P\'s. All pollen,\r\ndust, wool, nylon, cotton, fish, meat, fruit, vegetables, grain, milk,\r\nwhisky, cigarettes, dogs, cats--everything! And wasn\'t it funny about us\r\nbeing allergic to women\'s face powder? Ha! We were allergic to women\r\nfrom their nylon hose to their face powder.\r\n\r\n"Thirty years of breathing purified, sterilized, filtered air, thirty\r\nyears of drinking distilled water and swallowing synthetic food tablets\r\nhad changed us. The only things we weren\'t allergic to were the metal\r\nand plastic and synthetics of our ship, _this_ ship. We\'re allergic to\r\nEarth. That\'s funny, isn\'t it?"\r\n\r\nGregory began to rock back and forth, laughing the thin high laugh of\r\nhysteria. James silently walked to a water hydrant and filled a plastic\r\ncup. He brought Gregory a small white pill.\r\n\r\n"You wouldn\'t take this with the rest of us at supper. You\'d better take\r\nit now. 

You need it."\r\n\r\nGregory nodded bleakly, sobering at once, and swallowed the pellet. He\r\nmade a face after the water.\r\n\r\n"Distilled," he spat. "Distilled ... no flavor ... no life ... like\r\nus ... distilled."\r\n\r\n"If only we could have blasted off again." Frankston\'s voice came\r\nmuffled through his hands. "It wouldn\'t have made any difference where.\r\nAnywhere or nowhere. No, our fine ship is obsolete and we\'re old, much\r\ntoo old. They have the spacedrive now. Men don\'t make thirty-year\r\njunkets into space and come back allergic to Earth. They go out, and in\r\na month or two they\'re back, with their hair still black and their eyes\r\nstill bright and their uniforms still fit. A month or two is all. Those\r\ncrowds that cheered us, they were proud of us and sorry for us, because\r\nwe\'d been out thirty years and they never expected us back at all. But\r\nit was inconvenient for Spaceport." Bitter sarcasm tinged his voice.\r\n"They actually had to postpone the regular monthly Trans-Galactic run\r\nto let us in with this big, clumsy hulk."\r\n\r\n"Why didn\'t we ever see any of the new ships either going out or coming\r\nback?" asked Gregory.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nFrankston shook his head. "You don\'t see a ship when it\'s in spacedrive.\r\nIt\'s out of normal space-time dimensions. We had a smattering of the\r\ntheory at cadet school ... anyway, if one did flash into normal\r\nspace-time--say, for instance, coming in for a landing--the probability\r\nof us being at the same place at the same time was almost nil. \'Two\r\nships passing in the night\' as the old saying goes."\r\n\r\nGregory nodded, "I guess Trippitt was the lucky one."\r\n\r\n"You didn\'t see Trippitt die," replied James.\r\n\r\n"What was it?" asked Frankston. "What killed Trippitt? So quickly, too.\r\nHe was only outside a few minutes like the rest of us, and eight hours\r\nlater he was dead."\r\n\r\n"We couldn\'t be sure," answered James. "Some virus. 

There are countless\r\nvarieties. People live in a contaminated atmosphere all their lives,\r\nbuild up a resistance to them. Sometimes a particularly virulent strain\r\nwill produce an epidemic, but most people, if they\'re affected, will\r\nhave a mild case of whatever it is and recover. But after thirty years\r\nin space, thirty years of breathing perfectly pure, uncontaminated air,\r\nTrippitt had no antibodies in his bloodstream. The virus hit and he\r\ndied."\r\n\r\n"But why didn\'t the rest of us get it?" asked Gregory.\r\n\r\n"We were lucky. Viruses are like that."\r\n\r\n"Those people talked about building a home for us," muttered Frankston.\r\n"Why didn\'t they?"\r\n\r\n"It wouldn\'t have been any different," answered James gently. "It would\r\nhave been the same, almost an exact duplicate of the ship, everything\r\nbut the rockets. Same metal and plastic and filtered air and synthetic\r\nfood. It couldn\'t have had wool rugs or down pillows or smiling wives or\r\nfresh air or eggs for breakfast. 

It would have been just like this. So,\r\nsince the ship was obsolete, they gave it to us, and a plot of ground to\r\nanchor it to, and we\'re home. They did the best they could for us, the\r\nvery best they could."\r\n\r\n"But I feel stifled, shut in!"\r\n\r\n"The ship is large, Frankston. We all crowd into this section because,\r\nwithout each other, we\'d go mad." James kicked the edge of the magazine\r\non the floor. "Thank God we\'re not allergic to decontaminated paper.\r\nThere\'s still reading."\r\n\r\n"We\'re getting old," said Gregory. 

"Some day one of us will be here\r\nalone."\r\n\r\n"God help him then," answered James, with more emotion than was usual\r\nfor him.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nDuring the latter part of the conversation, the little red signal had\r\nbeen flashing persistently. Finally James saw it. Ross was in the outer\r\nlock. James threw the decontaminator switch and the signal winked out.\r\nEvery trace of dust and pollen would have to be removed from Ross\'s suit\r\nbefore he could come inside the ship.\r\n\r\n"Just like on an alien planet," commented Gregory.\r\n\r\n"Isn\'t that what this is to us--an alien planet?" asked Frankston, and\r\nneither of the other men dared answer his bitter question.\r\n\r\nA few minutes later, Ross was back in the cabin, and James helped him\r\nout of his spacesuit.\r\n\r\n"How are the geraniums, Ross?" asked Gregory.\r\n\r\n"Fine," said Ross enthusiastically. "They\'re doing just fine."\r\n\r\nHe walked over to his bunk and lay down on his side so he could see out\r\nof the viewport. 

There would be an hour left before darkness fell, an\r\nhour to watch the geraniums. They were tall and red, and swayed slightly\r\nin the evening breeze.\r\n\r\n                                                         --LYN VENABLE\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Galaxy Science Fiction_ December 1952.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and\r\n    typographical errors have been corrected without note.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\n"_Oh, he is dead!" my mind cried out._\r\n\r\nNovna, my dear, I am writing this as a release for my conscience.\r\nThose things which trouble me are not such as one exchanges with vigil\r\ncompanions, or indeed with anyone not bound by ties like ours.\r\n\r\nIf I were at home with you I would exchange with your soul in a moment\r\nthe feeling of my own, but distance permits no such consolation and it\r\nis not suitable for me to exchange so familiarly with my colleagues.\r\n\r\nI find myself questioning the value of our customary refusal to\r\ncommunicate thoughts of a delicate and sensitive nature. The Earth\r\npeople, who speak their thoughts, perhaps are less primitive than\r\nwe like to imagine. They seem to have no sense of the danger of\r\noverwhelming the soul of another with unwanted confidences. The purely\r\nvocal nature of their communication does not admit an excessive degree\r\nof emotion to their relationships. They do not have to erect any\r\nartificial barriers between each other, as we must who exchange on a\r\nmental level.\r\n\r\nThese doubts of mine never could have arisen if we men of Hainos had\r\nnot presumed to observe the alien ways of those creatures on the third\r\nEarth, so like ourselves and yet so remote, though we have hovered\r\nabove them, listening and watching, for twelve of their generations.\r\n\r\nThis vigil, though it is to last but one journey around the sun, has\r\nseemed longer and less fruitful than all the others. I think I shall\r\nnot come again, but leave such work to those who can remain efficient\r\nand disinterested Observers, unmoved by doubt and anxiety. Novna, you\r\nmust begin to think what we two shall do with the rest of our eternity,\r\nfor now that I have spent some small portion of mine in fifty vigils, I\r\nfind they have become distasteful. We might go to the Palace of Art and\r\nstudy to be poet-priests. My last vigil has convinced me that I am more\r\nfitted for that life than this.\r\n\r\nWhen our mission left Hainos for the third Earth, there was aboard our\r\nship the poet-priest Gven. You must remember the many nights we sat\r\nbeneath the rocks by the ocean, listening as his soul gave ours his\r\nsongs. Innocent they were, and filled with talk of purity and light,\r\nthough Gven is as old as the rest of us, even if he is as different\r\nfrom you and me as the Earth child is from its parents.\r\n\r\nYou have never seen him, I think. He is smaller than I, slight of\r\nbuild and tender-faced. How out of place he looked among the ship\'s\r\nsturdy men of science, with their ages of discipline and austerity\r\nwritten indelibly into their features. They did not want him. They told\r\nthe commissioner that they did not want him.\r\n\r\n"Let him stay at home," they said, "and sing his songs to those who\r\nwish to listen."\r\n\r\nBut the commissioner himself, and, I suspect, the commissioner\'s wife,\r\nwas as fond as any of Gven and his songs, so he said Gven was to come\r\nif he liked.\r\n\r\nPoor Gven tried hard enough to make us like him. He offered us the only\r\ngift he had, that of his songs, but no one cared to hear them except\r\nme, and I was ashamed to say so. In the end he was reduced to sitting\r\nfor hours, looking out into the night through which the ship bore us,\r\nsaying nothing to anyone, for fear of our scorn. He would have liked\r\nus to tell him about the Earth people, for his studies at the Palace\r\nfitted him sadly for a scientific expedition.\r\n\r\nOf the Earth people, however, we hesitated to speak freely, even among\r\nourselves, for all of us feel strongly about them, in one way or\r\nanother. Our exchanges on the matter have always been burdened with\r\nemotion; and we find we cannot share easily our thoughts about Earth\r\npeople, unless we banter lightly and say little of what we really feel.\r\n\r\nWhen our long-ship drew near the third Earth, we were transferred into\r\nthe round-ship in which we were to carry on our observations. I could\r\nsee Gven was limp with excitement, but as always, I would not exchange\r\nwith him for fear of the others, not even to drain off that excess of\r\nfeeling which was to prove so dangerous to him.\r\n\r\nPerhaps he thought it would be different, once we had established\r\nourselves in our designated area of observation. Then we might warm\r\ntoward him, giving him the comforts of our experience. If such were his\r\nexpectations, he was disappointed. Whatever he gathered from us was\r\npurely accidental, information that we exchanged among ourselves as we\r\nworked. Only in this way did he learn of those few bonds we had forged\r\nwith the Earth people.\r\n\r\nIt is our custom, as you know, for each man to select one of the Earth\r\npeople as his subject. This is not part of our work, it is only a\r\ndevice to drive away the tedium that descends upon men far from home\r\nand bound to exacting work in a confined place. We begin to feel quite\r\npassionately concerned with our subjects, and occasionally find it\r\ndifficult to return to our primary concerns.\r\n\r\nFor some time I had been spending my free hours in the world of a\r\ngentle old merchant named Jacobs. I lived his life with him briefly,\r\nseeing his wife and children as he saw them, going with him to his\r\nstore. His memories were good ones, filled with hard work and simple\r\npleasures. One day, when I had left the computing tables to prepare\r\nfor dinner, I sought the mind of Jacobs. He was crossing the street and\r\nas he turned his head, he saw the shining lights of an automobile just\r\nbefore it struck him. I withdrew from his mind in a shower of pain and\r\ndarkness.\r\n\r\n"Oh, he is dead," my mind cried out to my vigil companions before\r\nI could smother the shock and emotion in it. They looked up at me,\r\nquestioning. Then I exchanged with them more coolly, "My man Jacobs has\r\nbeen killed crossing the street."\r\n\r\nKeven, the fuel technician, reached my mind first. "A pity, I lost a\r\nsubject myself that way not long ago. It is a bad death for them, poor\r\nthings. They might build overpasses, mightn\'t they? 

A pity."\r\n\r\nIt has never failed to unsettle me, the way my companions have come\r\nto accept the idea of death so easily. To me it is always a horror,\r\nunnatural and alien. You cannot quite see how it is, Novna, for you\r\nhave never been in the mind of one who dies.\r\n\r\nI withdrew for a little while to mourn my man Jacobs, for my sorrow was\r\nnot to be shared with the others. It was while I sat thinking of the\r\ndead Jacobs that Gven approached hesitantly and sat near me.\r\n\r\n"Is it possible," he asked, "that one can read the soul of an Earth\r\nman? Could I? 

Or perhaps that would not be permitted to me?"\r\n\r\nHis eagerness made me ashamed of the silence I had maintained between\r\nus. "It is certainly possible for you to try, though it cannot always\r\nbe done. You need ask no one for permission."\r\n\r\nThe delight in his eyes made me forget Jacobs a little. "I may try\r\nanyone at all?

"\r\n\r\n"I advise you to search about a little. Don\'t seize on the first one\r\nyou contact as a subject. 

You have less time than the rest of us for\r\nthis sort of thing."\r\n\r\nGven thanked me shyly and went away. Later I saw him sitting at the\r\nopen panels, looking down at the cloud-topped mountains and sandy\r\nvalleys over which we circled. His face was still and pale as he\r\nconcentrated.\r\n\r\nThe next day at dinner, Gven sat playing with his food, looking up\r\nat the rest of us frequently, as if his fear of our coldness were\r\ncontending with his wish to open his mind to us. I was not the only\r\none to notice his excitement, but the rest sat looking at their\r\nplates stonily. They liked Gven even less than they had at first, and\r\npreferred to ignore his presence altogether. At last I lifted my head\r\ndefiantly and my thought streamed across the table into the mind of\r\nGven with such energy and violence that the others raised their eyes\r\nfrom their food in quick surprise.\r\n\r\n"It must be that you have found a subject. I should like to hear about\r\nit.

"\r\n\r\nAt once Gven let his thoughts explode in undisciplined profusion. The\r\nmen drew back a little, shocked by the unfamiliar impact of another\'s\r\npassion on their minds.\r\n\r\n"The very first mind I sought was that of a girl who calls herself\r\nMaria Dolores. Often her mind turns in upon itself and she reflects\r\nlike this, \'Maria Dolores, you have behaved badly to your papa today.\r\nNow you must go and ask him to forgive you and give him a kiss.\' In\r\nthis way she scolds herself for small misdemeanors. Her world is\r\ncomposed of happy, innocent trivialities, though as her purity touches\r\non them and causes them to glow briefly before they are left behind, it\r\nseems that there are no more divine and lovely things in existence than\r\nthose in the world of my Maria Dolores."\r\n\r\nGven blushed and paused for a moment, then rushed on. "I sense that\r\nher father and mother have barricaded her from everyone else. They are\r\nstrict with Maria Dolores and sometimes she wishes she could go out to\r\ndances as the other girls do. But she is not sad for long, and goes\r\nto gather flowers for the dinner table. She sets them in long silver\r\ndishes, that reflect the pink and red glow of the sunset slanting\r\nthrough the window. This pleases Maria Dolores and she stands watching\r\nfor a long time."\r\n\r\nGven would have said more, but all at once Corven, the cultural\r\nresearcher, interrupted, looking at me. "Noven, what have you brought\r\nupon us by your curiosity? We are being buried in an avalanche of\r\npoetic fancies."\r\n\r\nAfter this, Gven sat silent, his face burning, and the rest of us began\r\nto talk of the relation between the sites of mines and the locations of\r\nproving grounds.\r\n\r\nFor many days, I watched Gven covertly. He no longer seemed to care\r\nabout our rebuffs, nor did he show any desire to ask us questions. He\r\nonly sat by the panels, his expression withdrawn and intent, while the\r\nrest of us hustled busily and a little self-consciously around him.\r\nI came to notice a certain perplexity in his face after a time, and\r\nfelt that I should ask if he needed any assistance. But I was awkward\r\nand unsure of myself, so I only watched him and said nothing. At last\r\nhe came to me, having built up a powerful reserve of feeling that\r\noverflowed with the more violence for having been repressed so long.\r\n\r\n"There is something that is to happen in the life of my Maria Dolores,"\r\nGven began directly.\r\n\r\nUnaccountably, I tensed and tried to suppress the warmth I felt toward\r\nhim. "Well, what is it then?" 

I answered.\r\n\r\nHe seemed not to notice the strain I was under. "They have told her she\r\nis to be married to a young man whom they have chosen for her. She is\r\nunhappy, but cannot tell them. Now they are making many preparations.\r\nMaria Dolores spends her time with her mother, sewing dresses and\r\npacking them away. Then her mother speaks to her of things that\r\nfrighten her and me, things that seem to happen when men and women are\r\nalone at night. She does not understand and lies awake when her mother\r\nhas gone, afraid and wondering. 

We are uneasy, Maria Dolores and I."\r\n\r\nHere, Novna, I must attempt to explain the marriage of Earth people.\r\nWhile with us marriage is the spiritualized union of masculine and\r\nfeminine natures in one soul, it is to them a more concrete thing.\r\nTheir junction is not only one of minds, but one of bodies as well.\r\n\r\nThe union seems not to be unpleasant for those who take part in it, but\r\nfor us, who so jealously guard our bodies from another\'s touch, the\r\nmarriage of Earth people is difficult to contemplate without revulsion.\r\n\r\nI was rescued from having to answer Gven by the laughter of Corven, who\r\nhad overheard the last of the poet\'s words. "Well then, poet, if she is\r\nunhappy, you must take her away, mustn\'t you? 

That\'s what you want, it\r\nseems, to take her away to Hainos and make her your Gvna."\r\n\r\nGven stood up and glared angrily at Corven. "Would it be so bad a thing\r\nto carry back one person of Earth? Why shouldn\'t we?" he flung at the\r\nother man.\r\n\r\nCorven turned away in disgust. "You know we have no authority to\r\nintervene in their affairs. This is what comes of letting a poet-priest\r\nmeddle in the concerns of science."\r\n\r\nA sullenness came over Gven\'s face, and he withdrew from us again,\r\nturning back to the panels. I knew he was with Maria Dolores. Though I\r\nwas uneasy over his ignorance, I could not help feeling relieved that I\r\nhad not been forced to enlighten him.\r\n\r\nMy anxiety proved to be well-founded. It was only a few weeks later\r\nthat we reaped the results of our long-cultivated conspiracy of\r\nsilence against the poet-priest. We were deeply engrossed in our work\r\nat the computing tables when our nerves were shattered by a cry of\r\nanguish from the mind of Gven. In a moment we were standing around\r\nhim, avoiding each other\'s eyes and scarcely daring to look at the man\r\nshuddering before us, his face in his hands.\r\n\r\n"It is done." Gven cast his anger at us like a stone. "It is as though\r\nshe had been killed. 

Why couldn\'t you tell me? You, Noven, I asked you.\r\nWhy couldn\'t you have spared me this?"\r\n\r\nThe men looked uneasily at me and back at Gven. Shaken, they drifted\r\naway, back to their work, still ashamed to meet each other\'s eyes. Gven\r\nsat there, grinding his fist into his palm, staring straight ahead.\r\n\r\nHe has been gone for some time now. At his request, a long-ship stopped\r\nfor him on its homeward cruise. I have not tried to reach another\r\nsubject, nor have any of the others. At least, if they have, they do\r\nnot speak of it. 

We are reluctant to attempt any communion with these\r\ncreatures whose alien nature has been so strikingly demonstrated to\r\nus. The game of Observation itself has become less a game, and we go\r\nabout our work with a vague sense of unrest, as though the descent of\r\ncatastrophe upon us were imminent.\r\n\r\nGven gave us one last gift before he left. He sang us a song that made\r\nus want to bend our heads to the ground in shame. If his songs are\r\nbitter now, and if there is no innocence in them, one needs not look\r\nfar to find the reason.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nHe was a man easily smiled at; a little birdlike individual carrying\r\nan umbrella and wearing upon his pink face a look remindful of\r\nhappy secrets about to be revealed. "\r\n\r\n"I certainly would." And, strangely enough, I did.\r\n\r\n"I am a researcher into the--well, the unusual."\r\n\r\n"Psychic research?" I inquired, wanting him to know we New Englanders\r\nwere not dullards.\r\n\r\n"No. Nothing to do with the supernatural at all. "\r\n\r\n"That would help.

"\r\n\r\nHis bright little eyes got even brighter. "Do you know, by chance, of\r\nthe Reamer mansion over in Carleton?"\r\n\r\nI certainly did. It was some thirty miles from Patterson, but as a\r\nchild, I\'d visited the place. All children within the radius had\r\nvisited the Reamer mansion at least once. It was an ancient fifteen\r\nroom cockroach trap with such a history of death and violence behind it\r\nas to cause the kids to walk on tiptoe through its silent rooms. I told\r\nthe professor I knew about it.\r\n\r\n"It has been vacant for fifteen years," he observed.\r\n\r\n"And will be vacant for twice fifteen more, I imagine."\r\n\r\n"That\'s just the point. 

Superstition. Otherwise solid and sane people\r\nwouldn\'t dream of moving into the Reamer mansion. And it\'s so silly.

"\r\n\r\n"It is?"\r\n\r\n"Of course. And that\'s why I\'m here. I intend to prove, so the most\r\nstubborn will understand, that the house itself has nothing whatsoever\r\nto do with its own grim past; that the people who lived in it are to\r\nblame."\r\n\r\nIt was a dull day and he was such an apparently sincere little man that\r\nI decided to keep the conversation alive. There were just--no clues, from what I\'ve learned. The\r\nnext unfortunate, a renter named Miles McCormick, was found dead along\r\nwith his wife and child as a result of lethal gas from a faulty stove."\r\n\r\n"That happened the year I was born. 

We have the old newspapers here,\r\ntelling about it."\r\n\r\n"Those reports, along with other material are what I wish to study,"\r\nProfessor Waits said, then went on. "The house stood vacant for five\r\nyears, until a Johnathan Hays bought it."\r\n\r\n"But Johnathan Hays never moved in. "\r\n\r\n"Look at it this way, Miss Hopstead. You are walking through a dark\r\nroom. A door is standing open. You come into violent contact with the\r\nedge of it. He couldn\'t read a map. He didn\'t know what a map was. He\r\nonly grinned when they told him that North was at the top.\r\n\r\nHe knew better.\r\n\r\nBut he did write a nice round hand, like a boy\'s hand. He knew Spanish,\r\nand enough English. For the sector that was assigned to him he would not\r\nneed a map. He knew it better than anyone else, certainly better than\r\nany mapmaker. Besides, he was poor and needed the money.\r\n\r\nThey instructed him and sent him out. Or they thought that they had\r\ninstructed him. They couldn\'t be sure.\r\n\r\n"Count everyone? All right. Fill in everyone? I need more papers."\r\n\r\n"We will give you more if you need more. But there aren\'t so many in\r\nyour sector."\r\n\r\n"Lots of them. _Lobos_, _tejones_, _zorros_, even people."\r\n\r\n"Only the _people_, Manuel! Do not take the animals. How would you write\r\nup the animals? They have no names."\r\n\r\n"Oh, yes. All have names. Might as well take them all."\r\n\r\n"Only people, Manuel."\r\n\r\n"_Mulos?_"\r\n\r\n"No."\r\n\r\n"_Conejos?_"\r\n\r\n"No, Manuel, no. Only the people."\r\n\r\n"No trouble. That has been explained to you."\r\n\r\n"_Little_ people. Not children, little people."\r\n\r\n"If they are people, take them."\r\n\r\n"How big they have to be?"\r\n\r\n"It doesn\'t make any difference how big they are. If they are people,\r\ntake them."\r\n\r\nThat is where the damage was done.\r\n\r\nThe official had given a snap judgement, and it led to disaster. It was\r\nnot his fault. 

The instructions are not clear. Nowhere in all the\r\nverbiage does it say how big they have to be to be counted as people.\r\n\r\n\r\nManuel took Mula and went to work. His sector was the Santa Magdalena, a\r\nscrap of bald-headed and desolate mountains, steep but not high, and so\r\ntorrid in the afternoons that it was said that the old lava sometimes\r\nbegan to writhe and flow again from the sun\'s heat alone.\r\n\r\nIn the center valley there were five thousand acres of slag and\r\nvitrified rock from some forgotten old blast that had melted the hills\r\nand destroyed their mantle, reducing all to a terrible flatness. This\r\nwas called Sodom. It was strewn with low-lying ghosts as of people and\r\nobjects, formed when the granite bubbled like water.\r\n\r\nAway from the dead center the ravines were body-deep in chaparral, and\r\nthe hillsides stood gray-green with old cactus. The stunted trees were\r\nlower than the giant bushes and yucca.\r\n\r\nManuel went with Mula, a round easy man and a sparse gaunt mule. Mula\r\nwas a mule, but there were other inhabitants of the Santa Magdalena of a\r\ngenus less certain.\r\n\r\nYet even about Mula there was an oddity in her ancestry. Her paternal\r\ngrandfather had been a goat. Manuel once told Mr. Marshal about this,\r\nbut Mr. Marshal had not accepted it.\r\n\r\n"She is a mule. Therefore, her father was a jack. Therefore his father\r\nwas also a jack, a donkey. It could not be any other way."\r\n\r\nManuel often wondered about that, for he had raised the whole strain of\r\nanimals, and he remembered who had been with whom.\r\n\r\n"A donkey! A jack! Two feet tall and with a beard and horns. I always\r\nthought that he was a goat."\r\n\r\nManuel and Mula stopped at noon on Lost Soul Creek. There would be no\r\ntravel in the hot afternoon. But Manuel had a job to do, and he did it.\r\nHe took the forms from one of the packs that he had unslung from Mula,\r\nand counted out nine of them. He wrote down all the data on nine people.\r\nHe knew all there was to know about them, their nativities and their\r\nantecedents. He knew that there were only nine regular people in the\r\nnine hundred square miles of the Santa Magdalena.\r\n\r\nBut he was systematic, so he checked the list over again and again.\r\nThere seemed to be somebody missing. Oh, yes, himself. He got another\r\nform and filled out all the data on himself.\r\n\r\nNow, in one way of looking at it, his part in the census was finished.\r\nIf only he had looked at it that way, he would have saved worry and\r\ntrouble for everyone, and also ten thousand lives. But the instructions\r\nthey had given him were ambiguous, for all that they had tried to make\r\nthem clear.\r\n\r\nSo very early the next morning he rose and cooked beans, and said,\r\n"Might as well take them all."\r\n\r\nHe called Mula from the thorn patch where she was grazing, gave her salt\r\nand loaded her again. Then they went to take the rest of the census, but\r\nin fear. There was a clear duty to get the job done, but there was also\r\na dread of it that his superiors did not understand. There was reason\r\nalso why Mula was loaded so she could hardly walk with packs of census\r\nforms.\r\n\r\nManuel prayed out loud as they climbed the purgatorial scarp above Lost\r\nSouls Creek, "_ruega por nosotros pecadores ahora_--" the very gulches\r\nstood angry and stark in the early morning--"_y en la hora de neustra\r\nmuerte._"\r\n\r\n\r\nThree days later an incredible dwarf staggered into the outskirts of\r\nHigh Plains, Texas, followed by a dying wolf-sized animal that did not\r\nlook like a wolf.\r\n\r\nA lady called the police to save the pair from rock-throwing kids who\r\nmight have killed them, and the two as yet unclassified things were\r\ntaken to the station house.\r\n\r\nThe dwarf was three foot high, a skeleton stretched over with\r\nbrown-burnt leather. The other was an un-canine looking dog-sized beast,\r\nso full of burrs and thorns that it might have been a porcupine. It was\r\na nightmare replica of a shrunken mule.\r\n\r\nThe midget was mad. The animal had more presence of mind: she lay down\r\nquietly and died, which was the best she could do, considering the state\r\nthat she was in.\r\n\r\n"Who is census chief now?" asked the mad midget. "Is Mr. Marshal\'s boy\r\nthe census chief?"\r\n\r\n"Mr. Marshal is, yes. Who are you? How do you know Marshal? And what is\r\nthat which you are pulling out of your pants, if they are pants?"\r\n\r\n"Census list. Names of everybody in the Santa Magdalena. I had to steal\r\nit."\r\n\r\n"It looks like microfilm, the writing is so small. And the roll goes on\r\nand on. There must be a million names here."\r\n\r\n"Little bit more, little bit more. I get two bits a name."\r\n\r\nThey got Marshal there. He was very busy, but he came. He had been given\r\na deadline by the mayor and the citizen\'s group. He had to produce a\r\npopulation of ten thousand people for High Plains, Texas; and this was\r\ndifficult, for there weren\'t that many people in the town. I had to steal their\r\nlist."\r\n\r\n"You can\'t be Manuel," said Marshal.\r\n\r\n"He can\'t be Manuel," said the big policemen and the little policeman.\r\n\r\n"Maybe not, then," the dwarf conceded. "I thought I was, but I wasn\'t\r\nsure. 

Who am I then? Let\'s look at the other papers and see which one I\r\nam."\r\n\r\n"No, you can\'t be any of them either, Manuel. And you surely can\'t be\r\nManuel."\r\n\r\n"Give him a name anyhow and get him counted. We got to get to that ten\r\nthousand mark."\r\n\r\n"Tell us what happened, Manuel--if you are. But they\r\nput an _encanto_ on me, and made me and Mula run a treadmill for\r\nthirty-five years."\r\n\r\n"Where was this?

"\r\n\r\n"At the little people town. Nuevo Danae. But after thirty-five years the\r\n_encanto_ wore off and Mula and I stole the list of names and ran away."\r\n\r\n"But where did you really get this list of so many names written so\r\nsmall?"\r\n\r\n"Suffering saddle sores, Marshal, don\'t ask the little bug so many\r\nquestions.
