Certify them! Send them\r\nin! There\'s enough of us here right now. We declare that place annexed\r\nforthwith. This will make High Plains the biggest town in the whole\r\nstate of Texas."\r\n\r\n\r\nSo Marshal certified them and sent them into Washington. This gave High\r\nPlains the largest percentage increase of any city in the nation, but it\r\nwas challenged. There were some soreheads in Houston who said that it\r\nwasn\'t possible. They said High Plains had nowhere near that many people\r\nand there must have been a miscount.\r\n\r\nAnd in the days that the argument was going on, they cleaned up and fed\r\nManuel, if it were he, and tried to get from him a cogent story.\r\n\r\n"How do you know it was thirty-five years you were on the treadmill,\r\nManuel?"\r\n\r\n"Well, it seemed like thirty-five years.

"\r\n\r\n"It could have only been about three days."\r\n\r\n"Then how come I\'m so old?"\r\n\r\n"We don\'t know that, Manuel, we sure don\'t know that. How big were these\r\npeople?"\r\n\r\n"Who knows? A finger long, maybe two?"\r\n\r\n"And what is their town?"\r\n\r\n"It is an old prairie-dog town that they fixed up. You have to dig down\r\nwith a spade to get to the streets."\r\n\r\n"Maybe they were really all prairie dogs, Manuel. Maybe the heat got you\r\nand you only dreamed that they were little people."\r\n\r\n"Prairie dogs can\'t write as good as on that list. Prairie dogs can\'t\r\nwrite hardly at all."\r\n\r\n"That\'s true. 

The list is hard to explain. And such odd names on it\r\ntoo."\r\n\r\n"Where is Mula? I don\'t see Mula since I came back."\r\n\r\n"Mula just lay down and died, Manuel."\r\n\r\n"Gave me the slip. Why didn\'t I think of that? 

Well, I\'ll do it too. I\'m\r\ntoo worn out for anything else."\r\n\r\n"Before you do, Manuel, just a couple of last questions."\r\n\r\n"Make them real fast then. I\'m on my way."\r\n\r\n"Did you know these little people were there before?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, sure. There a long time."\r\n\r\n"Did anybody else ever see them?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, sure. Everybody in the Santa Magdalena see them. Eight, nine people\r\nsee them."\r\n\r\n"And Manuel, how do we get to the place? 

Can you show us on a map?"\r\n\r\nManuel made a grimace, and died quietly as Mula had done. He didn\'t\r\nunderstand those maps at all, and took the easy way out.\r\n\r\nThey buried him, not knowing for sure whether he was Manuel come back,\r\nor what he was.\r\n\r\nThere wasn\'t much of him to bury.\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was the same night, very late and after he had been asleep, that\r\nMarshal was awakened by the ring of an authoritative voice. He was being\r\nharangued by a four-inch tall man on his bedside table, a man of\r\ndominating presence and acid voice.\r\n\r\n"Come out of that cot, you clown! Give me your name and station!"\r\n\r\n"I\'m Marshal, and I suspect that you are a late pig sandwich, or caused\r\nby one. I shouldn\'t eat so late."\r\n\r\n"Say \'sir\' when you reply to me. I am no pig sandwich and I do not\r\ncommonly call on fools. 

Get on your feet, you clod."\r\n\r\nAnd wonderingly Marshal did.\r\n\r\n"I want the list that was stolen. Don\'t gape! 

Get it!"\r\n\r\n"What list?"\r\n\r\n"Don\'t stall, don\'t stutter. Get me our tax list that was stolen. It\r\nisn\'t words that I want from you.

"\r\n\r\n"Listen, you cicada, I\'ll take you and--"\r\n\r\n"You will not. You will notice that you are paralyzed from the neck\r\ndown. I suspect that you were always so from there up. 

Where is the\r\nlist?"\r\n\r\n"S-sent it to Washington."\r\n\r\n"You bug-eyed behemoth! Do you realize what a trip that will be? You\r\ngrandfather of inanities, it will be a pleasure to destroy you!"\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know what you are, or if you are really. I don\'t believe that\r\nyou even belong on the world."\r\n\r\n"Not belong on the world! We own the world. We can show written title to\r\nthe world. Can you?"\r\n\r\n"I doubt it. Where did you get the title?"\r\n\r\n"None of your business. I\'d rather not say. Oh, well, we got it from a\r\npromoter of sorts. A con man, really. I\'ll have to admit that we were\r\ntaken, but we were in a spot and needed a world. He said that the larger\r\nbifurcates were too stupid to be a nuisance. We should have known that\r\nthe stupider a creature, the more of a nuisance it is."\r\n\r\n"I had about decided the same thing about the smaller a creature. We may\r\nhave to fumigate that old mountain mess."\r\n\r\n"Oh, you can\'t harm us. We\'re too powerful. But we can obliterate you in\r\nan instant."\r\n\r\n"Hah!"\r\n\r\n"Say \'Hah, _sir_\' when you address me. Do you know the place in the\r\nmountain that is called Sodom?"\r\n\r\n"I know the place. It was caused by a large meteor."\r\n\r\n"It was caused by one of these."\r\n\r\nWhat he held up was the size of a grain of sand. Marshal could not see\r\nit in detail.\r\n\r\n"There was another city of you bug-eyed beasts there," said the small\r\nmartinet. "You wouldn\'t know about it. 

It\'s been a few hundred years. We\r\ndecided it was too close. Now I have decided that you are too close."\r\n\r\n"A thing that size couldn\'t crack a walnut."\r\n\r\n"You floundering fop, it will blast this town flat!"\r\n\r\n"What will happen to you?"\r\n\r\n"Nothing. I don\'t even blink for things like that."\r\n\r\n"How do you trigger it off."\r\n\r\n"You gaping goof, I don\'t have time to explain that to you. 

I have to\r\nget to Washington."\r\n\r\nIt may be that Marshal did not believe himself quite awake. He certainly\r\ndid not take the threat seriously enough. For the little man did trigger\r\nit off.\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen the final count was in, High Plains did not have the highest\r\npercentage gain in population in the nation. Actually it showed the\r\nsharpest decline, from 7313 to nothing.\r\n\r\nThey were going to make a forest preserve out of the place, except that\r\nit has no trees worthy of the name. Now it is proposed to make it the\r\nSodom and Gomorrah State Park from the two mysterious scenes of\r\ndesolation there, just seven miles apart.\r\n\r\nIt is an interesting place, as wild a region as you will ever find, and\r\nis recommended for the man who has seen everything.\r\n\r\n\r\n  --R. A. LAFFERTY\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


]\r\n\r\n\r\nGoro put down his tools and relaxed into a pile of wood shavings, his\r\nback against a half-finished bathtub. To enjoy the evening cool, he\r\ntold himself, wiping his face with a blue and white rag. Actually,\r\nhe wanted to postpone the evening meal. Either the rice would be\r\novercooked to a sticky goo or he would be picking hard, underdone\r\nkernels out of his teeth all night. And bean soup, when he made it,\r\nalways had things swimming in it that had no business there.\r\n\r\nA night insect went _weep-weep-weep_. The sound, the night\r\nfalling, and the thought of his own cooking made him think of his dead\r\nwife.\r\n\r\n"She was a good cook, poor thing," he thought out loud. "My, my--how I\r\nmiss her."\r\n\r\nHe gave a deep sigh. Oh, to have a wife again--a jolly, round wife and\r\na good cook. Just like the old one with perhaps the small exception\r\nthat she would not eat a man out of house and home and herself into\r\nthe grave in the bargain. Had he said that aloud? Bad sign, when a man\r\ntalks to the night insects--better to go into the house, better to eat\r\nrice and bean soup. He shuddered.\r\n\r\nHe began to get up and paused halfway, one hand against the wood of the\r\ntub, the other shielding his eyes. He peered into the forest that came\r\nalmost to the work yard. Someone was coming through there, he heard it.\r\nHe sat down again. Fireflies flitted among the trees. What if it were\r\nhis wife\'s spirit--would it be a chubby ghost? It should be.\r\n\r\nA woman walked out of the forest.\r\n\r\nShe was tall, he noticed, watching her thread her way among finished\r\nand unfinished buckets and tubs, tall and slender--almost gaunt. She\r\nhad her sleeves tied back out of the way with a white _tasuki_\r\ncord, as though ready for hard work, and her bare arms were wiry and\r\ncapable looking.\r\n\r\nShe bowed.\r\n\r\nGoro scrambled to his feet, catching a splinter or two in his shoulder\r\non the way up. He bowed.\r\n\r\n"Good evening," said the woman. "Is this the house of Goro, the cooper\r\nwho wants a wife that does not eat too much and is a good cook?"\r\n\r\nGoro\'s eyes crossed and his mouth fell open. His fingers scrabbled.\r\n\r\n"You _do_ look unwell ... like a starved goldfish," said the\r\nwoman, "--I don\'t mean to seem rude."\r\n\r\n"I haven\'t had dinner ..." said Goro, for want of anything brilliant to\r\nsay. He felt wondrously helpless; things like this did not usually come\r\nup in the tub-making business.\r\n\r\n"Naturally, poor thing. I\'m sure you can\'t cook well, either," said\r\nthe woman and Goro marvelled how ever she had guessed it. "Well, I can\r\ncook. I can do the work of three women. Into the house with you now,\r\nbefore you catch cold. 

Shoo!"\r\n\r\nShe drove him ahead of her into the house.\r\n\r\n"I would say I\'m quite charming," she said, closing the door behind\r\nthem, "when one gets used to me. As for my name, why, \'wife\', I think,\r\nwill do nicely."\r\n\r\nAnd sometime in the next few days still with the feeling that he was\r\nbeing left out of things, Goro found himself married.\r\n\r\nThe new wife was an excellent cook and indeed did the work of three\r\nordinary women. Dinner was never late, and the house was generally\r\nspotless. 

She spoke neither too much nor too little. On evenings when\r\nGoro came home discouraged, she always had some good remark ready\r\nabout the tub-making business--how much artistry and labor went into\r\na good bucket, how unreasonably little money went to the hard-working\r\nartist--cheering things, flattering things. Goro gained weight and was\r\nnot unhappy. At mealtimes his wife ate a little more than a bird but\r\nnot quite so much as a large cat.\r\n\r\nThe food bills went up and up.\r\n\r\nGoro gradually discovered that with the little eating going on, he was\r\nusing up food at a rate to feed six or seven coopers together with a\r\nfew aunts and uncles.\r\n\r\n"Curious ...," he muttered, "... very," and determined to investigate.\r\n\r\nOne morning he made a great fuss about getting measuring equipment\r\ntogether. He told his wife that he was going to a village half a day\'s\r\nwalk away, to take measurements for the village head-man\'s new tub.\r\nThen he went a short distance into the forest and waited behind a tree.\r\n\r\nWhen he saw his wife go to a nearby meadow to gather mushrooms, he\r\nflitted around to the back of the house. Hiding his tools behind\r\nthe rear door, he crept inside. He shinnied up the center pole and\r\nflattened out against one of the big ceiling beams. And waited.\r\n\r\nHis wife came back and put on the fire the largest pot in the house.\r\nFrom the storage bins she took about five pounds of rice and fell to\r\nwashing it. She ladled out enough bean paste to nearly fill another big\r\npot, and made bean soup.\r\n\r\n"Who," wondered Goro on his beam, "is she expecting, and how many of\r\nthem?" He blinked, blinked again--his eyes rather rolled up.\r\n\r\nShe had slid the kitchen door out of its frame and was using it for\r\na dumpling factory, lining the dumplings up--lines and lines of rice\r\ndumplings like fat well-paid soldiers.\r\n\r\nThen she stretched and peered about as if to make sure she had not\r\nforgotten something. Satisfied that she had not, she parted her hair\r\nand exposed the mouth in the center of her head.\r\n\r\nGoro made a circle of his thumbs and forefingers, trying to calculate\r\nthe size of the thing and nearly fell off his perch. It was fairly\r\nlarge.\r\n\r\nInto this crater, his wife pushed dumplings by ones and twos and they\r\ndisappeared. To make certain, she washed them down with all the bean\r\nsoup, ladles of bean soup.\r\n\r\nWhen she had disposed of everything she waited a moment, expectantly. A\r\ncheery, satisfied rumble came from the top of her head.\r\n\r\n"Burps, too," thought Goro. "A regular volcano. 

Wonder if there\'ll be\r\nsmoke." 

He was too interested to be frightened.\r\n\r\nBut nothing further happened. She bound her hair back neatly, smiled,\r\nand left the house on some errand like any good, wifely wife.\r\n\r\nGoro slipped down and out of the house, picking up his tools on the\r\nway. He went back into the forest, found a comfortable tree and sat\r\ndown against its trunk to smoke his tiny pipe and think.\r\n\r\n"I must have married one of the monsters the priests and old men talk\r\nabout, a yamam\'ba. A \'mountain-mother\'. Hmm," he nodded, bit his lip,\r\nand squinted his eyes.\r\n\r\n"Now why do you suppose they call them that?" he asked a squirrel that\r\nsat upright near his left foot, like an attentive, furry little doctor.\r\n"They come from the mountains--fine. But what\'s motherly about them, I\r\ndo not understand.\r\n\r\n"Squeerp!" said the squirrel, and ran halfway up the tree. From there\r\nit peered down and examined Goro\'s head.\r\n\r\nHe tilted his head back so that the squirrel could get a better look\r\nand told it that, at any rate, this was no kind of wife for a good man.\r\n\r\nThen he stood up and began to walk home, looking down at the ground,\r\nkicking thoughtfully at fallen leaves and occasionally scratching his\r\nhead.\r\n\r\nHe came out from among the trees and across the yard of his home,\r\ndragging his feet like a man who has walked a long way.\r\n\r\nHe started speaking as soon as he put down his tools.\r\n\r\n"Wife, I have been thinking about our marriage and--it hurts me to\r\nsay it, you understand--but it was too sudden. No--don\'t interrupt,"\r\nhe said, though his wife had shown no sign of breaking in. 

"I\'m very\r\nsorry, but I feel that we\'re simply not suited to each other."\r\n\r\n"All right, husband, I\'ll leave," she answered in quite an ordinary\r\nvoice, "even if it makes me unhappy. Could you do only one thing for me\r\nbefore I go? Nothing much--I\'d like you to make me a tub--as a kind of\r\nsouvenir. A very large one. 

For bathing in."\r\n\r\n"The simplest thing in the world," said Goro, glad to get off so\r\neasily. "I have one ready, it happens. The very one I was sitting\r\nagainst when you came out of the forest. A very sound tub, one of my\r\nbest."\r\n\r\n"It has a lid, I hope," she said.\r\n\r\n"All of my tubs have lids," said Goro. "Well-fitting lids. Water stays\r\nwarm in _my_ tubs, even without a fire, once that lid is on. Come,\r\nI\'ll show it to you."\r\n\r\nHe led her out to the tub.\r\n\r\n"See? There\'s the lid, right up against it," he said, thumping the tub\r\nwith his fist. "Feel that wood! Isn\'t it a beauty?"\r\n\r\nShe looked into the tub and agreed that it was getting harder and\r\nharder to find real quality in tubs. "Too bad there\'s that large hole\r\nin it," she said.\r\n\r\n"Hole?" said Goro. "Hole? A hole in one of my tubs? Impossible ...\r\nwhere\'s that hole!"\r\n\r\nHe put his hands on the edge to raise himself and peered over.\r\n\r\n"There. Bottom right," she said. "Can\'t you see it?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, the bottom ..." said Goro, leaning further over the edge. "It\'s\r\ntoo dark to--"\r\n\r\nShe seized Goro\'s trousers in a firm grip and heaved.\r\n\r\n"--see," he finished, at the bottom of the tub. He was still wondering\r\nhow he had gotten down there when the lid came down, bang, and it grew\r\nvery dark. He felt the tub sail up, come to rest on something and begin\r\nto move forward with an up and down rocking movement.\r\n\r\nIt did not take Goro long, in his bucket-shaped night, to realize that\r\nthe yamam\'ba, having no further reason to pretend a feminine weakness\r\nshe probably despised anyway, had placed the tub on her head and was on\r\nher way home. To the mountain.\r\n\r\n"Excuse me," he called out. 

"Where are we going?"\r\n\r\n"To dinner," came his former wife\'s voice through the wood. It grated\r\nunpleasantly. He decided to ask no more questions.\r\n\r\nDeep into the woods went the yamam\'ba, cutting through thicket and\r\nunderbrush, the tub jouncing easily on her head, up and up into the\r\nmountains. Tireless on her long, rangy legs, she travelled along\r\ndead, forgotten roads lined with gnarled ugly trees. Goro heard their\r\nbranches, bump-crack-bump, against his self-made prison. 

A thin edge\r\nof lesser darkness began to show at the top. He hoped it was the first\r\ntime the lid had slipped on a tub made by Goro; this sort of thing\r\ncould ruin years of reputation. But it might mean a way out of the tub.\r\n\r\nThe opening grew wider. Looking up, he was able to see a few stars. Did\r\nhe imagine it, or was the tub slowing down? He hoped he was not going\r\nto be eaten immediately.\r\n\r\nThe tub stopped and settled.\r\n\r\nSomething rough, twisted, and snakelike appeared in the opening. It did\r\nnot move. 

Nothing moved. He put out his hand--it was a branch.\r\n\r\nHe gave the branch a delicate jiggle; it felt solid. The yamam\'ba, he\r\nguessed, must have tired and sat down to rest against a tree. Very\r\ncautiously he lifted himself by the branch, trying to move neither the\r\nlid nor the tub which must still be resting on the monster\'s head.\r\n\r\nHe heard a faint snore. Top or forward mouth, he wondered. He pulled\r\nhimself to his feet, trying not to breathe and at last stood with his\r\nhead out of the tub. The branch was thick, and the next branch, right\r\nabove, looked dependable. Healthy wood; he appreciated that. Then came\r\na few feet of bark--that would be hard climbing--but above that, four\r\nor five branches, almost a ladder. Further, it was too dark to see.\r\n\r\nHe tensed, took a deep breath, then gave a push and sent the heavy lid\r\ncrashing down on the sleeping yamam\'ba. Up she leaped, and the tub\r\nwent flying, but Goro was already climbing from branch to branch. In a\r\nnearby tree some monkeys woke up and watched Goro\'s footwork with shame\r\nand envy.\r\n\r\nFrom the ground the yamam\'ba stared up at him. It was a rare chance to\r\nsee just what a yamam\'ba really wore for a face, and he decided it was\r\nnot very attractive.\r\n\r\nDown below, the monster was letting down her horrible hair in a\r\nbusinesslike manner.\r\n\r\n"Dinner will be early," she said with a ghastly, girlish laugh. "I was\r\ngetting quite hungry."\r\n\r\nShe started up the tree, the top mouth opening and closing. There were\r\nteeth in it.\r\n\r\n"We yamam\'ba are very good with trees," she said, climbing steadily.\r\n"Don\'t climb any higher. It will only make you tired and sweaty and\r\nbitter to the taste. 

Say prayers instead and become calm and delicious."\r\n\r\n"I hope I burn your tongue if you have one in there," said Goro, a\r\nlittle beside himself. "And try not to be such a chatterbox. You\'re\r\nmaking my head buzz."\r\n\r\nHe _did_ hear a distinct buzzing, a small roaring right by his\r\nhead where he was holding on to a thin branch. He tried to move his\r\nhand away from the sound. Something small sat down on his thumb and set\r\nit on fire.\r\n\r\n"Ya-yowch!" he said, loudly.\r\n\r\n"Tee-hee-hee!" went the yamam\'ba, coming up with an intimate rustling\r\nof leaves.\r\n\r\nGoro sucked his thumb which had swollen surprisingly and stared at the\r\nball-like thing hanging only an arm\'s length away. The buzzing came\r\nfrom it. Very carefully he reached out to see if he would be able to\r\ngrab it instantly. He thought the size would be about right.\r\n\r\nA hard, scaly hand with claws came groping through the branches. He\r\nmoved his foot out of the way and waited for the head. It appeared, the\r\ntop mouth gaping.\r\n\r\n"Tee-hee-hee," said the yamam\'ba, using both mouths.\r\n\r\n"Tee-hee-hee yourself," said Goro. "Have a goody." And into the top of\r\nher head he dropped the buzzing ball.\r\n\r\n"Whatever it was, it had a bad taste and your blood will wash it away,"\r\nsaid the yamam\'ba but just then the hornets woke up, highly irritated\r\nfrom lack of sleep.\r\n\r\nThey flew \'round and \'round inside the yamam\'ba. A few of them tickled.\r\nMost of them stung. And all of them together worked a havoc in the\r\ndelicate equipment that makes up the yamam\'ba interior.\r\n\r\nThe yamam\'ba made a noise like a frying and a noise like a boiling,\r\nand a noise like nameless things running through the night with their\r\nears on fire. She tumbled from the tree, into the tub waiting below\r\nand bounced about inside it making unpleasant sounds too numerous to\r\nmention.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nGoro followed, but more slowly. He arrived in time to see the tub\r\nskipping and hopping at the edge of the road which at that point\r\nwas quite narrow. It teetered for a moment and then sailed out in a\r\ngracious curve, trailing its uproar behind it. Goro kneeled and peered\r\ndown. It was very dark. From far below came a soft boompety-boomp. 

Then\r\na mere whisper of a crash.\r\n\r\nGoro got up, shaking his head. He dusted his knees and went away down\r\nthe road, growing smaller in the cold, lonely night.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


copyright on this publication was renewed.]\r\n\r\n\r\nRafferty was a gambler of the old school. He didn\'t believe in any of\r\nthe fancy electronic gadgets that the casinos went in for these days,\r\ndidn\'t much care for the psionic games of chance and other tricky and\r\nprobably rigged affairs. Give him a good poker game any time, and he\r\nwould be happy.\r\n\r\nHe stood in the door of the Ganymede Casino, outlining himself against\r\nthe gaudy lights flashing within, standing there patiently. Inside, the\r\nrich and would-be rich of a dozen planets were enjoying themselves,\r\nplaying the brightly-lit games and throwing money around in handfuls.\r\n\r\nRafferty waited for some attention. His hand slid to the bulky roll in\r\nhis pocket--one hundred hundred-credit bills, 10,000 smackers in all.\r\nIt was all Rafferty had. He was here to triple it, or else.\r\n\r\nTomorrow 30,000 had to be handed over to Lee Walsh. It was the result\r\nof the one mistake Rafferty had made.\r\n\r\nWalsh was a big-time gambler, with ulcers and high blood pressure and\r\nten million in the bank. Rafferty was straight middle-time, a man who\r\ngenuinely enjoyed his chancy profession. And Walsh had said, "Why don\'t\r\nyou play something _I_ like to play? All the time poker, poker, poker.\r\nWhy don\'t you switch to something else."\r\n\r\n"I like poker," Rafferty said. "I win at poker. Why switch?"\r\n\r\nWalsh seemed to stiffen. "Let\'s have a little game of planet-faro,\r\nRafferty. Just you and me. I\'m tired of all this poker."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t like planet-faro. It\'s a lousy game. All those flashing\r\nlights--it\'s more like pinball than honest-to-darn gambling."\r\n\r\n"You ain\'t chicken, Rafferty?"\r\n\r\n"Chicken?"\r\n\r\n"Yeah. 

Let\'s try some planet-faro."\r\n\r\nSo they did--and Rafferty had sat by leadenly while Walsh cleaned him\r\nout. Thirty thousand shiny credits down the drain, and the debt due\r\ntomorrow at noon. You didn\'t welsh on Walsh, either. It was sort of a\r\nslogan.\r\n\r\nRafferty didn\'t have the thirty thousand. He had two alternatives: he\r\ncould scrape up the cash somewhere and hand it over, or he could grab\r\nan out-system liner and get going toward Aldebaran, and hope to live.\r\nHe wouldn\'t--not for long.\r\n\r\nHe decided to scrape up the cash. And there was one sure way to do\r\nthat. Poker.\r\n\r\nPoker was getting to be an unpopular game, and there were two reasons\r\nfor it. One was the advent of more popular new types of gambling\r\ndevices; the other reason was that Rafferty was so good it didn\'t pay\r\nto compete against him. He often had trouble getting up a game. People\r\ntended to slink away when they heard Rafferty wanted to play poker. He\r\nplayed it hard and he played it mean, and he didn\'t lose too often.\r\n\r\nThat was why he had come to the Ganymede Casino. On the big\r\npleasure-moon, anyone could find some sort of game going--and if he\r\ncouldn\'t, the house would be glad to provide some competition. There\r\none around I can get into?

"\r\n\r\nThe impeccable man frowned slightly. "I don\'t think so,\r\nMr.--ah--Rafferty. Wouldn\'t you care to try our Roto, or the\r\nplanet-faro, or robot roulette? We--"\r\n\r\n"I want to play poker," Rafferty said. The chips were down now; he had\r\nto stick to his specialty.\r\n\r\n"Well, I\'ll see what I can do. Would you wait here, please?

"\r\n\r\nRafferty waited. He waited while the impeccable man cruised around\r\nthe huge gameroom, murmuring gently to someone here, someone there.\r\nIn all cases the response was the same: a shrug, a curious glance in\r\nRafferty\'s direction, a quick and emphatic shake of the head.\r\n\r\nNo one wanted to play. Usually Rafferty could count on some fool\r\nmillionaire anxious to try to best the great Rafferty at five-card\r\nstud. Not today, though. There were no takers.\r\n\r\n"I\'m sorry, Mr. Rafferty; I couldn\'t seem to promote a game. But the\r\nplanet-faro--"\r\n\r\n"Poker," Rafferty said.\r\n\r\n"Would you object to playing a two-handed game with one of our\r\nemployees?" the usher asked suddenly. 

"Naturally he\'ll be staked by the\r\nhouse, and I think you\'ll find him fit competition for you."\r\n\r\nRafferty chewed at his lip. He needed the money--and if the house\r\noperator was staked by the casino, it might be possible to cart off\r\nquite a load.\r\n\r\n"Okay," he grunted. "Bring on your shill."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe usher led him to a small, highly-polished card table in the back,\r\nand signalled to a man waiting to one side.\r\n\r\n"Mr. Steel, this is Mr. Rafferty."\r\n\r\n"Hello," Rafferty said.\r\n\r\n"Pleased to meet you," said the other. His voice was a soft purr; his\r\nface, an expressionless mask. Rafferty smiled. He was quick to size up\r\nhis opponents, and this time he could tell he was up against a good one.\r\n\r\n"Chips?"\r\n\r\nA house girl had come by. She was clad only in a strip of something\r\nfilmy across her breasts and another round her middle, and she had a\r\ntrayfull of chips. Rafferty casually handed her the hundred bills and\r\naccepted his stack of chips. She also gave him an unopened deck of\r\ncards.\r\n\r\n"Care to?" Rafferty asked, offering the cards to his opponent.\r\n\r\n"No. Go ahead."\r\n\r\nMethodically Rafferty broke the seal, spilled the cards out, flipped\r\nthe jokers to one side, and riffled through the deck. There were\r\nfifty-two of them, all right, and they looked good. 

He started to\r\nshuffle.\r\n\r\nThe first few hands passed quickly. Steel was a quiet, noncommittal\r\nplayer who seemed to have a tremendous reserve of calmness. It wasn\'t\r\ntoo surprising, thought Rafferty, considering it wasn\'t his dough at\r\nstake. But a shill has professional pride.\r\n\r\nThe first three deals were in the nature of warmups, and Rafferty\r\nemerged from them twenty or thirty credits to the good. He felt the\r\ncards moving the right way; luck was with him tonight. 

He wondered if\r\nhe could come away with a million. The Casino had no limit.\r\n\r\nFourth hand he decided to experiment with some offensive tactics. Steel\r\ndealt; Rafferty scooped up his cards and looked them over. Jack, Four,\r\nEight, Seven, King. Spade, club, spade, heart, diamond. Coolly he\r\nfanned the cards out and pushed a hundred credits toward the middle of\r\nthe table. Steel saw him.\r\n\r\n"How many?"\r\n\r\n"I\'ll stand pat."\r\n\r\n"So will I."\r\n\r\n"Five hundred," Rafferty said.\r\n\r\n"See that and raise it a hundred."\r\n\r\n"I\'ll bump to two."\r\n\r\n"I\'m with you," Steel said. "What do you have?"\r\n\r\nWithout a facial flicker Rafferty exposed his hand. "Jack high. 

You?

"\r\n\r\n"You beat me. It\'s your kitty."\r\n\r\nRafferty scooped the pot in, frowning inwardly. He\'d made his\r\nbluff--but Steel had been bluffing right along with him. It was only\r\nluck that the little man hadn\'t been holding a Queen.\r\n\r\nRafferty pulled Jack high again on the next deal, took three, came up\r\nwith nothing and folded. On the next hand both men played it cautiously\r\nand Rafferty dropped fifty credits when Steel\'s pair of kings took his\r\ntens.\r\n\r\nNext deal, Rafferty again came up with nothing. Inwardly he cursed; the\r\ncards weren\'t coming as well as they had. He decided to bluff again,\r\nsince the previous attempt hadn\'t yielded any information about his\r\nopponent\'s tactics.\r\n\r\nThis time he pushed the bet up to a thousand before calling.\r\n\r\n"Three sevens," Steel said.\r\n\r\n"You beat me," Rafferty said, and collapsed his hand.\r\n\r\n"Mind if I look?" Steel said.\r\n\r\n"Yes," said Rafferty. He was surprised; it was a rank amateur\'s trick\r\nto ask to look at a hand that had been tossed in. Coming from a cool\r\ncustomer like Steel, it didn\'t make much sense.\r\n\r\nBut slowly Rafferty began to fathom the way his opponent\'s mind worked.\r\nAnd slowly, as his genius for the game asserted itself, Rafferty began\r\nto win.\r\n\r\nBy 2100 his pile of chips totalled near fifty thousand. It was enough\r\nto pay off Walsh and still come out with a comfortable profit for the\r\nevening\'s work--but Rafferty didn\'t want to quit. He didn\'t play the\r\ngame that way.\r\n\r\nHe decided to go for a killing. He had Steel figured, now and he could\r\ntake the house for a fortune.\r\n\r\nNursing three jacks and a pair of fours, he pushed the betting higher\r\nand higher. Steel kept right with him.\r\n\r\n"Three thousand? I\'ll see you and raise one."\r\n\r\nWithout letting expression cross his face, Rafferty pushed a few more\r\ncredits out. Then a few more. 

Then a few more. Five thousand credits\r\nhung on this deal, now.\r\n\r\nHe remained totally blank-faced. That was the secret of poker: never to\r\ntip off an opponent to anything. Steel was good, but Steel kept giving\r\nhimself away.\r\n\r\nLike now, for instance. Perhaps the shill didn\'t know it, but his right\r\neyebrow was twitching faintly. So far, every time Steel had bluffed a\r\nweak hand, that eyebrow had twitched.\r\n\r\nWell, now Rafferty had him. He had a full house; it was going to take a\r\nbunch of fancy cards to top it. And Steel was almost certainly bluffing.\r\n\r\n"Six thousand," Rafferty said.\r\n\r\n"Seven."\r\n\r\n"Seven five."\r\n\r\nIt reached nine. Finally Rafferty said, "Okay. What do you have?"\r\n\r\nCasually Steel lowered his hand. Jack, Queen, Queen, Queen, Queen. That\r\nmade four Queens.\r\n\r\nHe hadn\'t been bluffing.\r\n\r\nAnd Rafferty was out nine thousand credits.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe kept his composure, but inwardly he was disturbed. By all rights\r\nSteel _had_ to be bluffing--but there they were, four queens.\r\n\r\nThe game progressed. A few curious onlookers had gathered. By playing\r\ncautiously, Rafferty started piling up chips again. His winnings\r\nmounted to a hundred thousand, hundred fifty. He had Steel figured now\r\nfor sure.\r\n\r\nBut it wasn\'t as sure as all that.\r\n\r\nRafferty staked five thousand on a straight flush. Steel saw him and\r\nadded five hundred on top of it.\r\n\r\n"I\'ll go with you," Rafferty said. "Here\'s another thousand." Straight\r\nflush, Queen high. Only three hands could possibly beat him--and one\r\nof them was a royal flush. It didn\'t seem likely. Besides, the lower\r\ncorner of Steel\'s mouth was drawn back, as it usually was when he had a\r\nfairly good hand and was playing it big.\r\n\r\nThe chips flew out madly. Rafferty watched the pile grow; neither man\r\nwould let the cat die. Ten, twelve thousand credits now. Fifteen. In\r\nthirty years of poker, Rafferty had never had fifteen thousand credits\r\nriding on one hand. But he was sure he had it.\r\n\r\n"What are you holding?" Steel asked finally.\r\n\r\n"Straight flush, Queen high." He started to reach for the chips.\r\n\r\nSteel\'s mild, purring voice interrupted him. "_What suit?_"\r\n\r\nFor the first time that night Rafferty\'s composure left him. "C-Clubs,"\r\nhe stammered.\r\n\r\n"Spades," Steel said sweetly, and put down the eight to Queen,\r\ninclusive and consecutive.\r\n\r\nIt just didn\'t figure, Rafferty thought glumly. He wasn\'t as annoyed\r\nover the wild improbability of two straight flushes the same hand as he\r\nwas because he had failed to guess Steel\'s facial reaction properly.\r\nHe\'d been dead wrong.\r\n\r\nHe got wronger. Steel sat calmly without saying a word except when\r\nnecessary, and gobbled in the chips. It seemed to Rafferty that Steel\r\nwas reading his every move.\r\n\r\nHe was holding two pair, and played it big. Steel stayed right with\r\nhim, and when the payoff came:\r\n\r\n"Three fours."\r\n\r\nThree fours won. But Steel wouldn\'t have ridden that far on the trio\r\nunless he knew pretty well that Rafferty didn\'t have much to show. He\r\nseemed to _know_. And as the game progressed, he grew less and less\r\nreadable himself. Eight\r\nhundred credits left. Eight hundred lousy credits.\r\n\r\nIt was just enough to book passage to Aldebaran. Rafferty slumped in\r\nhis chair.\r\n\r\nThe gambler in him urged him to go on, to try to win the thirty\r\nthousand he needed and clear out. But another part of him told him\r\nit was futile; Steel was getting sharper and sharper, and it was\r\ninevitable he\'d lose even the remaining eight hundred. He didn\'t want\r\nthat to happen.\r\n\r\nHe rose stiffly.\r\n\r\n"Had enough?" Steel asked.\r\n\r\n"I think so."\r\n\r\n"I hope I haven\'t discouraged you. "I can\'t win. And at least\r\nthis way I\'ll be on Aldebaran tomorrow when Walsh and his gunmen come\r\nlooking for me."\r\n\r\n"What\'s that?

"\r\n\r\n"Never mind." Rafferty turned away, scooping up his remaining chips.\r\nHe cashed them in and shambled out the door, still unable fully to\r\nunderstand that for the first time in his life he had met his master\r\nat the poker table.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAfter Rafferty was gone, the impeccable usher came over to Steel, who\r\nwas sitting patiently by the huge pile of chips.\r\n\r\n"You clean him out?"\r\n\r\n"Just about," Steel said. 

"He had a little left to book passage with."\r\n\r\n"It looked bad for a while, there. He was better than a hundred\r\nthousand ahead of you."\r\n\r\n"It took me some time to detect his playing patterns," the house\r\nman said. "He was very, very good. "I took 9200 credits from him. It\'s thirsty\r\nwork. 

How about a drink?"\r\n\r\n"Sure thing," the impeccable man said. "I guess I can spare a drink for\r\nthe best house operator this casino has." He took an oilcan from his\r\njacket and inserted it at the back of Steel\'s neck. The robot grinned\r\nhappily at the lubrication; his soft photonic eyes beamed.\r\n\r\n"I enjoy playing poker," Steel said. "But someday you must enlarge my\r\ncircuits so I can take part in planet-faro too. 

It looks like a very\r\ninteresting game."\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


The hell with it, he\r\nthought happily. He was going to get himself completely stewed tonight.\r\nLive high, die young, and have a good-looking corpse.\r\n\r\nOr maybe it would be better simply to get aboard a spaceship and try to\r\nget away. Maybe the Interstellar Police would never find him.\r\n\r\nHe shook his head dismally. 

That wouldn\'t work, either. Nothing would\r\nwork.\r\n\r\nIf only he\'d had some practice fighting a Dornellian!\r\n\r\nHe reached out for his beer, not noticing that someone had taken the\r\nvacant seat next to him. His elbow collided with a glass. The glass\r\ntipped, pouring a green, bubbling liquor all over the Dornellian\r\nsitting next to him.\r\n\r\n"Stupid Earthman!" snapped the Dornellian contemptuously. "A clumsy\r\nbeast like you shouldn\'t be allowed to enter a public place!"\r\n\r\nWith one hairy paw, the Dornellian shoved against Larry\'s shoulder,\r\nintending to push him off the bar stool.\r\n\r\nLarry moved back, more in astonishment than anything else. He hadn\'t\r\nknown that Dornellians had any particular prejudice against Earthmen,\r\nbut there was unmistakable racial hatred in the alien\'s voice. He put\r\nout his hand to the bar and stopped himself from falling off the stool.\r\n\r\n"What\'s the idea of that?" Larry growled. "That was an accident, and--"\r\n\r\n"Are you trying to argue with me? Here is the rest of the drink!" The\r\nDornellian laughed and heaved the remaining contents of the glass in\r\nLarry\'s face.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nA blinding tide of red fury washed over Larry. Without thinking,\r\nreacting purely by instinct, he lashed out at the Dornellian.\r\n\r\nHis fist didn\'t contact; it was blocked by the heavy forearm of his\r\nopponent. A hand raked out at Larry, a hand with six fingers, each of\r\nwhich was tipped with long, cutting talons. Larry moved his head aside\r\nbarely in time. The talons raked across his cheek, drawing blood. If he\r\nhadn\'t ducked, the cut would have ripped his throat open.\r\n\r\nThe Dornellian\'s other hand slashed out. Larry blocked it with his own\r\narm and sent a hard left to the midsection of the eight-foot monster.\r\n\r\nThe Dornellian backed away, snarling. The fight was on for real, now.\r\n"Little Earthman, I\'m going to kill you!"\r\n\r\nHe leaped in suddenly, and his fist smashed against Larry\'s face. Larry\r\nrolled with the blow, but it brought the taste of blood to his mouth.\r\n\r\nHis feet moving fast, the Earthman bobbed back away from the giant.\r\nHe felt a glow of pleasure within himself. Here was his chance to\r\npractice a little with a Dornellian! What better training was there for\r\na championship bout than a barroom brawl? He had to watch out for those\r\nclaws though--those deadly razors that sprouted from the Dornellian\'s\r\nfingertips.\r\n\r\nTwo other Dornellians started to move in, but an Aldebaranian--a huge\r\nreptilian beast, slow-moving but powerful--stepped in front of them.\r\n\r\n"Keep back," he hissed, in his snakelike voice. "This is a personal\r\nquarrel."\r\n\r\nLarry heard an Arcturian spider-man click his mandibles together and\r\nwhisper: "Yes, let the Earthman fight it out by himself."\r\n\r\nLarry wasn\'t too worried. 

He had fought to the death on half a hundred\r\nplanets, and hadn\'t been killed yet. An ordinary Dornellian didn\'t\r\nbother him much. He moved in confidently for the knockout.\r\n\r\nHis fist lashed out, but his opponent was even faster. Larry connected\r\nwith nothing but empty air, and the Dornellian\'s claws raked down his\r\nside as the other hand slammed against the side of his head.\r\n\r\nDazed, Larry danced back. His arm was dripping blood, and his head felt\r\ngroggy and heavy.\r\n\r\nThe Dornellian threw a left jab, and Larry blocked it with his own left\r\narm. But the giant had done something unexpected. Instead of striking\r\nwith his closed fist, he had suddenly extended his fingers. The sharp\r\nclaws stabbed deep into the muscle of the Earthman\'s forearm, sending a\r\nwave of pain to his shoulder.\r\n\r\nAgain Larry backed away, his arm aching from the wounds. Quickly, he\r\nreversed his direction and stepped back in. This time, he used a kick\r\nbut the Dornellian sidestepped. The toe of Larry\'s boot caught his hip.\r\nCursing, the Dornellian closed in.\r\n\r\nHe punched a hand forward, claws extended. Larry stepped to one side\r\nand grabbed the hairy wrist. Using the giant\'s strength and weight\r\nto his own advantage, he propelled the monster across the room,\r\nslamming him up against the bar. Then he leaped forward to smash in the\r\nDornellian\'s ribcage with his heavy boots.\r\n\r\nHe was not quick enough. The giant rolled aside and sprang to his feet.\r\nSnarling viciously, he advanced toward the Earthman.\r\n\r\nOne hand came down in a hard, chopping blow. Then Larry remembered\r\nthat the Dornellian nervous system wasn\'t much like an Earthman\'s; the\r\nnerves just weren\'t in the same places.\r\n\r\nBut where were they? Again he cursed Blackmer. The manager hadn\'t told\r\nhim anything about Dornellians, had let him sign for the fight with\r\nFornax Kedrin even though it would be sheer murder.\r\n\r\n_Well_, Larry thought somberly, _I\'ll learn tonight. If I ever get out\r\nof this bar alive._\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe took a deep breath and glanced at the giant, who had recovered from\r\nLarry\'s onslaught. He\r\nturned away, mopping his face clean, and started to pick up his\r\nunfinished beer when the wailing of sirens echoed through the bar.\r\n\r\nPolice! Someone had called the Dornellian police!\r\n\r\nThe Arcturian spider-man sidled up to him. "Well done, Earthman," he\r\nsaid in his whispering voice. As\r\nwell trust the Arcturian as anyone; if the police caught him, his life\r\nwouldn\'t be worth a counterfeit credit.\r\n\r\nNo one tried to stop him as he ran out the door.\r\n\r\nThe Arcturian\'s car was waiting just outside. Frankly, I was surprised.

"\r\n\r\n"So was I," Larry said. "I don\'t know why I\'m bothering to run away.\r\nAll they\'ll have to do is pick me up at my hotel."\r\n\r\nThe Arcturian chuckled dryly. 

"No. I don\'t think anyone recognized you.\r\nDon\'t forget that all Earthmen look alike to other beings. The only\r\nreason I knew who you were is that I\'m a fan of yours. I was glad to\r\nsee you beat that Dornellian, believe me."\r\n\r\n"Thanks," Larry said. "But it\'s not going to do me any good when I get\r\ninto the ring against Fornax Kedrin. If an ordinary Dornellian citizen\r\nputs up a fight like that, what am I going to do against a professional\r\nboxer?"\r\n\r\nThe Arcturian laughed again. "Just get in there and fight, Filmore. You\r\ncan handle him. 

I\'m sure you can."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe car pulled up before the hotel where Larry and his manager were\r\nstaying, and Larry got out. His last thought before he blacked out was that he\'d get\r\ninto the ring and do his best. He\'d already beaten _one_ Dornellian;\r\nhow tough could Fornax Kedrin be? He\r\nwas bound to get killed sooner or later anyway. You here?"\r\n\r\nThe manager\'s bed had been slept in, but there was no sign of him.\r\nLarry groped for the house phone, grabbed it, spoke into it. "Do you\r\nknow where Mr. 

Blackmer is?"\r\n\r\n"He\'s in the bar, sir," said the switchboard boy. "Do you want me to\r\ncall him for you?"\r\n\r\n"Yes, please."\r\n\r\nA moment later, Larry heard the manager\'s harsh voice. "And after I get through\r\nwith the Dornellian, I\'m going to knock your teeth in. This is my last\r\nfight for you."\r\n\r\n"Now Larry," Blackmer said. "Don\'t be hasty. I--"\r\n\r\n"Shut up! Nobody knows who did it. But I got another bout lined\r\nup on Domerang VI with--"\r\n\r\n"Skip it," Larry said. "I\'ll discuss it with you some other time."\r\n\r\nLarry slowly dropped the receiver back on the hook. 

He grinned. And\r\nthen he began to laugh.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nThere was nothing special about the little man who came into Larry\'s\r\nplace, unless it might have been his air of vague familiarity and the\r\nmixed expression on his face. He looked disgusted and defensive and at\r\nthe same time a little resentful, with a dash of something else thrown\r\nin which none of us recognized until later.\r\n\r\nI\'d have mistaken him for another reporter from the _Advertiser_\r\nacross the street if the five newsmen already at the bar hadn\'t given\r\neach other a blank look that meant only one thing: none of them knew\r\nhim. Neither did Larry, who was trying to bring in the first broadcast\r\nfrom Mars on the television set bracketed to the wall over his whiskey\r\nstock, and who wasn\'t pleased at having his little after-hours party\r\ncrashed.\r\n\r\n"The bar\'s closed," Larry said. His tone didn\'t invite argument. 

"City\r\nordinance. No customers after 1:00 a.m."\r\n\r\nThe little man looked at the clock, which said 3:15, and then at the\r\nfront windows which were shuttered tight. Then he looked at the six of\r\nus sitting at the bar with our drinks.\r\n\r\n"I\'ll have bourbon and water," he said. He sat down at the end of the\r\nbar on the stool next to mine and looked at his reflection in the\r\nmirror without approval.\r\n\r\nLarry got the look that bartenders get with troublesome customers.\r\n\r\n"The bar\'s closed," he said again. "It\'s a city--"\r\n\r\n"Water on the side," the little man said. "Don\'t mix it."\r\n\r\nAbe Marker, who does sports for the _Advertiser_, got up and checked\r\nthe front-door lock. The thumb-catch hadn\'t been thrown, so Abe put it\r\non and came back to the bar.\r\n\r\n"Nobody else will wander in," he said. "Make with the t-v, Larry.\r\nYou\'re holding up the show."\r\n\r\nLarry looked stubborn.\r\n\r\n"It\'s after 1:00 a.m.," he said. 

"And that door was supposed to be\r\nlocked. There\'s a city ordinance--"\r\n\r\n"You\'re breaking it already," the little man said, looking at us. He\r\ndidn\'t seem angry, just weary and disgusted. 

"Not that I give a damn.\r\nAll I want is a bourbon and water."\r\n\r\n"Better give it to him, Larry," Willard Saxton said from down the bar.\r\nWillard is the _Advertiser\'s_ science editor and is an authority on the\r\nplanets, especially Mars. "He\'ll probably turn you in if you throw him\r\nout."\r\n\r\nLarry muttered and looked mulish, but he rang up the little man\'s money\r\nand gave him a bourbon and water. The little guy drank it and looked\r\nat himself in the bar mirror with an expression that was just short\r\nof being a sneer. Larry grunted and went back to fiddling with the\r\ntelevision set.\r\n\r\nAbe Marker came over and sat down on the stool to my left.\r\n\r\n"They\'re doing this all over town tonight," he said, explaining to the\r\nlittle man across me. "The bars have to observe curfew as usual, but\r\nmost of them are letting a few regular customers stay late to see the\r\nMarscast. Everybody is anxious to know what Colonel Sanderson and his\r\ncrew found up there, so--"\r\n\r\n"They\'re going to be disappointed," the little man said. 

He sounded\r\nsour but positive. "Mars ain\'t what people think it is, not by a hell\r\nof a sight. It stinks."\r\n\r\nWe all looked up at that, and somebody snickered.\r\n\r\n"Have you been to Mars, sir?"\r\n\r\nThe little man didn\'t seem to mind when we laughed.\r\n\r\n"Maybe," he said, and shoved his shot glass forward. "Another bourbon,\r\nbartender."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe station announcer came on screen then and told us what we already\r\nknew, that contact with Colonel Sanderson\'s party was delayed because\r\nof transmission difficulties. The Sanderson expedition would leave Mars\r\nfor Earth in two more days, when the current opposition was completed,\r\nbut in the meantime the program sponsors appreciated the interest shown\r\nby their public and would relay the broadcast to us as soon as contact\r\nwas established.\r\n\r\nA film cartoon featuring a lizard named Freddie came on next, and Larry\r\nturned down the sound so he could hear orders for refills. The little\r\nman drank his bourbon and water and sneered at his reflection in the\r\nmirror; none of us paid him any further attention, but talk started up\r\nagain along the bar.\r\n\r\nSomebody at the other end asked how long it took a television signal\r\nto travel across all that space, and choked on his drink when Willard\r\nSaxton told him.\r\n\r\n"My God," he said when he stopped coughing. "You mean Mars is so far\r\naway it takes three minutes just to _see_ it?"\r\n\r\nAll of us laughed at that but Larry and the little man at the end of\r\nthe bar.\r\n\r\n"What I\'m wondering," somebody else said, "Is how the colonel and his\r\nboys feel after breathing nothing but canned air for a year."\r\n\r\n"Maybe the air up there is better than our scientists think," Abe\r\nMarker said. He winked at us and looked at the little man on my right.\r\n"How about it, friend? Is the air good on Mars?"\r\n\r\n"Breathable, but not good," the little guy said. 

"It smells like dead\r\nfish."\r\n\r\nSilence fell along the bar while we waited for a straight man to raise\r\nhis head.\r\n\r\nWillard Saxton took the bait. "And why should it smell so, may I ask?"\r\n\r\n"Because Mars is lousy with fish," the little man said. "And because\r\nwhen fish die, they stink."\r\n\r\nLarry did a brisk business for a few minutes while we sized the little\r\nguy up again. He definitely wasn\'t drunk, but the task of deciding\r\nwhether he was being dead-pan-comic or just nasty was a sort of\r\nchallenge that called for thought.\r\n\r\n"But you\'d need extensive oceans to support so many fish," Willard\r\nSaxton argued, still taking it seriously. "And if Mars had oceans we\'d\r\nhave seen them long ago. They reflect light."\r\n\r\n"Mars is too level for oceans," the little man said. "The water spreads\r\nout thin to make one big marsh, and you can\'t see it because the weeds\r\nthat grow up from the bottom camouflage it."\r\n\r\nSomebody down the bar said, "This gets curiouser and curiouser," and\r\neverybody laughed again but Willard and Larry and the little comic.\r\nSomebody else asked if he was a professional and what show was he on,\r\nbut he didn\'t answer. He just pushed his shot glass forward instead.\r\n\r\n"Another bourbon," he said.\r\n\r\nThe announcer came on screen again when the lizard cartoon went off\r\nand said that the Mars party\'s signal was beginning to come through\r\nand that as soon as it cleared up they would put it on the cable. Then\r\nhe told us about a new kind of pretzel prepared with a special salt\r\nguaranteed not to give us hardening of the arteries, and after that we\r\nhad another film cartoon. This one was about two crows at a circus, but\r\nnobody could follow it because Larry turned down the sound again.\r\n\r\nBetween his third and fourth stingers Willard Saxton--who had a\r\nreputation to uphold, being science editor of the _Advertiser_--had\r\nmade up his mind by now to put the little man in his place. Spectroanalysis findings--"\r\n\r\n"A spectroanalysis of Earth from Mars," the little man said, "shows\r\nnothing beyond our Heaviside layer, and proves that we can\'t live here\r\nbecause nothing can breathe pure ozone."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nHe finished his bourbon and made chains of wet rings on the bartop with\r\nhis glass. The mixed look on his face was so strong that for a moment I\r\nalmost thought of the name for it.\r\n\r\nWillard stalled for time by ordering another stinger--a double, this\r\ntime--and Abe Marker took over.\r\n\r\n"How about those pictures of Martian dust storms the boys at Palomar\r\nmake?" Abe asked. "You can\'t have dust storms on a marshy planet, can\r\nyou?"\r\n\r\n"Those aren\'t dust storms," the little man said. "They\'re clouds of\r\ngnats."\r\n\r\n"_Gnats?_" we all said at once, and somebody down the bar,\r\nquicker-witted than the rest of us, added: "Gnats to you too, Charlie!"\r\n\r\n"A fact," the little man said, but not as if he cared. 

"They travel in\r\nswarms thousands of miles wide, and they bite like hell."\r\n\r\nWe sat and watched the two voiceless crows flap through the television\r\ncartoon for a while. Nobody spoke until the film was over and the\r\nscreen went blank, when the little man caught Larry\'s eye and held up\r\none finger.\r\n\r\n"Bourbon," he said.\r\n\r\nWe heard a confused muttering of voices in the background and waited\r\nexpectantly for Colonel Sanderson to speak to us from Mars, but\r\napparently the network people were still having trouble with their\r\ntransmission beam. The screen stayed blank.\r\n\r\n"You left out the interesting part, Charlie," somebody called from down\r\nthe bar. "The Martian natives. How about them?"\r\n\r\n"There aren\'t any--as you\'d know them," the little man said. He seemed\r\nto grow thoughtful for a moment. "But they are intelligent. They do\r\nthings you couldn\'t do."\r\n\r\n"Such as what?" somebody asked.\r\n\r\nThe little man shrugged. "Teleport. They\'re good at it too."\r\n\r\nSaxton let out a laugh. "That would make them more intelligent than\r\nus!" he said. "What do these Martians look like?"\r\n\r\nThe little man screwed up his face distastefully. "Frogs."\r\n\r\nThe reporter who had asked about natives got choked on his drink and\r\nhad to be pounded on the back. On my left, Abe Marker leaned against\r\nthe bar to look past me at the little guy.\r\n\r\n"Frogs we got now," he said admiringly. "By the billions?"\r\n\r\n"There are more frogs on Mars," the little man said, "than there are\r\ngnats and fish together, and they never stop croaking. You\'d have to\r\nhear it to believe it."\r\n\r\nThe television screen lit up suddenly, chopping off conversation, and\r\nwe were watching the first Marscast in history.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nColonel Sanderson himself was talking. He looked the way Stanley must\r\nhave looked when he found Livingstone, gaunt and bearded and jumpy; and\r\nhis crew, lined up behind him before the ship\'s pickup camera, were in\r\nno better shape. The lot of them stared hungrily out at us as if they\r\nhad just found a peephole into Heaven and couldn\'t wait to see if\r\nthere was a gate farther along the fence.\r\n\r\n"... established conceptions of Martian areography are completely\r\nerroneous," the colonel was saying. "There are no drifting deserts\r\nof sand or howling typhoons of ferrous dust. We can show you actual\r\nconditions better by camera, I think, than they could be detailed in\r\nwords."\r\n\r\nThe view jumped to another camera aimed from an outside port, and we\r\nsaw Mars. Colonel Sanderson\'s voice kept up a running commentary behind\r\nthe scene, but we only half heard him.\r\n\r\nThe ship rested in about two feet of water. Around it the whole world\r\ncurved up to the horizon in a shallow concave sweep like the inside of\r\na great rusty bowl, lined with knee-high reeds that grew as far as the\r\neye could see out of a knee-deep marsh. A fist-sized sun hung low in\r\nthe sky, its glare dulled to a muddy crimson by a shimmering cloud of\r\ngnats that whirled and danced to infinity. There was a sort of vast,\r\nfeatureless roaring in the background that sounded like Niagara at two\r\nhundred yards, not deafening but loud enough to force Colonel Sanderson\r\nto raise his voice.\r\n\r\n"The frog noise is worst," he was saying. "It drives us to the point\r\nof insanity at times.... One member of our party has succumbed to it\r\nalready, a machinist named Willkins who disappeared two weeks ago.\r\nApparently the poor fellow drowned himself in the marsh, since no trace\r\nof him has been found since."\r\n\r\nThat was when I realized why the little man on the stool beside me\r\nlooked so familiar--because I had seen his pictures in the papers,\r\nalong with the rest of Sanderson\'s crew, a thousand times during the\r\npast year. The mixed expression on his face made sense now, too; he\r\nwasn\'t only disgusted and defensive, he was _guilty_.\r\n\r\n"So that\'s how you knew what it was like," I said. "You couldn\'t stick\r\nit out with the others, so you jumped ship. You deserted!"\r\n\r\nHe gave me a hangdog look. "It\'s not deserting unless the country is at\r\nwar," he said. "It\'s just going over the hill, A.W.O.L."\r\n\r\nThe television roar got louder, and when I looked up the ship\'s\r\ncameraman was doing a close-up for our benefit. He panned the shot\r\ndownward until we seemed to be standing ten feet above the marsh, and\r\nat that distance I could see plainly what it was that caused the uproar.\r\n\r\nThe water between the reddish-brown reeds was thick with huge frogs,\r\nall blinking and croaking like mad.\r\n\r\nI remember thinking then that you couldn\'t really blame a man for\r\njumping ship in a hole like that. It was bad enough to be stuck\r\nthirty-odd million miles from home, so far that light itself needed\r\nthree minutes to--\r\n\r\n"Hey, wait up!" I said to the little guy, who was sneering at himself\r\nin the mirror again. "If you went A.W.O.L. up there, then how the hell\r\ndid you get back _here_?"\r\n\r\nI didn\'t find out.\r\n\r\nThe guy was gone. He had been standing there so close I could have\r\ntouched him, but now he was gone. I looked around quick. 

Nobody else\r\nseemed to have noticed. All eyes were on the TV screen.\r\n\r\nThen I saw it. On the floor. Two wet marks--right where the guy should\r\nhave been, where he _was_. Two wet marks that had a funny shape to\r\nthem--web-like.\r\n\r\nI felt my throat tighten at the thought. I shook my head. 

What was\r\ngoing through it was fantastic, impossible and downright lunacy. There\r\nwas an intelligent life-form on Mars--beings that looked like frogs\r\nand could teleport. Could they also mimic human shape temporarily?\r\nEspecially if they got hold of one for a model--say a missing\r\ncrewman....\r\n\r\n"Hey! Where are you going? 

Don\'t you want to see the Marscast?"\r\n\r\nI was walking to the door. I looked back at the barkeep. "I\'ve seen\r\nenough, Larry, I got things to do."\r\n\r\nHe shrugged. 

"Yeh, what?

"\r\n\r\n"Like hunting frogs," I told him as I shoved the door open. "I got a\r\nhunch we\'ll be doing a lot of that before very long...."\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nGod knows I didn\'t want Hacker in the preliminary delegation right from\r\nthe start. I wasn\'t thinking, either, of the screwball ways history can\r\ngo about poetically repeating itself sometimes. I just knew that an\r\nuppity, smart-alecky kid of fifty could only cause trouble.\r\n\r\nHe already had.\r\n\r\nRayna had been our earlier landfall on the First Interstellar\r\nExpedition. It possessed a fairly intelligent form of life, even if\r\nthe Raynans were oviparous and technologically retarded. Hacker had\r\ntaken over the bulldozer to clear the area around our craft, _Terra I_,\r\nand he had been repeatedly told to stay very close to it. But no, he\r\ninsisted on flattening out the peat-like top of the nearest hill too.\r\nUnfortunately that hilltop was an incubation bed for Raynan fledglings.\r\nThe massacre involved not only a vast number of hatching eggs but five\r\nadult females, and we had to get away pronto while thousands of paper\r\nlimbs waved threateningly at the murderers from Earth.\r\n\r\nI\'m only the Science Chronicler of this expedition but Dr. Barnes is\r\nChief Medical Officer. His protests should have mattered where mine\r\ndidn\'t. "I\'m a hundred per cent behind Johnson," he told Captain\r\nWeber. "That kid\'s no damned good. The three of us will go into town\r\nwith these Newtaneans and, sure as I\'m standing here, Hacker will do\r\nsomething wrong."\r\n\r\nCaptain Weber, looking worried as usual, tried to explain. "He\'ll\r\njust do the chauffeuring." But he got off that tack immediately when\r\nhe saw we were not following along. "Look, I know he\'s a pest. But\r\nthis is a political matter, for the good of the Space Corps. His\r\ngreat-great-uncle is President of the World Council. For all I know the\r\nold man hates his guts, won\'t listen to a word he says, but let\'s not\r\ntake any chances. 

We\'re going to need plenty of these expeditions. 

And\r\nhyper-drive craft take an awful lot out of the economy."\r\n\r\nThe upshot of the matter was that we patriotically agreed to the setup.\r\nThe captain gave Hacker a good chewing-out about respecting the rights\r\nof the Newtaneans.\r\n\r\nThe kid turned out to be surprisingly amenable on that score. "They\'re\r\n_human_!" he said, and I could see he was very sincere about it. "I\r\nwouldn\'t do anything to hurt them, sir. 

What\'s more, they must be\r\nalmost as smart as we are and I\'m not about to commit suicide."\r\n\r\nSo the three of us got into the jeep and rolled out of _Terra I_ onto\r\nNewtane\'s soil.\r\n\r\nI still felt uncomfortable about Hacker, though. He had tasted blood\r\non Rayna and the effect of that on him had been unusually bad; he had\r\nacquired a reckless attitude toward the rights of intelligent life,\r\nhis own included.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAs if to prove me wrong, he drove very carefully over the special\r\nroad the Newtaneans had laid out overnight from our landing area\r\nto the highway a mile or so away. The three carloads of scowling\r\nplenipotentiaries up ahead looked appealingly funny. While the\r\nNewtaneans were remarkably, even handsomely, like us (except for a\r\ncertain closeness of the eyes and a reversed ordering of their fingers)\r\ntheir facial muscles carried different emotional convictions. On our\r\nlanding ten hours before those officials had thought our smiling faces\r\nindicated angry aggressiveness and we had been equally uncertain about\r\ntheir intentions. But their Semanticizer had eventually made the true\r\nstate of affairs clear. Evolution had determined that an upward set of\r\nNewtanean facial muscles meant a bad situation, a downward set pleasure\r\nand cordiality. The more they scowled the more we smiled and everybody\r\nwas very happy about the potential flowering of transgalactic culture\r\nthat we were instituting.\r\n\r\nWhen we turned onto the magnificent superhighway, however, Hacker\r\nbecame furious. He kept trying to pull over to the right but a steady\r\nstream of scarab-shaped cars, filled with curious sightseers, kept\r\ngetting in his way.\r\n\r\n"This is crazy," he cried.\r\n\r\n"I think they drive on the left here," Dr. Barnes tried to explain.\r\n\r\n"That\'s what I mean--they\'re crazy!"\r\n\r\n"They did it that way in England for centuries," I said. "It took a\r\nlong time to get them to change."\r\n\r\n"Fine, fine." Suddenly he laughed, as if pleased with his capacity\r\nfor tolerance. "If it\'s good enough for them it\'s good enough for us\r\nvisitors. They sure know how to build beautiful roads!"\r\n\r\nI suppose I should have been pleased with this shift toward good\r\nhumor but I wasn\'t. I just could not like the youngster. He had been\r\nforgivably cocky for his age before, but now something nasty had been\r\nadded.\r\n\r\nStill, he remained on his best behavior as we approached Crona, the\r\ncapital city. Its golden towers gleamed in the sun and everywhere there\r\nwere crowds of beautiful tan people, waving to us and happily scowling\r\ntheir welcome.\r\n\r\nThe lead cars stopped before a particularly elegant skyscraper that was\r\nset in the middle of vast, symmetrical gardens. We got out and were\r\ngreeted by dignitaries accompanied by technicians with Semanticizing\r\nequipment. (If this equipment worked slowly, it was still faster than\r\nany we\'d developed.) The men who came toward us were puzzled when we\r\nextended our hands but, once the translation came through and they\r\nunderstood it was an Earth custom, they copied our gesture. Only they\r\nall put out their left hands. It took a while before reasonable contact\r\ncould be made.\r\n\r\n"Interesting," said Dr. Barnes. "They all seem to be left-handed."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t see what\'s so interesting about that," Hacker snorted through\r\nhis puggish nose. "I\'ve seen left-handed people on Earth."\r\n\r\n"Good for you," the doctor answered drily.\r\n\r\nHacker looked a little annoyed but for once managed to keep quiet.\r\n\r\nI explained to the receiving delegation how hyper-radio contact could\r\nbe established with our system for information exchanges and then told\r\nthem tomorrow\'s group from _Terra I_ would be much larger. It would\r\nbe in a position to set out the technical arrangements in all the\r\nnecessary detail.\r\n\r\nThe dialogue crept along as translations were made, but finally an\r\nespecially regal figure stepped forward and told us the rest of the\r\nproceedings would take place within the building. We followed the\r\nNewtaneans into a hall so vast that we still seemed to be outdoors.\r\nSubtle colors were playing free-form patterns on the walls and the\r\nsynesthetic reaction was that of hearing a music too beautiful, too\r\nperfect, for the relative crudity of the human ear to grasp alone.\r\n"This," Hacker laughed, "is my idea of heaven!"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI wasn\'t about to unbend and openly agree with him on anything. 

But\r\ncelestial it really was. And then the subtly rich smells of the food\r\nbegan to play on our nostrils. It was brought out on great automatic\r\nservers and robot arms set heaping, steaming plates before the fifty\r\nNewtaneans. We, of course, had to refuse, taking out our compacted\r\nrations and setting them before us.\r\n\r\nAll the Newtaneans were still meat-eaters. The main course was a small\r\nfowl, thoroughly browned in gravy. For me the most interesting thing\r\nabout it was that four drumstick legs stuck out of each torso rather\r\nthan the regulation two found on all earth-based birds. For Hacker,\r\nthough, a more practical matter was involved.\r\n\r\n"I\'d sure like to try a helping of that bird," he said.\r\n\r\nThe two of us, naturally, were shocked. "That must have been a living\r\ncreature once," said Barnes.\r\n\r\n"So what?"\r\n\r\n"Well, our civilization is essentially vegetarian. They just haven\'t\r\nreached our level as yet in that respect.

"\r\n\r\n"Nuts loaf to you!" Hacker snapped. "And synthetic yeast pie too! I\'ve\r\neaten flesh.

"\r\n\r\nThat _really_ upset me. I know there\'s still a little surreptitious\r\nmeat-consumption on Earth--genetics shows we must get a few throwbacks\r\nin every generation--but I\'d never before met anyone who openly boasted\r\nabout it. Synthetic foods meet gourmet needs better than traditional\r\nones do anyway. (Of course, I don\'t mean the dull compacted stuff\r\nwe get on long space hops but the food served on Terran planets\r\nthemselves.) Any Earthman eating flesh back home is deliberately trying\r\nto taste the atavistic sensations of savagery.\r\n\r\n"You know how immoral that is," I told him.\r\n\r\n"Hacker, let\'s forget the moral issue," Barnes said, considering him\r\nwith disgust. "Let\'s just be sensible. 

We don\'t know enough about\r\nNewtane yet to eat _anything_."\r\n\r\nHacker laughed. "Why, it smells just like our own food, only better."\r\nHe picked at his vita-concentrate. "Oh, let\'s forget about the whole\r\nthing.

"\r\n\r\nWe tried to. Several dignitaries rose to their full seven feet and\r\nspoke slowly into Semanticizers, flinging their queer hands out for\r\nemphasis with their thumbs waving where our pinkies do. Suddenly,\r\nthough, Hacker got up from his seat and hurried down the long table to\r\nthe place where the leading spokesman was eating. He leaned over him,\r\nspeaking into the nearest translator, and I could see the Newtanean\r\nsmiling broadly, as if trying to refuse something, while Hacker\r\nfrowned. Finally the smile faded into a friendly scowl. Nothing good\r\ncould be coming out of this.\r\n\r\nA minute later a robot arm proffered a loaded plate to Hacker and he\r\nstarted back to us with it. Barnes rose to stop him, but before Hacker\r\nreached us he had taken two mouthfuls of the meat.\r\n\r\nI have never seen such sheer self-satisfied delight on a human face as\r\nafter those first bites.\r\n\r\n"You shouldn\'t be doing that," Barnes said when he sat down next to us\r\nagain.\r\n\r\n"You\'re just old fogies," Hacker grunted through a meat-stuffed mouth.\r\n"This is the best food I\'ve ever eaten."\r\n\r\nHe somehow shoveled another load of meat between his lips.\r\n\r\nThirty seconds later his face twisted into a caricature of the human\r\nphysiognomy, all writhing lines, as if every muscle were breaking loose\r\nfrom its neighbors. The last unswallowed portion of food erupted from\r\nhis mouth and he fell forward into the vile mess.\r\n\r\nHe was dead.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nPandemonium spread through the hall. Everywhere wildly smiling faces\r\nexpressed despair at such an end for an honored guest. Barnes sprang\r\ninto action, pulling the portable medical kit from his belt and\r\nimmediately starting blood tests while some native doctors joined him\r\nwith their emergency equipment. "Must start revitalizing immediately,"\r\nhe said, then stopped, ashen-faced, as he studied an analyzer tube.\r\n"Fantastic! No, it can\'t be!"\r\n\r\nThe Newtaneans were equally bewildered. They rushed Hacker to a nearby\r\ntreatment chamber. All I could do was wait, while the Newtanean leader\r\nexplained that Hacker had told him we had authorized his trying the\r\nfood. There was no need to doubt his story. 

It was just what the\r\nkid would have done. I did my best to assure him that we knew his\r\nintentions had been honorable.\r\n\r\nA half-hour later Barnes returned, a robot platform following with\r\nHacker, body covered by a preservative glaze, on it.\r\n\r\n"Nothing can be done," he said. "I\'ve tried everything. Hacker\'s too\r\nthoroughly dead for anything ever to bring him back. We\'ll just have to\r\ntake his body home for further study."\r\n\r\n"But what killed him?" I demanded.\r\n\r\n"A dozen or so things out of a thousand possibilities."\r\n\r\n"You mean you don\'t have any idea?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, I have _some_ idea. Too many ideas in fact. Look, Johnson,\r\nchemistry\'s not your specialty but this is fairly elementary. All life\r\ncontains protein, right?"\r\n\r\n"Right."\r\n\r\n"And all protein consists of amino acids. _Every_ natural protein\r\nback home is built on levo--left turn--amino acids. Here it is just\r\nthe opposite, the mirror image of what we know. Every amino acid is\r\ndextro--to the right!"\r\n\r\n"But how can it be different here?"\r\n\r\n"Johnson, they could ask the same question about us with equal\r\njustification--or, rather, equal lack of justification."\r\n\r\nI was trying to feel my way through the confusion. "Barnes, I know a\r\nworld could be made of anti-matter but--"\r\n\r\n"No, no. Anti-matter is a reversal of changes within the atom.\r\nThese atoms are the same as ours. It\'s the organization that is\r\ndifferent--regular molecules with a different twist."\r\n\r\n"But why should it have killed him then? We absorb starch and reject\r\ncellulose which is closely related. But the body just refuses to accept\r\nthe cellulose. It doesn\'t necessarily go ahead and die."\r\n\r\n"Starch and cellulose are both dextro, old man. This is a more\r\nfundamental difference. 

Maybe the body just throws off some of these\r\ncompounds too. But there were some--plenty, I suspect--it couldn\'t\r\nthrow off." He glanced toward the stiffening corpse, sympathetically.\r\n\r\n"The poor kid couldn\'t leave well enough alone."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWell, we are two universal days out from Newtane and soon we will drop\r\nfrom hyper-drive as we reach the orbit of Pluto. I shouldn\'t still\r\nbe feeling as uneasy as I do. 

I\'m sure I shouldn\'t. We have had five\r\nfriendly, informative days with the people of a great civilization\r\nremarkably like ours, and President Hacker has radioed he understands\r\nperfectly that we were not responsible for the tragedy, nobody was. The\r\nkid, it seems, wasn\'t the apple of his eye anyway.\r\n\r\nNinety men and one corpse returning to the security of _terra firma_.\r\nI should, when all is said and done, be happy with the way most things\r\nhave worked out. But I am a Chronicler and I know the peculiarly\r\nsymbolic, seemingly superficial ways in which history manages to repeat\r\nitself.\r\n\r\nIt is more than three centuries since the last war on Earth between\r\nrightists and leftists. That was a matter of differing concepts of\r\neconomics and politics. I can\'t help wondering, though, whether there\r\nare not even more fundamental points of eventual conflict in the\r\nuniverse that we have barely discovered. If there are, I\'m beginning\r\nto suspect they\'ll still have something to do with the unfathomable\r\ndifference between Right and Left, a difference that took many lives\r\ncenturies ago--and may not be through with us yet.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\nThere is a small striped smelt called the grunion which has odd\r\negglaying habits. At high tide, on the second, third, and fourth nights\r\nafter the full of the moon from March to June, thousands of female\r\ngrunions ride in on the waves to a beach in southern California near\r\nSan Diego, dig tail-first into the soft sand, deposit their eggs, then\r\nride back on the wash of the next wave. The whole operation lasts about\r\nsix seconds.\r\n\r\nOn the nights when the grunion are running, hordes of people used to\r\ncome to the beach with baskets and other containers, and with torches\r\nto light the scene, and try to catch the elusive little fish in their\r\nhands.\r\n\r\nThey were doing that on an April night in 1960. In the midst of the\r\nexcitement of the chase, only a few of them noticed that something else\r\nwas riding the waves in with the grunions.\r\n\r\nAmong the few who stopped grunion-catching long enough to investigate\r\nwere a girl named Marge Hickin and a boy named Gene Towanda. They were\r\nUCLA students, "going together", who had come down on Saturday from Los\r\nAngeles for the fun.\r\n\r\n"What on earth do you think these can be, Gene?" Marge asked, holding\r\nout on her palms three or four of the little circular, wriggling\r\nobjects, looking like small-size doughnuts, pale straw in color.\r\n\r\n"Never saw anything like them," Gene admitted. "But then my major\'s\r\npsychology, not zoology. 

They don\'t seem to bite, anyway. Here let\'s\r\ncollect some of them instead of the fish. That dingus of yours will\r\nhold water. 

We can take them to the Marine Biology lab tomorrow and\r\nfind out what they are."\r\n\r\nMarge Hickin and Gene Towanda had started a world-wide economic\r\nrevolution.\r\n\r\nNone of the scientists at the university laboratory knew what the\r\nlittle live straw-colored circles were, either. In fact, after a\r\npreliminary study they wouldn\'t say positively whether the creatures\r\nwere animal or vegetable; they displayed voluntary movement, but they\r\nseemed to have no respiratory or digestive organs. They were completely\r\nanomalous.\r\n\r\nThe grunion ran again that night, and Gene and Marge stayed down to\r\nhelp the laboratory assistants gather several hundred of the strange\r\nnew objects for further study. They were so numerous that they were\r\nswamping the fish, and the crowds at the beach began to grumble that\r\ntheir sport was being spoiled.\r\n\r\nNext night the grunion stopped running--but the little doughnuts\r\ndidn\'t. They never stopped. They came in by hundreds of thousands every\r\nnight, and those which nobody gathered wriggled their way over the land\r\nuntil some of them even turned up on the highways (where a lot of them\r\nwere smashed by automobiles), on the streets and sidewalks of La Jolla,\r\nand as far north as Oceanside and as far south as downtown San Diego\r\nitself.\r\n\r\nThe things were becoming a pest. There were indignant letters to the\r\npapers, and editorials were written calling on the authorities to do\r\nsomething. 

Just what to do, nobody knew; the only way to kill the\r\ncircular little objects from the sea seemed to be to crush them--and\r\nthey were too abundant for that to be very effective.\r\n\r\nMeanwhile, the laboratory kept studying them.\r\n\r\nMarge and Gene were interested enough to come down again the next\r\nweekend to find out what, if anything, had been discovered. Not much\r\nhad: but one of the biochemists at the laboratory casually mentioned\r\nthat chemically the straw-colored circles seemed to be almost pure\r\nprotein, with some carbohydrates and fats, and that apparently they\r\ncontained all the essential vitamins.\r\n\r\nCollege student that he was, Gene Towanda immediately swallowed one of\r\nthe wriggling things down whole, as a joke.\r\n\r\nIt tickled a little, but that wasn\'t what caused the delighted\r\namazement on his face.\r\n\r\n"Gosh!" he exclaimed. 

"It\'s delicious!"\r\n\r\nHe swallowed another handful.\r\n\r\nThat was the beginning of the great _margene_ industry.\r\n\r\nIt was an astute reporter, getting a feature story on the sensational\r\nnew food find, who gave the creatures their name, in honor of the boy\r\nand girl who had first brought the things to the attention of the\r\nscientists. He dubbed them margenes, and margenes they remained.\r\n\r\n"Dr. O. Y. Willard, director of the laboratory," his story said in\r\npart, "thinks the margenes may be the answer to the increasing and\r\nalarming problem of malnutrition, especially in undeveloped countries.\r\n\r\n"\'For decades now,\' he said, \'scientists have been worried by the\r\ngrowing gap between world population and world food facilities.\r\nOver-farming, climatic changes caused by erosion and deforestation, the\r\nencroachment of building areas on agricultural land, and above all the\r\nunrestricted growth of population, greatest in the very places where\r\nfood is becoming scarcest and most expensive, have produced a situation\r\nwhere, if no remedy is found, starvation or semi-starvation may be the\r\nfate of half the Earth\'s people. The ultimate result would be the slow\r\ndegeneration and death of the entire human race.\r\n\r\n"\'Many remedies have been suggested,\' Dr. Willard commented further.\r\n\'They range from compulsory birth control to the production of\r\nsynthetic food, hydroponics, and the harvesting of plankton from the\r\noceans. Each of these presents almost insuperable difficulties.\r\n\r\n"\'The one ideal solution would be the discovery of some universal food\r\nthat would be nourishing, very cheap, plentiful, tasty, and that would\r\nnot violate the taboos of any people anywhere in the world. In the\r\nmargenes we may have discovered that food.\'\r\n\r\n"\'We don\'t know where the margenes came from,\' the director went on to\r\nsay, \'and we don\'t even know yet what they are, biologically speaking.\r\nWhat we do know is that they provide more energy per gram than any\r\nother edible product known to man, that everyone who has eaten them\r\nis enthusiastic about their taste, that they can be processed and\r\ndistributed easily and cheaply, and that they are acceptable even to\r\nthose who have religious or other objections to certain other foods,\r\nsuch as beef, among the Hindus or pork among the Jews and Mohammedans.\r\n\r\n"\'Even vegetarians can eat them,\' Dr. Willard remarked, \'since they are\r\ndecidedly not animal in nature. Neither, I may add, are they vegetable.\r\nThey are a hitherto utterly unknown synthesis of chemical elements in\r\nliving form. Their origin remains undiscovered.\'"\r\n\r\nNaturally, there was no thought of feeding people on raw margenes.\r\nOnly a few isolated places in either hemisphere would have found live\r\nfood agreeable. Experiment showed that the most satisfactory way to\r\nprepare them was to boil them alive, like crabs or lobsters. They could\r\nthen be ground and pressed into cakes, cut into convenient portions.\r\nOne one-inch-square cube made a nourishing and delicious meal for a\r\nsedentary adult, two for a man engaged in hard physical labor.\r\n\r\nAnd they kept coming in from the Pacific Ocean nightly, by the million.\r\n\r\nBy this time none of them had to be swept off streets or highways.
