The\r\nbeach where for nearly a century throngs had gathered for the sport of\r\ncatching grunion was off bounds now; it was the property of California\r\nMargene, Inc., a private corporation heavily subsidized by the Federal\r\nGovernment as an infant industry. The grunions themselves had to find\r\nanother place to lay their eggs, or die off--nobody cared which. The\r\nsand they had used for countless millennia as an incubator was hemmed\r\nin by factory buildings and trampled by margene-gatherers. The whole\r\nbeautiful shore for miles around was devastated; the university had\r\nto move its marine biological laboratory elsewhere; La Jolla, once a\r\ndelightful suburb and tourist attraction, had become a dirty, noisy\r\nhonkytonk town where processing and cannery workers lived and spent\r\ntheir off-hours; the unique Torrey Pines had been chopped down because\r\nthey interfered with the erection of a freight airport.\r\n\r\nBut half the world\'s people were living on margenes.\r\n\r\nThe sole possession of this wonderful foodstuff gave more power to\r\nthe United States than had priority in the atomic bomb. Only behind\r\nthe Iron Curtain did the product of California Margene, Inc. fail\r\nto penetrate. _Pravda_ ran parallel articles on the same day, one\r\nclaiming that margenes--_brzdichnoya_--had first appeared long ago on a\r\nbeach of the Caspian Sea and had for years formed most of the Russian\r\ndiet; the other warning the deluded nations receiving free supplies as\r\npart of American foreign aid that the margenes had been injected with\r\ndrugs aimed at making them weak and submissive to the exploitation of\r\nthe capitalist-imperialists.\r\n\r\nThere was a dangerous moment at the beginning when the sudden sharp\r\ndecline in stocks of all other food products threatened another 1929.\r\nBut with federal aid a financial crash was averted and now a new high\r\nlevel of prosperity had been established. Technological unemployment\r\nwas brief, and most of the displaced workers were soon retained for\r\njobs in one of the many ramifications of the new margene industry.\r\n\r\nAgriculture, of course, underwent a short deep depression, not only in\r\nAmerica but all over the world; but it came to an end as food other\r\nthan margenes quickly became a luxury product. Farmers were able to cut\r\ntheir production to a small fraction of the former yield, and to get\r\nrich on the dizzying prices offered for bread, apples, or potatoes.\r\nAnd this increased the prosperity of the baking and other related\r\nindustries as well.\r\n\r\nIn fact, ordinary food costs (which meant margene costs) were so low\r\nthat a number of the larger unions voluntarily asked for wage decreases\r\nin their next contracts. California Margene, Inc. was able to process,\r\npack, and distribute margene cakes at an infinitesimal retail price,\r\nby reason of the magnitude of the output.\r\n\r\nAn era of political good feeling fell upon the western world, reflected\r\nfrom the well-fed comfort of vast populations whose members never\r\nbefore in their lives had had quite enough to eat. The fear of famine\r\nseemed to be over forever, and with it the fear of the diseases and the\r\nsocial unrest that follow famine. 

Even the U.S.S.R. 

and its satellites,\r\nin a conciliatory move in the United Nations Assembly, suggested that\r\nthe long cold war ought to be amenable to a reasonable solution through\r\na series of amicable discussions. The western nations, assenting,\r\nguessed shrewdly that the Iron Curtain countries "wanted in" on the\r\nmargenes.\r\n\r\nMarge Hickin and Gene Towanda, who had started it all, left college\r\nfor copywriting jobs with the agency handling the enormous margene\r\npublicity; they were married a few months later.\r\n\r\nAnd the margenes continued to come in from the sea in countless\r\nmillions. They were being harvested now from the Pacific itself, near\r\nthe shoreline, before they reached the beach. Still no research could\r\ndiscover their original source.\r\n\r\nOnly a few scientists worried about what would happen if the margenes\r\nshould disappear as suddenly as they had arrived. Attempts at breeding\r\nthe creatures had failed completely. They did not undergo fission,\r\nthey did not sporulate, they seemed to have no sex. No methods of\r\nreproduction known in the plant or animal kingdom seemed to apply\r\nto them. Hundreds of them were kept alive for long periods--they\r\nlived with equal ease in either air or water, and they did not take\r\nnourishment, unless they absorbed it from their environment--but no\r\nsign of fertility ever appeared. Neither did they seem to die of\r\nnatural causes. They just kept coming in....\r\n\r\nOn the night of May 7, 1969, not a single margene was visible in the\r\nocean or on the beach.\r\n\r\nThey never came again.\r\n\r\nWhat happened as a result is known to every student of history. The\r\nworld-wide economic collapse, followed by the fall of the most stable\r\ngovernments, the huge riots that arose from the frantic attempts to\r\nget possession of the existing stocks of margene cakes or of the\r\nrare luxury items of other edibles, the announcement by the U.S.S.R.\r\nthat it had known from the beginning the whole thing was a gigantic\r\nAmerican hoax in the interests of the imperialistic bloodsuckers,\r\nthe simultaneous atomic attacks by east and west, the Short War of\r\n1970 that ruined most of what bombs had spared of the Earth, the slow\r\nstruggle back of the remnant of civilization which is all of existence\r\nyou and I have ever known--all these were a direct outgrowth of that\r\nfirst appearance of the margenes on the beach near San Diego on an\r\nApril night in 1960.\r\n\r\nMarge and Gene Towanda were divorced soon after they had both lost\r\ntheir jobs. She was killed in the hydrogen blast that wiped out San\r\nDiego; he fell in the War of 1970. "Margene" became a dirty word\r\nin every language on Earth. What small amount of money and ability\r\ncan be spared is, as everyone knows, devoted today to a desperate\r\ninternational effort to reach and colonize another habitable planet of\r\nthe Solar System, if such there be.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAs for the margenes, themselves, out of the untold millions that had\r\ncome, only a few thousand were lucky enough to survive and find their\r\nway back to their overcrowded starting-point. In their strange way of\r\ncommunication--as incomprehensible to us as would be their means of\r\nnourishment and reproduction, or their constitution itself--they made\r\nknown to their kin what had happened to them. There is no possibility,\r\nin spite of the terrific over-population of their original home and of\r\nthe others to which they are constantly migrating, that they will ever\r\ncome here again.\r\n\r\nThere has been much speculation, particularly among writers of science\r\nfiction, on what would happen if aliens from other planets should\r\ninvade Earth. Would they arrive as benefactors or as conquerors? Would\r\nwe welcome them or would we overcome and capture them and put them in\r\nzoos and museums? Would we meet them in friendship or with hostility?\r\n\r\nThe margenes gave us the answer.\r\n\r\nBeings from outer space came to Earth in 1960.\r\n\r\nAnd we ate them.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n             The humblest events sometimes result from the\r\n            most grandiose beginnings. You\'d never imagine\r\n             space travel starting this way, for instance!\r\n\r\n\r\nI suppose there\'s a guy like McCleary in every office.\r\n\r\nNow I\'m not a hard man to get along with and it usually takes quite a\r\nbit more than overly bright remarks from the office boy to bother me.\r\nBut try as I might, I could never get along with McCleary. To be as\r\ndisliked as he was, you have to work at it.\r\n\r\nWhat kind of guy was he? Well, if you came down to the office one day\r\nproud as Punch because of something little Johnny or Josephine had\r\nsaid, it was a sure cinch that McCleary would horn in with something\r\nhis little Louie had spouted off that morning. At any rate, when\r\nMcCleary got through, you felt like taking Johnny to the doctor to find\r\nout what made him subnormal.\r\n\r\nOr maybe you happened to buy a new Super-eight that week and were\r\nbragging about the mileage, the terrific pickup, and how quickly she\r\nresponded to the wheel. Leave it to McCleary to give a quick run-down\r\non his own car that would make you feel like selling yours for junk at\r\nthe nearest scrap heap.\r\n\r\nWell, you see what I mean.\r\n\r\nBut by far the worst of it was when vacation time rolled around. You\r\ncould forgive a guy for topping you about how brainy his kids are, and\r\nyou might even find it in your heart to forget the terrific bargain he\r\ndrove to work in. But vacation time was when he\'d really get on your\r\nnerves. _You_ could pack the wife and kids in Old Reliable and roll out\r\nto the lake for your two weeks in August. You might even break the bank\r\nand spend the two weeks at a poor man\'s Sun Valley. But no matter where\r\nyou went, when you came back, you\'d have to sit in silence and listen\r\nto McCleary\'s account of his Vacation in the Adirondacks, or his Tramp\r\nin the Canadian Wilds, or maybe even the Old French Quarter.\r\n\r\nThe trouble was he always had the photographs, the ticket stubs, and\r\nthe souvenirs to prove it. Where he got the money, I\'ll never know.\r\nSometimes I\'d tell the wife about it and she\'d sniff and wonder what\r\nkind of shabby house they lived in that they could afford all the other\r\nthings. I never looked him up myself. Tell you the truth, I was afraid\r\nI\'d find the McClearys lived on Park Avenue.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nNow you look forward to a vacation all year, but particularly during\r\nthe latter part of July, when, what with the heat and the stuffy\r\noffice, you begin to feel like a half-done hotdog at a barbecue. I was\r\nfeeling even worse than usual as I was faced with spending my two weeks\r\nin my own backyard, most of my vacation dough having gone to pay the\r\ndoctor. The only thing I minded was having McCleary find out about it\r\nand seeing that phony look of sympathy roll across his fat face while\r\nhe rambled on about the vacation _he_ was going to have.\r\n\r\nIt was lunch time and we had just finished talking about the latest on\r\ntelevision and what was wrong with the Administration and who\'d win the\r\npennant when Bob Young brought up the subject of vacations. It turned\r\nout he was due for a trip to the Ozarks and Donley was going after\r\nwall-eye pike in northern Wisconsin. I could sense McCleary prick up\r\nhis ears clear across the room.\r\n\r\n"How about you, Bill?" Donley asked me. "Got any plans?"\r\n\r\nI winked heavily and jerked a thumb warningly toward McCleary, making\r\nsure McCleary couldn\'t see the gesture.\r\n\r\n"My vacation is really going to be out of the world this time," I said.\r\n"Me and the wife are going to Mars. Dry, you know. Even better than\r\nArizona for her sinus."\r\n\r\nEven with the wink they were caught off guard for a minute.\r\n\r\n"Mars?" Donley said feebly, edging his chair away. "Yeah, sure. 

Great\r\nplace. Never been there myself, though.

"\r\n\r\nYoung just gaped, then grinned as he caught on. "I understand it\'s a\r\nwonderful spot," he chipped in.\r\n\r\nI casually peeled a hard-boiled egg the wife had packed in my lunch\r\nbucket and leaned back in my swivel chair. "It\'s really swell," I said\r\ndreamily, but loud enough so McCleary couldn\'t help but overhear.\r\n"Drifting down the Grand Canal at evening, the sun a faint golden disk\r\nbehind the crystal towers of Marsport...." I let my voice drift into a\r\nlong sigh and reached for Donley\'s sack of grapes.\r\n\r\nAbout this time McCleary had gnawed his way through a big pastrami\r\nsandwich and waddled over. He stood there expectantly, but we carefully\r\nignored him.\r\n\r\n"Always wanted to go myself," Donley said in the same tone of voice he\r\nwould have used to say he\'d like to go to California someday. "Pretty\r\nexpensive, though, isn\'t it?"\r\n\r\n"Expensive?" 

I raised a studiedly surprised eyebrow. "Oh, I suppose\r\na little, but it\'s worth it. The wife and I got a roomette on the\r\n_Princess of Mars_ for $139.50. That\'s one way, of course."\r\n\r\n"Mars!" Young sighed wistfully.\r\n\r\nThere was a moment of silence, with all three of us paying silent\r\ntribute to the ultimate in vacations. McCleary slowly masticated a leaf\r\nof lettuce, his initial look of suspicion giving way to half-belief.\r\n\r\n"Let\'s hear some more about it," Young said enthusiastically, suddenly\r\nrecovering from his reverie.\r\n\r\n"Oh, there isn\'t much more," I said indifferently. "We plan to stay at\r\nthe Redsands hotel in Marsport--American plan. Take in Marsport, with\r\nmaybe a side trip to Crystallite. If we have time we might even take a\r\nwaterway cruise to the North Pole...."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI broke off and dug Donley in the ribs.\r\n\r\n"Man, you never fished until you have a Martian flying fish at the end\r\nof the line!" I grabbed a ruler off the desk and began using it as an\r\nimaginary rod and reel. "Talk about fight ... oh, sorry, Mac." My ruler\r\nhad amputated part of a floppy lettuce leaf that hung from McCleary\'s\r\nsandwich.\r\n\r\nI settled down in my chair again and started paying attention to my\r\nlunch. "Nothing like it," I added between mouthfuls of liverwurst.\r\n\r\n"How about entertainment?" Young winked slyly.\r\n\r\n"Well, you know--the wife will be along," I said. "But some of the\r\nplaces near the Grand Canal--and those Martian Mist Maidens! Brother,\r\nif I was unattached...."\r\n\r\n"There ain\'t any life on Mars," McCleary said, suspicious again.\r\n\r\nAll three of us looked at him in shocked silence.\r\n\r\n"He says there\'s no life on Mars!" Donley repeated.\r\n\r\n"You ever been there, McCleary?" I asked sarcastically.\r\n\r\n"No, but just the same...."\r\n\r\n"All right," I cut in, "then you don\'t know whether there is or isn\'t.\r\nSo kindly reserve your opinion until you know a little about the\r\nsubject under discussion."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI turned back to Donley and Young.\r\n\r\n"Really a wonderful place for your health. Dry, thin air, nice and cool\r\nat night. 

And beautiful! From Marsport you can see low-slung mountains\r\nin the distance, dunes of soft, red sand stretching out to them. If\r\nI were you, Bob, I\'d forget all about the Ozarks and sign up on the\r\nrocket."\r\n\r\n"There ain\'t any rockets going to Mars," McCleary said obstinately.\r\n\r\n"Isn\'t," I corrected. "I mean, there is. Besides, McCleary, just\r\nbecause you never heard of something doesn\'t mean it doesn\'t exist."\r\n\r\n"The government\'s still working on V-2," McCleary said flatly. "They\r\nhaven\'t even reached the moon yet."\r\n\r\nI sighed softly, acting disgusted at having to deal with somebody as\r\nstupid as McCleary. "Mac, that\'s the government and besides they\'re\r\ndealing with military rockets. And did you ever hear of the government\r\nperfecting something before private industry? Who perfected the\r\ntelephone, the radio, television? The government? 

No, private industry,\r\nof course! Private industry has always been ahead of the government on\r\neverything, including rockets. Get on the stick, Mac."\r\n\r\nMcCleary started in on his lettuce leaf again, looking very shrewd.\r\n\r\n"How come I never heard of it before now?" he asked, springing the\r\nclincher argument.\r\n\r\n"Look, Mac, this is relatively new. The company\'s just starting, can\'t\r\nafford to take full-page ads and that sort of thing. Just give \'em\r\ntime, that\'s all. Why, a couple of years from now you\'ll be spending\r\nyour vacation on Venus or Jupiter or some place like that. From now on\r\nCalifornia and the Bahamas will be strictly old hat."\r\n\r\nMcCleary looked half-believing.\r\n\r\n"Where\'d you get your tickets?"\r\n\r\nI waved vaguely in the direction of downtown. "Oh, there must be at\r\nleast a couple of agencies downtown. Might even be able to find them in\r\nthe phone book. Look under _Interplanetary Rocket Lines_ or something\r\nlike that. You might have a little difficulty, of course. 

Like I say,\r\nthey\'re not too well advertised."\r\n\r\nMcCleary was about to say something more, but then the one o\'clock bell\r\nrang and we went back to the office grind.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWell, McCleary didn\'t say anything more about it the next day, even\r\nthough we\'d throw in a chance comment about Mars every now and then, as\r\nif it were the most natural thing in the world, but Mac didn\'t rise to\r\nthe bait. We gradually forgot about it.\r\n\r\nThe next couple of weeks came and went and then my two weeks in August.\r\nLike I said before, my vacation dough had gone to pay the doctor, so I\r\nstayed at home and watered the begonias.\r\n\r\nThe Monday morning after vacation, we were all back in the office, if\r\nanything looking more fagged than we had when we left. When lunch time\r\nrolled around, Donley and Young and I piled our lunches on Donley\'s\r\ndesk--his desk was near a window on the north side of the building\r\nso we could get the breeze--and talked about what we had done during\r\nvacation.\r\n\r\nMcCleary ambled up and like it usually does after McCleary comes\r\naround, the conversation just naturally died down. After a two minute\r\nsilence I finally took the hook.\r\n\r\n"Okay, Mac," I said, "I know you\'re just dying to tell us. Where did\r\nyou go?

"\r\n\r\nHe almost looked surprised. "To Mars," he said, like he might have said\r\nAunt Minnie\'s.\r\n\r\nThe three of us looked blank for a minute and then we caught on. It\r\ntook us a while to recover from laughing and my sides were still aching\r\nwhen I saw McCleary\'s face. It definitely had a hurt look on it.\r\n\r\n"You don\'t think I did," he accused us.\r\n\r\n"Oh, come off it, McCleary," I said crossly. "A gag\'s a gag, but it can\r\nbe carried too far. Where\'d you go? 

California, Oregon, some place like\r\nthat?"\r\n\r\n"I said I went to Mars," McCleary repeated hotly, "and I can prove it!"\r\n\r\n"Sure," I said. "Like I can prove the world\'s flat and it\'s supported\r\nby four elephants standing on a turtle\'s back like the old Greeks...."\r\n\r\nI cut off. McCleary had thrown a couple of pasteboards on the desk and\r\nI picked them up. The printing on it was like you see on a Pullman\r\nticket. It said something about a roomette, first-class passage on the\r\n_Martian Prince_, for $154.75, and there was even a place where they\r\nhad the tax figured. In two blanks at the top of the ticket, they had\r\nit filled out to _E. 

C. McCleary and wife_. The bottom half was torn\r\noff, just like they do with train tickets.\r\n\r\n"Very clever," I said, "but you shouldn\'t have gone to all that trouble\r\nto have these printed up."\r\n\r\nMcCleary scowled and dropped a little bunch of kodachrome slides on the\r\ndesk. 

I took one and held it up to the light. It showed Mac and his\r\nwife mounted on something that looked like a cross between a camel and\r\na zebra. They were at the top of a sand dune and in the distance you\r\ncould see the towers of a city. The funny thing was the towers looked a\r\nlittle--but not much--like minarets and the sand dunes were colored a\r\nbeautiful pink.\r\n\r\nI passed it on to Donley and Young and started leafing through the\r\nrest. They were beautiful slides. McCleary and spouse in front of\r\nvarious structures in a delicately tinted marble and crystal city.\r\nMcCleary in a pink-and-black boat on a canal that looked as wide as the\r\nMississippi. McCleary standing on a strangely carved sandstone parapet,\r\nadmiring a sunset caused by a sun looking half as big as ours. And\r\neverywhere were the dunes of pink sand.\r\n\r\n"Pictures can be faked, Mac," I said.\r\n\r\nHe looked hurt and got some things out of his desk--a sateen pillow\r\nwith scenes like those on his snapshots, an urn filled with pink sand,\r\na tiny boat like a gondola, only different, a letter opener made out\r\nof peculiar bubbly pink glass. They were all stamped "Souvenir of\r\nMars" and that kind of junk you don\'t have made up for a gag. I know\r\nmass-produced articles when I see them.\r\n\r\n"We couldn\'t afford the first-class tour," McCleary said expansively,\r\n"but I figure we can cover that next year." He turned to me puzzledly.\r\n"I asked the passenger agent about the _Princess of Mars_ and he said\r\nhe had never heard of the ship. And it\'s Mars City, not Marsport.\r\nCouldn\'t understand how you made a mistake."\r\n\r\n"It was easy," I said weakly. I pointed to the pasteboard ducats.\r\n"Where\'d you get these, Mac?"\r\n\r\nHe waved generously in the direction of downtown. "Like you said,\r\nthere\'s a couple of agencies downtown...."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nYou know, sometimes I think we misjudged McCleary. It takes a while to\r\nget to know a guy like Mac. Maybe his Louie _is_ brighter than Johnny,\r\nand maybe his chugmobile _is_ something terrific.\r\n\r\nFor the last few years, all on account of Mac, my two weeks in August\r\nhave really been well spent Beautiful! Why, from Mars City you can\r\nsee low-slung mountains in the distance and dunes of soft, red sand\r\nstretching out to them. And the sunsets when you\'re standing on the\r\nparapets of that delicate crystal city.... And, man, fishing in the\r\nGrand Canal....\r\n\r\nHow do you get to Mars? There\'s probably a couple of agencies in your\r\nown town. You can look them up in your phone book under "Vacation at\r\nthe Planets of Pleasure" or something like that. They might be a little\r\ndifficult to find, though.\r\n\r\nYou see, they\'re not very well advertised yet.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nEnd of Project Gutenberg\'s Two Weeks in August, by Frank M. Robinson\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


You just give \'em the story.

"\r\n\r\n"Yessir," I agree. But I don\'t like that crack about comic headlines.\r\n\r\n"And get some dope on the Solver," he growls as he stamps out. "Make it\r\nbrief."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWell, our files had plenty on the Solver, since it was a hot news item.\r\nThey claimed it could answer anything. It was a machine that covered an\r\nacre of floor and stood about thirty feet high--all full of wires and\r\nrelays and counters. Also there were tanks of stuff that the inventor\r\ncalled the bio-chemical conceptors. These tanks were hooked up with a\r\nmillion fine wires, from one tank to the next, and all tied in with\r\nelectronic tubes. It was a sort of super-brain.\r\n\r\nThe Solver was invented because the human brain is limited to a few\r\nconcepts at one time. Science needed a brain that could juggle a whole\r\nbunch of ideas simultaneously. And since the Solver was fed only facts,\r\nits multi-brain wasn\'t cluttered with useless junk.\r\n\r\nIt had taken months to build it--and a lot of dough. So the scientists\r\nweren\'t anxious to have it snitched from them by any politician like\r\nSassoon.\r\n\r\nI called up Professor Connor, the inventor, and told him who I was.\r\n\r\n"I have no comments for the press!" he says tartly. In the visiplate,\r\nhis beard was thrust forward so pugnaciously that it was all out of\r\nfocus and I had to peer through the brush in order to see his face.\r\n\r\n"Take it easy, Professor." I smiled suavely. 

"The Press is your best\r\nfriend. If you\'re getting a dirty deal we will tell the whole world\r\nabout it! Are you going to appeal the court decision?"\r\n\r\n"Yes," he says after a pause. 

"I am!" He strokes his beard so that it\r\nclears from the visiplate and I can see a fairly benign looking old\r\ngeezer. "I was only defeated on a technicality today. As inventor and\r\nowner of the Solver, my rights are patent."\r\n\r\n"How come Sassoon grabbed your gadget, Professor?"\r\n\r\n"The Solver is not a gadget!" he snaps. "It\'s a delicate machine--and\r\ndangerous! The man who controls it can solve any riddle, given time.\r\nTherefore, it should remain under scientific control. It belongs\r\nrightfully to the Science Department."\r\n\r\n"Yeah--but how about Sassoon?"\r\n\r\nThe professor\'s snort rattled the receiver.\r\n\r\n"Sassoon is already head of Geo-politics. The other departments of\r\ngovernment won\'t last long if Geo-politics controls the Solver. Sassoon\r\nis an unscrupulous bandit!" And the professor snapped off his set.\r\n\r\nMaybe he was right. In the news room it was no secret that Sassoon was\r\ngoing to be the Big Shot or bust. In fact, I had a dilly of a headline\r\nall cooked up for the day Sassoon seized the scepter.\r\n\r\nThe following morning, however, the news wasn\'t so funny. Professor\r\nConnor was going to see his lawyer that day. Here\'s the teletype copy:\r\n\r\nPROFESSOR CONNOR KILLED IN CRASH. CAR COLLIDES WITH CAB AT CORNER OF\r\n5TH AND GRAND. CONNOR\'S CORPSE CONSIGNED TO CREMATORY. ODDS 50 TO 1 ON\r\nSASSOON. AP.\r\n\r\nOld B. J. raised holy cain over that one!\r\n\r\n"Connor\'s corpse consigned to crematory!" he yowled. "One more crack\r\nlike that and you, Pennyweight, are fired!"\r\n\r\n"Pennyfeather," I correct B. J.\r\n\r\n"Featherweight, Pennyweather, Periwinkle!" he foams. 

"What\'s the odds!\r\nYou Featherbrain!"\r\n\r\nBefore I can answer, he\'s gone, slamming the door and blowing papers\r\noff my desk.\r\n\r\nWell, a couple of days later Sassoon announces that the Solver will be\r\nunveiled to the public with due ceremony, come Wednesday. The Science\r\nDepartment is invited to attend at the Solver Building. Which is very\r\nmagnanimous, considering that the Science Department paid for the\r\nbuilding and the Solver too!\r\n\r\n"Jellyfeather," says old B. J. "You go down and cover this unveiling."\r\n\r\nThat\'s how I came to witness the Joe Squeeb incident.\r\n\r\nI had a seat in the hall right down in front--just behind the\r\ndisgruntled-looking scientists. Maybe they had a right to feel that\r\nway, but they knew better than to ignore Sassoon\'s invitation. Sassoon\r\nwas very sensitive about such things as being snubbed. So they were all\r\nthere, sitting like a row of hungry blackbirds.\r\n\r\nUp on the platform, the chairman opened the proceedings with a nice\r\nlittle speech which safely said nothing, and then he handed over the\r\nmeeting to Sassoon.\r\n\r\nSassoon was a big, fat man with slick black hair and eyes that reminded\r\nme of old B. J.\'s. Fishy. Sassoon, however, put on the jolly act--big\r\nsmile and breezy manner, the "we\'re-all-one-big-family" touch.\r\n\r\nMost of the people fell for it, and gave him a laugh when he sprung\r\nhis warming-up joke. But the boys with the brains in front of me just\r\ngloomed. I saw Sassoon give them a quick once-over before he went on to\r\ndescribe the wonders of the Solver. He gave a pretty good speech, too,\r\nif you didn\'t know what was behind it.\r\n\r\n"Mankind," he finally ended, "will look back on this day as on the dawn\r\nof a new era. Posterity will bathe in the flow of a new wisdom that has\r\ncome from our hands!"\r\n\r\nThen he pulled a cord that opened a huge curtain behind him, and the\r\nSolver was unveiled. Appropriate oh\'s and ah\'s followed. 

It did look\r\nimpressive at that. Like a gigantic calculating machine.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIn front of it there was a wide platform with several desks. These\r\nwere occupied by attendants ready to feed data which the Solver might\r\nrequire. Each desk had a microphone for that purpose, and there was one\r\ngilded microphone near Sassoon. This one was for stating the question.\r\nA large loudspeaker was suspended high up to deliver the Solver\'s\r\nanswers.\r\n\r\nI once read that the ancient Greeks had a similar setup, called the\r\nDelphic Oracle. Only some fellow got the wrong answer once and blew the\r\nwhole works some way.\r\n\r\n"And now," Sassoon beamed on his audience, "we will demonstrate the\r\nSolver in action. Perhaps we should allow our scientific friends the\r\nhonor of asking it the first riddle. After all, we owe science a great\r\ndeal, ha-ha!"\r\n\r\nBut none of the savants made a move. Maybe they felt balky. However,\r\nSassoon was too smart to allow any awkward pauses.\r\n\r\n"But then, perhaps the honor should go to some less illustrious\r\nperson." His cold eyes had spotted the figure of a little man in\r\noveralls, standing in a half-open doorway. 

The little man leaned on a\r\nbroom. I found out later he was Joe Squeeb, the janitor of Solver Hall.\r\n\r\n"Since we must always remember our democratic traditions," Sassoon\'s\r\nvoice was slick as warm margarine, "I think our humblest worker should\r\nhave the great honor of asking the Solver its first public question.\r\nCome here--you!"\r\n\r\nThe janitor dropped his broom and turned to flee, but Sassoon\'s voice,\r\nwith just a slight grate to it, pinned him in his tracks like a\r\nmesmerized rabbit.\r\n\r\n"Come, come. You, with the broom. Step up here!"\r\n\r\nJoe Squeeb moved as if pulled by invisible chains. On the stage with\r\nSassoon, he blinked nervously at the audience. Then he suddenly\r\ngrinned, showing snaggy teeth, like a man who feels he\'s a goner.\r\nSassoon towered over him as they talked together for a moment before\r\nSassoon turned to face the audience again.\r\n\r\n"This, ah, gentleman, is Joe Squeeb, our janitor. He has agreed to try\r\nand stump the Solver, ha-ha!"\r\n\r\nSassoon\'s great hand smacked Squeeb on the back and nearly sent the\r\nlittle man sprawling into the row of stony-faced scientists.\r\n\r\n"And now, Mr. Squeeb--ask your question." Sassoon pushed him to the\r\ngilded microphone.\r\n\r\n[Illustration: "Ask it a question."]\r\n\r\nSqueeb\'s Adam\'s apple bobbed. He shuffled his feet and twisted his\r\nscrawny neck. I heard his panicky whisper to Sassoon.\r\n\r\n"What\'ll I ask it?"\r\n\r\n"Come, come!" Sassoon frowned heavily. "Don\'t jump around like that!\r\nAsk it some question in arithmetic. Or maybe you know all the answers,\r\nho-ho!"\r\n\r\nSqueeb rolled his eyes. I guess he wasn\'t used to thinking because he\r\nacted as if he was in pain. Then, suddenly, his face lighted up.\r\n\r\n"I got it," he said triumphantly. "I remember a problem that stuck all\r\nof us."\r\n\r\nEvidently he had dredged the depths of his mind for some long forgotten\r\nproblem of high school days.\r\n\r\n"All right." Sassoon switched on the control. "Ask it, man, and get it\r\nover!"\r\n\r\nSqueeb gulped, gave his waiting audience a last hopeless grin, and\r\ncleared his throat.\r\n\r\n"Exactly what is the area of a circle," he asked brightly, "with a\r\nradius of one inch?"\r\n\r\nBertrand, the great mathematician, sitting just in front of me, gave a\r\nsort of gasp. Then the raspy notes of the Solver squawked a reply.\r\n\r\n"The area of a circle with a radius of one inch is exactly--Three point\r\none, four, one, five--nine--two--six--"\r\n\r\nBertrand, the mathematician, had a notebook and pen out, scribbling as\r\nthe Solver announced the figures in a plodding monotone. He covered one\r\nline and started on the next.\r\n\r\nThe audience began to stir impatiently. 

This was not very entertaining.\r\nSassoon frowned, quickly smiled again.\r\n\r\n"How long does this go on?" he asked jocularly.\r\n\r\nOne of the desk attendants moved forward.\r\n\r\n"It\'ll be quite a long time," he said. "The answer has never been\r\ncompleted."\r\n\r\n"Oh--six-- --nine-- -- --five," the Solver intoned persistently.\r\n\r\n"Switch the blasted thing off!" Sassoon ordered irritably.\r\n\r\nThe Solver gurgled to silence.\r\n\r\n"Now." Sassoon cleared his throat. "We will ask it another question."\r\n\r\nThe same attendant coughed discreetly.\r\n\r\n"Just a minute, Mr. Sassoon," he said apologetically as the boss\r\nof Geo-politics swung around to face him. "The Solver is not purely\r\nmechanical, you know. The actual work is done by the bio-chemical cells\r\nand these cannot be reset to zero without discharging their concept\r\nenergy."\r\n\r\n"Huh?" Sassoon frowned at the interruption. "Well, discharge \'em!

"\r\n\r\n"That\'s the trouble, sir. A Solver cell is like a human brain cell,\r\nit must complete its function in order to relapse into inactivity.\r\nShutting off the Solver merely holds its processes in abeyance. When we\r\nswitch on the power again, the cells will continue where they left off\r\ntill their task is completed."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nSassoon thought that one over.\r\n\r\n"Then switch it back on again. Let\'s get this over," he snapped, and\r\nturned to look for Joe Squeeb. But the janitor had discreetly faded.\r\nHis broom leaned, deserted, in the doorway. Squeeb wasn\'t so dumb as he\r\nlooked!\r\n\r\n"Nine-- --Six-- -- --Four--" The Solver was slowing down a little as\r\nthe calculations became more involved with unwieldy quotients. But\r\nthere was grim resolve in the metallic tone.\r\n\r\nI tapped Bertrand on the shoulder.\r\n\r\n"How long will this take?" I asked.\r\n\r\n"Couldn\'t say." 

He smiled thinly. "We once wore out several machines\r\non that problem. Imagine a Joe Squeeb saving us from--" He stopped\r\nabruptly.\r\n\r\n"Can\'t you tell the Solver some way that the present answer is close\r\nenough?"\r\n\r\nBertrand shook his head.\r\n\r\n"As you may recall, Joe Squeeb definitely asked for an exact answer.\r\nThe Solver will give it--regardless!"\r\n\r\n"Eight-- --one-- --two--" The Solver was beginning to sound labored.\r\nInside the great machine relays were madly racing.\r\n\r\n"I guess Joe Squeeb just lost a job," I murmured.\r\n\r\n"He has another job waiting for him." Bertrand almost grinned. "We need\r\nsomeone to dust our equipment--someone who knows enough not to monkey\r\nwith things. It\'ll really be a pension job."\r\n\r\nI looked at Sassoon. He appeared very unhappy. Not only had he made\r\na chump of himself, but it looked as if he\'d spiked his own guns by\r\ngumming up the Solver. He couldn\'t use the machine for his own ends and\r\nhe\'d have no excuse for stealing the next one to be built.\r\n\r\nWhen I left Solver Hall the machine was gurgling a number about\r\nevery twenty seconds and slowing down all the time. Sassoon had\r\nasked Bertrand to get busy and shut it up some way, and Bertrand was\r\ngently explaining to him that it was merely a matter of time--lots of\r\ntime--before the Solver would stop. Unless Sassoon wanted it torn apart.\r\n\r\nI sent out a teletype release to the waiting world. It read:\r\n\r\nSASSOON SUMMONS SCIENTISTS FOR SOLUTION AS SOLVER STRANGLES ON SQUARING\r\nOF CIRCLE. SASSOON SWEARS TO SILENCE SOLVER. ODDS 1,000,000 TO 1 ON\r\nSOLVER. AP.\r\n\r\nTen seconds after the release, old B. J. was at my desk. Red eyed!\r\n\r\n"Pinfeather," he roars, "you\'re fired!"\r\n\r\n"It\'s Pennyfeather," I retort. "And I quit two seconds before you\r\nspoke!"\r\n\r\n"All right, all right! 

Bunnyweather, then!" He clutches the edge of my\r\ndesk. "Only get out of my sight! 

Quick!"\r\n\r\nAnd that is Joe Squeeb\'s story. Right now he\'s working for swell wages\r\nat Science Hall. They all call him Joe and ask him all the time how\r\nis his family and how is his arthritis. He\'s even putting on a little\r\nweight.\r\n\r\nAs for old B. J.--I figure he\'ll come around to me, apologizing, some\r\nday. 

Unless apoplexy gets him first. I\'m just waiting while I write\r\nthese memoirs.\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


But this vast distance did not mean that isolation could endure\r\nforever. Instruments within the ship intercepted radio broadcasts and,\r\nwithin the hour, early TV signals. Machines compiled dictionaries and\r\ngrammars and began translating the major languages. The history of the\r\nplanet was tabulated as facts became available.\r\n\r\nThe course of the ship changed slightly; it was not much out of the way\r\nto swing nearer Earth. For days the two within the ship listened and\r\nwatched with little comment. They had to decide soon.\r\n\r\n"We\'ve got to make or break," said the first alien.\r\n\r\n"You know what I\'m in favor of," said the second.\r\n\r\n"I can guess," said Ethaniel, who had spoken first. "The place is a\r\ncomplete mess. They\'ve never done anything except fight each other--and\r\ninvent better weapons."\r\n\r\n"It\'s not what they\'ve done," said Bal, the second alien. "It\'s what\r\nthey\'re going to do, with that big bomb."\r\n\r\n"The more reason for stopping," said Ethaniel. "The big bomb can destroy\r\nthem. Without our help they may do just that."\r\n\r\n"I may remind you that in two months twenty-nine days we\'re due in\r\nWillafours," said Bal. "Without looking at the charts I can tell you we\r\nstill have more than a hundred light-years to go."\r\n\r\n"A week," said Ethaniel. "We can spare a week and still get there on\r\ntime."\r\n\r\n"A week?" said Bal. "To settle their problems? They\'ve had two world\r\nwars in one generation and that the third and final one is coming up you\r\ncan\'t help feeling in everything they do."\r\n\r\n"It won\'t take much," said Ethaniel. "The wrong diplomatic move, or a\r\ntrigger-happy soldier could set it off. And it wouldn\'t have to be\r\ndeliberate. A meteor shower could pass over and their clumsy instruments\r\ncould interpret it as an all-out enemy attack."\r\n\r\n"Too bad," said Bal. "We\'ll just have to forget there ever was such a\r\nplanet as Earth."\r\n\r\n"Could you? 

Forget so many people?"\r\n\r\n"I\'m doing it," said Bal. "Just give them a little time and they won\'t\r\nbe here to remind me that I have a conscience."\r\n\r\n"My memory isn\'t convenient," said Ethaniel. "I ask you to look at\r\nthem."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBal rustled, flicking the screen intently. "Very much like ourselves,"\r\nhe said at last. "A bit shorter perhaps, and most certainly incomplete.\r\nExcept for the one thing they lack, and that\'s quite odd, they seem\r\nexactly like us. Is that what you wanted me to say?"\r\n\r\n"It is. The fact that they are an incomplete version of ourselves\r\ntouches me. They actually seem defenseless, though I suppose they\'re\r\nnot."\r\n\r\n"Tough," said Bal. "Nothing we can do about it."\r\n\r\n"There is. We can give them a week."\r\n\r\n"In a week we can\'t negate their entire history. We can\'t begin to undo\r\nthe effect of the big bomb."\r\n\r\n"You can\'t tell," said Ethaniel. 

"We can look things over."\r\n\r\n"And then what? How much authority do we have?"\r\n\r\n"Very little," conceded Ethaniel. "Two minor officials on the way to\r\nWillafours--and we run directly into a problem no one knew existed."\r\n\r\n"And when we get to Willafours we\'ll be busy. It will be a long time\r\nbefore anyone comes this way again."\r\n\r\n"A very long time. There\'s nothing in this region of space our people\r\nwant," said Ethaniel. "And how long can Earth last? Ten years? Even ten\r\nmonths? The tension is building by the hour."\r\n\r\n"What can I say?" 

said Bal. "I suppose we can stop and look them over.\r\nWe\'re not committing ourselves by looking."\r\n\r\nThey went much closer to Earth, not intending to commit themselves. For\r\na day they circled the planet, avoiding radar detection, which for them\r\nwas not difficult, testing, and sampling. Finally Ethaniel looked up\r\nfrom the monitor screen. "Any conclusions?"\r\n\r\n"What\'s there to think? It\'s worse than I imagined."\r\n\r\n"In what way?"\r\n\r\n"Well, we knew they had the big bomb. Atmospheric analysis showed that\r\nas far away as we were."\r\n\r\n"I know."\r\n\r\n"We also knew they could deliver the big bomb, presumably by some sort\r\nof aircraft."\r\n\r\n"That was almost a certainty. They\'d have no use for the big bomb\r\nwithout aircraft."\r\n\r\n"What\'s worse is that I now find they also have missiles, range one\r\nthousand miles and upward. They either have or are near a primitive form\r\nof space travel."\r\n\r\n"Bad," said Ethaniel. "Sitting there, wondering when it\'s going to hit\r\nthem. Nervousness could set it off."\r\n\r\n"It could, and the missiles make it worse," said Bal. "What did you find\r\nout at your end?

"\r\n\r\n"Nothing worthwhile. I was looking at the people while you were\r\ninvestigating their weapons."\r\n\r\n"You must think something.

"\r\n\r\n"I wish I knew what to think. There\'s so little time," Ethaniel said.\r\n"Language isn\'t the difficulty. Our machines translate their languages\r\neasily and I\'ve taken a cram course in two or three of them. But that\'s\r\nnot enough, looking at a few plays, listening to advertisements, music,\r\nand news bulletins. I should go down and live among them, read books,\r\ntalk to scholars, work with them, play."\r\n\r\n"You could do that and you\'d really get to know them. But that takes\r\ntime--and we don\'t have it.

"\r\n\r\n"I realize that."\r\n\r\n"A flat yes or no," said Bal.\r\n\r\n"No. We can\'t help them," said Ethaniel. "There is nothing we can do for\r\nthem--but we have to try."\r\n\r\n"Sure, I knew it before we started," said Bal. "It\'s happened before. We\r\ntake the trouble to find out what a people are like and when we can\'t\r\nhelp them we feel bad. It\'s going to be that way again." 

He rose and\r\nstretched. "Well, give me an hour to think of some way of going at it."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIt was longer than that before they met again. In the meantime the ship\r\nmoved much closer to Earth. They no longer needed instruments to see it.\r\nThe planet revolved outside the visionports. The southern plains were\r\ngreen, coursed with rivers; the oceans were blue; and much of the\r\nnorthern hemisphere was glistening white. Ragged clouds covered the\r\npole, and a dirty pall spread over the mid-regions of the north.\r\n\r\n"I haven\'t thought of anything brilliant," said Ethaniel.\r\n\r\n"Nor I," said Bal. "We\'re going to have to go down there cold. And it\r\nwill be cold."\r\n\r\n"Yes. It\'s their winter."\r\n\r\n"I did have an idea," said Bal. "What about going down as supernatural\r\nbeings?"\r\n\r\n"Hardly," said Ethaniel. "A hundred years ago it might have worked.\r\nToday they have satellites. They are not primitives."\r\n\r\n"I suppose you\'re right," said Bal. "I did think we ought to take\r\nadvantage of our physical differences."\r\n\r\n"If we could I\'d be all for it. But these people are rough and\r\ndesperate. They wouldn\'t be fooled by anything that crude."\r\n\r\n"Well, you\'re calling it," said Bal.\r\n\r\n"All right," said Ethaniel. "You take one side and I the other. We\'ll\r\ntell them bluntly what they\'ll have to do if they\'re going to survive,\r\nhow they can keep their planet in one piece so they can live on it."\r\n\r\n"That\'ll go over big. Advice is always popular."\r\n\r\n"Can\'t help it. That\'s all we have time for."\r\n\r\n"Special instructions?"\r\n\r\n"None. We leave the ship here and go down in separate landing craft. You\r\ncan talk with me any time you want to through our communications, but\r\ndon\'t unless you have to."\r\n\r\n"They can\'t intercept the beams we use."\r\n\r\n"They can\'t, and even if they did they wouldn\'t know what to do with our\r\nlanguage. I want them to think that we don\'t _need_ to talk things\r\nover."\r\n\r\n"I get it. Makes us seem better than we are. They think we know exactly\r\nwhat we\'re doing even though we don\'t."\r\n\r\n"If we\'re lucky they\'ll think that."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBal looked out of the port at the planet below. "It\'s going to be cold\r\nwhere I\'m going. You too. Sure we don\'t want to change our plans and\r\nland in the southern hemisphere? It\'s summer there."\r\n\r\n"I\'m afraid not. The great powers are in the north. They are the ones we\r\nhave to reach to do the job."\r\n\r\n"Yeah, but I was thinking of that holiday you mentioned. We\'ll be\r\nrunning straight into it. That won\'t help us any."\r\n\r\n"I know, they don\'t like their holidays interrupted. It can\'t be helped.\r\nWe can\'t wait until it\'s over."\r\n\r\n"I\'m aware of that," said Bal. "Fill me in on that holiday, anything I\r\nought to know. Probably religious in origin. 

That so?"\r\n\r\n"It was religious a long time ago," said Ethaniel. "I didn\'t learn\r\nanything exact from radio and TV. Now it seems to be chiefly a time for\r\neating, office parties, and selling merchandise.

"\r\n\r\n"I see. It has become a business holiday."\r\n\r\n"That\'s a good description. 

I didn\'t get as much of it as I ought to\r\nhave. I was busy studying the people, and they\'re hard to pin down.

"\r\n\r\n"I see. I was thinking there might be some way we could tie ourselves in\r\nwith this holiday. Make it work for us.

"\r\n\r\n"If there is I haven\'t thought of it."\r\n\r\n"You ought to know. You\'re running this one." Bal looked down at the\r\nplanet. Clouds were beginning to form at the twilight edge. "I hate to\r\ngo down and leave the ship up here with no one in it."\r\n\r\n"They can\'t touch it. No matter how they develop in the next hundred\r\nyears they still won\'t be able to get in or damage it in any way."\r\n\r\n"It\'s myself I\'m thinking about. 

Down there, alone."\r\n\r\n"I\'ll be with you. On the other side of the Earth."\r\n\r\n"That\'s not very close. I\'d like it better if there were someone in the\r\nship to bring it down in a hurry if things get rough. They don\'t think\r\nmuch of each other. I don\'t imagine they\'ll like aliens any better."\r\n\r\n"They may be unfriendly," Ethaniel acknowledged. Now he switched a\r\nmonitor screen until he looked at the slope of a mountain. It was\r\nsnowing and men were cutting small green trees in the snow. "I\'ve\r\nthought of a trick.

"\r\n\r\n"If it saves my neck I\'m for it."\r\n\r\n"I don\'t guarantee anything," said Ethaniel. "This is what I was\r\nthinking of: instead of hiding the ship against the sun where there\'s\r\nlittle chance it will be seen, we\'ll make sure that they do see it.\r\nLet\'s take it around to the night side of the planet and light it up."\r\n\r\n"Say, pretty good," said Bal.\r\n\r\n"They can\'t imagine that we\'d light up an unmanned ship," said Ethaniel.\r\n"Even if the thought should occur to them they\'ll have no way of\r\nchecking it. Also, they won\'t be eager to harm us with our ship shining\r\ndown on them."\r\n\r\n"That\'s thinking," said Bal, moving to the controls. "I\'ll move the ship\r\nover where they can see it best and then I\'ll light it up. I\'ll really\r\nlight it up."\r\n\r\n"Don\'t spare power."\r\n\r\n"Don\'t worry about that. They\'ll see it. 

Everybody on Earth will see\r\nit." Later, with the ship in position, glowing against the darkness of\r\nspace, pulsating with light, Bal said: "You know, I feel better about\r\nthis. We may pull it off. Lighting the ship may be just the help we\r\nneed."\r\n\r\n"It\'s not we who need help, but the people of Earth," said Ethaniel.\r\n"See you in five days." With that he entered a small landing craft,\r\nwhich left a faintly luminescent trail as it plunged toward Earth. As\r\nsoon as it was safe to do so, Bal left in another craft, heading for the\r\nother side of the planet.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nAnd the spaceship circled Earth, unmanned, blazing and pulsing with\r\nlight. No star in the winter skies of the planet below could equal it in\r\nbrilliancy. Once a man-made satellite came near but it was dim and was\r\nlost sight of by the people below. During the day the ship was visible\r\nas a bright spot of light. At evening it seemed to burn through the\r\nsunset colors.\r\n\r\nAnd the ship circled on, bright, shining, seeming to be a little piece\r\nclipped from the center of a star and brought near Earth to illuminate\r\nit. Never, or seldom, had Earth seen anything like it.\r\n\r\nIn five days the two small landing craft that had left it arched up from\r\nEarth and joined the orbit of the large ship. The two small craft slid\r\ninside the large one and doors closed behind them. In a short time the\r\naliens met again.\r\n\r\n"We did it," said Bal exultantly as he came in. "I don\'t know how we did\r\nit and I thought we were going to fail but at the last minute they came\r\nthrough."\r\n\r\nEthaniel smiled. "I\'m tired," he said, rustling.\r\n\r\n"Me too, but mostly I\'m cold," said Bal, shivering. "Snow. Nothing but\r\nsnow wherever I went. Miserable climate. And yet you had me go out\r\nwalking after that first day."\r\n\r\n"From my own experience it seemed to be a good idea," said Ethaniel. "If\r\nI went out walking one day I noticed that the next day the officials\r\nwere much more cooperative. If it worked for me I thought it might help\r\nyou.

"\r\n\r\n"It did. I don\'t know why, but it did," said Bal. "Anyway, this\r\nagreement they made isn\'t the best but I think it will keep them from\r\ndestroying themselves."\r\n\r\n"It\'s as much as we can expect," said Ethaniel. "They may have small\r\nwars after this, but never the big one. In fifty or a hundred years we\r\ncan come back and see how much they\'ve learned."\r\n\r\n"I\'m not sure I want to," said Bal. "Say, what\'s an angel?"\r\n\r\n"Why?"\r\n\r\n"When I went out walking people stopped to look. Some knelt in the snow\r\nand called me an angel."\r\n\r\n"Something like that happened to me," said Ethaniel.\r\n\r\n"I didn\'t get it but I didn\'t let it upset me," said Bal. "I smiled at\r\nthem and went about my business." He shivered again. "It was always\r\ncold. I walked out, but sometimes I flew back. I hope that was all\r\nright.

"\r\n\r\nIn the cabin Bal spread his great wings. Renaissance painters had never\r\nseen his like but knew exactly how he looked. In their paintings they\r\nhad pictured him innumerable times.\r\n\r\n"I don\'t think it hurt us that you flew," said Ethaniel. "I did so\r\nmyself occasionally."\r\n\r\n"But you don\'t know what an angel is?"\r\n\r\n"No. I didn\'t have time to find out. Some creature of their folklore I\r\nsuppose. You know, except for our wings they\'re very much like\r\nourselves. Their legends are bound to resemble ours."\r\n\r\n"Sure," said Bal. "Anyway, peace on Earth."\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Amazing Science Fiction Stories_\r\n    January 1960.
