He kept looking at\r\nthe floor. He was in his early eighties and sometimes seemed like a\r\nyoung man to Sal. 

His ideas maybe. He thought differently about the\r\nChildren and where things were going.\r\n\r\n"We\'re going to get out tonight," Captain Murphy said again. "We\'ll get\r\nthat barge loaded and we\'ll get out."\r\n\r\nSal sat up. The pills had made his heart settle down a bit, and his\r\nhands were comparatively calm.\r\n\r\n"Is the barge almost loaded now? It better be," Sal said. 

"They\'ll\r\nattack any minute now. I know that much."\r\n\r\n"Another hour\'s all we need. If they attack before then we can hold\r\nthem off long enough to get that barge into the river. Once we get into\r\nthe river with it, we\'ll be safe. We can float her down and into the\r\nsea. Somewhere along the coast we\'ll land and wherever it is will be\r\nfine for us. We\'ll have licked the Children. They know we\'ve found the\r\nonly eatable food stores in God knows how many thousands of miles in\r\nthis goddamned wasteland. They can\'t live another month without this\r\nstuff, and we\'re taking it all down the river. That\'s right isn\'t it,\r\nDoc?

"\r\n\r\nCartley looked up. "But as I said before, squeezing a little more life\r\nout of ourselves doesn\'t mean anything to me. What do we want to get\r\naway and live a little longer for? It doesn\'t make sense, except in a\r\nridiculous selfish way. So we live another month, maybe six months, or\r\na year longer? What for?"\r\n\r\nSal glanced at Murphy who finally sat down.\r\n\r\n"We want to live," Murphy said thickly, and he gripped his hands\r\ntogether. "Survival. It\'s a natural law."\r\n\r\n"What about the survival of the species?" Cartley asked. "By running\r\nout and taking the food, we\'re killing ourselves anyway. So I don\'t\r\nthink I\'ll be with you, Murphy."\r\n\r\n"What are you going to do? 

Stay here? They\'ll torture you to death.\r\nThey\'ll do to you what they did to Donaldson, and all the others\r\nthey\'ve caught. You want to stay for that kind of treatment?

"\r\n\r\n"We ought to try. Running off, taking all this food, that means they\'re\r\nsure to die inside a few weeks. They might catch a few rats or birds,\r\nbut there aren\'t even enough of those around to sustain life beyond\r\na few days. So we kill the future just so we can go on living for a\r\nlittle longer. We\'ve got no reason to live when we know the race will\r\ndie. My wife refused to fight them. They killed her, that\'s true,\r\nbut I still think she was right. We\'ve got to make one more attempt\r\nto establish some kind of truce with the Children. If we had that,\r\nthen we might be able to start building up some kind of relationship.\r\nThe only way they can survive, even if they had food, is to absorb\r\nour knowledge. You know that. Without our knowledge and experience,\r\nthey\'ll die anyway, even if they had a thousand years of food supplies."\r\n\r\n"It can\'t be done," Murphy said.\r\n\r\nCartley looked at the shadows for a long time. Finally he shook his\r\nhead. "I don\'t have any idea how to do it. 

But we should try. We can\'t\r\nuse discipline and power because we\'re too weak. And too outnumbered.\r\nWe\'d have to do that first in order to teach them, and we can\'t. So\r\nthere has to be some other way."\r\n\r\n"Faith?" Sal said. He shook his head. "They don\'t believe in anything.\r\nYou can\'t make any appeal to them through faith, or ethics, any kind of\r\ncode of honor, nothing like that. They\'re worse than animals."\r\n\r\nCartley stood up wearily and started to walk away. "They hate us," he\r\nsaid. "That\'s the one thing we\'re sure of. We\'re the means and they\'re\r\nthe ends. We made them what they are. They\'re brutalized and motivated\r\nalmost completely by hatred. And what\'s underneath hatred?" He fumed\r\nback toward Murphy. "Fear."\r\n\r\nSal stood up. "I never thought of them as being afraid," he said.\r\n\r\n"That doesn\'t matter," Murphy said. "It\'s the hate and vicious\r\nbrutality we have to deal with. 

You do whatever you want to do,\r\nCartley. We\'ve voted, and we\'ve voted to move the stuff out tonight on\r\nthe barge. The world we helped make is dead, Cartley. The Children grew\r\nup in a world we killed. We\'ve all got bad consciences, but we can\'t do\r\nanything about it. The chasm between them and us is too wide. It was\r\nwide even before the bombs fell. And the bombs made it a hell of a lot\r\nwider. Too wide to put any kind of bridge across now."\r\n\r\n"Just the same, we ought to die trying," Cartley said. When he went\r\noutside, Sal followed him.\r\n\r\nThe barge was about loaded. All outer defense units had been pulled in\r\nand were concentrated on the head of the pier behind walls of sandbags.\r\nBurp guns and machine guns were ready, and the barge lay along the side\r\nof the pier in the moonlight like a dead whale. There were several\r\nsewer openings near the head of the pier. Men were stationed around\r\nthese sewers with automatic rifles, hand grenades and flame throwers.\r\n\r\nSal walked to where Cartley stood leaning against the partly closed\r\ndoor of the rotting warehouse. Jagged splinters of steel and wood\r\nangled out against the sky.\r\n\r\nAfter a while, Sal said softly, "Well, what could we try to do, Doc?"\r\n\r\nCartley turned quickly. Some of the anguish in his eyes had gone away,\r\nand he gripped Sal\'s shoulders in hands surprisingly strong for so old\r\na man. "You want to help me try?

"\r\n\r\n"Guess I do. Like you said, we only have a little time left anyway. And\r\nif we can\'t help the Children, what\'s the good of it?"\r\n\r\nThey stood there in the shadows a while, not saying anything.\r\n\r\n"This way," Cartley said. He led Sal down away from the pier and along\r\nthe water\'s edge. Dry reed rustled, and mud squished under their shoes.\r\n\r\n"Here," Cartley said. There was a small flat-bottomed rowboat, and in\r\nit were several cartons of food supplies, all in cans. There were also\r\nseveral large tins of water.\r\n\r\n"We\'ll need a little time," Cartley said. "We\'ll have to wait. I figure\r\nwe\'ll row upstream maybe a few hundred yards, and hole up in one of\r\nthose caves. We can watch, Sal. We can watch and wait and try to figure\r\nit out."\r\n\r\n"Sure," Sal said. 

"That seems the only way to start."\r\n\r\nCartley sat down on the bank near the boat, and Sal sat down too.\r\n\r\n"The Children," Cartley said, "never had a chance to be any other way.\r\nBut we\'re the oldsters, and we\'ve got this obligation, Sal. Man\'s a\r\ncultural animal. He isn\'t born with any inherent concepts of right,\r\nor wrong, or good or bad, or even an ability to survive on an animal\r\nlevel. We have to be taught to survive by the elders, Sal. And we\'re\r\nthe elders." He hesitated, "We\'re the only ones left."\r\n\r\nA flare of horrid light exploded over the warehouse down river and it\r\nlit up Cartley\'s face and turned it a shimmering crimson. His hands\r\nwidened to perfect roundness and he raised his hands in a voiceless\r\nscream to stop the sudden explosions of burp guns, grenades, machine\r\nguns, and rifles.\r\n\r\nLooking down river then, Sal could see the flames eating up through the\r\nwarehouse. The pier, the barge, everything for a hundred square yards\r\nwas lit up as bright as day, and the flare spread out over the river\r\nand made a black ominous shadow of the opposite bank.\r\n\r\n"They\'re getting away," Cartley said.\r\n\r\nSal watched the barge move out. The Children came screaming out of the\r\nblazing warehouse, overran the pier, streamed into the water. But a\r\nsteady blast of fire from the barge drove them back, and in a few more\r\nminutes the barge dissolved downriver into darkness.\r\n\r\nCartley\'s hands were shaking as he gripped Sal\'s arm. "Let\'s go now. 

We\r\nneed time. Time may help us a lot, Sal. We can wait and watch. 

We can\r\nfigure something out."\r\n\r\nSal heard the screams and mocking savage cries coming up over the\r\nwater, and then the jagged cries of some oldsters who hadn\'t managed to\r\nget away.\r\n\r\nStill looking downstream toward the blazing pier, Sal pushed Cartley\r\ninto the rowboat, and they shoved off. Sal started rowing, but he kept\r\nlooking back.\r\n\r\n"They should have put them in the same shelters with us," Sal said,\r\n"that would have made a difference. But they put us in separate\r\nshelters."\r\n\r\nOnly the oldest and the youngest had been saved. The old out of\r\npity and because they were helpless, had been granted the safety of\r\nshelters. The young because they were the symbols of hope had been\r\ngranted shelters, too.\r\n\r\n"No," Cartley said. "It started long before that. The chasm was\r\nbuilding up long before the war. This alienation between the young and\r\nthe old. Between the sun and the seed. That\'s what we\'ve got to bring\r\nback, Sal. Between us, we have stored up a hundred and seventy-nine\r\nyears of human culture. There isn\'t a kid back there, Sal, more than\r\ntwelve years old."\r\n\r\n"We\'ll find a way," Sal said.\r\n\r\nThe rowboat was about fifteen feet away from the thick reeds growing in\r\nthe marshy ooze of the bank.\r\n\r\nCartley heard the sound first and turned, his face white. When Sal\r\nlooked toward the bank, he saw the girl. She came on out from the\r\ncurtain of reeds and looked at them. 

She was perfectly clear in the\r\nmoonlight standing there. She wore a short ragged print dress and she\r\nhad long hair that seemed silken and soft and golden in the moonlight\r\neven though it, her dress, her little legs and her face were streaked\r\nwith mud.\r\n\r\nSal hesitated, then pulled heavily on his left oar and the boat nosed\r\ntoward her. Up close, Sal could see her face, the clear blue eyes wet,\r\nand the tears running down her cheeks.\r\n\r\nThe girl reached out and asked in a sobbing breath,\r\n\r\n"Granpa? Is that you, Granpa?"\r\n\r\n"Oh God, Oh God," Cartley said. He was crying as he picked her up and\r\ngot her into the boat. He was rocking her in his arms and half crying\r\nand half laughing as Sal rowed the boat upstream.\r\n\r\n"Yes, yes, honey," Sal heard Cartley say over and over. "I\'m your\r\ngranpa, honey. 

Don\'t cry. Go to sleep now. I\'m your granpa and I\'ve\r\nbeen looking for you, honey, and now everything\'s going to be all\r\nright."\r\n\r\nIt\'s funny, Sal thought, as he kept on rowing upstream. It\'s a funny\r\nthing how one little girl remembered her granpa, and how maybe that was\r\nthe beginning of the bridge across the chasm.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


"\r\n\r\nMelinda did not quite recoil. He was perhaps five feet tall, with a\r\ngleaming hairless scalp and a young-old face. He wore a plain gray\r\ntunic, and a peddler\'s tray hung from his thin shoulders.\r\n\r\n"Don\'t want any," Melinda stated flatly.\r\n\r\n"_Please._" He had great, beseeching amber eyes. "They all say that. 

I\r\nhaven\'t much time. I must be back at the University by noon."\r\n\r\n"You working your way through college?"\r\n\r\nHe brightened. "Yes. 

I suppose you could call it that. Alien\r\nanthropology major."\r\n\r\nMelinda softened. The initiations those frats pulled nowadays--shaving\r\nthe poor guy\'s head, eating goldfish--it was criminal.\r\n\r\n"Well?" she asked grudgingly. 

"What\'s in the tray?"\r\n\r\n"Flanglers," said the little man eagerly. "Oscilloscopes. Portable\r\nforce-field generators. A neural distorter." Melinda\'s face was blank.\r\nThe little man frowned. "You use them, of course? This _is_ a Class IV\r\nculture?" Melinda essayed a weak shrug and the little man sighed with\r\nrelief. His eyes fled past her to the blank screen of the TV set. "Ah, a\r\nmonitor." He smiled. "For a moment I was afraid--May I come in?"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nMelinda shrugged, opened the door. This might be interesting, like a\r\nvacuum-cleaner salesman who had cleaned her drapes last week for free.\r\nAnd Kitty Kyle Battles Life wouldn\'t be on for almost an hour.\r\n\r\n"My name is Porteous," said the little man with an eager smile. "I\'m\r\ndoing a thematic on Class IV cultures." 

He whipped out a stylus, began\r\njotting down notes. The TV set fascinated him.\r\n\r\n"It\'s turned off right now," Melinda said.\r\n\r\nPorteous\'s eyes widened impossibly. "You mean," he whispered in horror,\r\n"that you\'re exercising Class V privileges? This is terribly confusing.\r\nI get doors slammed in my face, when Class Fours are supposed to have a\r\nsplendid gregarian quotient--you _do_ have atomic power, don\'t you?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, sure," said Melinda uncomfortably. 

This wasn\'t going to be much\r\nfun.\r\n\r\n"Space travel?" The little face was intent, sharp.\r\n\r\n"Well," Melinda yawned, looking at the blank screen, "they\'ve got Space\r\nPatrol, Space Cadet, Tales of Tomorrow ..."\r\n\r\n"Excellent. Rocket ships or force-fields?" Melinda blinked. "Does your\r\nhusband own one?" Melinda shook her blonde head helplessly. "What are\r\nyour economic circumstances?"\r\n\r\nMelinda took a deep rasping breath, said, "Listen, mister, is this a\r\ndemonstration or a quiz program?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, my excuse. Demonstration, certainly. 

You will not mind the\r\nquestions?"\r\n\r\n"Questions?" There was an ominous glint in Melinda\'s blue eyes.\r\n\r\n"Your delightful primitive customs, art-forms, personal habits--"\r\n\r\n"Look," Melinda said, crimsoning. "This is a respectable neighborhood,\r\nand I\'m not answering any Kinsey report, understand?"\r\n\r\nThe little man nodded, scribbling. "Personal habits are tabu? I so\r\nregret. 

The demonstration." He waved grandly at the tray. "Anti-grav\r\nsandals? A portable solar converter? Apologizing for this miserable\r\nselection, but on Capella they told me--" He followed Melinda\'s\r\nentranced gaze, selected a tiny green vial. "This is merely a\r\nregenerative solution. You appear to have no cuts or bruises."\r\n\r\n"Oh," said Melinda nastily. "Cures warts, cancer, grows hair, I\r\nsuppose."\r\n\r\nPorteous brightened. 

"Of course. I see you can scan. Amazing." He\r\nscribbled further with his stylus, glanced up, blinked at the obvious\r\nscorn on Melinda\'s face. "Here. 

Try it."\r\n\r\n"You try it." Now watch him squirm!\r\n\r\nPorteous hesitated. "Would you like me to grow an extra finger, hair--"\r\n\r\n"Grow some hair." Melinda tried not to smile.\r\n\r\nThe little man unstopped the vial, poured a shimmering green drop on his\r\nwrist, frowning.\r\n\r\n"Must concentrate," he said. "Thorium base, suspended solution. Really\r\njolts the endocrines, complete control ... see?

"\r\n\r\nMelinda\'s jaw dropped. She stared at the tiny tuft of hair which had\r\nsprouted on that bare wrist. She was thinking abruptly, unhappily, about\r\nthat chignon she had bought yesterday. They had let her buy that for\r\neight dollars when with this stuff she could have a natural one.\r\n\r\n"How much?" she inquired cautiously.\r\n\r\n"A half hour of your time only," said Porteous.\r\n\r\nMelinda grasped the vial firmly, settled down on the sofa with one leg\r\ntucked carefully under her.\r\n\r\n"Okay, shoot. But nothing personal.

"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nPorteous was delighted. He asked a multitude of questions, most of them\r\npointless, some naive, and Melinda dug into her infinitesimal fund of\r\nknowledge and gave. The little man scribbled furiously, clucking like a\r\ngravid hen.\r\n\r\n"You mean," he asked in amazement, "that you live in these primitive\r\nhuts of your own volition?"\r\n\r\n"It\'s a G.I. housing project," Melinda said, ashamed.\r\n\r\n"Astonishing." He wrote: _Feudal anachronisms and atomic power, side by\r\nside. Class Fours periodically "rough it" in back-to-nature movements._\r\n\r\nHarry Junior chose that moment to begin screaming for his lunch.\r\nPorteous sat, trembling. "Is that a Security Alarm?"\r\n\r\n"My son," said Melinda despondently, and went into the nursery.\r\n\r\nPorteous followed, and watched the ululating child with some\r\ntrepidation. "Newborn?"\r\n\r\n"Eighteen months," said Melinda stiffly, changing diapers. "He\'s cutting\r\nteeth."\r\n\r\nPorteous shuddered. "What a pity. Obviously atavistic. Wouldn\'t the\r\ncreche accept him? You shouldn\'t have to keep him here."\r\n\r\n"I keep after Harry to get a maid, but he says we can\'t afford one."\r\n\r\n"Manifestly insecure," muttered the little man, studying Harry Junior.\r\n"Definite paranoid tendencies."\r\n\r\n"He was two weeks premature," volunteered Melinda. "He\'s real\r\nsensitive."\r\n\r\n"I know just the thing," Porteous said happily. "Here." He dipped into\r\nthe glittering litter on the tray and handed Harry Junior a translucent\r\nprism. "A neural distorter. We use it to train regressives on Rigel Two.\r\nIt might be of assistance."\r\n\r\nMelinda eyed the thing doubtfully. Harry Junior was peering into the\r\nshifting crystal depths with a somewhat strained expression.\r\n\r\n"Speeds up the neural flow," explained the little man proudly. "Helps\r\ntap the unused eighty per cent. The pre-symptomatic memory is\r\nunaffected, due to automatic cerebral lapse in case of overload. I\'m\r\nafraid it won\'t do much more than cube his present IQ, and an\r\nintelligent idiot is still an idiot, but--"\r\n\r\n"How dare you?" Melinda\'s eyes flashed. "My son is _not_ an idiot! You\r\nget out of here this minute and take your--things with you." As she\r\nreached for the prism, Harry Junior squalled. Melinda relented. "Here,"\r\nshe said angrily, fumbling with her purse. "How much are they?"\r\n\r\n"Medium of exchange?" Porteous rubbed his bald skull. "Oh, I really\r\nshouldn\'t--but it\'ll make such a wonderful addendum to the chapter on\r\nmalignant primitives. What is your smallest denomination?"\r\n\r\n"Is a dollar okay?" Melinda was hopeful.\r\n\r\nPorteous was pleased with the picture of George Washington. He turned\r\nthe bill over and over in his fingers, at last bowed low and formally,\r\napologized for any tabu violations, and left via the front door.\r\n\r\n"Crazy fraternities," muttered Melinda, turning on the TV set.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nKitty Kyle was dull that morning. At length Melinda used some of the\r\nliquid in the green vial on her eyelashes, was quite pleased at the\r\nresults, and hid the rest in the medicine cabinet.\r\n\r\nHarry Junior was a model of docility the rest of that day. While Melinda\r\nwatched TV and munched chocolates, did and re-did her hair, Harry Junior\r\nplayed quietly with the crystal prism.\r\n\r\nToward late afternoon, he crawled over to the bookcase, wrestled down\r\nthe encyclopedia and pawed through it, gurgling with delight. He\r\ndefinitely, Melinda decided, would make a fine lawyer someday, not a\r\nuseless putterer like Big Harry, who worked all hours overtime in that\r\ndamned lab. She scowled as Harry Junior, bored with the encyclopedia,\r\nbegan reaching for one of Big Harry\'s tomes on nuclear physics. One\r\nputterer in the family was enough! But when she tried to take the book\r\naway from him, Harry Junior howled so violently that she let well enough\r\nalone.\r\n\r\nAt six-thirty, Big Harry called from the lab, with the usual despondent\r\nmessage that he would not be home for supper. Melinda said a few\r\nresigned things about cheerless dinners eaten alone, hinted darkly what\r\nlonesome wives sometimes did for company, and Harry said he was very\r\nsorry, but this might be _it_, and Melinda hung up on him in a temper.\r\n\r\nPrecisely fifteen minutes later, the doorbell rang. Melinda opened the\r\nfront door and gaped. This little man could have been Porteous\'s double,\r\nexcept for the black metallic tunic, the glacial gray eyes.\r\n\r\n"Mrs. Melinda Adams?" 

Even the voice was frigid.\r\n\r\n"Y-Yes. Why--"\r\n\r\n"Major Nord, Galactic Security." The little man bowed. "You were visited\r\nearly this morning by one Porteous." He spoke the name with a certain\r\ndisgust. "He left a neural distorter here. Correct?"\r\n\r\nMelinda\'s nod was tremulous. Major Nord came quietly into the living\r\nroom, shut the door behind him. "My apologies, madam, for the intrusion.\r\nPorteous mistook your world for a Class IV culture, instead of a Class\r\nVII. Here--" He handed her the crumpled dollar bill. "You may check the\r\nserial number. The distorter, please."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nMelinda shrunk limply onto the sofa. "I don\'t understand," she said\r\npainfully. "Was he a thief?"\r\n\r\n"He was--careless about his spatial coordinates." Major Nord\'s teeth\r\nshowed in the faintest of smiles. "He has been corrected. Where is it?"\r\n\r\n"Now look," said Melinda with some asperity. "That thing\'s kept Harry\r\nJunior quiet all day. I bought it in good faith, and it\'s not my\r\nfault--say, have you got a warrant?"\r\n\r\n"Madam," said the Major with dignity, "I dislike violating local tabus,\r\nbut must I explain the impact of a neural distorter on a backwater\r\nculture? What if your Neanderthal had been given atomic blasters? Where\r\nwould you have been today? Swinging through trees, no doubt. What if\r\nyour Hitler had force-fields?" He exhaled. 

"Where is your son?"\r\n\r\nIn the nursery, Harry Junior was contentedly playing with his blocks.\r\nThe prism lay glinting in the corner.\r\n\r\nMajor Nord picked it up carefully, scrutinized Harry Junior. His voice\r\nwas very soft.\r\n\r\n"You said he was--playing with it?"\r\n\r\nSome vestigial maternal instinct prompted Melinda to shake her head\r\nvigorously. The little man stared hard at Harry Junior, who began\r\nwhimpering. Trembling, Melinda scooped up Harry Junior.\r\n\r\n"Is _that_ all you have to do--run around frightening women and\r\nchildren? Take your old distorter and get out. 

Leave decent people\r\nalone!"\r\n\r\nMajor Nord frowned. If only he could be sure. He peered stonily at Harry\r\nJunior, murmured, "Definite egomania. It doesn\'t seem to have affected\r\nhim. 

Strange."\r\n\r\n"Do you want me to scream?" Melinda demanded.\r\n\r\nMajor Nord sighed. He bowed to Melinda, went out, closed the door,\r\ntouched a tiny stud on his tunic, and vanished.\r\n\r\n"The manners of some people," Melinda said to Harry Junior. She was\r\nrelieved that the Major had not asked for the green vial.\r\n\r\nHarry Junior also looked relieved, although for quite a different\r\nreason.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nBig Harry arrived home a little after eleven. There were small worry\r\ncreases about his mouth and forehead, and the leaden cast of defeat in\r\nhis eyes. He went into the bedroom and Melinda sleepily told him about\r\nthe little man working his way through college by peddling silly goods,\r\nand about that rude cop named Nord, and Harry said that was simply\r\nastonishing and Melinda said, "Harry, you had a drink!"\r\n\r\n"I had two drinks," Harry told her owlishly. "You married a failure,\r\ndear. Part of the experimental model vaporized, _wooosh_, just like\r\nthat. On paper it looked so good--"\r\n\r\nMelinda had heard it all before. She asked him to see if Harry Junior\r\nwas covered, and Big Harry went unsteadily into the nursery, sat down by\r\nhis son\'s crib.\r\n\r\n"Poor little guy," he mused. "Your old man\'s a bum, a useless tinker. He\r\nthought he could send Man to the stars on a string of helium nuclei. Oh,\r\nhe was smart. Thought of everything. Auxiliary jets to kick off the\r\nnegative charge, bigger mercury vapor banks--a fine straight thrust of\r\npositive Alpha particles." He hiccuped, put his face in his hands.\r\n\r\n"Didn\'t you ever stop to think that a few air molecules could defocus\r\nthe stream? Try a vacuum, stupid."\r\n\r\nBig Harry stood up.\r\n\r\n"Did you say something, son?"\r\n\r\n"Gurfle," said Harry Junior.\r\n\r\nBig Harry reeled into the living room like a somnambulist.\r\n\r\nHe got pencil and paper, began jotting frantic formulae. Presently he\r\ncalled a cab and raced back to the laboratory.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nMelinda was dreaming about little bald men with diamond-studded trays.\r\nThey were chasing her, they kept pelting her with rubies and emeralds,\r\nall they wanted was to ask questions, but she kept running, Harry Junior\r\nclasped tightly in her arms. Now they were ringing alarm bells. The\r\nbells kept ringing and she groaned, sat up in bed, and seized the\r\ntelephone.\r\n\r\n"Darling." Big Harry\'s voice shook. "I\'ve got it! More auxiliary\r\nshielding plus a vacuum. We\'ll be rich!"\r\n\r\n"That\'s just fine," said Melinda crossly. "You woke the baby."\r\n\r\nHarry Junior was sobbing bitterly into his pillow. He was sick with\r\ndisappointment. Even the most favorable extrapolation showed it would\r\ntake him nineteen years to become master of the world.\r\n\r\nAn eternity. Nineteen years!\r\n\r\n                                                        --JAMES CAUSEY\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\n    This etext was produced from _Galaxy Science Fiction_ January 1953.\r\n    Extensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S.\r\n    copyright on this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and\r\n    typographical errors have been corrected without note.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


]\r\n\r\n\r\nWhen the two Geno-Doctors were gone, Miryam took the red capsule from\r\nunder the base of the bedlamp and slipped it between her dry lips.\r\n\r\nReason told her to swallow the capsule quickly, but instead she held it\r\nunder her tongue, clinging, against her will, to the last few moments\r\nof life.\r\n\r\nShe knew she was being weak, that she was still seeking hope where\r\nthere was no hope, and she prayed to the ancient God of the Ghetto that\r\nthe gelatin coating would dissolve quickly.\r\n\r\nPain interrupted the prayer, spreading like slow fire from deep within\r\nher young body, where the unwanted child of Genetics Center stirred so\r\nrestlessly, so impatient to be born.\r\n\r\nThe white walls of her Center room blurred in and out of focus. Shadows\r\nmerged together in brief, uncertain patterns. Lights flickered where\r\nthere were no lights, and the darkness was so intense it had a glare of\r\nits own.\r\n\r\nAt the worst of the pain cycle, Miryam bit down on her under lip until\r\nthe flesh showed as white as her teeth. She fought off temptation to\r\ncrunch the capsule and put an end to all pain, all fear.\r\n\r\nNo, she would not go that way. She would go in a moment of blinding\r\nclarity, knowing why, savoring the last bitter sweet second of her\r\ntriumph.\r\n\r\nWith a subconscious gesture of femininity, Miryam brushed the dark,\r\ndamp hair from her forehead, and wiped the perspiration from her lips.\r\n\r\n"Pretty little thing," one of the Geno-Service agents had called her,\r\nwhen she was arrested last fall in the Warsaw suburb where she had\r\ntaught nursery school since escaping from the Ghetto.\r\n\r\n"Doesn\'t look a bit like one of her kind," another agent had said,\r\nputting his hand under her chin and turning her face to the glare of\r\nhis flashlight. "No wonder she fooled the Psycho and Chemico squads....\r\nLucky for us!

"\r\n\r\n"What\'s the matter, little one?" 

the first agent had spoken again.\r\n"Didn\'t you know we were coming? I thought all of you people were\r\nsupposed to be telepaths.... Or doesn\'t it work when you\'re asleep?"\r\n\r\nHe flipped the covers off her trembling body and whistled.\r\n\r\n"Hands off!" the Geno-Sergeant had warned sharply. "She\'s for Center!"\r\n\r\nNow the capsule under her tongue was moist and soft. 

Time fled on\r\nswift, fluttering wings. Soon the horror would be done.\r\n\r\nBut the stubborn spark still glowed, and Miryam allowed her mind to\r\ndrift down the long, shining corridor to the room where the younger of\r\nthe two Geno-Doctors was changing into a white coat. The older man, who\r\nwore the gold trefoil of Geno-Sar on his collar, tilted back in his\r\nchair.\r\n\r\n"She should be just about due," he said cheerfully.\r\n\r\n"Yes, Sir," replied the young doctor, sounding the proper note of\r\ndeference for a man who communed daily with the political elite.\r\n\r\n"What do you think of her?"\r\n\r\n"Well, Sir, frankly--I was surprised--" The young doctor twisted\r\nmuscular arms to button the back of his jacket. He had but recently\r\ncome from the Genetics Sanitarium on the Black Sea, and his face was\r\ntanned deep brown. "From reading the weekly reports of your staff, I\r\ndidn\'t know she was that--that young--"\r\n\r\nMiryam trembled with a hope she dared not recognize, but it was crushed\r\nout of her by the Geno-Sar\'s booming voice.\r\n\r\n"Not only one of the youngest--but one of the very best specimens we\'ve\r\nhad to work with at Center! You read her psi rating?

"\r\n\r\n"Yes, Sir. Seventy-two point four, wasn\'t it?"\r\n\r\n"Seventy-two point six! Absolutely phenomenal! Closest thing to a pure\r\ntelepath our agents have ever turned up for us! This could be a big\r\nnight for Center, my boy.... A big night!

"\r\n\r\nThe young doctor shook his head to clear away the lingering image of a\r\ntragic, lovely face against a tear-stained pillow. Miryam was startled\r\nto find this image in his mind, and her pulse leaped again.\r\n\r\nIn a carefully professional tone, the young doctor asked:\r\n\r\n"What was her rating after insemination? Did the emotional shock...?

"\r\n\r\n"Not at all! Oh, naturally, she was uncooperative in the tests, but\r\npentathol and our cross-references gave us a true picture!"\r\n\r\n"And the spermatozoa?

"\r\n\r\n"Best we could get! Refrigerated about thirty years ago from a specimen\r\nthat tested forty-seven point eight."\r\n\r\nThe Geno-Sar paused, and because a comment was obviously in order, the\r\nyoung doctor said:\r\n\r\n"This certainly could be a big night for Center!"\r\n\r\nThe Geno-Sar snapped his cigarette lighter with an expansive flourish.\r\n\r\n"All the sciences have been taking a crack at psi--ever since the last\r\nPolitbureau directive gave it number one priority. You should have\r\nheard the talk at Sar-Bureau meeting this afternoon! The Math-Sar\r\nactually laughed at Genetics ... told us to stick to our white mice!"\r\n\r\nThe young doctor made a polite cluck of disapproval.\r\n\r\n"Those stupid mathematicians could learn something of heredity from\r\ntheir own ancients," the Geno-Sar continued, growing heated. "Think of\r\nLiebnitz, gifted at 14--Galois, a genius before he was 21!"\r\n\r\nThe Geno-Sar recovered his temper, and winked.\r\n\r\n"Of course, I didn\'t say that at the meeting--the Bureau chief is very\r\npartial to Math--but I did remind them, most pointedly, of the known\r\ndata on inherited sensory differences between individuals. And you\r\nshould have seen the squirming! Especially when I got into the taste\r\nstudies and the phenyl-thio-carbamide tests! Then, when I told of\r\nGenetics research on sense of time--sense of direction--sensitivity to\r\npain, sound and smells--Well, the Chief was hanging on my every word!\r\nThe Psycho-Sar became desperate to the point of rashness, and he jibed\r\nat me about our ancient master, Profim Lysenko." The Geno-Sar\'s head\r\ninclined slightly as he pronounced the name. "But the Chief himself\r\ngave the correct answer! He quoted from a Bureau directive which stated\r\nclearly that sensory characteristics, like any others, could well have\r\nbeen acquired in the first place, and then passed on through heredity!\r\nOh, I tell you, it was a heart-warming afternoon!"\r\n\r\nThe younger man had been paying him only half attention.\r\n\r\n"It\'s strange we should find some cases of psi among her people," he\r\nmused. "When I was at the University I always meant to study something\r\nabout the--" he hesitated and searched for the approved term, "--the\r\nspecimen races, but I never had time...."\r\n\r\nFor an instant the Geno-Sar\'s steel-blue eyes narrowed, and Miryam was\r\nshocked to find him appraising the young man for possible heresy. She\r\nhad always regarded the scientific mind as something remote, cold, but\r\nnever as something that could commit a heresy.\r\n\r\nHowever, the Geno-Sar decided to table the subject.\r\n\r\n"Of course you didn\'t!" he boomed. "You couldn\'t have made such a\r\nsplendid record without total specialization! Each to his own, that\'s\r\nhow science has prospered under the benevolence of our party!" He\r\nglanced up at the clock. "Well, aren\'t we just about ready for this\r\ndelivery?"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nMiryam drew back her mind. What a fool she was to go on seeking!\r\n\r\nThe child resumed its inexorable turning within her swollen body,\r\nand she knew she could never give to the world a life conceived so\r\nterribly, so coldly, without love or passion or tenderness.\r\n\r\nEven in these final moments, with the gelatin melting under her tongue,\r\nMiryam shuddered with the remembered anguish of struggling up from the\r\ndepths of anaesthesia to find herself bearing the seed of a child, from\r\na faceless man who had died long ago.\r\n\r\nOften, during the carefully guarded months of pregnancy, she had\r\nwondered about that man, who he had been, how his talent had compared\r\nwith hers.\r\n\r\nMiryam knew little about genetics, or any other science. The scientific\r\nmind had always frightened her, and she had feared to explore it.\r\nBut she knew there was no truth to the folklore that psi was a\r\ncharacteristic of her people. She knew of only a few cases outside\r\nher own family, although within her family it seemed to have been a\r\ncharacteristic that had recurred frequently for many generations. Her\r\nfather had cautioned her about selecting a husband, and pleaded with\r\nher not to flee the Ghetto.\r\n\r\nFor the past three days, since the nurse had momentarily left the\r\ncabinet at the end of the corridor unlocked and unguarded, Miryam had\r\nknown that she need not be concerned about the success or failure of\r\nthis terrible experiment. From the nurse\'s mind she had plucked the\r\nessential facts about the potency of the red capsule. This knowledge,\r\nfor all its loneliness, had been something to cherish, to press to her\r\nfull breasts, as she would never hold that child of horror.\r\n\r\nTears filled her eyes, squeezed in droplets between the closed lids.\r\nTears because she was so alone. Tears of unbearable sadness and pity,\r\nfor her people, for her youth and her young body, for the warmth that\r\nwould be eternally cold, for the unnatural child that squirmed and\r\nturned, and would never cry.\r\n\r\nIn a last forlorn gesture, in a final seeking before the darkness\r\nclosed, Miryam let her mind stray out of the white room, out of the\r\nmarble magnificence of Center. She let her thoughts escape on the soft\r\nbreeze of the early summer evening.\r\n\r\nHow beautiful it was, even here in the city, amid the science buildings\r\nthat formed bright islands of light around the minarets and vaulted\r\ndomes of Government Square.\r\n\r\nEven these awesome buildings were lovely in the purple dusk. Their\r\nwindows were like scattered emeralds of light.\r\n\r\nHow could there be so much beauty without compassion? So much knowledge\r\nwithout understanding? So much human genius without humanity?\r\n\r\nAnd what a battering of thoughts in the mild air around the centers of\r\nscience! What a discordance! What a tumult of theories, each of them\r\nnurtured within its own walls by the zealous Sars.\r\n\r\nThere were the Departments of Chemistry and Physics. There was the\r\nglass-walled tower of Astronomy! There was the Institute of Psychology,\r\nwith all its many bureaus. And the new Electronics Building, alabaster\r\neven in the dusk.\r\n\r\nThey were all there, extending in stately splendor along the main\r\navenues, and along the park, where the gossamer mist was rising.\r\n\r\nHow intolerant were the thoughts they radiated! How sure!\r\n\r\nElectronics said: "Quite obviously the answer to psi is in the\r\nelectrical currents of the brain. Our newest electro-encephalograph has\r\ndemonstrated...."\r\n\r\nChemistry said: "Solution to psi inevitably will be found in the\r\nchemical balance of the cells...."\r\n\r\nParapsychology said: "We must continue to ignore those who insist upon\r\nattributing physical properties to a non-physical characteristic...."\r\n\r\nAnd underneath this learned babble, Miryam heard the moth-like\r\nwhispering of her own people, starving in the Ghetto, or hidden\r\nthroughout the city, disguised, furtive, tense.\r\n\r\nHer mind came close to Government Square, and she cringed, as she\r\nhad cringed all her young life. The somatics were unbearable. Hatred\r\nand fear, blind prejudice, jealousy, cunning, ceaseless intrigue and\r\nplotting, setting Sar against Sar, using the genius of each science,\r\ndividing and ruling.\r\n\r\nNo, there was nothing left. No hope, no promise. This was the end of\r\ntime. This was the night of the world.\r\n\r\nWithdrawing again, retreating into itself, Miryam\'s mind brushed the\r\nfragment of a thought. It was a half-formed thought, more a groping,\r\nmore a question, than an idea. 

It was delicate, fragile, a wraith and a\r\nwisp. But it came to her as clear as the note from a silver bell.\r\n\r\nStartled, she hesitated in her withdrawal, and perceived the young\r\nGeno-Doctor in the corridor near her room. He had paused by the\r\ncasement window, and was staring out at the twinkling islands of light\r\naround Government Square.\r\n\r\nAnd as his gaze wandered moodily from Tech, to Psycho, to Chemico, to\r\nall the incandescent, isolated centers of genius, the idle speculation\r\nhad formed.\r\n\r\n"Wouldn\'t it be an unusual view if all those bright islands were\r\nconnected by strings of light...?"\r\n\r\nOnce formed, the speculation had fanned the ember of a thought:\r\n\r\n"Wonder if psi will build those strings of lights?"\r\n\r\nThen the young doctor turned almost guiltily from the window to\r\nmeet the Geno-Sar coming down the corridor. And he said with crisp\r\nefficiency,\r\n\r\n"I\'ll check out 12-A for delivery."\r\n\r\n"Good boy! I\'ll go on up and check the staff...." The Geno-Sar rubbed\r\nhis hands together, and walked off, repeating nervously, "Two psi\r\ncharacteristics must be the answer--two psi--"\r\n\r\n"Maybe they are," the young doctor murmured softly. "Maybe they are...."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nDelivery, Miryam thought. The life within her throbbed and prodded.\r\nThere was an ebbing of pain for a moment, and in that moment she saw\r\nwith the blinding clarity she had sought that this child of hers might\r\nbring new hope to the world. That psi ability might be the answer to\r\nmany things for the race of mankind. What did it matter that it was\r\nconceived without love and emotion. What did it matter that she was\r\nbeing used as an experiment ... if this child within her could fulfill\r\nthe promise.\r\n\r\nMiryam spat the soft capsule between her quivering lips. She watched it\r\nroll and bounce across the polished tile floor, toward the door.\r\n\r\nPain returned, and its fire was warm. There were no shadows on the\r\nwall. Pain returned, and it had purpose and promise. Wonderingly, she\r\nbeheld the concept that science, too, lived with fear, each science in\r\nits own Ghetto. And if the young doctor was right, if psi....\r\n\r\nAs the doctor stepped into the room, he bent over and picked up the\r\nred capsule. His thumb and forefinger felt the warmth, the moisture,\r\nand he looked long and thoughtfully into Miryam\'s dark, glowing eyes.\r\n\r\nHis fingers shook as he wrapped the capsule in a piece of tissue and\r\ndropped it into the pocket of his white jacket. He picked up the chart\r\nfrom the foot of the bed.\r\n\r\n"Miryam--" His voice was not under complete control, and he began\r\nagain, with an effort at lightness. "Miryam--that\'s a strange name.\r\nWhat does it mean?"\r\n\r\n"It is an ancient spelling," she whispered, her eyes deep and dark,\r\nfilled with pain and wonder. 

"You may find it easier to call me--Mary."\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


Cruthers was a busy man. Coordinating the biggest parade in New\r\nYork\'s history is not easy. He was maneuvering his two hundred pounds\r\naround Washington Square with the agility of a quarterback. He had his\r\nhands full organizing marchers, locating floats, placing the many brass\r\nbands in their proper order and barking commands to assistants. But Mr.\r\nCruthers approached the job with all the zeal of an evangelist at a\r\nrevival meeting.\r\n\r\nAs he approached the south-west corner of the square he saw something\r\nthat jarred his already frayed nerves. He stopped abruptly. The mass of\r\nclipboards and papers he was carrying fell to the street. There before\r\nhim were one hundred and fifty ants, each of them at least six feet\r\ntall. His first impulse was to turn and run for the nearest doctor. He\r\nwas certain that the strain of his job was proving too much for him. But\r\none of the ants approached him. It seemed friendly enough, so Mr.\r\nCruthers stood his ground.\r\n\r\n"My group is waiting for their assignment." The ant\'s voice seemed to be\r\ncoming from the very core of its thorax which was a violent red.\r\n\r\n"Good Lord!" Mr. 

Cruthers\' mouth opened up as wide as an oven door.\r\n\r\n"Mr. Cruthers, I believe the parade is about to start and my group--"\r\n\r\nMr. Cruthers managed to blurt out. "What the devil _are_ you anyway!"\r\n\r\n"This _is_ the parade marking the International Geophysical Year, is it\r\nnot?" The ant had a pleasant, friendly voice.\r\n\r\n"Well, yes, but--"\r\n\r\n"And you are Mr. Cruthers, the manager of the parade, is that not\r\ncorrect?"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nMr. Cruthers rubbed his eyes and took another look at the strange\r\ncreature. Its head was a brilliant yellow. It had two large goggle eyes\r\nwhich rolled like itinerant marbles when it spoke. The low slung abdomen\r\nwas a burnt brown. It was bad enough, Cruthers thought, that these ants\r\nwere six feet tall, but it was nightmarish to see them in three colors.\r\n\r\n"Mr. Cruthers," the ant continued, "haven\'t you been instructed by the\r\nNational Academy of Sciences that the Martian V.F.W. is to participate\r\nin this parade?"\r\n\r\n"The Martian--!!" 

Mr. Cruthers\' mouth was open again. Then he realized\r\nthat when the ant spoke its mouth didn\'t move. He picked up his\r\nclipboard and papers from the street. His voice was hostile now. "What\r\nthe hell is this, some kind of a gag! What are you trying to do, scare a\r\nman half to death!"\r\n\r\n"Oh, we\'re not joking, Mr. 

Cruthers. The National Academy--"\r\n\r\n"They didn\'t say anything to me about a bunch of clowns dressed up like\r\nants!" Mr. 

Cruthers\' indignation became intensified. He was loathe to\r\nadmit that he\'d been taken in by such obviously animated costumes. "Now\r\nlook here, I\'m a very busy man."\r\n\r\n"The arrangements _have_ been made, Mr. 

Cruthers. If my group is refused\r\na place in this parade we shall file suit immediately. As manager you\'ll\r\nbe named co-defendant." The ant was gentle but firm.\r\n\r\nThe thought of being sued softened Mr. Cruthers\' attitude. "Well, I\'m\r\nvery sorry, pal, but every contingent in this parade is listed on my\r\nclipboard and you\'re not. I know this list by heart. 

What did you say\r\nthe name of your group was?"\r\n\r\n"The Martian V.F.W."\r\n\r\nMr. Cruthers was amused. "Those sure are the craziest outfits I\'ve ever\r\nseen," he chuckled. "Where\'d you get them? Walt Disney make them for\r\nyou?" He followed his own little joke with a long throaty laugh.\r\n\r\nThe ant was impatient. "About the parade, Mr. Cruthers, there isn\'t much\r\ntime."\r\n\r\n"Oh, yes, the parade. Well, let me see," he thumbed through the\r\nclipboard, "I guess there\'s always room for a few laughs. How many in\r\nyour group?"\r\n\r\n"One hundred and fifty. And we also have a float with us. Not a very\r\nlarge one. 

It measures twenty by twenty."\r\n\r\n"Tell you what. You move your group to the corner of Thompson Street and\r\nThird Street. Get behind the Tiffany float and follow them, okay?"\r\n\r\nThe ant paused a moment to record the instructions in his mind. Then he\r\nturned to leave.\r\n\r\n"Oh, wait a minute," Mr. Cruthers cried before the ant could rejoin his\r\ngroup. "Just who did you speak to at the National Academy of Sciences?"\r\n\r\n"I believe it was a Mr. Canfield."\r\n\r\nMr. Cruthers\' face lit up. "Well, why didn\'t you say so in the first\r\nplace! I\'d have placed you right away."\r\n\r\n"That\'s perfectly all right, Mr. 

Cruthers."\r\n\r\n"Listen, I don\'t know what you guys do but those costumes should\r\ncertainly bring the house down. There\'s going to be four million people\r\nwatching this parade. I bet that\'s the biggest audience you\'ve ever\r\nseen."\r\n\r\n"It certainly is." With that the ant strode away.\r\n\r\n"Good luck!" Mr. Cruthers shouted after him.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"Daddy! Daddy, look! Look at the big rocket!" The little boy jumped up\r\nand down gleefully. "It must be a whole mile long, Daddy! What kind is\r\nit?"\r\n\r\n"That\'s the Vanguard, son."\r\n\r\nAn autumn breeze from the East River chilled their vantage point at\r\nSixty-First Street and Fifth Avenue.\r\n\r\n"The Vanguard?" The name meant nothing to the boy. "Gee, I\'ll bet it can\r\nfly all the way to the stars!"\r\n\r\n"It\'s the rocket that carried the first artificial satellite into\r\nspace."\r\n\r\nThe parade, now three hours old, continued past the reviewing stand.\r\n\r\n"I wanna get a better look at the Vanguard!" the boy shouted.\r\n\r\nThe father lifted the boy onto his shoulders. The little fellow laughed\r\nand whooped it up, firing several shots from his Captain Video Ray gun\r\nat the passing missile.\r\n\r\nThe rocket moved on and the noise of the crowd diminished slightly.\r\n\r\nA one-hundred piece brass band was passing in front of them. They were\r\nplaying "The Stars and Stripes Forever." They were followed by the Sak\'s\r\nFifth Avenue display; nine small floats, each depicting life on another\r\nplanet. The National Academy of Sciences had a success on its hands.\r\n\r\n"Wow! Daddy, I wanna ride on it! I wanna ride on that float and visit\r\nall those planets! Can I, Daddy!" The boy became all limbs trying to\r\nsquirm down from his father\'s shoulders.\r\n\r\n"You stay right where you are, young man," the father struggled to hold\r\nhis balance.\r\n\r\n"But I wanna go to the stars. I can watch the rest of the parade from\r\nVenus or Mercury! Please, Daddy!

"\r\n\r\nThe father grinned. "Not just yet, son, but it won\'t be long before man\r\nwill go to the stars."\r\n\r\n"Who lives up there, Daddy?"\r\n\r\n"Oh, there isn\'t any life up there yet."\r\n\r\n"If no one\'s living up there why does anyone want to go there?"\r\n\r\n"Well, maybe there\'ll be too many people on earth someday and then we\'ll\r\nhave to find other planets with more room."\r\n\r\nAnother monstrous brass band was going by. The boy became restless. He\r\nbegan to toy with his ray gun, half interested in seeing if there were\r\nany sparks left in it. "Why can\'t there be something besides so many\r\nbands in a parade? I wanna see another float."\r\n\r\nThe father tried to interest the boy by pointing out all the famous\r\npeople who were also there: a variety of statesmen the world\'s leading\r\nscientists and religious and cultural leaders, the president of the\r\nUnited States.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe boy was interested but not in what his elder was saying to him. He\r\nwas looking downtown, his eyes squinting, trying to make out figures as\r\nfar away as Fifty-sixth Street. Then his mouth opened, not uttering a\r\nsound yet, just waiting to burst with joy at what was coming toward\r\nthem.\r\n\r\nHis father looked up at him. "I wish you\'d tell me what you are looking\r\nat. 

I\'m all the way down here on street level, remember?"\r\n\r\n"Daddy, they look like ants!"\r\n\r\n"What?"\r\n\r\n"Ants, Daddy, ants! A whole army of them. Ain\'t it exciting?

"\r\n\r\n"What on earth are you talking about?"\r\n\r\n"They\'re doing somersaults and back flips and everything! They\'re coming\r\nright this way! Gee, there\'s hundreds of them. And they got a float\r\nbehind them, Daddy! A great big float with something burning on it."\r\n\r\nThe child sitting on his shoulders made mobility impossible for the\r\nfather. And he couldn\'t see around the spectators. He resigned himself\r\nto stand and wait for this new spectacle to overtake them. The reaction\r\nto this new sight had already begun to work its way uptown. In the\r\ndistance, but getting closer every second, he could hear unrestrained\r\nlaughter and rejoicing.\r\n\r\n"Hey, take it easy!" The boy was beginning to ride the shoulders like a\r\nbronco buster. "By the time they get here I won\'t have any shoulders\r\nleft. Where are they now?"\r\n\r\n"They\'re almost here, Daddy! And they aren\'t ants at all. They\'re just a\r\nbunch of clowns dressed up like it." He began to giggle hysterically.\r\n"Golly, they\'re funny. Can you see them yet, Daddy?"\r\n\r\nBefore the father could produce an answer the ants were in view. They\r\nwere a sight that couldn\'t fail to stimulate the funny bone. By\r\ncomparison with real ants everything about them had been grossly\r\nexaggerated to achieve the proper effect. They walked on their two back\r\nlegs but the four front apertures were far from idle. 

Some of them\r\nturned somersaults, others did complicated flips consisting of two or\r\nthree spins in mid-air. Still others, doing a kind of animated cakewalk,\r\ncarried toy ray guns which they fired at random into the crowd. The\r\nguns were something like the little boy\'s Captain Video ray gun, only\r\nlarger. They emitted little streaks of blue sparks which shone brightly\r\nbut disappeared when contact was made with air.\r\n\r\nThey were easily the hit of the parade, a three ring circus all by\r\nthemselves, as they pranced and clowned their way up Fifth Avenue giving\r\nthe spectators a whale of a show that was completely new.\r\n\r\nThe guests on the reviewing stand refrained from any hilarity until they\r\nsaw the float that four of the ants were pulling behind them. It was in\r\nkeeping with the rest of the nonsense they were perpetrating. The float\r\nboasted eight larger ray guns, three on either side and two in the rear,\r\nthat fired the same fascinating blue sparks. Behind each gun an ant\r\nstood on its head, wildly waving six legs in the breeze, begging to be\r\nnoticed and laughed at. Above the guns, emblazoned in fiery orange\r\nletters, were the words: "MARTIAN V.F.W." This was interpreted by one\r\nand all as a punch line and was treated accordingly.\r\n\r\nIt was heartwarming to be able to see the president and so many other\r\ndignitaries abandon composure in favor of a good old fashioned belly\r\nlaugh.\r\n\r\n"Daddy, I can\'t laugh any more," the boy had to pause between every\r\nother word. "My stomach hurts. Aren\'t they the funniest things you ever\r\nsaw?"\r\n\r\nThe father was too convulsed to be able to answer him.\r\n\r\n"Daddy, one of them is coming this way! He\'s firing his Captain Video\r\nray gun at us!" They boy squeezed his father and held on tight.\r\n\r\nThe father took a deep breath in order to be able to speak. "Take your\r\ngun and fire back at him, son. Fire away! Go on, he\'s just being\r\nplayful!" He broke forth with another gust of laughter. "I won\'t see\r\nanything as funny as this again if I live to be a hundred!"\r\n\r\nThe ant pranced over to where they were standing, firing its gun in\r\nevery direction. The boy fired back. The ant took one look at the lad\'s\r\ngun and let out a long cackling sound which built to a crescendo and\r\nthen stopped as though it had been turned off. The ant rejoined the\r\ngroup and they continued on their merry way.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe boy fired several shots into the float as it passed. He wanted to\r\nsee if he could knock out those blazing orange letters: MARTIAN V.F.W.\r\nThe letters continued to burn, but in the boy\'s mind he was certain he\r\nhad made several direct hits.\r\n\r\nThe boy and his father watched the float until it was out of sight. They\r\nknew there wouldn\'t be another attraction like those ants. They must\r\nhave been real professionals, the father thought. Such teamwork! Such\r\nprecision! 

Each one of them having a specific job to do and each doing\r\nit to perfection. After them everything was bound to be anticlimactic.\r\n\r\nMore marchers, more bands, a few more floats. The boy was beginning to\r\ntire. It had been a long day. Now everything was dull. "Daddy, I don\'t\r\nwant to see any more. Let\'s go home."\r\n\r\n"We\'ll stay another five minutes."\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe parade somehow seemed to be slowing down. The father yawned and let\r\nhis son down from his shoulders. He looked across the street at the\r\npresident and the other dignitaries on the reviewing stand. All were\r\nslowly raising their hands in salute as another color guard drowsily\r\nmade its way by.\r\n\r\nSoon the last group in the parade was passing the reviewing stand.\r\nAnother brass band. They were moving with the speed of a glacier. 

A full\r\nfive seconds elapsed between each note of music. Everything was\r\nhappening in slow motion. On the reviewing stand the dignified hands\r\nwent up, agonizingly slow, to a final salute and they stayed there. The\r\ngreatest minds in the world stood motionless, unalterably still. Just as\r\neach wave of pandemonium had unfurled itself up Fifth Avenue during the\r\nparade, so now did silence take command.\r\n\r\nThe little boy tugged at his father\'s coat. "Daddy! Daddy," he\r\npleaded, "why has the parade stopped? I wan-na-go-home--" His\r\nwords came more slowly with each passing second, like a high\r\nspeed phonograph playing at thirty-three and a third r.p.m.\r\n"Dad-dy--why--don\'t--you--an--swer--me--Da--ddy--why--don\'t--" His\r\nfather never heard him.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nFifty miles above the Atlantic the fleet of spaceships hung suspended\r\nlike lanterns. In the lead ship the ant in charge of communications\r\nreported to the commander.\r\n\r\n"We\'ve just received the first communique from the advance guard, sir."\r\n\r\n"Read it to me.

"\r\n\r\nThe communications chief read from a large perforated paper.\r\n"Time--0600--mission accomplished. Manhattan island cut down the\r\nmiddle--immediate result of super-isonic rays; four million dead--rays\r\nspreading east and west--estimated time of rays\' full effect;\r\n0800--island will then be neutralized--awaiting further orders." The ant\r\nfolded the paper and looked up at the commander. "Shall I relay further\r\norders, sir?"\r\n\r\n"No." The commander of the ants paused and stroked his chin. "We\'re\r\nmoving in."\r\n\r\n\r\nTHE END\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\nTranscriber\'s Note:\r\n\r\nThis etext was produced from _Amazing Science Fiction Stories_ May 1959.\r\nExtensive research did not uncover any evidence that the U.S. copyright\r\non this publication was renewed. Minor spelling and typographical errors\r\nhave been corrected without note.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n


]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n               He did not have the qualifications to go\r\n               into space--so he had them manufactured!\r\n\r\n\r\nIt was after oh-one-hundred when Kane arrived at my apartment.\r\nI checked the hall screen carefully before letting him in, too,\r\nthough the hour almost precluded the possibility of any inquisitive\r\npassers-by.\r\n\r\nHe didn\'t say anything at all when he saw me, but his eyes went\r\na bit wide. That was perfectly natural, after all. The illegal\r\nplasti-cosmetician had done his work better than well. I wasn\'t the\r\nsame person I had been.\r\n\r\nI led Kane into the living room and stood before him, letting him have\r\na good look at me.\r\n\r\n"Well," I asked, "will it work?"\r\n\r\nKane lit a cigarette thoughtfully, not taking his eyes off me.\r\n\r\n"Maybe," he said. "Just maybe."\r\n\r\nI thought about the spaceship standing proud and tall under the stars,\r\nready to go. And I knew that it had to work. It _had_ to.\r\n\r\nSome men dream of money, others of power. All my life I had dreamed\r\nonly of lands in the sky. The red sand hills of Mars, moldering in\r\naged slumber under a cobalt-colored day; the icy moraines of Io and\r\nCallisto, where the yellow methane snow drifted in the faint light\r\nof the Sun; the barren, stark seas of the Moon, where razor-backed\r\nmountains limned themselves against the star fields--\r\n\r\n"I don\'t know, Kim; you\'re asking a hell of a lot, you know," Kane said.\r\n\r\n"It\'ll work," I assured him. "The examination is cursory after the\r\napplication has been acted on." I grinned easily under the flesh mask.\r\n"And mine has."\r\n\r\n"You mean Kim Hall\'s application has," he said.\r\n\r\nI shrugged. "Well?"\r\n\r\nKane frowned at me and blew smoke into the still air of the room. "The\r\nKim Hall on the application and you aren\'t exactly the same person. I\r\ndon\'t have to tell you that.

"\r\n\r\n"Look," I said. "I called you here tonight to check me over and because\r\nwe\'ve been friends for a good long time. This is important to me, Kane.\r\nIt isn\'t just that I _want_ to go. I _have_ to. 

You can understand\r\nthat, maybe."\r\n\r\n"Yes, Kim," he said bitterly. "I can understand. Maybe if I had your\r\nbuild and mass, I\'d be trying the same thing right now. My only\r\nchance was the Eugenics Board and they turned me down cold. Remember?\r\nSex-linked predilection to carcinoma. Unsuitable for colonial breeding\r\nstock--"\r\n\r\nI felt a wave of pity for Kane then. I was almost sorry I\'d called him\r\nover. Within six hours I would be on board the spaceship, while he\r\nwould be here. Earthbound for always. Unsuitable for breeding stock in\r\nthe controlled colonies of Mars or Io and Callisto.\r\n\r\nI thought about that, too. I knew I wouldn\'t be able to carry off\r\nmy masquerade forever. 

I wouldn\'t want to. The stringent physical\r\nexamination given on landing would pierce my disguise easily. But\r\nby that time it would be too late. I\'d _be_ there, out among the\r\nstars. And no Earthbound spaceship captain would carry my mass back\r\ninstead of precious cargo. I\'d stay. If they wanted me for a breeder\r\nthen--okay. In spite of my slight build and lack of physical strength,\r\nI\'d still be where I wanted to be. In the fey lands in the sky....\r\n\r\n"I wish you all the luck in the world, Kim," my friend said. "I really\r\ndo. 

I don\'t mean to throw cold water on your scheme. You know how few\r\nof _us_ are permitted off-world. Every one who makes it is a--" he\r\ngrinned ruefully--"a blow struck for equality." He savored the irony\r\nof it for a moment and then his face grew serious again. "It\'s just\r\nthat the more I think of what you\'ve done, the more convinced I am that\r\nyou can\'t get away with it. Forged applications. Fake fingerprints\r\nand X-rays. And _this_--" He made a gesture that took in all of my\r\nappearance. Flesh, hair, clothes. 

Everything.\r\n\r\n"What the hell," I said. "It\'s good, isn\'t it?"\r\n\r\n"Very good. In fact, you make me uncomfortable, it\'s so good. But it\'s\r\ntoo damned insane."\r\n\r\n"Insane enough to work," I said. "And it\'s the only chance. How do you\r\nthink I\'d stack up with the Eugenics Board? Not a chance. What they\r\nwant out there is big muscle boys. Tough breeders. This is the only way\r\nfor me."\r\n\r\n"Well," Kane said. "You\'re big enough now, it seems to me."\r\n\r\n"Had to be. Lots to cover up. Lots to add."\r\n\r\n"And you\'re all set? Packed and ready?"\r\n\r\n"Yes," I said. "All set."\r\n\r\n"Then I guess this is it." He extended his hand. I took it. "Good\r\nluck, Kim. Always," he said huskily. "I\'ll hear if you make it. All of\r\nus will. And we\'ll be cheering and thinking that maybe, before we\'re\r\nall too old, we can make it, too. And if not, that maybe our sons\r\nwill--without having to be prize bulls, either."\r\n\r\nHe turned in the doorway and forced a grin.\r\n\r\n"Don\'t forget to write," he said.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThe spacefield was streaked with the glare of floodlights, and the ship\r\ngleamed like a silvery spire against the desert night.\r\n\r\nI joined the line of passengers at the checking desk, my half-kilo of\r\nbaggage clutched nervously against my side. My heart was pounding with\r\na mixture of fear and anticipation, my muscles twitching under the\r\nunaccustomed tension of the plastiflesh sheath that hid me.\r\n\r\nAll around me were the smells and sounds and sights of a spaceport, and\r\nabove me were the stars, brilliant and close at hand in the dark sky.\r\n\r\nThe queue moved swiftly toward the checking desk, where a gray-haired\r\nofficer with a seamed face sat.\r\n\r\nThe voice of the timekeeper came periodically from the loudspeakers\r\naround the perimeter of the field.\r\n\r\n"_Passengers for the Martian Queen, check in at desk five. It is now H\r\nminus forty-seven._"\r\n\r\nI stood now before the officer, tense and afraid. This was critical,\r\nthe last check-point before I could actually set foot in the ship.\r\n\r\n"_It is now H minus forty-five_," the timer\'s metallic voice said.\r\n\r\nThe officer looked up at me, and then at the faked photoprint on my\r\npapers.\r\n\r\n"Kim Hall, age twenty-nine, vocation agri-technician and hydroponics\r\nexpert, height 171 centimeters, weight 60 kilos. Right?

"\r\n\r\nI nodded soundlessly.\r\n\r\n"Sums check within mass-limits. Physical condition index 3.69.\r\nFertility index 3.66. Compatibility index 2.99." The officer turned to\r\na trim-looking assistant. 

"All check?"\r\n\r\nThe uniformed girl nodded.\r\n\r\nI began to breathe again.\r\n\r\n"Next desk, please," the officer said shortly.\r\n\r\nI moved on to the medics at the next stop. A gray-clad nurse checked my\r\npulse and respiration. She smiled at me.\r\n\r\n"Excited?" 

she asked. 

"Don\'t be." She indicated the section of the\r\nchecking station where the breeders were being processed. "You should\r\nsee how the bulls take it," she said with a laugh.\r\n\r\nShe picked up an electrified stamp. "Now don\'t worry. 

This won\'t hurt\r\nand it won\'t disfigure you permanently. But the ship\'s guards won\'t let\r\nyou aboard without it. Government regulations, you know. We cannot load\r\npersonal dossiers on the ships and this will tell the officers all they\r\nneed to know about you. Weight limitations, you see.

"\r\n\r\nI almost laughed in her face at that. If there was one thing all Earth\r\ncould offer me that I wanted, it was that stamp on my forehead: a\r\npassport to the stars....\r\n\r\nShe set the stamp and pressed it against my forehead. I had a momentary\r\nfear about the durability of the flesh mask that covered my face, but\r\nit was unnecessary. The plastiskin took the temporary tattoo the way\r\nreal flesh would have.\r\n\r\nI felt the skin and read it in my mind. I knew exactly what it said.\r\nI\'d dreamed of it so often and so long all my life. My ticket on the\r\n_Martian Queen_. My pass to those lands in the sky.\r\n\r\n     CERT SXF HALL, K. RS MART QUEEN SN1775690.\r\n\r\nI walked across the ramp and into the lift beside the great tapering\r\nhull of the rocket. My heart was singing.\r\n\r\nThe timer said: "_It is H minus thirty-one_."\r\n\r\nAnd then I stepped through the outer valve, into the _Queen_. The\r\nair was brisk with the tang of hydrogenol. Space-fuel. The ship was\r\nalive and humming with a thousand relays and timers and whispering\r\ngenerators, readying herself for space.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nI lay down in the acceleration hammock and listened to the ship.\r\n\r\nThis was everything I had wished for all my life. To be a free man\r\namong the stars. It was worth the chances I had taken, worth the lying\r\nand cheating and danger.\r\n\r\nThe conquest of space had split humanity in a manner that no one could\r\nhave foreseen, though the reasons for the schism were obvious. They\r\nhinged on two factors--mass and durability. Thus it was that some\r\nremained forever Earthbound while others reached for the sky. And\r\nbureaucracy being what it was, the decision as to who stayed and who\r\nwent was made along the easy, obvious line of demarcation.\r\n\r\nI and half the human race were on the wrong side of the line.\r\n\r\nFrom the ship\'s speakers came the voice of the timer.\r\n\r\n"_It is H minus ten. Ready yourselves for the takeoff._"\r\n\r\nI thought of Kane and the men I had known and worked with for half of\r\nmy twenty-nine years. They, too, were forbidden the sky. Tragic men,\r\nreally, with their need and their dream written in the lines of pain\r\nand yearning on their faces.\r\n\r\nThe speaker suddenly snapped:\r\n\r\n"_There is an illegal passenger on board! All persons will remain in\r\ntheir quarters until he is apprehended! Repeat: there is an illegal\r\npassenger on board! Remain in your quarters!_"\r\n\r\nMy heart seemed to stop beating. Somehow, my deception had been\r\nuncovered. How, it didn\'t matter, but it had. 

And the important thing\r\nnow was simply to stay on board at all costs. A space ship departure\r\ncould not be delayed. The orbit was computed. The blastaway timed to\r\nthe millisecond....\r\n\r\nI leaped to the deck and out of my cubicle. A spidery catwalk led\r\nupward, toward the nose of the ship. Below me I could hear the first\r\nsounds of the search.\r\n\r\nI ran up the walk, my footsteps sounding hollowly in the steel shaft. A\r\nbulkhead blocked my progress ahead and I sought the next deck.\r\n\r\nThe timer said: "_It is H minus six_."\r\n\r\nIt was a passenger deck. 

I could see frightened faces peering out of\r\ncubicles as I ran past. Behind me, the pursuit grew louder, nearer.\r\n\r\nI slammed open a bulkhead and found another walk leading upward toward\r\nthe astrogation blisters in the topmost point of the _Queen_.\r\n\r\nBehind me, I caught a glimpse of a ship\'s officer running, armed with a\r\nstun-pistol. My breath rasped in my throat and the plastiskin sheath on\r\nmy body shifted sickeningly.\r\n\r\n"_You there! Halt!_" The voice was high-pitched and excited. I flung\r\nthrough another bulkhead hatch and out into the dorsal blister. I\r\nseemed to be suspended between Earth and sky. The stars glittered\r\nthrough the steelglass of the blister, and the desert lay below,\r\nstreaked with searchlights and covered with tiny milling figures. The\r\nwarning light on the control bunker turned from amber to red as I\r\nwatched, chest heaving.\r\n\r\n"_It is H minus three_," the timer said. "_Rig ship for space._"\r\n\r\nI slammed the hatch shut and spun the wheel lock. I stood filled with\r\na mixture of triumph and fear. They could never get me out of the\r\nship in time now--but I would have to face blast away in the blister,\r\nunprotected. A shock that could kill....\r\n\r\nThrough the speaker, the captain\'s talker snapped orders: "_Abandon\r\npursuit! Too late to dump him now. Pick him up after acceleration is\r\ncompleted._" And then maliciously, knowing that I could hear: "_Scrape\r\nhim off the deck when we\'re in space._ That _kind can\'t take much_."\r\n\r\nI felt a blaze of red fury. _That_ kind. The Earthbound kind! I wanted\r\nto live, then, more than I had ever wanted to live before. To make a\r\nliar out of that sneering, superior voice. To prove that I was as good\r\nas all of them.\r\n\r\n"_It is H minus one_," said the timer.\r\n\r\nOrders filtered through the speaker.\r\n\r\n"_Outer valves closed. Inner valves closed._"\r\n\r\n"_Minus thirty seconds. Condition red._"\r\n\r\n"_Pressure in the ship. One-third atmosphere._"\r\n\r\n"_Twenty seconds._"\r\n\r\n"_Ship secure for space._"\r\n\r\n"_Ten, nine, eight_--"\r\n\r\nI lay prone on the steel deck, braced myself and prayed.\r\n\r\n"_Seven, six, five_--"\r\n\r\n"_Gyros on. Course set._"\r\n\r\n"_Four, three, two_--"\r\n\r\nThe ship trembled. A great light flared beyond the curving transparency\r\nof the blister.\r\n\r\n"_Up ship!_"\r\n\r\nA hand smashed down on me, crushing me into the deck.\r\n\r\nI thought: _I must live. I can\'t die. I won\'t die!_\r\n\r\nI felt the spaceship rising. I felt her reaching for the stars. I was\r\na part of her. I screamed with pain and exaltation. The hand pressed\r\nharder, choking the breath from me, stripping the plastiskin away in\r\nlong, damp strips.\r\n\r\nDarkness flickered before my eyes. I lay helpless and afraid and\r\ntransfigured with a joy I had never known before.\r\n\r\nDistorted, half-naked, I clung to life.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nWhen I opened my eyes, they were all around me. They stood in a\r\nhalf-circle, trim, uniformed. Their smooth faces and cropped hair\r\nand softly molded bodies looked strange against the functional steel\r\nangularity of the astrogation blister.\r\n\r\nI staggered to my feet, long strips of plastic flesh dangling from me.\r\n\r\nThe _Queen_ was in space. I was in space, no longer Earthbound.\r\n\r\n"Yes," I said, "I lived! Look at me!"\r\n\r\nI stripped off the flesh mask, peeled away the red, full lips, the long\r\ntransformation.\r\n\r\n"I\'ve done it. Others will do it, too. Not breeders--not brainless\r\nornaments to a hyper-nymphoid phallus! Just ordinary men. Ordinary men\r\nwith a dream. You can\'t keep the sky for yourselves. It belongs to all\r\nof us."\r\n\r\nI stood with my back to the blazing stars and laughed at them.\r\n\r\n"In the beginning it was right that you should be given priority\r\nover us. For centuries we kept you in subjection and when the Age of\r\nSpace came, you found your place. Your stamina, your small stature,\r\neverything about you fitted you to be mistresses of the sky....\r\n\r\n"But it\'s over. Over and done with. We can all be free--"\r\n\r\nI peeled away the artificial breasts that dangled from my chest.\r\n\r\nI stood swaying drunkenly, defiantly.\r\n\r\nThey came to me, then. They took me gently and carried me below, to the\r\ncomfort of a white bunk. They soothed my hurts and nursed me. For in\r\nspite of it all, they were women and I was a man in pain.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


"\r\n\r\n"You\'re right." Gregson touched his belt-stud, giving the signal that\r\ncalled all five crewmen to hand. They appeared quickly--Lasseux,\r\nBeveridge, Golovunoff. Liquid scorpions were enormous masses of clear,\r\njellyish liquid that oozed forward across the rock and sand with\r\nremarkable speed. A liquid scorpion changed shape constantly, its mass\r\nshooting out legs wherever they were needed. Only the eyes, fixed in a\r\nbulge over the center of its mass, and the almost-solid, curved stinger\r\nthat arched over its back remained the same.\r\n\r\nThe first landing party had stood transfixed while one of the crew was\r\nattacked and absorbed before their eyes. Clear, the scorpion had been\r\nalmost invisible to them until it flowed about the navigator\'s legs and\r\nparalyzed him with the swaying stinger. When his frantic struggles had\r\nceased, the creature flowed over his body and absorbed it. As the party\r\nwatched, the clearness slowly became a thin, dark red, and the body\r\ncould no longer be seen.\r\n\r\nAvengers had poured out of the ship after the giant scorpion, which\r\nreared back, tripling its height and halving its width.
