He waited\r\nseveral degrees of heat, but no further movement touched the sensitive\r\nreceivers in his mass.\r\n\r\nA falling rock, he decided, collecting himself and starting forward\r\nagain. He slithered down rocky walls, pouring almost like water when\r\nthe drop was long and drawing together at the bottom. When his feeling\r\nof touch warned him of the shade whose coolness might solidify him and\r\nleave him helpless in the open, he drew hurriedly away and changed\r\ndirection.\r\n\r\nFinally, he reached an open spot that was likely to contain food.\r\nHis mass ached for something to consume, but he flooded himself thin\r\nagain and waited, feeling. There was no vibration through the surface,\r\nnor did his "sense" tell him of anything other than the possibility\r\nof nourishment. Xen hesitated only a degree of heat before bubbling\r\nexcitedly into the open space.\r\n\r\nTouch found him something edible almost immediately--he flowed around\r\nand over it, absorbing it hungrily. His mass dissolved it almost\r\nimmediately and ached for more. He slid thin, reaching out in every\r\ndirection until contact was made, then absorbing the food instantly and\r\nmoving on.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nCurt, lying in meager shade that would be gone in half an hour when\r\nthe third and largest sun rose, first saw the movement when it was on\r\nthe rocks. His already frayed nerves gave a frightened leap. He lay\r\nperfectly still. Where he had seen the movement on the rocky shelf\r\nthere was now nothing.\r\n\r\nThe nothing moved forward.\r\n\r\nCurt shivered. He was certain he was seeing nothing, and yet his eyes\r\nwere trying to tell him there was movement. When it reached the flat\r\nplace and flowed swiftly forward, he realized that it was a liquid\r\nanimal and was suddenly pointedly conscious of the weight of the pistol\r\nagainst his hip.\r\n\r\nHe watched carefully for the eyes and the stinger, but saw none. That\r\nfrightened him. If he could not find the brain, he had no mark to\r\nshoot at. As he watched, the liquid creature flowed against one of the\r\nhardy, sun-browned plants and jerked in reaction. Instantly, it flowed\r\nover the plant and absorbed it. The liquid turned momentarily a thin\r\nbrownish green and then cleared again.\r\n\r\nCurt watched it with narrowed eyes. It was just possible that this\r\ncreature ate only plant life. The colonists had realized that the\r\nliquid scorpions had fed upon something else before they arrived, but\r\nno one had been able to discover what that something was.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nXen was in the process of absorbing a plant when the vibration sense\r\nalerted him. Terror shot through him and he spread thinly across thirty\r\nfeet of ground and lay motionless, his "sense" telling him frantically\r\nthat a Sting was hunting nearby.\r\n\r\nHe lay for many degrees of heat, waiting. Sense of vibration and\r\nknowing both told him that the Sting was approaching, but uncertainly,\r\nsearching. Then both senses reacted startledly to a new danger on the\r\nother side. New movement! A new feeling that his "sense" could not\r\nunderstand.\r\n\r\nThe Sting was approaching at an angle that would inevitably bring it in\r\ncontact with Xen. Absorption was the penalty for being caught. Xen was\r\nresigned to death, for he could not possibly escape the Sting. And now\r\nthere was this new sensation on the other side of him. Whatever it was,\r\nhe had no idea; but likely it was as voracious as the Sting.\r\n\r\nNow the new thing vibrated jerkily around him and stopped between him\r\nand the Sting. The vibrations from the eager Sting accelerated rapidly,\r\neagerly, as it flowed over the ground. Then, for no reason except that\r\nthe new creature had moved slightly, the Sting recoiled. The jerks were\r\nplainly recorded through the earth to Xen; and as he felt the heavy\r\njar, his "sense" told him that the danger from the Sting was past. The\r\nSting was dead.\r\n\r\nXen drew himself together and considered that.\r\n\r\nThe new thing vibrated jerkily the place from which Xen had first felt\r\nit move. It must be solid as the rocks to move so jerkily, Xen thought.\r\nThe Sting-killer drew itself back under the enormous rock and ceased to\r\nmove.\r\n\r\nCuriosity drew Xen forward, fear dragged him back. He spread thin and\r\ndrew together with uncertainty. At last, he oozed forward carefully\r\nuntil he reached the rock. The Sting-killer was pressed back under the\r\nrock, where touch told Xen a tiny amount of the cold-carrying shade\r\nremained. Xen puzzled at that. Why should this creature hide from the\r\nlife-giving suns?\r\n\r\nHe reached out and absorbed a plant thoughtfully. This thing was\r\ndifferent from the liquid structures he had always known. 

If it was\r\nsolid where they were liquid, perhaps then it was also opposite in its\r\nneeds. Maybe this Sting-killer needed cold instead of heat.\r\n\r\nWhile Xen was considering this difficult thought, the Sting-killer\r\nbegan to move again.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nCurt gasped. The shade was gone. The third sun was reaching long rays\r\nunder the rock to sear his already-burned flesh. He had to find more\r\nshade.\r\n\r\nMovements were very painful. 

His lips were cracking and his face had\r\nblackened. The injured knee had swollen inside the protective suit; it\r\nthrobbed and ached. Dazedly, he pulled himself to his feet.\r\n\r\nOn the rock beside him, spread an inch thick, was the almost-invisible\r\ncreature he had been forced to circle in order to stop the liquid\r\nscorpion. He wondered tiredly if it was dangerous. It lay completely\r\nmotionless, just as it had when the liquid scorpion had approached. So\r\nit was probably more afraid of him than he was of it. He turned away.\r\nThere appeared to be shade down the valley--perhaps a mile, perhaps\r\nthree. Too much for him, he knew, but he set out, feeling the sun beat\r\ncruelly at him, crying out when the pain in his knee forced him to\r\ncatch his balance against the sun-heated rock.\r\n\r\nHe knew without turning that the liquid creature was following him,\r\nstopping when he stopped, starting when he started. When he knew he\r\ncould go no farther and felt his knee give weakly to his weight, he saw\r\nit ooze forward and began to flow over his legs. He tried to reach his\r\npistol, but it seemed so far away.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nXen, following the Sting-killer curiously, put together all that he had\r\nlearned. This creature was different from himself. 

It needed shade. It\r\nhad killed his enemy, which was possibly also its own enemy. Now it was\r\ntrying to reach the shade, but its progress grew steadily slower.\r\n\r\nHe considered that progress. The only thing he could liken it to was\r\none of his own kind, caught out in the time of cold, trying to reach\r\nthe heat-retaining sands, slowly congealing into a solid mass and\r\ndying. 

This, then, was the reverse process. Perhaps the Sting-killer\r\nwould become liquid after a certain degree of heat.\r\n\r\nXen\'s sense of knowing warned him gently about too much wandering\r\nin the open, where countless Stings could be hiding. He drew back,\r\nunwilling to stop following this interesting creature. The Sting-killer\r\nvibrated the ground and lay still suddenly. Xen waited for a "sense" of\r\ndeath but none came. This might be for the new thing a stage similar to\r\nthat when one of Xen\'s own kind became unable to move from the cold,\r\nbut still lived and feared.\r\n\r\nCaught between his own fear and a very strange sensation that he could\r\nnot interpret, Xen waited a degree of heat. Then he oozed forward and\r\nspread himself over the still shape, until it floated within him. When\r\nhe flowed over one part, the thing struggled pitiably. Xen drew back\r\nstartedly and the movement ceased. Carefully, he retraced his course,\r\nleaving the part free. This time there was no struggling.\r\n\r\nSpurred by fear of Stings, Xen began to flow across the land, letting\r\nhis "Sense" guide him to the coldness. He slithered up slopes, poured\r\nover steep drops, always collecting himself in time to catch his burden.\r\n\r\nHe found a place that would stay cold until the next time of heat\r\nand halted in front of it, his anxiety evident in the way he spread\r\nand collected himself, back and forth. At last he inched forward,\r\nfeeling the agony of the cold bite into every cell. Bunching himself\r\nbehind the Sting-killer, he made it flow along him until it broke\r\nfree and lay upon the shaded rock. Xen drew back as hurriedly as his\r\nalready-sluggish mass would allow. He spread thin across the earth and\r\nlet the heat liquefy his body again....\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nIt was when the time of cold was only a few degrees away that Xen felt\r\nthe heavy vibration which nearly made him dissolve with fear. It lasted\r\nfor a few degrees and then weakened and made only a small tremor. Now\r\nmany smaller vibrations reached him, like many creatures moving about.\r\nThe tremors spread out, moving slowly toward the rocky valley.\r\n\r\nXen lay still trying to identify the vibrations. They were not those of\r\nStings. As they approached, he recognized them as resembling in great\r\nnumbers the creature he had put upon the rock.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nCurt imagined he heard voices, an incoherent babble of them. He\r\nstruggled to sit up, but there was an incredible weight on his chest.\r\n\r\n"Lie still," a voice said clearly, and his mind echoed, "Still ...\r\nstill ... still...."\r\n\r\nHe struggled again. "Liquid," he croaked painfully, "liquid animal ...\r\nliquid...." The weight was still there. He heard one last voice say,\r\n"Poor guy, he must have run into scorpions."\r\n\r\nThen he was lifted and it seemed as though the lifting would never\r\ncease.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nXen waited until the small tremor was gone and the great vibration had\r\nroared and disappeared. He knew by the sense of emptiness that the\r\nSting-killer had gone back to his own kind. 

For a moment he felt very\r\nalone, though he knew the sand was full of Xens.\r\n\r\nSlowly, he drew himself together. For the time of cold was but a few\r\ndegrees away, and he must seek the warm sands.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n            Why bother building a time machine when there\'s\r\n       something much easier to find right in your own kitchen?\r\n\r\n\r\nSomebody someday will make a study of the influence of animals on\r\nhistory. Although not as famous as Mrs. 

O\'Leary\'s cow, Mrs. 

Graham\'s\r\ncat should certainly be included in any such study. It has now been\r\ndefinitely established that the experiences of this cat led to the\r\nidea of quick-frozen people, which, in turn, led to the passage of\r\nZeritsky\'s Law.\r\n\r\nWe must go back to the files of the Los Angeles newspapers for 1950\r\nto find the story. In brief, a Mrs. Fred C. Graham missed her pet\r\ncat on the same day that she put a good deal of food down in her\r\nhome deep-freeze unit. She suspected no connection between the two\r\nevents. The cat was not to be found until six days later, when its\r\nowner went to fetch something from the deep-freeze. Much as she loved\r\nher pet, we may imagine that she was more horror than grief-stricken\r\nat her discovery. She lifted the little ice-encased body out of the\r\ndeep-freeze and set it on the floor. Then she managed to run as far as\r\nthe next door neighbor\'s house before fainting.\r\n\r\nMrs. Graham became hysterical after she was revived, and it was several\r\nhours before she could be quieted enough to persuade anybody that she\r\nhadn\'t made up the whole thing. She prevailed upon her neighbor to go\r\nback to the house with her. In front of the deep-freeze they found a\r\nsmall pool of water, and a wet cat, busily licking itself. The neighbor\r\nsubsequently told reporters that the cat was concentrating its licking\r\non one of its hind legs, where some ice still remained, so that she,\r\nfor one, believed the story.\r\n\r\nA follow-up dispatch, published a week later, reported that the cat was\r\nunharmed by the adventure. Further, Mrs. Graham was quoted as saying\r\nthat the cat had had a large meal just before its disappearance; that\r\nas soon after its rescue as it had dried itself off, it took a long\r\nnap, precisely as it always did after a meal; and that it was not\r\nhungry again until evening. It was clear from the accounts that the\r\nlife processes had been stopped dead in their tracks, and had, after\r\ndefrosting, resumed at exactly the point where they left off.\r\n\r\nPerhaps it is unfair to put all the responsibility on one luckless\r\ncat. 

Had such a thing happened anywhere else in the country, it would\r\nhave been talked about, believed by a few, disbelieved by most, and\r\nforgotten. 

But as the historic kick of Mrs. O\'Leary\'s cow achieved\r\nsignificance because of the time and place that it was delivered,\r\nso the falling of Mrs. Graham\'s cat into the deep-freeze became\r\nsignificant because it occurred in Los Angeles. There, and probably\r\nonly there, the event was anything but forgotten; the principles it\r\nrevealed became the basis of a hugely successful business.\r\n\r\nHow shall we regard the Zeritsky Brothers? As archvillains or pioneers?\r\nIn support of the latter view, it must be admitted that the spirit\r\nof inquiry and the willingness to risk the unknown were indisputably\r\ntheirs. However, their pioneering--if we agree to call it that--was,\r\nequally indisputably, bound up with the quest for a fast buck.\r\n\r\nSome of their first clients paid as high as $15,000 for the initial\r\nfreezing, and the exorbitant rate of $1,000 per year as a storage\r\ncharge. The Zeritsky Brothers owned and managed one of the largest\r\nquick-freezing plants in the world, and it was their claim that\r\nconverting the freezing equipment and storage facilities to accommodate\r\nhumans was extremely expensive, hence the high rates.\r\n\r\nWhen the early clients who paid these rates were defrosted years later,\r\nand found other clients receiving the same services for as little\r\nas $3,000, they threatened a row and the Zeritskys made substantial\r\nrefunds. By that time they could easily afford it, and since any\r\npublicity about their enterprise was unwelcome to them, all refunds\r\nwere made without a whimper. $3,000 became the standard rate, with $100\r\nper year the storage charge, and no charge for defrosting.\r\n\r\nThe Zeritskys were businessmen, first and last. Anyone who had the fee\r\ncould put himself away for whatever period of time he wished, and no\r\nquestions asked. The ironclad rule that full payment must be made in\r\nadvance was broken only once, as far as the records show.\r\n\r\nA certain young man had a very wealthy uncle, residing in Milwaukee,\r\nwhose heir he was, but the uncle was not getting along in years fast\r\nenough. The young man, then 18 years old, did not wish to waste the\r\n"best years of his life" as a poor boy. He wanted the money while\r\nhe was young, but his uncle was as healthy as he was wealthy. The\r\nZeritskys were the obvious answer to his problem.\r\n\r\nThe agreement between them has been preserved. They undertook to\r\nservice the youth without advance payment. They further undertook to\r\nwatch the Milwaukee papers until the demise of the uncle should be\r\nreported, whereupon they would defrost the boy. In exchange for this,\r\nthe youth, thinking of course that money would be no object when he\r\ncame out, agreed to pay double.\r\n\r\nThe uncle lived 17 years longer, during which time he seems to have\r\nforgotten his nephew and to have become deeply interested in a mystic\r\nsociety, to which he left his entire fortune. The Zeritskys duly\r\ndefrosted the boy, and whether they or he were the more disappointed\r\nis impossible to imagine. They never forgot the lesson, and never made\r\nanother exception to their rule.\r\n\r\nHe, poor fellow, spent the rest of his life, including the best\r\nyears, paying off his debt which, at $3,000 plus 17 years at $100 per\r\nyear, and the whole doubled, amounted to $9,400. The books record his\r\nslow but regular payments over the next 43 years, and indicate that\r\nhe had only $250 left to pay when he died. We may, I think, assume\r\nthat various underworld characters who were grateful ex-clients of\r\nthe Zeritskys were instrumental in persuading the boy to keep up his\r\npayments.\r\n\r\nCriminals were the first to apply for quick-freezing, and formed the\r\nmainstay of the Zeritskys\' business through the years. What more easy\r\nthan to rob, hide the loot (except for that all-important advance\r\npayment), present yourself to the Zeritskys and remain in their\r\nadmirable chambers for five or ten years, emerge to find the hue and\r\ncry long since died down and the crime forgotten, recover your haul and\r\nlive out your life in luxury?\r\n\r\nDue to the shady character of most of their patrons, the Zeritskys kept\r\nall records by a system of numbers. Names never appeared on the books,\r\nand anonymity was guaranteed.\r\n\r\nLaw enforcement agents, looking for fugitives from justice, found no\r\nway to break down this system, nor any law which they could interpret\r\nas making it illegal to quick-freeze. Perhaps the truth is that they\r\ndid not search too diligently for a law that could be made to apply.\r\nAs long as the Zeritskys kept things quiet and did not advertise or\r\nattract public attention, they could safely continue their bizarre\r\nbusiness.\r\n\r\nCity officials of Los Angeles, and particularly members of the police\r\nforce, enjoyed a period of unparalleled prosperity. Lawyers and other\r\nexperts who thought they were on the track of legal means by which to\r\nliquidate the Zeritsky empire found themselves suddenly able to buy a\r\nranch or a yacht or both, and retire forever from the arduous task of\r\nearning a living.\r\n\r\nEven with a goodly part of the population of Los Angeles as permanent\r\npensioners, the Zeritsky fortune grew to incredible proportions. By the\r\ntime the Zeritsky Brothers died and left the business to their sons, it\r\nwas a gold mine, and an inexhaustible one at that.\r\n\r\nDuring these later years, the enterprise began to attract a somewhat\r\nbetter class of people. Murderers and other criminals continued to\r\nfurnish the bulk of the business, but as word of this amazing service\r\nseeped through the country, others began to see in it an easy way of\r\nsolving their problems. They were encouraged, too, by the fact that\r\nthe process was painless, and the firm completely reliable. 

There were\r\nno risks, no accidents, no fatalities. One could, in short, have\r\nconfidence in the Zeritskys.\r\n\r\nSoon after Monahan\'s great exposure rocked the nation, however, many of\r\nthese better-type clients leaped into print to tell their experiences.\r\n\r\nOne of the most poignant stories came from the daughter of a Zeritsky\r\nclient. Her father was still, at the age of one hundred and two,\r\npassionately interested in politics, but the chances of his lasting\r\nuntil the next election were not good. 

The daughter herself suggested\r\nthe deep freeze, and he welcomed the idea. He decided on a twenty year\r\nstay because, in his own words, "If the Republicans can\'t get into the\r\nWhite House in twenty years, I give up." Upon his return, he found that\r\nhis condition had not been fulfilled. His daughter described him as\r\nutterly baffled by the new world. He lived in it just a week before he\r\nleft it, this time for good. 

She states his last words were, "How do\r\nyou people stand it?"\r\n\r\nSome professional people patronized the Zeritskys, chiefly movie stars.\r\nAfter the expose, fan magazines were filled with accounts of how the\r\nstars had kept youthful. The more zealous ones had prolonged their\r\nscreen lives for years by the simple expedient of storing themselves\r\naway between pictures. We may imagine the feelings of their public\r\nupon discovering that the seemingly eternal youth of their favorites\r\nwas due to the Zeritskys and not, as they had been led to believe, to\r\nexpensive creams, lotions, diet and exercise. There was a distinctly\r\nunfavorable reaction, and the letter columns of the fan magazines\r\nbristled with angry charges of cheating.\r\n\r\nBut next to criminals, the majority of people who applied for\r\nquick-freezing seems to have been husbands or wives caught in\r\ninsupportable marital situations. Their experiences were subsequently\r\nwritten up in the confession magazines. It was usually, the husband who\r\nfled to Los Angeles and incarcerated himself for an appropriate number\r\nof years, at the end of which time his unamiable spouse would have\r\ndied or made other arrangements. If we can believe the magazines, this\r\nscheme worked out very well in most cases.\r\n\r\nThere was, inevitably, one spiteful wife who divined her husband\'s\r\nintentions. By shrewd reasoning, she figured approximately the number\r\nof years he had chosen to be absent, and put herself away for a like\r\nperiod. In a TV dramatization rather pessimistically entitled _You\r\nCan\'t Get Away_, the husband described his sensations upon being\r\ndefrosted after 15 years, only to find his wife waiting for him, right\r\nthere in the reception room of the Zeritsky plant.\r\n\r\n"She was as perfectly preserved as I was," he said. "Every irritating\r\nhabit that had made my life unbearable with her was absolutely intact."\r\n\r\nThe sins of the fathers may be visited on the sons, but how often\r\nwe see repeated the old familiar pattern of the sons destroying the\r\nlifework of the fathers! The Zeritsky Brothers were fanatically\r\nmeticulous. They supervised every detail of their operations, and kept\r\ntheir records with an elaborate system of checks and doublechecks. They\r\nwere shrewd enough to realize that complete dependability was essential\r\nto their business. A satisfied Zeritsky client was a silent client. One\r\ndissatisfied client would be enough to blow the business apart.\r\n\r\nThe sons, in their greed, over-expanded to the point where they could\r\nnot, even among the four of them, personally supervise each and every\r\ndetail. A fatal mistake was bound to occur sooner or later. When it\r\ndid, the victim broadcast his grievance to the world.\r\n\r\nThe story appeared in a national magazine, every copy of which was sold\r\nan hour after it appeared on the stands. Under the title _They Put the\r\nFreeze on Me!_ John A. Monahan told his tragic tale. At the age of 37,\r\nhe had fallen desperately in love with a girl of 16. 

She was immature\r\nand frivolous and wanted to "play around" a little more before she\r\nsettled down.\r\n\r\n"She told me," he wrote, "to come back in five years, and that started\r\nme thinking. In five years I\'d be 42, and what would a girl of 21 want\r\nwith a man twice as old as her?"\r\n\r\nJohn Monahan moved in circles where the work of the Zeritskys was\r\nwell known. Not only did he see an opportunity of being still only 37\r\nwhen his darling reached 21, but he foresaw a painless way of passing\r\nthe years which he must endure without her. Accordingly, he presented\r\nhimself for the deep-freeze, paid his $3,000 and the $500 storage\r\ncharge in advance, and left, he claimed, "written instructions to let\r\nme out in five years, so there\'d be no mistakes."\r\n\r\nNobody knows how the slip happened, but somehow John A. Monahan, or\r\nrather the number assigned to him, was entered on the books for 25\r\nyears instead of five years. Upon being defrosted, and discovering\r\nthat a quarter of a century had elapsed, his rage was awesome. Along\r\nwith everything else, his love for his sweetheart had been perfectly\r\npreserved, but she had given up waiting for him and was a happy mother\r\nof two boys and six girls.\r\n\r\nMonahan\'s accusation that the Zeritskys had "ruined his life" may be\r\ntaken with a grain of salt. He was still a young man, and the rumor\r\nthat he received a hundred thousand for the magazine rights to his\r\nstory was true.\r\n\r\nAs most readers are aware, what has come to be known as "Zeritsky\'s\r\nLaw" was passed by Congress and signed by the President three days\r\nafter Monahan\'s story broke.\r\n\r\nSeventy-five years after Mrs. Graham\'s cat fell into the freezer,\r\nit became the law of the land that the mandatory penalty for anyone\r\napplying quick-freezing methods to any living thing, human or animal,\r\nwas death. Also, all quick-frozen people were to be defrosted\r\nimmediately.\r\n\r\nLos Angeles papers reported that beginning on the day Monahan\'s story\r\nappeared, men by the thousands poured into the city. They continued\r\nto come, choking every available means of transport, for the next two\r\ndays--until, that is, Zeritsky\'s Law went through.\r\n\r\nWhen we consider the date, and remember that due to the gravity of the\r\ninternational situation, a bill had just been passed drafting all men\r\nfrom 16 to 60, we realize why Congress had to act.\r\n\r\nThe Zeritskys, of course, were among the first to be taken. Because of\r\ntheir experience, they were put in charge of a military warehouse for\r\ndehydrated foods, and warned not to get any ideas for a new business.\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n            


]\r\n\r\n\r\n"You have no choice," the patrolman said. "The Council sends for you."\r\n\r\nHe moved across the veranda of Heric\'s cottage, bulking dark against\r\nthe sky-glow of Nyark the first city. On the slope of lawn below stood\r\nhis copter, its beetle-black shell glistening faintly in the starshine.\r\n\r\nHeric stood rigid with alarm in his doorway, still holding the book\r\nhe had been reading. The night-wind ruffling his hair and the homely\r\nsounds from the kitchen where Marta prepared their evening meal made\r\nhis danger doubly fantastic.\r\n\r\n"They\'ve found out somehow about my dreams," Heric said. "They\'ll put\r\nme through the adjuster and I\'ll come out of it--someone else. 

I won\'t\r\ngo!"\r\n\r\nHe was a mild man, overseer of the cereal grain fields outside Nyark\r\nthe first city, holding the confidence of his superiors and the respect\r\nof his workers. He and Marta had been happy in the quiet eddy of their\r\nisolation, until the dreams came.\r\n\r\nThe patrolman took a gleaming silver shock-cone from his belt. "I am\r\nsorry, Arnol Heric. You must come with me."\r\n\r\nStark panic made Heric drop his book and strike out wildly, smashing a\r\nfist into the officer\'s face. The patrolman staggered back, teetered\r\nfor balance on the veranda\'s edge and fell heavily. The sound of his\r\nhead striking the stone walkway below was as definite as the thud of a\r\ndropped melon.\r\n\r\nHeric went down the steps and knelt to feel the man\'s limp wrist. There\r\nwas no pulse. He put an ear to the slack lips, and there was no breath.\r\nShock numbed him and drove his thoughts into strange, tortured channels.\r\n\r\n"I\'ve killed him," he said.\r\n\r\nA sound caught his ear and he looked up to see Marta on the dark\r\nveranda above him, her face a pale oval blur with enormous,\r\nfright-widened eyes. "I didn\'t intend this to happen, Marta. I--I lost\r\nmy head."\r\n\r\nShe came down at once and put a soft hand on his shoulder. "Of course,\r\nof course, darling. 

Here, let me help you."\r\n\r\nTogether they lifted the patrolman\'s body into the copter\'s control\r\nseat, where it lolled bonelessly against the instrument panel. Heric\r\ntouched a button and the machine rose and soared eastward on a random\r\ncourse away from Nyark the first city.\r\n\r\nThey watched, holding hands like uneasy children, until it was lost\r\nagainst the stars. Then they went inside to the light and warmth of\r\ntheir cottage.\r\n\r\nHeric voiced the thought first: "They\'ll send for me again tomorrow,\r\nwhen he doesn\'t return."\r\n\r\nHe had again the ominous sensation, felt a dozen times in as many days,\r\nof being very close to understanding the strange auguries that had so\r\ntroubled his sleep of late. For a moment he hovered on the brink of\r\ncomplete comprehension before his fearful thought recoiled, leaving him\r\nuneasy and bewildered.\r\n\r\nWhen he slept the dream came more strongly than before.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n_The sere globe of Earth spun below him, frightfully riven by the\r\nhalf-healed wounds of some ancient cataclysm. Dull seas steamed and\r\nrain fell and vegetation crept across the scars, but there was life in\r\none place only._\r\n\r\n_There was a ruined city like a forest of standing shards, rising stark\r\nand cold against a desolate sky. A horde of silent figures poured\r\nthrough its streets, bent upon a myriad errands whose purposes he might\r\nhave guessed but dared not--he found himself one of the throng, yet his\r\ndread of understanding hid their intent as a mist might have obscured\r\ntheir faces. The crowd moved always eastward, its thousand faces rapt\r\nin impossible ecstasy. His own expectancy mounted to an unbearable\r\npitch, stifling him with the promise of total understanding. He had\r\nonly to follow them and--_\r\n\r\nHe awoke to find himself crouched on the cold floor of his bedroom,\r\ndrenched with perspiration and trembling violently from the strain of\r\nfighting back the monstrous concept toward which his dream had carried\r\nhim.\r\n\r\nMarta\'s voice was urgent in his ears. Marta\'s hands tugged at his arm,\r\nher breath was warm on his damp face. "Arnol, wake up! _Arnol!_"\r\n\r\nFor an instant he had an indescribable sense of being infinitely\r\nmultiplied, as if this moment were reproduced forever, a single frame\r\nin a succession that stretched endlessly before and behind him. Then\r\nthe dream tilted and swept away and he let Marta lead him, unresisting,\r\nback to bed.\r\n\r\nFor a long time he lay shivering in the darkness, his face hidden\r\nagainst her warm shoulder. And at last, when the tension had gone out\r\nof him, he slept again.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\nThey came for him at daybreak, four burly patrolmen with Council\r\ninsignia on their helmets and silver shock-cones in their hands. Heric\r\nlooked back as he entered their copter to see Marta on the verandah,\r\nlovely in the soft disarray of her too-early rising, her eyes bright\r\nand blind with unshed tears.\r\n\r\n"I\'ll come back," he called. "It\'s going to be all right!"\r\n\r\nWhen the copter rose he waved at her, buoyed up unexpectedly by the\r\nring of certainty he had managed to force into his voice. He had a\r\nlast glimpse of Marta before distance and the morning mists hid her, a\r\nsmall, forlorn figure with raised face staring after him, her belted\r\nhouse-robe fluttering in the wind.\r\n\r\nThey sank through the ordered vastness of Nyark the first city, into\r\na bustle and rush that was symbolic of the Council\'s will to restore\r\nNyark--and finally Earth--to their former glory. Heric was led to a\r\nquiet chamber where the Council, in their deep crescent of seats behind\r\nthe Leader\'s throne, awaited him.\r\n\r\nHe had seen them before only in newscasts, when it had awed him a\r\nlittle to think that in their hands lay the destiny of a world in\r\nrebirth. He was surprised now to feel that their wrinkled parchment\r\nfaces and thin bodies, hidden under sleeveless blue robes, lent them a\r\nfutile anonymity rather than the distinction he had expected. _Why_, he\r\nthought, _they look like scrawny, earthbound birds._\r\n\r\n"Why am I here?" Heric demanded. 

Rebellion grew in him, roughening his\r\nvoice. "I have broken no law, nor have I been lax in my overseeing. I\r\nprotest this adjustment to what you call normalcy."\r\n\r\n"Yet you must endure it, Arnol Heric," the Leader said. A rustle of\r\nassent whispered through the robed Council. "You should not have defied\r\nour messenger. It may be too late now."\r\n\r\nAnger swelled Heric\'s demand. 

"What do you mean?"\r\n\r\n[Illustration: He felt the breath of madness touch him....]\r\n\r\nHis answer was a great, cloudy bubble that sprang from nowhere about\r\nhim. The Council vanished behind its milky haze. There was a brief\r\nsensation of motion, and after that--nothing.\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n_He was in the void of his dreams again, imprisoned in darkness.\r\nBut there was a difference--the dull globe of Earth spun faint and\r\nmisty, half-seen through an obscuring curtain. A smooth, hypnotic\r\nthought-current flowed into his mind from the adjuster, commanding him,\r\nwarring with the half-sensed truth that still sought his awareness._\r\n\r\n_"You are Arnol Heric, overseer of cereal plantings. You have had\r\nno disturbing dreams. Forget, Arnol Heric. There is no need for\r\nalarm...."_\r\n\r\n_There was a long struggle before his will fought clear, and he knew\r\nthat the Leader\'s fear of being too late had been realized. The pitted\r\nEarth-sphere grew plain, the desolate city sharpened and drew near. He\r\nwalked the thronged streets and turned his face toward the east, and\r\nthis time he did not repulse the truth when it lay before him._\r\n\r\n_There was a silent room where a figure reclined laxly in a chair made\r\nmassive by its crystal maze of shining coils. Two guards flanked the\r\nchair watchfully, and in it sat--_\r\n\r\n_Himself._\r\n\r\nAnger shook him like a terrible wind, without warning. It was all a\r\nmonstrous farce, then--he was the center of it all, and they had hidden\r\nhim in his overseer\'s niche to blind him to reality.\r\n\r\nHe opened his eyes in the adjuster, pushing the futile thought-current\r\nfrom his mind. The guards stiffened at his movement, their silver\r\nshock-cones ready.\r\n\r\n"I know myself now," Heric said. He stood up, shaking off the web of\r\ncrystal contacts from the adjuster. 

"And I know you. 

Put away your\r\nuseless weapons."\r\n\r\nThey dropped their cones and stood with lowered eyes, waiting his\r\npleasure with a deference that made his lip curl. He left the room\r\nwithout a backward look, knowing they would warn the Council but having\r\nno need now for secrecy.\r\n\r\nHe went down a wide-arched corridor, striding with sure step to the\r\ncity\'s heart. He found the power source at ground level, in a vast\r\ndim cavern full of soft-purring machines. He singled out the great\r\noperations board with its master switch that controlled the city\'s\r\nlife--and in his path he found the Leader and his council, shielding\r\nthe control from him with the massed crescent of their bodies.\r\n\r\n"Stand back," Heric commanded.\r\n\r\nThe Council stirred uneasily, but did not break.\r\n\r\n"Hear us out, Arnol Heric," the Leader begged. "Remember that we, being\r\nnot-human, yet have human emotions. 

We are the end result of the robot\r\nrace men created to serve them in ages past, and you are right when\r\nyou suppose that we may not defy you because we are your property. But\r\nthere is a thing which you do not know, hidden from you even in your\r\ndreams for your own safety. 

Stay your hand, Master."\r\n\r\nThe sound of Heric\'s laughter echoed emptily through the vast room.\r\n\r\n"Stay my hand and let you adjust me into submission again? Let you send\r\nme back to planting wheat, drowning my identity in ignorance? I know\r\nthe human race is almost dead--I know that you hide the truth from the\r\nfew of us who remain because you think us doomed to extinction. You\r\nwould bury us in ignorance and rule in our stead as if you were men and\r\nwe your servants."\r\n\r\n"_We_ are the servants," the Leader said. "Yet you would immobilize us.\r\nWhy?"\r\n\r\n"Because I would rather know my fate and meet it without your\r\nmeddling," Heric answered. "Because I do not believe that my race\r\ncan ever die completely. I shall stop you in your tracks like the\r\nmechanical things you are, and I shall find the others of my people who\r\nare left and start life over with them. And this time we shall know\r\nbetter than to build machines!"\r\n\r\n       *       *       *       *       *\r\n\r\n"We have no desire to perpetuate ourselves," the Leader said. "We were\r\ncreated to serve humanity, and to insure our obedience to the love\r\nof men was made our strongest instinct. Without men our life would be\r\nan endless torture of loneliness, for we can be happy only in your\r\nhappiness. We hid the truth from you, and kept you busy outside Nyark\r\nthe first city, to protect your sanity."\r\n\r\nHeric took a forward step. 

"Back, all of you!"\r\n\r\nThey drew aside to let him pass. The Leader knelt as Heric brushed by\r\nhim, and the Council knelt with averted faces behind him. Their sigh\r\nwhispered through the great room.\r\n\r\n"Wait, Arnol Heric. Do you know that we have made you immortal?"\r\n\r\n[Illustration: "Wait, Arnol Heric. 

Do you know that we have made you\r\nimmortal?"]\r\n\r\nHe paused with his hands upon the master control, disturbed by a\r\nresurgence of that indescribable extension he had felt on waking from\r\nhis dream. Angrily he shook it off, bracing himself.\r\n\r\nHe wrenched open the switch.\r\n\r\nThe machine-murmur died. The cavernous chamber stilled until Heric\'s\r\nheart beat loud in the tomblike silence. The Council knelt motionless,\r\nlike even rows of cold statuary.\r\n\r\nHe turned from them and went through the hushed room and out into the\r\nstreets of Nyark the first city. Silence lay before him. Vehicles stood\r\nunpowered, drivers frozen. In the shops the crowds hovered motionless\r\nlike static, three-dimensional shadows.\r\n\r\nHe went swiftly through the dead city with his face turned toward the\r\nhills. The silence bore him down with an implacable weight, and the\r\ndesire to escape it grew upon him until he found himself running,\r\ndodging wildly in and out among stalled vehicles and frozen pedestrians.\r\n\r\nHe reached the city\'s edge, but the sun and wind of open country did\r\nnot dispel his oppression. The sun was as silent as the city, and the\r\nbreeze was a drear lament in his ears. Loneliness crept at his heels\r\nlike a black, timorous hound; he felt as if he were the only living\r\nthing in a dead and forgotten world. Panic claimed him.\r\n\r\nIt was noon when he reached his cottage. He crawled up the verandah\r\nsteps, spent and panting, and found the silence with him here even in\r\nhis last retreat.\r\n\r\n"Marta!" he croaked. He pulled himself erect, clutching at the arched\r\ndoorway for support.\r\n\r\n"Marta!"\r\n\r\nHe had been so sure that there would be other men. He had been able to\r\nfend off madness back there on the plain, only because he had known\r\nthat Marta was here waiting for him....\r\n\r\nHe found her standing in the silent living room, her still face turned\r\ntoward the door through which he must come when he returned. She wore\r\nthe clinging, colorful gown he had liked best, and her bright, fair\r\nhair was carefully arranged as if she were on the point of going out.\r\n\r\nHer lashes were lowered as if in sleep, and he had the instant\r\nconviction that she had closed her lids to hide the mechanical luster\r\nof her eyes from him when he should come and find her.\r\n\r\n"_Marta_," he whispered.\r\n\r\nHe sagged against the entrance arch, with the bitter sound of the\r\nLeader\'s words in his ears: "We can be happy only in your happiness...."\r\n\r\nNot one of them was human, not even Marta. He was the last man on Earth.\r\n\r\nAnd he was immortal.\r\n\r\nThis was the thing that had been hidden from him even in his dream,\r\nlest he go mad. This silence that pressed him down was the silence of\r\neternity.\r\n\r\nHe was alone in a world of death and dust, and would be alone forever.\r\n\r\nHe felt the breath of madness touch him. He heard the Council\'s sighing\r\nwhisper of "_Immortal_ ..." and he recalled the eerie sensation of\r\ninfinite multiplication that had come to him when he pulled open the\r\nmaster switch.\r\n\r\nHe thought: _How many times has this happened? And how many times will\r\nit happen again?_\r\n\r\nWhen he spoke, he used unconsciously the same words he had used when he\r\nleft her at daybreak.\r\n\r\n"I\'ll come back, Marta," he said. "It\'s going to be all right."\r\n\r\nThen he went outside and turned his face toward the silent city and\r\nbegan to run....\r\n\r\n\r\n        \r\n
